# 南华真经义海纂微

**The Ocean of Meanings in the *True Scripture of Southern Florescence*: A Compilation of Subtleties**

**Title:** *The Ocean of Meanings in the True Scripture of Southern Florescence: Admiring the Subtle*
Compiled by Chu Boxiu of the Southern Song, completed circa the *gengwu* year of the Xianchun era.
Incorporating the annotations of thirteen masters—Guo Xiang, Lü Huiqing, Lin Yidu, Chen Xiangdao, Chen Bixu (Jingyuan), Wang Pang, Liu Gai, Wu Chuan, Zhao Yifu, Lin Xiyi, Li Shibiao, Wang Dan, and Fan Yingyuan—along with Chu’s own critical judgments and overarching discussions. Occasional interspersed readings or exegeses from sources beyond these thirteen commentators.
One hundred and six fascicles.
**Source of the base text:** *Daoist Canon of the Zhengtong Era*, *Washen* Section, *Jade Instructions* Category.

---

**Fascicle One of *The Ocean of Meanings in the True Scripture of Southern Florescence: A Compilation of Subtleties***
By Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin

**Inner Chapters: "Free and Easy Wandering" (First)**

In the Northern Darkness there is a fish, whose name is *Kun*.
The greatness of *Kun*—no one knows how many thousand *li* it spans.
It transforms into a bird, whose name is *Peng*.
The back of *Peng*—no one knows how many thousand *li* it stretches.
When it rouses itself and takes flight, its wings are like clouds hanging from the sky.
This bird, when the seas surge, will journey to the Southern Darkness.
The Southern Darkness is the Celestial Pond.

*The Qi Xie* is a record of marvels.
Its words say: When *Peng* journeys to the Southern Darkness, it strikes the water for three thousand *li*, then mounts the whirlwind to ascend ninety thousand *li*, departing with the winds of the sixth month.
The "wild horses" of the air, the dust motes—all living things are blown about by the breath of one another.
Is the deep blue of the sky its true color?
Or is it so distant that it has no limit?
When one looks down from above, it is just like this.

**Guo Xiang’s Annotation:**
The reality of *Kun* and *Peng* is something I have not yet fathomed.
The great purport of Master Zhuang lies in the free and easy wandering of self-attained nonaction.
Thus, he exhausts the conditions of the small and the great to clarify the fittingness of one’s allotted nature.
Those of far-reaching vision should grasp its convergence and forget its lodging.
That *Kun* transforms into *Peng*—only the Northern Darkness suffices to bear its body;
only the winds of ninety thousand *li* suffice to lift its wings.
How could this be a fondness for the strange?
It is simply that great things necessarily arise in great places, and great places necessarily give rise to such great things—this is the inherent principle.
The wings of *Peng* are too vast to lift easily, so it must strike the whirlwind before ascending ninety thousand *li*, departing for half a year before resting at the Celestial Pond.
The "wild horses" are wandering *qi*; *Peng* relies on them to fly.
When *Peng* looks down from above, it is just as when humans look up from below at the sky.

**Lü Huiqing’s Annotation:**
The *qi* of the world is one.
When yang reaches its extreme, yin arises; when yin reaches its extreme, yang arises—like a ring without end.
All things follow this in waxing and waning, flourishing and decaying; there is nothing that is not so.
The *Kun* of the Northern Darkness transforms into the *Peng* of the Southern Darkness—this is the passage from yin into yang.
The extremes of yin and yang are both obscured by the sky.
Three thousand and ninety thousand are both odd numbers.
The sixth month marks the distance between *zi* and *si*, *wu* and *hai*.
That *Peng*’s number is odd and it departs with the winds of the sixth month to rest suggests that *Kun*’s number is even and it departs with the dissipation of the sixth month—this can be known.
The "wild horses" and dust motes are all living things blown about by one another’s breath.
Breath is the work of *qi*, filling heaven and earth without gap.
Humans, dwelling within it, look up from below and see the sky’s deep blue—is this its true color?
Or is it so distant that it has no limit? It cannot be known.
Precisely because it cannot be known, one does not take one’s dwelling as below, so how could *Peng*, looking down from above, know what makes it high?

**Lin Yidu’s Annotation:**
The north is the direction of water.
Darkness is the concealment of light.
The Northern Darkness is where yin and yang enter and exit.
Master Zhuang uses *Kun* and *Peng* to illustrate the transformations of yin and yang, thus beginning with the Northern Darkness.
*Kun* is a yin creature; *Peng* is a yang creature.
*The Supreme Mystery* says: "The obscure has no form, the profound cannot be fathomed; stillness is called returning to the mandate"—this is the image of *Kun*.
All things flourish, polishing the work of heaven and illuminating the myriad things—this is the image of *Peng*.
When *Kun* first transforms into *Peng*, though it belongs to the yang kind, it has not yet departed from the obscure and subtle, so no one knows how many thousand *li* it spans.
Next, it speaks of three thousand *li*—the number is not yet complete.
Finally, it speaks of ninety thousand *li*—movement must have its limit.
Even the most distant and vast of embodied things cannot escape the reckoning of yin and yang, so when it moves, it is nine; when it rests, it is six.
Departing with the winds of the sixth month to rest is returning to yin.
Yin and yang alternate in their revolutions, mutually endless and beyond inquiry.
The "wild horses" and dust motes, the breath of living things, show how wind arises from the subtle and accumulates to the substantial, so that *Peng* awaits it to journey south.
**Chen Xiangdao’s Annotation:**
The Dao disperses to become yin and yang; yin and yang disperse to become the myriad things.
Emerging from yin and yang to return to the Dao, there is nowhere one does not wander freely;
entering yin and yang to cling to things, there is nowhere one is not bound.
Darkness is the concealment of light; light is the manifestation of darkness.
The Northern Darkness is entering to become the Dao; the Southern Darkness is emerging to become affairs.
Thus, Master Zhuang in the north lodges the deep-diving fish, and in the south lodges the soaring bird.
Water, in direction, is north; in *qi*, is essence; in season, is winter; in number, is one.
The transformations of things always begin here.
*Kun* as a creature is yang within yin; *Peng* as a creature is yin within yang.
Lurking in the north and journeying to the south do not depart from the directions of yin and yang.
Ninety thousand *li* and the sixth month do not depart from the reckoning of yin and yang.
Its back like Mount Tai, its wings like hanging clouds—it is not free from embodiment.
In transformation, it relies on water; in soaring, it relies on wind—it is not free from dependence.

When it stirs to take flight, it cannot be without emotion.
When it flies and rests, it cannot be without limit.

Even with the vastness of the *Kun* and *Peng*, their confinement within yin and yang is thus.
How much more so for the cicada, the turtledove, and the quail?

Master Bi Xu’s Chen Jingyuan annotates:
The Dao takes generation and transformation as its priority, and yin and yang as its origin.
The Northern Darkness gives birth to the *Kun*, which transforms into the *Peng*—its qi and form already complete, yet none know why it is so.
For the generation and transformation of yin and yang are divine and unfathomable.
At the inception of a thing’s transformation, its measure cannot be exhausted, hence it is said: "one knows not how many thousands of *li*."
Having life, it must have a destination, thus it stirs to fly and migrates to the Southern Darkness.
Having life and a destination, its capacity and strength cannot be without limit, hence it strikes the water for three thousand *li*, rides the whirlwind to ascend ninety thousand *li*, and departs only after six months of rest.
Six is a yin number, hence it is called "rest."

Within heaven and earth, the primordial qi billows and swirls, rising and falling in ceaseless return, hence the metaphors of "wild horses" and "dust motes."
All living things mutually rely on the breath of qi to propel and sustain one another, drifting east and west without obstruction or hindrance.
If one were to delimit things by the smallness or greatness of their forms, then yin and yang would be sundered, above and below would appear distinct, and none could attain harmony.

Wang Xu annotates:
The *Kun*, when lurking, dwells in the north.
The *Peng*, when flying, migrates to the Southern Darkness.
Even the most immense of embodied things, though capable of transformation, cannot escape the categories of yin and yang, and thus are constrained by creation and unable to attain freedom.
As the *Yi* says: "Directions gather by kind; things divide by groups."
The so-called "wandering in freedom" belongs only to that which is without direction or form.
Striking the water for three thousand *li* marks the flourishing of yang’s initial reckoning.
Movement must have its limit, hence it rides the whirlwind for ninety thousand *li* and departs only after six months of rest.
"Wild horses" and "dust motes" are what the *Peng* relies upon to fly—gazing downward from above is like a man on earth observing the heavens.
One who views the small from the great lacks clarity, and thus the *Peng* is burdened by its own vastness.

Xu Zhai’s Zhao Yifu annotates:
Zhuangzi’s *Kun* and *Peng* illustrate the qi of heaven and earth’s yin and yang.
The fish transforms into a bird, migrating from north to south, from yin to yang, from stillness to motion.
The Classic designates the Southern Darkness as the "Celestial Pond," but since heaven envelops earth, the Northern Darkness is also a Celestial Pond.
Three is the inception of yang, for one contains three.
Nine is the extremity of yang, for three times three is nine.
Yang is born at *zi*, and six yangs culminate at *si*, hence the six-month rest.
"Wild horses" and "dust motes," though differing in size, share the same qi, breathing and propelling one another.
A man’s view of heaven is like the *Peng*’s view below—though high and low differ, the principle is one.

Lin Xiayi’s *Yunzhai Oral Exegesis* states:
The discourse on the *Kun* and *Peng*’s transformations merely depicts the boundless joy within the breast.
I say: worldly people, seeing only the small, engage in endless strife. If they knew of such worlds beyond heaven and earth, they would regard their own bodies as no more than a grain of millet in a granary!
The *Kun* and *Peng* are but allegories; one need not be bound by the theories of yin and yang.
For a bird to fly, it must rely on qi.
The addition of a single character—*shu*—renders it extraordinary.
"Three thousand" and "ninety thousand" merely describe its loftiness and distance.
"Departing after six months of rest" means that each flight requires half a year’s repose.
"Wild horses and dust motes, breathing and propelling one another"—these three lines elucidate the following passage.
"Gazing at the boundless heavens" further illustrates the height of the *Peng*’s flight, revealing the force of the brushwork.

Chu Shi’s *Insights* states:
"Darkness" refers to the undifferentiated oneness of primordial qi.
The north governs moistening qi, nurturing the germination of all things.
The south governs scorching qi, fostering the growth of all things.
Proceeding from north to south reflects yang’s birth from yin.
Though their positions differ, the qi remains uninterrupted.
The vast distance between them makes their gradual transformation imperceptible, just as the turning of the four seasons—intense cold and sweltering heat—do not arise in a single morning.
Thus, the *Kun* and *Peng*’s transformation, from extreme stillness to motion, riding the wind for ninety thousand *li* and resting for six months, does not transcend the mutual alternation of yin and yang, but resides within the undifferentiated oneness of primordial qi.
Hence, both north and south are called "Darkness."

The Old Immortal of Nanhua lamented the wars among the states and the cramped, vulgar pursuits of his time.
Scholars of the age were confined by their limited perceptions, prizing rhetorical stratagems and seizing fame and profit, while neglecting their own innate nature.
Thus, he composed his work with fervor, crafting far-reaching discourses to elucidate the supreme principle and liberate the human mind.
He declared that one who attains this Dao harmonizes virtue with heaven and earth, moves in unison with yin and yang, and adapts to concealment or revelation in all circumstances, wandering freely without hindrance.
The yin and yang of heaven and earth are the yin and yang of the human body; water and fire derive their origins from them, and the transformations of nature and emotion rely upon them.
They extend above and coil below, reaching all extremes.
Yet they are not perceptible to sight or hearing, so he established the *Kun* and *Peng* as provisional names, guiding learners to first understand the mind through things, then forget form to unite with the Dao, deeply rooting and settling the ultimate, and merging subtly with the mechanism of transformation.
The yin and yang of our bodies are in constant motion; the heaven and earth within us never cease.
From this, we know that human nature is inherently endowed with freedom, yet the vulgar world remains deluded, forgetting truth to chase falsehood, fretting over life and death, and worrying over gain and loss, unaware of what true freedom entails.
Thus, he expounds further to dispel their confusion, likening human life and death to a fish transforming into a bird—shedding scales for feathers, abandoning swimming for flight—emotions following form in transformation, each fulfilling its nature.
Creation is boundless, and so too is its endowment; where is there room for love or aversion?
At the inception of a thing’s transformation, its changes are immeasurable, hence "one knows not how many thousands of *li*."

When the roc migrates to the Southern Darkness, the measure of thirty thousand *li* takes form—its journey powered by six months’ breath, where yin wanes and yang waxes, the ceaseless mechanism of creation. The "wild horses" and "dust motes" are but metaphors for fleeting phenomena. Should one master the root and grasp the essence of the roc’s flight, one would transcend the mundane, roaming beyond the dust of the world. The six directions’ inflow of qi and the mutual respiration of the ten thousand beings serve only to propel one another, lifting all without becoming a burden. In every movement and turn, there is nowhere one does not find ease—such is the *xiaoyaoyou*, the carefree wandering. Thus, this passage crowns the sutra’s intent.

The line *"Its wings beat the air as if in fury"* has seldom been elucidated in commentaries. Yet a meaning beyond the words may be appended here: Heaven and earth are endowed with the One Qi; the ten thousand things are endowed by heaven and earth. From the One Qi, heaven and earth divide; through their union, the ten thousand things arise. Separating and merging without end, generation and transformation are boundless—small and great, short and long, each fulfills its allotted portion. From receiving qi to taking form, from numerical limits to material change, embracing yin and holding yang, each awaits its time. What must transform cannot but transform; what must take flight cannot but fly—all driven by the celestial mechanism, though the transformed remain unaware. *"Beating the air as if in fury"* expresses the inevitability of movement: *nu* (fury) is akin to *yong* (vigorous), compelled by qi to surge forth swiftly, as if enraged—yet this is no mere indignation or resentment. All things coiled long will spring forth; all bent long will stretch. Do they weary of constancy and crave change? Rather, confined within form and great transformation, they follow the ebb and flow of the two qi—fullness and emptiness, waxing and waning—a principle inescapable.

The *Qiwulun* speaks of *"the ten thousand hollows roaring in fury,"* and the *Waiwu* of *"plants and trees growing in vigor"*—both convey this same idea. The *Daodejing*’s *"the ten thousand things rising together"* echoes it as well. Observing this cycle of return, the meaning of the *"six months’ breath"* becomes clear. Yet世人 see only the fury and not the rest, know only action and not return. Thus, they turn from the realm of carefree wandering, daily drifting toward the domain of striving, entangled in affairs, ensnared by troubles, toiling like draft animals, lost and without refuge—how lamentable!

Master Guanyin said: *"Though heaven and earth are vast, they can enslave the formed but not the formless."* To escape servitude to the two qi, seek it before the *mingyu* takes shape.

Moreover, if water is not deep, it lacks the strength to bear a great vessel. Pour a cup of water onto a hollow in the floor, and a mustard seed may serve as a boat—yet place the cup there, and it will run aground, for the water is shallow and the vessel too large. If wind is not thickly gathered, it lacks the strength to bear great wings. Thus, only at ninety thousand *li* does the wind lie beneath, and only then can one ride the wind. Only by bearing the blue sky on one’s back, unobstructed, can one then set course for the south.

The cicada and the fledgling dove laugh, saying: *"We burst forth in flight, darting between the elm and sandalwood—sometimes we fall short and land on the ground. Why travel ninety thousand *li* to the south?"* One who journeys to the near wilderness returns after three meals, belly still full; one bound for a hundred *li* prepares provisions the night before; one traveling a thousand *li* gathers three months’ rations. What do these two creatures know?

Lesser knowledge cannot fathom greater; short years cannot comprehend long. How do we know this is so? The morning mushroom knows not dawn and dusk; the summer cicada knows not spring and autumn—these are short-lived. South of Chu lies the *Mingling*, for whom five hundred years are a spring, five hundred years an autumn. In high antiquity, there was the *Dazhuang*, for whom eight thousand years were a spring, eight thousand years an autumn. Yet Pengzu alone is famed for longevity—how pitiful that common folk compare themselves to him!

This passage serves as an extended metaphor to elaborate the preceding text. Next, it presents the dialogue between the cicada and the fledgling dove to illustrate the distinction between small and great, each content with its own measure and free from envy. This is the essence of the *xiaoyaoyou* (carefree wandering). It further discusses how the distance of one’s journey determines the provisions required—how much less do these two creatures know?

Here, the "two creatures" refer to the cicada and the fledgling dove, both equally ignorant. The contrast between lesser knowledge and greater knowledge, shorter years and longer years, unfolds through layered metaphors, yet the principle remains unchanged. The meaning of the classic text is clear and requires no further annotation.

This echoes Tang’s questioning of Ji. Beyond the northern lands of unbroken vegetation lies the Dark Sea, a celestial lake. There dwells a fish, its breadth spanning thousands of *li*, its length unknown—its name is Kun. There is also a bird named Peng, its back like Mount Tai, its wings like clouds hanging from the sky. It beats the whirlwind, spiraling upward ninety thousand *li*, piercing the clouds, bearing the blue heavens on its back, then turning southward, bound for the Southern Darkness.

The quail laughs at it, saying: "Where is it going? I leap and flutter upward, no more than a few fathoms before descending, soaring among the mugwort and wormwood—this is the perfection of flight. Where is *it* going?" Such is the distinction between small and great.

Thus, those whose knowledge suffices for a single office, whose conduct matches a single village, whose virtue aligns with a single lord, or whose influence sways a single state—they regard themselves in the same way. Yet Song Rongzi would still laugh at them. For though the whole world praises him, he is not encouraged; though the whole world blames him, he is not disheartened. He has settled the division between inner and outer, distinguished the boundary between honor and disgrace—this is all. In his relation to the world, he is not frantically driven. Yet even so, he has not yet established himself.

Liezi could ride the wind and travel, effortlessly and gracefully, returning after fifteen days. In his pursuit of fortune, he was not frantically driven. Though he thus avoided walking, he still depended on something. But one who rides the constancy of Heaven and Earth, harnesses the transformations of the six *qi*, and wanders through the boundless—what does *he* depend on?

Therefore it is said: The Perfect One is without self, the Spirit Man is without achievement, the Sage is without name.

Lu Deming’s *Sound and Meaning* notes: Ji was a worthy of Tang’s time. Cui’s commentary states: He was also of the *Qi Xie* school, able to recognize the winters of the *Mingling* and *Dazhuang*. Guo Xiang’s annotation: Tang’s questioning of Ji also says: "All things have their limits; when left to follow their nature, they flourish." Thus Zhuangzi regarded Ji’s question as valid. Lü Huiqing says: This reference to Tang’s questioning of Ji is because such words have existed since antiquity—what is called "repeated words." Ji’s account of Kun and Peng is the same as the one just cited, as seen in the *Liezi*, though more concise.

Lin Yidu’s annotation records the affair of Yin Tang and Xia Ge. It begins with "In the ancient beginning, there were things" and ends with "within the boundless." Beyond the boundless, there is again no boundless—this aligns with the preceding text and is thus adduced as evidence. Yet Guo Xiang claims: "All things have their limits; when left to follow their nature, they flourish"—this is not Zhuangzi’s original intent. Readers may seek the correct interpretation in the *Liezi*.

Chu’s *Superficial Observations* states: According to the *Liezi*, it was Yin Tang questioning Xia Ge. Ge and Ji are similar in sound and meaning, both denoting urgency. Cui’s interpretation takes this sentence as concluding the preceding discussion of the *Mingling* and *Dazhuang*, while Lü’s annotation uses it to introduce the following discourse on the Dark Sea—each follows their own division of the text. The *Daguan* edition with eight commentaries treats this sentence as an independent passage, though this seems forced between the preceding and following sections. Lin’s annotation aligns with Cui’s, while Chen Jingyuan’s *Bixu* edition begins the second chapter here, following Lü’s view.

Upon careful examination of the text’s intent, it aims to substantiate the meaning of Kun and Peng. Thus, it first introduces the theme and then presents two pieces of evidence: the account from *Qi Xie* and Tang’s questioning of Ji. It further corroborates Zhuangzi’s words with the *Liezi*’s *Tang Wen* chapter on the Dark Sea and celestial lake. Therefore, this chapter naturally begins after the phrase "Tang’s questioning of Ji is also thus," with "is also thus" serving to confirm the preceding text and generate the following discourse. Many readers fail to recognize this distinction, mistakenly treating it as the conclusion of the previous chapter. If it were the conclusion, the meaning would be exhausted, and the next chapter would not restart the discussion from "Beyond the northern lands of unbroken vegetation"—this would not be the proper structure of argument.

Thus, I venture to append this explanation to clarify the doubt. Lin of Zhuxi also states: According to this sentence, it should belong to the following section as a concluding phrase turned into an opening one. The subsequent text then reintroduces the discussion of Kun and Peng, not to re-explain the earlier lines on "knowledge sufficing for an office" or "conduct matching a village," but to show that the capacities of small and great each have their proper application, with fitness as the measure. Song Rongzi’s laughter at them indicates he is not moved by honor or profit, embodying the use of what is seemingly useless—transcending the realm of knowledge and ability. Yet even he is deemed "not yet established," revealing the loftiness of his vision.

Liezi, who could ride the wind yet still depended on something, reaches the ultimate in harnessing the six *qi* to wander the boundless. Thus, it concludes: The Perfect One is without self, the Spirit Man is without achievement, the Sage is without name. These three represent the pinnacle of the human Dao, summarizing the central meaning of the *Xiaoyaoyou*’s opening chapter. For the utmost Dao is profoundly mysterious, ascending to the realm of the sage—yet it does not exceed the principle of the "three withouts." Entering it, one speaks of perfection; emerging, one speaks of sageliness. The spirit moves within it, unbounded and without fixed direction. Its vastness resides in humanity, its principle merely entrusted.

Thus, in establishing teachings, there is naturally an order. All living beings cling to private profit, yet it is easy to plant the value of forgetting the self.

Pride and self-importance easily arise; next, one must forget merit. Once personal merit is forgotten, others’ praise will naturally follow. Yet one must further forget fame to distance worldly burdens. When burdens are far removed, the body remains whole, the Dao pure, and virtue unadulterated. In this state, one’s conduct among others and responses to affairs will be flawless, and the names of the three—Perfect One, Spirit Man, and Sage—will blend and dissolve into oneness.

Observing the talented and heroic figures of past and present, those who have built merit and established fame are many, yet few have preserved their wisdom and integrity. Is this due to insufficient intelligence? No—their Dao-heart remains obscured, hindered by something within. In youth, one studies; in maturity, one acts, aspiring to establish merit. Merit serves others, yet once achieved, it invites envy. One cultivates the self and builds a career to spread one’s name, for fame refines customs,

Later, the text cites the butcher’s carving as a metaphor for *youwei* (purposeful action) and the spirit-medium’s invocation as a metaphor for *wuwei* (effortless non-action). The *shenren* (Spirit Man) cannot but practice *wuwei*, just as the sage cannot but practice *youwei*.

Chen Xiangdao’s commentary states: Yao was one who governed the world; You was one who forgot the world. Governing the world brings substantive loss yet establishes a name; forgetting the world gathers substance yet erases the name. When the world is already well-governed, it cannot be handed to another; when the world is wholly forgotten, it cannot be taken up in another’s stead. This is why Yao’s aspiration could not be realized through You, and why You’s resolve could not be bent by Yao. The rising of the sun and moon serves as a metaphor for wisdom that pervades all things; the falling of timely rain, for the Dao that aids the world. The wren finds sufficiency in a single branch, content with externals; the mole drinks its fill, content within. The butcher is one who acts upon affairs; the spirit-medium, one who remains untouched by them. Action brings many burdens, so the unburdened never inquire beyond their station—this is why You did not overstep his role to replace Yao.

Chen Bixu’s commentary states: The emblems of rank and the throne must not be lent to others. How dare one lightly accept the greatest treasure! You valued his person and disdained worldly things, refusing to treat the world as a profit. If each person refused to profit from the world, the world would govern itself. Thus, he served no kings or lords, elevating his own path—his resolve was worthy of emulation. He who knows others is wise; he who knows himself is enlightened. Without knowing others, one cannot navigate benefit and harm in human affairs; without self-knowledge, one cannot grasp Heaven’s mandate and merge with spontaneity. This is how Yao knew You, and how You knew himself.

Wang Dan’s discourse states: Heaven emerges from *wuwei*; humanity, from *youwei*. The *wuwei* practitioner sees *youwei* as a burden; the *youwei* practitioner takes *wuwei* as the foundation. In his *youwei* phase, Yao was Son of Heaven, possessing all under Heaven, yet did not consider it excess. In his *wuwei* phase, You was a commoner, hidden on Mount Ji, yet did not consider it lack. Yao is likened to Heaven’s workings—sun, moon, and timely rain; You to human efforts—artificial fire and irrigation. Yao, though capable of governing the world, dared not usurp You’s role; You, though capable of governing, refused to replace Yao. Then who shall govern the world? If governed by Yao, it is *youwei* with *wuwei* at its core; if by You, it is *wuwei* with *youwei* as its expression. The Dao within the sage appears as Yao when manifest and as You when concealed—what need is there for choice?

Xu Zhao’s annotation states: Yao and You are not two separate beings; the reader must seek their meaning beyond the words. The dialogue between Yao and Shun in the *Tian Yun* chapter conveys this same intent.

Chu Shi’s *Guanjian* states: Upon reading the chapter on Yao’s abdication, the pure and ancient spirit of yielding and deference comes vividly to life, revealing how the sage reveres the Dao and honors virtue, placing others before self, governing the body as primary and treating worldly rule as secondary. Those who wage war and seize even an inch of land—how degenerate are later ages! Yao compared his achievements to the humble tasks of kindling fire and irrigation, his humility reaching its utmost—how could he have set his heart on imperial trappings? You measured his capacity by the wren and the mole, content within his innate bounds—how could he have sought fortune and rank? With a divine Yao on the throne, there naturally arose a You in reclusion, their resonance drawn by shared principle. Yao’s concern for the world ran deep: though the Four Seas were at peace, none but You could succeed him. You’s disregard for the world was absolute: the Four Seas already governed, what had he to do with it? Without unwavering conviction in great responsibility, Yao’s profound wisdom would not be evident; without lofty disdain for acceptance, You’s pure embrace of the Dao would not be seen. The sage does not weigh importance by public or private roles but by righteousness and principle in departure or stay—this depends on the Dao’s unfolding and the timeliness of the moment. Yao’s knowledge of You was precise, so he did not wait for trials but offered the throne in his stead. Had You suddenly accepted, he would not have lost the dignity of tranquil rule; had Yao gracefully retired, he could have concealed his brilliance. In the highest antiquity, the sage’s visibility and obscurity aligned with the Dao, like tallying tokens—how could the vulgar fathom its depths?

Moreover, You’s relationship to Yao was as subject to ruler by station, as teacher to student by the Dao. His subtle counsel and the marvel of heart-transmission were the very means by which he aided Yao—even had he received the world, it would not have been excessive. Yet You’s integrity was such that he asked, “What use is the world to me?” The saying “Names are but guests to reality” alone suffices as a model for all ages. Extending this principle, it not only awakens Deng Ye from his dream and silences the quarrels of the belligerent, but also inspires later generations to imagine the allure of Mount Ji and the Ying River, where even a single gourd is felt as a burden. Ultimately, the analogy of the spirit-medium not overstepping his role to take the butcher’s place illustrates Yao’s supreme virtue in knowing others and You’s hidden virtue in knowing himself. Each rests in what is fitting, each finds sufficiency in what is sufficient—and the world is at peace.

Though the spirit-medium and the butcher differ in rank and labor, their positions seem unequal, yet both are bound by sincerity in invoking the spirits and reverence in facing affairs. There is a principle by which one could replace the other, yet the ancients would not do so. In later ages of moral decline, some rebel against ethics and reason, vainly seeking to usurp another’s role. Fortunately, this scripture endures, clarifying the proper measure of advancement and retreat, the boundaries of bestowal and reception, and cutting off the world’s ambitions for ill-gotten gains. Alas!

The Old Immortal of Nanhua is also a sage. Knowing that after the Dao and worldly ways had both perished, men would devour one another, he meticulously recorded the yielding deeds of the ancient sages, hoping that by tracing You’s flight, one might seek his heart. This is akin to Bian Que administering medicine before illness arises—a subtle means of aiding the world’s teachings, though few recognize it. With reverence, I have expounded the intent behind his words and brought it to light.

Jian Wu asked Lian Shu, saying: "I heard words from Jie Yu—vast yet without measure, gone and never returning. I was startled and terrified by his speech, as if it were the Milky Way without end. So grand and divergent, it seemed far from human sentiment."

Lian Shu said: "What did his words say?"

Jian Wu replied: "On the distant Mount Miaogu She, there dwells a divine person. Their skin is like ice and snow, their bearing supple as a maiden’s. They eat no grains, but draw in wind and drink dew. They ride the clouds and qi, mount flying dragons, and roam beyond the four seas. Their spirit congeals, so that things suffer no blight and the year’s harvest ripens. I deem this madness and do not believe it."

Lian Shu said: "Indeed. The blind cannot partake in the spectacle of patterns, nor the deaf in the sound of bells and drums. Is it only the body that may be deaf and blind? The mind, too, may be so. His words are like a maiden’s—timely yet untouched. That person, that virtue, would unify the myriad things as one. Should the world’s kindling be in chaos, who would trouble themselves with the affairs of the world? That person—nothing harms them. Though great floods reach the heavens, they do not drown; though great droughts melt metal and stone and scorch mountains to ash, they do not burn. Their dust and chaff could mold even Yao and Shun—who would deign to busy themselves with worldly matters?

The people of Song carried ceremonial caps to Yue, yet the Yue people, with shorn hair and tattooed bodies, had no use for them. Yao governed the people of the world and brought order to the realm’s affairs. Yet when he went to see the Four Masters on Mount Miaogu She, north of the Fen River, he suddenly lost all thought of his empire."

**Guo Xiang’s Annotation:** The divine person is none other than the sage. Though dwelling in the halls of governance, they are no different from those in the mountains and forests. Here, one who embodies royal virtue is placed upon this mountain to show that the world has no way to recognize them. Thus, they are set beyond the farthest reaches, pushed beyond the bounds of sight and hearing.

**Lü Huiqing’s Annotation:** Only those who embody the Dao can ascend Mount Miaogu She. The divine person is what all human hearts share; only those who exhaust the spirit can perceive them. *Miao* means to gaze distantly; *gu* means "for now"; *she* means "to reject." To climb this mountain is to see all worldly affairs as unworthy of regard—thus one gazes distantly and rejects them. Who but a divine person could attain this?

**Lin Yidu’s Annotation:** This passage contains the utmost truth. What the sages kept secret and did not speak of is this: the Dao reaches a point beyond words, so Jie Yu’s speech is invoked to clarify the way of the divine and the sage, with intent lodged in Miaogu She. *Miao* suggests remoteness—this mountain need not exist, much like the Five Mountains in the *Liezi*. The divine person is sage yet unknowable; how could words ever exhaust them?

**Chen Xiangdao’s Annotation:** Mount Miaogu She is a metaphor for the Dao. The divine person has no form—the Dao is their form; the divine person has no function—the Dao is their function. Thus, where the divine person dwells is simply the Dao.

**Chen Bixu’s Annotation:** The divine person is an allegory for the sage-king who embodies the Dao, serene and without action, rising and descending with transformation. With no trace of governance, those who act deem them mad and do not believe.

**Lü Chou’s Annotation:** Mount Miaogu She is set beyond the seas as a rhetorical device to marvel at the divine person’s wondrous dwelling, which the vulgar cannot know.

**Wang Pang’s Annotation:** Mount Miaogu She lies in the Northern Sea, a metaphor for returning to the root and reviving the mandate.

**Lecturer Fan of West Shu’s Hidden Realm:** The mountain is a metaphor for the body. *Miao* and *she* suggest its profound obscurity. The divine person is the utmost spirit within the body. If one seeks within this obscurity and finds the body’s utmost spirit, then not eating grains, drawing in wind, drinking dew, riding clouds, mounting dragons, and roaming the four seas are no exaggeration. To seek this outside oneself—is that not far indeed?

**Chu’s Insight:** The chapter on the divine person of Miaogu She speaks of one who does not consume worldly sustenance. Without direct transmission from the sages, how could their teachings descend to humanity? The lodging of the Dao is most essential here. Yet the words are subtle and profound, difficult for beginners to fathom. Examining the prior annotations, Lü and Lin grasp the thread, while later, Lecturer Wu Yin elaborates fully, directly pointing to the mystery and revealing the sages’ unspoken secret, opening the inherent heaven of learners. Alas, that I cannot lead all beings by the hand to ascend Miaogu She and join in carefree wandering! His intent is truly universal.

**Bo Xiu’s Postscript:** Having fortunately received such compassionate instruction, I dare not keep it private. With reverence, I append these annotations to propagate the Dharma and extend their meaning, offering a detailed explication below:

Their skin like ice and snow—embodying pure simplicity, unstained by dust. Supple as a maiden—preserving softness to remain whole, untouched by harm. Not eating grains, drawing in wind and drinking dew—they sever worldly tastes and absorb heaven and earth’s clarity. Riding clouds and mounting dragons, roaming the four seas—they soar through the vastness, merging with the primordial qi’s obscurity. This is what is meant by "arriving without moving, wandering with creation."

Their spirit congealed, so that things suffer no blight and the year’s harvest ripens—this is the utmost cultivation of spirit. Not only do they preserve themselves, but they also aid heaven and earth’s transformation and nurture the myriad things’ spontaneity. This speaks of the effect of extending oneself to others, thus merging with the unfathomable spirit and uniting with the boundless Dao!

Yet some, swayed by names and forms, seek this mountain beyond the farthest reaches—the divine person becomes even more distant. I humbly observe that the wonders of exhausting the spirit and perfecting transformation are fully revealed in this chapter. Yet those who hear it deem it madness and do not believe—how could this be only Jian Wu? This passage aligns with the second chapter of the *Liezi’s* "Yellow Emperor," differing slightly in wording but identical in meaning.

Zhuangzi of Nanhua attributed this to Jie Yu—this was but a means to lend mystery to his traces. The rest of the text is plain and comprehensible, so I shall not belabor its explication. Only the phrase *"du you shi nü ye"* admits of two interpretations: Guo Xiang, Cheng Xuanying, and others explain it as "like a maiden in her prime, naturally sought after by all things." Yet those whose wisdom is deaf and blind deny such a principle exists. Zhao of Xuzhai takes *shi* as "this," *nü* as "you," citing the *Book of Documents* where *"shi nü gong"* shares the same meaning. Lian Shu thus tells Jian Wu that the divine person resembles *you*. The *Liezi*'s "what is born and what takes form" aligns with Zhao's phonetic gloss in Yongzhai's oral exegesis.

As for the passage on "dust, grime, chaff, and husks molding Yao and Shun," it may seem to slight them—yet upon examining the sutra's intent, it is in fact the highest veneration. What the world extols as Yao and Shun, revering them as sages, are but the dust, grime, chaff, and husks of their names. How could the true essence of Yao and Shun be captured in words? When Yao went to see the Four Masters on Mount Miaogushe, their teachings diverged. According to Lu Deming’s *Sound and Meaning*, Sima Biao’s old commentary identifies them as Wang Ni, Nie Que, Pi Yi, and Xu You. Guo Xiang’s annotation states that the Four Masters are figurative, illustrating that Yao was not confined to being "Yao." For Yao was truly profound: in advancement, he was Yao; yet from the perspective of advancement, he observed his profundity—inner and outer realms thus differed. The world sees only Yao as Yao; how could they recognize his profundity? Thus, to seek the Four Masters beyond the seas based on Yao’s encounter is to mistake those who ride the waves of things for those who attain true freedom.

Master Cheng’s commentary explains the Four Masters as four virtues: the root, the trace, the neither-root-nor-trace, and the neither-neither-root-nor-trace. Yao, reflecting inwardly upon the source of his mind, penetrated the realm of the Dao, transcending these four distinctions—hence it is said he "went to see the Four Masters." Lü Huiqing annotates: "Yao went to see the Four Masters on Mount Miaogushe—this is to see the divine person. The divine person is the mind seeing itself, thus there is no self. With no self, even if one possesses the world, what use is the world?"

Another interpretation holds that Yao’s teacher was Xu You; Xu You’s teacher was Nie Que; Nie Que’s teacher was Wang Ni; and Wang Ni’s teacher was Pi Yi. All Four Masters mastered the spirit, and Yao entered through them—hence he "went to see them." Lin Yi’s solitary annotation reads: "Yao’s achievements in governing the world and pacifying the seas resemble a man of Song carrying ceremonial caps to Yue—useless. Chen Xiangdao annotates: "The Four Masters were those who did not take the world or things as their concern." Lian Shu ascribes to the divine person the qualities of being unharmed by great floods or droughts; Wang Ni ascribes to the perfected person the qualities of being unscathed by marsh fires or river freezes; the River Lord ascribes to the virtuous person the qualities of being unharmed by cold or heat, or harmed by birds and beasts; Confucius ascribes to the true person the qualities of traversing Mount Tai without obstruction or entering deep springs without getting wet. These four persons all harmonized their minds with primordial qi and merged their bodies with yin and yang. Yao attained the Way of the Four Masters—hence it is said he "went to see them."

Chen Bixu annotates: "Those who forget the world have no attachment to superficial names, yet the more they are revered, the more profoundly they forget. Thus, by putting the self aside, the self endures; by placing the self last, the self leads. This is why the world delights in exalting them without tiring." Wu Chou annotates: "From Yao’s own perspective, inner and outer realms differ. Those who govern the world and pacify the seas see only its edges. Yet Yao’s mind was vast and all-pervading, far beyond distant frontiers—no single region could confine him." Zhao of Xuzhai annotates Yao’s "going to see the Four Masters": "Was there truly someone to be seen? It was but an inward search. Only those who understand that Xu You *is* Yao can grasp this." The central theme of this chapter lies in the dialogue between Jian Wu and Lian Shu. Mastering this unlocks the meaning from beginning to end.

Lin Yongqi’s interpretation states: "The Four Masters, being nameless, are variously identified as Xu You, Nie Que, Wang Ni, and Pi Yi, or as the root, the trace, the neither-root-nor-trace, and the neither-neither-root-nor-trace. Such pursuits only grow more absurd. This is precisely Zhuangzi’s playful wit—like what people today call 'head-cutting words,' meant to provoke reflection. For the world is confined by its own perceptions, unaware of its delusion; only with great insight can one pierce through." Lecturer Fan of West Shu’s Wuyin says: "The Four Masters symbolize the four great elements; *miaoshe* describes their subtlety. Though Yao governed the world and pacified the seas, his traces appeared active while his mind never strayed from the Dao. He could reflect inwardly upon the four great elements in their subtlety—thus, with all burdens dissolved, he attained freedom."

Chu’s *Superficial Observations* states: "The above interpretations of the Four Masters vary. Some capture the general meaning but miss the specifics; others align with the numbers but stray from the essence. Among the accessible explanations, Xuzhai’s is most sound in principle, while Lecturer Fan’s encompasses both number and meaning—both are worthy of esteem." Now, these so-called Four Masters are allegorical, illuminating the Dao. Yet the Dao, as a thing, is elusive and obscure, difficult to define by form or number. Only when the scholar’s focus is undivided and they arrive at their own insight can the truth be grasped—mere words cannot exhaust it. Based on the sutra’s intent, I venture this explanation: Yao’s teacher was Xu You; Xu You’s Way derived from Nie Que, Wang Ni, and Pi Yi—thus the Way of the Four Masters was one. Yao, forgetting form to seek the Dao, was said to have "gone to see them" on Mount Miaogushe, which is the earlier metaphor of inwardly observing the subtlety within the self. This Way is timeless, whether in ancient or modern times, ruler or subject.

The ruler who attains this Dao becomes the present-day Emperor Yao; the commoner who attains this Dao becomes the present-day Xu You. The Fen River marks the site of Yao’s capital—without leaving his place, he could perceive the Four Masters, for the Dao is not to be sought in distant quests. "Profoundly relinquishing his realm" describes casting it aside like worn-out sandals.

Further delving into the ancestral sutra, I have privately found resonance, reverently discerning its forms, entities, essences, and truths. In interpreting the Four Masters, their meanings align seamlessly. Once the Four Masters are seen, the highest worth resides within oneself. The honor of ten thousand chariots and the wealth of the four seas become matters of no concern.

Hui Zi said to Zhuangzi: "The King of Wei bestowed upon me seeds of a great gourd. I planted them, and they bore fruit of five *shi* in capacity. When used to hold water or broth, its strength could not support its own weight. When split to make ladles, its vastness left no vessel to contain it. Though not lacking in size, I deemed it useless and smashed it."

Zhuangzi replied: "You are indeed inept at putting great things to use. There was a man of Song skilled in crafting an ointment that prevented chapped hands. For generations, his family made their living by washing silk. A traveler heard of this and offered a hundred gold pieces for the formula. The clan gathered to deliberate: 'For generations, we have earned no more than a few pieces of gold from washing silk. Now, in a single morning, we could sell this craft for a hundred gold. Let us give it to him.' The traveler acquired it and presented it to the King of Wu. When Yue raised a challenge, the King of Wu appointed him general. In winter, he engaged the Yue forces in naval battle, decisively defeating them, and was enfeoffed with lands. The same ointment that prevented chapped hands brought one man a fief, while another remained bound to washing silk—such is the difference in how it was used. Now you possess a gourd of five *shi*—why not consider fashioning it into a great float to drift upon rivers and lakes, instead of fretting over its vastness leaving no vessel to contain it? Clearly, your mind remains entangled in conventional constraints!"

Hui Zi said to Zhuangzi: "I have a great tree, which people call the *chu*. Its massive trunk is gnarled and unfit for the carpenter’s line, its slender branches twisted and unsuited to compass or square. Standing by the roadside, no craftsman gives it a glance. Now your words are vast but useless—rejected by all."

Zhuangzi replied: "Have you alone never seen the wildcat or weasel? Crouching low to lie in wait, it pounces on passing prey, leaping east and west, heedless of height or depth..."

Trapped by snares and crushed in nets, they die in woven traps. Now consider the yak: its bulk hangs like clouds trailing the sky. This creature may be great indeed, yet it cannot catch a mouse. You possess a great tree and fret over its uselessness—why not plant it in the land of Nothing Whatever, the boundless wilds? Wander carefree at its side, recline at ease beneath its shade. Unfelled by axes, untouched by harm, it suffers no use—how then could it know hardship?

Guo Xiang’s note: The salve keeps hands from cracking, so they float flax in water. Yet the *peng* is no mere vessel of direct passage. All things have their proper place; if they find it, where could they not be at ease? Whether small or great, if they lose their measure, the logic of profit and harm becomes the same. When use finds its proper place, all things wander free.

Lü Huiqing’s note: Hui Zi, bound by form and vessel, called Zhuangzi’s words vast but useless, so he compared them to the great gourd. From its planting to its growth, I have observed his words from beginning to end—yet in truth, a five-*shi* gourd cannot even lift itself, for he seeks it in form and is burdened by embodiment. Split it to make a ladle, and its vastness finds no container; thus, in use, it is confined to the cosmos and cannot escape. To employ a great thing in a great place—yet Hui Zi is burdened by embodiment, so he doubts and questions. Thus Zhuangzi answers with clumsiness in using greatness. He then cites the salve for chapped hands as an analogy: the Dao’s words are one, but if used poorly, they cannot even suffice for the limbs—so generations wash flax for mere coins. If used well, they not only suffice for the body but can rescue a drowning world, as in naval battles where land is seized and titles conferred. A vessel that never fills when poured, never empties when drawn—this too is one’s rivers and lakes. You possess a great vessel yet cannot float it in a great place, fretting over its lack of containment—is this not rightly called a mind entangled in conventional constraints?

Hui Zi, still unenlightened, again questioned the great *chu*. Things take usefulness as their use, and their use is small; they take uselessness as their use, and their use is great. The wildcat and weasel leap and bound, dying in nets—they cannot be without action and perish by their own cunning. The yak is vast but cannot catch a mouse. This is the analogy of carefree wandering and non-action, preserving form and life. The sage’s relation to the Dao is to embody it with deep roots and firm stem, so that as a tree, it becomes great. For those who wish to plant it, nothing is better than returning to seek the heart. The heart as a thing knows no abode; find its unknowable place and settle there—this is planting it in the land of Nothing Whatever. Fill it, and it pervades the six directions; still it, and the myriad things do not disturb. Wander at its side, recline beneath it—never for a moment depart. Then what hardship could the so-called vast and useless know, that you should sigh over it?

Though Hui Zi was most wise, he could not thoroughly empty the heart and discard knowledge to reach the state before things arose. Thus, he could not doubt the Dao, so Zhuangzi expounded on uselessness and dispassion. Those who doubt later may ponder and grasp it.

Lin Yi’s sole note: The King of Wei bestowed upon me the seeds of a great gourd, an analogy for Heaven endowing me with a hollow nature. Its growth is an analogy for receiving and preserving it. Its capacity of five *shi* is an analogy for filling it with the five constants. To hold water and wine, its clarity and coolness can mirror the myriad things. Yet its hardness cannot lift itself—are not the five constants within the body also heavy? Split it to make a ladle, and it divides in two. Its vastness finds no container, so it is deemed useless and smashed—an analogy for the scattering of nature, which cannot be preserved, though all remains bright within. Thus, one assumes it cannot be restored and fails to awaken, for emotion has seized it. You cannot preserve the great gourd’s use, just as one cannot fulfill their nature. Thus, he cites the Song man’s salve for chapped hands to clarify the difference in use. People possess a hollow nature; they should fill it with carefree wandering, follow non-action, just as one considers the great gourd’s form and fashions it into a great float to drift upon rivers and lakes—why then fret over its lack of containment? Failing to fulfill nature is not true attainment, so he says it is a mind entangled in conventional constraints. Hui Zi again questions the great *chu*—gnarled and twisted, rejected by all—as a mockery of Zhuangzi’s words being vast but useless. Thus, he cites the wildcat, weasel, and yak in reply. Though small and great differ, and quickness and dullness vary, those skilled in use are not free from hardship. Therefore, the sage preserves the root of life and embodies the Dao as use. The *chu* deepens its roots and flourishes in branches and leaves; life secures its foundation, and the myriad affairs are ordered. The *Book of Changes* says: "Constancy is the stem of affairs." This is why the stem is the foundation. *Nothing Whatever* speaks of its emptiness; *boundless* speaks of its vastness. You possess a great tree—just as one possesses a true mandate—why not plant it in the land of emptiness and boundlessness, allowing it to wander carefree and non-active, unharmed and uncut? This is how the spirit-person achieves great auspiciousness.

Chen Xiangdao’s note: Things have their proper place; affairs have their fitting use. The trouble lies only in not using them well. The salve for chapped hands is one, yet the Song man’s use of it brought small profit, while the Wu man’s use brought great. The art of weakening the seven states was one, yet Chao Cuo’s use of it brought disaster, while Zhufu Yan’s use quelled chaos. Is the use of the great gourd any different? The gourd as a thing is hollow within and excels at containment; round without, it excels at floating. Placed on the ground, it loses its floating nature.

Round yet too cumbersome to lift, split into ladles, it destroys its spherical form and the gourd becomes hollow and useless. But if one hollows it into a floating vessel and sets it upon rivers and lakes, it rises effortlessly and adapts to every purpose. Of all things under heaven, the small are easily put to use, the great are difficult to employ—yet human nature is ever skilled in using the small, often clumsy in wielding the great. Those who handle great things with the skill of small ones do not follow their nature or accord with principle; how can they cast off the encumbrance of a mind like tangled mugwort?

Hui Shi again deemed Zhuangzi’s words grand but useless, likening them to the great catalpa—knowing only the use of the useful, not the use of the useless. Zhuangzi replied that the wildcat and weasel, small yet useful, cannot escape misfortune; the yak, large yet useless, suffers no harm from other creatures. Thus, the use of the useful is not as good as the use of the useless. The great catalpa is useless, but if planted in a place of uselessness, the planter may wander carefree, and the tree itself escapes the axe’s bite and the toil of being shifted between profit and harm or battered by worldly custom—how can these be spoken of in the same breath?

Chen Bixu’s note: Some things are unsuited to worldly use, and people readily discard them, not understanding the use of the useless. Thus, things have no fixed size or refinement—it lies in man’s skillful use. Later, the parable of the great catalpa further illustrates the useless: the wildcat and weasel, nimble and clever, perish in traps; the yak, lacking skill, preserves its life. Quick wit invites calamity, dullness preserves the self—this has long been so! Earlier, the roc and the quail were discussed as creatures of feeling, their carefree wandering valued for their soaring freedom. Here, the gourd and catalpa are used to show the carefree wandering of the unfeeling, the essence lying in avoiding harm and loss. Those who grasp this truth find goodness in every direction.

Wang Xiu’s note: The *Da Tong* doubts the uniqueness of the passage yet refines its phrasing.

Zhao Xuchi’s note: Hui Shi questioned Zhuangzi about the great gourd and great tree as useless, and Zhuangzi answered with the salve for chapped hands and the yak to clarify the use of the useless.

Lin Fuzhai’s *Oral Exegesis*: The *zun* is a floating gourd tied to the waist to cross midstream. If one loses a boat, a single gourd is worth a thousand gold—this is what is meant. Zhuangzi, having used the salve for chapped hands to illustrate Hui Shi’s ignorance of proper use, then said: with such a great gourd, why not consider making a floating vessel for rivers? A "mugwort-mind" is one whose heart is blocked like overgrown mugwort. Hui Shi again mocked Zhuangzi’s words with the swollen catalpa, and Zhuangzi replied that the wildcat and weasel, though small, are trapped by their cunning, while the yak, though large, preserves its life through lack of skill. He meant that things, whether great or small, have different aptitudes—one cannot deem all great things useless. "Wuhe" and "Guangmo" refer to the spontaneity of creation and the center of the supreme Way, where there is a place of joy. Though useless to the world, one may yet escape misfortune.

Chu Guan’s *Superficial Insights*: Creation generates things, filling heaven and earth, and their usefulness or uselessness depends on the moment’s encounter—whether they grow in a forest or not is secondary. Thus, some are used in the past but discarded now, or discarded now but used later—this arises from human action, not the thing’s inherent nature. Observe the straw dogs of sacrifice, the scattered remnants of Zhu and Chen—this is evident. Moreover, the gourd of King Wei of Liang was unlike ordinary seeds; those who saw it were astonished and could not fathom its use. No wonder Hui Shi found it strange and questioned it. Zhuangzi, knowing Hui Shi’s clumsiness with great things, used the salve for chapped hands to illustrate. Things are fundamentally the same, yet their value may differ tenfold, a hundredfold, or a thousandfold—it lies in whether one uses them well or poorly. People are often skilled in using small things, and the world readily embraces the small—what they achieve is thus limited. The world is often clumsy with great things, and some grow complacent in guarding the great—what they hoard is thus evident. A five-*dan* gourd, grown to maturity, is not the work of a single morning. Yet now, not only can it not fulfill its great use, but it is battered and discarded—how unfortunate for this gourd! All exceptional things are endowed by the qi of creation; their uselessness may yet await a purpose. Since it is too large to be split for household use, one should consider preserving it whole for use on rivers and lakes, aiding deep crossings and matching the function of boats and oars—then the gourd’s uselessness becomes its wondrous use. Hui Shi, with all his resourcefulness, did not think of this, his mind blocked like mugwort. He again mocked Zhuangzi’s grand words as useless, comparing them to the swollen catalpa, unfit for compass or square. Zhuangzi replied that the wildcat and weasel, clever and swift, die in traps, while the yak, lacking skill, preserves its life—what a difference in gain and loss! Now you have a great tree, yet instead of planting it in a place of uselessness to enjoy carefree wandering, you fret that carpenters will not notice it—this is what Master Nanhua deeply laments. Thus, he seized the question to correct Hui Shi, freeing him from the shackles of form and tools, preserving his nature and life in emptiness and mystery, transcending action to enter non-action, and achieving great use through uselessness. This is the essence of the *Free and Easy Wandering*.

The *Free and Easy Wandering* chapter is vast and profound, its allusions lofty and far-reaching, its language boundless, its meaning sublime. Reading it, one seems to ride the cool wind and ascend the boundless, forgetting worldly cares to roam the heavens. Truly, it is the grand rule for surpassing conventional meanings, breaking through barriers, untying knots, and releasing bonds—the swift path to penetrating the mysterious and investigating the subtle.

Bo Xiu, unworthy as he is, has ventured his humble insights and appended a general discussion at the end: Those who follow the supreme principle harmonize the Way with all affairs; those who preserve their true nature unite with things in oneness.

Where the heavenly principle is attained, yet one remains un-*Free and Easy*—such a case has never existed. The infant’s heart is originally without knowledge; knowledge grows with the body, and as things present themselves, gains and losses lodge in the mind, where ice and fire clash. Abandoning this to serve that, there is no respite. Unless one illuminates principle with perfect clarity and lets the Dao and righteousness prevail, even those of utmost nobility or wealth cannot escape this fate.

Thus, the essential task in studying the Way is first to seek the joy of the sages and worthies, to investigate it with one’s own body, and only then will one gain true strength. The *Book of Changes* says: “Find joy in Heaven and know destiny.” Yan Hui delighted in his gourd bowl, Mencius nurtured his vastness until it filled Heaven and Earth, and Yuan Xian sang as he walked, his voice ringing like metal and stone—all transcended the burdens of external things, preserved the Heaven within themselves, and in every action or stillness, found nothing that was not joy. Only then can one speak of the *Free and Easy Wandering*.

The leviathan of the Northern Darkness transforms into the roc, striking the wind and beating the water as it migrates to the Southern Darkness. This illustrates how scholars, confined by narrow learning and petty aspirations, fail to perceive the profound clarity of the sea of nature or recognize the pearl of destiny that has already sunk and been lost. Thus, Zhuangzi presents this great creature, born in vastness, to clarify our own origins. With long cultivation, body and spirit merge in transformation, moving between yin and yang, their function unfathomable. Those who “know enough to hold one office, compare their conduct to one village, match their virtue to one lord, or win the trust of one state” will awaken to the lightness of external things and the weight of their own Heaven. Then they will see themselves nurtured by the wind, soaring above the clouds, and merging with the boundless transformation. What worldly cares could ever reach them?

Thus, only when one “rides Heaven and Earth, harnesses the six qi, and roams the infinite” does one attain the ultimate *Free and Easy Wandering*. The most divine and sagely, too, are but those who merge and transform as one—fame and merit are merely external things. The chapter where Yao offers the throne to Xu You serves to confirm this principle, inspire the spirit of humility and deference, awaken later generations, and sever their longing for external bonds, greatly benefiting the Way of governance.

When Jian Wu hears the words of Jie Yu, the secrets of the spirit-person are expounded to illustrate the utmost numinosity within the body. The task is to grasp, preserve, and nurture it to attain this state—it is not to be sought afar. “Dust and grime, husks and chaff, can mold a Yao or Shun”: the virtue of the spirit-person moves in harmony with Heaven. Extending its residue alone suffices to bring about the governance of Tang and Yu, yet its true essence is beyond the ken of ordinary people.

When Yao went to visit the Four Masters on the distant Guye Mountain, the wondrous principle there defies conjecture. One must personally visit the Four Masters of Guye to understand without words—scholars, take heed!

This chapter begins by discussing the leviathan, the roc, the cicada, the young dove, the spiritual plant, and the morning mushroom, showing that whether in short or long years, all are discourses on exhausting principle. At the end, it presents the great gourd that preserves itself through emptiness and the great tree that secures itself through deep roots, illustrating the fulfillment of one’s nature to the utmost of destiny. This is the great accomplishment in studying the Way, entering the realm of the spirit. Swift without haste, arriving without movement—where could one go that would not be the *Free and Easy Wandering*?

*Commentary on the Meaning of the True Classic of Southern Florescence*, *Volume One of the Ocean of Subtleties*, concludes.

*Volume Two of the Collected Subtleties on the Meaning of the True Classic of Southern Florescence*
By Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin

**Chapter One: On the Equality of Things**

Nanguo Ziqi, leaning on his armrest, sat in repose. Gazing upward, he exhaled deeply, his spirit seeming to have lost its counterpart. Yan Cheng Ziyou stood in attendance before him and asked, "What is this? Can the body truly be made like withered wood, and the heart like dead ashes? Yet the one who now leans on the armrest is not the same as the one who did so before."

Ziqi replied, "Yan, is this not well asked? Today, I have lost my self—do you understand? You have heard the *human pipes*, but not the *earthly pipes*; you have heard the *earthly pipes*, but not the *heavenly pipes*!"

Ziyou said, "May I ask the method?"

Ziqi said, "The great clod breathes forth *qi*, and its name is wind. It does nothing of itself, but when it arises, the myriad hollows roar in fury. Have you alone not heard its ceaseless murmuring? The towering forests and mighty trees, with hollows a hundred spans around—some like noses, some like mouths, some like ears, some like beams, some like rings, some like mortars, some like pools, some like marshes; some whistling, some wailing, some shrieking, some inhaling, some crying, some wailing, some roaring, some gnashing. The first sings *yu*, and the followers sing *mo*. A gentle breeze brings a small harmony; a violent gale, a great harmony. When the fierce wind subsides, all hollows fall silent. Have you alone not seen their trembling and swaying?"

Ziyou said, "The *earthly pipes* are these myriad hollows; the *human pipes* are the bamboo flutes. May I ask about the *heavenly pipes*?"

Ziqi said, "The wind blows in ten thousand different ways, yet each makes itself so. All take of themselves—who is it that stirs them?"

**Guo Xiang’s Commentary:**
To unite with heaven and humanity, forgetting self and other, is to dissolve into emptiness, as if one has lost one’s match. "Withered wood" and "dead ashes" describe a state of stillness and passionlessness—standing like a withered tree, moving like drifting dust. In their bearing, whether in motion or stillness, I cannot be one with them; in their self-so spontaneity, I cannot be two. If the self is already lost, what thing remains to be known?

Flutes and pipes vary in length, their notes—*gong* and *shang*—follow different scales, thus producing sounds of myriad differences in pitch and duration. Yet the measure they receive is one, each taking of itself—here is revealed the *heavenly pipes* of heaven and earth. The great clod exhales its breath—what thing is there? Heaven and earth are but a clod, exhaling of themselves.

The roaring of ten thousand hollows, the diverse apertures of trees, the varied sounds of all apertures—none fail to accord with what they receive. *Tiaotiao* and *diaodiao* describe the wind’s near-stilling, its faintest stirring. Above, the *human pipes* and *earthly pipes* are made clear; Ziyou then asks of the *heavenly pipes*. Ziqi says: "The wind blows in ten thousand different ways, yet each makes itself so"—this is the *heavenly pipes*. Are the *heavenly pipes* some separate thing? They are but the *human pipes* and *earthly pipes*, meeting with the class of living beings and together forming one heaven. Living things are clods that live of themselves—it is not I who give them life. Since I cannot give life to things, things cannot give life to me. That which is so of itself is called *natural*. Does this refer to the azure expanse?

**Lü Huiqing’s Commentary:**
That by which a person has form and mind is simply the presence of a self. If there were no self, one would be like dead ashes or withered wood—nothing extraordinary. Ziyou does not know whence the self arises, is enslaved by form and mind without respite, and does not understand how one might reach such a state. Yet in the *tara* interval between past and present, he perceives the difference between leaning on the armrest then and now—his observation is thus discerning. In the past, leaning on the armrest was a time of responding to things; now, it is a time of leaving things behind. If one knows whence the self arises, then presence and absence have never not been in one’s own hands. The bamboo flute is a thing—all people hear it and know its hollowness, its emptiness. That by which I am I is likewise so. What difference is there between the roaring of ten thousand hollows and the time when one has a self and is enslaved by form and mind? What difference is there between the hollowness of all apertures and the time when one has lost the self and is like withered wood or dead ashes?

It is said: "Yet you alone do not hear, do not see"—the arising of the *earthly pipes* is only what you have ever heard and seen; the arising and ceasing of the mind is what you have never heard or seen. By investigating what you have heard and seen to fathom what you have never heard or seen, the *heavenly pipes* may be known.

**Lin Yi’s *Duyi* Commentary:**
The wind emerges from emptiness, seeking without trace, arising from stillness and returning to stillness, born from nothingness and returning to nothingness. Only the differences in what the apertures receive vary. What people hear also differs; compared to the myriad things’ endowments, it is the same. All apertures are sounded by the wind; all forms are enslaved by transformation. If the wind cannot sound, then all apertures are empty; if transformation cannot enslave, then all things rest. As for that which has no sound and no aperture, the wind cannot enter it—this is what Liezi calls *yidu*.

**Wang Pang’s Commentary** (following Lin’s interpretation):
The *human pipes* arise from being made so; the *heavenly pipes* have that which is natural. Who is it that abides in and embodies them? Each takes of itself in its roaring—nothing more. The sundial has its constant measure, yet those who grieve or rejoice see it as varying in length. The moon’s movement has its constant path, yet those who observe its waxing and waning see it as racing east and west. The wind blows in ten thousand different ways, yet each takes of itself—how is this different? This is why it is called the *heavenly pipes*. The wind, being empty, enters well; apertures, being empty, receive well. Pipes arise from emptiness alone. Observing things through emptiness, all things are equal; observing things through fullness, all things differ.

**Chen Bixu’s Commentary:**
The wind in heaven and earth is like the *yuanqi* in the human body—this is non-action, like the state of *zuowang*. The roaring of ten thousand hollows is like the time of human activity. Only because the apertures differ do the sounds of the pipes vary so widely—yet this too arises from the natural. Examining the naturalness of the three pipes, the principle returns to the profound stillness of *zuowang*.

**Zhao Xuzhai’s Commentary:**
Sounds emerge from all apertures—who truly rouses them? There is that which gives rise to sounds within them, yet it cannot be heard or seen. This is the *heavenly pipes* within the *earthly pipes*. The *human pipes* are likewise, yet not fully encompassed by bamboo flutes. Thus, the later chapter compares them to knowing, speaking, dreaming, waking, joy, anger, sorrow, and happiness—day and night succeeding one another without knowing their origin. The origin is the beginning of life. Morning and evening obtain this, whence life arises—this is the heaven of pipes, the so-called *true master* and *true lord*, which is the same idea.

**Lin Yongzhai’s *Kouyi* Commentary:**
This passage in Zhuangzi is a marvel within marvels. The ancients said poetry is a painting with sound, meaning it can depict scenes that are hard to describe. Yet no painting has ever captured sound. From "rushing" to "whistling," eight words describe eight sounds. *Yu* and *yong* are their harmonizing sounds. The wind between heaven and earth is formless and shadowless, a sound that can be heard but not seen—yet it is brought forth from the tip of the brush. This is why it is marvelous.

**Chu Guan’s *Guanjian* Commentary:**
Examining the above text: "One’s form can surely be made like withered wood"—this is stated directly. "Can one’s mind surely be made like dead ashes?"—this is asked in return. Ziqi says: "Now I have lost my self." Knowing it is "I" means the mind does not respond like dead ashes—there is a true self present. This is the principle of extinguishing movement but not extinguishing illumination. Ziyou asks for the method, and the answer is the great clod exhaling its breath, merely illustrating it with the *earthly pipes*. When asked again, Ziqi then says: "The wind blows in ten thousand different ways, yet each makes itself so." Only here is the true mechanism of the *heavenly pipes* revealed. Alas, Ziyou knows that form can be withered but the mind cannot be ashes—this is the true self—yet he does not realize this is the heaven of pipes.

The heart is the lord of heaven, and the *lai* (pipes) are the function of this heart. All that is used to extend knowledge, investigate things, respond to opportunities, and adapt to changes—manifesting in words and actions—are of this nature. It need not be perceived as sound to be called *lai*. The lord may sit in upright repose, doing nothing, but must never lose his position for a single day. The heart may be still and thoughtless, but must never be extinguished for even a moment. Though the heart makes no sound, that which gives rise to sound resides within it, like a bell or drum suspended, known before it is struck. The deluded cling to the arising and ceasing of forms, thus their perception of sound is intermittent.

The *lai* of humans and earth have movement and stillness; the *lai* of heaven is natural, transcending both movement and stillness, possessing a true master and true lord, the true ruler of all sounds and perceptions. Later in the text, it speaks of "not being blown," and "the speaker has words"—this is so. The common people, in their daily lives, remain unaware, entangled in interactions, exhausting their spirit and vitality, and thus suffer from the disorder of things. This is like carrying firewood to extinguish a fire.

If scholars can turn inward and seek, grasping their true direction, then examining inwardly within themselves and observing outwardly among things, they will find that beginning and end each accord with their root source, and the great and small all harmonize in unity. How could there be any disorder? In examining the meaning of the *great clod*, Guo Xiang says it is "no-thing." Master Cheng comments: "It is the Creator." This too is a name for the natural. It is also called "heaven." Now, the original text states that the *great clod* bears me with form, and the *Liezi* says: "The earth is but accumulated clods." Interpreting it as earth may be close in meaning. Yet this *great clod* seems to refer to the exhalation of qi between heaven and earth, which is what the *Daodejing* calls "like a bellows." The mechanism of opening and closing, the root of yin and yang, the primordial qi transforming and operating therein—this is what stirs and animates the myriad things, causing them to surge, sway, shake, and flourish.

On a grand scale, it can lift houses, uproot trees, shatter mountains, and raise seas—these are its violent outbursts. When its mechanism halts and the *lai* ceases, all returns to silence and nothingness. Where then are the things it once stirred? The true person uses this to illustrate the arising and ceasing of the heart—this is a most profound insight. Yet what causes this arising and ceasing lies in a person’s focused thought and skillful inquiry.

The great knowledge is leisurely, the small knowledge is petty; great words blaze, small words chatter. In sleep, the hun-souls intermingle; when awake, the body opens. Entangled in interactions, one battles daily with the heart. The careless, the cunning, the secretive—small fears make them tremble, great fears leave them dazed. Their outbursts are like the release of a crossbow trigger—this is what is meant by "controlling right and wrong." Their restraint is like a sworn oath—this is what is meant by "guarding it." Their decline is like autumn and winter, speaking of their daily dissipation. Their drowning in their pursuits makes them irrecoverable. Their weariness is like a sealed letter, speaking of their aged exhaustion. The heart near death cannot be revived.

Joy, anger, sorrow, fear, delight, thought, sighing, change, compassion, coquetry, wantonness, charm, and affectation—these arise from emptiness like music from a hollow, or steam forming mushrooms. Day and night they alternate before us, yet none knows whence they sprout. Alas! Alas! If by dusk one grasps this, it is the very source from which life arises! Without that, there is no self; without the self, nothing is grasped. This is nearly so, yet none knows what moves it. As if there were a true master, yet no trace of it can be found? One may act with self-assurance, yet its form remains unseen. Does it have essence but no form?

The hundred bones, nine orifices, and six viscera—all are complete within me. To which should I feel closest? Do you delight in all of them equally? Or do you favor some? Are they all like ministers and servants? Are these ministers and servants insufficient to govern one another? Do they take turns ruling as lord and subject? Or is there a true lord residing within? Whether one seeks and finds its nature or not, does it add or diminish one’s truth?
