Once receiving its completed form, it does not perish until its end. It grinds and wears against things, its course racing on like a gallop, with none able to halt it—is this not sorrowful? A lifetime of toil, yet no success is seen. Exhausted and weary, with no place to return—is this not lamentable? People call this not dying, but what does it profit? The body transforms, the heart follows suit—can this not be called great sorrow?

Guo Xiang’s Commentary:
To know that waking and sleeping differ, that interactions and fears take varied forms, that decline and dissipation occur daily, that drowning in pursuits leads to irreversible loss—all these shifts of nature and events alternate day and night, as if a true master exists yet leaves no trace. Clearly, all things are self-so, with nothing compelling them to be so. Now, the one who acts trusts that action is possible; when essence matches its object, form does not appear distinct. Then the hundred bones, nine orifices, and all else are entrusted to spontaneity, and none fails to delight in them. Yet if there is partiality, high and low encroach upon one another, and none serves as minister or servant. The division of lord and subject is like heaven’s height and earth’s lowness—placed where they naturally belong. The true lord allows things to be thus of themselves, without artifice. To nearly grasp true nature and employ what is self-so—whether knowing or not, all remains at ease. Yet the wise guard their knowledge to await the end, while the foolish cling to ignorance until death. Opposing and aligning forces intertwine, each trusting their own bias, indulging their conduct without self-reflection. This, compared to the sorrow of the multitude, is indeed sorrowful. Yet people never regard this as sorrow—it is simply the nature of things. Each thing is so by nature; what is there to lament?

Thus, a lifetime of toil, weariness, and exhaustion—though alive, it is in truth no different from death. The greatness of this sorrow is such that people never consider it sorrowful. Then what is lamented is not truly lamentable.

Lü Huiqing’s Commentary:
*Xianxian* and *jianjian* clarify the difference between great and small. Sleeping, waking, engaging, and entangling show the differences among the careless, the cunning, and the secretive. Likes and dislikes lie within, and when things touch them, their eruption is like the release of a crossbow trigger. Names and principles confront the outside, and when things draw them, their restraint is like a sworn oath. This speaks to their differing inclinations and aversions. Their decline like autumn and winter, leaving none able to revive—this speaks to the varying depths of desire.

Joy, anger, sorrow, delight, thought, sighing, change, compassion, coquetry, wantonness, charm, and affectation—these are the differing manifestations of their emotional states. All these are the myriad differences of the blowing wind, yet each moves of itself, like music emerging from emptiness or steam forming mushrooms. Day and night they alternate, yet none knows whence they sprout—this is the work of the heavenly pipe, the non-doing of spontaneity.

Are not the differences in vessels’ sizes, inclinations, aversions, and depths of desire like the varied shapes of cliffs and hollows? Are not the differences in *xian*, *jian*, carelessness, fear, joy, anger, sorrow, and delight like the varied sounds of roaring and murmuring? Music arises from emptiness, steam forms mushrooms—seeking their origin yields nothing, like the wind passing through hollows, producing *tiaotiao* and *diaodiao* sounds with no place to return. From this perspective, where does the self that is the self reside? How can the body not become like withered wood? How can the heart not become like dead ashes?

The difficulty of knowing the heavenly pipe and seeing the true lord lies in utterly losing the self to unite with it in spirit. Grasping this by dusk is to know the source from which life arises—this is to know what cannot be known in its sprouting yet unite with it in spirit. Without finding its trace or seeing its form, one cannot discern what moves it and so searches throughout the body’s frame, knowing it has never had a fixed place.

No part of the person is unloved, yet among the hundred bones and nine orifices, to which should one feel closest? With no single closeness, all become like ministers and servants, with none ruling as lord. If ministers and servants are insufficient to govern one another, they take turns as lord and subject—this is not the true lord. Searching within the body’s frame for what moves it yields nothing, yet the existence of a true lord can be known. All people have a true lord; whether one seeks and finds its nature or not, nothing is added or diminished. Why? It is not that the heartless are distant from it, nor that the heartful are near.

Lin Yidu’s Commentary:
To contend with the myriad things with a mind of utmost restraint is to end only in exhaustion. The careless are shallowly obscured, the cunning deeply so, and the secretive even more so. The crossbow trigger speaks to their eruption, which cannot be retraced. The sworn oath speaks to their restraint, which cannot be seized. Pursuing right and wrong, bound to guarding victory, their essence and qi decline like autumn and winter’s withering. Drowning in profit and desire, they cannot be restored to goodness.

Those from the preceding "flaming brilliance" and "leisurely ease" to Yao, Yi, Qi, and Tai—all discuss those who cannot perceive the Unique: they are enslaved by yin and yang, manifesting these myriad emotional states. Joy emerges from emptiness, thus sound arises from the soundless. Mushrooms form through steaming, thus form is born from the formless. Day and night alternate before us, yet none know their origin; dawn and dusk receive this to live, yet understand not how. Without the true lord, I would not exist; without me, the true lord’s name would have no claim. The true lord issues commands yet acts not; the governor receives the lord’s mandate and exercises governance. As a thing, it belongs neither to yin nor yang, neither within nor without; it may be spiritually apprehended, not sought through images. The utmost of nature and destiny—emotions await the true lord before proceeding, yet the true lord’s form remains unseen.

Of man’s hundred bones and nine orifices, all should follow their natural course. If one cannot forget and instead cherishes them, partiality arises: what pleases becomes lord, what displeases becomes servant or concubine. Servants and concubines cannot govern themselves, so the true lord governs them. The true lord, acting not, dwells in the central void; the hundred limbs and nine orifices serve without awareness. Whether one seeks and finds its nature or not, nothing is added or diminished from its truth. Laozi said: "Abandon learning, and there will be no sorrow"—to seek is of no benefit to attainment.

All things reside within creation, their transformations boundless, yet the true lord remains indestructible. Mortals, having chanced to become human, thus cling to the self, unaware of that which does not perish. Locked in mutual conflict and erosion, they toil like draft animals, their forms and hearts transformed—then all is over. Is this not profoundly lamentable?

Chen Xiangdao’s Commentary:
When knowledge and speech respond to externals, while contention and fear assail within, their eruption brings the burden of right and wrong; their restraint, the obstruction of guarding victory. Their virtue withers to irrecoverable decay, their hearts stifled until yang can no longer return. Joy, anger, sorrow, and delight become mere reactions to things—how could they know what is called "free and unfettered"? Joy emerges from emptiness; steam gives rise to mushrooms. The transformations of yin and yang, the endless alternation of day and night—observing form and sound, their origin is distant indeed! Yet none know where they begin. Observing self and other, it is near at hand!

Yet none know what compels them—thus it seems a true master exists, though no trace of it can be found.

This true master is the functioning of the Dao. The eye sees, the ear hears, the hand grasps, the foot walks—all these I merely preserve, yet who claims them as private possessions? Servants and concubines attend to others yet cannot be truly commanded. When ruler and subject alternate roles, they cannot avoid acting. But where a true lord resides, there has never been action.

When seeing occurs, the eye serves as lord, yet what enables this has a lordship beyond the eye. When walking occurs, the foot serves as lord, yet what enables this has a lordship beyond the foot. All these are inherent to humanity—whether one grasps their essence or not, nothing is added or taken from their truth.

Those who wield the tools of time and entrust themselves to the boundless—how could form alone suffice? The deeply rooted in generative abundance, though existing, do not perish; they drift with things along the paths of right and wrong, until form transforms and the heart follows—this is the greatest sorrow! As it is said: "No sorrow is greater than the death of the heart."

Zhao Xuqi’s Commentary:
Knowledge, speech, sleep, wakefulness, engagement, contention, concealment, secrecy—responding to ten thousand changes, they are like the wind stirring the pipes, blowing myriad differences. That which arises is the initial movement of the mechanism; that which lingers is the retention after movement. Abundance dwindles, growth decays—this is one’s gradual decline. Entering without exit, closing without opening, until exhaustion and final return—this is one’s end. When a fierce wind passes, all hollows become empty—this is what it means to let things follow their own course.

Joy, anger, and the twelve states—arising from emotion, manifesting in voice, sound, and countenance—who causes them thus? Joy emerges from emptiness; mushrooms arise from steam—this clarifies that the twelve states all arise from self-origination. When emotion meets things, rising and falling follow one another, their origin unknown. All that is born from nothingness has a master residing within nothingness. Morning and evening obtain this source of generation—this is the heaven of the pipes. Without it, there is no self. As the *Doctrine of the Mean* says: "Without sincerity, there is no thing," yet without things, sincerity cannot be revealed. Thus it is said: "Without me, there is nothing to grasp." These words nearly approach the Dao.

Not knowing who truly compels them, it is as if a true master resides within, yet no beginning can be sought.

Faith is to follow one’s nature in action. Emotion is the manifestation of nature. Nature itself is formless and invisible. Within a person’s body, the hundred bones and nine orifices cannot be of one accord—whom then should I hold dear? Where lies partiality? It is said that within must reside a true sovereign, only then can all be governed. The benevolent see it as benevolence, for they grasp its essence. The common people use it daily yet remain unaware, for they do not grasp its essence. Whether grasped or not, the true sovereign remains undiminished and unaugmented. Once this form is received, the form may perish, but nature does not vanish. Yet people of the world, bewildered by right and wrong, profit and harm, know no rest, willingly rotting with the grasses and trees—how lamentable!

The *Oral Teachings of Lu Zhai* states: The man of great wisdom moves with ease and self-possession; the man of petty wisdom counts every star and weighs every ounce. Grand words blaze brightly, radiant with splendor. In this single phrase lies the intent of Zhuangzi, encompassing even Yi, Zhou, Kong, and Meng. Petty words chatter on, glancing ahead and behind—within this single phrase lie the doctrines of the Hundred Schools and the gossip of the marketplace. When spirits commune, the spirit gathers in the heart; when form unfolds, the four limbs all move. These two phrases encompass all, from emperors to commoners. It speaks of how, at night, one rests in sleep, yet at dawn, in the moment of encounter, one responds and engages, the mind toiling as if in battle—this is what Mencius meant by "what one does by day may fetter and lose it."

"Loose" refers to slackness and irrelevance. "Cunning" implies speech laden with traps. "Subtle" denotes deep thought, leaving no trace. This describes how those who respond to things with their minds are all beset by worry, fear, and lack of freedom—what is called "the petty man is ever anxious." Confucius spoke of the petty man as anxious. Zhuangzi’s intent, however, is that even Yao, Shun, Yu, and Kong were anxious. Debates focus on right and wrong, like an archer aiming at a target. The desire to prevail hardens the heart, unyielding as a sworn oath. Yet the mind, consumed by care and toil, withers day by day, month by month. Once ensnared by obsession, there is no return. Such people, though their bodies live briefly, their hearts are already beyond revival.

The above depicts the worldly mind’s inclinations—joy, anger, and the twelve other states. It further describes their shifting appearances, like music emerging from emptiness or mushrooms steaming into being, all shaped by the Creator. This is the "blowing of the ten thousand differences." Day and night alternate, speaking of the Creator’s comings and goings, yet no origin is seen. Between dawn and dusk, one merely obtains this source of life. This points to the Creator as non-Creator; without it, I cannot exist. The Creator’s work is revealed through people. Such reasoning seems near and visible, yet what compels people to perceive the Creator remains unknown. The true sovereign is the Creator. "As if" suggests one dare not assert its actual existence. "No trace" means its beginnings are unknowable. The Creator’s actions are indeed real, yet its form remains unseen. Thus, no one knows what compels it.

"Having emotion" speaks of reality, that is, faith. From "day and night alternate" onward, it describes the Creator’s work, though ever-present, unseen by people. It urges one to reflect deeply here. The hundred bones, nine orifices, and six viscera—all are complete in a person. Whom then should I uniquely favor with private delight? When the head aches, the hand scratches—then the hand serves the head. When the eyes look, the feet walk—then the feet serve the eyes. The servant is like a concubine, unfit to govern. Hands, feet, ears, eyes, nose, and mouth serve one another, with the served as ministers and the serving as lords. Since the lordship of the hundred parts cannot be fixed, the heart, as the master of the body, should be deemed the lord. Yet the heart cannot govern itself; what governs it is the Creator—thus, the Creator is the true sovereign. Seeking thus, one wishes to see the truth clearly. Yet whether seen or not, the so-called true sovereign remains unchanged.

Once a person receives form from the Creator, they guard it without loss until this form perishes. Yet unable to yield, they are overwhelmed by external things. Their entire life passes like a fleeting colt, toiling in vain—how can this not be lamentable? As the form decays—from decline to whitening, from whitening to aging—the body weakens, and the heart grows weary, for the heart follows its form. Can this not be called a great sorrow? A profound sigh for what cannot be saved.

The above *Collected Explanations* are clear and need no repetition. Among them, the eight characters—*lǜ* (deliberation), *tàn* (sighing), *biàn* (change), *zhé* (submission), *yáo* (flippancy), *yì* (indulgence), *qǐ* (opening), and *tài* (attitude)—flow spontaneously from the true person’s lips, unmatched in other texts. Most commentaries fall short. Only Master Cheng’s commentary states: *Lǜ* is forethought of the future; *tàn* is lament for the past; *biàn* is altering old matters; *zhé* is submission without resistance. The explanations of *lǜ* and *tàn* are indeed excellent, yet the meanings of *biàn* and *zhé* remain unclear. Here, I propose: *biàn* is restlessness and busyness; *zhé* is fear and immobility. This may fully capture the text’s intent.

The commentary further states: *Yáo* is frivolity; *yì* is extravagance; *qǐ* is the opening of desires; *tài* is seductive charm. This seems inadequate for the above text. Here, I propose: *Yáo* is self-indulgence in pleasure; *yì* is reckless abandon; *qǐ* is the opening of emotion to receive things; *tài* is arrogance and longing. It speaks of those who, in pursuing things and forgetting themselves, exhibit these varied states within a single body—calculating gains and losses, scorched by fire and frozen by ice. Thus, body and heart decay together, daily nearing death.

Yet how could this be inherent in our nature? It arises from drowning in worldly desires, from the inversion of emotions and consciousness—forgetting what ought not be forgotten, clinging to what ought be forgotten. It is like music emerging from emptiness, like steam giving rise to mushrooms: illusory as dust, bubbles, shadows, flickering into being and vanishing in an instant—how could such things matter? The vast expanse of the heart should recognize that which is profoundly still, utterly silent, enduring since ancient times without cease.

This turmoil is but a shifting realm of dust, a fleeting illusion; once seen through, it dissolves. Returning to examine the self and the world, one finds their origin in primordial nothingness, a temporary sojourn in this realm. For now, we repay the debts of past karma, severing the roots of birth from the fertile earth, inheriting the primal qi of the cosmic mother. Neither grasping nor rejecting, ever pure and ever still—though the body dwells in the clamor of the world, the spirit transcends into the sacred realm. How could worldly burdens ever reach it?

Is human life truly so deluded? Am I alone in this delusion, or are there those who are not? If one follows the inclinations of the heart as one’s teacher, who is without a teacher? Why must one wait for knowledge to be passed down before the heart claims it for itself? Fools, too, share in this! To assert right and wrong before the heart is fully formed is like arriving in Yue today yet claiming to have reached it yesterday. Thus, one takes what is not as what is.

Taking what is not as what is—even the divine Yu could not comprehend it; how then could I? Speech is not mere breath. Those who speak have their words, yet what they speak of remains unsettled. Is there truly speech? Or has there never been speech? Does it differ from the chirping of fledglings? Is there discernment in it? Or is there no discernment?

Where does the Dao conceal itself to give rise to truth and falsehood? Where does speech conceal itself to give rise to right and wrong? Where does the Dao go that it ceases to exist? Where does speech abide that it cannot be trusted? The Dao is obscured by partial attainment; speech is obscured by florid ornamentation. Thus arise the disputes of the Confucians and Mohists, each affirming what the other denies and denying what the other affirms. To affirm what they deny and deny what they affirm, nothing surpasses illumination.

Nothing exists that is not "that"; nothing exists that is not "this." From the perspective of "that," one does not see; from self-knowledge, one knows. Thus it is said: "That" emerges from "this," and "this" likewise depends on "that." The theory of "that" and "this" arising together is born. Yet even as they arise, they die; even as they die, they arise. Even as something becomes permissible, it becomes impermissible; even as it becomes impermissible, it becomes permissible. Through "this" comes "right," through "wrong" comes "right."

Therefore, the sage does not proceed by such means but illuminates all by the light of Heaven—this, too, is a form of "this." "This" is also "that," and "that" is also "this." "That" has its own right and wrong, and "this" has its own right and wrong.

Does "that" and "this" truly exist? Or do "that" and "this" truly not exist? Where "that" and "this" find no counterpart, this is called the pivot of the Dao. Once the pivot finds the center of the ring, it responds without end. "Right" is one endless cycle; "wrong" is likewise one endless cycle. Thus it is said: nothing compares to illumination.

Guo Xiang’s Commentary:
Now, those who know do not know how they know yet know spontaneously. Those who live do not know how they live yet live spontaneously. Thus it is said: none in the world are not deluded. That by which the human heart suffices to govern the uses of the body is called the "completed heart." Following one’s completed heart as teacher means each has their own master, entrusting it to what is naturally fitting, thereby completing what was incomplete—this is not knowledge but the heart’s own attainment. Thus even the foolish follow their completed heart, never employing what they deem short while discarding what they deem long. To have right and wrong before the completed heart is formed is like saying one arrived in Yue today when one arrived yesterday. Clearly, right and wrong cannot be absent from the turning of things. Therefore, the perfected person accords with both. In principle, there is no right or wrong, yet the deluded take them to exist. This is to take what is not as what is. Once the deluded heart is formed, even the sage cannot undo it. Speakers each have what they affirm, hence their difference from mere sound. "I am right, that is wrong"—if this is taken as having speech, it is insufficient to settle anything; if taken as having no speech, it still relies on this to have speech. Speech and the sound of a wheel’s hub, whether articulated or not, cannot be definitively settled. The sentiments of the world are never uniform, yet what is spoken cannot differ. As for the Dao, it does not reside in speech—where is it hidden so as to have truth and falsehood, right and wrong? Not knowing that this Dao is entirely present and entirely permissible, one clings to minor achievements and flourishing displays, which obscure the Dao. Yet the Dao cannot be obscured. Thus truth and falsehood, right and wrong, operate in flourishing displays but halt at what is truly fitting; they appear in minor achievements but vanish in great wholeness. Confucians and Mohists each affirm and negate the other, each prizing their own views. Now, to affirm what Confucians and Mohists negate and negate what they affirm, nothing compares to using their own reversals to illuminate them. Then one knows that what they affirm is not truly right, and what they negate is not truly wrong. All things affirm themselves, thus none are not "this." All things oppose each other, thus none are not "that." Without "that" and without "this," this is called profound sameness. All things do not know what "that" sees but only know what they themselves know, taking themselves as right and thus taking "that" as wrong. It is like the living, who take life as life, while the dead take life as death—permissible and impermissible are likewise. Thus in the debates of Confucians and Mohists, I cannot agree. As for each obscuring their own distinctions, I cannot disagree. Following the world’s right and wrong, right and wrong are never inappropriate. If "this" is also "that," then I am opposed by "that." If "that" is also "this," then "that" takes itself as right. "That" and "this," being and non-being—none are definitively settled. Right and wrong chase each other, reversing endlessly, called the "ring." The ring is empty at its center. Now, taking right and wrong as the ring and attaining its empty center, there is no right and no wrong, thus one can respond to right and wrong. Right and wrong are endless, thus the response is likewise endless.

Lü Huiqing’s Commentary:
When I contend with things, form and heart transform without my awareness—this is the height of delusion. The perfected person’s heart is still as a mirror, not requiring anything to be so, simply attaining its completed heart. I do not attain my completed heart, hence my singular delusion. The perfected person is fundamentally not deluded. If one can truly follow one’s completed heart as teacher, who would lack a teacher? Why must one know to replace old habits when the heart naturally takes what it does? The foolish share in this; not being deluded yet able to be teachers, they simply do not seek it. The completed heart is what we receive from Heaven without deficiency, thus it suffices to clarify true right and wrong. If it is deficient due to things, then the so-called right and wrong are not settled. Taking what is fundamentally without right and wrong as having them, even the divine Yu could not resolve it. What can I do? Speech is not mere sound; speakers have speech, which is blown by things, not blowing things to make them so. Thus when speech is not settled, whether it is spoken or never spoken, its difference from the sound of a fledgling cannot be discerned. The Dao is nowhere absent, thus speech is never not the Dao. Where is the Dao hidden so as to have truth and falsehood? Things are never not the Dao, thus speech is also the Dao. Where is speech hidden so as to have right and wrong? Knowing the Dao is nowhere absent, where does it not reside? Knowing speech is never not the Dao, where does it not apply? Yet there are places it does not reside and things it does not apply to, for the Dao is obscured by minor achievements and one does not know great wholeness; speech is obscured by flourishing displays and one does not know the original reality. Hence there are the right and wrong of Confucians and Mohists. To affirm what they negate and negate what they affirm, nothing compares to illumination. Illumination is the verification of returning to the mandate and knowing the constant. Now, the right and wrong of Confucians and Mohists do not depart from knowledge and perception yet have never used illumination, thus they are insufficient to be the standard of right and wrong. If one sets aside knowledge and turns the light inward to observe with illumination, then what things call "that" and "this" truly have no fixed substance. Without fixed substance, there is nothing that is not "that," nothing that is not "this." From "that," one does not see, thus taking "that" as "that." From self-knowledge, one knows, thus taking oneself as right. The argument from "that" is likewise, thus "this" fundamentally has no fixed substance. Yet the world takes it as having "that"—this is like the living taking life as life while the dead take death as life, thus taking what is not as what is. From the perspective of the Dao, when things are living, seeking whence their life comes; when dying, seeking whither their death goes.

To know that life and death are of one body is to see that what is just born is precisely what will just die, and what is just dying is precisely what was just born. So too with right and wrong. All these are but fabrications of our minds. Exhaust the mind and fathom the spirit, return to a state beyond self, and their substance is never different. Thus, what is "right" follows from "wrong," and what is "wrong" follows from "right"—they merely alternate in function.

The sage does not follow these paths but illuminates them by the light of Heaven; this is what is meant by "illumination." Lin Yi’s annotation: Amidst the obscurity of human life, the true nature that is never obscured is not absent—it is merely veiled by things and unknown to itself. The sage does not tread the paths of right and wrong, but forgets cares, stills thoughts, and illuminates by the light of Heaven. Yet what the sage illuminates is only because the world has right and wrong. Thus it is said: "It also follows from right." Taking this as right is also what the other takes as other; taking that as wrong, the other also takes itself as right. Between this and that, each has its own right and wrong. Zhuangzi seeks to clarify that there is no fixed "this" or "that" and does not determine their reasons. Thus, he borrows the words of Guo and Ju to speak of being and non-being.

Having forgotten "this" and "that," and further forgotten the reasons for "this" and "that," "this" and "that" cannot stand as counterparts to me—this is called the *pivot of the Dao*. The pivot is the mechanism of opening and closing, of turning. The ring is empty yet not divorced from form. The pivot’s substance is round and moves—this is *wondrous existence*. The ring’s substance is round and still—this is *true emptiness*. Wondrous existence and true emptiness mutually support and function together, thus responding endlessly. Without the utmost clarity in the world, who could attain this?

Chen Xiangdao’s annotation: The human mind is inherently clearer than water or fire. Yet when it races with things and transforms with form, it becomes so obscured as to seem without knowledge—this is the covering of *ignorance*. What obscures is the human; what does not obscure is Heaven. Those who nurture the mind well do not let the human extinguish Heaven but preserve what is not obscured. Human life is such that Heaven bestows form, and the Dao bestows the mind. If one follows the mind as it is formed and takes it as a teacher, one darkly accords with the Dao. Why must there be those who know change and take the mind for themselves? Change refers to the transformations of yin and yang. To know change and take the Dao for the mind is to be a knower. Everyone has a formed mind that can be taken as a teacher—why must only the knower be so? Without a formed mind, to have right and wrong is to take non-being as being.

Adorning one’s words with flourish, even a divine Yu could not comprehend them—how much less one who is not a divine Yu? The human mind, when honored by the Dao, becomes a ruler; when sought by the Dao, becomes a teacher. With a mind of right and wrong as one’s teacher, right is right and wrong is wrong, and knowledge is complete. With a mind of right and wrong as one’s servant, right becomes wrong and wrong becomes right, and one returns to folly. The ancients began by taking the mind as teacher and ended by forgetting the mind. Taking the mind as teacher, right and wrong are thus made manifest. Forgetting the mind, right and wrong are thus dissolved.

Words are not like the wind. Words are spoken by speakers, while the wind blows naturally without ceasing. Words arise from debate and are without flaw or blame. The cries of fledglings do not come from what they imitate yet still contain debate. Words begin with speech and end in silence, thus differing from the wind. Debate begins with argument and ends in non-argument, thus differing from the cries of fledglings.

Where does the Dao not go that it is not present? The Dao is fundamentally without concealment, yet it is concealed in minor accomplishments. Where do words not reside that they are not permissible? Words are fundamentally without concealment, yet they are concealed in ornate flourish. Minor accomplishments do not darkly accord with the great Dao, and thus true and false arise. Ornate flourish does not reach actuality, and thus right and wrong become manifest.

Now, to affirm what the Confucians and Mohists reject and return to true right, and to reject what the Confucians and Mohists affirm and return to true wrong—the sage does not follow "this" and "that" but illuminates them by the light of Heaven; this too follows from right. The pivot is what turns and opens or closes. The ring is round and empty, responding well. The pivot finds its center in the ring to turn. The myriad things find their pivot to respond. Thus, right and wrong are entrusted to the two paths and are endless.

Chen Bixu’s annotation: In human life, all are swayed by desires and aversions, their true nature disturbed by right and wrong, obscured and unclear. The perfected person transcends life and death, the wondrous principle shining clearly—how could there be obscurity? Not taking the Dao and ancient laws as teachers but clinging to one’s own views is called a *formed mind*. If one follows the formed mind as a teacher, who lacks a teacher? Everyone has their own teacher, so there is no need for the worthy to replace the unworthy. If one takes the formed mind for oneself and claims to have gained something, then the foolish have many allies. Thus, those who accord with the Dao are one with the Dao, and those who lose it are one with loss.

Before the mind is formed, to have right and wrong is like claiming to arrive before reaching one’s destination—principle is fundamentally non-existent, yet one forcibly calls it existent. Following this existence, existence proliferates endlessly, and even the most virtuous spiritual persons cannot know its reasons. The wind is like a sound. Thus, words differ from it, as each side clings to victory, and there is no fixed speech. Words are for expressing meaning. The wind has no meaning to take. If one does not take meaning from words, how do they differ from the cries of fledglings?

The great Dao is never concealed, yet scholars have true and false. The perfect words are never obscure, yet speakers have right and wrong. The person of the Dao is without gaps—where could they not be? Words transform and all things pass—where could they not reach? When the great Dao declines, there is benevolence and righteousness—this is called *minor accomplishment*. When knowledge and wisdom emerge, there is great falsity—this is called *ornate flourish*. Confucianism follows the Zhou and Confucius; Mohism follows Xia and Yu. What the Confucians affirm, the Mohists reject; what the Mohists affirm, the Confucians reject. Now, to affirm what the Confucians reject and reject what the Mohists affirm, there is nothing better than mutual clarification, so that right and wrong of both sides may proceed together.

The nature of things originally has no "that," yet it arises from their opposition. Originally there is no "this," yet it arises from self-assertion. From "that," one does not see—just as Huan, becoming a Confucian, did not see Di as a Mohist. From self-knowledge, one knows—Di’s adherence to Mohism arose from self-assertion, while Huan’s self-affirmation as a Confucian likewise depended on Di’s existence.

"That" and "this," "right" and "wrong" are like those who value life when alive and delight in death when dead. Thus the sage illuminates them through Heaven, not through man, yet one cannot call them nonexistent—they arise from this. "That" and "this" each have their own right and wrong; to seek their ultimate existence or nonexistence is to return to the extremity of forgetting words, where no counterpart can be found—this is called the *pivot of the Dao*.

The pivot is empty at the center, turning without obstruction, like the function of a door hinge, which lies in the socket to respond endlessly. As for the pivot of the Dao, it turns things through principle. Though heaven and earth are vast and the myriad things are numerous, none can oppose the subtlety of the Dao’s pivot.

*Xu Zhai’s Commentary*: "Mang" refers to being restless yet unaware of one’s destination—without it, one is not "mang." The *cheng xin* (fully formed heart-mind) is what Zisi called "sincerity that completes itself." This is the original nature; if one can fully realize it, there is nothing it does not penetrate. All people possess this heart-mind—why seek another teacher?

"Dai" refers to the principle of alternation between day and night, life and death. If one can take the *cheng xin* as one’s teacher, this principle becomes self-evident—why seek knowledge like Zilu, who asked about ghosts, spirits, and death? This is merely the desire to know *dai*. Thus Confucius answered with serving others and understanding life, wishing him to grasp it from his own heart-mind.

When principle is not yet clear and one first establishes right and wrong, taking what is not as what is—this is delusion. Even the sage can do nothing about it.

Words are the voice of the heart-mind; blowing is the sound of wind or bamboo. The *kou yin* is the sound of a fledgling trying to break from its egg. Though these three differ, the presence of sound within them is not distinct. When one speaks, there is speech—meaning the moment between intending to speak and not yet speaking, which remains undetermined. Is there truly speech? Then the words have not yet emerged. Is there no speech? Then the words are about to emerge. At this moment, it cannot be discerned—like the *kou yin*.

The Dao is nowhere absent, yet distinctions of true and false arise. Words are never inapplicable, yet divisions of right and wrong emerge. Confucians and Mohists mutually affirm and reject—without illumination, they cannot be distinguished.

Things have no "that" in themselves; things have no "this" in themselves—this is Heaven. "That" is man. Seeking it from man, it cannot be seen. From self-knowledge, one knows it; knowing one’s nature, one knows Heaven. "That" arises from "this"—the formed is born from the formless. "This" also depends on "that"—the formless relies on the formed. The theory of "that" and "this" arising together is like existence and nonexistence, movement and stillness giving rise to one another.

The world is confused by the path of right and wrong, unable to distinguish them. The sage clearly perceives the principle of right and wrong, yet it ultimately amounts to affirming what is right. "That" and "this" depend on each other; existence and nonexistence give rise to one another—they cannot be considered distinct. To find no counterpart is to stand alone beyond "that" and "this," existence and nonexistence—this is the pivotal essence of the Dao.

The pivot resides at the center and governs externally, responding to endless changes like a ring without end—only the wise know this.

*Yongzhai’s Oral Exegesis* says: "Mang" is the appearance of being without insight. Heaven generates the masses, endowing them with things and principles. Heavenly principle is never unclear, but human desires obscure it, leading to confusion. How could one who knows the Dao be like this?

The *cheng xin* is Heavenly principle in its undifferentiated wholeness, complete in all respects. If one can take this as one’s teacher, who lacks it? "Knowing *dai*" is the title of ancient worthies. *Dai* means transformation, referring to understanding the principle of change. "Self-attainment" means having insight. If one cannot perceive this undifferentiated principle yet forcibly distinguishes right and wrong, it is like arriving in Yue today after having set out yesterday—having no real insight yet insisting it exists. Even the sage cannot enlighten such a person.

The blowing of the ten thousand things differs, yet all are merely sound. When sound forms patterns, it becomes speech—distinct from blowing or bamboo. When one speaks, there is speech, each expressing their intent—these four words are the source from which debates over right and wrong arise. Does what is spoken come from you? Or from the Creator? Hence it is said: undetermined. The *kou yin*, having no knowledge, is likewise undetermined.

The Dao originally has no true or false—why does obscurity give rise to such distinctions? Words originally have no right or wrong—why does obscurity give rise to such divisions? The Dao encompasses the small and great, the refined and coarse; words encompass affirming what is right and rejecting what is wrong. "Minor accomplishment" refers to limited understanding and partial views. "Ornate flourish" means self-aggrandizement in pursuit of fame. When partial views prevail, the perfect words are obscured, and from this arise the mutual rejections of Confucians and Mohists.

If one wishes to settle right and wrong, one must illuminate them with natural Heavenly principle. When self and other oppose, right and wrong arise—thus it is said: "That" arises from "this," and "this" also depends on "that," just as life gives way to death, and death in turn gives way to life. The two cannot be separated; it is better to affirm what is right in each. This is why the sage does not adhere to partial views but illuminates them with Heavenly principle, merging self and other into one—grasping the pivotal essence of the Dao. It begins like the emptiness at the center of a ring, responding to things endlessly. Right and wrong are each without end, yet they are illuminated by Heavenly principle alone.

*Note*: Many interpretations take *cheng xin* as good, while others take it as bad. Considering the subsequent text—"before the heart-mind is formed, there is right and wrong," and "this is like arriving in Yue today after having set out yesterday"—the *cheng xin* is where the distinction between right and wrong first sprouts and cannot be spoken of as good.

I once attended the lecture seat of Master Fan Wuyin of Western Shu, where I humbly received his teachings: "Before the *cheng xin* forms, true nature remains undifferentiated, vast as the Great Void. Once the *cheng xin* arises, it departs from nature, giving rise to both good and evil. In worldly interactions, one cannot entirely avoid the *cheng xin*; one should then model oneself on the state prior to its formation, where good and evil do not sprout, and right and wrong leave no trace—how could anything then fail to be harmonized?"

His discourse was precise and sufficient to resolve all prior doubts. Expounding further on my own understanding, I venture to offer this humble insight: For one, halting a thought is not difficult; preventing its continuation is difficult. If, at the very moment the *cheng xin* first forms, one models oneself on the state prior to its formation, then thoughts will not continue, and nature may be restored. Thus, when confronting things, the heart-mind arises; when things are forgotten, nature manifests. The heart-mind is the function of nature, the origin of the myriad dharmas, and the master of the body—it cannot be dismissed as nonexistent. Yet if one speaks of the *cheng xin*, it has already flowed into intention.

The heart-mind, as a thing, moves in and out without fixed time, its abode unknown. Yet whatever the square inch of the heart-mind desires to do invariably arises in response to things. The heart-mind is *li* (detachment); *li* governs fire. Fire cannot manifest on its own but must cling to something before it appears. If the heart-mind is one with the Great Void, it has nothing to cling to. Moreover, if the heart-mind clings to things and produces good, it is still inferior to having no heart-mind and no action—how much worse if it clings to things and produces evil?

Master Guanyin said: "When things come to seek me, vast as boulders, I respond with nature, and things float lightly away." This is the essential Dao of relinquishing things, departing from the person, gathering nature, and returning to nature. Scholars who return to seek it will find it an inexhaustible teacher.

The character *zhi* (知) was formerly pronounced in the departing tone, though some read it in its original tone. The following text, where "the foolish" (*yu zhe*) is paired with "those who possess evidence," suggests that the pronunciation *zhi* (智) is appropriate, akin to *yu* (预). Bi Xu alone, aligning with a faction, differs from the majority.

As for the meaning of *zhi dai* (知代), interpretations vary. Carefully examining the intent of the scripture, *zhi dai* refers to the heart-mind acting on its own, where "knowing" is employed in place of self-seeking in the Dao—this is what is meant by the *cheng xin*.

*End of the second fascicle of the* Nan Hua Zhen Jing Yi Hai Mu Wei *(*The Ocean of Admiration for the Subtleties of the* Nan Hua *True Scripture*).*

*Textual notes:*
1. *According to the Shide Hall edition and Lu Wenzhou’s collation, both instances of* diao *are written as* dao*.*
2. *In most editions, the character* shou *is followed by* sheng*.*
3. *Sheng* (胜) *is a corruption of* zhi *(之).*

*Beginning of the third fascicle of the* Nan Hua Zhen Jing Yi Hai Zuan Wei *(*The Gathered Subtleties of the Ocean of Meaning of the* Nan Hua *True Scripture*) by Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin.*

**Chapter Two: On the Equality of Things**

To illustrate that a finger is not a finger by means of a finger is not as effective as illustrating that a finger is not a finger by means of what is not a finger. To illustrate that a horse is not a horse by means of a horse is not as effective as illustrating that a horse is not a horse by means of what is not a horse. Heaven and earth are one finger; the myriad things are one horse.

What is permissible is permissible; what is not permissible is not permissible. The Dao is completed through its practice; things are so called because they are so named. Why are they so? They are so because they are so. Why are they not so? They are not so because they are not so. Things inherently have that which makes them so; things inherently have that which makes them permissible. There is nothing that is not so; there is nothing that is not permissible.

Thus, consider the following examples: mats and pillars, leprosy and Xi Shi, the expansive, the strange, the deceptive, and the monstrous—all are united in the Dao. Their division is their completion; their completion is their destruction. Yet all things are neither completed nor destroyed, for they return to unity. Only the enlightened understand this unity. Therefore, they do not employ it but lodge it in the ordinary.

The ordinary is utility; utility is penetration; penetration is attainment. Attaining this, one approaches the subtlety. Following this without knowing why it is so is called the Dao.

To exhaust one’s spirit in striving for unity while failing to recognize their sameness is called "morning three." What is "morning three"? The monkey keeper distributed chestnuts, saying, "Three in the morning and four in the evening." All the monkeys were angry. He then said, "Very well, four in the morning and three in the evening," and all the monkeys were pleased. The names and realities remained unchanged, yet joy and anger were employed—this too follows from such reasoning.

Therefore, the sage harmonizes with right and wrong and rests in the equality of heaven. This is called "walking two paths."

Chen Bixu said: The metaphors of finger and horse, from Sima Biao, Xiang Xiu, and Guo Xiang to the renowned scholars of the Tang, were all considered Zhuangzi’s allegorical constructions. Thus, interpreters have differed in their conclusions. Yet upon examining the two treatises, *White Horse* and *Pointing to Things*, within Gongsun Long’s *Six Discourses*, which contain the arguments that a white horse is not a horse and that a finger is not a finger, it becomes clear that Zhuangzi’s enigmatic compositions have their origins.

Guo Xiang’s commentary: To affirm oneself and negate others is the common tendency of the world. If I use my finger to illustrate another’s finger, then that finger becomes a non-finger in relation to mine. Conversely, if I use another’s finger to illustrate mine, then my finger becomes a non-finger in relation to theirs. Both self-affirmation and mutual negation arise from this. These petty distinctions are merely the adherence to partial views. The sage, knowing that heaven and earth are one finger and the myriad things are one horse, abides in vast tranquility, each in its proper place, all attaining self-realization, without further right or wrong.

What is permissible to oneself is called permissible; what is not permissible to oneself is called impermissible. The Dao is never unfulfilled; things are never not so. Each is so in its own way; each is permissible in its own way. Take, for example, mats laid horizontally and pillars standing vertically, leprosy and Xi Shi’s beauty—what is meant by equality is not the uniformity of shapes or the sameness of standards. Thus, the expansive, the strange, the deceptive, and the monstrous are all united in the Dao.

For things, what one considers destruction, another considers completion. What I call completion, another calls destruction—all arise from self-regard and failure to see the other. Only the enlightened are not confined to one perspective; they lodge appropriately in self-utility and thus do not impose their own constructs. Not knowing why one follows and yet following is called the Dao. The Dao is simply unity. For the enlightened, what need is there to labor the spirit in striving for unity? To exhaust one’s spirit in pursuit of unity is no different from failing to achieve it—it is the same as the monkeys’ self-affirmation based on their preferences.

Therefore, the sage does not favor one side but entrusts all to natural equality, allowing the world’s right and wrong to proceed along two paths.

Lü Huiqing’s commentary: To illustrate that a finger is not a finger by means of a finger, despite distinctions of name and reality or small and large, does not transcend their shared essence—how could it suffice to prove it a non-finger? To illustrate that a horse is not a horse by means of a horse, despite distinctions of coat color or quality, does not depart from their shared kind—how could it suffice to prove it a non-horse? Only by not relying on right and wrong and illuminating them through heaven can one transcend shared essence and depart from shared kind, thereby determining the true right and wrong of the world.

Thus, though heaven and earth are vast, they are no different from one finger, for they arise with me and share the same essence. Though the myriad things are numerous, they are no different from one horse, for they are one with me and share the same kind. Then how can the permissible and impermissible of things arise on their own?

The Dao is completed through its practice, not through non-action. Things are so called because they are named, not because they are inherently so. Their being so or permissible arises from what is not so or impermissible, yet seeking the agent behind this yields nothing—thus, one knows their fundamental non-existence. This is the equality of things. Why then pursue or abandon them?

Small and large, beauty and ugliness are inherently opposed, yet when united through the Dao, their division becomes their completion, and their completion becomes their destruction. Yet all things are neither completed nor destroyed, for they return to unity. Only the enlightened understand this unity. Thus, I do not employ it but lodge it in the self-utility of things. Lodging in things is penetration; penetration is attainment without obstruction, approaching the Dao. Yet this cannot be considered the Dao, for one still knows why it is so. Only by knowing the formlessness of this and following it without knowing why it is so can it be called the Dao.

The Dao unites all because the origins of small and large, beauty and ugliness lie within it. If one does not know this and labors the spirit in pursuit of it, this is precisely what prevents unity. It is like the morning three and evening four, or morning four and evening three—though the sum remains seven, joy and anger arise. This is how the monkeys are tamed by their keeper, and how the keeper ensnares the monkeys.

Likewise, it is simply by virtue of this. Lin Yi’s solitary annotation states: "Right and wrong each cling to their own; self and other hold different sentiments. Comparing another’s finger to one’s own, one takes one’s own finger as right and the other’s as wrong. Now, if one wishes to still the debate of right and wrong and instead takes the other’s finger as primary, comparing it to one’s own, then the other’s finger becomes right and one’s own becomes wrong. The analogy of horse to horse follows the same principle. Through repeated mutual comparison, self and other alike assert their own rightness while awaiting the other’s wrongness. Yet when right and wrong converge in the Dao, then though heaven and earth are vast and the myriad things are many, taking them near at hand from the body, they are but one finger; taking them afar from things, they are but one horse.

That which admits neither affirmation nor denial, neither rightness nor wrongness—this is the supreme principle of the world. The Dao that can be spoken is realized through practice; the thing that can be named is affirmed through designation. To take what one deems right as right and what one deems wrong as wrong is to remain bound by attachment. Better to let things follow their natural course and be as they may. When vertical and horizontal, beauty and ugliness are once more united as one, then the Dao is nowhere unfulfilled, and things are nowhere untrue.

Their division is their completion—this speaks of the Dao dispersing into things. Their completion is their destruction—this speaks of things having a beginning and an end. The Dao itself knows no completion or destruction. Completion and destruction are but the solitary perceptions of things. Splitting wood to make a vessel, the vessel is completed as the wood is destroyed—this is simply the work of creation and transformation. The enlightened one discards solitary perception and merges with the supreme principle. Acting without acting and lodging in the commonplace, one entrusts it to constant use, and thus there is nowhere it does not penetrate, nowhere one does not attain self-mastery—this is to approach the Dao.

The Dao is fundamentally without penetration or attainment; it is things that are without penetration or attainment, and thus the names of penetration and attainment arise. By virtue of this, one returns to the nameless. Having done so without knowing why, one may reluctantly call it the Dao.

The spirit and clarity within the self should be allowed to follow their natural course. Now, to labor the spirit in pursuit of unity is to stray far indeed—how is this different from the monkey keeper’s allocation of acorns, morning three and evening four, where name and reality remain unchanged yet joy and anger serve as their function? Those in the world who do not comprehend the supreme principle are like the many monkeys, swayed by joy and anger. Thus, the sage harmonizes with right and wrong yet rests in spontaneity, allowing both to proceed while returning to a single unity.

Chen Xiangdao’s annotation states: "Taking the body near at hand to illuminate heaven and earth, then heaven and earth are one finger; taking things afar to illuminate the myriad things, then the myriad things are one horse." Though heaven and earth are vast, they do not depart from having form; though the myriad things are numerous, they do not depart from having function. Not departing from form, then even in emptiness they are but one finger; not departing from function, then even in the world they are but one horse. As for the Dao, however—it is without form yet forms are completed through it; without function yet functions are perfected through it. It is nowhere and yet everywhere, non-acting and yet nothing is left undone—how could it be spoken of as one finger or one horse?

Chen Bixu’s annotation states: "The finger here refers to the pointing out of right and wrong. The common sentiment of people is to take this as right and point to that as wrong. That, not knowing it is wrong, then points to this as not yet right. Thus, one clings to this finger as right and calls that finger wrong. If there were no mutual pointing in the world, then things would be things of themselves, not forced by people; fingers would be fingers of themselves, not arrogantly asserting this deluded pointing. When things are not forced by people, one forgets things; when fingers do not arrogantly assert this deluded pointing, they are no longer fingers. Moreover, the finger that does not point to things has no this or that, no right or wrong. The finger that points to things forcibly generates this and that, right and wrong—this is not a true finger.

A horse inherently has form and color. To pick out color and name it is merely to speak of 'horse.' Speaking of 'horse,' then the horses of the world are one horse—white and black are not included. Now, if one seeks color to name a horse, it is called a 'white horse.' Seeking a white horse, then yellow and black horses are excluded. This is to lose its form by seeking color. Losing form by seeking color, then a white horse is not a horse. If, moreover, the fashion of the time favors white, then white is taken as right and 'horse' as wrong—this is to take wrong as right and right as wrong.

Those who harbor the heart of right and wrong yet cannot equalize them point to things with this and that, but forgetting this and that, then even the vastness of heaven and earth is but one finger. Those who distinguish the multiplicity of kinds yet cannot unify them take form and color with inclusion and exclusion, but shedding inclusion and exclusion, then even the profusion of the myriad things is but one horse. Viewed from what is the same, the permissible is permissible; viewed from what is different, the impermissible is impermissible. If the Dao is not practiced, it fails; when it fails, who would call it so?

In general, following principle, what is so is so, and nothing is not so; opposing principle, what is not so is not so, and nothing is so. If one fully accords with principle, then there is nothing that is not so, nothing that is not permissible, and one naturally merges in darkness. Though things assume ten thousand forms and their kinds differ, only the Dao unites and makes them one. It is like a craftsman making vessels: in calculating their completion, who considers the destruction of the raw material? Discussing completion, there is no destruction; discussing destruction, there is no completion. In relation to the Dao, they once more unite as one.

Thus, the enlightened one, recognizing that the uncarved block of the Dao is not used by the world, lodges it in self-utility—this is to use by means of non-use. Knowing the use of non-use, one attains self-mastery, and what is attained is fully realized. Yet traces remain. One who deeply understands the Dao merges with it in mind and body alone. Having done so without knowing why, there is no path of 'this' to follow.

If one labors the spirit to make things one, it is like the monkey keeper’s manipulation of knowledge to ensnare the many monkeys, or the monkeys’ use of joy and anger—it is likewise by virtue of this. Wang Xiu’s annotation states: "Raising the finger and horse to illustrate the non-finger and non-horse, one already has finger and horse in this."

Thus, attainment lies only in the state before things ever arose. Heaven and earth differ in form; the myriad things differ in function. Because they have form, though vast, they are equal in being existent; because they have function, though numerous, they are equal in being finite. As for that which lacks nothing and pervades all—how could it be spoken of as a single finger or a single horse?

The transformations of the myriad things inherently possess what is permissible and impermissible, what is so and what is not so. One should simply merge with the ultimate principle, unburdening the heart. The Dao accomplishes all without exception; nothing fails to conform to it. Thus, what is permissible and impermissible, what is so and what is not so, all belong to the ultimate principle. Aligned with the ultimate principle, the myriad things—whether vertical or horizontal, beautiful or ugly—are all reduced to one. The Dao disperses and becomes things, yet in the end, there is a beginning.

Creation and destruction are the deluded perceptions of things. When one merges with the principle, there is neither creation nor destruction—the Dao unites all as one. Nevertheless, this does not negate the creation and destruction of the myriad things; it merely lodges them in constant function without claiming them as its own. Thus, there is nowhere it does not penetrate; penetration is attainment, and attainment is nearness.

If one labors the spirit and illumination to force unity, how can one know their sameness? Hence, the analogy of the monkey keeper follows: though the tubers offered morning and evening differ, their quantity neither increases nor decreases. Though circumstances change, the heart remains without gain or loss. Those who submit to worldly sentiments without examining the ultimate principle differ not from the common monkeys. The sage harmonizes the presence and absence of right and wrong, allowing both to proceed.

Zhao Xuqi’s annotation states: Knowing that beyond the finger there is something that moves it, one knows the finger is not the finger. Knowing that beyond the horse there is something that drives it, one knows the horse is not the horse. Finger and horse are things with form; the non-finger and non-horse are formless. To illustrate the formless nature of form using form is not as effective as using the formless to illustrate the formless nature of form. Thus, one knows that the movements of heaven and earth and the arising of the myriad things all have something that governs them—this may be sought beyond heaven and earth and the myriad things.

What is permissible and impermissible, what is so and what is not so, the vertical and horizontal, the beautiful and ugly, the vast and minute, the strange and monstrous, right and wrong, creation and destruction—all unite as one. Then there is no right or wrong, and even when there is right, it is not employed. *Yong* means constancy; constancy is the use of non-use, which is the means to penetration. Penetration is attainment; attainment is nearness to the Dao.

If one relies on this to cease, then not only does the "not so" come to rest, but the "so" also comes to rest. When both right and wrong cease, yet one remains unaware of why, this is not true knowledge—it is to depart from form and abandon knowledge, claiming it as "sitting in forgetfulness." How is this not labor?

Spirit is illumination; illumination is spirit. "Three in the morning, four in the evening" is no different from "four in the morning, three in the evening." One is deluded by right and wrong, before and after, unaware of their sameness. The monkey keeper follows the monkeys’ joy and complies with it—this, too, is by virtue of this.

Yongzhai.

Here follows the translation:

---

It is said: "Finger" means the finger of the hand. If I take my finger to be the true finger, then I take another’s finger to be not the true finger. Yet that person who deems my finger not the true finger takes my finger to be not the true finger. Self and other stand opposed, and right and wrong cannot be fixed.

The "horse" refers to the counting rods in the game of *bosai*; in the *Record of Rites*, under the "Touhu" chapter, the tally of "horses" may be many or few, and so too with the right and wrong of the players. Because there is self and other, there is right and wrong. But if Heaven’s office is to cover and Earth’s office is to bear, how can they be divided into self and other?

This speaks of the necessity to equalize the judgments of things. What is acceptable is accepted; what is unacceptable is not accepted. The Dao moves and is completed—all is spontaneous. Things are called so because they are so, and what underlies their being so is no different from what underlies their not being so. In the distinctions among things, there is originally what is so and what is acceptable. Since nothing is not so and nothing is unacceptable, the horizontal and the vertical each fits its place, the beautiful and the ugly each fulfills its nature. All are penetrated and unified, returning to the Creator.

All things are not destroyed without being completed, and are not completed without being segmented. For example, trees are felled to build a house; the house is completed and the trees are destroyed. Knowing this principle, one lets go of what is "so" and does not employ it, lodging it instead in the constant. Taking constancy as one’s use, one follows the use and all is penetrated; penetration is attainment, and attainment is exhaustiveness.

People labor their spirit and understanding, creating one-sided theories, unaware that the principle is fundamentally the same. This is called "three in the morning"—these two characters are used to set forth the analogy, following the same method as in the "Fangsheng" passage. Name and reality do not change, yet joy and anger follow them. This illustrates that though the names of right and wrong differ, the principle in reality is the same. If one can follow what is so, then the world will naturally have no contention, and right and wrong will proceed in their two courses.

Master Chu’s limited insight says: Self and other differ in feeling, right and wrong point to each other. The west of the eastern house is the east of the western house; what precedes Heaven and Earth is what follows the Supreme Ultimate. This has been unequal from ancient times to the present, yet the True Person raises the analogies of the "not-finger" and the "not-horse"—this may be called skillfully equalizing the *Discourse on Equalizing Things*.

Taking the finger to illustrate that the finger is not the true finger is the view of ordinary people. Taking the not-finger to illustrate that the finger is not the true finger is the view of the Perfected Person. The meaning of the "not-horse" is the same. In the world, the views of the Perfected are few, and the views of the ordinary are many. Thus, the theories that "Heaven and Earth are one finger" and "the myriad things are one horse" only deepen the confusion.

Let us resolve this by saying: What differs is the feelings of the world; what is the same is the principle of the world. One principle can penetrate ten thousand feelings, so the not-finger is also the true finger. Ten thousand feelings cannot return to one principle, so the true horse is also not the true horse.

The finger and the horse involve form and description, and thus cannot escape right and wrong. The not-finger and the not-horse transcend form, number, words, and discussion. Therefore, though Heaven and Earth are vast, they can be illuminated by one finger, for it is born together with me. Though the myriad things are many, they can be likened to one horse, for they are one with me.

If one grasps their feelings and penetrates their principle, then though things differ in ten thousand ways, they are fused within me. Though affairs are separated by a thousand miles, they are connected in the heart. The ancients who unified the feelings of the multitude and possessed the Great Thing attained this.

The Most High said: "Attain the One, and the ten thousand affairs are complete." This is the equalizing of things, the end of discourse—is it not the ultimate discussion?

The ancients—their knowledge reached a point. To what point? Some took it to be as if things had never begun to exist. This is the utmost, the exhaustion—nothing can be added to it! Next were those who took it that things exist, yet had never begun to have boundaries. Next were those who took it that boundaries exist, yet had never begun to have right and wrong.

The manifestation of right and wrong is the injury to the Dao; the injury to the Dao is the completion of partiality. Is there truly completion and injury? Is there truly no completion and injury?

---

The presence of completion and injury—thus did Master Zhao play the zither; the absence of completion and injury—thus did Master Zhao not play the zither. When Master Zhao played the zither, when Shi Kuang wielded his baton, when Master Hui leaned upon the catalpa tree—these three masters’ knowledge approached the subtleties! All were at their peak, and so their deeds were recorded in their later years. Only because they cherished their arts did they differ from others; cherishing them, they sought to illuminate others thereby. Yet what they illuminated was not what could be illuminated—thus they ended in the obscurity of "hard and white." And Master Zhao’s son, in turn, ended with the threads of his father’s art, achieving nothing his whole life. Could this be called completion? Even I, too, would be complete. Could this not be called completion? Then things and I would have no completion.

Thus, the dazzling confusion of doubt is what the sage contemplates. To refrain from using it yet lodge it in the common—this is called "illuminating through non-illumination."

Guo Xiang’s commentary: One who knows that things have never begun to exist looks outward without scrutinizing the cosmos, inward without perceiving his own body—thus he is vast and unburdened, responding to all without obstruction. Next are those who acknowledge things yet without boundaries; though they have not entirely forgotten, they can still forget self and other. Next are those who acknowledge boundaries yet without right and wrong; though they have not forgotten self and other, they can still forget the right and wrong of self and other. Without right and wrong, the Dao is whole. When the Dao is injured, emotions become partial and attachment takes form. Is there truly presence or absence of completion and injury?

Sounds cannot all be enumerated. Thus, though blowing pipes and plucking strings may involve many fingers, many sounds are lost. Those who grasp the flute or strum the zither seek to manifest sound, yet in manifesting sound, sound is lost; in not manifesting sound, sound is whole. Thus, to seek completion and incur injury—this was Master Zhao’s zither-playing; to achieve no completion yet incur no injury—this was Master Zhao’s not playing the zither. These three masters all sought to distinguish, yet illuminated what could not be illuminated—thus their knowledge exhausted their forms, their batons strained their waking hours, their leaning upon the catalpa brought only darkness. Relying on their peak abilities, they endured long; otherwise, they would have faltered early. The three masters took themselves as distinct from the multitude, desiring others to share their cherished arts—yet others ultimately did not understand. Thus, their arts and doctrines ended in obscurity. Master Zhao’s son, too, ended with the threads of his father’s art, achieving nothing in the end. If these three could be called complete, then my own incompletion would also be completion. If this cannot be called completion, then things and I have no completion.

The sage darkens his own abilities, shaping all things without omission. Now, these three masters sought to illuminate others with their cherished arts—was this not delusion? The sage is one without self. The dazzling confusion of doubt is contemplated and bounded. The vast, the strange, the deceptive, the uncanny—these are penetrated and unified. Let the myriad differences each rest in what they rest in, and the multitude not lose what they deem right—then the sage refrains from using, yet the uses of the ten thousand things are fully employed. The transformations of unbridled freedom, the peculiarities of the stubbornly strange, the bending to follow the lacking—though their uses are myriad, they are clearly self-evident.

Lü Huiqing’s commentary: The Dao is nowhere absent, thus nothing is not the Dao; nothing is not the Dao, thus there is nothing beyond the Dao. This is how the ancients could regard things as never having begun to exist—able to merge with things as the Dao. To know and halt here is to reach the utmost. Next are those who acknowledge things yet without boundaries; though they cannot merge with things as the Dao, they can still unite things through the Dao. Next are those who acknowledge boundaries yet without right and wrong; though they cannot unite things through the Dao, they can still relinquish things to accord with the Dao. Though the knowledge of these two does not fully align with the Dao, it is not yet injured. When right and wrong become manifest, the Dao is thereby injured; when the Dao is injured, emotions arise, and attachment takes form. Yet from the perspective of the enlightened, things have never begun to exist—is there truly presence or absence of completion and injury? Master Zhao’s zither-playing, Shi Kuang’s wielding of the baton, Master Hui’s leaning upon the catalpa—these nearly grasped the meaning of completion and injury. If this can be called completion, then those without completion are also complete; if this cannot be called completion, then things and I ultimately have no completion. Why labor the mind over questions of presence or absence, completion or injury, seeking to achieve completion? When the radiance of subtlety is not yet exhausted, confounding our hearts with doubts of presence and absence, we still contemplate and dispel it, returning to clarity before halting. How much less can there be things? Thus, to refrain from using yet entrust it to the self-accomplishment of the ten thousand things—this is called "illuminating through non-illumination."

Lin Yidu’s commentary: Life and death are the greatest of things—if one can be without life and death, then other things need not be negated to be negated. Thus, to regard things as never having begun to exist is the utmost. Next are those who acknowledge things yet without boundaries; though they have not forgotten that life and death constitute "things," they have not yet reached the boundaries of self and other. Next are those who acknowledge boundaries yet without right and wrong; though they have left worldly learning to follow the Dao and already have boundaries, they can still know the differing emotions of self and other, allowing each to be right or wrong without imposing right or wrong. The body of the Dao is undifferentiated, originally without self and other. Once right and wrong are established, each clings to one corner—this is how the Dao is injured and attachment takes form. With attachment comes aversion, and self and other are fully present. The noble person discusses the Dao to remedy injury, yet when words manifest distinctions, they further create divisions. Thus, Zhuangzi does not fix the presence or absence of completion and injury—grasping the meaning, he forgets words, and therein lies the point. The sages of old, at the height of brilliance, were still and unmoving—this was Master Zhao’s not playing the zither. When the Dao is the mean, it responds and thoroughly penetrates—this was Master Zhao’s playing the zither, Shi Kuang’s wielding of the baton, Master Hui’s leaning upon the catalpa. The knowledge of these three masters approached the Dao but did not reach it; yet their arts were at their peak, and so their deeds were recorded in their later years, meaning they never awakened their whole lives.

To not fully realize one’s nature is to be confused; to not exhaustively investigate principle is to be doubtful. Radiance is the scattering of light.

What the sage seeks does not lie in enlightenment but in delusion, thus entrusting it to the common uses of ordinary people while remaining unobscured. Chen Xiangdao’s annotation: "The Supreme Simplicity (Taiyi) is before qi is seen, yet those who embody it take it as the state before things ever existed—this is the utmost, the complete! The Supreme Beginning (Taichu) is the inception of qi, yet those who embody it regard life as loss and death as return. The Supreme Commencement (Taishi) is the inception of form, yet those who embody it take nonbeing as the origin, life as the substance, and death as the corpse, thereby further entangling themselves in the notions of life and death as loss and return."

When one transgresses against things yet does not depart from the Dao, there has never been any boundary. Boundaries belong to virtue. Those who take nonbeing, life, and death as origin, substance, and corpse are already confined by boundaries and have not yet engaged with affairs. Thus, there has never been right and wrong; the Dao has never been diminished, yet it is diminished by the manifestation of right and wrong. Love has never been complete, yet it is completed by the Dao’s diminution.

The Dao is uncarved wood. Right and wrong are vessels. When vessels are completed, the uncarved wood is destroyed. The Dao is rivers and lakes. Love is the moisture of dew. When rivers and lakes are lost, the moisture of dew follows—this is why completion and diminution perpetually follow one another. Thus, Zhuangzi does not definitively speak of their presence or absence but leaves it to people to seek with their own understanding.

Joy that does not rely on things is the joy of Heaven. Joy that depends on things is the joy of man. The joys of Master Zhao, Shi Kuang, and Master Hui all inevitably rely on things; their preferences merely differ from those of the multitude. What one’s body desires to clarify ultimately ends in seeming right but being wrong.

Things are never without completion, nor are they ever with completion. Viewing the arts of these three masters through common eyes, there is nothing that is not complete—this is why radiance scatters without light, and the world is thereby confused and doubtful.

Chen Bixu’s annotation: "Before things ever existed, one roams at the inception of things—this refers to those who recline in stillness. Next, there are things but no boundaries—this is the state of being alone, having lost one’s counterpart. Next, there are boundaries but no right and wrong—this is the state of ‘I have lost myself; do you understand?’ When right and wrong are manifest, the Dao is diminished; the Dao’s diminution is what completes love. Is there truly presence or absence of completion and diminution?"

The arts of Master Zhao, Shi Kuang, and Master Hui are their innate strengths, yet if one seeks to make those of lesser nature understand them, knowledge is exhausted and essence depleted, and both cannot be attained. The great meaning lies in self-clarity and self-governance alone. If one uses clarity to instruct others, these are but ordinary skills—how can they be called completion?

The sage regards extraordinarily refined and exceptional matters as disturbances beyond the common, thus setting boundaries and dwelling within the proper scope of things, entrusting them to personal use. In this way, the arts of the three masters each have their own clarity.

Zhao Xuqi’s annotation: *Liezi* states, "That which gives birth to things cannot be called nonexistent; the Limitless (Wuji) becomes the Supreme Ultimate (Taiji)." With the Supreme Ultimate, there is yin and yang—this is called having boundaries. When yin and yang divide, hardness and softness take form, and good and evil arise. Before joy, anger, sorrow, and happiness are expressed, there has never been anything—this is called the center, yet there has never been nothing. Joy, anger, sorrow, and happiness are boundaries. Whether they are moderated or not is the manifestation of right and wrong. Once the center is expressed, nature moves and becomes emotion. Love is the root of emotion. With movement and stillness, there is completion and diminution.

Master Zhao’s zither playing is not understood except by Shi Kuang. Master Hui’s eloquence is not grasped except by Zhuangzi. Though the three masters each attained the subtleties, they did not know the zither playing without playing, the listening without hearing, or the eloquence without eloquence—thus, Zhuangzi came after them.

Zhuangzi said of what set him apart from Master Hui: "What I clarify differs from him.
