He clarifies what is insufficient to be clarified, and though he exhausts the debates of hardness and whiteness, sameness and difference, he ultimately remains in obscurity and lack of clarity. As for Master Zhao’s son, he does not understand the mystery of the stringless zither and ultimately achieves nothing. To call this completion is also to call it incompletion—neither can be truly ascribed to it. Thus, clarity emerges from confusion and doubt. This is what the sage esteems."

*The Oral Teachings of Yongzhai* states: "Though this passage speaks from the inception of heaven and earth, one who grasps this principle finds it present before one’s eyes. For instance, before a thought arises, there has never been anything; once this thought arises, there are things. Through this thought, things and self emerge—this is having boundaries. From things and self arise likes, dislikes, joy, and anger—this is having right and wrong. Without reflecting back to the time before a thought arose, one only sees the turmoil in one’s breast—this is the Dao’s diminution and love’s completion. Yet when this thought passes, all is as it was—thus, one sees that there has never been completion or diminution. If one can realize this, it is all of immediate personal use.

First, the principle of completion and diminution is explained, then illustrated with the analogy of zither playing, followed by Shi Kuang and Master Hui. The arts of these three masters all gained great renown in the world, enduring throughout their lives. Their preferences, though they deemed them distinct from the world, led them to boast and explain, yet their listeners could not understand. Thus, they achieved nothing in their lifetimes.

The debate over hardness and whiteness was Gongsun Long’s affair, yet Zhuangzi attributed it to Master Hui, merely borrowing the name of his distinctions. Confusion that breeds doubt is seeming clarity that is not clarity—this means the sage’s mind never clings to traces, and what is seen is as if present, as if absent.

The character *tu* (图) is glossed as ‘desire.’ What the sage desires is precisely this: to set aside what is not used and lodge it in the ordinary—this is called ‘clarity.’"

The ancients prized true knowledge and cast aside delusive knowing, relinquished stagnant being to preserve wondrous being—thus safeguarding the authenticity of life and preserving the Dao of spontaneity. As the human heart grew shallow and the world’s ways declined, things arose to obstruct its emptiness and clarity, boundaries formed to limit its domain. Self and other stood opposed, and right and wrong became manifest; with right and wrong manifest, the Dao suffered loss and partiality took shape.

Yet how could there truly be completion or loss? Once more, this is raised as a warning to awaken the human heart, that it may grasp the fundamental purport of *equalizing things*. Completion and loss belong to the coarse paths of things—if one can truly return to a state beyond things, where would completion or loss arise?

Zhaowen’s mastery of the zither was most refined, yet because he never transcended form, sound, measure, and number, he could not escape completion and loss. *Zhi ce* refers to striking time with a staff. *Ju wu* means reclining against a table while discoursing. These were the strengths of Master Kuang and Master Hui, each taking pride in their own abilities, cherishing them to old age without waning. Not only did they cherish them themselves, but they also sought to enlighten others—yet without considering what suited those others, they merely clamored to impose agreement, ending in confusion, never awakening, never realizing.

And Zhaowen’s son, in turn, inherited the thread, yet throughout his life achieved nothing. The first three masters completed their arts but lost the Dao, yet each believed themselves complete. Zhaowen’s son lost both in art and in the Dao, yet still considered himself correct. This shows how each took their own rightness as partial, and how completion and loss have no fixed standard.

The dazzling confusion of doubt refers to how the arts of these three masters muddled the world and bewildered the eyes and ears. Thus, what the sage desires is precisely this: to set aside what cannot be used and lodge it in the ordinary Dao, gradually restoring the original state—this is called *using one’s light well without dazzling*.

Now, let me say this: is it of the same kind as these examples? Or is it not of the same kind?

To be of the same kind or not of the same kind—if we take them as the same kind, then there is no difference from those examples. Nevertheless, let me try to speak of it:

There is a beginning; there is that which precedes the beginning; there is that which precedes even the preceding of the beginning. There is being; there is non-being; there is that which precedes non-being; there is that which precedes even the preceding of non-being. Suddenly there is being and non-being, yet we do not know which of the two—being or non-being—is truly being or non-being.

Now I have already spoken, yet I do not know whether what I have called it is truly speaking or truly not speaking. Nothing in the world is greater than the tip of an autumn hair, yet Mount Tai is small; nothing is longer-lived than a child who dies young, yet Pengzu is short-lived. Heaven and earth are born together with me; the myriad things and I are one.

Since we have already become one, can there still be speech? Since we have already called it one, can there be no speech? One and speech make two; two and one make three. From this point onward, even the most skillful reckoner cannot reach it—how much less can ordinary people? Thus, from non-being to being, we reach three—how much more so from being to being? Do not proceed further; rest here.

Guo Xiang’s commentary:
Now, to say there is no right or wrong—do we not know whether this is of the same kind as those who speak of being, or not of the same kind? If we call it the same kind, then I take non-being as right, while they take non-being as wrong—this is not the same kind. Though right and wrong differ, they are still not free from having right and wrong, and thus are of the same kind as those. Therefore, whether of the same kind or not, they are all of the same kind, no different from those.

To be truly not of the same kind, nothing is better than having no mind. First, cast aside what is wrong; then cast aside the casting aside. Cast aside again and again—right and wrong are gone. Nevertheless, let me try to speak of it:

There is a beginning—this implies an end. There is that which precedes the beginning—here there is no end or beginning, and life and death are one. There is that which precedes even the preceding of the beginning—here, to speak of oneness is not as good as not being one and yet being naturally equal; this is to forget even oneness.

There is being—where there is being, beauty and ugliness, right and wrong all arise. There is non-being—where there is non-being, we do not yet know that there is no non-being, and right and wrong, likes and dislikes still linger in the heart. There is that which precedes non-being—here, we know there is no non-being, yet we still cannot be without knowledge. There is that which precedes even the preceding of non-being—suddenly there is being and non-being, yet we do not know which of the two—being or non-being—is truly being or non-being. Here, all knowledge is forgotten, and suddenly we realize there is nothing at all.

When there is nothing at all, then heaven and earth, the myriad things, self and other, right and wrong—all become clear and certain. And yet we do not know whether what I have called it is truly speaking or truly not speaking—all is swept away, leaving not even the slightest dust in the heart.

If we take forms as relative, then Mount Tai is greater than the tip of an autumn hair. But if each thing abides in its own nature and reaches its limit, then a large form is not in excess, nor is a small form insufficient. When a thing is sufficient in its nature, then the tip of an autumn hair is not merely small in its smallness, nor is Mount Tai merely large in its largeness. If we take sufficiency in nature as greatness, then nothing in the world is greater than the tip of an autumn hair. If sufficiency in nature is not greatness, then even Mount Tai can be called small. If Mount Tai is small, then nothing in the world is large. If the tip of an autumn hair is large, then nothing in the world is small.

When things are sufficient in their natural state and at peace in their allotted nature, then even heaven and earth are not long-lived enough to be born together with me, and the myriad things are not different enough to be one with me. The myriad things and myriad forms, when self-sufficient, are one. Once they are one, there is no principle that requires speech. Some things cannot clarify their oneness on their own, so we call them one to correct them. But once we call them one, this is already speech. One and speech make two; one is originally one, but speech makes it two—can we not call this three? To speak of one with speech still makes three. With so many things and so many names, how can they all be accounted for?

Thus, those who speak of oneness are no different from those others; but those who forget oneness have no speech and yet are naturally one.

Lü Huiqing’s commentary:
People cannot cast aside self and other, forget right and wrong, and reach the state before there was anything because they do not know where the mind of self and other, right and wrong begins. To grasp this principle, one must observe it from the beginning, hence the saying: "There is a beginning." The beginning is originally nothing; once there is this beginning, then there is an origin. It also says, "There is that which precedes the beginning"—this is to cast aside its origin. But if what is cast aside does not depart, then one is still not free from having an origin.

It also says, "There is that which precedes even the preceding of the beginning"—this is to cast aside the casting aside. When there is no origin and no casting aside, then the source from which my mind arises becomes clear. One knows that all that exists now emerges from nothing. Only by knowing this can life and death be in my hands; I can prevent what I do not desire from arising. Thus it says, "There is non-being"—yet to have this non-being is still not free from being. "There is that which precedes non-being"—this is to cast aside non-being. "There is that which precedes even the preceding of non-being"—this is to cast aside the casting aside.

If we seek the origin and cannot find it, and seek non-being and also cannot find it, then enlightenment comes in an instant, and all things naturally align. Thus it says, "Suddenly there is being and non-being, yet we do not know which of the two—being or non-being—is truly being or non-being," guiding scholars to forget words and grasp it with the heart.

Nevertheless, what I have spoken of now is also that which precedes anything—how could I know whether it is speaking or not speaking? This also lets scholars know that speech has never truly been speech. Only by knowing where my mind arises can we see that the tip of an autumn hair, Mount Tai, the child who dies young, Pengzu, and even heaven and earth, the myriad things—all arise from this. Then small and large, long and short—how can they have a fixed form?

Nameless, it is the beginning of heaven and earth; if one knows this, then I too begin from the nameless. With the self, there is heaven and earth—thus heaven and earth are born together with me. Named, it is the mother of the myriad things; if one knows this, then I too am born from the named. Without the self, there are no myriad things—thus the myriad things and I are one.

Lin Yi’s solitary note: Only without speech can the solitary be seen; only by seeing the solitary can one transcend classification. Now, though I speak, it is to dispel being, yet speech itself becomes being. Seeking to dispel being and return to non-being to escape classification, the act of dispelling itself becomes a form of classification. Thus, classification and non-classification are both classifications, differing not at all from that.

Yet without speech, there is no way to awaken the deluded world, so I venture to speak of it. That which has a beginning is visible in form, seeing things but not the Dao. That which has never had a beginning sees the Dao yet does not forget it. That which has never had what never had a beginning—here, qi, form, and substance are complete yet undivided, called "primordial chaos," the ultimate of the Dao.

That which has being is not wondrous being. That which has non-being is not true non-being. How can we know whether being or non-being is truly being or non-being? "One yin, one yang—this is called the Dao." "Unfathomable yin and yang—this is called the spirit." Yet unable to forget speech, we are compelled to speak—is this truly speaking? Truly not speaking?

What the world calls small and large refers to form; what I call small and large refers to the Dao. What the world calls long life and early death refers to existence; what I call long life and early death refers to non-existence. The tip of an autumn hair, near to formlessness, compared to Mount Tai, is surely large. Yet measured against the absence of gain or loss, Mount Tai is small. A child who dies young, near to non-existence, compared to Pengzu, is surely long-lived. Yet measured against the absence of life and death, Pengzu is short-lived.

Near to non-existence, one can be born together with heaven and earth; near to formlessness, one can be one with the myriad things.

Chen Xiangdao’s note: The Dao in the world has no end, no beginning, neither being nor non-being. Yet when it scatters and lodges in things, then end and beginning follow one another, being and non-being give rise to each other. Thus, from the perspective of the manifest, that which has a beginning is that which has being. From the perspective of the wondrous, the ultimate lies in that which has never had what never had a beginning, never had what never had non-being—this is the highest.

*Laozi* says: "Nameless, it is the beginning of heaven and earth." Non-being is the essence; beginning is the function. Now, to first speak of having a beginning and then of being and non-being is to use function to trace back to essence. As for the Dao as a thing: non-being is not emptiness, being is not solidity. It is nowhere yet everywhere, does nothing yet accomplishes all. Thus, the ancients who spoke of the Dao often dwelled in ambiguity, not clinging to being or non-being, to dispel the burden of speech.

Chen Bixu’s note: "Has a beginning" refers to the Dao generating the One. "Never had a beginning" is the primordial chaos of Great Non-being. "Never had what never had a beginning" is beyond sight and hearing, the emptiness of emptiness. These three describe the Dao before qi arose. "Has being" refers to things taking form and transforming alone, existing in isolation. "Has non-being" refers to things before their forms appear, in tranquil stillness. "Never had non-being" refers to before the signs of form, silent and vast, the utmost non-being. "Never had what never had non-being" refers to the profound stillness and vastness, untouchable, the non-being of non-being. These four describe the Dao before form arose.

"Suddenly there is being and non-being"—the Dao is everywhere, generating and transforming without cease. The myriad things stand alone yet doubt their solitude, flitting back and forth. Heaven and earth shift imperceptibly—how can there be being or non-being? Speaking or not speaking, one cannot escape description. To transcend both, is it not to forget speech?

Zhao Xuzhai’s note: "Has a beginning" and "has being" are both being. Ascending further to "no beginning" and "no being," though one takes them as non-being, the self still remains—so they cannot be called non-being. Then how can we know being and non-being? Heaven and earth are born together with me—there is no long life or early death. The myriad things and I are one—there is no large or small. Yet to speak of "one" is already to involve speech. With speech, there are distinctions. From non-being to being, the transitions are endless. Only with no destination can what is called "thus" also be nothing. How much more so what is not?

*The Oral Teachings of Yongzhai* says: "Has a beginning," "never had a beginning," and "never had what never had a beginning" correspond to *Liezi*’s "Great Simplicity," "Great Plainness," and "Great Beginning." If Mount Tai is called large, heaven and earth are larger still—thus Mount Tai may also be called small. Pengzu is the longest-lived, yet compared to heaven and earth, he is short-lived! Heaven and earth are born together with me in the Great Void; the myriad things are born together with me within heaven and earth. Even grasses, trees, and insects blend indistinguishably with me.

In the world, nothing is said to be larger than Mount Tai, nothing longer-lived than Pengzu. This is to judge by form, which knows no limit. Yet viewed from the emptiness of inherent nature, Mount Tai is but a tiny thing, Pengzu but an infant. Though the tip of an autumn hair is fine, at the inception of form it shares this principle—how can the supremely large not reside within it? Though a child who dies young is short-lived, at the inception of life it shares this nature—how can the longest-lived not reside within it? Heaven and earth are but the greatness of form; the myriad things are but the multitude of form. Tracing them to their origin, how are they not one?

Thus, through repeated and reciprocal discourse, one shatters the attachments of worldly views and unlocks the ultimate mechanism of the principles of things. Proceeding from this, the meanings of the millet-grain holding Mount Li and the mustard seed containing Mount Sumeru may be understood by analogy.

If the scholar can truly grasp the emptiness at the center of the ring, resting in the natural division of the celestial balance, then the teachings that enlarge the tip of an autumn hair and diminish Mount Tai, that grant longevity to a child who dies young and shorten the lifespan of Pengzu—these are not merely corrections of common folly or remedies for the errors of sentient beings, but the ultimate realization of principle, which is indeed so.

Yet how is it that worldly eyes see only the ceaseless, uneven flux of the myriad things, while the realm of clarity within the square inch of the heart is swept away with them, like water rushing into a ravine, with no hope of returning to the source? Therefore, the perfected person earnestly instructs, guiding one to turn back and investigate the original beginning, to merge self and other, to be of one body and one family, without hindrance to one’s benevolence, joyfully and harmoniously sharing in the enjoyment of purity and stillness—such was the age of Fuxi, the Yellow Emperor, and the present day. This is the esoteric transmission of the heart by the sages and worthies.

What need is there for debate over longevity and early death, self and other, great and small, past and present? All arise as one, and the great joy is akin to the earlier metaphors of the finger and the horse. Though the words may seem contrary to reason, the principle is in fact profoundly precise—this is what is meant by "straight words seeming reverse," and it is the Way for those who understand.

The Way has never had boundaries; words have never had constancy. Yet because of this, distinctions arise. Let me speak of these divisions: there is left and right, order and righteousness, division and debate, competition and contention—these are called the eight virtues.

Beyond the six directions, the sage preserves but does not discuss; within the six directions, the sage discusses but does not debate; regarding the *Spring and Autumn Annals* and the intentions of the former kings, the sage debates but does not argue. Thus, division implies what is undivided; debate implies what is undebated. Why is this? The sage embraces it, while the multitude debates it to display to one another. Therefore, it is said that debate implies what is unseen.

The great Way is not named; great debate does not speak; great benevolence is not benevolent; great integrity is not modest; great courage is not aggressive. When the Way is made manifest, it is no longer the Way; when words are debated, they do not reach; when benevolence is constant, it does not succeed; when integrity is pure, it is not trusted; when courage is aggressive, it does not succeed. When these five are rounded, they nearly approach squareness. Thus, to know to stop at what one does not know—this is perfection! Who knows the debate of non-debate, the Way of non-Way? If one can know this, it is called the celestial treasury. It is filled yet never full, drawn from yet never exhausted, and one does not know whence it comes—this is called preserving the light.

In ancient times, Yao asked Shun, saying: "I wish to attack Zong, Kuai, and Xu’ao, yet when I face south, I am not at ease. What is the reason for this?" Shun said: "Those three lords dwell among the mugwort and reeds. Why are you not at ease? In ancient times, ten suns appeared together, and the myriad things were all illuminated—how much more so for one whose virtue surpasses the sun!"

Guo Xiang’s commentary: The Way has never had boundaries; it is obscurely present in all things. Words have never had constancy; right and wrong have no fixed standard. The Way is unbounded, so the myriad things freely occupy their allotted domains. Left and right differ in convenience; each thing has its principle. Grouped by kind and distinguished by category, they compete and contend in debate—summarized, these are the eight virtues. Beyond the six directions, referring to what lies outside the divisions of inherent nature, though principle exists there, it does not move the sage, so it is not discussed. Within the six directions, the sage sets forth their natures and settles them. The intentions of the former kings follow their completed traces, congealing in perfect appropriateness, so each thing divides itself, and each affair distinguishes itself. If one were to divide them by oneself, one would not see their self-distinction. The sage embraces non-debate, while the multitude debates what they know to display to others, hence there is what is unseen.

The great Way has no name; it is left to name itself. Great debate does not speak yet distinguishes itself. Great benevolence has no love yet preserves itself. Great integrity has no place to contain its modesty. Great courage goes nowhere without following others. When the Way is used to illuminate others, both self and other are lost; when words are used to divide others, they do not reach self-division. When things are constantly loved, they are not universally cared for. When integrity is forced, it is not pure. Aggressive courage is detested by the world. These five all injure what is appropriate by acting, unable to stop at their original nature, and endlessly seek outside themselves—like trying to square the circle or envying birds as a fish. Thus, what one does not know lies outside the divisions of inherent nature. Not seeking forced knowledge and stopping within what one does not know—this is perfection.

Non-speech and non-Way—this is called the celestial treasury, vast and all-embracing. The heart of the perfected person responds but does not store; principle exists without trace, allowing its natural clarity to shine without obstruction.

In the past, Yao wished to attack the three states and asked Shun. Shun said that what things find peaceful has no baseness, so the mugwort and reeds are the wondrous abode of the three lords. Why be ill at ease? When ten suns appeared together, nothing was not illuminated; when virtue surpasses the sun, there is nothing it does not shine upon. Now, to seize the wishes of the mugwort and reeds and attack to make them follow oneself—this is not the expansive Way, so one is not at ease in spirit and understanding. If things flow freely in their natures, each resting in what is peaceful, then there is nothing inappropriate in them, and nothing in oneself that is not joyful.

Lu Huiqing’s commentary: The Way is present everywhere without exception—it has never had boundaries. Words, wherever they exist, cannot be fixed—it has never had constancy. From their natural absence, distinctions arise, and thus there are boundaries. Only because there are boundaries do left and right arise, leading to competition and contention, showing that one cannot help but act with virtue, thus reaching this point. Therefore, some things are preserved but not discussed, some are discussed but not debated, and some are debated but not argued. Observing the words of the Six Classics, one may know the sage’s reasons for discussing or not discussing, debating or not debating, arguing or not arguing.

Where principle reaches its utmost, there is distinction without distinction, debate without debate. If one insists on distinguishing and debating every single thing, it will ultimately lead to competition and contention. The sage knows that principle cannot be debated—it is simply embraced. The multitude, however, debates to display themselves, yet remains blind to what truly matters.

Thus, the five—Dao, speech, benevolence, integrity, and courage—when rounded to dull their sharp edges, incline toward the Dao. The mind’s outward expression is sharpness; when rounded to its utmost sharpness, it does not give rise to the mind—how could knowledge find room there? This is the debate of non-debate, the Dao of non-Dao.

The Celestial Treasury holds myriad differences yet is supremely rich. Thus, it is never filled when poured into, never exhausted when drawn from, and its source remains unknown—this is brilliance that does not dazzle. Yao wished to replace Zong, Kuai, and Xu Ao but could not rest easy. The three still dwelled among the brambles and weeds, for they had not been felled. Yet even without felling them, Yao could not rest easy—this was not a response to things that does not conceal, but rather a case of things being probed before emerging. When virtue advances daily, can there be any unease? Such words address what wisdom’s light has yet to illuminate, hence this discussion persists. The deeds of Zong, Kuai, and Xu Ao remain unrecorded in history.

Lin Yi’s sole annotation: Where the Dao has divisions, things divide themselves; where it has no divisions, I have never divided or debated. In every matter debating itself, there is what is not debated—I have never debated. Things divide themselves, thus there is division without division; matters debate themselves, thus there is debate without debate. The sage conceals and does not speak; the multitude debates to display, hence they do not see. The Dao is present everywhere yet cannot be named. The debate of non-debate—this is true debate.

The myriad things each fulfill their nature and destiny—where would I impose my benevolence? Great integrity has no corners, so there is no place for resentment. Great courage is not harmful—it is spiritually martial yet does not kill. All things, when obstructed, develop edges and angles; when unimpeded, they have no fixed form. The five all suffer from obstruction: Dao obstructed by clarity, speech by debate, benevolence by convention, integrity by purity, and courage by harm. If one rounds and files their edges to merge with the great whole, one approaches the Dao’s square.

The Celestial Treasury is the natural storehouse to which all things return. Thus, it is never filled when poured into, never exhausted when drawn from. Compared to the essence of life’s nature, it neither increases nor diminishes. Seeking its source yields nothing—this is called preserving brilliance, its light hidden within, concealed yet unextended.

The sage’s mind is profoundly still, each resting in its proper place, without regard for distance or depth, entrusted to self-attainment. This is the self-concealment of the Celestial Treasury, the origin of preserved brilliance.

Chen Xiangdao’s annotation: The Dao has never had boundaries—like tenons and tiles, it is present everywhere. Speech has never had constancy—it exists yet is not discussed, debated yet not argued. When the Dao descends as virtue, emerging with distinctions, it takes form with left and right, principle with order and righteousness, speech with division and debate, and affairs with competition and contention—how can one expect things to be equal?

Dao made manifest yet not the Dao—such were Gongsun Qiu and his followers. Speech debating yet falling short—such were Gongsun Long and his followers. Benevolence bound by convention yet unfulfilled—such were Mo Di and his followers. Integrity fixated on purity yet untrustworthy—such were the followers of Zhongzi of Yu Ling. Courage bent on harm yet unfulfilled—such were the followers of Beigong You. These five, when their edges are sharpened, can be rounded to approach the Dao. Pushed further upward, they reach the unfathomable spirit—what is called true knowledge as non-knowledge.

Nowhere not concealed—this is the Celestial Treasury. Not endangering one’s authenticity—this is preserved brilliance. This is the nature that neither loses nor gains. The debate of non-debate encompasses all; the Dao of non-Dao penetrates all. This is the effect of the Dao in fully realizing one’s nature.

Those who magnify the Dao regard all with equal benevolence, valuing the near to embrace the distant. If one takes the distinction between self and others as the heart, right and wrong as debate, and seeks to attack others among the brambles and weeds, even facing south as a ruler will not bring ease. What is hoped for is small, what is lost is great—this is not what is called knowing preserved brilliance.

Chen Bixu’s annotation: Nothing enters where there is no gap—what barrier could obstruct boundaries? Utmost speech is never inappropriate—what constancy could fix it? Yet the speakable and expressible—how could they lack rules? Left and right, order and righteousness belong to boundaries; division, debate, competition, and contention belong to speech. These boundaries and speech have their actual principles, hence they are called virtue.

Beyond the six directions, the sage does not discuss—where principle exists, affairs are set aside. Within the six directions, the sage does not debate—where affairs are proper, words are forgotten. The rise and fall of dynasties, the sage discusses in detail with praise and blame, leaving warnings for posterity—not to boast of vast debate. Thus, what is divided within is not divided without; what is debated here is not debated there. The sage embraces it, the wise do not speak; the multitude debates, those who speak do not know.

The great Dao cannot be named—it is fitting for all things. When the five—debate, benevolence, integrity, and courage—are complete, there is non-action in the Dao, and principle naturally aligns. If even one matter is amiss, like fitting a circle into a square, it will inevitably clash with things. Thus, not overstepping one’s bounds to seek knowledge and injure natural nature—the debate of non-debate, the Dao of non-Dao—all are concealed within the human heart. Is this not the Celestial Treasury?

With form, pouring fills; with a source, drawing exhausts. Now, neither filling nor exhausting—this is knowing the source’s depth, the form’s vastness. Depth and vastness cannot be seen, hence it is called preserved brilliance.

The Three Lords still dwell amidst the mugwort and wormwood, like the wren content with a single branch. The "ten suns" are compared to Yao’s virtue, speaking of how nothing remains unilluminated. The *Daodejing* states: "A great state desires only to shelter and nurture its people; a small state desires only to serve others. When both attain what they desire, the greater should humble itself." Zhao Xuzhai’s commentary notes: "The Dao has never been bounded—it exists everywhere without exception. Words have never been fixed—nothing remains beyond their reach. Only when one seeks to clarify what is right do boundaries and divisions arise, leading to the eight contentions of left and right." Beyond the Six Directions lies the formless; within them, the formed. The formed arises from the formless, and the formless is its root. To preserve without discussion is to be wordless; to discuss without debate is to speak. When matters reach debate, disputes arise. The *Spring and Autumn Annals*, a work of the Sage’s brush, conveys right and wrong through praise and blame, yet even this arises from necessity, and the various commentaries may not fully grasp the Sage’s intent. Thus it is said: "There are things unseen."

Zhuangzi invokes this to clarify his own purpose in writing. "The great Dao cannot be named" to "great courage is not contentious"—these five are rounded and nearly square. "Rounded" here means to shave away the edges to form a circle; "nearly square" is to approach the Dao. When the Dao is made manifest and the five virtues are named, the Dao is fragmented. To know one’s limits in what one does not know is to be beyond naming—this is the Dao’s perfection. The "wordless word" is spoken by those who speak; the "Dao-less Dao" is followed by those who follow. If one can grasp this, one’s center is empty, hence the "Celestial Treasury," the source from which all things arise. As for "pouring without filling, drawing without exhausting," this is to be without limit, to not know whence it comes or whither it goes. "Preserved brilliance" means to conceal one’s light.

Zong, Kuai, and Xu’ao do not appear in the classics or histories. The following chapter speaks of "proper place, proper flavor, proper color," referring to the mouth’s delight in taste, the eye’s in color, and the limbs’ in ease—all rooted in inherent nature. Yao sought to overcome and discard these, yet though he occupied the highest position, he took no joy in them. Shun told Yao that the Emperor possessed true insight: these three are at peace in their proper places—why discard them? Only the Sage can fulfill the form. Viewed thus, Zong, Kuai, and Xu’ao seem to be allegories.

The *Yongzhai Oral Exegesis* states: "Boundaries" refer to self and other; "constancy" means having a fixed position. The perfect Dao and perfect words are originally without self or other, but the private biases of the human heart introduce the notion of "rightness," giving rise to many divisions. The eight virtues merely reflect the opposition of self and other. Once self and other are set against each other in discourse, each clings to its position, and debate never ends. Thus, beyond the Six Directions, we preserve without discussion. As the Buddhists say: "The four directions and above and below cannot be conceived." Within the Six Directions lie many principles—when has the Sage not spoken of them? Yet he does not exhaustively debate to impose knowledge on the world. What appears in the historical records are the intentions of former kings in governing the world—how could the Sage refrain from discussion? Yet when has he ever contended over right and wrong? In all matters under heaven, forgetting words is the highest; once debate begins, it is because the heart lacks insight. Thus there is "no division, no debate."

"The great Dao cannot be named" means it has no opposition. "Great debate does not speak"—this is the highest speech. "Great benevolence is not benevolent"—it leaves no trace of benevolence. The macaque hides its food, calling it "fullness." If one takes moderation for frugality, the mind becomes self-satisfied, and it cannot be called great frugality. The "unskilled" show no sign of using courage. "Rounded" means circular. The five virtues above are all round things, originally undifferentiated. If the slightest trace appears, they approach square things, developing edges and corners. True knowledge is knowing without knowledge—only then can one perceive the convergence of heavenly principle. Thus one cannot add to it or diminish it, and one does not know whence it comes. Concealing one’s light without revealing it is called "preserved brilliance." Zong, Kuai, and Xu’ao are matters unseen in the records—are they not also allegories?

The "mugwort and wormwood" metaphorically represent the obstructions of worldly desires, meaning those Three Lords are self-obscured by desires and cannot turn toward transformation. If I harbor even the slightest displeasure, self and other are set in opposition. The sun illuminates all things without exception—how much more should virtue, surpassing the sun, be unable to tolerate these Three? The reason the Sage does not debate right and wrong is that he illuminates them by heaven. The "ten suns" are like the analogy of "nothing is brighter than clarity." Yao’s desire to attack Zong, Kuai, and Xu’ao seems disconnected from the preceding text, yet the opening phrase "in former times" links it as an evidentiary reference. This event does not appear in other classics, so there is no way to verify it. The names of the three states are also difficult to interpret, and the various commentaries remain silent. Only the *Pronunciation and Meaning* records Cui’s explanation: Zong is one, Kuai is two, Xu’ao is three. Chen Bixu’s *Pronunciation and Meaning* also cites Cui, with another version: Zongkuai, Congzhi, and Xujiao. The *Questions on the World* chapter also mentions Yao attacking Congzhi and Xujiao, yet the reader must discern the author’s intent rather than be constrained by the factual details.

My humble observation, appended to this compilation in hopes of engaging those with broader knowledge: The purport of the classic, following the earlier discussion of boundaries, constancy, and contention, suggests that the Three States serve as metaphors for the three conditions of "within and beyond the Six Directions," "the intentions of former kings," and "discussion, debate, and argument"—all of which one seeks to attack and discard. This is to transcend the right and wrong of words and debates, to restore the profound silence of the Dao and virtue. Yet even Yao could not overcome this on his own and asked Shun about it. Shun replied that the Three Lords still dwell amidst the mugwort and wormwood, meaning they already exist but are not discussed. It is better to let them reside in a realm without people, so that for me there is no concern, and for them there is no hindrance—what is there not to release?

Further evidence states: In ancient times, when ten suns appeared together, all yin forces retreated, and eyes and limbs awaited this accomplishment. How much more so now, when the Emperor’s virtue surpasses even the sun? Then those three conditions would depart of themselves without need for attack—such is the inherent principle.

This is to convey through parable that when debate, discussion, and argument do not arise, right and wrong naturally cease. This is the great purport of *Equalizing Things*.

---

*Zhuangzi: The Essential Meaning of the Southern Florescence*, *Gathered Glimmers from the Sea of Meaning*, Scroll 3
1. According to Guo Xiang’s commentary, the character *shi* 施 should be *chou* 丑.
2. The character *you* 有 is superfluous.

*Zhuangzi: The Essential Meaning of the Southern Florescence*, *Gathered Glimmers from the Sea of Meaning*, Scroll 4
By Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin

**“Equalizing Things,” Third Chapter**

Nie Que asked Wang Ni, “Do you know what all things agree upon as right?”

Wang Ni replied, “How would I know?”

“Do you know what you do not know?”

“How would I know?”

“Then do things have no knowledge?”

“How would I know? Nevertheless, let me try to speak of it: How can I be certain that what I call knowing is not not-knowing? How can I be certain that what I call not-knowing is not knowing? Now, let me ask you this: When people sleep in damp places, their waists ail and they become half-paralyzed—is that like a loach? When they dwell in trees, they tremble and shudder in fear—is that like a monkey? Of these three, which knows the proper dwelling? People eat the flesh of livestock, deer eat grass, centipedes relish snakes, owls and crows delight in mice—of these four, which knows the proper flavor? Apes and monkeys take gibbons as mates, elk and deer couple with one another, loaches and fish swim together. Mao Qiang and Lady Li were considered beautiful by people; yet when fish saw them, they dove deep, when birds saw them, they flew high, when elk and deer saw them, they bolted away. Of these four, which knows the proper beauty of the world? From my perspective, the beginnings of benevolence and righteousness, the paths of right and wrong, are tangled and chaotic—how could I know their distinctions?”

Nie Que said, “If you do not know benefit and harm, does the Perfected Person likewise not know benefit and harm?”

Wang Ni replied, “The Perfected Person is spirit-like! When great marshes burn, they cannot be made hot; when rivers and lakes freeze, they cannot be made cold; when swift thunder splits mountains and winds shake the sea, they cannot be made startling. One such as this rides the clouds and qi, mounts the sun and moon, and roams beyond the Four Seas. Life and death bring no change to them—how much less the beginnings of benefit and harm!”

**Guo Xiang’s Commentary:**
What is agreed upon is not necessarily right; what differs is not uniquely wrong. Neither self nor other can correct the other, so there is no use for knowledge. If one claims to know what one does not know, this is to possess knowledge yet be unable to entrust things to their own proper places. Thus, Nie Que asked three times, and Wang Ni answered with three “I do not know.”

“How can you be certain that what I call knowing is not not-knowing, or that not-knowing is not knowing? Fish swim in water—all aquatic creatures share this, and all call it knowing. Yet from the perspective of birds, what was previously called knowing becomes not-knowing. Thus, I cite people, loaches, and monkeys to illustrate the differing conveniences of the myriad things. Next, I cite people, deer, centipedes, and crows to show that beauty and ugliness have no fixed master. Then I cite apes, gibbons, elk, deer, loaches, fish, Mao Qiang, and Lady Li to demonstrate that what the world finds pleasing differs. If one were to reject what differs, there would be no way to know what is agreed upon as certainly right. Only by not disputing them can all things be left in their natural state.”

Nie Que had not yet grasped the subtlety of not-knowing and still suspected that the Perfected Person ought to know. This doubt remained unresolved. The Perfected Person is spirit-like, for their essence merges with things. Though they encounter the most extreme changes, they never depart from the self.

**Lü Huiqing’s Commentary:**
To know the limit of not-knowing is what all things agree upon as right. To know what all things agree upon as right is not not-knowing. Only the Dao cannot be known; knowing it is the very reason for not-knowing. Not-knowing is the reason for knowing it—thus the essence of the Dao becomes visible.

Now, people take bodily comfort and ease as the proper dwelling, the taste of livestock as the proper flavor, and beautiful appearances as the proper beauty. As for what gibbons and monkeys find comfortable, what centipedes and crows find sweet, and how fish, birds, elk, and deer pair with one another—each takes what it knows as the proper standard of knowing. Then how can people and the myriad things have a proper dwelling, proper flavor, or proper beauty? If one truly cannot determine the proper dwelling, flavor, or beauty yet claims to know them, then what they know is clearly not right. Thus, from my perspective, benevolence, righteousness, right, and wrong are tangled and chaotic—how could I know their distinctions? This is why there are four questions and four “I do not know.”

The Perfected Person is spirit-like, for spirit subtly encompasses the myriad things in its expressions. The myriad things are none other than the self, yet the self is nothing at all. Who could make them cold or hot, startling or fearful?

**Lin Yidu’s Commentary:**
People and birds and beasts each follow their own preferences, mutually loving and hating—who knows the proper dwelling, proper flavor, or proper beauty of the world? The proper dwelling of the world is that there is no proper dwelling. The proper flavor of the world is that there is no proper flavor. The proper beauty of the world is that there is no proper beauty. Yet those who take nothingness as right see only nothingness, so they speak only of the differences between having dwellings, flavors, and colors, not of nothingness as the proper standard.

From my perspective, right and wrong, benevolence and righteousness, are tangled and chaotic—whom could one follow to correct them? Thus, not knowing their distinctions is precisely how one distinguishes them.

**Chen Xiangdao’s Commentary:**
The Dao takes not-knowing as its inner aspect and knowing as its outer. Thus, knowing is not-knowing, and not-knowing is knowing. Yet even knowing through not-knowing does not escape the taint of having, so one cannot definitively say whether it is knowing or not-knowing. Moreover, one does not speak of having no dwelling, flavor, or color as the proper standard—all this is merely to cast off the burden of discriminating words.

When marshes burn yet one is not hot, when rivers freeze yet one is not cold, when swift thunder does not startle—this is because one’s heavenly integrity is whole and one’s spirit does not retreat.

Riding the clouds and qi, mounting the sun and moon—thus one is not swift yet arrives swiftly, does not move yet reaches. **Chen Bixu’s Commentary:** Taking sameness as right results in no wrong; taking wrong as sameness results in no right. All things differ in form and kind, each unaware of the other. Though one may forget all knowing, each thing remains as it is. Moreover, what I know is commonly called "not knowing," for the other does not know this. What I do not know is commonly called "knowing," yet things do not know one another. What I call knowing is the principle of the myriad things; what I do not know is the nature of the myriad things. Thus, on the Hao Bridge, how could one truly know the joy of the minnows? The cicada drinks but does not eat; the silkworm eats but does not drink—each unaware of why it is so. All things differ in form and kind, and so too do their colors and flavors. Their natures and dispositions are endowed differently—how can they be forcibly equalized? Thus, benevolence, righteousness, right, and wrong are matters the sage does not distinguish.

The perfected person’s spiritual transformations are unfathomable, so the workings of creation cannot alter them. The square inch of the heart is empty. The body is not one’s own—thus one may ride the clouds and qi. Hearing and sight are unused—thus one may mount the sun and moon. Wherever one is, it is fitting—thus one may wander the four seas. Life and death do not change it; what do gain and loss matter? **Zhao Xuqi’s Commentary:** What I call knowing is not necessarily knowing; what I call not knowing is not necessarily not knowing. Confucius said: "Do I possess knowledge? No, I do not." To speak of it is to reach the point of "no knowing"—only then is it true knowing. In dwelling, flavor, and color, humans, birds, and beasts each find what suits them; they cannot all be the same. Mencius said: "The nature of a dog is like the nature of an ox; the nature of an ox is like the nature of a man." This is precisely the same idea. To recognize the rightness of dwelling, color, and flavor, one must depart from dwelling, color, and flavor—only then is there true recognition. To know the rightness of benevolence, righteousness, right, and wrong, one must depart from benevolence, righteousness, right, and wrong—only then is there true knowing.

Nie Que again asked about the perfected person, and Wang Ni replied with the tale of the divine person of Mount Guye. Both were speaking in parables. **Yongzhai Jiangyi** states: Nie Que’s question about sameness and rightness, and Wang Ni’s answer of "How would I know?"—this is knowing to stop at what one does not know. Knowing is not not-knowing; not-knowing is not knowing—this further means that not-knowing is true knowing. The subsequent discussion of right dwelling, right flavor, and right color is a metaphor for the absence of distinction between self and other. The conclusion on the chaotic entanglement of transformation and right/wrong is like the differences in dwelling, flavor, and color—how can they be distinguished? Wang Ni is already the perfected person, spiritually subtle and boundless. Unaffected by heat, cold, or startling thunder, he roams his mind at the beginning of the formless. Even life and death do not move his heart—how much less gain, loss, right, and wrong?

The various commentaries on Nie Que’s first question—"What do things share as right?"—seem to lack illumination. Examining the text’s intent, I say: what humans and things share is their nature; what differs is their dispositions. Nature flows into dispositions, and each thing takes itself as right. With their partial views, they point and criticize, debate differences and breed resentment, argue to extremes and ignite strife—even to the point of treating kin like strangers or enemies. The root of this trouble lies in the word "knowing," which gives rise to false distinctions. Thus, Wang Ni’s threefold answer—"How would I know?"—aims to turn Nie Que back to what he does not know, to grasp their shared nature and fathom the principle of great unity—then he will draw near the Dao. Fearing he may not yet comprehend, Wang Ni further illustrates with examples: the differing needs of humans, birds, and beasts prove that dwelling, flavor, and color have no fixed rightness. Then what is called knowing—is it truly knowing? What is called not knowing—is it truly not knowing?

The highest ancients said: "Those who know do not speak; those who speak do not know." Now that there are words, what is to be done with knowing? I say: gather much knowing to seek what is not known; follow the words to investigate what they express. Then who can say that not-knowing is not true knowing, or that having words is not wordlessness?

Qu Quezi asked Changwuzi: "I have heard from the Master that the sage does not engage in affairs, does not pursue gain, does not avoid harm, does not delight in seeking, does not follow the Dao; speaks without speaking, speaks where there is no speech, and roams beyond the dust and grime. The Master considered this reckless talk, but I believe it is the practice of the wondrous Dao. What do you think?" Changwuzi said: "The Yellow Emperor would have been enlightened by these words—how could Confucius understand them! Moreover, you are too hasty in your calculations. Seeing an egg, you seek a rooster to crow at dawn; seeing a slingshot, you seek a roasted owl. Let me speak to you recklessly, and you may listen recklessly. Why cling to the sun and moon or embrace the cosmos? Let them merge and flow, setting aside their slippery confusion, to honor one another as servants. The masses toil endlessly; the sage appears foolish and dull, blending the myriad ages into a single purity. All things are thus, and so they encompass one another. How do I know that delight in life is not delusion? How do I know that hatred of death is not like a lost youth who does not know the way home?

Li Ji was the daughter of the border warden of Ai. When the state of Jin first obtained her, she wept until her collar was soaked. Yet once she reached the king’s palace, shared his bed and mat, and ate fine meats, she regretted her tears. How do I know that the dead do not regret their earlier clinging to life? Those who dream of drinking wine wake to weep; those who dream of weeping wake to hunt. In their dreams, they do not know they are dreaming. Within the dream, they may even interpret it—only upon waking do they know it was a dream. And there is a great awakening—only then does one know this was all a great dream. Yet fools believe themselves awake, priding themselves on their knowing."

"O lord, O herdsman—how rigid you are! You and I, Qiu, are both dreaming; when I say you are dreaming, that too is a dream. Such words are called *diaogui* (consoling paradox). Should a great sage arise once in ten thousand generations to comprehend their meaning, it would be as if encountering them at dawn or dusk.

Guo Xiang’s note: Affairs come and principles respond of themselves—one does not follow and serve them. Proceeding directly without avoidance or pursuit, this alone is perfection. Without ‘that’ there would be no ‘this’; without ‘this’ there would be no ‘that.’ Thus, the speaker’s words are reckless, and the listener’s hearing is clear. Entrusting all to what lies beyond the dust and grime, merging obscurely with what transcends sight and sound.

Now, Quque hears reckless words and deems them the practice of the wondrous Dao—no different from seeing dawn and demanding the rooster’s crowing merit, or seeing a slingshot and expecting the owl’s roasted flesh. Let me speak recklessly, and you listen recklessly: to take life and death as day and night is to stand beside the sun and moon; to regard the ten thousand things as one body is to embrace the cosmos. Because there is that which is deemed base, hierarchy arises, and confusion and disorder follow, none able to set it right—better to leave it to its natural course, harmonizing with spontaneity.

Thus, the multitude toils and frets, while the sage remains still and unknowing, surveying ten thousand generations to grasp their changes—this may be called ‘mixed,’ yet it merges with transformation, ever wandering in solitude. Accumulate this over ten thousand years, and the ten thousand years become one ‘this.’ Accumulate ‘so’ over the ten thousand things, and the ten thousand things become one ‘so.’ How do we know that delight in life and dread of death are not delusion? Like Lady Li, within a single lifetime, emotions shift so drastically—how much more with the difference between life and death? Can they truly know one another? Observe the changes and differing feelings between waking and dreaming, and the desires of life and death cannot be the same. Though life and death differ, each attains its wish.

Just as one dreams without knowing it is a dream, so too in death one does not know it is death. Only with a great awakening does one realize this was all a great dream. Fools, dreaming, believe themselves awake, smugly taking their preferences as lords and their aversions as herdsmen—how narrow-minded! How much more so when they interpret dreams within dreams? This is no ordinary discourse; it is consoling yet strange, encountered once in ten thousand generations as if at dawn or dusk. Those who speak of the profound unity of life and death are exceedingly rare.

Lü Huiqing’s note: The sage knows neither benefit nor harm, thus neither approaches nor avoids; lacks nothing, thus neither rejoices nor seeks; follows no false path, thus does not cling to the Dao. ‘Having words’ is the very means to ‘having no words’; ‘having no words’ is the very means to ‘having words.’ Only the unburdened heart can attain this.

Quque once heard the Master’s words and dismissed them as reckless, then took them for the wondrous Dao—yet both are mistaken. The Dao is not carried by speech or silence. Thus, what the Yellow Emperor heard with clarity, how could Confucius comprehend it? The rooster’s crow arises from dawn, yet dawn is not the rooster’s crow; the owl’s roast comes from the slingshot, yet the slingshot is not the owl’s roast; the wondrous Dao emerges from what is heard, yet what is heard is not the wondrous Dao. Those who hear the Dao today believe themselves enlightened, yet do not know to diminish daily until reaching non-action—all are Quque’s ilk.

The Dao cannot be transmitted through words or received by ear. My speaking and your listening are both reckless—what is desired is to forget words and unite in mind. Know how the sun and moon are sun and moon, and merge with their light, then you may stand beside them. Know how the cosmos is the cosmos, and its mechanism lies in your grasp, then you may embrace it. For it is all-encompassing—this is the practice of the wondrous Dao, not merely hearing of it.

Confusion and hierarchy based on subordination are firmly set aside. The multitude labors without seeing success, while the sage appears foolish and unknowing, abiding without dissipation. Though ten thousand years pass, surveying and unifying them yields purity. The ten thousand things are all ‘so,’ and through this they interpenetrate—I embody the ten thousand things, and the ten thousand things are my body. Survey ten thousand years and unify them into purity, and a child who dies young may outlive Pengzu. The ten thousand things are all ‘so’ and interpenetrate through this, so a autumn hair may be greater than Mount Tai.

Viewed through Lady Li, how do we know the dead do not regret their earlier clinging to life? What then is there to delight in life or dread in death?

Lin Yidu’s note: The sage responds to inevitability—when has he ever pursued affairs? Without discrimination, there is no approach or avoidance; with a heart utterly sufficient, there is no seeking or clinging. Thus he may be silent when the time is for silence, speak when the time is for speech, and wander beyond the dust and grime. Hearing belongs to acuity, clarity to brightness—what the Yellow Emperor’s acuity and brightness attained was freedom from confusion and obstruction. How could Qiu comprehend it?

Like lips meeting, when things become confused and disordered, the wise set them aside to let each reach its limit. Ministers serve lords, servants serve ministers—this is the natural order. Allow their inequality without disturbing the mind’s equality. Thus, the foolish and the still do not differ; surveying the changes of ten thousand years and unifying them yields purity.

People all delight in life, yet life cannot be prolonged; all dread death, yet death cannot be avoided. At peace in life, like Lady Li in Ai’s borderlands; at peace in death, like Lady Li in the king’s palace. How do we know the dead do not regret their earlier clinging to life?

Chen Xiangdao’s note: The sage does not cut himself off from things, yet never forgets affairs without responding; does not let things burden him, yet never toils in service. What benefits me, I do not approach; what harms me, I do not avoid. Meeting the world’s demands, I do not rejoice or seek; merging with the Dao, I do not cling to it. Though silent all day, I have never been without words; though speaking all day, I have never had words."

The reckless miss the mark, while those who listen with clarity hear and understand. The Master deemed recklessness as falling short; Quque saw it as the wondrous Dao and thus overshot. Hence the saying: "To plan too early."

Dwelling beneath the sun and moon while embracing their radiance, living within the cosmos while holding it close—none but those who command yin and yang, who govern heaven and earth, are fit for such a task. When things align, act; act only when action is fitting. When they are muddled and turbid, set them aside; do not act when action is unfit.

Though one may serve as ruler and minister to another, such roles are but momentary alignments. The toiling, foolish hermit—this is what the *Laozi* calls "the crowd all have their means, while I alone am dull and coarse."

To encompass ten thousand years is to see antiquity as the present; to achieve purity is to see the many guided by the One. People all know the joy of life yet not its suffering; all know the dread of death yet not its rest. Thus, in clinging to life and fearing death, they do not see how their delight and aversion are delusions. How much less can they comprehend life and death?

The ancients called the dead "those who return," so the living are but "wayfarers." If one mourns the young dead without knowing their return, people call it delusion—yet is not living without knowing death also delusion? Life and death, going and returning, are like waking and dreaming. If the sorrows and joys of dreams are not to be taken as real, how can the sorrows and joys of waking be truly so?

Chen Bixu’s note: *Menglang* describes a lack of precision. *Ying* is the luster of jade. To judge jade, one should look, yet it speaks of "listening"—is this not confusion? The Yellow Emperor, master of the Dao, saw and heard without relying on eyes and ears. To still cling to words is like listening for jade’s luster.

The rooster heralds the dawn; the magpie knows when to roast. To grasp the Dao, one must rely on the heart—this has its root. Those who delight in superficial ends and hasty plans are but reckless, frivolous followers of fleeting sounds.

To "embrace the sun and moon" is to abide in constant illumination. To "hold the cosmos" is to encompass all. When things fit perfectly, act without hesitation. When they are muddled, set them aside and forget their contradictions.

To honor one another as servants is the toil of the vulgar world. The sage appears foolish and dull, his heart like cold ashes, his form withered. To unify the myriad ages into a single, pure whole is to traverse past and present as a single day’s dusk, to merge all transformations into undifferentiated perfection.

To find contentment in life and joy in death is still to remain within the bounds of yin and yang—how can one thus embody the profound mystery of the Dao? The maiden of Li Rong, having lost the bliss of Ai Feng, gained the favor of the state of Jin; abandoning one for the other, she clung to neither as if to drifting wood. Within a single lifetime, sorrow and joy remain unfathomable—how then can one lightly discuss the threshold of life and death?

Those who dream of drinking wine or weeping do so because of shifting emotions—such things are not found in the perfected person. To regard ten thousand generations as a single morning is the awakening of the truly enlightened. To see life and death as a single thread—how could there still be dreams? The foolish, in their dreams, believe themselves awake, exalting themselves as rulers and regarding others as mere herdsmen—how crude and narrow this is! The perfected person treats life and death as a great dream and transcends them as a great awakening. The multitude takes the mingling of souls as dreams and the opening of the body as wakefulness, inverting truth and delusion, bewildered by life and death.

Thus, the enlightened one utters these profound words on dreams and awakening to lament the strange illusions of those who chase death. The bonds of life and death, though without rope or knot, cannot be undone—yet if, after ten thousand generations, one encounters a great sage who loosens these fetters of life and death, it is as if meeting in the span of a single dawn and dusk.

Wang Pang’s note: The knowledge of the Confucians, confined to the realm of form and instrument, never fully grasped the Dao—what they did not know was true knowledge. All speech and hearing are insufficient to exhaust reality, and thus are called delusion. To "embrace the sun and moon" and "hold the cosmos" is understood only by those of keen insight; it cannot be explained to the multitude. Like finely minced meat that blends perfectly, one sets aside the world’s confusions, allowing each to reach its utmost without entanglement. As servants to lords and subordinates to superiors, this is the natural order, inherently without hierarchy.

The multitude is enslaved by confusion, while the sage merges with the formless. Between the span of ten thousand years and the transformations of the myriad things, the permutations of the husk and the kernel are countless. Unifying these changes into pure essence can be grasped by the heart but cannot be transmitted through words.

Next, the argument delights in life and abhors death, illustrated by the parable of Lady Li—its meaning is precise and fitting. This further clarifies the *Qi Wu Lun*: it begins by equalizing "this" and "that" and ends by unifying life and death. Once life and death are one, how can things not be equal? The truly awakened one is fundamentally without awakening; the term "awakening" is only provisionally applied in contrast to the unenlightened—it is the awakening of non-awakening. Awakening and non-awakening alike must not be clung to. The foolish, in their smug certainty of being awake, are still dreaming. Precisely because they have such dreams, I cannot but speak of dreams to them—yet the truly awakened one knows that awakening and dreaming are originally no different.

The ancients spoke only when compelled, and thus elucidated this point to console those who, though aligned with the ultimate truth, appear strange to the multitude.

Zhao Xuzhai’s note: The sage does not engage with the dust and grime of the world. This is what Changwu told Quque in ordinary times: Quque took it as the marvelous Dao, while Changwu dismissed it as imprecise. Quque still harbored doubts, so Changwu said to him: These few words are what the Yellow Emperor heard and saw—I do not know them. Moreover, you have not yet reached this understanding yet hastily deem it marvelous—is this not premature?

The practitioners of life-nurturing arts do not know where the great Dao resides. They take heaven and earth as doors and gates, Kan and Li as the hub and axle, seeking to harmonize with the creative transformations of their own bodies. What they cannot fathom, they set aside and do not speak of, instead arranging the hundred bones, nine orifices, and six viscera into a hierarchy of ruler and minister—how can this suffice for true governance? This is to honor one another as servants while remaining unaware of the true ruler within.

The multitude toils in confusion, entangled in profit and harm, while the sage, appearing dull, knows yet does not speak. Each thing possesses this principle, emerging and entering the mechanism—how can one be certain that death is not more joyful than life? *Liezi* records that Yin of Zhou, who amassed great wealth, dreamed at night of being a servant, while his laborers dreamed of being lords. In their dreams, they were rulers or herdsmen as if it were their fixed state. Now, our exchange of questions and answers is already dream-speech; telling you this is a dream is also a dream. To call it "strange and uncanny" is to say that the whole world is lost in dreamlike delusion without realizing it—this is truly lamentable. After ten thousand generations, if a great sage appears—one who understands what no one else has known—able to comprehend this liberation, it is as if meeting in the span of a single dawn and dusk. To awaken to this truth takes but a moment.

*The Oral Teachings of Yongzhai* states: *Menglang* means lacking substance. "Listening to luster" means hearing and thereby understanding. "Premature judgment" refers to your words being as they are, yet hastily deeming them the practice of the marvelous Dao—this is seeing little yet thinking much of oneself. To "embrace the sun and moon," to "hold the cosmos in one’s bosom," to perfectly align with the ultimate truth and merge into oneness—these are the confusions the world clings to, exalting one another as servants, yet all are subordinates, creating their own hierarchies. The multitude toils in confusion, while the sage is utterly without knowledge, viewing ten thousand years as a single principle without admixture. Lady Li’s remorse and tears shatter the delusion of delighting in life and abhorring death; the shifts between drinking wine and weeping in dreams reveal the illusory nature of such transformations. Even the interpretation of dreams within dreams exhausts human sentiment—thus, when Wei Jie asked and Le Guang answered, their exchange did not reach profound understanding.

The "great awakening" is the great enlightenment. "Ruler and herdsman" refer to the distinctions of noble and base. "Strange and uncanny" means utterly bizarre. My words may seem utterly bizarre, yet they contain profound truth. After ten thousand generations, if a great sage appears, his insights will meet mine as if in the span of a single dawn and dusk.

This will also be understood by later generations, such as Yang Ziyun, who grasp my intent.

The sage acts through non-action, allowing things to follow their own course—thus, profit and harm neither reach nor touch him, for he does not deliberately seek to avoid or embrace them. Without craving, the heart’s chamber remains empty; without clinging to the Dao, even emptiness is forgotten. He issues commands without speaking, as if silence were speech. He speaks without obstruction, as if speech were silence. In this state, how could dust or defilement ever stain him?

This is what Quchue had heard from the Master in daily discourse, dismissing it as reckless talk while believing himself to be practicing the wondrous Way. When he sought confirmation from Changwu, Changwu replied that these words were indeed profound, yet only the Yellow Emperor could fully comprehend them—he feared even the Master might not fully grasp them, let alone Quchue, whose cultivation remained incomplete. To merely admire their beauty was premature, like seeing the dawn and demanding the hour of dusk.

"Let me speak recklessly," he said, "and you listen recklessly—what do you think?"

To carry the sun and moon at one’s side and embrace the cosmos—this is the work of spirit-men, not something to be discussed with those who do not share the radiance of sun and moon or take heaven and earth as their constant. If one can practice what was previously described of the sage, then one may advance toward this. The key lies in carefully discerning what aligns with nature and acting accordingly, while setting aside what is entangled in the vulgar. Proceeding from the subtle to the wondrous, ascending step by step, is like the hierarchical reverence among men: servants defer to scholars, scholars to grand officers, grand officers to ministers, each rank rising above the last—until the sage enters the realm of the spirit.

The common people, blind to this, are enslaved by their knowledge and perceptions, unable to rest even for a moment. The sage, appearing foolish and undiscerning, unifies the myriad years and the chaos of events into one, blending them into pure wholeness—transcending past and present, forgetting life and death. The sage does not merely perfect himself; he enables all things to bear witness to this Dao, ripening them through mutual resonance. Thus, he is born together with heaven and earth and becomes one with the ten thousand things.

The reason most people cannot attain this is that their hearts are deluded by delight in life and fear of death, while joy, anger, sorrow, and pleasure ravage their nature. This is why the later text elaborates further to dispel their confusion. Observe Lady Li’s tears of remorse—how can we know that the dead do not regret their former clinging to life? The groundlessness of drinking wine and weeping, the endless transformations between waking and dreaming, and the interpretation of dreams within dreams—all serve as metaphors for those most deeply lost in the world’s delusions.

Only through the great awakening does one realize this is all a great dream. Yet fools, still dreaming, believe themselves awake, distinguishing ruler and herdsman, noble and base—how utterly blind and obstructed they are! If the whole world is dreaming, what division remains between self and other?

Thus, those who understand these words delight in their apt strangeness, while the deluded are shocked by their uncanniness. After ten thousand generations, one who grasps their meaning will meet them as if in the span of a single dawn and dusk. How rare are those in the world who truly comprehend this Dao!

The essence of this chapter lies in the two words "great awakening"—readers should ponder them deeply.

Quchue and Changwu are fictional names used in their dialogue. The "Master" refers to Confucius, though this is also a parable.

Suppose you and I were to debate: if you defeat me, does that mean you are right and I am wrong? If I defeat you, does that mean I am right and you are wrong? Is one of us right and the other wrong? Or are we both right or both wrong? Since neither of us can truly know, how can others resolve this? Whom should we ask to judge?

If we ask someone who agrees with you, how can they judge fairly, already sharing your view? If we ask someone who agrees with me, how can they judge fairly, already sharing my view? If we ask someone who differs from both of us, how can they judge fairly, being different from us both? If we ask someone who agrees with both of us, how can they judge fairly, already sharing our views?

Thus, neither you, nor I, nor others can truly know—must we wait for another? What does it mean to harmonize with the heavenly equilibrium?

It means: "Is" is not "is," "so" is not "so." If "is" is truly "is," then its difference from "is not" requires no debate. If "so" is truly "so," then its difference from "not so" requires no debate. The mutual dependence of changing voices is like their independence. Harmonizing with the heavenly equilibrium and following the boundless flow—this is how one exhausts the years.

Forgetting time, forgetting right and wrong, roused by the boundless, one lodges in the boundless.

Guo Xiang’s commentary: Only in not knowing does one maintain integrity; only in not seeing does one discern. Yet discernment is insufficient for self-assurance, for it remains opposed to things. Debating all day without resolution, nothing can be settled—one must leave it to self-correction. Agreement leads to affirmation, difference to negation, but neither is trustworthy. If "is" is truly "is," there will be no one to negate it. If "not" is truly "not," there will be no one to affirm it. Thus, right and wrong arise from contentiousness and rest in the heavenly balance. Entrust them to the twofold course and let them settle themselves.

Affirmation and negation, right and wrong—these cannot be resolved by relying on others. The world cannot correct itself; one must allow things to correct themselves. The debate over right and wrong is but the clamor of change, and such clamor, though mutually dependent, is insufficient for resolution—thus, it is as if independent. Harmonizing with nature’s divisions and following the boundless transformation, the realm of right and wrong naturally dissolves, and the subtleties of life and destiny are fully realized.

Forgetting time unifies life and death; forgetting right and wrong transcends affirmation and negation. Swept into oneness, this is the ultimate principle. The ultimate principle flows without limit, so those who lodge in it cannot be confined.

Lü Huiqing’s commentary: The world’s so-called right and wrong are merely: I affirm what you negate, you affirm what I negate; sometimes affirming, sometimes negating; or both affirming, both negating—all arising from you and me. Since neither you nor I can truly know, the question of right and wrong remains ultimately unresolved.

Man is inherently shaped by his encounters—who then can correct him? Yet correction itself comes from man. If a man is not identical to oneself, he must be identical to another; if not different from oneself, he must differ from another. If not identical to both oneself and another, he must differ from both. This yields no more than four possibilities, yet none can truly correct him—thus, neither oneself, another, nor any man can truly know one another.

Does this depend on the other? The text says it does not. Only the sage understands this truth: though the interplay of transformation and sound appears dependent, it is as if independent. Then, right and wrong find no counterpart and rest in the equilibrium of heaven.

Why say this? Right and wrong have no inherent reality; they arise merely from the emergence of sound through transformation. Whether oneself and another are interdependent or not depends on the delusions of the discriminating mind. If one harmonizes with the natural boundary and does not engage in distinctions, follows the boundless unfolding, and responds to things by letting them grow, then the myriad things do not burden the heart.

To exhaust the years is to merge ten thousand ages into a single, undifferentiated whole. The absence of debate over "is" and "is not," "so" and "not so" arises from recognizing their shared essence—all things are thus. To exhaust the years is to forget time; to be free of right and wrong is to forget distinctions. It begins in the boundless and thus ends in the boundless.

Lin Yidu’s annotation: Zhuangzi further seeks to forget words, hence this discourse. Suppose you and I debate until it seems I am indeed wrong—he constructs arguments to dispel it. If I prevail over you, or you do not prevail over me, whom shall we ask to judge? This dispels what was already dispelled. If one identical to another judges, it amounts to being identical to both oneself and another—how then can it be judged? This dispelling, dispelled again, reaches the point where nothing remains to be dispelled—this is its ultimate refinement.

Words of "is" are not necessarily true; words of "so" are not necessarily so. Thus, their differences and similarities are equally undebatable. "So" and "is" oppose each other, yet both are subject to debate. There are those that transform, those that transform transformation, those that produce sound, and those that produce the sound of sound. The transformation of the transformer is not manifest without sound; the sound of the sounder is not evident without transformation. Transformation is the essence of sound; sound is the function of transformation—this is the interdependence of transformation and sound.

Yet sound emerges from transformation, which cannot know it. Transformation encompasses sound, which cannot recognize it. This is why they appear independent. Interdependence arises from two things; if all transformations are united as one, the path of interdependence cannot arise.

Sound is constant sound, not dependent on things to become sound—hearers merely generate hearing in response to things. Transformation is constant transformation, not dependent on sound to become transformation—observers merely generate understanding in response to sound. This is why they are interdependent yet appear independent.

As for the transformer of transformation, it is not transformed by transformation; the sounder of sound is not sounded by sound—what then is there of interdependence or independence?

Harmonizing with the root of life and destiny, following the residue of change and transformation, the years of past and present may be exhausted, yet that which constitutes the self is neither ancient nor modern and knows no limit.

Chen Xiangdao’s annotation: The "natural boundary" is the origin of life and destiny. "Boundless unfolding" is the endless flux of change.
