Harmonizing with the natural boundary and following the boundless unfolding, things and self are not obscured by right and wrong but each fulfills its allotted portion of life and destiny—this is what it means to exhaust the years.

To forget time is to unite life and death as one continuum; to forget distinctions is to merge affirmation and negation into a single thread. Life and death, affirmation and negation are inherently boundless—yet to know the one who forgets, how could one regard it as something substantial? It is merely lodged there.

Chen Bixu’s annotation: To awaken is to cease disputation; to dispute is to fail to awaken. Endless contention leaves no clarity, no convergence—only mutual distrust. When water is clear, it mirrors beauty and ugliness; when the heart is empty, it equalizes sameness and difference. If the center lacks mastery, one depends on externals, becoming a wanderer swept along by things.

From Jizi’s view, Bigan appears foolish; from Bigan’s view, Jizi seems base. From Guan [Zhong] and Yan [Ying]’s view, Boyi and Shuqi seem clever; from Boyi and Shuqi’s view, Guan and Yan seem gluttonous. Their choices clash, their desires diverge—who can set them right? Yet birds nest in trees, beasts rest in dens, each content in its own place—who says they are not equal?

For emotions of self and other are mutually dependent, just as disputes over right and wrong are echoes of transformation. If emotions do not depend on one another, where do self and other arise? If disputes lack right and wrong, where do echoes of transformation come from? Thus, empty the heart to harmonize with natural boundaries, and employ marvelous function to release stagnation—this is how one exhausts heaven’s years without entanglement in right and wrong. To exhaust heaven’s years is to forget time; to be free of right and wrong is to forget distinctions. Only then can one soar into the boundless.

With inexhaustible things and limitless principles, one merely lodges within the inexhaustible and limitless.

Zhao Xuqi’s annotation: Self-realized learning is difficult to express to others. Once spoken, debates arise—who can adjudicate them? Confucius said, *"No one understands me!"* and later, *"Is it only Heaven that understands me?"*—this is the same sentiment. Echoes of transformation depend on one another, like the chick’s peck and the mother’s tap occurring simultaneously.

Harmonizing with the natural boundary and following boundless unfolding is to blend one’s light and merge with the dust. Whether something *is* or *is not*, *so* or *not so*—none can be definitively disputed. Thus, when the whole world fails to understand and speech brings no resolution, it is because echoes of transformation do not depend on one another. In such cases, one should merely blend light with dust and delight in heaven’s years—why insist on clamorous argument?

To forget time and forget distinctions is to consign this life and this principle to oblivion. The Creator’s work is endless; we too become endless with it.

*The Common Studio’s Oral Exegesis* states: Victory and defeat do not determine right and wrong, so you and I, in our disputations, cannot truly know one another. Obscured by darkness, neither your vision nor mine is clear—who then can set us right? To argue in agreement with the other is impossible; to argue in agreement with oneself is also impossible. To argue in a way neither agrees with you nor me is impossible, just as arguing in a way that agrees with both is impossible. Thus, none of the three can truly know one another—one must depend on *that*.

*That* refers to the transformations of creation, the so-called "natural boundary." The act of harmonizing is simply to follow *this*. Whether *is* or *is not*, *so* or *not so*—both are preserved. If one insists on affirming *this* as *so* and *right*, then *not so* and *not right* arise, and disputes over right and wrong ensue.

"Echoes of transformation" refer to using words to convert and subdue. "Dependence" means opposition. If one opposes with right and wrong, with words, seeking to convert and subdue, how is this better than following what *is* without opposition? Thus it is said: If they do not depend on or oppose one another but instead seek unity, this is harmonizing with the natural boundary and roaming boundlessly to exhaust the years. In this way, one forgets both time and principle.

To stir and dance in the realm of nothingness—this "stirring" also conveys the meaning of *xiaoyaoyou* (carefree wandering). If one can truly be thus, one lodges for a lifetime in the realm of nothingness.

When right and wrong, victory and defeat each cling to one side and cannot correct one another, then you, I, and others all fail to know one another—must we depend on *that*? It is simply to entrust it to creation.

This passage’s various explanations are thorough, yet the meaning of "echoes of transformation" remains profound and obscure. The mechanism of dependence and non-dependence is also difficult to fully express in words. Only those who exhaust the spirit and penetrate transformation can illuminate it with the heart—then the ultimate principle becomes self-evident. Among the explanations, *Duli Lun* stands the highest, forming its own school of thought and complementing the classic text in depth and surface, surpassing mere philological study.

*The Common Studio*’s discussion of "echoes of transformation" is uniquely insightful, and its theory of the "boundless" is especially profound. To put it concisely: the distinctions between life and death, waking and dreaming arise from *transformation*. The disputes between self and other, right and wrong arise from *echoes*. Waking and dreaming depend on form; right and wrong arise from emotion—thus they seem mutually dependent. Yet *transformation* transforms on its own, unaware of how it transforms. *Echoes* resound on their own, unaware of how they resound—thus they seem not to depend on one another.

In the end, the utmost principle of things cannot escape the naturalness of creation. This is the source and convergence of all transformations, the great equality of the myriad things.

The discussion of "echoes of transformation" depending on one another shares the same meaning as the dependence of form and shadow—elucidated in both earlier and later passages.

Master Lü’s later appended note states: *"The dependence of echoes of transformation... thus exhausting the years"* should properly precede *"What does it mean to harmonize with the natural boundary?"* The text’s arrangement is disordered here; the meaning makes this clear.

The Shadowy Doubt asked the Shadow: *"Earlier you were walking, now you have stopped; earlier you were sitting, now you have risen—why this lack of constancy?"*
The Shadow replied: *"Do I depend on something to be thus? Does what I depend on also depend on something to be thus? Do I depend on snake scales or cicada wings? How could I know why I am thus? How could I know why I am not thus?"*

Once, Zhuang Zhou dreamed he was a butterfly—fluttering and joyous, a butterfly content in its own nature, unaware it was Zhou. Suddenly he awoke, and there he was, palpably Zhou again. But was it Zhou dreaming he was a butterfly, or a butterfly now dreaming it is Zhou? Between Zhou and the butterfly, there must be a distinction. This is called the transformation of things.

Guo Xiang’s commentary: The *wangliang* is the faint shadow beyond the shadow, where the heavenly mechanism operates of itself. In sitting and rising, it depends on nothing; in its solitary attainment, who knows the reason? To demand what it depends on, to trace its origin, is to arrive at last at the principle of dependence on nothing and solitary transformation. If it depended on snake scales or cicada wings, the lack of constancy would not be hard to explain. What makes it unknowable is precisely that it depends on no such thing but transforms alone.

Some say the *wangliang* depends on the shadow, the shadow on form, and form on the Creator. But is there a Creator? If not, how could it create things? If so, it would not suffice to produce the myriad forms. Clearly, the myriad forms create themselves and depend on nothing—this is the true nature of creation. The *wangliang*’s reliance on the shadow is like saying they arise together, not that one depends on the other. Thus, the *wangliang* is not controlled by the shadow, nor the shadow by form. Form is not transformed by nothingness; whether things transform or not, whether they are so or not, depends on others or on themselves. How could I know the reason?

When he dreamed he was a butterfly, he did not know he was Zhou; suddenly he awoke, and there he was, palpably Zhou. From Zhou’s perspective, this is called awakening—but it is not necessarily not a dream. Now, not knowing the butterfly is no different from the dream’s not knowing Zhou: each suits its own moment’s nature. Thus, there is no way to prove the butterfly is not now dreaming it is Zhou. There are cases of feigned sleep that yield dreams spanning a hundred years—how can we prove that this hundred years is not itself a dream in feigned sleep? The distinction between waking and dreaming is no different from the debate between life and death.

What makes him content in his own nature is that his role is fixed, not that there is no distinction. Time does not pause for an instant; the present does not endure. Yesterday’s dream has already transformed by today. The changes of life and death—how are they different? Why trouble the mind over them?

Lü Huiqing’s commentary: The *wangliang* and the shadow are of the same kind, yet it does not know the shadow depends on nothing for form. Just as you and I and others are of the same kind, yet do not know we depend on nothing beyond ourselves. The shadow’s walking and stopping, sitting and rising, merely follow form—thus it has no constancy. But being without emotion, how could it know dependence? If the shadow depends on form, what does form depend on to be so? The shadow’s dependence on form is not like a snake’s dependence on its scales to slither or a cicada’s on its wings to fly. How could one know why it is so or not so?

If one understands that things are without knowledge, then even snake scales and cicada wings depend on nothing. When he was a butterfly, he fluttered joyously, unaware of Zhou; when he was Zhou again, he was dazed, unaware of the butterfly. A single body’s changes—even these it does not know. How then could things, transforming into different forms, know one another? If things do not know one another, each returns to its root. If things do not depend on one another, none finds its counterpart. Is there anything that is not equal?

Lin Yidu’s commentary: The shadow arises from form, seeming to depend on it yet not truly depending. The *wangliang*, not knowing that both form and shadow belong to creation, assumes that walking and stopping, sitting and rising, depend on form. But without the light of sun or fire, even with form, how could a shadow arise? This is what is meant by not depending. The shadow says, “What I depend on also depends on something to be so”—what the shadow depends on is form, yet form cannot be without dependence, meaning it depends on creation. The shadow’s dependence on form is already slight, and form within creation is even smaller. Thus it says, “I depend on snake scales or cicada wings,” referring to the most minute and insubstantial of things. The *Outer Chapters*’ “insect’s arm, rat’s liver” conveys the same meaning.

Zhuangzi’s use of the butterfly is to show that dreaming and waking are no longer distinct. To understand the principle of Zhuang Zhou dreaming he was a butterfly is to exhaust the theory of life and death. Dreaming he was a butterfly, he did not know he was Zhou; waking as Zhou, he did not know he was a butterfly. There is a force that prevents their merging, and a time when they separate. The transformation of the myriad things is like this.

Chen Xiangdao’s commentary: The *wangliang* exists only after the shadow, the shadow appears only after form, and form is born only after creation. Form’s relation to creation is already illusory—how much more the shadow? The shadow’s relation to form is already external—how much more the *wangliang*? None of these are truly real, so they are not worth debating. To take what is not truly real as real, and then to question what is not worth debating—this is why Zhuangzi uses the shadow’s answer to dispel the doubt.

From the perspective of self-narration, the things of the world never fail to depend on one another; from the perspective of principle, they never begin to depend. If the shadow is a thing that depends on form—without sun or fire, it would not be seen. If it depends on sun or fire—without form, it would not exist. Then are form, shadow, sun, and fire truly dependent? Or without dependence? How could one know why they are so or not so? Snake scales and cicada wings refer to their minor uses. Those who awaken to the Dao grasp the substance and not the flower; those who are deluded by things grasp the flower and not the substance. The butterfly is a thing that grasps the flower; yet Zhou dreamed of it—this is to seek the Dao yet not escape the thought of things, to grasp the substance yet not escape the dream of the flower. When he awoke, he no longer allowed thought to burden his spirit or dreams to replace reality. Thus, Zhou and the butterfly were indeed distinct.

Only those who fully comprehend the transformations of things and the essence of change may partake in this discourse.

Chen Bixu’s annotation: The shadow does not depend on form, nor does form depend on yin and yang—how could they be compared to the molted skins of snakes or the cast shells of cicadas, which are mere things? Among all interdependent phenomena, none are so closely bound as form and shadow; yet even here, one speaks of their non-dependence, making clear that external things cannot be interlocked, for all things in the myriad realms are self-so. Only when all dependencies are utterly forgotten, standing alone in solitary transformation, may one discuss transcending life and death to return to primordial undifferentiation. This is what is called the "suspended liberation of the Emperor."

The natures of Zhou and the butterfly are but the wondrous existence of a single qi. Once, as a butterfly, it was Zhou’s dream; now, as Zhou again, is it not the butterfly’s dream? Though the distinction between Zhou and the butterfly differs, the wondrous qi of their existence is one. The mechanism of creation is subtle and unfathomable; if one could grasp this, then creation would reside within oneself and not be subject to external things. This is what is meant by "that which gives life does not live, that which transforms does not change." Once having become a thing, how could it not transform? The shift between death and life, the migration of forms—all is encompassed in the dream of the Painted Garden. Its principle is exhausted therein.

Zhao Xuzhai’s annotation: The shadow’s movement, stillness, sitting, and rising all depend on form; yet that which enables movement, stillness, sitting, and rising must have something that forms form within it. The snake relies on its ventral scales to move, the cicada on its wings to fly; yet what enables their movement and flight is not the scales or wings. Every motion and stillness of humans and things arises from dependence. The shadow depends on form, but what form depends on is not form itself. If even form does not know why it is so, how can one demand an explanation from the shadow? Thus, in Zhuang Zhou and the butterfly, self and other are both transformed, fluttering and wandering—waking and dreaming become as one.

*The Yongzhai Commentary* states: The shadow speaks of my movement, which depends on form, and form in turn depends on the Creator’s shaping of form—just as the snake’s scales and cicada’s wings. Once the snake and cicada have molted, their scales and wings remain, yet can they move on their own? I depend on form, and form depends on another—how can one know why things are so or not so? This is the metaphor of non-dependence on the other. Once, Zhou dreamed of the butterfly without knowing he was Zhou; upon waking as Zhou, was it not the butterfly’s dream? Yet this waking and dreaming must have a distinction; here, the text seems to conclude yet does not, refusing to state it plainly, precisely to prompt inquiry at this point. This is called "transformation of things," meaning the principle of the myriad things’ change is no more than this. The snake’s scales and cicada’s wings—some say they refer to molted shells, but the interpretation of "clinging scales and wings" is superior. For the snake relies on them to move, the cicada on them to fly, illustrating that what enables movement in the human body seems dependent yet ultimately is without dependence, thus clarifying the principle of solitary transformation. Therefore, the text repeatedly discusses this, ultimately returning to non-dependence, focusing on the individual. Hearing with the ears, seeing with the eyes, grasping with the hands, walking with the feet—all arise from dependence. Yet that which employs form seems to depend on the Creator but is in truth without dependence.

All things under heaven are born from being, and being is born from non-being. Being is for utility, non-being is for function. Thus, being and non-being, utility and function, are never without mutual generation. If one can reverse inquiry to the wondrousness of ultimate non-being and wander at the origin of things, then one will understand how being arises and how form is employed. Now, with form for movement and a mind for thought, one still does not know what governs them—then how can the shadow’s generation from form be known by the penumbra? No wonder confusion arises and questions are asked.

*The Parables* chapter contains the passage where the multitude of penumbras question the shadow, illustrating how the deluded in the world are many, hence the text does not address it uniformly. It states: "You are the cicada’s shell. The snake is its molt." This aligns with the meaning of scales and wings here. The original text once said: "The true person of old did not dream in sleep," yet Master Nanhua himself spoke of dreaming as a butterfly—why? It is to borrow waking and dreaming to establish the unity of life and death. Not knowing death while alive is like not knowing life while dead; though the two do not know each other, their principle is fundamentally the same. If one observes this through waking and dreaming, the nest will be visible. Why should one worry about death while alive or envy life while dead?

The butterfly, as a creature, has no nest-building toil, no hunger or thirst to rest from; it flutters and dances, roaming freely between heaven and earth. Those who see it delight in its self-contentment and do it no harm. Its generation is unrelated to species—often it transforms from other insects or arises from rotting wheat.

The *Zhile* chapter records that the root of the crow’s-foot plant becomes a *ji’ao* grub, while its leaves transform into butterflies—thus they too emerge from the transformation of plants, their origin unfathomable and their end equally unknown. Such are the Dao-attainers amidst the fluttering and flying, and thus the perfected sometimes dream of them. Man and things, though their forms diverge into many kinds, all receive their nature from spontaneity. Spontaneity is the subtlety of the supreme Dao, the foundation upon which the ten thousand transformations stand. Thus Zhuangzi’s butterfly dream and waking, though each knows not the other, ultimately return to transformation—there is no difference between them. We come to know that the ten thousand forms of movement and stillness, the ten thousand changes of life and death, the sentient and the insentient, all ultimately equalize in transformation. Transformation is the beginning and end of form and number, the egress and ingress of the ten thousand kinds, driven by the Creator’s arrangement. The bold and strong cannot resist it; things receive their carving and polishing, their forms return to the mold—unaware of the *how* yet thus it is. Therefore the enlightened surrender and follow it. Thus waking and dreaming merge, life and death become one.

Yet Zhou (Zhuangzi) and the butterfly must have their distinction—this distinction is the Heaven of things. Though each thing has its own Heaven, they fundamentally share the same Heaven. If one reads *fen* (distinction) literally, distinctions multiply endlessly, and how could the principle of the world’s things achieve unity and transformation with them? If there remains an untransformed element, viewing life and death as waking and dreaming, regarding past and present as morning and evening—then what things could be equalized, and what room would there be for discourse?

Yet Zhuangzi and the butterfly, dream and waking, have already been discussed—there must be those who understand. *Mencius* says: “The inequality of things is the nature of things.” Yet Zhuangzi titles his chapter *The Equality of Things*—some suspect this contradicts the Confucians, further emphasizing the inequality of natures. They fail to consider that Mencius spoke only for Xuzi’s sake. Moreover, what Mencius addressed was *qing* (nature/feeling), while what Zhuangzi addressed was *li* (principle). When principle is one but its manifestations are many, the inequality of natures is fitting. Thus Nanhua (Zhuangzi) originally pursued the ultimate, taking one principle to equalize the world’s discourses on things.

At the chapter’s outset, he sets up a dialogue between two masters, elaborating on the inequality of human and earthly *lai* (pipings), to clarify the spontaneity of Heaven’s *lai*—not only does principle not await equalization, but equalization does not reach it. Thus, through side proofs and oblique references, he does not directly name Heaven’s *lai*, desiring that the mind契合 and grasp it naturally. The myriad living things, red and profuse, undergo ten thousand changes of flourishing and withering, each with its own form and color, each with its own dissolution and rest—ultimately returning to Heaven’s *lai* and stopping there. Heaven’s *lai* is without form or sound, yet the source from which form and sound arise, the manifestation of divine transformation.

If one thoroughly investigates the origins of the multitudinous workings of human and earthly *lai*, then Heaven’s *lai* may be known. Thus Guo Xiang’s commentary states: “Is there yet another thing? It is simply the myriad apertures, like bamboo joined to the realm of the living, converging to form one Heaven.” As for knowing words, waking and dreaming, the completed mind, the affirmation and negation of speech, the arising and perishing of right and wrong—these differ not from the myriad apertures roaring in fury. Yet when one attains the center of the ring to respond to the inexhaustible, then emptiness awaits things, and things are without obstruction. This is forgetting and that transforming of itself—what the wind achieves when apertures are empty.

“Heaven and earth are one finger; the ten thousand things are one horse”—this is equalizing the unequal. Vast, forgotten, strange, and wondrous, the Dao unites them as one, equalizing without awaiting equalization. As for the monkey-keeper’s distribution of chestnuts, the joy and anger that arise therefrom, and Zhaowen’s zither playing with its gains and losses—these illustrate that having a mind and acting are insufficient to transform things, so how can one hope for equalization? Only when “Heaven and earth and I are born together, and the ten thousand things and I are one” can one speak of equalization! Yet one fears that some may take one and words as two, two and one as three—this is the omen of scattering and inequality.

Only by reaching the state before things ever began, pouring from the inexhaustible, knowing the great dream through great awakening, and unifying the ten thousand years into one pure whole—this is the way to grasp the world’s things and equalize them. The shadow’s attendant asks the shadow, not knowing that difference lies in waiting. Nanhua’s butterfly dream—who can fathom whether it is sameness or difference? Thus he exhaustively discusses the inequality of self and things, life and death, waking and dreaming, yet ultimately returns to the transformation of things. What Nanhua calls *hua* (transformation) is what the *Great Change* calls *shen* (spirit) latent in the indistinct; it appears in daily use yet cannot be known through knowledge.

From this, one awakens: the ten thousand things are one form, the ten thousand forms are one transformation, the ten thousand transformations are one spirit. When spirit is illuminated and transformation is penetrated—who is the thing, and who am I? This is called the great equalization. *The Profound Meaning of the Nanhua True Scripture*, Scroll Four ends.

*According to Zhao Lian’s proposal, the character ‘飘’ should be added. ‘木’ is a corruption of ‘本.’*
*The Profound Meaning of the Nanhua True Scripture*, Scroll Five
By Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin

**Inner Chapters: The Main Principle of Nurturing Life, First**

Our life has limits, but knowledge is without bounds.
To pursue the boundless with the limited is perilous;
and to persist in such pursuit is perilous indeed.

In doing good, do not seek fame;
in doing evil, do not court punishment.
Follow the central course as your guiding principle—
thus may you preserve the body,
perfect life,
nurture your kin,
and fulfill your years.

**Guo Xiang’s Commentary:**
Life has limits, for one’s allotment is finite.
To lift the heavy while grasping the light is bounded by one’s strength.
Those who crave victory may strain their sinews to the utmost,
yet their desires remain unfulfilled—such is the boundlessness of knowledge.
The name of knowledge arises from imbalance
and vanishes into profound extremity.
Profound extremity means following one’s allotted measure
without the slightest excess.
Though bearing a weight of ten thousand *jun*,
one may suddenly forget its heaviness upon the body;
though responding to ten thousand affairs,
one may obliviously forget their presence within oneself.
This is the main principle of nurturing life.
If one uses finite life to chase boundless knowledge,
how can one not become exhausted?
Having exhausted oneself, to then seek knowledge as a remedy
is to harm one’s true nature while attempting to nurture it—
great peril indeed.
One must forget good and evil and abide in the center,
letting the ten thousand things act of themselves,
merging obscurely with what is most fitting.
Thus, punishment and fame remain distant,
while the integrity of principle resides within.
For one who can take the central course as constant,
every affair becomes a means of nurturing life.
Not seeking excess, one fully realizes principle and fulfills one’s years.

**Lü Huiqing’s Commentary:**
Life follows form and thus has an end;
knowledge pursues things and thus is endless.
To let life follow knowledge is perilous indeed.
To persist in such pursuit is perilous to the end.
When all under heaven know beauty as beauty, ugliness arises;
when all know goodness as goodness, un-goodness arises.
Good and evil both arise from knowledge—
how far apart are they?
Only by not upholding the conduct of benevolence and righteousness to seek fame above,
nor indulging in depravity and perversion to court punishment below,
abandoning both good and evil and following what cannot be otherwise as one’s constant—
this is to still the mind, relinquish knowledge,
and rest in the Dao of unknowing.
What more could be added to preserving the body,
perfecting life,
nurturing one’s kin,
and fulfilling one’s years?

**Lin Yidu’s Commentary:**
What has form cannot be prolonged by yin and yang;
what is formless cannot be exhausted by fate’s reckoning.
Thus, to pursue boundless knowledge with finite life is perilous indeed.
When true nature is rent, good and evil arise;
when good and evil are established, fame and punishment follow.
To do good without seeking fame is the true good of all under heaven.
To do evil without courting punishment is the true evil of all under heaven.
Only by following the natural tendencies of life and destiny
without diminishing or adding,
merging with the ten thousand things without harm or praise—
then punishment and fame cannot reach one.
The reason fame for goodness exists is that it is established by those who fall short.
The reason fame for evil exists is that it is born of excess.
Some lightly regard life and rush toward righteousness to seek fleeting fame;
some value life and chase profit, only to perish midway—
these are what is meant by "good that seeks fame" and "evil that courts punishment,"
not the following of life’s natural tendencies by removing what is excessive.
**Chen Xiangdao’s Commentary:**
Those who skillfully nurture life take the self as master within
and external things as guests.
Not pursuing the boundless with the limited, one avoids peril.
Moving from the heart without violating what is naturally desired—
the joys of the present body are not to be forsaken.
Thus, one is not swayed by fame.
Roaming in accord with one’s nature,
not opposing what the ten thousand things desire—
posthumous fame is not to be sought.
Thus, one is not reached by punishment.
Following the central course in response,
arising only when unavoidable,
taking this as constant without excess—
then within oneself, there is no conflict with things,
and in others, there is no harm to oneself.
Thus may one preserve the body and nurture one’s kin,
perfect life and fulfill one’s years.
The *Book of Changes* says:
"Goodness not accumulated is insufficient to establish fame;
evil not accumulated is insufficient to destroy the body."
Thus, doing good is never without proximity to fame,
and doing evil is never without proximity to punishment.
Yet when Zhuangzi speaks of this,
his "good" is not apart from the Dao—
it is merely what lies within one’s allotment.
His "evil" is not a transgression of principle—
it is merely different from good.
Laozi said to Nanrong Chu:
"Your centrality still brims with what you deem evil."
The "evil" he speaks of is like this—
thus his "good" may be known.

**Chen Bixu’s Commentary:**
Longevity and early death are the limits of life.
Vast learning is the boundlessness of knowledge.
What is granted by heaven is profound and unknowable;
what is done by humans is laborious and rife with flaws.
Thus, the main principle of life’s pattern lies in skillful nurturing.
Yet some prize fame and chase profit, never resting,
ever increasing artifice to the detriment of their lives,
until peril is all that remains.
The goodness of self-preservation lies in not seeking fame—
this means guarding simplicity with minimal change,
like the people of Hanyin.
The evil of self-harm lies in not courting punishment—
this means sinking into indulgence,
like the followers of Gongsun Chao and Mu.
To neither do good nor do evil,
to take the central course as constant—
this is the middle way of the sage,
which can preserve the body,
perfect life,
nurture one’s kin,
and fulfill one’s years.
This is the main principle of what gives rise to life.

**Zhao Xuzhai’s Commentary:**
From youth to prime, from prime to old age,
from old age to death—
this is the finitude of life.
Weaving through ten thousand affairs,
enduring from ancient times to the present—
this is the boundlessness of knowledge.
Yet people, deluded by false knowledge, toil endlessly,
believing they know peril.
Life has an end, and knowledge too has an end—
when form transforms, the heart follows.
Can this not be called great sorrow?
In the world, doing good brings endless praise;
doing evil brings endless blame.
Boyi died for fame, Robber Zhi died for profit—
though what they died for differed,
the harm to life and injury to nature were the same.
Evil is certainly not to be done,
but neither must good be done—
for to do so is to act with intention.
One should only follow the central course as one’s guiding principle.

The Governing Vessel is the center. Before joy, anger, sorrow, or delight arise, its response to things issues wholly from the spontaneity of nature, and what manifests externally is precisely this center. To follow nature is called the Dao—this is the meaning of "tracing the Governing Vessel as one’s guiding principle."

Among the eight extraordinary vessels, the central channel is the Governing Vessel. Lin’s *Yongzhai Oral Exegesis* states: "To make a finite body follow endless thoughts—when will such restless turmoil cease?" "Perilous" describes its dreadful danger; yet even amid peril, one applies mental calculation, believing oneself to be wise—only to end in peril nonetheless.

The passage "Do good without seeking fame, and you may fulfill your allotted years" is precisely the learning of the life-nurturing school, which Zhuangzi himself practiced. If one does good, there is no deed of fame-seeking to be praised; if one does evil, there is no criminal act to be pointed out—this is the conduct described in the "Webbed Toes" chapter: "Above, one dares not practice the seven virtues; below, one dares not commit perverse acts." Respond only when pressed, and respond without intention; make this one’s constant way, and one may preserve the body, fulfill life, nurture one’s kin, and complete one’s years—this is what Mencius meant by "whether long-lived or short-lived, one does not waver, but cultivates oneself and awaits destiny."

Chu’s *Personal Insights* states: The *Inner Chapters* begin with the "Free and Easy Wandering," the learning of fulfilling nature, to clarify the Dao. Next comes the "Discussion on Making All Things Equal," discourse on exhausting principle, to respond to transformation. Then follows the "Essentials of Nurturing Life," the essentials of preserving destiny, to cultivate the self. Thus, the opening argument warns that to make the finite follow the infinite is to let life take its natural course without the calamity of premature death. To return to the state before knowledge and revert to the ultimate undifferentiated darkness is to remove the harms that afflict the body—what peril could then remain? If one truly can do this, then one follows the world’s good and calls it good, follows the world’s evil and calls it evil; though one acts, it is as if one does not act—what encumbrance of fame-seeking or punishment could there be?

When people conduct themselves and engage with the world, there are good and evil acts they ought to perform. As for sages and worthies, who bear the weight of the world, uphold the moral order, and sustain living beings, there is even more they cannot but do regarding good and evil. Reward one person, and the world is encouraged; punish one person, and the world is admonished. Let the world’s likes and dislikes guide the world’s rewards and punishments—like the movement of heaven and earth, spring and summer give life and growth without claiming favor, autumn and winter bring sternness and decay without incurring resentment. For heaven and earth act without intention: cold and heat move of themselves, things grow and mature of themselves, things wither and decay of themselves—this is simply the way of the seasons, with no personal favor or resentment involved.

If Yi’s skill in hitting the mark is subtle yet clumsy in concealment, this is the good of fame-seeking. If one can be like a flying tile that strikes a person without provoking blame, then one avoids the nearness of punishment.

These two lines embody the meaning of the *Daodejing*’s "establishing virtue as if negligent." Some commentaries cite the sayings "goodness not accumulated is insufficient to make a name" and "evil not accumulated is insufficient to destroy the self" as proof—yet this is *acting* in a way that draws near to fame and punishment. Others cite "above, one dares not practice the conduct of benevolence and righteousness; below, one dares not engage in licentious and perverse deeds"—yet this is *not acting* in a way that avoids fame and punishment. Though the phrasing may seem similar, the meaning is fundamentally different. The present text’s intent is that what the common world calls good and evil is private and bounded, merely revealing its pettiness. What the sages and worthies call good and evil is impartial and without contention, acting through non-action. How could shallow understanding ever glimpse this?

Consider how the Four Fiends’ evil led Emperor Yao to remove them, how Jie and Zhou’s evil led Tang and Wu to exile them, and how Shaozheng Mao’s evil led the Master to execute him—thus the good and evil of the sages and worthies becomes clear. To do good or evil and draw near to fame or punishment, or to refrain from good or evil and remain without fame or punishment, are both the natural course of principle. Yet now, to act without drawing near to fame or punishment—this is what the common world sees as good or evil, while the hearts of sages and worthies ever accord with the central Way, aligning with the spontaneity of Heaven’s principle. Thus, profit and harm cannot reach them, and this is where the Dao and its virtue return.

The character *du* (督) glosses *zhong* (centrality), referring to the state before joy, anger, sorrow, and pleasure arise—not merely the midpoint between good and evil. If, in the moment before the seven emotions stir, one follows this as the constant Way, then emptiness, clarity, numinous penetration, and freedom from attachment arise. I and the Great Ultimate become one undifferentiated whole—how then could one know whether the body is preservable, life is whole, or kin are nurtured?

How can one exhaust the years? Master Guo glossed *du* (督) as "centrality" (*zhong* 中) but failed to clarify its meaning. Later, I obtained Xu Zhai’s precise and apt citations. Indeed, every human body possesses the *du mai* (督脉, Governor Vessel), which runs along the center of the spine, penetrating above and below, and is paired with the *ren mai* (壬脉, Conception Vessel)—this is where the root of life resides. Few who are not adept in the arts of nourishing life can fully fathom this. Thus, the seam down the center of a robe’s back is also called *du*, as noted in the *Liji* commentary on the *Shenyi*. When Pao Ding butchered an ox for Lord Wenhui, wherever his hand touched, shoulder leaned, foot pressed, or knee braced, the sounds of slicing and parting resounded in perfect harmony, matching the rhythm of the *Sanglin* dance and the cadence of the *Jingshou* melody. Lord Wenhui exclaimed, "Ah! How excellent! Has skill truly reached such heights?"

Pao Ding laid down his knife and replied, "What your servant delights in is the Dao, which transcends mere skill. When I first began butchering oxen, all I saw was the whole ox. After three years, I no longer saw the ox in its entirety. Now, I encounter it with spirit rather than sight; my senses halt while my spirit moves. Following Heaven’s principle, I cleave through the great gaps, guide the blade through the great cavities, and proceed according to its inherent structure. I have never touched the tendons or ligaments, much less the great bones! A good butcher changes his knife once a year, for he cuts; an ordinary butcher changes his knife every month, for he hacks. My knife has lasted nineteen years, dissecting thousands of oxen, yet its edge remains as if freshly whetted. For where the joints have spaces, and the blade has no thickness, inserting the thicknessless into the spaced allows ample room for the blade to glide—thus, after nineteen years, its edge is still as if newly sharpened. Nevertheless, whenever I encounter a complex joint, I perceive the difficulty, grow cautious, focus my gaze, slow my movements, and wield the knife with utmost care. Suddenly, the ox falls apart like a clod of earth. I stand holding the knife, look around in satisfaction, then wipe it clean and put it away."

Lord Wenhui said, "Excellent! From Pao Ding’s words, I have learned how to nourish life."

**Guo’s Commentary:**
From "wherever his hand touched" to "matching the cadence of the *Jingshou* melody," this describes how he applied skill with ease, effortlessly parting the ox, aligning with its natural structure while harmonizing with rhythm—directly embodying the Dao in his craft, for what he delighted in was not mere skill. "All I saw was the whole ox" means he did not yet perceive the spaces within its structure. "I no longer saw the ox in its entirety" means he saw only those spaces. "Encountering it with spirit rather than sight" refers to meeting the principle without reliance on the eyes. "My senses halt while my spirit moves" means the faculties of perception cease, allowing the mind to follow the principle freely. "Following Heaven’s principle" means not forcing arbitrary cuts. "Cleaving through the great gaps" means separating where there are divisions. "Guiding the blade through the great cavities" means directing it through the empty spaces. "Proceeding according to its inherent structure" means the knife does not act recklessly, gliding through emptiness without ever encountering the slightest obstruction. Thus, after nineteen years, the blade remains as if newly whetted. "Whenever I encounter a complex joint" refers to the entangled and clustered parts; he halts his gaze, slows his movements, and wields the knife with utmost care. Suddenly, the ox is dismembered, its structure parted without trace of the blade, like scattered earth. At ease and self-content, he wipes the knife clean and puts it away—just as the knife is preserved through skillful use, so too is life preserved through skillful nourishment.

**Lü’s Commentary:**
Things are obstructed by their solidity, while the Dao flows through emptiness. Before one hears the Dao, all one sees are things; after hearing the Dao, all one sees is the Dao. "Encountering it with spirit rather than sight" illustrates how one who has heard the Dao grasps it with the heart rather than through sensory knowledge. "My senses halt while my spirit moves" and "following Heaven’s principle" to "the great bones" all describe how he no longer saw the ox in its entirety. Nothing in the world is not the Dao, and nowhere does it not flow freely—this is the principle at work. "All I saw was the whole ox" is a metaphor for those who change their knives and harm life. "After nineteen years, its edge remains as if newly whetted" is a metaphor for not harming life. In its form, the ox has never been a solid whole—does this not resemble the spaces between its joints? In its life, it has never been truly alive—does this not resemble the thicknessless edge of the blade? In its gliding, there is always ample room—does this not resemble one who embodies the Dao and roams among the ten thousand things? Nevertheless, "whenever I encounter a complex joint," I perceive the difficulty—this is where one must be cautious, for what humans fear cannot be taken lightly. Growing wary, focusing the gaze, slowing the movements, and finally wiping the knife clean to put it away—this is to be as careful at the end as at the beginning, ensuring no failure. Thus, one preserves life without harm.

**Yi Duzhu’s Commentary:**
The ox is a metaphor for the principle of life and destiny, while the knife represents life itself. By following the principle of life and destiny without contrivance, life unfolds naturally. Proceeding according to its constant principle, one harmonizes with the five notes and unites with music and dance. *Sanglin* is the music of Tang; *Jingshou* is the music of Yao. "Matching" refers to the harmony of sound and dance. Pao Ding claimed to lodge the subtlety of the Dao in the coarse craft of butchery—what he delighted in was not mere skill. At first, "all I saw was the whole ox" because he relied on sight. Later, "I no longer saw the ox in its entirety" because he encountered it with spirit. Now, relying solely on spiritual encounter rather than sight, the inner sinews, bones, and skin all become mysteriously aligned. As *Laozi* says, "Abandon sagacity and discard knowledge"—this refers to the halting of the senses. As the *Yijing* says, "Not hasty yet swift"—this refers to the movement of spirit. Following the principle of spontaneity, where there are great divisions, he cleaves them apart; where there are great cavities, he guides the blade through. All this proceeds according to its inherent structure—how could it involve forced, private skill? Thus, the tendons and minor obstructions were never touched—how much less the great, twisted bones? Though the good butcher and the ordinary butcher differ in the frequency of changing knives, both ultimately harm the blade—just as all ultimately harm life.

The common butcher speaks of the many, the skilled butcher speaks of the few, while the Cook Ding speaks of the singular—this is the divine butcher, is it not? With the blade of no thickness entering the spaces that exist, his edge remains as if newly whetted after nineteen years.

The common butcher, encountering the knotted joints of bone and flesh, sees only the difficulty of wielding the knife and must proceed with caution. His gaze halts, his movements slow—this is like the subtlety of life and destiny, where nurturing is even more difficult. When he lifts the knife and looks around, full of confidence, the ox is dissolved to the point where there is no longer any "dissolving." Honing the blade and storing it away, one understands that the perfected person acts only when unavoidable, then retreats to concealment in the profound.

The *Daode* commentary states: Those who rely on sight see only the object and not the principle; what they see is nothing but the ox. Those who encounter with spirit see the principle and not the object; they have never seen the whole ox. What they see is nothing but principle, and so with a blade of no thickness they enter the existing spaces, moving with effortless ease.

Is the Way of nurturing life different from this? The mind must be empty, not full; one must respond to things with compliance, not opposition. In ease, one meets it with appropriateness, no different from the resonance of sound; in difficulty, one handles it with care, no different from the stillness of caution. In success, one examines the path and considers the omens, no different from lifting the knife and looking around; in the end, one preserves wholeness and returns, no different from honing the blade and storing it away.

The masterful butcher, though he dissolves many, never touches the blade. The masterful responder to things, though he encounters much, never harms life.

The *Bixu* commentary states: With clear perception, one grasps principle; with consummate skill, one hits the mark. Cook Ding had long studied the Way of nurturing life and merely used his craft as a means of advancement. At first, he saw the ox and not the principle; later, he saw the principle and not the ox. Encountering with spirit rather than sight, he governed the internal by dismissing the external. The senses halted, the spirit moved—seeing and hearing were not through the ears and eyes. Following the principle of nature, he achieved a mysterious alignment, cleaving apart the great divisions and guiding the blade through the great cavities, moving freely in the void. He never touched the minor obstructions of tendons, much less the great, twisted bones! Thus, after nineteen years, his blade remained as if newly whetted. His knife moved with such subtlety that the ox was dissolved with a whisper—unaware even of its death.

The butcher, observing the empty spaces, dances the blade with consummate skill to preserve its wholeness. How could one who nurtures life fail to withdraw into deep seclusion, preserve the body without loss, and maintain the integrity of Heaven’s truth?

Li Shibiao’s discourse states: Things are fundamentally no-things; their essence naturally separates. The Dao is unobstructed—where is there need for dissolution? What Zhuangzi calls "dissolving the ox" is to separate from things and empty the mind so that one never sees the ox, to ride the void and follow the principle so that one never touches the blade—this is dissolution within non-dissolution.

Nineteen years is not a short time in the cycle of yin and yang; dissolving thousands of oxen is not a small number in responding to the changes of worldly affairs. Yet his blade remained as if newly whetted because, while traces shift in an instant, grasping the root ensures that the ancient and the present never depart. The self is but an illusion—what knife is there to wield? The myriad things are all delusions—what ox is there to dissolve? When self and things are forgotten, subject and object vanish. Thus, without cleaving, the great divisions naturally separate; without guiding, the great cavities naturally open. The knife moves with effortless grace, free from the labor of responding to things; when set down, it bears no burden of lingering attachments. In the end, honing the blade and storing it away returns one to non-use.

Viewed through the Dao, dissolution is non-dissolution; what is not an obstruction is dissolved, yet one does not know whether it is an obstruction or not—what is not dissolved becomes an obstruction. One does not compare Cook Ding to the common butcher, for the solver dissolves the obstruction; nor does one compare the common butcher to Cook Ding, for the obstructed obstructs the dissolution. When both dissolution and obstruction are dismissed, there is only emptiness. Roaming beyond the myriad things with this Dao, what could ever obstruct one?

Zhao’s commentary states: Cook Ding’s dissolution of the ox, his advances and retreats, his circling and turning, all harmonized with rhythm. The ox’s meridians and channels all converged at the head, and when the butcher’s blade struck precisely at this convergence, the hundred bones instantly fell apart. This is what elicited the astonishment of Lord Wenhui. Ding further explained that his skill had advanced to the level of the Dao. In difficult places, he was always cautious and fearful, his mind at rest, his gaze alert, his movements halting, his actions slow, ever wary of the slightest damage to his blade. Thus, after nineteen years, it remained as if newly whetted. For others, within a year or two, the blade would either chip or break. This is the way of one who nurtures life well.

The *Yongzhai Oral Exegesis* states: "Playing the blade" refers to the advance and use of the knife. "In harmony with sound" means it accords with the pitch-pipes. *Sanglin* and *Jingshou* are both names of musical compositions. "Never seeing the whole ox" means that the ox’s body, though divisible, is perceived through a single perspective. "Spiritual encounter" is akin to "mental communion." "The senses cease" means that ears and eyes perceive nothing, yet the unspoken spirit moves of itself, following the ox’s natural grain and the hollows of its bones and joints—all inherently so. I merely dissolve it accordingly. In wielding the blade, I never traverse the spaces between flesh and bone, much less the great bones. The difference between a skilled butcher and an ordinary one lies in how often they must replace their knives, yet both inevitably suffer damage. Here, after nineteen years, the blade remains as if newly whetted—this speaks to its undamaged state. With a blade of no thickness entering a body of interstices, the edge moves freely within—this speaks to the absence of obstruction. This is a metaphor for worldly affairs, all of which possess their own natural principles. Simply follow them, and the mind remains at ease; nothing can harm you.

The phrase "even so" carries profound meaning: in navigating life, how can one always encounter favorable circumstances? When faced with adversity, most grow flustered and lose composure. Yet if one bends and adapts, proceeding with equanimity, the heart remains unmoved. After the matter passes, it dissolves as if it had never occurred—this is the true efficacy of nurturing life. The *Butcher Ding* chapter conveys the essentials of life-nurture most intimately, depicting the precision of his movements and pauses to correspond with the rhythms of walking, standing, sitting, and lying down. Never for a moment does one depart from this, and the artistry of its portrayal is unmatched.

For all things under heaven, great or small, principle resides within. In dissecting the ox, one grasps its principle, and thus the eye no longer sees the whole ox, while the blade finds room to move. In nurturing life, one grasps its principle, and thus the body enjoys ample ease, and affairs proceed without hindrance. "Playing the blade in harmony with sound" is a metaphor for responding to things with perfect accord. "Laying down the blade and facing [the lord]" is a metaphor for forgetting life and attaining principle.

If the mind is set on responding to things, all one sees is the ox. But when embodying the Dao and merging with things, one never sees the whole ox. "Spiritual encounter without reliance on sight" means following nature, employing emptiness, and thus rendering knowledge and perception unnecessary. After nineteen years, the blade remains as if newly whetted—this speaks to one who never clashes with things, whose life suffers no harm, and whose nurturing of spirit is such that it endures without decay.

Yet whenever he reaches a dense cluster—seeing its difficulty, where bones and flesh intertwine in a tangle—this is a metaphor for the times when worldly affairs and social obligations grow complex and demanding. One must exercise caution and vigilance to achieve success, stabilizing the mind before responding. Ordinary people, however, pursue rich flavors, extravagant clothing, lavish dwellings, high rank, sensual pleasures, and fleeting joys as their means of nurture. The more they indulge, the more they lose their lives—this is what the classic means by "nurturing the form is ultimately insufficient to preserve life."

Now, Butcher Ding’s delight was in the Dao, and thus all he saw was the Dao. In all matters, he remained untroubled and unobstructed. Though adversity and fortune alternated, and myriad changes and setbacks arose, he ultimately resolved them with skill, as effortlessly as dust passing before him. How was this so?

For one who nurtures the master of life, mysterious virtue fills the inner self, and the true mechanism responds externally—whether in personal conduct or in dealing with things, all is fitting and harmonious. When the response is complete and one returns to nothingness, this is called "honing the blade and sheathing it." How could there be the wear of monthly sharpening?

The True Person, foreseeing that later generations of those who study life-nurture would drown in stillness and non-action, unable to engage with the world’s affairs, abandoning human matters while claiming the Dao can be established—such a Dao would be rare indeed! Thus, he embedded the Dao within a craft to convey his meaning, and whether the ox is dismembered or not becomes irrelevant.

Upon further reflection, "every encounter with the *zu*" seems to refer to the *zu*-butcher. Seeing the difficulty of the *zu*-butcher’s task, he pauses in caution, yet ultimately finds no difficulty. Li Shibiao’s interpretation aligns with this. From "pauses in caution" onward, Zhao’s punctuation diverges, which also makes sense, though the final phrase "the blade grows ever finer" feels incomplete.

Gongwen Xuan saw the Right Master and exclaimed in shock: "What manner of man is this? How can he be one-legged? Is this Heaven’s doing, or man’s?" The reply came: "It is Heaven, not man. Heaven’s creation made him thus solitary, while human appearance is shared. From this, we know it is Heaven, not man."

A marsh pheasant takes ten steps to peck, a hundred steps to drink, yet it does not seek to be fed and penned. Though its spirit may flourish, this is not goodness. Guo’s commentary: *Jie* refers to the name for partial amputation. What knowledge cannot overcome is Heaven’s doing; to defy what one knows is man’s. *Du* (solitary) points to the one-legged state. If a master’s knowledge cannot preserve both feet, then what knowledge cannot overcome is Heaven’s will. With the Right Master’s wisdom, if he insisted on preserving both, his spirit would be inwardly distressed, his form outwardly worn—how could it be merely a matter of one leg? "Having both" describes walking with two feet. An appearance of having both would never raise doubt as to its being fate. To take having both as fate is to know that the solitary one is not of oneself.

To roam freely in the realm of self-contentment is the subtlety of life-nurture—what need is there to enter a cage and submit to care? The pheasant’s spirit flourishes, its will and qi brimming with ease, wandering in the clear and open wild, so naturally that it does not even recognize goodness as goodness.

Lü’s commentary: The Right Master’s appearance was human, yet Heaven-made. Standing solitary and independent, Gongwen Xuan thus doubted he was human. "Heaven’s creation made him thus solitary" means his nature and life’s principle were originally so. As for engaging with things and having a shared appearance, that is merely human.

The marsh pheasant drinks and pecks freely, its heart roaming with Heaven, a metaphor for fulfilling its nature and life. Not seeking to be fed in a pen—though its spirit may flourish, this is not goodness—a metaphor for being constrained by the human world and unable to roam freely. Even if the care in the pen allows the spirit to flourish, it is not what is truly good, far inferior to the rare yet self-contented pecking and drinking in the marsh.

The *Yi Du* commentary: Heaven created this person with a solitary foot, while human appearance is shared. This speaks to life-nurture not residing in the physical form but in the flourishing of the spirit. Thus, the marsh pheasant, though drinking and pecking sparingly, remains spiritually unharmed. The abundance of grain and millet in the pen only burdens the body. Nurturing the spirit lies in aligning with one’s nature, which is why the ancients found utmost joy in a single acre of office, coarse food, and a gourd of drink—this clarifies the principle.

The *Xiang Dao* commentary: *Jie* means not communicating with things, solitary and without companions. The Right Master fully embodied what he received from Heaven, differing from those whose appearance is shared with others. Hence, Gongwen Xuan said: "..." As for the pheasant, it finds sustenance in the marsh yet is troubled when penned. When it dwells in the marsh, its spirit may be said to flourish; when troubled in the pen, even flourishing is not goodness. For in navigating the world and engaging with things, there is always something to guard against.

He who departs from man to enter the realm of Heaven never fails to find contentment in himself. The Right Master, startled by human affairs, reveals a spirit that flourishes in goodness—this much is clear. Yet when the pheasant’s spirit flourishes yet remains ungood, its alarm at human interference is equally evident.

The *Bixu* commentary: To do good yet escape misfortune is Heaven’s decree; to do evil and draw near to punishment is man’s doing. "Having companions" means mutual association, while "solitary and without companions" invites calamity from Heaven. Though one may violate laws and inherit folly, this too is not man’s doing. When a man’s form and appearance are whole and fair, he moves in company with others, making it difficult to admire such wholeness without forgetting his own flaws. How long has it been that men know not the origin of worldly affairs and their vicissitudes? When matters arise, they are perplexed by their causes; in their perplexity, external things harm them. Yet if one knows the cause of such harm, one may entrust it to its natural course, remaining inwardly free from alarm—thus avoiding deeper injury.

The *Zhao* commentary: The Right Master was Meng Ni. *Jie* refers to one who follows the example of the solitary. "No man lacks eyes, yet I alone am eyeless"—this is Heaven’s doing, not man’s. Thus he invokes the pheasant to explain himself. In the marsh, the pheasant pecks once every ten steps and drinks once every hundred, yet it cannot forget the snare, for its eyes see danger and fear harm. Such constant vigilance—how could it foresee that its true self would be caged and reared by man? The brightness of its two eyes is thus unreliable. Hence it is said: though its spirit flourishes, it is not good. The spirit resides in the eyes; when its essence and radiance manifest, it is called "flourishing." To rely on the eyes for vigilance yet fail to escape harm is worse than the eyeless, who entrust themselves wholly to Heaven.

*Yongzhai* says: The Right Master was a man who had lost a foot and served as the Right Master of the court. *Jie* means "solitary," for he retained but one foot. "Heaven’s doing or man’s?"—was his deformity Heaven-sent? Though amputation is clearly man’s work, he claimed it was Heaven’s doing that made him solitary. While others walk with two feet side by side, his singularity is Heaven’s design, not man’s. Moreover, the world’s excesses and deficiencies, though wrought by man, all stem from the Creator. When man faces hardship, he should accept it. The marsh pheasant pecks once every ten steps and drinks once every hundred, showing how hard it is to find food—yet it would not choose the ease of a cage, where food and drink are plentiful. Though the caged pheasant’s belly may be full, its spirit may flourish, yet it remains unhappy—hence it is called "not good." *Jie* is pronounced *wu*, meaning "severed foot." Master Cui’s version writes it as *ji* ("flesh"), but earlier commentaries differ in interpretation; the original pronunciation, explained as "partial amputation," is more fitting. The phrase "having companions" remains unclear; here, it is tentatively glossed as "of the same kind." Though the Right Master’s solitude was imposed by man, his single foot was Heaven’s portion, and his appearance remained akin to others. Moreover, endowed with the most refined form and an inner fullness, how could he abandon his wholeness because of a missing foot? Thus, he rested in fate and attributed it to Heaven, knowing that what should be preserved lies in virtue and nature. Virtue is born with life, and nature is life’s master—neither departs from these two, and this is called "receiving proper nurture." What does the mutilation of the body add or take away? To wish men to accept hardship and follow the natural course of their nature and fate is to preserve what is nobler than feet. What is nurtured is not the bodily form. Thus, the later analogy of the marsh pheasant takes joy in preserving its nature and sorrow in captivity. Revisiting the text’s intent: though the marsh pheasant’s drinking and pecking are arduous, it refuses domestication. If caged, though food and drink are abundant, it loses the freedom to fly and roam. Though its *form* may flourish, it is not good. Most versions read *shen* ("spirit"), but if its spirit flourished, how could it be called "not good"? Moreover, in confinement, there is no principle by which the spirit could flourish—this is a scribal error, left uncorrected.

*The Ocean of Meanings in the Authentic Scripture of Southern Florescence*, Scroll Five, concludes here. (Note: A character "whole" should be added below.)
*The Ocean of Meanings in the Authentic Scripture of Southern Florescence*, Scroll Six, by Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin.

**Inner Chapters: The Main Principle of Nurturing Life, Part Two**

When Lao Dan died, Qin Shi went to mourn him and wailed three times before departing. His disciples asked, "Was he not your master’s friend?" Qin Shi replied, "He was." "Then is such mourning proper?" "Yes," he said. "At first, I thought he was a true person, but now I see he was not. When I entered to offer condolences, I saw elders weeping for him as if for their own children, and youths weeping as if for their own mothers. Those who gathered there must have been moved to speak when they had no need to speak, to weep when they had no need to weep. This is fleeing from Heaven and doubling one’s emotions, forgetting what one has received—what the ancients called ‘the punishment of fleeing from Heaven.’ To come is the master’s timing; to depart is the master’s compliance. Abiding in timing and complying with the natural course, even a moment’s joy cannot enter—this the ancients called ‘the Great Release of the Sovereign.’

The finger is exhausted in fueling the fire, yet the fire is transmitted, and its end is unknown.

**Guo’s Commentary:**
Qin Shi mourned when others mourned and wailed when others wailed. His disciples found it strange that he did not stand by the door to observe the transformation, yet wailed three times. But the perfected person has no emotions and merely joins the crowd in wailing. The elders wept as if for their children, the youths as if for their mothers—this betrays a prior attachment to things, a failure to abide in principle, leading to such excessive love. The nature bestowed by Heaven has its own proper measure; it cannot be escaped, nor can it be augmented. To be overly moved by things, exceeding what is fitting, is to flee from Heaven. To gallop between the realms of sorrow and joy, though no external punishment has been inflicted, one’s nature and emotions are already exhausted—is this not a punishment? To come is to be born in due time; to depart is to die in accord with principle. Without timing, there is no peace; without compliance, there is no abiding. Merging obscurely with the transformations of creation, sorrow and joy have no place to insert themselves. To be bound is to be suspended; thus, to be unbound is the Great Release.

The fuel is like the previous fuel. The previous fuel is exhausted by the finger, yet the principle of fire’s transmission remains unbroken, so the fire is passed on without end. The heart attains the center of nurturance, so life continues without cessation. This clarifies that nurturing life is the very means by which life is generated. Time does not return, and the present does not pause. Human life is but a single breath, a single attainment. The previous breath is not the present breath, so nurturance continues life; the previous fire is not the later fire, so the fuel transmits the flame. The transmission of fire and the continuation of life arise from nurturance reaching its utmost. How could the world know that life ends only to be reborn?

**Lü’s Commentary:**
Mourning is a ritual: one weeps for the dead and consoles the living. Three wails make the mourning for the dead seem insufficient, while departing without words makes the consolation for the living seem inadequate. This is why the disciples doubted whether he was truly a friend and found such mourning improper. At first, I thought he was a true person, assuming that those who followed Lao Dan had all attained the Dao of nurturance. But seeing the elders and youths weep with such longing, unable to abide in timing and comply with the natural course, I knew he was not a true person. There must have been those who spoke when they had no need to speak, wept when they had no need to weep—inner and outer aligning to bring them together. What one receives from Heaven—one’s nature and the emotions of life—has never been touched by external things, yet they allow themselves to be moved by sorrow and joy. This is fleeing from Heaven and doubling one’s emotions, forgetting what one has received. There is no place that is not Heaven, yet they seek to flee from it—inevitably incurring punishment. Knowing that to come is to abide in timing and to depart is to comply with principle, the ancients called this "the Sovereign’s Great Release," for one has never truly died.

Fire depends on fuel, yet fire is not the fuel. As for the fuel, though the finger may exhaust it, the fire is transmitted without end. Why? The fire in this fuel is like the fire in that fuel—how could its transmission ever end? Fire is an analogy for life; fuel is an analogy for form. Understanding this, one knows that what makes life life has never died—how could sorrow or joy enter?

**Yi Du’s Commentary:**
The perfected person is fundamentally without emotion. That Qin Shi mourned and wailed for Lao Dan’s death was like the people mourning Yao’s death as if they had lost their parents. If he were not as insensate as wood or earth, how could he make the world forget its attachments? Yet what makes him seem emotional is merely his lack of fixation. The *Rites* say: "Those who understand life offer condolences; those who understand death grieve." Qin Shi offered condolences for Lao Dan’s life and wailed three times before departing, grieving for his death. His disciples found it strange that he stopped at three wails, questioning whether he was truly Laozi’s friend. He replied that three wails were sufficient. At first, I thought he was a true person, so I mourned when others mourned and wailed when others wailed. But now I see that fleeing from Heaven and doubling one’s emotions, forgetting what one has received, is not the way.

The body is like an excrescence; life and death are like night and day. How do we know the living are not dead ghosts, or the dead not living people? Why cling so desperately to sorrow and joy over life and death in one’s heart? The great earth exhales essence and breathes out qi, nurturing and forming things—none know whence they come. Though Heaven and Earth, yin and yang, cannot be called their parents, the deluded of the world cling to the love of parent and child and wail for them. How much more so when they mourn another’s kin as if it were their own child or mother? This is why people gather and unite in such excessive sorrow, speaking when they have no need to speak, weeping when they have no need to weep—these are the affairs of the mundane world. Qin Shi saw this as fleeing from nature, doubling sorrowful emotions, and forgetting the original nothingness of what we receive from creation. Heaven’s punishment is fate; to flee from fate is to be burdened by punishment and give rise to sorrow. To regard coming as timing and departing as compliance, sorrow and joy cannot enter—this the ancients called "the Sovereign’s Great Release." To have life is to be suspended; to be without life is to be released. When one attains the utmost of fate, one’s life endures beyond antiquity without aging, like the finger exhausted in fueling the fire, yet the fire is transmitted without end.

Liu Guo’s annotation: The analogy of firewood and flame illustrates the spirit’s lodging in form yet constant transference. The utmost person of antiquity bore the poised soul and regarded the bodily frame as a temporary abode precisely for this reason. How much less would they measure the body and lose reverence for its honored form?

Zhao’s annotation: Qin Shi wept for Laozi without sorrow, and his disciples doubted him. Shi then explained what he had witnessed. Some commentators have mistakenly assumed that Shi was dissatisfied with Laozi, believing it improper to evoke such intense grief in others. This entirely misses the original intent. Laozi, in life, harmonized his light with the dust and never clashed with things, yet people cherished him all the same. Thus, they spoke when there was no need to speak, wept when there was no need to weep. In his death, he fled from creation, turned his back on worldly sentiment, and forgot what he had received from Heaven—by this point, even Heaven could do nothing. Hence it is said: to flee from Heaven’s punishment, to regard coming as no cause for joy and departing as no cause for sorrow—this is what is meant by "resting in due time and complying with sequence." "Suspended" refers to the great affliction of having a body. "Released" means that only now do I know myself to be free. The "Sovereign’s Great Release" signifies that the Creator labors us with life and reposes us in death. The finger is exhausted in fueling the fire; when the firewood is spent, the flame ceases, yet that which does not cease endures eternally. Thus it is said: the fire is transmitted without end.

Yongzhai’s note: Qin Shi was a friend of Laozi. He wailed thrice and departed, demonstrating his freedom from attachment, which is why his disciples doubted and questioned him. Shi said: "At first, I took Laozi for an extraordinary man. Now, seeing his disciples weep as if for an elder or a youth, so excessively sorrowful, I realize Laozi must not have fully shed his bodily traces, for something moved their hearts beyond expectation. That which Heaven bestows is originally nothing, yet if one is stirred by sentiment, one forgets the original nothingness of what is received, flees from Heaven’s principle, and betrays the truth of emotion—all of which offend against Heaven. Hence it is said: to flee from Heaven’s punishment. Human life comes as it is fated; death departs as it is fated."

When one follows the seasons and accords with them, there is no cause for sorrow or joy. Knowing this principle, even Heaven cannot bind me with life and death—hence the saying: "The Sovereign’s suspended release."

The analogy of fire transmitted through fuel illustrates life and death: observe the fuel, and you see it must eventually be consumed, yet the fire in the world has never ceased from ancient times to the present. The argument reaches this point, then concludes with three metaphorical phrases—truly a stroke of genius. In previous commentaries, the character *zhi* (指) is often glossed as "to point with the hand," but if this were its meaning, the act of pointing would already be implied in the preceding text. Upon closer examination, *zhi* here should be understood as *zhi* (旨), meaning "principle" or "essence." The principle is exhausted in the fuel, yet the fire is transmitted without end—this meaning is perfectly clear. The *Knowledge Wanders North* chapter’s discussion of *zhou* (周), *bian* (遍), and *xian* (咸) as different names for the same reality, all pointing to a single essence, confirms this interpretation.

A single household’s fuel may be exhausted, but the fire of the world is inexhaustible, for those skilled in tending fuel know how to transmit it. A single person’s body may perish, but the spirit within it is without end, for those skilled in nurturing life know how to preserve it. The fire in that fuel is like the fire in this fuel, yet their flames differ. The spirit that lodges in a later body is like the spirit in the present body, yet each breath is distinct. The difference in flames explains why there is kindling and extinction; the distinctness of breaths explains why there is death and life. Yet the fire of the world has never been exhausted, nor has the spirit ever perished—because there are those who master them.

Consider how fire may be obtained by focusing sunlight, striking stone, drilling wood, or scraping bamboo. The nature of fire pervades heaven and earth, yet without human effort, it cannot be brought forth. The transformation of the spirit operates likewise. Remove the fuel, and to what does the fire cling? Destroy the form, and where does the spirit lodge? Thus we know that transmitting fire depends on obtaining fuel, and lodging the spirit depends on obtaining form—this is how the perfected person achieves wondrous use and completes the full work of heaven and earth. *Nanhua* invokes this to conclude the meaning of the *Preserving Life’s Integrity* chapter, profound indeed in its import!

Those who grasp the principle of nurturing form do not harm it; those who attain the Way of nurturing spirit act without contrivance. Form is the lodging of life; spirit is the master of life. The Way of emptiness and non-being is that by which one nurtures the spirit. Worldly people merely know how to nurture life, yet do not know how to nurture the master of life. The more they nurture, the more they lose life, so the true person teaches: "Do not let the finite follow the infinite"—this is the essence of nurturing life.

Those who hold the Dao in their hearts are without intention toward good or evil. Those who meet things with emptiness—what have they to do with fame or punishment? Accord with the mean and do not lose constancy; herein lies the principle of preserving the body and fulfilling one’s years. The analogy of butchering an ox illustrates responding to things, with the knife as a metaphor for life. After nineteen years, the blade is as if newly whetted, though it has passed through countless joints and complex cuts. Yet the sharpness and clarity of my skill grow ever more enduring—this is the master of life. One must nurture it well, for only through daily nurturing can one prevail in such moments, achieving great use through non-use.

As for "whetting the knife and concealing it," this means having leisure after responding to things, gathering one’s knowledge and veiling one’s brilliance. Things attain their proper state, affairs reach their principle, yet one’s efficacious use remains unharmed. The great recluses of old dwelled in the marketplace yet interacted with things, ever responsive yet ever tranquil—this is the Way they attained. Thus the essentials of learning the Dao begin with emptiness and stillness. Without emptiness, one cannot preserve the spirit; without stillness, one cannot return to the mandate. When nature is whole and the mandate is restored, the work of nurturing life is complete.

Like a mirror set before a stand, reflecting without leaving traces—what do things add to me? Ordinary people, chasing things and losing their true nature, entangled in affairs and resisting principle, tossed between gain and loss, their hearts filled with sorrow and resentment—how can their lives not be harmed? Hence the pheasant in the marsh does not wish to be caged, as illustrated in the later analogy.

Laozi, whom *Nanhua* revered as the greatest sage, spoke of death to teach people to rest in their time and abide in accord, to guard constancy and attain completion. Yet the wondrous transformation of following form and soaring beyond it is beyond the world’s comprehension—thus the saying: "The death of a sage is called *shen* (spirit)." Qin Shi mourned him with three cries, already an excess of world-transcending ritual, yet his disciples still harbored doubts. He therefore explained that coming and going are as they naturally are, and one should accept them without resistance—this is "the Sovereign’s suspended release," where the Creator cannot bind one.

To exhaust the principle of fuel is to transmit fire without end; to exhaust the principle of nurturing form is to preserve the spirit without loss.

The formed must end in exhaustion, yet I cannot but nurture it. Using the illusory to cultivate the real is also a principle of mutual support—only, it must not be as excessive as Zhang Yi’s futile over-nurturing. Thus, the ultimate value lies in preserving and returning to the form whole; when the whole is returned, the spirit suffers no misdirection. Emerging from being and entering non-being, where can one go that is not right?
