Fuxi attained this and inherited the Mother of Qi; the Yellow Emperor attained this and ascended to the cloudy heavens; Fu Yue attained this and rode the tail of the Winnowing Basket to rank among the stars. The Most High said: "He who dies yet does not perish is long-lived."

*The Ocean of Meanings in the True Scripture of the Southern Florescence, Scroll Six* ends here.
*The Ocean of Meanings in the True Scripture of the Southern Florescence, Scroll Seven*
Compiled by the Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin

**Chapter One: "The Human World"**
Yan Hui sought an audience with Confucius and asked to depart.
Confucius said: "Where to?"
He replied: "To Wei."
Confucius said: "What for?"
He replied: "I have heard that the lord of Wei is in his prime, yet his conduct is willful. He treats his state lightly and does not recognize his faults. He treats the people’s deaths lightly, and the dead are measured by the state as if they were rushes in a marsh—the people have nowhere to turn. I once heard you say: ‘Leave a well-ordered state; go to a disordered one. A physician’s gate sees many illnesses.’ I wish to apply what I have heard to reflect on its principles, that his state might perhaps be set right."
Confucius said: "Alas! You will likely go and be executed! The Way does not tolerate mixture; mixture leads to excess, excess to disorder, disorder to anxiety, and anxiety cannot be remedied.

The utmost person of old first established it in himself before establishing it in others. If what is established in oneself is not settled, how can one attend to the conduct of violent men? Moreover, do you know where virtue’s dissipation and knowledge’s emergence come from? Virtue dissipates for the sake of fame; knowledge emerges from contention. Fame is that by which people clash; knowledge is the instrument of contention. Both are inauspicious tools, not means for perfect conduct.

Furthermore, though virtue be deep and trust solid, if one does not penetrate others’ qi, and though fame be heard and uncontentious, if one does not penetrate others’ hearts—yet you would forcefully present the language of benevolence and righteousness, the carpenter’s square and ink line, before a violent man: this is to make others resent what they themselves lack, which is called ‘sowing resentment.’ One who sows resentment will surely be resented in return—you will be in danger as a husband to others!

Moreover, if you delight in the worthy and despise the unworthy, why would you seek to be different? If you lack the royal music, the lords will surely ride roughshod over you to vie for victory. Your eyes will be dazzled, your countenance smoothed, your mouth will flatter, your demeanor will conform, and your heart will comply. This is like quenching fire with fire, flooding water with water—it is called ‘adding to the excess.’ Following the beginning without end, if you persist in thick words without trust, you will surely die before the violent man!

In the past, Jie killed Guan Longfeng, and Zhou killed Prince Bigan—both were men who cultivated themselves to humble the people below and oppose their superiors above, so their lords used their cultivation to cast them out. These were lovers of fame. In the past, Yao attacked Congzhi and Xufang, and Yu attacked Youhu. Their states became wastelands of corpses, and they themselves were executed—yet their use of arms did not cease, and their pursuit of fame and substance knew no end. Have you alone not heard of this? Fame and substance are what even sages cannot overcome—how much less can you?

Nevertheless, if you must have a way, come and tell me."
Yan Hui said: "If I am upright yet empty, diligent yet single-minded, will that do?"
Confucius said: "Alas! How could it? When one is full of yang, boastful and ostentatious, with shifting colors, even ordinary people do not oppose it. Following others’ likes and dislikes to seek harmony in their hearts—this is called ‘daily gradual virtue that does not succeed,’ let alone great virtue! You would cling without transformation, outwardly comply while inwardly disdaining—how could that ever suffice?

Then let me be inwardly straight and outwardly yielding, achieving while aligning above. Being inwardly straight is to be a companion of Heaven. One who is a companion of Heaven knows that the Son of Heaven and oneself are both children of Heaven—why should one’s own words be esteemed while others’ are not, or be resented while others’ are? Such a one is called a child—this is what it means to be a companion of Heaven. Being outwardly yielding is to be a companion of others. Bowing, scraping, and humble service are the rites of a minister—everyone does this; how dare I not? Doing what others do, others will find no fault in it—this is what it means to be a companion of others. Achieving while aligning above is to be a companion of antiquity. Though one’s words may instruct, they are in fact admonitions. What antiquity had, I do not possess. Such a one, though upright, is not blamed—this is what it means to be a companion of antiquity. Would this do?"
Confucius said: "Alas! How could it?"

The Way is too rigidly upright, modeling itself on standards without adaptability—though steadfast, it remains blameless. Yet this is all it amounts to; how could it ever bring about transformation? It is still the way of one who follows their own mind.

Guo’s commentary: To act alone, sharing no desires with the people, is to drive the entire state into mortal peril, regarding them as mere weeds. With no refuge, the people are left adrift—this is why Yan Hui wished to go and save them. Confucius said that Hui’s Way was insufficient to rescue them, for like a hundred physicians attending a single illness, it would only breed confusion and fail to bring even one cure. Only when one possesses the proper capacity may one engage with the world.

If one forces their thoughts into perilous action, it shows that what resides within them is not yet settled. Virtue scatters and flows, knowledge spills forth uncontrollably—this is because of pride in reputation and competition for goodness. Even if a tyrant were utterly ruined, what he clings to and cherishes would still be nothing but fame and cunning. Fame arises, and contention follows; knowledge is employed, and strife erupts. Only by relinquishing fame and knowledge can one’s conduct be perfected.

Now, Hui’s virtue is sincere, but what he has yet to grasp is that the other does not comprehend it. Though he might wish to restrain him with benevolence and righteousness, the other would take it as an attempt to destroy him for personal gain and would surely turn against him. If one merely delights in the worthy and despises the foolish, hearing the Way and submitting, they are deemed an enlightened ruler. With an enlightened ruler, there will be no lack of worthy ministers—what is remarkable about your going? Moreover, it would only bring harm. You must remain silent and still; if you speak, he will surely exploit his sovereign’s authority to vie for victory, adorn his faults, dazzle your eyes, and calm your countenance. Before you can save yourself, you will abandon your own principles to follow him—not only failing to save him but furthering his evil.

In ancient times, Long Feng and Bi Gan, though subordinates, took on the burdens of their rulers and were thus cast aside by them. A violent ruler does not merely seek to indulge his desires; he also seeks fame, though not by the proper means. A ruler who cherishes fame and demands desire, even Yao or Yu could not transform him without resorting to force. How then do you intend to go empty-handed and transform him?

Hui said: "If I rectify my form, empty my heart, speak with humility and without contradiction—would this suffice?"
Confucius said: "Alas! How could it? The ruler of Wei is of a haughty and overbearing nature, brimming within and flaunting without. When others provoke him, he responds with scorn and humiliation to satisfy his extravagant heart. He is obstinate and unyielding—how could this ever do?"

Hui then proposed three further approaches: "Inwardly upright, one is a companion of Heaven; outwardly yielding, one is a companion of others; achieving while aligning above, one is a companion of antiquity."
Confucius still deemed this insufficient, for his governance and affairs were not yet in harmony. Though not grandly expansive, it might avoid blame, yet it would not bring transformation. This was because he carried these three methods with him, still unable to be without mind.

Lü’s commentary: In his prime, he acted recklessly with his state. Acting alone, he treated the people’s lives as trifles. The people died for the state, and if the state’s affairs demanded death, then the recompense should be profound—yet it was diminished and measured as if bestowing dew upon reeds! Such extreme parsimony is why the people had no recourse.

Yan Hui wished to humble himself to uphold the Way, but the Master did not permit it, detesting the杂多 of such an approach, which would only disturb without saving. First establish it within yourself, and then you may establish it in others—there is nowhere this will not suffice. Now, what resides within Hui is not yet settled; how can he attend to the conduct of a violent man?

Virtue scattered and knowledge unrestrained are the instruments of contention. Moreover, when virtue is profound and trust is firm, it suffices to reach others’ qi and prevent them from descending into baseness and betrayal. When fame and rank are not contested, it suffices to reach others’ hearts and prevent them from falling into suspicion and jealousy—only then may one speak with them.

Hui has not yet reached this point, yet he would forcefully employ the measured words of benevolence and righteousness to enlighten a violent man before him. This is to possess beauty while inciting others’ hatred. He is merely fond of fame—so contend with him through fame. He is merely fond of cunning—so deploy cunning against him, leading him to wield the tools of destruction. This is to lead him by the head. Observe what he puts forth, and you will know what he will turn to—Hui’s going would be nothing but peril.

If a ruler delights in the worthy and despises the unworthy, then he is the same as you—why seek to be different? If you speak with him, merely agreeing without instruction, he will surely exploit others to vie in clever debate, his demeanor harsh and his gaze piercing, his heart already set. Before you can seek escape or compliance, it will be too late. This is like using water to extinguish water or fire to extinguish fire—submission will only perpetuate the beginning without end.

He does not expect sincerity and generosity from me, yet if I speak with him, I will surely die before the violent man. In ancient times, Long Feng and Bi Gan cultivated themselves and served the people, yet were suspected of hoarding favor—thus their rulers cast them aside. They, too, were merely fond of fame. Even Yao and Yu could not transform the rebellious states without resorting to their destruction. If fame and reality are what the sage cannot overcome, how much less can one like you?

To be upright yet empty is not true emptiness. To strive for unity is not true unity. Pride swells within and manifests without; when others provoke him, he seeks to gratify his heart. Even minor virtue is not achieved—how much less great virtue? Using this to correct his ruler would at best result in outward compliance while inwardly remaining unchanged—how could it transform him?

To take one’s own words and judge others’ goodness or badness is to regard oneself as base and others as noble. From the perspective of the Way, the Son of Heaven and oneself are both children of Heaven—what distinction is there between them? To be a companion of Heaven, of others, and of antiquity—Hui believed that with these three he might adapt to change and perhaps succeed. Yet in responding to things, if one has not attained oneness and emptiness of mind, this is why it is called "too much."

Outwardly lodging uprightness in antiquity is to govern others by standards, not by the person, and to alter what one knows—this is not true deliberation. Deliberation is to subtly discern others’ intentions and grasp them—then it is firm. Though blameless, how could it bring transformation? It is because one follows their own mind and has not yet attained mindlessness.

The worthy in relation to a state are like physicians treating illness: when a state is well-governed, the worthy have no role to play and depart; when a state is in chaos and ungoverned, the worthy bear their surplus of virtue to attend it. Those with illness flock to the physician’s gate; those with a state seek worthy scholars. Wishing to apply what I have heard from the Master’s teachings, I contemplate their principles and act accordingly—might this perhaps bring healing to Wei’s afflictions?

Confucius deemed Wei’s shallowness insufficient for transformation. The sage embraces oneness as the model for the world, so those entangled in multiplicity are right to despair of remedy. First establish it in oneself, and what lies in others becomes self-evident without words. If what is established in oneself remains unsettled, how can one attend to the domain of the violent and practice the Way there?

Virtue, once it acquires a name, becomes dissipated; knowledge, once it engenders contention, emerges—both are inauspicious instruments that cannot be fully enacted in the world. Cultivate qi to the point of fullness, and only then can one penetrate others’ qi; cultivate the mind to the point of stillness, and only then can one penetrate others’ minds. Without attaining this, merely applying the rigid standards of moral discourse before the violent will surely provoke their hatred of one’s excellence and bring harm upon oneself.

Moreover, if the lord of Wei delights in the worthy and detests the unworthy, why would he seek you only to set himself apart from others? You should remain silent—if you speak, he will exploit his lordly authority to engage in verbal sparring, while your countenance and form reveal your thoughts outwardly, and your heart conforms inwardly. Once you begin to comply, there will be no end to it. If you do not heed my earnest words, you will surely die before the violent.

In ancient times, Guan Longfeng and Bi Gan cultivated themselves to aid their people, yet their lords ensnared and destroyed them—this was the fault of their love of reputation. The three states of Congji, Xu’ao, and Youhu attacked one another in pursuit of fame and substance; even Yao and Yu could not transform them and had to raise armies to punish them, leaving their states desolate and their persons executed before ceasing. From this, we know that those who seek fame and substance cannot escape calamity.

Yan Hui proposed aligning with emptiness and striving for oneness. The Master said that the lord of Wei was full of yang but hollow in response to others’ influences—minor virtue could not succeed, let alone great virtue. Yan Hui then presented three principles: being a companion to others, to Heaven, and to antiquity, hoping thus to avoid the exhaustion of the age. The Master again did not approve.

Excessive governance by laws without true deliberation—deliberation here means private scrutiny, a kind of covert scheming. Though firm, it remains blameless, yet it still involves distinctions between inner and outer, past and present, which is why it cannot escape the exhaustion of the age. From the perspective of one who commands the transformations of things, how could there be any difference between Heaven, humanity, and antiquity? Only the mindless can partake in this.

*Detailed Daoist Annotation:*
The perfected in relation to the world never engage in thought yet suffice to please the hearts of those who think; they never act yet suffice to refine the reflections of those who act. How is this so? They respond only after being moved, act only under compulsion—how could they toil busily over the world’s affairs?

Yan Hui knew of thought and action for ordering the age but did not understand thoughtlessness and inaction for responding to things. Seeking to correct the lord of Wei’s tyrannical excesses and rescue the people from dire straits, Confucius thus rebuked his meddlesome disturbance.

The perfected first establish it in themselves—this is embracing oneness. Then they establish it in others—this is being a model for the world. If what is established in oneself remains unsettled, it becomes fragmented; acting in the domain of the violent, it becomes disorderly.

Virtue is the substance of reputation; when reputation prevails, virtue dissipates. Knowledge is the instrument of contention; when contention arises, knowledge emerges. One whose virtue is profound and trust is unshakable is inwardly steadfast; one who has not penetrated others’ qi remains outwardly uncontentious in reputation. Without penetrating others’ minds, to forcibly expound the rigid standards of benevolence and righteousness before the violent is to speak deeply where acquaintance is shallow—it only invites their enmity.

From “delighting in the worthy and detesting the unworthy” to “surely die before the violent” speaks of the exhaustion brought by knowledge. From “Jie killed Guan Longfeng” to “what the sage cannot overcome” speaks of the exhaustion brought by reputation.

Aligning with emptiness and striving for oneness is to be full of yang. Being full of yang means one’s substance is inherently self-enclosed. Yan Hui’s initial impulse was to employ knowledge to save the age; when he realized its impossibility, he sought to withdraw knowledge and return to emptiness and oneness. Finding this also impossible, he then aimed to unify emptiness and oneness with the three companionships.

Thus, being a companion to Heaven means advancing one’s own integrity without assessing others’ goodness or badness; being a companion to others means acting as they do without offending their flaws; being a companion to antiquity means citing the ancients to criticize the present without being resented. Aligning with emptiness and striving for oneness is mere obstinacy, insufficient to speak of virtue—calling it untransformative means not understanding adaptability. The three companionships amount to mere scrutiny, insufficient to speak of governance. How can one who has not attained transformation transform others?

*Blue Void Annotation:*
To lightly use one’s state is to fail to value oneself; to lightly use the people’s lives is to fail to value others. The dead are beyond counting, so the state is used as a measure. The plantain is a hollow grass—though the lord of Wei may possess virtuous blessings like the plantain’s unreality, the people have nowhere to turn.

Yan Hui said that many illnesses gather at the physician’s gate and wished to contemplate how to save them. The Way does not tolerate杂乱; multiplicity breeds confusion. First establish it in oneself to set the root—if the root is not set, how can one transform others?

Those who lose virtue do so for reputation; those who employ knowledge do so for contention. What people cannot know is the great name; what people do not contend over is the great knowledge. Not knowing, not contending—this is how one fully enacts the Way. Yet to forcibly expound the rigid standards of benevolence and righteousness before the violent is to make others hate one’s excellence, as if courting destruction. To honor the worthy and distance the sycophantic is to be enlightened—why seek further distinction?

Should they seize the advantage to vie in cunning debate, your eyes will flicker in outward alarm, your complexion smooth in inward restraint; your mouth will falter between assent and dissent, your bearing crumble into disarray. Once the heart yields, all steadfastness is lost, and compliance at the outset leaves no end to submission.

Thus you risk disbelieving earnest counsel and perishing before the violent. He then cited Long Feng and Bi Gan as proof: where the Way is absent, the distinction between defiance and compliance becomes stark; where the Way prevails, the very principle of defiance and compliance is forgotten.

In former times, even Yao and Yu could not transform the Three States and resorted to conquest to destroy them. How then could you, Yan Hui, hope to transform the Lord of Wei with mere words? Such an attempt would be not merely futile. If your resolve is not yet emptied, if your effort is not yet unified—if arrogance swells without and none dare oppose you—how can you, whose nature cannot be altered, empty and unify yourself to transform others?

Yan Hui then proposed aligning with Heaven, with humanity, and with antiquity as a means to avoid calamity, but the Master did not permit it, for he still harbored the intent of a teacher and had not yet embodied the vast, obscure Dao.

Zhao’s commentary: The dead are measured by the marsh; corpses pile high in the wetlands, as if the marsh were their measure. Like plantains, the people are mown down like grass.

Yan Hui wished to go and save them, but the Master sighed, saying, "You will surely suffer punishment." To persuade others while fearing they will not comply is to multiply your arguments. To insist they must follow is to introduce disorder. From disorder comes anxiety; from anxiety comes inability even to save oneself—how then can one save others?

Your heart’s resolve is not yet settled; how can you lightly venture before the violent? When reputation is established, virtue is lost; when contention arises, knowledge is born. If remonstrance is heeded, faults are attributed to the ruler, while merit is claimed by the minister. Thus reputation clashes and knowledge sparks contention—this is not how one fully enacts the Way.

Though your virtue is profound and your integrity sincere, your qi and spirit have not yet attained penetration. To flaunt your own rectitude and provoke others’ faults is to invite their hatred—this is what people call courting disaster, and you will only bring ruin upon yourself. If they possessed a heart that delights in the worthy and despises the unworthy, they would seek you out without pause—why wait for you to go to them?

If you remain silent, so be it; but should you speak, they will press their arguments to seek victory. In that moment, your eyes will blur and dare not meet theirs; your countenance will soften and dare not resist. Your mouth will scramble to explain, your demeanor will cringe and comply, your heart will yield to their desires. Thus you will not only fail to help but will make matters worse! Only by accommodating their will can you avoid being cornered.

Long Feng and Bi Gan were slain for their loyalty—this is to be denied one’s reputation. Cong Ji, Xu Ao, and You Hu waged war and contended, only to be attacked by Yao and Yu—this is to be denied one’s substance. If even sages cannot prevail against reputation and substance, how can you hope to correct the Lord of Wei?

If you must go, you must have a way—try explaining it to me. Yan Hui replied with "emptiness and resolve, effort and unity," but the Master deemed it impossible. The Lord of Wei is haughty, self-indulgent, and steeped in flattery from dawn to dusk—how much less would he heed sudden attempts to correct him? Once he clings to his ways without change, you will outwardly comply while inwardly daring no dissent—this is even more unacceptable!

Yan Hui then revised his approach, proposing alignment with Heaven, humanity, and antiquity, but the Master again refused, saying the Lord of Wei’s misgovernance is too severe—how can antiquity serve as a comparison? Though he may not punish you for it, your methods end there—how can they effect transformation? His conduct aligns with those who are self-righteous; how could he follow antiquity?

Yongzhai remarked: I have heard that when the state has the Way, one appears; when it lacks the Way, one withdraws. Zhuangzi reverses this, saying one departs from well-ordered states and approaches disordered ones—like a physician whose skills are needed only when illness abounds at the gate. What use is one in a state already well-governed?

You wish to convey what you have learned from the Master to the Lord of Wei, hoping to stabilize his state, but the Master deemed it inadvisable. From disorder to anxiety—how can one torment oneself and still save others? First establish it in yourself. The moment you seek reputation, your natural virtue is already lost, and private knowledge gives rise to contention.

Reputation and knowledge are the world’s most perilous affairs; they cannot be fully enacted. Thus, though your virtue is profound and your integrity sincere, if you have not yet grasped others’ nature and qi and forcibly present the standards of benevolence and righteousness before the wicked, disaster will befall you.

Having not been summoned, you go of your own accord. With the nobility of a lord, they will seize your words to vie for victory. Overwhelmed, your eyes will blur, your complexion will humble itself to appease them, your mouth will scramble to explain, your form will cringe and submit, your heart will yield to their desires. Compliance thus pursued knows no end!

Long Feng and Bi Gan were killed for their loyalty—this was the fault of seeking reputation. Yao and Yu attacked the Three States, for those who sought reputation and self-interest were unbearable even to them—how much less can you, seeking reputation, remonstrate with the Lord of Wei?

Yan Hui said, "If I embody emptiness, resolve, effort, and unity, perhaps I can go and transform him," but the Master deemed it utterly impossible. The Lord of Wei’s yang qi is overflowing; if you attempt to move him with words, he will suppress your heart to gratify his own. If you cling without yielding, outwardly seeking harmony through emptiness while inwardly maintaining effort and unity—can you truly believe this will suffice?

Yan Hui then proposed three conditions that might persuade the Lord of Wei, but the Master again refused, saying your criticisms of governance are too numerous and will never bring peace. Even if you master these three, you will incur no blame, but this only spares you—how can it transform others? Your three proposals all stem from the intent of a teacher; the moment you harbor such intent, you depart from the natural Way.

The general meaning of the various explanations has been thoroughly addressed; no further repetition is needed here. As for the interpretation of certain characters, some discussions may have been overlooked, and presumptuous annotations have been appended at the end. For instance, the phrase *ze ruo jiao* (泽若蕉) is rather difficult to explicate. Some separate *ze* into its own clause, leaving the following two characters incomplete. The character *ze* (泽) has two possible meanings. As for *jiao* (蕉), interpretations vary; older annotations on pronunciation and meaning take *ze* as "wilderness" and *jiao* as equivalent to *qiao* (樵, "firewood"), which does make sense.

"To measure the dead by the state" is akin to the historical records of measuring grain by cattle and horses—it signifies their vast, uncountable number. With so many people dead, the grain, millet, grasses, and trees cannot flourish, and the marshes appear as if stripped bare by firewood gatherers; the governance of the state may thus be discerned.

To forcibly expound upon benevolence and righteousness, as if applying a carpenter’s inked line, before a violent ruler is to impose upon others what they despise as beautiful. The character *yan* (衍) appears uniformly in all versions, except in the *Bixu Zhaojiangnan Guzang* edition, which writes it as *jie* (街). Later in the text, following Master Cui’s edition, it appears as *e yu qi mei* (恶育其美), where *yu* (育) means "to sell," linking it to the sense of *xuan* (衒, "to flaunt") in the preceding text. Yet this ultimately fails to align with the purport of the classic.

Upon consulting the *Records of the Grand Historian: Treatise on Music*, one finds: "Those who recognize the patterns of ritual and music possess the arts of governance," and further: "The brilliance of the expounder." Here, *shu* (术) is interchangeable with *mi* (迷, "to delude"), preserving an ancient usage.

This chapter mentions the "violent ruler" thrice. Most interpretations take it to mean "tyrannical and brutal," yet upon careful examination, the first two instances should be rendered as "to manifest violence," meaning to display the ruler’s violent methods before others—this reading flows smoothly and aligns with the preceding and following text. The final instance directly refers to the brutality of the man in question, namely Kuai Kui.

*South China Zhenjing Yihai Muzhai*, Scroll Seven, concludes. #1 The character *zi* (子) appears as *hui* (回) in all editions.

*South China Zhenjing Yihai Zuanwei*, Scroll Eight
Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin

**Chapter Two: Among the Human World**
Yan Hui said: "I have no further means to advance. May I ask for the method?"
Zhongni replied: "Fast. I shall tell you of it. Do you think it easy to act while maintaining this? Those who deem it easy act against Heaven’s fitting order."
Yan Hui said: "My family is poor. For months now, I have neither drunk wine nor eaten meat. Would this suffice as fasting?"
He replied: "This is the fasting of sacrificial rites, not the fasting of the mind."
Hui said: "May I ask about the fasting of the mind?"
Zhongni said: "Unify your will. Do not listen with the ears but listen with the mind. Do not listen with the mind but listen with qi. Listening stops at the ears; the mind stops at signs. Qi is that which is empty and awaits things. Only the Dao gathers in emptiness. Emptiness is the fasting of the mind."
Yan Hui said: "Before I received this teaching, I was truly myself. Having received it, I have never been myself. Can this be called emptiness?"
The Master said: "It is complete! I shall tell you. If you can enter and wander within its bounds without being moved by its name, then enter and sing; if not, then stop. Without gate, without harm—abide in one dwelling and lodge in inevitability, and you will be close. To sever ties is easy; to walk without touching the ground is difficult. To be employed by others is easy to feign; to be employed by Heaven is difficult to feign. I have heard of flying with wings, but never of flying without wings. I have heard of knowing with knowledge, but never of knowing without knowledge. Look upon that emptiness: an empty chamber generates brightness, and auspiciousness comes to rest. If one does not come to rest, this is called sitting in motion. To follow the ears and eyes, inwardly connecting yet outwardly detached from the mind’s knowing—even ghosts and spirits will come to dwell, let alone men! This is the transformation of the myriad things, the pivot of Yu and Shun, the ultimate course of Fuxi and Jiqu, and how much more so for those who are scattered!"

Guo Xiang’s commentary:
Those who act with intention find it truly difficult; to regard acting with intention as easy is to fail to see its fittingness. "Unify your will" means to discard heterodox paths and follow the singular. Abandon the ears and eyes, forget the mind’s intentions, and align with the self-attainment of qi and nature—this is emptiness awaiting things. Before attaining the fasting of the mind, one possesses a self; having attained it, one no longer possesses a self. Releasing the mind into the realm of self-attainment, stopping at the actual—this is like the notes of a melody responding without intention, hence the term "singing." Let things be as they are—this is "without gate." Entrusting the world to its natural peace—this is "without harm." Inevitability is the necessity of principle. To embody the dwelling of utmost oneness and meet the tally of necessity is to exhaust principle. To desire not to act is easy; to act without treading upon the ground is impossible. To be without action is easy; to act without harming nature is impossible. What is obtained through seeing and hearing is coarse, hence easily deceived; the recompense of nature is subtle, hence difficult to act upon. Those who lose little of the real lose little of wholeness; those who lose much of the real lose much of wholeness. The recompense of loss and gain accords with one’s portion, and to defy Heaven with artifice—is this not difficult? The analogy of wings and knowledge speaks of the necessity of possessing the means to accomplish a task. Without the dwelling of utmost emptiness, there is no way to achieve the reality of transforming things. To regard being as non-being is the empty chamber. When the chamber is empty, pure brightness arises, and auspiciousness gathers there. If one does not stop at what is fitting and does not meet the ultimate, this is like sitting in stillness while the mind gallops without cease—external enemies have not arrived, yet one is already inwardly exhausted. How can one transform things? To close the ears and eyes and naturally attain—this is to externalize the mind’s knowing! Thus, to follow one’s nature directly and penetrate all without obstruction—even the hidden and obscure cannot bind one, let alone the burdens of the human world. Among things, there is none, noble or base, that does not connect itself through the mind’s knowing and the ears and eyes. Therefore, what the world calls knowledge and perception—does one know because one desires to know, see because one desires to see? People of the world act with desire to know and see, driving the spirit within and losing the ears and eyes without. Thus, they are ill at ease in their bodies and out of harmony with things."

Lü’s commentary:
Zhongni told Yan Hui that in matters of action, to act is never easy without difficulty. The fasting of the mind is to be without thought or action and return to the mindless state—without unifying the will, this cannot be conveyed. "Do not listen with the ears but with the mind" means listening without hearing. "Do not listen with the mind but with qi" means the mind is without knowing. Listening without hearing stops at the ears; the mind without knowing stops at signs. Emptiness awaiting things is only qi. Only the Dao gathers in emptiness—this is how one returns to the mindless state. In regard to the mind, one has never attained what can employ it, hence one cannot be without self. Thus, before Hui attained the fasting of the mind, he truly possessed a self; having attained it, he could be without self. "Without being moved by its name" means forgetting its emptiness. "Entering and wandering within its bounds" means the mind’s emergence is shaped by things. "Enter and sing; if not, then stop"—like metal and stone, which sound only when struck. When it stops, there is no gate through which the many movements can disturb, no harm through which the various evils can afflict. Abiding in one dwelling and lodging in inevitability to act—with this, one may traverse the human world and be close.

The Master further instructed that to cease advancement is easy, but to tread no ground is difficult. To tread no ground, nothing surpasses erasing all traces; to escape the burdens of things, nothing surpasses forgetting the self. Yet forgetting the self without authenticity is merely to fall into pretense.

Man possesses knowledge and thus has what he does not know, so serving man is easily feigned. Heaven is without knowledge yet knows all, so serving Heaven is difficult to counterfeit. Preserving the mind with which I serve Heaven—this is serving Heaven; how could pretense be permitted?

Man’s knowledge serves as wings; clip those wings, and he halts, no longer able to fly. Behold that empty chamber—when the room is void, brightness arises, and auspicious signs appear, resting where they rest. Yet not to rest in this is called "sitting in motion," whence arise good and ill fortune, regret and shame, all born of movement.

When one attains true stillness, the ears become like eyes, the eyes like ears; the mind congeals, the form dissolves, and flesh and bone fuse as one. The eyes turn inward, transcending the mind’s knowing; then spirits and gods will come to dwell—how much more so men? This is the transformation of the myriad things, the ultimate practice of the ancient sages.

*Dú’s Annotation*: Fasting of the mind values emptiness of heart. If the heart still harbors something, then attaining fasting is difficult. Those who treat fasting as easy and neglect it are unfit for the vastness of Heaven.

To listen with the ears is proper hearing; to listen with the mind is reverse hearing; to listen with qi is no hearing. Proper hearing with the ears aims to exhaust principle; reverse hearing with spirit aims to fulfill one’s nature; no hearing with emptiness aims to reach destiny.

Listening that stops at the ears is inferior to stopping at the mind. The mind makes distinctions, but when tallying signs, division yields to unity. When intention reaches qi, there is nothing left to hear—only emptiness awaiting things. The Dao gathers here; this is the wondrous function of the fasting of the mind.

*Liezi* states: The body harmonizes with the mind, the mind with qi, qi with spirit—this meaning is the same.

When Yan Hui awakened, he said, "Hui has not yet attained." Zhongni taught him the fasting of the mind. Before attaining it, Hui truly possessed a self; having attained it, he was without self. The Master further told him: Though you have reached emptiness, if you enter the realm of action, you must remain unmoved by names.

The mind is like a flute: empty, awaiting qi. When qi enters, it sounds; when it does not, it stops—where is there room for the mind in between? Entrusting the egress and ingress of the myriad things, it is without gate; consigning the world’s self-governance, it is without harm. Embracing the One and abiding in it, one rises only when compelled to respond to things, lodging their principle in them without claiming possession—this is perfection.

To exhaust the principle of nature and destiny while acting—such action is none other than Heaven’s. Serving man is easily feigned; serving Heaven makes pretense difficult. Wings for flight, knowledge for knowing—this illustrates that Yan Hui must possess a dwelling of utmost emptiness to transform things.

Gazing upon that prior realm, utterly void and clear—this is an analogy for the mind. When brightness arises, the Dao gathers—this is called nature. When spirit abides in stillness, auspicious signs come to rest. Those who cannot rest sit in form while their spirit races.

Those who attain stillness need not have ears and eyes fixed outward; mind and will need not be confined within. Thus, though there may be thought and action, there is no worldly entanglement. Spirits and gods will come to dwell—how much more so men?

*Detailed Daoist Annotation*: Acting from having is what the ancients found difficult. Where there is thought, there must be fasting; where there is action, there must be vigilance. Thus, those who would make their virtue spiritually luminous must fast the mind—this is why Zhongni instructed Yan Hui.

*Wenzi* says: The highest learning listens with spirit, the middle with the mind, the lowest with the ears. Listening that stops at the ears is limited to what the ears can hear; listening that stops at tallying signs is limited to what the mind can unite. Listening with qi is boundless, vast and free-flowing—thus it employs form without being employed by form, awaits things without being awaited by things. Empty yet unobstructed, responsive yet not retaining, this is how single-mindedness preserves qi, preserving qi attains emptiness, attaining emptiness gathers the Dao—this is the meaning of the fasting of the mind.

Before Hui attained the fasting of the mind, he still sighed as if possessing a self; having attained it, he was without self. Thus, he could enter its bounds without being moved by its name—when entering, it sounds; when not, it stops. Without gate, without harm, he drew action back to non-action. Dwelling in one abode and lodging in inevitability, he extended non-action to lodge in action.

Heaven not treading earth is easy; treading without touching the ground is difficult. Non-action is easy; engaging the world without transgression is difficult. Doing what men do is serving man, hence easily feigned; doing what Heaven does is serving Heaven, hence difficult to counterfeit.

Without wings, the bird cannot fly; without knowledge, man cannot know. Without emptiness, the room cannot generate brightness—how could auspicious signs come to rest? If one does not rest, even in silent seclusion among mountains and forests, one is still "sitting in motion."

When ears and eyes turn inward, there is no hearing, no seeing; transcending the mind’s knowing, there is no thought, no knowledge. Thus, emptiness reaches its extreme, stillness its sincerity—spirits and gods come to unite, how much more so men? This is how one commands the transformation of the myriad things without being transformed by them—the lifelong practice of the ancient sages.

*Bìxū’s Annotation*: Ritual fasting involves advancement; the fasting of the mind awakens to the root. Not listening with the ears but with the mind is to abandon illumination and observe the wondrous. Not listening with the mind but with qi is to merge into the vast and boundless. Beginners reach this point scattered and difficult to gather, yet there is a wondrous gateway: when listening stops at the ears, spirit concentrates on its charge, inner vision does not stray, and outer dust does not enter.

When the mind rests upon the tally, auspicious light congeals and coalesces, and the numinous palace becomes profoundly clear while the heart’s sovereign attains stillness. Thus, the primal qi pervades emptiness, fundamentally requiring nothing, yet within this non-dependence, numinous beings gather of themselves—just as the *jiaoli* and fire-peach do not grow in thorny thickets. This principle is known only to those who cultivate and practice.

The attainment of efficacy lies in the subtle application of the fasting of the mind. In truth, it is the turning back of the self; one has not yet emptied the heart. When there has never been a turning back, even emptiness is forgotten. If one can enter the domain of laws and decrees, remaining unmoved and unassuming amidst things, one may nearly escape entanglement. *Entering* means to listen and receive; *wu* means speech without artifice. When listened to, one speaks; when not listened to, one ceases. Expansive words are called "no gate"; the flavor of principle is called "no harm." For one whose heart is undivided, dwelling in the unavoidable and entrusting merit to the forest of beings—halting progress is easy, but walking without touching the ground is difficult. This illustrates how others are easily deceived, while the self is hard to delude. With wings, one may soar through the gorges to the heavens; with the Dao, one may respond to change. When the chamber is empty, yang brightness arises; when the heart is settled, celestial radiance emerges. To sit idly in a hall while harboring likes and dislikes is like a horse tethered in its stall yet galloping a thousand miles in intent.

Not resisting the six senses externally allows one to inwardly gather the numinous light, leaving no room for worldly affairs to stain or defile.

*Zhao’s Annotation*: When listening stops at the ears and the mind rests upon the tally, one attains perfect stillness. Qi is emptiness awaiting things, responding and thus penetrating. Only the Dao gathers in emptiness; emptiness is where all principles converge—this is called the fasting of the mind. Yanzi suddenly realized: "When I cannot move as I wish, there is an ‘I’; when I can move as I wish, there is no ‘I.’" The Master praised his attainment of perfection and further instructed him: "You may enter their domain without being swayed by fame. When in accord, speak; when not, cease." *No gate* means I have no crevice for others to exploit; *no harm* means they do not perceive me as a threat. Dwelling in the unavoidable, one may nearly succeed. Halting progress is easy; walking without touching the ground is difficult—this too embodies the meaning of the unavoidable. Being used by others involves intention, hence is easily feigned; being used by Heaven follows principle, hence is hard to counterfeit. Flying without wings or knowing without knowledge is to be swift without haste, to arrive without traveling.

*Que* refers to the nature of emptiness. An empty chamber generates brightness; a vast space radiates light. When auspiciousness comes to rest, neither misfortune nor fortune arrives. If one harbors a mind seeking blessings, this is called "sitting while galloping." Following the ears and eyes inwardly unites them with clarity; transcending the mind’s knowledge unites them with emptiness. Thus, one may join the company of spirits and gods—who among men would not believe it?

*Yong Qi* said: "If you rely on your cunning to act, the moment this intention arises, Heaven’s will is displeased." First, focus the will to keep it untainted. Listening with the ears remains external; listening with the mind still involves an "I"; listening with qi leaves no thing. When listening stops at the ears, it does not enter the heart; when the mind rests upon the tally, it aligns with things, creating a division between self and other. Emptiness is where the Dao resides; only the Dao gathers in emptiness—this single word *emptiness* is the fasting of the mind. Before receiving instruction, Yanzi still had an "I"; after receiving instruction, there had never been an "I"—forgetting the self is emptiness. The Master further warned that the human world is like a cage: you may enter and move within it without being swayed by fame. *Entering* means to *wu*—when one may speak, speak; when one may not, cease. Without fixed direction, there is no gate; without scent or taste, there is no harm—these are metaphors for a mind without intention or striving. Taking unity as one’s dwelling and lodging the heart in the unavoidable, one fulfills the Way of the human world. Halting progress without moving is easy; walking without touching the ground is difficult. Being enslaved by human desires makes deception easy; only by darkening the mind and following the Creator’s decree can one leave

The term *mou* (谋) has been debated, with Xia’s interpretation of it as "planning" deemed inadequate. Yongzhai’s gloss of it as "reckless action" comes closer. Now, to clarify: "listening with the ears" halts at hearing the Dao without fully practicing it; "listening with the heart" halts at aligning with the Dao without fully forgetting it. But when one listens with *qi*, there is nothing unheard, nothing unaligned—roaming boundlessly, merging with the Great Void. Where is the Great Void not present? Thus, one awaits things with perfect receptivity, and nothing escapes. What the ears obscure, the heart clarifies; what the heart aligns with is *qi*, which, in stillness and non-action, empties itself to receive all things—this is what Mencius called "the vast and overflowing *qi* that fills all between heaven and earth." Observe how it is never filled when poured, never exhausted when drawn, ever-increasing when given, ever-responsive yet ever-still—what need has it for waiting or not waiting?

All under heaven is pervaded by a single *qi*, shared by all beings and the Great Void. Only emptiness and *qi* are neither identical nor separate, mutually revealing essence and function, thus nowhere obstructed. The Dao, however, is neither emptiness nor *qi*, yet can be both—transforming the rigid under heaven, governing the solid, awaiting things without awaiting, responding perfectly without exhaustion. The marvel of "fasting of the heart" lies in emptiness alone. Thus, it can still all actions, illuminate all things, like a mirror unveiled, like a scale suspended—nothing escapes its measure of weight or beauty, yet it bears no burden of favor or resentment, giving or taking. In this way, one dwells in the human world as if at play.

Yanzi suddenly realized: "Before grasping the function of 'fasting of the heart,' I truly had an 'I'; once grasping it, there has never been an 'I'—how swift is the transformation!" The Master often praised him for appearing foolish in his unceasing compliance, which was the true proof of having never had an "I." When Yanzi was about to depart for Wei, the Master instructed him thus: the daily transmission of inner learning concerns the subtleties of nature and destiny, truly for cultivating the self. Now, as he was to engage in governance and assist the Way, the Master detailed the intricacies of ruler-minister relations and worldly affairs, harmonizing form and *qi*, emptying within and manifesting without—above, to attain the marvelous function of "fasting of the heart," below, to reveal the true mechanism of transformation. This is how the sage follows heaven as his companion without entanglement in the affairs of the human world.

When Duke Ye’s son Gao was sent as an envoy to Qi, he asked Confucius: "The king has entrusted me with great responsibility. Qi treats its envoys with utmost respect but little urgency. Even a common man cannot be swayed—how much less a lord! I tremble with fear." You once told me: "In all matters, great or small, few succeed without some discord. If a matter fails, one faces human-inflicted harm; if it succeeds, one faces harm from the imbalance of yin and yang. Only those of virtue can achieve success or failure without harm. I eat coarse food without craving refinement, and my cook has no desire for coolness. Yet this morning I received my orders, and by evening I am drinking ice—is this not inner heat? I have not yet encountered the reality of the matter, yet I already suffer from yin-yang imbalance. If the matter fails, I will surely face human-inflicted harm. Facing both possibilities, a minister is unfit for the task. Please instruct me further!"

Confucius replied: "There are two great precepts under heaven: one is destiny, the other is righteousness. Your love for your parents is destiny—inescapable in the heart. A minister’s service to his lord is righteousness—there is no place under heaven where it does not apply, nowhere to flee. These are the great precepts. Thus, in serving one’s parents, one finds peace regardless of circumstance—this is the height of filial piety. In serving one’s lord, one finds peace regardless of the task—this is the height of loyalty. In serving one’s own heart, joy remains unchanged before all things, knowing the inevitable and accepting it as destiny—this is the height of virtue. As a minister and son, one inevitably faces the unavoidable. Proceeding with the nature of affairs while forgetting the self, how can one have leisure to delight in life or fear death? You may go now.

Let me repeat what I have heard: In close dealings, trust must be mutual; in distant dealings, words must convey loyalty, and those words may be transmitted. Transmitting words that please or anger both sides is the most difficult task under heaven. Words that please both sides tend to be excessive in praise; words that anger both sides tend to be excessive in blame. All excess is falsehood, and falsehood cannot be trusted. Distrust brings calamity to the messenger. Thus, the *Fayan* says: 'Transmit the constant truth, not the excessive words—this is nearly perfect.' Guo’s commentary notes: 'In matters great or small, few succeed without some discord. Success brings harmony, failure brings anger—this is unavoidable even for the King of Chu.' If success removes human harm, one’s five viscera are already bound in ice and fire. Entrusting success or failure to others without distressing the heart—only those of virtue can do this.

Now, one who faces fire does not seek coolness, knowing the meagerness of one’s provisions. Yet drinking ice due to inner heat truly arises from anxiety over the difficulty of the task. Before the matter is resolved, one fears failure; if it indeed fails, fear congeals within, and the net of punishment ensnares without. The Master taught the great precepts of destiny and righteousness—naturally firm and unbreakable. If a lord could be fled or parents abandoned, they would not be precepts. Knowing the inevitable and accepting it as destiny, one is free from sorrow or joy—what change could there be?"

Thus, one remains profoundly serene, accepting all encounters as destiny, without interposing the heart between them. Even in serving ordinary people, one finds no situation unsuited—how much more so with lord and kin? Matters have their inevitable course; principle is ever-pervading. One must simply proceed as fate decrees.

If faith in the Dao is not steadfast, if delight and aversion linger in the heart, if one schemes for life and frets over death, success in affairs will never be seen. Words born of joy or anger often exceed the truth; those who transmit them should neither lose nor embellish the mean. Should the transmission err toward excess, it verges on falsehood. The receiver, harboring doubt, imputes fault to the messenger. Thus, one ought not convey momentary lapses in speech, but rather the enduring disposition, distilling its sincerity—this approaches wholeness.

Lu’s Annotation: External things cannot be made certain, yet in all affairs, great or small, success alone brings joy—this is insistence on certainty. Whether success or failure comes, the ebb and flow of human and cosmic forces remain—this is the way of war. Only those of virtue can transcend the self; transcending the self, they know no insistence; knowing no insistence, they know no ebb.

If, before action is taken, anxiety already kindles inner heat, then one has not yet grasped the true nature of the matter but has already succumbed to the ebb of yin and yang—so deeply is one unable to forget the self. Thus, Confucius taught that love for kin is destiny, and service to one’s lord is righteousness—neither can be untied from the heart. In serving parents, one does not choose between level or perilous ground; in serving one’s lord, one does not choose between ease or difficulty—one accepts all with equanimity. This is the height of loyalty and filial piety. Then, in tending the heart, how could sorrow or joy readily shift before one? If sorrow or joy shifts readily, it is because one makes choices and cannot accept what comes. One who can tend the heart will find all service to kin and lord equally at peace.

If one can truly accept without choosing, then one acts in accord with the nature of affairs, forgetting the self—how could there be leisure to delight in life and fear death?

Yi Du’s Annotation: All who seek to establish affairs rejoice in success and grieve over failure; thus, whether success or failure comes, none escape the ebb. Can one escape this ebb? Only those of virtue, perhaps.

Zigao himself confessed: "I eat coarse food, not refined, so when I cook, the fire does not burn long, and I do not seek coolness. Yet this morning, upon receiving my charge, by evening I drink ice—my inner heat is plain to see. Before even encountering the true nature of the matter, I cannot escape the ebb of yin and yang and human forces. As a minister, I am unworthy of this task—pray, instruct me."

Confucius taught the great precepts for minister and child: destiny lies with Heaven, righteousness with man. A child’s love for parents cannot be untied from the heart; a minister’s service to his lord admits no alternative but the lord. The heart is the true lord of man. If one seeks it within and serves it, one forgets even lord and kin, entrusting all to nature and remaining unmoved by sorrow or joy. In matters beyond one’s control, one acts in accord with the nature of affairs, forgetting the self—how could there be leisure to delight in life and fear death?

Confucius further taught the way of transmitting words: In close dealings with others, one may demand truth, so mutual trust prevails. At a distance, one cannot lose the transmission, so one conveys words with fidelity. Yet the most difficult words to transmit are those born of joy or anger, for praise or blame in excess resembles delusion and credulity. To err is to bring calamity upon the transmitter. Thus, convey the enduring disposition, not the excesses of speech—this is the way to preserve wholeness.

The *Bi Xu* commentary states: The hearth harbors no desire for clarity, for purity lies in the composed and indifferent. To drink ice for internal heat only exacerbates the afflictions of sorrow and vexation. To avoid the perils of yin-yang and the human Dao, one seeks instruction from Confucius.

Confucius teaches that father and son are joined by Heaven’s decree as *ming*, while ruler and minister are bound by the Dao as *yi*. Moreover, beneath the workings of creation, all are tied to ruler and kin—nowhere can one escape within Heaven and Earth. This is called the Great Precept. Thus, one does not select circumstances but abides in them; to choose is to fail in loyalty and filial piety.

For one who attends to the heart, sorrow and joy do not alter what lies before; only trust in the Dao and entrustment to *ming* remain. As ministers and children, there are indeed matters beyond one’s control. Shun’s potting and fishing, Yu’s governance of the waters—only by exhausting devotion and forgetting the self can one rest in *ming* and *yi*.

Mutual trust in proximity, fidelity in speech from afar—both are advances. Observing the path, one discerns their root. Transmitting words is like treading forward; the value lies in moderation. Excess or deficiency both err, and error brings calamity to the transmitter, for deviation from constancy incurs loss.

The *Zhao* commentary states: If plans for affairs fail, disgrace and humiliation follow—this is the decline of the human Dao. If plans succeed, joy and fear intermingle—this is the peril of yin-yang. My coarse and rough fare, my hearth’s silence without song—can this not be called frugality? Yet though no internal heat afflicts me, my breast already burns as if scorched. Before affairs succeed or fail, both perils converge upon me. What teaching can you offer?

Thus, he imparts the Great Precept of *ming* and *yi*, likening service to a ruler to service to kin. Having pledged oneself as a minister, how can one spare concern for the self? He further instructs on the way of transmission: fidelity and trust as the foundation, caution in transmitting words amid joy and anger—this is how wholeness is preserved.

*Yongzhai* says: If one schemes for the state and fails, punishment is certain—this is the decline of the human Dao. If one labors in calculation and succeeds, anxiety and thought breed illness—this is the peril of yin-yang. Since receiving my charge, I have eaten without savor, my breast seared with toil, yet before truly grasping affairs, this affliction has already taken hold. Should matters fail, punishment will follow—thus both perils are borne. What teaching can you offer?

Confucius instructed him in the two great precepts. *Precepts* are akin to laws. *Ming* is what one receives from Heaven. Serving kin is coeval with life itself, thus it cannot be sundered from the heart. *Yi* is what one ought to do—serving one’s lord is the foremost duty. In serving kin with utmost filiality, one follows their commands east or west, south or north, without choosing where to settle. With the heart devoted to loyalty, though sorrow and joy arise before one, it remains unaltered. For affairs may be easy or difficult, yet once the lord’s command is issued, it is what one must do—Heaven’s *ming* is the same, and there is nothing to be done but accept it. Should a minister or child encounter misfortune, one must simply perform the task at hand in truth—how could one then spare concern for the self?

Zigao, about to be sent on a mission to Qi, sought confirmation from Confucius regarding what he had heard in ordinary times, and also to dispel his own confusion—his heart torn between the anxiety of duty and the dread of peril, hoping for a remedy. Confucius taught him the two precepts of *ming* and *yi*: the great principles of loyalty and filiality—serving kin cannot be sundered from the heart, and serving one’s lord admits no escape under Heaven. In affairs of the heart, sorrow and joy find no purchase. Herein lies the essence of standing in the world. Yet the heart is the lord of Heaven, the source of all transformations; if one can serve the heart to the utmost, one’s conduct toward lord and kin may be known. To accept what cannot be helped is to know how one should conduct oneself in ordinary times. Firm in the Dao and clear in self-knowledge, what attachment or aversion could there be to life or death?

This is how one instructs all under Heaven who serve as ministers and children—to find peace in what is difficult to accept. The utmost of loyalty and filiality is the fulfillment of standing in the world. Confucius further expounded on the difficulty of transmitting words as an envoy, teaching him the way to preserve wholeness, so that the lord might not lose virtue and the minister might not disgrace his charge. This was a step below what he had revealed to Yan Hui. Only Yan Hui, who had mastered *ming* and exhausted the spiritual, could grasp Confucius’ discourse on the fasting of the mind and attain the ultimate state of sitting in forgetfulness. Zigao, however, still harbored concerns of gain and loss, advantage and harm, so Confucius merely instructed him to transmit commands with care and preserve the integrity of a minister. Herein lies the sage’s art of teaching according to capacity, guiding step by step with benevolence.

*The Meaning of the "True Scripture of Southern Florescence," Gathered from the Sea of Annotations*, Scroll Eight, concludes.
---
*According to Guo Xiang’s commentary, the character 有 should be followed by 心.*
*天 is a scribal error for 夫.*

*The Meaning of the "True Scripture of Southern Florescence," Gathered from the Sea of Annotations*, Scroll Nine.
By the Daoist of Wulin, Chu Boxiu.

**Chapter Three: In the Human World**

Those who contend with skill and strength begin in brightness but invariably end in darkness; when excess prevails, deceit and cunning multiply. Those who drink wine with ritual propriety begin in order but invariably end in chaos; when excess prevails, strange pleasures abound. All affairs are thus: they commence in sincerity but conclude in vulgarity. What begins simply will inevitably grow vast. Words are like wind and waves; deeds are like gain and loss. Wind and waves are easily stirred, while gain and loss are easily imperiled. Thus, wrath arises without cause, and artful speech with biased words. When beasts are cornered, they do not choose their cries; their breath becomes ragged, and in that moment, a murderous intent takes hold. When scrutiny is too severe, a base heart responds in kind, though one remains unaware of it. If one does not know how this comes to be, how can one know where it will end?

As the *Fa Yan* states: Do not alter decrees, do not urge completion—excess only compounds the error. To alter decrees and urge completion at the outset is to court peril; what is beautifully accomplished endures, while what is badly done cannot be undone. How can one not be cautious?

Yet to ride things with the mind, entrusting oneself to necessity to nurture the center—this is perfection! Why act in expectation of reward? Nothing compares to delivering one’s mandate. This is the most difficult.

**Guo’s Commentary:**
Beginning in brightness and ending in darkness, the desire to prevail leads to excess, where harm arises and principle is abandoned. Beginning in order and ending in chaos, toasts follow sequence until drunkenness and debauchery know no bounds. Trouble arises from simplicity, and affairs emerge from the subtle—this is the principle of ultimate consequences. Words are like wind and waves; deeds bring gain or loss. When affairs attain their truth, peril may be stabilized and disorder settled. Wrath arises from artful words exceeding truth and biased speech missing the mark. Like a beast driven to desperation, its intent exhausted and breath disordered, it erupts in sudden fury, and both parties breed resentment in response. When scrutiny is too precise, vulgar and miserly thoughts arise unconsciously—how then can one know where fortune or misfortune will lead? To alter decrees and urge completion is to invite danger. What is beautifully accomplished follows the transformations of time, like planting—it cannot be rushed. To force completion of what one dislikes is to invite regret. Moreover, to lodge the mind in things and follow the inevitable course of principle is the fullness of the Mean, the ultimate in engaging the world. One should simply fulfill the reality of the mission—why interpose one’s own intentions? To deliver one’s mandate is easiest, yet to apply the mind with joy or anger makes it difficult.

**Lü’s Commentary:**
When the human heart is deep and still, words become wind and waves, easily stirred; when stilled, they rest in truth and peace. Deeds become gain or loss, easily imperiled. In such moments of ease and peril, one cannot but be cautious. To tend the heart and forget the self is to transcend the ebb and flow of yin and yang; to neither alter decrees nor urge completion is to transcend the ebb and flow of human affairs. When the heart emerges, it is shaped by things—this is riding things with the mind. Action arises from necessity; to entrust oneself to necessity is to nurture the center. Now, in being sent to Qi, nothing compares to delivering one’s mandate. To fulfill one’s duty is to remain unmoved by life or death, fortune or misfortune, and thus attain the truth of affairs. Why act in expectation of reward? Only to deliver one’s mandate with utter sincerity—this alone is difficult.

**Yi Du’s Commentary:**
Those who contend with skill and strength begin in joy and end in anger; those who drink wine with ritual begin in order and end in chaos. "Strange cunning" refers to deceit, and "strange pleasures" to unnatural delight. Affairs commence in trust and sincerity but conclude in coarseness and crudeness. What begins simply will inevitably grow vast—this is the constant way of human affairs.

The heart is likened to water, and words to wind and waves. Virtue is substance; conduct is ornament. Without conduct, virtue does not diminish; without ornament, substance is not lost. When the heart is already joyful, it is easily moved; when virtue is already lost, it is easily imperiled. The expression of anger and wrath arises from cunning words that lack substance, from biased speech that strays from reason—like being driven into a corner where silence is forced, where cries are uttered without regard for sound, where qi becomes pent-up and stagnant, and flaws and afflictions arise together. This illustrates that those who govern their hearts should release them into a state of non-action. To lead them onto the path of worry and distress is no different from driving a beast into a desperate corner.

To "restrain" is to reproach others too harshly; to "press" is to coerce them too severely. The unworthy heart responds in kind without even realizing it. For an emissary, altering decrees or urging their fulfillment are both perilous endeavors. True excellence matures over time—benevolence lies in its ripeness. If one urges the completion of what another detests, regret will soon follow. Can one not be cautious? Riding the myriad things to roam the heart, entrusting oneself to the supreme principle to nurture the center—what must be done arises from necessity. Following the "supervisor" as one’s guiding thread embodies the meaning of nurturing the center through necessity. This is perfection. Why then must one force action to repay the ruler’s virtue? Nothing compares to delivering one’s mandate without disgrace—this alone is difficult.

**Bixu’s Commentary:**
Cunning changes invite contention; excessive pleasure leads to chaos. Words like wind and waves are easily stirred, while conduct that loses substance is hard to stabilize. When a beast is cornered, it emits vicious sounds; when one reproaches others too deeply, harmony is lost—this is simply how principle operates, though none know why it must be so. Those who follow laws and decrees do not alter them; those who humbly cultivate themselves require no urging. Excellence matures over time—great vessels are late in completion. If what is forced to completion has no chance for correction, what is taken must also be given.

Riding things to roam the heart is to follow their nature; entrusting oneself to necessity is to empty the self. To act in repayment is false; to forget oneself is easy. The difficulty of delivering a ruler’s mandate lies neither in difficulty nor ease—only those who embody the Way can achieve it.

**Zhao’s Commentary:**
What begins in yang ends in yin; what begins in order ends in chaos—this is the inevitable principle. Water meets wind and waves arise; a beast nears death and roars—this too is the necessary course of events. A single word uttered can incite anger in others—is this not like wind and waves? Once angered, one acts upon it—is this not the loss of substance? Altering decrees and urging completion is excessive; to add to such matters is to court danger. What is beautifully completed arises from joy and endures, for its value lies in its duration. What is forced to completion begins without intent and cannot last.

When the heart is lodged in things, yet rests wholly in necessity without being moved, the way of nurturing the center reaches its pinnacle. Why anticipate difficulty and act in repayment? Nothing surpasses delivering one’s mandate with utter sincerity—this alone is difficult.

**Yongzhai’s Note:**
Yang is joy; yin is aversion. Excessive indulgence in amusement leads to the misuse of strange cunning. To invite others to drink with ritual: order marks the beginning of the feast, when all is measured and decorous; chaos comes when voices rise in clamor. When drinking exceeds propriety, pleasure becomes abnormal, and contention may arise. *Liang* means trust; *bi* means deceit. In human affairs, words give rise to wind and waves; conduct with traces of fame loses substance.

The expression of anger and wrath stems from cunning words and biased speech—like the cries of a dying beast, what choice is there in sound? When qi is pent-up in anger, cruelty and malice arise together. This is restraint and pressing, so the unworthy heart responds without knowing why. Here, the discussion returns to the emissary’s duty.

To "not alter decrees" is to convey their constant essence; to "not urge completion" is to let things unfold naturally. The moment one entertains excessive intentions, one seeks to add to matters, and plans become perilous. Excellence matures over time—human relationships reach perfection not in a day. A single misstep can turn good into ill, leaving no chance for correction. If one rides things to roam the heart, entrusting oneself to necessity to nurture the center’s uprightness, this is perfection. Why then act further to fulfill a mandate? One should simply deliver the ruler’s command with sincerity, without overthinking success or failure.

The Dharma of the transcendent is the Dharma of the worldly; to dwell in the world without entanglement is to transcend it. First, the difficulty of delivering a mandate is discussed, then the text broadly addresses the inevitable course of worldly affairs, where none know why things must unfold as they do—seeking only to understand their principle. The metaphors of wind and waves, of lost substance, are apt indeed.

"Restraint and pressing" are taken to extremes: *he* (pressing) is akin to *he* (investigation), though few commentaries elaborate. Only *Yi Du* separates them into two terms. Here, following the original meaning of *he*: it refers to the kernel where the vitality of fruit resides, where benevolence is contained. The ancients used it to illustrate the intent of the Seven Affections. To carve away at the kernel is to injure benevolence and extinguish vitality; to carve away at conduct is to injure righteousness and sever human bonds. Thus, the unworthy heart responds without intending to.

*Xiao* means "to resemble"—the Seven Hearts bestow likeness, treating all equally. If kindness and benevolence are absent, the heart loses its likeness—what evil would it not commit? Such outcomes are summoned by one’s own actions, and the mechanism cannot be ignored. The *Wenzhongzi*’s *Zhougong* chapter states: "Those who delight in the strange and revere the bizarre, unrestrained in their excess, will inevitably summon an unworthy heart in response." This saying originates here.

"Beautiful completion" and "forced completion" are opposing concepts. Some commentaries read *e* (forced) with a departing tone, but here it is interpreted with its original sound: the completion of beauty and goodness is most difficult, requiring long accumulation and transformation.

The completion of transgressions and evils is most effortless—once formed, even the desire to reform may come too late.

The preceding line warns against altering the state’s decrees and ordinances at will; the following line cautions against encouraging the arrogance of the Marquis of Qi. Ride the currents of things to roam the mind, act in accordance with principle, and do not preemptively weigh success or failure. When circumstances leave no choice, nurture the center; when principle reaches its limit, halt without losing the central Way. This is sufficient—why fabricate actions to repay one’s lord? Better to deliver one’s mandate: simply accept life and death, fortune and misfortune—what difficulty lies in this?

The Master first instructed on the great admonitions of fate and destiny, yet ultimately returned to the original intent. Observing this passage, it exhaustively captures the nature of things—who would claim the *Nanhua* [Zhuangzi] scorns the world beyond and neglects worldly affairs?

Yan He was about to serve as tutor to the crown prince of Duke Ling of Wei. He asked Lian Boyu, “There is a man here whose virtue is heaven-sent in its destructiveness. If I deal with him without restraint, I endanger the state; if I deal with him with restraint, I endanger myself. His knowledge suffices only to recognize others’ faults but not the causes of those faults. In such a case, what am I to do?”

Lian Boyu replied, “Excellent question! Be vigilant, be cautious—rectify yourself! In form, nothing surpasses compliance; in heart, nothing surpasses harmony. Yet these two carry their own perils. Compliance must not become subservience; harmony must not become ostentation. If form complies and becomes subservient, you will face ruin, destruction, collapse, and downfall. If the heart harmonizes and becomes ostentatious, you will invite fame, reputation, calamity, and misfortune.

If he acts like an infant, act like an infant with him. If he acts without boundaries, act without boundaries with him. If he acts without limits, act without limits with him. Guide him thus, and he will enter a state without blemish.

Do you not know the mantis? It brandishes its arms to block a chariot’s wheels, unaware of its incapacity—such is the beauty of its talent. Be vigilant, be cautious! To accumulate praise for one’s beauty and then provoke him is perilous indeed!

Do you not know those who raise tigers? They dare not feed them living creatures, for fear of inciting their killing rage; they dare not feed them whole creatures, for fear of inciting their tearing rage. They time their hunger and satiety, understanding their temper. Tigers and humans are of different kinds, yet tigers fawn upon those who raise them—this is compliance. Thus, those they kill act in defiance.

Those who love horses use baskets to collect their dung and gourds to collect their urine. Yet when a mosquito or fly alights and they swat it untimely, the horse may break its bit, shatter its bridle, or fracture its chest. Love may reach an extreme where it incurs loss—can one not be cautious?

Guo’s commentary: The nature of petty men is such that if guided by rules, they resent restraint; if left unrestrained, they throw the state into chaos. Unaware that the people’s faults arise from oneself, they blame the people without self-correction—what then is to be done? The repeated admonitions converge on the need to rectify oneself. Form should not deviate from compliance, yet harmony does not mean sameness. Compliance in form is outward submission; subservience leads to complete assimilation. Harmony in principle is righteous aid; ostentation leads to self-promotion. Assimilation means failing to support when in peril, perishing together. Self-promotion in harmony invites slander, as he will resent being surpassed and fabricate calamities. Thus, one must blend like dust in light, rendering distinctions of closeness, distance, benefit, and harm indiscernible.

Acting like an infant avoids setting sharp edges to provoke his scales. Now, to take on a task for which one’s knowledge is inadequate is like the mantis brandishing its arms against a chariot’s wheels—accumulating talent and praise to provoke is the path to danger. Thus, compliance with principle engenders love even among different kinds, while defiance of norms turns even the closest into adversaries. In dealing with the world, the boundary between compliance and defiance cannot be ignored.

Lü’s commentary: A virtue that is heaven-sent in its destructiveness is beyond human cultivation. To engage him without restraint endangers the state; to engage him with restraint endangers oneself—no approach is viable. Recognizing others’ faults without understanding their causes makes the task all the more difficult. The error of compliance lies in subservience, which leads to assimilation; the error of harmony lies in ostentation, which leads to differentiation. Thus, ruin, destruction, collapse, downfall, fame, reputation, calamity, and misfortune arise from assimilation without knowing how to support, or differentiation without knowing how to comply.

Acting like an infant, without boundaries, or without limits—though one engages him without restraint, the state is not endangered; though one engages him with restraint, the self is not imperiled. This is to follow the nature he possesses and guide him, as when King Xuan favored bravery and wealth, and Mencius led him toward the kingly Way.

The later references to the mantis and the love of horses are illustrative analogies, their meaning clear and requiring no full explanation.

Yi Du’s commentary: “Heaven-sent destructiveness” means his evil virtue is innate and unalterable. *Fang* means “rule.” To engage him beyond the rules is to indulge his desires and corrupt order, endangering the state; to engage him within the rules is to suppress his desires and stifle his nature, endangering oneself. Recognizing his faults without understanding their causes—what is to be done? The answer is to first rectify oneself. Form, being external, should align with others—thus, nothing surpasses compliance. The heart, being internal, should differ from others—thus, nothing surpasses harmony.
