Compliance must not become subservience, lest it invite familiarity; harmony must not become ostentation, lest it invite self-display. Subservience and familiarity lead to ruin, destruction, collapse, and downfall; ostentation and self-display lead to fame, reputation, calamity, and misfortune. Hence the need for vigilance and caution.

*Ying’er* means “without knowledge.” *Dingqi* means “boundaries.” *Ya* means “shore.” Follow his actions, adapt without resistance, then guide him to enter a state without blemish. The mantis brandishing its arms is a warning to Yan He not to clash with his sharpness.

To nurture a tiger or tend a horse is to enable Yan He to guide them with principle.

*Detailed Daoist Annotation*: Serving a ruler is easy; instructing a ruler is difficult. Instructing a ruler is easy; instructing a crown prince is difficult. With power so exalted and position so weighty, principle struggles to transform—how much more so when his virtue is inherently destructive! This is why one must tremble with caution.

To "align in form" is to draw near without mingling, bending externally. To "harmonize in heart" is to differ without discord, remaining upright internally. External bending ensures one does not lose others; internal uprightness ensures one does not lose oneself. If one aligns and submits, one becomes boundless with them, endangering one’s state. If one harmonizes and projects, one becomes constrained with them, endangering one’s person. Thus, one must engage as with an infant—without boundaries, without shores—guiding them to enter a state without blemish. The ancients who mirrored their lord’s excesses or matched his extravagance did so for this reason.

*Yu’s Annotation*: "Trembling" follows the previous explanation.
*Bixu’s Annotation*: To collude in evil is to bring chaos to the state; to lead them by the Dao is to harm oneself. Only those skilled in the art of expansion and contraction can truly instruct them. If one examines one’s own faults, no ominous virtue remains.

To rectify oneself is the teaching without words. In form, nothing surpasses compliance—engaging without constraint. In heart, nothing surpasses harmony—seizing with principle. To comply and submit is to share in evil, leading to ruin, destruction, collapse, and downfall, thus endangering one’s state. To harmonize and project is to display self-importance, leading to fame, reputation, calamity, and misfortune, thus endangering one’s person. Therefore, from *ying’er* to the absence of shores lies the Dao of expansion and contraction, of giving and seizing.

The mantis brandishing its arms against the chariot’s wheel—with talent fine yet strength feeble, how could it not fail? Nurturing a tiger or tending a horse illustrates that controlling things lies in defense, while employing others lies in authority. To lose authority, overreach, and seek to master things is to harm oneself alone.

*Zhao’s Annotation*: Aligning in form ensures they do not distance themselves from me; harmonizing in heart supplements what they lack. Harmony is like blending broth—not sameness that makes it harmonious. Even so, one may still not escape danger. To comply and submit is to indulge the lord’s evil; to harmonize and project is to expose the lord’s evil—ruin, destruction, collapse, and downfall follow, sinking all into oblivion.

Names and omens—these are the pursuit of fame that invites calamity. Thus, one must blend radiance and merge with the dust, leaving no foothold for flaws, to attain perfection.

The three metaphors—the mantis, the tiger, and the beloved horse—differ in circumstance yet share the same intent. *Yuanzhai* observes: "Its virtue is devoured by Heaven," meaning it is consumed by the celestial. "Without method" signifies the absence of restraint. If one indulges their transgressions, the state is surely imperiled; yet to correct them invites misfortune upon oneself—what then is to be done? To instruct them to rectify themselves is to govern others by one’s own standards.

"Compliance" means following in accord. "Harmony" means attunement. Outwardly following while inwardly attuning still brings no respite. To follow in accord until one becomes indistinguishable is to comply and submit; to attune while revealing one’s edges is to harmonize and project—ruin and ominous disaster are all that remain.

The infant, the unguarded, the boundless—these depict the state of reckless ignorance. When they are thus, I simply comply; when they show signs of awakening, I subtly guide them, that they may suddenly awaken and perhaps enter a place without flaw.

The mantis raises its arms in fury—this illustrates how petty talent, puffed with self-importance, presumes to take on great matters, and seldom does it not end in failure. "Rearing tigers" and "cherishing horses" are analogies whose meaning is self-evident.

To observe Bo Yu’s instruction of Yan He is yet a step below the Master’s teaching of Zi Gao, for Zi Gao still knew to honor the Lord of Chu, bearing a mind of reverence and trepidation in service. Thus the Master warned him of the great caution inherent in fate and duty, concluding with "riding things and roaming the mind," entrusting all to necessity. Though he entrusted himself to the mission, he still preserved his sovereign integrity, never to the point of sacrificing himself for others while forgetting his own nature.

Yan He, however, already knowing that the burdens of governance could not be shouldered, yet sought to shoulder them—first doubting himself while demanding another’s trust—this was already somewhat contrary to principle. Thus Bo Yu told him, "Rectify yourself first!" Only when the root is established can the branches be raised. "Outward compliance and inward harmony" merely reflect the recognition that force cannot prevail against the prevailing tide, and so this expedient counsel is offered for self-preservation—it is no true way of governance. How much less so is the path of "complying to enter" and "harmonizing to emerge"?

To treat another as an infant, as one without guard or bound—this is the extreme of "complying to enter." Though there may be an opportunity to enlighten through timely guidance, how can one of the esteemed rank of a mentor-teacher lack the art of gentle persuasion and resort to such measures? Even if one thus leads them to understanding, it may only spare them from flaw—how can it transform others?

The mantis raising its arms in fury is precisely the metaphor for Yan He’s impending misfortune. "Rearing tigers" and "cherishing horses" further reinforce the earlier analogy, urging even greater caution.

When Carpenter Shi traveled to Qi, he passed by Qu Yuan and saw the oak that was the spirit of the land. Its girth could shade an ox, its circumference spanned a hundred spans, its height towered above the mountains by ten *ren* before branches appeared, and its sides could furnish enough timber for a dozen boats. Onlookers thronged like a marketplace, yet the master carpenter paid no heed and walked on without pause. His disciple, sated with gazing, ran to catch up with Carpenter Shi and said, "Since I first took up the axe to follow you, Master, I have never seen timber so magnificent as this. Why did you refuse to look and walk on without stopping?"

The master replied, "Enough!"

"Do not speak of it! It is a worthless tree. If made into a boat, it would sink; if made into a coffin or outer coffin, it would quickly rot; if made into vessels, they would swiftly break; if used for doors and windows, it would ooze sap; if used for pillars, it would be eaten by worms. This is a useless tree, good for nothing, and thus it has attained such longevity."

Carpenter Shi returned home, and the oak spirit of the land appeared to him in a dream, saying: "With what would you compare me? Would you compare me to the so-called 'fine timber'? Consider the loquat, pear, orange, and pomelo—all fruits of their kind. When their fruits ripen, they are stripped, their large branches broken, their small branches snapped. This is how their abilities bring suffering to their lives, so they do not complete their natural lifespan but die prematurely, self-destructing under the blows of the common world. All things are like this. As for me, I have long sought to be of no use, nearly dying in the process, until now I have attained it—this is my great usefulness. Had I been useful, could I have grown so vast? Moreover, you and I are both things—how could one thing pass judgment on another? And you, a nearly dead worthless man, what would you know of a worthless tree?"

Carpenter Shi awoke and interpreted his dream. His disciple said: "If it seeks to be useless, why does it serve as a spirit tree?"

"Hush!" he replied. "Say no more. It merely lodges there, taking it as reproach from those who do not understand it. Were it not a spirit tree, it would have been felled long ago! Moreover, what it preserves differs from the common lot, and to praise it with conventional standards is far indeed from the truth!"

At the chapter’s close, to speak of "virtue and reputation" is to seek its praise or blame through moral principles—how far removed this is! The preceding section exhaustively describes the difficulty of conducting oneself and responding to the world; this chapter again invokes the spirit oak, which preserves itself through worthlessness and fulfills the usefulness of the useless. "Nearly dying, only now have I attained it—this is my great usefulness" stands as a single truth.

"Why lament the judging of things? You and I are both endowed with form as things—would you use me?" The "scattered man on the verge of death" refers to you, who exhaust yourself with ability, nearly dying in the process. How could you, content in uselessness, comprehend my state?

The disciple further asked: If the oak’s fundamental aim is to embrace uselessness, why does it serve as a spirit tree? Carpenter Shi silenced him, saying: It merely lodges there, not seeking to be a spirit tree. Precisely because it is taken as reproach by those who do not understand it—had it not been a spirit tree, would it not have been felled long ago? Moreover, what it preserves is its lack of utility, differing from the common lot. To praise it with the standards of a spirit tree is far indeed from the truth!

This illustrates how the uncarved man preserves himself in the world, unwilling to be puffed up or lauded by others. Even if he gains reputation among his village, it is but a temporary lodging—how could he take it as honor? Only because he cannot be exploited for gain can he not be harmed.

Southward Master Ziqi roamed the hills of Shang, where he saw a great tree unlike any other—so vast that a thousand four-horse chariots could shelter beneath its canopy, its rustling leaves concealing all within. Ziqi exclaimed: "What tree is this? Surely it must possess extraordinary timber!"

Yet when he looked up at its slender branches, they were gnarled and twisted, unfit for beams or rafters. When he looked down at its massive roots, they were split and hollow, useless for coffins or outer caskets. Chewing its leaves burned the mouth, and inhaling its scent induced a three-day frenzy. Zijing remarked: "This is indeed a tree of no use—yet it has grown to such immense size!"

Alas! The spirit-like man values such uselessness.

In Song there was a region called Jing, where catalpa, oak, and mulberry were prized for timber. Those with trunks the span of a hand or arm were felled to make perches for monkeys; those three or four spans around were cut down for the beams of grand mansions; those seven or eight spans wide were sought by wealthy households for their finest coffins. Thus, before reaching their natural lifespan, these trees met their end midway under the axe—this is the calamity of being useful.

Now consider the white-browed ox, the upturned-snouted pig, or a man with hemorrhoids: none may be offered in sacrifice to the river. The shamans and priests know this well, deeming them inauspicious. Yet this is precisely what the spirit-like man regards as the greatest auspice.

Guo’s commentary: The Son of Heaven, being of no use to his hundred officials, allows them to manage their duties—those with keen eyes see for him, those with sharp ears listen for him, the wise strategize for him, and the brave act for him. What does he do? He remains profoundly still. When all talents are employed where they belong, the "useless" man becomes the one on whom all usefulness depends.

Lü’s commentary: First, the great tree ends its days in peace through its uselessness; next, the catalpa and oak of Jing meet early death under the axe, illustrating the peril of usefulness. Thus the sage and the spirit-like man, in their application of the Way, push utility to its utmost depth and conceal it in profound obscurity. Therefore, what seems useless becomes the means of all efficacy, and what appears to lack usefulness is in fact the master of all use. Those who wander the world and share in the fortunes and misfortunes of the people must understand this well.

Yi Du’s commentary: "High-named mansions" refers to grand, illustrious buildings. "Coffin planks" are the boards used for caskets. This speaks of how fine timber invites early destruction. "Jie" refers to sacrificial offerings and thanksgiving rites. The white-browed ox, the upturned-snouted pig, and the man with hemorrhoids—these three cannot be used in river sacrifices, and the shamans deem them inauspicious. Yet the spirit-like man values the usefulness of the useless, which is the true great auspice.

Detailed Daoist commentary: As the *Laozi* says: "That which is bent will be preserved whole; that which is crooked will be made straight."

The tortoise, revered for its divinity and appearing in dreams, is not as fortunate as one dragging its tail through the mud; the monkey, prized for its dexterity and displayed for its cleverness, is not as secure as one preserving its whole body in the depths of the thicket. Thus, what is deemed "without talent" is precisely what the spirit-like man values as true talent; what is called "inauspicious" is what the spirit-like man regards as the greatest auspice.

Bi Xu’s commentary: When the seven apertures are overused, they become dull and blocked; when the hundred bones are labored, they grow weary and unsustainable. Only the nameless numinous thing governs the whole, its radiance inexhaustible, filling the great void—thus do the myriad spirits find their harmonious breath.

The shamans reject and refuse to sacrifice creatures with blemishes, yet the spirit-like man honors the humble offering of sinking sacrifices.

Zhao’s commentary: The great trees of Shangqiu and the sacred beams of the altars share the same fate—like the catalpa and cypress of the Jing clan, their very usefulness prevents them from fulfilling their natural span. They are no match for the white-browed ox, the upturned-snouted pig, or the man with hemorrhoids, who preserve themselves precisely by being "without talent."

Juan Zhai observes: The trees of Shangqiu echo the theme of the previous chapter. The spirit-like man preserves his life by this very "lack of talent." The land of the Jing clan is suited to catalpa, cypress, and mulberry. *Dai* refers to a stake; *li* means the ridgepole of a house. *Gaoming* denotes a great family, that is, a household of high repute—though the pronunciation is the same, the character differs. *Jie* is the name of an ancient shamanic text. In the *Jie*, it is written: "An ox with a white forehead or a pig with an upturned snout cannot be used to sacrifice to the river." In ancient times, humans were sometimes offered in sacrifice, as in the case of Ximen Bao, hence the addition of "the man with hemorrhoids." The shamans deem these three inauspicious, yet it is precisely their "inauspiciousness" that spares them from the calamity of being killed. From the perspective of the spirit-like man, this is the greatest auspice. The various commentaries have elucidated the main idea, but some characters remain unglossed; these are appended below:

*Yin jiang long qi suo lai*—this speaks of being subtly nourished by its shade; some attach *yin* to the preceding phrase, but this is untenable. *"There must be a man of extraordinary talent"*—to punctuate this as a complete phrase and attach *fu* to the following line is incorrect. *Zhou jie* refers to wood grain that spirals and scatters. *Yi* is the perch for monkeys. *Chan bang* refers to a coffin made from a single plank. *Gaoming zhi li*—*li* should be glossed as *li* (ridgepole), following the *Liezi*: "lingering echoes coil around the beams." *Gaoming* undoubtedly means "eminent." Juan Zhai’s interpretation is most apt; this chapter shares the same meaning as the previous one. There, the addition of the man with an illness to escape the peril of river sacrifice, and the conclusion that the spirit-like man regards this as the greatest auspice, make the intent of the text abundantly clear. Here, further elaboration is unnecessary.

As for the man "Disjointed and Scattered": his chin recedes into his navel, his shoulders rise above his head, his topknot points to the sky, his five organs sit above, his two thighs press against his ribs. Mending clothes and washing laundry suffice to feed himself; winnowing chaff and sifting grain suffice to feed ten. When the authorities conscript soldiers, Disjointed waves his arms among them; when great labor is demanded, Disjointed, citing his chronic illness, is exempt from service. When grain is distributed to the sick, he receives three bushels and ten bundles of firewood. Though his body is disjointed, he nourishes himself and lives out his natural years—how much more so one who is "disjointed in virtue"!

Guo’s commentary: The spirit-like man is of no use to things, yet things each find their own use. He ascribes merit to the multitude of beings, merging with them in obscurity and leaving no trace—thus he avoids the harms of the human world. One who dwells in the substance of constant beauty is "disjointed in virtue."

Lü’s commentary: *Zhi* is not the wholeness of the body; *li* is not the unity of things. To be "scattered" is to be open and clear; to be "disjointed" is to be dispersed and diffuse—thus free from the burdens of bodily existence. Therefore, one "disjointed in form" cannot be subjected to conscription or labor; one "disjointed in virtue" cannot be encumbered by affairs.

Yi Du’s commentary: To be "disjointed in form" is to forget the body and overcome it through principle; to be "disjointed in virtue" is to forget virtue and abide by fate. To cast off the body and dull the senses is to "forget the form"; to embody the highest virtue without claiming it is to "forget virtue." The man who forgets his form preserves his body and fulfills his years, merely avoiding the harms of human entanglements. But the one who forgets virtue—his knowledge encompasses all things yet returns to the simplicity of ignorance, his illumination rivals the sun and moon yet reverts to the obscurity of darkness—how can one who merely forgets his form be mentioned in the same breath?

Bi Xu’s commentary: To dwell in the body without use is to be "disjointed in form"; to embrace the Dao as if foolish is to be "disjointed in virtue."

Zhao’s commentary: The world knows virtue as beauty but does not know virtue as a burden—hence Zhuangzi uses the parable of Disjointed and Scattered. Yong Qi observes: *Hui cuo* means a topknot. *Liang pai* refers to the two sides of the thighs. *Cuo zhen* means sewing clothes; *zhi xie* means washing clothes. *Gu jia* is the tool for winnowing grain to obtain its essence. Disjointed and Scattered, disabled in form, is exempt from labor and even receives grain and firewood—this too is the idea of preserving oneself by being "without talent." The virtue of the perfected man is likewise "disjointed," for he regards "no use" as the greatest use.

*Hui cuo*—pronounced *gui zui*. *Hui* is also pronounced *gu* (ancient *huo* cut); *cuo* is pronounced *zuo* (ancient *zi huo* cut). The topknot on the nape—Sima explains: "A topknot," for in ancient times the topknot was at the nape, the spine curved and the head lowered, so the topknot pointed to the sky. Xiang observes: The two shoulders hunch upward, forming a topknot-like protrusion. Today, the reading often follows the initial sound, and this aligns with the *Da Zongshi* chapter: "the fleshy growth points to the sky"—the character differs, but the meaning is the same.

From "his chin recedes into his navel" to "his two thighs press against his ribs" describes the appearance of his disability. *Gu xiao bo jing*—Sima explains: *Xiao* is the same as *ce*, a small winnowing basket; sifting grain is called *jing*. Cui observes: *Gu xiao* means to rub and separate; *bo jing* refers to divination and augury. Today, most follow Sima’s interpretation, as these two skills are essential for daily sustenance, allowing him to feed ten people. This is a rhetorical device, illustrating that though his form is deficient, his means of nourishment are more than sufficient.

That one so fragmented in form fares thus—how much more so one fragmented in virtue? This passage’s weight lies in the latter phrase, for virtue abhors rigidity; rigidity is no virtue. "Fragmented" means to be unconstrained and at ease in virtue, to be so unconstrained and at ease—this is the highest virtue, which does not cling to virtue.

Now, one fragmented in form escapes conscription and levies, yet grain and firewood come to him in abundance. Then one fragmented in virtue—no human harm can reach him, and the celestial rank bestows its grace. How fitting!

*The Ocean of Meanings in the Authentic Scripture of the Southern Florescence*, Scroll Nine—concluded.

---

**Postface to *The Ocean of Meanings in the Authentic Scripture of the Southern Florescence*:**
When I first read the *Zhuangzi*, I found its discourse on the equality of things wild and boundless, seemingly at odds with human sentiment.

While laid low by illness in a verdant chamber, I dreamed of one who spoke to me of the wooden cock. Thereupon, I took up the book once more and unraveled its threads, only then grasping the true intent of its discourse—most apt for saving the age, though men may yet fail to recognize it.

For since the virtue of the Zhou declined and the rites, music, punitive expeditions no longer issued from the Son of Heaven, the Warring States lords clashed and contended, reducing their people to ruin. The root of this calamity lay in ignorance of *fen*—one’s allotted place. At such a time, Zhuangzi sought to awaken the deluded and lance their affliction, hence the subtle words with which he opened *The Free and Easy Wandering*. Therein, the turtledove and the quail dare not compare themselves to the great Peng—such is the *fen*-awareness of creatures. Therein, Xu You dares not accept Yao’s empire—such is the *fen*-awareness of men. Were all under heaven to know *fen*, the lowly would not yearn for nobility, the small would not scheme for greatness, the strong would not bully the weak, the many would not oppress the few. Rulers would be true rulers, ministers true ministers, fathers true fathers, sons true sons. The whole world would rest content in the natural course of their allotted *fen*, and the scourge of usurpation, excess, and strife would vanish of itself. Thus, the inequality of things need not be forcibly equalized—all would be equal without effort.

Moreover, Zhuangzi lived in the same age as Mencius. Had his words been contrary to the Dao or of no benefit to the world’s teaching, Mencius would surely have opposed him. Yet readers, clinging to his phrasing and neglecting his meaning, often dismiss him as heterodox, echoing Guo Xiang’s judgment. How could this be true understanding of Zhuangzi?

One day, the Daoist Chu Boxiu of the Central Metropolis presented his *Explication of the Zhuangzi*, appending his own insights, and showed it to me. I rejoiced in his diligent distillation, his precise selection, and the many surpassing insights he had attained. Thus, I shared my thoughts with him. Startled, he bowed and said: *"To resolve the discourse on the equality of things with the single word *fen*—this is beyond my reach. Might I prevail upon you to write a preface and carve it upon wood?"* I replied: *"This is but my idle speculation. Are there not those in the world who penetrate this book more deeply? You should seek them out and obtain their confirmation. Another day, return to me, and we may yet refine it together. As for a preface, I dare not."*

In the fourth month of the first year of the Xianchun reign, Liu Zhensun of the Northeast inscribed this at his lodging in Gusu, the Wooden Cock’s Nest.

The Dao is one; when expressed in words, it becomes two. Thus it is said: *"The Dao asks no questions; questions receive no answer."*

It is also said: *"To know the Dao is easy; to refrain from speaking of it is difficult."* The one who knows does not speak; the one who speaks does not know. The good do not dispute; the disputatious are not good. Then may we forget words? If words could be forgotten, the *Nanhua Sutra* would not have been written; if words could not be forgotten, the *Nanhua Sutra* would not exist. Yet since the *Nanhua Sutra* does exist, so too do the various schools of commentary. Nevertheless, though the *Nanhua Sutra* spans over a hundred thousand words, it has never spoken, nor has it ever not spoken. Why? Its words are all parables. Later generations seek what it has already said but do not seek what it has not said. They pore over lines and count characters, divide chapters and parse sentences—yet the more they dissect its words, the further they stray from the Dao.

Xueyan the Feathered Robe, Chu Boxiu, dwelt near the celestial realm of the Five Nuns, yet his spirit roamed above the Lacquer Garden and the waters of Pu. He compiled the various commentaries, adjudicated them with his own insights, committed them to writing, and—finding this insufficient—even carved them into wood to ensure their immortality. His effort was indeed diligent.

Alas! The Dao is transmitted through words, like Master Zhao playing the zither. The Dao cannot be transmitted through words, like Master Zhao not playing the zither. The greatest sound is soundless; whether the zither is played or not, the music remains unharmed. Yet one may catch the fish and forget the trap, seize the hare and forget the snare—is this not so? But are the trap and snare the fish and hare? The Dao and words: one yet two, two yet one.

Ah!

The *Nanhua* Classic, the various interpretations of the schools, Zhu’s limited insights, and your own conjectures—these are but layers of allegory within allegory.

Written on the fifth day of the fifth month in the first year of Xianchun by Benxin Weng and Wen Jiweng at Daoshan Hall.

Among the works of the ancient masters, such as Master Meng’s orthodoxy and Master Zhuang’s marvels, all represent the pinnacle of written expression. Though later generations have produced scholars, none have surpassed them. Yet the *Zhuangzi* is especially difficult to read. Even one of great wisdom like Su Dongpo claimed to have grasped its meaning, but upon examining his writings, his occasional discussions of Zhuangzi often still miss the original intent. How much less could those like Pang Huaiqing, whose hearts brim with venomous stings, ever attain the imperial suspension of bonds?

In recent times, those who interpret Zhuangzi have grown more numerous, and their explanations have even surpassed those of earlier scholars. Yet they inevitably buttress their arguments with the words of our sages or cling to the gateways of Chan Buddhism—appearing similar, but not truly so. I say it would be better to use the *Zhuangzi* itself to explain the *Zhuangzi*, cutting off all upward clinging and downward entanglements, so as to approach the harmonious and self-sufficient lineage and glimpse its boundaries.

Master Zhu Boxiu of Wulin, a follower of the Daoist tradition, neither Confucian nor Mohist, read this book with undivided focus, avoiding the pitfalls of straying paths and lost sheep. His singular aim was to seek the ancestral intent from a thousand years past, to synthesize the essence of various interpretations, and to append his own insights, selecting what brought him peace without dismissing others. After a lifetime of effort, he completed the work—his dedication was indeed diligent. Observing him, I see clarity in his gaze and tranquility in his spirit, the fruits of his learning.

I have long enjoyed reading Zhuangzi, often finding moments of joyful resonance, though I never committed my thoughts to writing. Now, old and ailing with dimming eyes, I can only admire Master Zhu’s accomplishment and have no leisure to scrutinize his successes or failures. Since he has exerted himself to publish his work and has asked me to write a preface for its opening, I smile and say: If the carvers’ work is not yet complete, then those who wield the mallet and chisel above could surely compose a preface for you.

Written on the *jiashen* day of the eighth month in the year *yichou* of Xianchun by Tang Hanshu of Poyang.

Zhang Zhan’s *Liezi* commentary records: Zhuangzi was a native of Mengcheng in Song, served as the magistrate of the Lacquer Garden in Liang, and composed a work in fifty-two chapters. Guo Xiang consolidated it into thirty-three chapters and wrote a commentary. Another account states: Xiang Xiu first annotated twenty-eight chapters of the *Zhuangzi* before his death, and Guo Xiang obtained his manuscript, completing it for circulation. Later, a separate version by Xiang’s family emerged, hence the similarities between the Xiang and Guo commentaries in wording and meaning.

Chen Jingyuan’s *Bixuzi* commentary notes in its preface: Zhuangzi studied under Master Changsang, received his esoteric teachings, and composed a work of over one hundred thousand characters titled *Nanhua*. The three-character titles of the Inner Chapters are original, while the Outer and Miscellaneous Chapters were edited by Guo Xiang. Now, counting the main text, only sixty-five thousand nine hundred characters remain.

In the nineteenth year of Kaiyuan during the Tang, Minister Pei Guangting requested the canonization of the Four Masters. In the first year of Tianbao, an edict decreed: The *Zhuangzi* should retain its original title, *Nanhua Zhenjing* (*True Classic of Nanhua*), as its meaning derives from the radiant essence of the southern brilliance, expounding the wonders of the Dao.

I humbly observe that the title *Nanhua* has existed for a long time. It seems to be a celestial office or duty, akin to the Eastern and Southern Poles, and cannot be recklessly interpreted through human reasoning or conjecture. Thus, no explanations of it are recorded. I have carefully presented this to address one difficulty in the introductory notes, awaiting the scrutiny of those with deeper knowledge.

At the end of Chen Bixu’s *Jieyi* is a record of collated *Zhuangzi* commentaries, based on the edition published by the Directorate of Education in the third year of Jingde. Also included is an ancient southern manuscript.

The texts were collated by Xu Xuan and Ge Huan. The edition from Fangying Palace on Mount Tiantai. Collated by Xu Lingfu. Guo Xiang’s commentary, from the edition of the Central Taiyi Palace. Collated by Zhang Junfang. Cheng Xuanying’s subcommentary, from the edition of the Central Taiyi Palace. Collated by Zhang Junfang. Wen Ruhai’s *Correct Meaning*, from the edition of the Central Taiyi Palace. Both Cheng and Wen were Tang-dynasty Daoist masters. The edition from the Li family library of Jiangnan. Zhang Qianfu’s supplementary notes. The edition of layman Liu Deyi. A figure of the Dazhong Xiangfu era. The names of the various commentators and exegetes compiled herein:

Guo Xiang’s commentary. The edition from the Haomen Palace. Lü Huiqing’s commentary. The Sichuan edition. Lin Yidu’s commentary. The old Masha edition. Chen Xiangdao’s commentary. The stored edition. Chen Jingyuan’s commentary. His courtesy name was Taichu, and his sobriquet was Master Bixu; a native of Jianchang, he served as the director of the Central Taiyi Palace during the Xining era. Summoned to court, he presented his exegeses of the *Dao De Jing* and *Nanhua Zhenjing*, which were then promulgated and included in the Daoist Canon. Wang Pang’s commentary. On the Inner Chapters. Liu Pan’s commentary. On the Outer and Miscellaneous Chapters, succeeding [Liu] Xiu. Wu Chou’s commentary. The above five commentaries are all found in the Daoist Canon. Figures of the Chongguan era. Xu Zhai Zhao Yifu’s commentary. On the Inner Chapters, the Fujian edition. Lin Xiyi of Zhuxi’s *Oral Exegesis*. The Fujian edition. Li Shibiao’s *Ten Discourses on the Zhuangzi*. Wang Dan’s *Introduction to the Zhuangzi*. The lecture notes of Master Wuyin Fan. His given name was Yuanying, and his courtesy name was Shanfu; a native of Shunqing in Shu. *Collected Subtleties of the Ocean of Meaning of the Nanhua Zhenjing*, scroll ten. The learning of Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin.

**Chapter Four: "In the Human World"**

Confucius traveled to Chu, where the madman Jie Yu wandered at his gate, singing:
*"O phoenix! O phoenix!*
*How the virtue has declined!*
*The coming age cannot be awaited,*
*The past age cannot be pursued.*
*When the world follows the Dao, the sage achieves completion;*
*When the world loses the Dao, the sage preserves life.*
*In this present time, one barely escapes punishment.*
*Fortune is lighter than a feather, yet none know how to bear it;*
*Misfortune is heavier than the earth, yet none know how to avoid it.*
*Enough! Enough!*
*To govern others with virtue—*
*Perilous! Perilous!*
*To mark the ground and follow the lines!*
*O tangled vines, tangled vines, harm not my path!*
*My path winds and bends—harm not my feet!"*

Mountain trees bring ruin upon themselves; fat burns itself in the flame.
Cinnamon is edible, so it is felled; lacquer is useful, so it is slashed.
All know the use of the useful, but none know the use of the useless.

**Guo’s Commentary:**
To proceed in accord with the times, exhausting the fittingness of convergence—
The rise and fall of the world pass unnoticed, left to their own course, and principle arises and completes itself.
How could it be for order and chaos to alter their seasons?
Order seeks its own completion, thus it abandons completion and does not fail;
Chaos seeks its own survival, thus it forgets survival and does not perish.
Exhausting the convergence of the present moment, merging obscurely with the age—only then can subtlety be preserved, punishment and reputation avoided.
To know the limit of what one does not know, to halt at what one cannot do,
To employ what employs itself, to act as it acts of itself,
To indulge one’s nature within without the slightest attachment to what lies beyond—
This is the utmost ease of non-action.
There has never been one whose nature and life were not preserved through non-action.
If nature and life are preserved yet it is not called fortune, such a principle has never been heard of.
Fortune is precisely what was earlier called "preservation"—it is not borrowed from external things.
How could it bear the weight of a goose feather?
To move in accordance with one’s nature, to act without transgressing measure—this is the utmost ease in the world.
To lift what lifts itself, to bear what bears itself—this is the utmost lightness in the world.
To abandon this utmost ease of non-action and practice that utmost difficulty of action,
To cast aside this utmost lightness of self-lifting and take up that utmost heaviness of bearing others—
This is the common delusion of the world.
To seek inner fortune is why fortune is so light;
To invite external misfortune is why misfortune is so heavy.
Misfortune is heavy yet none avoid it—this is the world’s great confusion.
To trace lines on the ground and follow them, one’s tracks cannot be concealed.
To confront things with a self is to fail to merge with them.
Not using one’s own brightness to dazzle others but allowing them to find their own clarity,
Not imposing one’s own attainment upon others but leaving them to attain of themselves—
Thus one blends indistinguishably with the world, and inner and outer share the same fortune.
*"Tangled vines"*—like *"lost yang"*—means to rely on solitude, not scattering outward, bending to complete one’s path, each self-sufficient.

**Lü’s Commentary:**
When the sage achieves completion, he completes himself and completes things;
When the sage preserves life, he merely preserves his own life.
Nothing in the world is as good as the Dao—thus no fortune is greater than this.
As a thing, it is beyond sight and hearing, light as a feather, yet the world does not know how to bear it.
Nothing in the world is as evil as opposing the Dao—thus no misfortune is greater than this.
As a thing, it turns non-being into being, heavy as the earth, yet people do not know how to avoid it.
To govern others with virtue is to assert a self;
To mark the ground and follow the lines is to court peril.
*"Tangled vines"* means not knowing where to go—only by bending can one preserve oneself.
Mountain trees, cinnamon, and lacquer are felled because they bring it upon themselves.
This is to know the use of the useful but not the use of the useless.
In the human world, there is order and chaos.
To bend and preserve oneself amid chaos—this is the best way to dwell in the world.

**Yidu’s Commentary:**
When the world follows the Dao, the sage establishes ritual and music to achieve success in his age;
When the world loses the Dao, he preserves his life and keeps harm at a distance.
The sage is not attached to life—he desires his body to endure and leave a model for later ages, which may be called *"completion."*
The Duke of Zhou in Zhou was the sage’s completion;
Confucius in Lu was the sage’s preservation of life.
Fortune does not arise from within one’s nature yet is rarely sought;
Misfortune often arises from beyond one’s nature yet is ceaselessly pursued.
What lies within one’s nature can be lifted—it is strong enough to bear, light enough to carry.
How could it have the weight of a goose feather?
What lies beyond one’s nature is entrusted to the body, heavy as the earth.
The deluded drown in it and do not avoid it, for they do not understand the root of fortune and misfortune.
The root is this: *śīla, samādhi, prajñā*—these are the fortune within one’s nature.
*Rāga, dveṣa, moha*—these are the misfortune beyond one’s nature.
To govern others with virtue is to fail to merge with the Dao;
To mark the ground and follow the lines is to fail to conceal one’s traces.
*"Tangled vines"* means to obscure one’s brightness and not harm the path of preserving life.
Emptying the heart and bending to things, each finds sufficiency in its nature and portion.
Mountain trees, cinnamon, and lacquer invite destruction as metaphors for those who cannot keep harm at a distance but seek usefulness and thus injure themselves.

**Xiang Dao’s Commentary:**
The sage’s mind—how could it be narrowly occupied with ordering the world?
He merely responds to the times and rides the principle, that is all.

Those in the world who know Confucius see only his outward forms and instruments, not the moments when he was free of affairs. Thus, first recounting his traces of governing the world, he ultimately cites the song of Jie Yu to confirm it—where traces vanish, the heart is revealed. What is meant by the sage’s completion? To devote the self to the Dao and achieve success. What is meant by the sage’s life? To devote the Dao to the self and preserve life whole.

"Enough, enough!"—this refers to those who now engage in governance, who mark the ground and follow the lines. "Tangled vines, tangled vines, do not harm my steps"—this refers to those who now embody the Dao, who do so.

**Bixu’s Commentary:**
With the Dao, one delights in completion; without the Dao, one preserves life whole. Those who bear the lightest of blessings are the scholars of non-action. Those who do not avoid the heaviest of misfortunes are the followers of power and profit. To boast of virtue and govern others is to be deeply self-possessed. To drive others to follow traces is to place the Way in greater peril.

"Tangled vines" means to obscure one’s brightness—obscuring brightness preserves one’s conduct whole. "Bending" means to withdraw the self and yield to preserve wholeness, resting content within one’s portion. The metaphors of mountain trees, cinnamon, and lacquer all describe those who conform to others’ conformity rather than conforming to their own.

**Zhao’s Commentary:**
The song of Jie Yu further laments Confucius’ failure to meet his time—it is not a mockery of Confucius. "When the world lacks the Dao, the sage lives"—this speaks of the phoenix appearing out of season. For one dwelling in such times, merely escaping punishment is enough. Minor blessings cannot outweigh them; heavy misfortunes are not avoided—this speaks of how deluded the world is.

To govern others with virtue is to make others resent one’s excellence. To mark the ground and follow the lines is to make others follow one’s traces. "Enough, enough!"—this says one cannot but cease. "Perilous, perilous!"—this says the danger is insurmountable. "Tangled vines, tangled vines, do not harm my steps"—obscuring one’s brightness preserves one’s conduct whole.

The passage from "mountain trees" to "the use of the useless" is Zhuangzi’s words, used here to conclude the meaning of the preceding chapters.

**Yongzhai’s Note:**
When the world possesses the Dao, the sage may achieve success. When the world lacks the Dao, the sage merely preserves life whole.

In this present age of chaos, merely escaping punishment is already fortune—how dare one seek anything more? To survive an age of chaos and avoid punishment while preserving life whole is but a feather’s blessing, yet you remain unaware of the calamities of such times, where slaughter is ever-present—this is a weight upon the earth, yet you do not evade it. Governing others with virtue is the path to disaster; better to cease. "Marking the ground and following the lines" speaks of self-imposed restraint and suffering—truly perilous. "Tangled vines" (miyang) are a metaphor for losing the radiance of one’s original nature—how can one walk in the world? "Turning aside" (quequ) means to shield and evade. "Surely it will harm my steps" says it cannot be done.

The various explanations have been detailed above; no further repetition is needed. According to the *Shu Shi* chapter of *Wenzhongzi*: "When the world possesses the Dao, the sage conceals himself; when the world lacks the Dao, the sage becomes manifest." Though the phrasing is the same, the meaning is reversed, each serving its own purpose. I have often observed that since the Qin and Han dynasties, those who established teachings among the various schools have frequently borrowed the language and ideas of the *Nanhua* (*Zhuangzi*), yet the classics, in their use of metaphors and analogies, never tread the same path as their predecessors, becoming ever more extraordinary. This is what is meant by: "Writing may be refined, but it is not ordinary writing."

"Turning aside to avoid harm to my steps"—this is how all versions read. *Que* is often pronounced *xi*, but *Bixu* alone reads it as written. Restoring the original text, it should be *quequ* ("turning aside"), which better aligns with the preceding passage. The original likely read thus, but errors in transmission mistakenly repeated the phrase "my steps." The discerning reader will recognize this.

For those who dwell in the human world, the relationship between ruler and minister is of greatest importance and cannot be neglected. Yet one must weigh what is appropriate, carefully observe the proper timing for action or withdrawal, measure oneself against past and present without shame, and transcend regret and misfortune to preserve oneself alone—this is true excellence. Thus, when Yanzi was about to go to Wei, the Master exhaustively explained the many dangers of serving a ruler: how fame and knowledge clash, how the mind and qi remain unfulfilled, how praise turns to slander, how the bow and banner precede the blade and saw—such things are common. How much more so for a minister as unassuming and humble as Yanzi, who would hastily seek to transform a ruler in his prime, acting alone and unyielding? Preserving oneself without regret was the Master’s urgent counsel to stop him, so that the ruler of Wei might recognize that the worthy do not advance lightly, thereby strengthening his resolve to honor the Dao and naturally undergo transformation. Why rush to feed his arrogance and abet his violent ways?

Yanzi then proposed cultivating emptiness, diligence, inner integrity, and outward flexibility as means to preserve himself, but the Master said this would only spare him trouble—how could it bring about transformation? Transformation is achieved not through words but through trust, dissolving others’ resistance without need for excessive policies that provoke opposition. At this point, Yanzi had no further progress to make and asked for guidance. This was the moment when human desires were emptied and the principles of Heaven were about to appear. The Master seized this moment of awakening and instructed him in the practice of *qi* ("equalizing"), urging him to receive teaching with an empty mind: "Do not listen with the ears but with the mind; do not listen with the mind but with *qi*." Thereupon, Yanzi realized in an instant that he had never truly been "Hui" (his given name). With his mind emptied, his form too was forgotten, and transforming others became effortless.

When Zigao was about to be sent to Qi, the Master taught him to attend to affairs while forgetting himself, to observe the winds and waves while guarding against true loss. When Yan He was about to serve as tutor to the heir of Wei, the Master taught him to approach without entering and to harmonize without projecting, to understand the tiger’s anger and communicate the horse’s disposition. All this served to illustrate the manifold dangers of the world and the difficulty of navigating external things.

For those of profound insight, who perceive the subtlest signs, advancing or withdrawing in accordance with righteousness is permissible. As for the crooked axle of the oak in the shrine, which took "no preservation as its preservation," or Shang Qiu Yi, whose extraordinary abilities appeared unremarkable yet were wondrous—these further expound how talent becomes a burden, yet the world fails to comprehend. Time and again, people rely on their abilities to seek employment without considering their proper measure or the appropriateness of their station. Fame brings envy and harm; profit invites calamity. Even if one wishes to preserve oneself through clumsy self-protection, it cannot be achieved.

Thus, the overarching meaning of this chapter lies in responding to the world externally while preserving one’s true nature internally, so that the Dao is never lost and things transform of themselves. The sages and worthies of antiquity, compelled to engage with the world, invariably followed this path in secret. Hence, the dialogue between Confucius and Yanzi is presented here to elucidate it. At the chapter’s end, the song of Jieyu (the "Madman of Chu") is cited to obscure the traces of the sages’ worldly endeavors and to curb the insatiable desires of the masses. The concluding metaphors of the torch’s flame, cinnamon, and lacquer serve as particularly sharp warnings to the world.

Only by understanding the difficulty of navigating the world can one dwell in it without difficulty. As the *Taishang* says: "Even the sage finds it difficult, and thus in the end there is no difficulty."

*End of the Tenth Scroll of the* Nanhua Zhenjing Yihai Zuanwei
*Beginning of the Eleventh Scroll of the* Nanhua Zhenjing Yihai Zuanwei

Master Chu Boxiu of Wulin, on *"The Sign of Full Virtue"* (Chapter One)

In Lu there was a limbless man named Wang Tai. Those who followed him were as numerous as those who followed Confucius. Chang Ji asked Confucius, saying: "Wang Tai is a limbless man, yet his followers divide Lu equally with you. He neither instructs while standing nor debates while seated; yet those who come to him empty depart filled. Is there truly a teaching without words, a shaping of the heart without form? What manner of man is he?"

Confucius said: "This master is a sage. I am merely a latecomer who has yet to visit him. I intend to take him as my teacher—how much more should those inferior to me! Why limit it to Lu? I would lead all under Heaven to follow him."

Chang Ji said: "Though he is limbless, he surpasses you, Master. Compared to the common run, he is far beyond them. If this is so, how does he employ his mind?"

Confucius said: "Life and death are great indeed, yet he does not change with them. Though heaven and earth collapse, he would not be lost with them. He examines what is without reliance and does not shift with things; he commands the transformations of things while guarding their root."

Chang Ji said: "What does this mean?"

Confucius said: "Viewed from what differs, the liver and gallbladder are as distant as Chu and Yue. Viewed from what is the same, the myriad things are all one. One who is thus does not know what the ears and eyes deem fitting but roams the mind in the harmony of virtue. He sees things in their unity and does not perceive their loss—regarding the loss of his foot as one would discard earth."

Chang Ji said: "He cultivates himself. Through his knowledge he attains his heart; through his heart he attains his constant heart. Why then do things vie to follow him?"

Confucius said: "Men do not mirror themselves in flowing water but in still water—only stillness can still the many. Receiving its mandate from earth, only the pine and cypress remain verdant through winter and summer. Receiving its mandate from heaven, only Shun was truly upright. Fortunate is he who can rectify life to rectify the lives of others. The proof of preserving the beginning lies in the substance of fearlessness. A single brave warrior can charge into nine armies. Those who seek fame and can bind themselves to it are yet like this—how much more one who governs heaven and earth, stores the myriad things, lodges in the six limbs as in a temporary abode, models the ears and eyes, unifies the knowledge of knowledge, yet whose heart never dies! He will choose a day to ascend on high, and men will follow accordingly. How would he deign to make things his concern?"

**Guo’s Commentary:**
"Coming empty and returning full—each attains what is sufficient for themselves. Though Wang Tai’s form is ruined, his heart is whole. Suddenly and alone he advances, yet none under Heaven can depart from him—how much less a single state! Life and death are humanity’s greatest transformations, yet he moves with change, so life and death cannot alter him. Though suffering and pleasure differ in nature, beauty and ugliness in feeling, each prizes what it deems beautiful—yet the myriad things share one beauty. Each affirms what it affirms—yet all under Heaven share one affirmation. If one distinguishes things by their differences, then from the vast perspective, one knows differences are not truly different. Thus, if one unites things by their sameness, one also knows sameness is not truly the same. Therefore, one unites them by their nothingness. Without beauty or ugliness, the ears and eyes find nothing unsuitable. Without unsuitability, there has never been disharmony. Regarding life and death as one, the loss of a foot is like discarding earth. Chang Ji still suspects Wang Tai has not forgotten knowledge to preserve himself or abandoned the heart to attain himself. Attaining the constant heart is to go forth evenly. If one cannot go forth evenly, one transgresses the constant with things. Thus, things come to him. Confucius illustrates with still water as a mirror—not that Tai draws things to follow him. Only the pine and cypress stand at the base; only the sage stands at the summit. Thus, those who are not upright all come seeking rectification. If all things were verdant and whole, the pine and cypress would not be prized. If all men rectified themselves, none would admire the great sage and flock to him. Fortunate is he who can rectify himself—not to rectify others by rectifying himself. Moving with transformation, there is nowhere he does not merge in darkness. His heart flows with life and death, so there is no time when he is not alive. Choosing a day to ascend is to choose without missing the encounter—this man makes no choice, but moves with heaven’s course and acts in due time. Thus, those who borrow from him vie to follow him. How would he deign to make things his concern?"

**Lü’s Commentary:**
"Those who study the Dao study what they cannot study; they practice what they cannot practice. Thus, the parable of Wang Tai. Those who follow Confucius know how to follow what they can practice but not what they cannot practice. Even if all Lu followed him, it would still be an equal division with Wang Tai. Following what one can practice means standing with instruction, sitting with debate—its teaching cannot be without words, its accomplishment cannot be without form. Following what one cannot practice means standing without instruction, sitting without debate, coming empty and returning full. Confucius and Wang Tai are but outer and inner to each other. If one does not take what one can do as the task of ruler or teacher, then the usefulness of the useless is far beyond the common—who would change with life and death? Who would be lost with heaven and earth’s collapse? Examining what is without reliance, knowing what one attains is truly not shifting with things, then life and death, collapse and ruin do not alter him—he merely commands the transformations of things. Not transforming, he guards the root and is never separated from it. Men only fail to view things from what is the same, so their ears and eyes do not inwardly connect. Able to view things from what is the same, the ears and eyes do not know what is fitting. Thus, he sees things in their unity and does not perceive their loss. Chang Ji says Tai harbors the inner sagely Dao, cultivating himself alone. Through his knowledge he attains his heart; through his heart he attains his constant heart. Why then do things vie to follow him and esteem him as ruler and teacher? Only stillness can still the many—this is why men come to him for a mirror."

The tree receives its mandate from the earth, yet only the pine and cypress remain whole. Man receives his mandate from Heaven, yet only Shun stands upright—could Shun not consider his upright birth a blessing and thereby make all men upright? Now, those knights who name themselves by courage can still charge into the nine armies—how much more so one who governs Heaven and Earth, stores the myriad things, and in whom life and death cannot effect change? This is not akin to seeking fame or making demands. He chooses his day to ascend, borrowing his comings and goings, so leisurely and thus—how could men not follow and esteem him?

Master Yi Zhu notes: At the outset, the learner gains nothing and thus goes forth in emptiness; in the end, he awakens and returns in fullness. The teacher silently imparts understanding, and the learner silently attains it. As the *Liezi* says: "Using no words as words is still speech; using no knowledge as knowledge is still knowledge."

Bound by yin and yang, one then has life and death. Riding the clouds and qi, mounting the sun and moon, life and death cannot effect change in him. Without reliance, he fulfills his nature, thus not shifting with things. Commanding things, he reaches his mandate, thus ever guarding his root.

The gallbladder clings to the liver, originally of one body. Chu and Yue are separated by thousands of miles; viewed from their differences, though of one body, they are divided by thousands of miles. Viewed from their sameness, they merge with the Dao in mystery, and the myriad things are one.

Wang Yi relied on what he heard and saw, thus unaware of what his ears and eyes deemed fitting or unified. His virtue suffered loss, and his form was not only forgotten by himself but also made others forget him. Chang Ji said that Wang Ling had not yet forgotten knowledge to make himself forget, nor had his heart attained the constant heart to surpass others—why then did things esteem him?

The answer: Wang Tai’s esteem was like still water serving as a mirror. Stillness is the natural state of nature; only one who first attains stillness can still the many. Though all are trees, only the pine and cypress stand upright, enduring frost and snow to crown the forest. Though all are men, only Shun stands upright, illuminating the myriad things and discerning human relations—how fortunate to upright his life and thereby upright all lives. To upright oneself and have things follow is the way.

The brave knight forgets life and charges into the nine armies, seeking fame and making demands—yet even he is thus. How much more so one who embodies the Dao? To govern the formed with the formless is called "officiating Heaven and Earth"; to store the myriad things with nothing is called "storing the myriad things." Lodging in the six bodily forms yet without possession, resembling ears and eyes yet without use—once knowing knows, he unites with creation, his heart never dying. Thus, he chooses his day to ascend in borrowing, his comings and goings at ease.

Master Dao notes: One replete in virtue, though maimed in form, remains whole; one lacking in virtue, though whole in form, remains deficient. Wang Tai’s virtue flourished within, his form forgotten without—life and death did not alter him, collapse and ruin did not abandon him. Thus, minor gains and losses are self-evident.

Discerning the unborrowed, he does not submit the inner to the outer; commanding the transformations of things, he does not harm the root with the branches. Though the myriad things and I differ in kind, I and the myriad things are one body. Thus, he views their unity and does not perceive their loss. The man of replete virtue sees and hears not with ears and eyes, thus unaware of what is fitting. For himself, he forgets the loss of his form and preserves his virtue; for others, they see the unity of his virtue and forget the deficiency of his form.

Hearing with the ears yet what is heard is not the ears; seeing with the eyes yet what is seen is not the eyes. Thus, he stands without teaching, yet teaching is thereby present; sits without discussing, yet discussion is thereby trusted. The constant heart is one, yet delusion and awakening naturally differ. Water’s nature is originally the same, yet its flow and stillness diverge. Water, by stillness, serves as a mirror; man, by uprightness, earns esteem.

The pine and cypress do not change their hue with cold or heat, thus among trees they are elders. Shun does not alter his uprightness with poverty or prosperity, thus among men he is a sage. Compared to Shun, though their visibility differs, their reception of Heaven and Earth’s upright mandate is the same—thus both can upright their lives to upright all lives. Yet uprighting life is the sage’s fundamental task; uprighting all lives is his secondary affair—hence it is called fortunate.

The brave knight inwardly harbors fearlessness and outwardly verifies his reputation from the outset, yet does not weigh life and death in his heart as he charges into the nine armies—this is wholeness in qi. How much more so wholeness in the Dao? One whole in the Dao officiates Heaven and Earth as his service, stores the myriad things as his provisions, lodges in the six bodily forms without possession, resembles ears and eyes without use. Knowing once, he is not divided by things; his heart abides yet is not controlled by form. His mandate lies within, not without—thus he can choose his day to ascend in borrowing.

Master Bixu notes: Unruled yet not chaotic—this is standing without teaching; unspeaking yet self-trusted—this is sitting without discussing. Purifying the heart to seek the Dao, one goes forth in emptiness; awakening to principle, one returns in fullness. Formless yet the heart is perfected; solitary yet virtue is replete.

The perfected man—Heaven and Earth cannot alter his virtue, life and death cannot change his nature. In all circumstances, he is profoundly merged, standing alone unchanged. Heaven and Earth subtly shift, yet he remains constant. Storing and concealing qi differ, yet within one body, Chu and Yue exist; movement and stillness share the Dao, thus between Heaven and Earth there is no duality.

Pursuing sounds and sights, the ears and eyes differ in what is fitting; blending self and things, affairs have no preferences. Thus, the heart without attachment reaches all destinations; self and other harmonize, gain and loss naturally vanish.

Now, seeing learners fill the gate, one calls it attaining the heart; witnessing one’s tranquil self-restraint, one calls it using the heart. The constant heart has no description—why then do things esteem him?

To observe one’s countenance, one must mirror still water; to seek the Dao, one must visit a worthy teacher. Only when the self is still can it still the hearts of all. Plants grow from the earth, and those that receive the earth’s qi in its purity are the pine and cypress. Animals are nurtured by Heaven, and those that receive Heaven’s qi in its purity are the sages. Guiding oneself with rectitude and following the teachings of emptiness and silence—thus the great man wages war with the Dao against life and death, and neither fame nor power are worthy of mention.

Heaven and Earth have their offices, movement and stillness have their gatherings; the body is not one’s own, so seeing and hearing are not employed. What is known is not two—how then could the heart ever die? One ascends at the appointed time, for departure and abiding have their seasons. Borrowing from others follows what is right; the true man follows himself.

Zhao’s commentary: When Wang Tai was crippled and maimed, all despised him, yet Confucius wished to lead the world to follow him. The Master’s vision far surpassed that of ordinary men, so he asked how Wang Tai cultivated his heart. Confucius spoke of Wang Tai’s Dao: the myriad things have life and death, yet he has no life and death; Heaven and Earth may collapse and fall, yet he has no collapse and fall—this is because he examines what is without reliance and guards his root.

Chang Ji did not understand, so Confucius again used the analogy of one body and the myriad things: the liver and gallbladder, Chu and Yue, are the same yet different; things and the self are different yet the same. Thus, with no seeing and no hearing, one accords with nature; self and things merge, and how could one know the loss of one’s feet? Chang Ji suddenly awakened and said: His learning is for the self—through his knowledge, he attains his heart, meaning the empty, numinous, knowing heart naturally attains knowledge through itself; attaining his constant heart means entering the state of neither death nor life through this empty, numinous knowing. What Wang Tai attained was no more than this—why then does the world esteem him?

Confucius further illustrated that only stillness can still all stillness, and only rectitude in life can rectify the lives of all, to clarify that what gives life does not live, and what transforms things is not transformed. He also spoke of the evidence of preserving the beginning and the reality of fearlessness: the beginning existed before Heaven and Earth, and one who preserves it will not fear even when life and death stand before him. Those brave men who die for fame are already thus—how much more so for one who has never died? This Dao encompasses Heaven and Earth, completes the myriad things in their diversity, and merely lodges in the six bodily forms, shaping them through the ears and eyes, enduring through all ages.

Ascending to the realm beyond is like rising to Heaven. Yongzhai said: Without form, there is nothing to see. The heart is formed, and things are transformed by its resonance. *Zhi hou* means "still later." *Xi jia* means "how could it be merely this?" The line "Life and death are indeed great" is where the discussions of the Buddhists all originate. "Heaven and Earth collapse and fall" is like the *Great Commentary* saying: "Qian and Kun are destroyed and lost," which also means collapse and fall. "Examining what is without reliance" means fully perceiving its reality. "Commanding the transformation of things" means the myriad things receive their mandate from me. The root is the beginning of things.

Ordinary people do not know that things share a single origin; even the liver and gallbladder are divided like Chu and Yue. If one knows this, then the myriad things and the self are one, and one does not merely listen with the ears or see with the eyes. Seeing things as one, one perceives no loss—this means that in observing the myriad things, nothing is lacking or excessive. Reading the chapter on Kui and Huan reveals this meaning. "For the self" means cultivating the self. "Through his knowledge" means that if one has this discernment, one can cultivate this self. "Attaining his heart through his heart" means that if one has this knowing heart, one can attain one’s original heart. The original and the knowing are not two things—this is merely how it is expressed. It means that all people have knowledge and a heart; if one can fully realize them, one can cultivate the self and attain the heart. Attaining the constant heart is all—why then does the world esteem him?

Flowing water and still water both serve as metaphors for the heart: the heart that can still itself is thus superior to the multitude. The multitude uses the heart of desire to seek stillness, hence the saying: "Only stillness can still all stillness"—this phrase is profoundly marvelous. The pine and cypress, Yao and Shun, uniquely receive what is proper from Heaven, so they can rectify their lives to rectify the lives of all. Life and nature share the same meaning. Preserving the original beginning has its evidence. The reality of fearlessness means that even men like Jing Ke and Nie Zheng could remain unchanged by life and death—how much more so for those with the Dao?

Heaven and Earth have their offices, movement and stillness have their gatherings. The body is not one’s own, so seeing and hearing are not employed; what is known is not two—how could the heart ever die? One ascends at the appointed time, for departure and abiding have their seasons. Borrowing from others follows what is right; the true man follows himself. The eyes resemble eyes yet are not limited to seeing; the ears resemble ears yet are not limited to hearing. Thus, how could there be anything that the knowledge of one knowing does not know?

The heart that sees nothing is called death—how could one choose a day to ascend to the Dao? This means one is always in the Dao. Establishing the teaching that is not taught, the world is transformed; sitting in the discussion that is not discussed, the world trusts. Without virtue fully within and things corresponding without, one is not equal to this. This is the Dao by which Wang Tai is still and by which one comes to mirror him. Learners wash their hearts to seek teaching, so they go empty; in the end, they truly see inner fullness, so they return fulfilled. Without emptiness, one cannot receive teaching; without fulfillment, one cannot awaken to principle. At the utmost awakening to principle, clarity and penetration are complete; things come and are mirrored—this is emptiness alone.

Thus, the essentials of the Dao are nothing else: the good teacher assists the naturalness of things; the good learner seeks to return to their naturalness. Using without imposing, the body naturally manifests—there is no need to add adornment. The *Highest* says: "I do nothing, yet the people transform themselves"—this is the teaching that is not taught, the ultimate teaching. Confucius said: "What does Heaven say? The four seasons proceed"—this is the discussion that is not discussed, the ultimate discussion. This is how the ancient sages taught people—it is up to the learner to respond accordingly.

Again, "for the self, through his knowledge he attains his heart, through his heart he attains his constant heart"—why then does the world esteem him?

The Guo school parses "through his knowledge he attains his heart, through his heart he attains his constant heart" as a single phrase, leaving "attains his constant heart" unaddressed. Cheng, Lin, and Wang all follow Guo’s interpretation. Only Master Lü parses it as "through his heart he attains his constant heart," which clarifies the meaning of the preceding and following text. Xu Qi and Wu Yin both adhere to Lü’s interpretation, and we follow it here.

Furthermore, the passage "receiving mandate from earth... only Shun alone is upright" appears irregular in phrasing, suggesting possible omissions. Chen Bixu’s *Illuminating* edition, collated by Zhang Junfang, reads: "Receiving mandate from earth, only the pine and cypress alone are upright, remaining verdant through winter and summer; receiving mandate from heaven, only Yao and Shun alone are upright, standing at the head of all things." Seven characters are thus restored, making the text coherent and complete. Guo Xiang’s commentary states: "Below, only the pine and cypress stand upright; above, only the sage stands upright." This confirms that the original scripture likely included the phrase "standing at the head of all things," which was lost in transmission.

Additionally, regarding "He then selects a day to ascend and transcend," Guo Xiang ends the sentence at "ascend" and treats "transcend" as a loan for "假" (borrow/assume), linking it to the following text. Chen Bixu follows this interpretation, while Master Lü reads "transcend" as "遐" (distant), ending the sentence there. Yi Du, Xiang Dao, Wang Pang, and Xu Zhai all adopt Lü’s reading. Upon reflection, "假人" (assuming human form) lacks coherent meaning, whereas "革从登遐" (transforming and ascending to the distant) makes the passage clear: it describes those who attain this Dao as unbound by departure or stay, ascending to the profound and remote realm. Further evidence appears in the *Liezi* ("King Mu of Zhou" chapter), where "登假" is consistently read as "登遐," supporting the view that Yong Qi’s gloss of "假" as "格" (to reach) derives from the later phrase "登假於道" (ascending to transcendence in the Dao).

Shentu Jia, an amputee, studied under Bohun Wuren alongside Zichan of Zheng. Zichan said to Shentu Jia: "If I leave first, you stay; if you leave first, I stay." The next day, they again sat together in the same hall. Zichan said to Shentu Jia: "If I leave first, you stay; if you leave first, I stay. Now I am about to leave—can you stay? Or will you not?" He added, "When you see the one in power, you do not avoid him—do you consider yourself equal to him?"

Shentu Jia replied: "In the Master’s school, are there truly those in power like this? You delight in your own authority and look down on others. I have heard: when a mirror is bright, dust does not settle; if dust settles, it is not bright. To dwell long with the worthy is to be without fault. Now, what you value most is the Master—yet you still speak like this. Is this not a fault?"

Zichan said: "Given your condition, you still vie with Yao in virtue—do you not reflect that your virtue is insufficient to compensate for your loss?"

Shentu Jia replied: "Those who justify their faults, claiming they should not perish, are many; those who do not justify their faults, claiming they should not survive, are few. Knowing one cannot help it and accepting it as fate—only those of virtue can do this. Wandering within Yi’s drawn bow: the center is the target, yet missing it is fate. Many mock my incomplete limbs! I bristled with anger, but when I came to the Master’s place, my anger dissolved and I returned to myself. Did the Master wash me with goodness? I have wandered with you for nineteen years and never knew I was an amputee. Now you wander with me within the realm of form and seek me beyond it—is this not a fault?"

Zichan, startled, changed his expression and said: "Say no more!"

Guo’s commentary: "I leave, you stay"—Zichan felt shame at walking alongside an amputee, prideful in his own authority, revealing his arrogance. Shentu Jia spoke of virtue, not rank. Zichan retorted that Shentu Jia, though maimed, belittled those in office, aspiring to equal the virtuous—yet his virtue could not compensate for his loss. Shentu Jia replied that justifying his faults, claiming he should not perish, were many; silently acknowledging them, accepting he should die, were few. When profit and harm contend, the world is like Yi’s drawn bow. Those who do not abandon themselves or forget knowledge, flowing with things, all wander within Yi’s range—even Zhang Yi’s ventures and Shan Bao’s seclusion could not escape it. Hitting the mark or not is a matter of fate. Mocking my incompleteness shows ignorance of fate; my anger at them shows further ignorance. Seeing the perfected one, who knows fate and forgets form, my anger subsided and I returned to normal. Did the Master wash me with the good Dao? Did I reflect on myself? Form is external; virtue is internal. Now you wander with me in virtue, yet seek my external appearance—is this not a fault? Zichan’s "Say no more" shows he had awakened and found the words excessive.

Lü’s commentary: Shentu Jia could disregard form and forget worldly power, while Zichan, pleased with his authority, could not forget his own. Those who nearly attain the Dao wash their hearts of dust to return to clarity, like a mirror. Yet speaking as you do shows the mirror is not bright, and dust settles. I do not justify my faults, claiming I should not perish, so I know I cannot help it and accept it as fate. Wandering within Yi’s drawn bow: the center is the target, a metaphor for acting without regret and thus avoiding harm. Missing it is fate, a metaphor for misfortune one cannot escape. Mocked for my incompleteness, I could not help but bristle with anger—yet coming to the Master’s place, I was transformed by the Dao and forgot it. Did he wash me with goodness? Did I awaken myself? Nineteen years is the full cycle of yin and yang. Wandering within the realm of form, he never knew I was an amputee—yet now you seek me beyond it. Is this not a fault?

Lin’s commentary: "Not violating" means "not avoiding." "Equal" means standing shoulder to shoulder with him. Zichan boasted of his governance and belittled others; Shentu thus used the mirror as a metaphor to reproach him. Zichan, seeing Shentu’s mutilated form yet still contending with him, was like one vying with Yao in virtue. Shentu said that among worldly people, many justify their faults as reasons they should survive, while few acknowledge their faults as reasons they should perish. He meant that Zichan had not forgotten things or abandoned form, valuing his own governance while slighting the virtue of the amputee. He also said that to vie with Yao in virtue was to justify one’s faults while unaware of impending ruin. To know the inevitable and accept it is to know fate. The range of the bow’s power is called its drawn circle—a metaphor for his own lack of the Dao to claim amputation, and thus amputation being fate. "Within the realm of form" refers to the principles of Dao, virtue, nature, and destiny; "beyond the realm of form" refers to the state of hands, feet, and physical appearance.

Detailed Daoist commentary: One whose virtue is full regards wealth and honor as floating clouds, and the body as a temporary lodging. Zichan, clinging to his rank to lord over the lowly and relying on his wholeness to despise the amputated, was unfit to speak of virtue—how then could he speak of fate? Thus it is said: wandering within Yi’s drawn bow, missing the mark is fate. Anger is the dust of one’s nature; once awakened, the dust is swept away and the mirror shines—this is one who was lost and then found.

Bixu’s commentary: Zichan studied under Bohun’s Dao yet could not forget the self; Shentu shared the same teacher yet could not forget virtue—how much less could those beneath them? That many claim they should not perish adorns their wrongs; that few claim they should survive shows how rare it is to blame oneself.

Within Yi’s drawn bow lies the metaphor: though one seeks wholeness, one cannot escape—all is Heaven’s mandate. When others laugh at my incompleteness, I bristle with anger, for the winds of indignation and the fires of resentment still burn within. Yet upon entering the Master’s presence, I am suddenly stilled, as though gazing into a pool of still water.

For nineteen years I wandered with him, yet never once did I perceive his lameness—such is one who forgets virtue and forgets form.

Zhao’s commentary: Most in the world adorn their faults, insisting their feet should not have perished, while few acknowledge their true transgressions! Fortune and misfortune alike are as when Yi, master archer, aims for the center of the target—a place of certain strike—yet one in ten thousand may escape. This is fate. How can one not count oneself fortunate? Instead, they mock others, and when mocked in turn, they cannot help but chafe with resentment—this too is ignorance of fate. But before Bohun, all such vexation dissolves.

When I wandered with Bohun, I never once perceived my own lameness. Now you wander with me within the bounds of form, where the six senses are but temporary lodgings, and the ears and eyes mere semblances—thus you and I are one. Yet you seek me beyond the bounds of form, where you are you and I am I, and no knowing passes between us.

Zichan bowed and said: "Sir, say no more. I recognize my error."

Yongzhai remarked: The phrase *"contending with Yao in goodness"* is also striking. You are lame—even if you do good, can you match Yao? Not reflecting on oneself is not measuring oneself. Those lost in their faults believe their feet should not have perished in multitudes; those not lost in their faults believe their feet should not have endured in few. Only those of virtue understand that all is fate—what can man do about it? These three lines describe three kinds of people.

The passage on *"wandering within Yi’s drawn bow"* is especially profound! It speaks of man in the world, where every movement is a perilous mechanism. The drawn bow’s aim is the arrow’s destined path—a metaphor for the world’s dangers. Whether one hits the mark or not is fate.

The discourse on *"within and beyond form"* reveals what no former sage has expressed. Shentu accepted fate and forgot his lameness; his virtue filled his inner being, leaving no sorrow for the outer. Zichan, proud of his rank and scornful of the lame, was enslaved to externals and blind to his inner truth. Though they studied together under Bohun, how could one so attached to power and position ever forget and be transformed by the Way? His mind’s mirror remained clouded, and dust settled upon it.
