*"Those who should not have perished are many; those who should not have endured are few"*—this is Shentu’s judgment on the survival of feet, for few who are lame recognize their faults and accept them. Yet fortune and misfortune alike return to fate, revealing that Shentu’s lameness arose from no fault of his own. Some misinterpret these two lines as referring to Zichan’s inability to forget form and grasp principle, but this is far off the mark.

Within Yi’s drawn bow, every place is a target—if one escapes, it is mere luck. Man in the world is never without care; if he finds respite, it is fortune alone. Yet when others mock my misfortune as their good luck, I still feel anger, for I have not forgotten myself. But when I am suddenly stilled and return to myself, I too am forgotten. Was it the Master who washed me with goodness? Or was it my own awakening? Then self and other are both forgotten, and subject and object intermingle—what room is left for joy or anger, or for seeking form?

*Collected Explications of the True Classic of Southern Florescence, Scroll Eleven* concludes.
#1 *Omissions and Errors* cites Zhang Junfang’s edition, which adds the character *"upright"* after *"also."*
#2 *Omissions and Errors* cites Zhang Junfang’s edition, which reads *"only Yao and Shun"* instead of *"only Shun,"* and adds the phrase *"among the ten thousand things"* before *"luck."*

*Collected Explications of the True Classic of Southern Florescence, Scroll Twelve*
Scholar Chu Boxiu of Wulin

**Chapter Two: The Sign of Full Virtue**

In Lu there was a man named Shushan Wuzhi, who had lost his toes. He came to see Confucius, walking on his heels.

Confucius said, “You were not careful before, and now you have suffered such misfortune. Though you come now, what can be done?”

Wuzhi replied, “I did not know what was important and so carelessly used my body—thus I lost my foot. But now that I come, I still have what is more honorable than feet. I strive to preserve this wholeness. Heaven covers all without exception; Earth bears all without exception. I took you, Master, to be like Heaven and Earth—how could I have known you would be like this?”

Confucius said, “I am indeed shallow! Why do you not come in? Please share what you have heard!”

Wuzhi departed. Confucius said to his disciples, “Take heed! Though Wuzhi is maimed, he still strives to study and make amends for past wrongs. How much more should one of full virtue do so?”

Wuzhi spoke to Lao Dan, saying, “Is Confucius not yet a perfected person? Why does he so eagerly take me as his student? He seeks to be known for strange and marvelous teachings, yet does not realize that the perfected person sees these as shackles.”

Lao Dan said, “Why not simply lead him to see life and death as a single thread, the acceptable and unacceptable as one continuum, and thus free him from his bonds? Would that not suffice?”

Wuzhi said, “Heaven has punished him—how can it be undone?”

---

**Guo’s Commentary:**
*Tread* means to follow closely. In life, one should not force things but let them arise naturally—this is valuing the body and knowing what is important. To forget one’s natural arising and act with caution and self-importance is to use the body lightly. “Still having what is more honorable than feet” means that though one foot was cut off, his virtue remained unharmed. To abandon self-importance and let things arise naturally is how one strives for wholeness. If Heaven and Earth were mere covering and bearing, they would sometimes rest—but Wuzhi, having heard what he heard, left, still finding it strange that Confucius would then go to study under Lao Dan. To teach others to find their own attainment is to follow the constant way; to abandon oneself and imitate others is to seek an extraordinary reputation. Thus, study is not for the sake of marvels, yet marvels arise from it; ritual is not for the sake of ornamentation, yet ornamentation flourishes through it. The perfected person sees these as fetters and seeks to merge with true principle. Confucius was not without this merging, but in following things, fame inevitably arises—he could not escape fame, and so how could his fetters be undone?

**Lü’s Commentary:**
Though Wuzhi lost his foot, what enabled him to walk was never forgotten—this is what is meant by “what is more honorable than feet.” Confucius wished to invite him in and discuss what he had heard, for the nature of things and the Dao of Heaven are not topics for casual learners. Wuzhi said nothing and departed, for there were things between them that could not be spoken aloud. His remark, “eagerly taking me as his student,” suggests doubt that Confucius was truly a perfected person. The Dao sees the cessation of learning as perfection, so what the world studies, the perfected person views as strange, marvelous, and shackling to the self. Only when life and death are seen as a single thread and the acceptable and unacceptable as one continuum are the shackles undone. Why not lead him to this? But what can be undone is human punishment; Heaven’s punishment cannot be undone.

**Yi Du’s Commentary:**
“Not knowing what is important” means forgetting things. “Using the body lightly” means forgetting form. “What is more honorable than feet” refers to the Dao. Wuzhi strove to preserve the Dao and forget the body, so that though the body was external, it remained intact. To compare the Master’s virtue to Heaven and Earth, yet still reproach him for lack of care and belatedness—this is to speak in terms of progress. But if one speaks from the heart, Confucius’s admission of shallowness and request to enter and discuss what he had heard are fitting. Wuzhi understood in silence, so Confucius urged his disciples to take note. Later, seeing Lao Dan, he doubted that Confucius eagerly studied to seek strange and marvelous fame, not realizing that the perfected person sees these as fetters. Why not consider how to free him? Confucius’s study under Lao Dan was simply what worldly affairs required, not out of any ulterior motive. Laozi, seeing that Wuzhi had not yet understood his heart, sought to free him from his bonds. Wuzhi believed it was Heaven’s decree and could not be undone.

**Xiang Dao’s Commentary:**
Shentu and Shushan, both maimed, approached Wang Tai—their maiming was the same, but how they bore it differed. Shushan and Shentu both strove to learn, but their reasons for learning differed. From the perspective of affairs, fame in teaching is honorable; from the perspective of the Dao, fame is a burden to the self. Thus, those of old who attained the Dao merged gain and loss into one and returned merit and fame to the multitude—this is called the “suspended release of the emperor.” Who could then honor or shame them? Yet worldly people compete for empty reputations in their time and scheme for posthumous glory, tormented and unaware of return, constrained and unable to find ease. How is this different from a prisoner in shackles? Confucius did not seek the strange to carve out a name; if he hated these fetters and sought to free himself, he would be acting against fate and doing even more. Where is the Confucius in that?

**Bi Xu’s Commentary:**
“What is more honorable than feet” refers to nature. If nature is not harmed, one can be called whole. Confucius invited Wuzhi into his chamber to discuss the Dao, but Wuzhi’s gaze conveyed his meaning, and he left without speaking. Confucius used Wuzhi’s example to instruct his disciples. Wuzhi said to Lao Dan, “Why does Confucius so eagerly take me as his student? He seeks fame through strange and marvelous teachings, yet does not realize that the perfected person sees these as punishment. Why not lead him to see that above, he is one with creation—life and death a single thread—and below, he is equal with things—the acceptable and unacceptable one continuum? Heaven’s punishment cannot be undone, for he has not yet erased his traces.”

**Zhao’s Commentary:**
The exchange between Shushan and Confucius is similar in meaning to the earlier one between Shentu and Zichan. Confucius transmitted the Dao and cultivated teaching, causing scholars from all over to gather provisions and flock to him—this is what is meant by seeking fame through strange and marvelous teachings.

Lao Dan said to Wuzhi, “Why not lead Zhongni to reflect on how to free himself from his fetters? To know this principle is to be without entanglements.”

Wuzhi replied, “Once a person has form, there are burdens—how can one soar high and remain beyond the world? Thus I say, how can Heaven’s punishment be undone?”

Yongzhai noted: “Not knowing one’s duty” means failing to understand affairs. “Honoring the foot” refers to one’s nature—these two characters are strikingly apt. “Eagerly” and “reverently,” “strange” and “marvelous” describe his pursuit of fame. “Fetters” mean fame becomes one’s burden. “Heaven’s punishment” is like Heaven’s penalty. All this is allegory.

Consider Wuzhi, who was maimed, yet still strove to study and redress his past misdeeds—how much more should one of complete virtue do so? These words benefit the world’s teachings.

The first chapter speaks of Wang Tai, who attained the Dao and fulfilled his destiny; the next of Shentu, who possessed virtue and understood destiny; this chapter of Wuzhi, who studied diligently to amend his faults. *Nanhua* discusses three grades of virtue’s fullness, echoing the sequence in *The Human World*.

The Master said of Shushan that his carelessness led to his punishment—his maiming must have had a cause. He himself admitted his folly in recklessly using his body, recognizing his error. Only by knowing one’s faults can one correct them, so the sage’s gate does not cast them out. “Honoring the foot” refers to what animates the form; by striving to preserve it, one seeks the Dao.

Wuzhi regarded the Master as heaven and earth, believing he could shelter and sustain him. The Master pointed to his past errors, saying, “What can be done now?” Wuzhi sighed at this, harboring dissatisfaction, unaware that the Master’s words were precisely the Way of sheltering and sustaining him. If Wuzhi reflected on how to amend his past faults, would the loss of his limb diminish his wholeness? This shows how sages and worthies transform and nurture, shaping all things without neglecting any grade of person—yet their accomplishments vary in degree, as seen in this chapter.

Duke Ai of Lu asked Confucius, “In Wei there is an ugly man named Aitai Tuo. Men who live with him grow attached and cannot leave. Women who see him beg their parents, ‘Rather than be another man’s wife, let me be his concubine’—dozens have done so. He never initiates speech but only harmonizes with others. Lacking a ruler’s position, he rescues people from death; without amassing wealth, he fills others’ bellies. His ugliness startles the world, yet he harmonizes without leading, and his wisdom does not extend beyond his domain. Yet men and women gather before him—he must possess something extraordinary. I summoned him to observe, and indeed, his ugliness startled the world. Living with me for less than a month, I took interest in his character; before a year had passed, I trusted him. With no minister in the state, I offered him the throne. He responded reluctantly, as if declining. I was ashamed, yet in the end, I entrusted him with the state. Soon after, he left me and departed. I grieved as if bereft, as though no one remained to share the joy of ruling the state. What manner of man is he?”

Confucius said, “Once I traveled to Chu and saw piglets nursing from their dead mother. After a moment, they shrank back and fled, for they no longer saw themselves in her, nor found her like them. What they loved in their mother was not her form but what animated it. Warriors who die in battle are not buried with military honors; those who lose a limb no longer cherish their shoes—neither retains its root.”

For the Son of Heaven’s consorts, they do not pare their nails nor pierce their ears; those who take a wife remain beyond the inner chambers and are no longer employed in service. If even those whose form is whole suffice for this, how much more the man of whole virtue? Now, Ai Taituo spoke not a word yet was trusted, had no merit yet was cherished, and was offered a state with such urgency that he feared only he might refuse—this must be one whose talent is complete and whose virtue leaves no trace.

Duke Ai said, “What is meant by *complete talent*?”
Confucius replied: “Life and death, survival and ruin, success and failure, wealth and poverty, worthiness and unworthiness, slander and praise, hunger and thirst, cold and heat—these are the changes of events, the movements of fate. They alternate before us day and night, yet knowledge cannot compass their beginning. Thus they cannot disturb harmony or enter the numinous chamber. Let them flow smoothly without losing their joy; let day and night pass without hindrance, ever bringing spring to things—this is to meet them with a heart that generates the seasons. This is called *complete talent*.”

“What is meant by *virtue that leaves no trace*?”
“Stillness is the fullness of water at rest. It may serve as a model, for within it preserves its clarity while outwardly remaining undisturbed. Virtue is the cultivation of perfect harmony. When virtue leaves no trace, things cannot depart from it.”

Later, Duke Ai told Minzi: “At first, I thought that facing south to rule the world and holding the people’s guiding thread while fearing their death was the height of understanding. Now, hearing the words of a perfected man, I fear I lack their substance—have I not recklessly spent myself and lost my state? Between Confucius and me, there is no lord and minister, only a bond of virtue as friends.”

Guo’s commentary: Those who startle the world yet draw people to them do so not through power or favor, nor through outward beauty. The man of complete talent harms nothing. Thus, he enters the beasts’ herds without disturbing them, joins the birds’ flocks without scattering them, and becomes a refuge for the ten thousand things.

When Duke Ai kept company with him, within less than a month he sensed his lofty purpose; before a year had passed, he entrusted him with the state’s governance. He responded with serene indifference, declining as if in passing, untroubled by honor or disgrace. The living are classed by talent and virtue; when these depart in death, they lose their kind and flee. If the essence remains akin, though forms differ, things harbor no ill will. If the essence is no longer akin, even mother and child cannot secure their bond. What animates form is talent and virtue.

A warrior’s armor is what he relies upon; if he dies in battle, what use is armor? When selecting consorts or celebrating a new marriage, all focus on outward beauty—thus even the highest may be swayed in their affections, and a chaste woman’s resolve may falter. Yet when virtue is whole, things naturally love it. Life and death, survival and ruin, hunger and thirst, cold and heat—these principles are fixed and inescapable.

Man’s life is no mistake; what life possesses is no illusion. Though heaven and earth are vast and the ten thousand things many, what I encounter is precisely this—exerting all strength and wisdom cannot alter it. Fate moves, events change, ceaselessly day and night, their beginnings beyond knowledge’s compass, thus beyond the heart’s attachment. Knowing fate’s inevitable course and events’ certain change, why cling to endings or beginnings, to the new or the old?

If one knows the constancy of nature and fate, though life and death, success and failure shift endlessly, one remains serene and self-possessed, harmony and principle dwelling within. The numinous chamber is the dwelling of the spirit; let no sorrow or alarm disturb it. Let harmony remain undisturbed, the numinous chamber at ease, never losing its joy—then, in tranquil accord, follow the four seasons and transform with them.

Of all things level, none surpasses still water. Within, it preserves its clarity; without, it remains free of pretense. Its dark mirror penetrates all, impartial to things—thus it perfects its stillness and enacts its model. Nothing it does not accomplish, nothing it does not harmonize. This is virtue that leaves no trace, and so the world delights to exalt it without tiring.

Lü’s commentary: Without lordly position, the most noble virtue cannot be named. Without accumulated wealth, the richest enterprise cannot be compared. When the world seeks it through desire and fails, they deem it most rare and long for it. The spirit has no fixed place yet is nowhere absent—thus knowledge does not exceed the four bounds. The ten thousand things bear yin and embrace yang, yet are distinct. Male and female unite before them, wondrous in their yin and yang beyond fathoming—thus one suspects they differ from others.

Serene and indifferent, declining as if in passing—this is not one who takes things as his concern. Entrusting him with the state was but a lodging. Soon after, he departed, and the duke mourned his loss as if bereft. The piglets’ nursing from their dead mother illustrates how the spirit in the mother is what is in the child, for they are of the same kind. When the spirit leaves the mother, they are no longer of a kind—thus they flee.

A warrior’s armor is for self-defense; if he dies in battle, what use is armor? The amputee’s disregard for his shoes—both have lost their root, for the spirit animates the form, which is their foundation. Consorts and new brides are valued for their whole form, how much more one of whole virtue? Trusted before speaking, cherished without merit—this must be one whose talent is complete and whose virtue leaves no trace.

Life and death, survival and ruin, and the rest are events when viewed by man, but the movements of fate when viewed by heaven. They alternate day and night, beyond knowledge’s compass—how could I presume to interfere? Harmony is what the spirit delights in. The numinous chamber is the spirit’s dwelling. When the spirit is harmonious, at ease, and never loses its joy, it knows no hindrance, no division of day and night, ever bringing spring to things—this is to meet them with a heart that generates the seasons.

Water’s stillness and clarity are its nature; within, it preserves itself, outwardly undisturbed—do not disturb it. The analogy of human nature is the same.

All things complete themselves to achieve fulfillment; all things unite as one to attain harmony. Virtue is the cultivation that brings completion and harmony.

When virtue leaves no trace, it returns to the primordial; how could things depart from their source of generation? As Lin Zhu notes: Though Aitai Tu held no rank or stipend, his repulsive appearance shocked the world, yet his inner abundance of talent and virtue drew the multitudes to him. Unbound by external divisions, he knew no limits within the four directions, uniting with things as one—thus male and female gathered before him. Placid and drifting, his bearing revealed no intent, no attachment. Soon he departed, for he was hard to approach yet easy to part from.

The piglet and its mother are of the same kind in life, but not in death—this illustrates how the noble person takes talent and virtue as kinship, not physical form as affection. Form refers to the six limbs and senses. What governs form is the principle of the Dao, virtue, nature, and destiny.

To die in battle yet leave one’s armor unused, or to be maimed yet discard one’s shoes—this shows that form takes talent and virtue as its foundation; without this foundation, form is useless. Concubines, attendants, those who pierce ears or take wives—all harm form for the sake of utility, selecting only those with whole bodies. How much more should one value those with whole virtue!

Life and death, survival and ruin, hunger and thirst, cold and heat—these are the changes of events and the movements of fate, alternating day and night. Even the most discerning cannot fathom their beginning, yet those with complete talent know no gain or loss, simply following them. Thus they do not disrupt harmony, never lose their joy, know no division of day and night, and ever bring spring to things, generating life within the heart.

This speaks of the boundless transformations of creation, where things arise anew each day, yet those who do not become things never perish. To meet and generate the seasons within the heart is for the perfected person to respond to things with the times, moved and thus penetrating all.

Still water, perfectly level, becomes the model for all under heaven. So too is one whose virtue leaves no trace. Virtue is the cultivation that brings harmony and completion, acting without awareness of its action. When virtue leaves no trace, things do not depart; success is achieved without awareness of its achievement.

As the *Dao* commentary explains: Wang Tai, though maimed, drew the most followers; Aitai Tu, though ugly, lost none. For there was reverence for his form, which remained whole despite his maiming; there was admiration for his supreme countenance, which remained beautiful despite his ugliness. This supreme countenance is one whose talent is complete and whose virtue leaves no trace. Men and women admired him, birds and beasts drew near, even rulers wished to entrust him with their states—not by preserving things for them, but by things preserving themselves.

Maternal love takes form as its foundation; warriors take courage as theirs; travelers take feet as theirs. That Aitai Tu was employed while present and missed when gone was because he had a foundation. When virtue is complete, it manifests as talent; when talent is complete, it enters as virtue. When virtue leaves no trace, one moves through life and death, survival and ruin without losing joy, never exchanging the self for things.

From the unbroken flow of day and night to the generation of seasons within the heart, one does not forget things for the self. Preserving within, one loses nothing of substance; undisturbed without, one is not swayed by reputation. Virtue is simply the cultivation of one’s nature, returning to completion and harmony.

Duke Ai’s relationship with Confucius began as ruler and subject but ended as friends in virtue—his awakening was indeed subtle. As Bi Xu notes: Power and wealth can sustain life, so the multitudes gather to them. Yet a common man draws crowds because his virtue is like a mountain. The self is one’s nature: in life, it remains of the same kind; in death, it loses its kind. When the sow loses her nature, the piglet loses its kind and flees—this illustrates how Duke Ai, lacking virtue, drove the perfected away.

Banners honor valor; shoes adorn feet. To die in battle or lose a foot is to forget one’s foundation—what use are adornments? The sixteen aspects—life and death, survival and ruin, cold and heat—are the dusty net of the world. Few who enter it escape; to entrust it to fate is to fill with virtue. Yet this is still the path of those within the world. Those who wander beyond it are suddenly and utterly freed, entering the great mystery. Thus Confucius could forget words, and Duke Ai ceased his questioning.

The vicissitudes of events, the ceaseless flux of morning and evening—though skilled astronomers measure and calculate, none can fix what lies ahead. Who could reckon their end? When the numinous chamber is empty, harmony and principle arise naturally. At ease and unobstructed, not bound by the constant, the joy of contentment and the emptiness of the wondrous heart are never interrupted.

The flourishing energy of spring is the same as the sagely heart that nurtures all things. The fullness of still water is what the great craftsman takes as his model. Virtue within completes the person; virtue without harmonizes things. The principle of completion and harmony is achieved only through cultivation.

To grasp the reins of the people yet worry over their deaths is to fail to treat all things as straw dogs. Forget the state, and the self is enriched; forget power, and virtue is filled.

As Zhao Zhu notes: Aitai Tu was Confucius in wordless form—when Confucius returned from Wei to Lu, his appearance was so repulsive that it was said, “Wei has an ugly man.” Men who dwelt with him longed to stay; this illustrates how lords revered him. Women wished to be his concubines; this illustrates how disciples followed him.

And harmony without leading, delusion without creation. The lord’s position gathers emoluments—this illustrates how the Dao succors all under Heaven to become an unadorned king. Knowledge does not extend beyond the realm; male and female unite before one’s eyes. What one knows does not surpass the commonplace of daily use; what one sees does not exceed the ignorance of husband and wife. Yet how does this differ from others?

Duke Ai cast aside form to embrace virtue, entrusting him with state governance, yet soon departed. Confucius compared him to a piglet suckling a dead mother—after a moment, it senses it is not of its kind and abandons her to flee. When the roasted meat did not arrive, Confucius left without doffing his ceremonial cap. Could he have done otherwise?

A warrior who dies in battle is as useless as an ornament on a coffin—just as a man with amputated feet has no use for shoes. The newly wed concubine further illustrates how talent is complete and virtue remains unmanifest.

The sixteen transformations—life and death, extreme cold and heat—are inescapable to all. They cycle day and night, their beginning and end beyond reckoning, yet they cannot disrupt the harmony of one’s Heaven-given nature. Entering the square inch of the heart, it brims with joy, and all things become spring. When encountering the moment of generation, response follows naturally.

The fullness of still water is what all under Heaven takes as its model. Virtue cultivated achieves harmony; in harmony, one merges with things. When virtue departs from things, it takes form; once formed, it is no longer virtue.

This is why Duke Ai called Confucius a "friend in virtue." Yuanzhai notes: "Knowledge does not extend beyond the four realms"—what one knows does not transcend the world. "Male and female unite before one’s eyes" means intimacy with things, akin to the idea of birds at the shore taking no alarm. The piglet’s analogy shows that human love and aversion do not depend on the beauty or ugliness of form.

A warrior who dies in battle is not mourned with ritual ornaments—just as a man with amputated feet has no use for shoes. This clarifies that virtue resides within, not without. The concubine, untrimmed nails, and unpierced ears all honor the integrity of form, eschewing adornment. The newly wed are exempt from service, as recorded in the *Rites*—this analogy illustrates the integrity of virtue.

Life and death, prosperity and ruin, changing circumstances, and the course of fate alternate before us day and night. Though the wise cannot trace their origins, they do not disturb the harmony within the breast. They do not enter the numinous storehouse, nor do they unsettle the heart.

Day and night without ceasing—this speaks of ceaseless renewal, becoming spring with all things, finding joy in every encounter. "Encountering the moment of generation in the heart" means response (encounter) and timeliness (the mean of the moment), adapting to what is felt in each situation.

"Talent complete" refers to the integrity of one’s nature. "Virtue unmanifest" means no display of merit. Inner preservation ensures outer stability—this describes how the levelness of water serves as a model.

The completion of harmony within one’s nature is the cultivation of virtue. When virtue remains unmanifest, there is nowhere it is not present, so things cannot depart from it.

This is not a lord-minister relationship but merely a "friend in virtue," akin to Mencius’ notion of "befriending."

Note: The meaning of "male and female" has varied interpretations. Some, following *Liezi*, take it as referring to birds and beasts—"male and female before one’s eyes, breeding in flocks along the Way." Yet considering the passage’s words—"men who dwelt with him longed to stay; women wished to be his concubines"—"male and female unite before one’s eyes" likely means that both men and women flocked to him.

As for those who die in battle, their burial does not employ *ying* ornaments. The traditional reading takes *zi* (资) as "use" or "offering," but some omit it entirely, leading to confusion. Later, the lecturer Wu Yin adopted the reading "without *ying*," which clarifies the text and aligns with the principle.

Further examination of the *Rites* (*Tan Gong* chapter) reveals: The Zhou placed *ying* ornaments; in Confucius’ funeral, they adorned the coffin walls with *ying* and set up mourning garments with *ying*. *Jiao* (绞) is pronounced *yao*; *qi* (萋) is pronounced *liu*. The *Rites of Zhou* writes it as *liuying*. The *Mingtang Position* states: "The Zhou’s *biyi* ornaments." Zheng’s commentary: The Son of Heaven’s eight *ying* all bear jade and hang feathers; feudal lords’ six *ying* bear *gui* tablets; great officers’ four *ying*; and scholars’ two *ying* bear *ai* caps with cords. From this, it is clear that *ying* were commonly used in ancient funeral rites, not solely as martial adornments.

Nanhua’s original intent was that the sages established rites to ensure people could nurture life and send off the dead without regret. The Zhou used bronze coffins adorned with *liuying*, with distinctions in rank and elaboration to suit each station—this was to honor the end of life. But those who die in battle do not meet a proper fate and have failed in the Way of warfare. Thus, their burial does not employ *ying*. If even their form cannot be preserved intact, how can one expect full ritual observance? It is like a man with amputated feet having no use for shoes.

This chapter, beginning with the analogy of the piglet suckling its dead mother and reiterating it here, merely illustrates that when virtue is full within, no external aid is needed; when virtue is lacking within, external adornment is of no benefit.

"Becoming spring with all things" is to "encounter the moment of generation in the heart." Those whose talent is complete and virtue unmanifest harbor perfect harmony within, engaging with things without barrier, like the spreading of spring’s warmth, bestowing the grace of life everywhere. With no deliberate intent, they respond to every stimulus.

Master Lianxi’s words—"not removing the grass before the window, for it shares the same mind as myself"—express this same idea.

Someone asked: When there is no stimulus or encounter, where does harmony reside? The answer: Like music suspended in the air, sound does not hide.

*Collected Exegeses on the Ocean of Meanings in the True Classic of Nanhua, Volume Twelve*
*Collected Exegeses on the Ocean of Meanings in the True Classic of Nanhua, Volume Thirteen*

The Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin on *"Virtue’s Overflowing Power" (Chapter Three)*

When the hunchbacked man without lips spoke to Duke Ling of Wei, the duke delighted in him; yet when he beheld whole men, their necks seemed to him mere stumps. When the jar-shaped man with emaciated limbs spoke to Duke Huan of Qi, the duke delighted in him; yet when he beheld whole men, their necks seemed to him mere stumps. Thus, when virtue excels, form is forgotten. If men forget what ought to be forgotten yet remember what ought not to be remembered, this is called *true forgetting*.

Therefore, the sage wanders freely, yet knowledge becomes a snare, covenants become glue, virtue becomes a bond, and craft becomes commerce. The sage does not scheme—what need has he for knowledge? He does not sever—what need has he for glue? He suffers no loss—what need has he for virtue? He does not traffic—what need has he for commerce? These four are the *fast of Heaven*; the fast of Heaven is the *nourishment of Heaven*. Having received sustenance from Heaven, what need has he for man?

One may possess the form of a man yet lack the passions of men. Possessing the form of a man, one mingles with men; lacking the passions of men, right and wrong do not cling to one’s person. How slight and small—this is what binds one to men! How vast and great—this alone completes one’s Heaven!

Huizi said to Zhuangzi: "Do men truly have no passions?"
Zhuangzi replied: "Indeed."
Huizi said: "If a man has no passions, how can he be called a man?"
Zhuangzi said: "The Dao gives him his appearance, Heaven gives him his form—how can he not be called a man?"
Huizi said: "If he is called a man, how can he have no passions?"
Zhuangzi said: "This is not what I mean by passions. What I call *no passions* means that men do not inwardly harm their bodies with likes and dislikes, but constantly follow nature without augmenting life."
Huizi said: "If one does not augment life, how can one preserve one’s body?"
Zhuangzi said: "The Dao gives him his appearance, Heaven gives him his form—do not inwardly harm your body with likes and dislikes. Now you strain your spirit outward, exhaust your essence, lean against a tree to chant, and recline upon a withered catalpa to sleep. Heaven chose your form, yet you clamor about *hardness and whiteness*."

Guo’s commentary: When one’s virtue excels in compliance with things, things forget their ugliness; when it excels in resistance to things, things forget their beauty. Virtue is what the world does not forget, while form is what principle does not retain—thus, to forget form is not true forgetting, but to forget virtue is *true forgetting*. To wander in the realm of self-attainment, to let go and reach everywhere—this is the completeness of talent and virtue. The four—knowledge, covenants, virtue, and craft—arise naturally from one another, their principles already inherent. Thus, the sage has no use for his own contrivance. Things are not random; all follow the course of supreme principle—one need only yield to it.

Sharing the form of men yet hollow as withered wood, one is vast and unobstructed, nothing unendurable, and so alone completes one’s Heaven. If man is not born of passion, how can life be known by passion? Huizi did not grasp that form and appearance are not passion, yet pressed further. Zhuangzi said: If right and wrong are taken as passion, then one without right and wrong or likes and dislikes, though possessing form and appearance, is merely a man—where then would passion reside? Not to harm the body with likes and dislikes, to proceed directly as circumstances demand—this is not passion. To follow nature without augmenting life is to rest in what is fitting.

Huizi still did not understand that life arises of itself, that principle is self-sufficient. Zhuangzi further explained that the principles of life are self-sufficient within form and appearance; yield to them, and they endure of themselves—passions of likes and dislikes only suffice to harm oneself. "Leaning against a tree, reclining upon a catalpa"—this describes the self-entrapment of those with passions, the passions of this world. To say "Heaven chose" makes clear that passion is not born of passion—how much less anything else!

Lü’s commentary: The lipless man and the emaciated cripple, by virtue of their excellence, were esteemed by the two rulers, for their forms were forgotten. Men do not know to preserve their spirit—what they forget is enslaved to sight and sound, thought and deliberation, which they do not forget. To forget what ought to be forgotten yet remember what ought not to be remembered—this is *true forgetting*. It is not merely that form is forgotten; in true forgetting, the sage’s wanderings are such that things cannot pursue him, yet all are preserved.

Thus, to treat knowledge as a snare—snares are not the trunk of the tree; to treat covenants as glue—glue is for binding what is scattered; to treat virtue as a bond—bonds are for joining disparate bodies; to treat craft as commerce—commerce is not for making vessels. The sage does not scheme—what need has he for knowledge? He does not sever—what need has he for glue? He suffers no loss—what need has he for virtue? He does not traffic—what need has he for commerce? These four are the *constant of Heaven*, thus requiring nothing from without.

Possessing the form of a man yet lacking the passions of men—this is because his wanderings lie in *true forgetting*. Mingling with men, he wanders among worldly customs; right and wrong do not cling to his person, so he rests in the evenness of Heaven. In his smallness, he belongs to men; in his greatness, he belongs to Heaven. In appearance, his movements and demeanor are none other than the Dao; in form, his six limbs and nine orifices are born of Heaven—what is needed to be a man is complete. Why doubt that he cannot be without passion?

Huizi simply took "no passion" to mean like wood or stone, unfit to be called a man. Zhuangzi said: What I call passion is that right and wrong do not cling to one’s person. What I call *no passion* is not to inwardly harm one’s body with likes and dislikes. If so, this suffices to preserve one’s body—why augment life? Huizi did not know that movement and stillness are one, yet sought stillness by reclining upon a catalpa. Not understanding this, he failed to grasp that his form was chosen by Heaven, yet clamored about *hardness and whiteness*.

Lin’s commentary: Form is what the world does not forget; virtue is what the world forgets. If a man can forget what the world does not forget and remember what the world forgets, then his talent and virtue are complete—this is *true forgetting*. The wanderings of the sage, as *Liezi* says, are to observe what changes, the ultimate in wandering. Knowledge is the source of schemes, hence a snare. Covenants bind things, hence glue.

Virtue perfected within responds to things without—thus it is called "engagement."
The craftsman fashions tools to seek profit—thus it is called "trade."
These four—engagement, trade, schemes, and bonds—are what the world pursues,
yet the sage neither plans nor severs, neither loses nor traffics. What need has he for these four?

Though these four belong to human affairs, they are also how Heaven nourishes mankind.
Having received sustenance from Heaven, why resort to human contrivance?

The sage’s form is the same as others’, so he mingles among men;
his nature differs from others’, so right and wrong do not adhere to him.
His form is slight, thus he belongs to man;
his nature is vast, thus he fulfills Heaven.

Huizi understood this nature but not its source.
Zhuangzi spoke of not inwardly harming the body with likes and dislikes—
this, in accord with the nature of life and destiny, is how one fulfills Heaven.
The passions of likes and dislikes respond to things, yet the self has no part in them.
Not augmenting life, one exhausts life’s principles without imposing one’s passions.
The Dao’s countenance and Heaven’s form remain unharmed by likes and dislikes—
this suffices to preserve one’s body.

Now you strain your spirit and weary your essence,
leaning against trees and reclining upon catalpa—
all these are the burdens of passion.
Heaven chose your form to wander uniquely among things,
yet you augment life and confuse the multitude,
like Gongsun Long’s wrangling over hardness and whiteness,
able to silence men’s mouths but not win their hearts.
This is to misunderstand the nature of life and destiny,
and be enslaved by creation.

*Detailed Commentary on the Dao*:
The sage’s Dao has no fixed direction, yet is nowhere absent;
it has no form, yet nothing it does not become.
Thus his mind finds no destination that is not wandering.
Wandering is the name for carefree roaming, unbound by attachments.
The question "What need for schemes, bonds, virtue, or trade?"
refers to what he wanders beyond.
Schemes arise from planning, bonds from covenants,
virtue from loss, craft from profit—
these four are the world’s means of mutual sustenance.
The man of full virtue has no use for them; he relies on Heaven’s nourishment alone.

The sage’s form is the same as others’, thus he seems slight in smallness;
his nature differs from others’, thus he alone fulfills Heaven.
The sage is not without passion—
his likes arise from non-disliking, his dislikes from non-liking.
Following what is naturally so without augmenting life,
this may be called "without passion."
Man’s life: his form is chosen by Heaven, his nature endowed beyond things.
His virtue is never unfilled—
only when entangled by things is it harmed.
Remove the harm, and virtue is full.

Huizi’s excessive speech was his greatest harm,
so this chapter ends by refuting him.

*Bixu’s Commentary*:
Between these two masters, their discourse forgets form but not yet virtue.
The sage wanders beyond the realm of intent, form, and forgotten virtue,
though in daily use he employs knowledge and virtue without self-importance.
Thus schemes and bonds never arise.
Without planning gain or harm, what need for schemes?
Without severing nature and passion, what need for bonds?
Without loss among things, what need for virtue?
Without amassing goods, what need for trade?
These four are how the myriad things are nourished by Heaven.

The dung beetle rolls its ninefold ball, the spider weaves its web—
this is unplanned knowledge.
Clouds and dragons, wind and tigers, pines and cypresses, dodder and mistletoe—
this is unsevered bonding.
Birds and beasts in forests and marshes, fish and turtles in rivers and lakes—
this is virtue without loss.
Each thing seeks its own advantage, each tends its own life—
this is trade without commerce.
This is Heaven’s nourishment, thus called "Heaven’s sustenance."
With form but no passion, one resembles a wooden rooster.

Faces a foot wide differ in appearance—this is the Dao’s gift.
Bodies six feet tall, empty sacks with no distinction—this is Heaven’s gift.
Neither belongs to passion.
Heaven entrusts you with form—how could it be passionate?
It merely ferments and arises of itself.

Now you possess a human form no different from others,
yet forcefully clamor about hardness and whiteness, sameness and difference before the multitude,
proclaiming yourself wise—
like smelted metal leaping from the furnace, how could it not seem strange?

*Zhao’s Commentary*:
Without lips or with great deformity, their ugliness is evident,
yet these two masters delighted in them and saw them as whole—
forgetting their forms and cherishing their virtue.
That form’s ugliness can be forgotten while the world forgets it not,
and virtue’s unforgettability is forgotten by the world—
this is true forgetting.

The sage wanders in this world,
fearing knowledge may lead to deceit, so establishes covenants to secure it;
fearing virtue insufficient to reach others, teaches trade to exchange goods,
amassing the world’s wealth.
Yet what makes the sage a sage is the absence of these four.
Thus he neither plans, nor severs, nor loses, nor traffics.

Slight in smallness—this is form.
Vast in greatness—this is virtue.

Huizi still doubted how one without passion could be human.
The answer: "When I speak of being without passion,
I mean not inwardly harming the body with likes and dislikes."
This was a direct pointer, yet Huizi still raised objections.
Zhuangzi warned him: "Master, you strain your spirit and weary your essence—
how exhausting your labor!
If one day your form were reclaimed by Heaven,
could you still prattle on with hardness and whiteness, sameness and difference?"

*The Oral Teachings of Yongzhai*:
Virtue has its excellence, form its forgettability.
To love virtue and forget form—
the world knows form but not virtue; this is true forgetting.
When the sage wanders, his mind wanders in Heaven.
Knowledge is for handling affairs, bonds for restraining the self—
engaging outwardly while forgetting inwardly.
Merchants sell their reputations to the world.
With the mind wandering in Heaven, these four become burdens—
thus he has no use for them.
"Heaven’s sustenance" is like "Heaven’s nobility."

Virtue and knowledge, previously praised, are here deemed harmful—
the brush dances freely, with some lapses in consistency.

"Having a human form" and what follows are Zhuangzi’s common expressions,
which Huizi questioned.

*The Oral Teachings of Yongzhai*:

Heaven bestows form—it is a thing. The Dao bestows appearance—things must have their patterns. What I call "having no emotions" is to forget likes and dislikes and not be harmed, to follow nature and not augment it. Now, Master Hui exhausts his spirit and wearies his essence in debates over "hard and white" and "sameness and difference." Yet Heaven granted you this form—why torment yourself so? Where virtue excels, delight lies in virtue, not in appearance. Where form is forgotten, one discards appearance to unite with the heart. This is how these two scholars were known by their lords, and how their lords were praised by later generations.

The sage’s wanderings do not depart from the human world. Leisurely and carefree, he observes its changes, walking without relying on his feet, seeing without relying on his eyes. Thus, things do not chase after form, nor do people flee from their emotions, yet his concern for the world never leaves his heart for a single day. Fame and reputation are demonic entanglements that disturb the nature; to treat them as wisdom gives rise to demands and deceit. The simplicity of knotted cords arose from the scattering of primal integrity, yet clinging to them like glue breeds fraud and falsehood. Artisans craft tools to serve needs, but when trade turns to commerce, cunning and deceit emerge. These are the corruptions of the age.

The true person still hopes to reverse them, declaring: "Without scheming, what use is knowledge? Without novelty, what use is glue? Without loss, what use is virtue? Without goods, what use is commerce?" His words strike deeply. This is the essential path of returning to purity and simplicity. Even if the sage were to reappear, he would not alter this teaching. If one could shed the burdens of glue-like attachments and demonic entanglements, one would become a companion of Heaven—how could the decay of the world reach them?

"Having a human form," one shares the same eating, drinking, and daily life as others; "having no human emotions," right and wrong, likes and dislikes do not stir within. How small this form is in the vastness of Heaven and Earth! How great this virtue is in the depths of human nature! With one’s own nature, one restores one’s own spontaneity—what need is there for others?

The Dao bestows appearance—whether beautiful or ugly, one accepts it. Heaven bestows form—whether long-lived or short-lived, one preserves it whole. Always following nature without augmenting life, knowing that non-augmentation means no harm, where then can emotions find a foothold?

Now, Master Hui does not cultivate the inner fullness of virtue but merely seeks to align with the world’s sentiments through verbal debate. Thus, he exhausts his spirit outwardly and wearies his essence, leaning on his armrest with closed eyes—his knowledge and abilities have enslaved him, and he is utterly worn out! I tell him: Heaven selected your form to be the spirit of the myriad things—was it merely so you could clamor about "hard and white" among men? Ascend by degrees to the mysteries of nature and destiny, the profundities of virtue and the Dao, and you may yet approach the sagely and the divine.

How pitiful that Master Hui is burdened by talent and drowned in debate, blind to his nature and confused by his emotions! This is the great flaw of scholars: losing virtue through knowledge. They fail to realize that human emotions are originally free of likes and dislikes—likes and dislikes arise from things. When emotions and things are forgotten, both are transformed. Always following nature without augmenting life—this is the emotion of having no emotions. What need is there for debate?

If Master Hui were to suddenly awaken, return to purity and simplicity, and advance beyond knowledge, his virtue could be fulfilled and his nature restored. Why then would he worry about failing to connect with others or respond to things? That by which things are given life is called virtue—it is Heaven’s pure and perfect endowment, the means by which form is completed and life honored. By cultivating it, one may come to hear of the nature and the Dao of Heaven.

Virtue originates in Heaven, but its fulfillment lies with man—how can one not cherish and esteem it? The resonance of things is but a minor response, a sign of virtue’s fulfillment. To verify its great achievement, there are those who assist Heaven and Earth, aiding transformation and nurturance. Thus, Wang Tai inspired Confucius’s respect, and if he wished to lead the world to follow him, his cultivation must have surpassed others. Without teaching or discourse, learners came empty and left full—unless one’s heart connected with hearts, death and life held no change, and one commanded things while transformation flowed from oneself, how could this be achieved?

Seeing unity and forgetting loss reveals how the attainer of the Dao forgets form. Only stillness can still all stillness, showing how emptiness serves as a mirror. These are the ways to fulfill virtue. When virtue is full, things turn to it, like pines and cypresses among the common trees, like Yao and Shun among the people. Is it merely good fortune to rightly order one’s own life? The true fortune lies in rightly ordering all beings, while one’s own life and death, fortune and misfortune are not clung to as trifles. Thus, choosing the day to ascend or depart rests with oneself—how could one be troubled by things?

Shentu Wujue endured mutilation and sought further amputation, seeing amputation as wholeness. Zichan, despite his noble position in governance, was arrogant toward the amputated—though noble, he was base. Without toes, one’s honor lies in what remains, and what remains is weightier than feet. When Heaven’s punishment cannot be undone, accepting one’s fate makes one no different from the whole. When Aichi saw the male and female rhinoceroses before him, he made Duke Ai forget his revulsion and wish to entrust him with the state. This was not love for his form, but love for what gave his form meaning.

Thus, when supreme harmony operates within, flaws and illnesses vanish without. Virtue renews daily, the Dao flows through spiritual transformation. Things are accomplished without claiming merit, and wherever one goes, things turn to them. Duke Ai befriended Confucius—his virtue was honored, and his rank could be forgotten. Duke Ling saw Wushen as whole—his virtue was honored, and his form could be forgotten.

The sage’s wanderings have no boundary with things. How vast! Alone, he completes his Heaven. He forgets what others cannot forget, and the pure and perfect naturally turn to him without refusal. Master Hui was rich in talent but poor in virtue, so he asked about the emotions of likes and dislikes. The answer addressed the emotions of nature and destiny, deeply correcting his error: let the Dao’s appearance and Heaven’s form not be harmed by likes and dislikes. Having form but no emotions, always following nature—thus virtue is fulfilled and things resonate, self and other both vanish. Right and wrong, likes and dislikes are transformed in wordless forgetting. What need is there to exhaust spirit and essence in clamoring over "hard and white"?

The Supreme One states: Supreme Virtue, Perfect Virtue, Vast Virtue, and Mysterious Virtue—all are the fullness of virtue. Goodness binds without cords, and the world will naturally submit; unsummoned, it comes of itself. To hold virtue is to grasp the tally—all are called "correspondence." Yet *Nanhua* expounds this in even greater detail, even taking the maimed, the crippled, and the repulsive as the basis of its discourse, thereby serving as a warning to those who esteem form and outward appearance over inner virtue.

*The Ocean of Meanings in the True Scripture of Nanhua*, Scroll Thirteen (concluded)

#2 The character *bai* 應作 *jie* 皆.

*The Ocean of Meanings in the True Scripture of Nanhua*, Scroll Fourteen
Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin

**Inner Chapters: The Teacher of Heaven #1**

To know what Heaven does and to know what man does—this is perfection.
To know what Heaven does is to be born of Heaven;
To know what man does is to nourish what his knowledge knows with what his knowledge does not know, so that he completes his Heaven-appointed years without dying prematurely—this is the fullness of knowledge.
Yet there is a danger.
Not knowing that one must await something before acting rightly, and what one awaits remains uncertain.
How can we be sure that what I call Heaven is not man, or that what I call man is not Heaven?
Only after there is a true person is there true knowledge.

What is a true person?
The true persons of old did not resist the few, did not dominate success, did not scheme with scholars.
Those who are thus do not regret their errors nor take pride in their rightness.
Those who are thus climb high without fear, enter water without getting wet, enter fire without feeling heat—such is the knowledge that ascends to the Dao in this way.

Guo Xiang’s commentary:
To know what Heaven does is to know that all is natural; thus one inwardly releases the self and outwardly merges with things, following them so that nothing is left undone.
What acts cannot act, yet action acts of itself.
What knows cannot know, yet knowledge knows of itself.
The true person abandons knowledge yet knows, does not act yet acts, lives by nature, and attains through sitting in forgetfulness.
Thus knowledge is called "cut off," and the name of action departs.

Man’s life depends on all that Heaven and Earth possess, and not a day can be without them.
Yet what the body possesses, knowledge may or may not know;
What principle holds, action may or may not perform.
What knowledge knows is little; what the body possesses is much.
What action does is few; what principle holds is vast.
What men know need not be the same, yet what they do dare not differ—if it differs, falsity arises and truth is lost.
Knowing that what man does has its hidden limits, one follows without forcing;
Knowing that what man knows has its bounds, one employs without excess.
Within the unity of the self, knowledge and unknowing meet and join.
Measuring by the fullness of knowledge, yet leaving the unknown to knowledge and entrusting it to Heaven—this still involves awaiting.
If one entrusts life to Heaven, then encountering things is fitting.
Our life has its limit—this is Heaven.
To seek to extend it—this is man.
Man is none other than Heaven; order and chaos, success and failure are all natural.
Only after there is a true person does all knowledge in the world attain its truth.
Not resisting the few, one follows the many.
Not dominating success, one does not rely on action; the mind roams freely, and the scholar preserves himself without scheming to reach it.
He simply preserves himself rightly without error,
Not weighing gain and loss in his heart.
This speaks of ascending to the Dao so far.

Lu Huiqing’s commentary:
To know what Heaven does is to know that what gives us life is Heaven—nothing acts, and man has no part in it; it is what knowledge cannot know.
What knowledge can know is what man does, so one nourishes what knowledge does not know with what it does know, using knowledge to nourish life rather than letting life follow knowledge.
Thus one can fulfill one’s years without dying prematurely. What the world calls the fullness of knowledge goes no further than this.
Yet it is not free from exhaustion, for what is called knowing Heaven and knowing man must await knowledge to be fitting. Knowledge is not the true Dao, yet one awaits it to be fitting—what one awaits is fundamentally uncertain. How then can we be sure that what I previously called Heaven is not man, or that what I called man is not Heaven?
Only the true person has true knowledge, knowing with what does not know and thus having nothing to await.

The world’s rights and wrongs are not uniform, so one simply follows the multitude.
Following the multitude, one cannot avoid resisting the few.
The way of Earth has no success yet takes turns in completion; rigidity cannot avoid dominating success.
Consulting and scheming with others cannot avoid plotting with scholars—these are all the sage’s responses to the world, not his truth.
The true person embodies pure simplicity without self, so though he errs, he cannot but err—what regret can there be?
Though he is right, he cannot but be right—what pride can there be?
If this is so, then climbing high is what I do—whom should I fear?
Water and fire are also what I do—whom should I wet or burn?
Knowledge is not the Dao, yet the true person’s true knowledge can ascend to the Dao in this way.

Lin Yidu’s commentary:
What Heaven does, man does not know, yet he must nourish it with man’s knowledge.
Within the self, what lies within the body, I do not know;
What lies beyond the body, I use to nourish what I do not know.
Thought has form; thoughtlessness leaves no trace. Now, using the thought that has form to think of thoughtlessness—thus it is clear that knowledge nourishes the unknown.
What knowledge nourishes is slight, yet the unknown does not escape its nourishment—hence it is called "full."
Though knowledge is full, it is not free from exhaustion, for it still awaits to be fitting.
Having something to await means uncertainty. Forgetting both knowledge and unknowing, how can there still be anything to await?
How can we be sure that what I call Heaven is not man, or that what I call man is not Heaven?
Only by not resisting the few do the many thus follow.

Not striving to dominate success, the many thus place him first;
Not scheming for followers, the many thus turn to him.
Whether he errs or acts rightly, principle accords with what is fitting—what regret or gain could there be?
One who is thus ascends heights without trembling, enters water without drowning, enters fire without burning. This is the most wondrous principle, attainable only by the true person—such is the knowledge that ascends to merge with the Dao.

Chen Xiangdao’s note:
To know what Heaven does is destiny;
To know what man does is righteousness.
Knowing Heaven but not man is to discard righteousness for destiny;
Knowing man but not Heaven is to discard destiny for righteousness.
Both are but one-sided aspects of the Dao, not its ultimate state.
Nourishing the unknown with what is known, his life is simply spontaneous.
What man does must rely on what nourishes it to be achieved.
Knowledge is not the Dao; relying on it to enter the Dao still requires awaiting what is fitting.
Knowing what Heaven does, what is awaited is Heaven—though fitting with Heaven, he knows not of man.
Knowing what man does, what is awaited is man—though fitting with man, he knows not of Heaven.
What is awaited remains uncertain; what is known cannot be without bias—this is not true knowledge.
The true person, in knowledge, harbors no expectations, thus does not resist the few;
In action, does not strive for dominance, thus does not force success;
In reliance, has nothing to await, thus does not scheme for followers.
One who is thus may err in governing the world, yet I know not why he errs;
May act rightly in following principle, yet I know not why he acts rightly.
Unaware of what is high, he ascends without trembling;
Unaware of water or fire, he enters without drowning or burning.
Such is the knowledge that ascends to merge with the Dao.

Chen Bixu’s note:
What Heaven does is to send down pure and wondrous qi, covering and nurturing the myriad things;
What man does is to move the spirit’s harmonious qi, nourishing and protecting the hundred bones.
To know that Heaven’s non-action is not emptiness, and man’s action is not stagnation—this is the ultimate.
The pure and wondrous qi, unaware of whence it comes, is called "solitary transformation."
Solitary transformation is spontaneous arising.
What knowledge knows is finite knowledge;
What knowledge does not know is infinite knowledge.
Nourishing infinite knowledge with finite knowledge, without overstepping bounds to seek understanding—this is the fullness of knowledge.
Yet it still rests in awaiting what is fitting, so better to forget all and entrust it.
The opposition of boundaries remains uncertain—how can we be sure that what I call natural is not human, or that what I call human is not natural?
One who is thus, with mind submerged in emptiness, traces merged with the dust of clamor, ascends into the great void, vast and boundless.

Wang Xiu’s note:
All who possess knowledge use it to harm life.
Only those who study the Dao keep knowledge within the Dao.
Keeping knowledge within the Dao is to nourish the unknown and thus ascend to merge with the Dao.

Zhao Xuzhai’s note:
What Heaven does arises spontaneously—this is what knowledge does not know.
What man does arises from compulsion—this is what knowledge knows.
Nourishing what knowledge does not know with what it knows is to know Heaven through knowing man, to serve Heaven through knowing Heaven.
One may fulfill destiny without misfortune or premature death, yet still face calamity.
The changes of life and death cannot be foreseen; having something to await means uncertainty.
But one who does not recognize or know, following the Emperor’s decree—dying at dusk after hearing the Way at dawn—what does he await?
The *Mencius*’ "Exhausting the Mind" chapter elucidates this principle.
*The Ordinary Studio’s Oral Teachings* states: When human affairs are exhausted, Heaven’s principle appears—thus he nourishes what knowledge does not know with what it knows.
Knowledge lies within me, but what is awaited lies without.
Sometimes one obtains without seeking, sometimes only obtains through seeking—neither can be certain.
If one says it comes from Heaven, one must seek to obtain it;
If one says it comes from man, there are things one seeks yet does not obtain.
How can we be sure that what I call Heaven is not man, or that what I call man is not Heaven?
Only with the true person does true knowledge arise—this speaks of one who possesses the Dao.
The few are insufficient; when in times of insufficiency, even if success comes, one does not boast or dominate.
"Scholars" refers to those of the same endeavor.
The *Shu Mountain* poem says: Do not act as a scholar with a tally—act without intention.
Thus, one does not regret failure nor rejoice in success, entrusting all to spontaneity.
Not trembling, not drowning, not burning—this is the meaning of "no entry without self-attainment."
"Ascending to merge" means profound attainment.

Chu Shi’s *Insights* states:
Knowing oneself to know others, knowing others to know Heaven—this is the proper path of knowledge.
Heaven is fundamentally non-active; when speaking of what Heaven does, it refers to the movement of the sun, moon, and stars, the progression of yin and yang, cold and heat.
What man does refers to the manifestation of good and evil, compliance and rebellion, the formation of fortune and misfortune, gain and loss.
Having known this, one nourishes what knowledge does not know with what it knows.
"What is known" refers to what knowledge reaches—human affairs that can be anticipated, Heaven’s principles that can be deduced.
"What is not known" refers to what is beyond knowledge, beyond anticipation, beyond calculation—dim, obscure, and numinous, like spirits and gods.
Fulfilling one’s natural lifespan without premature death—this speaks only of knowing man, hence it is called the fullness of knowledge.
Yet it still awaits knowledge to be fitting, so what is awaited remains uncertain.
How can we be sure that what I call Heaven is not man, or that what I call man is not Heaven?
The fusion of Heaven and man is true knowledge.
The *Qi Wu Lun* says: "Knowledge stops at what it does not know." This is it.
"The few" refers to times of poverty and constraint; "success" alludes to times of abundance.
Not trembling, not drowning, not burning—this is the meaning of "no entry without self-attainment."
"Ascending to merge" means profound attainment.

In times of constraint, one must yield—resistance harms life.
In times of abundance, one must remain humble—arrogance invites disaster.
The conduct of the *mosheng* (exemplary person), when illustrated through affairs, carries profound meaning—precisely what the classics call "no deliberation, no premeditation."
In such a state, interactions with the world may occasionally exceed what circumstances demand, yet this is merely happenstance—what regret could there be?
When circumstances themselves are happenstance, what self-satisfaction could arise?
It is like a drifting tile or an empty boat: without intent to encounter things, things do not resent them.
Thus, ascending heights—what is there to fear?
Entering water—what is there to drown in?
Entering fire—what is there to burn?
If even those who ascend to the Dao through knowledge are like this, how much more so those who forget knowledge and attain sudden awakening?

The true person of old slept without dreaming, woke without worry, ate without relishing flavor, and breathed deeply.
The true person’s breath rose from the heels, while the breath of ordinary people rose only from the throat.
Those who are cramped and submissive speak as if choking.
The deeper one’s cravings, the shallower one’s heavenly mechanism.

The true person of old did not delight in life nor detest death.
They emerged without joy, returned without resistance—
gone in a flash, come in a fleeting moment, nothing more.
They did not forget their origin nor seek their end.
They received and rejoiced, forgot and returned—
this is called not abandoning the Dao with the heart, not aiding Heaven with human effort.
This is the true person.

Guo’s commentary:
Sleeping without dreaming means having no mental constructs.
Waking without worry means accepting whatever comes.
Eating without relishing flavor means eating as a matter of course.
The true person’s breath rises from the heels, coming from the very root.
Choked speech arises from uneven qi—only when the root is deeply settled and utterly still does one return to unity, free of desire, embodying transformation, at ease and unforced.
Thus, coming and going present no difficulty; all beginnings and endings, all changes, are forgotten.
How could one who has even forgotten life still seek the meaning of death?
Whatever is received, they meet without resistance.
When things ceaselessly stir the heart and people recklessly pursue them, the heavenly principle is extinguished.
The true person, knowing how to use the heart, does not act thus.
To aid Heaven is to harm it.

Wu’s commentary:
Without deliberation, one sleeps without dreaming.
Without cravings, one eats without relishing flavor, and thus breathes deeply from the heels.
The heel is the origin of qi, the source of breath.
The body’s heel is the foot; the breath’s heel is its point of origin—both are spoken of as the lowest.
Deeper and deeper still—ordinary people lose their grounding and become cramped and submissive.
Their speech chokes as if gagging—how could they breathe from the heels?
Their heavenly mechanism is shallow, stirred by the slightest touch.
But when breath rises from the heels, one is far removed from things.

Those who delight in life, abhor death, rejoice in emergence, and resist return—abandoning what they call "tranquility"—are those who discard the Dao with their hearts. Their attachments reach their end, yet they cannot joyfully accept it, forget and return to it. They obscure the natural and thereby augment life—this is how people assist Heaven.

Yi Du’s commentary:
The true person sleeps at night and awakens at dawn, no different from others. Yet they do not dream and are without sorrow—this sets them apart. When the heart dances with thought, the hun-spirit remains at ease and does not wander among things; thus, their sleep is dreamless. When the form is without contrivance, the shen-spirit remains at rest and is not enslaved by things; thus, their waking is without care. Their food is not savored, as if they do not eat at all. Their breath is deep and profound, for the true person’s qi is stored in the profound and subtle. The heel is the body’s lowest extremity. Qi is concealed in secrecy and does not burst forth externally. Breath enters through the nose, but the heart governs it. Those who are submissive are constrained by others; their qi is broken and bent, so their speech is choked as if gagging. The throat is where food is received. Those deeply mired in cravings have spirits that scatter and awareness that dims. Examining their heavenly mechanism, it resides only above the liver and diaphragm, before the face and eyes—far removed from the root. As *Mencius* says: "Those who are full of desires, though they may preserve something of it, do so but little." This is the case. If one does not know how to delight in life, how can they rejoice in emergence? If one does not know how to abhor death, how can they resist return?

Swift and unobstructed they come and go—only the most spiritually attuned remain unmoved. Not forgetting their origin, they return to their root. Not seeking their end, they entrust it wholly to fate.

While alive, they do not question what comes their way but receive it with joy. When their time comes, they do not ponder where they go but forget and return. This is called not abandoning the Dao with the heart, nor aiding Heaven with human effort.

*Detailed Commentary on the Dao* states: The true person of old slept without their spirit intermingling, thus they had no dreams. When awake, their form remained unopened, thus they knew no sorrow. They tasted flavors yet were not enslaved by taste, so food held no savor. They nurtured directly without depleting their true nature, so their breath was deep. Neither delighting in life nor abhorring death, they entrusted life and death to Heaven. Neither rejoicing in emergence nor resisting return, they entrusted emergence and return to things. Such as these move freely and unobstructed.

Those burdened by things forget their beginning; those chasing profit seek their end. What they receive may not suit them, and their return depends on reflection. Only the true person does not forget their origin but returns to their root, does not seek their end but arrives at fate. Thus, they receive with joy and forget to return. Without thought, they do not abandon the Dao with the heart. Without action, they do not aid Heaven with human effort. This is the true person.

*Green Void’s Commentary* states: One whose spirit is concentrated does not dream. One whose heart is empty knows no sorrow. Without cravings, they find no savor in food. The true person’s fire lies beneath water, so their breath reaches everywhere. The common person’s water and fire contend, thus they find no ultimate peace. Those deeply mired in cravings have shallow heavenly mechanism; when true water is muddied, heavenly light dims. Those who practice the Dao harbor no delight or aversion; those who entrust themselves to fate harbor no joy or resistance. Not forgetting their origin preserves their root; not seeking their end avoids premeditation. Not using the heart to discard the great Dao, not enhancing life to invite misfortune—this is the conduct of the true person.

*Empty Studio’s Commentary* states: Without sleep, without waking, without eating, without breath—this is the true person. Breath emerges from the throat, as all people know. But when deeply asleep, the throat rattles—this is what is meant by "choked speech as if gagging." Delighting in life and abhorring death, rejoicing in emergence and resisting return—this is what is meant by "deep cravings, shallow mechanism." The true person is free of these, thus their comings and goings are unconstrained. Therefore, they do not obscure Heaven’s inherent nature and interact with things endlessly.

Receiving with joy, they are not burdened by life. Forgetting to return, they revert to their root. Not abandoning the Dao with the heart unites heart and Dao. Not aiding Heaven with human effort unites person and Heaven. The true person’s relation to the Heavenly Dao is simply to rest in naturalness.

*Ordinary Studio* says: Their sleep is dreamless—spirit is settled. Their waking is sorrowless—they engage with things without mental conflict. Their food is unsavory, for they seek no satiety. Their breath is profoundly deep—Daoist cultivation truly originates here. When spirit is settled, breath is deep, rising from the heels to the mouth and nose. Without cultivation, the breath of emergence and return stops at the throat. The difference between tranquility and agitation in the body reveals whether one has true insight. Speech confined to the mouth is easily subdued by others—one may observe this in those who question Chan.

Craving is human desire; heavenly mechanism is heavenly principle. Depth and shallowness refer to the measure of their waxing and waning. Each sentence in this passage forms a coherent thread—both Daoist texts and Buddhist scriptures derive from this. From "not knowing how to delight in life" onward, it speaks only of emergence and return. Not forgetting the origin and not seeking the end is the teaching of "tracing origins and embracing endings."

Receiving form from Heaven, how could one not rejoice? Returning it whole, one harbors no attachment. Not abandoning the Dao with the heart means the heart *is* the Dao. Not aiding Heaven with human effort means longevity and early death are fated—human effort adds nothing.

Their sleep is dreamless, like their waking. Their waking is sorrowless, like the Dao. Food is unsavory, thus bland and flavorless. Breath is profoundly deep, thus never leaving its root. The true person’s breath reaches the heels—this is the esoteric teaching of life cultivation. *Nanhua* reveals this principle out of pity for worldly people who chase things and lose their true nature, whose spirit declines and qi dissipates. Many doubt the word "heel," finding it hard to reconcile. It is a metaphor for the body’s lowest extremity. If one seeks within, perceiving the depth of their breath, they will understand what is meant by "heel." The common person’s breath emerges from the throat, as all know. But its origin is the heel. When cravings steam and rise, the double gates become blocked, and breath departs from the heel, unable to return, lingering at the throat. Thus, when slightly oppressed by external things, their qi is bent and constrained, and their speech is choked as if gagging.

The *Appended Judgments* of the *Book of Changes* says: "Those who lose what they guard speak in a constrained manner." This is all due to deep-seated cravings that harm the heavenly mechanism—it is not that the heavenly mechanism is inherently shallow. Not forgetting the origin is to receive with joy. Not seeking the end is to forget and return. Regarding "not abandoning the Dao with the heart," I suspect "abandon" (*juan*) should be "follow" (*yuan*), meaning to pursue or chase. This aligns with the subsequent phrase "not aiding Heaven with human effort." The *Discourse on Equalizing Things* states: "Not delighting in seeking, not following the Dao," confirming that the sound is preserved but the character is corrupted.

Such a one’s mind is steadfast, their demeanor serene, their forehead broad and full. Chill as autumn, warm as spring, their joy and anger harmonize with the four seasons. They adapt to things without knowing their limit.

Thus, when the sage employs military force, he may overthrow a state yet not lose the people’s hearts. His beneficence extends through ten thousand generations, yet he does not act out of love for others. One who delights in connecting with things is no sage; one who clings to kinship is not truly humane; one who follows the seasons is not a worthy; one who fails to reconcile profit and harm is no gentleman; one who pursues reputation at the cost of self is no scholar; one who sacrifices the self without authenticity is no master of others.

Such as Hu Bujie, Wu Guang, Boyi, Shuqi, Jizi, Xuyu, Ji Ta, and Shentu Di—these are servants of others’ service, conforming to others’ conformity without conforming to their own. Guo’s commentary: "Where one dwells, contentment becomes their aspiration." Though they act, they do no harm to stillness. Their broad, full foreheads bear the appearance of great simplicity. Those who embody the Dao and harmonize with change share the same warmth and severity as cold and heat, without intention toward things. Thus, they do not seize what is fitting for things, and nothing is unfitting—hence, none can fathom their limit.

In overthrowing a state, he follows the people’s desire to overthrow it. Warm as the spring sun, those bathed in his grace do not feel gratitude. Chill as autumn frost, those withered by him bear no resentment. The sage takes no delight, yet nothing is obstructed and things flow naturally. He has no kinship, yet by following principle, things sustain themselves. One who relies on the seasons is not as worthy as one who forgets the seasons and naturally aligns with them. Unable to unify the paths of right and wrong, and instead pursuing profit while avoiding harm, one injures virtue and burdens the self.

A true scholar abandons reputation and finds self-possession. Thus, when reputation matches reality, fortune responds to the person. Losing one’s nature and forcing compliance with things brings much servitude—how can one then master others? Like Hu Bujie and Wu Guang, all such figures abandon the self to imitate others, pursuing that which harms the self.

Lü’s commentary: "Their mind and will are set upon the Dao." Serene in demeanor, their spirit congeals, unmoving. With broad, full foreheads, they return to simplicity, free of affectation. Chill as autumn, they harbor no malice. Warm as spring, they hold no attachment. Joy and anger harmonize with the four seasons, aligning with Heaven’s harmony—thus, they accord with things. In overthrowing a state without losing the people’s hearts, they harbor no intent to harm. Extending grace through ten thousand generations without acting out of love, they harbor no intent to love. Toward things, they follow their natural flow. Toward humanity, they forget all under Heaven. Toward the seasons, their conduct and withdrawal lie within themselves.

One who remains steadfast in adversity—what the gentleman guards differs from the common people—is a scholar. One who forgets loftiness and depth, life and death, is a master of others. Thus, from sages and worthies to masters of others, though their ranks differ in honor and baseness, all must possess what is called authenticity to fulfill their names. Like Hu Bujie and Wu Guang, all are servants of others’ service, conforming to others’ conformity without conforming to their own. Only by acting without purpose does one truly conform to one’s own conformity.

Lin’s commentary: "Their mind and will forget the self. Their demeanor forgets things. Their broad foreheads forget form. Chill as autumn—this is the integrity of the perfected. Warm as spring—this is the humanity of the perfected. Joy and anger harmonizing with the four seasons—thus, people, birds, and beasts each find their fitting place.
