Their spirit leaves no trace; their virtue does not perish—how could there be any limit?"

The sage’s use of military force is not by choice but follows the guilt of the condemned, thus not losing the people’s hearts—this is evident in the deeds of Tang and Wu. The sage’s beneficence is vast in reach and enduring in bestowal, yet he never begins with a heart to love others—this is evident in the heart of Yao and Shun. The sage entrusts things to their natural flow, not delighting in their connection—thus, kinship and distance cannot be imposed, which is the essence of perfect humanity. The worthy’s actions align obscurely with the seasons, not seeking alignment with them. To unify the path of the Dao, one must reconcile profit and harm—deviating from this is no gentleman. Pursuing reputation at the cost of self-cultivation is no scholar. One who masters others stands firm and can employ others; losing one’s nature and feigning for the sake of things brings subjugation—this is no master of others.

Detailed Daoist commentary: "Internally undisturbed, thus their mind and will. Externally unmoved, thus their serene demeanor. Killing is not for might; giving life is not for humanity. Their broad, full foreheads reveal their freedom from the influence of things." The sage’s use of military force follows the people’s desire to overthrow, thus not losing their hearts—this is the utmost of righteousness. Following the people’s desire for benefit, he benefits them without acting out of love—this is the perfection of humanity. Toward things, he connects by not connecting. Toward humanity, he is intimate by not being intimate.

Bound by the seasons, human affairs falter—this is no worthy. Reconciling profit and harm, emotions and deceit multiply—this is no gentleman. Pursuing reputation at the cost of the self—such were Boyi and his like. Sacrificing the self without authenticity—such were Shentu Di and his like.

Bixu’s commentary: "Mind and will are unified. Serene demeanor is reflection. Foreheads broad and unmoving, simple as uncarved wood. Knowing Heaven, they harmonize with the four seasons; knowing man, they accord with things. Forgetting external profit, they gain internal profit. Guarding against internal harm, they distance external harm. Preserving both self and reputation is the mark of a good scholar. Sacrificing the self to follow things brings much servitude—like Hu Bujie and his followers, all are subjugated and lose themselves."

Zhao’s commentary: "Their mind and will—*will* should read *forget*. Their serene demeanor is stillness. Their broad, full foreheads bear the appearance of sincerity. Chill as autumn, warm as spring, they follow the four seasons, accord with things, and none can fathom their limit—wherever they go, all is in harmony. Overthrowing a state without losing the people’s hearts means killing without incurring resentment."

"Bestowing blessings upon all generations without partiality is to benefit without expectation of reward. Those who pursue immediate gains in worldly matters fall short of sagehood. Those who show favoritism to kin fall short of true benevolence. Those who merely adapt to changing times fall short of worthiness. Those who fail to comprehend the interplay of profit and harm fall short of being a noble person. Those who pursue reputation at the cost of their true nature fall short of being a scholar. Those who sacrifice themselves for external things cannot command even the slightest movement—like the followers of Hu Bujie, all lose their true selves in vain.

Yongzhai notes: *Zhi* (志, will) implies a fixed intent with a definite focus. *Kuiran* (頯然) describes a grand appearance. *Qieran* (妻然) signifies anger; *nuanran* (暖然), joy. Without intentional joy or anger, they resemble the four seasons—spring and autumn—adapting to circumstances, each finding its proper place, without a fixed abode. This is what is meant by 'engaging and generating timeliness in the heart.' Waging war to devastate the world or bestowing blessings to cherish it—both are enacted without deliberate intent. Thus, even in the fall of a state, none bear resentment. Those who receive such virtue say, 'The emperor’s power—what is it to me?'

From 'taking joy in understanding things' onward, this passage critiques the so-called sages and worthies to illuminate the unattainable Way of the true person. The term *zhi* (志) has been variously interpreted with strained and inconsistent readings. Zhao’s correction to *wang* (忘, forgetfulness) aligns with the sense of serene demeanor, and his argument is most fitting. The original text likely read thus, with only a minor scribal error. The description of the forehead as *kuiran* resembles Lao Dan emerging from his bath.

From the true persons of ancient times to this portrayal: they are unmoved within by life and death, profit and harm, and thus their outward appearance reflects this. Joy and anger harmonize with the four seasons, merging with the Dao of Heaven. Accord with things merges with the virtue/power of humanity. Who can fathom their limits? Waging war or losing a state without losing the people’s hearts means others forget themselves in relation to me. Bestowing blessings upon all generations without partiality means I forget others in relation to myself.

The sage exhausts their own nature to comprehend the nature of things, ever emerging from spontaneity, not through deliberate effort or joy in understanding. Perfect benevolence has no favorites yet embraces all; the penetrating person is never out of step with the times. The noble person unifies profit and harm, neither avoiding nor seeking, and thus calamity ceases to afflict them arbitrarily. Conduct gives rise to reputation, and reputation manifests conduct. To lose one’s true self is to lack substance—such a one is no scholar. Those who lose themselves in pursuit of falsity are merely enslaved—how can they command others? Only the true person, unenslaved by others and self-sufficient, attains this. *The Ocean of Meanings in the Southern Florescence True Scripture*, Scroll Fourteen, concludes.

[Note: #1 ‘Heaven’ is a scribal error for ‘great.’ #2 Based on the context of the text, this ‘human’ is a scribal error for ‘Heaven.’]
*The Ocean of Meanings in the Southern Florescence True Scripture*, Scroll Fifteen. By Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin."

**Chapter Two of the Inner Chapters: The Great and Venerable Master**

The true persons of antiquity bore a countenance of rightness yet formed no cliques, appeared insufficient yet did not defer; they were angular yet not rigid, expansive in their emptiness yet not ostentatious. How radiant their semblance of joy! How towering their inevitability! How vivid their hues that roamed my gaze, how steadfast their power that stilled my virtue! How stern their likeness to the world! How lofty their ungovernability! How continuous their love of seclusion, how forgetful their speech!

They took punishment as their body, ritual as their wings, knowledge as their timing, and virtue as their guide. Taking punishment as their body, they were magnanimous in execution; taking ritual as their wings, they moved through the world; taking knowledge as their timing, they acted only when unavoidable; taking virtue as their guide, they reached the heights with all who had feet—and yet others mistook them for diligent practitioners.

**Guo’s Commentary:**
The true person harmonizes with things without partisanship. They yield without fail to be exalted, appearing insufficient yet not deferring. They wander alone without rigid adherence, vast and unburdened, attaining substance. Joyous and at ease, they seem glad. In motion and stillness, they abide in the utmost necessity, unharmed by things and without forced direction. The perfected person is not stern, yet moves with the world, hence their semblance of sternness. Towering and ungovernable, they are lofty and self-content. Continuous in their love of seclusion, they are profound and far-reaching. Punishment is the body of governance, not of their own making; ritual is the world’s own conduct, not their imposition; knowledge is the movement of the times, not their own doing; virtue is what others follow, not their own creation.

Taking punishment as their body, they entrust governance to its natural course, even in execution remaining lenient. Taking ritual as their wings, they follow the world’s ways, hence nothing is unachievable. The flow of high and low cannot be reversed; the lordship of great and small is an unavoidable tendency. Embracing the confluence of all streams, dwelling at the pinnacle of mastery, they entrust the knowledge of the times to the world’s affairs, yielding to the unfolding of events and consigning all to the realm. The heights are the root of nature; all things are sufficient in their root. Entrusting the flourishing of virtue to its own course, they reach the root with all who have feet. When the root is attained, principle is exhausted.

**Lü’s Commentary:**
The true person bears rightness with things yet forms no cliques. Their abundant virtue seems insufficient, and they do not defer. The sages of old lamented the loss of angularity, but the true person’s angularity remains—adapting to the world, not rigidly bound. Their Way fills the six directions yet never begins with things, yet they dwell in its substance. How luminous their joy! Towering in inevitability, they move only under compulsion. Profound in their hues that roam my gaze, they embrace all things. Steadfast in their power that stills my virtue, they do not lose themselves. What people fear cannot but be feared, hence their stern semblance to the world—yet they remain governable. Towering and vast, they are ungovernable. Continuous in their love of seclusion, they do not commune with things, hence their forgetfulness of speech. All this describes their semblance, not their definable form.

The humane pity execution, for they love; the inhumane delight in it, for they hate. The true person is without love or hate, so how could their execution not be magnanimous? Here their embodied principle is revealed. Mastering oneself and returning to ritual, sight, hearing, speech, and action are all ritual—using it as wings to move through the world. Entering the timeless, how could there be occasion? Things are probed before knowledge arises, hence their unavoidability in affairs. Virtue, like wheel-tracks to follow, allows all with feet to reach the heights with them. The heights are the elevated center of the land. The center cannot but be elevated—this is virtue. All this employs one’s true self; what diligent action is there?

**Lin’s Commentary:**
The true person harmonizes with things without partisanship, their heart seemingly insufficient yet their Way towering above all things. As the *Laozi* says: "Putting oneself last, one advances first; appearing insufficient, one does not defer." In accord with others, angular in independence, yet all may enter—hence they are not rigid. Their Way is expansive, empty yet not ostentatious. Joyful, their countenance shines; towering, they move only under compulsion. Their hues roam without concealment, their power abides in stillness. Only by roaming their power do they seem stern to the world; only by stilling their power are they towering and ungovernable. In the end, they withdraw into seclusion, continuous in their love of closure, forgetting speech in delight. Taking punishment as their body, their execution is like autumn and winter—the natural principle, magnanimous even in killing. Ritual is the flower of virtue, the means of outward conduct, like wings. Taking knowledge as their timing, they follow the natural course of the times, acting only when unavoidable. The heights are the land’s elevation; all with feet may reach them. Taking virtue as their guide is the same. All this is the true person emerging to harmonize with others—how could they ever force their mind?

**Xiang’s Commentary:**
Their countenance of rightness without cliques cannot be measured by closeness or distance. Appearing insufficient without deference cannot be measured by nobility or baseness. Angular yet not rigid, their conduct is not rounded yet not rigidly fixed. Empty yet not ostentatious, their refinement is not substantial yet not devoid of essence. How luminous their semblance of joy—at ease and self-content! Towering in inevitability, they respond only under compulsion. How clear their hues that advance my gaze—spirit refined within, manifest without! How steadfast their power that stills my virtue—utilized outwardly, undisturbed within!

Lofty, vigilant, and unbroken—these three are the utmost in relinquishing action. Ashamed of their words, they reach the utmost in relinquishing speech.

The Dao of the true person, arriving at the relinquishing of action and speech, takes punishment, ritual, knowledge, and virtue as its foundation. The classics often compare the Dao to mountains and virtue to hills, as in the Miao-Gu-Ye Mountain, the Hidden Well and Powdered Mound, the Ju-Ci Mountain, and the Kunlun Hills.

The Dao of the true person, though applied without movement, leads others to mistakenly believe it involves action—this is to misconstrue the labor of the myriad things and doubt the uncarved simplicity of heaven and earth.

**Bi-Xu’s Commentary:**
The true person’s demeanor is free of factions, yet they remain humble as if foolish, lowly yet unyielding. Angular yet not rigid, empty yet not ostentatious, joyful in semblance, compelled only by necessity—this describes their vast and unobstructed responsiveness, measured in all interactions. Clear and harmonious, their gentle countenance instructs. Lofty and vigilant, they listen with severity and gaze upward. Unbroken in their love of silence, joyful in forgetting words—such is the Dao of the true person, unfathomable and unknowable.

Yet punishment, ritual, knowledge, and virtue are the instruments of governing the world, further embodied in structure, support, timing, and adherence. If punishment is not lenient, governance loses its foundation; if ritual does not flourish, transformation fails to spread; if knowledge is not clear, affairs stagnate. Only by following virtue in accord with ritual can one walk the Way.

A hill is elevated earth, a gathering place for people and things. "Having feet" means all who can walk may reach it. The true person, acting without action, naturally aligns with heaven’s principle. Yet when the world sees their accomplishments, they assume it was through movement.

**Zhao’s Commentary:**
They harmonize with things without forming cliques, encompassing all without partiality. If the center is insufficient, external things easily intrude—here, nothing enters, for the solid appears empty. Angularity has edges, readily clashing with things; if rigid and not angular, it is no longer angular. Empty yet not ostentatious, vast yet not boastful. Joyful in semblance, towering in inevitability—their outward demeanor radiates ease, while inwardly they act only under compulsion. Clear in advancing my gaze, tranquil yet adaptable. Harmonious in stilling my virtue, balanced yet not drifting.

Lofty in their worldly guise, they bear human form but lack human passions. Vigilant and unrestrained, vast and great—nothing can resist them. Unbroken in their love of silence, no lock can open what they close. Joyful in forgetting words, they accomplish through silence.

Punishment, ritual, knowledge, and virtue are the Dao of responding to the world only when necessary. Punishment serves as structure, its model clear yet concealed in non-use. Ritual serves as support, harmonizing knowledge with harmony, further moderated by ritual. Knowledge serves as timing, ensuring action and stillness do not miss their moment. Virtue serves as adherence, guiding those with feet to the hill.

A hill is a mountain. "Having feet" refers to people. Those who join them have no feet—they merely lend form to appearance and senses. Yet people see them as unmoving yet arriving, truly believing they have feet.

**Yuan-Qi’s Cloud:**
Righteous yet not factional, they stand alone without leaning. Humble as if insufficient, yet not self-deprecating. Angularity marks virtue’s edges; angular yet not rigid, they possess virtue’s edges without sharpness.

Expansive in ease, empty as if nothing were there. Unadorned, they are substantial. Joyful in semblance, yet not joyful. Towering in necessity, their worldly responses carry an air of inevitability. Radiant in fullness, their vitality shines forth, hence "advancing my gaze." Harmonious in self-possession, "advancing my virtue" brings auspicious stillness.

In appearance, they seem stern like others, yet inwardly they harbor the towering sense of inevitability. Vigilant and unrestrained, they do not yield to the world. Unbroken in density, they prefer silence, reluctant to speak. Before speaking, they seem unwilling; after speaking, it is as if they have not spoken—hence their joy in forgetting words, two phrases expressing one meaning.

Punishment as structure, though severe, leaves ample room, never offending my heart. Ritual as support, moving through the world while accommodating custom. Timely use of knowledge is the unavoidable response to affairs. Following heaven’s virtue naturally, without force—like people ascending hills, all who can walk arrive without needing to assume it requires labor.

This describes the true person’s state: their mind is profound and unfathomable, so we discuss only their outward semblance. Righteous yet not factional, they harmonize with things without forming cliques. Humble as if insufficient, yet not yielding—those who humble themselves are revered by others. Among the common, one must align with things and form cliques, must appear insufficient and yield. Angular yet not rigid, secure yet not cutting. Empty yet not ostentatious, substantial as if empty.

Joyful and towering in semblance—they seem pleased to aid and benefit others, yet it is as if compelled, their responses utterly without intent, thus truly responsive. Radiant in advancing my gaze, their vitality shines forth, drawing people’s delight. Harmonious in stilling my virtue, they love others with virtue, and others joyfully receive it—all this speaks to the abundance of their virtuous bearing, transforming all things.

Lofty—difficult to explain. The *Cui* edition reads "vast," signifying a virtue so boundless it encompasses the world, sufficient to embrace this age. Hence, vigilant in their greatness, they alone perfect heaven. Unbroken in their love of silence, their root remains unseen—thus the Dao of the true person admits no sound.

Punishment, ritual, knowledge, and virtue are all instruments of the former kings for governing the world. Acting in accordance with nature, harmonizing with the people, following virtue—all may ascend to the heights.

To follow is to proceed with ease, not necessarily through strenuous effort. Chen Bixu’s *Zhaowen Ruhai* and Zhang Junfang’s collated edition both render the three *hu* particles after "this age" as *ye*, aligning with the rhythm of the preceding and following sentences—this too has its rationale.

Thus, their delight in it is one, and their aversion to it is one.
That oneness is one, and that non-oneness is one.
The one joins the company of heaven; the non-one joins the company of man.
Heaven and man do not overcome one another—this is called the true person.

Life and death are a matter of fate; their constancy of night and day belongs to heaven.
That in which man has no part—all this is the nature of things.
They regard heaven as their father and cherish it as they do their own bodies—how much more should they cherish that which transcends all!
Men deem the presence of a ruler superior to themselves and would die for him—how much more should they do so for that which is true!

When the spring dries up, fish find themselves stranded on land, moistening one another with dampness, wetting one another with foam—better to forget one another in the rivers and lakes. Rather than praising Yao and condemning Jie, better to forget both and be transformed by the Dao.

Guo’s commentary: Always without intent, one follows others—thus likes and dislikes, good and evil, are no different from them.
To be without any non-oneness is heaven; to insist on "that" and "this" is man.
The true person unites heaven and man, levels self and other, vast and without any non-oneness, obscure and without resistance.

To know life and death is to reach the utmost of fate—this is no delusion.
The true person, in daylight, attains daylight; in night, attains night. Taking life and death as day and night—what could they not attain?
Yet when men fail to attain something, anxiety and foreboding fill their hearts—all this is the sentiment of things, not principle.

The transcendent is called "solitary transformation."
What man relies upon is heaven; what heaven gives birth to is solitary transformation.
Man takes heaven as father, accepting day and night, cold and heat without aversion—how much more should one accept solitary transformation in the realm of profound obscurity, surely finding it impossible not to embrace it!

The true does not depend on things; it is naturally unalterable—how could it be merely the command of a true ruler?
Thus, the analogy of the stranded fish: rather than loving one another in insufficiency, is it not better to forget one another in abundance?
Praise and blame both arise from insufficiency. Those who are utterly sufficient forget good and evil, leave behind life and death, and become one with transformation—how could they know where Yao or Jie reside?

Lü’s commentary: Things see what they are one with and do not see what differs. Thus, those who delight in them find beauty and goodness, and beauty and goodness arise from this; those who do not delight in them find ugliness and ungoodness, and ugliness and ungoodness also arise from this. Therefore, delight and aversion are one.
Oneness is like water’s stillness; non-oneness is like water’s waves—yet both are water. Knowing this, one does not merely cease when ceasing.

Yet there is oneness and non-oneness: the one joins the company of heaven, withdrawing and concealing in secrecy; the non-one joins the company of man, sharing fortune and misfortune with the people.
That which arrives without being summoned is fate; that which acts without being made to act is heaven.
Life and death alternate like night and day, arising from fate and heaven—thus, that in which man has no part is the nature of things. Why should I grieve or rejoice in their midst?

Taking heaven as that from which I am born, I cherish it as I do my own body—how much more should I cherish that from which life itself is born! As father, it is transcendent—how could I not love it?
If I merely know its transcendence and love it, then life has nothing to heed.

Men deem the presence of a ruler superior to themselves and would die for him—how much more should they do so for that which is true! If I know its truth and heed it, then death has nothing to resist.

When the source of nature and fate dries up, stranded in the arid land of human artifice, they pursue the dampness of righteousness with foam—better to forget one another in the rivers and lakes of the Dao’s arts, unaware of life and death, gathering and dispersal.

Delight in life and aversion to death are sentiment; to be without death and without life is the Dao.
Praising Yao and condemning Jie are mere sentiment; to know the forgetting of both and be transformed by the Dao—then that by which one forgets life and death is not originally different.

Lin’s commentary: This speaks of punishment, ritual, knowledge, and virtue as all true—thus it further clarifies delight and aversion, merging them into one. That oneness is one, that non-oneness is one—thus oneness and non-oneness become one again.
Heaven and man are equal, without high or low—how could there be any overcoming between oneness and non-oneness?

The principle of life and death is fate; the constancy of yin and yang is heaven.
The true person follows nature: in daylight, attains daylight; in night, attains night. Taking life and death as day and night—what could they not attain? Yet if anxiety lingers in the heart, it is merely the sentiment of things, not principle.

The transcendent is the ancestor of heaven and earth; the true is the mother of the myriad things.
Things are born of heaven and take heaven as father, joyfully following without daring to oppose—how much more should they do so for the ancestor of heaven? Taking a ruler as superior to oneself, one would die for him—how much more should one do so for the mother of the myriad things!

The stranded fish moistening one another with foam—better to forget one another in the rivers and lakes. This illustrates the age of the great Dao, where things each roam freely, cocks crow and dogs bark within earshot, yet the people do not come and go. But in later ages, the Dao scatters and simplicity is lost; the single foot is divided into seven, and the whole is carved into righteousness. Father and son, elder and younger brother harbor feelings and deceive one another, then begin to seek how to govern—praising Yao and condemning Jie, their disputes endless. Better to forget one another in spontaneity.

Chen Xiangdao’s commentary: The one advances nothing in the world, standing solitary and independent, dwelling alone like a clod of earth. Heaven attains it and becomes clear; earth attains it and becomes tranquil; lords and kings attain it and become the world’s standard. Thus, the ancients who attained the Dao began by achieving oneness, progressed by embracing oneness, and ended by returning to oneness.

The true person is thus without destination yet never departs from oneness. All things are fundamentally one, yet their failure to be one arises from private intentions; when one merges with oneness, one knows that even these private intentions are but oneness. Therefore, entering into oneness, one becomes a companion of Heaven; departing from oneness, one becomes a companion of man. To be a companion of Heaven without losing man, or a companion of man without abandoning Heaven—then oneness and non-oneness are again one.

Night is the concealment of day, death the beginning of life. Seeing that night and day are not worth clinging to, how can life and death be worth lamenting? Thus, the true person has no attachment to life or death, and life and death come to them as one. As for those who cannot attain this unity, it is the nature of things. People know to take Heaven as their father and the ruler as their superior, yet do not know that what is transcendent is most worthy of love, and what is true is most worthy of preservation.

Perfect benevolence has no partiality, yet there is kindness to sustain life—those who nurture are insufficient in benevolence. Perfect wisdom has no knowledge, yet there are emotions to oppose one another—those who praise are insufficient in wisdom. Rivers and lakes are likened to the vastness of the Dao, which is why those who speak of the Dao often use water as a metaphor.

Bi Xu’s note: *De yu* means "to be with."

People’s inability to unify their likes and dislikes, harmonize Heaven and man, or equalize self and other—all these are bonds of worldly emotion. They know only to revere and love the mandate of Heaven yet fail to recognize the need to preserve its wondrous Dao; they know only to die for loyalty to their lord yet do not know to cast aside the self and cultivate the true. Fish out of water moisten one another with foam, but in rivers and lakes, they forget. People, deluded by principle, oppose and praise one another, but attaining this Dao, they are transformed.

Zhao’s note: To like is one, not to like is also one—likes and dislikes lie with others, while I have none.

Heaven has no likes or dislikes; people themselves have likes and dislikes—what victory or defeat is there? Knowing that night and day alternate by Heaven’s doing, and life and death alternate by fate’s doing, one who comprehends the Way of day and night also understands the principle of life and death. Those who do not grasp this principle delight in life and fear death—such is the nature of emotion. That by which a child is filial to their father is because the father is like Heaven, yet if one does not love the Heaven within oneself, is that acceptable? That by which a minister is loyal to their lord, even to the point of death without regard, yet does not revere the true lord within—is that acceptable? Fish on land long for water; people in chaos long for order—both cannot escape the emotion of delighting in life and fearing death. To forget in rivers and lakes, to forget in the unfolding of the Dao—then life and death are one principle, what joy or fear is there?

Juan Zhai said: Oneness is spontaneity, creation. Differences in likes and dislikes do not lie beyond creation, so oneness and non-oneness are both one. If people can share likes and dislikes, they know Heaven and thus become companions of Heaven; if they take likes and dislikes as distinct, they know only man and thus become companions of man. The true person has no likes or dislikes, no distinctions between Heaven and man, but simply follows spontaneity.

Fish in a dry streambed moistening one another with foam is a metaphor for people acting in the world; forgetting in rivers and lakes is a metaphor for embodying the Dao in non-action. The line "praising Yao and condemning Jie" is where one’s unique insight is attained—without Jie, there is no Yao; without praise, there is no blame. Forgetting both and entrusting them to spontaneity is the ultimate transformation of the Dao.

This discussion shows that the true person’s likes and dislikes arise from perfect impartiality, which is also like having no likes or dislikes. Thus, to like is one, not to like is also one; oneness is one, non-oneness is also one. Oneness, being a companion of Heaven, arises from spontaneity and is without anything that is not one; non-oneness, being a companion of man, may arise from circumstances and is not purely one. Viewed from the Dao, oneness and non-oneness are also one. Heaven does not depend on man to be complete, nor man on Heaven—what victory is there to be had?

I fear that世人 may cling to the differences in descriptions and lose sight of the great unity of principle. Therefore, I further illustrate with the analogy of life and death being like Heaven’s alternation of night and day. All who bear Heaven and tread the earth cannot avoid what they do not comprehend—this is merely the obscuration of worldly emotion. If one gathers emotion back to nature and merges Heaven and man, then one can comprehend the principle of life and death, just as night and day are constant and not worth clinging to.

People take Heaven as their father and still revere and love it—how much more should they love what is transcendent within themselves? The lord is above oneself, and one still dies for them—how much more should one preserve what is most true within? This directly points to the essence of the Dao, showing that everyone can return to seek what is transcendent and most true within themselves. Then they will know that one’s life and death are but the arising and ceasing of a single thought, the coming and going of a single breath. If one does not understand this, one loses the reason for living—how is this different from fish on land pursuing moisture with foam? How does it compare to forgetting in rivers and lakes?

*Master Nanhua* said: In making this argument, I am no different from praising Yao and condemning Jie, for I have not yet forgotten and transformed the Dao. My aim is for people to forget words and grasp it with the heart, sweeping away the paths of discourse.

*Collected Exegeses on the Meaning of the True Scripture of Master Nanhua*, Scroll Fifteen (concluded)
#1 "True" should be "straight."

*Collected Exegeses on the Meaning of the True Scripture of Master Nanhua*, Scroll Sixteen
By Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin

**Chapter Three of the Inner Chapters: The Great and Venerable Teacher**

The Great Clod bears me with form, wearies me with life, eases me with old age, and rests me with death. Thus, to be good to my life is to be good to my death.

Hiding a boat in a ravine or a mountain in a marsh may seem secure, yet in the dead of night, a forceful one carries them away—those in the dark do not know. Though concealing the small and the great may be fitting, there is still escape. But to hide the world within the world is to find no place of delay—this is the great truth of all things.

Yet people delight in possessing human form. If human form, amidst the ten thousand transformations, has never had an end, how can its joy be measured? Therefore, the sage roams where things cannot escape and all abide.

How excellent—#1 to be good to old age, to be good to beginning and end! Even people emulate this, let alone that on which the ten thousand things depend and the one transformation awaits.

**Guo’s Commentary:**
Form, life, old age, and death are all myself. Thus, form bears me, life wearies me, old age eases me, and death rests me. Though these four change, they have never ceased to be me—why should I惜 them? Life and death are both fate. Without goodness, so be it; with goodness, there is life. Not only is life good, but my death is also good.

To speak of the inescapability of life, death, and transformation, one must first present the ultimate of inescapability, then clarify the sign of inevitable change, and finally entrust oneself to it without attachment. For the greatest #2 force is none other than transformation—lifting heaven and earth to pursue the new, bearing mountains and rivers to abandon the old. Thus, it does not pause even for a moment; in an instant, it has already entered the new, and heaven, earth, and the ten thousand things are never still. The world is ever renewed, yet people regard it as old; boats and mountains shift daily, yet they see them as before. In the blink of an arm’s exchange, all is gone into obscurity.

Thus, the "I" of the past is no longer the "I" of today. I and the present both pass away—how could I cling to the old? Not knowing to embody transformation and instead seeking to conceal it from change, even in the deepest and most secure hiding, nothing can prevent its daily transformation. To hide nothing and entrust oneself to it is to embody heaven and earth, unite with transformation, and seek escape in vain. This is the great truth of all things, not some narrow, partial intent.

Human form is but one encounter amidst the ten thousand transformations—how could only human form be delightful while other things have no joy? The sage roams the paths of transformation, drifts upon the stream of daily renewal, and with the ten thousand things and ten thousand transformations, transforms without end. Who can escape this? To equalize oneself within a hundred years, to be good to youth and not neglect old age, is enough to be a teacher to others. How much more so to be one with the ten thousand things, to embody transformation—should this not be the joy of all under heaven?

**Lü’s Commentary:**
The Great Clod has no feelings toward me. If one is good to my life, then one must be good to my death—why should I delight in one and detest the other? Things, whether great or small, exist when the mind is present and vanish when the mind is absent. If it is not the Dao, nothing remains that does not depart.

Thus, hiding a boat or a mountain in a ravine or marsh may seem secure, yet if my mind forgets them, they are suddenly lost. In the darkest hour of midnight, if something moves and hides them in the depths of mystery, is this not the work of a forceful one? Though hiding the small and great may be fitting, there is still escape. To use a life of limits to hide the boundless cosmos and expect no escape—is this the nature of ordinary things?

The world is the unity of the ten thousand things. To attain this unity and hide within it, where could the forceful one carry it away? Without true knowledge, one cannot partake in this.

**Lin’s Commentary:**
The Great Clod is the name for the Creator. In terms of form, it bears; in terms of life, it wearies; in old age, one is powerless and naturally at ease; in death, one does not seek rest yet finds it. The true person knows no ease and no rest—this is spoken only for those wearied by life.

To master the principle of being good to my life is to be good to death as well. If one cannot fulfill goodness in life, what hope is there for goodness in death? A boat is chosen for its ability to float and move; a mountain, for its stillness and immobility. Midnight symbolizes the obscure principle without trace. The forceful one refers to the Creator, bearing things away—speaking of their ceaseless transformation.

Form follows the shifts of change—how can things guard the old? In the space between a bow and a raise, ten thousand transformations have already occurred. People grasp at what they mistake for constancy. Thus, Zhuangzi uses the analogy of boats, mountains, ravines, and marshes. Only those who use things without being used by things cannot be moved by the Creator.

Yuxiong said: "Revolving without cease, heaven and earth shift imperceptibly—who notices?" This aligns with the same meaning.

As for hiding the world within the world, there is nothing to hide and all is entrusted. Seeking escape is futile—this is the great truth of all things, uniting with the principle of nature and fate, becoming one with transformation.

To lodge the nature of no birth and no death within the form of ceaseless change is but one encounter amidst the ten thousand transformations—why delight solely in having form? Life does not exceed a hundred years, yet the one who gives form has no end or beginning. What limit is there to the encounters? How can their joy be measured?

The path the sage roams is that of hiding the world within the world, thus nothing is not preserved. To be good to premature death and old age, to be good to beginning and end—though one has not forgotten life and death, one can fully realize nature. Thus, one may serve as a model for others. How much more so for one who, attaining the mandate, can master things, on whom the ten thousand things depend and the one transformation awaits!

**Xiang Dao’s Commentary:**
From birth to death, the great transformation has four aspects: bearing me, wearying me—these should be detestable, yet people delight in them...

The one who frees me, the one who rests me—these should be joyous, yet people detest them. There is no other reason: they lack the Dao to make them good. The Dao’s goodness to my life is precisely its goodness to my death. In life, one floats; in death, one rests. What is mine remains with me, entrusted to where it abides, not forced to follow what lies beyond. How could one hoard what is stored to secure what one possesses, or delight in form to pride oneself on what one encounters?

To hide a boat in a ravine is to hide something small; to hide a mountain in a marsh is to hide something great. At midnight, it cannot be seen. With force, it cannot be resisted. Though the boat and the mountain differ in size and movement, they are alike in being carried away by the powerful—so too with humans and transformation: should one hide it in stillness? Or hide it in motion? Transformation cannot be escaped by stillness or motion. How much better to hide the world within the world, vast and unobstructed, becoming one with transformation?

The great truth of all things is to become one with transformation; they are merely burdened by things and sunk in the petty. The sage roams where things cannot pursue, thus is not bound by things yet is what things depend on, does not await transformation yet is what transformation awaits.

**Bixu’s Commentary:**
The great clod is primordial qi. The "I" is the name for the numinous thing, yet the numinous thing is fundamentally nonexistent. Birth, aging, death—where do they arise? From having form. Thus, I am not originally borne—it is because of form; I am not originally wearied—it is because of life; I am not originally freed—it is because of aging; I am not originally rested—it is because of death. Observing how the Dao’s goodness can give life to things, one knows it must also be good at giving death to things. Now, to take joy in Heaven as goodness to my life and to know fate as goodness to my death—what fault is there in this?

The "powerful one at midnight" is the unfathomable spirit of yin and yang. To carry and flee is the ceaseless work of creation. Moreover, can one who hides things lack guards lest they escape? How can they be prevented? Yet things do not lie in hiding; there is a principle that does not shift. Who can know this? If the flying does not know the sinking, then the sinking is hidden; if this does not know that, then that is hidden. This is called self-hiding, not hiding by things. This is the great truth of all things, not something borrowed from the enlightened.

To take the cosmos as a single chamber is to lose the world’s existence—what is this if not hiding? "Unifying the world" is the general name for all things, moving and still. The so-called hiding is subtle shifting without awareness. Dreaming of being a bird and soaring in the sky, dreaming of being a fish and diving into the abyss—endless transformations, endless joys. Why delight solely in encountering human form?

What things cannot pursue is creation. The sage travels the path of no-mind and no-transformation, thus all things are preserved. People imitate and merely admire the road, yet when it comes to the essential, they have nothing to say—this is what the ten thousand transformations revere. To have goodness and dependence is not true liberation.

**Zhao’s Commentary:**
Life is the traveler; death is the one who returns. Life must have death; travel must have return. This is how creation is good to my life and good to my death—simply resting in naturalness. Boat and ravine, mountain and marsh—these are fitting for hiding small and large, yet yin has a way to shift them unawares. This speaks of how form inevitably changes. But to hide the world within the world—then above and below, the four directions, past and present, all are inseparable. How could they return?

Form and color are one’s nature; one’s nature is form and color. The great truth of all things means that this principle applies to humans and things alike. To possess a hundred limbs and be human is already cause for delight—how much more so for the one who gives form? The sage knows that being confined to the world of form does not escape fate, yet joins with it boundlessly, thus all things are preserved. To handle premature death, old age, beginning, and end with goodness—people still emulate this. How much more so for the one who moves beyond form yet can give form to form? This is what the ten thousand things depend on, what the one transformation awaits—the highest goodness. How can it not be revered?

Things are myriad, yet transformation is one. This one is here. **Yongzhai** says: The metaphors of hiding the boat, hiding the mountain, and the midnight flight speak of how human plans, though deeply secret, cannot be free. To hide the world within the world is to entrust it to naturalness, with nothing to pursue. The true state of the ten thousand things is always thus. People all delight in having form yet do not know that the human body undergoes a thousand changes, and the ten thousand things are complete within me. How can their joy be measured?

The sage’s mind roams in spontaneity, without gain or loss, drinking the sun and wandering where things cannot pursue—yet all things are preserved. To be good to premature death and old age, to be good to beginning and end—creation can do this, and people still emulate it. How much more so the Dao? What the ten thousand things depend on, what the one transformation awaits, is simply the Dao. Its words rise higher with each passage—such is Zhuangzi’s brushwork.

The "great clod" originally refers to earth, but here it signifies creation. "Bearing me with form" is like saying "clothing bears me"—with a hundred limbs complete, spirit rides them, for it cannot but bear. "Wearying me with life" means that daily activities, food and drink, pain and cold—all serve to toil me, and I cannot but be wearied. "Freeing me with aging" means that when blood and qi decline, the body daily weakens, the mind daily fades, and I cannot but be freed. "Resting me with death" means that when qi is exhausted and spirit departs, the four great elements separate, and one lies still in the great chamber—this cannot but be rest.

From this, one knows that people’s worry about death while alive is all delusion. If in life one thinks of how to be good to one’s life—avoiding harm to life, defiance of principle, injury to others, and damage to things—how could one’s death not be good?

That which gives me life is Creation, but that which makes my life good is myself. What difference is there between life and death? Hiding a boat in the mountains—this is a metaphor for man dwelling within the transformations of Creation yet seeking to escape its changes, which cannot be done. If among the things of the world there is hiding, there must be escape; if there is escape, then it ceases to exist. Only that which has no place of hiding allows things no escape and thus all remain. The place where things cannot escape and all remain is the realm of "nothing-whatsoever," the vast and boundless wilds. Roaming therein, following the unobstructed flow of the mindless, gazing with open clarity—nothing is not preserved. This is the Way of "hiding the world within the world."

Though one emerges from the mechanism and enters the mechanism, though the ten thousand transformations of life and change unfold, one sees only daily renewal—where can things escape? Yet worldly people, clinging to private views, often take things as their own possessions, believing boats and mountains to be inescapable things, gullies and marshes to be hidable places, and forms and substances to have unchanging methods. They do not realize that the hidden pivot silently turns, not pausing even for an instant, and that things, earth, and form all transform together without awareness.

Then is there a Way to transcend and escape transformation? It is said: hold to no hiding and no clinging; let the mind roam with Heaven. Even seeking the present moment cannot be attained—how then could one know what is called escape and transformation? To die young well or to grow old well—all original texts agree; only the Chen Bixu edition collated by Zhang Junfang reads "to be young well or to grow old well," which is superior in meaning.

The Dao has sentiment and sincerity, yet is without action and without form. It can be transmitted but not received, can be attained but not seen.

The Dao is self-so from its own root, existing before Heaven and Earth, enduring from antiquity; it spiritually animates ghosts and emperors, gives birth to Heaven and Earth. It stands before the Great Ultimate yet is not high, lies beneath the Six Poles yet is not deep, precedes the birth of Heaven and Earth yet is not ancient, endures beyond high antiquity yet is not old.

When Xīwéi attained it, he used it to lift Heaven and Earth; when Fúxī attained it, he used it to inherit the Mother of Qi; when the Northern Dipper attained it, it remained ever unaggressive; when the sun and moon attained it, they never ceased; when Kānhuài attained it, he inherited Mount Kūnlún; when Féngyí attained it, he roamed the great rivers; when Jiānwú attained it, he dwelled in the great mountains; when the Yellow Emperor attained it, he ascended to the cloudy heavens; when Zhuānxū attained it, he resided in the Dark Palace; when Yúqiáng attained it, he stood at the North Pole; when the Queen Mother of the West attained it, she sat in the Lesser Expanse—none knew her beginning, none knew her end. When Péngzǔ attained it, he lived from the age of Yǔ to the Five Hegemons; when Fù Yuè attained it, he assisted Wǔ Dīng, oversaw the world, rode the Eastern Rope and the Tail of the Winnowing Basket, and ranked among the arrayed stars.

Guō’s commentary: The emotion of no-emotion is non-action; the emotion of constant nothingness is formlessness. Though transmitted from antiquity and dwelling within, none can receive and possess it; all attain self-containment, yet none see its form. Existing before Heaven and Earth from antiquity confirms that nothingness cannot be made to have or to lack—how then could it generate spirit? It does not spiritually animate ghosts and emperors, yet ghosts and emperors animate themselves; it does not give birth to Heaven and Earth, yet Heaven and Earth arise of themselves. Thus we know that spirit is ultimately insufficient to be called spirit, and that which does not spirit is true spirit. The Dao is high yet not high, deep yet not deep, enduring yet not enduring, old yet not old—nowhere is it not present, yet wherever it is present, it is not.

Above and below, it goes everywhere, yet cannot be called high or low; within and without, it reaches everywhere, yet cannot be named inner or outer. It shifts with transformation, so cannot be called enduring; it has no beginning or end, so cannot be called old. From Xīwéi attaining it to lift Heaven and Earth to Fù Yuè riding the Tail of the Winnowing Basket and ranking among the stars, the Dao cannot be grasped—this speaks of attaining it as self-attainment. The difficulty of life lies in solitary transformation and self-attainment; once life is attained, why would one fail to attain cessation of life and act upon it? To act is to harm one’s life.

Lǚ’s commentary: The ears and eyes attain it to see and hear; the hands and feet attain it to move—how could it lack emotion? Cold and heat attain it to alternate; the myriad things attain it to be born and nurtured—how could it lack sincerity? Yet seeking its agent, none can be found—this is formlessness. Some understand without words; some perceive it in an instant—this is transmissibility. Yet none can possess it—it cannot be received. With the mind, one intuits it, and it harmonizes effortlessly—this is attainability. Yet no trace of it can be seen—it is invisible. The birth of the myriad things has never lacked a root, yet the Dao is self-so from its own root. The myriad things arise only after Heaven and Earth, yet the Dao existed before Heaven and Earth, enduring from antiquity. Ghosts and emperors attain me to be spirit, yet I am not spirit—even ghosts and emperors lack numinous resonance. Heaven and Earth attain me to be born, yet I am not born—even today, they remain the Great Ultimate. High and deep describe its form; enduring and old describe its time. Yet I am without form and without time—thus the Dao is hidden and nameless.

Though the sages of antiquity differed in concealment and manifestation, none failed to attain the Dao and become sagely—this is not limited to Xīwéi through Fù Yuè alone. The Dao is the mother of the world; from Heaven downward, none fail to attain the Dao and stand—this is not limited to the Northern Dipper and the sun and moon. This is not something human sentiment can fathom, yet it is nothing more than what those who attain the Dao can do—is this not why it is called the Great Master?

Lín’s commentary: Emotion refers to the nature and destiny of life. Sincerity means that within it lies constancy, acting without contrivance and perpetually natural, beyond the control of yin and yang. The Dao has emotion toward the myriad things, thus they live without resistance. Yet it accomplishes without ever acting, responds without ever taking form. That which can be transmitted or received has not departed from things; that which can be attained or seen has not departed from form. Transmission without that which is transmitted cannot be received; attainment without that which is attained cannot be seen. The son of Shū Biān could not receive it from his father; Xiàngwǎng sought the pearl but could attain it without seeing it. In stillness, the sun returns to destiny—this is self-so from its root. Each returns to its root—this is self-so from its own root. Enduring from antiquity, it is able to preserve preservation without change.

Spirit in humans is called ghost; spirit in Heaven is called emperor. The death of a sage is called spirit, for his death is no different from his life; the death of an ordinary person is called ghost, for his life is no different from his death. Thus, exhausting human spirit, I precede Heaven and Earth. As *Lǎozǐ* says: "The gate of the Mysterious Female is called the root of Heaven and Earth." Thus, in height it is not high, in depth it is not deep, in birth it is not born, in age it is not old.

From Xīwéi to Fù Yuè, this broadly discusses those who attained the Dao, its meaning akin to *Lǎozǐ*’s "Of old, those who attained the One." The Great Ease is before qi is seen; the Great Beginning is the inception of qi. Before qi is seen is the father, thus qi is the mother. The Dipper is the guiding rope of Heaven. Kānhuài is the name of a spirit. Féngyí is the water spirit. Jiānwú is the name of a regulator. Yúqiáng is the spirit of the Northern Sea. From the Queen Mother of the West to Fù Yuè, all were ancient attainers of the Dao—though their deeds cannot be fully investigated, one should seek them with the mind and not cling to their traces.

Detailed Annotations on the Dao:
That which responds and thereby penetrates is the realm of the affective; because it is affective, it is trustworthy. That which is utterly still and unmoving is non-action; because it is non-action, it is formless. As the *Qiwù Lùn* states: "It may be practiced and trusted, yet its form is not seen," and again: "It is affective yet formless—how could the Dao be easily known?" Precisely because of this, it may be transmitted through the mind but cannot be received [as an object], may be attained through one’s nature but cannot be seen. For what is transmitted is no transmission, and what is attained is no attainment.

In its origin, it is self-so and self-rooted; before Heaven and Earth existed, it was already eternally present. In its function, it spirits forth ghosts and spirits forth the Divine Lord, gives birth to Heaven and gives birth to Earth. Above and below, it has no fixed abode—it cannot be spoken of in terms of height or depth; its transformations have no fixed form—it cannot be spoken of in terms of age or duration. Spiriting forth ghosts and spirits forth the Divine Lord, the Dao is the father of spirits; giving birth to Heaven and giving birth to Earth, the Dao is the mother of spirits.

From Xīwéi to Fù Yuè, these speak of the ancients who attained the Dao—some ascended to Heaven, some coiled within mountains, some submerged in the abyss—yet all preserved their undying longevity and unfathomable spirit. This is the subtlety of the Great Master.

Bìxū’s Annotation:
Ever skillful in saving beings—this is the affective. Responding and thereby penetrating—this is the trustworthy. Affective yet non-active, trustworthy yet formless: this is why it may be transmitted but not received, attained but not seen. Ghosts govern the yin, the Divine Lord rules the yang; the unfathomability of yin and yang arises from their possession of spirit. The ceaseless generation of Heaven and Earth arises from their possession of the Dao. The Dao’s height, depth, duration, and age cannot be grasped by thought or discourse, for it is omnipresent.

Lord Lǎo spoke of attaining the One in relation to Heaven and Earth, the Valley Spirit, the myriad things, and the feudal lords. Zhuāngzǐ of Qīyuán spoke of those from Xīwéi to Fù Yuè who attained it—yet here, the One is forgotten. Thus the Dao’s transformations are inexhaustible to the thousand sages.

Zhào’s Annotation:
Affective and trustworthy—these may be named and spoken of. Non-active and formless—these cannot be named or spoken of. Transmissible yet not receivable: affective and trustworthy in reality, yet nothing to receive. Attainable yet not visible: non-active and formless in reality, yet nothing to see. That by which ghosts are numinous and the Divine Lord governs is the spirit that arises from this.

The following elaborates on the Dao’s functions—its meaning is already clear and requires no further explication.

Yōngzhāi’s Remarks:
The preceding section did not mention the word "Dao," but here it is finally introduced to speak of the Great Master. Affect and trust are both real. Non-action offers no point of entry; formlessness has no fixed shape. Transmissible yet not receivable, attainable yet not visible—only those who embody the Dao know this. The *Guānyǐnzǐ*, Chapter One, clearly addresses the matter of transmission.

Self-so and self-rooted—this traces its origin. Before Heaven and Earth existed, this Dao was already present: this is called the Limitless that gives rise to the Supreme Polarity. Ghosts are the advance of creation; the Divine Lord is the ruler of Heaven. That by which ghosts and the Divine Lord are spirit is this Dao; Heaven and Earth also arise only after the Dao. This is called: "The Supreme Polarity gives birth to the Two Modes." Thus its height, depth, duration, and age cannot be known.

From Xīwéi to Fù Yuè, all spoke of those who attained the Dao and thereby achieved such things. From the beginning of the chapter, which narrates the Way of the Perfected and the principle of life and death, to this point, it further discusses the Dao’s essence and the ancients who attained it, offering proof. Though the language is extraordinary, the principle is perfectly clear—all commentaries have discussed it in detail.

The question of "spiriting forth ghosts and spirits forth the Divine Lord" is particularly striking. I humbly append my humble insights at the end of this passage: ghosts and the Divine Lord are yin and yang, self-so and self-rooted, formless yet spirit. In motion, they give birth to Heaven and Earth—these may be named and spoken of, are formed yet spirit. In their essence, they are nowhere and yet everywhere, non-active and yet all-active.

How then could one even discuss the loftiness, profundity, longevity, or venerability of such matters? This principle fundamentally derives from the *Daodejing*: "The gate of the Mysterious Female—this is called the root of Heaven and Earth." The Mysterious Female is but another name for yin and yang. To comprehend the gate of the Mysterious Female is to grasp the meaning of ghosts and the Divine Lord. The spirit resides within yin and yang, alternating as substance and function—this is called the wondrous subtlety of the boundless and unfathomable.

Truly, if one knows that which gives birth to Heaven and Earth, then the origin of one’s own body becomes known without deliberate inquiry. Once the source is known, how could its departure remain obscure?

*Collected Subtleties of the Meaning of the Southern Florescence Scripture*, Scroll 16
#1 "夫" is a scribal error for "夭"
#2 "The greatness of potent power" in Guo’s commentary originally read "the power of powerlessness"
#3 "坯" is a scribal error for "壤"

*Collected Subtleties of the Meaning of the Southern Florescence Scripture*, Scroll 17
Compiled by the Daoist of Wulin, Chu Boxiu
"Great Master of the Inner Chapters," Chapter Four

Nanbo Zikui asked Nü’ou, “You are advanced in years, yet your complexion is like that of a child—how is this so?” Nü’ou replied, “I have heard the Dao.”

Nanbo Zikui said, “Can the Dao be learned?” Nü’ou answered, “Alas, how could it be! You are not the right person. Now, Pulang Yi possesses the talent of a sage but not the Dao of a sage, while I possess the Dao of a sage but not the talent of a sage. I wished to teach him, hoping that he might indeed become a sage. If not, to impart the Dao of a sage to one with the talent of a sage would be easy indeed. Yet I still guarded it and instructed him.

After three days, he was able to put the world outside himself. Having put the world outside, I again guarded it for him, and after seven days, he was able to put things outside himself. Having put things outside, I again guarded it for him, and after nine days, he was able to put life outside himself. Having put life outside, he could then attain morning clarity. With morning clarity, he could then perceive the solitary. Perceiving the solitary, he could then transcend past and present. Transcending past and present, he could then enter into that which is neither dead nor alive.

That which slays life does not die; that which gives life to life does not live. As a thing, it sends nothing forth without escort, receives nothing without welcome; destroys nothing without completion, and accomplishes nothing without fulfillment.”

Its name is "Cherry Tranquility." "Cherry Tranquility" means that only after being buffeted does one attain completion.

Nanbo Zigui said: "How did you alone come to hear of this?"
He replied: "I heard it from the son of Deputy Ink, the son of Deputy Ink heard it from the grandson of Recitation, the grandson of Recitation heard it from Gazing Clarity, Gazing Clarity heard it from Whispered Assent, Whispered Assent heard it from Waiting Service, Waiting Service heard it from At the Pivot, At the Pivot heard it from Dark Obscurity, Dark Obscurity heard it from Joined Solitude, and Joined Solitude heard it from Doubting the Beginning."

Guo's commentary: "External" means to relinquish. Things are what one requires morning and evening, intimately bound and hard to forget. To externalize life is to relinquish it entirely. Having relinquished life, whatever one encounters is at peace, suddenly unobstructed, perceiving the incipient and acting—this is morning clarity. Forgetting before and after is perceiving the solitary; without past or present, the solitary is all there is. Clinging to life gives rise to death; abhorring death gives rise to life. Without clinging or abhorrence, there is neither death nor life. Allowing things to escort and welcome, there is nothing that does not escort and welcome. Allowing things to destroy and complete, there is nothing that is not destroyed and completed. One who merges with things—where things entangle, so too does one entangle—yet has never not been tranquil. Entangled yet allowing it, nothing is not bent to completion.

From hearing it from Deputy Ink to Dark Obscurity, Dark Obscurity is that by which one names the nameless yet is not nothing, and then further entrusts it to Joined Solitude—mystery upon mystery. The principles of nature are formed through accumulated practice, thus after seven layers one reaches the name of nothingness, and after nine layers one doubts that nothingness is the beginning.

Lü's commentary: When people hear the Dao, their anxieties and breaths cannot enter, hence with age their complexions wither. Those who possess the Dao of the sage grasp its great root and great origin; those who possess the talent of the sage can extend this Dao to the world and the state. Boliang Yi had the talent but not the Dao, thus I guarded and instructed him, proceeding from the coarse to the refined. Having externalized the world, one then externalizes things; having externalized things, one then externalizes life; having externalized life, one then attains morning clarity—this speaks of profound obscurity within the body’s self-examination, reaching clarity that is like dawn. Perceiving the solitary means that "that" and "this" find no counterpart. Without past or present, the myriad ages are unified into one pure completion. Neither dead nor alive—those who die are slain by me, yet I have never died; those who live are given life by me, yet I have never lived. Though escorting, welcoming, completing, and destroying are all buffeting, I have never been endangered, hence the name "Cherry Tranquility." "Cherry Tranquility" means that only after being buffeted does one attain completion.

The Dao, when embodied, is the norm; what is discussed in texts and ink is merely its deputy. "Recitation" means to string together and recite; "sons and grandsons" speak of where the Dao is born. "Gazing Clarity" is the clarity of perceiving principle. "Whispered Assent" is to tread and practice it. "Waiting Service" is to await things and employ them. "At the Pivot" is to chant and delight in it. From Deputy Ink to Gazing Clarity, one studies and gains insight; from Whispered Assent to At the Pivot, one practices and reaches joy, yet these are still insufficient to be the body of the Dao. "Dark Obscurity" is without seeing or knowing. "Joined Solitude" is where even nothingness does not stand. Doubting it as the beginning yet not knowing it as the beginning—this is its very beginning.

Lin's commentary: The Dao is the counterpart of destiny; talent is the capacity of nature. Those with the talent of the sage have fully realized their nature; those with the Dao of the sage have reached destiny. To say the sage’s talent is without the Dao is not so—when emerging to save the world, what governs is talent. To say the sage’s Dao is without talent is not so—when withdrawing into non-action, what governs is the Dao. Instructing one with the talent of the sage in the Dao of the sage, guiding them into non-action, seems easy. Yet I still guarded and instructed him: after three days, he could externalize the world; after seven days, he could externalize things; after nine days, he could externalize life. Forgetting the world and things is still easy; life is what people find hardest to forget. Externalizing life means not living yet being able to give life—this is the ultimate attainment of the Dao. When the qi of night is preserved, dawn is also clear; only then can one perceive the solitary. The solitary is apart from yin and yang, without counterpart, seen beyond what the eyes can reach. Without past or present, it is not pushed by the changes of the world. Neither dead nor alive, one reaches destiny. Commanding things yet not commanded by things—this is being able to slay life. Making things into things yet not made into a thing by things—this is being able to give life. As a thing, it is also a forced name, thus one allows things to escort, welcome, complete, and destroy. When things are buffeted by things, they are disturbed and not tranquil; only the Dao is buffeted and then completed.

"Deputy Ink" is the deputy of brush and ink. "Luo" is the place where texts emerge. "Recitation" is the act of memorizing and practicing. "Gazing Clarity" is having insight and understanding principle. "Whispered Assent" is assenting by leaning close to the ear. "Waiting Service" is acting with dependence. "At the Pivot" is seen in chanting and song. "Dark" is the essence of the subtle; "obscurity" is the concealment of clarity. "Joined" is one that severs being, two that severs nothingness; "solitude" is the name of emptiness and stillness. Only then does one doubt that nothingness is the beginning. These nine names are established to illustrate that hearing the Dao must proceed gradually.

Detailed commentary on the Dao: Things are the burdens of the body, thus externalizing things allows one to externalize life; life is the burden of the Dao, thus externalizing life allows one to attain morning clarity—since the qi of night is not forgotten, dawn is clear. The Dao has no counterpart, thus what is seen is solitary. Unifying past and present into one time, connecting death and life into one thread, there is no escorting or welcoming, no completing or destroying. The pure qi is not diminished within, and the myriad things do not buffet it without, so one’s complexion is like that of a child—nothing strange in this. Those who cling to life slay life, yet those who slay life do not die; those who cling to slaying give life, yet those who give life do not live.

As for things in their nature:
what departs is without fail escorted,
what arrives is without fail welcomed,
what is completed is without fail destroyed,
what is destroyed is without fail completed—
this is what is meant by "entanglement yielding completion."

Master Bixu notes:
One possessing the innate endowment of a sage must rely on the sage’s wondrous function;
one harboring the sage’s wondrous function must rely on the sage’s innate endowment.
Yet if one clings to uncarved simplicity without transformation,
this cannot be called perfection.
Only by preserving and transmitting it can it be deemed transmissible.

To set the world aside is to realize that the bluntness of earth may be relinquished;
to set things aside is to see that the dregs of entanglement need not be heeded;
to set life aside is to awaken to the emptiness of memory and ferment;
to attain morning clarity is to perceive dawn alone.
To see alone is to regard the Dao as without peer.
Without past, without present, one connects all generations;
without life, without death, one returns to the source.
Those who slay life do not die,
those who give life do not live—
this means that those who execute the thieves of life preserve their bodies,
while those who advance the delusions of life hasten death.

Things merely entangle,
preferring completion yet unable to overturn.
*Fu mo* are teaching texts;
*luo song* is recitation;
to perceive principles is called "gazing clarity";
to hear instruction is called "attentive assent."
When awaiting service, one waits for application;
when at the pivot, one chants.
*Xuan ming* refers to profound obscurity;
*can liao* refers to reaching the utmost;
*yi shi* means no knowing of a beginning before the beginning.

Zhao’s commentary:
Setting aside the world, things, and life—
these three are one in relinquishment,
differing only in moving from coarse to refined.
Once one can set life aside,
nothing remains unilluminated—
this is what is called "morning clarity."
With morning clarity, what is seen stands alone;
what is seen standing alone means past and present endure;
with past and present enduring, how can there be life and death?
As *Liezi* states:
"That which gives life does not live,
that which transforms does not transform"—
this clarifies the principle.

Escorting and welcoming, destroying and completing—
all follow the spontaneity of things,
yet nothing is not escorted or welcomed,
nothing is not destroyed or completed,
for one never ceases to engage with things.
"Entanglement yielding" means that when one is ensnared by such words,
a sudden awakening dissolves all principles—
this is "entanglement yielding completion."

Zikui further asked how one might hear such words.
*Fu mo* are writings;
*luo song* are words;
*zhan ming* is seeing;
*nie xu* is hearing;
*xu yi* is acting;
*yu shu* is singing;
*xuan ming* is silent comprehension;
*can liao* is seeking in the distant;
*yi shi* is doubting a beginning.
All are figurative expressions.

Yongzhai said:
Only those who unite Dao and talent in full—
beyond the Five Emperors and Three Kings—
are Yi Yin, the Duke of Zhou, and Confucius.
The three days, seven days, nine days need not be rigidly interpreted;
they simply denote one stage surpassing the next.
"Morning clarity" means the chest is radiant,
like the limpid qi of early dawn.
"Seeing alone" means seeing for oneself what others do not see.
Without past or present, there is no life or death.
"Slaying life yet not dying,
giving life yet not living"
means that though one slays, it is not death,
and though one gives life, it is not life.
Without escorting or welcoming, without completing or destroying,
all is spontaneous—
amidst entanglement and turmoil, what is settled remains constant,
this is "entanglement yielding completion."

After words come written bamboo slips—
ink’s duplicate.
Wrapping and reciting them,
reading by the text, reciting from memory,
is like a son begetting a grandson.
Later passages echo earlier explanations:
the Dao is gained through reading,
giving rise to many names,
until ultimately returning to creation.
*Xuan ming* is the beginning of qi;
*can liao* is the beginning of the nameless;
*yi shi* is the beginning before the beginning.
Though the Dao is attained through texts,
it is originally inherent in our nature.

The Dao establishes the center and founds the pole,
enlightening the human heart;
talent opens things and accomplishes tasks,
expanding patterns and creating enterprises.
The sage takes the world as his heart,
bearing the weight of transformation—
in these two, neither can be neglected.
Weighing their relative importance,
one should abide in the Dao with surplus,
never inclining toward talent’s dominance.
Thus in the transformation of Nü Yu,
Boliang still preserved and transmitted it,
fearing talent’s obstruction of the Dao and the difficulty of entry.

First setting the world aside discards the coarse;
setting things aside discards what is external;
setting life aside discards what is within.
If even what is within is relinquished,
nothing remains unforgotten.
"Morning clarity" illuminates what things do not;
"seeing alone" perceives what things cannot.
Without past or present, time cannot be constrained;
without life or death, form cannot be fixed.
To regard death as cruelty is to be unable to slay life;
to regard life as grace is to be unable to give life.
Only by having no escorting or welcoming,
no completing or destroying,
can one have nothing not escorted or welcomed,
nothing not completed or destroyed—
this is called "entanglement yielding tranquility."

Master Guo glosses *ying* as "entanglement";
here it is taken as written.
Living in the world, one engages with things,
rarely without entanglement disturbing the heart.
The multitude are entangled and disordered;
the sage is entangled yet tranquil.
Entanglement yielding disorder is the Dao’s loss;
entanglement yielding tranquility is the Dao’s completion—
akin to the principle of constant response and constant stillness,
though the phrasing is rather extraordinary.

Later passages from *fu mo* to *yi shi* are thoroughly explained;
here they are not repeated.

Zisi, Ziyu, Zili, and Zilai spoke among themselves:
"Who can take non-action as the head,
life as the spine,
death as the tailbone,
and know that death, life, existence, and perishing are one body?
We would befriend such a one."
The four looked at one another and smiled,
their hearts in perfect accord,
and so became friends.

Soon after, Ziyu fell ill.
Zisi went to inquire of him, saying:
"How magnificent!"

The Maker would shape me into this contorted form!
My spine is crooked, my back hunched,
five tubes jutting from my nape,
my chin buried in my navel,
shoulders towering above my crown,
and a fleshy lump pointing skyward.
The qi of my yin and yang is in disarray—
yet my heart remains at ease, untroubled.
Though my calloused soles mirror the well’s depths, I say:
Alas! Would the Maker truly fashion me into this twisted state?

Zisi asked: "Do you resent this?"
He replied: "No, why should I resent it?
Were my left arm transformed into a rooster,
I would use it to herald the dawn;
were my right arm turned into a crossbow,
I would use it to hunt roasted quail.
Were my corpse made into a wheel
and my spirit into a horse,
I would mount them and ride—why seek another steed?
Moreover, gain is but timing,
loss is but compliance.
Abiding in timing, dwelling in compliance,
neither joy nor sorrow can enter.
This is what the ancients called ‘suspended release.’
Those who cannot release themselves are bound by things.
Yet things have long been no match for Heaven—
what have I to resent?"

The Maker would shape me into this twisted state—
as if weary of my life,
prompting Zisi’s question.
Three transformations unfold in gradual succession,
yet what I embody remains one:
this is what is meant by the myriad changes never reaching an end.
Why should I resent it?
Taking non-being as the head,
life as the spine,
death as the tailbone—
the spirit is that which turns them.
Thus, I make my corpse into a wheel,
my spirit into a horse,
and ride them without hesitation.
How could I seek another steed?

Life’s arrival cannot be known—
gain is but timing.
Its departure cannot be resisted—
loss is but compliance.
Abiding in timing, dwelling in compliance,
sorrow and joy cannot enter,
and nothing remains suspended.
This is the meaning of release.
To seek against timing,
to resist what is compliant—
this is to be bound by things and unable to release oneself.
What comes cannot be refused,
what goes cannot be stopped—
thus we know things are no match for Heaven.
Why should I resent it?

Yongzhai observes: "Head, spine, corpse—these are but the beginning and end. Man emerges from non-being into being, and once there is being, there follows life and death. From *How grand!* onward, all describes the symptoms of this affliction, showing how I am bound by such petty constraints—this is the work of the Creator.

The passage on *gradual transformation* is most extraordinary: if the Creator were to slowly change my body into other things, I would simply make use of them—this is the meaning of following the transformations of creation without preference or aversion. Though spoken in parable, it carries its own truth.

*Release* means the heart is free from attachment. Those who cannot free themselves are bound by things—how can the myriad things ever overcome the principle of nature?

Consider these four: taking non-being as the head, life as the spine, and death as the tailbone—those who understand that life, death, existence, and extinction are one body are fit to be friends. This aligns with the *Gengsang Chu* chapter, which begins with non-being and being, then life arising and swiftly turning to death, taking non-being as the head, life as the body, and death as the tailbone. Whoever grasps that non-being, being, life, and death are a single continuum—such a one I would befriend. The various commentaries have discussed this in detail.

In the passage below, Guo [Xiang] parses *there is sand* as a phrase, while my interpretation follows his. The *Pronunciation and Meaning* records Cui’s edition, which parses *from his heart* as a phrase, linking *idle and untroubled* to the following text—this also makes sense.

Man, confined within the forms of Heaven and Earth, is already bound by the Creator. Now, afflicted with such cramped deformities, he is further bound by his own form. Though the qi of yin and yang may scatter externally, if the heart remains idle and untroubled, gazing at one’s reflection in a well, one may sigh at being bound by form—yet if one cannot ultimately forget attachment and find peace in what Heaven has bestowed, what aversion could there be?

If my arm were transformed into a rooster or a crossbow pellet, I would seek the reality of rooster or pellet. If my corpse and spirit were transformed into a wheel or a horse, I would seek their use. Having entered the mechanism of transformation, one should follow whatever comes and yield to it—how could one resist?

Gain is timing; loss is compliance—this is what is meant by *when it comes, Master, it is timing; when it goes, Master, it is compliance.* This is what is called *release.* Bound, one is tied to the Creator; released, the Creator cannot hold one. Those who are bound yet cannot free themselves are knotted by things. Only by following the principle of nature, neither clinging nor resisting, can one untie these bonds.
