Thus it is said: *things cannot overcome Heaven.*

Soon after, Zilai fell ill, gasping as if near death. His wife and children gathered around weeping. Zili went to see him and shouted: "Away! Begone! Do not disturb his transformation!" Leaning against the doorframe, he said to them: "How grand is the Creator! What will it make of you next? Where will it send you? Will it make you into a mouse’s liver? A bug’s arm?"

Zilai replied: "A child follows their parents’ commands, whether east or west, north or south. Yin and yang are to man no less than parents. If they bring me near death and I do not obey, I would be defiant—what fault would lie with them? The great clod burdens me with form, labors me with life, eases me with old age, and rests me with death. Thus, to treat my life well is to treat my death well.

Now, if a great smelter were casting metal, and the metal leapt up saying, *I must become a Moye sword!* the smelter would surely deem it an inauspicious metal. Now, if one were to acquire a human form and say, *I am a man! A man!* the Creator would surely deem it an inauspicious person. If one takes Heaven and Earth as a great furnace and the Creator as a great smelter, where could one go and not be acceptable? Falling asleep in completion, awakening in continuity."

Guo’s commentary: "Death and life are like waking and sleeping. By principle, one should sleep without wishing to be startled. When transformation brings death, do not be alarmed by it."

Since ancient times, some have defied their parents’ commands, but none have defied the changes of yin and yang. When it is time to die, it cannot be forbidden. To harbor a rebellious heart is to hasten one’s death through defiance—this is not the fault of death. Thus, to treat one’s life well is to treat one’s death well; the principle is constant in both.

*I am a man! A man!*—one wishes only to be human. When metal leaps in the smelter, the world knows it is inauspicious. Life is not made by design; it arises of itself. To cling to it is delusion. Just as people know that metal’s attachment is inauspicious, if one recognizes that one is no different from metal, then the attachments of the heart can be released. Waking and sleeping remain the same, and one is not burdened by life and death.

Lü’s commentary: "Mice and bugs are what people most despise, and their scattered qi and forms becoming livers or arms are what people most loathe. At such a time, to ask about what is despised and loathed is to test Zilai’s equanimity. Knowing that yin and yang are to man no less than parents and obeying them, knowing that the great clod rests me with death and treating it well—why ask what it will make of you or where it will send you?

When metal leaps in the smelter, people deem it inauspicious. So too with man’s wish to remain human. If one takes Heaven, Earth, and the Creator as a furnace and smelter, then mouse livers and bug arms are no different—where could one not go? Why should I be concerned? *Falling asleep in completion, awakening in continuity*—this speaks of the ease between death and life, like waking and sleeping, without alteration."

Lin’s commentary: "Mouse livers and bug arms are the smallest of things, akin to the snake’s scales and cicada’s wings in the *Qi Wu Lun*, showing that the transformations of creation are endless and beyond human knowledge. A child obeys their parents’ commands without daring to defy them. Man receives from yin and yang no less than from parents—why not obey the changes of life and death? Whether becoming a mouse’s liver or a bug’s arm, one follows what comes and finds peace. The Creator brings me near death—how dare I resist?"

Should one resist, the fault lies with the child—what fault is theirs? *Xiang Dao’s commentary*: "The mouse liver is anger stored within; the bug’s arm, anger manifest without. Living between heaven and earth, to resist the commands of yin and yang and refuse to heed them—how is this different from a mouse’s liver or a bug’s arm? Yin and yang’s relation to man is no less than that of parents, and one cannot but obey. To compare the body to smelted metal: one cannot leap and twist to become a *Mo Ye* blade. This illustrates the absence of joy or anger in matters of life and death."

*Bi Xu’s commentary*: "The Dao exists even in excrement and urine—how much more in a mouse’s liver or a bug’s arm! Those who defy the commands of their elders are called unfilial; then how can those who resist the principles of transformation be said to follow the Dao? When the Creator brings one near death, to refuse and resist is to betray one’s innate nature—what fault lies with transformation? It is like a great smelter casting metal: the mold cannot be defied, so how can transformation be resisted? *Falling asleep in the merging of the hun-souls, awakening in the opening of form*—though the states of merging and opening differ, the nature of stillness remains one."

*Zhao’s commentary*: "‘What use is there for you?’ ‘Where could you go?’—this speaks of having no use for you. One may transform into something as minute as a mouse’s liver or a bug’s arm—this is unknowable."

The forging of metal into a sword is the work of the great smelter alone; the shaping of form into a human is the decree of the Master of Transformation alone. To become a mouse’s liver or a bug’s arm—how could I possibly know? *Cheng-ran* in sleep embodies the principle of total return; *lian-ran* in waking embodies the principle of revival.

Fuzhai observes: "Mouse liver and bug’s arm denote the most minute of things—this aligns with Zhaozhou’s saying of ‘after the fire has burned through, a single stalk of reeds remains.’ To follow the decree is to obey; to resist is to defy—this echoes the earlier idea that things cannot overcome Heaven. The analogy of forging metal is most striking. Jia Yi said: ‘Yin and yang are the charcoal; the myriad things are the copper—all emerge from this.’ *Cheng-ran* in sleep, *lian-ran* in waking—taking life as sleep and death as waking, yet these six characters conclude the preceding passage with such marvelous artistry.

The ancients spoke of friendship as that which is ‘in accord with the unobstructed’; thus could they correct one another when near death. When Zilai’s wife and children wept around him, he rebuked them to withdraw, lest they disturb his transformation—this was conduct unlike that of ordinary people. He further explained that one exists in the world as but one among the myriad things, and that the number of humans is beyond reckoning—so *what use is there for you?* This again dispelled his attachments and opened his boundless heart.

Mouse liver and bug’s arm speak of life in its most insignificant and negligible form. If even this is the decree of the Creator, one must accept it—how could it be resisted? From this, one sees that those who clearly understand the principle of life and death find joy in every circumstance and peace at all times. Extending this thread further, they can rescue friends from peril and resolve the confusions of the world—is this not a great benefit?

The Great Clod bears me with form until my death. Here, the earlier text is reiterated to address the common fear of death and the futile attempts to plan for future lives, where the slightest attachment entangles one for ten thousand kalpas. It is like metal leaping in the smelter—only to be bound and rendered unyielding by its own difference.

Thus, the perfected person takes Heaven and Earth as the furnace, the Creator as the smelter, and the boundless transformations as limitless—what need is there to cling to the label of ‘human’ and fret over its loss? How much less concern should there be for a mouse, a bug, a liver, or an arm? Observing how the ancients conducted themselves in this way, how could life and death ever constrain them? For they took life as sleep and death as waking. If death is waking, then what moment is not waking?

*The Seventeenth Fascicle of the* Ocean of Meanings of the *True Scripture of Southern Florescence* concludes here.

---
*The Eighteenth Fascicle of the* Ocean of Meanings of the *True Scripture of Southern Florescence*
Priest Chu Boxiu of Wulin

**The Fifth Chapter of the Inner Chapters: "No Master in Great Divination"**

Zisang Hu, Mengzi Fan, and Zi Qin Zhang became friends, saying to one another: "Who among us can join together in non-joining, act for one another in non-acting? Who can ascend to heaven and wander in the mists, stirring the boundless without end, forgetting one another in life, with no final limit?" The three looked at one another and laughed, their hearts in perfect accord, and so they became friends.

After some time, Zisang Hu died, his body yet unburied. When Confucius heard of this, he sent Zigong to attend to the rites. One wove cords, another plucked the zither, and together they sang in harmony:

*"Alas, Zisang Hu! Alas, Zisang Hu!*
*You have returned to your true nature,*
*While we remain here as men—how strange!"*

Zigong hurried forward and said: "May I ask—is it proper to sing before the dead?" The two looked at one another and laughed: "What does he know of the meaning of ritual?"

Zigong returned and reported to Confucius: "What manner of men are they? They cultivate no conduct, yet cast off their bodily forms. They sing before the dead without change in countenance—there is no name for them. What manner of men are they?"

Confucius said: "They wander beyond the bounds, while I wander within them. Beyond and within do not reach one another, and to send you to mourn them was my folly. They now join with the Creator as one, wandering in the single qi of heaven and earth. To them, life is but an excrescent growth, a hanging wart; death is the bursting of the wart, the draining of the abscess. For those like this, how could they know where life and death, before and after, reside? Borrowing from other things, they entrust themselves to a shared body, forgetting their livers and gallbladders, leaving behind their ears and eyes."

They cycle through beginning and end, unaware of origin or boundary;
adrift and wandering beyond the dust and grime,
at ease in the work of non-action.
How could they fret over the rites of the vulgar world,
seeking to please the eyes and ears of the multitude?

Zigong said: "Then upon what Way do you rely?"
Confucius said: "I am one of Heaven’s punished people."
"Yet even so, I share this with you."

Zigong said: "May I ask what this Way is?"
Confucius said: "Fish are made for water, as men are made for the Dao.
Those made for water dig ponds to sustain themselves;
those made for the Dao find stability without effort.
Thus it is said: fish forget one another in rivers and lakes,
men forget one another in the arts of the Dao."

Zigong said: "May I ask about the *jiren*?"
Confucius said: "The *jiren* is one who is odd among men yet companion to Heaven.
Thus it is said: what is petty in Heaven is noble among men;
what is noble among men is petty in Heaven."

Guo’s commentary:
Those who embody Heaven and Earth, who darkly merge with transformation—though hands and feet, the five viscera, never consciously cooperate, the hundred joints harmonize as one, cooperating in non-cooperation.
Though never consciously acting for one another, inner and outer together achieve their ends, acting in non-action.
But if one strains mind and will to care for hands and feet, moves limbs to tend the viscera, then the more one acts for them, the more inner and outer are exhausted.
To forget one’s life is to forget all things, to follow change and submit to transformation—where then is any limit?
They look at one another and laugh, hearts in perfect accord,
for they see the deepest kinship without the sentiment of love.
When others weep, they weep too—this is the crossroads of the vulgar world.
To sing before the dead is the aspiration of those beyond the bounds.

Those who grasp the meaning of ritual must wander outside to order what is within, guard the mother to preserve the child.
But if one prides oneself on reputation, is bound by emotional constraints,
then filial piety cannot bear sincerity, compassion cannot bear substance;
father and son, brothers, harbor feelings and deceive one another—
how could this be the great meaning of ritual?

There is a principle of ultimate depth, where inner and outer merge;
never has one who attains the utmost wandering beyond failed to merge within.
Mourning is a matter of those within the bounds—
to apply it to those beyond is folly.
To see life as an excrescent growth, a hanging wart—
qi gathering in its time, not what one delights in;
to see death as the bursting of the wart, the draining of the abscess—
qi scattering of itself, not what one regrets.
Life and death alternate, never beginning or ending—
thus one knows not where victory or defeat lie.
Gathering and scattering, transformation—all are different things.
Though what they borrow differs, together they form a single body.
Thus they forget liver and gallbladder, leave behind ears and eyes,
follow principle and proceed directly—
even the five viscera are forgotten, what thing remains to be known?
What they show to the multitude is but the dust and grime.

Lu’s commentary:
Cooperating in non-cooperation, acting in non-action—
this is the place of returning to the root and recovering destiny.
Ascend to Heaven and one reaches the great brightness above;
wander in mist and one enters the gate of profound obscurity—
thus stirred and prodded without limit, with no end or exhaustion.
For them, to return to the real is joy—
thus to sing before the dead is only fitting.
The former kings established ritual to balance likes and dislikes,
restoring the rightness of the human Way—
then for those who take joy in returning to the real,
how could this not be the meaning of ritual?

Those who wander beyond the bounds take Heaven as their companion,
thus they see death as joy and have no cause for sorrow.
Those who wander within the bounds take men as their companions,
thus they see death as sorrow and dare not rejoice.
If the many were to take these three as companions and delight in their death,
then those who double death and forget life would be legion.
Without these three, one is entangled between life and death,
unable to untie the knot—this is what the perfected lament.

The aspirations of inner and outer differ—
this is why they do not reach one another.
Confucius sent Zigong to mourn, wishing him to understand
that the meaning of ritual does not lie beyond the feelings of life and destiny,
and that the world’s subtle principles are not confined to ritual and law.

Wandering in the single qi of Heaven and Earth,
they are neither yin nor yang.
To see life as an excrescent growth is to see life as loss and indulge it;
to see death as the bursting of the abscess is to see death as return and delight in it.
Borrowing from different things, entrusting to a shared body—
this is not to take them as real.
Forgetting liver and gallbladder, leaving behind ears and eyes—
cycling through beginning and end, unaware of origin or boundary,
how then could they perform the rites of the vulgar world?

Confucius, though wandering within the bounds, extols the loftiness of those beyond—
Zigong suspects that though he wanders within, what he relies upon may not be there.
For what he wanders is the trace, while what he relies upon is the heart.
"Heaven’s punished people"—this means the Heavenly punishment is inescapable.
Yet Confucius embodies his nature, embraces the spirit,
and wanders the vulgar world at ease—
what reliance could burden his heart?
Thus he wanders within the bounds without needing to leave,
endures Heaven’s punishment without needing to escape.
This is not something I alone share with you—
I also draw fish as an analogy for men.
Digging a pond to sustain oneself does not require great waters;
finding stability without effort does not require wandering beyond.
To wander beyond and merge within,
to let each thing follow its nature so that the Way of emperors and kings is fulfilled—
this is to be odd among men yet companion to Heaven.
In terms of nature, there is no small or great among men;
in terms of human principle, those who companion Heaven may be called noble.
Fish forget one another in rivers and lakes,
men forget one another in the arts of the Dao—
each is self-sufficient and forgets the rest."

"To forget one another in rivers and lakes is not merely to dig a pond; to forget one another in the arts of the Dao is not merely to be without affairs. The odd man who companions Heaven does so by being external rather than internal.

Those whom Heaven deems petty and men deem noble are those starved by ritual and law yet ignorant of the true nature of life. As Lin notes: there is a Way of mutual accord, but no affairs of mutual accord; there is a heart of mutual endeavor, but no traces of mutual endeavor.

Ascending to heaven and roaming in mist—this is to reach the ultimate emptiness. Those who twist and turn do so beyond the bounds of creation. Those whose will is born with them do not cling to life. Without end or exhaustion, they have never died—they merely weave baskets and plait curtains.

Returning to the true self is still to be human, which is why a sigh of reliance arises. Zigong, perplexed, posed his question, and the two, seeing that Zigong did not grasp the meaning of ritual, exchanged smiles.

Cultivating one’s virtue and conduct without adherence to ritual and law, forgetting the body externally, equalizing life and death—such a Way is unfathomable and cannot be named.

Confucius said: 'He who wanders beyond the bounds and he who wanders within them—beyond the bounds lies the meaning of ritual, within them lies its form. The circumstances of inner and outer differ, and thus they do not intersect.'

To be a companion to the Creator is to render creation insufficient to match one’s use. To roam within the single qi of heaven and earth is to render heaven and earth insufficient to exhaust one’s longevity."

Those with superfluous growths and dangling warts—these are but confluences of qi. Those afflicted by sores, ulcers, and paralysis—these are but dispersals of qi. Strange entities are but transformations of life and death; the same body is but the six limbs, ears, and eyes. If strange entities are but illusions, how can the same body be real?

To forsake the inner and forget the outer, to know neither end nor beginning—this is to speak of merging with transformation as one. Confucius, constrained by benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and law, took these as ultimate limits, much like the inescapable bonds of heavenly punishment. Yet he could not but act thus, hence his words: "I share this with you."

Zigong, seeing that the three men did not conform to the human Dao, asked about "uncanny persons." Confucius replied: "Those who do not conform to the human Dao seek resemblance to the heavenly Dao. Those who accompany heaven speak of them as 'noble persons'; those who accompany humanity, lacking the words of heaven, speak of them as 'petty persons.' The sage, able to embody both heaven and humanity, harmonizes the myriad things—what need has he for 'uncanny persons' or 'accompanying heaven'?"

A detailed commentary on the Dao states: Form is what creation fashions; fate is what creation bestows. One who cannot accord with form will inevitably suffer constraint and aversion; one who cannot accord with fate will inevitably suffer distress and sorrow. Zisi accorded with form, and Zilai accorded with fate—though their paths differed, both took non-action as their head, life as their spine, and death as their tailbone, fundamentally the same. Yet according with form does not mean forgetting form, nor does according with fate mean forgetting fate.

But when the three friends ascended to roam the heavens and wander the mists, stirring and prodding the boundless—this was forgetting form. When they sang before the corpse without change in countenance—this was forgetting fate. To forget form is to forget one’s liver and gall, to forsake one’s ears and eyes. To forget fate is to reverse end and beginning, to know no origin or limit. Such are the deeds of those who wander beyond the bounds.

Confucius, however, dwelt within the bounds without refusal, accepting heavenly execution without avoidance. Unoccupied, he attained serenity; he did not require the beyond to find joy. Like fish weaving through ponds to sustain themselves, they need not the rivers and lakes to be at ease. Viewed through the Dao, who can say the petty person is not a noble one, or the noble person not petty? Yet when we speak of noble and petty persons in terms of their alignment with heaven or humanity, those three men were merely more worthy than heaven’s petty persons.

The sage harmonizes self and other, finding contentment in all circumstances—what need has he for the trivialities of "uncanny persons" or "accompanying heaven"?

The *Bixu* commentary states: To be without mutual engagement is to engage oneself; to be without mutual action is to act for oneself. To engage oneself is to govern oneself; to act for oneself is to act without acting—this is how one attains mutual forgetting. Ascending to roam the heavens and wander the mists is to tread loftily beyond the dust. Stirring and prodding without limit, one attains boundless emptiness—thus they forget one another in life, knowing no end or exhaustion.

Their arranging of songs and playing of lutes in harmony was not for Sanghu’s sake but to lament and admonish the multitude. Weeping and wailing are the forms of ritual; composure in life and acceptance in death are its essence. Those who cultivate the Way leave no trace of their words unfulfilled, yet their path cannot be named—who can say whether they are noble persons?

Those beyond the bounds grasp the subtle meaning; those within grasp the coarse traces. Those several men were about to roam with transformation through the great void, merging indistinguishably with the primordial chaos, taking life and death as the rise and fall of waves—how could they be bound by the fixed patterns of heaven and earth? Borne of the five phases’ strange entities, entrusted to creation’s single body, they cast off form and thus forgot liver and gall, discarded brilliance and thus forsook ears and eyes. Emerging from emptiness, entering the hollow, untouched by the world’s defilements, they attained the essence of the beyond—how could they perform the elaborate falsities of ritual to display before the multitude?

The enlightened make self-reliance their duty and regard reliance on the sagely path as disgrace. Thus, though the aims of sages and worthies differ, their responses to things remain unaltered. Fish find water and forget the waves; people attain the Dao and forget the road. Each weaves through its pond to nourish itself, unoccupied and preserving life.

To follow nature is to forget ritual and law; to cultivate ritual and law is to lose nature. Heaven’s petty persons are humanity’s noble ones—these are they who lose nature. Humanity’s noble persons are heaven’s petty ones—these are they who cultivate ritual and law. He who can unite both—is this not the way of Mengsun Cai?

The Zhao commentary states: To engage in non-engagement, reaching the point of no end or exhaustion—this is the Dao of the divine persons of Guye. The previous chapter spoke only of equalizing life and death; here, there are those who transcend both life and death.

Zifan and Qinzhang played lutes and sang in harmony, delighting in returning to the real, laughing at Zigong’s ignorance of ritual’s meaning. Confucius, understanding where their Dao resided, elucidated the subtlety of forgetting liver and gall, forsaking ears and eyes. Zigong then asked: "Master, will you rely on those beyond the bounds or those within?" Confucius replied: "You and I are both bound by ritual and law—this is an inescapable heavenly punishment."

Fish weave through ponds to find sustenance, seeking peace in water. Unoccupied, one attains serenity, seeking peace in the Dao. Fish do not depart from water, nor do people depart from the Dao—this is wandering within the bounds. To forget one another in rivers and lakes, to forget one another in the Dao’s unfolding—this is wandering beyond the bounds. The "uncanny person" does not conform to humanity but unites with heaven. The heavenly Dao is real; the human Dao is false—this is their distinction.

Fuzhai states: To engage without intent, to act without acting, ascending to roam the heavens and wander the mists, stirring and prodding the boundless—this is to wander beyond the myriad things. To forget one another in life, knowing no end or exhaustion, is to neither forget one’s beginning nor seek one’s end.

"Waiting upon affairs" refers to tasks like assisting in brewing or weaving mats. "Returning to the real" is returning to the origin. "The meaning of ritual" refers to ritual’s essence. Some say this is a parable of *Zhuangzi*. According to the *Book of Rites*, Yuan Rang’s *Lishou* song shows that since ancient times, there have been those who departed from the world and severed ties with custom—this did not await the learning of the Dao.

Cultivation without attainment—this speaks of the absence of virtue and practice. To be a companion to the Creator is to be a friend to the Creator. "Roaming the single qi of Heaven and Earth" means roaming the origin of things. "Growths, sores, and ulcers" are metaphors for this body as a superfluous thing in Heaven and Earth, which must be excised and dissolved before one is at ease—this is the meaning of toiling in life and resting in death. "Borrowing from other things, entrusting to the same body" refers to the theory that earth, water, fire, and wind combine to form the body. "Reversing and repeating end and beginning, unaware of their bounds"—then in wandering and freedom, where is there no fitting place?

Zigong asked the Master whether his reliance was on the inner or the outer realm. "Heaven’s punished people" refers to those under Heaven’s inescapable judgment, who thus cannot be people of the outer realm. "To share this with you" means to speak of the joy of the outer realm. "Digging a pond to nurture [fish]" is enough for self-sufficiency—this speaks of obtaining water, no matter the amount, and of attaining the Dao, where one lives according to one’s allotted measure. The *jiren*—the uniquely different person—thus accords with Heaven. If Heaven deems one a noble person, then people deem one base; if people deem one noble, then Heaven deems one base. What Zhuangzi calls a "noble person" carries a tone of mockery toward the sages and worthies, for he holds that rites, music, laws, and measures do not arise from nature. Only by breaking the measuring cups and smashing the scales, so that the people do not contend, does one become a noble person of Heaven. This is also an expression of indignation toward a perverse world, an excessively lofty argument.

"Being together without being together"—indifference perfects friendship. "Acting without acting"—tranquility perfects virtue. "Ascending to roam the heavens and wander the mists"—then one flies without constraint. "Forgetting one another in life"—then one is unaware of body and world. In freedom beyond things, where is there an end? A single smile without opposition—then spirit communes and hearts align, the Dao present in a glance. This is not like the shallow customs of later ages, where people discuss matters face-to-face but laugh behind one’s back.

When Zisang Hu died, Confucius sent Zigong to assist with the affairs—thus Zisang Hu’s character may be known. His two friends played the zither in harmony, delighting in returning to the real—thus their intent and interest were not far off. Zigong, versed in ritual and culture, was right to find this strange and ask about it. For the essence of ritual is known only to those who roam beyond the world, and the Master was not unaware of this. Sending Zigong to observe and provoke his question was meant to instruct him.

To be a companion to creation and roam the single qi of Heaven and Earth is to not divide the transformations of yin and yang. Thus life is seen as a growth, left to hang and attach; death as a sore or ulcer, ultimately to be dissolved and excised. How can one know where before and after lie? Borrowing the four great elements to form a body, blending inner and outer and forgetting both, reversing and repeating end and beginning, unaware of their bounds—this is the Dao of the great master.

Zigong again asked the Master which realm he relied upon. The Master said that teaching people through benevolence, righteousness, rites, and music is the utmost exhaustion of creation. "To share this with you" means that nothing escapes this. Fish rely on water to live; people rely on the Dao to live. Those at ease in water dig ponds to suffice; those at ease in the Dao live settled without affairs. This metaphor speaks of those who roam within the world, who are content within the world. As for forgetting one another in the expanse between rivers and lakes—this metaphor speaks of roaming beyond the world, unbound by worldly rites. Thus, in the face of the changes of life and death, one remains composed and unafraid.

Zigong, hearing of the customs of those beyond the world who leave society and cut ties with convention, asked about the *jiren*. The answer was that those who differ from people are companions to Heaven—this speaks of their defiance of convention necessarily harmonizing with the Dao. From this, one knows that Heaven’s base people are people’s noble ones, and people’s noble ones are Heaven’s base ones. The two lines are but one, clarifying the difference between differing and accompanying, and the divergence of Heaven and people.

Yan Hui asked Confucius: "Mengsun Cai—when his mother died, he wept without tears, his heart was not grieved, and he did not mourn in his dwelling. Lacking these three, he was praised throughout Lu for his skill in handling mourning. Is it truly possible to gain such a reputation without substance?" Hui was deeply puzzled by this.

Confucius said: "Mengsun Cai has fully realized it—he has advanced beyond knowledge. Though he sought to simplify, he could not, for he had already simplified. Mengsun Cai did not know why he lived, nor why he died; he did not know what to follow first, nor what to follow after. As if transformed into a thing, he awaited the transformations he did not know! And as he was about to transform, how could he know he would not transform? As he was about to not transform, how could he know he had already transformed? You and I are merely those who dream and have not yet awakened!

Moreover, he had a startled form but no harm to his heart; he had a morning dwelling but no feeling of death. Mengsun Cai alone was awake—others weep, and so he weeps. This is simply his way. Moreover, we have joined in calling this 'I'—how can we know what I call 'I'? You dream of being a bird and soaring in the sky, or of being a fish and diving into the abyss. Do you not know whether the speaker now is awake or dreaming?

When one reaches contentment, laughter does not follow; when laughter is offered, arrangement does not follow. At peace with arrangement and departing from transformation, one enters the vastness of the single Heaven." Guo’s commentary: "Those who fully grasp the principle of life and death and respond appropriately to inner and outer—acting in accordance with Heaven’s course—are not matched by knowledge. Selecting life and death without grasping their difference is like the progression of spring, autumn, winter, and summer. There is nothing one does not accept, and one becomes one with transformation. This is like forgetting what one knows in the present—how could one wait for knowledge to preemptively worry? Having transformed and lived, how can one know the time before life? Being in the midst of transformation and dying, how can one know the time after death?

Now, in dreams, one takes oneself to be awake—then there is no way to prove that waking is not dreaming, or that life is not death."

Life and death, waking and dreaming—one knows not where they reside. Yet in whatever one encounters, there is nothing that does not bring self-possession. Why grieve over this while worrying about that? To regard transformation as the body’s startling movements is not to let it harm or burden the heart. To see the body’s changes as a morning dwelling renewed is not to take them as death in one’s nature.

Those who remain constantly awake meet no situation without resistance, so when others weep, they weep too—this is simply what is fitting for them. Life and death, change and transformation—all are mine. Mysteriously one with inner and outer, ever renewed with transformation, how could one know where I truly am? Dreaming of being a bird, dreaming of being a fish—there is nowhere one does not find self-possession. The changes of life and death are never worth lamenting. All one creates is fitting, so one does not reach laughter.

"Arranging" means "shifting." In ritual, weeping must be sorrowful, laughter must be joyful—if sorrow and joy linger in the heart, one cannot shift with what is fitting. Now, Mengsun always fits, at ease with shifting. Moving together with transformation, he thus enters into the vast emptiness and becomes one with Heaven.

Lü’s commentary: Only when one knows that things have never truly begun does one see no difference between inner and outer, life and death. Why must one wander beyond the world, taking death as joy, even singing before the corpse? Thus, in mourning, Mengsun weeps as others do, yet is not burdened by sorrow—this is how he differs from them. Therefore, the example of Mengsun shows that the utmost attainment does not depart from the common ways of the world. In life, it is still so; in death, it is still so; in weeping, it is still so—though one may wish to select, one cannot.

Those three masters, though unaware of where life, death, existence, and extinction reside, took life as loss and death as return—yet they did not truly know the reason for life or the reason for death. Taking the return to the real as joy, sighing for others—this was not yet to be free from attachment to before or after. Mengsun, however, did not know the reason for life or the reason for death, so in life there was nothing lost, and in death there was nothing to return to. Free from attachment to before or after, in death there was nothing to delight in, and in life there was nothing to sigh over.

Not only was it like this, but even if one were transformed into another thing, one would still await that unknown transformation, and it too would remain unknown. When about to transform, how could one know it will not transform? When about to remain unchanged, how could one know it has already transformed? Then are we now, together with you, not yet awakened from the dream?

He who has a human form may be startled by its changes, yet his heart remains unmoved—thus nothing harms the heart. Life and death are like night and day, so there is a morning dwelling. Without the emotions of others, there is no emotional death. This is why Mengsun alone was awakened.

Only by knowing this does one weep when others weep, without tears that are not sorrowful—this arises from what is fitting for them and is nothing strange. Moreover, when you dream of being a bird or a fish, you do not know it is a dream. Then how can one be certain whether what is now spoken is waking or dreaming? This makes clear that Mengsun forgot the self and alone was awakened.

What brings laughter is fitting, yet it is not self-fitting—thus one does not reach laughter. Laughter is what arranges, yet if one offers laughter, it is not joyful laughter—thus one does not reach arrangement. "Arrangement" means dispelling sorrow and letting it go. Thus, Mengsun’s forgetting of life and death cannot be created or offered. Being at ease with arrangement is not to arrange with intention; letting go of transformation is to know it cannot be resisted and to follow it.

Vastness is without obstruction, Heaven is without human artifice, oneness is without duality—the Dao is fully realized here.

Yi Du’s commentary: Few know life but not death; Mengsun knew what others did not, thus daily advancing in knowledge. At ease with life, at ease with death—what selection could there be? What Mengsun selected was the Dao, not knowing the difference between life and death to avoid or pursue them.

Transformation comes uninvited and leaves untraceable. Forgetting and awaiting it, one responds when principle arrives. Only what transformation cannot move is the principle of understanding life and penetrating death. Thus, when about to transform, how could one know it will not transform? When about to remain unchanged, how could one know it has already transformed? All attachments to the world are dreams. Once truly awakened, life and death cannot burden one—how much less the rites of the world?

When Mengsun’s mother died, seeing others startled, he too was startled, yet his heart was not harmed. Morning belongs to the arising of yang; form is likened to a dwelling. Ordinary people follow form with their emotions, so both emotion and form die. The perfected person knows form is not one’s own, regarding it as a morning dwelling. Thus, the form may die, but the nature does not die. Mengsun cast off the dust and alone awakened—thus he is called "alone awakened."

The *Shuowen* says: "乃 depicts the difficulty of qi emerging." Mengsun’s weeping did not come from his original heart but followed others in weeping—this is why it was difficult.

My life, my death—nowhere is it not mine. Dreaming of being a bird, dreaming of being a fish, one is at ease with whatever is encountered. Do we not know whether what is now said is spoken in waking or in dreaming? Not having penetrated the principle of life and death, even in waking one is still in a dream. Once truly awakened, there is no longer waking or dreaming.

Fitting by chance, fitting is not constant—if one forces it, one does not reach laughter. Laughing for others when the heart is not joyful—this is offering laughter. "Arrangement" is the principle of shifting with creation. Only one who is fitting in all situations reaches laughter. Only one who is joyful then laughs reaches arrangement. Thus, the perfected person is at ease with shifting, forgets transformation, enters into vastness, and becomes one with Heaven.

Xiang Dao’s commentary: Mengsun’s mastery of mourning was the Dao. Yan Hui’s reproach was emotion. Mengsun could not select what he selected—what he selected and took was only the Dao. Moreover, how could one know where life and death, before and after, reside? Those who are bound to form and burdened by life follow the emotions of ordinary people.

One whose form is startled yet whose heart remains unharmed does not submit to form. One who dwells in the morning abode yet feels no sorrow in death is not burdened by life. Thus, one follows what lies in the other without resistance—hence, when others weep, one weeps. One rests in what lies within oneself without worry—hence, though one weeps, there is no grief. For ease arises from what brings comfort, and laughter springs from what brings joy; forcing ease does not lead to laughter, and laughing for others cannot be arranged and cast aside.

Mengsun’s heart knew neither sorrow nor joy—he merely wept when others wept, which is called "offering" it. That he did not reach grief was fitting, for he was at ease with shifting without harm to his heart, released from transformation without sorrow in death, and thus entered into vastness to become one with Heaven.

Bixu’s commentary: Weeping and wailing while observing mourning rites is the ritual of serving the dead. Without tears, there is no grief—this is the Way of understanding death, which only those who fully practice it and advance in knowledge attain. Seeing life and death as a single thread, nothing can be discarded. Though one may simplify life and death, one cannot simplify weeping and wailing. Avoidance and pursuit are the emotions of ordinary people.

Now, those who possess form are transformed by things, and things follow their transformations. When transformation is imminent, how can one know whether death enters emptiness and vastness and will not become human again? When transformation is not imminent, how can one know whether life dwells in fleeting shadows and is lost in the blink of an eye? Form follows transformation and shifts—hence, there is startled form. The heart is one with emptiness and vastness—hence, there is no harm to the heart.

Form is but the temporary union of spirit. Today, one dwells in it and tends to it; tomorrow, it is cast aside as a discarded thing. Only the enlightened follow change and remain ever-living—hence, there is no sorrow in death. *The Shuowen* says: "乃 depicts the difficulty of qi’s emergence," referring to the challenge of forgetting sorrow and grief when weeping is not easy. Life is mine, death is mine—thus, it is said, "together with me." The perfected person has no self—where is there a place that is not me? Dreaming of being a fish or a bird, soaring through the sky or plunging into the abyss, is no different.

People have long been deluded by the illusions of life and death, waking and dreaming, not realizing that those who dwell in long light have no waking or dreaming, and those who transcend form have no life or death. Forced ease and joy do not reach laughter; natural offerings of laughter do not reach the countenance. Arrangement has no foothold.

Mengsun was at ease with arrangement, undisturbed by transformation, and thus entered into the vastness of Heaven, merging into oneness without duality.

Zhao’s commentary: When Mengsun’s mother died, he felt no grief, yet his mastery of mourning brought him fame throughout Lu. The Master said Mengsun had fully grasped the principle of life and death, reaching the realm of ultimate knowledge. Yet he could not but observe mourning and weep—this is what is meant by "unable to discard." However, without sorrow or grief, he had already discarded something.

Not knowing the origin of life and death, before and after, he served his mother in life and death as one. If she had transformed into another thing, that which he did not know—neither born nor transformed—how could he wait for what he did not know to transform with her before stopping? What transforms is form; what does not transform is not form. How can the transforming and the untransforming know one another?

Having startled form yet no harm to the heart, dwelling in the morning abode yet no sorrow in death—this is what is meant by "possessing human form but not human emotions." The Master said to Yan Hui: "You and I have not yet awakened," but Mengsun had already awakened. Weeping when others weep, not knowing why—this is the morning. Morning is life, night is death. The world clings to life as the self, unaware that it is but the morning of night.

What I call "me" endures through ancient and present times, ever-present. Dreaming of being a fish or a bird—does one know it is a dream? Is there any difference between speaking of dreams now and being in a dream? One who creates ease finds contentment in all situations—hence, does not reach laughter. One who offers laughter rejoices at the trigger—hence, cannot arrange and cast it aside. At ease with the Creator’s arrangement, detached from the realm of ceaseless transformation, one ascends to the distant and becomes a companion of Heaven.

Yongzhai said: "Advancing in knowledge" means progressing ever further in understanding the Dao. "Unable to discard" refers to the rites of mourning and the act of weeping, which one still wishes to cast aside but cannot. Though unable to discard, what one does is already greatly simplified.

"Not knowing the origin of life and death, before and after" means being unable to discern beginning or end, following creation as a thing, awaiting the transformation one does not know. This is to let things take their natural course. How can one know what will transform, what has already transformed, or what will not transform? Those who know the Dao find my actions strange—this is because my dream has not yet awakened.

Form changes with age, which may be startling, but the heart remains at ease—hence, no harm to the heart. *Dan* is life; *zhai* is dwelling; life and death are like night and morning. Knowing that life’s dwelling is temporary, death is not truly death—hence, there is no sorrow in death. "Awakened, one weeps when others weep"—this is merely following the crowd. This is where one wishes to discard but cannot.

This is the subtlety of self-attainment: wishing to discard yet unable, one follows the crowd in weeping. Moreover, those who now join me in finding this strange—how can they know what I truly mean by "me"? This is Zhuangzi’s playful flourish in his writing; the reader must view it with a separate eye.

Dreaming of birds or fish is but an extension of the earlier transformation into a butterfly. Speaking now—whether awake or dreaming—is like Zhuang Zhou dreaming of being a butterfly, or the butterfly dreaming of being Zhuang Zhou. When the mind is set on something, there are times it does not reach laughter—this is the intensity of ease. Laughing in response to things is when things silently laugh at me, arising naturally—what need is there for arrangement?

All things in the world—success and failure, gain and loss—are already arranged. I merely rest in what is arranged and follow transformation, thus entering into vastness, Heaven, and oneness. Vastness, Heaven, and oneness are but creation, given such names.

The preceding chapter tells of Zisi, Ziyu, Zili, and Zilai as friends—Ziyu’s body was afflicted yet his heart remained untroubled; Zilai faced death yet his spirit felt no dread: both had grasped the principle and followed transformation. The next chapter speaks of Zisanghu’s death, where his two friends strummed the zither and sang in harmony, forgetting form and delighting in transformation. In this chapter, mourning his mother, he wished to simplify rites but could not, so he wept without tears and his heart felt no sorrow. Unknowing of whence life comes or whither death goes, how could he know that lurching and wailing were proper to ritual?

The greater meaning is to clarify that life and death are not to be distinguished, urging one to rest in and follow them, to delight in and forget them. The living are not crushed, the dead are spared terror, and where the spirit’s way reaches, joy flows freely—then the root and refuge of one’s being will not lodge in a body of violence. Observe the transformations of cicadas, butterflies, and dragonflies: their principle may be extended. On the verge of change, poised and still, they know no division between self and other, but harmonize with the qi of Heaven and Earth. Thus, one may discourse on the shell here while the form transforms there. During transformation, if mistakenly touched by another creature, the intent turns to anger and shifts into a malign kind—mind changes within, form alters without, for something has summoned it. Though transformation arises from the Creator, it also reveals how things shape themselves. How can one not be vigilant of this mechanism?

What the heart inclines toward becomes its fulfillment; in fulfillment, true joy is inwardly complete, not dependent on laughter for its presence. Laughter in response to things is but offered mirth; silent laughter arises from strain and falls short of the naturalness of spontaneous arrangement. The rise and fall of things depend on the Creator’s arrangement; human sorrow and joy depend on what that arrangement brings. To rest in arrangement and follow transformation is to enter into vastness and merge with the natural, where Heaven and humanity blend without duality.

This speaks of Mengsun’s clarity in destiny and mastery of change, his following of transformation and forgetting of emotion, taking life and death as but night and day, lodging waking and dreaming within them—how could sorrow or joy bind him? Someone asked: Mengsun forgot emotion in life and death, his heart free of grief—this is understanding, but applied to mourning his mother, does it not show filial impiety and violate ritual, making him a transgressor of moral teaching? The answer: Those beyond the world repay their parents in substance, not in form. There is something in hidden merits and secret conduct, in dissolving karmic knots and attaining the marvel of preserving spirit and transcending transformation—how could they stoop to the trifling rites of the vulgar? Once, Confucius’ friend Yuan Rang, upon his mother’s death, climbed a tree and sang—an even more extreme case! Confucius passed by as if he heard nothing and ultimately did not reproach him. This is the distinction between wandering within and beyond the world, the difference between ritual propriety and inner truth. Without profound insight, one cannot speak of this.

*The Eighteenth Scroll of the Ocean of Meanings in the True Scripture of Southern Florescence* concludes.
#1 The *Quewu* cites Zhang Junfang’s edition, where “待” is written as “侍.”
#2 Guo’s commentary edition has “情” as “形.”
#3 Zhu Guiyao’s *Zhuangzi Inner Chapters Evidence and Supplement* has “乃” as “盈.”

*The Nineteenth Scroll of the Ocean of Meanings in the True Scripture of Southern Florescence*
By Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin

*The Sixth Inner Chapter: The Great and Venerable Teacher*

Yi’erzi sought an audience with Xu You.
Xu You asked, “How has Yao endowed you?”
Yi’erzi replied, “Yao instructed me: ‘You must personally embody benevolence and righteousness, and clearly distinguish right from wrong.’”
Xu You said, “Then why have you come to court? Yao has already branded you with benevolence and righteousness, and mutilated you with right and wrong—how will you wander the paths of boundless freedom, unconstrained roaming, and ceaseless transformation?”
Yi’erzi said, “Even so, I wish to wander within its bounds.”
Xu You said, “It cannot be. The blind cannot partake in the beauty of brows and eyes, nor the blind in the splendor of blue and yellow, embroidered and patterned robes.”
Yi’erzi said, “Wu Zhuang lost her beauty, Ju Liang lost his strength, and the Yellow Emperor lost his wisdom—all within the crucible of refinement. How do we know the Creator will not cease branding me and mend my mutilation, allowing me to ride perfection and follow you, Master?”
Xu You said, “Alas, it cannot be known. Let me speak to you of its general principles: O my teacher! O my teacher!”

The Way nurtures the ten thousand things yet claims no righteousness; its blessings extend through the ages yet claim no benevolence; it is older than high antiquity yet claims no eld; it sustains heaven and earth, sculpts the myriad forms, yet claims no artistry. Such is the realm in which I wander.

Guo’s annotation: Branding with benevolence and righteousness, mutilating with right and wrong—this is to mar oneself with form-bound teachings, unable to roam the fields of self-attained freedom. Yi’erzi dares not seek the central path and wishes only to advance to its fence. Xu You disagrees, for not all things in the world are self-complete; some must be smelted and forged into vessels. Thus, Wu Zhuang, Ju Liang, and the Yellow Emperor all heard the Dao and only then lost what they had pursued. This is but a borrowed metaphor to dispel the burdens of action. That which proceeds unwavering and direct is nature itself. To proceed and harm one’s nature, and then to correct that harm, is also nature. How do we know that my nature will not cease its branding and mend my mutilation, allowing me to ride the perfected Way and follow you, Master?

The Way nurtures and blesses the ten thousand things—all occurs of itself, without preference or aversion. Where, then, could the seven virtues be lodged? Thus, though it appears ever-new, it is not artifice. To wander in non-action, to take no master as master—this alone suffices.

Lü’s annotation: The great thoroughfare of the Dao is the path of boundless freedom, unconstrained roaming, and ceaseless transformation. Wu Zhuang was ensnared by her beauty; Ju Liang was ensnared by his strength; the Yellow Emperor fasted in mind and disciplined his form to return to non-knowing, yet initially could not avoid employing knowledge. The crucible is for smelting and casting, the hammer for forging and refining. The loss of their burdens was not innate but occurred within the process of smelting and refining. How, then, do we know the Creator will not cease my branding and mend my mutilation, allowing me to ride my perfected heart-mind and follow the Master’s non-action?

That which nurtures and blesses the ten thousand things, which is older than high antiquity, which sculpts the myriad forms—this is what I wander within and take as my teacher. If you wish to cease your branding and mend your mutilation, take this alone as your teacher.

Lin’s annotation: To embody benevolence and righteousness is to fulfill one’s nature; to clarify right and wrong is to exhaust principle. Yao governed the world within the realm of forms, hence his admonition to Yi’erzi. Xu You said: Since Yao has already branded you with benevolence and righteousness, mutilated you with right and wrong, why have you come? "Boundless freedom" means far-reaching vastness; "unconstrained roaming and ceaseless transformation" describe a state of coming and going at ease. Yi’erzi, having awakened to the constraints of benevolence, righteousness, right, and wrong, now wishes to wander within the fence of the Dao. Xu You uses the blind and deaf as metaphors, yet Yi’erzi, eager to receive teaching, cites the three who lost their beauty, strength, and wisdom—all within the crucible’s refining. The attainment of the Dao also comes through learning. How do we know the Creator will not cease and mend my branding and mutilation, allowing me to ride the perfected Way and follow the Master? Xu You says all things create themselves; both I and the world are unknowable—one can only merge with the obscure. "O my teacher!" refers to the Dao.

To shatter the ten thousand things yet claim no righteousness is akin to losing a state yet retaining the people’s hearts. For the ten thousand things are all natural—where could the names of benevolence and righteousness be lodged? To be older than high antiquity yet claim no eld speaks to the Dao’s timelessness. To sustain heaven and earth is the Dao’s substance; to sculpt the myriad forms is its function. Such is the realm in which I wander.

Detailed Daoist annotation: Those of old who discoursed on the Dao underwent two transformations to reach righteousness, eight to reach right and wrong. Benevolence and righteousness are the Dao’s dispersion; right and wrong are further refinements of righteousness. Thus, the harm of the seven virtues is like branding, and the harm of right and wrong is like mutilation. To lose one’s knowledge is to attain non-knowing, which surpasses the loss of beauty or strength. Xu You says the blindness and deafness caused by benevolence, righteousness, right, and wrong cannot lead to the Dao. Yi’erzi claims that beauty, strength, and knowledge, once refined and discarded, can all lead to the Dao. Thus, what was previously marred can be mended and ceased; what is later perfected comes through instruction. To shatter the ten thousand things is not to oppose them; to bless the ages is not to love them. To be older than high antiquity is to be ever-new; to sculpt the myriad forms without artifice is to conceal its function. Can one who does not wander beyond benevolence, righteousness, right, and wrong achieve this?

Bi Xu’s annotation: To take sagely traces as punishments—where, then, can one wander in the fields of untrammeled freedom, unbound and self-attained? Those endowed with knowledge, strength, and beauty find these difficult to relinquish, yet all are lost upon hearing the Dao. This speaks of how even sages and worthies rely on forging and refining to perfect their natures—how much more so those of middling or lesser talent? Though now marred by sagely progress, how do we know the Creator will not mend and cease this? For the nature’s emptiness and numinosity—what harm do branding and mutilation bring? Now, riding this perfected nature to follow the Master—what doubt remains? The Dao as teacher has never borne the names of benevolence and righteousness. That you now bear the disgrace of branding and mutilation—is this not strange? Only when light and shadow both vanish can one wander the realm of the Dao.

Zhao’s annotation: Xu You said to Yi’erzi: Since Yao has branded and mutilated you with benevolence, righteousness, right, and wrong, you can no longer enjoy the joy of untrammeled wandering. Yi’erzi wishes to wander within its fence, so Xu You admonishes him with the blind and deaf. Yi’erzi then awakens to how benevolence, righteousness, right, and wrong in his heart indeed harm the Dao. He cites beauty, strength, and knowledge as examples, saying that once refined in the great crucible, all becomes clear. How do we know my branding will not cease and my mutilation be mended? "O my teacher!" refers to the Dao I take as my teacher. What I call benevolence and righteousness are not what you call benevolence and righteousness. The yin’s desolation and the killing of the ten thousand things—this is not righteousness. The yang’s expansion and the birth of the ten thousand things—this is not benevolence.

Spanning from ancient times to the present—this is not old age. Encompassing all with its winding completeness—this is not craft. Such is my Way, and nothing more; it is here that one must wander.

Yongzhai says: "Yáodàng" means to roam freely. "Zìwéi" means to move without constraint. "Zhuǎnxǐ" means to transform and shift. The metaphor of the blind and deaf means you lack the capacity to hear the Dao. Yi’erzi says: abandon old habits and awaken on your own—this transformation occurs in an instant. I wish to follow the principles of nature in serving my teacher. Xu You sighs that this is not yet certain, for he does not yet know if you can truly do so.

From "O my teacher!" onward, the text reveals the great theme of this chapter: to act without acting, to be natural and spontaneous, without imposing my own intentions. Thus, it cannot be named benevolence or righteousness. As the *Yijing* says: "It drums all things into motion yet shares no sage’s worries"—this is the same idea. The phrases "older than high antiquity" and the following two lines all describe the natural Dao.

When the mind wanders in the natural, one sees that heaven and earth are born together with me, and the ten thousand things and I are one. Such is the realm in which I wander—nothing more.

Xu You embodies absolute non-action, forgetting even the world. Yao cannot escape action, seeking to benefit all under heaven. To forget all is to be at ease while the world transforms; to benefit all is to toil while the world rests. The sage’s emergence and withdrawal create the distinction between the inner and outer realms. What differs is the outward trace; what is the same is the heart.

To personally practice benevolence and righteousness, to clearly distinguish right and wrong—this is the learning of the inner realm. To roam freely, move without constraint, and transform without cease—this is the wandering of the outer realm. Yi’erzi, branded and mutilated by the rites and teachings of the inner realm, hears these words and awakens in his heart. He wishes to abandon the inner realm and wander in the outer, a noble aspiration indeed—but Xu You does not yet grant it.

Yi’erzi then cites three men of exceptional natural endowment who, upon hearing the Dao, were transformed. Thus, my coming here is also within the process of refinement and tempering. Those who study the Dao seek to return to their original state, preserve their wholeness, and avoid harm. Once branded and mutilated, to hope the Creator will cease the branding and mend the mutilation—is this not difficult? If one truly understands that things shape themselves, then what is called branding and mutilation also lies in self-cessation and self-mending. What has the Creator to do with it?

Yi’erzi says: if by chance the branding can cease and the mutilation be mended, I will become whole again. Seizing this opportunity for wholeness, I will follow my teacher and advance toward the Dao—it is not too late. People often persist in their errors without correction, lost without thought of return. Yi’erzi’s awakening to yesterday’s wrongs and today’s truths can be called a true return.

What people take as their teacher is the Dao. "O my teacher!" refers to the Dao. The following four lines elucidate the Dao of the great master, transcending benevolence and righteousness to span past and present. It arises from non-action and transformation without transformation—how could worldly skill or craft compare? To "wander" is to roam contentedly within it, finding boundless freedom everywhere. Thus, the text does not speak of it repeatedly.

Yan Hui says: "I am healed!"

Confucius said: "What do you mean?"
Yan Hui replied: "I have forgotten benevolence and righteousness!"
Confucius said: "Good! But it is still not enough."

Another day, they met again, and Yan Hui said: "I am healed!"
Confucius asked: "What do you mean?"
Yan Hui replied: "I have forgotten ritual and music!"
Confucius said: "Good! But it is still not enough."

On yet another day, they met again, and Yan Hui said: "I am healed!"
Confucius asked: "What do you mean?"
Yan Hui replied: "I have attained *zuowang*—sitting in forgetfulness!"
Confucius started in surprise and said: "What is *zuowang*?"
Yan Hui said: "I have cast off my limbs and body, dimmed my hearing and sight, departed from form and abandoned knowledge, merging with the Great Thoroughfare—this is called *zuowang*."
Confucius said: "To merge is to be without preferences; to transform is to be without constancy. You are truly worthy! I, Qiu, would follow after you."

Guo’s commentary: Yanzi’s healing lies in reduction, while the Master spoke of benevolence as the advance of universal love and righteousness as the achievement of things. Love is not benevolence, yet benevolence is enacted through it; achievement is not righteousness, yet righteousness is manifest in it. To retain benevolence and righteousness is insufficient to comprehend the spontaneous arising of love and benefit—thus, forgetting them is permissible. Yet merely forgetting their traces still does not reach profound attainment. Ritual is the function of the body, and music is the instrument of joyful life; forgetting the instruments is not as good as forgetting that which produces them. *Zuowang* means not only advancing toward the goal but also forgetting the means of advancement—internally unaware of one’s own body, externally oblivious to heaven and earth. Only then can one merge vast and empty with transformation, becoming one with it in all things. Without difference from things, there is no place that is not fitting—thus, without preferences or aversions, one merges with transformation. Since transformation is always fitting, there is no constancy.

Lü’s commentary: Humanity has been human for so long—though enlightenment may dawn in a single word, returning to nothingness is not the work of a day. When Yan Hui heard of fasting the mind and ceased to be himself, he awakened to the Dao in a single word. His forgetting of benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music, culminating in *zuowang*, was not the achievement of a day. To merge is to see all things as one, hence without preferences; to transform is to have no fixed limit, hence without constancy. To merge with the Great Thoroughfare is simply to merge with transformation.

Lin’s commentary: Forgetting benevolence and righteousness and advancing to forget ritual and music still does not depart from boundaries—there is still something. Advancing further to nothingness, the limbs and body are cast off, hearing and sight are dimmed. Departing from form and abandoning knowledge, merging with the Great Thoroughfare—this is the ultimate. Casting off and dimming still involve effort; departing and abandoning are natural. Merging with the Great Thoroughfare is becoming one with things. Preferences and aversions arise from difference; in oneness, there are no preferences or aversions. To command the myriad things is called transformation; in transformation, there is no constancy. Yan Hui could become one with things and merge with transformation. I, too, wish to follow after him—this is Confucius’ humble expression.

Xiang Dao’s commentary: If one takes streams as the sea, one sees the streams but not the sea; if one gathers the hundred streams into the sea, one sees the sea but not the streams. The Dao is the sea; benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music are the streams. Yan Hui attained the Dao and forgot benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music—this is seeing the sea and forgetting the streams, yet the Dao is still not forgotten. When one departs from form and forgets things, abandons knowledge and forgets the mind, resting serenely without entanglement—where, then, is the Dao? It is forgotten along with the self—this is Yan Hui’s worthiness. Righteousness is close to ritual, and benevolence is close to music; thus, one forgets ritual after forgetting righteousness, and forgets music after forgetting benevolence. Yan Hui’s forgetting still had something not forgotten, and his healing involved reduction. Not forgetting what is to be forgotten, one returns to true forgetting; reducing again and again, one reaches non-reduction. Without attaining the subtlety of *zuowang*, how could one reach this?

Bi Xu’s commentary: Yanzi’s healing refers to reducing the external to heal the internal. Loving things is called benevolence; benefiting things is called righteousness. Love and benefit belong to the external—forgetting them is permissible, but it is not yet the Dao. Ritual is the dignity of the body; music is the harmony of the heart-mind. The heart-mind and body belong to the internal—forgetting them is permissible, but it is not yet the Dao. *Zuowang* is forgetting without cease. Casting off the limbs and body means responding and then forgetting; dimming hearing and sight means illuminating and then forgetting. Responding and then forgetting is departing from form and abandoning knowledge; illuminating and then forgetting is merging with the Great Thoroughfare. One’s body merges with the great emptiness, hence without preferences or aversions; the heart-mind merges with creation and transformation, hence without permanence or constancy.

Zhao’s commentary: A noble person cannot abandon benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music for a single day. When Yanzi’s heart-mind fused with principle, the names of these four vanished, and he forgot them. Casting off the limbs and body is departing from form; dimming hearing and sight is abandoning knowledge. Merging with the Great Thoroughfare is becoming one with the Dao. The Master’s intent was that preferences and aversions are both relinquished, constancy and change are both dissolved—this is what is called merging, this is what is called transformation. If you are truly capable of this, I will take you as my teacher—though I suspect it may not be so. To speak of casting off and dimming, of departing and abandoning, is still to have intention—it cannot be called true attainment.

Yongzhai said: The discourse on *zuowang* is Zhuangzi’s use of Yanzi’s name to depict the subtlety of attaining the Dao. To speak of attainment, one first forgets benevolence and righteousness, then forgets ritual and music—this is putting the world outside oneself, then putting the myriad things outside. Reaching *zuowang*, both being and non-being are relinquished; the four limbs and senses are no longer self-aware, merging with the Dao of the Great Thoroughfare. Becoming one with the Dao is transformation; in transformation, there is no abiding, and the heart-mind arises. Benevolence and righteousness originate in the heart-mind—when the heart-mind attains emptiness, forgetting them is easy. Ritual and music arise from habit—once habits are long established, forgetting them is difficult. Yanzi had already forgotten both, thus accomplishing what others find difficult. Yet the Master still deemed it insufficient, wishing to advance him toward the ultimate of the Dao—here one sees the intent behind refining Yanzi.

When others reach this point, they would gaze at the precipice and turn back! Yet Yanzi advanced further into the subtleties of *zuowang*, prompting the Master to exclaim in astonishment and inquire in reverse, marveling at how swiftly he had attained it. Yan Hui replied that by relinquishing form and discarding knowledge, one merges with the Great Thoroughfare; only after forgetting the self can one forget things—this is *zuowang*. To merge without knowing why one merges is the Dao of the Great Thoroughfare—how could it be a matter of willfully seeking union?

It is like the ceaseless movement of the great transformation, which never pauses for an instant. As one abides within it, one moves in unison with it—from the ignorance of childhood to the wisdom of maturity, from the toil of adulthood to the ease of old age, through the vicissitudes of withdrawal and engagement, activity and stillness, rise and fall, change and transition—what constancy could there be? For it is not that one desires transformation and seeks it; the principles of things unfold naturally, the same from ancient times to the present. Only those who attain the Dao may choose not to transform, yet even they cannot help but forget—these two lines serve as the Master’s verification of the *zuowang* episode.

He wished for others to seek unity amid diversity, to find constancy in transformation, to embody truth through forgetting, and to merge with the Dao in emptiness—then would they reach the ultimate! The utmost! If one can truly refrain from allowing external habits to obscure the pristine purity within, then *zuowang* becomes but a natural part of the path of learning the Dao. The Master extolled Yanzi as worthy, thereby encouraging his progress and guiding his disciples.

Ziyu and Zisang were friends, and after ten days of continuous rain, Ziyu said: "Zisang must be in dire straits!"

He wrapped rice and went to feed him. Arriving at Zisang’s gate, he heard sounds like singing, like weeping—plucking the zither, Zisang cried: "Father! Mother! Heaven! Man!" His voice could not bear the strain, yet he hastened to recite his verse.

Ziyu entered and asked: "Why do you sing your poem in this manner?"
Zisang replied: "I ponder who has brought me to this extremity, yet I cannot find the answer. Would my parents wish me to be poor? Heaven covers all without partiality; earth bears all without favor—would heaven and earth single me out for poverty? I seek the one who has done this, yet I cannot find him. Thus, I have reached this extremity—it is fate!"

Guo’s commentary: These two men assist each other in what is no assistance at all. Now, wrapping rice to bring and feed him is simply the natural course of heaven’s principle, not an act done only after considering aid. Zisang plucks the zither and mournfully sings, seeking the one who has done this yet finding none—this shows that all things arise naturally, without any doer.

Lü’s commentary: In *The Great Master*, Zhuangzi concludes with Mengsun Cai and Yan Hui, holding them as those who, like Confucius’ disciples, embody their nature, embrace the spirit, and follow the Dao in navigating the world—only then do they reach perfection. Yet he feared that scholars might deem Zisang’s followers inferior to Mengsun’s, or Ziyu’s inferior to Ziduo’s, and so he combined them in discussion. Their words all come to rest in fate, accepting it with equanimity. Though the paths of these masters differ, they share the Dao as their great master and ultimately converge in fate.

Lin’s commentary: Zisang forgets form and abandons life, so when afflicted by illness, he does not regard it as illness—he ascribes it all to fate alone. His voice could not bear the strain, for his strength was diminished by illness, and thus he recited his verse with such urgency. Parents are the closest of kin; heaven and earth are the most impartial. Would they single me out for poverty? Seeking the one who has done this yet finding none, he concludes it is merely fate! All transformations return to a single fate—this is the ultimate of the Dao.

Bixu’s commentary: To clothe the cold and feed the hungry is like fish moistening each other with foam—it is not feigned sentiment. His voice could not bear the strain—he was exhausted. Hastening to recite his verse, it lacked coherence. At the extremity of poverty and illness, seeking the one who has done this yet finding none, he ultimately ascribes it to fate. Accepting fate, nothing remains impassable.

Zhao’s commentary: Zisang endures poverty and accepts fate, just as the Master, beset in Chen and Cai, never ceased his zither and song, and Yanzi, dwelling in a narrow alley, never altered his joy—their resolve was the same. Yongzhai said: "His voice could not bear the strain"—his strength was weak, and his voice faint. 'Hastening to recite his verse'—his emotions were constrained, and his words pressed. 'Would my parents wish me to be poor? Would heaven and earth single me out for poverty?'—these words are most exquisite. Seeking the one who has done this yet finding none, he ascribes it to fate, for the principle of nature stands above heaven and earth. Fate is the principle of nature—this is what is called the Great Master. In this passage, *Zhuangzi* surpasses *Liezi’s* "Power and Fate."

In ancient times, what was called friendship entailed mutual support in the Dao and virtue, the completion of character and achievement, aid in times of peril, and unwavering loyalty unto death. Observing Ziyu’s conduct toward Zisang, one sees no shame in the way of friendship: troubled by the rain, he feared Zisang’s illness, knowing his poverty; wrapping rice to bring and feed him, he knew Zisang’s hunger; entering the gate and hearing his song, he asked in alarm, fearing Zisang’s distress might lead to resentment and the loss of his integrity. Zisang’s words—"Would my parents wish me to be poor? Would heaven and earth single me out for poverty?"—can be called the discourse of a transcendent man, unshaken by hardship. Yet to still feel emotion in such extremity shows he had not yet forgotten it entirely. Later, ascribing it to fate, he overcame with reason and handled it with principle, leaving Ziyu speechless.

The *Nanhua* uses this to conclude the purport of *The Great Master*, echoing *The Western Inscription*: "Poverty, lowliness, sorrow, and grief jade you to completion"—for without long polishing and utmost cultivation, one is not fit for great tasks. Those who study the Dao should deeply embody this.

The multitudes of people and things are governed by the ruler. The multitudes of disciples are instructed by the teacher. Heaven produces the sage and worthy to serve as rulers and teachers, establishing the foundations of governance, expanding the wellsprings of transformation, so that people may know the reverence due to virtue and power, and the inquiry owed to nature and fate. Thus, the bonds of ruler and minister, father and son remain unbroken, and the world and state return to order.

Yet the root of rectifying the mind and sincerity of intention, the subtlety of transmitting the Dao and imparting learning—without a teacher, none can bear the task of the Way. How perfect! The great master is the one whom scholars revere, and the title "great" crowns him, as if calling him "father of all fathers." First, he establishes the foundation by discussing knowing heaven, knowing man, and clarifying duty and fate. Nurturing what is known with the knowledge of what is unknown unites man with heaven. Knowing arises from not-knowing—this is the fullness of knowledge. Thus, he follows with the true man and true knowledge: sleeping without dreams, waking without care, going forth without delight, returning without resistance, emptiness without adornment, joy in forgetting words. Though seemingly without action, the instruments of governance—punishments, rites, knowledge, and virtue—are subtly embodied, guiding one to the ultimate of the inner sage and outer king.

If one would die for a beloved father or loyal ruler, how much more would one do so for one who is truly transcendent? The value of the true surpasses even the commands of ruler and father, yet the world remains ignorant, merely pursuing the trivial and fleeting, not realizing that forgetting each other in rivers and lakes is far better. The great clod bears our forms, allowing us to grow old in ease and die in rest—this is the goodness of creation toward our bodies. Yet most people prize life and fear death, so he sets forth the metaphors of hiding the boat in the ravine and the mountain in the valley to dispel their delusion. Where there is form and life, principle follows without fail. Though ravines and marshes are deep and firm, they are not exempt from change—thus, one sees that the creator is formless yet powerful.

To enshrine the boundless cosmos within a finite body—how could one ensure it does not drift away? Only by concealing the world within the world itself can one avoid loss, for this is the realm where the sage roams, the ground upon which all transformations depend. Birth of heaven, birth of earth, myriad changes without end—why should one rejoice merely in possessing a human form? To traverse ancient ages without aging, to ascend the clouded heavens and dwell in the dark palace—these are the wondrous workings of the perfected person, the foundation upon which the *Great Master* is built, the very lifeblood upon which people and creatures, disciples and followers, depend.

When Youyu exists beyond past and present, life and death cannot bind him. When Si and Lai befriend one another without discord, self and other cannot divide them. Thus, whether holding a rooster in the left hand or a zither in the right, whether riding the spirit-horse or the wheel of the buttocks, one listens to the transformations of creation and finds peace in whatever is encountered—this is what the ancients called "suspended liberation." How could the trifling limbs of insects or the liver’s span warrant the deluded doubts of smelters and foundries?

Zifan and Qinzhang sang and played strings to mourn Sanghu, seeing worldly engagement as toil and return to the true as fortune—this is wandering beyond the mundane, apart from世俗俗. When one joins with creation as a companion, then longevity and early death, poverty and success cannot exhaust its changes; heaven and earth, cold and heat cannot constrain its form.

Mengsun’s body was startled, yet his heart remained unharmed. Though he dreamed of becoming a fish or a bird, soaring through the heavens or plunging into the abyss, he found peace in the transformations of the moment—how could mere bodily form alter his essence?
