Long ago, Master Nanhua dreamed of becoming a butterfly, and it was the same. As for what is now called waking or dreaming, only one who transcends waking and dreaming knows.

Yanzi cast off his body and muted his senses, sitting in forgetfulness to reach the ultimate. Transmitting the mind’s hidden principles, he carried on the lineage of the sacred gate. The indigo deeper than the plant—this was truly the power of the master’s transformative teaching.

As for Zisang playing the zither, now singing, now weeping, one could not grasp the source of his actions, and so ultimately ascribed them to fate. Though he possessed the Way of the *Great Master*, he could not put it into practice in his time. Thus, this chapter concludes with Zisang’s acceptance of fate. The perfected person, having attained the Dao, transcends fate, and worldly burdens cannot bind him.

The *Great Master* is devoted to magnifying the Dao and awakening the people, yet fate may bring success or failure, movement or stillness—this depends on the times, though the Dao suffers no loss. What is called true knowledge thoroughly investigates heaven and humanity, fully realizing nature and destiny without doubt.

To exhaust principle and fulfill one’s nature to the point of destiny—this is in regard to ordering oneself. To command the transformations of things while preserving their origin—this is in regard to governing things. Ordering one’s own destiny—this is Zisang. Governing the destiny of things—this can only be the *Great Master*!

*Collected Subtleties of the Meaning of the Nanhua True Scripture*, Scroll Nineteen—Concluded
*Collected Subtleties of the Meaning of the Nanhua True Scripture*, Scroll Twenty

Master Chu Boxiu of Wulin’s *First Chapter on "Fit to Be King"*

Nie Que questioned Wang Ni four times, and four times Wang Ni professed ignorance. Thereupon Nie Que leapt up in great joy and went to report this to Master Pu Yi.

Master Pu Yi said: “Have you only now come to know this? The Lord of Yu falls short of the Lord of Tai. The Lord of Yu harbored benevolence to entice people; though he gained their allegiance, he never emerged from the realm of the ‘non-human.’ The Lord of Tai moved with unhurried ease, awakened in tranquil openness—now taking himself for a horse, now for an ox. His knowledge was true to his nature, his virtue utterly genuine, and he never entered the realm of the ‘non-human.’”

Guo’s commentary: The Lords of Yu and Tai were both crossroads of worldly affairs, not the means to advance. What advances is the world—who names it? Thus, riding the transformations of leather, treading through ten thousand generations, the world may be level or perilous, yet traces may fall short. Those who take what they love as ‘human’ and what they hate as ‘non-human’ draw boundaries of right and wrong. To emerge from the realm of the ‘non-human’ is to enter a state where nothing is ‘non-human.’ Thus, there is no gain, no loss, no right, no wrong—how could this be merely harboring benevolence to entice people? Taking oneself for a horse or an ox—how could there be any ‘human’ or ‘non-human’ in this? Allowing self-knowledge, his nature was true; allowing self-attainment, there was no falsity. Not entering the realm of right and wrong—this is how he severed the age of the Lord of Yu.

Lü’s commentary: When Nie Que asked Wang Ni, “Do you know what things share as right?” and “Do you know what you do not know?”—then are things without knowledge? What is called ‘knowing’ is not ignorance, and what is called ‘not knowing’ is not knowledge. Wang Ni answered four times with “I do not know.” What things share as right extends only to what one does not know. Wang Ni’s ignorance was true ignorance, embodying it. Yu also means “anxious care,” and Tai means “tranquil stability.” To have knowledge and be anxious is not as good as to be without knowledge and be tranquilly stable. The Lord of Yu’s nearness harbored benevolence to entice people, and people followed him—thus he truly gained their allegiance. Yet by valuing benevolence as right, he inevitably deemed the absence of benevolence as wrong, never emerging from the ‘non-human.’ There was ‘human’ and ‘non-human,’ chaotic and confused. The Lord of Tai moved with unhurried ease, awakened in tranquil openness—taking himself for a horse or an ox, none found it objectionable. Thus, his knowledge was trustworthy and unquestioned, his attainment genuine and unfabricated. How could he know the absence of benevolence as wrong and enter the ‘non-human’? From Wang Ni’s perspective, it is clear that the Lord of Yu falls short of the Lord of Tai. ‘Falls short’ refers to advancement; the Lord of Tai is what the Lord of Yu advanced toward. To attain the traces of this advancement, one must release the mind and free the spirit, deeply entering what Wang Ni did not know.

Lin’s commentary: The Lord of Tai represents the pristine simplicity of high antiquity. By the time of Yao, simplicity had dispersed and laws were established. Shun further expanded upon Yao’s laws, which is why he fell short of the Lord of Tai. It is not that the Way of the sages differed, but that the changes of the times compelled the sages’ responses to differ as well. The Lord of Yu took benevolence as good and enticed the world—thus he gained the people’s allegiance, yet never emerged from the ‘non-human.’ If people possess benevolence, then they take the absence of benevolence as ‘non-human.’ From the perspective of the human Dao, the Lord of Yu indeed emerged from the ‘non-human’; from the perspective of the Heavenly Dao, even those who possess the ‘human’ are not free from the ‘non-human.’ *Xuxu* and *yuyu* both describe a relaxed, unhurried demeanor, depicting his simplicity. Sometimes taking himself for a horse, sometimes for an ox—he was at ease with it. Thus, his knowledge was true to his nature, and his virtue was utterly genuine. ‘Never entered the realm of the non-human’ means he was without right and wrong.

Xiang Dao’s commentary: The Dao takes not-knowing as its inner core and knowing as its outer form; not-knowing is profound, knowing is shallow. Thus, when Nie Que asked four times, Wang Ni answered each time with “I do not know,” and Nie Que awakened, rejoicing as he reported this to Master Pu Yi. Master Pu Yi then spoke of the traces of non-action. The Scripture says: “The Lord of Yu summoned benevolence and righteousness to disturb the people of the world,” and “The Lord of Yu’s medicine was a sore; Shun had a foul stench.” Both harbored benevolence to entice people toward the Dao, yet their simplicity was already lost—thus they never emerged from the ‘non-human.’ The Lord of Tai, however, forgot both self and others, free from entanglements. If you called him an ox, he answered to ox; if you called him a horse, he answered to horse. What he knew was true to his nature, what he attained was utterly genuine, and his Dao was simple and undiluted. Thus, it is said: “He never entered the realm of the ‘non-human.’” When Qin Shi said to Lao Dan, “I took you for a human, but now you are not,” the meaning of ‘non-human’ is like this.

Bi Xu’s commentary: When the sage practices the teaching without words, the four questions and four instances of not-knowing form the guiding thread of *Fit to Be King*. The Lord of Yu is an analogy for having knowledge; the Lord of Tai, for having no knowledge. Harboring people to entice people involves good and evil. ‘Never emerged from the non-human’ means following the same current as the vulgar. Taking oneself for a horse or an ox means forgetting both things and self. Knowing one’s nature without falsity—thus it is said his nature was true. What he practiced was not lost—thus it is said his virtue was genuine. ‘Never entered the realm of the non-human’ means transcending beyond the dust of the world.

Zhao’s commentary: The Master said: “Do I possess knowledge? I possess no knowledge.” This means that only when one reaches the state of no-knowledge is it true knowledge. Nie Que leapt up in awakening and reported this to Master Pu Yi. Master Pu Yi said: “Why have you come to know this so late? The Lord of Yu took benevolence as good, seeking to win the people’s hearts—this human accord never departed from Heaven.”

The Lord of Tai achieved self-possession in waking and sleeping alike. To take oneself for a horse was acceptable; to take oneself for an ox was also acceptable. Joy and anger did not arise, and both things and self were forgotten—this was the Way of the true person. His knowledge was genuine, matching the turning of the seasons without error. His virtue was utterly real, without the slightest falsity—this accord with Heaven never departed from the human. The Lord of Yu compared to the Lord of Tai was like Yao compared to Xu You.

Yongzhai observed: Four questions met with four silences—this was the meaning of the *Vimalakīrti Sūtra*’s "non-dual Dharma-gate of non-speech." Nie Que, awakened to this wordless teaching, rejoiced and reported it to Pu Yi. Pu Yi said: "Have you only now come to realize this? The Lord of Tai, an ancient sage-king, embraced benevolence to bind the people’s hearts—this too could win the people, yet it did not go beyond being like Heaven. It meant he merely followed Heaven as his companion, for the non-human was none other than Heaven. Thus it is said he ‘never departed from the non-human.’ ‘Never departed’ means nothing more than this. Not calling it Heaven but the ‘non-human’—this is his extraordinary phrasing. Taking oneself for a horse or an ox—he left such matters unquestioned, letting others call him what they would. What he knew was all real principle; his virtue was inherent, all celestial truth. At this stage, even ‘Heaven’ was insufficient to name it. Left to its own natural course, it transcended even creation. Thus it is said he ‘never entered the realm of the non-human.’ First he speaks of ‘departing,’ then of ‘entering’—observe his choice of words.

Nie Que’s questions to Wang Ni are the same four questions from the *Equalizing Things* chapter. This text cites them again at the outset to clarify that true knowledge is no-knowledge, and thus one knows all things. The Way of the sage-king, above all, should forget knowledge and let things follow their course—letting the keen-eared listen, the clear-sighted see, the wise plan, and the brave defend, while I sit upright in tranquil non-action to achieve governance without effort. Is this not magnificent? Thus Nie Que, moved by Wang Ni’s responses, rejoiced and told Pu Yi. Pu Yi said: "Only now do you understand that the Lord of Yu fell short of the Lord of Tai? For he took benevolence as good and could not help but display it. ‘Never departed from the non-human’—his virtue merely accorded with the human. The Lord of Tai, self-possessed in waking and sleeping, with knowledge and virtue both genuine, ‘never entered the realm of the non-human’—his Way accorded with Heaven, so where was there any departure or entry? His Way accorded with Heaven, and the people turned to him. This is the foremost principle of *Responding as Emperor and King*."

The character *zang* was formerly written as *cang* (藏); thus Cui’s commentary reads: "Embracing benevolence and righteousness to bind the people." Cheng’s subcommentary followed this. Lü’s edition used *zang* (臧), glossing it as "good." Later scholars such as Lin and Chen all adopted Lü’s interpretation. Some argue that *zang* and *cang* are interchangeable, but as the *Han History: Treatise on Food and Goods* states: "Light and small, easy to *zang*," this shows *zang* was borrowed for *cang*, not the reverse. Most modern editions use *zang*, and interpreting it as "good" is appropriate.

Jian Wu met the madman Jie Yu. Jie Yu asked: "What did Ri Zhongshi tell you?"

Jian Wu said: "He told me that one who rules others issues laws, standards, principles, and measures from himself—who would dare not obey and be transformed?"

Jie Yu the Madman replied: "This is deceitful *power*. In governing the world, it is like crossing the sea by digging a river or commanding a mosquito to bear a mountain. Does the sage’s governance extend beyond this? First rectify, then act—this is simply ensuring one’s capacity for the task. Moreover, the cormorant flies high to evade the harm of nets and arrows, the mole digs deep beneath the sacred mound to avoid the calamity of pitfalls—yet you deem these two creatures ignorant!

Guo’s commentary: If one entrusts all to the myriad things, affairs resolve themselves without effort; but if one seeks to govern the world through a single person, no achievement is possible, and the burden is insurmountable. Thus, the sage’s governance consists in preserving what lies within his proper sphere, rectifying each being’s nature and destiny, and refraining from what he cannot do. Even birds and beasts each have their means of self-preservation—this is why emperors and kings rely on them without interference, allowing the myriad things to perfect themselves. Have you not yet learned from these two creatures, who preserve themselves without need of instruction?"

Lü’s commentary: One who rules others makes his voice the law and his person the measure, yet employs others solely at his own discretion—this is what is meant by ‘issuing laws from oneself.’ When affairs are governed by principle, and others must gauge his intentions, this is what is meant by ‘applying standards, principles, and measures to others.’ Such are merely the uses of manifest influence, not the transformation of things through command. Thus, what is called ‘law’ may not be law, what is called ‘principle’ may not be principle—it is nothing but deceitful *power*. It is like crossing the sea by digging a river, which cannot succeed, or commanding a mosquito to bear a mountain, which cannot be borne. The weightiest of things, the sacred vessel that cannot be forced—if one issues laws, standards, principles, and measures to others from himself, this is merely external governance. First rectify, then act, ensuring one’s capacity for the task—this is not what is meant by external governance. If it were so, there would be no partiality or bias, and people would not perceive his inclinations; no duplicity or deceit, and people would not discern his aversions; no likes or dislikes, and people could neither approach nor avoid him."

What I do all emerges from the realm of profound sameness—thus the true and false of the world are revealed, and who would dare wield cunning devices to plumb the depths of my ninefold abyss for its pearl?

Now, the crow soars high and the rat burrows deep to seek refuge—could one call these two creatures devoid of knowledge? Yet if man, surpassing these creatures in understanding, cannot rid himself of self and allow others no means to pry, then he is not their equal.

Master Lin notes: To govern the world by imposing one’s own laws and standards is ultimately no more successful than crossing the sea by digging a river or commanding a mosquito to bear a mountain—it is to undertake what one cannot bear.

In ancient times, the sages governed the world by allowing the people to dwell in peace and all things to follow their nature—why then would they toil over laws and standards to govern externally? The sages, in accordance with the nature of people and things, ensured competence in affairs and entrusted them accordingly, confining themselves to their proper roles.

The crow soars high and the rat burrows deep to avoid harm—this they do without instruction. The people possess their constant nature; let them fulfill their allotted roles, and why impose laws, standards, principles, and measures to disrupt their inherent nature?

The *Daode* commentary states: At midday, one does not govern the multitude with obscurity; at the outset, one does not respond to things with arbitrary power. Not governing the multitude with obscurity is to impose laws from oneself; not responding to things with arbitrary power is to impose standards and measures upon others. Thus, it is like crossing the sea by digging a river without following its principles, or commanding a mosquito to bear a mountain without measuring its capacity. Not following its principles is not what is meant by "first rectifying, then acting"; not measuring its capacity is not what is meant by "ensuring one’s competence for the task."

Even the crow and the rat know to soar high and burrow deep to avoid harm—how then could the sage’s governance rely on imposing laws from oneself to seek respite?

Master Bixu notes: When the expansive Way of managing the world and the transformative power of principle are employed, which of the common people would dare not listen and be transformed? Those who do not cultivate themselves but instead adorn others engage in deceitful *power*.

To "govern externally" is to say one must first govern internally; if one does not first rectify and then act, one cannot lead the multitude. Even the lowly creatures of bird and rat shun harm to preserve their lives—how much more should man do so?

To impose laws, standards, and measures is the instrument of governing the age, not the means by which one who rules possesses virtue. Master Zhao notes: The sun at its zenith first informed Jianwu that the sage’s governance of the world, establishing laws and setting forth regulations as models for all ages, would ensure the world’s submission. Jieyu said the sea is boundless—attempting to cross it by digging a river, or commanding the tiniest of insects to bear a mountain—is like relying on mere laws, standards, and measures to order the world and guide it toward transformation, which is entirely without principle.

"I favor stillness, and the people naturally become upright; I practice non-action, and the people naturally transform"—the sage exhausts what lies within himself. How could he make external governance his duty? Even the crow and the rat know to avoid danger and seek safety without instruction—could man be inferior to these two creatures?

Master Yongzhai says: Laws, standards, and principles all emerge from oneself, using one’s person to transform the world. To "measure others" is to transform the people. The structure of "laws, standards, and principles" is akin to "harmony and ease." "Deceitful *power*" means self-deception, not true virtue. To "govern externally" is to transform through one’s person, leaving traces. "First rectify, then act" is to follow the principles of nature and destiny. "Ensuring competence for the task" is to fulfill this natural course.

The crow and the rat in their evasion and rest—this speaks of how those bound by limits are burdened by trammels, yet even they are not inferior to these two creatures in their innate knowledge. The one who "acts at midday" is he who strives for clarity and delights in taking the lead; thus, I tell Jianwu of the way to rule as a sovereign: if one issues laws, standards, and principles from oneself, then governs others by these measures, they disrupt the natural dispositions of life and destiny—who among the people would dare not obey and be transformed? Yet such compliance is but outward submission, not heartfelt sincerity.

Thus, Jieyu points to this as "deceitful *power*," meaning it is not true virtue; it not only deceives others but also deceives oneself. To govern the world by such means is to rely on emptiness and achieve nothing—it is surely beyond one’s capacity. How could the sage’s governance be concerned with externals? Laws, standards, and principles are all tools for governing what lies outside. "First rectify, then act"—this is to firmly grasp one’s task, to speak of the principles of virtue, nature, and destiny, which are the inner duties of one’s person. Rooted within, they may then be extended to ordering the family, governing the state, and bringing peace to the world. Moreover, even birds and rats know to fly high or burrow deep to avoid harm—how much more should one who aspires to rule others not practice deceitful *power* and invite calamity, for they would be inferior even to these two creatures.

Thus, the ancients who responded to the call of emperors and kings did so without desire or action, and the world transformed itself. If one relies on cunning and ability to govern, the ruler toils above while the people descend into chaos below—how can order be expected? If one issues laws, standards, and principles from oneself, who among the people would dare not obey and be transformed?

Most commentaries parse the phrase as "following the classics and the people," but Lin and Zhao parse it as "following the measure." The *Bixu* edition, collated by Zhang Junfang, reads: "Issuing laws, standards, and principles from oneself, how could the common people dare not obey and be transformed?" Further examination of the *Wu Men Guan* edition reveals a unique variant: "issuing regulations from oneself," with "regulate" as the distinct character. After weighing the various interpretations, Lin and Zhao’s parsing is superior, and I follow it here.

Tian Gen wandered to Yin Yang, arriving at the banks of the Liao River, where he encountered the Nameless Man and asked him, "May I inquire about governing the world?" The Nameless Man replied, "Begone! You are a vulgar man—why do you ask such an inopportune question? I am about to join the Creator in shaping humanity. When weary, I ride the boundless bird, soaring beyond the six directions to wander in the land of Nothingness, dwelling in the vast wilderness. Why do you trouble me with governing the world and disturb my heart?"

He asked again. The Nameless Man said, "Let your heart wander in simplicity, unite your *qi* with the void, follow things as they are without imposing private intentions—and the world will be governed."

Guo’s commentary: To ask about governing the world is not to transcend the Great Beginning or abide in the Mysterious Darkness. To "join the Creator in shaping humanity" is to let people act of their own accord. "Boundless" describes the tattered and fragmented. Riding the tattered, one gallops through the ten thousand things, thus able to move freely and dwell in the realm of spontaneous attainment, governing without governing. Following one’s nature is simplicity; stillness within one’s nature is the void. Letting nature generate itself is impartiality; seeking to augment it with the heart’s desires is partiality. Partiality is indeed insufficient to generate, while following impartiality preserves wholeness.

Lü’s commentary: The Nameless Man embodies the Dao; one who embodies the Dao has nothing to accept or reject. Here, it speaks of acceptance and rejection as if in common with others. Acceptance is joining the Creator in shaping humanity; rejection is riding the boundless bird beyond the six directions. Why? For such a one, existence and nonexistence lie within oneself, and entry and exit know no bounds—who would willingly take governing the world as their concern? Why do you trouble me with governing the world and disturb my heart? To "let your heart wander in simplicity" and "unite your *qi* with the void" without imposing private intentions—this is the way to effortlessly take hold of the world.

Lin’s commentary: Tian Gen is the root of nature. "Nameless" refers to the sage’s unpredictability, meaning he does not reveal himself beforehand but only responds when questioned. "Joining the Creator in shaping humanity"—when weary, he rides the obscure and soaring beyond the six directions, illustrating that the sage’s Dao is present everywhere yet truly without action. This is sufficient to respond to emperors and kings. "Why do you trouble me with governing the world and disturb my heart?"—this means it is insufficient to move me. Tian Gen asked again. The answer was to let the heart wander in simplicity, which purifies the spirit, and to unite *qi* with the void, which nurtures *qi*. Thus, things come without resistance, great harmony prevails without partiality, and without striving for governance, the world is governed.

Xiang Dao’s commentary: Tian Gen speaks of the root; the Nameless Man speaks of the sage. Tian Gen arises from the root to address the branches, emerging from obscurity to seek clarity, and asks about governing the world—the Nameless Man thus disdains him. To "join the Creator in shaping humanity" already involves action. Thus, when weary, he rides the boundless, soars beyond the six directions, wanders in Nothingness, and dwells in the vast wilderness. "Boundless" is a metaphor for the heart’s wandering—this is to "let the heart wander in simplicity, unite *qi* with the void, and follow things without partiality." If so, the world governs itself without governance—why impose methods of rule?

Bi Xu’s commentary: "Joining the Creator in shaping humanity" is to willfully create. Riding the boundless, soaring beyond the six directions—this is to tread the subtle and mysterious, transcending yin and yang. Wandering in Nothingness, dwelling in the vast wilderness—this is the realm of the Dao, the domain of emptiness. Following things as they are without imposing private intentions—partiality loses the natural.

Zhao’s commentary: Tian Gen is a title for the sovereign. "Nameless" is the designation of the true person. Yin Yang is a place of flourishing brightness. The Liao River is a land of desolation. The Creator covers and supports heaven and earth, sculpting the myriad forms—yet it is fundamentally without intention. I am already weary of it and transcend beyond form and *qi*—why trouble me with governing the world and disturb my heart? The Nameless Man asked again. He answered with the principle of following things as they are—any intention to act is partiality.

The error in Tian Gen’s question lies in the word "act"—with non-action, the world governs itself.

Yongzhai notes: To be a person with the Creator is to dwell in the world while following the natural. Roaming within the world is sufficient; one may then wander beyond the Creator’s domain. Mangmiao is the *qi* of emptiness and nothingness. "What exists" and "vast wilderness" are the great void, boundless and infinite. Why trouble my heart with governing the world?

The character *bo* in the silk manuscript, in Cui’s version, is written as *wei*, both conveying the sense of "why." Vague and formless, *qi* is akin to *xing*—with this heart and this *xing* both aligning with the natural. Earlier, it was said: "Do not listen with the heart but listen with *qi*." Thus, *qi* here should be interpreted as *xing*. Following the Creator without imposing private intention, the world governs itself—why act for the world?

The Nameless Man is akin to "Master Vacuous" or "Sir Non-Existent." Tian Gen symbolizes the root of the natural, which should remain hidden, nurturing and allowing things to transform on their own. Yet now, drawn toward the realm of flourishing brightness, he reveals himself in pursuit of action—hence his question about governing the world. The Nameless One, whom the sage disdains, asks in a way that displeases my heart. He then declares the joy of non-action and unfettered wandering, using it to enlighten him.

"To be a person with the Creator" means to move in harmony with transformation, following without aiding. Mangmiao, like *yaoming*, is a metaphor for flight without trace. Kuanglang describes a vast, open expanse. He says: "I roam freely and at ease—how could you, with governance of the world, disturb my heart?"

Tian Gen asked again. The Nameless Man instructed him to let his heart wander in blandness, free from desires, and to harmonize his *qi* with the formless, untroubled void. Following things as they are without imposing private intention—any intention to act for the world introduces partiality and loses the natural. This is called "governing," yet it is the very source of chaos.

The way to govern the world is nothing other than skillfully returning to the root of the natural. When the self is cultivated, the world is governed. Tian Gen, unaware of turning inward to seek within himself, clings to his treasure and loses his way—how lamentable!

*The Ocean of Meanings in the Authentic Scripture of the Southern Florescence*, Scroll Twenty, concludes.

[Note #1: Following Guo’s commentary, *zang* is written as *cang*.]
[Note #2: In the Shidetang edition, the character *yu* is written as *yu*.]

*The Ocean of Meanings in the Authentic Scripture of the Southern Florescence*, Scroll Twenty-One.
By Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin.

**Chapter Two: Responding as Emperor and King**

Yang Ziju saw Lao Dan and said: "Suppose there is a man here—swift in action, strong and resolute, penetrating in understanding, clear in discernment, and tireless in studying the Dao. Could such a one be compared to an enlightened king?"

Lao Dan replied: "In the eyes of a sage, he is but a petty functionary bound by skill, one who wearies the body and startles the mind. Moreover, the patterns of tigers and leopards bring hunters, the agility of apes and monkeys invites snares, and the cunning of dogs draws leashes—could such be compared to an enlightened king?"

Yang Ziju, startled, said: "I venture to ask: how does an enlightened king govern?"

Lao Dan said: "The governance of an enlightened king—his achievements cover the world yet seem not his own; he transforms and bestows upon the ten thousand things, yet the people do not rely on him. No name is raised, and things rejoice of themselves. He stands in the unfathomable and roams in the realm of nothingness."

**Guo’s Commentary:**
"Bound by skill and startling the mind—such efforts leave no room for the self and are unworthy of comparison to a sage-king. For one whose body is entangled by patterns and abilities does not traverse the empty to cultivate the boundless. Without an enlightened king, none in the world can attain self-realization; yet his work lies in non-action, returning the burden to the world, so that all may carry their own tasks. Thus, though his achievements cover the world, he does not claim them as his own; though things are transformed, he does not rely on them as his power. Things all believe they have attained their own joy, and though he dwells in the path of ceaseless change, he remains without fixed form. Identifying with the ten thousand things, he roams in emptiness. If one cannot merge with things, how can one roam in the void?"

**Lü’s Commentary:**
"Swift in action" means hastening to affairs. "Strong and resolute" means not overcoming with softness. "Penetrating in understanding" means not attaining true non-knowledge. "Clear in discernment" means clarity that does not arise from itself. "Tireless in studying the Dao" means not yet having reduced the self to embody the Dao. Having skills wearies the body and thoughts; being bound disturbs the mind—like artisans exchanging short and long, having and lacking, such is not how a sage employs the world. Tigers, leopards, apes, and dogs are hunted or leashed because they invite it—thus, those who weary the body and disturb the mind to be used by the world have brought it upon themselves through strength and clarity. "Leashed" means being employed by others through skill and force. If one does not claim power and does not rely on transformation, then those who possess abilities cannot raise a name for him, and things merely rejoice of themselves. The reason for this is that he stands in the unfathomable and roams in nothingness. Thus, the earlier comparison to an enlightened king was indeed misguided."

**Lin’s Commentary:**
"Enlightened" is the dispersion of spirit; "king" is the movement of the sage. "Responding as Emperor and King" means emerging to govern the world. Thus, when asked whether swiftness and clarity could be compared to an enlightened king, the answer is: if such could be so compared, then all petty functionaries bound by skill, wearying the body and disturbing the mind, could aspire to sagehood. Could tigers and leopards, hunted for their patterns, or apes and dogs, leashed for their agility, be compared to an enlightened king? Yang Ziju, astonished, inquired about the governance of an enlightened king. The reply was: his achievements cover the world yet are not claimed as his own; he transforms the ten thousand things yet does not rely on them. This means that the enlightened kings of old had no designs on the world, yet the world turned to them, extending their spirit to embody the virtue of heaven and earth, and moving their minds to respond to the changes of things—all beginning from this. Thus, though he has achievements, he does not raise them as his name; though he transforms things, he does not rejoice in it himself. Therefore, the world ascribes merit to him, and things rejoice of themselves. Standing above the unfathomable, yin and yang cannot restrain him; roaming in the realm of nothingness, the ten thousand things cannot burden him."

**Xiang Dao’s Commentary:**
"Swift in action and strong and resolute" differ from the infant’s simplicity. "Penetrating in understanding and clear in discernment" differ from one who is enlightened yet appears dim. "Tireless in studying the Dao" differs from one who abandons learning and is without care. The enlightened king is the sage, and the sage transforms the world through non-action. Now, to be diligent in these three and entangled with things is like exchanging skills for profit—how could this not weary the body and disturb the mind, inviting exhaustion? The governance of an enlightened king does not claim achievements, so what effort does he exert upon the people? Transforming things without reliance, what do the people gain from him? Thus, his name is not raised, his traces are not manifest, his substance is not amassed, and no exhaustion reaches him. He makes emptiness the root of all fullness and supplies the ten thousand things’ needs with nothingness."

**Bi Xu’s Commentary:**
"Swift in action" means rushing toward affairs. "Strong and resolute" means intolerance of adversity. "Penetrating in understanding" and "clear in discernment" mean prizing cleverness. To presume knowledge of this and neglect natural spontaneity is to bind oneself with skills, weary the body, and disturb the mind. Tigers, leopards, apes, and monkeys are metaphors for how abilities invite harm—like achievements that seem not one’s own. Forgetting the self, the people do not rely on him; forgetting achievements, no name is raised; forgetting the name, he roams in nothingness; forgetting all, such is the governance of an enlightened king."

**Zhao’s Commentary:**
"Swift in action" means swift in purpose. "Strong and resolute" means firm and decisive. "Penetrating in understanding" and "forceful in action" mean such a one could be compared to an enlightened king. The answer is: the Dao values softness, obscurity, and non-action—such a one opposes the Dao and is burdened by talent. How could this not weary the body and disturb the mind, bringing harm? Like tigers, leopards, apes, and dogs hunted or leashed, all invite disaster through their abilities and are unfit to govern the world. Yang Ziju further inquired, still attached to action. Laozi, abiding in non-action, replied: achievements are completed yet seem not to arise from oneself; things are transformed yet one does not rely on them as ability. Things each find their own harmony, and none can name his merit—just as Confucius praised Yao, saying the people could not name his achievements, yet they were majestic."

Yongzhai remarked: The earlier criticism of "forceful vigor" and the like, though not naming names, was a veiled reproach of Confucius. *Xu* refers to convict laborers; *yi* means "to alternate," akin to conscripted service. The phrase *yao* has ancient precedent, much like the Han term "ghost-firewood gatherers." Those bound by *shou* were artisans ensnared by their own intricate skills. Such a path of learning wearies both body and mind—just as tigers and leopards, with their patterned hides, invite hunting, or apes and dogs, through their agility and cunning, bring themselves to be leashed. This is severe censure indeed.

Ziju pressed further with his questions. Laozi at last revealed: "When merit blankets the world yet seems not to arise from oneself, so that things rejoice of their own accord—this is the meaning of 'achievement without possession,' the sense of 'what power does the emperor add?' To stand in the unfathomable is to wander in the realm of nothingness, where the brush dances of its own accord."

The foregoing passages all misconstrue the intent of the original chapter. The term *xiangji* has been variously interpreted; the *Pronunciation and Meaning* cites Emperor Jianwen of Liang, who took *xiang* as "echo," akin to the "resonant" in the passage on Cook Ding—reading it as "echo." Yet weighing the chapter’s overarching meaning, Lü, Lin, and Bixu’s literal interpretation of the character is superior. Here, I propose: *xiangji* denotes swiftness in responding to things; *qiangliang* describes one who does not abide in softness; *wuche* means delighting in thoroughfare with things; *shuming* refers to one who does not preserve obscurity. The study of the Dao prizes non-action, yet to take tireless effort as merit is like bartering and binding oneself through skill—inevitably wearying body and mind. What is sought is not the true Way.

Moreover, the question "Could this be compared to an enlightened king?" is Lao Dan’s rhetorical counter: If one deems the earlier traits—swift response, forceful vigor, and the like—worthy of comparison to an enlightened king, then are tigers and leopards, hunted for their patterned hides, or apes and dogs, leashed for their agility and prowess, also fit to be compared to enlightened kings? Only then did Ziju awaken. Abashed, he inquired about the governance of an enlightened king. Laozi replied: to forget merit, to bestow virtue freely, to flee from fame, to vanish from form—only then can one speak of enlightened governance. For what Ziju discussed was outward conduct, while what Lao Dan expounded was the heart. The division between heart and conduct has long been thus.

The phrase *zhi mao* is untenable; *mao* has two pronunciations, *li* and *lai*, but how could a dog seize an ox of such great size? The *Pronunciation and Meaning* records that Li’s edition reads *li* ("raccoon dog"), which is apt.

In Zheng there was a divine diviner named Ji Xian, who could foretell a person’s life or death, fortune or misfortune, longevity or early demise—down to the year, month, or day—with godlike precision. When the people of Zheng saw him, they fled in haste. Liezi, however, was entranced upon meeting him. Returning home, he told Huzhi: "At first, I took your Way as supreme, but now I see there is something even greater." Huzhi replied: "I have shown you only its outward form, not its true substance. How could you have attained the Dao? A flock of hens without a rooster—how could they lay eggs? By flaunting your Way before the world and insisting on its truth, you have made it possible for others to read your fortune. Bring him to me tomorrow, and let him see me."

The next day, Liezi brought Ji Xian to meet Huzhi. Upon leaving, Ji Xian said to Liezi: "Alas! Your master is dead—he will not live. He will not last ten days!"

I saw something uncanny—like damp ashes.
Liezi entered, tears soaking his lapels as he told Huzhi.
Huzhi said: "I showed him the earthly pattern, sprouting yet neither stirring nor upright. He must have seen my sealed virtue-mechanism. Bring him again tomorrow."

The next day, Liezi brought him to see Huzhi again. Upon leaving, Ji Xian said to Liezi: "How fortunate your master is to have met me! He has hope now—he is fully alive! I saw his sealed power unfold."
Liezi entered and told Huzhi.
Huzhi said: "I showed him the boundless expanse of heaven and earth, where names and realities do not intrude, and the mechanism springs from the heels. He must have seen my virtuous mechanism at its finest. Bring him again tomorrow."

The next day, they came to see Huzhi once more. Upon leaving, Ji Xian said to Liezi: "Your master’s bearing is flawed. Though he penetrates things and clarifies affairs, he still relies on keen perception. With this, he vainly presumes to know one thing by another, binding his skill to external connections, wearing out his body and exhausting his mind."

The tiger, leopard, ape, and monkey are hunted and trapped for their abilities—such gifts do not originate from themselves.

Forget the self, and the people will not depend on you;
Forget merit, and no name can be ascribed;
Forget the name, and you wander in the realm of nothingness;
Forget all, and the governance of an enlightened king is thus.

Zhao’s commentary: "Swiftness of purpose" refers to those whose aspirations are quick and keen. "Strength and boldness" describes those who are resolute and daring. When things arise, they discern clearly and act with unyielding force—can such be compared to an enlightened king? The answer lies in the Dao’s esteem for softness, obscurity, and non-action. Those who act thus oppose the Dao and are burdened by their own talents. Not only do they weary the body and exhaust the mind, but they also invite harm! Like the tiger, leopard, ape, and monkey, lured into the hunt or ensnared by their own prowess, their abilities bring disaster—such men are unfit to govern the world.

Ziju pressed further, expounding on active governance. Laozi, abiding in non-action, replied: When merit encompasses all under heaven, it seems not to issue from oneself; things transform, yet one does not rely on this as ability. Each thing finds its own harmony, and none can name one’s merit—just as Confucius praised Yao, saying the people could not name his achievements, yet they towered in their majesty.

Yongzhai observed: The phrases "swiftness of purpose" and "strength and boldness," though not directed by name, are a veiled rebuke of Confucius. *Xu* refers to convict laborers; *yi* means "to change," akin to "conscripted service." The phrase *yao gu you ci yu* echoes an ancient saying, much like the Han term "ghostly firewood gatherers." Those bound by *shou* are artisans and craftsmen, ensnared by their own skill and technique. To pursue learning in this way is to labor both body and mind—like the tiger and leopard, whose patterns draw hunters, or the ape and monkey, whose agility invites snares. This is the harshest of critiques.

Ziju asked again. The reply concluded: When merit blankets the world yet seems not to originate from oneself, so that things rejoice of their own accord—this is the meaning of "merit achieved yet unpossessed," and "what power does the emperor add?" To stand in the unfathomable is to wander in nothingness, as if dancing at the tip of a brush. The foregoing passages all obscure the intent of the "Decree" chapter.

The term *xiang ji* has elicited varied interpretations. The *Pronunciation and Meaning* cites Emperor Jianwen of Liang, who equates *xiang* with *xiang* ("echo"), as in the passage where Cook Ding’s knife *xiang ran* ("resonates")—thus reading it as "echo." Yet upon examining the chapter’s intent, Lü, Lin, and Bixu’s literal interpretation of the character proves superior.

Here is my proposed reading: *xiang ji* denotes swift responsiveness to things; *qiang liang* ("unyielding force") refers to one who fails to embrace softness. *Wu che* ("penetrating things") means delighting in communion with them; *shu ming* ("unobstructed clarity") describes one who does not conceal their radiance. The study of the Dao values non-action, yet to prize tirelessness as merit is akin to bartering and binding oneself through skill—inevitably wearying body and mind. What is sought is not the true Way.

Moreover, can such qualities as *xiang ji* and *qiang liang* truly be compared to the enlightened ruler? This is Lao Dan’s rhetorical question: if the foregoing discussion of swiftness and force were to liken one to a sage-king, then would the tiger and leopard, hunted for their patterns, or the ape and dog, ensnared for their agility and tenacity, also suffice as metaphors for enlightened rule?

Ziju then awoke to the truth and inquired about the governance of the enlightened ruler. He was told that only by forgetting merit, bestowing virtue freely, fleeing fame, and concealing one’s form could one begin to discuss such governance. For Ziju’s discourse concerned outward conduct, while Lao Dan’s addressed the inner heart. The division between heart and trace has endured for ages.

As for *zhi mao* ("grasping the yak"), the interpretation falters—*mao* has two pronunciations, *li* and *lai*, yet how could a dog seize a great ox? The *Pronunciation and Meaning* records Li’s emendation to *li* ("raccoon-dog") as correct.

In Zheng there was a divine diviner named Ji Xian, who could discern a person’s life and death, fortune and misfortune, longevity and early demise, predicting them by year, month, or day with uncanny accuracy. The people of Zheng, upon seeing him, would flee in haste. When Liezi encountered him, he was entranced and returned to tell Master Hu, saying: "At first, I believed your Way to be supreme, yet now I see there is something even greater."

Huzi replied: "I have taught you only its outward form, not its essence—how could you have truly attained the Dao? A flock of hens without a rooster will never lay fertile eggs. Yet you parade the Way before the world and insist on its truth, so naturally others can read your fortune. Bring him to me tomorrow, and let him examine me."

The next day, Liezi brought Ji Xian to see Huzi. Upon leaving, the diviner said to Liezi: "Alas! Your master is dead—he will not live. Not even ten days remain!"

I saw something strange—he saw only damp ashes."

Liezi entered, his tears soaking his lapels as he told Huzi. Huzi said: "Just now I showed him the earthly pattern, sprouting yet neither stirring nor upright. He likely saw only my sealed virtue-mechanism. Bring him again tomorrow."

The next day, Liezi brought him to see Huzi once more. Upon leaving, the diviner said to Liezi: "Fortunate indeed that your master has met me! He was fading, but now he is fully alive—I saw his sealed power!"

Liezi entered and told Huzi. Huzi said: "Just now I showed him heaven and earth, where names and realities do not enter, and the mechanism arises from the heels. He likely saw my virtuous mechanism. Bring him again tomorrow."

The next day, Liezi brought him to see Huzi once more. Upon leaving, the diviner said to Liezi: "Your master is unsettled—I cannot read him. Let him settle, and I will examine him again."

Liezi entered and told Huzi. Huzi said: "Just now I confined my display to the Great Thoroughfare, where nothing prevails. He likely saw my balanced qi-mechanism. The stillness of a deep pool, the stillness of still water, the stillness of flowing water—each is called a deep pool. There are nine names for the deep, and here he has witnessed three. Bring him again tomorrow."

The next day, Liezi brought him to see Huzi once more. Before he could stand firmly, the diviner lost himself and fled. Huzi said: "Pursue him!" Liezi chased him but could not catch up. Returning, he reported to Huzi: "He has vanished, disappeared—I could not reach him."

Huzi said: "Just now I showed him what had never yet emerged from my source. I met him with emptiness and compliance, leaving him unsure who or what I was. Thus he took me for drifting reeds, for flowing waves, and so he fled."

Thereafter, Liezi considered himself as one who had never yet begun to learn and returned home, not venturing out for three years. He cooked for his wife, fed pigs as he would feed people, and in all matters remained unattached. He carved and polished only to return to simplicity, standing alone like an unhewn clod. Amidst the tangled world, he remained thus to the end.

For Jiyian divined others by reading their hearts with his own, yet when I am without heart, what he relies upon to divine cannot stand alone—thus he lost himself and fled, never to be found again. Emptied and yielding, unknown as any particular thing, one is without heart and without action. When still, he takes it for drifting reeds—yet none know it as reeds. When moving, he takes it for flowing waves—yet none know it as waves. Seeking me in motion or stillness, he finds nothing—this is why he flees.

Feeding pigs as one feeds people is the utmost forgetting of self. Unattached to affairs, one reaches the extreme of emptiness. Carving and polishing only to return to simplicity, standing alone like an unhewn clod—amidst the world’s entanglements, one guards one’s domain to the end, unchanged by all the clamor of the ten thousand things.

Lin’s commentary: When Liezi saw Jiyian, he doubted whether his master’s Dao fell short. Huzi explained that substance is revealed through form, and the Dao is made manifest in affairs. He said, “You and I have exhausted form but not yet substance—how could we attain the Dao? It is like a flock of hens without a rooster—how could they lay eggs? Since you have not yet grasped the substance of my Dao, your Dao still contends with the world and must be validated by others, so Jiyian could divine you. ‘Damp ashes’ signify the signs of impending death. I showed him ‘earthly patterns’—had I not shown them, there would be no pattern at all. Without trembling, there is only stillness and motionlessness—this is integrity, the integrity of the One. Thus the body remains at peace. Without integrity, there is no One—this is what makes ‘earthly patterns.’

Though virtue holds its mechanism, it remains sealed and untriggered—something he cannot comprehend. ‘Heaven and earth’ signify the work of covering and supporting, which extends to things, just as the mechanism of the Dao emerges from its root, yet name and reality have not yet entered. The ‘heel’ is the lowest part of the form. ‘Utmost goodness’ is called ‘that which can be desired.’ What he perceives is the ‘mechanism.’ Huzi called himself ‘authority’—authority perceives only the coarse, while the mechanism resides in the subtle.

First, I sealed the mechanism within utmost stillness, and the diviner suspected death. Next, I released the mechanism from the lowest depths, and he suspected life. Then, neither moving nor still, neither dead nor alive, uneven and unaligned—there was nothing by which to divine. ‘Supreme harmony’ is utmost emptiness at the center. ‘None prevails’ is what *Liezi* calls ‘no trace.’ ‘Balance’ is perfect equilibrium—responding to things, it becomes uneven and unaligned. Qi, though empty and awaiting things, has not yet departed from the mechanism.

Huzi concealed his spirit in the interval of utmost emptiness and no trace, where the unevenness of movement and stillness, yin and yang, is like the balance responding to things—thus Jiyian could not divine him. *You* is a great fish. ‘Abiding’ means lingering. Still water forms a deep pool—this illustrates ‘earthly patterns.’ Flowing water forms a deep pool—this illustrates ‘heaven and earth.’ The great fish coils within the deep, now clear, now swift, uneven and unaligned—this illustrates ‘supreme harmony with no trace.’

*Liezi* speaks of nine deep pools; here, three are cited to clarify Huzi’s affair. Supreme harmony has not yet departed from the mechanism of qi, but when it has never yet emerged from my source, it becomes one with Heaven—this is why Jiyian lost himself and fled. Without heart and following things, one is empty and yielding, unknown as any particular person or thing.

‘Yielding’ means following. ‘Reeds’ means compliance. If he takes it for yielding reeds, I take it as yielding reeds. If he takes it for flowing waves, I take it as flowing waves—this speaks of Huzi’s transformations within himself. Seeing Huzi’s Dao, Liezi awakened and realized he had never yet begun to learn. Returning home, he cooked for his wife and fed pigs as he would feed people, unaware of distinctions between noble and base, self and other. Unburdened by tasks, he shed ornament to return to simplicity, standing alone like an unhewn clod. Though affairs were tangled, he guarded his domain to the end, unchanged by them.

Detailed commentary on the Dao: Roaming with the Dao, one is without heart, so the mechanisms of life and death, fortune and misfortune vanish within—nothing can be divined. Mingling with the world, one is encumbered, so the omens of life and death, fortune and misfortune appear without—thus they can be divined. This is why Jiyian’s divination succeeded with others but failed with Huzi.

‘Earthly patterns’ are the congealed form of yin softness. ‘Heaven and earth’ reveal the work of covering and nurturing. ‘Supreme harmony’ is the central qi of Heaven and Earth. Yin softness congeals in form, so its response to things is still—this is called ‘sealing the mechanism of virtue,’ like the deep pool of still water. The work of covering and nurturing is manifest, so its response to things is beautiful—this is called ‘the mechanism of goodness,’ like the deep pool of flowing water. As for ‘supreme harmony where none prevails,’ it is neither moving nor still, neither dead nor alive, neither above nor below, centered like a balance—this is called ‘the mechanism of balanced qi,’ like the deep pool where the great fish coils.

Whether water is still, flowing, or swirling with great fish, the deep pool remains one. Whether Huzi’s mechanism is sealed, released, or in supreme harmony, his Dao remains one. Those who observe water well examine its depths; those who observe people well examine their Dao. Liezi, awakening to Huzi’s Dao, knew his own insufficiency. Since even the diviner could not stand alone, he lost himself and vanished, never to be found again.

Emptied and yielding, unknown as any particular thing, one is without heart and without action. When still, he takes it for drifting reeds—yet none know it as reeds. When moving, he takes it for flowing waves—yet none know it as waves. Seeking me in motion or stillness, he finds nothing—this is why he flees. Feeding pigs as one feeds people is the utmost forgetting of self. Unattached to affairs, one reaches the extreme of emptiness. Carving and polishing only to return to simplicity, standing alone like an unhewn clod—amidst the world’s entanglements, one guards one’s domain to the end, unchanged by all the clamor of the ten thousand things.

Lin’s Annotation:
When Liezi met Jixian, he doubted whether his master’s Dao was inferior. Huzi explained that substance is revealed through form, and the Dao is made manifest in affairs, saying: "You and I have exhausted its form but not its reality—how then can we attain the Dao? It is like a flock of hens without a rooster—how could they lay eggs? Since you have not yet grasped the reality of my Dao, your Dao still contends with the world and must rely on others’ belief, which is why Jixian could divine your fate. 'Damp ashes' are the sign of impending death.

He showed him *Earth’s Pattern*—without display, there would be no form. Without quaking, there is only stillness and motionlessness. Correctness is constancy, and constancy in the One brings bodily tranquility. Without correctness, there is no Oneness, and this is what constitutes *Earth’s Pattern*. Though virtue possesses a mechanism, it is sealed and not released—something beyond Jixian’s knowledge.

*Heaven and Earth* refers to the work of covering and bearing that has already extended to things, like the Dao’s mechanism issuing from its root while its name and reality have yet to take shape. The *heel* is the lower part of the form. *Utmost goodness* means what is desirable. What Jixian perceived was merely the mechanism.

Huzi called himself *the balance*—what the balance perceives is coarse, while the mechanism contains subtlety. At first, he concealed the mechanism in perfect stillness, and the diviner suspected him dead. Next, he released the mechanism from the utmost depths, and the diviner suspected him alive. Then, neither moving nor still, neither dead nor alive, uneven and irregular, he became impossible to divine.

*The Supreme Unitary* is perfect emptiness at the center. *No Contender*—as *Liezi* says, "No trace." *The Scale* is perfect equilibrium, responding to things with unevenness and irregularity. *Qi* is emptiness awaiting things, yet still not free from mechanism. Huzi concealed his spirit in the boundless, traceless void, where the unevenness of movement and stillness, yin and yang, was like the scale responding to things—thus Jixian could not divine him.

The *you* is a great fish. *Abiding* means settling. Still water forms a deep pool, illustrating *Earth’s Pattern*. Flowing water forms a deep pool, illustrating *Heaven and Earth*. The great fish coils to make its pool, clear or turbid, swift or slow, uneven and irregular—this demonstrates *the Supreme Unitary with no contender*. *Liezi* speaks of nine deep pools; here, three are cited to clarify Huzi’s methods. Even *the Supreme Unitary* is not yet free from the mechanism of qi. As for *not yet having emerged from my source*, one becomes one with Heaven—this is why Jixian lost himself and fled.

Without heart and following things, one is empty and yielding, unknown as any particular person or thing. *Disciple* means to let go. *Yielding* means to follow. If he is to be a disciple, one takes him as a disciple; if he is to be flowing waves, one takes him as flowing waves—this describes Huzi’s transformations as self-contained.

When Liezi witnessed Huzi’s Dao, he awakened to self-realization, feeling as if he had never studied at all. Returning home, he cooked for his wife, fed pigs as he fed people, and no longer distinguished between noble and base or self and others. Unburdened by affairs, he shed ornamentation to return to reality, standing alone like an unhewn clod. Though the world’s affairs were in turmoil, he guarded his domain to the end, unchanged by all the clamor of the ten thousand things.

Detailed Daoist Annotation:
One who wanders with the Dao is without heart, so the mechanisms of life and death, fortune and misfortune dissolve within—impossible to divine. One who engages with the world is encumbered, so the omens of life and death, fortune and misfortune appear without—possible to divine. This is why Jixian could divine the multitude but was confounded by Huzi.

*Earth’s Pattern* is the congealed form of yin softness. *Heaven and Earth* is the visible work of covering and nurturing. *The Supreme Unitary* is the central qi of Heaven and Earth. Yin softness congeals to respond to things with stillness—this is called *sealing the mechanism of virtue*, like the deep pool of still water. The work of covering and nurturing responds to things with beauty—this is called *the mechanism of goodness*, like the deep pool of flowing water. As for *the Supreme Unitary with no contender*, it is neither moving nor still, neither dead nor alive, neither above nor below, balanced at the center like a scale—this is called *the mechanism of qi in equilibrium*, like the deep pool where the *you* coils.

Whether water is still, flowing, or coiled by the *you*, its depth is one. Whether Huzi’s mechanism is sealed, released, or in *the Supreme Unitary*, his Dao is one. Those who skillfully observe water examine its depth; those who skillfully observe people examine their Dao.

Liezi, awakening to Huzi’s Dao, knew his own insufficiency. Since even the diviner could not stand alone, he lost himself and vanished, never to be found again.

Emptied and yielding, unknown as any particular thing, one is without heart and without action. When still, he takes it for drifting reeds—yet none know it as reeds. When moving, he takes it for flowing waves—yet none know it as waves. Seeking me in motion or stillness, he finds nothing—this is why he flees. Feeding pigs as one feeds people is the utmost forgetting of self. Unattached to affairs, one reaches the extreme of emptiness. Carving and polishing only to return to simplicity, standing alone like an unhewn clod—amidst the world’s entanglements, one guards one’s domain to the end, unchanged by all the clamor of the ten thousand things.

Lin’s Annotation:
When Liezi met Jixian, he doubted whether his master’s Dao was inferior. Huzi explained that substance is revealed through form, and the Dao is made manifest in affairs, saying: "You and I have exhausted its form but not its reality—how then can we attain the Dao? It is like a flock of hens without a rooster—how could they lay eggs? Since you have not yet grasped the reality of my Dao, your Dao still contends with the world and must rely on others’ belief, which is why Jixian could divine your fate. 'Damp ashes' are the sign of impending death."

He showed him *Earth’s Pattern*—without display, there would be no form. Without quaking, there is only stillness and motionlessness. Correctness is constancy, and constancy in the One brings bodily tranquility. Without correctness, there is no Oneness, and this is what constitutes *Earth’s Pattern*.

Though virtue possesses its mechanism, it remains sealed and unmanifest—something beyond his comprehension.

Heaven and Earth perform their covering and bearing functions, extending to all things, yet like the mechanism of virtue and the Dao, though issuing from the root, their name and reality have not yet taken form. The "heel" refers to the lower part of the body. "Utmost goodness" means that which is desirable.

What he perceived was merely the mechanism. Huzi called himself "adaptive power," for adaptability reveals only the coarse, while the mechanism preserves the subtle.

At first, he concealed the mechanism within perfect stillness, and the diviner suspected him dead. Next, he released the mechanism from the lowest extreme, and the diviner suspected him alive. Then, neither moving nor still, neither dead nor alive, uneven and irregular, he became unreadable.

"Supreme Unitary" is utter emptiness at the center. "No sign" refers to what *Liezi* calls "no trace." "Balance" is perfect equilibrium, responding to things with uneven irregularity. *Qi* is emptiness awaiting things, yet still bound to mechanism.

Huzi concealed his spirit in the realm of utter emptiness and tracelessness, where motion and stillness, yin and yang, remain uneven—like a scale responding to weight—so that Jixian could not divine him.

The *you* is a great fish. "Abiding" means settling. Still water forms a deep pool, illustrating *Earth’s Pattern*. Flowing water forms a deep pool, illustrating Heaven and Earth. The great fish coils to make its pool, now clear, now deep, now swift—uneven and irregular—demonstrating the meaning of *Supreme Unitary* and *no sign*.

*Liezi* speaks of nine deep pools; here, three are cited to clarify Huzi’s methods. Even *Supreme Unitary* has not yet escaped the mechanism of *qi*. But when one has "never yet emerged from my origin," one becomes one with Heaven—this is why Jixian lost himself and fled.

Without intention, one follows things, thus empty and yielding, unaware of who or what one is. "Yielding" means letting go. "Following" means compliance. If he becomes yielding, one follows his yielding; if he becomes a flowing wave, one follows the wave—this describes Huzi’s transformations as self-originating.

Seeing Huzi’s Dao, Liezi awakened and realized he had never truly learned. Returning home, he cooked for his wife, fed pigs like a common man, and no longer distinguished between noble and base or self and other. Unburdened by affairs, he discarded ornament for substance, stood alone like an unhewn block, and though matters were chaotic, he guarded his boundaries and never altered.

The *Daoist Commentary* states: Those who wander with the Dao are without intention, so the mechanisms of life and death, fortune and misfortune, vanish within and cannot be divined. Those who engage with the world bear burdens, so the mechanisms of life and death, fortune and misfortune, appear externally and can be divined. This is why Jixian’s divination succeeded with others but failed with Huzi.

*Earth’s Pattern* is the congealed form of yin softness. Heaven and Earth reveal their nurturing function. *Supreme Unitary* is the central *qi* of Heaven and Earth. Yin softness congeals, so its response to things is still—hence the sealed virtue-mechanism, like a still-water pool. The nurturing function appears, so its response to things is beautiful—hence the "goodness-mechanism," like a flowing-water pool. As for *Supreme Unitary* with *no sign*, it is neither moving nor still, neither dead nor alive, neither above nor below, centered like a scale—hence the "balanced *qi*-mechanism," like the pool where the great fish coils.

Still, flowing, or coiled by the great fish, the deep pool remains one. Sealed, released, or in *Supreme Unitary*, Huzi’s Dao remains one. Those who observe water well examine its depth; those who observe people well examine their Dao.

Liezi, awakening to Huzi’s Dao, knew his own insufficiency. When reality does not enter, the heart does not stir. Only in perfect stillness does the mechanism emerge from the lowest extreme—the origin of the body’s vitality. Nurtured, it becomes vast *qi*; expanded, it becomes all-pervading benevolence. This is called "continuing one’s nature and manifesting it," ceaselessly generating life.

Again seeing Huzi, he marveled at his uneven motion and stillness, his unreadability—such are the wondrous workings of the perfected, transcending all calculation. *Supreme Unitary* is emptiness at its utmost, so no trace or sign can be perceived. The scale, perfectly balanced, responds well. *Qi*, utterly empty, enters well. Both are without intention toward things, so they respond spontaneously without awaiting stimulus—yet they are called "mechanisms" in terms of what they reveal.

The three deep pools illustrate the profound meaning of the three mechanisms. Though *Liezi* mentions nine, citing only three was enough to exhaust Jixian’s skill. The perfected do not intend to astonish or overpower others; they merely reveal "never yet emerged from my origin"—a non-revelation, a traceless origin, nothing but emptiness. What emergence or entry could there be? Thus, the more Huzi’s revelations approached truth, the further Jixian’s divinations strayed—no wonder he lost himself and fled.

Once Jixian was obliterated and lost, Huzi too became as nothing. Then what was Liezi to do? Realizing that all he had previously learned was mere earth and stubble, he now recognized the true Dao. Amidst chaos, he guarded his boundaries and held to this to the end—this is what it means to exhaust the Dao.

This chapter truly embodies the subtle principle of "responding to emperors and kings," using Jixian’s divination to reveal the wonder of Huzi’s Dao, so that those intoxicated by divination’s artifice might awaken a little.

"With you and I"—*with* means approval, as in Confucius’ "I approve of Zeng Dian." "Having exhausted its form"—one version reads "without form," where Heaven’s curving in the northwest is "without" (adding *卜* to *无* makes *无*, and *既* is a variant). "Not correct" should read "not still." "Uneven" is read as written. "No sign" is undoubtedly *朕*. The character *審* in "three deep pools" in *Liezi* is written as *潘*, pronounced *pan*, meaning "water coiling in a hollow."

The *Pronunciation and Meaning* of this classic states: Sima’s edition writes *蟠* (coil), meaning "to gather," which may approximate the sense. *弟靡* (dī mǐ) in the old commentary is glossed as *颓* (decline), though its source is unclear; here, following the *Liezi* text, *茅靡* (máo mǐ) is correct. As the wind over grass must bend it, this better accords with the following imagery of "waves and flow."

*Southern Florescence True Classic: Ocean of Subtle Meanings, Scroll Twenty-One* concludes.

---
**Note 1:** The Ming *Zhengtong Daoist Canon* original reads *技* (art), which is correct. *授* (transmit) is a manifest error.
**Note 2:** The *Exegesis* cites Cui’s edition, where *正* (correct) is written as *止* (still).
**Note 3:** The *Jiangnan* ancient canon, cited in *Omissions and Errors*, also writes *正* as *止*.
**Note 4:** The *Zhuangzi Fuzhai Oral Exegesis* originally had *自* (self); *目* (eye) is a mistaken substitution.
**Note 5:** *雷* (thunder) is an error for *审* (examine).

*Southern Florescence True Classic: Ocean of Subtle Meanings, Scroll Twenty-Two*
By Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin
"Responding to Emperors and Kings, Part Three"

Body free of fame’s corpse, mind free of schemes’ storehouse,
hands free of tasks’ burden, spirit free of knowledge’s lordship.
Embrace the boundless to its end and wander without trace;
exhaust what Heaven has bestowed, yet perceive no gain—
it is emptiness alone.

The perfected one’s heart-mind works like a mirror:
neither chasing nor welcoming, responding yet not retaining.
Thus it masters things without harm.

Guo’s commentary:
Things naturally assume their names and each devises its own schemes;
things naturally bear their tasks and govern their knowledge.
Following the world’s self-so, one drives ten thousand things without limit.
Exhausting what Heaven has bestowed, one stops when full.
To perceive gain is to know no stopping; without emptiness, one cannot bear the solid.

The heart-mind like a mirror reflects without emotion:
what comes is met, what goes is released.
Thus, though the world entire comes to be mirrored, there is no weariness of spirit.

Lü’s commentary:
Free of fame’s corpse, I have no name, and all under Heaven cannot name me.
Free of schemes’ storehouse, I do not scheme, and all under Heaven schemes for me.
Free of tasks’ burden, I do nothing, and those who bear tasks shoulder responsibility.
Free of knowledge’s lordship, I have no concerns, and all under Heaven concerns itself for me.
Embracing the boundless to its end is the utmost of vastness.
Wandering without trace, even spirits cannot perceive—
how much less can men?

If so, one exhausts what Heaven has bestowed yet perceives no gain—
this is what is meant by “constantly relying on nature without augmenting life.”
The so-called emptiness: is it emptiness only after emptying?
My heart-mind is originally empty.

Its heart-mind like a mirror:
not chasing, what has passed leaves no residue;
not welcoming, what has not come cannot be foreseen.
Responding yet not retaining, what is present cannot be grasped.
Exhausting what Heaven has bestowed in this way,
one masters things without harm.

Lin’s commentary:
The perfected one’s heart-mind: when things stir, it penetrates;
when affairs conclude, it is still—like a mirror.
Bright, without emotion, it responds to things, and beauty or ugliness cannot deceive.
This is called “mastering things without harm.”
The perfected one does not contend, yet right and wrong cannot deceive;
following time and complying with principle, even spirits cannot harm him.

Xiang Dao’s commentary:
A mirror’s relation to things: when they arrive, it responds,
yet its light does not conceal.
When they depart, it lets them go, and its light remains unchanged.
It does not welcome their coming nor chase their going;
the myriad things do not exhaust it, yet it responds to them.
Constantly empty and without intent—
this is how it masters things without harm.

From “free of fame’s corpse” to “perceive no gain”:
through the heart-mind’s emptiness, one attains the Dao.
From “the perfected one’s heart-mind” to “responding yet not retaining”:
through the Dao’s emptiness, one reaches its use.

Bixu’s commentary:
To be fame’s corpse is to exhaust one’s form;
to be schemes’ storehouse is to endanger one’s spirit;
to bear tasks’ burden is to deplete one’s talent;
to be knowledge’s lord is to cloud one’s understanding.
Not embracing to the end is to be bounded;
leaving traces is to be unfit for wandering.
Exhausting what Heaven has bestowed is simply to bear it.
To perceive and gain is not wondrous—
no perception is emptiness alone.

The heart-mind like a mirror: when things come, it reflects them.
They come and go on their own, and beauty or ugliness is not concealed.
Without intent to master things, things cannot harm it.

Yongqi’s note:
“Free of fame’s corpse” means “doing good without approaching fame.”
“Free of schemes’ storehouse” means “without schemes, what use is knowledge?”
“Free of tasks’ burden” means “though affairs cannot be left undone, one does not take tasks upon oneself.”
“Free of knowledge’s lordship” means “though one cannot be without knowledge, one does not take knowledge as lord.”
These four “free of” are prohibitive, like the four “not” in the *Analects*.

“Embrace” means to perceive and see.
Perceiving the Dao to its end without limit,
the heart-mind wanders in the beginning of no-thing.
Heaven bestows this principle upon me;
I exhaust it yet do not consider it a gain.
To perceive gain is to verge on advancement.

Pushao concludes this passage with “emptiness” as its core.
The lines from “the heart-mind like a mirror” onward
simply explicate this one word, “emptiness.”
The prose rises and falls, and within its plainness lies divine subtlety—
is this not wondrous?

Zhao Xuzhai treats this passage and the “Emperor of the Southern Sea” as one chapter,
but his commentary is brief and does not discuss it.

Note: This passage continues from the preceding chapter on Ji Zhai,
summarizing its meaning as the text’s flow makes clear.
“Fame’s corpse,” “schemes’ storehouse,” “tasks’ burden,” and “knowledge’s lordship”
refer to Ji Zhai relying on knowledge and schemes to scrutinize things,
seeking fame and bearing tasks.
From “embracing the boundless to its end” onward
speaks of Master Hu’s Dao as unfathomable.
“The perfected one” clearly refers to Master Hu.
Not intending to master things, yet unable not to master them—
this is how Ji Zhai lost himself and fled.
Only by not contending can one skillfully master things;
how then could one be harmed?
This further clarifies that relying on the Dao, its use is boundless,
while relying on skill, one’s ability is limited.

The Emperor of the Southern Sea was Shu,
the Emperor of the Northern Sea was Hu,
and the Emperor of the Central Realm was Hundun.
Shu and Hu often met in Hundun’s land,
and Hundun treated them very well.
Shu and Hu plotted to repay Hundun’s virtue, saying:
“All men have seven apertures for seeing, hearing, eating, and breathing—
only this one has none. Let us try to bore them.”
Each day they bored one aperture,
and on the seventh day, Hundun died.

Guo’s commentary:
To act is to ruin it.

Lü’s commentary:
The Southern Yang symbolizes the manifest and having;
the Northern Yin symbolizes the sudden and nothingness.
The Center is neither having nor nothingness—
this is how they meet and unite.
Though Shu and Hu differ from Hundun,
Hundun never differed from them, so they treated him very well.
Knowing his goodness and plotting to repay it,
they bored apertures for seeing, hearing, eating, and breathing,
daily piercing him to connect with things—
how could his simplicity not be lost?

Yi Du’s commentary:
The Dao’s body is whole as Hundun;
when divided, it becomes Shu and Hu.

Its essence resides within, its coarse aspects without;
dividing the center to make a south—this is how the Dao is lost.
Those who lose the Dao must begin from without,
hence they meet in the land of Hundun.
Hundun admits of no impossibility,
thus it is said they treated him very well.
Boring one aperture each day
shows how harm arises.
On the seventh day, Hundun died—
this means that before the number reaches its limit,
it is already enough to lose the Dao.

Xiang Dao’s commentary:
Yin and Yang unite to form Hundun;
Hundun disperses into Yin and Yang.
To prefer union over dispersal is to wield it without fixed form;
to bore into union from dispersal is to make it easily ruined.
*Laozi* says: "There are images, there are things, there is essence"—
this refers to Hundun, Shu, and Hu.
Plotting to repay Hundun’s virtue is to use feeling to extinguish the Dao;
boring apertures until Hundun dies is to use the human to extinguish Heaven.
"Seven days" means that before the number is exhausted,
it is already enough to kill Hundun.

Bixu’s commentary:
The Southern Emperor embodies active endeavor,
the Northern Emperor embodies non-action,
and the Central Emperor embodies great simplicity.
Before the three qi divide, it is called "Hun";
before the five phases manifest, it is called "Dun."
With having and nothingness undivided,
it is said: "They treated him very well."
The Southern and Northern Emperors did not recognize Hundun’s truth
and rashly undertook empty boring,
leading to the scattering of simplicity.
*Laozi* says: "Open its apertures, hasten its affairs—
throughout life, it will never be fathomed."
This is the case.

Wu Chou’s commentary:
Shu is dark yet has form;
Hu is subtle yet has number.
When Hundun’s whole body disperses,
it is called the Central Emperor—
yet it does not depart from between Shu and Hu.
Thus, when Shu and Hu meet,
it is none other than the land of Hundun.
They treated him very well because he was impartial and selfless;
plotting to repay his virtue made them partial and intentional.
The Dao’s whole body would suffer harm,
so before the number was exhausted,
the "Hun" divided and the "Dun" scattered—
this is why it is called death.

Zhao’s commentary:
The first four chapters of *Responding to Emperors and Kings* discuss the Dao of governing the world,
while the latter chapter clarifies the earlier meaning and ascribes merit to Hundun’s virtue.
The South is *Li*, governing the eyes and overseeing seeing;
the North is *Kan*, governing the ears and overseeing hearing.
To rely on the keen clarity of ears and eyes
and force what one does not know
is to begin to depart from one’s true nature.
This is why the wise act without contrivance and detest boring.

Yong Qi states: This passage merely speaks of how keen perception and intelligence can burden the self, hence its use as an illustration. To block the limbs and shut off perception and intelligence is to become Hundun. Originally a plain observation, it was crafted into the tale of boring one aperture each day—truly a stroke of genius. Hundun is primordial qi. The human body possesses seven apertures, like a newborn infant: though eyes, ears, nose, and mouth are formed, it lacks knowledge—this is the wholeness of Hundun. When knowledge sprouts and likes, dislikes, joys, and angers arise, the apertures of Hundun are bored. *Mencius* says: "The great man does not lose the heart of a newborn infant"—this is Hundun unborrowed. Zhuangzi’s inversion of the tale renders it even more extraordinary. Who among later scholars could match such ingenuity?

This chapter comprises seventy-four characters. Guo Xiang cites a line from the *Daodejing* to encapsulate it, concise and precise beyond compare. After careful reflection, I offer my humble insight, appended to the existing commentaries:

What the *Nanhua Jing* calls Hundun is akin to what the *Daodejing* terms "pristine unity" (*hun cheng*) and the *Chongxu Jing* calls "primordial chaos" (*hun lun*)—all metaphors for the Dao’s complete, originally endowed, and uncontrived whole. Yet as the world waxes and wanes, the Dao moves with the times: gradually transforming into being, suddenly into non-being, its body thus fractured. The progression from one to three does not yet reach the point of boring; but when beings meet in the realm of Hundun, things interact and the mind arises—like fire added to kindling, an inevitable principle.
