Hundun, undivided, is perfectly suited to this state. Had Shun and Hu not been moved by sentiment and sought to repay its virtue, Hundun’s □ power would have remained unmarred. Thus they could not escape the entanglement of harm born from kindness: boring one aperture each day, the calamity entered through severance. After seven days, Hundun died—its emotional apertures opened, and its harmonious qi was lost. How fitting!

The path of emperors and kings, once trodden, leads to the demise of the great Dao’s essence—how is this different? The ancient rulers who responded to emperors and kings governed through non-action, and the myriad things transformed; they were desireless, and the world was content; profound and still, the hundred clans were settled. This was the proven efficacy of Yao, Shun, and the Three Dynasties, which later kings emulated to establish enduring norms. How could those who know governance—rushing to scheme and expand—compare? Thus, the *Nanhua* begins this chapter with Nie Que’s question to Wang Ni, using Yu’s parable to illustrate overthinking and Tai’s to exemplify non-action. Non-action suffices to match Heaven, which is what emperors and kings must embody, the mandate they inherit, and the trust of the countless people!

Yet those who devise standards and measures to transform the world’s people differ not from hunters who net birds and trap rodents—only hastening their flight into lofty skies or deep burrows. More action breeds intention; intention gives rise to schemes, from which deceit is born. Even the natural bond between father and son cannot remain secure; how then, in the relationship between ruler and people, can one hope for the mutual oblivion of wild deer and branches? Thus, when Tian Gen asked how to govern the world, the answer was: "Calm the mind, still the qi, follow things without partiality." When Zi Ju asked about the enlightened king’s rule, the answer was: "Forget merit, bestow goodness, let things delight themselves"—all ways to respond to emperors and kings through non-action. Those who possess the world and its states should seek it here.

Zheng had a divine diviner who foretold life and death, illustrating how strategists who scrutinize governance can predict a state’s rise and fall, discerning the subtle before it manifests—truly the oracle bones of their age. Yet upon first seeing Master Hu, they mourned his impending death; upon seeing him again, they rejoiced at his recovery; a third time, they doubted his uneven state, unable to divine anything. Thus, the limits of reading forms and faces became clear. When they saw him again, they fled in dismay—how mutable was Master Hu, and how un-divine was Ji Xian!

This shows that those who predict a state’s fate through schemes and calculations cannot transcend human artifice, and their use is thus finite. But the ruler who embodies non-action, modeling Heaven and the Dao, sitting in stillness while his spirit reaches the four directions, merging with transformation without limit—majestic and boundless, beyond the people’s comprehension—how can schemes measure him, or arts and numbers fathom him?

The chapter concludes with the two emperors of the South and North meeting at the center, illustrating how the Dao disperses into things, departing from non-being into being. Shun and Hu are but alternate names for being and non-being, the division of the subtle and wondrous. Their reunion is not without merit, yet where there is one, there is dispersion—hence the boring by Shun and Hu. Only by treating it well must there be those who bore well; better to transform without intention, to forget and interact in mutual transformation.

A ten-thousand-hu boat cannot hold a needle’s drip—how surprising that Hundun died after seven days! Privately, I reflect: the *Nanhua Jing* overflows with torrents of vast and surging eloquence, innovating and astonishing, towering above the other masters as if beyond the reach of rules and standards. Yet the profundity of its *Inner Chapters*—probing the divine, exhausting transformation, threading the Dao through Heaven and humanity—stands as a solemn and rigorous system, on par with the *Yijing* and *Laozi*. Beginners who fail to grasp its essence are scarcely less dazzled than by the five colors of Zhuangzi’s "floriate language."

Examining its creative intent and structured discourse, beginning with *Free and Easy Wandering* and concluding with *Responding to Emperors and Kings*, the essentials of learning the Dao lie in returning to seek within oneself, finding joy in all circumstances. Then, observing the myriad things externally, one sees that principles are without distinction. When things are equalized, the self is forgotten, and the master of nurturing life is attained. Nurturing life is to perfect oneself; responding to the world is to perfect things—both depend on virtue’s fulfillment. When virtue is full, the myriad things align in harmony.

The master as ancestral teacher establishes the origin of the Dao, setting a model for all under heaven, extending the lifeline of sages and worthies, and dispersing the clouds of delusion for ten thousand generations—thus the foundation of *The Great Ancestral Master* is laid. Applied to the art of governance, what difficulty could there be? Internally, one becomes a sage or spirit; externally, one responds as emperor or king. This is how the Dao, when gathered within the self, is never in excess, and when dispersed throughout the world, is never insufficient.

Though the achievements of emperors and kings are said to be but the surplus of sages, to elevate the world to true purity and lead the people to clarity and stillness, to respond to transformation and perfect governance—nothing surpasses this. Thus it concludes the purport of the *Inner Chapters*. Jiao and Hu were born, yet Hun Dun died—this metaphor illustrates how the success of external kingship may come at the cost of the inner sagely Way. Nowadays, many are those who bore openings into Hun Dun and so cause his death. How then shall we revive him?

It is said: "Block the apertures, close the gates, and employ them without strain." Is this not the true method for cultivating Hun Dun’s continuity?

Examining further the titles of the seven chapters, each has its governing principle. Though some examples may be dense and their distinctions blurred, I have surmised their essential aims and paired them with those whose virtue aligns with the ancients:

The ultimate discourse of *Free and Easy Wandering* rightly belongs to Xu You and Song Rong, who dissolved the world’s extreme entanglements of desire to preserve each one’s heavenly nature.

The ultimate discourse of *The Equality of Things* rightly belongs to Ziqi and Wang Ni, who loosened the delusions of self and other, is and isn’t, to attain their fundamental sameness and accord with the Great Thoroughfare.

The ultimate discourse of *The Secret of Nurturing Life* rightly belongs to Lao Dan and Peng Zu, who corrected the errors of over-cultivating the bodily form to know what should come first in the Way of life.

The ultimate discourse of *Fit for Human Society* rightly belongs to Huan Huan and Jie Yu, who clarified the proper timing of withdrawal and engagement, lest one provoke the dragon’s scales and invite calamity.

The ultimate discourse of *The Sign of Full Virtue* rightly belongs to Wang Tai and Shentu Jia, who showed that inner fullness requires no external validation, and that when virtue abounds, things cannot depart from it.

The ultimate discourse of *The Great Ancestral Master* rightly belongs to Confucius and Yan Hui, who possessed sagely virtue yet did not occupy its position, but magnified this Dao to awaken the people.

The ultimate discourse of *Responding to Emperors and Kings* rightly belongs to Shun and Yu alone, to whom the pivot of song and litigation returns—responding to heaven and following the people not by choice, but by necessity. Here, the *Nanhua* aspires to the ancient sages and worthies, inscribing their standards for ten thousand generations.

As for the attainments of the perfected person: they neither cling to the seven chapters nor depart from them, yet harmonize with their spirit. Thus they externally blend with the dust and light, while internally preserving luminous insight, moving between subtlety and sageliness, opening and closing with the transformations of the mechanism—unbound by the constraints of formal teaching.

Those who would truly study the *Nanhua* should seek within the *Inner Chapters*, and their understanding will be more than half complete.

*Collected Subtleties of the Ocean of Meaning of the True Scripture of Nanhua*, Scroll Twenty-Two—End
*Collected Subtleties of the Ocean of Meaning of the True Scripture of Nanhua*, Scroll Twenty-Three

**The Outer Chapters: "Webbed Toes" – First**

Webbed toes and supernumerary fingers arise from nature—yet they exceed in virtue. Pendulous growths and dangling wens emerge from form—yet they exceed in nature. Those who multiply methods of benevolence and righteousness and apply them are arrayed within the five viscera—yet this is not the rectitude of the Dao and virtue.

Thus, toes fused together are but useless flesh conjoined; fingers branching from the hand are but useless digits grown. Those who multiply methods and branch them within the passions of the five viscera indulge in perverse conduct through benevolence and righteousness, proliferating the use of their keen perception.

**Guo Xiang’s Commentary:**
Webbed and branched limbs all arise from form and nature; they are not borrowed from external things. Whether fused or not, each suffices in its nature. Yet these alone are fused and branched, thus exceeding their nature—hence they are called excessive. Some say this is not nature and seek to excise it, but this would mean the Dao has no place to abide, virtue has no vessel to bear it, humans discard what is essential, and things reject their proper use—how could this accord with the intent of perfect governance?

Things have small and large, abilities have few and many; what is large is fused, what is many is superfluous. The distinction between fusion and superfluity exists in all things. If none are employed, this is to abandon the nature of the myriad things entirely. Those who merge with things do not multiply.

Thus, those who multiply methods of benevolence and righteousness spread them across the five viscera, yet this is merely the rectitude of one school—unable to harmonize with things without distinction or align each with its proper nature and destiny. The few and many of methods have no fixed limit; the difference between few and many has a definite measure. They cannot encroach upon one another. Each guarding its measure, none fail to find their own fulfillment.

Some, hearing that multiplicity is insufficient to rectify the few, seek to discard the many and rely on the few—this is to cast aside the entire world. Is this not delusion? Webbed toes and branched fingers arise simply because nature and destiny cannot be otherwise; they do not exist for any use. Just so, the passions of the five viscera naturally multiply in methods. Yet those with fewer methods forcibly exalt them, leading to perversion and losing the perfect equilibrium within the body.

Keen perception has its proper measure: multiplicity is not excess, paucity is not deficiency. Yet the sway of passions and desires never fails to despise the few and prize the many. If one forgets what is prized and preserves one’s inherent measure, then in nature there is no excess, and all distinctions are complete.

**Lü Huiqing’s Commentary:**
Webbed toes and supernumerary fingers do not fail to arise from nature, yet virtue does not possess them. Pendulous growths and dangling wens do not fail to emerge from form, yet nature does not possess them. To have what is not possessed—this is why they are excessive.

Qi configures as the five phases, virtue as the five constants, affairs as the five practices, and form as the five viscera. Thus, those who multiply methods of benevolence and righteousness are not absent from the five viscera—yet they are not the rectitude of the Dao and virtue, for these too are what is not possessed. Therefore, toes fused and fingers branched are both useless; what is called the rectitude of the Dao and virtue is simply non-action returning to unity.

**Lin Yidu’s Commentary:**
Webbed and branched limbs are born with form—arising from nature. Wens and growths arise from form—emerging from form. Nature corresponds to virtue: nature resides in Heaven, virtue in humans. Form contrasts with nature: nature is internal, form external. What arises from Heaven, humans deem excessive; what emerges from the external, the internal deems excessive—this is the principle of nature.

Transformation, righteousness, and the Dao and virtue never fail to interact, yet the paths of benevolence and righteousness are despised by the Dao and virtue as wens and growths are despised by form. Webbed limbs illustrate the root of benevolence and righteousness; wens and growths illustrate their offshoots. Form and nature illustrate the rectitude of the Dao and virtue.

Webbed limbs arise from nature and cannot be removed—just as the root of benevolence and righteousness also arises from nature. Wens and growths emerge from form and can be removed—just as the offshoots of benevolence and righteousness arise from human artifice and can thus be discarded. If one can forget the descriptions of transformation and righteousness, one merges with the principle of nature and destiny, becoming one with the Dao and virtue. Forgetting the encumbrance of bodily form, even webbed limbs arise from form and nature, equal to the four limbs. Wens and growths are external to form; the imposition of benevolence and righteousness is external to nature. Removing them preserves form; forgetting them unifies the Dao.

**Chen Xiangdao’s Commentary:**
Nature is established through virtue; form is completed through nature. Webbed toes and supernumerary fingers have no place in virtue—hence they are called excessive to nature. The beginnings of benevolence and righteousness are present at birth—these are the fused branches of the Dao. Yet their use appears only after birth—these are the growths and wens of the Dao.

People know that fused limbs are useless and growths are burdensome, yet they do not realize that the practice of benevolence and righteousness is the same. When the Dao and virtue are esteemed, benevolence and righteousness become useless; when benevolence and righteousness are employed, the Dao and virtue become encumbered.

**Chen Jingyuan’s (Bixuzi) Commentary:**
Webbed and branched limbs are born with life—thus they arise from nature and are the surplus of life and virtue. Wens and growths arise after birth—thus they emerge from form and are external burdens to nature. Hence both are called excessive.

When the five phases are balanced, the five constants are unbiased—this is the rectitude of the Dao and virtue. Yet to multiply benevolence and righteousness is to have some among the five viscera’s qi endowment receive less—thus it is not the rectitude of the Dao and virtue. Moreover, webbed and branched limbs on hands and feet are merely useless digits—what harm could they do? Yet when the passions of the five viscera are fused and branched, indulging in perverse conduct through benevolence and righteousness and multiplying the use of keen perception, this is to fuse and branch in useful places—thus compounding the harm.

**Lin Xiyi’s (*Yongzhai Oral Teachings*) Commentary:**
What is born with life arises from nature; what humans alone possess is called virtue. Webbed limbs arise naturally, yet compared to what all humans share, they are excessive.

Excess growths and warts are likewise burdensome. Here, the terms "nature" and "virtue" slightly diverge from those in our sacred scriptures. "Multifarious" means manifold. To list them among the five viscera—this is to say they do not arise from within, hence they are not the rectitude of the Dao and virtue.

Gaozi spoke of righteousness as external; Zhuangzi went further, deeming benevolence external as well. To regard benevolence and righteousness as perverse excesses and to speak of them alongside keen perception—all this is to reject the learning of inward cultivation, thus revealing only their meddlesomeness.

**Master Chu’s (*Guanjian*) Insight:**
What Heaven commands is called nature; what things receive to live by is called virtue; to embody and fulfill virtue and nature is called form. All these are endowed by the natural, and thus one venerates life to align with the Dao, embodying Heaven to establish the ultimate, being utterly sincere without cease.

Anything beyond virtue and nature is but excess growths and warts—what is meant by "manifold in benevolence, righteousness, and keen perception," yet not the rectitude of the Dao and virtue. Thus, Master Zhuang of Qiyuan placed this discourse at the head of the *Outer Chapters*, and critics called his disparagement of benevolence and righteousness excessive. Yet the teachings of Laozi and Zhuangzi did not scorn benevolence and righteousness out of a fondness for loftiness; rather, when the Dao and virtue are honored, benevolence and righteousness are already within them. However, the benevolence and righteousness of that era were mostly excessive and offshoots, not the true essence. Thus, they had no choice but to refute and reject them. If benevolence and righteousness were rooted in the heart and practiced in accord with principle, how far would they be from the Dao and virtue?

Excess growths and warts are temporary gatherings of qi, initially causing no pain or itch—leaving them be incurs no harm. Yet some, disliking their burden on the body, seek to excise them, only to cause greater harm. Thus, the perfected person skillfully employs analogies to dispel confusion, hoping scholars will inwardly comprehend and intuitively grasp the truth, distinguishing the false to reveal the real. Then the supreme principle of Heaven’s mandate may be fully attained, and the noble worth of life restored to the unity of Dao and things. Heaven and humanity merge, and looking back, excess growths and warts are no burden to our form. What is called keen perception and benevolence and righteousness all arise from our virtue and nature—these, too, are subtle manifestations of the Dao. Yet if one does not follow their traces to seek goodness in things but instead reflects to return to the root and unite with the great harmony, one ultimately returns to the mystery of the Dao and virtue. Where then is perversity?

The phrase "manifold in the use of keen perception" appears thus in all current editions. Chen Jingyuan of *Bixuzi* noted that Zhang Junfang’s collated edition omits the character "manifold," citing the later phrase "excess in perception" as evidence—his argument is quite extensive.

Thus, to be excessive in clarity is to disorder the five colors, to indulge in ornate patterns, to dazzle with azure and yellow, embroidery and brocade—is this not so? And is this not Li Zhu? To be excessive in perception is to disorder the five sounds, to indulge in the six pitch-pipes, the tones of metal, stone, silk, and bamboo, the notes of *huangzhong* and *dalü*—is this not so? And is this not Shi Kuang?

To branch in benevolence is to pluck virtue and obstruct nature, to seek fame and reputation, causing the world to clamor in praise of unattainable standards—is this not so? And are these not Zengzi and Shi Yu? To be excessive in eloquence is to pile tiles and knot cords, to twist phrases, to roam the mind amid debates of hardness and whiteness, sameness and difference, and to exhaust oneself in vain praise of useless words—is this not so? And are these not Yang Zhu and Mo Di?

All these are manifold offshoots of the Dao, not the ultimate rectitude of the world. That which is truly rectified does not lose the truth of its nature and destiny. Thus, what is joined is not called excess; what is branched is not called divergent. What is long is not called surplus; what is short is not called deficient. Therefore, though the legs of the owl are short, lengthening them brings sorrow; though the legs of the crane are long, severing them brings grief. Thus, what is long by nature should not be cut; what is short by nature should not be extended—then there is nothing to remove, and sorrow departs.

**Guo Xiang’s Commentary:**
Those with ears and eyes are never troubled by envying the deaf and blind; their trouble lies in admiring Li Zhu and Shi Kuang. Yet Li Zhu and Shi Kuang, though keen of perception, disrupt the mastery of ears and eyes. Zengzi and Shi Yu were long in benevolence, but those short in it forcibly emulate them. To emulate them in benevolence is to make benevolence false. The world never admires Jie and Zhi but must admire Zengzi and Shi Yu—thus Zengzi and Shi Yu’s clamor misleads the world, causing it to lose its true nature more than Jie and Zhi ever did. To gallop in eloquence and craft perilous words is never to pause in the speech of Taozha but to vie in disputation between Yang Zhu and Mo Di—thus Yang Zhu and Mo Di disrupt the mastery of pure words.

Those several masters followed their natural endowments, each multiplying offshoots and taking their own way as rectitude. Yet to take one’s rectitude as the standard for all is to make all unrectified. Thus, the ultimately rectified do not use their own rectitude to govern the world but allow the world each to attain its own rectitude. Viewed thus, the ultimately rectified is evident.

To use branches to rectify the trunk is to call the trunk excess. To use the trunk to rectify branches is to call branches deformities. To use the short to rectify the long is to call the long surplus. To use the long to rectify the short is to call the short deficient. Each has its own rectitude; one cannot use this to rectify that and thereby diminish or obscure it. Knowing that the allotment of nature cannot be cut or extended and leaving it be, there is nothing to remove, and sorrow departs of itself.

**Lü Huiqing’s Commentary:**
"Clarity" means to see of itself; now, to take what is seen as clarity is to join one’s self-seeing with what is seen, making it excessive. "Perception" means to hear of itself; yet sounds, pitch-pipes, and strings are all external—thus they are multiplied and made excessive. The source from which the Dao emerges is the free flow of nature’s spontaneity—then the world is sufficient in itself and not surplus.

To pluck virtue is to force growth; to obstruct nature is to stifle what gives life. Only by overdoing it to seek fame does the world drum in unison to uphold unattainable standards—this is how Zengzi and Shi Yu branched in benevolence. The Dao lies in non-speech, thus eloquence is not the Dao. Tiles are valued when aligned like scales, but piling them burdens; cords are valued when straight, but knotting them entangles; phrases serve to convey meaning, yet twisting them hides it. The mind is valued for emptiness, yet it advances into debates of hardness and whiteness, sameness and difference, exhausting conduct in vain praise of useless words—like piling tiles and knotting cords, this is how Yang Zhu and Mo Di were excessive in eloquence.

All these fall short of the ultimate correctness of the world. That which is ultimately correct never loses the true nature of life and destiny, thus it acts without contrivance and remains naturally unaltered. Lin Yi’s solitary note: Those who are paired in brightness are confused by the five colors, unaware that the Dao within may be inwardly perceived. Those who are excessive in hearing are confused by the five sounds, unaware that the harmony of soundlessness lies beyond the reach of hearing. Branching into the seven apertures leads to dissipation, hence they pluck virtue and obstruct nature to gather fame, causing the world to resonate like blowing reeds or striking bells, mutually fanning and stirring to uphold their laws, ever feeling inadequate.

Those paired in eloquence speak as if piling tiles in peril, their grasp as firm as knotted cords. Heretical doctrines, subtle and obscure, are called "concealed phrases"; stubbornly clinging to debates on "white horses" and "difference and sameness," they expend effort on useless words—all these are the ways of excessive pairing and branching, not the ultimate correctness of the world. The ultimate correctness of the world is the Dao and virtue. Dao and virtue arise from the principles of life and destiny alone. That which is truly correct corrects things but is not corrected by things; it does not lose the true nature of life and destiny, and the distinctions of the myriad things become clear.

Thus, what is joined is not called paired, what branches is not called deformed, what is long is not called excessive, and what is short is not called insufficient. Each follows its natural allotment, and worries have no place to linger and thus vanish of themselves. Chen Xiangdao’s note: Displaying virtue and obstructing nature exemplify Zeng Shen’s excessive benevolence toward his parents and Shi Qiu’s excessive benevolence toward his lord. Piling tiles and knotting cords describe perilous words, exhausting oneself in praise. The sage has no fame, yet those who branch into benevolence seek it; the benevolent have no worries, yet the benevolent are beset by many, thus they are far from the Dao.

Deformities like paired toes do not naturally arise from the body, nor do benevolence and righteousness naturally arise from the Dao. When the body abides in its natural state, paired toes are no burden—thus what is joined is not called paired, and what branches is not called deformed. When the Dao abides in its natural state, benevolence and righteousness are no hindrance—thus one preserves virtue and nurtures nature, and that is all. Yet people of this age, already ensnared in the exhaustion of benevolence and righteousness, still gaze in distress, like those with paired toes or branched limbs. The unbenevolent, forcing benevolence and righteousness to glut themselves on wealth and honor, violate the true nature of life and destiny, becoming like those with paired toes.

Chen Bixu’s note: Paired toes, compared to the five digits, are deemed insufficient. Excessive brightness, with its doubled nature, is called excessive. The sage withdraws sight and reverses hearing to cultivate inner illumination; worldly customs admire Li Zhu and Shi Kuang’s keen sight and hearing, indulging the senses in external sights and sounds, exhausting their bodies. Thus, Li and Shi Kuang become the leaders of those who disorder ears and eyes! Those who branch into benevolence pluck virtue and obstruct nature to gather fame, rushing about in all directions and losing their true nature—thus Zeng and Shi become the patriarchs of those who delude the human heart.

Eloquence deployed in all directions is like piling tiles in layers; the transmission of learning is like knotting cords in tangles. Subtle and abstruse debates—are these not what "concealed phrases" and hidden words refer to? Wandering in eccentricity—are these not what "separating and uniting, affirming and negating" refer to? Praising minor doctrines—are these not what "exhausting jade tablets without progress" refer to? Great eloquence appears inarticulate, for much speech leads to frequent impasses—thus Yang Zhu and Mo Di become the chiefs of those who indulge in extravagant and perverse theories.

All excess or deficiency in form and nature fall short of the ultimate correctness of the Dao. To possess one’s correct nature and be able to correct oneself is called "true correctness." To compel others to follow oneself or to follow others is to lose the true nature of life and destiny. What is joined is not called paired, what branches is not called deformed—this is forgetting the body. The crane’s sinews are not severed, the hare’s sinews are not extended; with no cause for worry, worries vanish of themselves.

*Fuzhai’s Meanings* states: The five colors and patterns were used in ancient times to nurture the eyes, yet Zhuangzi deemed them chaotic and excessive, echoing Laozi’s "the five colors blind the eyes." Li Zhu was one who relied on brightness—if one deems this wrong, those who rely on brightness would deem it right. The same applies to those excessive in hearing. Virtue and nature are fundamentally still, yet forcing oneself into benevolence is to pluck virtue and obstruct nature, causing the world to be deluded and stirred into upholding unfeasible laws. Words that are verbose yet insipid are like piling tiles and knotting cords; altering phrases to argue is to roam the mind among debates on hardness and whiteness, sameness and difference.

"Exhausting steps" means laborious toil. Such words are useless yet praised with self-satisfaction, merely self-inflicted toil—if one deems this wrong, then Yang and Mo’s followers deem it right. Excessive pairing and branching refer to all superfluous matters, not the ultimate correctness. "True correctness" means being naturally so, not losing the true principle of life and destiny. Thus, what is joined is not called paired, what branches is not called deformed, what is long is not called excessive, and what is short is not called insufficient. These lines convey the meaning of "great as a hair, small as a mountain."

"Deformity" means rising; to have something deformed is to be unbalanced and unrestrained. The crane’s long legs and the hare’s short legs arise from their inherent nature; what nature finds at ease has no worry to dispel. "Why do the benevolent have so many worries?"—Yao, Shun, Confucius, and Mencius are all included in this! This passage elucidates the previous idea: each person has a correct nature, each nature has its inherent capacities, and each capacity has its proper measure—even a hair’s breadth cannot be forcibly altered. Thus, those who admire Li Zhu lose their brightness; those who emulate Shi Kuang harm their hearing.

Those who emulate Zengzi and Shishu exceed in benevolence; those who study Yangzi and Mozi deviate into contention. These all strive for what they lack to attain what others possess, elevating themselves to match others, clinging without end—this is not the ultimate correctness of the world.

That ultimate correctness fulfills the true nature of life without longing or envy. People rest content in their allotted roles, and things find their proper place: joined yet not called fused, branched yet not called deformed, long and short each fitting without the burden of excess or insufficiency. The world’s worries cease, vanishing of themselves without need for removal.

This is called "fulfilling one’s own nature and then fulfilling the nature of things." Thus, the joy of preserving things is the very joy of preserving oneself!

Upon examining the classic text, *jingwa* (景瓦) should likely be *leijiu* (累九). Where it reads *zhengzheng* (正正), it ought to follow the preceding passage as *zhizheng* (至正). *Bu wei ba* (不为跋) should be *qi* (岐). These are all errors in transcription.

*Collected Explications of the Ocean of Meanings of the Southern Florescence Canon, Scroll Twenty-Three Concludes*
*Collected Explications of the Ocean of Meanings of the True Southern Florescence Canon, Scroll Twenty-Four*

**Outer Chapters: "Webbed Toes and Extra Fingers" (Second)**

Is it not that benevolence and righteousness run counter to human nature? Why else would benevolent men be so full of sorrow?

Consider the man with webbed toes—when they are severed, he weeps. The man with an extra finger—when it is bitten off, he wails. Both cases, whether in excess or deficiency of number, share the same sorrow. Now, the benevolent of this world gaze in distress at the world’s afflictions, while the unbenevolent sever their nature’s bonds to glut themselves on wealth and rank. Thus, is it not that benevolence and righteousness run counter to human nature?

Since the Three Dynasties and beyond, why has the world been so clamorous? Those who rely on hooks, cords, compasses, and squares to achieve correctness carve away their nature. Those who depend on ropes, glue, and lacquer to secure firmness encroach upon their virtue. Bending and twisting with rites and music, sacrificing to the praise of benevolence and righteousness to console the world’s hearts—this is to lose what is constant.

The world has its constancy. What is constant? The crooked need no hook, the straight no cord, the round no compass, the square no square. Adhesion requires no glue or lacquer; binding needs no rope. Thus, the world arises in harmonious spontaneity, unaware of how it arises; all attain in unison, unaware of how they attain. From ancient times to the present, this has never changed—it cannot be diminished.

Then why do benevolence and righteousness cling like glue, lacquer, and knotted cords, weaving through the space of Dao and virtue? They only serve to delude the world!

Minor delusions distort direction; great delusions distort nature. How do we know this is so? Ever since the time of Yu, when benevolence and righteousness were summoned to disturb the world, all have rushed to answer the call of benevolence and righteousness—is this not to exchange one’s nature for benevolence and righteousness?

**Guo Xiang’s Commentary:**
Benevolence and righteousness are inherently part of human nature and should both be allowed their course. To fear that benevolence and righteousness are not of human nature and thus fret over them—this is truly excessive sorrow. The man with webbed toes, being deficient, weeps when they are cut; the man with an extra finger, being in excess, wails when it is gnawed. If all things vary in form and number, there will be no end to sorrow. Only when each abides in its natural state, bending to accommodate without harm, is there no cause for grief!

Yet when the path of universal love is exalted, the world’s eyes grow confused. To advance what is exalted, then lament its failure to bring rest—this is to cast people into peril and then rescue them. And yet, the governance of this age deems this benevolence.

If no such exalted path existed, people would rest content in their lot. How then would they imitate others, coveting what is not theirs? All things have their constancy. Left to themselves without interference, all attain in unison without self-awareness. Thus, they remain undivided from things and ever whole. Following the Dao, they attain spontaneously, embracing simplicity and walking alone, untangled by external things.

Benevolence and righteousness, clinging without end, only serve to delude and cause beings to lose their truth. To mistake east for west harms not the body, but to pride oneself on benevolence and exalt righteousness is to lose one’s constancy and court destruction—this is the greatest delusion.

To act without harming things is not to perform benevolence, yet benevolence naturally arises. All principles are fitting, not for the sake of righteousness, yet righteousness manifests. When fitting yet unharmful, the world does not rush toward benevolence and righteousness. To abandon oneself and follow others is to lose one’s constancy. Thus, the heart’s disorder does not arise from ugliness but ever dwells in beauty; the world’s disturbance does not stem from evil but ever lies in benevolence and righteousness. Therefore, benevolence and righteousness are the very tools that disturb the world.

Is this not to exchange one’s nature for benevolence and righteousness? Though Yu did not intend to alter nature, the world’s nature was already changed!

**Lü’s Commentary:**
Benevolence and righteousness are arrayed among the five virtues, yet the greatest benevolence is not benevolent, and the utmost righteousness is not righteous. How then are they not of human nature? Only when they are pursued to excess, not following the true course of Dao and virtue, does one suspect they are not of human nature. The benevolent man’s many sorrows arise from this excess.

Webbed toes and extra fingers, whether in excess or deficiency of number, share the same sorrow when removed. The benevolent of this age, gazing in distress at the world’s ills, resemble those in excess; the unbenevolent, who sever their nature to glut themselves on wealth and rank, resemble those in deficiency. Yet none recognize that this is not the true disposition of nature and cling to it, weeping when cut or wailing when gnawed.

To rely on compasses, cords, glue, and lacquer for correctness and firmness is to carve away one’s nature and encroach upon one’s virtue, losing what is constant. What is constant? It requires no compass, cord, glue, or lacquer to be naturally correct and firm. It arises and attains without knowing how, ancient yet uncorrupted, present yet unrenewed—this is the constancy of Dao and virtue’s true course.

Then why do benevolence and righteousness cling like glue, lacquer, and knotted cords, weaving through their midst to delude the world? To mistake direction is to take east for west; to alter nature is to take nothing for something. Human beings are tranquil at birth, yet benevolence and righteousness are summoned to disturb them—is this not to exchange one’s nature for benevolence and righteousness?

**Yi Du’s Commentary:**
Benevolence and righteousness arise from human nature. Now, to pluck virtue and block nature in the name of benevolence and righteousness is not spontaneous. Thus, Zhuangzi suspects they are not of human nature. Otherwise, why would the benevolence of Zeng and Shi be so full of sorrow?

The ancients practiced benevolence and righteousness by expanding their innate nature. Later ages, however, followed only the periphery of benevolence and righteousness, falling into artificiality and pretense. Thus, all one sees is their excessive sorrow.

If one does not follow the heavenly Dao, taking webbed toes and extra fingers as afflictions of human nature and seeking to harm and remove them, one will only weep and wail in grief. The analogy of webbed toes and extra fingers to benevolence and righteousness is apt, for if one truly fathoms their root, they are one with nature and cannot be removed. Yet failing to do so and merely following their path, others, seeing their advance, will seek to cast them off.

This is the cause of sorrow. The benevolent of this age gaze in distress at the world, and when the heart is troubled, the eyes become disordered. For all things, following their natural course brings peace, while harming their nature and life brings sorrow. Webbed toes, too, are a natural part of one’s nature; to cut and remove them is like the benevolent who, grieving over the world’s ills, seek to remedy them—only compounding their sorrow. The unbenevolent, however, rend the true essence of their nature and life to glut themselves on wealth and rank. This stems from the excesses of benevolence and righteousness, which, when overemphasized, become false—hence the doubt that benevolence and righteousness are not true to human nature.

Since the Three Dynasties, simplicity has scattered and cannot be restored—how clamorous it has become! To rely on hooks, strings, compasses, and squares for correction is not the natural way of rectitude; it is called carving away one’s nature. To depend on cords, glue, and lacquer for firmness is not the natural way of stability; it is called encroaching upon one’s virtue. Bending and yielding are but the remnants of ritual and music. Pursuing compliance is the advancement of benevolence and righteousness. To use these to console the hearts of the world is to lose what is naturally constant. What is constant in the world—does it require anything to be correct and firm? Not knowing how it lives, it lives of itself; not knowing how it attains, it attains of itself. Thus it harmonizes past and present, equalizes life and death, and nothing can harm or diminish it!

Then why must the paths of benevolence and righteousness be ceaselessly strung together, like glue and lacquer, like bound ropes, drifting between the Dao and virtue? This speaks of how the followers of Zeng and Shi cannot roam the Dao and virtue with an empty mind, but are instead bound by benevolence and righteousness, unable to break free. Why do the people of the world vie to admire the name of benevolence and righteousness, only to confuse their hearts?

Changing direction is easy to awaken from; altering one’s nature leads to delusion without return—this is the distinction between small and great. Zeng and Shi merely followed the traces of benevolence and righteousness, so they may be criticized. Yet even the benevolence and righteousness of Youyu, which fulfilled his nature—why did Zhuangzi still criticize them? It is because he reproached them for their beginning, which could not but be so. Moreover, the former kings employed benevolence and righteousness to perfect the people’s nature and return them to the Dao. Later ages, however, took their leftover threads and revered their teachings, believing that the utmost of Heaven’s mandate lay therein. Grasping what was meant to perfect nature, they took it as nature itself—how could they abandon its name and delight in its reality?

What is rejected is Youyu’s teachings; what is preserved is Youyu’s heart. The *Classic* says: "Receiving the mandate from Heaven, only Shun was truly upright." This refers to preserving his heart. The *Bixu Commentary* states: "Forcing and shaping are the carving of nature; contriving and conforming are the encroachment upon virtue." These all lose what is naturally constant. The crookedness or straightness of fleabane and hemp—which requires hooks and strings? The roundness or squareness of pearls and jade—which requires compasses and squares? The intertwining of pines and creepers—which requires glue and lacquer? The joining of paired branches and twin ears—which requires bound ropes? The materials of things and their heavenly nature all arise from the natural. Thus, all things grow spontaneously, all attain spontaneously, past and present are as one, without rise or fall.

To align with the Dao and virtue yet rush toward benevolence and righteousness is to change direction; to pursue profit and fame while harming life is to alter one’s nature. Ever since Youyu promoted the worthy, banished the wicked, and summoned benevolence and righteousness to sway the world, the world has had none who do not hasten to lose their lives thereby—this is the delusion of great confusion. The *Yongzhai Oral Teachings* say: "Webbed toes, though an affliction of the hands and feet, cannot be forcibly removed; forcing their removal brings sorrow and suffering." "Gazing in distress" means half-closing the eyes, their lashes bristling, conveying the sense of sitting alone in sorrow. Grieving over the world and exhausting oneself, coveting wealth and rank—these are all self-inflicted torments, hence they are spoken of together.

To doubt that benevolence and righteousness are not of human nature is to say they do not arise from what is naturally so. Since the Three Dynasties, this view has flourished—how noisy it has become! The virtue of one’s nature arises from the natural, not from human effort. If one must rely on cultivation to be correct, this is self-mutilation. Hooks, strings, glue, and lacquer are all metaphors for cultivation. Thus, bending and yielding to console the world all lose what is naturally constant. Yet the crooked and straight, round and square, requiring no human effort, are the true principles.

"Spontaneously" is akin to "weeds." What causes weeds to grow? What grants things their commonality? Not knowing how they grow, not knowing how they attain—thus past and present are as one, without addition or loss. "Ceaselessly" describes unending action. Glue and lacquer bind of themselves; bound ropes constrain of themselves. To depart from nature in pursuit of benevolence and righteousness, endlessly engaging in it, is to become mired and bound—how can one then roam between the Dao and virtue? It only deludes the world.

Minor delusion inverts the four directions; great delusion alters the nature of Heaven and Earth! Establishing the name of benevolence and righteousness to sway the world, the world is driven by it and rushes toward it, knowing benevolence and righteousness but not the Dao and virtue—this is to exchange one’s nature for external things. Benevolence and righteousness arise from human nature and emotions; those who lack them counterfeit them. Webbed toes arise from the body; those burdened by them despise them.

The *Nanhua* [Zhuangzi], seeing that the world exalts benevolence and righteousness, abandons the self to imitate others, pursues the path while forgetting the root, thus laments: "Are benevolence and righteousness not of human nature?" It means that forcing one’s nature to act thus does not arise from ease, but gathers the world’s sighs to become one’s own sorrow. Fearing the world’s disorder, one rushes to remedy it yet cannot prevail. Gazing in distress, hearts scorched with worry—is this not like cutting and removing webbed toes? Those unbenevolent ones rend their nature and life without regard, glutting themselves on wealth and rank without cease. When their calamity strikes, they are undone, losing both themselves and their possessions before stopping.

Where there is the true of benevolence and righteousness in nature, there must also be the false that counterfeits it. How detestable are those who, like birds of prey, use these vessels to oppress the people of the world—hence the repeated lament: "Are benevolence and righteousness not of human nature?"

Since the Three Dynasties, those who practice benevolence and righteousness—how hollow and frivolous they have become! The fundamental nature of things is upright and firm, arising from spontaneity. That which requires external correction is not perfectly upright; that which depends on reinforcement is not truly firm. Thus, to pare away one’s nature and encroach upon virtue is to lose what is constant and natural—no different from the webbed toes of hands and feet.

What is constant and natural takes its own form—curved or straight, square or round—without need of compass or carpenter’s square. Self-arising and self-attained, it knows no distinction between ancient and modern, no difference between completion and loss. When the Dao and virtue are perfectly blended, benevolence and righteousness become superfluous. Why then do men cling so stubbornly to their advancement, deluding the world?

Minor delusion confuses directions, misplacing east and west—yet this does little harm. But great delusion alters one’s nature, losing what is constant and natural, rebelling against the Dao and betraying virtue. The harm it brings cannot be fully described! Yet this malady has long seeped deep, ever since the time of Youyu, who summoned the Seven Virtues to disturb the world, imposing benevolence and righteousness to replace natural nature. When nature is no longer true, benevolence and righteousness become false as well. Still, the world rushes to obey, content in the loss of its nature, never awakening—this is what the true person laments.

Let us examine this: since the Three Dynasties, the world has bartered its nature for things without exception. The petty man sacrifices himself for profit; the scholar, for fame; the grandee, for his family; the sage, for the world. Though their undertakings differ and their reputations vary, they are one in harming their nature to serve external ends.

Zang and Gu, two men herding sheep together, both lost their flock. Asked what Zang was doing, he held a bamboo slip and read; asked what Gu was doing, he played at dice. Though their pursuits differed, their loss of sheep was the same. Boyi died for fame beneath Shouyang Mountain, while Robber Zhi died for profit atop Dongling. Though their deaths differed, they were equal in maiming life and harming nature. Why must Boyi be right and Robber Zhi wrong? The world is wholly given to sacrifice. Those who sacrifice for benevolence and righteousness are called gentlemen by custom...

Those who sacrifice for wealth and property are called petty men by custom. Yet their sacrifice is the same—some are deemed gentlemen, some petty men. But if we consider their maiming of life and harm to nature, then Robber Zhi is no different from Boyi. How then can we distinguish between gentleman and petty man?

Guo’s Commentary: Before the Three Dynasties, there were indeed traces of non-action, which later men of action revered. Yet in revering them, they lost their natural state. Even sages had no choice but to exchange the ease of inaction for the scars of action. The quail nests in the wild and eats from the cart’s grain; the crow flies without pattern—where do they not sacrifice? Thus, one who constantly merges with the world adapts to its changes, yet this very adaptation is a sacrifice to the world’s paths. What one encounters may at times bring scars, baldness, or the changes of scripture, and in advancing, one harms the world’s paths. Yet if one roams the eight directions with spirit and qi unchanged, or bears scars on hands and feet without disturbance to one’s form, then where is the sacrifice? There is none. Yet though one does not sacrifice what one ought not, one’s traces still conform to the world’s sacrifices.

What the world cherishes is life. Now, if one sacrifices it excessively, maiming life in all cases, then the right or wrong of what is sacrificed is no longer worth discussing. Why is life maimed? Why is nature altered? All stems from revering the legacy of non-action! If one knows that advancement is achieved through non-action, then one severs excessive reverence, removes extremes, and returns to merging with the ultimate.

Yao and Jie were equal in self-contentment; how then distinguish between gentleman and petty man?

Lü’s Commentary: The spirit descends to become the sage, while the king is but the sage’s outward form. From the Three Dynasties onward, all have followed the legacy of sage-kings, and what made them spirit has vanished from sight. Even Yu’s calloused hands, Tang and Wu’s campaigns—though born of necessity—could not escape sacrificing to the world’s ills. Zhuangzi sought to sever such advancement and return to the original source of the spirit’s heaven. Thus, his critique of the sage is fitting, not a belittlement.

The male slave who marries a maidservant is called Zang; the female slave who marries a male servant is called Gu. Herding sheep is a metaphor for guarding the mind, and guarding the mind is how one nurtures the heart. One who reads with a bamboo slip may do no wrong yet cannot avoid being matched with wrong; one who gambles in idleness may be dissolute and unprincipled, yet what emerges from them is principled. Both harm the guarding of the mind. Though their pursuits differ, their loss of sheep is the same. Boyi died for fame, which is the metaphor of reading with a bamboo slip and losing the sheep; Robber Zhi died for profit, which is the metaphor of gambling and losing the sheep. Though their deaths differed, they were equal in maiming life and harming nature. This is why those who embody the Way value forgetting both and transforming through the Dao.

Moreover, the world is wholly given to sacrifice. Those who sacrifice for benevolence and righteousness do not realize that their person is closer than fame; those who sacrifice for wealth and property do not realize that their person is greater than property. Their sacrifice is the same—some are called gentlemen, some petty men. Yet in maiming life and harming nature, Robber Zhi is no different from Boyi. They do not know that the affliction of gain is equal to the affliction of loss.

Du’s Commentary: Boyi died for the fame of purity; Robber Zhi died for the profit of greed. Neither knew whether fame or life was closer, whether life or property was greater. What they pursued was but the dust and husks of externals! Boyi’s fame endures on Shouyang Mountain, but where is Boyi’s person? Robber Zhi’s wealth accumulated on Dongling, but where is Robber Zhi’s spirit? Thus it is said: in maiming life and harming nature, they were equal. If so, why must Boyi be right and Robber Zhi wrong? This is the oneness of the Dao.

Boyi was the sage of purity, yet Zhuangzi harshly criticized him because his traces were visible in the world and set in opposition to Robber Zhi. Thus, Zhuangzi spoke this to correct the contemporary flaw of emulating Boyi—those who rigidly uphold conduct and revere action. Though Boyi’s fame was set in opposition to Robber Zhi’s, his spirit wandered with Confucius, and scholars must not be unaware of this.

The world is wholly given to sacrifice. If one does not sacrifice for benevolence and righteousness to seek fame, then one must sacrifice for wealth and property to satisfy desire. The great governance of the world does not depart from the realm of profit and fame. Those who sacrifice for benevolence and righteousness are called gentlemen by custom, yet they do not know they are Heaven’s petty men. Those who sacrifice for wealth and property are called petty men by custom, yet they do not know they are equal to the world’s so-called gentlemen.

Those who sacrifice for benevolence and righteousness diminish their allotted share to augment their nature; those who sacrifice for wealth and property diminish their nature to augment their allotted share. If both can settle into the natural state of their nature and destiny, then Heaven’s gentlemen are not the world’s gentlemen, and the world’s petty men are what the classics call petty men.

Detailed Daoist Commentary: Before the Three Dynasties, the world exchanged its nature for transformation through righteousness; after the Three Dynasties, the world exchanged its nature for things. The longer the world endures, the more its simplicity scatters. Boyi died for fame, for he could not weaken his resolve; Robber Zhi died for profit, for he could not strengthen his bones.

Zang represents the goodness of righteousness; Gu represents the goodness of trustworthiness. A male slave who marries a maidservant is called Zang; a female slave who marries a male servant is called Gu. Men value righteousness; women value trustworthiness—thus it is. The sheep is a creature that is docile yet not partisan, reverent yet observant of ritual. Its nature is never not good. The creators of characters took *yang* (sheep) with *yan* (speech) to form *shan* (goodness), and *yang* with *da* (great) to form *mei* (beauty). Thus, Zhuangzi’s use of the lost sheep as a metaphor for lost virtue is fitting. Zang and Gu differed in restraint and indulgence, yet were equal in losing their sheep; Boyi and Robber Zhi differed in goodness and evil, yet were equal in maiming life.

How then can one distinguish between the gentleman and the petty man? The *Bixu* commentary states: "Where there is pursuit, there is compliance." Once fame and reputation become manifest, advancement cannot be evaded. Zang and Gu lost their sheep—this is minor confusion leading to the loss of direction. Boyi and Robber Zhi maimed life—this is great confusion leading to the loss of nature. If all under Heaven pursue [external things], then even Robber Zhi becomes a Boyi. What distinction remains between gentleman and petty man?

*Yongzhai* observes: "To speak of the realm, the state, fame, and profit in the same breath is to diminish the great by the small, to debase the high by the low—this is the general tendency of the text." The deeds of these several men differ, yet their maiming of life is one; their studies and diversions differ, yet their loss of the sheep is equal. All are errors of compliance with things.

Did Zhuangzi not know the worthiness or baseness of Boyi and Robber Zhi? His intent was to satirize the gentleman, and so he borrowed the petty man to illustrate it—this too is the intent to debase the high by the low. In high antiquity, simplicity and sincerity prevailed; the customs of the people were harmonious. They required no governance yet governed themselves, and thus the people rested in the naturalness of their allotted nature, while the ruler achieved transformation through dignified inaction.

From the Three Dynasties onward, nature was exchanged for things; the pursuit of artifice led to the loss of authenticity. Though the worthy and foolish, the noble and base differed, each took what they pursued to be right and did not perceive their distance from the Dao. Thus, their maiming of life and injury to nature were no different. Thereafter, those who ruled over the people established punishments, policies, rewards, and penalties to guide, regulate, encourage, and restrain them. Yet when both high and low grew weary, deceit and treachery arose. When punishments, policies, rewards, and penalties could no longer control them, the people ceased to be their people, and the state ceased to be their state. This truly originates in the mutual compliance of high and low, leading to the failure of both ruler and people.

The metaphor of Zang and Gu losing their sheep is most apt. Moreover, if all under Heaven pursue [external things], all lose their original Heaven-endowed nature and become mired in one-sided views. They even condemn those who do not comply—what distinction remains between gentleman and petty man? Boyi’s purity and Robber Zhi’s filth are as distinct as black and white to later ages. Yet the Master of the Mulberry Orchard blends them as one. In terms of what they pursued, none could avoid compliance; even the sage cannot escape judgment—how much less Robber Zhi?

The governance of the realm under Heaven is like a balance: to depress one side is to elevate the other, for the circumstances admit no alternative. Only by seeking equilibrium can harmony be achieved. If all under Heaven ceased compliance and avoided the maiming of life and injury to nature, then surely a distinction would exist between the sage and Robber Zhi! Yet the grounds of their goodness or evil must be observed from beyond the confines of benevolence, righteousness, sageliness, and wisdom.

*Collected Exegeses on the Meaning of the Southern Florescence True Scripture*, Scroll Twenty-Four, concludes.
#1 Guo’s edition reads "upright."
#2 The character "upright" is written as "inquiry."

*Collected Exegeses on the Meaning of the Southern Florescence True Scripture*, Scroll Twenty-Five.
By Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin.

**Outer Chapters: "Parallel Limbs," Chapter Three**

Moreover, those who bind their nature to benevolence and righteousness—though as discerning as Zengzi or Shi Yu—are not what I call *good*. Those who bind their nature to the five flavors—though as discerning as Yu Er—are not what I call *good*. Those who bind their nature to the five tones—though as discerning as Music Master Kuang—are not what I call *keen*. Those who bind their nature to the five colors—though as discerning as Li Zhu—are not what I call *clear-sighted*.

What I call *good* is not a matter of benevolence and righteousness, but of treasuring one’s own *power* alone. What I call *good* is not a matter of benevolence and righteousness, but of following the natural dispositions of one’s nature and fate. What I call *keen* is not a matter of hearing others, but of hearing oneself. What I call *clear-sighted* is not a matter of seeing others, but of seeing oneself.

Those who do not see themselves but see others, who do not attain themselves but attain others—these are people who grasp others’ attainments without attaining their own, who follow others’ satisfactions without satisfying themselves. Those who follow others’ satisfactions without satisfying themselves—whether Robber Zhi or Bo Yi—are equally given to excess and perversion.

I am ashamed before the *Dao* and *virtue*, and thus above I dare not cling to the conduct of benevolence and righteousness, while below I dare not engage in excess and perversion.

**Guo’s Commentary:**
Binding one’s nature to benevolence is merely following benevolence; only by letting nature flow freely through the five flavors can one be truly good. If one does not entrust it to oneself but binds it to others—however discerning those others may be—one has already lost oneself. Each should employ their ears and eyes without being constrained by Li Zhu or Music Master Kuang; only then is one truly keen and clear-sighted.

Thus, those who excel in self-attainment forget benevolence and are transformed. To regard benevolence and righteousness as good and harm oneself in pursuit of them is to act contrary to one’s nature and fate, even to the point of self-injury. If one’s own person is not humane, what can one do for others? Only by following one’s nature and fate can one benefit others without burdening oneself, aligning with self-attainment—this may be called good.

To sever oneself from Li Zhu and Music Master Kuang and rely solely on one’s own hearing and seeing is to preserve the keenness and clarity of all things. Those who do not see themselves but see others, who do not attain themselves but attain others, abandon themselves to imitate others. In imitating others, one has already perished. Though their paths of loss may differ, the loss is the same. Thus, ashamed before the *Dao* and *virtue*, I do not act, decline progress in obscurity, sever myself from conduct and fame, forget profit and loss, move freely amidst entanglements, and leave behind both self and others—this is all.

**Lü’s Commentary:**
Nature is what things belong to; it does not belong to things. Yet Zengzi and Shi Yu belong to benevolence, Yu Er to flavors, Music Master Kuang and Li Zhu to tones and colors—these are not what I call *good*. Treasuring one’s *power* is the essence of *good*; it is not that benevolence and righteousness can make one good, but that one follows the natural dispositions of one’s nature and fate.

To speak of benevolence and righteousness is to impose a label, and what is treasured remains uncertain. To follow the natural dispositions of one’s nature and fate is to be without labels and beyond naming—this is true *good*. The same applies to keenness and clarity: not hearing others but hearing oneself, not seeing others but seeing oneself—this is called seeing what is to be seen and hearing what is to be heard. If one’s seeing and hearing lie in others rather than oneself, one grasps others’ attainments, follows others’ satisfactions, and fails to attain one’s own nature and fate or satisfy oneself. Then Robber Zhi and Bo Yi—what difference is there between them? Both deviate from the true *Dao* and *virtue*.

Above, one does not act for the *Dao*; below, one does not act perversely—thus both are forgotten. Bo Yi was a sage, yet how could one who does not attain and satisfy himself be a sage? If he sought to rectify the stubborn and strengthen the weak through his conduct, he could not avoid acting. Zhuangzi speaks of the natural dispositions of nature and fate to forget both fame and profit, hence equating Bo Yi and Robber Zhi as excess and perversion. Yet when discussing lofty integrity and defiant conduct sufficient to correct the world, Bo Yi and Shu Qi’s integrity is ranked alongside Xu You, Shan Ju, Confucius, and Yan He in the *"Abdication of Kings"*—this is perplexing.

**Yi’s Commentary:**
*Binding* means nature is attached to something, not universally aligned with things without partiality. Thus, Zengzi, Shi Yu, Yu Er, Music Master Kuang, and Li Zhu—each bound to benevolence, flavors, tones, and colors—cannot avoid following external things, and are not what I call *good*. Treasuring one’s *power* means following the natural dispositions of one’s nature and fate. These natural dispositions—true nature, true flavor, true color, true tone—are what all things inherently possess, yet those individuals force them, failing to attain or satisfy themselves.

Only by being true to one’s nature can one avoid binding it to things, and then true flavors, tones, and colors become apparent. Containing one’s keenness leads to inward listening; containing one’s clarity leads to inner vision. Inward listening brings one to hear the *Dao*; inner vision brings one to see the *Dao*. When the *Dao* is attained, one’s nature is attained.

Those who do not see themselves but see others have lost themselves in chasing things. Those who do not attain themselves but attain others have strayed from their nature in seeking the *Dao*. Though Bo Yi and Robber Zhi differ, their excess and perversion are the same. Thus, one knows that hypocrisy and righteousness lead to the loss of the *Dao*, while excess and perversion disrupt *virtue*—both are what Zhuangzi does not do.

**Xiang’s Commentary:**
Where there is sound, there is true sound; where there is color, there is true color; where there is flavor, there is true flavor. The sounds that are sounded are heard, yet the true sounds have never been uttered. The colors that are colored are manifest, yet the true colors have never been displayed. The flavors that are tasted are known, yet the true flavors have never been presented.

The ears and eyes of humans are originally empty and still. When sounds and colors appear before them, the true is lost amid the false; the same applies to flavors. *Laozi* says: "The five colors blind the eyes; the five tones deafen the ears; the five flavors dull the palate." How much worse is it to multiply branches and bind one’s nature to them?

**Bixu’s Commentary:**
Zeng, Shi, Yu the Elder, Shi Kuang, and Li Zhu were all biased toward a single ability, enslaving their natures to external things and losing their celestial authenticity—how could this be called goodness? Those who treasure virtue regard self-attainment as goodness, following the natural inclinations of their nature and destiny, hearing and seeing for themselves alone. To seek what others seek or conform to what others conform to is to lose oneself to external things.

Thus, the superior do not dare to practice the seven virtues, nor the inferior to indulge in perverse excesses—this is how one nurtures the uprightness of nature and the correctness of destiny. *Yongzhai* says: To follow the natural inclinations of one’s nature and destiny is to accord with spontaneity. The discourse on hearing and seeing for oneself alone is its unique and unmatched insight. The entirety of the *Great Treasury* teachings does not surpass this meaning. Self-attainment and self-conformity are self-seeing and self-awakening.

Generally, to distinguish the original mind from external things, yet fail to grasp the original mind and instead chase after externals, is all perverse excess. The superior do not dare to cling to the conduct of benevolence and righteousness, nor the inferior to engage in perverse and deviant acts—doing good without approaching fame, doing evil without approaching punishment. The Dao/Way and virtue/power are spontaneity itself; to approach fame or punishment is to depart from spontaneity.

Observing Zhuangzi’s words here, how could he not be rectifying the mind and cultivating the person? His criticisms of Yao, Shun, Confucius, Zeng, Shi, and Boyi are not substantive arguments but merely the flourishes of his brush. If one’s nature is like the great void, exhausting it yields nothing, yet it is nowhere absent. Once it becomes attached to something, it falls into partiality and bias, no longer the uprightness of the Dao/Way and virtue/power.

Though Zeng, Shi, Li, and Kuang were endowed with exceptional qi, excelling in their particular strengths, from the perspective of the Dao/Way, they were still not free from perverse excess. How much worse is it to exalt others’ strengths while belittling their own, so that few avoid learning the steps of Deng Zhu! Thus, none of them can be considered truly good. True goodness lies in following the natural inclinations of one’s nature and destiny, emerging from the uprightness of the Dao/Way and virtue/power, without the faults of forced striving or partiality.

The ears, eyes, and mouth, in relation to sounds, colors, and flavors, neither forcibly penetrate nor forcibly resist, but follow their spontaneity without harboring private inclinations—this is the utmost correctness under heaven, and what external thing could disturb it? When one’s intelligence and clarity reach the point of hearing and seeing for oneself, it differs from the worldly intelligence and clarity. When one’s goodness lies in self-attainment and self-conformity, it differs from what the world calls goodness.

When benevolence and righteousness depart, the true nature is preserved—this is treasuring one’s virtue/power. Virtue/power resides within, and the Dao/Way comes to harmonize with it; how could external things find their way in? If one does not attain and conform to oneself but instead conforms to others, then it is all perverse excess. What distinction remains between the worthy and the unworthy?

The *Nanhua* [Zhuangzi] claims it does not dare to act either above or below but rests in the self-attainment of nature and destiny—this is the uprightness of the Dao/Way and virtue/power. The *Inner Chapters* of this classic were titled by the Master of Qi Garden [Zhuangzi], each with profound meaning. The *Outer* and *Miscellaneous Chapters* were edited and revised by Guo Xiang, who merely took the first characters of each chapter as their titles, though their essential meanings remain.

Since the *Inner Chapters* elaborate on the principles of the Dao/Way, virtue/power, nature, and destiny, the *Outer Chapters* begin by discussing what virtue/power and nature ought not to possess—like superfluous branches and tumors on the body. I humbly suggest that the original intent of this chapter derives from the *Daodejing*’s "leftover food and redundant conduct," illustrating how those who see and pride themselves on their own abilities are far from the Dao/Way. Yet the *Nanhua* [Zhuangzi] expounds upon this with such vast and flowing eloquence, for to propagate the Dao/Way and elucidate its teachings, one cannot but exhaust words to convey its meaning, dispelling the world’s delusions and guiding it back to spontaneity and harmony with the Dao/Way.

A person’s virtue/power is pure like jade within uncut stone. As it is gradually nourished, it shines like wood and illumines like mountains. But when carved by intelligence or divided by the seven virtues, seeking goodness in external things, one’s innate simplicity is lost. Thus, he cites Zeng, Shi, Li, Kuang, Yang, and Mo—those who grasped only a partial aspect of their nature and followed perverse habits—as examples of the "superfluous branches" of the Dao/Way. Yet the world still rushes to admire them, losing the natural inclinations of their nature and destiny and departing from the uprightness of the Dao/Way and virtue/power—this is how the world is thrown into chaos.

Only by forgetting their differences and unifying them, like the hare and the crane, which have no need for interruption or continuity yet each loses nothing of its spontaneity, can one approach the Dao/Way. Yet if the world is all deluded, what can I do? Thus, he sets forth the parable of Zang and Gu losing their sheep to illustrate how Boyi and Robber Zhi each took their own biases as the distinction between gentleman and petty man, though both harm life and injure nature in the same way.

If one truly can abandon traces and cease esteeming, so that one’s nature has no attachments, return to the root and merge with the ultimate, and wander in the origin of things, then superfluous branches and tumors will be forgotten along with the body. Gentlemen and petty men alike will attain self-possession, and thus the ultimate lies in following the natural inclinations of nature and destiny, while one’s original intelligence and clarity remain undiminished.

Not hearing others but hearing for oneself, not seeing others but seeing for oneself—this aligns with what Yanzi called "the benevolent loving themselves, the wise knowing themselves." Thus, self-attainment and self-conformity leave no room for envy or longing, and the distinctions between the worthiness of Yi and the baseness of Pi will become clear.

The twenty-fifth fascicle of *The Ocean of Subtleties in the Meaning of the True Classic of Nanhua* concludes.
The twenty-sixth fascicle of *The Ocean of Subtleties in the Meaning of the True Classic of Nanhua* begins.

The Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin comments on "The Horse’s Hooves" (Chapter One):

Horses’ hooves can tread frost and snow, their coats can ward off wind and cold; they graze on grass and drink from streams, lift their hooves and gallop across the land—this is the true nature of horses. Even if there were halls of righteousness and royal chambers, they would have no use for them.

Yet when Bo Le arrived, he declared, “I am skilled in managing horses.” He branded them, pared them, carved them, and pierced them; he bound them with halters and hobbles, penned them in blackened stalls—and thus twelve or thirteen out of every hundred horses perished. He starved them, parched them, galloped them, raced them, drilled them, and aligned them; ahead lay the peril of ornamental trappings, behind the threat of whips and scorn—and thus more than half the horses died.

The potter says, “I am skilled in shaping clay: round vessels meet the compass, square ones meet the carpenter’s square.” The craftsman says, “I am skilled in working wood: curved pieces fit the hook, straight ones align with the marking line.” But do the nature of clay and wood truly desire to conform to compass, square, hook, and line?

Yet generation after generation, people praise Bo Le for his skill in managing horses, and potters and craftsmen for their skill in shaping clay and wood—this is also the error of those who govern the world.

Guo’s commentary: Whether a horse is slow or swift, each is sufficient in its own nature; it does not reject the saddle out of hatred for riding, but merely does not covet splendor. When one deliberately seeks to manage it, one fails to manage it. What is called “good management” is in fact the beginning of harm. Those who excel in driving horses aim to exhaust their abilities, yet exhausting ability lies in allowing them to act on their own. Instead, they force them into rapid strides, seeking performance beyond their capacity—hence many cannot endure and perish. If one were to rely on the strength of slow and swift horses alike, adapting to their natural pace, then even if their tracks reached the farthest corners of the earth, the nature of all horses would remain intact.

Some, hearing of allowing horses to follow their nature, claim this means letting them roam untethered; hearing of the wind of non-action, they say inaction is inferior to external effort—how reckless and unreturning! The world deems those who follow nature without artifice as poor managers, while those who use compass and square to distort nature until death are called skilled—is this not a grave error?

Lü’s commentary: When horses graze and drink without coveting halls of righteousness or royal chambers, it is like farmers and weavers being self-sufficient without yearning for lofty positions. Bo Le’s branding, paring, carving, and piercing of horses—causing twelve or thirteen out of a hundred to die—is like forcing benevolence and righteousness upon the world, sowing the first seeds of doubt. Starving, parching, galloping, and racing them until more than half die is like bending and breaking ritual and music, causing the world to fracture. The world has its constant nature; one should act according to it. Yet potters and craftsmen, in their skill at shaping round, square, curved, and straight forms, all violate this constant nature. To govern the world while violating its constant nature is to fail to understand the Dao of “letting be” and thus err in governance.

Yi Du’s commentary: The true nature of horses is to roam freely in the wilds without coveting halls of righteousness or royal chambers. Yet when Bo Le arrives, he brands, pares, carves, and pierces them, and twelve or thirteen out of a hundred horses die; he starves, parches, gallops, and races them, and more than half perish. All this is due to exalting artificiality and rigidifying true nature. Potters and craftsmen shape clay and wood to meet compass, square, hook, and line—but is this what clay and wood desire? The sage’s governance of the world through benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music is no different. Yet the world praises Bo Le for his skill in managing horses, craftsmen for their skill in shaping clay and wood, and sages for their skill in governing the world—all because the great Dao has scattered, the wholeness of heaven and earth is no longer seen, and only the governance of people is lauded. This is why Zhuangzi so deeply condemns it.

Xiang Dao’s commentary: Earth has form but no life, wood has life but no awareness, horses have awareness but no sense of duty—though these three differ, those who excel in managing them all follow their nature without violating their spontaneity, adhere to their principles without imposing force. Thus, horses exhaust their abilities, and clay and wood fulfill their uses. How could those who excel in governing the world be any different?

Bi Xu’s commentary: The knowledge of horses extends only to grazing, drinking, and galloping across the land. Having no use for halls of righteousness or royal chambers is like the marsh pheasant’s refusal to be caged. Yet when Bo Le begins to manage them, their nature is already harmed; their strength cannot bear the burden, and more than half die. Earth has its round and square forms, so potters apply compass and square; wood has its curved and straight grains, so craftsmen use hook and line; horses have their slow and swift natures, so Bo Le wields whips and scorn; people have their worthy and foolish natures, so sages establish laws and standards—all are responses to their inherent qualities. Those who later drive horses to ruin do not possess Bo Le’s talent; those who govern the people and fail do not follow the sage’s Dao. Yet they blame Bo Le and the sages—this is to misunderstand true skill, which is why Zhuangzi laments.

Yongzhai’s note: *Yi tai* and *lu qin* are the dwellings of kings. An alternate reading is *Xi tai*, meaning “nurturing,” for environment transforms qi, and nurture transforms the body. Burning, paring, carving, and scraping are all forms of management. *Zhui* refers to bridling the head.

The term *bi* refers to hobbling the feet; *lian* means "to arrange in order"; *gen* is the bit; *shi* encompasses trappings like reins and tassels. Horses are controlled by humans and cannot follow their own nature, which is why so many perish. Potters and carpenters shape clay and wood into vessels—no different from horses subjected to burning, paring, carving, and bridling. Yet people praise Bo Le and craftsmen as skilled, just as those below the era of Tai Shi extol rulers for governing the world. All things possess inherent natures, and people possess inherent virtues; when virtue remains unsevered, human nature is preserved. Why then pursue excessive demands and overindulgence, harming virtue and injuring nature?
