The True Person laments that in this degenerate age, humanity destroys Heaven’s endowment, refusing to abide by its original allotment while seeking knowledge beyond its proper bounds. From rulers governing subjects to subjects serving rulers, all are ensnared in the web of cunning and defense. As knowledge proliferates, the hearts of the unworthy respond in kind—even severe punishments and harsh laws cannot restrain them. The root of this disorder lies in the rulers’ excessive love of knowledge, which sparks a thirst for it and then imposes it through instruction. Is this not laborious and meddlesome? To rectify the source and purify the origin, to eradicate these ills, the text uses the horse as a metaphor to expose the failures of governance, hoping that those entrusted with the Way of rule may take heed.

Since the Three Dynasties, human nature has strayed, and the establishment of punishments, policies, rewards, and penalties—these four are the reins, trappings, whips, and scorn of governing the world. Yet the sprouts of cunning and deceit arise precisely from this. The later passage speaks of those who "steal even the wisdom of sages"—this is the same flaw.

What then should today’s rulers do? They should prioritize the Dao and virtue, with the four measures as auxiliaries—this would suffice. To abandon the Dao and virtue while relying solely on punishments and policies is no different from Bo Le’s treatment of horses. Though swift steeds may distinguish themselves, the harm suffered by horses is not slight. If one neither embraces the Dao nor employs the four measures, not even a single household can be ordered—how then could the world be governed? The analogy of the potter’s kiln does not depart from the earlier meaning; the fault lies with us.

The phrase "skillful governance" betrays self-congratulation and a deliberate effort to impose order—how can this restore human nature and preserve inherent virtue? Thus, the text says: *This is the error of those who govern the world.* My view is that those who truly govern well do not act thus. People possess inherent natures: they weave to clothe themselves and farm to feed themselves—this is called "shared virtue." Uniting without faction is called "Heaven’s spontaneity." In the age of utmost virtue, their movements are steady, their gazes unassuming. At that time, mountains had no paths or tunnels, marshes no boats or bridges; the myriad things grew wild, their villages contiguous; birds and beasts thrived in herds, grasses and trees flourished unchecked. Thus, one could lead beasts by a tether and wander freely, or climb to inspect the nests of crows and magpies. In the age of utmost virtue, humans dwelled alongside birds and beasts, mingled with the myriad things—how could one distinguish between noble and base? With shared ignorance, their virtue remained unsevered; with shared desirelessness, they embodied uncarved simplicity. In simplicity, human nature is preserved.

Yet when sages arose, they clambered to promote benevolence, strained to uphold righteousness—and the world began to doubt. They sprawled into music, dissected into ritual—and the world began to divide. If unhewn simplicity is not marred, who would fashion sacrificial vessels? If white jade is not shattered, who would carve ceremonial tablets? If the Dao and virtue are not abandoned, why adopt benevolence and righteousness? If nature and emotion remain unsevered, why employ ritual and music? If the five colors are not disordered, who would create patterned designs? If the five tones are not confused, who would harmonize the six pitches?

To carve simplicity into vessels is the craftsman’s crime; to destroy the Dao and virtue for benevolence and righteousness is the sage’s error.

Guo’s commentary: *To govern by non-governance is true governance.* The virtues of the people differ in small ways but align in the essentials. What cannot be forsaken is clothing and food; what cannot be abandoned is farming and weaving—these are the shared foundations of the world. Those who uphold this Way reach the pinnacle of non-action, so that when left to themselves, they naturally unite—not through faction, but through Heaven’s spontaneity. *Steady and unassuming* describes contentment without external cravings. Not seeking undeserved gains, they find sufficiency within their households. In primordial chaos, all things attain their due, and the world dwells in tranquil indifference—how could states differ or households diverge? Content with their nature, free from rapacious desires, they harmonize with things without harm, their virtue unsevered and their nature preserved in simplicity, untroubled by knowledge or desire.

The sage is the thoroughfare through which the people attain their nature—not the means by which it is obstructed. The phrase "when sages arose" is akin to saying "when the thoroughfare emerged." Once the sage’s progress is manifest, benevolence and righteousness lose their authenticity, ritual and music depart from nature, and only their outward forms remain. With sages come these ills—what is to be done?

To carve simplicity into vessels, shatter jade into tablets, transform plain colors into patterns, and tune sounds to pitch—all are shifts from the unhewn to the ornate, abandoning roots to exalt branches, marring Heaven’s simplicity. Though the world may prize these things, they are not true treasures. Craftsmen have their compasses and squares; sages have their vaunted progress.

Lü’s commentary: When the people return to their inherent nature and do not stray from their truth, the so-called sages cannot be seen. Thus, desireless and simple, there is no doubt; with shared virtue and no division, there is no separation. But once truth is forsaken and sages emerge, promoting benevolence and righteousness not from spontaneity, instituting ritual and music not from perfect rectitude—the world begins to doubt and divide. Carving simplicity into vessels illustrates the destruction of the Dao and virtue for benevolence and righteousness; shattering jade into tablets illustrates the severance of emotion and nature for ritual and music. All are superfluous, branching paths.

Abandon craft and return to simplicity, and the craftsman’s crime is erased; discard benevolence and righteousness to embrace the Dao and virtue, and the sage’s error is absolved.

The *Yi Du Zhu* states: The divine beings of antiquity, in their governance of the world, held no intent to rule, but followed the people’s constant nature, aligning only with the ultimate of the true mandate. They wove to clothe themselves, tilled to feed themselves, shared virtue in mutual kinship, and formed no factions. That which is "heavenly released" arises from spontaneity, not human artifice. "Filled" means replete within; "manifest" means truth revealed without. They acted as their feet led them, not by crooked paths, trusted what their eyes beheld, and did not stray into depravity. Birds and beasts, grasses and trees—all fulfilled the principle of their natures without premature decay or obstruction. Beasts could be tethered, nests could be approached, for when humans lacked cunning hearts, creatures had nothing to fear. Dwelling together in tribes, the people rejoiced of themselves—how would they know of gentlemen or petty men? To be "the same in non-knowing" is not to lack innate knowledge; to be "the same in non-desiring" is not to lack what may be desired. It begins with virtue undivided and ends in what is called uncarved simplicity—the people’s constant nature is thus attained.

"Zheng-dun-ti-fu" describes the exertion of effort. To practice benevolence and righteousness without following the principle of nature and mandate is to begin the world’s doubt. "Straying and diffuse" is the dissipation of music; "selective and partial" is the bias of ritual. From transformed righteousness arise ritual and music; from ritual and music, nature and emotion become divided—this is how the world comes to be split. Now, benevolence and righteousness emerge from the Dao and virtue, while ritual and music arise from nature and emotion. In high antiquity, the age was plain and the people simple: benevolence and righteousness were one with the Dao and virtue, ritual and music were inseparable from nature and emotion. In later ages, the Dao and virtue were abandoned in favor of benevolence and righteousness, nature and emotion were set aside to discuss ritual and music—thus arose the benevolence and righteousness of Zeng and Shi, which were not the righteousness of Yao and Shun, and the ritual and music of the common age, which were not the ritual and music of the Three Dynasties. This is why Laozi sought to strike them down and eradicate them, and why Zhuangzi likewise rejected them. To carve simplicity into vessels, the craftsman cannot but bear guilt; in seeking to remedy near corruption, even the sage cannot but incur error.

The *Xiang Dao Zhu* states: In the age of utmost virtue, nurturing life did not yield to craving or desire, and their conduct was full and steady, their gaze direct and unerring. What they sought did not exceed their proper share, so mountains had no paths or tunnels, and marshes no boats or bridges. Thus, they saw others as themselves, saw themselves as things, forgot both self and other, and made no distinction between inner and outer. This is why they could enter among beasts without disturbing the herd, or among birds without disrupting their flight—how would they know of gentlemen or petty men? The mind may possess knowledge and choose, yet return to non-knowing and embrace all; the will may have desires and move, yet the bones stand without desire. In governing the world, the sage empties what has knowledge and fills what has none, thus enabling the people to be the same in non-knowing; weakens what has desire and strengthens what has none, thus enabling the people to be the same in non-desiring. Non-knowing ensures virtue remains undivided; non-desiring ensures the people remain in uncarved simplicity. "Unadorned" is the substance of nature, pure and white, unstained by things. "Uncarved" is the wholeness of nature, undifferentiated and unscattered into vessels. As the *Laozi* says: "Manifest the unadorned, embrace the uncarved, lessen selfishness, diminish desire." The scripture states: "Unadorned and uncarved, none in the world contend with them"—this is the abundance that comes from attaining the people’s nature.

The *Bi Xu Zhu* states: The people have a constant nature: they know to weave for clothing and till for food, are one and form no factions, roam in spontaneity, trade has not yet arisen, they do not visit one another, customs are frugal and things flourish, within there is no cunning and without there is no fear—thus uncarved and simple, the people’s nature is attained. Those who are unskilled in governance exert effort to practice benevolence, pride themselves on upholding righteousness, depart from the Dao to do good, and harbor doubt without trust. They bend and twist to create ritual, indulge in excess for music, act with treacherous virtue, and split the harmony of equilibrium. Sacrificial vessels and the six pitch-pipes are all methods of orderly governance, but in excess they become disorder. That this is called the craftsman’s guilt and the sage’s error reveals the common tendency of past and present to assign blame only when ruin is evident.

The *Fu Qi* states: "Shared virtue" means what they receive from heaven is the same. "Constant nature" is what the previous chapter called "constant thusness"—pure and without faction, freely delighting in spontaneity. "Full and steady" describes contentment; "direct and unerring" describes straightforward gazing—both depict their artless, uncalculating manner. "Mountains have no paths or tunnels" means roads were not yet opened; "marshes have no boats or bridges" means fords were not yet established.

All things perpetually thrive, bound to their native lands; birds and beasts dwell intermingled, yet nothing harms another. Grasses and trees grow unchecked, never suffering the calamity of axe or adze. Beasts roam tethered, nests are climbed and inspected—humans and creatures forget one another. In such a state, how could there be any division between noble and base? Without knowledge or desire, they are purely of heaven’s principle.

Yet when sages arise, they forcibly enact benevolence and righteousness, disseminating rites and music, and only then do preferences begin to diverge, no longer purely one. The Way and virtue are natural; Zhuangzi treats benevolence and righteousness as external, thus saying: "When the Way and virtue are not abandoned, why seek benevolence and righteousness?" Nature and emotion are inherent; Zhuangzi treats rites and music as forced upon the world, thus saying: "When nature and emotion are not estranged, why employ rites and music?" Ornamentation disorders the five colors; the six pitch-pipes disorder the five tones—all are metaphors for human effort, not spontaneity. The craftsman’s guilt and the sage’s error serve to conclude the preceding passage.

The earlier discussion of governance’s ills sought to reform them; thus it is said that good governance is otherwise. Above is set forth the age of utmost virtue, where the people’s nature is truly pure and without longing, where clothing and food suffice and there is no craving for excess. "Mountains have no paths or tunnels, marshes have no boats or bridges"—this means the people do not travel, and boats and carriages have no use. "Living things are bound together, grasses and trees grow unchecked"—this speaks of their flourishing abundance. "Beasts may be tethered, bird nests may be climbed"—this speaks of their artless merging with things. From this we know that phoenixes nest in towers and unicorns roam in parks: the utmost harmony summons them, and this principle is indeed so.

In such a state, those above have no desires, those below have no knowledge; virtue is not estranged, and the people remain simple. How then could there be any division between noble and base? Yet in later ages, sages governed the world through action, exerting themselves in benevolence and righteousness, striving to establish rites and music—only then did the people begin to doubt, and the world begin to divide.

Thus the *Nanhua* deems the carving of unhewn wood and the cutting of jade the craftsman’s guilt, and the abandonment of the Way for benevolence the sage’s error. Yet if unhewn wood and jade are not carved, how can vessels be made? If benevolence and righteousness are not established, how can the Way be protected? It is said: the world’s unhewn wood has long since scattered—there is no end to the need for vessels. The Way of the sages has long since scattered: first it transformed into benevolence and righteousness, then into rites and music, and now benevolence, righteousness, rites, and music remain in name alone. This will cause later generations to lament those who come after.

Here ends *Fascicle Twenty-Six of the Ocean of Meanings in the True Scripture of the Nanhua*.

**Fascicle Twenty-Seven of the Ocean of Meanings in the True Scripture of the Nanhua**

*[Note: The Guo annotation version writes 练 as 驰.]*

**Chapter Two: "Horse’s Hooves"**

Now, the horse—dwelling on land, it eats grass and drinks water; when joyful, it rubs necks with its kin; when enraged, it turns its back and kicks. This is all the horse knows. Yet when a crossbar is fastened upon it, when its head is adorned with crescent-shaped ornaments, the horse learns to swerve, to balk, to startle, to feign, to gnaw the bit, and to steal the reins. Thus, the horse’s knowledge and ability to become a thief are the fault of Bo Le.

In the age of Emperor Hexu, the people dwelt without knowing what to do, wandered without knowing where to go, chewed their food in contentment, and strolled with bellies full—this was all they knew how to do. But when the sages came, bending and shaping rites and music to correct the forms of the world, dangling the snares of benevolence and righteousness to soothe the hearts of the world, the people then began to stretch and strain for cunning, to vie for profit without cease. This, too, is the fault of the sages.

*Guo’s annotation:* If one guides by true knowledge and rides by nature, then a journey of ten thousand *li* may be reached without losing the horse’s true nature. Yet when horses of differing natures are uniformly pressed into service, their strength is exhausted, and their postures become forced.

The people’s true ability lay in chewing their food and strolling with full bellies. But when the sages bent and shaped them with rites and music, dangled the seven virtues before them, the people began to crave knowledge—all these faults arise from urging them toward what is esteemed.

*Lü’s annotation:* The horse’s eating grass and drinking water, its rubbing and kicking, are all it knows—just as the people of Emperor Hexu’s time, without knowledge or striving, chewed their food and strolled with full bellies. The fastening of the crossbar and the adorning with crescent ornaments are like the bending and shaping of rites and music, the dangling of the seven virtues to correct and soothe the world. The horse’s learning to swerve, feign, gnaw the bit, and steal the reins is like the people’s stretching, straining, craving knowledge, and vying for profit without cease.

To swerve (*jieni*) is to resist control; to balk (*yine*) is to refuse restraint; to startle (*jing*) is to be struck with fear; to feign (*man*) is to simulate illness—all describe the horse’s state of fury. To gnaw the bit (*guixian*) is to free the bit itself; to steal the reins (*qiepei*) is to slip free of the reins. When man harms the horse’s true nature, it becomes crafty and turns to theft. This is the fault of Bo Le.

If one wishes the horse’s knowledge not to lead to theft and the human heart not to crave knowledge, there is no other way—only by returning to true nature.

*Yi Du’s annotation:* The horse’s true nature lies in eating when hungry, drinking when thirsty, submitting when joyful, and kicking when enraged—it knows nothing beyond this. But when the crossbar is fastened and the crescent ornaments are applied (the crescent-shaped ornament on the forehead resembles the moon; *qi* means to adorn and arrange), the horse’s body is labored, and so it learns to swerve. *Jie* is like the *jie* in "attendant" (*binjie*), referring to those who assist the horse on either side. *Ni* is the same as in "herdsman" (*maoni*), meaning the one who tends the horse. When the horse is constrained by man, it learns of attendants and herdsmen, and deceit arises.

To balk (*chan*) is to block the will; to restrain (*e*) is to prevent the body from stretching; to startle (*jing*) is like being struck with fear; to feign (*man*) is like being stricken with illness—all describe its state of fury. To gnaw the bit (*guixian*) is to free the bit; to steal the reins (*qiepei*) is to slip free of the reins. When man harms the horse’s true nature, it becomes crafty and turns to theft. This is the fault of Bo Le.

Emperor Hexu was a sovereign of high antiquity. The people dwelt without knowing what to do, wandered without knowing where to go, chewed their food in contentment, and strolled with bellies full—like infants, they knew nothing beyond this. The bending and shaping of rites are but the ends of propriety, able only to correct outward forms but not the nature and emotions. The dangling of benevolence and righteousness is but the ends of virtue, sufficient to soothe the heart but unable to bring lasting peace.

Thus the people’s love of knowledge knows no end—this, too, is the fault of the sages.

*Xiang Dao’s Commentary* notes: The sages soothed the hearts of the world with benevolence and righteousness, and the people first began to doubt; they corrected the forms of the world with rites and music, and the people first began to divide. A horse eating grass and drinking water is like the people plowing to eat and weaving to clothe themselves. When pleased, they rub necks together; when angered, they turn their backs on one another—just as the people remain one and do not form factions. Piercing oxen and bridling horses are all the faults of human artifice. That horses, through their cunning, can become thieves—is this good horsemanship? Thus this chapter, from beginning to end, speaks of this to condemn the extremes of human artifice.

I say: to abandon the Dao and virtue and pursue benevolence and righteousness is to leave ruler and minister, father and son unable to avoid division and doubt. To abandon benevolence and righteousness and follow the Dao and virtue is to dwell in kinship even with birds and beasts and the myriad things. Thus the chapter concludes with Hexu.

*Bixu’s Commentary* notes: The true knowledge of horses was known only by Zaofu and Taibing, who, without applying whip or spur, could ride a thousand *li* in a day. But from Bo Le onward, horses were fitted with crossbars and bits, their foreheads marked with moon-shaped plates, and thus they could not escape the vices of gnawing the bit and stealing the reins. The constant nature of the people was known only by Hexu, who, without establishing laws and measures, allowed them all to follow their Heaven-given nature. But from Yao and Shun onward, rites and music bent and shaped them, benevolence and righteousness were dangled before them, rewards and punishments were added, and strife never ceased—its ills grew ever worse. Thus it is called the fault of the sages.

*The Oral Teachings of Yongqi* states: This passage takes the earlier argument and turns it to even greater wonder. Observe its phrases "rubbing necks" and "turning backs"—they vividly show the states of joy and anger. The "moon-shaped plate" is what we now call the forehead mirror. *Jie* means "alone," the state of standing apart and glaring in anger. *Min’e* means curving the neck to resist the bit. *Jing* means fierce. *Man* means sudden. It describes their resistance to bridling, their cunning in slipping the bit, their stealth in seizing the reins, and their defiance of human control—hence they are called thieves, and this is Bo Le’s doing. Had there been no crossbars, bits, or reins, how could their defiant, glaring, resistant postures have appeared? The people’s love of knowledge and competition for profit are no different from the horses’ gnawing of bits and stealing of reins.

The sages of antiquity took the well-being of the world as their duty, fearing even a single person might lose their place. They sought to nurture and secure them—how could this have been for worldly gain? It arose from the truth of human nature and the uprightness of the Dao and virtue, from what was right for them to do. This is called "the highest virtue does not act as virtue," "the lower know only that it exists," and "praise and fame do not reach it." But in later ages, simplicity scattered and the people grew cunning; deceit and artifice arose. Those who responded to the mandate of the sages crawled and toiled, striving to rescue the people from fire and water. They earnestly guided them, awakening them from their delusions. They loved and benefited them, and benevolence flourished; they restrained and regulated them, and righteousness bore fruit; they ordered and adorned them, and rites arose; they harmonized and delighted them, and music emerged. This, too, was a matter of following what the people valued and adapting to what was fitting, establishing institutions—it was not yet a grave departure. Yet when governance endures, the people grow complacent; when laws endure, abuses arise. Reforms become harsh, strict orders invite transgression—such is the inevitable course of events.

Alas! Once the seven apertures are drilled, can one ever return to the state of chaos? This is why *The Horses’ Hooves* was written, and why its metaphors and analogies are so numerous and far-reaching. The final section returns to the true knowledge of horses, restoring the chapter’s original intent. It cites the age of Hexu, when the people knew only to chew their food and drum their bellies, content in effortless ease—from this, one can see that those above did not disturb them.

The *Nanhua* [i.e., *Zhuangzi*] invokes the past to illuminate the present, hoping to restore a fraction of the ancient purity. Yet how can the world’s ways, rushing toward profit without cease, be halted? In the end, it ascribes blame to the sages—how could a gentleman of words refrain from doing so? It is urgent in warning the people’s hearts and rescuing the age’s ills, and thus it must invert matters to correct them. Yet some criticize it as the work of a disgruntled hero—this is a mistake! Those who would truly understand the *Zhuangzi* should grasp its intent and overlook its words.

*Jieni* was formerly read as *jiani*, a harsh sound with an obscure meaning. Here it is restored to its original pronunciation: when people use knowledge to control horses, the horses’ knowledge first shows signs of defiance, plotting to gnaw the bit and steal the reins. Thus horses are not inherently cunning—it is humans who awaken their cunning.

This chapter’s single intent is divided into four sections. The first introduces the theme, using the governance of horses to illustrate the governance of the people. This aligns with the *Book of Documents*’ metaphor of horse-tending for ruling the people, but here the chapter’s beginning and end depict the horse’s nature, emotions, joys, and angers with such vivid detail that even the finest painter could not surpass it. How, then, could the goodness or badness of the human heart escape its keen judgment?

The second section borrows the metaphor of molding clay to develop the argument, stating that deliberate action in governance, bending and distorting the people’s nature, is inferior to non-action and allowing things to transform themselves. It then cites the age of utmost virtue, when there was no knowledge or desire, and the later kings’ establishment of laws, which first caused the world to doubt—no different from Bo Le’s burning, branding, carving, and boring to pursue the "gait of the wind," which was called governance but brought the greatest harm. This is what is meant by the sages’ fault: they set up benevolence, righteousness, rites, and music to teach the people, commanding and urging them, fearing they would not comply. Yet they did not realize that as branches and leaves flourished, roots and trunks withered; as government became more manifest, deceit and abuses arose. This is how simplicity scattered, punishments arose, and strife between high and low never ceased.

Thus the *Qiushui* [i.e., *Zhuangzi*] speaks loftily to correct this, using broad analogies to transform the world, urging it to abandon falsity and return to truth, to know where to turn. In this, one sees that the heart of the perfected person has not yet hardened toward the world. The final section invokes the ancient people’s simplicity and the thickness of their customs, their joyful ease, to prove the efficacy of the ancient kings’ non-action. Later sages bound them with rites and music, soothed them with benevolence and righteousness, and sought governance to excess—until it became ungovernable.

The Supreme One says: "Governing a great state is like cooking a small fish." The *Nanhua*’s discourse grasps this truth.

**End of Chapter 27 of *The Ocean of Subtle Meanings in the True Scripture of Nanhua* #1**
*(Note: “能” is a loan character for “态”.)*

**Chapter 28 of *The Ocean of Subtle Meanings in the True Scripture of Nanhua*, Compiled by Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin**

**Opening the Strongbox**

To guard against thieves who pry open strongboxes, rummage through bags, or break into chests, one must tighten cords, fasten locks, and secure bolts—this is what the common world calls "wisdom." Yet when a great thief arrives, he hoists the chest, lifts the box, and shoulders the bag, fleeing with all haste, only fearing that the cords and locks are not secure enough. Thus, what was once called "harmony" has become nothing more than stockpiling for the great thief.

Let us examine this: Is there any so-called "wisdom" in the common world that does not accumulate for the great thief? Is there any so-called "sage" who does not guard for the great thief? How do we know this is so?

In ancient times, the villages of Qi were so close that one could see their neighbors and hear the cries of their chickens and dogs. Nets and snares were spread, and plows and hoes tilled the land across more than two thousand *li*. Within its four borders, the establishment of ancestral temples, altars of soil and grain, cities, houses, prefectures, districts, townships, and hamlets—was there ever a time when these were not modeled after the sages? Yet one morning, Tian Chengzi killed the ruler of Qi and stole his state. What he stole was not merely the state—he also seized the sages’ wisdom and laws. Thus, Tian Chengzi bore the name of a bandit, yet lived in the security of Yao and Shun; small states dared not condemn him, and great states dared not punish him. For twelve generations, he held Qi. Was this not stealing the state along with its sagely laws to guard his bandit’s body?

Guo’s commentary: "Accumulating for the great thief, guarding for the great thief—this is how unreliable wisdom proves to be. Those who model themselves after sages follow only their traces, and traces are but the remnants of what has passed, not tools for responding to change. How can they be revered and clung to? Clinging to fixed forms to govern the boundless, when the boundless arrives, one becomes obstructed. This is why one guards a state only to have it guarded by others. If the great thief does not steal the sagely laws, he has no means to overthrow the state. Sagely laws are merely tools for human use, not instruments of perfect governance."

Lü’s commentary: "Tightening cords and fastening locks to prevent thieves from prying open boxes or breaking into chests—this is what the common world calls 'wisdom.' Yet when the great thief arrives, he carries them off, only fearing they are not secure enough. Thus, is there any so-called 'wisdom' in the common world that does not accumulate for the great thief? Establishing ancestral temples, altars of soil and grain, cities, houses, prefectures, and districts to guard the four borders—this is what the common world calls 'sageliness.' Tian Chengzi stole Qi along with its sagely laws to guard his bandit’s body. Is there any so-called 'sage' who does not guard for the great thief? Such is the sageliness and wisdom of the common world—true sageliness and wisdom are not like this!"

Yu Du’s commentary: "To *dun* is to secretly open. Tightening cords and fastening locks—this is the wisdom of the common world, sufficient only to fend off petty thieves. When the great thief arrives, he carries them off, and the very cords and locks that were meant to prevent theft instead become resources for the thief. The 'wisdom' of the common world is not the wisdom that encompasses all things, so it inevitably accumulates for the great thief. The 'sageliness' of the common world is not the unknowable sageliness, so it inevitably guards for the great thief. This is why Laozi and Zhuangzi sought to abandon it. Tian Cheng stole the state along with its sagely laws to guard his bandit’s body. Thus, all the sagely institutions that appear in the laws are not exempt from theft. Yet to compare Tian Cheng’s security to that of Yao and Shun—is this not excessive?

One may ask: All those who possess a body and are entrusted with the world are but husks and remnants—what is there to compare in terms of superiority or inferiority? As for Yao and Shun, who could not be entrusted with the world, how could Tian Chengzi be placed on par with them?"

Bi Xu’s commentary: "*Zhi* refers to those who craft baskets, chests, cords, and locks. *Ji* refers to those who amass and hoard treasures. *Sheng* refers to those who wield tallies, weights, scales, axes, and halberds. *Shou* refers to those who protect ancestral temples, altars of soil and grain, and borders. Moreover, the institutions and laws established in Qi were never not modeled after the sages, yet Tian Cheng seized their sagely wisdom and took possession of the state. Thus, sagely wisdom becomes the resource of the great thief!"

Yongzhai’s commentary: "The wisdom of the common world is originally meant to guard against petty thieves. When the great thief arrives, he carries it all away. When the Tian clan usurped Qi, they lent grain at private measures but collected at public ones—this is evident in the *Zuozhuan*. They borrowed the sages’ laws to advance their bandit schemes, as was common in the Warring States period. This is why Zhuangzi used this analogy. Guarding against thieves with cords and locks is the wisdom of the common world. Breaking into houses, shouldering chests, and rummaging through bags—this is the wisdom that transcends the common. How often does one encounter such transcendent wisdom in the workings of creation? If used to steal the harmony of heaven to nourish the body and preserve the spirit, or to steal the benefits of earth to enrich one’s family and state, what could not be achieved? Yet instead, one covets the hidden treasures of a room, seeking ill-gotten gains while disregarding the inescapable judgment of the public and the indelible stench of infamy. How can one not reflect deeply on this?

I have examined the cause: If the world had no accumulations to guard, how could thieves seize them? From the desire to fill one’s baskets to the theft of a state—truly, one must be vigilant against the first frost, lest it lead to solid ice! The thief of a state, if he does not steal its sagely laws along with it, has no means to establish himself. Thus, sagely laws are the sharpest tools in the world—it all depends on how one uses them."

Should its power fall into the hands of a cunning usurper, none have failed to be controlled by it in turn. As the later text states: *"He who steals a hook is executed; he who steals a state becomes a feudal lord."* Yet at the gates of these lords, "benevolence and righteousness" reside—petty thieves face execution while great thieves go unrestrained. How can this serve as a defense for the common people? Having stolen a state to become its ruler, he then forbids the people from theft—does he not know that benevolence and righteousness cannot be abandoned? Is this not using the sagely laws to guard his own thievish person? Zhuangzi of the Painted Hall lamented this truth, thereby condemning the ambitions of usurpers through the ages. The severity of the *Spring and Autumn Annals* may thus stand alongside it in the world.

Let us examine this: Among those the world calls most wise, are there none who accumulate for great thieves? Among those called most sagely, are there none who guard for great thieves? How do we know this is so? In ancient times, Long Feng was beheaded, Bi Gan was disemboweled, Chang Hong was torn apart, and Wu Zixu was torn to shreds—though all four were virtuous, their lives could not escape destruction. Thus, when Robber Zhi asked the Master of the Broad Hall, *"Does theft have its own Way?"* the Master replied, *"Where could there be no Way? To divine the treasures hidden in a room is wisdom; to enter first is courage; to withdraw last is righteousness; to know what is possible is knowledge; to divide spoils equally is benevolence. Without these five, no one in the world has ever become a great thief."*

From this we see: the good cannot stand without the Way of the sage, nor can Robber Zhi act without it. Since the good in the world are few and the ungood many, the sage’s benefit to the world is slight while his harm is great. Thus it is said: *"When the lips are gone, the teeth grow cold; when Lu’s wine was weak, Handan was besieged."* The sage’s rise gives birth to great thieves. Only by striking down the sage and releasing the restraint on thieves can the world begin to be ordered. When rivers run dry, valleys empty; when hills are leveled, abysses fill. Once the sage is dead, great thieves will not arise, and the world will be at peace without incident. But so long as the sage does not die, great thieves will not cease. To rely on the sage to govern the world is to multiply the gains of Robber Zhi.

When measures and bushels are made to quantify, they are stolen along with the grain; when scales and balances are made to weigh, they are stolen along with the goods; when tallies and seals are made to authenticate, they are stolen along with the authority; when benevolence and righteousness are made to rectify, they are stolen along with the virtues. How do we know this is so? He who steals a hook is executed; he who steals a state becomes a feudal lord. At the gates of these lords, benevolence and righteousness reside—is this not the theft of benevolence, righteousness, and sagely wisdom? Thus, those who pursue great thieves, exalt feudal lords, and steal the benefits of benevolence, righteousness, measures, scales, tallies, and seals—even the rewards of high office cannot entice them, nor the threat of the executioner’s axe deter them. This multiplication of gains for Robber Zhi, making him unstoppable, is the fault of the sage.

Therefore it is said: *"A fish must not leave the depths; the state’s sharpest tools must not be displayed."* The sage is the world’s sharpest tool, not something to be flaunted before it. Guo Xiang’s commentary notes: *"When tyrannical rulers wield the authority of kings to slaughter worthy ministers, none dare resist—all because of the sagely laws. Without these laws, how could Jie and Zhou have unleashed their poison and made the world tremble?"* Wisdom, courage, righteousness, knowledge, and benevolence—these five are meant to restrain thieves, yet they become the very resources of theft. Thus, the sage’s benefit to the world is slight while his harm is great.

Though these words are true, the sage cannot be entirely abolished, for the world’s knowledge has not yet been wholly eradicated. Thus, the sagely Way is still needed to govern it. If knowledge is not abolished but sagely wisdom alone is discarded, the world’s harm will be greater than if the sage remained. Though the harm of the sage is great, it is still preferable to the chaos of a world without him. Yet even this is not as good as abolishing all knowledge and leaving no harm at all.

How grave it is! The world seeks nothing but profit, yet cannot unite in abandoning its knowledge. How deluded it is, losing the path to its own nature! The lips do not grow cold to chill the teeth, nor did Lu’s weak wine besiege Handan—yet when the lips are gone, the teeth grow cold; when Lu’s wine was weak, Handan was besieged. The sage’s rise does not intend to give birth to great thieves, yet great thieves arise. This is the natural order of mutual generation, the inevitable sequence of events.

Moreover, the sage does not establish reverence for things, yet cannot prevent things from revering him. Regardless of rank or truth, if sagely laws are exalted, the world will swallow its voice and submit in unison—this is precisely what Jie and Zhou relied upon to perfect their great theft. If instead one rejects reverence and embraces simplicity, discarding prohibitions and replacing them with few desires, then by striking down the sage, one’s own simplicity remains intact. Even if thieves are left unchecked, their villainy will naturally cease.

Draining rivers does not intend to empty valleys, nor does leveling hills intend to fill abysses—yet when rivers run dry, valleys empty; when hills are leveled, abysses fill. Abolishing the sage does not intend to stop theft, yet when the sage is abolished, theft ceases. Once theft ceases, the pursuit of ostentation and excess vanishes entirely.

To rely on the sage to govern the world is to provide Jie and Zhou with his laws. The more they rely on them, the greater the gains they cannot relinquish. Thus, petty thieves follow their lead, and great thieves profit from them. The rewards of high office and the axe of execution—these weighty tools are meant to restrain thieves. Yet great thieves pursue and steal them, turning them to their own use. Thus, they perfect their great theft, wielding the seven virtues, leveling with scales, authenticating with tallies, enticing with high office, and threatening with the axe. Only by stealing these public instruments can they exalt themselves as feudal lords.

Therefore, benevolence, righteousness, rewards, and punishments are sufficient only to execute those who steal hooks. That great thieves cannot be restrained stems from the weight of their stolen gains. The weight of these gains comes from the sage’s refusal to relinquish them. When fish leave the depths, they are caught by men; when sharp tools are displayed, they become resources for thieves. Thus, they must not be shown to others.

Lü’s Annotation: What the world calls knowledge and what it calls sageliness are both constructed through laws. Even the utmost knowledge and utmost sageliness do not transcend the names of sageliness, courage, righteousness, wisdom, and benevolence—yet they know not *how* knowledge is knowledge, nor *how* sageliness is sageliness. Thus, the Four Masters could not preserve their own bodies, while the corrupt instead turned these very qualities into resources for theft. What the world calls sageliness and knowledge thus becomes nothing more than the accumulated stores of great thieves.

Utmost knowledge lies in unknowing; utmost sageliness lies in namelessness. Yet the world’s sageliness and knowledge instead serve to empower thieves—thus, they benefit the world little and harm it much, no idle claim. Lips and teeth exemplify mutual dependence; the thin wine of Lu and the siege of Deng’s capital exemplify how things not inherently dependent may yet become so.

Therefore, to govern the world, nothing surpasses abandoning the trappings of the sage, releasing thieves and brigands, and forgetting both good and evil. The heart’s valley is not empty, yet thievish thoughts arise within it because the sage is treated as a deep abyss and dammed. Drain the sage’s river to dryness, and the valley will empty, and thieves will not arise. The heart’s abyss is not solid, yet thievish thoughts enter its gaps because the sage is treated as a mound and toppled. Level the sage’s mound and reduce it, and the abyss will fill, and thieves will not encroach. This is why, when the sage is already dead, great thieves do not arise, and the world remains without incident. What is called death is simply the cessation of such thoughts.

When thievish thoughts arise and great thieves emerge, even if one relies heavily on the sage to govern the world, this is merely heaping advantages for thieves—this is elaborated below in the passage on "stealing them together." Thus, those who steal hooks are executed, while those who steal states become feudal lords, and none can restrain them. At the gates of feudal lords, benevolence and righteousness reside—this is to steal sageliness, knowledge, benevolence, and righteousness together. How much more so for those who exalt themselves above feudal lords? Even with chariots, caps, axes, and halberds, none can restrain or encourage them.

All this stems from the error of deviating from the true to become a sage, yet still using the sage’s laws to enlighten the world—this is to display sharp tools to others. Thus, great thieves are able to seize them.

Yi Du’s Annotation: The Dao has both noble and base adherents. Those who attain the Dao’s correctness find sageliness, courage, righteousness, wisdom, and benevolence all aligned with it. Yet when these qualities are pursued in their incorrect forms, they become nothing more than the tools of great thieves. What thieves call the Dao is merely the deluded intent they harbor, entering first and exiting last, discerning right from wrong, and dividing things equally. Those who grasp a part of it become petty thieves; those who destroy and seize it all become great ones.

Zhuangzi once used parables in the *Miscellaneous Chapters* to contrast with our Master Confucius, clarifying that the knowledge of great thieves and great sages is the same—only their application differs. The good use these five qualities to establish themselves; the wicked use them to become thieves. Good and evil both originate in the human heart, yet those who do good in the world are always few, while those who do evil are always many—this is why Zhuangzi so sharply corrects them.

The weak wine of Lu and the siege of Deng’s capital, the rise of sages and the emergence of great thieves—this is the natural principle of mutual generation, reaching its extreme. Did the sages who established laws intend to provoke human deceit? People merely followed their traces to create falsehood. What is called "striking down the sage" is a profound rejection of the sage’s advancement—akin to the Chan saying, "Had I met Śākyamuni at his birth, I would have struck him dead with one blow." Releasing thieves and brigands is likewise meant to end deception.

The waters of rivers and valleys flow into one another; mounds and abysses rely on each other—this illustrates how the sage’s traces become resources for great thieves. When the sage is already dead, this embodies the intent to "abandon sageliness and discard knowledge." When great thieves do not arise, the paths of contention and striving all vanish.

If one does not abolish sageliness and knowledge to stop theft but instead relies even more on the sage’s laws to govern the world, the corrupt will seize upon them to become thieves—this is heaping advantages for them. Measures, scales, tallies, seals, benevolence, and righteousness are all tools by which the sage governs the world. Zhuangzi’s meaning is that anything involving forms, implements, or laws becomes a resource for great thieves. When thieves steal a state, measures, scales, tallies, and seals all fall into their possession, and punishments and rewards issue from them alone.

Moreover, the forms, implements, and laws by which Yao, Shun, and the Three Dynasties harmonized governance are the same as those of later ages—yet their success and failure differ. What they relied upon was indeed these things, but once their achievements were complete, these things, though still present, could be discarded. Later ages, clinging rigidly to these as their sole reliance, find that once their authority falls into the hands of the treacherous, what they relied upon for stability often leads to peril—this is exemplified by the case of Tian Chengzi.

The sage retreats into seclusion, wielding ultimate power to turn the myriad transformations, thus moving heaven and earth without the world perceiving his mechanism, and subduing the realm without people naming him as martial. This is how he guides the ten thousand things within the realm, and none in the world can resist—how could he display sharp tools to others?

Detailed Daoist Annotation: In governing others, none surpasses the state of Qi; in governing oneself, none surpasses the Four Masters; in bringing chaos to others, none surpasses Robber Zhi. All claimed to have modeled themselves on the sages. Yet Qi could not escape the usurpation of the Tian clan; the Four Masters could not evade the execution of their contemporary rulers; while Robber Zhi ended his life in old age.

Thus, modeling oneself on the sages to govern brings no benefit; stealing the sages’ teachings to do evil incurs no harm. The sages’ relation to the world, then, is not enough to stop thieves—it is precisely enough to provoke them. Zhuangzi was not ignorant of the sages; he merely responded to things as circumstances demanded.

Yet later ages saw calamities and chaos arise in their wake—this is like lips perishing and teeth growing cold, or the thin wine of Lu leading to the siege of Deng’s capital. Can one blame the lips for the teeth growing cold, or fault Lu for the siege of Deng? Those who invariably trace blame back to the sages are merely shirking the burdens of their own paths.

Master Bi Xu annotates: When knowledge emerges, it may bring either benefit or harm; when sageliness manifests, it may lead to life or death. One unmoved by benefit or harm possesses supreme knowledge; one undisturbed by life or death embodies supreme sageliness. As for the Four Masters—each prided themselves on knowledge and boasted of sageliness, only to bring about their own destruction—how could they have known true knowledge or true sageliness? Sageliness and knowledge are the very conditions that give rise to great thieves. When sageliness and knowledge arise, great thieves appear; when great thieves cease, sageliness and knowledge vanish. Seize and discard the sages, cast them away entirely. Release and abandon the thieves, hold no store in their plunder. When sageliness and knowledge are obliterated, the people’s nature returns to purity and simplicity, and the world is at peace, free of strife.

Those who steal benevolence, righteousness, sageliness, and knowledge do so to exalt themselves; those who plunder gold, jewels, and jade do so to enrich themselves. Yet what Heaven bestows is public, while what men seize is private. If the public remains public and the private remains private, how could caps and carriages ever serve as incentives, or axes and halberds as deterrents? Master Yongzhai observes: Though the Four Masters were worthy, each met with punishment, while Robber Zhi evaded harm—this shows that worthiness is unreliable, and those who steal sageliness and knowledge may yet profit thereby. The Way of the thief is a fabrication by Zhuangzi to satirize the world; though his words seem strange, they hold profound truth. When he speaks of the few who benefit the world and the many who harm it, his insight is piercing. The analogies of lips and teeth, rivers and valleys, make clear that the sages do not create thieves—they instead provide the very means by which great thieves arise. If sages do not appear, great thieves will not arise, and without sages or thieves, the world governs itself. To esteem the sages and seek governance through them is to say that when sages reappear and establish laws, the wicked will seize upon them to deceive the world—just as the warring lords of the Warring States, who usurped and seized power, were all great thieves. Those who steal a belt-hook are executed, while those who steal a state become lords; once enthroned, they too claim to love the people and benefit all things—thus they steal benevolence, righteousness, sageliness, and knowledge as well. Though called great thieves, all seek to overthrow them; yet when lords usurp states and rule over others, this is called "hoisting." And though the world has never punished them with execution, Zhuangzi’s words arise from indignation at such a world.

What the world calls supreme knowledge and supreme sageliness invariably ends up amassed by great thieves; by contrast, those who do not claim sageliness or knowledge have nothing to accumulate, and thieves cannot covet what they lack. Thus, he invokes the Four Worthies to prove that sageliness and knowledge cannot be relied upon. Heaven endows the loyal and worthy to correct the ruler and assist the state; where integrity and righteousness lie, they hold fast even unto death, without wavering. Yet those above may fail to perceive them, resenting their blunt words and thwarted desires. At first, they are distanced; in the end, they are banished or executed. Though their loyalty cannot be extinguished, it is only after their execution that the sighing ceases. The execution of the loyal and worthy is the good fortune of treacherous ministers. With such evidence of blame, how can a state endure? When ministers become great thieves, where is their excess? Their excess does not transcend the laws of sageliness and knowledge. Because what they seize is weighty, their plunder cannot be slight. Yet the steps to such calamity do not accumulate in a single day: they gauge their ruler’s susceptibility to deception, the officials’ vulnerability to fraud, and seize the moment, riding the tide to carry out their perverse designs. Still, they cannot escape relying on sageliness, knowledge, benevolence, and righteousness to govern, as the founders of states before them have done. As one declines and another rises, so do rivers, valleys, hills, and abysses wax and wane. When sages appear, thieves arise—just as the thin wine of Lu led to the siege of Deng’s capital. Though governance through sageliness and knowledge is esteemed, it is fitting that it should heavily benefit thieves. Those who steal a belt-hook are constrained by the laws of sageliness and knowledge, while those who steal a state seize those very laws to control others. Thus, the good are few, and the wicked many; though caps and carriages, axes and halberds exist, they cannot serve as incentives or deterrents.

The *Analects* says: "The people may be made to follow, but not to understand." If the sages’ governance of the world must rely on some mysterious transformation, then this passage—from "How could one not model oneself on the sages" to "The sages are the world’s sharpest instruments"—contains eleven instances of "sage." In the current text, all remain as such, though Chen Bixu’s edition, collated by Zhang Junfang, uniformly renders them as "sageliness and knowledge." Referring to earlier passages—"what the world calls knowledge, what the world calls sageliness"—this reading is also plausible. Given the chapter’s intent to critique the many flaws of lawmaking, following the Yuan edition is appropriate. My conjecture is that when Zhang was commissioned to collate the text, and when Bixu submitted his annotations for imperial review, they may have feared that passages discussing sages could cause offense, and so provisionally replaced them with "sageliness and knowledge," a change that persisted in transmission. Yet where "sage" is indispensable—such as "How could one not model oneself on the sages," "Without the sages’ Dao, nothing is established," "Without the sages’ Dao, nothing proceeds," "The sages are dead," "The sages do not die"—it cannot be altered. Elsewhere, replacing "sage" with "sageliness and knowledge" is also reasonable. As for "The sages are the world’s sharpest instruments," this undoubtedly refers to sageliness and knowledge.

*Southern Florescence True Scripture: Sea of Annotations and Subtle Meanings*, Scroll Twenty-Eight concludes.
*Southern Florescence True Scripture: Sea of Annotations and Subtle Meanings*, Scroll Twenty-Nine.

The Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin, *Stealing the Chest*, Chapter Two

Thus, sever sageliness and cast off knowledge, and great thieves will cease; smash jade and shatter pearls, and petty thieves will not arise; burn tallies and break seals, and the people will return to simplicity; dismantle measures and snap scales, and the people will know no contention. Only when all the world’s sagely laws are exhausted can one begin to discuss matters with the people.

Uproot and confound the six pitch-pipes, melt down flutes and zithers, and stop up Master Kuang’s ears—then the world will begin to contain its own hearing. Erase patterns and scatter the five colors, glue shut Li Zhu’s eyes—then the world will begin to contain its own clarity. Destroy and discard hooks and marking-lines, cast aside compass and square, cripple the craftsman’s fingers—then the world will begin to possess its own skill. Thus it is said: “Great skill appears clumsy.”

Erase the conduct of Zeng and Shi, silence the mouths of Yang and Mo, cast off benevolence and righteousness—then the world’s virtue will begin to merge in profound unity. When people contain their own clarity, the world will know no dissipation; when they contain their own hearing, the world will know no encumbrance; when they contain their own knowledge, the world will know no confusion; when they contain their own virtue—

Those such as Zeng, Shi, Yang, Mo, Master Kuang, the craftsman, and Li Zhu all externally establish their virtue and thereby throw the world into chaos—such are those whom the Dao deems useless.

Guo’s commentary: Remove what they rely upon, and prohibitions become unnecessary; devalue what they prize, and punishments cease of themselves. Eliminate the means by which they feign rectitude, and their deceptions and artifices cannot proceed. Minor imbalances are the tools of major imbalances. When nothing external is feigned, one’s inner simplicity remains whole, and no harm of self-loss arises.

Sound and color are what Li and Kuang prize. One receives life with a fixed allotment, yet what they prize draws it away—thus life and destiny are lost. If instead one destroys what they prize, abandons their impositions, and follows one’s own nature, hearing and clarity are each preserved, and people contain their true essence.

Though the spider and mole-cricket are base creatures, they weave webs and roll pellets without seeking the craftsman’s aid—thus all things possess their own abilities. Though their abilities differ, if none dares deviate from what they practice, then what seems skillful becomes clumsy. Therefore, one who excels in employing others assigns tasks according to their abilities, does not demand of the people the craftsman’s skill, and allows the multitude of arts to appear unskilled—then the world naturally attains great skill. By using each one’s innate ability, compass and square may be discarded, and the master artisan’s fingers may be crippled.

Remove the standards that disorder one’s nature, and the world will each return to its simplicity and unite in profound virtue. Those like Zeng, Shi, Yang, Mo, Li, Kuang, and the craftsman are endowed with diverse methods, causing the world to leap and emulate them. In emulation, one loses oneself; the loss originates from them—they are the instigators of chaos.

As for what the Dao employs: sight does not exceed what is seen, thus all eyes are perfectly clear; hearing does not exceed what is heard, thus all ears are perfectly keen; action does not exceed what is possible, thus all skills are perfectly adept; knowledge does not exceed what is known, thus one’s constant nature is perfectly suited; virtue does not exceed what is attained, thus all virtue is perfectly fitting. Why establish what lies beyond one’s inherent capacity, causing the world to race about without ability to return?

Lü’s commentary: What Zhuangzi calls “severing sageliness and casting off knowledge” does not mean destroying classics or abandoning governance and education—it means not allowing them to arise in the heart. “Smashing jade and shattering pearls” does not mean emptying treasuries or discarding them in the mountains—it means not harboring a mind that values them. “Burning tallies and breaking seals” does not mean burning and smashing them—it means trusting trust itself, so the people return to simplicity, and tallies and seals are no longer relied upon. “Dismantling measures and snapping scales” does not mean actually dismantling and snapping them—it means leveling levelness itself, so the people know no contention, and measures and scales are no longer relied upon. Only then do the people recover the essence of their nature and destiny, and one may begin to discuss matters with them.

Stopping up Master Kuang’s ears aims to return hearing inward; when I return hearing inward, the world contains its own hearing. Gluing shut Li Zhu’s eyes aims to turn vision inward; when I turn vision inward, the world contains its own clarity. Crippling the craftsman’s fingers allows the world to begin possessing its own skill. Erasing the conduct of Zeng and Shi, silencing the mouths of Yang and Mo—then the world’s virtue begins to merge in profound unity. This lies in my casting off knowledge and severing skill, not seeing what may be desired.

Those who externally establish their virtue and thereby plunge the world into chaos are not those who contain their own hearing, clarity, knowledge, and virtue, and return to the essence of nature and destiny—such are those whom the Dao deems useless. Yet some claim Zhuangzi truly wished to strike down the sages, release thieves and bandits, and destroy laws and institutions—how could one engage in subtle discourse with such as these?

Yi Du’s commentary: Great thieves steal the law; petty thieves steal objects. Those who steal objects are restrained by law; those who steal the law are transformed by the Dao. Tallies and seals were originally meant to convey trust. Measures and scales were originally meant to achieve balance. Yet in their corruption, those who convey trust become utterly untrustworthy, and those who achieve balance become utterly unbalanced—this is why Zhuangzi wished to burn, break, dismantle, and snap them, so that eyes do not enter into color, ears do not enter into sound, and the heart does not enter into sensory entanglements. When the myriad forms and appearances are blocked externally, and one takes nature and destiny as the master, withdrawing vision and returning hearing, not yearning for Li or Kuang yet attaining what is inherently one’s own nature—this is called “great skill appears clumsy.”

Zeng, Shi, Yang, and Mo confuse and disorder the world—thus one wishes to erase their conduct and silence their mouths, so all return to unity, and the world’s virtue begins to revert to the Dao and merge in profound unity. When people contain their own clarity, the world’s clarity suffices for mutual illumination; when they contain their own hearing, the world’s hearing suffices for self-perception; when they contain their own knowledge, the world’s knowledge suffices for self-understanding; when they contain their own virtue, the world’s virtue suffices for self-attainment.

Thus one remains unscorched and unburdened, undeluded and unswayed. Those several masters—Zeng, Shi, Li, and Kuang—all fail to fulfill their inherent nature, causing the world to exhaust its spirit and weary its thoughts in pursuit of them, thereby plunging the world into chaos. Such methods serve no purpose in the Dao.

As detailed in the *Daoist Commentaries*: Xun Qing said, "Tallies, contracts, and deeds serve as tokens of trust. If superiors favor schemes and stratagems, inferiors will exploit this and resort to deceit. Lots and hooks serve as means of impartiality; if superiors favor partiality and self-interest, inferiors will exploit this, and even balanced scales and hanging weights will be skewed. Measuring vessels and grain measures serve as means of fairness; if superiors favor subversion, inferiors will exploit this and resort to treachery. If superiors covet profit, inferiors will exploit this and descend into baseness." Thus, laws arise from the sage’s necessity and are preserved by later kings’ vigilance. With the right people but no such laws, antiquity did not fail to achieve good governance; with such laws but no such people, the degenerate age cannot avoid theft and disorder.

Zhuangzi’s discourse does not encompass the mutual reliance of people and laws. To measure by these standards, to correct by these means—such actions invite theft of the very principles, leading only to joy in burning, smashing, snatching, and breaking without end. His intent is to sing of the dissolution of the scattered and its return to unity, to strip away the flowery and restore the fruit, thereby reverting to the root of virtue and the Dao.

The *Bi Xu Lüe* omits this discussion. *Fu Zhai* states: "Striking jade, shattering pearls, even snatching measures and breaking scales—these are all hyperbolic expressions to reinforce the intent of 'rejecting sages and discarding knowledge,' not literal arguments. They align in meaning with the *Laozi*’s 'not valuing rare goods to prevent theft among the people,' though the rhetoric here is excessive."

Su Dongpo remarked: "When one learns to read, the seeds of sorrow and trouble begin—yet how could one wish for the world to remain entirely illiterate?" "Disturbing order" means to unravel and disrupt; "scorching and severing" means to burn and discard.

Externally displaying one’s virtue is to prize external things while losing one’s original heart. To sink into chaos without restraint is to disturb and disrupt it. This passage merely elaborates on the preceding text to conclude the intent of "rejecting sages and discarding knowledge," allowing people to preserve their nature and align in virtue. The various commentaries have already expounded on this in detail; no further redundant explanations are needed.

Do you alone not know of the age of utmost virtue? In ancient times, under the reigns of Rongcheng, Dating, Bohuang, Zhongyang, Lilu, Lixu, Xuanyuan, Hexu, Zunlu, Zhu Rong, Fuxi, and Shennong, the people used knotted cords for record-keeping. They found sweetness in their simple food, beauty in their plain garments, joy in their customs, and contentment in their dwellings. Neighboring states were within sight of one another, the sounds of chickens and dogs carried between them, yet the people lived to old age and died without ever traveling to visit one another. In such an age, perfect governance prevailed. But now, it has come to this: the people crane their necks and stand on tiptoe, saying, "Wherever there is a worthy one," they carry provisions and rush toward him, inwardly abandoning their kin and outwardly forsaking the affairs of their lords. Their footprints crisscross the borders of the feudal lords, and their carriage tracks entwine a thousand *li* away. This is the fault of those above who esteem knowledge. If those above truly favor knowledge yet lack the Way, the world will fall into great chaos.

How do we know this is so? When the knowledge of bows, crossbows, snares, and cunning traps proliferates, birds are thrown into chaos above. When the knowledge of hooks, bait, nets, and weirs multiplies, fish are thrown into chaos in the water. When the knowledge of fences, traps, nets, and pitfalls abounds, beasts are thrown into chaos in the marshes. When the transformations of cunning deceit, gradual poison, obstinate sophistry, the "hard and white" debate, and the "same and different" distinctions multiply, the common people are bewildered by disputation.

Thus, the world repeatedly falls into great chaos, and the blame lies in the love of knowledge. For the world knows only to seek what it does not know and does not know to seek what it already knows. It knows only to condemn what it deems not good and does not know to condemn what it deems good. This is why great chaos arises. Above, it eclipses the brightness of the sun and moon; below, it scorches the essence of mountains and rivers; in between, it topples the operations of the four seasons. Even the creatures that pant and crawl, the tiny and delicate beings, all lose their nature. How severe is the chaos wrought by the love of knowledge upon the world! This has been the case since the Three Dynasties and after—abandoning the people of simple diversity and delighting in the flattery of the restless, forsaking the serenity of non-action and delighting in the clamor of contention. Such clamor has already thrown the world into chaos!

Guo’s commentary: The people used knotted cords, which sufficed to record essential matters. What was fitting became naturally sweet; what was proper became naturally beautiful. Though the sounds of chickens and dogs carried between them, they did not visit one another—this was the perfection of having no desires. Now, people carry provisions to chase after the worthy, abandoning their kin and forsaking their lords. Even the path to perfect governance has led to such corruption—this is the fault of those above who esteem knowledge. The more meticulously one schemes, the more cunningly one evades. Even birds and beasts cannot be ensnared by knowledge—how much less so for humans! What those above esteem, those below cannot rest content with what little they have. When the few in nature pursue the many, they become lost. Not seeking what they already know but seeking what they do not know—this is to abandon oneself and imitate others, exceeding one’s proper bounds. Praising what one deems good gives rise to competition and striving. Fortune and misfortune, regret and shame arise from action, and the movements of knowledge can truly shake heaven and earth, commanding the lives of all. How can rulers not be wary of their knowledge!

Lü’s commentary: The governance of the sage constantly ensures that the people remain without knowledge and without desire. Without knowledge, they used knotted cords. Without desire, they found sweetness in their food, beauty in their garments, joy in their customs, and contentment in their dwellings, living to old age and dying without visiting one another. This was the age of utmost virtue. When the world all knows beauty as beauty, ugliness arises. When all know goodness as goodness, it is no longer goodness. Knowing to condemn what is not good is to recognize ugliness and non-goodness; not knowing to condemn what one deems good and beautiful is to fail to recognize goodness and beauty. Returning to non-action, even beauty and goodness are not the true nature of life. The people did not visit one another yet formed their own communities—these were the people of simple diversity. Now, wherever there is a worthy one, people carry provisions and rush toward him—this is the flattery of the restless. Their teachings resemble a father’s, their admonitions resemble a son’s—this is the clamor of contention. All this is the fault of esteeming worthies and favoring knowledge. Knowledge gives rise to sages, and sages give rise to great thieves. Sages and great thieves both emerge from knowledge. Thus, this chapter consistently speaks of abandoning knowledge.

Yi Du’s commentary: In the time of the twelve ancient emperors, the people ate without discrimination and found sweetness in their food, wore whatever garments were at hand and found them beautiful, and lived wherever they dwelled, finding contentment in their customs. Though the sounds of chickens and dogs carried between them, they did not visit one another, for people and creatures multiplied without seeking anything from the outside. As the *Laozi* says: "Do not esteem worthies, and the people will not contend." Now, people carry provisions to chase after the worthy, undeterred by distance, their inborn nature corrupted by fame and profit—this is the fault of those above who favor knowledge. From bows and crossbows to the debates of "hard and white" and "same and different," this passage again clarifies the fault of those above who favor knowledge, leading fish, birds, beasts, and humans to all fall into chaos and lose their nature.

What is not known is "knowledge"; what is already known is "innate knowledge." What is not good is not desirable; what one deems good is desirable. Zhuangzi wished for people to forget their external desires, to fill their natural principles, and not to see the goodness of what is desirable. When those above favor knowledge yet lack the Way, they eclipse the brightness of the sun and moon, scorch the essence of mountains and rivers, and topple the operations of the four seasons. Even the smallest creatures and beings lose their nature—from this, the greater can be inferred. The "people of simple diversity" refers to each following the nature they received, their simplicity and purity undispersed. Now, they abandon this simplicity and delight in the restless, forsake serenity and delight in clamor—no wonder the world is thrown into chaos!

A Detailed Annotation on the Dao states: When military commands proliferate, chaos ensues; when words multiply, disputes arise. Thus, the more knowledge one possesses, the more affairs one has; the more affairs one has, the more exhaustion follows—this is why those who govern the world value the abandonment of petty knowledge and the illumination of great knowledge. If one seeks what one does not know yet neglects to seek what one already knows, then in the pursuit of exhaustive understanding, such knowledge becomes superfluous. If one does not reproach what is not evil yet reproaches what one already deems good, then in the fulfillment of inherent nature’s benevolence, one falls short. Deficient in benevolence and burdened with superfluous knowledge, what one knows is not true knowledge, and what one reproaches is not rightly reproached.

The *Heavenly Revolutions* states: The knowledge of the Three Sovereigns above obscured the brightness of the sun and moon, below disrupted the essence of mountains and rivers, and in between toppled the operations of the four seasons. Their knowledge trespassed even the tails of centipedes and the beasts of the wilds, so that none could preserve the integrity of their nature and life—this aligns with the meaning of the preceding passage. The *Commentary* says: "Excessive affairs are the bane of life; excessive speech is the thief of virtue." Restlessness is the mark of excessive affairs; clamor is the mark of excessive speech. How could the world not fall into chaos?

The *Azure Void Annotation* notes: The *Southern Florescence* cites the governance of the ancient Twelve Lords—such as Rongcheng and Datian—who ruled through non-action, to expose the flaws of those who govern in the present age. Knotted cords marked the beginning of legislation, yet affairs cannot remain perpetually still; stillness prolonged gives way to motion, until those above favor knowledge and the world descends into chaos. If even birds, beasts, insects, and fish cannot rest in their existence, how much more so for humans? The poison of cunning and deceit offends the harmony of Heaven, so that grasses, trees, and all crawling creatures suffer its harm.

The *Supreme One* says: "To govern a state with knowledge is the state’s bane; to govern without knowledge is the state’s blessing." How true are these words!

Fuzhai observes: Of the Twelve Lords, only Fuxi, Shennong, and Xuanyuan appear in the classics; the rest remain unrecorded. Some may have been transmitted from ancient traditions, while others may have been invented by Zhuangzi—much like the Buddha’s words: "In some past kalpa..." Viewed within the span of Heaven and Earth, since the time of Fuxi, written records confirm over three thousand years; before Fuxi, there must have been six others, though their names are lost to history. One cannot hastily dismiss their existence. Among those I have encountered, there are worthy men who, carrying provisions, hasten to join them—secretly placing Confucius and Mencius among their ranks. The debates of that era—over "hard and white," "dirt and purity," "same and different"—were the concerns of those who loved to argue. To speak of fishing and hunting alongside such disputation is akin to Zhuangzi’s mockery of Zeng, Shi, and the like alongside measures and scales. Those who seek what they do not know strive outward for novelty; those who seek what they already know find it clear and self-evident, the natural principle. What is deemed unvirtuous in others, what is already virtuous in oneself—this is what the *Discourse on Equalizing Things* means by "affirming what one affirms and negating what one negates." To know only the faults of others while remaining blind to one’s own rightness is itself a fault. From the vast—sun, moon, mountains, and rivers—to the minute—breath, fleeting shadows, and the slightest stirrings—nothing escapes the loss of its true nature. How grave is the chaos wrought by the love of knowledge upon the world!

A sigh concludes the passage, yet it is substantiated by the Three Dynasties. The *Free and Easy Wandering* begins with Tang’s questioning of Ge, while this text ends with "from the Three Dynasties downward"—though their openings and closings differ, they share the same mechanism. This chapter invokes the age of utmost virtue, when above and below sought nothing, and each person was self-sufficient, to contrast with the present. Of the twelve rulers, some remain unrecorded in the annals. From Zhu Rong onward, the records gradually become verifiable, but I surmise that before Fu Xi, the people’s nature was unadorned simplicity, like an unknotted cord. Thus, all they ate was sweet, all they wore was fine; their customs brought joy, their dwellings peace. What did they know of imperial power? Neighboring states were within sight, yet free from fear of raids; the cries of chickens and dogs carried between them, and they enjoyed abundance. People lived and died without visiting one another, tilling and building for their own needs, seeking nothing beyond. These few lines depict the pristine simplicity of high antiquity, further evoking the *Dao De Jing*’s "Small States and Few People" chapter.

Later ages, however, stretch their necks and stand on tiptoe, shoulder their provisions, and rush toward worthies, abandoning their lords and forsaking their kin, traveling a thousand *li* in pursuit. The promotion of worthies spurs the people to seek the strange and strive for the extraordinary, exalting what lies beyond their senses. Inevitably, those whose reputations outstrip their substance respond, leading all to vie in falsity. How could the world not fall into chaos? The following text clarifies how the love of knowledge harms all things, causing the people to lose their nature, so that even birds, beasts, insects, and fish cannot preserve their innate dispositions.

All seek what they do not know—pursuing knowledge beyond their bounds, such as measuring heaven and earth or inquiring into ghosts and spirits. What they already know refers to their innate understanding, discerning the subtle and perilous, honoring virtue and nature. What they deem unvirtuous includes their own faults, which they demand perfection from others to correct. What they deem virtuous includes their own rightness, which they flaunt in self-reliance. If one can discern and follow this with precision, then all goodness arises from authenticity, and each nature returns to its proper state. Without governance, the world governs itself. Should one act contrary to this, the sun, moon, mountains, and rivers grow dim and disordered—how could the people find peace? All this stems from the ruler’s excessive love of knowledge.

The "various peoples" refer to those who preserve the purity of primordial *qi*, fit to be models for the world. This chapter takes *zhen kuang* as its title, a phrase rarely addressed in commentaries. The meaning of *zhen* is uniquely glossed by Lin Yi as "latent opening." Upon consulting the *Jian Yun*, *nao* means "flank," so *zhen kuang* describes reaching into a basket from its side to take what lies within—an act of stealth. The text’s intent is that when governance loses the Way and laws proliferate, the ruler uses knowledge to guard against the people, while the people use knowledge to spy on the ruler. Where defenses are incomplete, they will seize the opportunity to exploit the gap.

Thus, the state’s sharpest instruments must not be displayed to others. Tian Chengzi stole Qi and usurped its sagely wisdom and laws, securing his own safety and making the state hegemonic—proof that even theft has its Way, and that the world’s conventional sagacity and knowledge are unreliable.
