No wonder these four men could not escape execution!

The world’s paths of good and evil both arise from the Dao of the sages, yet those who do evil are ever many, while those who hasten toward good are ever few. Thus, it is clear that such ways benefit the world little and harm it much. The principle of waxing and waning is like lips and teeth, rivers and valleys—mutually dependent. If sagely knowledge is further imposed upon the world, the advantage it gives to thieves and corrupters will be no small matter.

One forges instruments to level things, yet others steal those very instruments. One establishes laws to govern, yet others steal those very laws. What am I to do?

This truly stems from those who govern failing to magnify the Dao and virtue to make the world’s sentiments impartial. Only then do treacherous heroes seize their power for private gain, and the world suffers harm. The *Nanhua* [Zhuangzi] strives to abolish sagacity and discard knowledge, smash measures and break scales, seeking to restore the governance of non-action from high antiquity. Yet the essence of returning to purity and reverting to simplicity lies in illuminating true knowledge to correct one’s course, and reverting to true goodness to preserve what one has received.

Seeking to rectify the world’s corruptions, its words cannot but verge on excess and reproach, hoping thereby to provoke a turning. The *Horse’s Hoof* [chapter] does not fully convey its metaphor—it reaches its extreme in *Zhen Kuang*. Alas! The Way is vast and difficult to employ; mere empty words are futile. Singing alone in the vanguard, one finds no response—no wonder that from ancient times to now, those who embrace the Dao retreat to mountains and seas, never to return. Alas!

If those entrusted with the governance of the Way were all to apply their minds as did the Master of the Lacquer Garden, how could the world’s Dao fail to flourish? How could its pristine customs fail to return?

*The Ocean of Subtleties in the True Classic of the Southern Florescence*, Scroll Twenty-Nine, concludes.

[Textual note: Guo’s commentary originally read *army* (軍); the Shide Hall edition emends *people* (民) to *mechanism* (機).]

*The Ocean of Subtleties in the True Classic of the Southern Florescence*, Scroll Thirty
by Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin

**Chapter One: "In Nurturing"**
We have heard of nurturing the world, never of governing it. To *nurture* (在) is to fear the world’s corruption of its nature; to *accommodate* (宥) is to fear the world’s alteration of its virtue. If the world neither corrupts its nature nor alters its virtue, can there be any who govern it?

In ancient times, when Yao governed the world, he made its people joyful in their natures—this was not tranquility. When Jie governed the world, he made its people weary in their natures—this was not contentment. That which is neither tranquil nor content is not virtue. And that which is not virtue cannot long endure—nowhere in the world does such a thing exist.

When people are excessively joyful, they incline toward yang; when excessively angry, they incline toward yin. When yin and yang are both imbalanced, the four seasons fail to arrive, the harmony of cold and heat is not achieved, and in the end, this harms the human form. If people’s joy and anger lose their proper place, if their dwellings lack constancy, if their thoughts and reflections find no ease, if the Way of the center fails to take shape—then the world begins to produce those who are haughty, contentious, arrogant, and startled, and only afterward do the conducts of Robber Zhi, Zeng, and Shi arise.

To reward all the world’s goodness would be insufficient; to punish all the world’s evil would be inadequate. Thus, the world’s vastness is not enough for reward and punishment. Since the Three Dynasties, rulers have clamored endlessly over reward and punishment—when do they have leisure to settle into the true condition of their natures and lives?

**Guo Xiang’s Commentary:**
To accommodate and let be is to govern; to govern is to create chaos. If nothing sways them, natures and lives remain unharmed, and desires and aversions do not err. But those above cannot practice non-action, so they introduce allurements and preferences, and the people’s natures become corrupted. What is prized in a sage-king is not his ability to govern, but his capacity for non-action, allowing things to act of themselves. Without governance, there is no alteration or corruption.

Though Yao nurtured the world, his advancement was still governance. Though governance and chaos differ, both lose the tranquility and contentment of later ages, causing things to vie for esteem and fear contempt, never finding ease—this they share. Joy and anger losing their place, dwellings lacking constancy—these are the results of rulers like Yao and Jie. Humans, within heaven and earth, are most capable of using their numinous awareness to stir joy and anger, disturbing life and disrupting yin and yang.

Thus, between gain and loss, joy and anger gather in the hearts of the people, the harmony of cold and heat is destroyed, the seasons’ rhythms go awry, the hundred norms fall into confusion, and the myriad affairs wither and collapse. To admire reward is to seek goodness, yet reward cannot suffice. To fear punishment is to cease evil, yet punishment cannot prevail. Forget reward and punishment, and let goodness arise of itself—only then are natures and lives fully realized!

Reward and punishment are how sage-kings respond to merit and fault; they are not meant to establish incentives or deterrents. Thus, when governance reaches its perfection, they are set aside. Yet since the Three Dynasties, rulers have clamored and competed, making what should be incidental their primary concern—when do they have leisure to settle into the true condition of their natures and lives?

**Lü Huiqing’s Commentary:**
The world is the unity of the myriad things; its constant nature and constant virtue are none other than our own nature and virtue. To nurture and accommodate the world is to nurture and accommodate ourselves. To *nurture* (在) is to preserve without loss, to follow nature without addition. To *accommodate* (宥) is to release without indulgence, like a park that accommodates its creatures. Without corruption or alteration, there is only non-action; with non-action, there is no self. If there is no self, then who governs the world? Thus, one forgets the right and wrong of Yao and Jie.

Humans are born tranquil—what joy or suffering is there? To impose joy or suffering is to corrupt their nature; to corrupt their nature is to alter their virtue. The myriad things bear yin and embrace yang, with harmonizing qi as their balance. Humans all possess this harmonizing qi, through which they commune with heaven and earth. Yet Yao made the people joyful in their natures, leading to excessive joy and an imbalance toward yang; Jie made the people suffer in their natures, leading to excessive anger and an imbalance toward yin. Thus, their harmonizing qi was harmed, the seasons’ unfolding was disrupted, the harmony of cold and heat was not achieved, and in the end, the human form was injured.

Thoughts and reflections finding no ease, the Way of the center failing to take shape—this is what is meant by mutual harm. Then the world begins to produce conduct that is haughty, contentious, arrogant, and startled—conduct that is extreme. Haughtiness exalts height; contention exhausts all; arrogance is unattainable; startlement is unbalanced—none of this is level, easy, centered, or upright. This is why reward and punishment cannot suffice, and why the true condition of natures and lives cannot find peace.

**Lin Yidu’s Commentary:**
All that the world generates of itself is self-existent; all that it attains of itself is self-accommodating. The sage observes the world’s self-existent nature and nurtures it, allowing each to wander in carefree ease. He follows the world’s self-accommodating virtue and accommodates it, allowing each to rest in the joy of its principle. To nurture is to allow the world to fulfill its nature; to accommodate is to allow the world to follow its virtue. Thus, natures are not corrupted, virtues are not altered, and the sage, too, practices non-action. How could there be anyone who governs the world?

A mind untroubled is called *tranquility* (恬), which carries the sense of peace and stillness. A mind that flows in accord is called *contentment* (愉), which carries the sense of joy and delight. Joy scatters the qi and stirs the mind, so it is not tranquil. Anger reverses the qi and oppresses the mind, so it is not content. The human mind is never not empty, yet when it reaches sorrow or joy, something has touched it.

Though Yao and Jie governed the world differently in good and evil, their touching of the human mind and harming of nature were the same—this was not the principle of the self-attained kings of old.

Can this endure for long? When joy is excessive, the yang qi is constantly dispersed; when anger is excessive, the yin qi is perpetually oppressed. Joy and anger arise from the ruler’s governance losing the mean, causing the people’s minds to lose their proper measure. This offends the harmony of Heaven and Earth and in turn harms the human form—such is the principle of mutual consequence.

Thus, people’s thoughts and deliberations fail to find their own fulfillment, and their way in life never reaches completion. All describe the state of the human form being harmed and yin and yang falling out of harmony. *Qiao gu* speaks with lofty pretension; *zhuo jing* acts with extraordinary strangeness. Because of Yao’s path, Zeng and Shi emerged; because of Jie’s ways, thieves and destroyers arose. Having praised Yao and condemned Jie, with good and evil intermingled, even exhausting all things under Heaven would not suffice for rewards and punishments—how much less for anything else? If those above make rewards and punishments their constant concern, how can the people of the world ever rest in the natural truth of their natures and lives?

Chen Xiangdao’s commentary: Those who hold the world desire to open Heaven but not to open man, to bring fortune but not to bring harm—nothing surpasses *zai* and *you*. In *zai*, nothing disturbs; in *you*, nothing oppresses. With no disturbance, natures are not corrupted, so all things grow spontaneously without knowing why they grow. With no oppression, virtues are not altered, so all things attain their due without knowing why they attain it. Who then governs the world?

Those who govern the world err either in failing to be tranquil or in failing to be content. Without tranquility, there is excessive joy that leans toward yang; without contentment, there is excessive anger that leans toward yin. Thus, the qi of the human body flows in communion with Heaven and Earth, and the yin and yang of the five phases lean toward the yin and yang of Heaven and Earth. Corresponding to this, the harmony of cold and heat is not achieved, and instead the human form is harmed. From this, those who seek lofty heights, plumb profound depths, prize the strange, or pursue the swift emerge—none follow the central way. If they do not exceed in doing good, they must exceed in doing evil. Thus, even all under Heaven is insufficient for rewards and punishments—how could they ever rest in the natural truth of their natures and lives?

Chen Bixu’s commentary: The rulers of high antiquity who preserved the world did so by being magnanimous—it was not that they had some intention to govern it. Thus, the world did not corrupt its natures or alter its virtues, and so it was self-governing through non-action. In former times, Yao lost the way of preserving the self and practiced benevolence and love, causing the people to lose their constant nature and come to cherish and praise him. Jie lacked the grace of magnanimity toward things and pursued harsh urgency, causing the people to lose their constant virtue and come to fear and despise him. Where natures are corrupted and virtues altered, there has never been one who did not perish. Human joy and anger connect to yin and yang; when yin and yang are not in harmony, the human form is harmed in return. *Qiao gu* refers to lofty and strange theories, likening them to the likes of Zeng and Shi. *Zhuo jing* refers to solitary, fierce conduct, comparing it to the followers of Robber Zhi. Rewards for good are insufficient—this shows how many feign goodness. Punishments for evil are inadequate—this shows how much true evil there is.

Thus, with clamor and competitive pursuit, making power and profit their sole concern—how could they ever find leisure for tranquil joy and long life? As the *Yongzhai Oral Teachings* of the Lin family states: *"In"* means to roam freely at ease; *"you"* means to be magnanimous and self-content. If the people of the world all kept their natures uncorrupted and their virtues unaltered, what need would there be to govern them?

*Tian* means stillness; *yu* means joy. Joy pertains to yang; anger pertains to yin. *Pi* means to augment—what medical texts call an "excess disorder." Attaining the center and harmony, Heaven and Earth take their proper places; losing the center and harmony, the four seasons fall into disorder, and people likewise fall ill. "Dwelling without constancy" refers to reckless action; "failing to form a pattern" means losing the central Way. *Qiao* describes those who love loftiness to excess; *gu* refers to contentious debate. *Zhuo* means isolation; *jing* means fierce intensity—all expressions of disharmony. Zeng, Shi, and Robber Zhi merely stand in for the worthy and the unworthy. When the mind is not in harmony, neither the worthy nor the unworthy are genuine.

Now, when the worthy are rewarded and the unworthy punished, those who sell themselves as worthy are not truly so—this is the case throughout the world. Thus, rewards prove insufficient, for such people are many. As all seek reward and shun punishment, they engage in pretense with one another—how could they ever rest in the natural principles of their natures and lives? *"In"* means merely to preserve, to possess the world without entanglement. *"You"* means to show compassion and care, thus regarding the people as though wounded.

Therefore, the sagely ruler sits upright in the ancestral hall, while the hundred clans find tranquil joy in their fields and furrows. Natures remain uncorrupted, virtues unaltered; forms and voices harmonize, and Heaven and Earth respond—this was the perfect governance of high antiquity. From the Three Dynasties onward, rulers clamored to make reward and punishment their business, leaving the people no way to rest in the truth of their natures and lives. By the Warring States period, there were even those who could not be encouraged by reward or deterred by punishment.

Zhuangzi’s doctrine of *"in"* and *"you"*—was it not the work of one who sought to restore antiquity? In the course of human life, daily contact with things brings encounters with both adversity and favor. Joy and anger cannot be entirely forgotten; the key lies in regulating them appropriately, expressing them in due measure, and never losing harmony. If joy or anger becomes excessive, leaning toward yin or yang, then cold and heat lose their proper order—how much more so for people?

Tracing the source of such excess, it stems from the governance of Yao and Jie: one made the people joyful, the other made them weary—thus arose the origins of joy and anger. From this, good and evil became manifest, rewards and punishments were established, and the world began to exalt lofty conduct, exhaust itself in contentious speech, and display solitary fierceness and startling boldness in action. The good became like Zeng and Shi; the evil, like Jie and Zhi. The whole world proved insufficient for encouragement or deterrence—how could they ever rest in their natures and lives? Those who wielded the Way of governance had nowhere left to apply their methods.

Yet the recluses of rivers and seas, mountains and forests, still held fast to this concern, hoping to find a remedy and restore health. Though their words may seem strange, their hearts were those of Fuxi and the Yellow Emperor—how could one dismiss them as mere eccentricities? Moreover, to delight in cleverness—is this not indulgence in sensuality?

To delight in keen hearing—is this not indulgence in sound? To delight in benevolence—is this not disorder in virtue? To delight in righteousness—is this not perversion of principle? To delight in ritual—is this not mere performance of technique? To delight in music—is this not mere indulgence in excess? To delight in sagacity—is this not mere display of artifice? To delight in knowledge—is this not mere attachment to flaws?

When the world seeks to rest in the true nature of its lives, these eight may be present or absent—it matters not. But when the world cannot rest in the true nature of its lives, these eight become like severed fragments, coiled restraints, heaped clutter, and knotted tangles, throwing all into chaos. Yet the world still venerates and cherishes them—how deeply deluded it is! Is it merely a matter of recognizing error and abandoning them? Instead, they fast and purify themselves to speak of them, kneel and sit to present them, drum and sing to mourn them—what can I do about this?

Thus, when the noble person is compelled to govern the world, nothing is better than non-action. Through non-action, the true nature of life finds rest. Therefore, one who values their own person above governing the world may be entrusted with the world; one who cherishes their own person above governing the world may be charged with the world.

If the noble person can refrain from loosening their five viscera, refrain from flaunting their keen perception, dwell in stillness yet manifest like a dragon, remain deep in silence yet resound like thunder, move with spirit and the heavens follow, act with ease and non-action so that the myriad things rise and accumulate—then what leisure do I have to govern the world?

Guo Xiang’s commentary: When one accords with principle, there is no delight; to delight is to invite excess and perversion. Whether these eight exist or not, one should follow their allotted portion, and the nature of life will find peace. Yet if these eight are retained, one cannot fully follow nature, and thus they become like crude restraints and tangled knots. To fail to abandon them is already an error, yet to venerate them—how could this not be profound delusion? It is not merely a matter of passing them by; instead, they are treasured and exalted in this way.

Moreover, non-action does not mean mere silent inaction; when each follows its natural course, the nature of life finds rest. "Compelled" does not mean forced by threats or punishments; it means embracing the Dao and holding to simplicity, acting in accord with the utmost spontaneity, so that the world naturally submits. Thus, whether one enters or withdraws, speaks or remains silent, one leaves it to the unconcerned mind. The spirit moves in response to things, and the heavens follow principle in their course—like dust stirred by the wind, all is left to its own nature.

Lü Huiqing’s commentary: When the world cannot rest in the true nature of its lives, what is called keen perception, benevolence, righteousness, ritual, music, sagacity, and knowledge are all not in their proper state, inevitably leading to disorder in virtue and perversion of principle. Whether these eight exist or not, it makes no difference to their fundamental truth. *Hóng* means to sever and leave incomplete; *juǎn*, to bind and leave constrained; *cāng*, to accumulate and leave undispersed; *náng*, to knot and leave unresolved. All these bring chaos to the world, yet they are still venerated and cherished, spoken of with fasting and purification, danced to with drums and song—believing these to be the world’s ultimate truth. The world has been deluded for so long—what can I do about it?

When governing the world, if one truly acts out of necessity and practices non-action, why would I not value and cherish my own person above governing the world, offering myself for its sake? Only then can one be entrusted or charged with the world. To value is not to treat one’s person lightly; to cherish is not to endanger one’s person. Entrustment is like entrusting one’s body; charge is like entrusting an object. Thus, valuing is weightier than cherishing, and entrustment is weightier than charge.

If the five viscera are not loosened, one does not scatter and indulge in benevolence and righteousness. If keen perception is not flaunted, one does not extend and attach to sounds and sights. To dwell in stillness yet manifest like a dragon means that manifestation arises from non-action. To remain deep in silence yet resound like thunder means that sound arises from not speaking. When the spirit moves, response follows; when the heavens follow, they come unbidden. Thus, with ease and non-action, the myriad things rise and accumulate—like breath piling upon breath, like dust gathering of its own accord. What leisure then is there to govern the world?

Lin Yidu’s commentary: Benevolence and righteousness are the substance of ritual and music; ritual and music are the adornment of benevolence and righteousness. When one fills the inner self from one’s nature, one becomes one with the Dao; when one seeks externally through keen perception, one departs from the Dao and pursues mere names. If the world could rest in the nature of life that resides within, then these eight—whether present or absent—could establish human virtue or the Dao of heaven. But if one chases names and pursues fame, these eight become severed fragments, coiled restraints, heaped clutter, and knotted tangles, throwing the world into chaos. This describes their obstructive and inflexible nature. Yet the world still venerates and cherishes them, fasting and purifying to speak of them, mourning them with drums and song—depicting the extent of their reverence. What can I do about it?

When the noble person, to whom the world turns, is compelled to govern, nothing is better than non-action. Through non-action, there is nothing that is not done. Non-action is for governing oneself; nothing not done is for responding to things. The Dao of Yao and Shun did not go beyond this. When the sage enters and harmonizes with heaven, they neither value nor cherish the world, nor do they recognize what is venerable or intimate—thus, there is nothing to entrust or charge. But when they emerge and engage with humanity, only then do they value and cherish the world, recognizing what is venerable—thus, they entrust it. Recognizing what is intimate—thus, they charge it.

Without valuing or cherishing, one merges with the spirit; with valuing and cherishing, one resides in the body. The body is where the spirit is entrusted; the world is entrusted to one’s body; one’s body is entrusted to heaven and earth; heaven and earth are entrusted to the void. Considering this, all that has form cannot escape having something to entrust. As the *Laozi* says: "One who values their own person above governing the world may be charged with the world; one who cherishes their own person above governing the world may be entrusted with the world." The meaning is the same, though the words differ. It speaks of those who have the intent to govern but have not yet attained it, as if there were an intention but not yet its realization. The *Laozi* speaks of those who already govern the world, while Zhuangzi speaks of those who have not yet governed.

Those who "may" are those who, having already gained the world, keep their hearts unattached to it—such were the ancients like Yao and Shun. Those who "can" are those who, not yet having gained the world, do not forget it in their hearts—such were the ancients like Confucius and Mencius. Each has its own focus. If one dissects the five viscera, spirit, essence, hun-soul, and po-soul scatter and are no longer whole; if one plucks out one’s keen hearing and sharp sight, ears, eyes, nose, and mouth follow their forms and do not return. How could this be the Dao of the noble person’s cultivation of the heart and nurturing of nature?

Thus, in stillness, one is like a corpse; in appearance, like a dragon; in silence, like an abyss; in speech, like thunder. These four all arise from non-intention, merely responding to the moment and following principle. Movement is like the spirit’s response to things; conduct is like heaven’s compliance with the seasons. Only thus can one be at ease and practice non-action, while the myriad things steam and pile up like motes of dust moving on their own—what have I to do with them?

Chen Xiangdao’s note: Regarding keen hearing, sagely wisdom, benevolence and righteousness, ritual and music in relation to the world—did the sages ever force themselves to act? All was but a response to the moment, an adaptation to change, an unavoidable necessity. The benighted cling to straw dogs as divine, point to thatched huts as sacred dwellings, and not only pass them by in error but even speak of them with reverence, drum and sing in unison—with such ways, how can the world not be deluded?

To value one’s person *in* governing the world is to regard governing the world as less weighty than one’s own person; to cherish one’s person *in* governing the world is to regard governing the world as less intimate than one’s own person. This is to forget the world. To value one’s person *for* the world and to cherish one’s person *for* the world is not to forget the world. To forget the world is merely to suit oneself; not to forget the world is to have something with which to suit others. Yet in neither case has one transcended the self.

The *Laozi* says: "Life cannot be preserved by valuing it; the person cannot be enriched by cherishing it." Then what value or cherishing can there be for one who has no self? To value and cherish one’s person, though inferior to the sages, is still what the world wishes for in a ruler—thus one may be entrusted with the world.

Yet the *Laozi* speaks of valuing one’s person as "may be charged" and cherishing one’s person as "may be entrusted." "Can" is a definitive term; "may" is a tentative one. To be charged is to receive what is entrusted; to be entrusted is to rely on what is depended upon. In terms of forgetting the world versus not forgetting it, the distinction between "can" and "may" becomes clear. As for the discourse on being charged and entrusted, it should follow the *Laozi* as the standard.

Without unraveling the true treasury, the Dao and its power are not diverted onto the byways of benevolence and righteousness; without plucking out keen hearing and sharp sight, ears and eyes are not submerged in the falsity of sounds and colors. To dwell like a corpse is to be without affairs; to appear like a dragon is to bring forth affairs—yet in having no affairs, one has never begun to have them. To be silent like an abyss is to not speak; to speak like thunder is to bring forth words—yet in not speaking, one has never begun to speak. Thus, one moves in accord with things, and such movement is not by the heart but by the spirit; one acts in accord with principle, and such action is not by heaven but by the human. At ease and practicing non-action, the myriad things steam and pile up as if within an abandoned bellows—what leisure is there to govern the world?

Chen Bixu’s note: Withdrawing sight and hearing inward, sounds and colors cannot delude. Concealing benevolence and righteousness within, how can the Dao and its power be lost? Restraining ritual and music in the person, falsity and deceit cannot intrude. Cutting off the pursuit of sagely wisdom, flaws and maladies cannot assail. These eight were what the ancients rolled up to cultivate the self; in later ages, they were spread out to lose the root. The southerners rolled up what was difficult to roll; the northerners confused what was easy to contain—speaking of the difficulty of rolling up and concealing, it must lead to disordering the world. The world does not value simplicity and ease but instead reveres and clings to complexity and difficulty—how deluded it is!

Thus, in facing the world, nothing is better than non-action. With non-action, the natural tendencies of life and destiny are never disturbed. To value and cherish one’s person *in* governing the world is to value and cherish the world, not one’s own person. If so, gain and loss are not one’s own, and sorrow and joy are not for oneself—thus one may be entrusted with the world.

The corpse does not speak yet is solemn and orderly; the dragon transforms and becomes manifest. The Dao and nature are true and constant, like an abyss’s still silence; commands and orders respond to the moment, like thunder’s issuing sound. The spirit moves within, and its image appears without. Abiding in magnanimity and self-possession, one responds to things and rises in action. Though it is said that one does not govern the world, the method of governance resides therein.

Lin’s *Yongzhai Oral Exegesis* states: The "sageliness" in "delighting in sageliness" is akin to the *-able* suffix, much like "calligraphy sage" (grass sage); thus even thieves may be called "sages." None of these can be explained by the lexical meanings of the *Analects* or *Mencius*. If one rests in naturalness, these eight—though present—cannot become burdens.

"Barbarian scrolls" connote constraint; "rustic sacks," meddlesomeness. "Fasting and vigil," "kneeling and sitting" speak of solemn reverence. "Drumming and singing in unison" refers to unawareness of hand-dancing and foot-stomping—this mocks the scholars of the time. "I" refers to others: *You all act thus—what then is to be done?*

The passage beginning with "of necessity" expounds the governance of non-action and naturalness; these three characters alone reveal the meaning of "possessing the world yet not engaging with it." Only when one values one’s person *as* more precious than governing the world can the world be entrusted to them; only when one cherishes one’s person *as* more beloved than governing the world can the world be confided to them. These two lines are textually striking yet principledly sound.

The *Record of Rites* states: "the binding of sinews and bones." To "unbind the five viscera" is to cease such binding. "Plucking" means overusing one’s intelligence. "Corpse-like abiding" refers to the *Rites’* dictum: "sit like a corpse." The "dragon" is a metaphor for literary brilliance, its majestic demeanor a model to emulate. "Abyssal silence" denotes profound stillness without speech; "thunderous sound," the power to move others. As Chan Buddhism says: *Though silent, its voice is like thunder.* When the spirit stirs within, heaven follows without—every movement and gesture, every turn and pause, is nothing but the principle of heaven. These three lines are both profoundly reasoned and textually striking.

"All things steam and pile up"—this is like all things breathing upon one another, meaning that if I but practice non-action above, the people will naturally act and rest like floating dust in the wind. Why then should one trouble the heart to govern them? The eight—intelligence, discernment, benevolence, righteousness, ritual, music, sageliness, and wisdom—though products of human effort, each contains its own natural principle. Simply enact what is effortless.

Their absence is no loss; their presence, no gain. If the heart clings to delight in them, stagnation arises and harm ensues—far worse than mere injury. Enacting what is effortless, one rests in the natural tendencies of life and destiny. Stagnation and obstruction breed harm, leading to constraint, meddlesomeness, and the disordering of the world. Galloping with intelligence, sageliness, and wisdom, a single person entangled at the top—how can the world hope for peace? Yet the world still admires and venerates them.

Expounding with fasting and vigil lends gravity to their words; advancing with kneeling and sitting lends weight to their transmission. As for drumming and singing in unison, they indulge in it without end. Their delusion is beyond remedy—what can I do about this? This is an emphatic lament.

When necessity compels one to act, movement follows only under duress. Nothing compares to non-action, allowing things to follow their nature. Thus, one who values their person for the sake of the world does not demean its people; one who cherishes their person for the sake of the world can draw close to its people. Only then may the world be entrusted to them. In such entrustment, the patterns interweave without distinction of weight or lightness.

Dissolve not the five viscera; gather the five constants and return them to the Dao. Do not exalt cleverness; efface sound and color to preserve one’s authenticity. Therefore, one skilled in emergence acts in accord with the moment, and their emergence is spirit-like. One skilled in stillness speaks in accord with the moment, and their utterance is grand. All arises from the work of self-cultivation aligning with the movement of supreme spirit—even heaven does not oppose it, let alone humankind.

At ease in non-action, I attain fulfillment; the myriad things rise and fall, each attaining fulfillment. When both things and self attain fulfillment, the world is governed—what leisure remains to govern the world?

The two characters *cāngnáng* have been variously glossed as "disorder," but without phonetic clarification. According to Mao Huang’s *Zeng Yun*, *náng* is appended to the entry for *zhēng* (狞), citing *Zhuangzi* as a note. Further examination of the *Book of Han* (section on Jia Yi’s biography) reads: "The state’s system is *qiǎngrǎng* (抢攘)," where the upper character is pronounced *cāng* (仕庚切) and the lower *náng* (女庚切), both meaning "disorder." Judging by this classical text, the old gloss of *cāngnáng* as "disorder" should align with the *Book of Han*’s *qiǎngrǎng* in sound and meaning.

*Southern Florescence True Scripture: Sea of Meanings, Compiled Glosses*, Scroll 30 concluded.
#1 Guo’s commentary reads "desire" (*yù*) for "aversion" (*wù*).
#2 The *Shide Hall* edition has "loss" (*shī*) for "premature" (*yāo*).

*Southern Florescence True Scripture: Sea of Meanings, Compiled Glosses*, Scroll 31.
Scholar Chu Boxiu of Wulin.

**Chapter Two: In Indulgence**

Cui Qu asked Lao Dan, “If one does not govern the world, how can the human heart be settled?”
Lao Dan replied, “Take heed! Do not disturb the human heart. The human heart, when pressed, sinks low; when urged, rises high. Low and high, it is imprisoned and slain. Supple and yielding, it yet overcomes the hard and strong. Sharp and carving, it is hewn and polished. In its heat, it burns like fire; in its cold, it congeals like ice. Swift as a glance, it twice strokes the lands beyond the four seas. At rest, it is deep and still; in motion, it soars to the heavens. Fierce and proud, it cannot be bound—is this not the human heart?

In former times, the Yellow Emperor first disturbed the human heart with benevolence and righteousness. Yao and Shun, thereupon, wore their thighs bare and their shins hairless, to nourish the forms of the world. They wearied their five viscera for benevolence and righteousness, strained their blood and qi to model laws and measures. Yet still they could not prevail. Yao then banished Gun to Mount Chong, exiled the Three Miao to Sanwei, and sent Gonggong into exile at Youdu—this was his failure to master the world. By the time of the Three Kings, the world was greatly alarmed. Below were Jie and Zhi; above were Zeng and Shi; and the Confucians and Mohists all arose. Thereupon, joy and anger suspected one another, the foolish and the wise deceived one another, the good and the bad reviled one another, the extravagant and the truthful mocked one another—and the world declined. Great virtue diverged, and the nature and destiny of life dissolved. The world prized knowledge, and the common people exhausted themselves in pursuit. Then saws and axes were fashioned, inked cords and chisels were wielded. The world was utterly disordered—all because the human heart was disturbed. Thus, the worthy concealed themselves beneath the great mountains and lofty crags, while the lords of ten thousand chariots trembled in fear within their ancestral halls.

In this age, those condemned to death lie heaped upon one another; those in cangues and stocks jostle one another; those executed or punished are seen everywhere. Yet the Confucians and Mohists still lift their skirts and bare their arms among the stocks and pillories. Alas! How extreme is their shamelessness, their utter lack of remorse! I know not whether sagely wisdom does not become the saw and cangue that break men’s limbs, or whether benevolence and righteousness do not become the stocks and pillories that pierce men’s flesh. How can we know that Zeng and Shi are not the arrows and pellets of Jie and Zhi? Therefore it is said: ‘Abandon sageliness, discard wisdom, and the world will be greatly ordered.’”

**Guo Xiang’s Commentary:**
Pressed, it sinks; urged, it rises—this speaks of its ease of agitation. Burning fire and congealing ice arise from the accumulation of joy and anger. If it is neither carved nor polished, preserving its original simplicity, how could there be ice and fire? In the space between a glance and a nod, it twice strokes the four seas—this is the movement of customs. At rest, it may be made as still as an abyss; in motion, it leaps bound to the heavens. The transformations of the human heart are without limit. Left to itself and released, it is still and naturally penetrates; governed and bound, it stumbles and grows fierce and proud. Fierce and proud—this is an uncontrollable force.

The Yellow Emperor did not act for benevolence and righteousness; when he merged with things, the traces of benevolence and righteousness appeared. Once these traces appeared, the world necessarily followed them—this is what disturbs things. As for the reputations of Yao and Shun, these are but advances. I lodge in this advance, but the advance is not I—thus, the alarmed are of the world. The more the world is alarmed, the more the advance grows coarse. Coarseness and subtlety are like the level and perilous paths—does the traveler ever change his feet? The sage is one, yet there are differences among Yao, Shun, Tang, and Wu. What differs are the names of the times and ages, which are insufficient to name the reality of the sage. Though there are the thoroughfares of benevolence and righteousness, what passes through remains whole.

From the mutual suspicion of joy and anger to the mutual mockery of extravagance and truth, none can be equal in self-attainment. Establishing minor differences without ceasing to divide, knowing no bounds yet prizing knowledge—thus, there is nothing to satisfy their demands. Hence the calamity of saws, axes, chisels, and mallets, and the carving of nature and destiny to this extremity. If one follows nature and dwells in what is fitting, then the worthy and the foolish follow their natures, the noble and the base tread their stations, and ruler and minister, high and low, all attain their utmost—there will be no trouble in the world. This advance disturbs the hearts of the world, setting them galloping without cease. Hating the upright and reviling the correct, factions draw one another on. Those who follow their true nature lose their ground; those who practice falsity usurp their handles. Thus, rulers worry above, and the people suffer below—all from the rotten Confucians clinging to their advances. Not considering the abandonment of advances to return to unity, they instead bare their arms and employ advances to govern advances—truly, they are without shame!

The cangue and stocks use the joining of planks as their mechanism; the stocks and pillories use the piercing of handles as their function. Sagely wisdom and benevolent righteousness are the advances that distance one from crime. When the people esteem these advances, hypocrisy arises. Where hypocrisy arises, and the tools to defend against insult are lacking—this has never been.

**Lü Huiqing’s Commentary:**
To indulge and not govern is how one does not disturb the human heart; to govern and confuse it is to disturb it. Pressed, it sinks; urged, it rises—none know its direction. Low and high, it is imprisoned and slain. To its cold congealing like ice—this is not what should be disturbed. In the space between a glance and a nod, it twice strokes the four seas—its comings and goings are without time. At rest, it is deep and still; in motion, it hangs from the heavens. Fierce and proud, it cannot be bound—this is what is called grasping what is preserved and abandoning what is lost.

The True Man feared that scholars would simply take Yao and Shun as not having attained the Way, so he further spoke of the Yellow Emperor disturbing the human heart with benevolence and righteousness. His aim was to abandon sageliness and discard wisdom—it was not that these men were inherently different. Without abandoning sageliness and wisdom, one cannot be without them. To disturb the human heart with benevolence and righteousness is because one has a heart. Having a heart, one has proximity, and cannot avoid sacrificing oneself for the world, leading to what is called “fierce virtue” and its abandonment.

From “wore their thighs bare” to “model laws and measures”—this is sacrificing oneself for the world, yet still unable to prevail, because one cannot abandon sageliness and discard wisdom. Extending to the Three Kings, below were Jie and Zhi’s extreme violence, above were Zeng and Shi’s excessive goodness, and the Confucians and Mohists all arose, mutually suspecting and deceiving one another. None attained the perfect correctness of the world, so the nature and destiny of life dissolved, and the common people exhausted themselves in pursuit. Thus, the calamity of saws, axes, chisels, and mallets arose inevitably.

Thus, the worthy withdraw and conceal themselves to avoid calamity, while the lords of ten thousand chariots tremble with anxiety yet remain unaware. The method for addressing this—simply because one cannot embody non-action—is nothing more than returning to the natural state of one’s nature and destiny.

In the present age, executions and punishments fill the land in an unbroken succession, far exceeding those of the Three Dynasties. Yet the Confucians and Mohists still sit cross-legged and roll up their sleeves among the condemned, eager to debate with them—this is the height of shamelessness!

If one now seeks to remedy this but does not return to the natural state of nature and destiny, and instead piles on sageliness, wisdom, benevolence, and righteousness, it is like fleeing from Heaven’s punishment only to tighten one’s bonds further, making them insoluble. It is to heap advantage upon Jie and Zhi, allowing them to set the precedent and be followed.

Lin Yi’s sole annotation: Those who advance upward crave elevation; those who push down rush toward baseness. Each is bound by their own constraints—this is how they become imprisoned and destroyed.

Graceful softness contends with hardness and strength; this is how *kangju* loses its authenticity. Carving and polishing damage simplicity. What is called “order” is in truth a means of provocation and disruption. Thus arises the stifling of yin and yang.

"Scorching fire congeals ice"—this expresses the idea that agitation overcomes cold, while stillness overcomes heat. In Ni Yang’s inquiry, to "caress the Four Seas twice" speaks of gaining the world in the span of a dream, like the events of *Nanke* in the pillow. "Abyssal stillness" means profound silence. "Suspended from Heaven" implies lofty and distant connections. "Frenzied arrogance" describes unbridled indulgence, akin to the metaphor of the "monkey-mind" and "horse-will."

The Dao began with Fuxi, became more pronounced under Yao and Shun, and then strayed from the Huangdi’s path, practiced to the point of emaciation without limbs, baldness without hair—merely nurturing the world’s form while failing to pacify its nature. They tormented their five organs for the sake of benevolence and righteousness, stiffened their blood and qi to model laws and standards, causing yin and yang to wage war within a single body. How could they find peace in nature and destiny? If nature and destiny are not at peace, how can they overcome the world’s deceptions and artifices? Thus arose the affairs of exile and banishment.

By the time of the Three Kings, the laws had grown ever more enduring, yet their flaws ever more glaring. Hence arose the divisions of Jie, Zhì, Zeng, and Shi; the rivalries of the Ru and Mohists; mutual suspicion and deceit. The pure wind was lost, and the world declined. Nature and destiny lay in ruins, and the people were exhausted. The "new saw" is a metaphor for benevolence and righteousness; the "inked line," for ritual and law; the "hammer and chisel," for punishments and statutes. All are tools that chafe against the human heart. Thus the world fell into great chaos, and even the lords of ten thousand chariots could not secure their thrones.

Amidst the carnage where the executed lie in sight of one another, their mutilated forms bearing witness to the multitude of the imprisoned and slain, the Ru and Mohists still cling to the fragments of benevolence and righteousness, leaping and gesticulating amidst the chaos, seeking some means to salvage the situation—this is ignorance of the root. For to govern the near by recounting the past is like quenching fire with fire: can it ever succeed?

*Jiezhe* are crossbeams, as *Huainanzi* states: "The large are pillars and beams; the small, *jiezhe*." *Zaobing* are chisel handles, where the wood is shaped like the head of a pillar. The whistling of the *haoshi* arrow. *Hengyang* (pillories and cangues) are completed only after the *jiezhe* are joined; the *zhi* and *jie* (fetters and stocks) are established only after the *zaobing* are fashioned. Those who would employ sagely wisdom and benevolence seek to keep the people far from crime. Yet when the people are ever advancing, deceit and artifice arise, and the *hengyang* and *jiezhe* are thus made ready.

Only by removing that which chafes against the human heart can the world be governed.

Chen Xiangdao’s commentary: *Mencius* speaks of the human heart, saying, "Hold fast to it, and it remains; let it go, and it is lost." *Zhuangzi* speaks of the human heart, saying, "It is proud and restless, and cannot be bound." To hold fast without letting go is the way of man; to release without binding is the way of Heaven. Those who govern must not discard Heaven for man, nor should scholars discard man for Heaven. To discard Heaven for man is not the way to grant freedom; to discard man for Heaven is not the way to nurture and fill.

When the human heart is pressed downward, it is confined as in a prison; when driven upward, it rages and kills. To wound and maim it, leaving it broken and incomplete; to carve and polish it, rendering it ornate yet hollow—thus the qi of yin and yang is scattered. When it lies still, it is sullen; when it rises, it is haughty. To grasp and bind it, forcing it to close and not expand, is to invite the response of an unworthy heart.

The Seven Virtues are internal, hence they distress the five viscera. Laws and statutes are external, hence they constrain the blood and qi. Yet when transformative virtue is practiced, deceit and falsehood arise; when laws and statutes are made manifest, violence and disorder erupt. Even in Yao’s age of perfect governance, the Four Fiends could not escape punishment—how much less so in the ages that followed the Three Dynasties?

Jie and Zhòu, though noble as Sons of Heaven, committed acts even the lowliest servant would not; Kong and Mo, though impoverished commoners, were feared by the highest ministers. The distinction between noble and base lies in conduct, not in rank—hence it is said that below there are Jie and Zhì, while above there are Zeng and Shi. Mutual suspicion and deceit led to utter chaos: this is the inner punishment. The carnage of *shusi* and the implements of *hengyang* are the outer punishments. When outer constraints are imposed, inner punishments follow; when inner punishments arise, outer punishments are enacted. Thus the Ru and Mohists emerged, and the world fell into chaos, after which executions and mutilations stretched as far as the eye could see. *Shu* means to sever; *lu* means to disgrace.

*Jiezhe* are the beams of *hengyang*; *jiezhe* are not *hengyang*, yet *hengyang* are completed only through *jiezhe*. *Zaobing* are not the *zhi* and *jie* of the stocks, yet the stocks are formed only through *zaobing*. Sagely wisdom and the Seven Virtues are not crimes and evils, yet crimes and evils arise only through sagely wisdom and the Seven Virtues. Thus sagely wisdom is likened to *jiezhe*, and transformative virtue to *zaobing*.

Bixu’s commentary: The human heart is originally still; when stirred, it becomes chaotic. To *pai* is to destroy it; to *jin* is to praise it. Scorching heat without, freezing cold within—once the machinations of the heart are set in motion, they pervade the empty expanse, and the heart’s habitual tendencies, once unleashed, run wilder than a galloping horse.

In ancient times, the Yellow Emperor first employed benevolence and righteousness to ensnare the human heart. Yao and Shun toiled and suffered to nurture the world, establishing the Seven Virtues and regulating laws and statutes, yet still they could not prevail. Thus they exiled the Four Fiends, and this extended to the Three Kings. The world was seized with terror; the Ru and Mohists arose together, mutually suspicious and deceitful. Virtue diverged, and authenticity scattered; wisdom flowed away, and the people were exhausted. Thus the sages and worthies concealed themselves to preserve their lives, while those in power were beset by peril and could not be saved.

The severity of laws and decrees stems from the agitation of the heart. That punishments and executions now race through the streets and alleys—is this not the consequence of the lofty discourses of the gentry? What began as the benefits of sagely wisdom and benevolence ended as the harms of *hengyang* and *jie*. Thus the worthy in office daily refine their laws, while the benighted in power daily multiply their decrees. Whether governance grows refined or coarse depends on the people alone.

Even rulers without the Way borrow the laws and statutes of sages and worthies to carry out their tyranny—are not Zeng and Shi the *haoshi* arrows that herald Jie and Zhì?

Fuzhai observes: This passage, when read alongside *Mencius*’s "entering and exiting without fixed times, their whereabouts unknown," is especially profound.

To be pressed downward is to be in a time of frustration, when the heart inclines toward the lowly; to gain power is to be ever advancing without cease. The more the heart strives upward, the more both high and low become prisons and executions, self-entangling and self-tormenting.

The unyielding may be softened by gentle restraint—Xiang Yu weeping over Lady Yu is such a case. To pare away sharp edges, to carve and polish, to grind and refine: the young who gain power lose their sharpness, and with further worldly experience, all is worn smooth.

Scorching fire and congealed ice—this describes how joy, anger, sorrow, and fear shift in an instant, the heart’s movements as swift as if traversing the four seas. Profound stillness is likened to immobility; the moment a thought arises, it is as if suspended from the heavens. *Fen* is the same as *fen*; *fenjiao* describes a state of haughty defiance. *Xi* means to restrain. This passage vividly depicts the human heart in a most extraordinary way.

"Thighs without flesh" means the spleen and flesh do not grow. "Shins without hair" means the feet are worn from toil. *Jin* means to stiffen the blood and qi, as if to say, "to bind internally with benevolence, righteousness, and laws." Despite such toil and suffering, the world remains ungovernable—hence the punishments of exile. Yao’s perfect governance could not avoid punishing the Four Fiends—how much less so in the ages after the Three Dynasties?

Jie and Zhòu, though exalted as Sons of Heaven, descended to the conduct of the lowliest; Zeng and Shi, though commoners, were admired for their reputations. The Ru and Mohists arose, mutually suspicious and derisive, and the true nature of life and destiny was utterly ruined.

Inner punishments lead to outer punishments: mutual suspicion and deceit brought utter chaos, while *shusi* and *hengyang* became the outer punishments. When outer constraints are applied, inner punishments follow; when inner punishments arise, outer punishments are enacted. Thus the Ru and Mohists emerged, the world fell into chaos, and executions stretched as far as the eye could see. *Shu* means to sever; *lu* means to disgrace.

The people’s demands were exhausted—there was nothing with which to answer them. Unable to prevail over the world, rulers resorted to punishments. Thus the worthy withdrew into reclusion while the sovereign toiled alone; the condemned multiplied, yet the Ru and Mohists still vaunted their lofty principles, strutting among the throng of convicts with their disjointed postures—how profoundly shameless! *Hengyang* were the stocks; *jiexi* were the central crossbars wedged tight. *Zuishi* were the whistling arrows of today. Only when the world was disordered did the name of “order” arise; only when the people’s hearts were corrupt did the pretext of “correcting” them emerge. The establishment of governing techniques began with the lawmaking rulers of the Middle Antiquity and decayed at the hands of later ministers who slavishly followed their traces. As the *Classic* says, does the nature of a tree inherently desire compass and square, hook and line? Cui Qu failed to understand that the human heart is originally endowed with perfect goodness and instead sought to govern the world’s hearts into goodness. The Old Master would have been ashamed to instruct him beyond “Simply do not disturb it—this is enough!” Why contrive to make it good? The corruption of today’s hearts lies in their fondness for suppressing the lowly and exalting the high, leading to contention, imprisonment, and slaughter. They do not know that yielding softness is the way of firm strength, and so they blunt their edges, carve their substance, delight and anger strike from without, ice and fire assail within—how much of that single spark of harmonious qi remains unscorched? Moreover, when a thought first arises, it is as if ten thousand rivers and a thousand mountains lie between, so vast is the gulf between stillness and the heavens—this is what is meant by “fuming arrogance that cannot be restrained.”

In high antiquity, nonaction prevailed: ruler and people each found their place, dwelling in primal chaos yet attaining tranquil vastness. When the Yellow Emperor began to govern, he first used the Seven Standards to constrain the human heart; by the time of Yao and Shun, governance was fully established, and the constraints grew ever deeper. The deeper the constraints, the more forcefully they were violated, so that the punishment of the Four Fiends became unavoidable, startling the world. Thus harm and grace arose in mutual succession—this is the inevitable consequence of such principles. Above, there were differing modes of governance; below, differing virtues. The nature of life and destiny became scattered beyond recovery, and the people’s demands were exhausted, with nothing left to offer. Then the disasters of saws, mallets, and chisels arose, and the world fell into chaos beyond remedy. The worthy concealed themselves to avoid calamity; rulers of ten thousand chariots trembled in anxious survival. The executed lay heaped upon the roads, and the failure of punishments to strike their mark was plain to see! Yet those who governed now rolled up their sleeves among the fetters and shackles, claiming they were equal to the burdens of turmoil and skilled in ordering chaos. They never realized that the cause of disorder was their own doing—no different from placing someone in drowning peril and then hitching up one’s robes to rescue them, believing this to be kindness. Not only does the other suffer distress, but the rescuer is also wearied and exhausted! From this we know that what the world calls sagacity, wisdom, benevolence, and righteousness are nearly always the stocks and crossbars of punishment; that Zeng, Shi, Yang, and Mo were not necessarily less than Jie and Zhòu’s instruments of harm.

The *Dao De Jing* says: “I practice nonaction, and the people transform themselves; I am without desire, and the people return to simplicity.” Is this not the governance of non-governance?

When the Yellow Emperor ascended the throne, he ruled as Son of Heaven for nineteen years, and his commands reached throughout the world. Hearing that Master Guangcheng dwelt atop Mount Kongtong, he went to see him and said: “I have heard that you have attained the perfection of the supreme Dao. I venture to ask: what is the essence of the supreme Dao? I wish to gather the essence of heaven and earth to aid the five grains and nourish the people; I also wish to regulate yin and yang to ensure the growth of all living things. How should this be done?”

Master Guangcheng replied: “What you wish to inquire about is the substance of things; what you wish to regulate is the dregs of things. Ever since you began to govern the world, clouds do not wait to gather before it rains, and plants do not wait to yellow before they fall. The light of the sun and moon grows ever more dim. With your heart so full of flattery and scheming, how can you speak of the supreme Dao?”

The Yellow Emperor withdrew, relinquished the world, built a solitary chamber, spread a mat of white cogon grass, and dwelled in seclusion for three months before returning to seek him again. Master Guangcheng lay with his head to the south, facing outward. The Yellow Emperor approached from downwind, crawling on his knees, bowed twice, touched his forehead to the ground, and asked: “I have heard that you have attained the perfection of the supreme Dao. I venture to ask: how should one cultivate the body to attain longevity?”

Master Guangcheng rose abruptly and said: “Excellent question! Come, I will tell you of the supreme Dao. The essence of the supreme Dao is profound and obscure; its utmost limit is dim and silent. See nothing, hear nothing, embrace the spirit in stillness, and the body will right itself. Be still, be pure; do not weary your body, do not scatter your essence, and you may attain long life. Let your eyes see nothing, your ears hear nothing, your heart know nothing—then your spirit will guard your body, and your body will attain long life. Guard your inner self, restrain your outer self, and excessive knowledge will lead to ruin. I have guided you to the great brightness above, to the source of utmost yang; I have led you into the gate of profound obscurity, to the source of utmost yin. Heaven and earth have their offices, yin and yang have their storehouses. Guard your body carefully, and things will flourish of themselves. I preserve the One and dwell in harmony, and so I have cultivated my body for one thousand two hundred years, yet my form has never declined.”

The Yellow Emperor bowed twice, touched his forehead to the ground, and said: “Master Guangcheng is what we call Heaven!”

Master Guangcheng said: “Come, I will tell you more. Those things are inexhaustible, yet people all take them to be finite; those things are unfathomable, yet people all take them to be limited. One who attains my Dao may become a sovereign above or a king below; one who loses my Dao may see light above but become dust below. Now all the myriad beings are born from the earth and return to the earth. Therefore I will leave you and enter the gate of the inexhaustible, roam the wilds of the boundless. I will share the light of the sun and moon and be constant with heaven and earth. Let what is near to me be bright; let what is distant be dim. Let others all perish—I alone will endure!”

Guo’s commentary: “To ask about the essence of the supreme Dao—this is indeed a substantive inquiry.”

To impose governance upon what should be left to itself is to bring ruin. If all people cultivate themselves without meddling in the world, the world will be well-ordered. The profound and obscure, the dim and silent—all are utterly without form. What Laozi and Zhuangzi repeatedly call "nothingness" makes clear that the generator of beings is no-thing, yet beings arise of themselves.

To forget seeing yet see of itself, to forget hearing yet hear of itself, to let things move as they will—thus one remains serene and does not perish prematurely. Guard within to preserve one’s true nature; close without to maintain one’s proper place. To presume knowledge of the boundless is to court defeat.

To fathom the source of yin and yang is to recognize that there are offices and repositories, yet one should simply let them be. To follow the utmost of one’s nature and destiny, to reach the ultimate of long life—only then, without dying young, can one extend to others. Beings are inexhaustible, yet people take them to be finite, seeing only one side.

The titles of sovereign and king rise and fall with the times; those who grasp the Dao of adaptability respond to the inexhaustible as one. Losing the inexhaustible Dao, one clings to a single partial view, unable to harmonize above and below, thus inclining and declining with shifting intent. Earth is without mind; born from the mindless, one should return to guard the mindless and proceed alone.

Entering the inexhaustible, roaming the boundless—thus one moves with transformation. Sharing the light of the sun and moon, constant with heaven and earth—all is left to itself. The coming and going of things are unperceived, so life and death are as one, and nowhere is there not preservation.

Lu’s commentary: “Above Kongtong, where there is no-thing yet great passage prevails.” The Dao is the uncarved simplicity of the nameless, hence called "substance." Yin and yang are the dispersal of the Dao, hence called "ruin." Clouds and mists do not wait to gather before spreading into desolation—this is not assisting their natural course but rather harming it.

Secluding oneself for three months, reaching the utmost in purity, following the wind to advance, tracing the root to seek it—only the Dao enables one to govern the self and endure. This is indeed to inquire into its essence. The profound and obscure are without form, beyond words and beyond thought, yet there is what is called "essence"—to speak of it is not to reach its ultimate. Only in utter dimness and silence does one attain the Dao’s utmost.

This speaks of the Dao’s body: without seeing, without hearing, one may enter the Dao and attain long life. Embracing the spirit in stillness, the form does not strive for correctness yet becomes correct of itself. Serene and pure, it cannot be disturbed or muddied; the form is not wearied yet preserved, the essence is not agitated yet restored—only then can one attain long life.

The spirit is formless yet clings to things; if it does not cling to things but returns to the unseen and unknowing, how can one guard the form? Guard within to block its openings; close without to shut its gates—this is the way to nurture and preserve the spirit. The opposite leads to excessive knowledge and ruin.

Those who do not know the Dao are confined by yin and yang and never reach their source. Without seeing, without hearing, without knowing, one enters the realm of great clarity, passes through the gate of the profound and obscure. Attaining and exhausting this, one knows that heaven and earth have their offices, and their governance lies herein; yin and yang have their repositories, and their storage lies herein. Guard your body carefully—things will naturally flourish, so why seek externally?

The Yellow Emperor further explained that what was earlier called "no seeing, no hearing" pertains to the body of the Dao. As for its function, no seeing is how one sees of itself, no hearing is how one hears of itself, no knowing is how one knows of itself. The Dao as a thing is inexhaustible and unfathomable, yet it ultimately resides in nothingness. Seeing, hearing, knowing—these take the inexhaustible as finite, the unfathomable as limited.

Those who attain the Dao become sovereigns or kings, for their spirit and clarity give rise to royal authority. Those who lose the Dao see light yet become dust, for their form does not transcend the space between illumination and earthly covering. The hundred beings are born from earth and return to earth by their form alone. Thus I will leave you, enter the inexhaustible, and roam the boundless—those who take this as an end or limit do not truly know me!

Sharing the light of the sun and moon, their brightness does not cease; constant with heaven and earth, their duration is without end. When I am near, one does not perceive it as near; when I am distant, one does not perceive it as distant. All people perish while I alone endure—seeking within myself, I know not what thing enables me to reach this. Of the myriad beings, humans are the most spiritually endowed. How rare it is for creation to produce one, and how rare among humans are those whose intelligence and insight can attain this—yet if they do not diligently pursue it, then those who treasure compassion will surely repeat these words again and again.

You Du’s commentary: The Yellow Emperor, having ruled for many years, regulated the cycles of yin and yang to govern the world—hence his progress. Guangcheng did not govern the world—hence his Dao. The Yellow Emperor sought to master heaven and earth and govern yin and yang—this is the work of one who embodies the utmost destiny and spirit. Yin and yang refer to qi; heaven and earth refer to form. Qi is refined while form is coarse; the refined is the essence of spirit, while yin and yang are the dispersal of the Dao.

What can be questioned and answered easily scatters into heaven and earth; what can be governed and entrusted scatters spirit into yin and yang. Clouds and mists do not gather before rain, yet yin and yang lose their principle; plants and trees do not yellow before falling, yet the myriad beings lose their Dao. Even the dimming of the sun and moon—none of this is the governance of the spiritually perfected.

Seclusion without being burdened by things; three months, the minor completion of a cycle. The essence of the supreme Dao is the Great Simplicity; the ultimate of the supreme Dao is the Great Ultimate. Yin and yang arise from the Great Simplicity; heaven and earth arise from the Great Ultimate. The profound and obscure, the dim and silent—without image or number—are thus called "essence" and "ultimate." The eye is not disordered by colors, the ear is not disordered by sounds—thus the spirit remains whole and undisturbed by the deviant.

Qi does not interfere, and form settles into oneness. Do not labor your form—*Laozi* says: "Bear the soul and spirit," this is it. Do not agitate your essence—*Laozi* says: "Embrace the One," this is it. The *po* governs form; the One is the number of essence. Those who study the Dao should expand their aspiration without being burdened by form, so that spirit constantly bears the *po* yet is not borne by the *po*—thus may one embrace the One and embody the spirit!

Now, when people die and differ in ascent or descent, it is because they extinguish spirit to follow form, letting spirit submit to the *po*, and so sink into dark yin, transforming into other beings. But those whose spirit is whole—though the *po*’s yin stagnates—will unite with spirit and go anywhere without hindrance.

When the eye sees nothing, it turns inward; when the ear hears nothing, it reverses its hearing; when the heart knows nothing, it thinks nothing. Thus, dust is barred from without, roots are secured within, and form may attain long life. Guard within, and the true does not scatter; close without, and dust does not enter—this is the meaning of "daily diminishing" in the Dao. To know much is to daily increase one’s affairs, and so invite ruin.

Above the great brightness, the Dao is manifest; at the gate of the profound and obscure, mysterious virtue resides. Supreme yang has no yin; supreme yin has no yang. The *yuan* is the root of yin and yang, the source from which the myriad things emerge. That things are boundless and unfathomable yet deemed finite is merely human speech. The *huang* is that from which kings arise—this is the Way of Heaven; kings emerge from the *huang*—this is the Way of Man. Light speaks of heaven, earth speaks of soil. Those who attain the Dao emerge as kings, withdraw as *huang*, and are bound by nothing; those who lose the Dao are partial—above, they appear as light; below, as mere soil.

Now, the hundred flourishing things of the world begin in soil and end in soil—does soil have intent toward them? Humans are born from the formless and die into the formless—how can they remain bound to the human realm? I shall depart from you: though the body dwells among men, the heart has already left to wander with the Creator!

The boundless has no visible beginning; the infinite has no visible end. The gate is that through which entry and exit occur; the wild is vast and without destination. Aligning with the sun and moon in brightness, uniting with heaven and earth in virtue—thus the mind of the perfected is like a mirror: things come, and it responds; things go, and it forgets. When things come to me, I am luminous, as if bound to them; when things depart, I am dim, as if forgetting them. The coming and going of things are all unperceived.

"All men may die, yet I alone endure"—this means the spirit-person unites with creation, and life and death cannot alter them.

*Detailed Commentary on the Dao*:
Heaven and earth have their offices—one may serve them but not defy them; yin and yang have their storehouses—one may entrust them but not abandon them. To govern yin and yang to prolong life is to steer heaven with human will, opposing nature—how many things would not be harmed?

*Laozi* says: "The Dao is level, yet people prefer shortcuts," and also: "To augment life is called ill-omened." If one seeks speed and forces growth, a child may be born before its time and perish. Clouds and mists not gathering before rain—how is this different from one who pulls up seedlings to hasten their growth? This is why those who defy the sun and moon only hasten their ruin!

The Yellow Emperor withdrew, relinquishing the world—he could transcend things but not yet transcend life, so he asked about the Dao of cultivating the body. Guangchengzi taught him to be utterly still and utterly pure, and thus he attained transcendence of life. He further taught that things are without limit—when dim and silent, seeing and hearing perceive nothing; when profound and obscure, even grasping finds nothing.

The ears and eyes are bandits of the heart—thus one must utterly refrain from seeing and hearing, then embrace spirit in stillness. Movement and turbidity are pests to form and essence—thus one must be secretly still to avoid laboring form, secretly pure to avoid laboring essence. This is why closing and guarding are prized, not the accumulation of knowledge.

Yang is manifest, so it abides above the great brightness; yin is hidden, so it enters the realm of the profound and obscure. Guarding the One is the perfection of essence; dwelling in harmony is the perfection of harmony. To contain virtue deeply is to be like an infant—this is the perfection of essence and harmony. Thus, one may live twelve hundred years without the body ever declining!

The Dao has no beginning before and no end after—it differs from that which has number; it is neither entangled above nor dim below—it differs from that which has form. Light is the essence of yang; soil is the substance of yin. Losing the Dao, one is enslaved above by yang and so appears as light; controlled below by yin, one becomes mere soil.

All things are born from soil and return to soil—I shall depart from it. Aligning with the sun and moon in radiance unites their brightness; abiding with heaven and earth as constant unites their virtue. When I am luminous, what unites with me becomes luminous as Dao; when I am dim, what distances itself from me becomes dim as things.

"All men may die, yet I alone endure"—this means they flourish their branches and leaves to harm the root, while I deepen the root and secure the stem to preserve the branches and leaves.

*Blue Void Commentary*:
To have desires, to take—this is not essence and subtlety, but coarse substance. To have methods, to govern—this is not wholeness of the true, but certain injury. To rule the world oneself brings yang disasters and yin calamities, and the two luminaries lose their brightness—how can one speak of the supreme Dao?

The Yellow Emperor withdrew, relinquishing the world, crawling on his knees to ask about cultivating the body. Guangchengzi first taught him of the profound and obscure, forcibly naming the essence of the Dao; of the dim and silent, forcibly naming the ultimate of the Dao. Not taking colors as colors, not taking sounds as sounds—thus spirit is still and form is upright. Stillness means spirit is not labored; purity means essence is not agitated. Not seeing recklessly, thus no sight; not hearing recklessly, thus no hearing; not thinking recklessly, thus no thought.

The three are all true, thus spirit abides and form endures. Guarding within empties the heart; closing without seals the apertures. Ever wary of how excessive knowledge brings ruin, one thus transcends yin and yang, meeting the realm of the Dao.

The three luminaries shine brightly, the five peaks stand firm—heaven and earth have their offices. The four seasons nurture life, the myriad things take form—yin and yang have their treasuries. Governing oneself, things transform and daily grow stronger; in purity and oneness, the harmonious and subtle gather, thus cultivating the body for one thousand two hundred years without the form ever decaying.

Li Chunfeng’s *Tian Yuan Zhu Wu Bo* states: "One thousand two hundred is called the great cycle, also known as the lesser reckoning of yin and yang." The Dao has no beginning, how could it have an end? Not knowing whose child it is, how could it have a limit? Above it is sovereign, below it is king—greatest within the realm. Above it is light, below it is earth—yet it is one thing.

The myriad things arise and perish of themselves; I too am but cultivation’s coming and going. The gate of the great void is boundless; the wilds of creation are infinite. Matching the sun and moon in radiance yet not displaying oneself, aligning with heaven and earth as constant yet not differing from them.

Things near me are like threads—subtle yet unperceived; things far from me are like darkness—obscure and unknown. When all others meet their destined end, I alone endure, for I possess that which does not perish.

Yongzhai states: "To govern yin and yang is to ensure each fulfills its office." The inherent nature of things is called *zhi*—this is the supreme Dao of earlier speech. "Things’ ruin" refers to harm done to them. Heaven and earth, yin and yang—all follow natural principle. The five grains grow of themselves, each unfolding as it must. To impose intention upon them is to harm them instead.

Clouds gather not yet rain falls—here it is, there it is not. Leaves fall without awaiting yellow—timing is lost. Profound and obscure, dim and silent, so subtle as to be invisible. Without sight, without hearing, ears and eyes both forgotten. Still and non-active, the form corrects itself; spirit remains pure and tranquil, the form unlabored. Qi unagitated, one may attain longevity—this is the origin of present cultivation arts.

No labor, no agitation—*wu* here shares the sense of *wu* ("do not"), conveying prohibition. No seeing, no hearing, no knowing—this further explains the lines "without reckless sight" and "embracing spirit." Guarding within stills the heart; closing without prevents things from stirring the five senses. Only in unknowing does virtue remain whole; excessive knowledge ruins affairs.

The great brightness is the great void; the profound and obscure is the infinite. The human body itself contains heaven and earth, yin and yang. When my heaven and earth each fulfill their offices, my yin and yang each rest in their places, then this body may be guarded with care, and all things within it grow firm. "Things" here refer to all within this body. What is guarded is singular and unadulterated; where it dwells, all is harmonious and compliant—thus one thousand two hundred years pass without the form decaying.

Guangchengzi speaks of heaven—of merging with it as one. How can things have limits when humans seek their ends? How can things be fathomed when humans demand their bounds? To pursue the boundless with the bounded is folly. The *Book of Changes* does not conclude with *Completion* but with *Incompletion*—thus we know things are endless and unfathomable. The Master by the river said: "Passing away like this!"—also pointing to the endless and unfathomable.

Above as sovereign, below as king—like the "inner sage, outer king" of the *Under Heaven* chapter. The sovereign acts not; the king acts—this is not the kings of the Three Sovereigns or Three Dynasties. "Above it is light" refers to the sun and moon; "below it is earth" refers to the ground. Dwelling between heaven and earth, utterly unknowing, one looks up to see only sun and moon, looks down to see only earth.

The hundred things arise from earth and return to earth—wondrous and foul, putrid and fragrant, all transform in turn. "Depart from you" means leaving the human world. The boundless gate, the infinite wilds—speaking of what lies beyond heaven and earth. Thus one may share the same longevity as heaven and earth, sun and moon.

*Jin* is the same as *ming* ("dark"). *Hun* means obscurity. Things that approach me come; those that recede go—whether things come or go, I remain oblivious. Kongtong is also written as Kongdong. Sima’s old commentary states:

When the Northern Dipper descends below the mountain.
The *Erya* states: "Northward, bearing the Dipper’s pole, is Kongtong Mountain." Though such a mountain has existed since antiquity, it also seems to carry symbolic meaning. The Dipper resides at heaven’s center, governing all transformations; the mountain, bearing the Dipper’s pole, stands at earth’s center. Kongtong, positioned at the center of heaven and earth, serves as a metaphor for the human heart abiding in the center to govern externals—those who dwell in it well command all things.

Guangchengzi may refer to Laozi, though we need not fixate on this; he is simply an ancient sage. The Yellow Emperor went to inquire about the supreme Dao and was told: "The essence of heaven and earth is a primordial, undifferentiated substance; the qi of yin and yang, once divided, is but a remnant.
