What you seek to ask still approaches the Dao; what you seek to govern is but a residue. Far removed from the Dao, how can it be worth discussing?"

The Yellow Emperor withdrew and lived in seclusion, then returned to ask about the Dao of cultivating the body. Only then was he instructed: "See nothing, hear nothing; embrace the spirit and rectify the form. Be still, be pure; exert no labor, stir no disturbance. Reach the origin of yin and yang—there lies the ultimate Dao of self-cultivation! Heaven and earth have their offices, yin and yang their storehouses." This refers to the inner workings of the body, guiding one to seek within. A lifespan of twelve hundred years merely reflects the brief span of human inquiry compared to a single cosmic cycle. If one seeks its division—the source of spirit’s descent and qi’s generation—it spans from ancient times to the present without end.

Since the existence of heaven and earth, yin and yang, there have been humans and all things. Those who come after my body are beyond calculation—this is the boundless and unfathomable. Yet people regard it as finite because they observe only the transformations of form and fail to perceive what does not change. "Above as sovereign, below as king"—this speaks of attaining the Dao, not of holding rank and title. Thus, though times may differ, the transformation of all things remains the same.

"Above it is light; below it is earth"—this describes those who lose the Dao: their essence and spirit become will-o’-the-wisps, their bones and flesh return to dust. Such are the vainly born and recklessly dead, mere playthings of creation’s forging. The myriad beings arise from earth and return to earth—this too hinges on whether one attains or loses the Dao. The Dao has no gain or loss; things have their departures and arrivals, emerging from and entering into mechanism—such is transformation.

"I shall depart from you"—this means I will not return to earth but ascend to the Great Void, thereby sharing the same longevity as the Two Modes and the Two Luminaries. Those who approach me are in harmony with the Dao, obscure and dark; those who recede from me are benighted and unknowing.

"All men shall perish"—this means the multitudes end in transformation, while I alone endure. This "I" is not the "I" of the nine orifices and hundred bones, but the original "I" of clarity, tranquility, subtlety, and emptiness—unseen by form, unsought by sound. Thus, it existed before heaven and earth, standing alone and unchanging.

I privately reflect that the two sages personally transmitted the essentials of the Dao in this chapter, which contains no lofty or difficult practices—only simplicity and clarity. Yet later generations, shallow and fond of the strange, contrived theories of visualization, extraction, and union, exhausting spirit and body in pursuit of tranquility. Some even blindly lead the blind, driving ice-carts upon volcanoes without awakening—how many fail to preserve their very source of life?

The world has long lacked true discernment. Upon reverently reading the teachings of Guangcheng, I have ventured these reckless words, which may yet find those who, though reckless, will grasp them.

*Collected Subtleties of the Meaning of the Southern Florescence True Scripture*, Scroll Thirty-One (End)
*(Note: According to the *Chengshu*, the character "上" was originally "山." The Shidetang edition reads "闲" as one character. The Shidetang edition reads "闭" for this character.)*

*Collected Subtleties of the Meaning of the Southern Florescence True Scripture*, Scroll Thirty-Two
*By the Daoist of Wulin, Chu Boxiu*

**Chapter "In Indulgence" the Third**

Cloud General was roaming eastward when he passed the branches of the Whirlwind Tree and chanced upon Vast Vagueness. Vast Vagueness was just then patting his chest and leaping about in play. Cloud General, seeing this, halted in astonishment and stood transfixed, asking: "Old sir, who are you? What are you doing here?"

Vast Vagueness, still patting his chest and leaping without pause, replied to Cloud General: "Roaming!"

Cloud General said: "I wish to ask you something."

Vast Vagueness looked up at Cloud General and sighed: "Ah!"

Cloud General said: "The qi of Heaven is disharmonious, the qi of Earth is pent-up; the Six Qi are unbalanced, the Four Seasons disordered. Now I wish to harmonize the nature of the Six Qi to nurture all living things—what should I do?"

Vast Vagueness, still patting his chest and leaping, shook his head and said: "I know not! I know not!"

Cloud General could get no answer. Three years later, he roamed eastward again, passing through the wilds of Song, where he once more chanced upon Vast Vagueness. Cloud General rejoiced greatly, hastening forward to meet him, saying: "Has Heaven forgotten me? Has Heaven forgotten me?" He bowed twice, touching his head to the ground, and begged to hear from Vast Vagueness.

Vast Vagueness said: "Drifting, I know not what I seek; reckless, I know not where I go. Roaming carefree, I observe the uncontrived. What do I know?"

Cloud General said: "I too thought myself reckless, yet the people follow wherever I go. I cannot be free of the people, and now they imitate me—pray, grant me a word of instruction."

Vast Vagueness said: "To disorder the warp of Heaven, to contravene the nature of things—even the Dark Heaven cannot bring this to fruition. Loose the grasses that bind the beasts, and the birds will all cry at night; calamity will reach the plants and trees, disaster the insects and worms. Alas! This is the fault of those who govern men!"

Cloud General said: "Then what am I to do?"

Vast Vagueness said: "Alas, how poisonous! Go back, go back, you immortal!"

Cloud General said: "I have met with Heaven’s difficulty—pray, grant me a word of instruction."

Vast Vagueness said: "Ah! Cultivate the heart. Abide in non-action, and things will transform of themselves. Cast off your form, expel your cleverness, forget both self and things. Merge with the great confluence, untie the heart, release the spirit, and be utterly without soul. The ten thousand things, drifting like clouds, each return to their root, each return to their root yet know it not. Vague and undifferentiated, they never depart from it all their lives. If they were to know it, they would depart from it. Ask not their names, pry not into their natures—things will thus live of themselves."

Cloud General said: "Heaven has bestowed virtue upon me, shown me silence. Seeking it in myself, I have now attained it." He bowed twice, touching his head to the ground, then rose and took his leave.

Guo's Commentary:
To seek without knowing what one seeks yet attain what one seeks, to go without knowing where one goes yet reach where one goes—thus the inwardly sufficient find all things self-correcting when they lift their gaze. Riding things is not for the sake of pathways, yet pathways manifest of themselves; wild abandon is not to summon the people, yet the people come of themselves—thus one is imitated by the people and cannot but comply. If one follows the nature of things without governing them, then feelings do not rebel and constants do not disorder, and the profound silence achieves what is naturally attained.

When beasts are scattered and crows cry at night, they depart from their source of stillness, and grasses, trees, and insects suffer harm while sitting idle. For where there are traces of governance, there disorder arises. Alas! How poisonous—this sigh over the excesses of those who govern.

*Fufu* describes the posture of sitting and rising, lamenting that one cannot be utterly unrestrained and far-reaching, hence dispatching the envoy to return. When the heart is harmed by use, then to nurture the heart—is it not precisely by not using the heart? When principle and things are not held in mind but entrusted to nature, then non-action transforms of itself. Merging with the confluence, one becomes boundless with things, utterly without soul, sitting in forgetfulness and entrusting oneself to solitude. Vague and undifferentiated, one knows nothing yet lets things return of themselves—only thus can one never depart from the root all one’s life. To know and then return is to depart from returning.

To inquire and to pry is to lose their self-arising; to be silent and know it is to always attain of itself.

Lü's Commentary:
Cloud General is one who takes nourishing the world as his own duty. The branches of the whirlwind are the extremities of movement. *Hong* (vast) and *meng* (obscure) in his name reveal his nature. If one wishes to harmonize the six qi to nurture all life, then one has the intention to nourish the world—yet I say this is not true knowing. All people have what they seek and where they go; I alone know neither what I seek nor where I go, attaining it only through unknowing.

*Yangzhang* describes constraint, as if even the wanderer were bound, yet I see that the truth of the world is nothing more than this. When the ten thousand things arise together, I observe their return. In returning, there is no delusion—what then do I know? To consider oneself wild and unrestrained is to be without self-interest. The people’s dissipation is not yet non-action. Heaven is non-action; things are without knowledge. To have knowledge and to act is to disorder the heavenly constants, rebel against the nature of things, and fail to achieve the profound Heaven.

The year has its profound Heaven—this is the winter solstice. The month has its profound Heaven—this is the last day. The day has its profound Heaven—this is midnight. And man too has his profound Heaven. Those of old who sought the abode of the upright qi to preserve their spirit and beautify their root did not fail to know this—yet this is not what the officials make manifest.

That the profound Heaven fails to be achieved and calamity befalls birds, beasts, and insects is nearly due to the error of not knowing non-action yet governing them. Medicine is used to cure illness; to govern with non-action is like administering poison where there is no illness. The envoy was sent back, desiring him to return to the root and seek it.

All people have a formed heart; it lies in self-nurturance alone. In self-nurturance, there is nothing to be done, and things transform of themselves. Encompassing the form, one forgets the six limbs; expelling cleverness, one forgets ears and eyes. Principle lies within me; things lie outside. The confluence is the emptiness of qi awaiting things. When I forget things and merge with the confluence, the heart is untied, the spirit released, and one is utterly without soul—this is how one abides in the Way of non-action.

When things are just arising, I do not know it; when I cause things to return to their root, I do not know it either. Thus vague and undifferentiated, they become one, never departing from it all their lives. Without inquiry and without prying, things arise of themselves. When one is without knowledge, one does not know one is without knowledge. To say, "Is this called unknowing?" is to inquire into its name. To ask, "Is this truly unknowing?" is to pry into its nature. It is like a thing just arising—if one uproots it to examine it, it cannot live. Heaven’s way of creating things is like this.

Du’s Commentary:
Cloud General is the commander of clouds. *Hongmeng* is the qi before the division of yin and yang. *Fuyao* refers to wind, signifying its formlessness. *Wandering* means following one’s natural inclinations—what *Liezi* calls "ultimate wandering." Cloud General had not seen the essence of the Dao, so he pointed to current affairs and asked about harmonizing the six qi to nurture all life.

Hongmeng said: "Wander!" He could not yet be without opposition. Next, he looked up and said: "Hmm! Now there is no opposition," yet he could not be without demonstration. Finally, he said: "I do not know, I do not know!" Then there was no demonstration—this is the ultimate attainment of the Dao.

*Yangzhang* means constraint; though one is bound at first, one ultimately attains of oneself, and all one sees is correct without delusion. Observing thus, what do I know? To take unknowing as knowing is true knowing.

Heaven has its constancy, and all things have their nature. To disrupt and oppose them is why the mysterious Heaven does not attain completion. The mysterious is the essence of the wondrous; the celestial offices are natural. Birds, beasts, insects—all possess the principle of life and destiny. Following this principle brings peace; opposing it brings chaos. Now, to forcibly govern them is to untie their bonds and make them cry out in the night.

The cultivation of the heart-mind: all dharmas arise from the heart-mind. Nurture it with principle, stabilize it with stillness. When things come, respond; when they depart, forget. Only then can one achieve non-action yet leave nothing undone, transcend form and abandon knowledge to merge with the great thoroughfare, where human relations and the principles of things blend into one. Thus, to release the heart-mind and liberate the spirit, to be vacant and without soul—this is the ultimate of the human Dao, by which one harmonizes with Heaven.

As for the myriad things—each illusory transformation returns to its root. This speaks of the impermanence of illusory forms in conditioned existence, while the empty nature is indestructible, thus reaching the destiny of life. Vast and undifferentiated, one remains thus all one’s life. If one claims to know it, the Dao departs.

At first, there was constraint, and thus names arose. Where life and destiny reside, there emotions arise. Names and emotions are not the concern of the spirit-person returning to destiny. Without inquiring into names, names do not harm reality. Without scrutinizing emotions, emotions do not overcome nature. Things then arise of themselves—this is the attainment of the principle of the myriad things.

Cloud General heard these words and awakened: Heaven referred to Hongmeng, who descended virtue and demonstrated silence. All speak of the spirit-person’s way of engaging with things—attaining that which is without attainment, thus rising in speech and departing.

*Bixu’s Commentary*: Cloud General is the marshal of rain and moisture; *Shuyou* is the practice of benevolence and kindness. The branches of the whirlwind are where the wind first passes. Hongmeng is primordial qi. *Wandering* refers to the movement of primordial qi. If the upper does not branch, the lower does not ascend; if the five movements are disordered, the six qi rebel—this is the wilds of Song, where moisture and nourishment abound.

Without knowing what one seeks, one is unattached to things. Without knowing where one goes, one wanders freely without intent. Though things are numerous, their divisions naturally align—what do I know? Clouds are originally without mind, yet the people follow and thus gain a mind. The general acts out of necessity, yet the people imitate and thus create boundaries. Intentional change disrupts constancy; self-will enslaves emotion. Disrupted and opposed, the principle of Heaven is difficult to complete. Thus, mountain forests lack tranquil scenes, and marshes lack harmonious qi—all due to laws being too explicit and regulations too severe!

*Heart-mind cultivation* means nurturing with the heart-mind. Non-action nurtures the heart-mind; action is nurtured by the heart-mind. The heart-mind is not mine to possess; nature is originally empty. Unaware of movement or stillness, one merges with the vast darkness. Light and shadow both vanish, returning to profound obscurity. Undifferentiated, one remains thus—knowledge causes separation!

Without name, without emotion—what is there to inquire or scrutinize? In silence, what is there to seek? Cloud’s virtue could not but rise in speech and depart—this is wondrous function.

Fu Zhai states: The branches of the whirling winds are the very land where the Fusang sun rises. The inquiry of Yusheng is identical to the Yellow Emperor’s question in the previous chapter. "Burdened governance" describes a state of chaos and turmoil. "Without delusion" is authenticity. Amidst chaos and turmoil, one observes one’s own authenticity. "Unable to abandon the people" means desiring to withdraw yet being unable. The people’s excesses take me as their model. The celestial principles and the nature of things are both spontaneous. To act with intention is to cause disorder. Opposing spontaneity, the mysterious Heaven cannot be completed. "Mysterious" means emptiness, akin to "prior to Heaven." Failing to assist things in their natural course, causing them to lose their nature, brings calamity even to grasses, trees, and insects. This is the fault of governing people with intention—how poisonous it is! "Transmit, transmit!" urges a hasty return.

"Heart-mind cultivation" means: cease your efforts, and this heart-mind will nurture itself. It is not called "nurturing the heart-mind" but "the heart-mind’s nurturing"—ponder this carefully. Simply abide in non-action, and things will spontaneously arise and transform. Expel all former cleverness, let distinctions and judgments dissolve, and forget all things—then you will merge with the vast primordial depths. The "vast depths" are the origin of formlessness and qi-lessness. Dissolve the heart-mind of intention, release the spirit of knowing. "Without soul" means without knowledge. Each returns to its root; what is born must perish. Though perishing, it does not perish—what perishes is reborn. Thus, it is said: each returns to its root yet remains unaware. In utter chaos, without knowledge or awareness, one never departs from the Dao throughout life. The moment knowledge and awareness arise, one strays from it.

The slightest discrimination is called "name"; likes and dislikes are called "emotion." Without inquiry, without scrutiny, there is no discrimination, no preference—this is non-action and spontaneity. Thus, all things fulfill their lives! Heaven bestows upon me the virtue of spontaneity, revealing to me the principle of wordless teaching. Turning inward to seek, I have already attained this Dao. Having obtained what is to be obtained, I bow in gratitude and depart.

Cloud General is one who dispenses rain and regulates yin and yang. Passing the branches of the whirling winds symbolizes entering the realm of activity, showing his desire to emerge and nourish all things. Hong Meng is primordial qi. "Leaping and roaming" describes movement in perfect ease. Primordial qi moves and rain is dispensed—this illustrates the transformative influence of a sagely ruler who leaves all things at peace. Cloud General wishes to harmonize the six qi to nurture all life, yet this inevitably involves intention, akin to the previous chapter’s notion of seizing Heaven and Earth and officiating yin and yang. Hong Meng responds with "knowing by not-knowing"—here the Dao is fully expressed. Cloud General, unable to comprehend, retreats, only to encounter Hong Meng again and pose further questions.

At first, Hong Meng tells him: seek not what you desire, nor where you are headed. Seek within yourself and you will be sufficient; there is no need to inquire of others afar. Roaming freely in the world, burdened yet self-content, one is thus able to perceive the true principle. Why then seek knowledge externally? These words clarify that despite instruction, Cloud General still fails to awaken. He then confesses his own recklessness and inability to abandon the people. Hong Meng admonishes his error, saying: You merely busy yourself with excessive words and deeds, disrupting the celestial constancy, opposing the principles of things, and corrupting the mysterious silence of Heaven. Thus, birds and beasts, grasses and trees, insects—all lose their proper place. This is the fault of governing people. "Poison" means to govern—how can one govern the world?

"Return and rest," he says, "ask no more." Yet Cloud General’s doubts remain unresolved, and he wishes to hear one final word. Hong Meng tells him: What you doubt is the heart-mind. Losing the nurturing of the heart-mind is to abandon the abode of spirit. Nurture it with non-action, and the spirit will be whole. With spirit whole, one is sufficient to transform all things. From "casting aside your form" to "silent and soulless"—this is the secret of heart-mind cultivation. At its utmost, even nurturing is forgotten. The myriad things drift like clouds, each returning to its root. Movement at its extreme inevitably stills—this is the principle of spontaneity. How can knowledge intervene? Simply abide in utter chaos, guard it and do not lose it. The moment knowledge sprouts, one strays from the Dao.

Inquiry into names and scrutiny of emotions belong to knowledge. If one can sever these, then all things will transform spontaneously—why strive to harmonize the six qi to nurture life? Cloud General then awakens: excessive words harm the Dao; silence is the virtue of descent. It lies in turning inward to seek within oneself. Thus, one who takes nourishing all things as their duty labors in vain, while one who entrusts the world to its own self-governance rests in effortless transformation. Nurturing the myriad things and harmonizing the world do not exceed the work of preserving spirit and nurturing the heart-mind. The spirit-like persons of antiquity, who ensured that creatures suffered no plagues and grains ripened in season, did so by this means.

The common people all delight in those who agree with them and despise those who differ. They desire agreement and reject difference because they harbor the ambition to stand out from the crowd. Yet how can one who harbors such ambition ever truly stand out? Relying on the crowd to secure what they have heard, they are no different from the masses in skill. Those who seek to govern others’ states grasp at the benefits of the Three Kings while blind to their perils—this is to gamble with others’ states. How often can one gamble and not lose the state? In preserving a state, success is less than one in ten thousand; in losing it, one failure brings ten thousand losses. How lamentable that those who possess lands do not understand!

Those who possess lands possess great things. Possessing great things, one must not be possessed by them. Being a thing yet not a thing, one can thus master all things. Understanding that the master of things is not a thing—how could this apply merely to governing the world and its people? Moving in and out of the six directions, roaming the nine provinces, coming and going alone—this is called "possessing alone." One who possesses alone is called most noble. The teaching of the great person is like the shadow following form, the echo responding to sound. When questioned, they respond, exhausting what is in their heart-mind, becoming the counterpart of Heaven and Earth.

Dwelling in noiselessness, moving without fixed direction. Leading you to the ceaseless flux of returning, roaming without bound; entering and exiting without side, sharing no beginning with the sun. Praising and discoursing on the form and body, merging with the Great Harmony—great harmony without self. Without self, how could one obtain what is called "having"? Those who weave the threads of having were the noble ones of old; those who perceive nothingness are friends of Heaven and Earth.

Guo’s Commentary: Those whose hearts desire to emerge from the crowd as mere stragglers all take standing out as their aim, which is why the multitude cannot surpass one another. When all take standing out as their aim, yet I alone go along without divergence, this is the greatest distinction from the crowd and becomes the master of the multitude. What I alone have heard is not as abundant as the many skills of the many. Thus, following the many brings tranquility; not following the many makes the thousands and ten thousands of the many all one’s adversaries. Those who wish to govern others’ lands do not follow the many in their self-governance but impose their own will—this is merely seeking the profit of the Three Kings in mastering things while failing to see the exhaustion of imposing one’s will. Did the Three Kings profit from such imposition? They simply followed the self-governance of all under Heaven! To monopolize all under Heaven with one’s own will—when all under Heaven is blocked, how can one’s self be open? Thus, one’s own person fails, and ten thousand losses follow. How lamentable that the lords who possess lands do not understand!

Those who possess great things cannot be used by things. To say one cannot employ things is to be a thing oneself, insufficient to possess great things. Those who employ things are not employed by things—this is not being a thing. Not being a thing, one can thus master all things under Heaven. Understanding that they act on their own without exhaustion. All people distinguish themselves, yet I alone wander in simplicity—this is called "going and coming alone," "possessing alone." Moreover, merging in profound unity with the many, not seeking recognition from the crowd, yet the crowd cannot but honor them—this is the highest nobility! If one clings to partial views, taking uniqueness as one’s aim, then even if aligned in one direction, one remains but a thing among the vulgar—no "possessor alone."

The hearts of the common people are form and sound; the teaching of the great person is shadow and echo. What heart does the great person hold toward all under Heaven? They allow each being to fully realize what is in their heart-mind. The questioner is the host; the responder is the counterpart. Dwelling in noiselessness, one awaits things in stillness; moving without fixed direction, one transforms with things. Lifting and guiding the ten thousand things, returning them to their self-moving nature—this is the perfection of non-action. Roaming without bound, one moves with transformation; entering and exiting without side, merging in profound unity without distinction, renewing with the sun. Thus, there is no beginning or end. Praising and discoursing on the great person’s form and bearing, they are no different from Heaven and Earth. With self, one cannot achieve Great Harmony. The difficulty of nothingness in all under Heaven lies in the self. Once the self is gone, what need is there to speak of having?

Those who perceive having were the noble ones of old, merely able to beautify their names. Those who perceive nothingness are friends of Heaven and Earth, allowing their solitary life to unfold. Lü’s Commentary: The non-action and spontaneity of the Dao is not only for the ruler to embody—those who assist the ruler with the Dao should also follow the many to attain tranquility, without meddling in governing others’ lands. What one person has heard is not as abundant as the many skills of the many. To insist on taking charge of others’ lands is to rely on luck to avoid loss. The rise of the Three Kings and the mutual support of ruler and minister were indeed based on this as profit, yet later ages often saw it as exhaustion. Those who wish to govern others’ lands grasp at its profit while failing to see its harm.

The Yellow Emperor’s question to Guangcheng and Yao’s meeting with the Four Masters all took mastery of great things as exhaustion, merely to clarify that those who master things are not things themselves. What I embody is the Dao; beyond the Dao, there is no thing—this is why it is called "possessing alone." The teaching of the great person is like form to shadow, sound to echo, yet does not take the lead in all under Heaven—this is how they become its counterpart. Dwelling in noiselessness, one remains serenely distinct from the self. Those who desire what aligns with the self and reject what differs from it take standing out from the crowd as their aim. Yet those who take standing out from the crowd as their aim—when have they ever truly stood out? Following the many to attain tranquility in what one has heard is not as abundant as the many skills of the many. Yet those who wish to govern others’ lands grasp at the profit of the Three Kings while failing to see its peril—this is relying on luck to govern others’ lands. How often can one rely on luck without losing others’ lands?

In preserving others’ lands, success is less than one in ten thousand; in losing them, one failure brings ten thousand losses. How lamentable that those who possess lands do not understand! Those who possess lands possess great things. Possessing great things, one must not be possessed by them. Being a thing yet not a thing, one can thus master all things. Understanding that the master of things is not a thing—how could this apply merely to governing the world and its people? Moving in and out of the six directions, roaming the nine provinces, coming and going alone—this is called "possessing alone." One who possesses alone is called most noble. The teaching of the great person is like the shadow following form, the echo responding to sound. When questioned, they respond, exhausting what is in their heart-mind, becoming the counterpart of Heaven and Earth.

Dwelling in noiselessness, moving without fixed direction. Leading you to the ceaseless flux of returning, roaming without bound; entering and exiting without side, sharing no beginning with the sun. Praising and discoursing on the form and body, merging with the Great Harmony—great harmony without self. Without self, how could one obtain what is called "having"? Those who weave the threads of having were the noble ones of old; those who perceive nothingness are friends of Heaven and Earth.

Guo’s Commentary: Those whose hearts desire to emerge from the crowd as mere stragglers all take standing out as their aim, which is why the multitude cannot surpass one another. When all take standing out as their aim, yet I alone go along without divergence, this is the greatest distinction from the crowd and becomes the master of the multitude.

My singular hearing cannot match the multitude of skills; thus, following the many brings tranquility, while defying them makes their thousands and tens of thousands all my adversaries. Those who seek to govern others’ lands do not rely on the people’s self-governance but impose their own will—this is merely chasing the profit of the Three Kings’ dominion without seeing the exhaustion of their own exertions. What the Three Kings profited from was not their own doing; they simply followed the self-governance of all under Heaven! To monopolize all under Heaven with one’s own will is to block its flow—how then can one’s own path remain open? Thus, the self remains unfulfilled while myriad things are lost. How lamentable! The lords of lands do not comprehend this.

Those who possess great things cannot be possessed by things. To say one cannot employ things is to be a thing oneself—unfit to possess great things. Those who employ things are not employed by things; thus, they are no longer things. Being no thing, they govern the things of all under Heaven, illuminating their self-governance without exhaustion.

People all distinguish themselves, yet I alone roam in simplicity—this is to come and go alone, to possess this solitude alone. Yet by merging with the profound sameness of the many, not seeking to impose upon them, the many cannot but esteem me—this is the highest esteem! If one clings to partial views, taking singular distinction as one’s aim, then even if aligned with a single purpose, one remains but a thing among the vulgar—not one who possesses solitude. The hearts of the common people are forms and sounds; the teachings of the great are echoes and shadows. What intent does the great one hold toward all under Heaven? Only to let each being’s aspirations fully unfold. The questioner is the host; the respondent, the counterpart. Abiding in soundlessness, one silently awaits things; moving without fixed direction, one follows their transformations. Lifting and guiding the myriad things to return to their self-moving nature—this is the perfection of non-action. Roaming without bound, one merges with transformation; entering and exiting without side, one attains profound sameness without distinction, ever renewing with the sun. Thus, there is no beginning or end. Praising and discoursing on the great one’s form and bearing finds no difference from Heaven and Earth. With a self, one cannot attain Great Harmony. The difficulty of all under Heaven lies in the self; once the self is dissolved, what need remains to possess possession?

Those who perceive having were the noble ones of old, merely embellishing their names; those who perceive nothingness are friends of Heaven and Earth, allowing their solitary life to unfold.

Lü’s Commentary: The Dao’s non-action and spontaneity are not only for the ruler to embody—even those who assist rulers with the Dao must follow the many to attain tranquility, without presuming to govern others’ lands. One person’s hearing cannot match the multitude of the many’s skills, yet to take it upon oneself to govern others’ lands is to risk losing all but by sheer luck. The rise of the Three Kings and the mutual accord of ruler and minister were indeed based on this profit, but later ages often saw it as exhaustion. Those who seek to govern others’ lands grasp at its profit without seeing its exhaustion.

The Yellow Emperor’s inquiry of Guangcheng and Yao’s meeting with the Four Masters all took great things as exhaustion, merely to clarify that those who govern things are not things themselves. What I embody is the Dao; beyond the Dao, there are no things—thus, I call it solitary possession. The great one’s teachings are like forms and sounds to echoes and shadows, not preceding all under Heaven—this is how they become its counterpart. Abiding in soundlessness, one silently faces the many’s thousands and hundreds as adversaries—how can one person’s hearing surpass theirs? This is why it cannot match the many’s multitude of skills!

When Yunjiang raved and the people followed wherever he went, all took standing out as distinction—until disaster befell birds and beasts, calamity reached insects. Was this not grasping the Three Kings’ profit without seeing their exhaustion? All that have appearance, image, sound, or color are things—how can things differ from one another? Thus, to illuminate that those who govern things are not things is to realize that the five viscera are not things. When the heart is not a thing, it can govern things; governing things is not merely governing things but also preserving the great thing, riding clouds and driving dragons, entering and exiting the Six Directions, coming and going alone. Those who possess great things cannot be without them. Not being a thing means not possessing them. If I can be no thing, and what enables me to be no thing is itself not a thing, who then harbors the intent to stand out? Not standing out from the many is truly standing out. When the heart does not stand out from the many, it does not possess its possession, and in truth returns to solitary possession; it does not esteem its esteem, and in name returns to the highest esteem. This is what Laozi meant by "not dwelling, not departing, without self yet accomplishing self."

The shadow has no sentiment toward the form, yet when the form stands, the shadow appears; the echo has no sentiment toward the sound, yet when the sound arrives, the echo responds. Its appearance—crooked or straight—lies not in itself but in the form; its response—clear or muddy, great or small—lies not in itself but in the sound. The great one’s teachings are like this: when questioned, they respond, fully expressing their thoughts without confusing the foolish. They serve as the counterpart to all under Heaven, not its master. Abiding in soundlessness, their silence suffices to respond to things; moving without fixed direction, their action suffices to encompass things. The ceaseless flux of returning is akin to observing the unconstrained with ease. Roaming without bound is akin to wandering through the beginning and end of things.

Form is the substance of life; the body, a distinction of form. Praise delights in life; discourse investigates its root. Merging with Great Harmony, Heaven and Earth are born together, the myriad things become one—how could there be the burden of a self? Bi Xu’s Commentary: The great one is the general name for the sage. The great one, through the Dao of self-governance, lifts and guides the myriad kinds, moving in accord with their nature and returning to their source. The Dao has no beginning or end, ever renewing without oldness. Praising the great one’s bearing finds it merging with the Dao. When the self is obscured, things are concealed; self and things are both forgotten—how could there be possession?

The noble person of humanity has yet to forget form; only one who forgets the self can transform things. Fu Zhai observes: Desiring others to be the same as oneself and disliking difference is to place oneself above the multitude. Insisting that all must conform to what one has heard before one can be at ease—though one seeks to stand out, one does not surpass the crowd. To claim unique insight, one must first ensure that none among the multitude knows. If one demands that all be the same as oneself, then one’s skills are no greater than those of the multitude. Seeking to govern another’s state in this manner is to seize the gains of the Three Kings while ignoring the harm that follows—like relying on luck to rule, seeing only ruin and never success. Those who hold states do not know their people and are thus deluded by such men. This is a clear rebuke of the itinerant persuaders of the time.

One who objectifies things has intent and exertion; one who does not objectify acts through non-action and spontaneity. Through non-action, nothing is left undone—thus it is called "not objectifying," and thus one can objectify all things. If one knows that objectifying things is itself not objectifying, then how could governing the world be the limit? Moving in and out of the Six Directions, roaming the Nine Provinces—this speaks of the Dao transcending the bounds of the myriad things. Operating freely within the workings of creation, one becomes one with Heaven, beyond human division. Thus, to come and go alone is called "possessing alone," and in this, one attains the highest nobility. The "great one" is precisely such a person of solitary possession.

Form must cast a shadow; sound must evoke an echo—this is the principle of nature. When questioned, I pour forth all that is in my heart in response. Facing the world thus, one’s single self bears the weight of all under Heaven. I am the host; the response is the guest—without echo, without sound, without scent, without direction, without advance.

*Naonao* describes the ceaseless flux of things. To lift and guide all the people of the world into this ceaseless flux is to act within the world without being apart from it—thus, the worldly and the transcendent are not two separate laws. Without beginning, without periphery—both are boundless. If one cannot see the start, how can one know the end? Judging by the form of the body, within the space between Heaven and Earth, all share this same form. Since one is the same as the myriad things, there is no self—what, then, is there to possess?

The noble ones of old saw only what was present. Only when one befriends Heaven and Earth does one perceive the absence. The "noble ones of old" include all from Yao and Shun downward. To dislike difference and favor sameness, to value oneself and belittle others—this is the common sentiment of those who seek to stand out. If one rejoices when the multitude aligns with oneself, then one is no different from the multitude—how has one ever stood out? Seeking to govern another’s state in this way is to covet past gains while blind to future harm! How often does luck not lead to the ruin of another’s state? For every state preserved, ten thousand are lost—this is an extraordinary flourish of the brush.

Alas for those who hold land yet do not know! Land is a great thing, yet one who possesses it without attachment can thereby govern all things under Heaven. If one clings to it, one becomes a servant of things. If one can perceive that the one who objectifies things is not themselves an object, then how could governing the world be the limit? Moving in and out of the Six Directions, roaming the Nine Provinces—this is the meaning of riding clouds and driving dragons, journeying through the Four Seas. Thus, one comes and goes alone, with no equal among things, possessing the Dao alone—what could be more noble?

The great one’s teaching is like form and shadow, sound and echo—responding as soon as questioned, never opposing the people’s wishes. As a counterpart to all under Heaven, one does not presume to be the host but remains the guest. The response arises from resonance, not from seeking. Dwelling without echo (read as *xiang*), one is present everywhere. Moving without direction, one goes everywhere.

The phrase "lifting you to follow the ceaseless flux" is difficult to explicate, and various interpretations have not clarified it well. Carefully examining the text’s intent, it aligns with the *Daodejing*’s idea of "who can be still and gradually give life to movement." Thus, the great one’s teaching lies in movement that transforms things, roaming without beginning or periphery, ever renewing without end.

"Praise and discourse" is akin to discussion. Discussing the great one’s bearing, one finds it in harmony with Great Unity, no different from the Dao—this is the meaning of the *Daodejing*’s "the bearing of profound virtue follows only the Dao." Many interpretations fixate on the words "praise and discourse," leading to incoherence in what follows.

The great one has no self; with the self gone, what thing could remain? The noble person pursues learning, aspiring to the Dao, and thus cannot yet forget things—all they see is presence, like the butcher who, at first, sees only the ox. The noble ones of old were like this; the noble ones of today can be inferred. Thus, one longs to behold those who perceive absence and honor them. Perceiving absence, one abandons learning and attains the Dao, like the butcher who, after three years, no longer saw the whole ox.

Heaven and Earth are born from absence. To perceive what gives birth to Heaven and Earth is to befriend them—this is no exaggeration. As for one whose virtue accords with nature, whose Dao transcends form, who roams the Eight Extremes, moving between being and non-being—such a one can grasp Heaven and Earth, seize yin and yang. How could mere friendship with them suffice? Thus, Master Kangjie said: "Heaven and Earth emerge from me—what else is there to say?"

The character *xiang* (响, "echo") originally had no alternate reading, but here it seems discordant with the following text and should be read as *xiang* (向, "direction"). *Xiang* means "direction." In the *Yangsheng zhu* ("The Secret of Nurturing Life"), *xiao ran xiang ran* is read like *xiang* ("echo"); in the *Yingdiwang* ("The Lord of Responses"), *xiang ji qiang liang* is glossed by the old commentary as "like an echo, swift as the response to sound." Thus, the two characters were interchangeable in ancient times, and here the confusion with the earlier *xiang* ("echo") following *sheng* ("sound") is an error.

The thirty-second scroll of *The Ocean of Meanings in the True Scripture of Southern Florescence* concludes here. #1 In the *Imperial Digest* (vol. 364), *jué* (爵, "rank") is written as *què* (雀, "sparrow"), and the same applies below. #2 In Zhao the Remonstrator’s edition, both instances of *xī* (僖) are written as *xiān* (仙).

The thirty-third scroll of *The Ocean of Meanings in the True Scripture of Southern Florescence*
by Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin

**Chapter Four: "In Yu" (Nurturing That Which Is Within)**

That which is base yet cannot be left unassigned is *things*;
That which is lowly yet cannot be left unaccommodated is *the people*;
That which is hidden yet cannot be left undone is *affairs*;
That which is coarse yet cannot be left unpresented is *law*;
That which is distant yet cannot be left unoccupied is *righteousness*;
That which is intimate yet cannot be left unexpanded is *benevolence*;
That which is regulated yet cannot be left unaccumulated is *ritual*;
That which is centered yet cannot be left unexalted is *virtue*;
That which is singular yet cannot be left unchanged is *the Dao*;
That which is numinous yet cannot be left unenacted is *Heaven*.

Thus, the sage observes Heaven yet does not assist it,
accomplishes virtue yet is not burdened by it,
emerges from the Dao yet does not scheme,
unites with benevolence yet does not rely on it,
diminishes righteousness yet does not accumulate it,
responds to ritual yet does not taboo it,
engages with affairs yet does not decline them,
orders by law yet does not disorder it,
depends on the people yet does not belittle them,
and follows things yet does not abandon them.

Things are sufficient to be acted upon, yet they cannot be left unacted upon.
One who is not enlightened by Heaven is not pure in virtue;
one who is not permeated by the Dao has no means to proceed;
one who is not enlightened by the Dao—how lamentable!

What is the Dao?
There is the Dao of Heaven, and there is the Dao of Man.
That which is revered through non-action is the Dao of Heaven;
that which is burdened through action is the Dao of Man.
The ruler embodies the Dao of Heaven;
the minister embodies the Dao of Man.
The Dao of Heaven and the Dao of Man are vastly distant—this cannot be left unexamined.

Guo’s commentary states: If one follows their nature and assigns them accordingly, there is order; if one reverses their nature and imposes upon them, there is chaos. Assigning the base leads to honor; accommodating the lowly leads to esteem—this is the natural tally of things. Affairs are hidden in their own realm, and each acts on its own; they cannot be left undone, but one should merely follow and assign them. Law is the edge of wondrous affairs—how could one, on account of its coarseness, fail to present wondrous affairs? One must occupy it, for this is what makes it distant. Intimacy suffers from partiality, thus expansion is necessary. Ritual and regulation risk being bound to singularity; if one embodies them in each thing, they accumulate and become all-encompassing. That which is below affairs, though centered, is not virtue; that which is difficult in affairs, though singular, is not the Dao. Clinging to intent without acting, though numinous, is not great—how much less so for that which is not centered, not singular, not numinous! Thus, the sage follows their spontaneous action, naturally uniting with the exalted. Without scheming, it is singular—this is what makes it unchanging. Relying on duality prevents expansion. Following one’s nature to occupy the distant is not accumulation. Naturally responding to ritual is not due to taboo; engaging with affairs through ritual, each acts according to its capacity, responding to movement with movement, without refusal or deference. Governing the coarse with the wondrous thus avoids disorder. Depending on the people’s spontaneous action without belittling their use, following things to their proper task without abandoning their root—this is the way. As for acting, how could one act merely because it is sufficient to do so? One inherently embodies this action and cannot cease it. Without enlightenment, there is action, and with action, virtue is not pure. Unable to empty oneself to await things, affair after affair loses its harmony—this is the lamentable state of one unenlightened by the Dao. The Dao of Heaven assigns the spontaneous action of the myriad things; the Dao of Man is burdened by action, unable to follow its own attainment. Aligning with Heaven’s assignment of things according to their nature, residing above things and each fulfilling its proper role—the ruler practices non-action and delegates to the hundred officials, while the hundred officials each have their duties, and the ruler does not intervene. Both attain spontaneity through non-action, yet the ruler’s Dao is at ease while the minister’s Dao is toilsome—the disparity between ease and toil cannot be spoken of in the same breath.

Lu’s commentary: Man is noble and things are base; though base, they must be assigned and cannot be left unassigned. Thus, one follows things without abandoning them, for their baseness means they are not worth acting upon yet cannot be left unacted upon—their action merely assists their spontaneity. The ruler is exalted and the people are lowly; though lowly, they must be accommodated, for even Heaven’s seeing and hearing depend on them—thus, one depends on the people without belittling them. That which adapts to change is called *affairs*; without foreseeing what has not yet come to pass, one cannot know their hiddenness—thus, one engages with affairs without declining them. That which is established and employed is called *law*; law is not the wondrous Dao, yet the world takes it as its standard—thus, one orders by law without disorder. Benevolence is what the noble person embodies and practices; benevolence is near while righteousness is distant, yet without righteousness, benevolence cannot act alone. Though distant, it cannot be left unoccupied—thus, one diminishes righteousness without accumulating it. Benevolence originates in filial piety and fraternal duty; righteousness benefits things. Righteousness is distant while benevolence is intimate, yet intimacy is limited to father and son—even tigers and wolves share this, which is not the ultimate. Thus, one unites with benevolence without relying on it. Ritual takes regulating the people’s hearts as its affair, yet there is nothing it does not pass through—thus, it cannot be left unaccumulated. One responds to ritual without taboo. Virtue is what is shared by nature; one who is not enlightened by Heaven is not pure in it—thus, one accomplishes virtue without being burdened by it. There is nothing that is not the Dao; this is what makes it singular, yet without change, the myriad things’ responses are not complete—thus, one emerges from the Dao without scheming. Non-action is how Heaven is numinous; to have non-action is not the entirety of non-action—thus, one observes Heaven without assisting it.

The preceding discussion sought to abolish sagely wisdom, cast aside benevolence and righteousness, and with the ends of tally-symbols and measuring scales, desired to burn, break, sever, and obliterate them without remainder. Yet from the subtleties of the Dao of Heaven to the hidden coarseness of affairs and laws, none can be absent. Why is this?

The numinosity of Heaven lies in this: with a single warming breath, the myriad things flourish; with a single cooling exhalation, the myriad things wane—yet its way of completing things is one and the same. Such was the insight of Zhuangzi. What was said before describes the moment when a single exhalation leaves the myriad things empty; what is said now describes the moment when a single warming breath fills the myriad things. Both serve only to complete things. Is this not how one embodies the numinous and enters into Heaven?

The Dao is one and nothing more. If one is not enlightened by Heaven, one cannot achieve non-action and remains impure in virtue—how much less can those below humanity force themselves to it? The Dao encompasses both Heaven and humanity; if one does not penetrate it, neither non-action nor action has any basis, and if one does not penetrate it, how much less can one be enlightened by it? Non-action governs things; action is governed by things. The Way of Heaven is non-action, and thus it is revered; the Way of humanity is action, and thus it is burdened. Zhuangzi was no shallow dabbler in worldly affairs or one given to action, yet he spoke so earnestly of this—having observed the principles of Heaven and Earth and the effects of past and present, he knew that gains and losses invariably lay therein.

*Dubi’s Annotation:* Things are the basest of entities, yet one does not refuse to let them follow their nature because of their baseness. The people are the most humble, yet one does not reject their constant nature because of their humility. To refuse things their nature is to have no things; to reject the people’s nature is to have no people. Can the world do without people or things? If affairs are not undertaken, they decay and become difficult to revive; if they are not concealed, they become too manifest and harm the Dao. Laws that are not coarse remain unknown to the people; if they are not displayed, the age does not fear them.

Righteousness is a path—distant, yet one may wander upon it. Benevolence is a dwelling—near, yet one may reside within it. Yet righteousness cannot be uninhabited, for one cannot be without benevolence. If benevolence is not expansive, there is no way to broadly bestow and relieve the multitude; if it is not intimate, love lacks gradation. If ritual is not moderated, it becomes licentious and lawless; if righteousness is not accumulated, it remains thin and insubstantial. If virtue is not lofty, it cannot distinguish itself from the multitude; if one does not hit the mean, one cannot reach the same end as those who are sufficient. Unity pertains to number, the dispersion of the Dao; change is inexhaustible, the transformation of the Dao. If the Dao had no number, scholars could not exhaust it; if it did not change, all ages would suffer its ills. If Heaven were not numinous, its works would not be wondrous; if it did not act, things would not be completed. As *Mencius* says: "That which is done without anyone doing it"—this is it.

These ten principles follow the sequence from application to embodiment. The sage aligns with Heaven, thus observing Heaven’s spontaneity without assisting it. Virtue arises from nature, and thus one completes it without being burdened by it. Scheming refers to pointing at affairs and speaking of them—how could one respond to things by pointing at affairs? Meeting is the natural convergence of things. Reliance is when the heart depends on something. When one harmonizes with benevolence and unites with nature, there is nothing to rely upon. Righteousness is acting in accordance with principle. Taboo is speech that violates the heart. To be thin in righteousness yet not accumulate it is great righteousness. To respond to ritual without taboo is great ritual. When affairs are accomplished, one engages with them without refusal; when laws are established, one orders them without disorder. The people are the foundation of the state—one relies on them without轻视 them. Things are the resources of the nation—one employs them without discarding them.

This passage speaks of the sage’s sequence from embodying the Dao to putting it into practice, following nature and complying with it. Things arise from the Dao, and the Dao governs things. The sage acts for the Dao, not for things, yet things naturally attain their fulfillment—thus, nothing is worth doing, yet nothing can be left undone. As *Xunzi* says: "One who is precise about things manages things; one who is precise about the Dao encompasses all." The more one manages things, the more one should seek precision in the Dao and not be enslaved by things.

Those of old who spoke of the Dao first clarified Heaven, then followed with virtue and the Way. By understanding what lies in Heaven to seek what lies within oneself, one becomes pure in virtue. If one does not penetrate the Dao, there is nowhere one does not encounter obstruction. The great Dao disperses and gives rise to the division between Heaven and humanity. The ruler practices non-action and resides above—this is the Way of Heaven. The minister practices action and resides below—this is the Way of humanity. Heaven is natural; humanity is made to be so. There are those who are human yet not Heavenly, but there has never been one who is Heavenly yet not human.

*Xiang Dao’s Annotation:* There are things, then there are people; there are people, then there are affairs; there are affairs, then there are laws. Enacting laws lies in righteousness; enacting righteousness lies in benevolence. Ritual is what moderates and adorns righteousness. From this, one reaches the mean, and virtue cannot but be lofty; the Dao cannot but be unified; in the end, Heaven cannot but be acted upon numinously.

This is the progression from humanity to Heaven. When one proceeds from Heaven to humanity, virtue is naturally attained; the Dao is applied to things; the people possess things; things exist for the people. One who is not enlightened by Heaven is harmed by humanity and thus impure in virtue; one who does not penetrate the Dao is muddled by affairs and thus has no basis for action. If one is not enlightened by the Dao, how can one penetrate it? The root lies above, the branches below; the essential lies with the ruler, the details with the ministers. Thus, a skilled carpenter does not act upon the wood itself but acts in wielding the adze; a skilled charioteer does not act in arranging the steps but acts in grasping the reins. How then can a ruler share the same tasks as his subordinates? How can a minister share the same virtue as his superior?

The *Classic* says: "Observe words with the Dao, and the rulers of the world are rectified; observe abilities with the Dao, and the officials of the world are well-ordered." The ruler sits and discusses—this is speech; the minister rises and acts—this is ability. Herein lies the distinction between action and non-action.

*Bixu’s Annotation:* There are no worthless things—one cannot call them base and refuse to employ them.

Man discards not man—one cannot call them lowly and refuse to employ them. Affairs have their manifest and hidden aspects—one cannot call them concealed and refuse to act. Laws value timeliness—one cannot call them crude and refuse to set them forth. Righteousness requires judgment—one cannot call it near or far and refuse to apply it. Benevolence is boundless love—one cannot call it partial and refuse to extend it. Ritual can order chaos—one cannot call it restraint and refuse to accumulate it. Virtue has its high and low—one cannot call it middling and refuse to elevate it. The Dao’s emptiness and nothingness—one cannot call it clinging to the One and refuse to change. Heaven’s principle is natural—one cannot call it numinous and refuse to act.

Observe Heaven yet do not assist its arrival; follow things yet do not abandon them—this reiterates the preceding ten principles. How can one speak of external things as trifling and unworthy of action when the needs of the living cannot be left unmet? Those who are blind to Heaven’s principle cling to ritual and law, stagnate in the familiar, and lose themselves in things—such people have no path to follow.

To speak without auspiciousness is how one attains reverence; to accept service and remain below is how one belongs to others. The king models himself on Heaven’s non-action; ministers serve their lord through duty. The Way of Heaven and the way of man differ in labor and ease—if one fails to discern this and inverts them, disorder begins here.

*Yongzhai* says: This passage conveys the idea that the refined and the coarse cannot be separated. The Dao is noble, things are base—how can man abandon things? The Dao is exalted, the people are lowly—how can a ruler forsake the people? Clarity is the Dao; when applied to affairs, affairs become obscure—yet how can one entirely abandon worldly matters? Thus, they cannot be left undone. The Dao is subtle, laws are coarse—how can laws be entirely discarded? Thus, they cannot be left unproclaimed. Speech on righteousness may distance one from the Dao, yet how can righteousness be abandoned? Thus, it cannot be left unapplied. Benevolent love, though not the ultimate Dao, cannot be forsaken—thus, it cannot be left unextended. Ritual has its forms and restraints, seeming to force the world—thus, it cannot be left unaccumulated. Virtue is what all people possess, yet there are places where one must stand on one’s own; though one may harmonize with the world, one cannot fail to rise above it. The Dao is unity with the natural—yet there are places where change is necessary, so it cannot be left unchanged. The numinous is what cannot be known; Heaven’s actions are inherently unknowable, yet human affairs cannot be left unattended—thus, they cannot be left undone.

To "observe Heaven yet not assist" means no room for force. To "complete through virtue yet not be burdened" is to accumulate and thereby ascend. This speaks of having no deliberate intent—no scheming, no calculation. No reliance, no self-regard as though one’s kindness were meager or pressing. To "accumulate" is not to transform; not to accumulate is to transform. No concealment, no taboos. No yielding, no retreat—this conveys simplicity and directness. Though the people may be relied upon, they are not treated lightly; though things may be leaned upon, they are not clung to, nor does one abandon the root for the branches.

From the earlier lines on the base not being left unengaged to this point, all has been expounded—yet it returns to the idea that things are not worth acting upon yet cannot be left undone. Here, "things" refer to the refined as Dao and the coarse as things, encompassing all matters and phenomena. If one’s mind is aligned with the Dao, are these not all unworthy of action? Yet there are those that cannot be left undone—this is where the human heart resides.

Moreover, those who do not understand Heaven do not perfect their virtue. Though worldly affairs cannot be left undone, one must also know the principle of the natural. If one does not understand Heaven’s natural principle, one’s virtue remains impure, and failing to align with the Dao is to be blind to Heaven—thus, one encounters obstacles everywhere. To be revered through non-action is Heaven’s natural Way; to be burdened through action is the human way, which cannot be left unattended. The former pertains to the mind of Dao; the latter, to the human mind. "Burden" is akin to "danger."

The ruler embodies Heaven’s Way, governing with the mind of Dao. The minister embodies the human way, making the human mind obey. These terms—ruler and minister—refer to the lord and subject within the self. As in the *Qi Wu Lun*, they take turns as ruler and minister, yet the true lord remains. From "the lowly cannot be left unengaged" to the end of this passage, this is the great guiding principle of the *Zhuangzi*, akin to the *Tian Xia* chapter.

Su Dongpo said: Zhuangzi never disparaged Confucius—this is evident in the *Tian Xia* chapter. I say: Zhuangzi never failed to understand the principle that the refined and the coarse, the root and the branches, are one—this is evident in this passage. This section begins with engaging things and following the people, embodying the meaning of "valuing the lowly as the root" and "taking the low as the foundation of the high." Next, it addresses affairs, laws, righteousness, benevolence, ritual, and virtue—none of which can be left undone, for they are the guiding principles of governance, indispensable even for a day. Then it speaks of the Dao as the One that cannot be changed—once grasped, all is achieved, and control rests with oneself. The existence or loss of the preceding eight principles is inconsequential, yet their wondrous function transcends these eight categories. It concludes with Heaven as the numinous that cannot be acted upon, for all proceeds from the natural.

From "observe Heaven yet not assist," it reverses the order of the preceding ten principles to return to the people and things, clarifying the reason for those ten so that scholars may know what to rely upon and not drift without direction. Nothing is more refined than the Dao; nothing is coarser than things. Yet in the end, it raises the idea that things are not worth acting upon yet cannot be left undone—thus, how difficult it is for man to part with things! But if one can understand Heaven, align with the Dao, and perfect one’s virtue, one need not abandon things, for things will not become a burden.

*Guan Yinzi* said: The sage does not abandon things but abandons attachment. Only those who do not align with the Dao find everything a burden. The Dao is but one. Yet here it distinguishes between Heaven and man to clarify the division of ruler and minister, just as primordial qi divides into yin and yang.

The alternation of yin and yang, the mutual dependence of Heaven and man—these cannot be neglected in isolation. Yet when it is said that they are far apart, this is to distinguish them in speech, thereby admonishing those who would be ministers under Heaven. Who would claim that the *Nanhua*’s discourse is solely about purity and emptiness, with no bearing on the Way of governance?

The general purport of this chapter is that when the noble person has no choice but to assume rulership over the world, nothing is better than non-action. Thus, they hold the preservation of the people and the accommodation of the masses in their hearts, never deliberately setting their minds on governing. As a result, the people’s natures remain uncorrupted, their virtue unaltered; those who stand above them keep their joy and anger balanced, their rewards and punishments just. They thereby rely on the world’s self-governance, sparing themselves the toil of governance. Thus, the people readily comply, and the law is not obstructed.

Later rulers of the world, having lost the essential means to assist the age and nurture the people, devoted themselves solely to rewards and punishments. Above, they were entangled in the disputes of the Confucians, Mohists, Zengzi, and Shun; below, they imposed the constraints of cangues and pillories. As a result, those who governed were overwhelmed with labor, while the people knew not where to turn. Yet they still believed that benevolence, righteousness, sageliness, and wisdom sufficed to grasp the world’s true condition. They revered and cherished these virtues, passing them down through families and states, never realizing they were but tools to harass the people. This is why the *Nanhua* wished to cast them aside entirely.

If what is said here is true, then what the world entrusts itself to, what emerges from the profound and thunderous, lies in this: that state governance does not descend into vulgarity, that the people’s hearts do not rot. At ease in non-action, allowing the myriad things to be stirred and moved by their own breath—what leisure is there to govern the world?

Next, the question of Cui Qu is posed to elucidate the intent of Lao Dan, making clear that the fault of governance lies in ensnaring the people’s hearts. This is the origin of cangues and pillories, the very means by which Jie and Zhou wrought their harm. Thus, the Yellow Emperor inquired of Kongtong, who instructed him in the essentials of embracing the spirit, rectifying the form, and attaining long life through clarity and stillness. The body is the root; family and state come after. Never has there been a case where the body was well-ordered yet the state fell into chaos.

Were today’s rulers of the world to put into practice the words of Guangcheng, the governance of the Three Dynasties would not be difficult to restore. To take hold of Heaven and Earth, to oversee yin and yang—all lies within our non-action. This is the Way of *zai you*.

Hong Meng instructed Cloud General to cast off bodily attachments, dull his senses, guard the root without straying—this is the Way of cultivating the self. At the chapter’s end, it exhaustively examines the rituals and laws of rulers and ministers, arguing that the distinction between the Way of Heaven and the Way of man lies in the difference between action and non-action. Though they may seem unrelated, what arises in the heart and manifests in deeds is one and the same. It is only to illustrate the proper roles of ruler and minister, to rectify what each ought to do.

The *Highest* says: “The duke becomes king, the king becomes Heaven, Heaven becomes the Dao.”

*Collected Subtleties of the Meaning of the Nanhua True Scripture*, Scroll Thirty-Three—concluded.
*Collected Subtleties of the Meaning of the Nanhua True Scripture*, Scroll Thirty-Four.

The Daoist of Wulin, Chu Boxiu, expounds:

Heaven and Earth are supreme, yet their transformations are uniform;
The myriad things are numerous, yet their governance is one;
The multitudes of people are vast, yet their lord is the ruler.
The ruler originates in virtue and is perfected by Heaven.
Thus it is said: The ancient rulers of the world practiced non-action—this was simply the virtue of Heaven.

Viewing speech through the Dao, the rulers of the world are rectified;
Viewing distinctions through the Dao, the righteousness of ruler and minister is clarified;
Viewing abilities through the Dao, the offices of the world are well-governed;
Viewing all things through the Dao, the responses of the myriad things are complete.
Thus, that which penetrates Heaven and Earth is virtue;
That which courses through the myriad things is the Dao;
That which governs people above is affairs;
That which possesses skill is technique.
Technique is encompassed by affairs, affairs by righteousness, righteousness by virtue, virtue by the Dao, and the Dao by Heaven.

Thus it is said: The ancients who nurtured the world had no desires, yet the world was sufficient;
They practiced no action, yet the myriad things were transformed;
They were profound and still, and the hundred clans were settled.
The *Record* states: “Penetrate the One, and the myriad affairs are complete.”
Without intention, one attains it, and ghosts and spirits submit.

Guo Xiang’s commentary: Heaven and Earth are uniform in non-action and transform of themselves;
The myriad things are one in self-attainment and thus well-governed.
The world may have diverse intentions, but the one without intention is its master.
Taking virtue as the origin, nothing fails to attain its due.
Attaining without gratitude is how Heaven is perfected.
Non-action means following the movement of nature;
To be a ruler by nature is not perverse.
Each abiding in its proper place: non-action occupies the superior position, action the inferior;
Offices attain their capacities, and governance is achieved.
When the superior practices non-action, the world responds in kind;
The myriad things all attain their due, Heaven and Earth are in communication, the Dao is unobstructed,
The myriad things follow their courses, each person attends to their affairs,
And technique is what things do not employ.
The root and branches encompass one another like the arm embracing the hand;
When the body is harmonious, the hundred joints are all unobstructed;
When the Dao of Heaven is smooth, root and branch are both unimpeded.
When one person hangs down their sleeves in profound silence, the hundred clans are at peace, and houses may be sealed—
Thus, with one act of non-action, all principles are universally upheld.

Lü Huiqing’s commentary: Heaven and Earth are vast, their transformations endless, yet not by their own doing.
Uniformity admits no distinctions of great or small, beauty or ugliness, long or short—this is how transformation occurs.
The Dao generates the One and extends to the myriad things—how could governance arise from this?
Yet when each returns to its root without awareness, this is how governance is achieved.
Though the multitudes of people are vast, their lord is the ruler.
Originating in virtue, their transformations penetrate the uniformity of Heaven and Earth;
Perfected by Heaven, their governance reverts to the oneness of the myriad things.
These two are both called “mysterious.”
The ancient rulers of the world practiced non-action—this was simply the virtue of Heaven.
Thus, when the true ruler governs the world, could there be anything that does not transform?
Viewing speech through the Dao, there is never speech—speech that is no-speech—
Could the rulers of the world fail to be rectified?
Viewing distinctions through the Dao, non-action is for the ruler, action for the minister—
Could the righteousness of ruler and minister fail to be clarified?
Viewing abilities through the Dao, there is nothing one cannot or can do—
Could the offices of the world fail to be well-governed?
Viewing all things through the Dao, nothing is not the Dao—
Could the responses of the myriad things fail to be complete?
That by which Heaven and Earth are Heaven and Earth is simply this attainment.
When a person attains this, their virtue communicates with Heaven and Earth, and the myriad things are none other than oneself.
The Dao as a thing is like this: the great above employ it to govern people—this is merely affairs.
Those who possess skill—this is merely technique.
Technique is encompassed by affairs, affairs by righteousness, righteousness by virtue, virtue by the Dao, and the Dao by Heaven—how fitting!
Truly knowing that all are encompassed by Heaven,
How could one who nurtures the world dwell among technique, ability, affairs, or action?
Thus, that the world is sufficient, transformed, and the hundred clans settled lies within oneself.
To penetrate the One and attain this is because of the absence of intention.
The myriad affairs all issue from the One;
The numinosity of ghosts and spirits issues from one’s own heart.

Lin Yidu’s commentary: The myriad things are born of Heaven and Earth;
Humankind is the most numinous among them.
Heaven and Earth have not departed from form;
Humankind is the utmost of form, innumerable in its complexity—
Yet all take the Dao as their宗!
Their transformations are uniform, as the *Book of Changes* says: “It encompasses the transformations of Heaven and Earth without omission.”
Their governance is one, as the world’s movements are rectified by the One.
Their lord is the ruler—few are those whom the many take as their宗.
The ruler of humankind originates in virtue and is ultimately perfected by Heaven.
“Mysterious” is where numbers arise; Yang Xiong said the One generates the Three Powers.
The “mysterious ancient rulers” refer to those before the Three Sovereigns;
Non-action is how they accorded with the virtue of Heaven.
Above, they practiced non-action, issuing commands only to rectify those below;
Below, they practiced action, exhausting their efforts to serve those above.
Viewing their issued commands through the Dao, the rulers of the world are rectified.
To distinguish and regulate is called “distinction.”
To esteem goodness is called “righteousness.”
When the few rulers govern the many people, their noble and base, toil and ease are all distinguished and regulated—
Viewing this through the Dao, their righteousness is clarified.
Viewing abilities through the Dao, the offices of the world are well-governed,
As *Mencius* says: “The capable are in their posts.”
Viewing all things through the Dao, the responses of the myriad things are complete—
Different paths converge, a hundred thoughts reach the same end.
The Dao has root and branch: the root establishes the body, the branch clarifies its use.
Zhuangzi’s roaming beyond the realm is not an exaggeration of his words—
It is how the body is established.

When the four observations lead into roaming within the realm, this is not because his words are too base—it is how its use is made manifest.

That which penetrates and unites Heaven and Earth is called “virtue/power.”
That which circulates through the myriad things is called “Dao/Way.”
Those who govern people by following principle above engage in adaptive affairs;
Those who possess some skill do so merely as technique.
Technique is the branch of affairs, thus it is subsumed by affairs.
Affairs are the branch of righteousness, thus they are subsumed by righteousness.
As for virtue/power being subsumed by the Dao/Way, and the Dao/Way being subsumed by Heaven—
All are rooted in the mutual dependence of root and branch.
Thus, the ancients who nurtured the world reached down to technique and up to Heaven.
Though the world’s hundred clans and myriad things are exceedingly numerous and vast,
Enabling them to be self-sufficient, self-stabilizing, and self-transforming
Is rooted in the Heavenly Dao’s non-action alone.
Thus, the luminous suffices to complete all affairs, and the obscure suffices to subdue ghosts and spirits.

Chen Xiangdao’s annotation: Heaven and Earth, though vast, equalize their transformations through non-action;
The myriad things, though multitudinous, equalize their governance through self-attainment.
Then how could the means by which the ruler governs people and concludes affairs lie outside this?
The ruler originates from the center and cannot but be exalted;
Virtue/power is perfected in the numinous and cannot but be enacted—
Yet Heaven’s enactment is in truth never enacted.
Thus, the ancients who applied the Dao/Way to the world did so by entrusting it to its spontaneity alone.
The ruler’s use of the world is through speech;
The minister’s being used by the world is through ability.
The union of ruler and minister has its righteousness;
The interactions of the myriad things have their responses.
Yet without the Dao/Way, speech is not rectified;
Without the Dao/Way, ability is not governed;
Without the Dao/Way, distinctions are not clarified;
Without the Dao/Way, responses are not complete.
Thus, all that appears in the realm of action is nothing but the Dao/Way.
Skill has its limits;
Technique has its craft.
Technique is subsumed by affairs, yet righteousness resides therein—
Because affairs are subsumed by righteousness.
Righteousness is subsumed by virtue/power, yet the Dao/Way resides therein—
Because virtue/power is subsumed by the Dao/Way.
When one understands the mutual inclusion of root and branch, essence and coarse,
Then ladders and thatch, tiles and pebbles are nothing but the Dao/Way;
People and the myriad things are nothing but Heaven.
For those who dwell in the world, what else is there to seek?
One need only extend this to nurture them.
When emotions are without desire, actions are without contrivance,
And nature’s profound stillness—only the uncontrived mind can achieve this.
Thus, within the One, the ten thousand are never not encompassed;
In the multitude of the ten thousand, the One is never not returned to.
As the *Tradition* says: “One who knows the One knows all without exception;
One who does not know the One cannot know anything.”
This is why the sage embraces the One as the world’s model,
And why lords and kings attain the One as the world’s rectification—
How fitting that the uncontrived mind attains it, and ghosts and spirits submit!
Chen Bixu’s annotation: Heaven and Earth, without contrivance, equalize their transformations;
Each thing governs itself, thus all is unified.
Though the multitudes pursue diverse occupations,
Only the ruler practices non-action—
Originating in non-virtue/power,
Perfected in spontaneity.
Heavenly virtue/power is self-governance, yet a wondrous efficacy resides therein.
Viewing the world’s teachings through the Dao/Way of spontaneity,
Those who are clear, still, and non-active—
Their rulers are surely rectified.
Where offices and duties do not overstep—
The righteousness of ruler and minister is clarified.
Where abilities match their tasks—
Their offices are surely well-governed.
