Surveying the myriad things, all attain their proper responses—
Then all may be fully equipped.
The Dao/Way is empty and penetrating, ascending above;
Virtue/power is soft and compliant, descending below;
Righteousness flows and circulates through things;
Affairs respond and serve people;
Technique follows ability and responds to skill.
Thus, when technique is subsumed by affairs, there is governance;
When affairs are subsumed by righteousness, there is appropriateness;
When righteousness is subsumed by virtue/power, there is compliance;
When virtue/power is subsumed by the Dao/Way, there is penetration;
When the Dao/Way is subsumed by Heaven, it accords with spontaneity!
“Without desire, the world is sufficient”—these three phrases
Echo the *Daodejing*: “Without desire, the people are naturally simple;
Without action, the people are naturally transformed;
Favoring stillness, the people are naturally rectified.”
When these three are blended and penetrate the One Real,
Then affairs are all completed, and spirits all submit.
If the world’s movements are to be rectified by the One—
Its lord and ruler, though few, are the multitudes’ ancestral model.
The ruler presides over people and things, taking virtue/power as the root,
Yet ultimately perfecting it in Heaven.
The profound is where numbers originate—
Yang Xiong said: “From the One Profound, the Three Directions arise.”
The profound ancient rulers—those before the Three Sovereigns—
Practiced non-action, thus harmonizing with Heavenly virtue/power.
Above, they practiced non-action, only issuing commands to rectify those below;
Below, they acted with devotion, only exhausting their efforts to serve those above.
Viewing through the Dao/Way the words they issue as commands—
Then the world’s rulers are rectified.
To distinguish and regulate is called “distinction.”
To esteem goodness is called “righteousness.”
When the few rulers govern the many people, their noble and base, toil and ease are all distinguished and regulated—
Viewing this through the Dao/Way, their righteousness is clarified.
Viewing abilities through the Dao/Way, the offices of the world are well-governed,
As *Mencius* says: “The capable are in their posts.”
Viewing all things through the Dao/Way, the responses of the myriad things are complete—
Different paths converge, a hundred thoughts reach the same end.
The Dao/Way has root and branch: the root establishes the body, the branch clarifies its use.
Zhuangzi’s roaming beyond the realm is not an exaggeration of his words—
It is how the body is established.
When the four observations lead into roaming within the realm, this is not because his words are too base—
It is how its use is made manifest.
That which penetrates and unites Heaven and Earth is called “virtue/power.”
That which circulates through the myriad things is called “Dao/Way.”
Those who govern people by following principle above engage in adaptive affairs;
Those who possess some skill do so merely as technique.
Technique is the branch of affairs, thus it is subsumed by affairs.
Affairs are the branch of righteousness, thus they are subsumed by righteousness.
As for virtue/power being subsumed by the Dao/Way, and the Dao/Way being subsumed by Heaven—
All are rooted in the mutual dependence of root and branch.
Thus, the ancients who nurtured the world reached down to technique and up to Heaven.
Though the world’s hundred clans and myriad things are exceedingly numerous and vast,
Enabling them to be self-sufficient, self-stabilizing, and self-transforming
Is rooted in the Heavenly Dao’s non-action alone.

Thus, its luminosity suffices to complete the myriad affairs, and its profundity suffices to subdue ghosts and spirits.

Chen Xiangdao’s annotation: Heaven and Earth are supremely vast, yet their transformations are uniformly rooted in non-action; the myriad things are exceedingly numerous, yet their governance is uniformly rooted in self-attainment. How, then, could the means by which a ruler governs the people and concludes matters lie beyond this? The ruler originates from the center and cannot but be exalted; virtue is perfected in the numinous and cannot but be enacted—yet Heaven, in its actuality, has never acted. Thus, those of old who guided the world by the Dao/Way did so by entrusting it to its own spontaneity alone.

The ruler’s use of the world is through speech; the minister’s being used by the world is through ability. The union of ruler and minister has its righteousness; the interactions of the myriad things have their correspondences. Yet speech, without the Dao/Way, cannot be rectified; ability, without the Dao/Way, cannot be ordered; distinctions, without the Dao/Way, cannot be clarified; correspondences, without the Dao/Way, cannot be complete. Thus, all that appears in the realm of action is nothing but the Dao/Way.

Art has its limits; technique has its craft. Technique is subsumed by affairs, yet righteousness resides therein—because affairs are subsumed by righteousness. Righteousness is subsumed by virtue/power, yet the Dao/Way resides therein—because virtue/power is subsumed by the Dao/Way. When one discerns the mutual inclusion of root and branch, of essence and coarse manifestation, then ladders and straw, tiles and pebbles are nothing but the Dao/Way; humans and the myriad things are nothing but Heaven. For those who dwell in the world, what else is there to seek? One need only extend this principle to nurture them.

When emotions are without desire, conduct is without contrivance, and nature is profoundly still—only the one without a heart can achieve this. Thus, within the singular there is nothing that does not encompass the myriad, and in the multiplicity of the myriad there is nothing that does not return to the singular. As the *Tradition* says: "One who knows the One knows all things; one who does not know the One cannot know anything." This is why the sage embraces the One to serve as the world’s model, and why lords and kings attain the One to serve as the world’s standard. That the one without a heart gains it and ghosts and spirits submit is only fitting!

Chen Bixu’s annotation: Heaven and Earth are without a heart, and thus their transformations are uniform; each thing governs itself, and thus all are equal. Though the multitudes engage in diverse occupations, only the ruler practices non-action, originating from non-virtue and perfected in spontaneity. The virtue/power of Heaven is self-governance, wherein wondrous efficacy resides.

Viewing the world’s teachings through the Dao/Way of spontaneity: where there is clarity and stillness, non-action, the ruler is surely upright; where duties are not overstepped, the righteousness of ruler and minister is clear; where abilities are matched to tasks, the offices are surely well-ordered; where all things are surveyed and their uses obtained, the requisites may be considered complete.

The Dao/Way is emptiness and penetration, ascending above; virtue/power is softness and compliance, descending below; righteousness is flowing and circulating through things; affairs are responses and governance in service to people; technique is following ability in service to art. Thus, when technique is subsumed by affairs, there is governance; when affairs are subsumed by righteousness, there is harmony; when righteousness is subsumed by virtue/power, there is compliance; when virtue/power is subsumed by the Dao/Way, there is penetration; when the Dao/Way is subsumed by Heaven, there is union with spontaneity.

The three phrases—"without desire, the world is sufficient"—correspond to the *Daodejing*: "Without desire, the people return to simplicity; without action, the people transform themselves; favoring stillness, the people rectify themselves." When these three are blended and penetrate the One Real, then affairs are all completed, and spirits all submit.

Things suddenly and unconsciously flourish without awareness of their glory; when not manifest, they silently withdraw, shedding all traces. Lü’s annotation: The Dao/Way is so vast that the heart, if not restrained, cannot embody it. To embody the Dao/Way through non-action is to appear human yet be transcendent.

To love and benefit others by this is called "benevolence"; to attain unity by this is called "greatness." Conduct no different from the common, yet supremely magnanimous; possessing ten thousand differences, yet supremely abundant. The person who holds fast to virtue/power unites the One and completes the myriad, like the main cord in a net. When virtue/power is perfected, one stands without reliance; when the Dao/Way is within me, there is no response that is not complete. No thing can topple one—thus is one whole.

The ten matters by which the noble person restrains the heart are these: seeking within oneself to illumine the heart; embracing all great matters without exclusion—this is the effect of self-restraint. Flowing abundantly to the myriad things, circulating without cease—if thus, then hiding gold and pearls in mountains and abysses, one does not know the desirability of wealth and profit, nor the shame of early death. One does not monopolize the world’s benefits but stores them in the world alone. One does not regard ruling the world as a personal elevation; what benefits things is not oneself.

To be manifest is to be luminous; luminosity comes from virtue/power, not from position. Dwelling above, one embodies the virtue/power of emperors and kings; dwelling below, one embodies the Dao/Way of mysterious sages and unadorned kings. When the myriad things are complete within me, there is but one treasury. As things are born, they die; as they die, they are born—all are but the same form.

**Annotation on "Dwelling in Solitude":**
To refine the heart-mind is to dispel its desires and render it empty. Action belongs to humanity; non-action belongs to Heaven. Sun, moon, and stars revolve above; flying, walking, moving, and growing things intermingle below—yet their transformations arise without knowing how they transform, their achievements unfold without knowing how they achieve: this is non-action that acts. Speech is what the sage cannot avoid; this is non-action that speaks. Heaven is simply its spontaneity. Virtue is simply self-attainment. Love and benefit constitute benevolence; the capacity to harmonize constitutes greatness. One who is magnanimous can contain what cannot be stored; one who is abundant shares broadly in common. Holding fast to virtue without deviation establishes order; unity that can expand establishes virtue. Following the Dao/Way in action enables all affairs—this is called completeness. If nothing can thwart one’s resolve, then nothing is lost.

To comprehend these ten principles is to have a heart-mind that embraces all without limit, flowing abundantly with things, finding joy within. What can wealth, riches, honor, or rank move? Longevity or early death, success or failure—these are but secondary matters! Thus one does not regard worldly profit as possession, nor does one deem ruling the world as grandeur. If one takes this as manifest, then one is luminous; if not manifest, one remains naturally radiant day by day. The myriad things are a single treasury; life and death are but the same form—only then does one merge mysteriously with creation. None but those who embody the Dao/Way can attain this!

**Detailed Annotation on the Dao:**
When the myriad things are complete within me, to possess them without loss is to be abundant. When order dissolves, the eyes of the multitude grow confused; when virtue is lost, the conduct of the multitude strays. Thus following the Dao is called completeness; not allowing things to thwart one’s resolve is called wholeness. Veiling the heart-mind’s vastness is to grasp the great image. Flowing abundantly with the myriad things is to have the world come to you.

Those of old who brought the Dao/Way to the world did not advance by display, nor instruct by speech—they allowed others to attain it themselves. When superiors transform inferiors, there is no delight or bait to please; when inferiors delight in superiors, they do not come seeking favor. Hiding gold and pearls in mountains and abysses is not to burden the body with things; not calculating longevity or early death, success or failure, is not to sacrifice the Dao/Way for the self. The profit of an age is vast, yet one does not claim it as private; the power of the world is weighty, yet one does not regard it as personal elevation. Ultimately, the myriad things cannot differ from one, nor can life and death alter one—could any but the unburdened heart-mind achieve this?

**Blue Void’s Annotation:**
The opening phrase "The Master said" refers to Zhuangzi receiving the esoteric teachings of Chang Sanggong. The Dao is vast and flowing, filling the great void; only one whose numinous treasury is empty can contain it. Governing oneself to accord with nature, abiding in the center while speaking of far-reaching matters, one distances oneself from discouragement. Measuring life to engage with things, the heart-mind does not retreat. What others detest, I harbor no suspicion; harmonizing light and blending with the dust, one does not erect sharp edges. The ten thousand kinds flourish, together enriching the realm. Upholding utmost virtue as order, following utmost principle to establish well, aligning with true constancy without bias, and withdrawing from external appearances to preserve the inner—clarifying this to refine the heart-mind, then affairs are all encompassed, principles all contained, kindness flows abundantly, and things all attain their fulfillment!

Gold, pearls, and wealth are the roots of rest; longevity or early death, success or failure are inner afflictions; private gain and elevated status are emotional maladies. If the heart-mind is bound to any of these, then rest is incomplete.

**Yongzhai’s Explanation:**
To refine the heart-mind is to dispel its cognitive awareness. Action through spontaneity is called Heaven. What is attained in oneself is called virtue. Speaking of non-action means there is nothing to contain in speech. Differences are also harmonized—this is called harmonizing differences. Distinctions have traces. Things differ, yet I possess them all—this is called abundance. The virtue one holds has its own order—this is called discipline. Standing resolutely as if established is the completion of virtue. Following the Dao in action, nothing is incomplete; external things cannot move the heart-mind—then what is within me is whole. Comprehending these ten principles, all affairs are encompassed and return to my heart-mind. Thus the heart-mind’s greatness has no bounds, and it flows abundantly with the myriad things.

Hiding gold and pearls in mountains and abysses is to store wealth in the world. Not regarding longevity or early death, success or failure as honor or disgrace, not claiming the profit of an age as private—this is the principle of "when a man loses his bow, another gains it." Though one may rule the world, one does not consider oneself exalted; the imperial carriage is not one’s heart’s desire. The brightness within the breast illuminates heaven and earth—this is true manifestation, hence one does not regard ruling the world as manifest. Gathering the myriad things into one is called a single treasury. Life and death do not alter one—hence they are called the same form.

Heaven and earth do not themselves cover and support; what covers and supports is the Dao. The sage does not himself act or speak; what enables action and speech is the Dao. Vast and boundless! The Dao is present in all, yet without refining the heart-mind to emptiness, there is no way to contain it. Only when the chamber is empty does brightness arise.

The Dao of Heaven is non-action and spontaneity. If one can act through non-action, one accords with the Dao of Heaven. Speaking of non-action is self-attainment. Applying it externally is called transformation through love and benefit. Things differ, yet the seer is one—then what one possesses is great. Conduct that does not differ from things—what is this if not magnanimity? All affairs of the myriad things I possess—this can be called abundance! Holding virtue implies something grasped; when virtue is complete, it does not depend on grasping. It is through having order that one can establish. Following the Dao to great completeness, what can thwart one’s resolve? Truly understanding this principle, then the heart-mind suffices to conceal all affairs, moving together with things. The boundlessness of things is met with my own boundlessness—this is called becoming one with transformation, and thus one can transform others.

Ultimately, gold and pearls are useless when hidden in mountains and abysses; wealth, riches, and honor are all external things—then what can longevity or early death, success or failure, restrain? Could any but the unburdened heart-mind achieve this?

Not taking worldly profit as one’s private gain—this is forgetting profit. Not taking rulership of the world as one’s own glory—this is forgetting fame. Yet what truly shines forth lies in realizing that "the myriad things are a single storehouse, and death and life share the same form."

The myriad things being a single storehouse means no division of self and other; death and life sharing the same form means no burden of coming or going. Could this be the ultimate piercing of the heart-mind?

Master Guo takes "from what shines forth then clarity" as a phrase, and later interpretations largely follow this, though it seems disjointed from the following text. Master Wu Yinfan’s reading, which connects it to the subsequent passage, offers greater coherence. Here, we adopt his approach.

*End of Chapter Thirty-Four of the* Nan Hua Zhen Jing Yi Hai Zuan Wei *(Profound Gatherings of the Ocean of Meanings in the* True Scripture of Southern Florescence*).*
*Chapter Thirty-Five of the* Nan Hua Zhen Jing Yi Hai Zuan Wei *(Profound Gatherings of the Ocean of Meanings in the* True Scripture of Southern Florescence*).*
*By Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin*

**Heaven and Earth (Part Two)**

The Master said: The Dao dwells in profound stillness, its clarity flowing and pure. Without metal or stone, there would be no sound. Thus, metal and stone possess voice, yet without striking, they do not resound. Who could fix the bounds of the myriad things?

The person of royal virtue moves with simplicity and feels shame in entanglement with affairs, establishing the root and origin while knowing communion with the numinous. Thus, their virtue is vast, and their heart-mind’s emergence is shaped by things. Therefore, form does not arise without the Dao, and life does not become luminous without virtue. To preserve form and exhaust life, to establish virtue and illuminate the Dao—is this not the person of royal virtue?

Vast and boundless! Suddenly emerging, suddenly moving, and the myriad things follow—this is the person of royal virtue. Gazing into the obscure, listening to the soundless: within obscurity, alone they perceive dawn; within silence, alone they hear harmony. Profound beyond profundity, they yet give form to things; numinous beyond numinosity, they yet refine essence. Thus, in their encounter with the myriad things, they meet all demands with utter emptiness, galloping through time to grasp their abode, whether great or small, long or short, near or far.

**Guo’s Commentary:** Sound arises from stillness, illustrating how one who embodies the Dao responds only when moved by things. Moving with simplicity, they do not seek entanglement with affairs. Establishing the root, their knowledge does not resist; thus, their virtue grows ever vaster, and their heart-mind emerges shaped by things, not preceding them in initiative. Sudden and impetuous—both describe their effortless response. Thus, they preserve form and exhaust life, establish virtue and illuminate the Dao, attaining royal virtue.

If one’s numinous hearing clings not to stillness, then harmony is lost in opacity. Only by plumbing the source can one give things their form; only by reaching utmost compliance can one exhaust subtlety. Firm in this, I entrust all to that, and their demands are met of themselves. Unfettered, I let them be, meeting only their ultimate limit.

**Lü’s Commentary:** "Dwelling in profound stillness" speaks of its depth and immobility; "its clarity flowing and pure" speaks of its pervasiveness and lack of turbidity. Such is the Dao! If one deems it non-existent, metal and stone cannot sound without being struck; if one deems it existent, metal and stone do not sound without being struck. Who could fix the bounds of the myriad things?

Simplicity means no admixture; passing away means no place it does not reach. Communion with affairs brings clarity to things; knowing communion with the numinous leaves nothing unpervaded. Why seek entanglement with affairs? The root is the Dao; affairs are its branches. Establishing the root, one enfolds affairs, and affairs naturally flow. The heart-mind, not probed by things, remains quiescent—neither pursuing nor resisting, responding without hoarding.

For the ear to hear, the eye to see, the mouth to speak, the heart-mind to think—all are the Dao. Thus, form does not arise without the Dao; in daily use, one remains unaware unless one possesses it within. Thus, life does not become luminous without virtue; only by preserving form and exhausting life, establishing virtue and illuminating the Dao, does one grasp it within and wield the ancient to steer the present.

Suddenly emerging and moving, the myriad things follow—this is to conceal all schemes and never force plans. Though the Dao as a thing is invisible, it is the source of all seeing; though inaudible, it is the source of all hearing. Profound, it yet gives form to things—within it, there are things. Numinous, it yet refines essence—within it, there is essence. Meeting all demands with utter emptiness, it is the inexhaustible wealth of heaven’s storehouse. Galloping through time to grasp their abode, whether great or small, long or short, near or far, their allotment is never insufficient—this is what the *Book of Changes* calls "each rectifying its nature and destiny, preserving the great harmony."

**Yi Du’s Commentary:** "Dwelling in profound stillness" speaks of the utmost depth under heaven; "its clarity flowing and pure" speaks of the utmost refinement under heaven. This uses the profundity of water to illustrate the Dao. Without metal or stone, there would be no sound—yet this depends on striking. Thus, sound arises from stillness, and resonance follows striking. So deep as to be unfathomable, who could fix the bounds of the myriad things?

Moving with simplicity, one embraces the unhewn and proceeds, thus not entangled in affairs. Affairs are the branches of the Dao; the numinous is its root. Abandoning branches to establish the root, one’s virtue is vast. "Shaped by things" means responding without initiating. Form does not arise of itself—what gives it life is the Dao. Life does not become luminous of itself—what illuminates it is virtue. Preserving form to illuminate the Dao is to fulfill form; exhausting life to establish virtue is to fulfill one’s nature. Thus, in their emergence and movement, the myriad things follow—this is the person of royal virtue.

Gazing into the obscure, they alone perceive dawn; listening to the soundless, they alone hear harmony—this is the ultimate of the Dao. Thus, profound, they yet give form to things; numinous, they yet refine essence. In their encounter with things, they meet all demands with utter emptiness, galloping through time to grasp their abode—this is why the Dao is inexhaustible.

**Detailed Daoist Commentary:** The Dao, through clarity and stillness, possesses the numinous—it does not respond without stimulus. Metal and stone, through clarity and stillness, possess sound—they do not resound without being struck. In its response, the myriad transformations push one another without fixed direction; in its resonance, the five tones vary endlessly. Who could fix their bounds?

To master things is to lose oneself; to reject affairs is to lose things. The sage follows things without delighting in mastery, engages with affairs without daring to refuse—thus they attain stability and responsiveness. It is like wood containing fire: without drilling, it does not ignite; earth containing water: without digging, it does not flow. Yet the utility of water and fire pervades all under heaven precisely because they respond.

*Laozi* says: "Know the masculine, guard the feminine." When the heart extends outward, something probes it. The world does not understand this, toiling endlessly with things as if they were affairs—becoming a corpse of names, a storehouse of schemes, a burden of tasks, a master of knowledge. Such folly leads to disordering heaven’s principles, inverting the nature of things, and forgetting oneself. Is this not lamentable?

Preserving form and exhausting life is not the same as forgetting form and life; yet those who forget form and life begin with preservation and exhaustion. Establishing virtue and illuminating the Dao is not the same as forgetting virtue and the Dao; yet those who forget virtue and the Dao arise from establishment and illumination. Thus, one need not act to share in the people’s fortunes and misfortunes. Suddenly, impetuously, the myriad things follow.

In obscurity, they perceive dawn—not with the eyes, but with spirit. In silence, they hear harmony—not with the ears, but with *qi*. Deeper still, they enter and discern things, yet remain able to shape them without losing themselves. This aligns with the *Yijing*’s essence: "Entering the numinous to achieve utility." More numinous still, they emerge and commune with things, yet remain able to refine them without being burdened. This aligns with the *Yijing*’s principle: "Using to secure the self and exalt virtue."

Profound yet able to shape things, they meet all demands with utter emptiness. Numinous yet able to refine essence, they gallop through time to grasp their abode. *Bixu’s Commentary*: Water, which nearly embodies the Dao, rests in stillness like a deep pool; when it moves, it flows with clarity—like metal and stone, which do not resound without being struck. Things have their nature; seeking them accordingly is how they may be obtained. To remain in unadorned simplicity, to feel shame at engaging with affairs—this is the root of standing firm, of returning to the root and reviving the mandate.

To comprehend the numinous is to know constancy, which is called illumination. Virtue extends everywhere; thus, in movement, one touches the true essence, and things come to probe it. The Dao’s body gives birth to things; virtue’s function makes it manifest. Those who skillfully preserve form must be able to exhaust life’s principles; those who skillfully establish virtue must be able to grasp the Dao’s subtleties.

Thus, virtue and achievement spread boundlessly—their emergence is formless, their movement traceless. In obscurity, they perceive dawn and hear harmony. A jade long hidden in a dark chamber gleams with radiance at night; spirit inwardly fortified shines with auspicious light in stillness. To shape things and refine essence is to speak of the wondrous and indistinct, the profound and true. To meet all demands with utter emptiness is to practice non-action yet leave nothing undone. To gallop through time and grasp one’s abode is to reach the extreme of movement and return to stillness.

Great and small, long and short, near and far—all are unified by the Dao alone. *Yongzhai* says: Metal and stone can resound, for this is heaven’s nature; that humans strike them is also heaven’s mechanism. How can one know what is called heaven is not human, or what is human is not heaven? "Unadorned simplicity" means to proceed in plainness. To feel shame at engaging with affairs is to be capable yet not act. The "root" is the origin of things.

When the heart extends outward, it responds to things—this is like being probed. All that has form and life shares this Dao, yet without self-attainment, the Dao remains obscure. To say one does not know how to preserve one’s form to exhaust the principles of life’s beginning, or to establish one’s virtue to illuminate the Dao’s spontaneity—this is beyond the capacity of anyone but the sage.

Suddenly, impetuously, they emerge at the head of the myriad things, compelled to move so that all things follow—like saying the myriad things behold them. Perceiving dawn and hearing harmony are but self-perception and self-hearing. Deeper still, they respond to things, able to be refined or coarse. What resides within them is emptiness, so their response to things is without self. Thus, with utter emptiness, they supply all things’ demands; in timely emergence, they grasp their abode—this cannot be fixed with a single word.

Whether great or small, long or short, near or far, this is the meaning of timeliness. "Near and far" should be read together to complete the sense. The Dao’s depth, its clarity—this is heaven. That metal and stone have sound is also heaven; that they are moved is human; that they are struck to resound is also human. Heaven and human mutually depend, manifesting in things—this illustrates the person of royal virtue, who proceeds in plainness and feels shame at engaging with affairs, not because they cannot, but because they await the stimulus to respond.

To stand firm in the root is like metal and stone becoming instruments. To comprehend the numinous is like sound residing in being struck. Yet within the sound, the sounding essence abides—how vast is such virtue! The heart, probed by things, extends outward—this is the meaning of responding to stimulus and achieving communion.

Thus, to preserve this form is to exhaust life’s principles; to establish one’s virtue is to illuminate the Dao’s spontaneity. Skillfully nurturing what lies within, when they emerge and act, how could things not follow? As for perceiving dawn in obscurity and hearing harmony in silence, their seeing and hearing surpass what ordinary people can attain. Profound yet able to shape things, things do not depart from the Dao; numinous yet able to refine essence, essence does not leave the numinous.

With utter emptiness, they supply all demands—empty yet inexhaustible, moving yet ever-renewing. Galloping through time to grasp their abode is the meaning of "the farther one goes, the more one returns." The conclusion with "great and small, long and short, near and far" is a striking literary flourish, showing that nothing escapes this principle. "Near and far" should indeed be read together, as *Yongzhai* observed.

The Yellow Emperor roamed north of the Red Water, ascended the Kunlun heights and gazed south. Upon returning, he lost his dark pearl.

Having sent Knowledge to seek it, he could not obtain it; having sent Li Zhu to seek it, he could not obtain it; having sent Chi Gou to seek it, he could not obtain it. Only then did he send forth Vague-Image, and Vague-Image obtained it.

The Yellow Emperor exclaimed: "How extraordinary! Can Vague-Image alone obtain it?"

Guo’s commentary: This illustrates how one attains the true—it shows that the use of knowledge is insufficient to grasp the true. With keen hearing and sharp sight, with eloquence and disputation, one strays ever farther from the true. Those who attain the true do not rely on deliberate effort; in the state of Vague-Image, one is immediately one with the true.

Lü’s commentary: North of the Red Water lies the utmost extremity of the mysterious. The Kunlun heights are the highest in form. Gazing south is to turn toward brightness and observe. The pearl, as a thing, cannot be sought through knowledge, perception, or speech—thus all sought it in vain. Vague-Image is neither non-being nor being, neither entangled nor obscured; this is how the dark pearl is obtained.

Yi Du’s commentary: Gazing south and returning, one seeks to recover the root through brightness, yet loses one’s true nature. Sending Knowledge to seek it, the true nature recedes further; using keen hearing, sharp sight, and eloquent speech to seek it—none succeed. Only by departing from form, relinquishing knowledge, dimming keen hearing and sharp sight, and forgetting speech—what is called Vague-Image—can one attain the true nature.

Bi Xu’s commentary: When the heart stirs, the true water loses its reflection; when one yearns for the heights, the supreme principle becomes estranged. Eager to return to the root, the wondrous Dao is already lost! That which is not keen of hearing—knowledge cannot match it; that which is not sharp of sight—vision cannot equal it; that which is not eloquent—speech cannot accord with it. Vague-Image is the state of indistinctness: when a person is without mind, they merge with the Dao; when the Dao is without mind, it merges with the person—this is merely called "obtaining" it. The Yellow Emperor’s exclamation, "Can Vague-Image alone obtain it?" implies that in truth, nothing is obtained.

*Fuzhai Oral Teachings* states: This speaks of seeking the Dao—not through keen hearing, sharp sight, or speech. As the Buddhist sutras say: "To seek the great perfect enlightenment with a mind of thought and deliberation is like trying to burn Mount Sumeru with a firefly’s flame." The dark pearl symbolizes the Dao; Vague-Image is the state of no-mind. Those who seek the Dao in the world often rely on knowledge, keen hearing, sharp sight, and eloquence, thereby losing their original true nature. They do not realize that there exists a knowledge beyond knowledge, a seeing beyond sight, a speech beyond words—these alone enable one to know all, see all, and speak all. The pearl symbolizes the mind’s perfect clarity; the dark signifies the mind’s wondrous function. Only by nurturing it in obscurity can its use be inexhaustible. Now, turning toward brightness to seek it—this is why it is lost. The three who sought it in vain all did so with intent. As for Vague-Image, form is also absent—how much more so the mind? Thus the dark pearl is obtained, eliciting the Yellow Emperor’s astonishment.

This pearl, all possess it—radiant through past and present, illuminating heaven and earth. In stillness, it congeals; in motion, it scatters. When the mind’s abyss is stirred by dust, its light is obscured; when the sea of nature surges, its place is lost. The body cannot even illuminate itself—how can it illuminate others? The Yellow Emperor initially believed that keen hearing, sharp sight, and knowledge sufficed to obtain the pearl, not realizing they were thieves of the pearl. Only after sending Vague-Image did he obtain it, thereby urging people to cast aside keen hearing, sharp sight, and knowledge, and return to the profound clarity of the sea of nature—then the dark pearl will appear of itself without seeking.

The steadfast should enter here. Yao’s teacher was Xu You; Xu You’s teacher was Nie Que; Nie Que’s teacher was Wang Ni; Wang Ni’s teacher was Pi Yi. Yao asked Xu You: "Can Nie Que be entrusted with heaven? I would rely on Wang Ni to assess him." Xu You replied: "How perilous it is to burden the world! Nie Que’s nature is keen of hearing, sharp of sight, quick-witted, and surpasses others—yet he still receives heaven through man. He scrutinizes prohibitions against transgression but does not know the source of transgression."

Can he be matched with heaven? He rides upon man yet lacks heaven, founds himself upon the body yet diverges in form, exalts knowledge and races like wildfire, is driven by threads of affairs, ensnared by things, turns in all directions to elicit responses from them, and strives to meet every contingency. He transforms with things yet never attains constancy—how could he suffice to be matched with heaven?

Nevertheless, there are clans and there are ancestors; he may serve as a father to the multitude, yet cannot serve as the father of fathers to the multitude. Governance is the harbinger of chaos, the calamity of those who face north, the bane of those who face south.

To match him with heaven—being a Son of Heaven whose keen hearing and sharp sight surpass others—would compel people to strain after him, and employing knowledge to seek a return to spontaneity only deepens the error. Thus, the absence of transgression lies not in enforcing prohibitions but in relinquishing knowledge. Were he entrusted with the world, he would lead later generations to rely on knowledge and lose their authenticity.

To take the myriad things as one’s root is to unify all transformations and harmonize disparate forms—this is the proper course. Yet if later generations were to follow his example in controlling things, they would diverge from them. When the worthy occupy positions of precedence, knowledge and perception are exalted in their wake, spurring a frenzied race like wildfire. This gives rise to the inception of toil and service. Bound and constrained, they manipulate things, directing and mobilizing them to respond to the demands of superiors. Unable to forget goodness, they benefit others by meeting contingencies, yet in chasing after things, they find no inner fulfillment. Today they receive its virtue; tomorrow they bear its harm—never attaining constancy. How could this suffice to be matched with heaven?

There are clans and ancestors, meaning his deeds and kind may be emulated. A father to the multitude is but a trace; the father of fathers to the multitude is that by which the trace arises. Were he entrusted with the world, he would not merely be a ruler of governance but a harbinger of chaos. Jie and Zhou were not themselves capable of killing loyal ministers; rather, they relied on the periphery of sagely knowledge to bring about their ruin. By the same token, Tian Chengzi was not himself capable of usurping the state of Qi; rather, he exploited benevolence and righteousness to undermine it. Thus it is said: the calamity of those who face north, the bane of those who face south.

Nie Que’s nature surpasses others, yet he does not dismiss keen hearing or abandon knowledge to act only when unavoidable. In receiving heaven through man, he is not whole in heaven. He scrutinizes prohibitions against transgression yet does not know that transgression arises precisely from the act of prohibition. To deem this in accord with non-action and match him with heaven—how could it not result in elevating man at the expense of heaven?

Founding himself upon the body yet diverging in form, he cannot be without self. Exalting knowledge and racing like wildfire, he cannot relinquish knowledge. Thus he is enslaved by the world, entangled by things, and unable to free himself. Turning in all directions to elicit responses from things, he does not abide in stillness while the people remain unaware of where to turn. Striving to meet every contingency, he does not stand upon the root and origin, nor does his knowledge penetrate the numinous. Thus he transforms with things yet never attains constancy—how could he suffice to be matched with heaven?

Nevertheless, what emerges from non-action invariably begins with reduction. There are clans and ancestors, so he may serve as a father to the multitude, yet the one who reduces is not the source from which the father of the multitude arises—thus he cannot serve as the father of fathers. This is to say: the inability to be without knowledge is what divides Yao from Jie and marks the harbinger of governance and chaos. Thus, those who govern the state through knowledge bring about the calamity of those who face north and the bane of those who face south.

Nie Que’s keen hearing and capacious knowledge merely grasp the traces of the great Dao. In receiving heaven through man, he has strayed far from the spontaneity of nature. Transgression arises from keen hearing and sharp sight, and when knowledge is employed to prohibit it, transgression only proliferates and cannot be restrained. Founding himself upon the body yet diverging in form, he has not forgotten form. Exalting knowledge and racing like wildfire, he wearies the spirit in frantic pursuit. Driven by threads of affairs, he initiates toil and service. Ensnared by things, he employs knowledge to obstruct them. Turning in all directions to elicit responses, he makes things turn to him. Striving to meet every contingency, he responds to the suitability of things. Yet he has not merged with the transformations of creation, instead chasing after things and transforming with them—all of which departs from spontaneity. Knowledge is sometimes exhausted in exertion, sometimes in plumbing origins; bearing its virtue, he later inherits its harm—never attaining constancy. Though he strives to meet every contingency and transform with things, he does not know the root of the great Dao. Thus it is said: there are clans and ancestors, so he may serve as a father to the multitude, yet cannot serve as the father of fathers. The father of fathers is one who has an ancestor.

Attaining the truth of the Dao, there is no governance, no chaos. Acting through non-action, there is neither calamity nor bane. But if one pursues advancement and relies on sagely knowledge, one cannot escape becoming a calamity and a bane.

His governance is meticulous, and his people are deficient. Nie Que—he gnaws at things and leaves them incomplete. From "keen hearing and capacious knowledge" to "never attaining constancy" is the gnawing; from "the harbinger of governance and chaos" to "the bane of those who face south" is the incompleteness. Clan is that to which things return; ancestor is that from which they begin. Those who governed the people in antiquity never failed to employ keen hearing and capacious knowledge, yet their subtlety reached the point of divine martiality without killing—only then did they attain perfection. Now Nie Que merely possesses keen hearing and capacious knowledge—this is why he may serve as a father to the multitude yet cannot serve as the father of fathers.

Qian is the father of the myriad things—a father to the multitude. Great governance is the father of Qian—the father of fathers. A father to the multitude governs the world; the father of fathers embodies the world in truth. In freedom and ease, there is no governance, no chaos; in governance, chaos arises. Thus it is said: the harbinger of governance and chaos. Understanding this and facing north, one is no true minister—hence the calamity of those who face north. Understanding this and facing south, one is no true ruler—hence the bane of those who face south.

Relying on keen hearing and sharp sight brings little blessing; transgressing one’s nature brings much harm. To expect a response of pure whiteness with a heart of schemes and devices is to be far indeed—how could he be matched with heaven?

He, relying on the power of rulership, scorns the principles of heaven, exalts his own form, and hastens his intellect. He enacts laws to constrain things, surveys all affairs, responds to the myriad with the one, and pursues things without cease—how could this align with nature? Yet such unfolding has a beginning and an end!

When governance and teaching are strict and constricting, they cannot be wholly transcended. Such methods may quell crises and resolve disasters, yet they make it difficult to serve as a minister—this is what is meant by "governing the state through knowledge."

*Fuzhai notes: "Matching heaven" refers to ruling all under heaven.*

Keen hearing, sharp sight, quick wit, and agile responsiveness—these are his surpassing traits. He cultivates human affairs to correspond with heaven, thus it is said: "He receives prohibitions and transgresses as if clinging to the heart without transformation." Yet if one understands the source of transgressions, prohibitions become unnecessary.

Riding upon man without heaven, he knows *youwei* (action) but not *wuwei* (non-action). Confronting things with the self is called "rooting in the body yet differing in form." Exalting his knowledge and employing it urgently is like fire racing forth. Enslaved by trivial matters while forgetting the root is called "being driven by threads." Startled by things, he is constrained by affairs. Responding to every stimulus, he measures each by its own standard—thus swept away by things, he loses the constancy of his natural state and cannot stabilize his responses.

Though he may not match heaven, he still possesses worthy qualities. A clan gathers and honors its ancestors; the "father of the multitude" emerges from the many and may serve as their father, while the "father of fathers" stands yet a degree higher.

*Shuai* (to lead) refers to generalship—this man’s utility in the world may bring order or chaos. Whether as ruler or minister, both roles invite calamity.

This speaks of Nie Que’s keen hearing and sharp sight, his surpassing nature—discussing his talent without addressing his Dao. "Taking man to meet heaven" means striving through *youwei* to align with *wuwei*, discerning prohibitions and transgressions without understanding their source.

If entrusted with all under heaven, he would govern the people through the advance of *youwei*, causing the world to lose its natural nature. "Rooting in the body yet differing in form"—liver and gallbladder as distant as Chu and Yue. Exalting knowledge and racing like fire—his schemes hasten urgently. Driven by threads, he is enslaved by affairs; startled by things, he is hindered by them. Looking about, he responds to every stimulus, yet cannot forget the self. Adapting to the myriad circumstances, he still cannot forget things. If he merges with things, he is swept along by them; if he lacks constancy, he loses his original self. How could this suffice to match heaven?

Yet clans have ancestors—Nie Que’s learning also has its lineage and master. Though he once heard the Dao from those who dwelt in nests, he may serve as a "father of the multitude" but not as a "father of fathers." The "father of fathers" is what is called "mysterious and yet more mysterious." Precisely because he cannot be a "father of fathers," governing the world through *youwei* only brings chaos. Whether as ruler or minister, both roles inevitably invite disaster. Thus it is said: employing knowledge is insufficient to govern the world.

Nie Que was Xu You’s teacher, yet You would not permit him to "match heaven." Why? For "matching heaven" belongs to the study of outer kingship, while the four masters transmitted the Dao of inner sageliness. Outwardly, they served as teachers to emperors and kings; inwardly, they were "fathers of fathers." What need had they for all under heaven? Thus You did not praise Nie Que’s strengths but revealed his shortcomings, preventing him from aspiring like an ant and preserving his loftiness—this was the utmost respect for a teacher and the most earnest defense of the Dao! Scholars should seek this with their hearts.

*End of the Thirty-Fifth Scroll of the* Nan Hua Zhen Jing Yi Hai Zuan Wei.

**Thirty-Sixth Scroll of the** *Nan Hua Zhen Jing Yi Hai Zuan Wei*

*#1: The character "由" is a misprint; the correct character is "田."*

**Heaven and Earth (Part Three)**

Yao observed the land of Hua. The border guard of Hua said: "Ah! A sage! I beg to offer blessings to the sage." "May the sage live long." Yao declined. "May the sage grow rich." Yao declined. "May the sage have many sons." Yao declined.

The border guard said: "Longevity, wealth, and many sons—these are what all men desire. Why do you alone not desire them?"

Yao replied: "Many sons bring many fears; wealth brings many affairs; long life brings many humiliations. These three are not what nurture virtue, so I decline."

The border guard said: "At first, I took you for a sage! Now you are merely a gentleman. Heaven generates the myriad people and must assign them duties. If you have many sons and assign them duties, what fear remains? If you are rich and distribute it among others, what affairs remain?"

"The sage dwells like a quail and eats like a bird, moving like a crow without leaving traces. When the world follows the Dao, he flourishes with all things; when the world loses the Dao, he cultivates virtue and withdraws into seclusion. After a thousand years, weary of the world, he departs and ascends in weariness, riding those white clouds to reach the imperial homeland. The three calamities never arrive, and his person remains free from harm—what humiliation could there be?"

The border guard departed. Yao followed him and said: "May I ask a question?"

The border guard replied: "Withdraw!"

**Guo’s Commentary:**
"Having many sons and assigning them duties ensures all things find their place and minds are at peace. Distributing wealth and entrusting it to others, the world thus remains free from affairs. Dwelling like a quail, one seeks no settled comfort; eating like a bird, one relies on things to be sufficient, acting in accord with one’s nature, not following fixed paths. Flourishing with all things, one may wander wildly yet tread the great way. Cultivating virtue and withdrawing into seclusion, even the deeds of Tang and Wu—responding to heaven and following the people—are not without their intervals. Thus, when life reaches its utmost length, one endures the changes of prosperity and adversity, living by the heavenly course and dying by the transformation of things. Weary of the world and ascending in transmission, riding clouds to the imperial homeland, the dispersal of a single breath reaches everywhere. The three breaths never arrive—what humiliation could there be?"

**Lü’s Commentary:**
"The sage exhausts the heavenly Dao, thus embodying transformation without being burdened by things. The gentleman exhausts the human Dao, thus sharing fortune and misfortune with the people. Though longevity, wealth, and many sons are what men desire, he cannot but decline them as bringing many affairs, many fears, and many humiliations. Yao did not fail to exhaust the heavenly Dao; what he shared with others was merely exhausting the human Dao. Dwelling like a quail, he knew not where he abided; eating like a bird, he knew not whence it came. Moving like a crow without pattern, his traces were unseen. The teachings of spirit transmission—seeking it in dietary practices and breath control—are dismissed by worldly scholars as madness and not believed, but this is wrong. For one born embracing the spirit, even in death, one must embrace the spirit and not forget; born preserving heaven, even in death, one must preserve heaven and not fall. The *Book of Songs* and *Book of Documents* both speak of being in heaven—why then doubt ascending in transmission?"

**Yu Du’s Commentary:**
"The border guard of Hua, a keeper of its frontiers, offered blessings to the sage, wishing him longevity, wealth, and many sons, but Yao declined them all. He replied that many sons would enslave him to their burdens and bring many fears; wealth would enslave him to possessions and bring many affairs; long life would enslave him to existence and bring many humiliations. These three are insufficient to nurture the virtue of non-action and are merely the burdens of having life. The border guard said: 'At first, I took Yao for one who embodied the Dao as a sage, but now, tending toward nothingness, he is merely a worthy gentleman. If he has many sons and assigns them duties, what fear remains? If he is rich and distributes it among others, what affairs remain? Dwelling like a quail without fixed abode, eating like a bird relying on things to be sufficient, moving like a crow without pattern—all speak of his absence of intent. Flourishing with all things, he brings goodness to the whole world; cultivating virtue and withdrawing into seclusion, he perfects goodness in himself. Living to a thousand years, weary of the world and ascending in transmission—how could the three breaths ever arrive?'"

**Bi Xu’s Commentary:**
"Having many sons and assigning them duties lets each govern themselves; being rich and distributing it among others is like hiding gold and pearls in mountains and abysses. Dwelling like a quail without building nests, eating like a bird without seeking satiety, moving like a crow without lingering—flourishing with all things, he seizes the moment to act. Cultivating virtue and withdrawing into seclusion, he maintains feminine stillness and self-guard. Shedding the dust of years, he treads the light and rides the void. White clouds symbolize the radiance of the Dao; the imperial homeland is the true realm. The blessings the border guard offered are what the world values, but Yao, unconfused, declined them. Following and asking again, the border guard said: 'Withdraw!'—perhaps hinting at the profound meaning of forgetting the self. Master Yongzhai said: 'Wealth, longevity, and many sons are what men desire, but those who study the Dao consider them unworthy of concern. Heaven generates the myriad people and must assign them duties—this means that upon birth, one has clothing and food. Distributing wealth means entrusting it to others. Dwelling like a quail without fixed abode, eating like a bird without seeking it, flying like a crow without leaving traces—all speak of absence of intent. Flourishing with all things, each attains its life. Cultivating virtue and withdrawing into seclusion means hiding when the Dao is absent. Weary of the world and ascending in transmission conveys the meaning of liberation. White clouds and the imperial homeland are the heights of emptiness and nothingness. The three calamities refer to youth, maturity, and old age, like the analogy of the *Śūraṅgama Sūtra*’s river of sorrow. Yao still wished to ask, but the border guard did not answer, only saying: 'Withdraw!'"

Jie Yu hastened to avoid him, and the Old Man with the Woven Bamboo Staff departed upon arrival—both exemplify this same principle.

How great indeed was Yao as a ruler! His benevolence shone forth, his righteousness stood firm, his virtue was vast, and his transformative influence was boundless. Once the world was well-ordered, he roamed and observed the splendor of Hua. That border guard, too, had concealed himself in reclusion to delight in Yao’s Dao, thrice blessing the sage and offering the world’s supreme beauty in tribute, believing the Dao could be preserved in silence. Yet Yao consistently declined, knowing this was no way to nurture virtue. The border guard pressed further, deeming the Dao an excrescence—until he witnessed Yao’s nine sons and two daughters serving Shun in the fields, possessing the Four Seas yet not claiming them, living to one hundred and eighteen before passing away. How towering and boundless, transcending the three breaths of mortal life! The border guard’s discourse aligned with Yao’s advancement, making him, too, a follower of Yao. Yet how could his governance—peerless as heaven, divine as spirits, radiant as the sun, vast as clouds—ever be fathomed by a border guard?

"Without display" likely means "without adornment," referring to outward traces. When Yao ruled the world, Bo Cheng Zi Gao was established as a feudal lord. When Yao ceded to Shun, and Shun to Yu, Bo Cheng Zi Gao resigned his lordship to till the soil. Yu went to see him and found him plowing in the wilds. Yu hastened to stand downwind and asked, "In the past, when Yao ruled the world, you served as a feudal lord. When Yao ceded to Shun, and Shun to me, you resigned your lordship to plow—what is the reason?" Zi Gao replied, "In the past, when Yao ruled the world, he did not reward yet the people were encouraged; he did not punish yet the people stood in awe. Now you reward and punish, yet the people grow unkind. Virtue has declined from this, punishments have been established from this, and the disorders of later ages begin from this. Sir, why do you not depart? Do not hinder my work." He bent low to plow, paying no further heed.

Guo’s commentary: In Yu’s time, three sages succeeded one another, governance was perfected, and virtue was complete. Yet as merit and beauty gradually receded, historical records had little to record. Even Confucius could not hear of it, which is why, though possessing the world, Yu did not cling to it—this was having yet not having. Thus, judging by the era, Yu was the most excellent; assessing the men, though three sages, they were fundamentally one with Yao. As no sage appeared in the times, the world’s heart suddenly turned to Qi. The supremely impartial, occupying their rightful place, entrusted the world to the people. Taking and giving were not their own, so they neither sought what was lost nor declined what was gained. They took it in an instant, received it with compassion—thus, though reviled by the reclusive scholars of Kangjie and ranked among the Three Kings, it is no wonder.

Zhuangzi used this to illustrate how corruption arose under Yao and took form under Yu—how much more so in later ages without sages? He entrusted this distant message to Zi Gao, causing him to abandon governance and return to the soil, aiming to abolish sagacity and return to unity, to discard knowledge and attain tranquility. Yet in truth, he had not heard of it.

Zhuangzi’s words cannot be confined to a single interpretation. Some take the Yellow Emperor’s advancement as surpassing Yao and Shun’s governance—was he merely exalting Yao while disparaging Yu? Thus, one should set aside his allusions and focus on his intent to abolish sagacity and discard knowledge.

Lü’s commentary: The ancients praised Yu as the Divine Yu. If his virtue reached the divine, then compared to Yao and Shun, there should be no gap—so "not rewarding yet the people were encouraged, not punishing yet the people stood in awe." That "rewarding and punishing yet the people grow unkind" was merely a matter of the times. Those who spoke thus aimed to show that governing the world with virtue renders rewards and punishments truly unavoidable.

Yi Du’s commentary: Bo Cheng Zi Gao served as a feudal lord under Yao, but under Yu, he retired to plow in the wilds. This is because Yao governed the world with non-action, so the people did not require rewards or punishments to be encouraged or awed. Now, with Yu employing rewards and punishments, the people grow unkind, virtue declines, punishments are established, and the disorders of later ages begin from this. "Sir, why do you not depart? Do not hinder my farming." He exerted himself in plowing, no longer turning back.

Xiang Dao’s commentary: The people of remote antiquity were sincere yet unaware of their loyalty, proper yet unaware of their trustworthiness. They did good without seeking fame, unaware of any encouragement; they did evil without fearing punishment, unaware of any deterrence. Though Yao did not reward or punish, the people were encouraged and awed—yet compared to those unaware of encouragement or awe, this was already a decline. How much worse to reward to encourage and punish to deter! This is why virtue declined and punishments were established.

In truth, Yao did not entirely lack rewards or punishments. Rewarding one person delighted the world—that is skillful rewarding. Punishing one person subdued the world—that is skillful punishing. Few rewards and punishments, yet widespread delight and submission—this can be called not rewarding and not punishing. Hua Feng held Yao to the standard of a sage, while Zi Gao held Yu to Yao’s standard. Yu’s view of Yao was profound, but Yao’s view of the sage was profound beyond profound.

Bi Xu’s commentary: Yao, Shun, and Yu’s governance of the world was like the Dao, virtue, and the sevenfold benefiting all people—their benefits were vast and broad. Yet Bo Cheng Zi Gao’s discourse was lofty, his will unyielding to convention, his integrity unbending. Truly, he was the teacher of kings! Having spoken, he returned to plowing, bending low without a backward glance, embodying the intent to prioritize agriculture, honor fundamentals, return to simplicity, and revert to purity.

Yongzhai’s note: This shows how the world declined further in Yu’s time, already falling short of Yao and Shun. "Do not hinder my work" means "do not disrupt my plowing." *Lülü* describes the posture of bending low to plow. Yao did not reward or punish, yet now, with rewards and punishments, the people grow unkind—this emphasizes that rewards and punishments are inferior to their absence, akin to the intent of the *Yi*’s "no litigation." It borrows the Three Sages to make this point.

The above passage’s purport is clear, and the various commentaries are thorough—no further elaboration is needed.

In the Great Beginning, there was Nonbeing—Nonbeing without name. From Unity’s arising, there was Unity yet no form. When things obtained it to come into being, it was called virtue...

Before form arose, there was distinction—yet this distinction remained seamless, and this was called *ming* (destiny). When the abiding and the moving gave birth to things, and things attained their principles of life, this was called *xing* (form). When form and body preserved spirit, each possessing its own patterns and norms, this was called *xing* (nature). Cultivating nature returns one to virtue; when virtue reaches its fullness, it merges with the beginning. This merging is emptiness; emptiness is vastness. Voices harmonize in spontaneous utterance; when voices harmonize, they unite with Heaven and Earth. Their union is seamless, appearing foolish or dull—this is called *xuande* (mysterious virtue), merging with the Great Compliance.

Guo’s commentary: "Nonbeing" means there was nothing to name. "Unity" is the beginning of Being, supremely subtle yet without the form of material principles. That from which Unity arises arises from the utmost Unity—not from Nonbeing. *Zhuangzi* repeatedly speaks of "the beginning" because what has not yet been born attains birth, and this attainment of birth is difficult. Yet it neither relies on Nonbeing above nor depends on knowledge below, suddenly and spontaneously attaining this birth. Why then seek life after birth and lose the spontaneity of one’s own birth? Nonbeing cannot generate things, yet it is said that "things obtain it to come into being"—this clarifies that the birth of things is self-attained, and this may be called virtue. Virtue, form, nature, and destiny are named according to their transformations, yet in their self-so-ness they are one. Cultivating nature to return to virtue means attaining it spontaneously without contrivance. If one differs from the beginning by acting in the middle way, then one harbors something within, and with something harbored, the virtue of nurturing it is diminished. To speak without intention yet utter spontaneously is to harmonize with spontaneous utterance. When voices harmonize, they unite with Heaven and Earth. Heaven and Earth also act without intention, and their union is seamless—sitting in forgetfulness, they unite spontaneously, not through deliberate alignment. This is called *xuande*. When virtue is mysterious, what it complies with is vast.

Lü’s commentary: Without Nonbeing, even Unity cannot be attained. Without name, there is that from which Unity arises, yet no form—this is the beginning of Heaven and Earth. Having already called it Unity, how can it be without name? That things obtain it to come into being is called virtue—this is the mother of the myriad things. Before completion, there was distinction, yet this distinction remained seamless, and this was called *ming*. *Ming* is without gap from the formless beginning. When the abiding and the moving gave birth to things, and things attained their principles of life, this was called *xing*. When form and body preserved spirit without loss, each possessing its own patterns and norms without deviation, this was called *xing*—nature that does not lose what follows the attainment of form. All this has no other source: the myriad things equally attain Unity to come into being. *Ming* has distinction yet no gap; *xing* preserves spirit without loss; spirit is that which subtly pervades the myriad things and fills the space between Heaven and Earth. Thus, cultivating nature to return to virtue merges with the formless Unity. When virtue reaches its fullness and merges with the beginning, even Nonbeing cannot be attained. This merging is emptiness, an emptiness extending to the state before things arose. Emptiness is vastness, a vastness extending to the point of not even merging with merging. In this way, speaking in terms of non-action, voices harmonize in spontaneous utterance. When voices harmonize, they penetrate Heaven and Earth and unite with them. The space between Heaven and Earth is like a bellows; when voices harmonize and unite with Heaven and Earth, it is like this. Their union is seamless—not a union of kindling, not a union of knowledge or perception. This is called *xuande*, originating in virtue and completing in Heaven. Merging with the Great Compliance means there is nothing to oppose.

Yu Du’s commentary: The Great Beginning is the origin of *qi*. As it had not yet taken form, it was called "being without." When things exist, names follow; here, there was nothing, so where could a name reside? "Unity" is what the Dao is named, what things are named by—neither attainable as being nor as nonbeing. That from which Unity arises arises from the utmost subtlety, before form existed. That things obtain it to come into being means that in receiving destiny, destiny lies within me—thus it is called virtue, the attainment of what lies within me. Before form, at the beginning of creation, there was already distinction and regulation. This distinction does not lie in things after they attain form; though there is distinction, it remains seamless—this is the *ming* of things. "Yet" (*qie*) signifies that this cannot be taken as constant. When things have life, they have form; life emerges from *ming*, form emerges from life. When humans have life, they share the same body as the Dao; when they have form, they share the same vessel as the Dao. The abiding and the moving—yin’s stillness and yang’s movement—give birth to things. When things are completed, their principles of life arise naturally. Thus, *ming* within me is called *xing* (nature); *xing* within things is called *li* (principle). Form is the image of the Dao. Form and body rely on spirit to exist; when they preserve their spirit, each possessing its own patterns and norms, this is called *xing*. *Ming* emerges before life; *xing* manifests after spirit. The world has long lost its nature, so the sage teaches the cultivation of nature. When nature is cultivated to the point of nothing left to cultivate, it returns to virtue. Returning to virtue, it darkly merges with the ultimate and unites with the beginning. The beginning is before things arose; without things, there is emptiness. Thus, merging is emptiness, and emptiness gives rise to an inexhaustible body—hence it is called vast. The vast does not act yet is never without acting, so voices harmonize in spontaneous utterance. Spontaneous utterance means acting without intention between speech and action. When voices harmonize, they unite with Heaven and Earth in their undertakings. Heaven and Earth unite with me, and I unite with them. Uniting with Heaven and Earth—how could this be achieved by knowledge? Seamless, like dullness, it unites spontaneously without intention. This is called the mysterious virtue, compliant in all directions—the ultimate of the sage’s Way.

Detailed Daoist commentary: From the Great Beginning to "without name" is a tracing upward. From "that from which Unity arises" to "this was called *xing*" is a tracing downward. Amidst the blur of primordial chaos lies the Great Simplicity. Transforming into *qi* is the Great Beginning. *Qi* transforming into form is the Great Origin.

Shape transforming into life is the Great Simplicity. Because there is the Great Beginning, there is Unity yet without form; because there is the Great Origin, things attain the principle of life; because there is the Great Simplicity, each possesses its own pattern and norm. That there is Unity yet without form—its essence is most true; that which is without form has distinction, and within it lies constancy. The "and yet" refers to what is coming but whose beginning remains unknown. Without interval, it is ever being born as it dies, ever dying as it is born. That which abides is yin; that which moves is yang. Things are born only after yin and yang abide and move. Principles become complete only after things are formed. The bodily form is what establishes and preserves the spirit; the spirit is what governs the bodily form and employs it. All things are complete within me, and none lacks the patterns, images, and norms that reside therein. This is what is called *xing*.

Only after there is virtue does there come to be *xing*. Thus, things first obtain life through it, and then each possesses its own pattern and norm. For humans, this is cultivation. From *xing* one attains the ultimate virtue, so only after *xing* is cultivated does virtue follow. The ultimate virtue is ultimately identical with the beginning. Identical, it becomes empty; empty, it becomes vast, and so returns to the state of an infant—this is the work of the *Great Person*. Harmonizing voices, voices harmonizing, and so attaining unity with Heaven and Earth—this is returning to simplicity, the work of the sage. In this unity, seamless and dull, like foolishness or stupidity, one returns to the boundless—this is the work of the *spiritual person*, reaching the divine where nothing can be added!

**Bi Xu’s Commentary:**
What has pattern is not the beginning; it is forcibly named the Great Beginning. Where Unity arises, there is still no advance; with advance, it pertains to primordial *qi*. The numinous and luminous thing that arises independently is called *virtue*. When *qi* descends yet no sign appears, the clear and turbid are already divided, and what is received is without interruption—this is called *ming*. In one stillness and one movement, the myriad things are transformed and born. Things attain the principle of life, and so this is called *form*. The bodily form preserves the spirit, and each has its own pattern and norm—this is called *xing*. Cultivating the natural *xing* and returning to the virtue of initial life, when virtue is identical with the Great Beginning, it becomes empty, vast, and boundless.

Harmonizing voices is like the union of the embryo; the union of the embryo is natural, and its utterance is without intention—this is what is meant by "speaking all day yet never speaking." The voice has upper and lower, like the union of Heaven and Earth. Closing the senses and shutting the gates, the wondrous principle is profoundly still; ultimate virtue is deeply obscure, identical with the Way of Great Compliance.

**Liu Yao’s Commentary:**
The Great Beginning is the beginning of *qi*, and so there is being and non-being. The Great Origin is the beginning of form, and so it is nameless. Where Unity arises, there are names; though Unity is yet without form, things obtain life because of this Unity. Without form, it is merely undifferentiated; yet once it can be named, the undifferentiated already has distinction. The "and yet" does not mean long-lasting stability. "Without interval" means beginning and end are like a ring, without any point that can be designated. "Within it lies essence, within it lies constancy"—this refers to the distinction of the formless. "Establishing virtue as if stealing" refers to the "and yet"; "continuous as if existing" refers to "without interval."

Now, when *ming* descends, if it does not abide, it is insufficient to give life to things; if it abides yet does not move, it is sufficient to give life to one thing but not to the myriad things. When it abides, it is never without movement; when it moves, it does not hinder its flow, and so it can give life to things. Things attaining the principle of life is called *form*; the bodily form preserving the spirit, each with its own pattern and norm, is called *xing*. With life comes *xing*; understanding *xing* profoundly is sufficient to know Heaven. Knowing Heaven, one returns to virtue; when virtue is perfected, one unites with the Dao.

**Yongzhai’s Sayings:**
The Great Beginning is the beginning of creation; what exists is merely non-being, and there is not yet this word "being." How could there be a name? This is where Unity arises. Unity is non-being, and so it is said, "There is Unity yet without form." Things obtain life, and so there is being. Each has its own being—all are virtue. "Without form" refers to the time when Unity arises. Though it has distinction, it cannot yet be divided, and so it is "and yet" without interval. "Without interval" is the "so it is"; "having distinction" is the "as if it were." This *ming* is Heaven’s *ming*, referring to the *ming* of *xing*.

Abiding and moving give life to things; primordial *qi* moves and, being born, becomes things—this is movement abiding here. Movement is yang; abiding and moving is stillness. Stillness is yin—this phrase contains the idea of yang generating and yin completing. Things obtain it and are born; once formed, the principle of ceaseless generation is complete. That the moving aspect of primordial *qi* becomes my life is called *form*. The bodily form preserving the spirit, each with its own pattern and norm, is called *xing*—this is what the *Book of Songs* means by "there are things, there are norms," and what the *Zuo Commentary* means by "the people receive the center of Heaven and Earth to live, possessing the norms of movement and majesty." All this is done by the spirit, which means that within *xing* there is the meaning of benevolence, righteousness, propriety, and wisdom.

Cultivating *xing* to return to its natural virtue, when virtue is perfected, it is identical with the beginning of non-being. Identical with the beginning, it becomes empty; empty, it becomes vast. Having become empty and vast, there are words that are not spoken. Harmonizing voices is not speaking. Utterance is speaking. The "harmonizing" of voices harmonizing differs from the previous "harmonizing." When this utterance of voices is speaking without speaking, it unites with the natural. With this natural union, it unites with Heaven and Earth. Seamless, like dullness or stupidity—this describes this "uniting." This is the mysterious virtue, identical with the Great Compliance. Great Compliance is the natural principle of the Great Beginning. Before the sign of *qi* appears, there is neither being nor name; even calling it the Great Beginning is merely "there is" and "there is not"—it cannot be named or spoken. This is the formless Unity, the source from which Unity arises. Once Unity is established, there are names.

All things attain the One and thereby live, each possessing the virtue of the natural. The division of creative power, the descent of essence—this truly originates here, serving as the root of humans and things. Though their forms remain unseen, the clear and turbid *qi* they gather already bears distinction. That which humans attain makes them human; that which things attain makes them things. Yet even so, they remain uneven and disparate—all living things, myriad species, differ in kind, while the primordial *qi* flows without the slightest gap. This is called *ming* (destiny). What Heaven commands, things receive as their *ming*.

All this arises from the subtle workings of creation, its traces beyond scrutiny. Only the sage, penetrating transformation, can fathom it through principle. As for the ceaseless movement that generates things—once things take form and their vital principle is called *xing* (form)—then humans and things, moving and still, become clearly visible. The world takes this as the beginning, unaware of its distant origins.

Each thing possesses its own vital principle, yet only spirit governs it. Preserving one’s spirit ensures that proper measure naturally manifests. For where there is a thing, there is its norm—all arising from the expression of one’s inherent nature, the foundation upon which life stands. Nature requires no cultivation, yet what is called cultivation means not losing one’s proper measure, fully embodying Heaven’s endowment and returning to the virtue by which one was born. When virtue reaches its utmost, it merges with the Great Beginning. This is the reflux returning to the source, the union of humanity with Heaven.

Such union is emptiness—returning to the root. Emptiness is vastness; no thing can compare, and "vastness" is but a forced name. *Hui-ming* (harmonizing voices) carries the meaning of *gu-yin* (hub-sound). The crow’s call arises without intention; speech without intention aligns with *hui-ming*, and *hui-ming* in turn aligns with it. Heaven and Earth’s unintentional yet perfect response is just like this.

When humans unite with Heaven and Earth, it cannot be achieved through intention or effort—only by sitting in forgetfulness does it occur spontaneously. Thus, *min-min* (seamless), like dullness, resembles the mother and chick’s *qi* responding in perfect synchrony, unknowing yet so. This is the sign that virtue has reached unity with the beginning.

In this state, virtue becomes mysteriously identical, without division between Heaven, things, self, or others. Nothing in the world is more compliant than this. *Liu-dong* (ceaseless movement) is grammatically unsound—it should be *liu-dong* (flowing movement), meaning "movement" itself. The sound remains, but the character is corrupted.

*End of the Thirty-Sixth Scroll of the* Zhuangzi Yihai Zuanwei *(Profound Ocean of Meanings in the* Classic of Southern Florescence*).*
*Variant in the* Kouyi *edition: "渭" is written as "浑."*
*Thirty-Seventh Scroll of the* Zhuangzi Yihai Zuanwei *by Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin.*

**Heaven and Earth, Fourth Chapter**

Confucius asked Lao Dan: "There are those who practice the Dao as if emulating others—what is permissible they deem permissible, what is not they deem not; what is so they deem so, what is not they deem not. Debaters say: ‘Separating hardness and whiteness is like something suspended in the void.’ If this is so, can they be called sages?"

Lao Dan replied: "These are but clerks bound by petty skills, their bodies wearied and minds exhausted. The hound trained to catch raccoons becomes anxious; the monkey lured from the mountains by its agility loses its natural ease. Qiu, I tell you what you cannot hear and what you cannot speak. All things with heads and feet yet without minds or ears are many; those with form and those without form or shape—all exist in utter nothingness. Their movement is rest; their death is life; their decay is renewal. Yet this is not their true nature.

There is governance that lies in man: forgetting things, forgetting Heaven, its name is ‘forgetting the self.’ One who forgets the self is said to enter the Heavenly.

**Guo’s Commentary:** To force the impermissible into permissibility, the not-so into so, is to distort one’s nature and emotions. "Suspended in the void" describes something lofty and manifest, easily seen. The hound trained for raccoons and the monkey’s agility—these all lose their natural state. "Heads and feet" mean beginnings and ends. "Without mind or ears" means they transform of themselves.
