Things with form are prone to change and cannot coexist with the formless and shapeless; thus, those who skillfully practice the Dao do not cling to the old but follow the ceaseless renewal of transformation. Their movement and rest, death and life have no fixed constancy—they are simply as they are, not by any deliberate use. Thus, when released, they attain spontaneity. Governance lies in man, not in self-assertion. When Heaven and things are all forgotten, what remains beyond forgetting the self?

**Lü’s Commentary:** Permissible or not, so or not—this is to make equalizing things one’s task. Separating hardness and whiteness like something suspended in the void is to make disputation one’s task. If "is" is truly "is," then the difference between "is" and "is not" requires no debate. If "so" is truly "so," then the difference between "so" and "not so" requires no debate. Then why should "permissible or not, so or not" be deemed impermissible? Yet if one makes this one’s task, it is to know equality without knowing *why* it is equal. Does one not say, "Is it hard? Yet it is not worn thin by grinding"? Does one not say, "Is it white? Yet it is not blackened by dye"? Hardness and whiteness, though never truly separate, are made to seem as distinct as something suspended in the void—why then would this be impermissible? Yet if one makes this one’s task, it is to know disputation without knowing *why* it is disputation. Though these two approaches differ, they are but the toil of clerks bound by petty skills, their bodies wearied and minds exhausted—how could they be sages? To possess some skill is to weary the body; to be bound by thought is to exhaust the mind. The monkey’s agility wearies the body through skill; the hound trained for raccoons exhausts the mind through thought. What you cannot hear and what you cannot speak—these are things with heads and feet yet without minds or ears: in Heaven, the sun, moon, and stars; on Earth, mountains, rivers, and plants. All things with heads and feet yet without minds or ears do not prevent them from being the sun, moon, stars, mountains, rivers, and plants. Why then doubt the mindless and emotionless in man alone? If they were truly without knowledge or emotion, then all things—those with form and those without form or shape—would be utterly nonexistent. Those with form are men and creatures; the formless are spirits; the shapeless is the work of creation. If these three had any trace of existence, they could not all coexist; that they all coexist is because they are utterly nothing. If they were utterly nothing, how could they be what you can hear or speak? Thus, their movement and rest, death and life, decay and renewal—these are not their true nature. Their true nature transcends the six senses—what use have they for equalizing or disputation? This is called chaos, not governance. There is governance, and it lies in man. Forgetting things, forgetting Heaven—its name is ‘forgetting the self.’ One who forgets the self is said to enter the Heavenly. Entering the Heavenly, there is governance without chaos.

**Yidu’s Commentary:** Some practice the Dao as if emulating others, imposing their own standards on things—permissible or not, so or not—unable to trust in the Dao, merely boasting of their ability to separate hardness and whiteness like something lofty and manifest, asking if this can compare to sages. The answer is that this is merely exchanging "is" and "is not," using such skills to bind the self, wearying body and mind—like a hound leashed for hunting or a monkey lured from the mountains, both having lost their natural state. Thus, I tell you what you cannot hear and what you cannot speak. "Heads and feet" are like Heaven and Earth; the profound subtlety of the great Dao cannot be fully expressed in words or sounds. Yet there are many things with beginnings and ends that, though spoken of, merge with the Dao without mind or ears. Those with form are the body; the formless and shapeless is the mind. All take these as existing, but I regard all that exists as nothing. Then their death and life, movement and rest, decay and renewal are but the principles of yin and yang’s ebb and flow—one does not know why it is so. Those who practice governance do so in man. If I forget things and forget Heaven, how could I busy myself with governing others? Forgetting both Heaven and things is called ‘forgetting the self.’ Thus, one merges with the principle of spontaneity—why then cling to the disputation of suspended distinctions?

**Xiang Dao’s Commentary:** Permissible or not, so or not—this is to invert one’s purpose. Separating hardness and whiteness like something suspended in the void is to multiply branches in disputation. The hound trained for raccoons becomes anxious because of its skill, thus unable to follow its own nature. The monkey lured from the mountains by its agility cannot rest in its natural ease. From this perspective, things with heads and feet yet without minds or ears are many.

When viewed from the perspective of nothingness, both the formed and the formless, the shapeless and all that exists, are utterly without residue. It is not that there is life and death, decay and rise—what makes these so is not their *so-ness*. Thus, the sage responds with nothingness.

If governance lies in others, that is all; but if it lies in oneself, then nothing is not forgotten. How much more so for those who contrive inverted abilities and stretch suspended distinctions in disputation!

**Bixu’s Commentary:** "Permissible or not, so or not"—this is adorning knowledge to seek difference. Separating hardness and whiteness like something suspended in the void, making all brightly apparent. Exchanging delusion for delusion, binding one another with skill, marring the body’s form, startling the mind’s repose—like a hunting hound leashed, a gibbon lured into a cage, all brought to rest through their own abilities. Those with heads and feet have visible forms; those without minds or ears remain unknowable. Without ears, they cannot hear; without minds, they cannot speak. The formed have heads and feet; the formless and shapeless have no minds or ears. That all exists means body and transformation merge in obscurity; that all is utterly without means there is no "without" to exhaust. Their movement and stillness, life and death, decay and rise—none of these are their *so-ness*. What then remains to be attended to?

Governance lies in others, but self-governance is all. Forget things, and you merge with things; forget Heaven, and you merge with Heaven; forget the self, and you become non-dual. What then cannot be entered?

**Yong Qi says:** The Way of governance, if imitated, reflects the intent of emperors and kings sharing a single thread. Using my "permissible" to clarify their "impermissible," using my "so" to clarify their "not so." Though the distinctions of hardness and whiteness, sameness and difference be manifold, I can discern them as if suspended in the void. Exchanging delusion for skill, bound by technique—this was explained in the previous section. "Anxious thoughts" arise from being bound by others; "coming from the mountains" means being captured by others. "Cannot hear," "cannot speak"—this is the meaning of "the nature and the Heavenly Dao cannot be heard." "Heads and feet" refer to the shared form of humans from crown to heel; "no mind, no ears" means no knowledge, no perception. The formless and shapeless, that which is spontaneously so—seeing the transcendent in the immanent, this is how the formed and the formless, the shapeless, all exist. "Utterly without" means such a person does not exist in the world. In all movement and stillness, life and death, success and failure, there is that which is spontaneously so—only one does not know it oneself. Relying on human affairs to govern, I remain without concern—hence, "governance lies in others."

Forgetting both things and Heaven is called "forgetting the self"; forgetting the self is entering spontaneity; entering spontaneity is becoming one with Heaven. Now, if someone imitates the governance of former kings, establishing laws and standards to regulate the masses, promoting teachings to guide the people—yet those laws do not accord with human nature, those teachings do not follow the principles of things—then they declare the impermissible permissible, the not-so so. This is what is meant by "separating hardness and whiteness like something suspended." Can such a one be compared to the sage? This is a critique of those in that era who, following Yang Zhu and Mo Di, took governance upon themselves and compared themselves to sages.

Lao Dan said: "This is like convicts in prison, exchanging abilities, binding one another with skill, laboring the body and disturbing the mind—no different from a hunting hound bound, a gibbon lured from the forest, all bringing calamity upon themselves through their abilities." This analogy reaches the height of contempt. What you cannot hear and cannot speak points directly to the subtle and profound obscurity of the Dao, to awaken the unenlightened.

Those with heads and feet are those who nearly stand between heaven and earth as humans. Those without minds or ears—those who cannot contemplate the Dao, cannot hear the Dao—are all too common. The formed is the human; the formless and shapeless yet all-pervading is the Dao. To utterly negate all is to reach the state of mutual forgetting, where what was previously called "unable to contemplate, unable to hear" becomes evident.

Their movements and stillness, life and death, decline and rise—these are but the vicissitudes of human affairs. If one clings to them as if governance lay solely in human hands, how could one enter the realm of heaven? Yet if one can forget things, then heaven and the self will forget each other without expectation. This is called "entering heaven," where the Dao harmonizes with nature, leaving no room for human artifice.

This chapter resembles the dialogue between Yang Ziju and Lao Dan in the "Responding to Emperors and Kings" chapter, differing only in the quality of their conclusions. Jiang Xun sought out Ji Che and said: "The Lord of Lu said to Qiao: 'I beg to receive your instruction.' Unable to decline, I had no choice but to speak. Yet I know not whether my words hit the mark—allow me to offer them for your consideration. I told the Lord of Lu: 'You must practice reverence and frugality, root out partiality and private interests, and promote those of public loyalty. Then what subject would dare not be harmonious?'"

Ji Che laughed with a shrug and said: "Your words, Master, in relation to the virtue of emperors and kings, are like a mantis raising its arms to block a chariot—utterly unequal to the task! Moreover, if one acts thus, one’s own position becomes precarious, like a high terrace attracting many visitors. Things will flock to you, and those who draw near will multiply."

Jiang Xun, startled, said: "I am utterly confounded by your words, Master. Nevertheless, I wish to hear the essence of your teaching."

Ji Che replied: "When the great sage governs the world, he sways the people’s hearts, transforming customs and shaping teachings. He eradicates their predatory impulses and advances their solitary aspirations, as if by nature’s own doing, so that the people remain unaware of how it comes to be. How could this be like the teachings of Yao and Shun, who led the people as if blindly following a guide? The desire to align with virtue must first reside in the heart."

Guo’s Annotation: One must practice reverence and frugality—not by forgetting frugality and merely restraining oneself. One must elevate public-spirited loyalty—not by forgetting loyalty and merely feigning it. Though free from partiality, this is still insufficient to counter the task of deceit and artifice. All such postures place oneself on high display, like a terrace or tower open to all eyes. They compel things to exceed their natural bounds, forcing them to contort and conform. Every step leaves a trace, unsettling the foundation of one’s own gait. Each will has its own inclinations; none can be imitated. Thus, one follows their natural sway and sways them—though swaying, it is not an act. One follows their natural drift and drifts with them—though drifting, it is not movement. Hence, predatory impulses vanish of themselves, solitary aspirations advance of themselves, teachings take shape and customs transform, all without trace. Nature is restored, yet none know how it came to be; all say, “It is simply our nature.” “Qijin” means self-reproach. One refuses to defer excessively to Yao and Shun, instead treating them as elder brothers. “The heart resides” means it does not chase externals, and thus virtue is aligned.

Lü’s Annotation: “One must practice reverence and frugality”—this is what is meant by suppressing one’s nature to observe the people, and thus one’s own position becomes precarious. “Elevating public-spirited loyalty”—this is what is meant by esteeming worthiness, and thus one’s terrace and tower become crowded. In this way, one cannot avoid leaving traces, and those who draw near will multiply. When the great sage governs the world, he sways and stirs the people’s hearts, transforming customs and shaping teachings—this is what is meant by “drumming and dancing them to exhaust their spirit.” If the people do not peer upward to follow the ruler’s path, then predatory impulses are eradicated and solitary aspirations advance, as if by nature’s own doing, so that none know how it comes to be. If this is so, then virtue surpasses that of Yao and Shun without effort—how could one treat Yao and Shun’s teachings as elder brothers, deferring to them in a murky, formless manner as if following behind? To align with virtue, the heart must reside within. When the heart resides within, there is non-action, and the myriad things transform.

Yi Du’s Annotation: Jiang Xun took reverence, frugality, and the elevation of public-spirited loyalty as the essentials of governing the people. Ji Che, however, saw that this could not accord with non-action and spontaneity, and so he laughed, bending slightly forward. Moreover, if one governs the state with such words, one places oneself in the highest position to stir the world’s attention, causing all things to flock to you, and those who gather beneath the terrace and tower will multiply. Startled by these words, Jiang Xun felt as if he had lost his bearings. He wished to hear the flow of the teaching, that it might reach him in the lower wind and transform him of itself. Ji Che explained that when the great sage governs the world, he follows the natural inclinations of the people’s hearts, like wind and rain swaying the myriad things, so that teachings take shape and customs transform. When external things invade and harm the good heart, it is called a “predatory impulse.” Once predatory impulses are eradicated, solitary aspirations advance. “Solitary” means having no counterpart and being unburdened by things, as if by nature’s own doing, so that none know how it comes to be. The common people say, “We use it but do not know it”—this is the governance of the spirit-like person. Yao and Shun are but dust, chaff, and husks, sufficient to mold and cast them. How could one treat Yao and Shun’s teachings as elder brothers and one’s own spontaneous Way as a younger sibling? To align with virtue, the heart must reside within. When the heart resides within, it does not chase externals.

Xiang Dao’s Annotation: “One must practice reverence and frugality”—this is not non-action. “Elevating public-spirited loyalty”—this is exalting worthiness. The virtue of the emperor-kings lies in non-action, so that the world knows no sighs of resentment; in not esteeming worthiness, so that the world knows no boastful strife. Thus, one follows their natural sway and sways them; one follows their natural drift and drifts with them. Hence, predatory impulses vanish of themselves, solitary knowledge advances day by day, as if by nature’s own doing, so that the people do not know how it comes to be. Now, if one makes reverence, frugality, and the elevation of public loyalty one’s task, this is to open the people’s Heaven and guide their predatory impulses, to warp Heaven’s Heaven and discard their solitary aspirations. How far this is from the virtue of the emperor-kings! Delicacies may please and cause passersby to stop, but their appeal is fleeting and cannot endure. A brief sip may suffice to prevent mutual forgetting, but its benefit is slight and cannot encompass the many. This is why the spirit-like person detests the multitude’s arrival and holds fast to the great image so that the world comes to him. As for drumming up the mantis’s defiant arms or erecting a precarious terrace and tower to make people rush together and follow the path—is this not the logic of delicacies and brief sips? In ancient times, Shun was burdened by his sageliness in a humble lane; Liezi was startled by the mirror-like clarity of his sincerity; Nan Guo Ziqi worried over knowledge and constant action; Gengsang Chu sighed over the burdens of the altars of soil and grain. The essential point lies in dwelling in shade to rest one’s shadow, dwelling in stillness to still one’s traces—only then is perfection attained.

Bi Xu’s Annotation: Reverence, frugality, and public-spirited loyalty are not non-action. Placing oneself in a precarious terrace and tower is not stability. Esteeming worthiness invites flattery. Leaving many traces invites falsity. When the people sway, the sage follows and employs them; when the people drift, the sage follows and settles them. When teachings take shape and customs transform, predatory impulses vanish of themselves, and each person advances their own aspirations as if by nature’s spontaneity. To treat Yao and Shun’s teachings as elder brothers is to honor their sagacity and wisdom; for the people to defer to them in a murky, formless manner is to lower themselves into scattered confusion. Now that the people are at ease in their spontaneity, why honor Yao and Shun’s sagacity and wisdom, causing the people to scatter and lose clarity? To align with virtue, the heart must have something to cling to—this is to have something to esteem, not spontaneity.

Yongzhai’s Note: The mantis’s defiant arms against the chariot’s wheel-tracks speak of small strength insufficient for great tasks. “One’s own position” refers to the ground of spontaneity. If one acts thus, it is like placing oneself in a precarious terrace and tower to attract the world’s gaze, causing all things to flock to you, and those who gather beneath will multiply—this is to be burdened by one’s reputation. “Swaying and drifting” mean transformation. “Predatory impulses” are the impulses of action. “Solitary aspirations” are the aspirations of solitary attainment. Once the people’s teachings take shape and customs transform, private impulses are eradicated and the Way advances, like innate knowledge of one’s nature, unaware of the ruler’s transformation. Taking Yao and Shun as lofty and oneself as secondary, one treats Yao and Shun’s teachings as elder brothers and defers to them.

The "mingxing" suggests a humble bowing of the head, a willing submission—when one aligns with the virtue of spontaneity, the heart finds peace. This is what the sage desires for the people. Those who transform things through action labor in their efforts; those who transform through non-action achieve far-reaching results. Uprooting public loyalty and erecting precarious terraces—these are transformations wrought by action. Eradicating predatory impulses and advancing solitary aspirations—these are transformations wrought by non-action.

"Swaying and drifting" is like stirring or inspiring, rousing the people’s hearts to shape teachings and reform customs. Guiding them with compliance and without obstruction—this is the beginning of transformation. Eradicating predatory impulses and advancing solitary aspirations is like administering medicine according to the illness—this is the middle stage of transformation. When it reaches the point where one acts as if by nature itself, and the people remain unaware of how it came to be—this is the culmination of transformation. The governance of Yao and Shun did not surpass this.

Why then elevate them as elder brothers and humbly defer as a younger sibling? "Mingxing" describes a state without distinction. If one desires to emulate the virtue of Yao and Shun, the heart becomes attached! All of this serves to uphold governance through action, sweep away the exaltation of Yao and Shun, and return to the intent of "rejecting sagacity and abandoning knowledge."

*The Thirty-Seventh Scroll of the* Nan Hua Zhen Jing Yi Hai Zuan Wei *concludes.*

*The Thirty-Eighth Scroll of the* Nan Hua Zhen Jing Yi Hai Zuan Wei
*By Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin*

**Heaven and Earth, Fifth Chapter**

When Zigong journeyed south to Chu and returned to Jin, he passed through Hanyin. There he saw an old man tending his garden, digging a tunnel to enter the well, then embracing a jar to draw water for irrigation. With great labor, he accomplished little.

Zigong said, "There is a device here that can irrigate a hundred furrows in a day, requiring little effort yet yielding much. Would you not desire it?"

The gardener looked up and asked, "How so?"

Zigong replied, "Carve wood into a machine: the rear heavy, the front light. Drawing water as if pulling, swift as boiling water—it is called a well-sweep."

The gardener flushed with anger, laughed, and said, "I have heard from my teacher: those who possess mechanical devices inevitably engage in mechanical affairs; those who engage in mechanical affairs inevitably harbor a mechanical heart. When a mechanical heart resides in the breast, purity and whiteness are incomplete. When purity and whiteness are incomplete, the spirit is unsettled. One whose spirit is unsettled—the Dao does not bear him. I am not ignorant of this, but I would be ashamed to act thus."

Zigong was taken aback, lowered his head, and made no reply.

After a while, the gardener asked, "What are you doing here?"

Zigong said, "I am a disciple of Confucius."

The gardener said, "Are you not one of those widely learned men who emulate the sages, boast to surpass the multitude, and strum mournful tunes to sell your reputation throughout the world? You are about to forget your spirit and qi, cast aside your form—yet you may still fall short! If you cannot even govern yourself, how can you govern the world? Be on your way and do not hinder my work."

Zigong, humbled and discomfited, lost his composure. After walking thirty li, he recovered.

His disciples asked, "Who was that man earlier? Why did you change countenance and lose composure, remaining unsettled for the rest of the day?"

Zigong said, "At first, I thought there was only one true man in the world—I did not know there was another like him. I have heard from the Master: in affairs, seek what is possible; in achievements, seek completion. To expend little effort yet accomplish much—this is the Way of the sage. Yet now it is not so. Those who hold to the Dao possess complete virtue; those with complete virtue possess complete form; those with complete form possess complete spirit. Those with complete spirit—this is the Way of the sage. Entrusted with life, they move among the people yet remain unaware of their destination, so profound and perfectly whole! They have forgotten the heart that seeks merit, profit, and cunning. Such a one does not pursue what his will does not incline toward, nor act on what his heart does not assent to. Though the world praises him, if it aligns with his principles, he remains unmoved; though the world condemns him, if it contradicts his principles, he remains unshaken. The world’s praise or blame neither benefits nor harms him—this is the man of complete virtue! As for me, I am but one tossed by the winds and waves."

Returning to Lu, he told Confucius what had transpired.

Confucius said, "He is one who falsely practices the arts of Master Hundun. He knows one aspect but not the other; he cultivates his inner self but neglects the outer. One who is clear and enters simplicity, practices non-action and returns to the uncarved, embodies nature and embraces the spirit, moving through the world—would you truly be so startled? Moreover, the arts of Master Hundun—how could you or I comprehend them?"

**Guo’s Commentary:**
What is used in accordance with the times is none other than perfect wholeness. To seek perfect wholeness by clinging to oneness and guarding the ancient is to miss the essence. If one neither forgets nor abandons, there is no path to near-perfection. The Way of the sage is simply to employ the hearts of the common people. The completeness of spirit is the Way of the sage-kings, not that of such a man. Zigong, hearing the discourse on perfect wholeness, submitted to it, yet he did not understand that the purely white are in harmony with the world. This is like the followers of Song Rongzi—they are not yet men of complete virtue. Zigong’s bewilderment before this man was like Liezi’s intoxication with Ji Xian. Confucius, seeing that he turned his back on the present and faced the past, ashamed to engage in worldly affairs, knew he was no true Hundun. He merely knew how to cultivate antiquity and embrace the simplicity of irrigation, unaware of the ease of following the times and responding to things. The true Hundun—how could he regard inner and outer as distinct and focus on cultivating only one? One who is clear and enters simplicity, practices non-action and returns to the uncarved, embodies nature and embraces the spirit, moving through the world—this is the true Hundun. Thus, he moves with the world, indistinct and without striving—how could he startle you? What the world recognizes is merely the outward trace!

**Lü’s Commentary:**
One who can wield the ancient to govern the present nearly makes daily life an extension of Hundun—how could this not be the state of heaven and earth’s beginning? He takes the presence of mechanical devices to imply mechanical affairs and a mechanical heart, yet does not know the origin of the mechanical heart. Before things ever existed, this is knowing one aspect but not the other. To know that forgetting spirit and qi and discarding form nourishes the completeness of virtue, yet not know that the Dao is present in all things—this is cultivating the inner but neglecting the outer. "Clear and entering simplicity... moving through the world"—this is what is meant by "discarding the heart and employing the form." When he heard Zigong’s words, he first grew angry, then laughed—rightly so, for he saw mechanical devices as a burden and refused to use them. Not knowing and not acting is how one becomes Hundun. This chapter discusses the heavenly virtue of non-action, lest some suppose that one must practice non-action like the old man of Hanyin, making it impossible to engage with the world. Thus, it speaks of the true extension of Hundun, who moves through the world without being burdened.

**Yu’s Commentary:**
*Huahuaran*—the appearance of exerting effort. The front is light to enter the water; the rear is heavy to lift it. The *tan* is the subtlety of movement; the *xie* is the mechanism manifest in the device. The mechanism appears in action, yet all arises from the heart. Mechanical affairs are external; the mechanical heart is internal. Whatever exists externally originates within. The heart, master of the center, values emptiness. Things must not be mixed; colors must not be stained—hence, "purity and whiteness." If the mechanism stirs within, things become mixed, colors become stained—thus, purity and whiteness are incomplete, the essence is disturbed, and the spirit is unsettled.

The spirit is that which bears the Dao; if it is unsettled, it becomes borne by things instead. I am not unaware of the device of the well-sweep—it is merely that I disdain to employ it.

From broad learning to selling one’s reputation throughout the world, all this aims only to be known by others. Forget the qi, and the heart becomes empty; abandon the bodily form, and the self is forgotten—only then may one approach the Dao. If you have not yet attained this, your own person remains untended; how then could you govern the world? You should depart now and not hinder my affairs.

"The One Man of the World"—this refers to Confucius. Yet he did not know there was another man, namely the Old Man of Hanyin. Confucius embodied the Dao of utmost loftiness, which Zigong could not comprehend, and thus he mistook the feigned cultivation of the supreme Way for the genuine and was perplexed in heart.

The sage’s approach to affairs is neither fixed nor unfixed; in matters of achievement, there is neither completion nor incompletion. Some expend little effort yet achieve much; others expend great effort yet achieve little. He never clings to one corner.

Zigong’s understanding of Confucius was merely of the Confucius who had donned the garb of the common world, and thus he marveled at the sight of one whose spirit was whole—the Dao of the sage. When governance reaches its utmost, it becomes one with Heaven. Thus, when he emerges, he walks alongside the people, and they do not know where he is bound. Vague and obscure in his nature, pure and complete in his conduct.

What the world calls merit, profit, and ingenuity all arise from human artifice—such a heart must surely forget these things. Zigong’s heart was not enlightened, and so he took the feigned Dao of the sage for the true.

The sage’s aspiration knows no bounds; the sage’s heart engages in non-action yet leaves nothing undone. Though he regards the world’s praise, he does not cling to it; though he receives the world’s censure, he does not reject it. To grasp what is meant is to grasp the intent of the words; to lose what is meant is to lose the intent of the words. Yet it is easier to disregard the world’s praise than to refuse its censure.

The Old Man of Hanyin did not pursue what his aspiration did not seek, nor did he act where his heart did not incline—thus he had yet to forget censure and praise, and so there were things he would not regard or accept. The nature of the sage, however, remains unharmed whether he follows the course of Heaven or dwells in seclusion; when he responds to things, he merely adapts to the moment.

As for those like this man, who are unaffected by the world’s censure or praise, one wonders what their hearts are truly like. Zigong had never heard the Master’s teachings on human nature and the Dao of Heaven, and so he took the Old Man for a man of perfect virtue while considering himself a man of the world’s tumult.

From the Master’s perspective, however, the Old Man still suffered from the flaw of clinging to one side. Hundun transcends form, qi, and the constraints of enumeration; "extension" is spoken in contrast to the Dao. To grasp one and discard two, to delight in the inner and forget the outer—these are not the complete Dao of the sage.

When clarity is manifest, its brightness is evident; when it enters plainness, it becomes unknowable. When non-action is manifest, it is evident; when non-action returns to simplicity, it becomes unknowable. To embody one’s nature is to unite with it; to embrace the spirit is to never depart from it. Thus, one may wander through the world, associating with others without losing one’s Heaven-endowed nature. Would you be truly astonished by this?

If you do not know and are not astonished, the distinction between genuine and feigned cultivation becomes clear.

**Detailed Annotation on the Dao:**
In the time of Hundun, people dwelled without knowing what they did, moved without knowing where they went, saw not with their eyes but with their spirit, heard not with their ears but with their qi—how then could ingenuity arise? The sage’s approach to the world is to embrace the One while encompassing the myriad, to wander within while responding without. What people do cannot be left undone; the tools that exist cannot be left unused. Thus, ingenuity lies in things, not in the heart; mechanical affairs lie in the moment, not in the device.

Serene and at ease, moving with the world, he knows not why things are as they are—even if Zigong were to revive Hundun in his time, could he defy Heaven and oppose men by refusing ingenuity? Ingenuity is employed merely to navigate change and prevent the people from growing weary.

Ingenuity arises from the mechanical heart, and the mechanical heart necessarily impairs purity and whiteness. This is to recognize one and ignore two, to cultivate the inner while neglecting the outer—such feigned cultivation of Hundun cannot escape the calamity of startling the world.

The perfected one’s virtue is not cultivated, yet things cannot depart from it. To cultivate the extension of Hundun is already a shallow virtue—how much more so for those who feign cultivation!

**Bi Xu’s Annotation:**
Zigong said of the gardener that he lived among the people, walking alongside them without their knowing where he went—was he truly different from the multitude? Merit, profit, and ingenuity surely did not enter this man’s heart. Unmoved by censure or praise, he was like Hundun. The man of the world’s tumult is easily swayed.

Hundun is natural; to cultivate it is not true, hence called "feigned." The "one" refers to essence, the "two" to function. Those who cultivate the heart depart from the world, while those who govern the external merge with the dust. To embrace one’s nature, hold fast to spirit, and wander through the mundane—this was the way of the ancients. Hundun has no apertures, so even spirits cannot fathom it—how much less can men?

Yongzhai says: "Mechanisms are tools; their use becomes scheming. What employs them is the heart. With a scheming heart, one cannot attain pure, empty clarity. Spirit arises unsettled and cannot embrace stillness or hold to unity, and thus cannot bear the Dao."

To emulate the sage is to admire the sage. *Yu yu* describes arrogance. "A lone string’s mournful song" speaks of one unknown to others, chanting to oneself—yet to compare this to striking a chime in Wei would be mistaken. To forget spirit and qi is akin to dismissing cleverness and insight; to cast aside the body is to forget the self. If you can do this, you may yet approach the Way. If not, you cannot even govern yourself—how then can you govern others?

*Beizou* means fleeting favor; *xuxu* describes self-doubt. Though one dwells in the world, acting as others do, one remains unaware of one’s own path—such a heart surely harbors no thoughts of merit, profit, or cunning. One who disregards praise will hardly heed slander. What is practiced in the world is called "attaining one’s purpose"; what is not practiced is called "losing one’s purpose."

"Wind and waves" speaks of being ensnared by worldly affairs and never at rest. *Jia* means great. *Hundun* refers to the primordial state of Heaven and Earth. To "know the One" is to hold fast to purity; to "not know the Two" is to keep the heart undivided. *Inner* is the heart; *outer* is the external world. Clarity allows entry into simplicity; non-action returns one to natural uncarvedness. *Embodying nature* is to preserve one’s true nature; *embracing spirit* is to become one with the spirit.

You have not yet grasped this Way—no wonder you are startled. To abandon toil for ease is human nature; fame, merit, and profit are also human desires. Yet in this world, some forsake the easiest path to follow the hardest, content with coarse fare and at peace in obscurity—how could mere wooden idols or earthen effigies attain such resolve? This only shows the depth of their devotion to the Way and the clarity of their self-knowledge. With firm and unshakable resolve, they overcome all obstacles; in time, they find peace, and peace leads to transformation.

Thus did the Old Man of Hanyin scorn cunning devices, content to carry his jar and till the fields, gazing at the clouds and skies. In the end, even the most persuasive words could not sway his heart or alter his conduct—were these not men like Chang Ju and Jie Ni of old? Though their lofty integrity may stem from innate purity, it is also the fruit of accumulated study and self-cultivation. What does it mean to "learn"? To emulate those who surpass you. What does it mean to "nurture"? To fill what lies within you.

His expression changed as he laughed—this laughter was surely his reply.

Zhun Mang was heading toward the Great Abyss when he encountered Yuan Feng on the shores of the Eastern Sea. Yuan Feng asked, "Where are you going?" He replied, "To the Great Abyss." "What will you do there?" "The Great Abyss is such a thing: pour into it, and it never fills; draw from it, and it never empties. I will wander there."

Yuan Feng said, "Do you have no concern for the horizontal-eyed people? I would hear of sagely governance."

Zhun Mang said, "Sagely governance? The sage enacts policies without error, promotes men without misjudgment, fully perceives the circumstances and acts accordingly. His words and deeds transform the world; with a wave of his hand or a glance, the people of the four directions all follow. This is what is called sagely governance."

"I would hear of the virtuous person."

"The virtuous person dwells without thought, moves without calculation, harbors no judgments of right or wrong, beauty or ugliness. All within the four seas rejoice in shared benefit, find peace in mutual provision. He is forlorn, like an infant who has lost its mother; bewildered, like a traveler who has lost his way. Wealth and resources abound, yet he knows not whence they come; food and drink suffice, yet he knows not their source. This is the bearing of the virtuous person."

"I would hear of the spirit person."

"The supreme spirit person rides the light, vanishing with form. This is called illuminating the vast. He fulfills his destiny and exhausts his nature; Heaven and Earth rejoice, and all affairs dissolve. The myriad things return to their true nature—this is called primordial chaos."

Guo’s commentary: "He acts as he wills, following the natural course. If he were to make things act for him, there would be no transformation."

He directs with a glance, and the people each attain their nature—this is because he allows them to act of their own accord. They share benefit and provision without any thought of self-interest. Virtue is the manifestation of the spirit person, hence it is called "bearing."

I would hear how one advances toward this.

The answer: To ride the light is to be without light, thus vanishing with form. Without self and allowing things to follow their course, empty and without attachment—this is not a forced union. When emotions are exhausted and destiny fulfilled, Heaven and Earth rejoice. Affairs do not obstruct joy—thus there are no affairs. When emotions return, primordial chaos knows no bounds.

Lü’s commentary: "Pour into it and it is never full; draw from it and it never depletes—this is the richness of Heaven’s treasury." Yuan Feng does not know its limitless supply yet meets the needs of the myriad things, thus appearing indifferent to the desires of the common people. Official appointments and promotions are never misplaced, so he is not indifferent to exalting worthies and employing the capable. Fully revealing the truth of affairs and acting as he wills, he does not compel others to conceal their nature and seek advancement. His words and deeds arise spontaneously, and the world transforms; with a wave of his hand or a glance, the people all come—thus he does not rely on rewards to encourage or punishments to deter. This is the sage’s manifestation in governance, yet not the means by which he embodies virtue.

The virtuous person thinks no thoughts, entertains no concerns, harbors no judgments of right or wrong, beauty or ugliness—his mind is ever empty. When the world rejoices in shared benefit and provision, all willingly submit without weariness. Like an infant who has lost its mother, he knows not where to turn. Like a traveler who has lost his way, he knows not where to go. With wealth and resources in abundance, he simply shares benefit with the world. With food and drink sufficient, he simply provides for the world. This is the bearing of the virtuous person, yet not the means by which he becomes spirit.

The vast expanse emits light to illuminate—this is the spirit’s way of riding it, not merely vanishing with light and form. Thus, though it illuminates, it remains boundless. To fulfill destiny is to shed the old and return to the constant. To exhaust emotions is to cast off falsity and dwell in truth. When all affairs dissolve, vacuity reaches its extreme; when the myriad things return to their emotions, they flourish and return to their roots. "Chaos" means merging into oneness; "obscurity" means even illumination is forgotten.

Yi Du’s commentary: "Water nearly attains the Dao—pour into it and it is never full, draw from it and it never depletes. Is this not the workings of the spirit?" Desiring to emerge and govern the people, one asks about sagely rule. When offices are mentioned, one knows promotions never fail their duties; when abilities are mentioned, one knows appointments never miss their mark. Fully revealing the truth of affairs, nothing is ever amiss. Words and deeds arise naturally, and the world transforms as one. With a wave of the hand or a glance, distant people all come—this speaks of the sage’s emergence to govern.

Without thoughts or concerns, forgetting beauty and ugliness, he is unburdened by things. The world’s joy in shared benefit is not self-provision. Like an infant who has lost its mother, he has nothing to rely on. Like a traveler who has lost his way, he has nowhere to go. With wealth, resources, food, and drink of unknown origin, he seeks nothing yet is self-sufficient.

The supreme spirit is spirit beyond spirit. Riding the light, he is above it and mounts it—form and shadow are unseen, returning to nothingness alone. To fulfill destiny is to arrive without striving. To exhaust emotions is to fully realize one’s nature. The spirit person has completed his destiny and fulfilled his nature; even Heaven and Earth rejoice—how much more so people, how much more so things! When the myriad things each return to the truth of their nature and destiny, they unite with the Dao—hence it is called "primordial chaos."

First, sagely rule is discussed as "fullness that radiates brilliance"—this is called greatness. Next, the virtuous person is "greatness that transforms"—this is called sageliness. Finally, the spirit person is "sageliness beyond knowing"—this is called spirit. Sagely rule speaks of his work; the virtuous person, his virtue; the spirit person, his Dao—yet in truth, all are the affairs of the sage.

Xiang Dao’s commentary: "In speech, he is earnest to respond to things; in the Dao, he is obscure to merge with them. Thus, outwardly he speaks of sagely rule, inwardly of virtue and spirit. Promotions never fail the capable, just as selecting the loyal and upright; with a wave or glance, the four directions all come—just as those who seek advancement gather. This is sagely rule, not governing by non-governance."

From "without thoughts or concerns" to "food and drink sufficient," the way to unite with the spirit is no more than this. Yet it is called the virtuous person because virtue is the essence of spirit, and spirit is the function of virtue. One who fully embodies essence has not yet attained the subtlety of function; one who attains the subtlety of function must return to essence. This is how the virtuous person and spirit person are distinguished.

Spirit corresponds to fire among the Five Phases—fire has no constant form, arising with things. When things exist, there is light; when things perish, it vanishes. The spirit’s utility enters and exits, and the people all employ it—riding the light to illuminate the vast is like this.

Bi Xu’s commentary: "The great ravine is the Eastern Sea. Pour into it and it is never full; draw from it and it never depletes—this illustrates the Dao’s inexhaustible source." Without fixed duties or abilities, not revealing his nature, acting without contrivance—this is the essence of governance. Words and deeds arise spontaneously, and the world transforms—this is the subtlety of sagely rule through non-governance.

Without thoughts or concerns, the mind functions like a mirror—thus the world willingly shares benefit and provision. Like an infant who has lost its mother, all it relies on is dear. Like a traveler who has lost his way, all directions are secure. Roaming the mind in tranquility, things abound and come of themselves. Merging qi in stillness, the belly is full and knowledge forgotten—this is the bearing of one who embodies virtue.

Riding the light of primordial qi, there is no light; if light is absent, how can form remain? This is called "illuminating the vast"—the Great Void is one body. Attaining Heaven’s mandate, the emotions of things are exhausted; inner joy forgets the outer. The myriad things return to their emotions, each to its root—this is called "primordial chaos." Stillness is called "returning to destiny."

Yongzhai observes: "To roam the great ravine" speaks of how the world is unworthy of contemplation—one must turn to observe the sea. When offices are bestowed appropriately and worthy individuals are promoted, one sees the substance in every matter that can be accomplished. Proceeding in accord with this, all actions and words become self-directed, not performed for others but for the self, and the world naturally transforms thereby.

When the sage raises a hand and points wherever he gazes, the people respond without fail—thus does he govern the world in stillness and motion. Stillness and motion arise without intention, hence he harbors no judgments of right or wrong, beauty or ugliness—this is what it means to think neither of good nor evil. The intent is to share provision and benefit, to rejoice with others as one.

Like an infant who has lost its mother, or a traveler who has strayed from the path, this speaks of finding joy in the human world while bearing an unavoidable sentiment. Wealth, resources, food, and drink are all set aside without concern—this expresses the absence of intention.

"Ascending spirit" describes how the spirit soars beyond heaven and earth. The light of sun and moon lies below, hence it is called "riding the light." With form extinguished, having a body is as if having none. "Illuminating the vast" means great clarity.

To reach the utmost of Heaven’s mandate is to exhaust the emotions within one’s nature, delighting in the Dao of heaven and earth so that no worldly affair burdens me. "Returning to emotion" is returning to true principle; returning to true principle, the myriad things and I become one. "Primordial chaos" is the meaning of *hundun*.

When one grows weary of the world’s narrowness and pettiness, one yearns for the great ravine’s inexhaustible flow—thus desiring to roam there.

Yuan Feng, suspecting the ruler had no concern for the people, inquired about sagely governance. The answer came: when offices are bestowed and promotions granted with perfect appropriateness, exhausting all talents, then those in office fulfill their duties, the overlooked are raised up, and all matters of governance fully reveal human sentiments and principles, allowing what ought to be done to proceed. For those who act and those who speak, all emerges from self-motivation, free from the flaw of affectation. With sincerity reaching things, how could the world fail to be transformed?

When a hand beckons or a glance directs, distant people all come—thus the near may be known. Such is the effect of the sage’s governance.

Next, he asked about the virtuous person. The answer came: dwelling without thought, moving without deliberation, their activity and stillness are without intention. Beauty and ugliness naturally dissolve. For all people under heaven who have not found their place, the virtuous person wishes to benefit, provide, and bring joy and peace. Thus, when cultivated throughout the world, their virtue is universal. Like an infant separated from its mother, wandering and losing its way, they regard the people with the compassion of one tending the wounded.

Wealth and resources are abundant, frugality ensures constant sufficiency. Food and drink are taken to fill the belly, nothing more. They do not know whence these come, for they never fix their mind on wealth or sustenance yet naturally supply their needs—this arises from their dedication to benefiting all under heaven. Such are the outward demeanors of the virtuous person, visible to the eye, yet not their true essence. As for their true essence, it admits no description.

Again, he asked about the spirit person. The answer came: ascending spirit, riding the light—this is what is meant by "proceeding above the great brightness." With form extinguished, having a body is as if having none—this is what is meant by "entering the gate of profound obscurity." This speaks of the spirit person’s movement between yang and yin, their transformations beyond measure.

"Ascending spirit" is the utmost of spirit. "Riding the light" means soaring through the void, treading upon radiance. Only through emptiness can light be emitted; only through vastness can illumination be contained. Only when one reaches the utmost of one’s mandate can one exhaust the world’s emotions, delight in the Dao of heaven and earth, and gauge it by the people’s hearts—thus the heavenly sight and heavenly hearing are no different.

All affairs dissolve, originating from my non-action, allowing the myriad things each to return to their original nature. This is called *hundun*. In *hundun*, I too am forgotten—how much more the things!

Discussing the spirit person and concluding with *hundun* further clarifies the source of their spirituality.

Menwugui and Chizhang Manji observed King Wu’s army. Chizhang Manji said, "Is it not inferior to the governance of Youyu?" Thus they avoided this calamity.

Menwugui said, "When all under heaven is equally governed, does Youyu govern it? Or does he govern it only after disorder?"

Chizhang Manji replied, "That all under heaven is equally governed is the wish—why calculate whether it is Youyu? Youyu’s treatment of sores is like applying a wig to the bald or seeking a physician for the sick. A filial son administering medicine to his compassionate father does so with a scorched countenance—this the sage finds shameful."

In the age of utmost virtue, worthies are not exalted, abilities are not employed. Superiors are like the tips of branches, the people like wild deer. Upright yet not knowing it as righteousness, loving one another yet not knowing it as benevolence, truthful yet not knowing it as loyalty, fitting yet not knowing it as trustworthiness, creatures moving and employing one another, not considering it a favor. Thus, actions leave no traces, affairs leave no legacy.

Guo’s commentary: Both sages governed only after disorder. Whether through yielding or military force, the difference lies merely in the times—there is no superiority between them. When governance is equal, desires are each satisfied—why calculate Youyu’s virtue and push him forward as ruler? Moreover, when all under heaven rests from wounds and chaos, they seek Youyu’s medicine. Administering medicine to tend a father, one’s countenance is scorched—governing all under heaven is not for glory.

In the age of utmost virtue, the worthy occupy their positions—not because they are exalted. The capable act on their own—not because they are employed. Superiors are like the tips of branches, rising above things yet not elevating themselves. Below, like wild deer, they are released and find contentment. Righteousness, benevolence, loyalty, and trustworthiness arise naturally from their nature, not from knowledge. Creatures employ one another, moving spontaneously. Thus, their actions require no gratitude to a master. Allowing things to act on their own, actions leave no traces. Affairs each remain within their bounds, so no teachings are transmitted to others.

Lü’s commentary: Youyu governed only after disorder, just as King Wu governed only after disorder. Who does not take all under heaven as their concern and yet falls short? Thus, Youyu’s treatment of sores is like applying a wig to the bald or seeking a physician for the sick—this is governing only after disorder. Administering medicine to tend a father, one’s countenance is scorched. The Dao does not reach the point of mutual forgetting, and the six relations lack harmony—this is what the sage finds shameful. Then how could Youyu’s governance be said to surpass King Wu’s?

Viewed from the perspective of progress, even Fuxi and Suiren cannot be called an age of utmost virtue. Viewed from the heart, the subtleties of Youyu and King Wu are precisely the age of utmost virtue. Through their non-action, they had no name. Without name, actions leave no traces, affairs leave no legacy. Who can compare or discuss between them?

Yi Duzhu’s commentary: Zhuangzi’s intent was to emulate the age of great antiquity, allowing people each to rest in the sentiments of their nature and fate. The way of Yao and Shun in governing all under heaven was but chaff and dregs, not what he valued.

When the people are in disorder, Youyu governs them with the seven virtues, like medicine treating sores. Wigs adorn the hairless, physicians attack illness—neither follows nature, just as governing follows disorder. Administering medicine to tend a father, one’s countenance is distressed. The world considers this filial, yet the sage finds it shameful. Speaking from the perspective of the heavenly Dao, this is to remedy the flaws of the human Dao.

In the age of utmost virtue, not exalting worthies means people do not contend for fame. Not employing abilities means people do not contend for skill.

The branch rises of itself without striving to be above, just as the wild deer dwells in the wild without striving to be there. Uprightness is the root of righteousness; mutual affection is the root of benevolence. Benevolence and righteousness are but names for uprightness and mutual affection. Sincerity is the root of loyalty; appropriateness is the root of trustworthiness. What the world calls sincerity and appropriateness merely seeks the reputation of loyalty and trustworthiness. Yet in the age of utmost virtue, benevolence, righteousness, loyalty, and trustworthiness are one with nature, never separated to pursue their names.

Living creatures move and employ one another, each following its nature, mutually serving without considering it a favor—it is simply so. To act without seeking advancement, to accomplish without seeking transmission, is to act without intent. The *Xiang Dao Zhu* notes: The harm of sores is not the same as the suffering of illness, and though the depth of suffering differs, their reliance on medicine is the same. The age of the Five Emperors was not the age of the Three Kings; though the world’s purity or turbidity differed, their reliance on governance was equal. From this perspective, can one deem Shun’s treatment of sores correct and King Wu’s treatment of illness wrong?

Zhuangzi regarded those who govern all under heaven as filial sons, and all under heaven as a compassionate father. Yin Wen considered himself a disciple and all under heaven his teacher. Those who take all under heaven to heart never fail to humble themselves to honor others, and thus earn the world’s affection and praise. Yet this differs from those who heedlessly lose their realm! The *Bixu Zhu* states: Dan Zhu was unworthy, so one of sagely brilliance replaced him; King Zhou of Yin was cruel and evil, so one who quelled disorder and chaos overthrew him. Neither was a state of tranquil, equal governance.

When the black-haired people were afflicted, Chonghua treated them with the medicine of benevolence and righteousness. To be ill and seek a physician, to be in disorder and seek governance—could this be what a good physician or filial son wishes to hear? Not exalting worthies means no contention; not employing abilities means no failure.

As above like the heartless tip of a branch, as below like a wild deer in carefree ease—this too is the principle of resonance and summoning. Where there is a domain, righteousness appears; where there is hatred, benevolence emerges; where there is deceit, loyalty becomes manifest; where there is falsehood, trustworthiness shines forth. Without the first four conditions, the latter four qualities would also vanish.

The mutual service of living creatures arises naturally, and none regard it as a gift. Without advancement, without transmission, none deem it extraordinary. *Yongzhai* states: "Man-Kai’s reliance on military force over yielding deference was condemned by *Wu Gui’s Inquiry*, and even the Yu dynasty was criticized for it. The world all desired governance, yet when the Yu dynasty governed, it was seen as a burden. Without sores, what need for medicine? Without baldness, what need for pine ointment? Without illness, what need for a physician? A filial son preparing medicine for his father wears a haggard look—how much better if the father were free of illness! A compassionate father and the shame of disgrace advance together, for the shame of disgrace follows later.

In an age of utmost virtue, all under heaven is pure and unified, and no names of worthies or abilities exist—thus, none are exalted, none employed. The tip of a branch and the wild deer are metaphors for being without emotion or desire. 'Uprightness' means cultivating the self. 'Mutual love' means mutual affection. 'Uprightness' and the four that follow were unknown—this means that in that time, there were no names for benevolence, righteousness, loyalty, or trustworthiness.

'Living creatures' refers to the people of simplicity, who serve and befriend one another without regarding it as a favor. 'Without advancement, without transmission' means that in that time, there were no matters of right and wrong, praise or blame. Only when the world is ungoverned does the name of governance arise; only when Yao’s son was unworthy did the abdication to Shun occur. For where yielding deference exists at the outset, military force must follow—just as sores precede medicine, baldness precedes hairpieces, and illness precedes physicians.

A filial son preparing medicine performs a duty, yet the sage feels shame for it, for nothing surpasses a father’s freedom from illness. How much more shameful is it to seek governance through military force? Thus, the age of utmost virtue is invoked to expose the shallowness of later customs, urging people to abandon the latter and embrace the former. Because none exalt worthies or employ abilities, they become like the tip of a branch, like the wild deer. The tip of a branch is the highest branch of a tree, lofty yet unaware of its elevation.

'Uprightness' likely means mutual correction, as can be inferred from the following text. These 'four unknowns' are what lead to convergence in the Dao, all transformed into a realm of mutual forgetting. Benevolence, righteousness, loyalty, and trustworthiness are merely distinctions made by the people of the world. 'Living creatures' refers to the simple folk who serve one another without regarding it as a gift, who befriend and assist without expectation of reward. 'Acting without advancement' is like a crow’s flight leaving no trace. 'Doing without transmission' means those passed by are transformed. This is the essence of an age of utmost virtue!"

*The Thirty-Eighth Scroll of the* Nan Hua Zhen Jing Yi Hai Zuan Wei *Concludes*
*The Thirty-Ninth Scroll of the* Nan Hua Zhen Jing Yi Hai Zuan Wei

The Daoist Priest Chu Boxiu of Wulin on "Heaven and Earth, Sixth"

A filial son does not flatter his parents; a loyal minister does not fawn upon his ruler—this is the height of ministerial and filial virtue. Yet when a parent’s words are affirmed and their conduct deemed good, the world calls such a child unworthy. When a ruler’s words are affirmed and their conduct deemed good, the world calls such a minister unworthy. But is this truly inevitable?

What the world calls "right" is affirmed as right; what it calls "good" is praised as good—yet such people are not deemed flatterers. Does this mean the world holds parents in stricter regard and rulers in greater reverence? To be called a "guide" to others provokes sudden anger; to be called a "flatterer" brings instant indignation. Yet all their lives, they guide others; all their lives, they flatter others—assembling crowds with polished words and elaborate metaphors, where beginning and end, root and branch, never align.

They drape themselves in robes, adorn themselves with colors, modulate their expressions to ingratiate themselves with the age, yet never admit to being flatterers. They mingle with the crowd, blending right and wrong, yet never consider themselves ordinary—this is the height of folly. Those who recognize their folly are not utterly foolish; those who recognize their delusion are not utterly deluded. The utterly deluded remain so all their lives; the utterly foolish remain so forever.

When three travel together and one is deluded, the destination may still be reached, for the deluded are few. But if two are deluded, the journey is laborious and the goal unattainable, for the deluded prevail. Now, with the whole world deluded, though I have aspirations, how can they be realized? Is this not lamentable?

Grand music does not reach the ears of the village; the tunes of *Zhe Yang* and *Huang Hua* elicit only coarse laughter. Thus, lofty words do not resonate in the hearts of the multitude; profound truths remain unspoken, while vulgar speech prevails. With two heels dragging in delusion, the destination cannot be reached. Now, with the whole world deluded, though I have aspirations, how can they possibly be realized? To know it is unattainable yet still strive for it is but another delusion—better to let go and not impose.

Not imposing, who then shares the worry? A leper gives birth at midnight, hastily fetching a light to examine the child, anxious only that it might resemble him.

Guo’s commentary: When a ruler’s or parent’s words are affirmed and their conduct deemed good, this is merely defying convention to follow them—hence the world calls them unworthy, unaware of where true correctness lies. The world does not deem it flattery to defer to rulers and parents out of reverence, for reverence alone cannot command allegiance; true allegiance lies in following convention.

Thus, the sage never isolates himself from the world but moves with the times. In the age of emperors, he is an emperor; in the age of kings, he is a king—how could he defy convention to impose his own way? The world takes majority agreement as correctness, so to be called a "guide" or "flatterer" provokes anger. Yet all their lives, they guide and flatter, never seeking truth but only mutual approval.

Assembling crowds with polished words and elaborate metaphors should incur the charge of flattery, yet the world rewards such behavior, using it to gather followers. This is how those who follow convention escape blame. With the world so utterly foolish, one cannot but conform.

The Way of the sage is one, yet the paths of emperors and kings differ—truly, the world’s delusion is insoluble, so one must follow and yield to it. With the whole world deluded, though I long for the supreme Dao, it cannot be attained. Even Yao, Shun, Tang, and Wu merely adapted to their times. Grand music is not prized in narrow alleys; vulgar folk delight in lewd tunes, joining in laughter. This is why the world never employs the sage but always relies on itself. Each clings to their own beliefs, unaware of their direction—nothing is better than aligning with them.

Seeking only what suits the moment, not forcing understanding, one may live without worry in this world. No one wishes to do evil; some are driven to it by harsh servitude, others lose their nature in confusion. Yet the confused may awaken, and the afflicted may seek goodness.

Lü’s commentary: When ministers and children affirm what their rulers and parents affirm and approve what they approve, the world calls them flatterers and deems them unworthy. But is it truly inevitable that affirming what is right and praising what is good is wrong? When they affirm what the world calls right and praise what it calls good, they are not deemed flatterers. Where, then, does the world’s strictness toward rulers and reverence for parents truly lie?

To be called a "guide" provokes anger, for the name is detested; yet all their lives, they guide others, assembling crowds with polished words and elaborate metaphors—beginning and end, root and branch, never aligning. Polished words and elaborate metaphors are not inherently reasonable, yet they are used to sway others, hence the charge of flattery. If even assembling crowds with such words is shameful, then those who, ignorant of the truth of life and destiny, drape themselves in robes, adorn themselves with colors, modulate their expressions to ingratiate themselves with the age, yet never admit to flattery—those who mingle with the crowd, blending right and wrong, yet never consider themselves ordinary—this is the height of folly.

Those who recognize their folly are not utterly foolish, for the ailing can name their illness, and the ill are not yet beyond help. But those who remain deluded and dull all their lives, unable to name their affliction, are beyond remedy. When three travel together and one is deluded, the destination may still be reached, like an age where the Dao flourishes and those who attain it are many while those who lose it are few. But if two are deluded, the journey is laborious and the goal unattainable, like an age where the Dao is lost and those who lose it are many while those who attain it are few. Now, with the whole world deluded, though I have aspirations, how can they be realized? The world’s Dao is utterly lost—no one remains to clarify this.

The people’s delusion has endured for so long that even if one clarifies their aspirations, none will follow—this is what the perfected ones deeply lament! Grand words do not penetrate the ears of the common folk; vulgar speech prevails. Even with Huizi’s wisdom, he still deemed Zhuangzi’s words useless—what then can be said of the world? If two of three travelers are deluded, the delusion of one alone may yet allow the destination to be reached, for a minor confusion merely misleads direction. But now, with the whole world deluded, this is no mere misdirection—it is a fundamental perversion of nature. Though I have aspirations, how can they be realized? I do not withhold the Dao out of selfishness, refusing to enlighten the world; to know it is impossible yet still force it is to add my own delusion to the rest. I am not one who exhausts his nature to the utmost while forgetting the world entirely. Thus, it is better to let go and not impose, to forget and be forgotten. If I do not impose, who then shares my sorrow?

Consider the leper who fears his child will resemble him—yet the Dao, as a thing, resides in the human heart, and if one alone cannot attain it, their affliction far surpasses leprosy! To align oneself with the vulgar and conform to a corrupt world is far worse than a child merely resembling his father. Though I let go and do not impose, will they not still suffer? Lin Yi’s annotation: The world calls a filial son one who obeys his parents’ wishes, and a loyal minister one who pleases his ruler. Yet if a parent’s actions are not wholly just and the child obeys without question, he falls into flattery; if a ruler’s deeds are not wholly just and the minister complies without restraint, he falls into sycophancy. True filial piety avoids flattery, true loyalty avoids sycophancy—this is the height of being a minister or child. If one serves ruler or parent by mere compliance, unable to measure their actions against the Dao and virtue, the world brands them unworthy—yet how can we be certain they truly are?

To follow ruler or parent while defying worldly norms is not necessarily right, but to defy ruler or parent while conforming to worldly norms is never called flattery. Does the world truly hold parents in greater reverence and rulers in higher esteem? Neither aligns with the ancient kings’ way of balancing both paths. *Dao* means guiding by their intent; *tan* means indulging their desires. The world condemns the name but not the deed, like one who hates drunkenness yet forces himself to drink. To speak in parables is skillful rhetoric; to adorn words is fine composition. What begins as right may end in wrong, what starts as good may end in corruption—this is the teaching of the village worthies, which the world readily follows. When corruption finally takes hold, no blame is assigned, which is why such behavior persists unchecked.

The world’s so-called gentlemen drape themselves in fine robes, adorn themselves with vibrant colors, and regulate their bearing with ritual—all to win the world’s affection. These are true flatterers who do not call themselves such, and those who associate with them mistake right for wrong yet do not consider themselves common—this is the height of folly. To be foolish yet recognize one’s folly is a lesser folly; to be deluded yet recognize one’s delusion is a lesser delusion. When three travel together and one is lost, the destination may still be reached, for the deluded are few. But if two are lost, the journey is laborious and the goal unattainable, for the deluded prevail. Now, with the whole world lost, Zhuangzi alone seeks the supreme Dao—how can it be attained?

Grand speech is bland and flavorless, like the *Xianchi* or *Dashao* melodies; the *Zheyang* and *Huanghua* are but vulgar ditties. Lofty words reach the highest clarity, ultimate words attain the Dao, yet ultimate words do not emerge because vulgar speech is abundant and prevails. A jar and a bell, both round and resonant when struck—if two jars and two bells are struck at once, the listener is left bewildered, with nowhere to turn. How much more so when the whole world is deluded? Though one may yearn for the Dao, who can be found to follow? To know the delusion cannot be dispelled yet still force its resolution is to add another delusion. Better to let go and not impose—if I do not impose, who then shares my sorrow?

Even the ugly long for their children to be beautiful—how then can the deluded not grow weary of their confusion and seek awakening? Detailed Annotation on the Dao: Where righteousness permits compliance, the filial son follows righteousness, not his father, as in the *Yi*’s *Gu* hexagram, line three: "Correcting the father’s corruption brings minor regret but no great misfortune." Thus, if a parent’s words or deeds are wrong, the world calls the obedient child unworthy. Where the Dao permits compliance, the loyal minister follows the Dao, not his ruler, as in the *Lin* hexagram, line two: "Approaching with sincerity brings good fortune and no misfortune." Thus, if a ruler’s words or deeds are wrong, the world calls the compliant minister unworthy. Yet when the world deems something right or good and approves it, it is never called flattery—does the world truly revere parents and honor rulers above all? It is because delusion is so pervasive that none can overturn it.

*Dao* indulges another’s faults; *tan* amplifies them. All people commit the deeds of flatterers yet despise the name—how could this be the only instance? They even resort to parables to clarify, adorned words to embellish, and gather crowds to propagate, ensuring that from beginning to end, root to branch, no one is held accountable for the faults they incur—truly, this is folly! If two are deluded, the journey is laborious and the goal unattainable, for they are lost on the path. If the sound of two jars and bells bewilders, the destination cannot be reached, for the confusion lies in intent. To govern the world by multiplying the few and reducing the many is easy; to govern by reducing the few and bewildering the many is difficult. When customs are shallow, vulgar songs and common speech easily lead astray, while grand words and lofty speech struggle to penetrate. Now, with the whole world deluded, though I have aspirations, how can they be realized?

Bi Xu’s Annotation: To follow worldly norms is to lose reverence for ruler and parent...

To follow ruler and parent is to gain the means to guide discourse among worldly customs. Yet ruler and parent represent the private goodness of one person, while worldly customs embody the public rightness of all under Heaven. Private devotion may lack loyalty and filial piety; public consensus may lack flattery and obsequiousness. Thus, the worthy and the noble have never stood entirely apart from their age.

Those who guide discourse fear being accused of impropriety, yet spend their lives doing so—merely seeking superficial agreement. They refine their words, gather crowds, and fill their doorways with shoes. The sage sees this and calls it guiding discourse, yet the world praises them. Who, then, is held accountable for their faults? They resent those who defy their will but accept those who comply with their smiles. Compared to those who don majestic caps and broad sashes, adorn their speech with ornate phrases, and revel in others’ praise—what difference is there? Those who can be enlightened are not deeply deluded; those with inner clarity are not utterly foolish. Those who remain unenlightened and dull-witted throughout their lives are merely ensnared by their craving for fame and profit.

If I were to explain their delusions with my own insights, I would be few against many—how could this not be lamentable? Grand words do not penetrate the ears of the common folk; lofty speech does not still the hearts of the masses. Like striking jars and bells, their sounds clash and diverge, not only failing to clarify but leaving no one knowing where to turn. Each person desires awakening, yet their confusion only deepens their confusion—who, then, shall share their sorrow?

The leper fears his child will resemble him, for he knows his own deformity. Yet do the deluded truly lack the heart to seek goodness? *Fuzhai* says: "Without flattery or obsequiousness, one can refine their ruler and parent. To agree with their every word and approve their every action without reproach is not true service." To a ruler or parent, remonstrance is right, and its absence is wrong. Yet if I, in dealing with the world, follow what it deems good and affirm what it deems right, does this not make worldly customs more revered than ruler and parent?

Now, what people call the *Dao* is merely what the world collectively approves—not something uniquely attained by the individual to walk alongside the Creator. If my *Dao* aligns with worldly customs, then my actions are nothing more than guiding discourse among them. I may despise the name of "guiding discourse," yet I cannot escape it my whole life—this shows I cannot differ from the world. Adorning my words and gathering scholars from all under Heaven to follow me, I may begin with ambitions loftier than my age, yet I cannot ultimately depart from the people of my time. Thus, my beginning and end, root and branch, fail to align.

The flowing robes, vibrant colors, and measured demeanor of the Confucians—these are but tools to ingratiate themselves with their age. All of this mocks the intentions of our sages. Those who study under me are but common and mediocre people; if my judgments align with theirs, then I, too, am but a common person. To associate with mediocrity yet not recognize oneself as mediocre—this is the height of folly and blindness. To remain unenlightened and dull-witted all one’s life is to lack self-awareness.

To analyze one’s direction is to consider one’s path. With the whole world deluded by its doctrines, though I alone have a direction, how can I turn back an entire age? *"Zhe Yang"* and *"Huang Hua"* are tunes of the streets and alleys, metaphors for vulgar speech. Grand sounds and ancient music represent the highest teachings. When vulgar speech prevails, the loftiest words are obscured.

To sit with feet dangling, refusing to move—this is the "two dangling feet" of confusion, as mentioned earlier. Some texts write "jars and bells," but this makes no sense; it is a copying error. To know something is unattainable yet force it is yet another delusion. If I do not press the matter, I need not concern myself with sorrow—this is self-consolation.

The leper fears his child will resemble him, for he knows his own deformity. Yet the deluded of the world lack such self-awareness, making them worse than the leper. At this point, the analogy seems to conclude yet does not—truly a remarkable stroke of the brush.

To approve the words and actions of ruler and parent is deemed unfilial by worldly standards. To approve the words and actions of worldly customs without being called flattering or obsequious shows that worldly customs are not more revered than ruler and parent. For ministers, loyalty is the essence of service; for children, filial piety is the essence of their duty. One should not serve ruler and parent with flattery. Yet in dealing with worldly customs, to affirm what it deems right and good without examining its substance is to do no more than guide discourse. To despise the name yet enact the reality, to follow it all one’s life without awakening, to adorn one’s words and gather crowds to boast—this ultimately harms the *Dao* and corrupts virtue, like the hypocrite who appears virtuous in the village. From beginning to end, root to branch, such inconsistency is truly perverse.

"Not holding each other accountable" means not reconciling with one another. They drape themselves in flowing robes, adorn themselves with vibrant colors, and modulate their demeanor to ingratiate themselves with the world, yet do not call themselves "guiding discourse"—what is this if not folly? Those who recognize their own folly and delusion are not truly foolish or deluded, for they may still be transformed. But those who remain unenlightened and dull-witted—even the sage can do nothing for them!

"If three walk together, it cannot be achieved"—this means the deluded of the world are many, and one person cannot turn them back. "Grand sounds do not enter the ears of the village; lofty words do not still the hearts of the masses"—this clarifies the earlier point. "Jars and bells" should be "dangling feet." Two people with dangling feet, confused and refusing to move, cannot reach their destination—how much less can one succeed when the whole world is deluded? Though I have aspirations, how can they be realized?

To know something is unattainable yet force it only deepens the confusion. Better to abandon it and not inquire—what sorrow remains then? These are the words of a true person seeing the hopelessness of salvation, sighing and consoling themselves.

The conclusion compares this to the leper who, when bearing a child or kindling a fire, fears his child will resemble him.
