Even the ugly do not wish their children to be like them—how much more must the deluded possess a heart that seeks goodness? If those in high positions can awaken them, their innate nature, which has never truly departed, will surely return.

The scripture states: "That which opens heaven gives birth to virtue; that which opens humanity gives birth to harm—how can one not be cautious?" A century-old tree, hewn into sacrificial vessels, adorned with blue and yellow patterns, is no different in its severed state from wood lying in a ditch. Compared to the ditch’s discarded fragment, the sacrificial vessel may seem fair or foul, yet their loss of original nature is the same. Robber Zhi and the virtuous Zeng and Shi may differ in conduct, but their loss of original nature is equal.

Moreover, the loss of original nature manifests in five ways:
First, the five colors confuse the eyes, rendering them unclear;
Second, the five sounds disturb the ears, dulling their acuity;
Third, the five odors clog the nose, befuddling the senses;
Fourth, the five flavors muddy the palate, scarring the mouth;
Fifth, attachments and aversions agitate the mind, causing the nature to scatter and soar.
These five are all harms to life.

Yet Yang Zhu and Mo Di, priding themselves on their divergence, claim to have attained the Way—this is not what I call attainment. If confinement can be called attainment, then the turtledove in a cage may also be said to have attained it! When attachments, aversions, sounds, and colors pile up within, and when caps of skin and kingfisher feathers, sashes and long girdles bind without—when the inner self is crammed within barriers and the outer self is entangled in snares, one may strut within the coils of restraints, believing oneself to have attained the Way. But if this is so, then prisoners with bound arms and manacled fingers, or tigers and leopards trapped in sacks and cages, may also be said to have attained it!

Guo Xiang’s commentary omits discussion here. Lü Huiqing notes: "The sacrificial vessel, adorned with blue and yellow, is like the cultivation of Zeng and Shi; the discarded fragment in the ditch is like the defilement of the thief. To cultivate one’s nature is to return to virtue, and when virtue reaches its fullness, it becomes one with the primordial—this is true attainment. Why compare Zeng, Shi, or the thief in such terms?

For color itself is not clarity, yet one who sees color clearly is clear; when the five colors confuse the eyes, they render them unclear. Sound itself is not acuity, yet one who hears sound keenly is acute; when the five sounds disturb the ears, they dull their acuity. Understanding this, one sees that the five odors fumigate the nose, the five flavors sear the mouth, and attachments and aversions agitate the mind—all operate in the same way. When the mind is free of clinging, yet attachments and aversions unsettle it, the nature scatters and soars without cease.

Those like Yang and Mo were indeed talented scholars of the world, yet they never heard the Dao. Their knowledge did not extend beyond these five harms, and so they prided themselves on their divergence, claiming attainment—just as the turtledove in a cage may believe itself to have attained it! When the inner self is piled with barriers, preventing the Dao from gathering, and the outer self is bound by restraints, preventing the mind from unraveling its delusions—when the inner self is crammed within barriers and the outer self is entangled in snares, from the perspective of one who has attained true understanding, such a person is clearly trapped within coils. Yet if they still believe themselves to have attained the Way, then prisoners with bound arms and manacled fingers, or tigers and leopards in sacks and cages, may also be said to have attained it!"

The *Dubious Lone Annotation* states: The green-and-yellow sacrificial vessel is to the broken wood in the ditch as beauty is to ugliness—though they differ, their root is one, and both have lost their true nature. Robber Zhi, Zengzi, and Shishi differ in conduct and righteousness, yet all have strayed from the root and lost their nature, just as the sacrificial vessel is to the broken wood in the ditch. The five colors confuse the eyes; the five sounds confuse the ears; the nose is ensnared by scents, the mouth by flavors—all obstruct and congest, leading to discord, illness, and harm. Pursuing profit and shunning harm muddles the mind, and when the mind is muddled, the nature scatters. These five are all harms to life, yet Yang Zhu and Mo Di, straying beyond the bounds of nature and destiny, take this as attainment. Unable to avoid entanglement, they mistake entanglement for attainment—just as the turtledove in a cage may believe itself to have attained it! Pursuing and rejecting sounds and colors barricades the inner self; caps, sashes, and official robes constrain the outer. When the inner self is crammed within barriers like a stockade, and the outer self is bound by cords—when the inner is choked with pursuits and rejections, like a stockade, and the outer is fettered by sashes and robes, like snares—then to still believe oneself to have attained the Way is no different from prisoners with bound arms and manacled fingers, or tigers and leopards in sacks and cages, claiming to have attained it!

The *Detailed Dao Annotation* cites the *Laozi*: "The five colors blind the eyes; the five sounds deafen the ears; the five flavors dull the palate." For in the life of man, nature is tranquil and undisturbed, virtue is profound and unshaken. Yet when illusory realms appear before him, the wellspring of spirit becomes muddled, until he forgets his innate and priceless nobility, chasing instead the endless filth of desire—how could this not be delusion? This is why the noble person values frugality. Yet Guan Yiwu said: "When the ears desire to hear sounds but cannot listen, it is called *blocked hearing*; when the eyes desire to see beauty but cannot gaze, it is called *blocked sight*; when the body desires comfort but cannot attain it, it is called *blocked ease*; when the mind desires to act freely but cannot, it is called *blocked nature*. All these blockages are tyrants that oppress." To be bound by these oppressive tyrants, fretting endlessly for the sake of long life—this is not what I call nurturing. Why? For the one who nurtures well does not fret, and the one who frets does not nurture well.

The *Azure Void Annotation* states: A tree born whole and green, when carved into vessels, has its nature destroyed; man, born at ease, when practicing righteousness, has his truth marred. Thus, seeing, hearing, eating, and resting may be preserved or abandoned—both are acceptable. Only when one’s pursuits are untethered from the heart can one roam beyond the dust and grime, far from the reach of snares and cages. As *Yongzhai* said: The broken wood in the ditch, though carved into sacrificial vessels, remains but withered timber—though honor and disgrace differ, both are but dead wood. This aligns with Zang and Gu losing the sheep. Sounds, colors, scents, and flavors all suffice to disorder the nature; to speak of these four alongside pursuits and rejections is to restrain them. *Kun-gen* refers to congestion that rises from the nose to the forehead. *Zhuo-kou* means to defile the mouth (some write *du*, but this is incorrect). *Li-shuang* means to deviate and lose. When the mind is muddled by pursuing right and rejecting wrong, the natural nature is lost. The teachings of Yang and Mo are those that muddle the mind with such pursuits. They entangle themselves in their own doctrines yet believe they have attained the Way—just as the turtledove in a cage may believe itself to have attained it! This is the harshest rebuke. Their pursuits and rejections of right and wrong obstruct the breast, hence "barricading the inner self." Caps, sashes, and official robes are the attire of Confucians, binding them with ritual—hence "constraining the outer." Within, the limbs are choked and filled, like a stockade; without, they are bound by ritual, like a prisoner in fetters. *Yuan-yuan* describes the gaze. Others see them suffering as if in bonds, yet they believe themselves to have attained the Way—then prisoners and caged tigers may also be said to have attained it! This is the most vehement condemnation of Yang and Mo.

This passage uses analogies to clarify the harm of losing one’s nature. The various explanations have been detailed; no further gloss is needed here.

The opening of this chapter discusses the great transformations of Heaven and Earth and the multitude of beings. For one who rules all under Heaven, to broadly observe with the Dao and universally act with virtue, to be without action and without desire, with offices ordered and duties clear—this is to unify differences so that no being may diverge. Nothing is greater than Heaven and Earth; nothing is more revered than the Dao and virtue. The sage’s Dao encompasses both covering and supporting, hence they are paired in esteem. If one asks, "Were there a sage but no Heaven and Earth, how could he be a sage?" I would reply, "Were there Heaven and Earth but no sage, how could they be Heaven and Earth?" Thus, Heaven and Earth and the sage arise together and cannot be without one another. Therefore, the *Nanhua* uses Heaven and Earth to illustrate the ruler’s virtue—this is the Dao by which one governs Heaven and Earth, rules the myriad things, and reigns over all under Heaven.

People see the sage’s multifaceted responses and suspect his wisdom and clarity surpass others by far, yet they do not know this arises from governing the mind with non-action. Thus, one who possesses the virtue to rule all under Heaven establishes the root and rectifies what lies within. Then Heaven and Earth, without seeking to align, align; the myriad beings, without seeking to transform, transform. He sees what has no form, hears what has no sound—his profound resonance and wondrous responses extend beyond this. Hence, the Yellow Emperor lost the Dark Pearl, yet *Xiangwang* retrieved it; Emperor Yao sought *Nieque*, yet *Xu You* shunned him—this shows the Dao cannot be sought with intent, nor attained with wisdom and clarity. When the people of *Hua* offered three blessings to the sage—wealth, office, and immortality as a celestial immortal—what burden would he bear? When *Zigao* declined the lords and returned to plow, it revealed that as virtue declined and punishments arose, the worthy withdrew and hid. Laws grew dense in the past, calamities accumulated in the future—from this, disorder began.

Thus, contemplating the Supreme Beginning’s "being and non-being," one exhaustively investigates the root of things’ arising, the source whence nature and destiny emerge. When virtue aligns with the primordial, the myriad beings transform of themselves—whether affirmed or denied, so or not so.

Those who cultivate reverence and frugality, who exalt impartial loyalty, have already turned their minds outward. The man of Hanyin’s shame at employing machinery, King Wu’s leading of armies to deliver the people—one embraces simplicity and guards authenticity, the other wields expedience to uphold righteousness. Their withdrawal or advance, movement or stillness, differ with the times, yet neither strays from the Dao.

As for those who terrorize others as if harming themselves, the utterly deluded remain benighted all their lives. To carve raw simplicity into vessels, to muddy the mind and wound the nature—when virtue is insufficient to preserve life, what can be done for the world? All such acts mistake hardship for attainment, like the arduous labors of Yang Zhu and Mo Di.

To compare them to turtledoves and magpies, tigers and leopards, is not merely to belittle them—it is to detest them all the more! Of old, Mencius refuted Yang and Mo, and the sagely Dao shone forth; generations have extolled him, deeming his merit no less than Yu’s. Here, too, I say: the merit of the *Nanhua* is no less than Mencius’s. May later ages find this judgment sound.

*Collected Subtleties of the Ocean of Meanings of the True Scripture of the Nanhua*, Scroll Thirty-Nine, concludes.

---

*Collected Subtleties of the Ocean of Meanings of the True Scripture of the Nanhua*, Scroll Forty.

The Daoist of Wulin, Chu Boxiu, on the Primacy of the Heavenly Dao

The Heavenly Dao operates without accumulation, and so the myriad things are brought to completion. The Imperial Dao operates without accumulation, and so the world submits. The Sagely Dao operates without accumulation, and so all within the seas obeys. Those who comprehend Heaven, penetrate the sagely, and attain the sixfold penetration and fourfold openness of the imperial virtue—when they act for themselves, they remain obscurely quiescent in all things.

The stillness of the sage is not because stillness is good and thus he is still; rather, nothing in the myriad things can disturb his mind, and so he is still. When water is still, it clearly reflects the beard and brows; when level, it serves as the carpenter’s standard. If still water is so luminous, how much more so the spirit! The mind of the sage is still—it is the mirror of Heaven and Earth, the looking-glass of the myriad things.

Emptiness and stillness, tranquility and nonaction—these are the level of Heaven and Earth, the ultimate of the Dao and virtue. Thus do emperors and sages repose in them. In repose, there is emptiness; in emptiness, there is fullness; in fullness, there is order. In emptiness, there is stillness; in stillness, there is movement; in movement, there is attainment. In stillness, there is nonaction; in nonaction, those charged with affairs bear their responsibilities. In nonaction, there is ease. In ease, cares and troubles cannot abide, and longevity is prolonged.

Emptiness and stillness, tranquility and nonaction—these are the root of the myriad things. Illuminating this and facing south, one becomes a ruler like Yao; illuminating this and facing north, one becomes a minister like Shun. Practicing this in high position, one attains the virtue of emperors and Son of Heaven; practicing this in low position, one follows the Way of the mysterious sages and unadorned kings. Retiring with this and wandering in inquiry, scholars of rivers and seas, mountains and forests submit; advancing with this to govern the age, one’s achievements are great, one’s name illustrious, and the world is unified.

Guo Xiang’s Commentary:
The Heavenly Dao, the Imperial Dao, and the Sagely Dao—all three accord with the nature of things without entanglement. Thus, though they attain the sixfold penetration and fourfold openness, they do no harm to stillness. Goodness arises from stillness, yet there are times for movement. When nothing in the myriad things can disturb the mind, one attains self-realization. Possessing the means yet allowing things to act of themselves, what is reflected is utterly luminous. All that is uneven or incomplete arises from action. In repose, there has never been movement. *Lun* means principle. In movement, the attainer does not lose that by which he moves. In nonaction, the myriad beings are left to their own devices, each bearing its own responsibility. Thus, Shun and Yu possessed the world yet did not interfere. *Yuyu* describes a bearing of ease and self-contentment. Tracing the root of the myriad things, all arises from nonaction. One who possesses the Dao and is submitted to by the world yet holds no rank is what is meant by an unadorned king valuing himself. Advancing to govern the age is a lesser path. Thus, in retreat, one becomes a Chao or You; in advancement, an Yi or Lü. The substance of nonaction is vast—what is there it cannot accomplish?

When the sovereign does not take up the task of the chief minister, then Yi and Lü remain still in their offices; when the chief minister does not seize the duties of the hundred officials, then the hundred officials remain still in their governance; when the hundred officials do not meddle in the affairs of the myriad people, then the myriad people remain still in their occupations; when the myriad people do not alter their respective abilities, then the world remains still and self-content. From the Son of Heaven to the common people, the more nonaction, the more exalted!

Lü Huiqing’s Commentary:
The Heavenly Dao revolves endlessly yet never possesses anything, and so the myriad things are completed—not through carving or chiseling. The Imperial Dao attends to ten thousand concerns in a single day yet never possesses anything, and so the world submits—not through seeking favor. The Sagely Dao is present everywhere yet never possesses anything, and so the world obeys—not through force. Comprehending Heaven and penetrating the sagely, knowing that all operate without accumulation, one attains the sixfold penetration and fourfold openness of imperial virtue. In operation, there is endless transformation; without accumulation, nothing lingers in the breast. Even in acting for oneself, one remains obscurely quiescent in all things, for one acts yet has never acted. How much more so when each person acts for themselves—could there be anything not still?

The stillness of the sage is not because stillness is good and thus he is still. If one takes stillness as good and only then becomes still, this is not true stillness. When nothing in the myriad things can disturb the mind, one is inherently still—not still because one has made oneself still. Why? The myriad things are given life by me, yet I am not born—what in them can mirror me? Understanding this, in their flourishing, one observes their return; in their profusion, one sees their root. In returning and rooting, one is inherently still. If still water is so luminous, how much more so the spirit! The mind of the sage, embracing all from the highest to the lowest, is not merely still like water reflecting the beard and brows or leveling the carpenter’s standard. Here, Heaven and Earth observe their mirror; here, the myriad things take their form.

Emptiness admits no opposition; stillness is unified and unchanging; tranquility rests in unknowing; blandness does not contend with things; silence is motionless; vastness merges with the formless—these six are how the sage embodies nonaction. The level of Heaven and Earth admits no high or low. The ultimate of the Dao and virtue admits no addition. Here do emperors and sages repose. Responding to the myriad changes of affairs, supplying the myriad needs of beings, yet without this, there would be no repose, and the spirit would weary amidst the press of tasks. How can one be empty? In emptiness, the mind is stripped bare, and affairs are veiled—yet its richness extends to ten thousand differences. Thus, emptiness is fullness. Though different, their principle is never disordered. Emptiness is not merely fullness; it is also stillness giving rise to movement, movement yielding attainment.

Who can abide in stillness long enough that movement arises slowly? Then stillness gives rise to movement, and movement compelled by necessity yet fitting—this is movement yielding attainment. Attaining emptiness and arriving at stillness, the myriad things cannot mirror the heart, and nonaction prevails. In nonaction, those who bear tasks are held accountable, while I remain unwearied.

Serene and unperturbed, this holds true in all directions—where can care or rest find a place to lodge? Thus, years and longevity are prolonged. Understanding the discourse on emptiness and stillness, one sees that serenity and quiescence are but the same, differing only in how they are expressed.

The teeming ten thousand things all grow from nonaction—this is their root. The sages of antiquity: some faced south as Yao, some north as Shun; some dwelled above with the virtue of emperors and kings, some below with the Way of mysterious sages; some withdrew to seclusion or roamed in obscurity, some advanced to govern the age. Yet their illumination of the root of the myriad things was one and the same.

Lin Yi’s solitary note: The Dao is all-pervading—thus in Heaven it is the Heavenly Dao, in emperors the Imperial Dao, in sages the Sagely Dao. Heaven moves by the Dao: cold and heat alternate, sun and moon succeed one another, never accumulating—thus the myriad things are all brought to completion by it. The movement of the Imperial Dao and Sagely Dao is likewise.

The emperor is the emergence of the spirit; the sage, the entry of the king. "Emperor" and "king" speak of their positions; "spirit" and "sage" speak of their Ways. Illumined by Heaven, they act without acting; penetrating the Dao, fortune and misfortune share the breath of the people. Acting without acting, their transformation pervades the six directions; sharing the people’s cares, their virtue accords with the four seasons.

Thus, the emperors and kings of old, though their reach spanned the six directions and their influence opened the four quarters, in their virtue simply entrusted things to their own course. Their minds were obscure yet utterly still—this stillness of the sage is not the stillness set against movement, nor the stillness of which the world speaks.

Goodness is what is called nature. From the perspective of its continuity with the Dao, it is goodness; from the perspective of its completion, it is nature. Nature is the mandate within me, never not still—yet why do people fail to attain this? Because their minds chase after things, and so they lose it. Only the sage, not allowing things to disturb the mind, can attain stillness.

The mind is like a ruler; nature is like a state. When the ruler is upright, the state is well-governed; when not, the state falls into chaos—this is the natural order. To fully realize one’s nature, one must first still the mind. When water is still, it is clear and level—this is what the great craftsman takes as his model. If still water can achieve this, how much more the human mind?

The mind is the dwelling of spirit. When stilled, essence unifies and spirit is whole; when disturbed, essence is exhausted and spirit wearies. With essence unified and spirit whole, the mind is round and luminous, illuminating all—this is the mirror of Heaven and Earth, the mirror of the myriad things.

The mind is empty, then still; still, then at peace; at peace, then able to attain nonaction. Nonaction is the level of Heaven and Earth, the ultimate of the Dao and virtue, the repose of emperors, kings, and sages. Only in nonaction can one meet the Dao in emptiness.

Emptiness then fullness—this is the natural principle of the myriad things, nowhere absent. Their action arises from nonaction, and thus what was once full becomes empty! Emptied and stilled, stillness then gives rise to movement—this is how movement is not lost. Not losing movement, one attains nonaction. In nonaction, each talent is entrusted with its task, each responsibility fulfilled, allowing them to exhaust the utmost of their nature and allotted roles.

Serene and self-content, the mind merges with the ultimate principle, forgetting the distinction between self and things. Care and misfortune cannot lodge within; life and death are not clung to. Returning to the root and recovering the mandate, one becomes one with the workings of creation—this is the root of the myriad things.

Illumined by this, whether facing south or north—like Mencius desiring to be a ruler and fulfill the ruler’s Way, or a minister and fulfill the minister’s Way—both take Yao and Shun as their model. The mysterious sage, like Yu or Shun, rises from obscurity with profound virtue; the uncrowned king, like Confucius, though without position, is revered.

Withdrawing to seclusion or roaming in obscurity—like Chao Fu and Xu You; leaving traces to govern the age—like Yi Yin and the Duke of Zhou. Though the traces of the sages vary with the times and respond to change, their Way is one.

Chen Xiangdao’s note: The Heavenly Dao moves without accumulation, yet the myriad things are completed; the Imperial Dao moves without accumulation, yet the world returns to it; the Sagely Dao moves without accumulation, yet the world submits. Thus, the sage’s relation to the world: when flourishing, he embodies the virtue of emperors and kings; when in obscurity, the Way of the mysterious sage.

The *Book of Documents* praises Yao for broadly enacting imperial virtue and ultimately becoming lord of the world—this is the Imperial Dao moving and the world returning to it. Mencius says Confucius, though he traveled east, west, south, and north, had no thought that was not obeyed—this is the Sagely Dao moving and the world submitting.

Emptiness and stillness, serenity and quiescence—this is the mind’s stillness and the qi’s indifference. Nonaction is the spirit. To attain emptiness and guard stillness, to make the mind serene and the qi indifferent, and to arrive at nonaction—this is how one becomes the level of Heaven and Earth, the ultimate of the Dao and virtue, the repose of emperors, kings, and sages. Repose is the place where they lodge.

The profound is the root of the wondrous; the plain is the substance of nature. The mysterious sage and uncrowned king are the same as the "profound virtue" spoken of in the *Book of Documents*; the emperor, king, and Son of Heaven are the same as its "enacting virtue."

Chen Bixu’s note: To embody without speaking is to be illumined by Heaven; to adapt to the transformations of things is to penetrate the sagely. Entrusting things to their growth and movement is to act naturally; obscure and unknowing is to attain utter stillness. The stillness of the sage responds to things without being swayed—it is not the stillness of quiescent extinction.

When one follows things with serene composure and thereby achieves, it is not that stillness is inherently good—rather, stillness arises because nothing can disturb the heart. When water is still, even a hair’s shadow cannot hide; when the heart is still, being and non-being are clearly reflected. Thus, emptiness and stillness allow auspiciousness to settle and the wondrous Dao to arise; tranquility and simplicity let spirit and qi flourish while pristine clarity gathers. Stillness and silence widen the numinous chamber and pacify the true sovereign; non-action preserves harmony and principle in full, perpetuating nature and life. This is no extraordinary feat—it is the ordinary state of Heaven and Earth, the ultimate correctness of the myriad things, the resting place of sages.

When the heart rests, affairs become empty. When affairs are empty, principle abounds. When principle abounds, nature becomes still. When nature is still, movement is no longer reckless. Through non-action, responsibility does not lie with oneself; when responsibility does not lie with oneself, joy increases and sorrow vanishes, and one’s years are long. Those who understand this recognize that the eight qualities—emptiness, stillness, and the rest—are the subtle functions of the Dao, the affairs of non-action.

In high position, one becomes an enlightened ruler; in low position, one becomes the teacher of emperors.

The Grand Scribe of Zhou and the Minister of Justice of Lu exemplify this. In reclusion and wandering, Boyi and Shuqi embody it. In manifesting governance to pacify the world, Shuo of Zhuan and Lü Wang demonstrate it. When ruler and minister each hold their proper positions without overstepping, the world is well-ordered.

Lin’s *Yongzhai Oral Exegesis* states: "The Way of the Thearch and the Way of the Sage are fundamentally difficult to distinguish. The classics further identify the Thearch with the Three Sovereigns and the Sage with the Five Emperors." Moving without accumulation—this is purity in ceaseless motion. The central meaning of this passage lies in the character "stillness." Within supreme stillness, movement occurs without accumulation—how could this resemble withered wood or dead ashes? "Six penetrations and four openings" signifies unimpeded freedom in all directions, above and below.

The stillness of the sage is not stillness for its own sake but stillness because it is good. This line is most vital: when the myriad things cannot disturb the heart, stillness is not sought but arises naturally. The analogy of water and mirror to stillness is profoundly apt. The eight characters—emptiness, stillness, tranquility, indifference, silence, solitude, non-action—unfold the meaning of stillness. This is the immutable principle of Heaven and Earth, the ultimate affair of the Dao and virtue, the resting place of the hearts of thearchs, sages, emperors, and kings.

To rest is to be empty—precisely as the Dao gathers in emptiness. To be empty is to be full—just as the Chan school says, "True emptiness gives rise to real existence." Within the fullness of principle, inherent order naturally emerges, like clarity within undifferentiated wholeness. Emptiness gives rise to stillness; stillness gives rise to movement—this is the mutual rooting of movement and stillness. Movement without misstep is called "attainment." Each fulfills its affairs and bears its responsibilities—this is non-action that accomplishes all.

Anxiety and weariness cannot take hold, for "taking hold" is like entering—this is the meaning of "the humane are without anxiety." Long life is the meaning of "the humane are long-lived." Again, the eight characters are invoked, concluding with the root of the myriad things, for this principle emerges from their very beginning. The remainder of the commentary largely accords with the previous explication.

Chu’s *Personal Insights* states: "To speak of Heaven is to include Earth; to speak of the sage is to include humanity; the Thearch encompasses the Three Powers and enacts transformation." Thus, with six penetrations and four openings, virtue operates within, enabling governance of people and transformation of things. Above, one becomes a sovereign; below, a king. In self-cultivation, one turns inward to order the self, returning to the source. The luminous Dao appears dim, yet nothing remains unstilled.

For ordinary people, stillness must be cultivated before it is attained, and only then can they sing its praises. How could the stillness of the sage be stillness pursued as a virtue? Nothing can disturb the heart—this is the reason. It is inherently still, not made so. When water is still, it is clear and level; the great craftsman takes this as a model. It is naturally clear and level, capable of reflection and measurement—an analogy for the human spirit, which, when supremely still, becomes luminous. Nothing in Heaven and Earth escapes its mirroring; what greater nobility could the self possess? Yet the deluded toil without knowing when to stop, exhaust themselves without knowing rest, gradually depleting themselves beyond remedy—how can this not be lamentable?

The way to nourish the spirit does not extend beyond emptiness, stillness, tranquility, indifference, silence, solitude, and non-action. How could the equilibrium of Heaven and Earth or the ultimate of the Dao and virtue lie beyond these? Thus, the principles of things find their precise accord here; the sage finds rest here. Though the myriad threads of existence clamor, they do not stir the heart. Yet within this seeming vagueness, the supreme principle abides. Things do not remain forever still—movement arises from this.

When those who bear affairs take responsibility, I practice non-action. Anxiety and misfortune depart, and years are long—this is grasping the root and holding fast to it. In this way, whether as ruler or minister, one accords with the Dao. In advancement or retreat, all is fitting.

Here the sagely Way models itself on Heaven, achieving the effect of movement without accumulation.

The *Nanhua zhenjing yihai zuanwei*, Scroll Forty, concludes.

---

**Scroll Forty-One**
**The Way of Heaven, Second Chapter**

Stillness makes one sagely; movement makes one kingly. Non-action brings honor; unadorned simplicity ensures none in the world can rival its beauty.

One who clearly comprehends the virtue of Heaven and Earth—this is called the great root and great origin, one who harmonizes with Heaven. Through this, one harmonizes and regulates the world, harmonizing with others. Harmonizing with others is called human joy; harmonizing with Heaven is called Heavenly joy.

Zhuangzi said: "O my master! O my master! You order the myriad things without cruelty, bestow blessings upon ten thousand generations without benevolence, outlast high antiquity without longevity, cover and bear Heaven and Earth, carve and shape all forms without artifice—this is called Heavenly joy."

Thus it is said: One who knows Heavenly joy—while living, moves with the course of Heaven; in death, transforms with things. In stillness, shares virtue with yin; in movement, flows with the waves of yang. Therefore, one who knows Heavenly joy bears no resentment from Heaven, no blame from others, no burden from things, no reproach from spirits.

Thus it is said: In movement, one is Heaven; in stillness, one is Earth. With a single mind settled, one rules the world. No spirits bring misfortune; no soul grows weary. With a single mind settled, the myriad things submit.

This means: by extending emptiness and stillness to Heaven and Earth, and penetrating the myriad things, one attains Heavenly joy. Heavenly joy is the heart of the sage, through which the world is nurtured.

Guo’s commentary: "Act when it is time to act; cease when it is time to cease—naturally revered by things."

Thus, only unadorned simplicity can match the beauty of Heaven. Heaven and Earth take non-action as their virtue. When their root and origin are made clear, one does not oppose Heaven and Earth. Following Heaven is how one responds to others; when Heavenly harmony is perfect, human harmony is complete. When Heavenly joy is attained, human joy is fulfilled.

Things change and intermingle, calling it "barbarism"—but this is merely "barbarism," not the Five. The Master’s violence... The Seven refers to the name of universal love; without love, there is nothing to call "Seven." Longevity means "duration is distant"; without duration, there is nothing to call "longevity." Skill means "subtlety in making"; all is self-so, so there is nothing to call "skill." This is called Heavenly joy—joy without intent, and joy is fulfilled.

Thus, in stillness, one shares virtue with yin; in movement, flows with the waves of yang. Though movement and stillness differ, the absence of intent unifies them. Always without intent, one rules the world without trace or affliction. My heart is still, and the hearts of the myriad things communicate. When communication occurs, they submit; when it does not, they rebel. How does the sage nurture the world? Through nothing but Heavenly joy!

Lü’s commentary: "Stillness makes one sagely—this speaks from within. Movement makes one kingly—this speaks from without. Non-action brings honor, so in serving the world, one need not rely on talent or wisdom. Unadorned simplicity ensures none can rival its beauty, so in governing the world, one need not rely on ornamentation. All is simply a matter of clearly comprehending the virtue of Heaven and Earth. Thus, whether in high or low position, in action or leisure, though circumstances differ, the great root and great origin remain unchanged. When one penetrates this, non-action harmonizes with Heaven. In regulating the world, one harmonizes with others. Harmonizing with Heaven is called Heavenly joy; harmonizing with others is called human joy—nothing more than learning from this alone."

Ordering things without cruelty, bestowing blessings without benevolence, shaping all forms without artifice—this is what Zhuangzi took as his master. Following the inherent inclinations of the heart, who lacks a master? Thus, this joy does not come from without—hence it is called Heavenly joy.

One who knows Heavenly joy—while living, moves with the course of Heaven, yet I have never been born; in death, transforms with things, yet I have never died. In stillness, shares virtue with yin, yet does not know it as stillness; in movement, flows with the waves of yang, yet does not know it as movement. No resentment from Heaven, no blame from others—because I have never been in their realm. No burden from things, no reproach from spirits—because I have never been in my own.

In movement, one is Heaven; in stillness, one is Earth. The reason lies solely in a settled mind. Thus, in ruling the world, externally no spirits bring misfortune, internally no soul grows weary—how could the myriad things not submit? The mind is settled because it is never not empty, never not still. I can extend emptiness and stillness to Heaven and Earth, penetrating the myriad things—this is how Heavenly joy is attained, the heart of the sage through which the world is nurtured.

Yi Du’s commentary: "The preceding discussion addressed the different paths of sages and worthies in advancement and withdrawal. Here it is said: in stillness, all can become sagely; in movement, all can become kingly. In lowly positions, one is an uncrowned king; in leisure, one is... submission. Non-action brings honor—this is what is called true honor. The sage’s heart never treats the world’s vessels as vessels, but embraces its own simplicity; never regards the world’s colors as colors, but sees its own plainness. If so, none in the world can rival its beauty. This is how one’s office is entrusted to the inner workings of nature and destiny, and the virtue of Heaven and Earth is made clear. The great root and great origin refer to destiny and nature. Only by following nature and destiny, harmonizing with Heaven, can one regulate the world and harmonize with others. How could Heaven and humanity overcome one another? Thus, each attains its joy. Though joyful, one does not know why one is joyful—it is simply fitting with one’s nature. In life, one moves with the course of Heaven—coming as it should, timely. In death, one transforms with things—departing as it should, compliant."

That which neither arises nor transforms—is this not the joy of Heaven? In motion and stillness, each attains its proper measure; released, there is no resentment from Heaven nor blame from others, no encumbrance from things nor reproach from spirits. The Dao now abides in Heaven, thus its movement is celestial. Virtue extends to the hidden, thus its stillness is earthly. Unburdened by things, the mind settles into oneness; emerging to govern the world, the myriad beings each rectify their nature and destiny. Spirits do not haunt, so there is no premature harm; the hun-soul does not weary, so the spirit congeals and nature is restored.

When thus the mind is settled within, the myriad things submit without; emptied of knowledge, stilled in heart, one extends the great root of Heaven and Earth and penetrates the ultimate principle of the myriad things—this is again what is called the joy of Heaven, where there is nowhere one goes that is not fitting. The heart of the sage, by which he nurtures the world, lies in this.

*Detailed Annotation on the Dao* states: Stillness that is sagely and movement that is kingly—this is the emergence of brightness. Movement that is kingly and stillness that is sagely—this is the descent of the numinous. The uncarved block is the root of vessels. When vessels are used in the world, some are employed, some set aside; yet the uncarved does not strive to be used, nor is its setting aside ever dishonored. Plainness is the root of colors. When colors appear in the world, some are deemed beautiful, some ugly; yet plainness does not strive for beauty or ugliness and remains ever esteemed. Thus, the uncarved and plain cannot be rivaled in beauty. When governance is harmonious, people are harmonious; when people are harmonious, Heaven and Earth are harmonious; when Heaven and Earth are harmonious, the myriad things flourish; when the myriad things flourish, spirits and ghosts are at peace; when spirits and ghosts are at peace, the hidden finds its place, and the luminous does not become baleful. Thus, people ascribe virtue to ghosts, and ghosts ascribe virtue to people—so the world is made clear.

As *Laozi* says: "Governing the world with the Dao, its ghosts do not act as spirits."
As *Liezi* says: "Things have no blight, ghosts no numinous echoes." Such is the case.

*Bixu’s Annotation* states: Stillness that is sagely and movement that is kingly both honor non-action and esteem the uncarved and plain. Qian and Kun take simplicity as their virtue. Simplicity is the ancestral root of the myriad things. When the ancestral root is not lost, human affairs are harmonious; when human affairs are harmonious, the principles of Heaven flow smoothly, and yin spreads unimpeded.

To carve oneself is not righteousness; to glorify oneself is not benevolence; to seek longevity for oneself is not true longevity; to transform oneself is not skill. Unenslaved by other things, this is called the joy of Heaven. When each thing delights and harmonizes itself, then movement is not movement, and stillness is not stillness. The settled mind cannot be shifted by creation and transformation, nor altered by yin and yang—it is non-dual with the Great Void. The heart of the sage, by which he nurtures the world, is nothing other than the Supreme Harmony.

*Fuzhai* states: Stillness that is sagely and movement that is kingly—these are the four words "inner sageliness, outer kingliness." The Dao is uncarved and plain, without ornament, yet the world’s beauty cannot surpass this. If one clearly understands this virtue of Heaven and Earth, one may become Heaven’s companion.

Harmony means union. The great root and great origin praise the virtue of nature, akin to the meaning of "self-rooted" and "self-originating." When the world is harmonized and regulated, one unites with others—just as Yao said, "You are Heaven’s union," and "I am humanity’s union." The lines "My teacher! Ah, how utterly free from artifice!" first appear in the *Great Master* chapter, attributed to Xu You, but here, with "Zhuangzi says" prefixed, it is clearly a parable and should not be taken as literal speech.

"Heavenly movement" means moving in accord with Heaven’s natural principle; "transformation of things" means changing with things. Stillness is yin; movement is yang. "Flow" means to follow. The Confucian school only says, "Do not resent Heaven, do not blame others," but here two more lines are added—"no encumbrance from things, no reproach from spirits"—rendering it even more spirited.

"Spirits" manifest as hauntings; the hun-soul wearies as fatigue. "Spirits" and "hun-soul" refer to the essence and spirit. When the mind is settled, the essence and spirit naturally settle, and the myriad things submit of themselves. Applying the principle of emptiness and stillness among Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things—this is called the joy of Heaven. "Nurturing the world" means to govern the world by well-nurturing its people.

The Dao within humans: in stillness, it is sagely; in movement, it is kingly—both honor non-action and esteem the uncarved and plain. This is like the virtue of Heaven and Earth, which never acts, never adorns, yet yin and yang, the four seasons, the sun, moon, mountains, and rivers—all act, all are adorned. Understanding this principle, the great root and great origin of the world are established.

The so-called root and origin are the Dao of inner sageliness and outer kingliness, uniting with Heaven. Used to harmonize and regulate the world, it unites with others. Human joy and Heavenly joy both arise from harmony; though their names differ, the source of joy is one. Like the distinction between inner and outer in sageliness and kingship, the Dao itself is not divided.

Harming things is not malevolence; benefiting the world is not the seventh virtue—one forgets good and evil. As for forgetting longevity and forgetting skill, one is not bound by time nor enslaved by ability or inability. What the *Nanhua* takes as its teacher is nothing other than this.

Life is Heavenly movement, natural motion; death is the transformation of things, movement that must have an end. Thus, movement and stillness accord with the Dao of Heaven. "No resentment from Heaven nor blame from others, no encumbrance from things nor reproach from spirits"—this further clarifies the source of joy. "Its movement is Heavenly, its stillness earthly"—this is the meaning of "shared virtue" and "shared flow." With a mind settled and non-active, the world turns toward it.

No reproach from spirits, so ghosts do not haunt. No encumbrance from things, so the hun-soul does not weary. Acting without shame before the hidden and manifest, why would things not submit? This is nothing other than extending the principle of utmost emptiness and profound stillness to Heaven and Earth and penetrating the myriad things. How could the heart of the sage, by which he nurtures the world, lie beyond this?

The virtue of emperors and kings takes Heaven and Earth as its root, the Dao and virtue as its master, and non-action as its constant. In non-action, one employs the world with abundance.

When acting, one is used by the world and finds insufficiency. Thus the ancients prized non-action. When the ruler practices non-action, the subjects also practice non-action—this means the subjects share the same virtue as the ruler, and when they share the same virtue, they do not serve as subjects. When the subjects act, the ruler also acts—this means the ruler shares the same path as the subjects, and when they share the same path, there is no true lord. The ruler must practice non-action to employ the world, while the subjects must act to be used by the world—this is an unchanging Dao.

Thus, the ancient kings who ruled all under Heaven, though their knowledge encompassed Heaven and Earth, did not rely on their own deliberation; though their eloquence adorned the myriad things, they did not delight in their own words; though their abilities exhausted all within the seas, they did not act on their own. Heaven does not produce, yet the myriad things transform; Earth does not grow, yet the myriad things are nurtured; the emperor and king practice non-action, yet the world achieves success. Thus, nothing is more spirit-like than Heaven, nothing more abundant than Earth, nothing greater than the emperor and king. Therefore, it is said: the virtue of emperors and kings matches Heaven and Earth. This is the Dao of riding Heaven and Earth, driving the myriad things, and employing the people as one would employ grass.

The root lies with the ruler, the branches with the subjects; the essential lies with the lord, the details with the ministers. The deployment of the three armies and five weapons is the least of virtues; rewards and punishments, benefits and harms, the application of the five punishments—these are the least of teachings; rituals, laws, measures, and standards, the comparison and scrutiny of names—these are the least of governance; the sounds of bells and drums, the adornments of feathers and banners—these are the least of music; weeping and mourning garments, the gradations of funeral attire—these are the least of grief. These five least things require the operation of spirit and the movement of the mind’s techniques before they can be followed.

The lesser arts were practiced by the ancients, but they were not what they prioritized. The lord leads and the minister follows; the father leads and the son follows; the elder brother leads and the younger brother follows; the elder leads and the younger follows; the man leads and the woman follows. This hierarchy of honor and precedence is the course of Heaven and Earth, and thus the sages took it as their model. Heaven is honored, Earth is lowly—this is the position of spirit and illumination; spring and summer come first, autumn and winter follow—this is the sequence of the four seasons. The myriad things transform and take shape, their flourishing and decline follow the flow of change. If even Heaven and Earth, most spirit-like, have a sequence of honor and precedence, how much more so does the human Dao!

In ancestral temples, kinship is honored; in court, respect is honored; in villages, seniority is honored; in conduct, worthiness is honored—this is the sequence of the great Dao. To speak of the Dao while violating its sequence is not the Dao; to speak of the Dao while not following the Dao—how can one grasp the Dao? Thus, the ancients who illuminated the great Dao first illuminated Heaven, then followed with virtue and power; once virtue and power were clear, they followed with benevolence and righteousness; once benevolence and righteousness were clear, they followed with the division of duties; once the division of duties was clear, they followed with forms and names; once forms and names were clear, they followed with the delegation of tasks; once the delegation of tasks was clear, they followed with investigation and reflection; once investigation and reflection were clear, they followed with right and wrong; once right and wrong were clear, they followed with rewards and punishments.

Once rewards and punishments were clear, the foolish and the wise found their proper places, the noble and the base assumed their ranks, and the worthy and the unworthy followed their natures. Abilities were distinguished, and names were adhered to. By this, one served superiors, nurtured subordinates, governed things, and cultivated the self. Without employing cunning schemes, one necessarily returned to the natural. This is called Great Peace, the ultimate of governance.

Thus, the *Book* says: "There are forms and names." Forms and names existed among the ancients, but they were not what they prioritized. Those who spoke of the great Dao underwent five transformations before forms and names could be raised, and nine transformations before rewards and punishments could be discussed. To abruptly speak of forms and names is to not know their root; to abruptly speak of rewards and punishments is to not know their beginning. To speak in reverse of the Dao and encounter the Dao while expounding—this is what people govern, how can they govern others? To abruptly speak of forms and names and rewards and punishments is to possess the tools of governance but not the Dao of governance. These can be used for the world but are insufficient to employ the world. This is called a disputatious scholar, a one-sided person.

Rituals, laws, measures, and standards, the comparison and scrutiny of names—these existed among the ancients. They are how inferiors serve superiors, not how superiors nurture inferiors.

**Guo’s Commentary:** "To employ the world with abundance" means to have leisure. If one is hurriedly seeking to be used by things, one may gain subjects, but when they become subjects, there is no surplus. The craftsman does not act in carving wood but acts in using the axe; the ruler does not act in handling affairs directly but acts in employing ministers. Ministers can handle affairs directly, and the ruler can employ ministers; the axe can carve wood, and the craftsman can use the axe. Each fulfills their ability—this is not acting. If the lord takes over the minister’s duties, he is no longer a lord; if the minister seizes the lord’s authority, he is no longer a minister. Each attends to their own tasks, and superiors and inferiors both attain their proper places—thus the principle of non-action reaches its perfection.

Those who employ the world also act, but they attain this acting by following their nature and moving spontaneously—thus it is called non-action. Those who are used by the world also act, but those below handle affairs directly—thus even Yao and Yu, when serving as ministers, were still called "acting." In the relationship between superior and inferior, the lord is still and the minister is active; comparing past and present, Yao and Shun practiced non-action while Tang and Wu acted. Each followed their nature, and the mechanisms of Heaven mutually arose—thus, in past and present, in superior and inferior, who does not practice non-action, and who acts? The one above rests in the inability to practice non-action and instead takes over the duties of ministers. If Gaoyao and Sun were prevented from exercising their clear judgment, and Houji were prevented from carrying out his sowing and planting, then talents would lose their tasks, and the lord above would be burdened by labor. Thus, the emperor lets his cap’s tassels hang before his eyes and entrusts the world to all—when all under Heaven act according to their own nature, this is non-action that accomplishes everything.

Heaven and Earth nurture the transformation of the myriad things—this is what is meant by "self-so." The emperor and king practice non-action, and the world achieves success—success is accomplished by others.

Emulating the non-action of Heaven and Earth, the spirit and the expansive heart form the root of the five extremities. When movement follows nature, the five affairs do not falter but arise of themselves. What comes first is the root. Though the precedence of ruler and minister, father and son belongs to human affairs, it all arises from the supreme principle—it is not something the sage has fabricated. The order of honor and humility, before and after, is inherently fixed, something all things cannot do without. This is the sequence of the Great Dao, not merely what human relations esteem. The reason we adopt the Dao is because it possesses sequence. Once nature is made clear, things attain their proper Way. When things attain their Way, they harmonize; principle finds its own accord, and though it accords, it does not lose its proper place. Attaining one’s place, each thing fits its form; when form is made clear, nothing remains to be altered. When things act on their own, blame and responsibility are removed. Each regards attaining its nature as right and losing its nature as wrong. Rewards and punishments are the retribution for loss and attainment. The foolish and the wise, the noble and the base—each fits its capacity, follows the disposition of its abilities, and does not encroach upon another’s work. Names match their realities, so from name to reality there is no excess.

From clarifying Heaven to penal codes, there are five; from rewards and punishments, there are nine—all are the sequence of nature. Those who govern others must follow this sequence, first clarifying Heaven, not abandoning rewards and punishments. They must only not lose the order of before and after. He who employs all under Heaven must thoroughly understand the Way of sequence, entrusting it to those of appropriate talent—this is how the one above nurtures those below.

As the Lü commentary states: In non-action, one person employs all under Heaven, and all under Heaven serves him, thus there is surplus. In action, all under Heaven employs one person, and one person serves it, thus there is insufficiency. One who does not understand Heaven is not purely virtuous; virtue is simply non-action. Thus, when the one above practices non-action, those below also practice non-action and align with the above—this is called virtue. The Dao encompasses both Heaven and humanity: the Way of Heaven is non-action and honor, while the Way of humanity is action and entanglement. Thus, when those below act, the one above also acts and aligns with them—this is called the Dao. The one above must practice non-action to employ all under Heaven, while those below must act to serve all under Heaven—this is an unchanging Dao.

Therefore, the ancient kings of all under Heaven knew that they did not deliberate for themselves, yet all under Heaven deliberated for them; they did not please themselves with eloquence, yet all under Heaven pleased them; they did not act on their own, yet all under Heaven acted for them. Heaven does not produce, yet the myriad things transform—this is not my production. Earth does not grow, yet the myriad things are nurtured—this is not my growth. The emperor and king practice non-action, yet all under Heaven achieves success—this is not my doing. This is how Heaven is divine, Earth is abundant, and the emperor and king are great. Non-action is how the Dao rides Heaven and Earth, gallops through the myriad things, and employs humanity.

Those who understand the five extremities must follow the movement of spirit and expansive heart, then comply with it. Thus, the so-called emptiness, tranquility, stillness, and non-action are the Way to preserve the spirit, clarify the heart, and nurture the root. Nurturing the root, the extremities follow. The extremities are what the ancients possessed but did not prioritize. The ruler leads and the minister follows; the husband leads and the wife follows—this is the sequence of honor and humility in the human Way. As for Heaven, it is positioned above through its divinity; Earth resides below through its clarity. Spring and summer generate and come first; autumn and winter complete and come after. Even the myriad things, from their initial transformation to sprouting, from their arising to differentiation, from the subtle to the manifest—all have their forms. In their flourishing and decline, their changes all follow established principles that cannot be altered. Heaven and Earth, though profoundly divine and unfathomable, possess an order of honor and humility, before and after. How then can the root and branches, the high and low of the human Way, be reversed?

Not only the precedence of ruler and minister, father and son, elder and younger brothers, husband and wife arise from the principle of Heaven and Earth. Even the ancestral temples, court assemblies, village gatherings, and momentary affairs—each has its own esteem and cannot be disordered. All are merely the sequence of the Great Dao. To speak of the Dao without its sequence—how can one attain the Dao? This is why the Hundred Schools have gone astray and not returned, and the Way of the sage-kings has remained obstructed and unfulfilled.

Heaven is the ultimate of nature and destiny. To clarify the Dao without understanding Heaven is to speak of a Dao that is not the Dao, a virtue that is not virtue. Only the true Dao and true virtue give rise to benevolence and righteousness. Benevolence on the left, righteousness on the right—there are divisions to uphold, forms to be seen, names to be spoken. With penal codes undisturbed, talents are employed without loss. Examining the heart within and scrutinizing conduct without, right and wrong attain their truth, rewards and punishments fit principle. The foolish and the wise occupy their proper places without daring to transgress; the noble and the base fulfill their positions without daring to exchange them. The benevolent and worthy, the unworthy—all follow their true natures without daring to feign. Assigning abilities to offices, each office performs its duties. Following names, each name matches its reality. In all matters—nurturing those below, governing things, cultivating the self—nothing does not proceed thus. Knowing that plans, if not used, must return to Heaven, this is how King Wen, though "not knowing, not perceiving," followed the pattern of the Lord, and the many officers of Zhou all upheld the virtue of Wen, responding to and revering Heaven. This is how great peace was achieved, rivaling the heights of Tang and Yu.

To hastily speak of penal codes and rewards without knowing their origin—are not Heaven and the Dao and virtue their origin? To invert is not to rectify; to take the branch as the root. To rush ahead is not to follow; to put last what should come first. To speak of the Dao without the sequence of root and branch, before and after, is to create disorder. Creating disorder, one becomes what others govern.

As the *Duyi* commentary states: The virtue of the emperor and king is rooted in Heaven and Earth, thus their encompassing and sustaining achievements are great.

The ruler abides in the Dao and virtue, thus the myriad things cannot sway him. Abiding in non-action, there is nothing that is not done. To act through action is to have insufficiency; to act through non-action is to have abundance. This is why the ancients prized non-action. Non-action is the Way of the superior; action is the Way of the inferior. The superior governs by the Dao, thus embracing all things; the inferior adheres to laws, thus being bound by things. If the superior does not embrace all things, it is not the virtue of emperors and kings; if the inferior does not bind himself to things, it is not the duty of a minister. This is the distinction between superior and inferior.

Those who ruled all under Heaven in ancient times followed the Dao in their conduct and moved in accord with principle, never displaying the advance of their actions. Knowing yet not considering it their own deliberation, discerning yet not taking pleasure in their own eloquence, capable yet not regarding it as their own doing, their virtue matched the transformative nurturing of Heaven and Earth, thus through non-action they achieved the accomplishments of all under Heaven.

The spiritual is the subtlety of the myriad things. The abundant is the accumulation of the myriad things. Heaven can be spiritual but not abundant; Earth can be abundant but not spiritual. Emperors and kings can embody both Heaven and Earth, their virtue filling the space between, which is what the *Yi* means by "the sage completes capabilities." This is the Way of riding Heaven and Earth, driving the myriad things, and employing the art of human governance.

That which is above form is the root of the Dao; that which is below form is its branch. The root is essential; the branch is detailed. The ruler’s Way is non-action, thus grasping the essential; the minister’s Way is action, thus valuing detail. The five branches of the inferior belong to this.

For emperors and kings, holding fast to the utmost essential and mastering the great root, the so-called branches will naturally rise. For ministers, dividing duties by office, each takes up his task, exerting their spirit, moving their minds, laboring diligently to the utmost, and only then do affairs follow and come to fruition.

Laws began with Fuxi and were completed under Yao. Once laws were established, those who studied the branches arose, not knowing that the Dao should come first. Thus, the lord leads and the minister follows; the father leads and the son follows—this is the natural principle.

The spiritual is the subtlety of illumination. Illumination is the coarse aspect of the spiritual. Heaven’s nature is spiritual; Earth’s nature is illumination. Heaven is noble, Earth is base—this is the positional distinction of the spiritual and the luminous. Spring and summer come first, autumn and winter follow; the sage follows this pattern, rewarding first and punishing afterward.

Transformation is departing from non-being and entering being. Change is altering form and shifting appearance. Sprouting is the emergence of things. Distinction is how things differ from one another. The life and death, flourishing and decline, transformation and variation of the myriad things, their shapes not being uniform, all return to nature, following only the sequence of Heaven. How much more so for the great relationships of human ethics? If their order is lost, it contradicts Heaven and abandons humanity—how can this be the Dao?

All things depend on Heaven for their existence; none emerge without the Dao. The Dao within me is called virtue; with virtue, loving others is called benevolence; loving appropriately is called righteousness; precedence and hierarchy are called duty; not encroaching or overstepping is called observance.

Form is the embodiment of things. Name is the designation of things. According to their forms and names, tasks are assigned as fitting. Investigating their essence and examining their affairs, one then distinguishes right and wrong, clarifies rewards and punishments. The wise and the foolish are placed appropriately, the noble and the base occupy their proper positions. The benevolent and worthy, the incapable and unworthy, each exercises their abilities without falsifying their nature.

Abilities each have their limits; names must match reality. By this, one serves superiors and nurtures inferiors, governs things and cultivates the self. Then knowledge and schemes become useless and return to nature, and governance reaches its ultimate perfection.

The *Lost Books* are the *Unwritten Records*. All that have names are designated according to form—this is how the Dao disperses. If one is obscured by the Dao, then it is eternal, existing before Heaven and Earth, never having form, never having name, thus it cannot be what comes first.

The five are the center of yin and yang, what is called mandate. Only when it reaches mandate can things be named, thus the five transformations allow forms and names to be established. Nine is the extreme of yang numbers. Rewards and punishments measure the times and adapt to change, being the culmination of the Dao, thus nine transformations allow rewards and punishments to be discussed.

Punishments and names are the branches of the Dao. Rewards and punishments are its culmination. To speak of the Dao without seeking its origin is to invert and rush ahead. Those who are governed know the tools of governance; those who govern know the Way of governance. Knowing the tools of governance can be applied to all under Heaven but is insufficient to govern all under Heaven—these are the pedantic scholars, those of partial understanding, who are obscured by the Dao.

*Detailed Commentary on the Dao* states: First the needle, then the thread, and a curtain can be made; first the thread, then the needle, and clothing cannot be completed. Needle and thread are small things, yet they cannot be without order—how much more so for the Dao?

Zhuangzi was confused about human relationships, neglecting the principles of lord and minister, father and son; regarding the Way of Heaven, he expounded the principles of spring, summer, autumn, and winter. From Heaven to punishments and names, he clarified the naturalness of the Dao and things; from employing to rewards and punishments, he clarified the necessity of human affairs.

When employing is insufficient, then investigation and examination arise; when investigation and examination are insufficient, then right and wrong arise; when right and wrong are insufficient, then rewards and punishments arise. Though constant punishment is not the Way to govern all under Heaven, it is a tool of governance.

Bo Cheng Zigao left because Yu employed rewards and punishments, for he criticized taking the branches of governance as the root. Things have roots and branches; affairs have beginnings and endings. Punishments and names are things, thus to hastily speak of them is to not know their root. Rewards and punishments...

Thus, those who hastily speak of them do not know their beginning.

*Bi Xu’s Commentary:* Taking Heaven and Earth as the ancestral model, one does not claim seniority; taking the Dao and virtue as the master, one does not serve as a guest. Taking non-action as the constant, one remains unassuming and thus ever abundant.

The ruler’s loyalty admits all without exception—this is *ren*; the minister’s Way leaves nothing ungoverned—this is *yi*. The ruler should remain serene and inactive; if he were to act in the manner of a minister, he would fail to preside. The minister should attend to affairs with diligence; if he were to adopt the ruler’s virtue of receptivity, he would fail to serve. The ruler does not monopolize talent or seize ability, thus he governs through non-action and employs all under Heaven. The minister, bound to his office, labors in action to manage affairs, thus he is employed by all under Heaven through action.

From this we know: to comprehend Heaven and Earth, one must gather the counsel of the many; to carve and adorn the myriad things, one must seek the deliberation of the many; to exhaust the four seas, one must rely on the efforts of the many. Such is the enterprise of non-action.

Heaven descends *qi* to nurture growth, thus nothing is more divine than Heaven; Earth ascends *qi* to bring forth transformation, thus nothing is richer than Earth. When emperors and kings govern themselves and their works are accomplished, their virtue harmonizes with the Two Modes.

The root is called *li* (principle); the branch is called *shi* (affair). *Li* resides in simplicity and essentials—this is the ruler’s Way. *Shi* resides in thoroughness and completeness—this is the minister’s duty. Though root and branch differ, they must await the subtle operation of spirit and the unfolding of the mind’s function. First, one follows the root of *li*, then the branch of *shi* is manifested. The sequence of priority and posteriority arises naturally with things. Yet none but the sage can model this.

Establishing teachings by sequence, taking the Dao as the master: when standards are set, benefit and harm follow; employing the stations of nobility and baseness, the wise are rewarded and the foolish punished; according to the division of talents and abilities, names are pursued to seek reality.

The above nine items constitute the governance and teaching of the age. After five transformations, *xingming* (forms and names) may be implemented, drawing on the principle of the Five Phases’ generation and conquest. After nine transformations, rewards and punishments may be discussed, following the purport of the ninefold extreme changes of *yang*.

*Xingming* takes the *li* of Heaven and the Dao and virtue as its root; rewards and punishments take penal measures and ritual vessels as their beginning. To rely solely on rewards and punishments—is this not an inversion of the Dao? To speak out of sequence—is this not reckless discourse?

*Xingming* and rewards and punishments are the tools of governance; their subtle application and proper sequence are the Way of governance. *Kui* (implements) are what serve all under Heaven; *li* (principle) is what employs all under Heaven.

Names, numbers, rituals, and teachings are how inferiors serve superiors; non-action and self-transformation are how superiors nurture inferiors.

*Yongzhai* says: "Encompassing Heaven and Earth" speaks of its greatness; "carving the myriad things" speaks of its skill. The myriad things generate themselves—Heaven does not generate them; the myriad things grow themselves—Earth does not grow them. The emperor and king accomplish the work of all under Heaven through non-action, thus they are one with Heaven and Earth.

The essential lies with the ruler—his Way is non-action; the detailed lies with the minister—his Way is action. Military might is the auxiliary of civil virtue. Thus, the deployment of the five weapons is the branch of virtue. Illuminating punishments to assist teaching, rewards and punishments alongside the five penalties—these are the branches of teaching.

Ritual, law, *xingming*, bells, drums, feathers, and flutes—none are the root of ritual and music. The operation of spirit and the movement of the mind’s unfolding come first; then one follows them. This means all arises from the heart, not from external imposition.

Later scholars have addressed the branches, but these are not to be prioritized. This discussion is especially subtle. Even Zhuangzi never intended to entirely abandon weapons, punishments, rituals, or music. The key is to know the proper sequence, like the course of Heaven and Earth. What flourishes does not flourish all at once; what declines does not decline all at once. Thus it is said: "to kill."

Honoring age, rank, kinship, and worthiness—this too is the natural principle of all under Heaven.

Next, the sequence of governance is set forth in nine grades: dividing and guarding is the duty; penal measures are the standard. *Yinren* (employing according to duty) means assigning tasks based on office. *Yuan* means exemption; *sheng* means elimination. If one does not undertake the affair, one is exempted and removed from it. *Shifei* (right and wrong) means distinguishing the good from the wicked. Rewards and punishments mean striking to record them, chariots and robes to manifest them, and the like. The foolish and wise are placed appropriately—this means matching the task. *Lüwei* means occupying the proper station. *Xi* means peace—when one’s true nature is at peace, then abilities follow names, each finds its place without contrivance, and all returns to spontaneity.

Though ancient texts speak of *xingming*, they never sought the branch by uniting it with the root. If one does not know priority and posteriority and speaks hastily, one loses the root and beginning. This is to be employed by all under Heaven rather than employing all under Heaven.

*Xingming* and rewards and punishments are the tools of governance; dividing and guarding *ren* and *yi* are the Way of governance. *Xingming* is *xingming* (forms and names)—the ancient script used them interchangeably.

To take Heaven and Earth as the ancestral model and the Dao and virtue as the master—what else is there? Simply to take non-action as the constant.

The attainment of non-action is already difficult—how much more so its constancy without change? This is why the ancients prized it. Non-action and action distinguish superior from inferior. To reverse this is for the ruler to fail in rulership and the minister to cease being a minister.

Not claiming thought as one’s own, not delighting in discrimination as one’s own, not asserting ability as one’s own—this is the root of non-action. Heaven does not produce yet things transform; Earth does not grow yet things nurture; the emperor and king do not act yet the world achieves merit—this is the efficacy of non-action. To call it "spiritual" or "abundant and great" suffices to encompass it. This is how the imperial virtue matches Heaven and Earth, rides upon them, and sets the myriad things and human affairs in motion—its surplus concerns, while its fundamental essence remains in the unelucidated principle of spontaneity.

From the three armies and five weapons to the gradations of ceremonial attire—though these are the least of the five affairs—yet they all depend on the movement of spirit and the defense of the mind, which the ancients did not discard, though they were not primary.

As for the order of ruler and minister, father and son, husband and wife, it is like the unalterable hierarchy of Heaven’s honor and Earth’s humility, from which the sage took his model. The positions of spirit and brightness are not disordered above and below; the sequence of the four seasons has its proper order. The transformations and creations of the myriad things take form in their respective categories, and the flourishing and decline of things become manifest. This is the order of Heaven and Earth, which humans take as their standard.

In ancestral temples, court assemblies, village communities, and all undertakings, there is always order, and the Way resides within it. To speak of the Way yet reject order—what Way is there to grasp? Thus, from first illuminating Heaven to the subsequent sequence of the Dao and virtue, down to the worthy and unworthy following their true nature—all depend on this order and cannot be without it. Each is assigned their abilities to examine their efficacy, and each is assessed by their names to verify their reality. Serving superiors and nurturing subordinates, governing things and cultivating oneself—nothing surpasses this as the essential method.

When schemes and plans are unused and all returns to spontaneity, this is the ultimate governance of Great Peace.

The subsequent quotation from the classics, "to nurture all under Heaven," expands upon the preceding residual meaning.

*Southern Florescence True Scripture: Ocean of Meanings Compiled and Elucidated*, Scroll Forty-One, concludes.

*Southern Florescence True Scripture: Ocean of Meanings Compiled and Elucidated*, Scroll Forty-Two.
By Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin.

**Heavenly Dao, Third Chapter**

Long ago, Shun asked Yao: "How does the Heavenly King employ his mind?"
Yao replied: "I do not slight the destitute, nor abandon the impoverished. I grieve for the dead, cherish the young, and pity women. This is how I employ my mind."
Shun said: "Noble indeed, yet not yet great."
Yao asked: "Then how should it be?"
Shun said: "In embodying the virtue of Heaven, one emerges in tranquility. The sun and moon shine, the four seasons proceed, as day and night follow their constant course, and clouds move while rain descends."
Yao exclaimed: "How entangled and restless! You align with Heaven; I align with man."
Now, Heaven and Earth are what the ancients deemed greatest, what the Yellow Emperor, Yao, and Shun all jointly admired. Thus, those who in ancient times ruled all under Heaven—what did they do? They simply followed Heaven and Earth!

**Guo’s Annotation:**
The "destitute" are the so-called impoverished. "Not abandoning" means constantly bestowing grace. Aligning with Heaven’s virtue, though active, remains still; the four seasons and day and night all proceed without contrivance, spontaneously. "Entangled and restless" suggests the eye suspects busyness, hence it is said: those who in ancient times ruled all under Heaven—what did they do? They simply embodied Heaven’s virtue.

**Lü’s Annotation:**
In Heaven’s virtue, though active, one is never without tranquility. The sun and moon shine, the four seasons proceed—advancing and retreating, bending and extending—none acts by design. Day and night follow their course, succeeding one another without awareness of their origin; clouds move and rain descends, and all under Heaven is evenly nurtured. Compared to this, is not "not slighting the destitute, not abandoning the impoverished" entangled and restless? What Shun spoke aligns with Heaven; what Yao spoke aligns with man. Yet the Confucians of the world know Yao only thus. Therefore, the text attributes this to the two sages to clarify that what is greatest and jointly admired lies precisely here, no different from the Yellow Emperor.

**Yi Du’s Annotation:**
"Not slighting the destitute... pitying women" expresses the intent of "not daring to disrespect the widowed and orphaned." Noble indeed, yet unable to extend grace to all generations without ceasing to be benevolent—this is why it is not yet great. Heaven’s virtue is the natural Dao, attained within oneself. Thus, though active, one is never without stillness. Like the sun and moon, the four seasons, clouds moving and rain descending—do these have a mind for the things of all under Heaven? The way of emperors and kings should be thus. Hearing Shun’s words, Yao realized his former employment of mind was entangled and restless, mired in human effort and ignorant of Heaven’s virtue. Hence, he deemed Shun aligned with Heaven and himself aligned with man. Aligned with Heaven means being one with Heaven; aligned with man means being one with man. Heaven and Earth cover and bear the myriad things, their virtue extending everywhere. Those who would be emperors and kings must embody this. Even the Yellow Emperor, Yao, and Shun could not surpass the virtue of aligning with Heaven and Earth in their greatness.

**Xiang Dao’s Annotation:**
