"Not slighting the destitute... pitying women" is benevolence. "Heaven’s virtue emerging in tranquility... clouds moving and rain descending" is the Dao. Benevolence is human, yet nothing is left undone—hence "aligned with man." The Dao is Heaven, yet nothing is done—hence "aligned with Heaven." Yet Yao and Shun followed the same Dao. Yao practiced Heaven’s Dao but spoke of man; Shun practiced man’s Dao but spoke of Heaven. Practicing Heaven yet aligning with man, his virtue attained only the beauty of fulfillment. Practicing man yet aligning with Heaven, his achievement culminated in the greatness of radiance. "Entangled" describes its confinement; "restless" describes its movement.

**Bi Xu’s Annotation:**
"Not slighting the destitute, not abandoning the impoverished"—the heart of a benevolent person cannot surpass this. Shun deemed it flawed, for it had not yet transcended, hence not yet great. In Heaven’s virtue emerging in tranquility, human affairs are moved. The sequence of dusk and dawn, the constancy of opening and closing, the ascent and descent of qi in exchange—these are the virtues of Heaven and Earth. Yao realized his own conduct was entangled and restless, disordered and again disordered. Aligning with Heaven is without mind; aligning with man is with effort. Heaven and Earth are what the ancients deemed greatest. Those who rule all under Heaven simply embody them.

**Yong Qi’s Annotation:**
Heaven’s virtue is the virtue of spontaneity. "Emerging in tranquility" means acting without acting. The sun and moon shine, the four seasons proceed—all are natural movements, one aspect of non-action. Thus, day and night follow their constant course without error; clouds move and rain descends, shaping the myriad things. Those who would rule all under Heaven embody this to establish virtue, and the people all return to it; they expand it to transform things, and things all follow. At these words, Yao reflected and suddenly realized: his former conduct—entangled and restless—how far removed was Heaven’s alignment from man’s! Viewed thus, the virtues of Yao and Shun seem to have a distinction, yet concluding with what the Yellow Emperor, Yao, and Shun jointly admired, they merge indistinguishably. Such is the subtlety of *Nanhua*’s rhetoric—its rises and falls, openings and closings. Scholars who savor it deeply will grasp it for themselves.

Confucius wished to deposit his books in the Zhou archives. Zilu advised: "I have heard that the Zhou’s archivist, an elder named Lao Dan, has retired and lives at home. If you wish to deposit your books, Master, you might first visit him."
Confucius said: "Excellent."
He went to see Lao Dan, who refused. Thereupon, he expounded the Twelve Classics to persuade him.

Lao Dan, struck by his discourse, said: "Too verbose! I would hear its essence."
Confucius replied: "The essence lies in *ren* and *yi*."
Lao Dan asked: "May I ask—are *ren* and *yi* man’s inherent nature?"
Confucius said: "Indeed. The noble man who lacks *ren* cannot be perfected; without *yi*, he cannot live. *Ren* and *yi* are the true nature of the realized person! What more could one seek?"
Lao Dan said: "May I ask—what are *ren* and *yi*?"
Confucius replied: "Joy in all things from the heart, universal love without partiality—this is the essence of *ren* and *yi*."
Lao Dan said: "Your latter words nearly miss the mark. Is not universal love impractical? And ‘without partiality’—is that not itself partiality? If you, Master, wish to ensure the world does not lose its shepherds, then know: Heaven and Earth have their constancy, sun and moon their brightness, stars their constellations, beasts their herds, trees their standing. You, Master, should emulate virtue and follow the Dao in your conduct—this is already perfection. Why then clamorously brandish *ren* and *yi* like one beating a drum to seek a lost child? Alas! You, Master, confuse man’s nature!"

Guo’s commentary: "Joy in all things from the heart, universal love without partiality—this is what the common world calls *ren* and *yi*. Thus, the text borrows Confucius to let Laozi correct it. The utmost *ren* advances without love. What the world calls ‘without partiality’ is abandoning oneself to love others, desiring others’ love in return—this is extreme partiality, not the public-mindedness that forgets the public! From ‘Heaven and Earth have their constancy’ to ‘trees their standing’—all are self-sufficient, needing no universal love. Love arises as events demand, ceasing when *yi* is fulfilled—this is forgetting *ren* and *yi*. To dwell on them constantly is to disorder the true."

Lü’s commentary: "Confucius, unheeded in his time, wished to store his teachings to await later noble men. The Twelve Classics refer to the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, wherein Confucius’ way of ordering the world lies. Teaching the world through the human Dao, he concealed its subtle workings without ever speaking of them—thus, the Twelve Classics’ way of ordering the world reduces to *ren* and *yi* alone. Laozi, cutting off learning to return to simplicity, revealed the true—thus *ren* and *yi* were to be cast aside, and he rightly deemed them not man’s inherent nature. From the human Dao’s perspective, *ren* not only perfects oneself but also perfects things; *yi* not only benefits things but also establishes the self. The noble man’s life and completion lie in *ren* and *yi*, hence they are deemed the true nature of the realized person. From the true perspective of the Dao, joy in all things from the heart is not imposed from without—without things, there is no lack of joy. The highest *ren* acts without acting. Laozi’s words nearly approach the truth but fall short; his later words on universal love are mistaken. The Heavenly virtue emerges in tranquility, clouds drift and rain falls—this is why he deemed it impractical. All names arise from insufficiency—thus ‘without partiality’ is itself partiality. To wish the world not lose its shepherds is merely to assist the self-so of the myriad things. Heaven and Earth have constancy, trees their standing—this is what is meant by the self-so of things. Virtue is non-action; the Dao follows the natural. Why then clamorously act like one beating a drum to seek a lost child? This speaks of man’s loss of nature—it cannot be restored through *ren* and *yi*."

Yi Du’s commentary: "The *zhengcang* historian was the official in charge of storing books. Confucius, his Dao unfulfilled, wished to store his books in the Zhou archives to await later generations. At the time, Lao Dan had resigned and returned home. Confucius went to rely on him, but Lao Dan refused. Confucius had edited the *Odes*, settled the *Documents*, revised the *Rites* and *Music*, and composed the *Spring and Autumn Annals*—six classics—and expounded the *Changes* with six commentaries, making twelve classics in all. He expounded these to Lao Dan, who deemed them fragmented and overly cautious, wishing to hear their essence. Confucius answered that the essence lay in *ren* and *yi*. Lao Dan, roaming beyond the world’s bounds, held that *ren* and *yi* were not natural nature. Confucius, roaming within the world’s bounds, held that *ren* and *yi* were the true nature of the realized person. Man’s heart naturally desires all things to be joyful, universally loved without partiality—this is the natural sentiment of human nature, further clarifying that *ren* and *yi* arise from nature. Lao Dan said, ‘Alas! Your latter words nearly miss the mark.’ Universal love still implies attachment—it does not compare to the utmost love without love. ‘Without partiality’ still implies partiality—it does not compare to not knowing partiality as partiality. If you, Master, wish to ensure the world does not lose its nurture, it is better to let things follow their nature, so they love one another without knowing it as *ren*, befriend one another without knowing it as *yi*. From ‘Heaven and Earth have constancy’ to ‘trees their standing’—all are non-action and self-so, each fully realizing its nature. Emulating virtue without knowing virtue as virtue, following the Dao without knowing the Dao as Dao—why then clamorously brandish *ren* and *yi* in the world to seek the restoration of nature, no different from beating a drum to seek a lost child?"

Detailed Daoist commentary: "Laozi’s teaching takes the Dao and virtue as its foundation; Confucius’ classics take *ren* and *yi* as their root. Emulating virtue and following the Dao, the world attains nature through non-action; dwelling in *ren* and practicing *yi*, the world acts and betrays its nature. This is why Zhuangzi records Confucius’ advancement to clarify it. ‘Joy in all things from the heart’ is delighting in each thing. Universal love is *ren*; without partiality is *yi*. Universal love still excludes some—it is not the utmost *ren*. The utmost *ren* has no favorites. ‘Without partiality’ still fulfills partiality—it is not the utmost *yi*. The utmost *yi* does not regard things. Thus, the noble man values forgetting *ren* and *yi* to seek their utmost. Confucius once told Lao Dan: ‘I have studied the *Odes*, *Documents*, *Rites*, *Music*, *Changes*, and *Spring and Autumn Annals*—I have long considered myself accomplished.’ This reference to the Twelve Classics means doubling the Six Classics into twelve."

The *Bixu Commentary* states: Confucius wished to store his books, but Lao Dan would not permit it, saying that what had already been presented was like straw dogs—unworthy of preservation. The Six Classics, when expanded, become twelve. Supreme *ren* achieves completion through non-action; supreme *yi* reaches fulfillment without being enacted. To act by following one’s nature—how could this be artificial? Delighting in things (*wu kai*) means one has not yet forgotten emotion; being without partiality still leaves traces. The emotions of *ren* and *yi* are far removed from the Dao!

It is like the constancy of spring’s growth and autumn’s harvest, the alternation of day’s sun and night’s moon, the fixed array of stars traversing the heavens, the flocking of birds and herding of beasts, the rootedness of grasses and trees—one may imitate and follow these, but why exert oneself so anxiously? *Yongzhai* says: "He stored the books in the Western Zhou" refers to traveling west to Zhou to examine its archives. "Expanded" (*fan*) means to speak of them repeatedly. "Reaching the midpoint of his discourse" means that when Confucius had spoken only halfway, Laozi deemed his words too diffuse.

*Wu kai* means taking joy in things. "Later words" refers to shallow and superficial speech. *Ji* means peril. How can one practice universal love when things are unequal? This is a convoluted and impractical doctrine. As soon as one acquires the name of being without partiality, the notion of partiality arises in the heart. If one wishes the world to lack nothing in its nurturance, then every thing possesses its own natural creation—how can human effort intervene? One should merely emulate the virtue of nature and follow the Dao of nature, and thus attain it!

"Beating the drum to seek a runaway child" describes disturbing the common customs. Confucius, seeing the decline of the age and the obscurity of the Dao, wished to store his deluded books in Zhou’s archives to await a sage of later generations. Though compelled to entrust empty words to posterity to establish teachings, his resolve was earnest. Laozi’s refusal stemmed from shame: since the Dao was not practiced in his own time, what use were mere dregs?

The Twelve Classics are interpreted variously. Lu’s *Pronunciations and Meanings* in the old commentary lists the *Odes*, *Documents*, *Rites*, *Music*, *Changes*, and *Spring and Autumn Annals* as the Six Classics, adding the Six Wefts to make twelve. Another account includes the *Changes*’ upper and lower canons with the *Ten Wings*. Yet another claims the *Spring and Autumn Annals* of the Twelve Dukes were composed by Confucius. This last interpretation seems most plausible. In any case, these are metaphorical references meant to convey meaning, and one need not fixate on their enumeration.

"Reaching the midpoint of his discourse" means that when Confucius spoke, his words were merely verbose and not essential. Confucius said the essentials lie in *ren* and *yi*, which are the foremost principles for governing the world. Lao Dan countered that these are not inherent in human nature, for returning to simplicity and reverting to the root reveals the presence of the Dao and virtue. Confucius replied with "delighting in things from the heart." Lu’s *Pronunciations and Meanings* notes that *wu* was originally written as *wu* ("do not"), and this reading is adopted here. The word *zhong* ("heart") should be pronounced in the departing tone, so that one is neither centered nor resentful. Thus, universal love without partiality constitutes the emotions of *ren* and *yi*.

Lao Dan said: "Perilous are words that fall short"—this is why they are distant from the Dao. Precisely because one is without partiality, one fulfills partiality. If one wishes the world to lack nothing in its nurturance, then heaven and earth, sun and stars, birds and beasts, grasses and trees—none fail to follow their natures and fulfill their proper places. When humans let virtue flow freely and follow the Dao, it is no different. Why then exert effort in *ren* and *yi*, like beating a drum to seek a lost child, which yields no result?

Shi Chengqi met Laozi and asked: "I have heard that you, Master, are a sage. I did not hesitate to travel a great distance, wishing to see you, journeying a hundred stages with calloused feet and never daring to rest. Now I observe you, and you are no sage. You have surplus grain in your rat holes yet discard your younger sister—this is not *ren*. Before you, cooked and raw foods are not exhausted, yet you hoard without limit." Laozi remained silent and did not respond.

The next day, Shi Chengqi met him again and said: "Yesterday, I criticized you, but now my heart has corrected itself. Why is this?" Laozi replied: "Those who are artfully wise and spiritually sagely—I consider myself beyond such things. In the past, when you called me an ox, you took me for an ox; when you called me a horse, you took me for a horse. If something truly possesses a reality, and others give it a name but one does not accept it, one incurs misfortune twice over. I wear what I wear, but I do not wear it because it is wearable."

Shi Chengqi walked like a crow, avoiding his shadow, and advanced to ask: "How should one cultivate the self?" Laozi said: "Your demeanor is haughty, your gaze piercing, your forehead lofty, your mouth gaping, your appearance stern—you resemble a horse reined in. When you move, you restrain; when you act, you are like a crossbow’s trigger. When you observe, you scrutinize; when you know, you are clever but see only excess. All this is to lack trustworthiness. At the borderlands, there is a man called Thief."

Laozi said: "The Dao is not exhausted in the great nor neglected in the small, so all things are complete within it. Vast is its capacity to embrace all; profound is its unfathomability. Forms, virtue, *ren*, and *yi* are the mere tips of spirit—who but the perfected person can stabilize them? The perfected person possesses the world—is this not grand? Yet it is not enough to burden him. Though the world strives and struggles, he does not join them; though he discerns no reliance, he does not shift for profit. He exhausts the truth of things and preserves their root, thus transcending heaven and earth, forgetting the myriad things, and his spirit is never troubled.

"In penetrating the Dao and uniting with virtue, he retreats from *ren* and *yi* and sets aside rites and music—thus the perfected person’s heart is settled." Guo’s commentary states: "Surplus grain in rat holes" means he does not cherish things. "Discarding his younger sister" means lacking familial affection. "Cooked and raw foods not exhausted before him" means he is utterly sufficient, hence always has surplus. All things return to his embrace, and whatever comes, he receives—he does not set narrow boundaries. His self-reproach for mockery and criticism is what startles. *Tuo* means "to have passed beyond." Calling him an ox or a horse follows whatever name things are given.

Possessing reality, he does not let praise or blame weigh upon his heart. If he were to receive them in his heart, both name and reality would become burdens—thus he would suffer calamity.

*Fu* means the bearing of one’s conduct. Not allowing praise or blame to bring calamity upon himself, he remains unchanged in his demeanor. If he were to act with deliberate effort, he could not maintain this constancy.

*Yairan* describes restless haste in advancing. *Chong* means "to emerge." *Erán* reveals what is manifest. *Quērán* is an open, gaping appearance. *Yìrán* is the look of one lifting the brows and staring with pride.

His will is set on swift movement, never at ease or unrestrained. His choices and rejections are rapid, his judgment clear and decisive—thus he is able to settle the hearts of all under heaven.

*The Ocean of Meanings in the True Scripture of Southern Florescence*, Scroll Forty-Two, concludes.

Scroll Forty-Three of *The Ocean of Meanings in the True Scripture of Southern Florescence*
Compiled by the Daoist of Wulin, Chu Boxiu

**Heavenly Dao, Chapter Four**

What the world values as the Dao are books, yet books are nothing more than words, and words have their own value. What is valued in words is meaning, and meaning follows something beyond. What meaning follows cannot be transmitted through speech, yet the world clings to antiquity and venerates transmitted texts. Though the world holds them in esteem, they are still not truly worthy of esteem, for what is esteemed is not what ought to be esteemed.

What can be seen at a glance are forms and colors; what can be heard are names and sounds. Alas! The world takes forms, colors, names, and sounds as sufficient to grasp the true nature of things, yet forms, colors, names, and sounds are fundamentally insufficient to grasp that nature. Thus, the wise do not speak, and those who speak are not wise—how could the world recognize this?

Duke Huan was reading in the hall. Below, Wheelwright Bian was carving a wheel. Setting aside his mallet and chisel, he ascended and asked the Duke: "May I ask, what words are contained in what Your Lordship reads?" The Duke replied: "The words of sages." Bian said: "Are the sages still alive?" The Duke said: "They are already dead." Bian said: "Then what Your Lordship reads are but the dregs of the ancients!" The Duke said: "How dare a wheelwright comment on what I read? If you have an explanation, speak; if not, you die." Wheelwright Bian said: "Your servant observes this from his own craft. When carving a wheel, if done too slowly, it is smooth but not firm; if too swiftly, it is rough and does not fit. Neither too slow nor too swift—it is grasped by the hand and responds to the heart. The mouth cannot express it, yet a certain art resides within. I cannot make my son understand it, nor can my son receive it from me. Thus, though I am seventy years old, I still carve wheels in my old age. The ancients, along with what could not be transmitted, are dead. What Your Lordship reads are but the lees and husks of the ancients!"

Guo’s commentary: What is truly valuable lies beyond words and meaning. Thus, only those who forget speech and abandon books can grasp the true nature of things. Wheelwright Bian’s inability to instruct his son shows that each thing has its own nature, and teaching is of no avail. The affairs of the ancients have perished in the present; even if transmitted, how could they make the past live again? The past does not exist in the present, and present affairs have already changed. Therefore, one must abandon learning, follow one’s nature, and adapt to the times to attain the Way.

Lü’s commentary: Zhuangzi speaks thus to urge scholars to forget words and books and not seek the Dao amid forms, colors, names, and sounds. Even in wheel-carving, a coarse craft, the balance of swiftness and slowness, the smoothness and roughness grasped by the hand and responding to the heart—even father and son cannot transmit or receive this. How much more difficult is it to transmit the Dao! If one cannot seek it in the heart but only reads books, then the metaphor of lees and husks is no empty word.

Yi Du’s commentary: The *Book of Changes* says: "Books do not exhaust speech, and speech does not exhaust meaning." Thus, what books record are but traces. The world believes books suffice to encompass the Dao, but this is ignorance of the Dao. Those who speak all value meaning, yet meaning follows the Dao without end. If speech cannot transmit it, how can books be worthy of esteem? What the world values is not what ought to be valued.

What cannot be spoken is the whole of the Dao; what can be spoken is but a fragment. The Dao arises naturally from the spontaneity of life and destiny. It must be met in formlessness, followed to its utmost principle, heard in silence, and seen in obscurity. Yet the world, confounding the constant nature of spontaneity, seeks the stale traces of former kings—striving further, they lose further.

The ears and eyes perceive only forms, colors, names, and sounds; the same is true of books. Yet the world, deluded and losing its nature, takes forms, colors, names, and sounds as sufficient to grasp the true nature of things—how lamentable! If one could forget forms, colors, names, and sounds, abandon speech and books, follow the heart, and meet with meaning, then the supreme principles of heaven and earth, the great truths of life and destiny, could be known without words.

Wheelwright Bian, seeing Duke Huan deluded by the stale traces of former kings and ignorant of the root of the great Dao, used the craft of wheel-carving to enlighten him. It lies in following principle without losing one’s nature. Neither too swift nor too slow, grasped by the hand and responding to the heart—this is the natural principle residing within. The mouth cannot express it, hence he could not instruct his son and carved wheels into old age. Wheel-carving is but a minor skill, yet even it cannot be transmitted through words—how much less can one seek the Dao in books? Only the adept scholar reads books to seek their meaning, discards their traces, and meets with their heart, thus avoiding Wheelwright Bian’s rebuke.

Xiang Dao’s commentary: Words in books relate to meaning as forms, colors, names, and sounds relate to true nature. True nature cannot be grasped through forms, colors, names, and sounds, nor can meaning be transmitted through words in books—this is certain! Thus, the adept in the *Book of Changes* grasps meaning and forgets images, grasps images and forgets words. The adept in the *Book of Odes* grasps intent and forgets phrases, grasps phrases and forgets lines. Is this not what is meant by discarding sacrificial straw dogs after the ritual, or casting away dregs to keep the pure wine? It was through Wheelwright Bian that Duke Huan awakened to the futility of reading books, just as Wang Shou, through Xu Feng, rose to dance and burn his books.

Bi Xu’s commentary: The ancients are gone, leaving only their words in books—how can these be worthy of esteem? It is like describing the five flavors: one can only speak of their forms, colors, names, and sounds, but the tastes of sweetness and bitterness can never be conveyed. Abandon forms, colors, names, and sounds, and the wise do not speak—thus one attains it. Wheelwright Bian’s hand responding to his heart, his ineffable skill—this is the art residing within, the reason he practiced it all his life. As years change with time, the Dao renews daily. When the ancients spoke of this, they could not but sigh with emotion.

Yongzhai’s words: Books can convey the Dao, which is why they are valued—the value lies in the Dao, not in the books.

To speak in terms of the Dao is why such words are esteemed, yet what is esteemed lies in the meaning, not in the words. Where meaning directs, words cannot convey it—thus neither words nor books are worthy of esteem. Forms and colors may be seen, names and sounds may be heard, but the Dao cannot be seen or heard. That世人 seek its reality through forms, colors, names, and sounds is truly lamentable!

This passage elucidates the earlier idea, illustrating with exquisite analogy that the Dao cannot be transmitted through words. Books record the words of the ancients, but when the ancients are gone, how can what they could not convey be obtained? Does the guest in the brewery know the taste of wine? Tracks are what shoes produce, yet tracks are not shoes. Books are where the Dao resides, yet books are not the Dao. The enlightened use books to clarify the Dao; the deluded abandon the Dao to seek books. Thus, Duke Huan was drowned in stale words, while Wheelwright Bian could advance his persuasion.

Using the coarse to illustrate the refined, drawing principles from concrete affairs—there is nothing that is not the Dao. The crafting of a new wheel involves selecting wood and applying skill to bear weight and travel far, a metaphor for embracing the Dao and holding virtue to benefit the world. The marvel of his axe-work, responding to his heart with his hands, could not be passed even from father to son. The measures of round and square, long and short, the rhythms of swift and slow, the nuances of sweet and bitter—all arise naturally, beyond the reach of words or books. How much less can the Dao of gods and emperors, which gives birth to heaven and earth, be exhausted in writing?

Bian devoted his life to this wheel—not to toil over hammer and chisel, straining sinew and bone, but to advance his skill through the Dao, uniting heaven with heaven. Grasping the essence of wheel-making, he expended little effort yet achieved much, and so followed it all his life without abandon. Extending this principle to books presents no difficulty.

Duke Huan, fixated on traces and neglecting the heart, declared the sages dead, allowing Bian to exhaust his words and correct his error. What the sages and worthies studied was the Dao; what they transmitted was the heart. If one grasps the heart, one knows the undying remains—this Dao can be attained in stillness, how could it lie in the clamorous dregs of paper?

This reveals that the sages and worthies spoke and wrote out of necessity, and *Nanhua* uses this to dispel the world’s attachment to images and clinging to texts. If scholars can truly see the moon and forget the finger, restoring their primordial nature, then looking back at those who clutch their books, they will not deign even to laugh. This passage’s intent resembles the "Butcher Ding" chapter, though it lacks Duke Huan’s acknowledgment—leaving this phrase for later generations, who will surely take it up.

This section is titled *The Dao of Heaven*, prominently displayed at its head. Next, it discusses the sagely Dao of emperors and kings, the undertakings of mysterious sages and plain kings, with virtue and power as the foundation, and the constancy of non-action—this is the Dao of riding heaven and earth, driving the myriad things, and employing the human and earthly. Within it, the tools of governance—virtue, teaching, ritual, music, benevolence, righteousness, division of duties, forms and names, rewards and punishments—are all complete, yet none depart from the constancy of the human Dao.

Why? Those who discourse well on the Dao of Heaven must root it in the human; those who fully realize the human Dao may match Heaven. Heaven and humanity communicate, root and branch are one, vast and all-embracing, deep and unfathomable—how can one know that Heaven is not human, or human not Heaven? As for the five transformations where forms and names may be raised, or the nine transformations where rewards and punishments may be spoken—these are unchanging principles for all ages, the means by which human standards exalt the Dao of Heaven.

When Heaven’s virtue emerges in tranquility, the sun and moon shine and the four seasons proceed, like the constancy of day and night, the movement of clouds and the descent of rain—Heaven acts of itself, radiant and uniquely transformative. How could the Dao of Earth or the Dao of Humanity not follow? Governing tools are cultivated to order the Dao, a general discussion of the Dao through the ages. Yet some use them to bring order, others to bring chaos, for they do not know the sequence of root and branch, priority and posteriority, or the proper balance of ruler and minister.

The world claims *Nanhua*’s teachings favor non-action and neglect governing tools, but observing the rituals, music, and political teachings expounded here—profound and subtle—none of the other masters can compare. All arise from the natural principles of Heaven, merely enacted through humanity. Truly understanding natural principles, one can use governing tools to penetrate the Dao of governance, so that ruler and minister, father and son, birds and beasts, grasses and trees all find their proper place. The world sings and plays *ji rang*, unaware of imperial influence—this is what is called non-action.

As for Confucius wishing to hide books and unraveling the classics to expound, or Cheng Qi asking about self-cultivation while his demeanor remained haughty—these were cases of clinging to humanity and forgetting Heaven, which Lao Dan did not approve. Only the perfected know benevolence and righteousness as the branches of the Dao, ritual and music as its guests. They can be Heaven and be human, upholding constancy and guarding the root, their spirit never troubled. Though the world exists, it does not burden them.

The conclusion, through Wheelwright Bian’s analogy of books and dregs, warns scholars not to chase traces and neglect the heart, pursuing the branch and forsaking the root, thus drifting ever farther from the Dao. One should investigate what the sages left that does not perish. Scholars should sever learning to enter transmission, and transmitters should attain the transmission beyond transmission—then the hearts of Heaven, Earth, and the sages will be revealed. Why cling to the dregs of the ancients?

The forty-third scroll of *The Ocean of Meanings in the True Scripture of Southern Florescence* concludes.

**Note 1:** The character "古" (*ancient*) in the original is rendered as "今" (*present*) in Zhao Jianyi’s edition.
**Note 2:** Guo Xiang’s commentary originally used "古" (*ancient*), but it was later altered to "今" (*present*).

**The forty-fourth scroll of *The Ocean of Meanings in the True Scripture of Southern Florescence***
*Compiled by Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin*

**Heavenly Revolution (Chapter One)**

Does Heaven revolve? Does Earth abide?
Do the sun and moon contend for their places?
Who governs and sustains this?
Who binds and upholds this?
Who, dwelling in non-action, propels and enacts this?
Is there some mechanism, sealed and inescapable?
Or does it turn ceaselessly, unable to halt itself?

Do clouds give rise to rain? Does rain give rise to clouds?
Who bestows and dispenses this?
Who, dwelling in non-action, indulges in excess yet urges this on?

The wind rises from the north, now west, now east,
now soaring, now wandering—who breathes and draws this in?
Who, dwelling in non-action, spreads and scatters this?

I venture to ask: what is the reason for all this?

Wu Xian of the Shao lineage declared: Come, let me tell you.

Heaven possesses the Six Ultimates and the Five Constants. Should emperors and kings align with them, there is order; should they defy them, there is calamity. The affairs of the *Nine* and the *Luo*—when governance is perfected and virtue complete—illumine and oversee the earth below, and all under heaven bear them aloft. This is called the Supreme August.

Guo Xiang’s commentary: Heaven does not revolve yet moves of itself; Earth does not abide yet rests of itself; the sun and moon do not contend for their places yet alternate and pass away of themselves. Who governs and sustains this? Who binds and upholds this? If there is nothing, then nothing can propel it; if there is something, each has its own affairs. Then who, dwelling in non-action, propels and enacts this? Each moves of itself—it cannot be known.

Clouds and rain cannot give rise to one another; each is so of itself. If one asks why they are so of themselves, for proximate affairs of things, one may know the reason, yet when tracing origins to the ultimate, there is no reason—they are simply so of themselves. Learned posturing may change, but Heaven’s nature cannot be defied!

Lü Huiqing’s commentary: Heaven’s revolution, Earth’s abiding—I know not their true revolution or true abiding. The sun and moon contending for their places—I know not their true contention. Seeking what gives rise, binds, upholds, or propels and enacts this—all prove unattainable. Is there some mechanism, sealed and inescapable? Or does it turn ceaselessly, unable to halt itself? This I cannot know.

Water ascends to become clouds; clouds disperse to become rain. Seeking what bestows and dispenses this, or what, dwelling in non-action, indulges in excess yet urges this on—proves unattainable. The wind rises from the west, now east, now wandering without fixed course. Seeking what breathes and draws this in, or what, dwelling in non-action, spreads and scatters this—proves unattainable. This is the unfathomable Dao manifesting as the numinous! To know the numinous in its workings is to see that what governs, sustains, bestows, and scatters—all arise from this alone.

The Five Constants are the Five Fortunes. Employing the Five Fortunes brings authority; employing the Six Ultimates brings awe. Aligning with them brings fortune; defying them brings calamity. The *Nine* and the *Luo* refer to the *Luo Scripture* and the *Nine Categories*. When the application of the Nine Categories reaches its utmost in fortune and extremity, governance is perfected and virtue complete. Illumining and overseeing the earth below, all under heaven bear them aloft—this is how the Supreme August is attained.

The Supreme August grasps Heaven and Earth, drives the sun and moon, bestows clouds and rain, breathes and draws in the winds and qi, yet ever dwells in the realm of non-action. Must one seek this in the primordial age of remote antiquity?

Lin Yidu’s commentary: Heaven, round, moves of itself—does it act with intent to revolve? Earth, square, rests of itself—does it act with intent to abide? The sun and moon come and go without cessation—thus they do not contend. Heaven’s revolution—who governs and directs it? Earth’s abiding—who binds and upholds it? The sun and moon’s coming and going—who, dwelling in non-action, propels and enacts this? All are so of themselves—how could there be agency in their midst?

Is there necessarily some mechanism, turning ceaselessly yet unable to halt itself? Heaven and Earth are form; revolution and turning are the Dao. The movement of the mechanism is neither compelled nor voluntary. The qi of yin and yang, when pent up, becomes clouds. Rain is the harmony of yin and yang. Clouds bring forth rain, yet there are times they cannot. Clouds becoming rain, rain becoming clouds—who initiates or ceases this? Who, dwelling in non-action, indulges in excess yet urges this on? All is unknowable—they simply are so of themselves!

Heaven generates water in the north, thus the wind rises from the north, now east, now west, soaring and wandering above. Who breathes and draws this in, or spreads and scatters it to make it so? The Six Ultimates are the four directions, above and below. The Five Constants are the Five Phases. All arise naturally, their reasons unknown. Should emperors and kings align with their principles, there is order; should they defy them, there is calamity.

The *Nine* and *Luo* refer to the nine regions and their settlements. This speaks of the emperor’s virtue broadly bestowed, distant peoples at peace, as the sun and moon illumine and oversee the earth below—all under heaven bear them aloft. Delighting in governance, at ease in life, the people’s nature returns to simplicity, as in the age of the Supreme August.

Chen Xiangdao’s commentary: Heaven and Earth’s revolution and abiding, the sun and moon’s coming and going—clouds emerge from Earth yet root in Heaven; rain descends from Heaven yet roots in Earth; the wind blows straight from the east yet arises from the north. Their covering and bearing, their illumining and overseeing, their scattering and moistening—is any of this willed? All is borne by the Dao’s spontaneity!

Now, the wild horses of the plains drift yet do not move; whirlwinds topple mountains yet remain still; rivers rush yet do not flow; the sun and moon traverse the heavens yet do not circle. Thus, Heaven and Earth’s revolution and abiding arise from their non-revolution and non-abiding; the sun and moon’s coming and going arise from their non-coming and non-going. Truly, who can fathom what governs and sustains this? Who knows what is meant by a true master?

Chen Bixu’s commentary: The qi of purity and subtlety revolves without cease; the forms of heaviness and turbidity never fail to rest. The essences of water and fire mutually ascend and descend. If there were one who governed and sustained, it would be laborious; if there were a mechanism turning ceaselessly, it would be contrived.

Rain transforms through clouds, thus rain emerges from Earth; clouds unite through qi, thus clouds emerge from Heaven. The clear and turbid qi of the human body are likewise. Thus, clouds do not become rain, rain does not become clouds—the principle of mutual aid is obscure, its workings hidden. How could there be an agent?

Clouds bestow of themselves; rain indulges of itself. If there were one who urged this on, it would be partial; if there were one who breathed and scattered, it would be ruinous. The six qi—cold, heat, dryness, dampness, wind, and fire—when extreme, transform. Thus they are called the Six Ultimates. The Five Phases—Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, Earth—when constant, transform. Thus they are called the Five Constants. When qi harmonizes, teaching is perfected; when phases clash, governance fails.

The *Nine* and *Luo* refer to the *Luo Scripture* and the *Nine Categories*—what the *Great Plan* sets forth.

When the ruler attains the *Nine Categories* of the *Great Plan*, the constant norms are rightly ordered, the Five Blessings spread, and the people submit. When the ruler loses the *Nine Categories* of the *Great Plan*, the constant norms are disordered, the Six Ultimates harm, and the people rebel. Neither submission nor rebellion—allowing things to be as they are—could this not be called the governance of the Supreme Sovereigns?

Lin’s *Jiang’s Exegesis from Yong Studio* states: The heavens move in a daily circuit—does this arise from their own motion? The earth has fourfold movement—does it remain fixed in place? The sun departs, the moon arrives, like men contending and seizing—hence it is called "strife." Their governance and maintenance all imply exertion. "Not of necessity, not of oneself"—this means it does not depend on another.

Heavenly qi descends; earthly qi ascends—thus they become clouds and rain. But who knows whether rain arises from clouds or clouds from rain? *Longshi* means "to act" or "to cease." *Yin* means "to indulge." *Le* means "play." Who would engage in such indulgent play to assist in the formation of clouds and rain? The heavens’ form leans toward the north, so winds come from the north, wandering east and west, up and down, scattering and swaying.

The question does not name a speaker—another shift in stylistic technique. The Six Ultimates are the six qi; the Five Constants are the Five Phases. All these are the principles of nature. The *Nine* and *Luo* refer to the九州 settlements—ancient texts use them interchangeably.

When the emperor-kings follow the principles of nature to govern the Nine Provinces, their achievements are complete, their virtue perfected. They illuminate the world, and all people bear them aloft—such were the men above the Three Sovereigns.

Chu’s *Superficial Observations* says: The heavens’ motion, the earth’s position, the sun’s departure, the moon’s arrival—these are known to all. Yet how they move, remain, depart, and arrive is unknown. Who governs and maintains this? Does some mechanism drive them, turning without cease? The heavens and earth are but things—the greatest in the void. Things move, yet what compels them? Men dwell between them yet do not perceive it, like ants on a millstone, unaware of their own rotation.

Do clouds arise to become rain, or does rain form from clouds? And the winds—east, west, up, down—who slackens or quickens their breath? The above are all questioning phrases, omitting the interrogator. Some consider this a variant of Zhuangzi’s style, unbound by conventional forms.

The interpretations of the Six Ultimates and Five Constants vary, but the *Great Plan*’s Six Ultimates and Five Blessings provide the proper explanation. Following them brings order; opposing them brings chaos—this is the division between rightly ordered and disordered norms. The *Nine Categories* refer to the affairs of the *Luo Scripture*. When emperor-kings act according to this principle, their governance is perfected, their virtue complete. They illuminate the Six Directions, and the world bears them aloft, achieving a people’s purity, material abundance, and the joy of great peace—none surpassed the governance of the Three Sovereigns of antiquity.

Note: This response seems unrelated to the question, yet upon examination, its intent aligns with the Way of governance. Ascending to the level of the Supreme Sovereigns means ruler and people each abide in their natural roles, human affairs fulfilled and Heaven’s principles unimpeded.

Dubi’s Annotation: Where there is benevolence, there are boundaries; thus, there is partiality and love. If partial love is called benevolence, then tigers and wolves also have partial love—why are they not benevolent? When asked about perfect benevolence, the answer is "no partiality," allowing the spontaneity of nature and destiny. Though there may be kinship, one does not recognize it as such.

The Grand Steward says: Where there is partiality, there is love; from love arises filial piety. Now, if perfect benevolence has no partiality, then there is no filial piety. Zhuangzi speaks of its root—excessive filial piety. The Grand Steward speaks of its expression—falling short.

Dark Mountain is a metaphor for the Dao, here used to illustrate filial piety, for those who die for filial piety stray far from the Dao’s root. Reverence resides in appearance; love emerges from the heart. To forget kinship is to forget one’s love and thus love all without distinction. Though one may forget kinship, kin cannot forget me—thus my filial piety still bears a flaw.

What lies within me is easily forgotten; what lies in others is difficult to transform. If one can make kin forget me but cannot also make the world forget, one remains encumbered. Only by making the world forget as well—each following the spontaneity of their nature and destiny, kinship unrecognized as kinship, love unrecognized as love—can one attain the Dao.

When the Dao is perfected to the point that virtue surpasses Yao and Shun, then non-action is achieved. Thus, benefits flow for ten thousand generations, yet the world does not know—how could this be mere sighs of praise for benevolence and filial piety? Indeed, benevolence and filial piety are not worth mentioning.

Filial piety, fraternal duty, benevolence, righteousness—these eight are all things men strive to perform, laboring their virtue. They are not the natural expression of virtue, hence the Dao’s dispersal. How could they be the most noble, the richest, the most desired?

State ranks are abolished—none are ranked, yet all remain natural. State wealth is abandoned—one discards the world like worn-out sandals. Fame and reputation are set aside—what one desires is to emulate Confucius. If so, then one abides in the Dao without change!

Detailed Annotation on the Dao: Fierce beasts do not lose their kin; stinging insects do not harm their loved ones. Thus, men’s partial love, called benevolence, is no more than this. Heaven and earth treat the myriad things as straw dogs, yet the myriad things nurture themselves. The sage treats the hundred clans as straw dogs, yet the hundred clans fulfill themselves. If one clings to traces of benevolence and love, delighting in favors and pleasures, one gains this but loses that, benefits one but neglects a hundred.

Mired in the traces of benevolence and love, one does not understand that the sage’s "non-benevolence" is the perfection of benevolence. Benevolence arises from filial piety; filial piety arises from love. From love to perfect filial piety, love is no longer worth mentioning. From filial piety to perfect benevolence, filial piety is no longer worth mentioning.

The so-called "perfection of benevolence"—how could it be merely the discourse of "surpassing filial piety" or "falling short of filial piety"? Yet the Grand Steward, taking filial piety and love as the perfection of benevolence, is deluded indeed! Traveling south from the northernmost Dark Mountain to observe, even upon reaching Deng, Dark Mountain grows ever more distant—this illustrates that the perfection of benevolence, being without partiality, cannot be spoken of in terms of filial piety and love. Once filial piety and love are established, the perfection of benevolence recedes.

The perfection of cap-wearing is not merely forgetting one’s kin, but causing one’s kin to forget oneself, thereby leaving behind the supreme virtue of Yao and Shun without acting, and forgetting the world entirely. Benefiting and nourishing all generations without awareness—this is the world forgetting oneself. In this way, benevolence is ever in surplus, and love does not arise from insufficiency. How could one merely sigh and speak of benevolence and filial piety? Sighing arises from insufficiency.

Master Bixu notes: The perfection of benevolence does not merely cherish its own kin, thus approaching impartiality—yet it is not truly without partiality. To speak of filial piety is to imply self-interest; self-interest is not the perfection of filial piety. Reverence pertains to outward form; love, to inner sincerity. Having intent makes it easy; having no mind makes it difficult. Practicing filial piety while the child takes no note is easy; providing care while the parent takes no account is difficult. Virtue extending to one household is easy; transforming the entire world is difficult. Forgetting others, forgetting transformation—this is called "total forgetting." The governance of total forgetting is the perfection of governance.

The kingly man regards sagely virtue as chaff and husks, treating the hundred clans as straw dogs, yet the practice of benevolence and filial piety never departs for even a moment—it is merely the cultivation of virtue and self-exhortation, not the seeking of recognition. The perfection of nobility: when virtue is complete, carriages and caps cannot sway the heart, thus state ranks are discarded. The perfection of wealth: when contentment is known, gold and jade cannot alter one’s resolve, thus state treasures are discarded. The perfection of aspiration: when self-sufficiency is attained, right and wrong cannot change one’s nature, thus fame and reputation are discarded. This is the unwavering adherence to the Dao.

Yongzhai observes: Tigers and wolves possess benevolence, and even bandits share something of the Dao’s intent. Though these critiques dismiss Confucian teachings, they hold their own reason. The perfection of benevolence is without partiality: to be partial yet unaware of partiality is the perfection of benevolence. "Filial piety is insufficient" does not mean one is unfilial—rather, filial piety transcends speech. The perfection of benevolence stands above filial piety, thus surpassing it. The Grand Steward’s question, however, speaks of falling short of filial piety.

Reverent filial piety still admits of progress; loving filial piety reaches mutual forgetting, extending to the forgetting of kin and the forgetting of the world—all signify that traces are inferior to no path, and having a mind is inferior to having no mind. Abandoning the virtue of Yao and Shun without acting, benefiting all generations without awareness—how could one sigh and boast of benevolence and filial piety? Filial piety and fraternal duty, even to the point of incorruptibility, are deemed fine virtues by the world, yet they are merely mutual encouragement to self-imposed hardship, not worth exalting.

What need has my perfection of nobility for state ranks? What need has my perfection of wealth for state treasures? What need has my perfection of aspiration for fame and reputation? Thus, all are cast aside—this is the unchanging adherence to the Dao, the natural course. The preceding eight are all forms of self-enslavement through action, while I remain ever without action.

Tigers and wolves, though utterly vicious, may be called benevolent for their parental affection—this is the world’s view of benevolence as partial love. Thus, the Perfected One, responding to the question, spoke in correction. The Grand Steward, doubting this was benevolence, asked about the perfection of benevolence. The answer—"the perfection of benevolence is without partiality"—how grand these words! Alas, the Grand Steward could not grasp them, ultimately reducing benevolence to partial love and further grounding benevolence in filial piety, failing to recognize the exalted nature of the perfection of benevolence. Filial piety, being insufficient to encompass it, is thus deemed "falling short." Traveling south without seeing Dark Mountain illustrates how partial love distances one from benevolence.

Reverent filial piety focuses on appearance; loving filial piety arises from the heart. Forgetting kin allows one to serve them appropriately, without difficulty. Causing kin to forget oneself removes their concerns, and action requires no further progress. Forgetting the world means transforming with it; the world forgetting oneself means transformation becomes imperceptible—like the spring wind and summer rain nurturing the myriad things without claiming credit. This is the perfection of benevolence and filial piety.

Thus, leaving behind the virtue of Yao and Shun without acting, like dust, chaff, and husks, is sufficient to mold even Yao and Shun. Benefiting all generations without awareness, one’s merit covering the world yet seeming not one’s own—how could one then sigh and speak of benevolence and filial piety? For to grasp the essence is to render words unnecessary.

The world esteems the eight virtues—filial piety, fraternal duty, incorruptibility, and purity—as fine, yet they are but self-imposed hardship! Cultivating the Dao to its perfection, one attains the perfection of nobility, wealth, and aspiration. Looking back, state ranks, treasures, and reputation are cast aside like the Dao’s non-action compared to the self-enslavement of the eight. This Dao spans ancient and present, never changing—this is why it is the perfection of nobility, wealth, and the ultimate aspiration of all.

**Heaven’s Motion (Part Two)**

Beigong Cheng asked the Yellow Emperor, saying: "When Your Majesty performed the music of *Xianchi* upon the wilds of Dongting, at first I heard it and was afraid; then I heard it again and was at ease; but when I heard it to the end, I was bewildered. Vast and silent, I could not find myself."

The Emperor said: "You were nearly so! I performed it with human affairs, harmonized it with Heaven, conducted it with ritual and righteousness, and established it upon the Great Purity. For the supreme music first responds to human matters, accords with Heaven’s principles, proceeds through the Five Virtues, and answers to nature. Only then does it regulate the four seasons and bring all things into perfect harmony.

The four seasons arise in succession, and the myriad things follow their birth. Now flourishing, now declining, their patterns of civil and martial order are constant. Now clear, now turbid, yin and yang are balanced, their sounds flowing like light. When the creatures of the earth first stir, I startle them with thunder; its end has no tail, its beginning no head. Now death, now life; now stillness, now motion—ever without limit, yet never to be awaited. This is why you were afraid.

Then I performed it with the harmony of yin and yang, illumined it with the brightness of sun and moon. Its sounds could be short or long, soft or hard; transformed yet unified, unbound by fixed custom. In valleys, it filled the valleys; in pits, it filled the pits. Stopping up the senses to guard the spirit, it took things as its measure. Its tones were vast and unbounded, its name lofty and bright. Thus do ghosts and spirits keep to their hidden realms, while sun, moon, and stars follow their courses.

I halted it at the finite, yet let it flow into the infinite. You sought to ponder it but could not know it; to gaze upon it but could not see it; to pursue it but could not reach it. Suddenly you stood upon the Way of the fourfold void, leaning on a withered catalpa and chanting. You knew your desires were exhausted, your strength spent in pursuit—how could I not have surpassed you? When form fills emptiness, it becomes pliable and yielding. You yielded, and so were at ease.

Then I performed it with the sound of no-rest, attuned it to the mandate of nature. It seemed to mingle with the spontaneous growth of things, a music of the forest without form. It spread and swayed without trailing, dark and obscure yet soundless. Moving without direction, dwelling in profound obscurity—some call it death, some life; some call it substance, some glory. It flows and scatters, unbound by constant sound. The world doubts it, so they consult the sages.

The sage is one who penetrates to the truth of things and fulfills their destiny. The heavenly mechanism is not set in motion, yet the five senses are all complete—this is called the music of Heaven, which delights the heart without words. Thus the clans of old composed this ode:

*Listening, you hear no sound;
Gazing, you see no form.
Filling heaven and earth,
Enveloping the six directions.*

You wished to hear it but found no point of contact—this is why you were bewildered.

Music begins with fear, and fear gives rise to reverence. Then I followed it with weariness, and weariness leads to withdrawal. Finally, it ends in confusion, and confusion leads to foolishness. Foolishness leads to the Way. The Way can be carried and shared.

Guo’s commentary: "Not finding oneself" means sitting in forgetfulness. From this we know that supreme music is not mere sound. It first accords with Heaven, responds to man, is grasped by the heart, and suits the nature. Only then is it expressed in sound and performed in melody. Thus the music of *Xianchi* could only be completed after the transformation of the Yellow Emperor.

The natural pitch-pipes fill heaven and earth. If one follows them without seizing control, the supreme music is complete. Thus one employs their spontaneous movement, turning without limit and taking change as the constant. At first, hearing its boundless transformations, one cannot await it with singleness—hence the trembling awe. Performing it with yin and yang, illumining it with sun and moon, is to employ the Way of Heaven. Unified in transformation yet unbound by fixed custom, it fills valleys and pits without exception. Stopping up the senses to guard the spirit, the great system remains uncut. When name matches reality, it is lofty and bright. Thus ghosts and spirits do not leave their places, and sun and stars do not stray from their courses. Halted at the finite, it yet dwells at the utmost limit; flowing into the infinite, it follows change wherever it goes. Pondering it, you cannot know it; pursuing it, you cannot reach it. Darkly it lets transformations take their course, vast and boundless, leaving nothing more to be done.

The knowledge and strength of things each have their limits. When form fills emptiness, there is no self—hence one yields to nature, and the fear and awe subside. Having subsided, one attains the state beyond weariness—this is its perfection. All that the mandate encompasses is but nature. Mingled without attachment, it arises in due course. Fitting within the body, it has no separate form. Spreading without trailing, dark and obscure yet soundless—this is the supreme music. Moving without direction, dwelling in profound obscurity—this is the ultimate tranquility. Death and life, substance and glory, change with things. This shows that the sage responds to the world without initiating, so that all with feeling and destiny draw upon it.

Forgetting music, one finds music sufficient—not displayed yet fully present. Delight lies in harmony, not in words. The ode of the Flame Emperor is the music of no-music, the perfection of music.

Trembling in awe, one reveres it—this is not yet great harmony. Then comes weariness, and withdrawal begins to fade. Confusion leads to foolishness, and foolishness to the Way. To take ignorance as foolishness is to reach the utmost. Lü’s commentary: Music is the Way.

The wilds of Dongting are a vast and desolate place. Though performed by man, it is beautified by Heaven’s principles—music arises from emptiness. Conducted with ritual and righteousness, established upon the Great Purity, it dwells in the Great Beginning. The four seasons and the myriad things are nothing but music. Flourishing and declining, the civil and martial patterns cannot be disordered; clear and turbid, yin and yang are harmonized without discord in their sounds, which flow like light between heaven and earth. Yet without resonance, they do not manifest.

Seeking its root and branches, there is no head, no tail. Death and life, stillness and motion—ever without limit, yet never to be awaited. This is why you were afraid."

Here is the translation:

---

This is nothing else: I revealed it through the human, and they entered it through the human. When one enters the Heavenly through the human, the ten thousand transformations differ—how can that which is called "the One" be awaited? It is fitting that they were afraid.

Moreover, when performed through yin and yang and illuminated by the sun and moon, it is simply the Heavenly. Its short and long are not constant; it fills valleys and ravines. Guarding the spirits with the divisions of the paths, taking things as measure—this is how it becomes sound. When flourished, it is not constrained by the cosmos. When lofty and bright, it is what makes the Heavenly; ghosts and spirits guard the hidden. The stars follow their courses, their cessation has limits, their flow has no end—it is only what is shown.

Desiring to ponder it yet not knowing, pursuing it yet not reaching, eyes exhausted and strength spent, one trails behind and grows weary. This is nothing else: I revealed it through the Heavenly, and they received it through the Heavenly.

I further performed it with no weariness, attuned it to spontaneity. Mixed and pursued, medicines arise, and the ten thousand things flourish abundantly. Forest music has no form, each returning to its root. When spread and flourished without trailing, movement has no direction. In the hidden and dark, there is no sound—dwelling in profound obscurity. Death and life are truly flourishing; scattered and wandering, without constancy, it is not constrained by the one.

This is what the world doubts, yet the sage embodies it in rising, dwelling, and hasty moments, never departing from it. What is called "sage" is nothing else: penetrating to feeling, following fate, ears listening and eyes seeing—nothing is not this. It is simply their Heavenly mechanism. Why seek to expand it?

This is the Heavenly music, wordless yet delighting the heart. Thus, the odes of Youyan-shi and the subtleties of *Xianchi* are like this. If you wish to hear it, it is fitting that you have no contact and my hearing is not employed—hence the confusion.

This is nothing else: forgetting the human, forgetting the Heavenly. First, fear gives rise to spirits; next, weariness gives rise to escape; finally, confusion gives rise to foolishness. The reason the body cannot bear the Way is its bright knowledge and perception. Only by discarding knowledge and becoming foolish can one bear the Way and unite with it.

*Yidu’s Commentary*: When the ancients spoke of the utmost music, was it merely the ends of bells, drums, pipes, strings, and measures? Its principle extends beyond the bounds of Heaven and Earth; its feeling flows through the subtleties of yin and yang. No form can be seen, no sound can be heard—what the *Rites* calls "music dwelling in the Great Beginning," what Laozi calls "the great sound is rare of voice."

First performed through the human, it has not yet departed from the human. Next performed through yin and yang—this is the Heavenly. Finally, it reaches the spiritual, where life and death cannot be fathomed, so it is attuned to the mandate of spontaneity. The human Dao is thus enacted with ritual and righteousness; the Heavenly Dao is illuminated by the sun and moon. "No weariness" is the spiritual—spirits command yin and yang, govern the sun and moon, and encompass ritual and righteousness. What the *Changes* calls "yin and yang unfathomable" is this.

When the Way reaches formlessness, people doubt it; doubt gives rise to confusion, confusion to foolishness, foolishness to the Way—this is what is meant.

*Xiang Dao’s Commentary*: First performed through the human and enacted with ritual and righteousness, refined by the Heavenly and established upon the Great Purity, its skill is seen in endless transformations—thus, hearing it inspires fear. Fear causes the spirit to depart, hence spirits arise. In the middle, performed through the harmony of yin and yang and illuminated by the brightness of the sun and moon, its function lies in the unfathomable flow and cessation—thus, hearing it induces weariness. Weariness causes the body to slacken and hearing to dull, hence escape. Finally, performed with the sound of no weariness and attuned to the mandate of spontaneity, its ultimate aim is the formless and soundless profound obscurity—thus, hearing it brings confusion. Confusion leads to abandoning knowledge as if benighted, hence foolishness. Rampant and reckless, yet treading the great square; unknowing and unperceiving, yet following the Heavenly pattern—this is called "foolishness giving rise to the Way."

*Bixu’s Commentary*: The music of great refinement is bland and does not enter the ear. First hearing it inspires fear—it is not what the vulgar find beautiful. Listening carefully, one grows weary; in the end, one is confused. Vast and silent, none know why. Performed through the human, it harmonizes and enlivens the myriad things; refined by the Heavenly, it blends beautifully with spontaneity. Enacted with ritual and righteousness, high and low do not transgress. Established upon the Great Purity, it sweeps clean the realm. The four seasons arise in turn and follow order; the ten thousand things follow their generation without opposition. Civil and martial principles are constant; yin and yang’s qi flows smoothly. Its sound is radiant light, its primal harmony universally responsive.

Empty yet inexhaustible, moving yet ever arising—how could it have an end? When yin and yang harmonize, ruler and minister unite in virtue; when the sun and moon shine, treacherous flatterers cannot advance. Thus, the governance of the Dao renews daily, transformation knows no stagnation. Ghosts have no numinous echoes; laws and commands do not err. To ponder and know is not wondrous; to gaze and see is not obscure; to pursue and reach is not dark. Standing alone in transformation without escape—this is why it is inexhaustible and unconstrained.

Vast and congealed, it is without compliance and weariness; when utmost harmony rests, there is no weariness. The utmost music is spontaneous, like the sound of thickets and tall bamboo—all are the Heavenly pipes. Who is the one who rages? The nature of things is serene; when spread and flourished, it does not trail. The true wind is tranquil; in the hidden and dark, there is no sound. The primordial qi is mixed and complete—thus, it moves without direction. The great image has no form—thus, it dwells in profound obscurity.

Seeing it now moving, now still, now grasping, now gathering, now flourishing—one calls it "life and death, truly flourishing." Following the qi’s waxing and waning, responding to the seasons in change, one doubts its constancy. Thus, examining the sagely laws, one penetrates the feelings of ghosts and spirits and follows the fates of the ten thousand things. Still as dead ashes, the mechanism ceases; the Five Phases move on their own, and the offices are complete.

The *Odes of Yan-shi* are ancient musical compositions—formless and unseen, soundless and unheard. With no means for sight or hearing, how could one not be confused? Fear in the heart brings misfortune; weariness in the spirit leads to concealment; confusion in the mind leads to foolishness. Foolishness is near the Way.

---

Yongzhai states: Performance proceeds from human affairs; its harmony arises from heavenly principle, ritual propriety—all is ordered and patterned. The Great Purity accords with the workings of creation. From this point onward, the music speaks of transformations startling and stirring, at once delightful and astonishing, flowing and radiant, without discernible beginning or end. Both constant and ever-changing, one seeks its unifying ground yet finds it unattainable—hence the fear. Yin and yang, sun and moon likewise convey this sense of harmonious radiance. Transformations are ceaseless, ever more wondrous in their emergence.

Obstruct the ears and eyes and guard with spirit; follow things and equalize their measures. Ghosts and spirits dwell in darkness; sun and stars follow their courses—all speak of relying not on cunning knowledge but on following nature. It halts at what is bounded, eludes pursuit, and takes form as though something yet is not something—thus one wishes to perceive it yet cannot exhaust it, wishes to pursue it yet cannot overtake it. Though the form is full, the self is forgotten as if empty. Utterly yielding and unrestrained, this is what leads to weariness. Without weariness, there is no cessation.

*Ming* is akin to principle. Intermingling and chasing one another, like the myriad things growing thickly, luxuriant in joy, spreading and swaying—not by pulling or dragging—dim and obscure yet inaudible, shifting and moving without fixed direction: thus life and death are truly flourishing, scattering and wandering without constancy. This is what the people of the world doubt, and so they examine it through the sages. Penetrating feelings and fulfilling fate, they reach the utmost of nature.

Though eyes, hands, and feet are all present, sight, hearing, and movement are all beyond self-awareness—this is called the joy of Heaven. As the *Śūraṅgama Sūtra* says: "Reversing the flow to perfect unity, the six senses cease to function"—such is the state. At this moment, though you may wish to listen, there is nothing to grasp, hence the confusion.

Yan’s four-line verse merely elaborates the preceding idea with a turn, forming a rhythmic cadence—such is the subtlety of this textual art. Earlier, fear, weariness, and confusion were mentioned, but their meaning was not yet clear; only at the conclusion is it revealed that foolishness can lead one into the Dao. It is said that one must traverse such realms to progress: weariness gives way to retreat, marking the moment when desire outstrips ability; confusion gives way to foolishness, the time when consciousness and perception are both forgotten.

In the *Nanhua*, the Dao is discussed through the example of the Yellow Emperor performing music in the wilds of Dongting, for nothing transforms things as swiftly as the Dao, and nothing moves people as deeply as music. Yet to seek the ultimate sound in the vast silence, one must be devoted to the Dao. When people first hear the Dao, their hearts are in turmoil—this is the beginning of fear. Soon, the struggle subsides, and weariness sets in. As emotions and perceptions gradually fade, fear and weariness dissolve, and one attains harmony and joy, returning to a state of unknowing—this is the sequence of entering the Dao.

I have privately examined the meaning of the three performances in this chapter, comparing them to the three winds in the *Qiwulun*. The first performance, with human agency, proceeds through ritual and propriety, beginning with deliberate action. The second, guided by Heaven, is established in the Great Purity, drawing closer to spontaneity. The four seasons alternate, the myriad things follow their growth, yin and yang harmonize, and their sounds flow like light—yet they do not depart from the patterns of civil and martial governance, prosperity and decline, purity and turbidity. This is the first performance, corresponding to the human wind.

The second performance harmonizes yin and yang, illuminated by the brightness of sun and moon. Its sounds may be short or long, soft or firm, filling valleys and ravines, measured by things themselves—this is the earth wind. The final performance is the sound of non-weariness, attuned to the mandate of spontaneity, filling the cosmos and embracing the six directions, following Heaven’s ceaseless and unbroken movement.

At this stage, one fulfills emotions and follows fate, seeing and hearing not through the ears and eyes. Though neither form nor sound, all forms and sounds abide in the wonder of the Heavenly wind. Thus, the intermingling and thriving growth of the myriad things, the roaring of ten thousand apertures—joy in the forest yet without form, the very cause of the roaring, sought yet unattainable. Spreading and swaying without pulling or dragging, like a fierce wind crossing the sea. Dim and obscure, without sound, as if the apertures were empty. Moving without fixed direction, dwelling in profound obscurity, one enters the unfathomable spirit. Thus, life and death truly flourish, scattering and wandering without constancy—this is what most people doubt, yet what the sages investigate.

The heavenly mechanism is not activated; the body is cast aside, and the senses are abandoned. Though the five senses are all present, they are preserved yet unused. To reach a state of wordless heart-joy—what is this if not the joy of Heaven? As the *Rites* says: "Great music harmonizes with Heaven and Earth." There is no one whose nature does not attain the Dao through harmony and joy. When joy reaches harmony, Heaven and Earth respond—this is not something humans can accomplish alone. Thus, this chapter uses music as a metaphor for the Dao, teaching scholars that when form and qi harmonize, the ultimate sound flows unimpeded without audible harmony, and this does not depend on the elaborate performances of metal, stone, silk, or bamboo.

At the end, Yan’s verse is cited to illuminate the ultimate Dao. The ultimate sound cannot be grasped by sight or hearing, hence the final confusion. Confusion leads to foolishness—this is the foolishness of Yanzi, which cannot be surpassed. Sight, hearing, and knowledge are all at once extinguished, so the Dao can be carried and journeyed with.

This music is not of ordinary craftsmanship; its sounds are inherent in the primordial. Utmost joy and harmony fill Heaven and Earth, beyond the reach of strings and bamboo. Day and night, it is ever-present, startling even the blind Kuang and making the clay figurines sing and the wooden puppets dance. How could the wonder of the *Xianchi* lie in mere sounds or musical measures?

The true listener does not rely on the ears but on the heart, not on the heart but on qi, uniting emptiness with emptiness, hearing in the realm of no-hearing. What is enjoyed is Heaven, and the joy is complete. As the *Taishang* says: "Music and food are but passing enticements to travelers." Beneath the depths, there must be those who hear the thunder and act—I shall discuss music with them.

*Taihe* should be *Taihe* (Great Harmony). *Tangran* should be *changran* (the appearance of being lost in thought). *Zhongshi* in another version is written as *Yan*, pronounced *biyao*, the name of a primordial, non-acting sovereign.

Confucius traveled west to Wei. Yan Yuan asked Shi Jin: "What do you think of the Master’s conduct?" Shi Jin replied: "Alas, your Master is in dire straits!" Yan Yuan asked: "Why?" Shi Jin said: "Before the straw dogs are displayed, they are reverently placed in fine baskets, wrapped in embroidered cloth, and the officiant fasts to present them. Once displayed, passersby trample their heads and spines, and fuel-gatherers take them to burn. If one were to gather them again, place them in fine baskets, wrap them in embroidered cloth, and wander or rest beneath them, they would not dream—indeed, they would surely curse frequently.

Now your Master has taken the already-displayed straw dogs of the former kings, gathering disciples to wander and rest beneath them. Thus, he was assaulted while felling a tree in Song, had his borders reduced in Wei, was impoverished in Shang and Zhou—is this not his dream? Besieged between Chen and Cai, he went seven days without cooking a meal, with death and life as neighbors—is this not his curse?

On water, nothing surpasses a boat; on land, nothing surpasses a cart. Just as a boat can travel on water, to seek to push it on land is to exhaust oneself without making even a short distance."

Are not past and present like water and land? Were not Zhou and Lu like boat and cart? Now to carry Zhou’s firewood to Lu is like pushing a boat on land—laborious yet fruitless, and one’s person will surely meet with misfortune. He did not understand the transmission of the boundless, which responds to things without exhaustion.

Have you alone not seen the well-sweep? Pulled, it bows; released, it rises. It is drawn by men, not drawing men, and thus bows and rises without offending anyone. Therefore, the rites, righteousness, laws, and institutions of the Three August Ones and Five Emperors did not pride themselves on uniformity but on governance. Thus, the rites, righteousness, laws, and institutions of the Three August Ones and Five Emperors were like the wild pear, the pear, the orange, and the pomelo—their flavors differ yet all are pleasing to the mouth. Therefore, rites, righteousness, laws, and institutions are what change with the times.

Now if one were to take a macaque and clothe it in the robes of the Duke of Zhou, it would gnaw and tear them to shreds, casting them off entirely before being satisfied. To observe the difference between past and present is like the difference between a macaque and the Duke of Zhou. Thus, when Xishi was afflicted with heart pain and knit her brows in her village, the ugly women of her village saw and admired it, returning home to clutch their hearts and knit their brows as well. The rich of her village, seeing this, firmly shut their doors and refused to come out; the poor, seeing it, took their wives and children and fled. They knew the beauty of knitting brows but did not know why it was beautiful.

Alas, how your Master has come to such straits! As Guo’s commentary says: All discarded things, useless in their time, invite other calamities. The canonical rites of the former kings were meant to suit their time and use; when their time has passed and they are not abandoned, they give rise to the beginnings of forced imitation. Thus, as times change and generations differ, rites should also change, following things without attachment, achieving success without labor, aiming only to accord with the times and respond to the needs of governance. What one deems beautiful, another may deem ugly. Rites and righteousness, when timely and in use, are like Xishi; when their time has passed and they are not abandoned, they are like the ugly woman.

As Lü’s commentary says: The rites, righteousness, laws, and institutions of the sages are all traces that respond to their age. When they respond to their age, they are revered and adorned—like the straw dogs not yet displayed, purified and presented with solemnity. But when their time has passed, they are discarded and abandoned—like the straw dogs already displayed, trampled by passersby. To take the already-displayed straw dogs and rest beneath them is to bind the heart, and one will not dream but surely curse. To take the former kings’ traces that responded to their age and, with disciples, ceaselessly chant and lecture on them is to invite the dream of felling trees in Song, having borders reduced in Wei, impoverishment in Shang and Zhou, and the curse of being besieged between Chen and Cai, with death and life as neighbors—this is the recompense. Only by being unable to let go and move on, binding the heart, does one find boats and carts unsuitable, Zhou and Lu impassable.

Not understanding the transmission of the boundless, which responds to things without exhaustion, one governs men in vain. The well-sweep’s bowing and rising without offense is not how one responds to change. The wild pear and pear’s differing flavors, both pleasing to the mouth, are like clothing a macaque in the Duke of Zhou’s robes—one knows the beauty of knitting brows but not why it is beautiful. To establish teachings and set forth the Dao without attachment, even if Confucius took the former kings’ traces that responded to their age and chanted and lectured on them, how could he have been bound? To see the felling of trees, the reduction of borders, the straits of Shang and Zhou, the peril of Chen and Cai, is like the passing of swallows, sparrows, painted insects before one’s eyes!

The Dao’s not being practiced—I know this well! Why then insist on boats and carts being used, Zhou and Lu being followed, not understanding the transmission of the boundless, and thus bowing and rising to offend, not knowing that rites, righteousness, laws, and institutions change with the times, or why knitting brows is beautiful? To study Confucius without knowing how to be Confucius is to fall into such folly. This is why Zhuangzi speaks of it repeatedly.

As Du’s commentary says: The *Six Classics* are the former kings’ discarded traces. When fitting, they are used; when past, they are abandoned—like straw dogs not yet displayed, placed in fine baskets, but once displayed, trampled and burned. If one were to take them again and rest beneath them, one would not dream but surely curse, for the remnants of sacrifices to ghosts and spirits may invite other calamities. Shi Jin conveyed this meaning to Yan Yuan: Now your Master is deluded by the ancient men of clay and their discarded traces, seeking to act in his time, making disciples wander and rest beneath benevolence, righteousness, rites, and music, and thus he cannot avoid the world’s ridicule and censure. This is like pushing a boat on land or driving a cart on water.
