One who responds to things without exhaustion follows the times and adapts to change, without past or present—this is the transmission of the boundless. Again, the well-sweep bows and rises as men pull it, not pulling men—now does Confucius exert himself in benevolence, righteousness, rites, and music to compel the world to follow him, unlike the well-sweep? Thus, the former kings’ laws and institutions are like the differing flavors of many fruits, all pleasing to the mouth, but only when they change with the times do they all fit. Clothing a macaque in the Duke of Zhou’s robes illustrates the incompatibility of past and present. Rites, righteousness, laws, and institutions are one, but the times in which they are used differ, just as the knitting of brows by Xishi and the village woman is one, yet beauty and ugliness differ.

As the detailed commentary on the Dao says: The songs of Qi, Chu, Yan, and Wei differ in melody yet all bring joy; the wails of the Nine Yi and Eight Man differ in sound yet all bring sorrow. Thus, the sage’s governance of the world rides the times to establish what is fitting, follows the people to set forth laws. If a fruit can benefit the state, its uses are not uniform; if a practice can facilitate affairs, its rites are not the same. Thus, Fuxi and Shennong taught without punishing; the Yellow Emperor, Yao, and Shun punished without anger. The Xia was plain without ornament; the Zhou was ornate without plainness. Can the laws of antiquity be practiced today? Can today’s laws be rigidly adhered to antiquity? Confucius applied the ancient to govern the present—he did not rigidly adhere to it.

Seeking to follow the traces in order to return to that which underlies the traces is but an empty endeavor. Master Jin feared that the world’s people would drown in the ills of clinging to the near, and so he began by comparing them to straw dogs and boats-and-carts, then to well-sweeps and bitter-orange branches, and finally to gibbons and ugliness-and-beauty—just as the ways of Zhou and Lu in ancient and modern times cannot be made one. His diagnosis declared: Those who govern by studying books do not fully grasp the nature of the horse; those who model the present on antiquity do not comprehend the changes of affairs.

Master Bixu’s commentary: Master Jin pitied Confucius for possessing talent yet lacking insight—like a straw dog already discarded, to reuse it would surely invite misfortune. For governance prizes daily renewal; treading in traces leads only to harm. If the Way of Zhou could be practiced in Lu, then the Taihang Mountains could be navigated by boat. Better to abandon stale traces and follow nature, responding to Heaven’s principles and adapting to the transformations of things. Thus, the rites, righteousness, laws, and standards of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors did not pride themselves on uniformity but on order—order itself became the model.

It is like the mouth’s relation to flavors: if one desires sweetness, then sweetness; if one desires pungency, then pungency—responding to the times and changing accordingly. Thus, to follow the gibbon’s nature is to tame it easily; to mimic Xi Shi’s frown only makes one uglier.

Master Yongzhai observed: Master Jin belonged to the same lineage as the Old Man Carrying Reeds and Jie Yu, the Madman of Chu—all implying that what the Confucians study are but the stale words of antiquity, useless in the present age. The metaphors of boats and carts on land and water speak to the difference of times. The transmission of the boundless Way does not cling to a single path; the ancient teachings adapt to the times without fixity, thus responding to the world without end. Moving with others without attachment to the self—this is the metaphor of responding to things without fixed direction.

The sourness of wild pears and the bitterness of orange branches differ in taste, just as the Three Kings differed in rites and the Five Emperors differed in music. To force the people of today to practice the rites and music of antiquity is like clothing a gibbon in the robes of the Duke of Zhou; for the people of today to imitate the ancients is like a village woman aping Xi Shi’s frown.

This passage presents six metaphors, each more striking than the last. Straw dogs are meant to convey reverence, yet if preserved after the sacrifice, they breed calamity. Laws and standards are meant to suit the times, yet clinging to traces after the moment has passed brings only harm. This is why Master Jin mocked Confucius and sought to awaken him from his obsessions with Shang and Zhou, to free him from the snares of Chen and Cai. Yet still he hurried about, hoping to revive antiquity in the present and practice Zhou in Lu—no different from poling a boat in search of the benefits of fording a river. No wonder his responses to things repeatedly failed, bringing him to the brink where life and death stood side by side.

If only he could have been like the well-sweep, rising and falling without intent, or the orange branch, sweet or sour to the taste—why then insist on clothing the gibbon in the Duke of Zhou’s robes or prizing the village woman for Xi Shi’s beauty? The transmission of the boundless Way means that the ancient teachings hold no fixed method; it is for those who govern to adapt to the times and enact policies that suit the people.

As the *Book of Changes* says: When at an impasse, change; through change, there is passage. Does this not describe Master Jin? "Taking disciples" refers to gathering them.

"Mī" is pronounced like "mǐ," referring to a disorder where something enters the eye. This interpretation does not apply here. Lu Deming’s *Pronunciations and Meanings* records Sima Biao’s gloss: "to be oppressed," pronounced *yǎn* (一琰切). Master Cheng’s *Commentary* directly writes it as "魇" (*yǎn*), meaning a nightmare or spectral disturbance—his explanation is apt.

*Southern Florescence: True Classic of the Vast Ocean of Meaning

Those who cling to power cannot share its handle with others. Grasping it, they tremble; releasing it, they grieve—yet they discern nothing, fixated only on what never ceases. Such are the people Heaven condemns.

Resentment and favor, taking and giving, admonition and instruction, life and death—these eight are the instruments of rectification. Only those who follow great transformations without obstruction can wield them rightly. Thus it is said: rectification is rectitude itself. Those whose hearts deem otherwise find the Gate of Heaven barred.

Guo’s annotation: Seeking it in the measures of yin and yang yields no attainment—this illustrates the meaning of "absolute learning" through Confucius and Laozi. Without the inner substance to receive the Dao, even hearing it, one lets it pass. Without an inner master, external things cannot rectify the self, and thus one never achieves penetration. What issues from within is the Dao of the sage; only when there is one outside capable of receiving it does it emerge. What enters from without is learning that completes one’s nature. Though nature may be perfected through learning, one must inherently possess its substance. Without an inner master, there is no vessel to contain the sagely Dao.

Names are what the world shares in common. To embellish beyond reality is to take excessively—excessive taking throws the world into chaos. Benevolence and righteousness are the nature of man, yet human nature changes, differing between ancient and modern times. Thus, to wander and pass through is to remain obscure; to cling to one corner is to become visible. Visibility breeds pretense and invites reproach. Therefore, the utmost is to adapt to the times without fixed advancement. Following simplicity, one is easily nourished. Not depleting oneself for the sake of things, wandering freely and yielding to them—this is true reaping. To reap the true is to render one’s countenance unfeigned.

There are those in the world who burden themselves with what they reject, yet perish for what they affirm—not standing in the garden of "no lending." Those who grieve when relinquishing power cannot but tremble when grasping it. Knowing advancement but not cessation, one forfeits one’s nature and life—this is the reason for condemnation. Clinging to the old without change is to lose rectitude.

Lü’s annotation: The Dao generates the One, the One generates the Two, the Two generates the Three—yet the Dao is not the One, Two, or Three. Seeking it in measures and numbers does not transcend their bounds, hence five years yield no attainment. The Dao divides into yin and yang, yet the Dao is not yin and yang. Seeking it in yin and yang does not surpass the vastness of Heaven’s expanse, hence twelve years yield no attainment.

The Dao cannot be offered to one’s kin or imparted to one’s brothers and descendants because there is no inner master and no external rectitude. Without an inner master, I may wish to transmit it, yet the other does not abide. Without external rectitude, the other may wish to receive it, yet I do not enact it. That things have a master is inherent to them; the Dao within oneself is simply what is inherently one’s own. To possess what one does not inherently possess is to lack an inner master and not abide. The archer’s target is what receives the arrow. The Dao in relation to man is simply what he receives—imposing it where it is not received is to lack external rectitude and not enact it.

What issues from within is not received from without; the sage does not emerge, for there is no rectitude. What enters from without has no master within; the sage does not conceal it, for it does not abide. Not concealing it means one cannot extend and admit it—thus the Dao cannot be sought in measures, yin and yang, but only within oneself. It cannot be offered to ruler or kin, but only self-attained.

Names cannot be taken excessively; excessive taking dissipates virtue. Benevolence and righteousness cannot be dwelt in long; long dwelling breeds attachment and reproach. Wandering freely, one is without constraint; following simplicity, one’s needs are easily met; not lending, one does not engage with things. Thus, all one reaps is true. Inability to yield emolument stems from knowing only wealth; inability to yield fame stems from knowing only prominence; inability to share power stems from knowing only authority. Those who cling to power are ensnared by grasping and relinquishing, harming their nature most grievously—discerning nothing, they mistake muddy water for a clear abyss. Without cessation, Heaven’s punishment is inescapable.

Resentment and favor, taking and giving, admonition and instruction, life and death—these eight are the instruments of rectification, not the Dao of rectification. Only by following great transformations without obstruction can one rightly employ these instruments. Employing the instruments through the Dao—this is why rectification is rectitude. The Gate of Heaven is the path by which those who follow great transformations without obstruction enter and exit. To deem otherwise is to know the Gate of Heaven remains barred.

Yi Du’s annotation: The Dao’s subtlety lies beyond yin and yang; its grossness resides within measures and numbers. Seeking it here yields no attainment—only through non-thought and non-seeking is it attained beyond yin and yang. It cannot be presented to superiors nor imparted to inferiors—there is no other reason: learning without reflection is delusion; reflection without learning is peril. Reflection is how one honors virtue; learning is how one pursues inquiry. "No inner master" means one cannot reflect. "No external rectitude" means one cannot learn.

What enters from without is learning. Without an inner master to reflect on it, what enters from without does not abide in the heart. What issues from within is reflection. Without learning to rectify it externally, what issues from within does not manifest in the human Dao. What issues from within, not being received externally, does not abide. The sage does not emerge. Learning that enters from without, without a master within, cannot reflect—the sage does not conceal, for emergence and concealment are matters of display and hiding.

The *Book of Changes* states: "Radiance renews daily"—this is virtue issuing from within. The noble person extensively studies past words and deeds—this is what enters from without. What issues from within extends vastness; what enters from without exhausts subtlety. This is how the Dao is preserved whole.

Names are the world’s public instrument.

If there is partiality, then it is an insubstantial name—one must not take it excessively. Benevolence and righteousness in relation to the Dao are like inns along a road: one may stay a single night, but cannot dwell there long. This means one should not cling too closely to benevolence and righteousness.

Free and unfettered, one acts without contrivance. Without lending, there is no expenditure. The wandering in pursuit of the true is the wandering of Heaven itself.

Those who crave wealth and power have dull and benighted minds, unable to perceive the profound principle. They rush headlong into ceaseless toil—these are the people Heaven punishes. Resentment and gratitude, life and death—these eight are instruments only the great person may rightly employ.

The Gate of Heaven is where the spirit comes and goes, now opening, now closing. All things emerge and enter here, and its transformations are inexhaustible.

The *Detailed Annotations on the Dao* states: Zhuangzi records that Confucius, at fifty-one, had yet to hear the Dao, using myriad words to show how difficult it is to encounter.

Measures and numbers do not exceed five; yin and yang do not exceed twelve. Benevolence establishes others, so one borrows the Way to act. Righteousness establishes oneself, so one lodges temporarily to dwell. Yet borrowing the Way to act does not mean one does not lodge—Mencius speaks of seven as the secure dwelling and the vast abode. Lodging temporarily to dwell does not mean one does not act—Mencius speaks of righteousness as the correct path and the great Way.

To lend is to supply another’s lack, only to be repaid in the end. Fields are where one labors to cultivate and nourish. Those who eat from simple, unadorned fields find their food sweet. Those who stand in gardens that do not lend find their lending good and complete.

The *Blue Void Commentary* states: Confucius understood the use of what is useful but had not attained the Dao of non-action. The Dao is a thing without threads or hairs to measure, without the smallest fraction to calculate, without branches or stems to trace. Thus, seeking it, one does not obtain it.

Laozi taught that the Dao is such a thing that even ruler and minister, parent and child, cannot transmit it—its vessel is difficult to find. Without an inner source, auspiciousness does not abide. Without external rectification, the highest virtue does not flow.

Subtle meaning arises from the sage’s heart, but without an external vessel to receive the Dao, though the subtle meaning is clear, it does not emerge. Profound words enter the learner’s ears, but without inner capacity to contain them, the listener, though enlightened, remains confused—how could the profound words ever be concealed?

Names are the guests of reality; taking too many invites calamity. Benevolence and righteousness are not fixed laws—how can waystations be places of secure dwelling? The perfected of old borrowed them to act, lodged in them temporarily, wandered in the realm of self-attainment, roamed the vast and boundless wilds, and though their walls adjoined, they did not visit one another—this is called the wandering in pursuit of the true. In truth, there is no falsity.

Those who flaunt wealth fear losing emolument; those who boast of glory cherish their names; those who rely on power harbor many suspicions—such are the common ways of the world. With discernment, one knows when to stop; knowing when to stop, one avoids disgrace.

Resentment and gratitude, life and death—these eight are bound to names and realities. When names accord with realities, instruments are not misused. To resist change is to obstruct; obstruction causes names and realities to falter. When names are correct, realities are correct. To force them is to block the numinous chamber.

*Yongzhai* says: Measures and numbers are rites and music; yin and yang are the principles of things. Five years and twelve years have no special meaning—they only speak of seeking coarsely and finely for a long time without attainment.

From “If the Dao could be silently transmitted” onward, these four lines are exquisitely expressed. Though one who studies the Dao may hear something from without, if there is no master within, it is not one’s own attainment and cannot be retained. Without external rectification, I have nothing to gain, and thus no external rectification—how can it act on its own?

“What issues from within” refers to teaching others: my words issue from within, but if you cannot receive them, the sage will not instruct you. “What enters from without” refers to receiving teaching: profound words enter your ears from without, but if you have no insight and no inner master, though you hear, you gain nothing—it is not that the sage conceals anything.

These four lines are most subtle. The Dao cannot be transmitted—the problem lies entirely in these four lines. One must not take names excessively—this is a rebuke to the Confucians’ love of fame. One must not dwell long in benevolence and righteousness, for they have crossroads.

To observe is to see. Where there is sound, it can also be seen—this is how calamity arises. Borrowing the Way and lodging temporarily carry the meaning of transformation when exceeded.

Simplicity, not lending, ease of nourishment without expenditure—these cost nothing of oneself. This is called gathering the true principle. Wealth, fame, and power—grasping them brings fear of loss; clinging to them brings sorrow from infatuation. Seeing nothing, one gazes at what never rests—bewildered and unable to return.

With no insight in the heart and no ability to turn and see one’s confusion, Heaven has stripped away one’s spirit. Resentment and gratitude, and the other six, exist in this human world, and thus these eight are employed. To employ what should be employed is called correctness—only those without intent can rightly use them.

Great change is creation and transformation. If one can follow it without obstruction, then what is within me is correct, and I can correct things. If one cannot be without intent and takes this as incorrect, then the Heaven within one’s breast is darkened and obstructed.

The *Book of Songs* says: “Heaven guides the people”—this is the meaning of the Gate of Heaven. The study of measures and numbers can be examined through pitch pipes and calendars. The study of yin and yang can be deduced through climate and seasons. But the essence of the Dao is not bound to pitch pipes or calendars, nor does it involve climate or seasons. Thus, seeking it in these ways, one does not obtain it. Only those without intent who follow transformation do not seek to conform yet conform—it cannot be obtained through seeking.

If the Dao could be offered, there would be none who would not transmit it to their children and grandchildren. This means the Dao cannot be transmitted with intent or obtained through private desire.

Without an inner source, there is no substance within, so the Dao does not flow. Without external rectification, the highest virtue does not act. It is like the people of Ying in the world without master craftsmen—thus, the Dao does not abide.

Without external rectification by a true master, if the inner core remains steadfast, and the outer form is properly aligned, one can achieve wondrous discernment. How much more so, then, the subtlety of transmitting and receiving the supreme Dao—where spirit communes and hearts resonate in the realm of the indistinct and obscure?

The sage awakens the people through the Dao, like heaven bestowing sweet dew, never choosing where it falls. Yet without vessels of jade and fine stone, it cannot be contained. This is what it means to lack receptivity without and no inner source within.

Fame, when excessively pursued, invites ruin and harm. Benevolence and righteousness, when clung to for long, breed demands and reproach. The perfected person borrows them without attachment, thus worldly cares and anxieties never reach them. Through carefree wandering, they act without contrivance; through simplicity, they are easily nurtured; through non-attachment, they have no loss. Even if things crowd before them, what concern is there? This is called the wandering of gathering truth—where not a trace of private falsity is permitted, like heaven’s movement, arising from spontaneity, ceaselessly generating and transforming. This is why the person is noble and the Dao is divine.

Yet the world values only wealth, prominence, and power, unable to relinquish them, clutching tightly with fear and sorrow—when will they ever know carefree wandering again? This is called ceaseless toil, seeing nothing to illuminate it, an inescapable heavenly punishment.

The eight afflictions—resentment and gratitude among them—are tools of rectitude. Only through rectitude can one use them without misstep. Even joy, anger, sorrow, and delight—though the sage cannot wholly eliminate them—lie in moderation.

Following great change without obstruction means wealth and honor do not corrupt, poverty and lowliness do not sway, might and force do not bend. Only when the self is rectified can tools be rectified; only then can things be set right. If one’s heart deems otherwise, the great vessel is not empty—how can the Dao be discussed?

The "Gate of Heaven" is a metaphor for the emptiness of the heart. The mind’s dharma is like the eye—how could it tolerate any obstruction? Confucius visited Lao Dan and spoke of benevolence and righteousness. Lao Dan replied: "When chaff gets in the eye, heaven and earth, the four directions, seem to shift. When mosquitoes and gnats bite the skin, one cannot sleep all night. Benevolence and righteousness, so intrusive, agitate the heart—no greater disorder exists. If you, sir, could let the world not lose its uncarved simplicity, you too would move with the wind and stand by virtue—why must you clamor like one beating a drum to seek a lost child?

The egret does not bathe daily to be white, nor the crow blacken itself to be black. The natural black and white of their essence need no distinction; the spectacle of fame and reputation cannot broaden them. When a spring dries up, fish gather on land, wetting each other with their breath, moistening each other with foam—yet this is not as good as forgetting each other in rivers and lakes."

When Confucius returned from seeing Lao Dan, he did not speak for three days. His disciples asked: "Master, when you saw Lao Dan, what advice did you give?" Confucius said: "Now, in this moment, I have seen the dragon! It coalesces into form, disperses into pattern, rides the clouds and qi, and nourishes itself in yin and yang. My mouth gapes, yet I cannot speak—what advice could I give Lao Dan?"

Guo’s commentary: External things, though small, greatly harm one’s nature. If the world does not lose its uncarved simplicity, its essence remains whole, and benevolence and righteousness naturally manifest. Moving with the wind, standing by virtue—this is the Way of easy adherence and practice. To brandish benevolence and righteousness in pursuit of the Dao’s domain is like beating a drum to seek a runaway—it cannot be attained. The egret’s whiteness and the crow’s blackness are naturally sufficient, with no partiality. Thus, the most complete forget fame and reputation; only by forgetting fame and reputation can one be truly broad.

The praise of benevolence and righteousness arises from insufficiency. Like fish forgetting each other in rivers and lakes, one forgets benevolence and thus embodies benevolence. Confucius said, "Now, in this moment, I have seen the dragon," meaning Lao Dan could transform and ride without constraint, naturally complete.

Lü’s commentary: The heart of the perfected person is like a mirror. Yet benevolence and righteousness, so intrusive, disturb it—are they not like chaff in the eye or mosquitoes biting the skin? The world all possesses the uncarved simplicity of the nameless. If one can keep it from being lost, one moves with the wind and stands by virtue—why must one clamor like beating a drum to seek a lost child? The world has already lost its uncarved simplicity, and to save it with benevolence and righteousness is no different from beating a drum to seek the lost—seeking it through fame and reputation.

Moreover, the egret’s whiteness and the crow’s blackness are the natural essence—what adornment is needed? Thus, the spectacle of praise cannot broaden human nature, just as they cannot. Fish on land, wetting each other with foam, though momentarily intimate, have already lost the principle of their nature—better to forget each other in rivers and lakes. The vulgar, clinging to benevolence and righteousness, share only fleeting affection while losing the principle of their nature—better to forget each other in the rivers and lakes of the Dao’s protection.

The dragon coalesces into form and disperses into pattern, never burdening its body. Lao Dan saw benevolence and righteousness as chaff and mosquitoes—thus, it is clear he was not burdened by them.

Du’s commentary: The uncarved is the wholeness of the Dao. Benevolence and righteousness are its dispersion. The wind is the Dao’s transformation of things. Virtue is the Dao within people. If the world does not lose the wholeness of the Dao, one should simply let it be, moving with the wind, standing by virtue—why must one brandish benevolence and righteousness to seek the Dao, like beating a drum to seek the lost? The egret’s whiteness and the crow’s blackness are naturally so—thus, they need no distinction. Fame and reputation serve to describe and judge, yet they distort the uncarved simplicity—thus, they cannot broaden it.

Fish on land, wetting each other with foam, though momentarily intimate, have already lost the principle of their nature—better to forget each other in rivers and lakes, each self-sufficient. The vulgar, clinging to benevolence and righteousness, share only fleeting affection while losing the principle of their nature—better to forget each other in the rivers and lakes of the Dao’s protection, each self-sufficient.

In ancient times, people lived to old age and death without mutual visitation—how much more does this exemplify the principle! When Confucius heard the words of Lao Dan, their transformations were inexhaustible, and he sighed that they were like the dragon, coalescing and dispersing without constancy. The mouth cannot even govern itself—how could one presume to regulate Lao Dan?

*Bi Xu’s commentary:* Those who cleave to benevolence and righteousness are like chaff lodged in the eye. Those who branch into cleverness and discernment are like mosquitoes and gnats feasting on the skin—how could they not stir confusion and disorder? Uncarved and unpolished, simplicity remains whole; emulate the pure wind to transform things, and embrace utmost virtue to attain self-sufficiency—why then bear the burden of benevolence and righteousness, rushing about in pursuit of worn traces? Like the egret’s whiteness and the crow’s blackness, things naturally form their own groups—what need is there for distinction? The mutual wetting of fish stranded in drought reveals a compassionate sentiment, yet how does this compare to the joy of forgetting one another in rivers and lakes?

When Confucius saw Lao Dan and called him a dragon, it was because the dragon, in profound union with primordial qi, coalesces to form its body, and in soaring flight, scatters to display its splendor. Its emergence and withdrawal are without intent, thus it rides upon the clouds; its movement and stillness accord with the seasons, thus it nurtures itself in yin and yang. Lao Dan’s sagely virtue was as unfathomable as this—what place was there for my admonitions to take hold?

*Yongzhai’s note:* "Feasting on the skin" and "chaff in the eye" are metaphors for perverse and contrary impulses. *Jian* means poison, denoting their bitterness. *Fen* means opposition. "Emulating the wind" means following transformation. *Zong* means to grasp. If the world did not lose its original simplicity, all would follow transformation in their actions and stand firm in virtue—what need would there be for teaching? It would be like carrying a great drum to seek the lost—no way to find them. The magpie’s whiteness and the crow’s blackness require no washing or dyeing; their natural qualities are self-evident—no need for debate. To display fame and reputation before the world is to invite judgment and division, and thus the mind cannot expand.

How long can fish stranded in drought sustain their mutual wetting? If they dwelt in rivers and lakes, they would forget one another in the water—a metaphor for the age of the utmost Dao, where all follow their nature without judgment, and superiors and inferiors likewise forget one another. "Coalescing to form its body" describes its undifferentiated wholeness; "scattering to display its splendor" describes its radiant manifestation. The dragon moves between heaven and earth, visible yet not visible. "Riding upon the clouds" places it above creation; "nurturing itself in yin and yang" means it delights in the Way of heaven and earth.

When Confucius saw Lao Dan and spoke of benevolence and righteousness, it was no different from discoursing on Yao and Shun before Dai Jinren. Thus, Lao Dan used chaff in the eye, mosquitoes feasting on the skin, and other metaphors to illustrate how benevolence and righteousness stir opposition in the heart, further sealing the world’s vital points to allow all to recover their undifferentiated truth. To transform things, move them with the wind; to cultivate the self, stand without losing virtue. Why must one proudly brandish the name of benevolence and righteousness as the ultimate attainment of the Dao? It would be like carrying a drum to seek the lost—no way to find them.

The magpie and crow require no washing or dyeing for their whiteness and blackness to be known—thus, no need for debate. The utmost Dao is vast and boundless, beyond naming or speech; to seek it in the reputation of benevolence and righteousness—how could this suffice to broaden it? Like fish in drought wetting one another, their affection is not without intimacy, yet how does this compare to the joy of forgetting one another in rivers and lakes? Yet the present age precisely takes such fleeting affection as benevolence, unaware that the sage does not transform through benevolence to its utmost.

When Confucius saw Lao Dan, he returned and spoke no more, for the Dao was present in the glance—no words were needed. The dragon’s formation of its body, its radiant display, its riding upon the clouds, its nurturing in yin and yang—all accord with the seasons in movement and stillness, its virtue and blessings extending to things while its spiritual transformations remain unfathomable. Thus, the ancients, in discussing sages and spirit-men, always used the dragon as a metaphor. None but Confucius could depict Lao Dan’s virtue, and none but Lao Dan could be worthy of Confucius’s metaphor. Yet these two sages, paragons of human relations, fully manifested the functions of the seven treasures, each illuminating the other—no room for ranking superiority between them.

**Heaven’s Movement (Chapter Four)**

Zigong asked: "Then are there indeed men who dwell in stillness like a corpse yet manifest like a dragon, who thunder in voice yet abide in profound silence, whose actions move like heaven and earth? Might I be permitted to witness such a one?" Thereupon, he sought out Lao Dan on Confucius’s reputation.

Lao Dan was just then reclining in his hall when he responded, softly saying: "My years have advanced and departed—what would you admonish me with?"

Zigong said: "The governance of the Three Kings and Five Emperors differed in method, yet their fame and renown were one. Why then did the former kings alone deem them not sages?"

Lao Dan said: "Young man, come closer! Why do you say they differed?"

Zigong replied: "Yao yielded to Shun, Shun yielded to Yu, Yu relied on labor while Tang relied on arms, King Wen served Zhou without daring to oppose, and King Wu opposed Zhou without consenting to serve. Thus, I say they differed."

Lao Dan said: "Young man, step back! Let me tell you of the governance of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors. The Yellow Emperor’s governance made the people’s hearts unified—when their kin died, they did not weep, yet none among the people condemned it. Yao’s governance made the people’s hearts affectionate—when they killed for their kin, none condemned it. Shun’s governance made the people’s hearts competitive—pregnant women bore children in ten months, and the children could speak at five months; before they could even babble, they began to choose between people, and thus men began to die young. Yu’s governance made the people’s hearts mutable—men had intentions, and weapons had alignment; killing thieves was not killing men. Each regarded themselves as a separate kind, and the world was thus thrown into great alarm. The Ru and Mohists all arose. Their beginnings had order, yet now, what can be said of women today?

"I tell you of the governance of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors—though called ‘governance,’ no chaos was greater! The wisdom of the Three Sovereigns above obscured the brightness of sun and moon, below severed the essence of mountains and rivers, and within disrupted the operations of the four seasons. Their knowledge trespassed upon the tails of fleas and lice, the beasts of the wilds—none could secure the natural course of their lives and natures. Yet they still deemed themselves sages. Is this not shameful? Truly, it is shameless!"

Zigong stood uneasily, shifting from foot to foot.

---

**Guo’s Commentary:**
"When kin died and none wept, if the people had condemned it, they would have forced themselves to weep. ‘Killing their killers’ refers to the gradations of mourning attire. That children could speak at five months means instruction was hastened. That they chose people before they could babble means competition in teaching was premature. Unable to harmonize self and other, their hearts competed in closeness and distance, thus they did not live out their natural years. ‘Weapons had alignment’ means the world already had disorder. Thieves deserved death; killing them was not murder. Unable to unify the myriad things, each man distinguished himself, and thus each became his own kind. Seeking to harmonize the currents of a hundred generations with the changes of the present age, the flaw reached this point—not through Yu, but through the world itself. To say the path of sagely wisdom did not throw the world into chaos, yet the world still fell into such disorder—this is the flaw of a hundred generations. The Ru and Mohists all arose from this. Today, women are taken as wives, yet above and below are in rebellion. This is not because the beginnings lacked principle, but because the flaw in the highest principle led to this. What more can be said? Even the governance of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors could not escape such flaws. Zigong had originally thought Laozi alone rejected the Three Kings, so he sought to equate them with the Five Emperors. Now, seeing Laozi universally condemn the Five Emperors and even the Three Sovereigns, he lost the basis of his argument and thus stood uneasily."

**Lü’s Commentary:**
"Laozi compared benevolence and righteousness disturbing the heart to chaff blinding the eyes or mosquitoes and gadflies biting the skin. Thus, he deemed the Five Emperors and Three Kings not sages. Zigong then inquired about yielding and contention, compliance and opposition, which were even cruder distinctions. Speaking in sequence, making the people’s hearts mutable was certainly not as good as affection, and affection was not as good as unity—yet all alike failed to avoid governing the world while giving the people intentions. Though called ‘governance,’ it was from this that the world’s chaos began. If knowledge is employed, it is not only the Five Emperors and Three Kings—even the wisdom of the Three Sovereigns would above obscure the sun and moon, below sever mountains and rivers, and their knowledge would trespass upon the tails of fleas and lice! Beasts that dwell in mountains and forests, moving by night and resting by day, though hungry and thirsty, still roam freely upon rivers and lakes—how much more so for the wildest creatures! Zigong heard Laozi condemn the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors but could not grasp the reason, so he stood uneasily."

**Lin’s Commentary:**
"'Dwelling like a corpse yet manifesting like a dragon, thundering in voice yet abiding in profound silence'—these are the affairs of spirit-men. ‘Reclining’ means sitting without pretense or response. ‘Softly’ means responding out of necessity. ‘Years advanced and departed’ means he was already old. The Three Kings and Five Emperors were names of sages; governing the world was the sages’ advancement. Though their methods differed, their fame was tied to this, so Laozi condemned them. If it were the heart of a sage, there would be no difference! Yu governed the waters, so he relied on labor. Tang overthrew Jie, so he relied on arms. King Wen served Yin, and King Wu overthrew Zhou—thus, I say they differed. In the time of the Yellow Emperor, the people did not exclusively cherish their own kin or love their own children, so there were those who did not weep when their kin died, and the world did not condemn it—purely following the Dao of heaven to govern. By the time of Yao, the law was perfected, descending from heaven into man, and the people’s hearts were already affectionate. Yet rites and laws were not yet detailed, so there were those who killed in their kin’s mourning, and the people did not condemn it. By Shun, the world was governed purely by the human Dao, and the people not only had affection but competition arose. Thus, simplicity was dispersed, the great Dao was abandoned, and benevolence and righteousness emerged! Human desires multiplied, so pregnant women bore children in ten months."

Instruction came too swiftly, so children could speak at five months. Before reaching the age of toddling, they already distinguished who was who—the heart of infancy was lost so readily! How far removed was this from the Way of spirit-men who never die?

By the time of Yu, the people’s hearts held competition, and simplicity and purity were transformed. Yet when he waged war and launched punitive expeditions, he never acted against the people’s will. Those he killed were thieves, and his aim was to end killing. As the *Book* says: “Punishment aims at no punishment.” Thus, he could not fully unify the myriad things, and each person distinguished themselves, dividing into clans and throwing the world into disorder.

Once the governance of emperors and kings had decayed, the disputes of Confucians and Mohists all arose. This was not because their beginnings lacked order, but because long accumulation led to corruption. Thus, taking women as wives and the inversion of high and low—nothing was more perverse than in this era. What more could be said?

Even rare creatures and tiny beasts do not stray from the natural course of their lives—how much more so for the people!

**Blue Void’s Annotation:**
Without speech, transformation spreads—like a corpse dwelling yet a dragon appearing.
A name resounds while the self remains obscure—like thunder’s roar in the depths of silence.
Rising and falling follow constancy, movement and action like heaven and earth.

The Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors differed in virtue, their governance distinct, yet all were bound to fame and reputation. The Yellow Emperor’s governance of the world was all-embracing and forgetful, so when kin died, none wept, and the people did not condemn it. Yao governed the world by fostering affection in the people’s hearts, so when kin were killed in mourning, the people did not condemn it. Shun governed the world by fostering competition in the people’s hearts, so pregnancies came early, children spoke before toddling, and people began to die young. Yu governed the world by transforming the people’s hearts, so they toiled ceaselessly for livelihood, and each harbored private intentions. Yet when they were punished, none resented it, for warfare had its proper place.

Yu passed the throne to Qi, and the world was transformed—thus it was said that “people formed their own clans.” This was not the private act of one man, so it was called “the world.” Yet when the sagely and wise arose, the world was alarmed; Confucians and Mohists flourished, and the great Dao was divided. It was fitting that maidens married early and the constant norms of human relations were taught—such was the consequence of establishing laws to achieve order, for when laws changed, chaos followed.

Eclipses of the sun and moon, the crumbling of mountains and drying of rivers, the disruption of the four seasons, and the excesses of climate—these inharmonious qi were less severe than the creeping vines of disorder that caused the myriad things to lose the natural course of their lives. This was the fault of governing the state through knowledge.

**Yongzhai’s Note:**
When Confucius’s reputation reached Lao Dan, he sent his disciples to pay respects. “Arrogant in the hall,” showing disdain. “Subtle in response,” their exchanges were barely audible.

The Yellow Emperor’s governance followed nature, and each subsequent era declined further. Mourning garments were graded by the weight of kinship—this was not so in ancient times but was established by later ritual. In antiquity, children were born after fourteen months and did not speak until two years old. Now they were born in ten months and spoke at five, able to ask who someone was before they could toddle.

“Heart transformed” meant changed from antiquity. “People had hearts” meant each harbored private intentions. “Warfare had its proper place” meant that waging war was deemed proper. Thieves could be killed, and laws were detailed. At this time, people all distinguished their own clans, loving their own kin and children, merely sharing this world together.

In its beginnings, there was still the Way of human relations, but its corruption led to the inversion of norms—taking women as wives—what more could be said? The *Record of Rites*’s passage on the great Dao and public-mindedness shares this intent.

Earlier, the Three Sovereigns were highly revered, but here they are equally denigrated, for even their knowledge could disrupt the principles of heaven and earth’s creation—poisonous as creeping vines. *Jie* means “few.” *Gui* means “to seek.”

The desires of small beasts were few, yet even they could not preserve the natural state of their lives. When the corpse sits still yet the dragon appears, the obscure becomes manifest in clarity. When thunder rumbles in the abyss of silence, harmony is heard in the absence of sound. Their movements were like those of heaven and earth, for yin and yang turned as one. This was Zigong’s praise and admiration for Lao Dan’s virtue, the reason he wished to meet him.

Lao Dan was then seated upright in the hall, rapt in stillness, still yet ever-responsive, answering even the most subtle of questions. Zigong said that the governance of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors differed, yet all bound their reputations to the world, first unifying the people’s hearts, then inciting their competition. As hearts changed, the world’s Dao declined further, and human hearts grew ever more deficient.

Not weeping at a parent’s death, shortening the mourning period—these were but minor omissions in ritual, not yet deeply harmful. But when children were born after ten months and spoke at five, transformation came too swiftly, and the people began to die young. With private intentions and personal inclinations, each treated themselves as a separate kind, and the world was thrown into chaos.

Tracing its origins, human relations were not entirely absent at first, yet in the end, they were never truly established. For their pursuit of order was excessive, failing to consider the nature of things, and forcing the world to follow their will—this was the very cause of disorder. What more could be said?

The knowledge of the Three Sovereigns had not strayed far from nature, yet it still disrupted the sun and moon, cast down mountains and rivers, and encroached upon the tail of the creeping vine. If even insects and beasts could not preserve the natural state of their lives, what could be said of the people? How much worse for later ages, where men indulged their emotions and relied on cunning and artifice?

How could such an approach ever convey the meaning of governing the state not by knowledge, or the blessing of the state’s fortune?

Confucius said to Lao Dan: “I have studied the Six Classics—*The Book of Songs*, *The Book of Documents*, *The Rites*, *Music*, *The Book of Changes*, and *The Spring and Autumn Annals*—for a long time, and I believe I understand their principles. Yet when I advised seventy-two rulers, expounding the Way of the former kings and clarifying the teachings of Zhou and Shao, not a single ruler adopted them. How difficult it is to persuade men! How hard it is to make the Dao clear!”

Laozi said: "Fortunate indeed! That you have not encountered a ruler of a well-governed age! The *Six Classics* are but the worn-out tracks of the former kings—how could they be the very tracks themselves? What you now speak of is but the near at hand. Tracks are what shoes produce, yet are tracks the same as shoes?

The white pheasants gaze at one another, their pupils unmoving, and the wind carries their transformation. The male insect cries upon the upwind, the female responds from downwind, and the wind carries their transformation. Each kind has its own male and female, thus the wind carries their transformation. Nature cannot be altered, fate cannot be changed, time cannot be halted, and the Dao cannot be obstructed.

If one attains the Dao, there is nothing that cannot be; if one loses it, there is nothing that can be. After three months, Confucius reappeared and said: 'I have grasped it! Crows and magpies nurture their young, fish coat themselves in foam, the slender-waisted wasp transforms, and when a younger brother is born, the elder brother weeps. How long it has been since I participated in transformation as a human! If one does not participate in transformation as a human, how can one transform others?'

Laozi said: 'Good! You have grasped it!'

Guo’s commentary: What advances is true nature. Following the true nature of things, what advances is the *Six Classics*. Yet in the affairs of men today, the natural is treated as shoes, and the *Six Classics* as tracks. Pheasants gaze at one another with their pupils unmoving, insects respond to each other’s cries, and both conceive without union—thus it is called 'wind transformation.' The males and females of the same kind each have their own means of mutual resonance. The variations in their resonance are beyond measure; if they belong to the same kind, their transformation is not difficult. Thus, there are even those who resonate from afar and are transformed by the wind. The perfected person follows and penetrates all, and though transformation has no fixed method, all is possible.

Those who lose the Dao have no way to succeed, just as crows nurture their young, fish coat themselves in foam, and the slender-waisted wasp transforms—each thing has its own natural disposition. Human nature, however, abandons the elder to favor the younger, hence the elder brother weeps when a younger brother is born. One who participates in transformation as a human follows their natural transformation; to expound the classics in explanation is already a deviation.

Lü’s commentary: The *Six Classics* are the laws of the former kings, their standards and measures set forth in writing—yet these are not what transform. What transforms is the numinous clarity alone. Tracks are what shoes produce, yet are tracks the same as the teachings? To transform by such means, the world rightly does not employ them.

The white pheasants gaze at one another, their pupils unmoving, and the wind carries their transformation—what resonates is the spirit, not sound. The male insect cries upon the upwind, the female responds from downwind, resonating through sound, not form. Each kind has its own male and female, thus the wind carries their transformation. In such cases, nature differs and cannot be altered, fate is fixed and cannot be changed, time flows and cannot be halted, and the Dao is unobstructed and cannot be blocked. How could this be fathomed by words, deliberation, or conjecture?"

Thus we know that what transforms the world does not lie in the presentation of precedents, but in seeking the Dao alone. Confucius attained this within three months—during his purification of mind and disciplining of form—awakening to the fact that crows, magpies, fish, and bees all live, yet the means by which they live are never the same. What knowledge cannot grasp is transformation alone!

A brother weeps for his younger sibling—emotion compels him so. Transformation allows all to live equally; emotion, however, prevents even brothers from sharing the same lot. To wish for others’ transformation is difficult indeed!

Long has it been—since Qiu ceased to be shaped by transformation as others are, he became one with the Dao and no longer aligned with the Creator’s design for humanity. How then could he transform others? Those who study Confucius yet fail to grasp his means of advancement invariably falter here.

**Du Yi’s Annotation:**
To govern the world by reciting the *Six Classics* without seeking their intent in virtue, power, nature, and destiny is like mistaking the track for the shoe that made it. The white pheasant and the insects both transform through the wind, requiring no union for offspring to arise. Male and female of the same kind each possess their own means of resonance; when kindred meet, transformation comes effortlessly. These are the natural principles of creation, the unalterable nature of destiny, the unstoppable flow of time, and the unobstructed Dao. One must simply allow them to unfold—never forcing the precedents of former kings to disrupt their natural essence.

The three months mark a single shift in the celestial seasons, illustrating the difficulty of awakening to the Dao. The magpie, fish, and bee—none of these generate life through lustful desire, and thus Confucius used them to elucidate Laozi’s teaching on the Dao.

"A brother weeps for his younger sibling" speaks to how people often cherish the young while neglecting the elder. "Long has it been" indicates this did not arise overnight. To "be shaped by transformation as others are" is to follow the Creator’s cycles of life and death without attachment, so that one may abandon the recitations of the *Six Classics* and allow others to transform naturally.

**Bixu’s Annotation:**
The wisdom of sages and worthies is applied in the present moment. What remains today are but bamboo slips and silk scrolls!

Do the responses truly align with practical affairs? The fitting response becomes one’s path; the excessive response becomes a thoroughfare. When white pheasants gaze at one another and call in harmony, where is there a thoroughfare? The nature of the worthy and the foolish cannot be altered; the fate of the noble and the base cannot be changed; the times of adversity and prosperity cannot be halted; the Dao of the sage cannot be obstructed.

To awaken is to turn tiles and pebbles into gold; to be deluded is to see jade as mere stone. Confucius thus realized that the magpie’s nestlings, the fish’s foam, and the bee’s offspring all arise of themselves, without reliance on anything external. Even between brothers born in succession, there is still partiality and affection—how much more so between different eras? This speaks to how each thing transforms on its own; how could there be one who partakes in transformation yet cannot transform others?

**Luanzhai’s Note:**
Where there is a path, there is a thoroughfare. To grasp advancement yet fail to grasp the path is like the parable of the dregs. From "When white pheasants gaze at one another" onward, the text is most extraordinary. All things are born of wind and qi, hence the term "wind-transformation." Each kind pairs as male and female, forming its own category among the myriad things, thus enabling such wind-transformation.

Nature, fate, time, and the Dao—all speak to the principle of spontaneity that cannot be defied. "Nestlings" refers to mating; "foam" refers to mutual moisture giving rise to life. Brothers share the same mother, yet after the first suckles, the milk ceases, so the elder, denied milk, weeps. "Not partaking in transformation as others do" means knowing humanity but not Heaven, failing to unite with the workings of creation.

This chapter uses the principle of creation’s ceaseless generation to illustrate the Dao of spontaneity, further asserting that what Confucians study is all "action with purpose." If one acts without purpose, one’s achievement aligns with creation. The deeper intent is to make people realize that this body arises from nothingness and is one with the myriad things, thereby shattering the worldly hearts of self-interest and self-love!

When white pheasants gaze at one another, when insects call and respond, each pairs as male and female by kind, thus wind-transformation. This is what is meant by "the two essences contend and the spirit responds," the natural principle of yin and yang seeking one another. Thus, nature and fate cannot be altered; time and the Dao cannot be obstructed.

From "The magpie rears its young" to "a brother weeps for his younger sibling," these four lines seem obscure at first reading, but upon close examination, their meaning on transformation is vast. The principles of embryonic, hatching, moist, and metamorphic transformation are all contained within, though people fail to perceive them. The waxing and waning of Heaven and Earth, the mechanisms of creation’s ebb and flow—though silently operating in the formless—are all revealed through the four modes of birth. Among these four, humans are the masters; among the multitudes, sages are the masters. The sage, who transforms by partaking in transformation, thus knows Heaven.

Thus, this chapter concludes with a discussion of transformation. If one does not govern Heaven and Earth, administer the myriad things, and act alone as the pivot of nurturing transformation, how can one transform others? The Most High said: "I act without purpose, and the people transform themselves." Observe the wind-transformation of pheasants and insects, the hatching of magpies, the foam-spawning of fish, the offspring of bees—all arise from natural nature, perfected through focused and steadfast effort. This resonance and response cannot be forced or explained; thus, it is called transformation. Humans, being the most spiritually endowed, possess a transformation even more wondrous than these, yet it does not exceed the principle of spontaneity and the effort of steadfast focus.

Thus, the *Doctrine of the Mean* states: "Only the utmost sincerity under Heaven can transform." Even with Confucius’ sageliness, he fasted and purified his heart for three months before attaining it—how could the subtleties of great transformation be lightly discussed?

This treatise begins with the movements of Heaven and the positioning of Earth, posing questions about the reasons for the sun, moon, wind, and clouds flowing and operating. It answers with the six directions and the five constants, the governance of the Supreme Sovereign, who embodies Heaven’s movements to enact virtue and teaching, thus transforming without purpose while the people delight in spontaneity.

Next, it discusses the utmost benevolence being without partiality, the utmost nobility casting aside rank, and acting without contrivance—also modeling the principle of Heaven’s movements. As for the performance of music on Dongting Lake, it clarifies the profundity of the Great Dao, harmonizing with yin and yang, enacting ritual and righteousness—this interdependence of Heaven and humanity is the foundation of establishing the ultimate.

Regulating the four seasons, harmonizing the myriad things, aligning cold and heat in proper sequence—this is the origin of generation and transformation. Moving without fixed direction yet dwelling in the profound and obscure, the celestial mechanism pauses while the five officials are complete—thus, one follows things in concealment, manifesting wherever touched, unbound by form or exhausted by sound, roaming freely. Wherever one arrives, there is nothing but utmost harmony; where silence abides, there is nothing but utmost joy.

As for governance, it is likened to the straw dogs already used in sacrifice; laws and institutions are like the opposed flavors of coarse and fine grains. The monkey tears the robe of the Duke of Zhou; the ugly woman mimics the beauty of Xi Shi—this illustrates that governance values appropriateness, and cooking the fresh lies in not stirring. For those in high position, if they can truly embody the Dao and model Heaven, moving in unison with transformation, timing their encouragement and nurturing to ripen and perfect, how could the people fail to be transformed?

When Confucius met Laozi, he sighed that he was like a dragon, for aligning humanity with Heaven had not yet reached complete transformation. Upon hearing the subtleties of the profound thunder, he then abandoned the well-trodden paths of the *Six Classics* to investigate their underlying principles. Within three months, partaking in transformation as others do, his path became one with humanity while his essence united with Heaven.

The *Book of Changes* states: "Heaven’s movement is ceaselessly vigorous"—this is what is meant by "movement." "Essence and qi become things; the wandering soul becomes change"—this is what is meant by "transformation"!

*Collected Explications of the Ocean of Meanings in the True Scripture of Nanhua*, Scroll 47, ends.
*Omissions and Errors*: According to the ancient Jiangnan manuscript, the character "人" is missing. Above it should be the character "至." The correct character is "生."
*Collected Explications of the Ocean of Meanings in the True Scripture of Nanhua*, Scroll 48, by the Daoist of Wulin, Chu Boxiu.

**Chapter One: On the Carving of Intent**

Those who carve their intent and esteem conduct, distancing themselves from the world and differing from common customs, who indulge in lofty discourse and resentful slander—doing so only to assert their superiority—these are the preferences of the recluses of mountains and valleys, the unworldly, the withered, and those who plunge into the abyss.

Those who speak of benevolence and righteousness, loyalty and trust, reverence and frugality, deference and yielding—doing so only to cultivate themselves—these are the preferences of the gentlemen of orderly times, the instructive, and the wandering scholars who dwell in ease.

Those who speak of great achievements, establish grand reputations, honor the rituals between ruler and minister, and rectify the hierarchy of superior and inferior—doing so only to govern—these are the preferences of the courtiers, those who exalt their lords and strengthen their states, and the ambitious who seek to merge accomplishments.

Those who retreat to marshes and lakes, dwell in seclusion and vast solitude, fish and idle in stillness—doing so only to practice non-action—these are the preferences of the recluses of rivers and seas, those who flee the world, and the leisurely.

Those who practice breath control, exhaling the old and inhaling the new, emulate the bear’s climbing and the bird’s stretching—doing so only to prolong life—these are the preferences of the practitioners of *daoyin*, those who nurture the body, and the long-lived like Pengzu.

Yet there are those who attain loftiness without carving intent, cultivate themselves without benevolence and righteousness, govern without achievements or fame, find tranquility without rivers or seas, and prolong life without *daoyin*. They forget nothing, yet possess all things. Serene and boundless, all virtues follow them.

This is the Dao of Heaven and Earth, the virtue of the sage.

Thus it is said: Serenity, stillness, emptiness, and non-action—these are the equilibrium of Heaven and Earth, the essence of the Dao and virtue.

Guo Xiang’s commentary: These various types, each with different preferences, indulge their inclinations and follow their own paths—this too is a form of freedom. Yet each attains only their own fulfillment; how could they establish all things? As for one who enables the myriad things to each fulfill their nature without self-loss, they must guide without clinging to any fixed action. Forgetting, they are thus able to possess; if they possessed, they could not save themselves from forgetting. Thus possession is not possession through possession, but possession through forgetting. If one forces oneself to act, they cannot remain boundless, and manifold evils arise.

That which does not act for the myriad things yet allows them to arise of themselves—this is Heaven and Earth. That which does not act for the hundred conducts yet allows them to perfect themselves—this is the sage. Without stillness and non-action, their equilibrium is imperiled, and their essence is lost.

Lü Huiqing’s commentary: From carving intent to seek loftiness to practicing *daoyin* to prolong life, all depend on external things and cannot achieve the state of "forgetting nothing, possessing all." Only in serene boundlessness do they escape the servitude of carving intent, benevolence, righteousness, achievements, or fame. All virtues follow them, and the loftiness, cultivation, governance, leisure, and longevity they sought come unbidden. Such is the Dao of Heaven and Earth, the virtue of the sage. Thus, to forget nothing and possess all is to be unburdened by being or non-being—this is the meaning of non-action.

Lin Qindu’s commentary: Those who strive for loftiness do not yet know cultivation; those who soar do not yet know governance; those who govern do not yet know non-action; those who practice non-action do not yet attain longevity; those who seek longevity do not yet master death and dissolution. Each is confined by their own limitations—none compare to the sage’s completeness. The sage attains loftiness without carving intent, cultivates without benevolence or righteousness, governs without achievements or fame, finds leisure without rivers or seas, and prolongs life without *daoyin*. Forgetting nothing, they abide in constant non-being; possessing all, they abide in constant being. Yet constant non-being is not true absence, nor is constant being true presence. Thus, serene and boundless, all virtues gather to them. The virtue of Heaven and Earth is likewise.

Serenity and emptiness both arise from the Dao and virtue. Distinguishing them: serenity and stillness are the equilibrium of Heaven and Earth; emptiness and non-action are the essence of the Dao and virtue.

Chen Bixu’s commentary: Lofty discourse—Xu You and Shan Juan. Rejecting the world—Bo Yi and Shu Qi. Withered and withered—Jie Zitui. Plunging into the abyss—Shentu Di and Bian Sui. Advancing and dwelling in learning—Confucius by the Yi and Si rivers, Zixia in the West River. Achieving merit—I Yin, Lü Wang, Guan Zhong, and Shang Yang. Marshes and lakes—Chaofu and Yan Guang. Leisure and seclusion—Gongyue Xiu and the shepherd boy. Fishing—Ren Gongzi and the Fisherman. Breath control—embryonic breathing and the six qi. Bear climbing and bird stretching—derivations of the marsh spirit’s five movements.

To forget and possess is to forget possession and enter the ultimate. Heaven and Earth are empty at their center, yet the myriad things arise; the sage is without mind, yet all virtues are perfected. Stillness is the equilibrium of Heaven and Earth; emptiness and non-action are the essence of the Dao and virtue.

Lin Yongzhai’s *Oral Teachings* states: To toil with intent, prizing action, espousing lofty theories, resenting the world, and detesting evil—this is striving for loftiness. Withered and withered—profound stillness. Plunging into the abyss—entering the mountains deeply. Cultivation—pursuing purity and teaching as a master in the world. Achieving merit—contemporary examples noted by Zhuangzi. Recluses and hidden scholars transcend right and wrong, unlike those who defy the world. Bear climbing and bird stretching—Hua Tuo’s Five Animal Frolics. To forget nothing and possess all is to practice non-action and yet act in all ways. Boundlessness—no fixed limit. All virtues follow—embodying all goodness. The sage embodies the natural Dao of Heaven and Earth, hence this attainment. The essence of the Dao refers to its inherent nature.

Chu Shi’s *Superficial Observations*: This chapter begins by discussing the differing aspirations of ancient worthies, from withered recluses to those who nurture the body for longevity—all are evident. Yet to attain loftiness without carving intent, to prolong life without *daoyin*, to forget and to possess, serene and immeasurable—this is the complete beauty of Heaven and Earth, the supreme virtue of the sage. It is not like the earlier cases, each clinging to partial views and believing themselves fulfilled. It is like Boyi’s purity and Hou Ji’s harmony, yet only Confucius is called "sage for the times"—the one who embodies the great synthesis. Only by forgetting all can one possess all; if one clings to possession, how can they ever attain forgetting?

A potter can shape myriad vessels, yet no vessel can shape a potter. Only by being formless can one shape forms; only by being non-thing can one master things. The virtue of Heaven and Earth and the sage is likewise.

Thus it is said: When the sage rests in ease, they are level and yielding; being level and yielding, they are serene. Serene and level, worries and afflictions cannot enter, and perverse qi cannot assail. Thus their virtue is whole, and their spirit is unharmed.

Thus it is said: The sage’s life follows the movement of Heaven; their death is the transformation of things. At rest, they share the virtue of yin; in motion, they move with the wave of yang. They do not precede fortune nor initiate misfortune. They respond only when stimulated, move only when pressed, and rise only when compelled. They discard knowledge and precedent, following the principle of Heaven. Thus they are free from heavenly disasters, unburdened by things, unblamed by people, and unaccused by spirits. Their life is like floating; their death is like resting. They do not scheme or plan ahead. Radiant yet not dazzling, trustworthy yet not bound by promises. In sleep, they do not dream; awake, they have no worries. Their spirit is pure and unadulterated; their po is not wearied.

Empty and serene, vast and unburdened—thus do they align with Heaven’s virtue. It is said: sorrow and joy are perversions of virtue; delight and anger are transgressions of the Dao; likes and dislikes are lapses in virtue. Therefore, a heart free from sorrow and joy is the perfection of virtue; unchanging unity is the perfection of stillness; non-action is the perfection of emptiness; non-engagement with things is the perfection of blandness; non-resistance is the perfection of purity.

Guo’s commentary: Abiding in serenity and ease, in stillness and silence, resting in emptiness and non-action—even when traversing perilous changes, one remains level and untroubled. Trouble arises from action; action arises from trouble. Thus, tranquility and simplicity interweave, dissolving into the natural principle and proceeding as one with it. Those who are neither level nor at ease—do they merely harm their form? Their spirit and virtue perish within.

Heaven’s movement follows its own natural course. Transformation of things is a shedding of all ties, motion and stillness without intent, entrusted to yin and yang, without leading or prompting. They move only when the moment arrives, rising as the principle demands. Heaven’s principle is spontaneous; knowledge and precedent are absent from its inquiry. Thus, disaster arises from defying Heaven; burdens arise from resisting things. Those who align with others are approved by the multitude, for they accord with self-attainment—hence, no blame. Life is like floating; death is like resting—indifferent, with nothing to regret. Entrusted to Heaven’s principle, they respond when the principle arrives. They employ the world’s own radiance, not their own dazzling; they employ the world’s own trustworthiness, not their own promises. Desiring nothing, their hun-soul is not wearied. Thus do they unite with Heaven and Earth in their serene and bland virtue. Supreme virtue is ever at ease; emotions find no foothold.

Stillness and unity cannot be altered. Utterly open and unobstructed, they admit not even the slightest discord—things come of themselves. The supremely bland harbor no inclination to engage with things; if mixed with turbid desires, there will be resistance. Lü’s commentary: The sage rests content, not enslaving the mind to grasping or discarding. Level, they do not incline; simple, they do not struggle. Serene, they are without knowledge; at ease, they do not engage with things. This is what is meant by "stillness and non-action"—nothing more.

Worry and trouble are the means by which perverse qi gains entry and assails, for knowledge and engagement with things create fissures. In life, following Heaven’s movement, they have never truly lived—thus, they do not heed departure. In death, transformed by things, they have never truly died—thus, they do not resist arrival. At rest, they share the virtue of yin, unaware of their stillness. In motion, they move with the wave of yang, unaware of their movement. Not preceding fortune, fortune does not arrive. Not initiating misfortune, misfortune does not come. To seek fortune or initiate misfortune, to respond without stimulus, to move without pressure, to rise without compulsion—this is to employ knowledge and precedent, the work of man. Following the spontaneity of Heaven’s principle, Heaven cannot bring disaster, things cannot impose burdens—thus, no blame from people, no accusations from spirits. How fitting!

Life floats; death rests—unmoved by feeling, responding when things arrive, their radiance arises from Heaven’s light, not from contrivance. Within, there is trustworthiness, not binding promises. Without dreams or worries, waking and sleeping are the same. Purity is unadulterated; non-fatigue arises from non-action. Heaven’s virtue is how the sage governs all under Heaven.

The emotions of sorrow and joy are hard to relinquish—hence, they are perversions of virtue. Delight and anger arise and vanish in an instant—hence, they are transgressions of the Dao. All four stem from likes and dislikes; likes and dislikes are the unmanifest sorrow, joy, delight, and anger. The human heart, ceaselessly churning with ten thousand thoughts—how can it attain even a moment of stillness? The virtuous one, free from sorrow and joy, attains unchanging unity—this is the perfection of stillness. Without fear, like an empty boat striking an object yet unprovoked—this is the perfection of emptiness. Not engaging with things, without flavor—this is the perfection of blandness. Thus, even entering water or treading fire, everywhere is oneself—how could there be resistance? This is the perfection of purity.

**Doubts Resolved, Annotation:**

The movements of Heaven are *timeliness*; the sage in life abides in its season.
The transformations of things are *compliance*; the sage in death dwells in its accord.
Though yin and yang differ, their benefit to things is the same.
Stillness is thus spoken of in terms of *virtue*; movement, in terms of *ripples*.
Fortune is the recompense of *rightness*.
Misfortune is the summons of *wrongness*.
If right and wrong do not originate from oneself, how could calamity or blessing take root?
Though right and wrong dissolve into the Dao, when stirred by externals, there must be response; when pressed, there must be movement—only then, and not before, do they arise.

He who seeks fortune at the onset of misfortune possesses *knowledge*.
He who responds without being stirred, moves without being pressed, embodies *constancy*.
Discard knowledge and constancy, and one follows the natural—free from celestial disasters, then free from the burdens of things; free from human reproach, then free from spectral blame.
Life drifts, death rests—thus, one knows neither delight nor aversion.
He who does not ponder acts without weariness.
He who does not premeditate has no cause for apprehension.
Not flaunting oneself prevents the birth of doubt and confusion.
Not scheming ensures great trust without covenant.
Sleeping without dreams, waking without care—such is the wholeness of spirit.
Purity and unweariedness also arise from this.
Emptiness and nothingness suffice to reveal *non-action*; tranquility and vastness suffice to reveal stillness.
In this, one aligns with Heaven’s virtue—thus, sorrow, joy, delight, anger, likes, and dislikes become the perversions and transgressions of the Dao and virtue.

When viewed through the Dao of Heaven, there is no sorrow, joy, delight, anger, likes, or dislikes.
When viewed through the Dao of man, these six cannot be avoided.
Thus, freedom from sorrow and joy is the perfection of virtue, clarifying that delight is its perversion.
Unchanging is the perfection of stillness, clarifying that delight and anger are its transgressions.
Without obstruction is the perfection of emptiness, clarifying that likes and dislikes are its flaws.
Not engaging with things further clarifies the meaning of "without obstruction."
Without resistance further clarifies the meaning of "not engaging with things"—thus is the perfection of purity.

**Bixu’s Annotation:**
Anxiety and weariness enter where ease is absent; worldly qi assails where tranquility is lacking.
For one whose spirit and virtue are whole and complete, what filth could stain them?
Life’s fleeting arrival follows Heaven’s course; death’s fleeting departure follows the transformations of things.
It neither diminishes nor augments one’s true nature, attaining the essence of yin and yang.
Not taking the lead in the world, one fundamentally does not respond—yet responds when stirred; fundamentally does not move—yet moves when pressed; fundamentally does not arise—yet arises when unavoidable.
Following Heaven’s principle without deceit, forgetting the burdens of things without arrogance.
With no human reproach, how could spectral blame exist?
Life drifts, death rests—following principle and abiding in nature, concealing one’s light and hiding one’s brilliance.
Great trust requires no covenant; waking and dreaming are naturally attained; spirit and soul leave no trace.
Emptiness, nothingness, tranquility, and blandness—these align with Heaven’s virtue.
The cultivator of virtue forgets sorrow and joy; the follower of the Dao forgets delight and anger.
Losing oneself lies in likes and dislikes.
Thus, the perfection of virtue is serene and formless within; the perfection of stillness cannot be swayed by life or transformation; the perfection of emptiness has no obstruction; the perfection of blandness distances itself from the vulgar; the perfection of purity encounters no resistance.

**Fu Zhai’s Annotation:**
Ease and tranquility are none other than *non-action*.
An unharmed spirit is none other than wholeness of virtue.
"Heaven’s movements" means acting in accord with Heaven’s principle.
"Transformations of things" means regarding the body as a cast-off husk.
Responding to stimuli, I harbor no intent; moving when pressed, arising when unavoidable—all express the intent of responding to things without attachment.
Discard private wisdom, depart from contrivance, and one follows the natural.
Floating or resting, drifting without attachment—what thoughts or schemes could there be?
Shining yet concealing oneself, one need not rely on things.
Spirit whole, thus pure and unwearied; soul at rest, thus untroubled.
All sorrow, joy, likes, and dislikes are not natural.
Only when sorrow and joy do not bind the heart is one’s virtue perfected.
Abiding in unity without distraction, one follows the natural—though engaging with things, one is not burdened by them.
Stillness, emptiness, blandness, purity—these are the virtues of the natural, merely expounded thus.
*Xiuxiu* describes a demeanor of harmony and joy.
Thus, ease and tranquility repel anxiety and perversity, for one’s virtue is whole and spirit unharmed.

"Heaven’s movements" speak of the circulation of a single qi; "transformations of things" speak of the dispersal of a single qi—this is what is meant by "same virtue, same ripples."
If even seeking fortune at the onset of misfortune is inadvisable, how much more so at the beginning of calamity?
Responding when stirred, moving when pressed—this speaks of unavoidable response to things, a response born of non-attachment, though active, it is *non-action*.
Discard knowledge and constancy, and one is without knowledge or affairs; follow Heaven’s principle, and one accords with the natural.
With no celestial disasters, the burdens of things are naturally avoided.
With no human reproach, how could spectral blame arise?
Thus, one drifts in life and rests in death, thoughts severed and schemes abandoned—like jade containing virtue, like Heaven’s seasons following their course.
Sleeping without dreams, waking without care; spirit pure, soul untroubled—this is called emptiness, nothingness, tranquility, and blandness, aligning with the virtue of the natural.

The heart is like a target; emotions are like arrows. When many arrows aim at one target, how could the target not be struck?
Now, men stand in the midst of the world yet do not think to dodge the arrows—hoping for wholeness of virtue and an unharmed spirit, how difficult!
Thus it is said: The body wearies without rest and becomes worn; essence is expended without cease and becomes labored; labor leads to exhaustion.
Water’s nature is clear when unadulterated, level when undisturbed; if dammed and not flowing, it cannot remain clear—this is the image of Heaven’s virtue.
Thus it is said: Pure and unadulterated, still and unchanging, bland and *non-acting*, moving in accord with Heaven’s course—this is the way to nourish the spirit.

As for the swords of Gan and Yue, encased and stored away, never dared to be used—this is the utmost in treasuring them.
The spirit flows in all four directions, reaching everywhere, above touching Heaven, below coiling upon the earth, transforming and nurturing the myriad things, beyond representation—its name is "unity with the Divine."
