The Way of purity and simplicity is to guard only the spirit; guard it without losing it, and unite with the spirit as one. When this oneness penetrates with precision, it harmonizes with Heaven’s order.

A rustic saying goes: The common crowd values profit, the incorruptible value reputation, the worthy esteem aspiration, and the sage treasures essence. Thus, "simplicity" means having nothing mixed with it; "purity" means not diminishing one’s spirit. One who embodies purity and simplicity is called a *zhenren*—a true person.

Guo’s commentary: All things have their proper place and must not be lost. Those who emulate Heaven’s virtue act without intention yet meet all things perfectly, never straying from what is most fitting. They dwell constantly in what is right, moving only in accord with the meeting. To chase and act is merely human conduct. One who cherishes a sword still stores it in its case—how much more should one dare to lightly use one’s spirit?

To embody the ultimate of Heaven and Earth, responding to the patterns of the myriad things with one’s spirit, is inherently like this: those who achieve the work of Heaven and Earth do so by following Heaven’s course, not by reckless use. Their nurturing knows no bounds, aligning with the Heavenly Emperor’s non-action. By constantly guarding purity and simplicity in utmost stillness without being swayed by externals, they enter the realm of the profound.

Essence is the true nature of things. To unite with the spirit is not merely to guard it; to not stray from one’s essence is not merely to treasure it—yet in practice, one must value and uphold it. If purity is defined as non-diminishment, then even if a hundred deeds are performed in unison and ten thousand transformations are mastered, one may still attain purity. If simplicity is defined as non-adulteration, then even if one possesses the splendor of dragons and phoenixes, an extraordinary sight, one may still attain simplicity. But if one cannot preserve one’s natural state and instead mixes it with external adornments, then even the coarse garments of dogs and sheep—how could they be called pure and simple?

Lü’s commentary: Observe the sage’s mind—empty, tranquil, and expansive. As previously stated, though one may engage in affairs all day, the spirit does not weary. The ancients spoke of setting aside the mind and employing the body, of seeing and hearing without relying on the eyes and ears—this is the way. Now, people bind their ears and eyes to sounds and sights, enslave their minds to pursuit and conformity, wearying the body without rest and expending essence without cease, leading inevitably to exhaustion and depletion.

Water’s nature is inherently clear and level—this is its natural straightness. It remains unadulterated and undisturbed, that is all. To know this yet mistake stagnation for stillness is to fail to keep it clear. The image of Heaven’s virtue is just the same. Thus, purity without admixture is the image of water’s clarity; stillness and oneness without change is the image of water’s levelness. Moving in accord with Heaven’s course is the image of water not mistaking stagnation for stillness.

Yet the world, in its vast diversity, imposes restraints on emptiness and stillness without knowing to observe the return amid activity or to return to the root amid the teeming—this is because they do not know the Way of nourishing the spirit. People of the world believe that nourishing the body is sufficient to preserve life, yet this is not enough to compare with it.

A sword is stored in its case because of its usefulness. The spirit reaches Heaven above and coils upon the Earth below—its usefulness far surpasses that of the swords of Gan and Yue! Its name is "unity with the Divine"—how could its value be merely that of a treasured sword? Yet they do not know to hone it with purity, store it with stillness, conceal it with non-action, and guide it with Heaven’s course—this is to fail to understand the distinction between what is noble and what is base.

Guard only the spirit, and guard it with purity and simplicity. While one is in the act of guarding, there is what is called "the guardian" and what is guarded. Guard without losing it, and the guardian and the guarded merge into one. "Order" here means principle. When a person harmonizes with Heaven’s principle, they too become Heaven.

This is why the sage treasures essence. Simplicity is absence of admixture; purity is non-diminishment. Only the true person can achieve this.

Yi Du’s commentary: The body must not be overworked; essence must not be overused. When the body is enslaved to essence, essence enters the spirit. When it reaches the spirit, transformation lies within oneself—one can transcend life and death. How could this be the labor of the body or the expenditure of essence?

Clarity can be washed; levelness can be emulated. Its ceaseless flow day and night is water’s nature. To embody the virtue of the natural and not drift into artificial contrivance is to remain unadulterated and unchanging, moving in accord with Heaven’s course.

Purity without constraint is how one exhausts principle. Stillness and oneness without change are how one fulfills one’s nature. Blandness and non-action are how one establishes the root. Movement in accord with Heaven’s course is how one follows the seasons. The Way of nourishing the body is complete.

The famed swords of Gan and Yue are all considered divine—stored in their cases and never dared to be used. Yet when it comes to the body, people do not know how to treasure it. Is it that they love their bodies less than their swords? No—it is simply that they do not reflect.

A sword is the treasure of a tool; the spirit is the treasure of the body. The treasure of a tool, when used, can only overcome a single foe. The treasure of the body, when concealed, can flow without end. In nurturing the myriad things—what the *Yi* calls "curving to complete without omission"—it cannot be represented, what is called "the spirit having no fixed form." Its name as "unity with the Divine" is but a forced designation.

To guard the spirit is to aim for the spirit. When one reaches the spirit, one unites with it, and purity and simplicity are no longer sufficient to describe it. When the oneness of essence penetrates, it harmonizes with the principle of the natural.

Again, rustic sayings are cited to affirm this: The sage treasures essence, and essence enters the spirit. What one embodies is purity and simplicity, but its function is merely the spirit. This is what is called a true person.

Bi Xu’s commentary: The body wearies and essence is expended when one exceeds one’s measure and harms one’s nature. Water’s nature is clear when unadulterated and level when undisturbed. The true water within the body is the same—if one is pure, still, and moves in accord with Heaven’s principle, though one does not refine the body, the spirit already reigns supreme.

A sharp sword is an external thing, yet one knows to treasure the spirit. To be swayed and scattered without gathering oneself—is this not a reversal of priorities?

One skilled in nurturing and guiding may accompany the workings of creation; one adept at preserving simplicity safeguards and maintains spirit and qi. Thus, they merge into profound unity and penetrate Heaven’s principle.

Rustic sayings list four matters, with treasuring essence as foremost: emptying the numinous palace and sealing the six apertures. When substance is unstained by dust, it is simplicity; when spirit is unagitated by affairs, it is purity. One whose embodiment is complete in purity and simplicity—how could this not be the true person?

Yongzhai observes: Using water as a metaphor for nurturing life, if it is pent up and cannot clear, it is not entirely like withered wood or dead ashes. "Unadulterated and undisturbed"—this is nonaction. "Not flowing and thus unable to clear"—within nonaction there is action. Does not Heaven’s movement, completing one cycle each day, exemplify action within nonaction? To nurture spirit is to nurture life; to lift up the word "spirit" is to make it intimate. One who cherishes a sword still keeps it sheathed—how much more should one treasure spirit? This same spirit transforms and nourishes the myriad things, yet leaves no trace visible, so its merit is equal to that of Heaven’s Lord.

For those who study purity and simplicity, at first they guard only spirit; with time, they become one with spirit. This is what is meant by "transforming through greatness." Before transformation, one remains separate from the Dao. When unity reaches the point of penetrating essence, one merges with Heaven’s principle—this is what is called "sagely and unknowable."

To treasure essence is to treasure spirit. Purity and simplicity are the "pure and unsullied" of *Qian*. The true person, the perfected person, the sage—these are not matters of superiority or inferiority. *Carving Intentions* speaks of nurturing spirit and includes the discourse on Heaven’s movement and the transformation of things; *Mending Nature* speaks of preserving the body and includes the discussion of time, fate, action, and error. Though nurturing spirit and preserving the body are treated in two separate chapters, this is where the work of learning lies, and scholars must examine it closely.

The Dao of nurturing spirit values nonaction, hence the analogy of water’s clarity—level, still, and ever-illuminating. When it moves, it models Heaven’s ceaseless vigor, coiling between the two poles. Yet this is fundamentally rooted in nonattachment, nonalteration, and nonaction—this is illumination within constant stillness. When essence is expended, it wearies and depletes; thus stillness is prized. When pent up and unable to clear, it requires movement. Yet within the realm of neither stillness nor motion, neither attachment nor detachment, the wondrous Dao abides. How could its value be merely that of a treasured sword from Gan or Yue?

To be one with the Lord is to be one with Heaven. Heaven is spirit. Thus, when essence penetrates and merges with Heaven’s principle, here one can no longer distinguish between the Dao of Heaven and the Dao of humanity. The passage concludes by citing rustic sayings as proof, returning to the treasuring of essence and affirming that one who embodies purity and simplicity will transform entirely. Who but the true person can attain this?

This chapter takes "Carving Intent" as its title, speaking of those who sharpen their will, defy the world, and correct customs through austere discipline and solitary resolve—attempting what all under Heaven cannot, and coveting others’ allegiance. This is no different from piercing an ox’s nose or bridling a horse’s head, losing their natural state. When wisdom grows long, virtue wanes, and the people become hard to govern.

Thus, the *Nanhua* [Zhuangzi] surveys the ancients, each with distinct aspirations: Bo Yi and Shu Qi’s defiance, Confucius and Mencius’ cultivation, Yi Yin and Fu Yue’s governance, Chao Fu and Xu You’s reclusion, Laozi and Peng Zu’s longevity. Viewed broadly, none seem without bias, yet they remain sages and worthies because their actions do not entangle them in doing, nor does their non-doing drown them in nothingness. They adapt to the times’ feasibility and their own advantage.

Therefore, what is prized is emptiness, non-doing, tranquility, and ease—aligning with Heaven’s movement and the transformations of things, sharing virtue and riding the same current. When knowledge and habit do not linger, and movement accords with Heaven’s principle, how could calamity or trouble arise? How could life and death or schemes and cares disturb one’s clarity?

Thus, in stillness, emptiness, and pure simplicity, one harmonizes with things without conflict, ultimately returning to the work of nurturing the spirit. The analogy of sheathing the treasured swords of Gan and Yue is extended: what weight does a sword hold for the body? Its rejection or acceptance is self-evident. Yet the world remains deluded in this regard. Hence, the argument begins by rejecting the habit of carving intent and exalting conduct, and concludes by affirming that one who embodies purity and simplicity is a true person—making it clear that those who carve and exalt are but counterfeits.

For nurturing life, purity and simplicity are the foundation; for purity and simplicity, guarding the spirit comes first. When one unites with the spirit, the great root of the Dao is established—what need is there to fuss over its branches by carving intent and exalting conduct?

The *Nanhua* speaks thus to correct the false habits of scholars of its time, guiding them to rest in the naturalness of their nature and destiny and return to the purity and simplicity of the Dao and virtue.

*Collected Explications of the Ocean of Meanings in the True Classic of Nanhua*, Scroll 48, concludes.
#1 The *Omissions and Errors* cites Zhang Junfang’s edition, where "resting in rest" (*xiu xiu yan*) appears as "resting in it" (*xiu yan xiu*). Yu Yue’s *Zhuangzi Pingyi* argues that the two characters "resting in it" (*xiu yan*) were transposed in transmission.

*Collected Explications of the Ocean of Meanings in the True Classic of Nanhua*, Scroll 49.
By the Daoist of Wulin, Chu Boshi.

**Cultivating Nature, Part One**

To cultivate nature through convention is to seek the recovery of one’s origin by means of vulgar learning. To muddy desire with conventional thought and strive for clarity through reflection is to be called a people benighted and deluded.

Those of old who governed the Way nurtured knowledge with tranquility. Born without making knowledge their aim, they were said to nurture tranquility with knowledge. Knowledge and tranquility mutually nourished one another, and harmony and principle emerged from their nature.

Virtue is harmony; the Dao is principle. Virtue admits of no exclusion—this is benevolence. The Dao leaves nothing unordered—this is righteousness. Righteousness made manifest, things draw near—this is loyalty. Centered in purity and returning to genuine feeling—this is joy. Trust embodied in conduct and form, following patterned refinement—this is ritual.

When ritual and music are practiced in a partial manner, the world falls into chaos. Those who rectify themselves yet obscure their own virtue do not impose it; if they impose it, things inevitably lose their nature.

**Guo’s Annotation:**
To cultivate one’s nature through convention and seek to restore the root of life and destiny by vulgar learning is to pursue what is ever further from the Way. To disorder the mind with desire and then employ thought in striving for clarity is to stray ever further the more one refines one’s thinking. Those who dispel delusion must first depart from convention and abandon desire before approaching the threshold. Only when tranquility is attained does knowledge not stray; when knowledge does not stray, nature is not lost. To act without making knowledge one’s aim and instead allow it to know of itself is to know all things while remaining serene and self-content. Knowledge that is not contrived does no harm to tranquility; tranquility that acts of itself does no injury to knowledge. When these two mutually nourish one another, how could harmony and principle arise from anything else?

Harmony ensures nothing is left unfulfilled; the Dao ensures nothing is left unordered. That which admits of no exclusion is not benevolence by design, yet the traces of benevolence unfold. That which leaves nothing unordered is not righteousness by design, yet the work of righteousness is manifest. If righteousness is made manifest yet does not arise from the center, things grow ever more distant. When benevolence and righteousness issue from the center and return to one’s original disposition, the will is fulfilled, and when the will is fulfilled, joy arises. Trust embodied in conduct and form, following patterned refinement—its outward trace is ritual.

To impose the practice of one body or the joy of one will upon the world is for one region to gain while ten thousand lose. When each rectifies its nature and life and veils itself in its own virtue, it does not impose this upon that. If one imposes this upon that, how can things not lose their nature?

**Lü’s Annotation:**
To cultivate nature through convention is to rest one’s aspirations in the mundane. Born and already having lost one’s origin, to then seek its recovery through vulgar learning is to stray ever further. To muddy desire with convention is to court peril in chasing after conformity, confounding one’s clarity, and then striving to attain it through thought is to grow ever more benighted.

Tranquility is to be at ease without knowing why. To nurture knowledge with this is not to strive for clarity through thought. To be born with knowledge yet not make it one’s aim or employ it is different from being at ease without knowing why. To nurture tranquility with this is not to seek the recovery of one’s origin through vulgar learning. The divine clarity of the *Book of Changes*, the "elusive and evanescent" of Laozi, and the tranquility and knowledge of *Zhuangzi*—in truth, they are one. Those of old who governed the Way never attained their end without mutually nourishing these two.

The flaw in tranquility lies in obscurity, leaving nothing to illumine the vast and open. The flaw in knowledge lies in entanglement, leaving nothing to return to the primal darkness. When these two mutually nourish one another, harmony and principle emerge from one’s nature—not from without.

That which pervades Heaven and Earth is virtue. Virtue is harmony. That which courses through the ten thousand things is the Dao. The Dao is principle. The essence of virtue is harmony, and its function admits of no exclusion—this is benevolence. The essence of the Dao is principle, and its function leaves nothing unordered—this is righteousness. Righteousness made manifest, things cannot but draw near—this is the center. Centered in purity and free from artifice, joy is born from this. Trust is to have it within and manifest it without, giving rise to patterned refinement—this is ritual.

When ritual is thin, it is the beginning of disorder. When the ten thousand things each rectify their nature and life, they veil themselves in their own virtue. What need has virtue to impose itself upon others? When ritual and music are practiced universally, the Dao and virtue grow ever more distant, and imposition cannot be avoided. Imposition causes things to lose their nature—this is why the world falls into chaos.

**Yi Du’s Annotation:**
The true person of old did not cultivate nature through convention but embraced simplicity, thereby recovering their original state. They did not muddy desire with convention but refined their thought to penetrate the Dao, thereby attaining clarity. How could they be benighted or deluded?

Only by cultivating nature through convention does one contend in artifice, and then seek the recovery of one’s origin through vulgar learning. Only by muddying desire with convention does one chase after emotion, and then employ thought to govern one’s clarity—all in vain.

To recover one’s origin is to fulfill one’s nature. To attain clarity is to reach destiny. The origin is where things have yet to arise; clarity is where the Dao is seen. Tranquility is ease; ease is stillness; stillness is knowledge; knowledge is movement. Movement and stillness mutually sustain one another. Thus, knowledge and tranquility mutually nourish one another, and harmony and principle emerge from one’s nature.

Harmony arises from what is so of itself—this is called virtue. Principle arises from spontaneity—this is called the Dao. Virtue is attained within, hence nothing is excluded—this is called boundless love. The Dao disperses through things, hence nothing is left unordered—this is called things finding their proper place.

To have capacity is to be benevolent; to have principle is to be righteous. Righteousness made manifest, things draw near—this is to show one’s lack of deceit. Loyalty is the absence of deceit. Benevolence suffices to embrace; righteousness suffices to order; loyalty suffices to draw things near. Then supreme joy arises within, and patterned refinement is manifest without.

Yet when ritual and music are practiced universally, the world falls into chaos. Those who rectify themselves yet veil their own virtue are sages. The virtue of the sage does not deliberately cover the world, yet the things of the world each rectify their nature. If one forcibly imposes virtue to cover them, things will lose their nature!

**Xiang Dao’s Annotation:**
At birth, humans are still—this is the nature of Heaven.

When things stir the senses, movement arises—this is the desire of human nature. What nature fundamentally is, is authenticity; what desire fundamentally values, is correctness. Now, if one refines one’s nature through worldly customs, authenticity is submerged in falsity, and if one seeks to restore one’s original nature through worldly learning, the more one learns, the more one loses one’s nature. If one muddies desire with worldly customs, correctness is drowned in depravity, and if one exhausts thought to attain clarity, the more one thinks, the more one’s will becomes confused.

Those who cultivated the Dao in ancient times did not act thus. They nurtured knowledge with tranquility, and so could govern their clarity and penetrate all principles. They nurtured tranquility with knowledge, and so could restore their original nature and exhaust all its potential. Nature is the root of knowledge and tranquility; harmonious order is their function. When knowledge and tranquility mutually nurture each other, benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music merge into the Dao and virtue. When knowledge and tranquility mutually lose each other, the Dao and virtue branch into benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music. Now, righteousness emerges from virtue, and principle emerges from the Dao—these are already diminished. How much more so when music emerges from benevolence and ritual from righteousness?

**Bixu’s Annotation:**
To stand in the road and avoid filth, to dwell in impurity yet seek reflection—what is this if not obscuration? Restlessness and competition only bring confusion; tranquility and stillness yield knowledge. When knowledge is not enslaved, one preserves stillness well. When knowledge is not employed, one can thus harmonize. When tranquility is naturally preserved, one thus attains order. Though one may borrow cultivation and practice, the root lies in natural self-attainment, and so one can harmonize self and others and, being unobstructed, govern things. Supreme benevolence is one with virtue, taking containment as its root; supreme righteousness is one with the Dao, taking unobstructed order as its source. To abide in harmony without excess is music; to regulate appearance and conform to measure is ritual. Ritual responds to things; music rectifies nature. Self-restraint preserves authenticity; leading others brings chaos. Those who rectify themselves veil their own virtue, and when virtue is firmly established, they guard tranquility without imposition—this is how each rectifies their nature and life, with tranquility and knowledge mutually nurturing.

**Yongzhai’s Note:**
"Refining nature with worldly learning" criticizes the Confucian and Mohist discourses on nature of the time. To cultivate nature with worldly learning in order to restore its original state, or to be muddied by profit and desire yet seek to attain a state of emptiness and clarity—this is the height of folly and ignorance. Stillness gives rise to wisdom, hence "nurturing knowledge with tranquility." When one knows that one’s original nature is without things, how can knowledge be employed? Only then can one attain stillness, hence "nurturing tranquility with knowledge." When the two mutually nurture each other, one then recovers one’s natural nature. "Harmonious order" means harmony and compliance, attaining one’s original harmonious and compliant nature through stillness and stability. The six characters "nurturing knowledge with tranquility, nurturing tranquility with knowledge" are most profound—Dao and virtue are precisely this harmony. To be all-embracing is to be all-loving; to be all-ordering is to let each attain its proper place. When righteousness is made manifest and things draw near, this is exhausting oneself—what is called loyalty. When the center’s authenticity and purity are outwardly expressed, and one seeks within the center what is expressed, this is joy arising, and once arisen, how can it cease? To trust in the conduct of one’s body and have natural refinement is to move in accord with ritual. To seek ritual and music externally without knowing their root is called "partial conduct," for one sees only half.

"Veiling" means obscuring. When virtue accumulates, others naturally rectify themselves. "Not imposing" means I do not apply virtue to others; imposition causes things to lose their nature. All explanations rely on worldly learning, but Chen Bixu, following Zhang Junfang’s collated edition, omits the character for "worldly" before "learning," making the meaning clear: nature is fundamentally natural and does not rely on cultivation. Today’s scholars value reputation and worldly approval, which is refining nature through custom. Yet they still painstakingly advance in learning to restore nature’s original state—broad but without focus, authenticity is lost all the more! Indulging in likes and dislikes, sinking into delusion without return—this is muddying desire with custom. Yet they still exhaust thought and contemplate minutely to attain clarity—knowledge is depleted and effort is wasted, and clarity becomes ever more distant!

Generally, unless one is endowed by Heaven with exceptional talent, one cannot be without learning; learning serves to nurture nature. Heaven bestows wisdom, illuminating with the achievements of the ancients, imprinting what is shared in my heart, aiming only to return to simplicity and restore the root—this is not to carve holes in people to increase their knowledge and augment their miscellaneous poisons. Human nature is fundamentally without evil, yet cannot be without desire. Following nature with the Dao, desire arises correctly, as in hunger and thirst, cold and fatigue, clothing and rest. Refining nature through custom, desire arises from depravity, as in craving fine food and rich drink, splendid clothing, and unrestrained repose. When desire enters depravity, nature loses its goodness, sinking into worldly custom and drifting ever farther from the Dao!

The Dao values tranquility and magnanimity; the world values ostentation and competition. Learning is not true learning; thought is not true thought—this is how the human mind and the mind of the Dao diverge, and how supreme goodness and great evil arise. Only by cutting off learning and thought can one restore nature’s original state and attain clarity. Why, then, does one pursue external learning to adulterate it and employ reckless thought to obstruct it? Thus, learning is said to obscure and authenticity to diminish; thought is said to trouble and the Dao to recede—this is what the true person laments!

As for those who preserve their natural nature without being refined by custom, they originally do not seek to restore it yet restore it; those who preserve the correctness of their desires without being muddied by custom originally do not seek clarity yet attain it. Only when the Dao gathers in emptiness is this so.

The *Analects* says, "Learning without thought is blindness; thought without learning is perilous." Learning and thought are what the sage and worthy rely on for cultivation—why does the *Nanhua* reject them? It is because the worthy take inner learning as learning and near thought as thought, while the sage takes the cessation of learning as learning and the absence of thought as thought—this is how they differ from the worldly learning of broad knowledge and extensive erudition.

From inner learning to the cessation of learning, from near thought to the absence of thought—here the sage’s and worthy’s capacities are complete!

Tranquility governs stillness; awareness governs movement. Stillness engenders moisture; movement engenders heat. When heat and moisture attain the mean, harmony and principle emerge. Harmony is the essence of virtue; principle is the fittingness of affairs. Both reside within our nature—they are not imposed from without.

The worldly know that tranquility cannot mutually nurture, so movement and stillness become partial. Profit and harm grind against each other, kindling a fire that scorches harmony, and true nature is diminished. Only those who cultivate the Way keep movement and stillness within the bounds of the Dao, responding to things without hoarding. They preserve tranquility to nurture awareness, yet when awareness arises, they do not employ it—thus nurturing tranquility in turn. When nature reaches harmony and affairs fulfill their principle, the harmony of heaven and earth responds. This is the clear proof of cultivating the self to order the world.

Later, [scholars] elaborated on *ren*, *yi*, loyalty, ritual, and music. The character *zhong* (loyalty) is discussed in detail in Guo Xiang’s commentary and Cheng Xuanying’s subcommentary—all should be understood as belonging to this mean.

When governance of the Way descends to exalting ritual and music, it grows ever more base, thus inviting disorder. Ritual and music do not themselves disorder the world; rather, those who follow them cannot avoid disorder—such is the force of circumstance.

If one could ascend from ritual and music to *ren* and *yi*, and from *ren* and *yi* return to the Dao and virtue, this would be the means to quell calamity and attain the safeguard of grand peace!

In ancient times, people dwelled in primordial chaos, yet with their age they attained serene indifference. In that era, yin and yang harmonized in stillness; ghosts and spirits did not disturb; the four seasons kept their rhythm; the myriad things were unharmed; the multitudes did not die young. Though humans possessed knowledge, they had no use for it. This was called "supreme unity."

At that time, none acted yet all was constantly spontaneous. When virtue later declined, Sui Ren and Fu Xi began to rule the world—thus compliance arose, yet unity was lost. When virtue declined further, Shen Nong and the Yellow Emperor began to rule the world—thus stability arose, yet compliance was lost. When virtue declined still further, Yao and Shun began to rule the world, initiating the currents of governance and transformation. They diluted purity and scattered simplicity, departing from the Dao to pursue goodness, risking virtue to enact conduct. Only then did they abandon nature to follow the heart.

Hearts vied with hearts in discernment, yet this was insufficient to settle the world. Thus they appended culture and augmented it with breadth. Culture extinguished substance; breadth drowned the heart. Then the people grew confused and disordered, unable to return to their nature and restore their origin.

Guo’s commentary: "Entrusting to spontaneity, thus attaining supreme unity." The decline of virtue stems from sages not succeeding one another. Those in power could not practice non-action yet coveted the legacy of non-action, thus bringing about corruption.

The world had already lost unity; confusion could not be resolved, so they let go and did not pursue it, contenting themselves with what was settled. Sages could entrust the world to its own attainment—how could they make the world attain sageliness! Thus the paths of emperors and kings shifted with the age, yet the Way of the sage remained ever whole.

"Goodness" is a term that exceeds what is fitting—there is goodness, yet the Dao is not whole. "Conduct" is acting contrary to nature—conduct is established, yet virtue is not level. When the heart enslaves itself, nature departs. When hearts compete to be first in discernment, there is no longer any entrusting to nature. Forgetting knowledge and entrusting to nature—only then is there stability.

Culture and breadth are adornments of the heart’s substance. The origin is the root of nature and destiny.

Lü’s commentary: What is called "dwelling in primordial chaos and attaining serene indifference" refers to the wondrous state of supreme unity in the eras of Sui Ren and Fu Xi. The various sages were but coarse elaborations of primordial chaos and serene indifference.

Viewed from that wondrous state, to go among the world with the Dao and cause the people to be without knowledge or desire is called "supreme unity"—and rightly so. Viewed from those coarse elaborations, though all ruled the world, their virtue could not avoid decline and did not emerge from supreme unity. Thus those who practice the Dao constantly reject sageliness and discard knowledge, returning to nothingness.

Yet this chapter’s discussion reaches this point precisely because, in the time of supreme unity, even Sui Ren, Fu Xi, and the Yellow Emperor could not find a place within its inquiry. Those who study the sages’ words and their elaborations, unaware that within themselves lies the capacity to set the myriad things in motion without sharing the sages’ anxieties—when they hear these words and react with shock, doubt, laughter, or astonishment, it is hardly surprising.

From Sui Ren to Yao and Shun, the currents of governance and transformation diluted purity and scattered simplicity. The responses varied in depth, as the saying goes: "When the great Dao is abandoned, there is *ren* and *yi*. When knowledge and wisdom emerge, there is great falsity."

The Dao is without un-goodness; if there is what is called "goodness," it does not accord. Virtue has no conduct; if there is what is called "conduct," it is not level. *Ren* is the chief of goodness; *yi* is the means by which it is enacted. When the Dao and virtue are risked, this is abandoning nature to follow the heart.

When transformation gives rise to desire, I would quell it with the nameless uncarved block. Now, to settle the world’s hearts with the heart—hearts vie in discernment yet remain insufficient to settle the world. Thus they append culture and extinguish substance, augment with breadth and drown the heart.

Culture is ritual and music; breadth is learning. Substance is nature. When ritual and music are enacted, the world is disordered. How can one seek to restore the origin and attain clarity?

Du’s annotation: From "people dwelled in primordial chaos" to "this was called supreme unity"—this meaning has appeared repeatedly above and will not be explained again.

Sui Ren altered fire; Fu Xi instituted culture, thus beginning the heart that acts for the world. Though they could comply with human hearts, they could not make them one, as in the age of primordial chaos. Shen Nong attacked Gong Gong; the Yellow Emperor battled Chi You—though their intent was to pacify the people, they were no longer compliant with the multitudes. Yao harmonized the hundred clans; Shun exiled the Four Villains—here began the currents of governance and transformation.

Thus, Confucius began his *Book of Documents* with the Tang and Yu dynasties. Goodness is the dispersion of the Dao, a path that people can trace and a practice they can follow. Yet when virtue becomes perilous and conduct becomes level, one abandons nature to follow the heart—and that heart, too, arises. When hearts recognize one another, distinctions forcibly emerge. To take knowledge as knowing is thus insufficient to settle the world.

When refinement prevails, substance perishes; when erudition accumulates, the heart labors. The people begin to grow confused and disordered, unable to return to their nature and feelings.

Du’s annotation: When one is whole in the Dao, there is nothing to comply with. Compliance is compliance with things, and without compliance, there is no rest. Without rest, there is no disorder. The loss of wholeness leads to compliance; the loss of compliance leads to rest; the loss of rest leads to disorder. From the ancients, three descents brought us to the Tang and Yu dynasties, where the people first grew confused and restless. Without means to return to their nature and feelings, they were not compliant; without means to restore their origin, they were not whole.

The Dao originally continues goodness, yet in practice, though one may act with virtue, it is perilous. Nature is the realm of the heart; the heart is the ruler of nature. Nature is never not tranquil, yet the heart may move it. What is tranquil is never not pure, yet what moves it severs it.

Those who are adept in the Dao preserve the heart to nurture nature. Those who are inept abandon nature to follow the heart, so that their hearts and others’ contend, vying to be first in recognition, grasping at right and wrong, weighing profit and harm—how far they have strayed from the Dao! What can such petty knowledge do to settle the world?

When knowledge is deemed insufficient to settle the world, one then clings to refinement to adorn substance, only to extinguish substance; one adds erudition to guide the heart, only to exhaust the heart. This is like raising dust to halt dust or fanning the wind to quench flames—how could the world not grow confused and disordered?

Bixu’s annotation: In the age of supreme virtue, there was unadorned simplicity and no knowledge, serene indifference and no desire—thus, all was pure and whole. Sui Ren drilled fire; Fu Xi drew the trigrams. To comply with the feelings of things is no longer to be whole. Shen Nong wielded the plow; the Yellow Emperor brandished weapons. To have something to rest in is no longer to be compliant. Yao campaigned against Dan Shui; Shun attacked the You Miao—thus, simplicity scattered.

To do good is to draw near to fame, to depart from the Dao. To act alone harms life, to make virtue perilous. To abandon the profound tranquility of nature and follow the heart one has cultivated, to measure heart with heart, to contend in prior recognition—this is the flower of the Dao and the beginning of folly. Thus, it is known that knowledge is insufficient to settle the world.

Serenity can nurture the myriad things; in the Dao, substance endures. To cut off learning is to still the heart; to discard knowledge is to return to the root; to practice non-action is to restore the origin.

Master Yongzhai observes: "Primal chaos" signifies concealment without self-revelation. "Vast stillness" means that above and below do not seek one another. When the world is wholly complete, nothing is lacking in the Dao, and daily it approaches oneness. To know there is a principle to follow is already to depart from pure oneness. When each person takes principle as their resting place, they assert the self and stray from the Dao.

The name of goodness only distances one further from the Way. Where conduct is visible, virtue is no longer balanced. To abandon the nature of spontaneity and follow the heart of deliberate action—when I act with intent and others respond in kind—is for heart to scrutinize heart. Knowledge is insufficient, and when augmented by ritual, music, and cultural refinement, to fix the mind upon these is to sink into drowning.

Spirits guard their depths; the myriad things fulfill their natures. As for humans, to possess knowledge yet not employ it—is this not to attain primal chaos and vast stillness? Can this be so? This is called "supreme oneness," for in high antiquity the ruler’s virtue was truly pure, and the people’s hearts knew no division.

When virtue declined, there arose those who opposed it, and thus to make harmonizing the world one’s aim was already to depart from supreme oneness. When there arose those who disturbed it, to make pacifying the world one’s aim was to violate true nature. Descending to the eras of Tang and Yu, governance and transformation dissolved simplicity, and departing from the Dao and virtue, they practiced good conduct—thus receding ever further from nature.

To measure heart with heart? Knowledge is insufficient, and when supplemented with literary embellishment, it is like embracing kindling to quench fire. If one cannot even attain one’s own nature and emotions, what can one do for the world?

The *Nanhua* discusses the age of Tang and Yu as already so far removed from the Dao. In high antiquity, simplicity was like that of an infant; next came the ability to speak and laugh, with joy and anger; from then on, joy, anger, sorrow, and delight intermingled within, while deceit, cunning, and treachery manifested in form. To hope for a return to simplicity and the restoration of uncarved purity—is this not difficult?

Now, desiring to clarify the source and purify the stream, one cites Suiren and Fuxi as examples of virtue in decline. What is longed for is to elevate the people above high antiquity, to a state of possessing virtue without rank—how lamentable!

*Collected Subtleties of the Meaning of the Nanhua True Scripture*, Scroll Forty-Nine, ends. #1 The correct character is *hou*.

*Collected Subtleties of the Meaning of the Nanhua True Scripture*, Scroll Fifty. By Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin.

**Cultivating Nature, Part Two**

From this perspective, the world has lost the Dao, and the Dao has lost the world—world and Dao mutually perish. How can the person of Dao arise in the world, and how can the world arise in the Dao? If the Dao cannot arise in the world, and the world cannot arise in the Dao, then even if the sage does not dwell in the mountains and forests, his virtue remains hidden. Hidden, yet not by his own concealment.

The ancients spoke of "recluses" not as those who crouch in concealment and remain unseen, nor as those who seal their words and refuse to speak, nor as those who hoard their knowledge and withhold it—rather, their time and fate were greatly awry. Had their time and fate aligned to flourish throughout the world, they would have returned to unity without leaving a trace. Had their time and fate been utterly thwarted in the world, they would have deeply rooted themselves, stabilized their essence, and awaited the turning—this is the way to preserve the self.

Guo’s commentary: The Dao, being without esteem, can thus endure in the world. Yet if the world endures, it esteems the Dao; once esteemed, the Dao is lost. The Dao cannot prevent the world from esteeming it, nor can the world refrain from esteeming the Dao—thus they mutually perish. Were there no esteem, they would mutually arise. The reason one does not conceal oneself now is due to the emotions that spur mutual arising. How does this arise? Through the absence of esteem.

None know to return to unity and still the paths, yet they chase traces to seek unity—striving further, they lose unity all the more. This is the greatest error! Even if one rises to clarify it, opens speech to express it, or displays knowledge to reveal it, how can mutual arising occur? When time and fate flourish, this is the time of tranquil indifference, where one follows the nature of things, and their nature unifies of itself—thus there are no bounds. When time and fate are thwarted, this is a time that cannot be tranquil, yet even in a world of affairs, the sage never fails to remain indifferent, deeply rooting and stabilizing essence to await its natural course. This is how the Dao is not lost—there has never been a case where the self endured and the world did not flourish.

Lü’s commentary: When world and Dao mutually arise, the sage acts and all things behold him. When world and Dao mutually perish, the sage wanders amidst the common world yet remains unknown—he is already hidden; why would he conceal himself in the mountains and forests? Returning to unity without trace is like the dream of Huaxu or the wanderings of Gushe. Deeply rooting and stabilizing essence is like the unshakable firmness of the unyielding. The way the dragon and snake endure through adversity is no different.

Observing Zhuangzi’s words, one senses his lament over the misalignment of time and fate. When world and Dao mutually perish, it is indeed cause for sorrow. Those who hear the Dao, encountering the flux of rise and fall, must know how to preserve the self. Yet Zhuangzi, who does not share the sage’s concerns, why would he lament amidst such great error?

Yi Zhu’s commentary: Dwelling in antiquity while practicing the Dao of today—this is the Dao losing the world. Dwelling in the present while practicing the Dao of antiquity—this is the world losing the Dao. Only with this world can this Dao be practiced; otherwise, world and Dao merely perish together. The Dao cannot arise in the world—this is fate. The world cannot arise in the Dao—this is the time. When time and fate are at odds, even if the sage does not dwell in the mountains and forests, his virtue remains hidden, as with Liezi in the Zheng gardens or Zhuangzi in the Lacquer Orchard.

To be hidden is to conceal one’s virtue. To conceal oneself is to hide one’s form. Chang Ju and Jie Ni were those who concealed their forms. The ancients’ recluses did not avoid land, avoid speech, or bind their knowledge—their time and fate were greatly awry, and they simply accepted it. When their time and fate aligned and their Dao flourished throughout the world, the sage never considered himself successful, returning to unity without displaying traces to others. When their time and fate were thwarted and their Dao was utterly obstructed in the world, the sage never considered himself impoverished, deeply rooting his foundation and stabilizing his essence. This is what Mencius meant by "great success does not augment, and reclusion does not diminish."

Unity is the essence of principle—only without striving can one enter the spiritual. The root is the fulfillment of nature—only by stabilizing essence can one reach destiny. The common people use it daily yet do not know it—this is what is meant by returning to unity without paths. A hundred generations await the sage without confusion—this is what is meant by deeply rooting, stabilizing essence, and awaiting it.

Detailed Dao commentary: The ancients knew that knowledge and tranquility nurtured each other—thus the Dao and the world could be understood. Today, world and Dao mutually perish—thus knowledge and tranquility can be understood. When the world loses the Dao, customs daily grow shallow. When the Dao loses the world, virtue daily declines. When the world cannot arise in the Dao, this is the time when heaven and earth are closed, and the worthy withdraw. Even if the sage does not dwell in the mountains and forests, he too will conceal himself—how much more so those beneath him?

The ancients’ "recluses" did not mean those who crouch in concealment, seal their words, or hoard their knowledge—they were those whose bodies emerged yet whose hearts remained hidden, like the floating duckweed, distinct from those who befriend trees and stones or herd with birds and beasts. The scripture speaks of "when the world has the Dao, the sage completes it"—his work is accomplished through non-action, returning to unity without trace. "When the world lacks the Dao, the sage lives"—he preserves his nature and life through enduring existence, deeply rooting and stabilizing essence. Completing it without forgetting others through self, living without harming self through others—thus he sees poverty as prosperity, prosperity as poverty. His spirit does not gallop outward, his essence is not depleted within—is this not the way to preserve the self?

Bixu’s commentary: When people endure, the Dao flourishes; when people perish, the Dao is lost. The mutual perishing of world and Dao is the course of history. People and the world are the branches—their essence lies in the root. Thus, Lao Dan as the Archivist, Nanhua as the Keeper of the Lacquer Orchard—their virtue was hidden. Yet they did not conceal themselves; the times made it so.

Boyi gathering ferns, Zilong fishing—this was the great misalignment of time and fate.

Returning to the One leaves no trace, achieving success without claiming it. Fu Yue in his trowel-wall building, Lü Wang in his riverbank fishing—these were deeply rooting and stabilizing essence. Yongzhai said: When the Dao and the world mutually perish, how can those of the Dao arise to stir the world’s perceptions? And how can the world’s people come to know the Dao? If the world does not know the Dao, then even if the sage stands before them, the multitude will not recognize him. It is not that the sage deliberately conceals himself; rather, the reclusive scholar, wishing to conceal his person, silence his words, and hide his knowledge, knows the time is not right—this is what is meant by "when the state lacks the Dao, feign foolishness." Returning to the One leaves no trace, achieving success without possessing it. Though the Dao may be practiced, it is entrusted to things without intent; what lies within me is simply the One.

"Rooting deeply" means withdrawing and concealing in secrecy; "stabilizing essence" means "daily secure your abode"—preserving the self to await the time. Examining the phrase "the Dao and the world mutually perish," the sentiment is deeply lamentable. The true person transcends worldly entanglements, naturally not troubled by personal encounters or their absence; this is spoken for the sake of the world’s course, and is indeed a lament for others’ sorrow. Yet in its ultimate realization, there is something that can resolve this sorrow: if one can, in an instant, illuminate the truth with principle, then one may dwell in poverty as in prosperity, regard slander as success—what then are gain and loss?

The recluses of old, knowing the misalignment of time and fate, accepted it; thus their virtue was hidden, but their persons were not concealed. Though dwelling in chaotic times, they harmonized their light with the dust, and no harm could reach them. The recluses of today, fleeing to remote places, make their traces conspicuous, unsettled in what should be settled—some even act strangely to provoke conflict.

Returning to the One without trace makes the luminous Dao appear dim. Deeply rooting and stabilizing essence makes the skilled merchant seem empty. This is what is meant by "adapting to the times in concealment or revelation, able to be dragon or snake"—wherever this body goes, it is preserved; wherever the Dao abides, it cannot be absent. The *Wenzhongzi*’s distinction between "heavenly concealment" and "human concealment" originates here.

The ancients who preserved themselves did not adorn their knowledge with eloquence, did not exhaust the world with their wisdom, did not deplete their virtue with their knowledge. Solemnly abiding in their place, they returned to their nature—what more was there to do? The Dao is not fulfilled through petty actions; virtue is not perfected through petty understanding. Petty understanding harms virtue; petty actions harm the Dao. Thus it is said: "Rectify yourself, and that is all!" "Enjoying wholeness" is called "attaining one’s aspiration."

What the ancients called "attaining one’s aspiration" did not refer to carriages and caps of office; it meant that nothing could augment their joy. What is now called "attaining one’s aspiration" refers to carriages and caps. Yet when these are on the body, they are not one’s nature and life—such things come fortuitously, as a lodging. As a lodging, their coming cannot be warded off, nor their going halted. Thus one does not indulge one’s aspirations for carriages and caps, nor follow the vulgar in poverty and constraint—one’s joy is the same in both. Therefore, one is simply without sorrow. If the lodging departs, one is not joyful. From this perspective, though there may be joy, it is not without distraction. Thus it is said: "Those who lose themselves in things and forfeit their nature to the vulgar are called inverted people."

Guo’s commentary: Following one’s true knowledge, guarding one’s self-attainment, walking the level path, vast and unobstructed—attaining one’s aspiration, solitary and serene in heart without sorrow or joy: this is "enjoying wholeness." What is called "attaining one’s aspiration" is fulfilling one’s inner self and being sufficient; comings and goings belong to external things, gain and loss are not of the self. Indifferent and composed, one does not sense the lodging on the body; open and self-content, one does not know poverty in oneself. Thus there is no joy in hearing praise or fearing blame. If the lodging departs and one is not joyful, then when it comes, one is distracted. Seeking externals while harming the inner self—this is inversion.

Lü’s commentary: Preserving the self is simply stillness; conducting oneself is not merely stillness, but must respond to change without harming stillness—this is acceptable. Forgetting words, yet knowing all without knowing; abandoning knowledge, yet virtue is fully equipped. Solemnly abiding in one’s place, one need not flee the world or separate from things, for worldly things cannot burden one—this is the way of conducting oneself. The Dao is not fulfilled through petty actions; virtue is not perfected through petty understanding. Thus one does not slightly diminish oneself to follow the world; this is what is meant by "rectifying oneself." "Enjoying wholeness" means that nothing can augment one’s joy. Aspiring to the Dao and seeking its attainment—this is what is called "attaining one’s aspiration." The Dao is one’s nature and life; carriages and caps are but lodgings of things. If one exchanges the joy of having nothing to augment for the departure of this lodging, one loses oneself and forfeits one’s nature—this is inversion.

Yi Du’s commentary: Preserving the self pertains to fate, speaking of what is in Heaven; conducting oneself pertains to the Dao, speaking of what is in man. Not adorning knowledge with eloquence is true knowledge without knowing; not exhausting the world with wisdom is forgetting the world entirely; not depleting virtue with knowledge is virtue without virtue. When the Dao acts externally, it is great; when virtue has something to recognize, it is vast. Petty actions harm the Dao; petty understanding harms virtue. Rectifying oneself means that all things in the world take their correctness from me—how could petty understanding or actions compare?

Sorrow and joy arise from nature and life; the world cannot diminish or augment them—this is the wholeness of sorrow and joy. Shun grieved over not winning his parents’ favor, yet even the world’s wealth and honor could not diminish his sorrow; Yanzi rejoiced in his gourd bowl and ladle, yet even the world’s wealth and honor could not augment his joy. Beyond this, all is external to sorrow and joy. If joy is not wholly preserved, it is not enough to be called "attaining one’s aspiration"; if something seizes one’s aspiration, it is lost again.

Man in the world is a lodging; carriages and caps on the body are a lodging within a lodging. Worldly people cling to their bodies as if they owned them, prizing carriages and caps and treasuring them, taking this as "attaining one’s aspiration." When the lodging departs, they are not joyful, not knowing that these are not of their nature and life.

Thus the noble person neither exults in prosperity nor feels shame in poverty—this is why they are free from sorrow. If one takes the transient carriages and caps as joy, and their departure as sorrow, then the joy of their former attainment was surely not untainted. To lose oneself and forfeit one’s nature is called "inversion"—no wonder!

**Detailed Annotation on the Dao:**
To exhaust knowledge in governing the world is a petty practice; to exhaust knowledge in exhausting virtue is a petty understanding. The Dao emerges from destiny, virtue emerges from nature. At birth, no one lacks the principle of preserving nature and destiny, virtue and the Dao. What the heart pursues lies nowhere beyond this—thus "attaining one’s aspiration" means nothing more than rejoicing in wholeness.

Those who lose their nature forget their priceless selves and chase after fleeting honors, taking carriages and caps as the root of life and destiny, and the physical form as the repository of sorrow and joy. They do not know that what they gain is but dust and decay, while what they lose is that by which they are themselves—how is this different from using the Marquis of Sui’s pearl to shoot a sparrow a thousand fathoms high?

**Bixu’s Annotation:**
The virtuous act values silence; the one who guards foolishness preserves blessings. Dwelling in tranquility, transcendent and serene, returning to the root and recovering destiny—what more is there to do? Petty practices distort custom; petty understanding boasts of its cleverness. Some lines bring benefit, others harm—how can this be called "attaining one’s aspiration"? What comes by chance cannot be warded off; what departs cannot be halted. To be swayed by things, gaining and losing—how much one is enslaved! Those without an inner master feel sorrow when it is lost, and thus their attainment is never untainted. This is joy in externals and loss within.

**Fu Zhai’s Saying:**
"Preserving the body" refers to times of non-action; "acting with the body" refers to times of action. To possess knowledge yet not adorn it with words, to have surplus wisdom yet not dare to use it all—thus, though one employs knowledge, one does not lose one’s natural nature. "Standing perilously in one’s place" means the foundation one establishes is lofty. "Returning to one’s nature" is to return to unity without trace. Non-action is the greatness of the Dao; action is a petty practice. Unknowing and unperceiving is the greatness of virtue; having knowledge is petty understanding. By rectifying oneself, things are rectified—thus what one rejoices in is whole, and the attainment of one’s aspiration lies here, not in external things. To add nothing to one’s joy is to turn inward and be sincere—no joy is greater than this.

Nature and destiny are Heaven’s nobility; carriages and caps are external things. Knowing their coming and going cannot be certain, the enlightened are not reckless in prosperity nor broken in poverty. Their joy is in the Dao, the same as others’ joy in carriages and caps. If joy resides in oneself, there is no time for sorrow; if joy depends on things, then when things depart, joy departs too. Joy that comes and goes is not true joy—thus it is never untainted.

The self and nature are the root; things and custom are the branches. To prize the branches and lose the root is called "the people of inversion." Discerning knowledge is the instrument of self-harm—thus those who preserve the body do not seek it. The virtue of the world returns to profound silence, to unknowing alone. "Towering" means standing alone, apart from the crowd. "Dwelling in one’s place" means being still and settled here, sufficient to return to one’s natural nature—what need is there for further seeking? Petty practices and petty understanding describe a narrow vision, thus a burden to virtue and the Dao.

The great person rectifies themselves, and things are rectified—thus perfect joy is whole and the original aspiration is attained. Only when nature and destiny are sufficiently valued within can carriages and caps be lightly regarded without.

What comes by chance, what departs temporarily—meet it without intention. If one sorrows when the transient departs, one must rejoice when it arrives, and that joy is surely tainted. When the self is lost through things and nature is lost through custom, then caps and shoes are worn upside down. To transform the people of the world thus would be difficult indeed!

"Acting with the body" should be "preserving the body"—the above text clarifies this. "Perilous" should be "towering."

The main idea of this chapter is that people, lacking a vision transcending worldly dust and blindly following worldly paths, gradually lose their original nature—all are those who refine their nature and confuse their desires with custom. Though not overtly evil, this obstructs the Dao even more. How much worse when one adds external learning and disturbs it with deluded thoughts, yet still hopes to restore the clarity of the beginning—this is like heading for Ying while turning the carriage north!

The True Person further fears that scholars may dread the vast emptiness, finding no place to apply effort, and thus sets forth the theory of harmonizing tranquility and knowledge, making it easier to enter. People living in the world, responding to situations and adapting to change, cannot forget knowledge. The use of knowledge harms tranquility—the key lies in carefully weighing what is appropriate and handling it with the Dao. When matters arise, knowledge and perception appear; when matters depart, tranquility remains. Over time, with long practice, both are transformed. Spirit, soul, and essence merge into supreme harmony, aligning nature and destiny with the subtle and formless, returning to the root of virtue and the Dao. From this, when one expands and dwells among the people of the world, blending indistinctly and attaining serenity, though possessing knowledge, one has no use for it. Thus the transformation is vast. How can one not lose the pure harmony? Customs tend toward superficiality and shallowness, departing from the Dao and endangering virtue, extinguishing authenticity and drowning the heart—leading to the mutual ruin of the world’s ways, beyond recovery!

Then there are the sages of the mountains and forests, deeply rooted and profoundly tranquil, awaiting the encounter of dawn and dusk. Preserving the body is how one preserves the Dao. The coming and going of the transient admit no joy or sorrow—how then can knowledge and discernment compare to the joy of wholeness and the attainment of aspiration, which transcends the glory of carriages and caps? People rest without knowing to seek this. This is the way of sages and worthies, concealing themselves to preserve their integrity.

The heart of the *Nanhua* is indeed revealed here.

*End of Volume Fifty of the* Nanhua True Scripture: An Ocean of Annotations and Subtle Meanings. *#1 The character "以" is missing below "不."*

*Volume Fifty-One of the* Nanhua True Scripture: An Ocean of Annotations and Subtle Meanings. *By the Daoist of Wulin, Chu Boxiu.*

**Chapter One: Autumn Floods**

When autumn floods arrive, the hundred streams pour into the Yellow River. The surging currents swell so vast that between its banks and islets, one cannot distinguish ox from horse. Thereat, the River Lord rejoiced, believing all the world’s beauty to be his alone. Following the current eastward, he reached the Northern Sea. Gazing east, he saw no end to the waters. Then the River Lord turned his face, sighed toward Ruo of the Northern Sea, and said:

There is a rustic saying: “One who hears a hundred teachings and deems none his equal—this describes me.” I once heard of those who belittle Confucius’s learning and make light of Boyi’s righteousness; at first, I did not believe it. Now that I behold the boundlessness of your waters, had I not come to your gate, I would have been in peril—forever ridiculed by those of great understanding.

Ruo of the Northern Sea replied:

A well-frog cannot speak of the sea, for it is confined by its hollow. A summer insect cannot speak of ice, for it is bound by its season. A narrow scholar cannot speak of the Dao, for he is constrained by his teachings. Now that you have emerged from your banks and beheld the great sea, you know your own limitations—only then can you be spoken to of great principles.

Of all the waters under heaven, none is greater than the sea. The ten thousand streams flow into it, yet it never fills, though none knows when they cease. Its tailgate drains it, yet it never empties, though none knows when it ends. Unchanged by spring or autumn, unmoved by flood or drought—its measure surpasses the flow of the Yangtze and Yellow River, beyond all reckoning. Yet I have never taken pride in this, for I compare my form to heaven and earth and receive my qi from yin and yang. Between heaven and earth, I am but a pebble or twig upon a great mountain. Even now, I feel my own smallness—how could I take pride in myself?

Consider the four seas within heaven and earth—are they not like a tiny crevice in a vast marsh? Consider the Central States within the seas—are they not like a grain of millet in a granary? The number of things is called ten thousand, yet humans are but one among them. Humans occupy the nine provinces, where grain grows and boats and carriages travel—yet each is but one among them. Compared to the ten thousand things, is this not like the tip of a hair on a horse’s body?

The succession of the Five Emperors, the strife of the Three Kings, the concerns of the benevolent, the toils of the devoted—all are encompassed herein. Boyi rejected it to gain fame; Confucius discoursed on it to display his erudition. Their self-regard was no different from your earlier pride in your waters.

**Guo Xiang’s Annotation:**
“Cannot distinguish ox from horse” describes its vastness. “Forever ridiculed by those of great understanding” means knowing one’s smallness and not presuming grandeur, for one’s principle and portion are inherently fixed, and the desire for eminence has no place therein. What beings naturally find peace in is each pursuing its own limit; knowing one’s portion, one may be spoken to of principle. The capacity of the hundred streams is measured by the river, the river by the sea, the sea by heaven and earth—each has its measure.

This rhetoric seems to suggest that observing the great can clarify the small, but its intent is otherwise! What the world rests in is not level; thus, those of great substance dismiss the small as insignificant, while those of small substance deem the great as utterly sufficient. Hence, they vie in boasting, look about in confusion—this is the delusion of the common folk. To correct this, nothing is better than first exhausting their differences and then following their own claims.

What is called “great” is utterly sufficient, so even an autumn hair adds no burden to heaven and earth. What is called “small” is without excess, so heaven and earth cannot surpass an autumn hair. Only then does each know its limit, and things rest in their portion. Those who wander freely use their natural steps to roam in the realm of self-contentment.

If one observes the great yet cannot be at peace with the small, or gazes upon the small and deems it much, one will rush into the realm of victory and defeat, aiding the world’s boastfulness—how can this grasp the essence of the *Nanhua*? The distinction between small and great cannot be overstepped. Thus, the deeds of the Five Emperors, Three Kings, seven worthies, and devoted scholars do not extend beyond a single domain. Things have their fixed domains; even the most knowing cannot exceed them. Thus, the contrast between small and great serves to illuminate the boundlessness of the supreme principle.

**Lü Huiqing’s Annotation:**
“When autumn floods arrive, the hundred streams pour into the Yellow River” is a metaphor for learning that comes from without yet does not reach the great Dao. “Between its banks and islets, one cannot distinguish ox from horse” means pursuing the Dao without transcending its two sides and center, thus failing to attain all-encompassing vision. “Following the current to the Northern Sea” means seeking along principle and thus finding its ultimate destination. “Turning his face, sighing toward Ruo” means returning to the great Dao, following the path of boundlessness.

“Confined by its hollow” limits small and great. “Bound by its season” restricts near and far. “Constrained by his teachings” is controlled by doctrines and boundaries. This is why the world cannot attain freedom. Emerging from the banks and beholding the great sea, one sheds these confines and attains the vision of boundlessness—only then can one be spoken to of great principle. “The ten thousand streams flow into it, yet it never fills” means that adding to it does not increase it...

The Tail Conduit drains it yet it never empties—thus diminishing it does not increase its loss. It is not constrained by near or far, nor limited by small or great: such is water’s nearness to the Dao.

The Four Seas lie within Heaven and Earth; the Central States lie within the seas; and humankind lies among the ten thousand things. Though faint as if absent or present, so slight is its standing, yet the Five Emperors, the Three Kings, the humane, and the worthy have wearied themselves with cares no greater than this. Some have even renounced it to make a name, or spoken of it to display their learning. Yet from the boundless perspective of the great Dao, their claims are trivial and their knowledge scant—how could this be mere empty talk?

Lin Yi’s solitary note: Those confined by locality cannot turn from their surroundings; those bound by time cannot adapt to change; those shackled by doctrine cannot follow the Dao. The Dao is the year; the sage is the season. Clinging to a single season and doubting the year, one will never hear of the Dao.

The sage’s words respond to the times and change accordingly: what changes is speech, what remains constant is the Dao. The Dao disperses into teachings, and each teaching peddles its master’s doctrine. Over time, these harden into rigid constraints, clogging the flow. Today, Confucians condemn Buddhists, Buddhists condemn Daoists—unaware that the Three Sages established their teachings with the same intent. Failing to grasp this, all remain bound by doctrine.

Now, the River Lord emerges from his banks and beholds the sea, no longer blinded by partiality, and thus can be spoken to of great principle. The Northern Sea receives the ten thousand streams yet never fills; the Tail Conduit drains it yet it never empties. Its flow far surpasses the Yangtze and Yellow River—how could it be measured? Yet it never boasts of this, for when compared to Heaven and Earth, it is shaped by them and governed by yin and yang. My form exists between Heaven and Earth like a twig or pebble upon Mount Tai. A termite’s nest in a tree hollow, a grain of millet or mustard seed placed among mountains and marshes—each is as insignificant as the Northern Sea within Heaven and Earth.

Things are numbered by the myriad as a full count. Humankind is but one among the ten thousand things. The Central States are but a gathering of people within the Nine Provinces—how different from a single hair on a horse’s body? The Five Emperors’ succession of abdications, the Three Kings’ wars of conquest, the humane’s concern for the people, the worthy’s fulfillment of duty—though their deeds differ, all are confined to the tiniest of measures. Boyi renounced his state to make a name; Confucius compiled the classics to display his learning and boast to his age—both were like the River Lord priding himself on his waters.

Chen Xiangdao’s note: Laozi often likened the Dao to water, for the Dao depends on having a root, just as water values having a source. Zhuangzi used the Northern Sea to represent the sage’s Dao and the autumn river to symbolize the proliferation of the Hundred Schools. At that time, the great Dao was fragmented among the Hundred Schools, and natural truth was submerged in vulgar habits. Yet those of limited vision still delighted in believing all the world’s beauty lay within themselves—like the frog in the well who cannot be spoken to of the sea, or the summer insect who cannot be spoken to of ice. Only upon awakening does one look up to the heavens and belittle the world’s dwellings, ascend Mount Tai and recognize the smallness of all other peaks—this is why the “Autumn Floods” was written.

The Hundred Schools’ learning exalts expansion and multitude, hence the allegory of the River Lord. The sage’s Dao values harmony with things, hence the allegory of the Sea Lord. The ten thousand streams flow into it yet it never fills; the Tail Conduit drains it yet it never empties—this is because the Returning Abyss has no bottom. When small and great are compared, the burdens of excess and deficiency arise; when small and great are forgotten, the emotions of pride and awe vanish. Zhuangzi does not seek mutual forgetting but mutual comparison, driving lesser ways to find their home in the great expanse.

Chen Bixu’s note: “Gazing at the ocean” describes the vastness of the waters. Before reaching the sea’s mouth, one remains narrow and crude, mocked by those without corners. Thus, adapting to change and embracing breadth is the great Dao. Noble and petty each have their limits; to speak beyond one’s measure is to invite disgrace. Only those who recognize their disgrace can be spoken to of principle; only those who know their folly are not truly foolish.

No water is greater than the sea, yet it never boasts—this embodies the virtue of humility, putting others first and oneself last. The struggles of Qi and Wei over a snail’s horn, the multitudes dwelling in the tiniest of spaces—these are analogies for the petty. The Five Emperors’ “continuity” refers to the succession of benevolence and righteousness.

Lin’s *Fuzhai Oral Teachings* states: *Jing* means turbid—the Yellow River surges and muddies, swelling its banks, hence “the great *jing* flow of the two banks,” not the *Jing* of the Jing and Wei rivers. *Yang* refers to the sea’s midst. *Ruo* is the name of a sea god. “Bound by locality and time” resembles the cricket unaware of spring and autumn. The Tail Conduit is the Scorched Waste, as seen in the *Classic of Mountains and Seas*. A *pan* hollow is a tiny burrow. Humankind is but one among the ten thousand things—this is discussed in relation to the vastness of the Great Void. Within the Nine Provinces, it is but a single entity—this is discussed in relation to grasses, trees, birds, and beasts. These two lines are exquisitely phrased, showing how small the world is: the knowledge and abilities of the Five Emperors and Three Kings do not exceed its bounds.

Chu’s *Superficial Views* states: “One who has seen the sea finds other waters unsatisfying; one who has studied at the sage’s gate finds other words inadequate.” Thus, when the autumn floods arrive, the River Lord rejoices; when he reaches the sea, he gazes in awe and shame—no wonder the Sea Lord invokes the parables of the well frog and summer insect. Then, describing the Northern Sea’s immeasurable vastness, he notes that the Four Seas within Heaven and Earth, the Central States within the Four Seas, are no more than a hair on a horse’s body—how can one know there is nothing beyond Heaven and Earth greater still? Thus, this chapter uses the dialogue between river and sea to clarify the distinctions of small and great, few and many, akin to the debates of the roc and cicada. The transformations of its literary structure grow ever more marvelous.

The Sea Lord first responds with the intent to loosen the constrained views of the narrow scholar, dispelling his delusions of self-importance and guiding him toward the grander Way. The full depth of this discourse unfolds below.

The River Lord asks: “Then may I consider Heaven and Earth as great and the tip of a hair as small?”

The Northern Sea Lord replies: “No. For things have measure without end, time without cessation, division without constancy, and beginning and end without fixity. Thus, the one of great wisdom observes both far and near: small yet not meager, great yet not excessive, knowing measure to be boundless. He verifies past and present, ancient and modern, and so remains untroubled by distance, unconfounded by brevity, knowing time to be unceasing. He examines fullness and emptiness, and thus gains without delight, loses without sorrow, knowing division to be inconstant. He perceives the level path, and thus lives without elation, dies without calamity, knowing beginning and end to be without fixity.

“Consider: what man knows is less than what he does not know; the time of his life is less than the time before his birth. Seeking to exhaust the boundless realm of the greatest with what is most minute—this is why he becomes confused and cannot attain self-possession. From this perspective, how can one know the tip of a hair suffices to define the finest limit? And how can one know Heaven and Earth suffice to exhaust the realm of the greatest?”

Guo’s commentary: “Each thing has its measure; life and death follow their seasons; gain and loss are allotted by fate; beginning and end renew daily. Each is sufficient in itself, without excess—thus, whether distant or near, small or great, each thing has its measure. *Shun* means ‘illuminating.’ *Jingu* means ‘past and present.’ *Yao* means ‘long.’ *Rang* means ‘short.’ Verifying past and present, one knows transformation does not cease with life and death—thus, one does not grow weary of the long nor stumble over the short. Observing the alternation of fullness and emptiness, one knows fate is not constant in gain. To forget sorrow and joy, life and death—this is the true Way of daily renewal. Illuminating the daily renewal of beginning and end, one knows the past cannot be clung to or retained. Thus, one treads the new without alarm, relinquishes the old without surprise. Though the transformations of life and death are as one, what one knows remains limited; each lifetime has its allotment. Better to rest content in one’s received portion—then great and small are both sufficient. If the tip of a hair does not seek the achievement of Heaven and Earth, then all else in the body becomes superfluous. If Heaven and Earth are not seen as greater than the tip of a hair, then their forms and appearances are merely self-sufficient—how can one know what defines the finest as fine or the greatest as great?”

Lü’s commentary: “The Dao is neither small nor great—how can it have a fixed form? Now, Heaven and Earth: we deem them the greatest, yet when we exhaust all we know, we cannot reach their limit. Then what we call great—is it truly great? What we call small—is it truly small? Small is not meager; great is not excessive—this is to know measure as boundless. I take *shun* as ‘past’ and *jin* as ‘present,’ yet before the word is spoken, the present has already become the past. Then what we call past and present—do they ever cease? Verifying that past and present are both ‘old,’ one remains untroubled by distance, unconfounded by brevity, knowing time to be unceasing. How can I languish in service to a century’s lord—this is to be troubled by distance. Pengzu was famed for his longevity, yet when the common people compare themselves to him, they stumble over brevity. The sun turns at noon; the moon wanes after fullness. Observing fullness and emptiness, one gains without delight, loses without sorrow, knowing division to be inconstant. There is always a beginning to an end, an end to a beginning. Tracing origin to outcome, one perceives the level path—thus, one lives without elation, dies without calamity, knowing beginning and end to be without fixity. Then what we call time, division, beginning, and end—are they truly known? If knowledge is not true knowledge, then what is known is surely less than what is unknown!
