After birth, one has knowledge; before birth, one has none—thus, the time of one’s life is surely less than the time before one’s birth. Knowing the most minute, yet seeking to exhaust the boundless realm of the greatest with it—how can this not lead to confusion and self-loss?”

Yu Du’s commentary: “Viewed by form, things have small and great; viewed by the Dao, things have no small or great. *Measure* is the balance of things. *Time* is the transformation of things. *Division* is the differentiation and regulation of things. *Beginning and end* are the life and death of things. From the perspective of great wisdom, none of these suffice to determine the far or near, small or great of things. Illuminating and verifying the Way traversed in past and present, though it be distant, the mind suffers no obstruction. What one takes is easily gathered, without forced stumbling—this is what one who knows time to be unceasing can do. Observing fullness and emptiness, gain and loss arise without attachment, knowing division to be inconstant. The world’s sorrows all stem from gain and loss; only the one of great wisdom knows gain and loss are not one’s own, allowing them to follow their natural course without joy or sorrow. Perceiving the level path, life and death do not move the heart—thus, one renews daily without clinging to the past. When man has knowledge, he is enslaved by it, toiling in body and resting in mind, chasing things and forgetting the self—this is not as good as the self-possession of non-knowledge. After birth, one is enslaved by life, restless and agitated—this is not as good as the time before birth, utterly still and empty. Man’s knowledge is most minute; the realm of the myriad things is most vast. To seek the vast with the minute—what is this if not confusion? To know the measure of things is boundless, then small and great are not matters of meagerness or excess. To know time is unceasing, then past and present are not grounds for weariness or stumbling. To know division is inconstant, then gain and loss are not grounds for sorrow or joy. To know beginning and end are without fixity, then life and death are not grounds for calamity or elation. What man uses to observe these is his knowledge.”

Thus, the possession of knowledge arises from the fact of having life. If one can obscure the very grounds of knowing and return to the state before birth, then who is to say the great is not the most minute, or the minute is not the most great?

*Bi Xu’s Commentary:* When the measure of things is boundless, one cannot speak of small or great. When time is unceasing, one cannot speak of succession or decay. When division is inconstant, one cannot speak of gain or loss. When beginning and end are without fixity, one cannot speak of transformation or change.

The great person purifies and gazes into the profound mirror, knowing distant things as small. Their use is manifold, yet near to the great principle, and what they expend is most minimal—thus their capacity knows no limit. To dance is to move as of old. Remote and unilluminable, like the present rushing past and unprovable; things shift and cannot be grasped, each day renews and cannot be clung to—thus time is hard to retain. What value is there in examining the fullness of wealth? Therefore, one does not rejoice in gaining it. Knowing the baseness of poverty and emptiness, one does not grieve in losing it. Knowing life and death as departure and return, one does not distinguish delight from aversion. Welcoming, one does not see the beginning; following, one does not see the end—how could principle have fixity?

Thus, discriminating knowledge has limits, while the vast and empty void is boundless. In life, profit and harm intermingle; in death, all is silent and vacant. To pursue the Kunlun wastes with the aims of an ant or midge is to be confounded. The tip of a hair is complete in itself, its minute detail more than sufficient; the vast expanse of heaven and earth is flawed and incomplete, its great domain insufficient.

*Yongzhai’s Note:* Earlier, it spoke of the great; here, it speaks of the absence of small and great—this is what is meant by "nothing is greater than the tip of an autumn hair, yet Mount Tai is small." The measure of things is boundless, meaning it cannot be quantified. Time is unceasing, meaning cold and heat, day and night. Division is inconstant, meaning being and non-being, gain and loss. Beginning and end refer to the new and the old.

Only the person of great knowledge can then possess the four knowings below: perceiving past and present as one, thus what approaches but has not yet arrived is distant yet not a cause for sorrow; what recedes and may be grasped is easy yet not a cause for struggle. Following the correct Dao, one leaves life and death to themselves. Understanding this, one knows the end is like the beginning—it cannot be taken as fixed.

What man knows is man; what he does not know is Heaven. After birth, I know it; before birth, how could I know? To seek the vastness of Heaven with man’s most minute knowledge—is this not confusion and self-loss? If one can know the inconstancy of the measure of things, time, and division, then what are beginning and end, small and great, more and less?

Examining the unceasing flux of past and present, this principle becomes visible. "Remote" refers to the passage of long time; "receding" refers to swift transformation. Not questioning is to be without weariness toward what is born. Not stumbling is to be without seeking to augment life.

The span of life is fixed by one’s allotted portion—one must simply accept it. Though man cannot be without birth or without knowledge, the sutra speaks of "not being as good as having no knowledge" and "not being as good as not yet being born." This is because worldly people do not pursue true knowledge but seek delusive knowledge, do not preserve life in its wholeness but seek to augment it. With what is limited, they chase what is boundless; forgetting their inherent portion, they covet what lies beyond. If they cannot even discern the advantages and harms that concern themselves, how can they determine the boundaries of the fine and vast in the principles of things?

"Not being as good as having no knowledge" refers to Wang Ni’s answer to Nie Que. "Not being as good as not yet being born" refers to the skull’s unwillingness to be troubled by inquiry. Yet since one is already born and already possesses knowledge, how can one avoid this? The answer lies in being able to take non-birth as birth and non-knowledge as knowledge—then what burden is there in life, and what possession in knowledge?

*The Meaning of the Ocean of the True Scripture of the Southern Florescence, Fascicle Fifty-One* (End)
#1 In Zhao Lian’s annotated edition, *xu* 虚 is written as *xu* 墟.
#2 *Meng* 盟 is an error for *ming* 明.
#3 *Shuai* 率 is an error for *nian* 年.

*The Meaning of the Ocean of the True Scripture of the Southern Florescence, Fascicle Fifty-Two*
By Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin

**Autumn Floods, Part Two**

The River Earl said: "All the debaters of the world say: 'The most refined has no form; the greatest cannot be encompassed.' Is this truly so?"

The Lord of the Northern Sea replied: "One who views the great from the perspective of the small cannot exhaust it; one who views the small from the perspective of the great cannot discern it. The refined is the subtlest of the small; the vast is the fullness of the great—thus their advantages differ. This is the nature of their conditions.

The refined and the coarse are limited to what has form. What has no form cannot be divided by calculation; what cannot be encompassed cannot be exhausted by calculation. What can be discussed in words is the coarse aspect of things; what can be grasped by intention is the refined aspect of things. That which words cannot discuss and intention cannot reach does not pertain to the refined or the coarse.

Therefore, the conduct of the great person does not involve harming others, nor does it emphasize benevolence and kindness. Their actions are not for profit, nor do they despise gatekeepers and servants. They do not contend over wealth and goods, nor do they excessively yield or defer. In affairs, they do not rely on others; they do not overvalue laboring for sustenance, nor do they despise greed and corruption. Their conduct differs from the common, yet they do not excessively avoid eccentricity. In action, they follow the multitude, yet they do not despise flattery and obsequiousness. The world’s ranks and emoluments are insufficient to encourage them; punishments and shame are insufficient to humiliate them. They know that right and wrong cannot be divided, and that the fine and the vast cannot be demarcated.

It is said: 'The person of the Dao is not renowned; the highest virtue is not attained; the great person has no self.' This is the utmost of restrained distinction."

**Guo’s Commentary:**
The eye’s vision has its limits; thus, in regard to the great, there is that which it cannot exhaust, and in regard to the small, there is that which it cannot discern. This is simply what the eye cannot reach. The refined and the great are not nonexistent—how could one know that which has no form and cannot be encompassed? Since great and small differ, their advantages cannot be the same. If something has no form and cannot be encompassed, then there is no difference in their advantageous conditions. That which words and intention cannot reach—how can there be refined or coarse? Words and intention exist, but that by which they exist does not. Seek beyond words and intention, enter the realm of no words and no intention, and only then will you attain it!

The great person has no intention but follows the movement of Heaven. With every step, they tread upon auspicious ground—how could they take the path of harming others? Without harming others, they do not overvalue their own kindness. Moving in accordance with principle and acting according to the capacity of things, they occupy their proper place. It is not that they despise and thus assign tasks; each fulfills their determined portion, naturally content and self-sufficient. Principle itself is without desire, thus there is nothing that must be or must not be. This is why they differ from the common yet follow principle, naturally upright. Glory and disgrace do not touch their hearts, thus they are profoundly the same. Entrusting things to their own nature, the nature of things flows freely, and merit and fame return to things—thus they are not renowned. When things each suffer no loss, then attainment and fame depart. It is simply a matter of entrusting things to themselves. Restraining to the utmost of their portion, they become obscure.

**Lü’s Commentary:**
One who views the great from the perspective of the small cannot exhaust it—this is merely what the eye’s power cannot reach, not that it cannot be encompassed. One who views the small from the perspective of the great—like a butterfly or gnat perched on a mosquito’s eyelash, seen yet unseen—this is merely what the eye cannot discern, not that it has no form.

The refined and the coarse pertain to what has form. What has no form cannot be divided by calculation; what cannot be encompassed cannot be exhausted by calculation. What can be discussed in words is the coarse aspect of things; what can be grasped by intention is the refined aspect of things. The Dao transcends words and intention and does not pertain to the refined or the coarse.

Thus, the conduct of the great person does not involve harming others—this is the nature of their inherent disposition. They do not emphasize benevolence and kindness—this is not deliberate action. Gatekeepers and servants act for profit. Yielding and deference mean not contending. Laboring for sustenance means not relying on others. Greed and corruption are the opposite. Avoiding eccentricity means acting for the sake of differing from the common. Flattery and obsequiousness mean following rulers and parents rather than the multitude. All of this arises naturally. The world’s ranks, emoluments, punishments, and penalties are insufficient to encourage or restrain them. How could they know the division of right and wrong or the demarcation of the fine and the vast? If one can restrain to the utmost of their portion, reaching the point of no division, this is why the person of the Dao is not renowned, why the highest virtue is not attained, and why the great person has no self.

**Yu Du’s Commentary:**
The scripture says: "Is the deep blue of the sky its true color, or is it so distant that it has no end?" Thus, one who views the great from the perspective of the small cannot exhaust it; one who views the small from the perspective of the great cannot discern it. The debaters of the world, relying on what their eyes can see, believe they have attained understanding—how foolish they are!

Moreover, Heaven and Earth are but small things within the void. From my perspective, they are boundlessly great—not because Heaven and Earth are great, but because my body is small! The tip of an autumn hair is fine within form, yet from afar, it cannot be seen—not because the autumn hair has no substance, but because I am distant from it. Abandoning the eye’s power and uniting with it in spirit, then even the greatest can be encompassed, and the smallest has form. This is why the Lord of the Sea excels in discussing the Dao and deducing it by principle.

The subtlest is called "minute"; the refined is even smaller. The *ping* is chaff. Viewed from the great, it is still a fine thing; viewed from the refined, it is already the fullness of the great. The refined and coarse of things can be grasped by intention; what can be discussed in words merely exhausts things—how could it suffice to encompass the Dao? Only the wordless word, what the ear cannot hear and intention cannot fathom, what those with minds cannot attain—how could it be exhausted by the refined or the coarse?

The great person is self-sufficient within their portion. Though they do not harm others, their benevolence and kindness extend to others, yet they do not emphasize it, following what is naturally present without adding to it. Though their actions are not for profit, they do not despise gatekeepers and servants. Gatekeepers and servants are those who hold the gate for sustenance. Though they do not contend over wealth and goods, they also do not excessively yield or defer to others. In affairs, they do not rely on others, and though they labor for sustenance, they do not overvalue it. Though their conduct differs from the common, they avoid eccentricity and act in accordance with the multitude.

All this constitutes the conduct of the great person.
Lofty, they do not emulate the purity and harmony of Yi or Hui;
Humble, they do not descend to the cruelty and violence of bandits and thieves.
How could they know of rank and emolument as incentives,
Or execution and disgrace as shame?
What concern have they for the distinctions of right and wrong,
Or the boundaries of the fine and the vast?

Thus, the Dao is without what can be heard,
Virtue is without what can be attained—
This arises from the great person’s selflessness,
Exhausting their nature within its allotted portion to reach utmost simplicity.

*Detailed Annotation on the Dao* states:
The great person in relation to the world forgets things through the mind,
Forgets the mind through the Dao.
They do not act to harm others—
One might suspect their benevolence and kindness to be excessive, yet they do not overemphasize benevolence and kindness.
Though they do not contend over wealth and goods,
One might suspect they should yield and defer to others, yet they do not excessively yield or defer.
In affairs, they do not rely on others,
One might suspect they overvalue laboring for sustenance, yet they do not overvalue it.
Though their conduct differs from the common,
One might suspect they indulge in eccentricity, yet they do not indulge in eccentricity.
They do not despise gatekeepers and servants to exalt themselves,
Nor do they despise the corrupt and filthy to purify themselves,
Nor do they despise flatterers and sycophants to assert their own integrity.

Thus, rank and emolument, execution and disgrace cannot disturb their inner being;
Right and wrong, the fine and the vast are not worth distinguishing externally.
Then how could the refined and the coarse—
Those confined to words, theories, intentions, and expressions—
Ever occupy their minds?

What is heard is not hearing of *that*;
What is attained is no attainment.
Reaching selflessness,
One loses the self—
How then could there be any *thing*?
Without simplifying to the utmost within one’s portion,
One cannot reach this ultimate state.

*Bixu’s Annotation* states:
The butterfly and the mantis do not venture to the sea’s edge;
The roc does not regard the mugwort and wormwood.
All vision has its limits—
Exceeding measure leads to peril.
Refinement does not transcend form,
Yet it remains bound by words, theories, intentions, and expressions.
Knowing that favor and profit summon harm,
They do not contend over wealth and goods.
Though their conduct differs from the common,
They remain harmonious without advocating divergence.
Rank and emolument are insufficient as incentives;
Execution and disgrace are not taken as shame—
They place their person outside such concerns.
Right and wrong cannot be distinguished;
The fine and the vast cannot be demarcated—
They empty their minds.
The Dao-person does not hear,
For to hear would be to make it speakable.
Ultimate virtue is not attained,
For attainment would be followed by loss.
The great person is without self—
The self, too, is but a thing.
All the above reaches the utmost simplicity within one’s portion,
Yet it is not a matter of natural spontaneity.

*Yongzhai* says:
Those who peer at the heavens through a tube cannot see all;
The roc and the sparrow gazing down at the dust cannot perceive clearly.
The infinitesimally small cannot be measured in parts—
To call it a hair or a mote would be inadequate.
The immeasurably vast cannot be encompassed in numbers—
To call it a grain or a trillion would be insufficient.
The refined and the coarse are confined by form,
Thus they can be inferred through words, theories, intentions, and expressions.
But if the small and the vast are both formless,
They transcend the reach of words and intentions,
And cannot be discussed in terms of refinement or coarseness.

Though they do not harm things, they also do not cherish them—
Thus it is said they do not act to harm others, nor do they overemphasize benevolence and kindness.
Gatekeepers and servants are base laborers who seek profit—
I do not seek profit, nor do I deem those who do as wrong.
I do not contend over wealth, nor do I consider yielding a virtue.
In all affairs, I act independently, relying on no one,
Yet I do not exhaust my strength to sustain myself.
I do not despise the corrupt and filthy,
And though my conduct differs from others, I do not set myself apart—
This is to follow the multitude, blending light and merging with the dust.
I do not despise flatterers and sycophants,
But remain at ease in their company,
Able to dissolve my own intentions.
Such people make no distinctions of right and wrong,
Merging the fine and the vast.
Not hearing, there is no fame.
Not attaining, there is no loss.
The great person unites ultimate principle with utmost simplicity,
Fulfilling the affairs of their allotted portion.
Simplifying to one’s portion is to fulfill oneself.
Viewing the vast from the perspective of the fine,
One stops at what cannot be exhausted—
Yet the vast does not stop there.
Viewing the fine from the perspective of the vast,
One stops at what cannot be perceived—
Yet the fine is not formless.
Refinement is the extreme of the fine;
Vastness is the fullness of the great.
Though the small and the vast differ,
Both have form and number, thus they are subject to formation and decay.
When refinement reaches formlessness,
And vastness becomes immeasurable,
They are no longer defined by form or divided by number—
Thus they are beyond formation and decay.

What is coarse can be discussed in words;
What is refined can be inferred through intention.
Beyond refinement and coarseness,
Words and intentions cannot reach—
Is this not the Dao alone?
Thus, the great person prioritizes benefiting things,
Yet does not overemphasize benevolence and kindness.
Though not moved by profit, they do not despise those who pursue it.
The following all describe how the great person’s conduct differs from the common,
Even to the point of not despising flatterers and sycophants—
Thus, the noble and the base proceed on their own paths,
Right and wrong, the fine and the vast are not worth distinguishing,
And how could rank and disgrace serve as incentives or deterrents?
From this, we know the great person empties the self to let virtue and the Dao return—
They do not transgress their portion to seek beyond it.
Virtue and the Dao are the most noble,
Yet seeking them within one’s portion is sufficient—
Thus, they are also the easiest.
Now, people of the world abandon the internal to seek the external,
Forsake the easy to pursue the difficult—
Is this not delusion?

The River Earl said:
"Beyond things, within things—
Where do the distinctions of noble and base arise?
Where do the boundaries of small and vast appear?"
The Lord of the Northern Sea replied:
"From the perspective of the Dao, things have no noble or base;
From the perspective of things, each esteems itself and despises others;
From the perspective of custom, noble and base do not reside in oneself.
From the perspective of differentiation,
Following what is great in each and deeming it great,
Then nothing is not great;
Following what is small in each and deeming it small,
Then nothing is not small.
Knowing that heaven and earth are but a grain of rice,
And a tip of hair is but a mountain,
Then the distinctions of measure become apparent.
From the perspective of function,
Following what each possesses and deeming it possessed,
Then nothing is not possessed;
Following what each lacks and deeming it lacking,
Then nothing is not lacking.
Knowing that east and west are opposites yet cannot be without each other,
Then the divisions of function are settled."

From the perspective of inclination,
Following what each deems right and deeming it right,
Then nothing is not right;
Following what each deems wrong and deeming it wrong,
Then nothing is not wrong.
Knowing that Yao and Jie each deemed themselves right and the other wrong,
Then the inclinations of conduct become apparent.

Of old, Yao and Shun yielded the throne and became emperors,
Zhi and Qiang yielded and perished;
Tang and Wu contended and became kings,
Duke Bai contended and was destroyed.
From this we observe:
The rites of contention and yielding,
The conduct of Yao and Jie,
Nobility and baseness have their times,
And cannot be taken as constant.

A battering-ram can breach a city wall,
Yet cannot plug a rat-hole—
This speaks of differing implements.
The famed steeds Qi Ji and Lü Li
Can gallop a thousand li in a day,
Yet catch mice not as well as a wildcat—
This speaks of differing skills.
The owl snatches fleas at night,
Discerns the tip of a hair,
Yet by day, though its eyes stare wide, cannot see a mountain—
This speaks of differing natures.

Thus it is said:
Shall we take right as our teacher and have no wrong?
Shall we take order as our teacher and have no chaos?
This is not yet to understand the principles of heaven and earth,
Nor the conditions of the myriad things.
It is like taking heaven as teacher while ignoring earth,
Taking yin as teacher while ignoring yang—
Its impossibility is manifest.
Yet still they speak without ceasing—
If not fools, then deceivers!

The abdications of emperors and kings differ,
The successions of the Three Dynasties differ.
Those who miss their time and defy custom
Are called usurpers;
Those who meet their time and follow custom
Are called righteous men.

Silent, O River Lord—
How could you know the gate of nobility and baseness,
The house of small and great?

**Guo’s Commentary:**
Things have no nobility or baseness—each is sufficient in itself.
That they esteem themselves and despise one another
Is but the petty workings of the Dao,
Which interweaves and equalizes them.
Nobility and baseness do not reside in oneself—
This is what is called inversion.
What is great is sufficient;
What is small leaves no surplus.

By virtue of its nature being sufficient to be called great,
Even a hairtip or cinnabar speck cannot differ in name from hills and mountains;
By virtue of its leaving no surplus to be called small,
Even heaven and earth or a grain of millet cannot differ in designation.

Yet should one observe distinctions without following this Way,
Then mutual imposition and mutual overthrow would be beyond all reckoning.
The world knows nothing but mutual "that" and "this"—
Such is the opposition of east and west.

Yet even lips and teeth never act for each other,
And when the lips are gone, the teeth grow cold—
What "that" does becomes the vast accomplishment of "this"!
Thus, if one relies on self-serving action and denies its achievement,
Then all achievements under heaven would be null;
If one recognizes their mutual indispensability and acknowledges their achievement,
Then all achievements under heaven would be present.

But should one forget the achievement of self-serving action
And dwell instead upon the kindness of mutual aid,
The more such kindness is stirred, the more hypocrisy and shallowness proliferate—
The world would suffer twofold loss,
And true nature would dissolve into chaos.
Thus, the apportionment of achievement can never be fixed.

All things are so of themselves—
Therefore, none are not so.

All things mutually negate one another, thus none are not negated.
To be without affirmation and without negation—this is Yao.
To be with affirmation and with negation—this is Jie.
Yet these two rulers each received their natural endowment from Heaven,
Unable to act for one another.
Viewing the world’s inclinations and dispositions through Yao and Jie,
One sees they cannot act for one another.

He who responds to Heaven and accords with man to receive all under Heaven—
His advancement is the advancement of yielding and deference.
Yet should one pursue the fleeing,
One loses the very ground of that advance.
If one embraces their differences and entrusts them to their own nature,
Then nothing fails to find its rightful place.

The principle of Heaven and Earth,
The essence of the myriad things,
Take accord with nature as order,
And loss of nature as chaos.
Divergent natures have different conveniences;
Affirmation and negation have no fixed ground.
If one entrusts them to the evenness of Heaven,
Allowing both to proceed freely,
Then though regions differ and kinds vary,
All alike attain their due.

Lu’s commentary: Viewed through the Dao, how can there be noble and base?
Viewed through things, each esteems itself and devalues others—
Yet the Dao is not a thing.
Viewed through custom, noble and base lie not in oneself—
Yet the Dao is not custom.
The Dao is neither thing nor custom,
Thus it is neither noble nor base.

Following what is great and making it great,
Following what is small and making it small,
Knowing that Heaven and Earth differ from the Great Void as a ladder differs from a grain of millet,
And that the tip of a hair differs from the formless as a hill differs from a mountain—
Then what is called difference becomes manifest in number.
Yet the Dao is not difference,
Thus it is neither small nor great.

Following what is present and making it present—
As there is east, so there is west.
Following what is absent and making it absent—
Without east, there is no west.
Knowing that east and west are opposed yet cannot do without one another,
Then what is called achievement finds its fixed apportionment.
Yet the Dao is not achievement,
Thus it is neither presence nor absence.

Following what is so and making it so,
Following what is not so and making it not so,
Knowing that Yao and Jie each arose from self-affirmation and mutually negated one another,
Then what is called inclination becomes manifest in disposition.
Yet the Dao is not inclination,
Thus it is neither affirmation nor negation.

If this is so,
Then one who embodies the Dao forgets both and rests in the evenness of Heaven—
What need has he to distinguish noble and base, small and great?

If one takes Yao and Shun’s yielding as right,
Then Zhi the Tyrant perishes.
If one takes Tang and Wu’s contention as right,
Then the Duke of Bai meets destruction.
The rites of contention and yielding,
The conduct of Yao and Jie,
Noble and base have their times—
They cannot be taken as constant.

A roof beam cannot plug a rat hole,
A qilin cannot catch mice,
An owl cannot see by day—
These three differ, yet to equalize them
Is to fail to understand the principles of Heaven and the essence of things.

Usurpation speaks of the solitary;
Righteous succession speaks of the many.
*Commentary on "the solitary":* As with things’ inner and outer—
This speaks of the inner and outer of natural endowment.

Without noble and without base—this is the principle of nature.
With noble and with base—this is a forced distinction.
Viewed through the Dao, there is no self and other, no right and wrong—
Who then is noble, who base?
Viewed through things, each esteems itself and devalues others.

The noble and base of things do not arise from nature,
But form through habit.
Thus viewed through custom, noble and base lie not in oneself.

The principle of small and great cannot be altered,
Yet their forms differ in degree.
If the small does not seek to become great,
Then the small suffices to be called great.
If the great does not seek to become small,
Then the great suffices to be called small.
Following what is great and finding it sufficient,
Then the tip of a hair may equal a mountain.
Following what is small and finding it without excess,
Then a mountain may equal the tip of a hair.
The degrees of difference among the myriad things are boundless—
What is observed is only thus.

Presence is wondrous presence, constant presence.
Absence is true absence, constant absence.
All moving and growing things under Heaven,
In their birth, nurturing, and growth,
All have their achievements within—
This may be called presence.
Yet the direction of achievement
Belongs to creation, to spontaneity alone—
This may be called absence.
Engaging presence, one does not see absence.
Obscuring absence, one does not see presence.
They are opposed like east and west,
Yet in truth cannot do without one another—
Thus the apportionment of achievement is naturally fixed.

The principles of the myriad things have right and wrong.
Self and other mutually negate—
This is how Yao and Jie were distinguished.
Following their spontaneity in mutual negation,
Then inclinations and dispositions become manifest.
Thus some yield and become emperors,
Some yield and perish.
Some contend and become kings,
Some contend and are destroyed.
The rites of contention and yielding
Were noble in the times of Yao, Shun, Tang, and Wu,
Yet base in the times of Zhi and the Duke of Bai.
If Yao is right and Jie wrong,
Each has its time—
They cannot be taken as constant.

Again, consider the differing uses of a roof beam, a qilin, and an owl—
Their skills, their natures, all differ.
To follow right, to follow governance, to follow Heaven, to follow yin—
Each is but one partiality.
Their impracticability is clear.

Abdication and succession,
If not in accord with the times and customs,
Are called usurpation.
If in accord with the times and customs,
They are called righteousness.
Rooted in one yet branching differently—
What grounds are there to judge their superiority?

*Detailed commentary on the Dao:* Viewed through the Dao, things have no noble or base.
Departing from the Dao to follow the customs of things,
Thus in difference there are small and great,
In achievement there are presence and absence,
In inclination there are right and wrong.
Yet if I follow what is great and make it great,
Follow what is small and make it small,
Extending this to the presence and absence of achievement,
To the right and wrong of inclination—
If I observe all through this single lens,
Who then knows the distinctions of great and small, presence and absence, right and wrong?

Yet the principles of all under Heaven differ yet are the same,
Are the same yet differ—
Their transformations are not uniform and cannot be taken as constant.
Viewed through difference, achievement, and inclination,
They differ yet are the same.
Some yield and become emperors,
Some yield and perish.
Some contend and become kings,
Some contend and are destroyed—
This is the same yet different.
Different yet the same lies not in things but in the Dao.
Same yet different lies not in traces but in time.

Not only this—
Uses have their distinct implements,
Abilities their distinct skills,
Lives their distinct natures.
Esteeming this devalues that,
Making that great diminishes this—
How can noble and base, great and small be distinguished?

Thus we know that right and wrong, order and chaos, Heaven and Earth, yin and yang are ever mutually employed—yet cannot be judged by noble or base, great or small.

*Blue Void’s Annotation:* The Dao holds no noble or base; these are but the likes and dislikes of things.

What the world esteems are all external things. To call the microcosm "small" and the tip of a hair "tiny" is not principle. If one deems something great because it is great, then all things may be called great; if one deems something small because it is small, then all things may be called small. This is the calculus of difference, which has long usurped principle.

East and west oppose each other, just as high and low cannot do without one another. If my achievement aids another, then it is so. Were I without achievement, what would they rely upon? What Yao deemed right, all under Heaven deemed right; what Jie affirmed, who dared affirm otherwise? Can the inclinations and conduct of the sage and the commoner be the same?

Yao, Shun, Tang, and Wu followed the seasons of Heaven and upheld their allotted roles. Jie and Zhou, the White Duke, defied human affairs and clung to the calculus of difference. Thus noble and base are not fixed—they lie in the divergence of inclinations and conduct. The gentleman and the petty man are distinguished by their capacity and insight!

Yet right and wrong, order and chaos, ever intertwine and lie in wait for one another—this cannot be left unexamined. Those who model themselves on Heaven without Earth, or on yin without yang, are rigid and benighted, unfit to speak of the Dao. Those who defy the times and go against custom, though noble, become base. Those who conform to the times and follow custom, though small, become great.

*Skin Studio’s Note:* When one exalts oneself and disparages others, even chickens and pigs may become emperors for a time. Noble and base do not reside in oneself—this is the meaning of "caps and carriages come and go."

To compare Heaven and Earth to a grain of millet, or a tip of hair to Mount Tai, is to render the calculus of gradation meaningless. Each fulfills its role as its allotted achievement. Farmer, merchant, artisan, and trader—none can be lacking in the world, just as east and west oppose yet cannot do without one another.

To affirm Yao and deny Jie is the natural consequence of inclination and conduct. Yet if none were ever abolished, how could a ruler arise to observe them? Thus the fixity of inclination and conduct cannot be determined. The meaning of "following this" in *The Equality of Things* lies in accepting small and great, presence and absence, right and wrong.

Thus the analogy of distinct implements, distinct skills, and distinct natures to Heaven and Earth, yin and yang, illustrates their mutual indispensability. Usurpers and righteous followers are but the arguments of Yao and Jie. Things hold no noble or base—one forgets even one’s own things. To exalt oneself and disparage others is to fail in discerning that and this. Noble and base do not reside in oneself—one forgets oneself and follows things. To call something great because it is great, or small because it is small, is to accord with what is fitting for things.

As for the presence or absence of achievement and inclination, right and wrong—these oppose yet cannot do without one another. Herein lie the principles of things and the sentiments of humanity!

Thus the accounts of contention and yielding, the deeds of good and evil, noble and base—these shift with the times and cannot be taken as constant. Just as distinct implements have distinct uses, distinct skills distinct abilities, and distinct natures distinct conveniences, they cannot be judged by a single standard.

To model oneself on order without chaos, or on yin without yang, is not to comprehend the principles of Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things. Succession and rebellion, compliance and defiance—each follows its time. You need not say more; even if you speak, you merely discuss their traces. How could you know the origin of noble and base, great and small? To know the origin of noble and base, great and small, one must seek it where things have not yet begun.

*Annotations to the Southern Florescence True Scripture: Ocean of Meanings*, Scroll Fifty-Two, concludes.

*#1 The three characters "故异便" (thus distinct conveniences), according to Ma Shulun’s* Zhuangzi Yizheng*, should be placed below the phrase "自大视细者不明" (those who view the small from a position of greatness are benighted) in the preceding text.*

*Annotations to the Southern Florescence True Scripture: Ocean of Meanings*, Scroll Fifty-Three.

The Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin on *"Autumn Floods,"* Chapter Three

The River Earl asked: "Then what should I do? What should I not do? In matters of giving and receiving, pursuing and abandoning—how am I to act in the end?"

The Lord of the Northern Sea replied: "Viewed through the Dao, what is noble and what is base? This is called *reversal and extension*—restrain the will, and you will be greatly at odds with the Dao. What is few and what is many? This is called *gratitude and bestowal*—cling to one course, and you will be out of step with the Dao.

Solemn as a state with its ruler, yet without private virtue; boundless as the sacrifices to the earth-altar, yet without private blessing; vast as the four directions without end, yet without fixed boundaries. Embracing the myriad things, who bears them up? This is called *without direction.*

The myriad things are of one measure—what is short, what is long? The Dao has no end or beginning; things have death and life. Do not rely on their completion. Now empty, now full, they do not abide in their forms.

Years cannot be lifted away; time cannot be halted. Ebb and flow, fullness and emptiness—when one ends, another begins. This is how we speak of the great meaning’s direction, how we discuss the principle of the myriad things.

When things come to life, they gallop like a swift steed. No movement without change, no moment without shift. What is to be done? What is not to be done? They will transform of themselves."

Guo’s commentary: "The Dao of noble and base turns and returns in cycles. If one clings to restraint, one will not be level with the Dao. Follow one’s allotted portion, and thus what is bestowed will have no constancy. If one cannot follow change, one will not be in accord with the Dao.

Without private virtue, one is impartial and fitting. Without private blessing, all under heaven seek it in common. Thus, drifting boundlessly without fixed place, one governs the multitude of beings, returning to their inherent portion and moving evenly—how could one prop them up with outstretched branches?

Only by being without direction can one take the myriad things as one’s direction, and none will not be sufficient.

Death and life are but one transformation in the endless—neither beginning nor end. Knowing that completion is impermanent, one does not take form as a fixed position and cling to it without change. One may wish to lift it away, but cannot; one may wish to halt it, but may not.

Change is called renewal; it never abides in the old. One should simply follow its use—it cannot be grasped. If one acts or does not act in its midst, one disrupts its self-transformation!"

Lü’s commentary: "Scholars in their mediocrity are bound to things. Once they hear that the Dao has no noble or base, no great or small, they are at a loss in matters of doing or not doing, giving or abandoning, pursuing or forsaking—this is only natural.

What is called noble and base is but the reversal and extension of things, not the Dao. Reversal implies going back; returning is noble, departing is base. Extension implies depletion; extending is noble, depleting is base. Thus, one should let the will roam freely without restraint. If one restrains the will, one will be greatly at variance with the Dao and fail to penetrate it.

What is called few and many is but the gratitude and bestowal of things, not the Dao. Gratitude implies flourishing; gratitude is few, flourishing is many. Bestowal implies gathering; bestowing is many, gathering is few. One should act in both ways without clinging to one. If one clings to one course, one will be out of step with the Dao and fail to match it.

Without private virtue means having no exclusive reliance on those one rules—this is what is meant by *restraining the will without restraint.* Without private blessing means having no exclusive bestowal on those one sacrifices to—this is what is meant by *acting without clinging to one course.* Without fixed boundaries means being in communication with the Dao and not greatly at variance with it.

Who bears them up? This is called *without direction.* The myriad things are of one measure—this is being in accord with the Dao and not out of step with it.

Relying on completion, one does not know that end and beginning cannot be grasped. Thus, abiding in form, one does not perceive fullness and emptiness and does not understand that allotment is impermanent.

Years cannot be lifted away, so one wanders without vexation. Time cannot be halted, so one advances without stumbling. Ebb and flow, fullness and emptiness—when one ends, another begins. This is simply the movement of heaven.

This is how we speak of the great Dao’s direction, how we discuss the principle of the myriad things—why should the heart be bound to matters of giving and receiving, pursuing and abandoning?

Swift as a gallop, they speak of how change and transformation shift imperceptibly—why should the heart be bound to the question of doing or not doing? They will transform of themselves—this is called *leaving transformation to its own course.*"

Yi Du’s commentary: "The principle of the myriad things is profoundly natural—neither doing nor not doing. Why then should one fix the mind on matters of giving and receiving, pursuing and abandoning?

*Extension* means surplus. *Bestowal* means allotment. Noble and base, few and many arise from forced distinctions, not the true principle of the Dao. The true principle of the Dao is simply one. Viewed through the Dao, noble is no addition, base is no diminution; many is no surplus, few is no deficiency—what distinction is there between noble and base, few and many?

Without private virtue means having no exclusive reliance on those one rules. Without private blessing means having no partial bestowal on those one sacrifices to."

The commentary below follows Lü’s explanation.

Xiang Dao’s commentary: "*Extension* refers to broad and level ground. Reversed, it becomes uneven. The division between level and uneven has no constancy—how is the alternation of noble and base different?

*Bestowal* is the function of benevolence. Gratitude is giving without considering it benevolence—how can the count of many and few be reckoned? Reversal and extension mean forgetting noble and base and not being burdened by names. Gratitude and bestowal mean forgetting few and many and not being burdened by profit. If one does not return to this truth, it has never been so."

Bi Xu’s commentary: "If one should receive but does not, what is to be done? If another abandons and I take, what is not to be done? Noble and base, great and small do not go beyond these two ends.

Noble and base have no fixed master but flow in endless reversal—this is the constant. The great Dao is utterly level, and the heart roams freely in self-contentment—this is penetration. Allotment has its measure, and few are grateful while many bestow—this is fitting. The ways of the world are uneven, and action or stillness adapt to change—this is principle."

Virtue made private loses its stern resolve; fortune made private cannot endure. With boundaries set, one’s reach is not vast; with fixed directions, the virtue of embracing all is lost—yet all these speak to the folly of prizing the noble and delighting in the base.

Forget the self, and there is no long or short; forget the heart, and there is no life or death; forget rank, and there is no fullness or emptiness; forget years, and one follows transformation; forget time, and one follows change. Forget the waxing and waning of growth and decay—then what could serve as beginning or end?

All things are born without cease, transform without cease; their shifts are swift as a gallop, their movements fleet as a race. Yin and yang, the four seasons—these are but self-transformations. How could one presume to intervene in what is or is not done?

Fu Qi says: Viewed through the Dao, there is no noble or base. Turn inward to seek within oneself, and one finds boundless ease—this is extension. If one binds oneself with notions of noble and base, right and wrong, one strays from the Dao. Bestowal has its measure, but to let go of bestowal is to be free of many or few. If one clings to a single course and is constrained by the measure of bestowal, one diverges from the Dao.

A state has its ruler, a sacrifice its altar—these are meant to illustrate that the heart takes the Dao as its master, not its private inclinations. When the heart is vast and boundless, without limit, there are no restrictive furrows. All things are complete within me—this is the virtue of embracing all. Without private attachments, who then would bear, support, or uphold?

No direction means no heart; no heart means no long or short, no life or death. Not relying on achievement is not to force completion. Fullness and emptiness follow the time; they cannot be fixed. Thus it is said: one does not take form as a position. Without past or present, years cannot be reckoned. Without going or coming, time cannot be halted.

The great principle is the Dao itself. Change and movement, shifting and turning—there is no time when this is not so. What is to be done? What is not to be done? All is left to creation, to spontaneity alone. Thus it is said: things will transform of themselves.

The River Earl, not yet understanding the principles of heaven and the nature of things, still harbored doubts and questioned the propriety of accepting or declining, pursuing or abandoning. The Lord of the Northern Sea explained that what the world calls noble and base, few and many, are but instances of reversal and extension, of bestowal and gratitude. If one clings to a single course, one strays from the Dao.

As a ruler’s virtue extends to all people, as the altar’s blessings are not private, so too does one clarify the boundlessness of the Dao and embrace all things. The life and death of things are but transformations of form, not the beginning or end of the Dao. Thus, completion has no fixed place. One does not cling to form as a position, nor resist its going or coming. The waxing and waning of all things are like this. Things are born as if racing, their mechanism unceasing. Let them transform of themselves—there is no need to intervene in what is or is not done, much less in accepting or declining, pursuing or uniting.

This teaches that in responding to things, one must be without heart—then life and death are no burden.

The River Earl asked: If so, then what is prized in the Dao?

The Lord of the Northern Sea replied: One who knows the Dao necessarily grasps principle; one who grasps principle necessarily understands adaptability; one who understands adaptability does not let things harm the self. The one of utmost virtue—fire cannot burn, water cannot drown, cold and heat cannot harm, birds and beasts cannot injure. This is not to say one resists them, but that one discerns safety and danger, finds peace in fortune and misfortune, is cautious in advance and retreat—nothing can cause harm. Thus it is said: heaven is within, man is without; virtue resides in heaven.

Know the conduct of heaven and man, rooted in heaven, positioned in attainment. To hesitate and bend or stretch, to return to essentials and speak of limits—

What is heaven? What is man?

The Lord of the Northern Sea replied: Oxen and horses have four legs—this is called heaven. To bridle a horse’s head or pierce an ox’s nose—this is called man. Thus it is said: Do not let man obliterate heaven; do not let habit obliterate fate; do not let attainment be sacrificed for fame. Guard this carefully and do not lose it—this is called returning to one’s true nature.

Guo’s commentary: Why value the Dao? Because it transforms of itself. One who knows the Dao knows one’s own inability. If one is incapable, how can one give birth to me? I am born of myself! The four limbs and hundred parts of the body form without one’s doing—what intention could there be after their formation? One who grasps this principle must be able to dispel excessive knowledge, relinquish emotions that obscure life, ride change and respond with adaptability, never letting things harm the self but always preserving wholeness. Thus, what the heart finds secure cannot be made perilous. Where intention meets no resistance, suffering cannot cause suffering. Though what the heart finds secure should not be violated, knowing it cannot be escaped, one rests in the encounters of fate. Examining advance and retreat as not one’s own, nothing can cause harm.

Heaven is within, and what naturally follows is without. The distinction between inner and outer is not made by design. Knowing the knowledge of the natural operates of itself, though one acts in the external, one constantly roots in heaven and positions in attainment. In harmony with the meeting, there is this transformation. To comprehend heaven and earth, to encompass the affairs of the myriad things, yet never lose the essential limit—thus the Dao of heaven and man is preserved whole.

Oxen and horses do not refuse bridling and piercing because it is the fixed mandate of heaven. If it accords with heaven’s mandate, then it is entrusted to human affairs while rooted in heaven. But if one acts excessively, driving and rushing without restraint, the principle of heaven is obliterated! If one does not follow what occurs of itself but forces action, where is fate to be found? What is attained has constancy; to pursue fame is to transgress.

Lü’s commentary: Letting things transform of themselves is the Dao. The Lord of the River did not understand, asking why value the Dao. The Lord of the Northern Sea explained that grasping principle and understanding adaptability, not letting things harm the self—these are the affairs of one who knows the Dao, not the ultimate embodiment of the Dao. As for water and fire not harming, cold and heat not assailing—this is how one who embodies the Dao naturally is. It is not that one resists them, but that one discerns safety and danger, is cautious in advance and retreat. Nothing can cause harm—this is merely knowing the Dao, grasping principle, and understanding adaptability. Finding peace in fortune and misfortune, knowing what cannot be altered and resting in it—this is heaven within. Discerning advance and retreat, knowing what people fear cannot but be feared—this is man without! Through this one enters virtue, though not yet able to be heaven without man, virtue resides in heaven.

Knowing the conduct of heaven and man, rooted in heaven, positioned in attainment—this is to go forth from heaven to man. To hesitate and bend or stretch, to return to essentials and speak of limits—this is to proceed from man to heaven. From “Do not let man obliterate heaven” to this point—speaking of returning to one’s true nature, how could one’s relation to the Dao be merely knowing it?

Yi Du’s commentary: This accords with Lü’s explanation.

Xiang Dao’s commentary: One who knows the Dao necessarily grasps principle; one who grasps principle necessarily understands adaptability. Adaptability means responding to things without intention and not losing equilibrium—how could one allow externals to injure the internal, letting things harm the self? To practice the Dao to this point is to be able to respond to others. To hesitate and bend or stretch is to return from man to heaven. To return to essentials and speak of limits—this is the discourse of the Lord of the Northern Sea. It begins with equalizing the great and small, unifying the noble and base; proceeds to discerning safety and danger, being cautious in advance and retreat; and concludes with clarifying heaven and man, returning to essentials and limits. For one who can equalize things can preserve the self; preserving the self, one can return to the Dao; and reaching the essential limit, one returns to one’s true nature.

Bixu’s commentary: One who knows the Dao of transformation and grasps the principle of life necessarily understands the adaptability of things. Thus one delights in wholeness without harm, discerns safety and danger, examines fortune and misfortune, and is prudent in advance and retreat. Therefore, one of virtue inwardly guards the principle of heaven and outwardly cultivates human affairs. Only then can position and enterprise be attained, and advance and retreat, exit and entry be at one’s discretion—one can return to the wondrous essentials and speak of the ultimate. Oxen and horses are the principle of heaven; to bridle and pierce them is to let man obliterate heaven. Hunger, thirst, galloping, and rushing are to let habit obliterate fate. Yellow horses and black oxen are to let attainment be sacrificed for fame. Guarding heaven and not losing it, one returns to simplicity without artifice.

Yongzhai said: This question is especially subtle. If one has already heard what creation does of itself, then one need not study the Dao. In Zhu Xi’s *Questions and Answers*, Liao Deming also posed this question. Master Zhu did not answer, likely finding it difficult to explain. Thus Zhuangzi here speaks of adaptability and clarifies it with the phrase “not letting things harm the self.”

The Dao is the general term. Principle is the principle inherent in each thing. Adaptability is what is at one’s discretion. Only with the complete substance of the Dao can one have this great function; understanding adaptability, one knows weight and lightness. *Bo* means to press close. One of utmost virtue certainly knows that every affair has its fate—how could things harm one? Yet one does not rely on this to press close to them. Just as one who knows fate does not stand beneath a crumbling wall, discerning safety and danger, being prudent in advance and retreat—this is the human heart within the heart of the Dao. How could one say it is all left to spontaneity?

Heaven within and man without—this is like the earlier passage: “The ruler follows the Dao of heaven; the minister follows the Dao of man.” Virtue resides in heaven—this refers to natural virtue. “Knowing the conduct of heaven and man”—this *knowing* arises from the human heart. Rooted in spontaneity and content with what is attained—this phrase again pertains to the heart of the Dao, the security of one’s position. To hesitate and bend or stretch—this refers to advancing and retreating each according to its principle, and this phrase again pertains to the human heart. Elucidating to this point, one reaches the utmost essentials of the Dao and the ultimate limits of principle.

Oxen and horses have four legs—this is received from spontaneity. Without bridling or piercing, they would have no use—this is a matter of the human heart. To obliterate heaven, obliterate fate, and pursue fame—this is the human heart flowing into peril!

"Three words suffice not"—this is a prohibitive phrase, meaning that if one knows heaven and knows man, and can guard this knowledge carefully without loss, then the heavenly principle is complete! This is called returning to one’s true nature, and thus human affairs are commanded by the heavenly principle.

From the beginning of this chapter to this point, there have been six questions, with answers like wind driving distant waves, gradually nearing and intensifying, until now they surge forth like snow-capped breakers, leaving one overwhelmed. Yet in an instant, all settles into stillness—wave-light stretches for ten thousand leagues, a single azure embracing the sky. When man sheds artifice and returns to truth, when the center of his shoulders is empty and limpid, it resembles this.

The man of utmost virtue, by understanding man to illuminate heaven, employs expedience to penetrate principle, discerns safety and peril, and carefully weighs withdrawal and engagement—what harm could external things bring him? Yet he never relies on this to act arrogantly toward others.

Heaven resides within, establishing the essence;
Man operates without, fulfilling its function.
Virtue lies in heaven, merging with the numinous and becoming unfathomable in all directions.

Embodying heaven and dwelling in virtue, one bends and stretches in accord with the world. Returning to the essential and ultimate words: do not lose your true nature. If this is so, then the Way of conducting oneself and others is fully realized! Thus, the River Lord’s mind became profoundly attuned, and he had no further questions.

Nowadays, scholars lack self-trust, their hearts clogged with doubts—many share the River Lord’s malady. If one could suddenly awaken at the words of Ruo of the Sea, as if clouds parting to reveal the moon, then with radiant clarity one would seek within and find sufficiency. What need would there be for further questions?

"Knowing the conduct of heaven and man"—*heaven* here should be *fu* (夫), a phonetic particle. *Positioned in attainment* (位乎得) should be *positioned in virtue* (位乎德), as the meaning of the text makes clear.

*Collected Explications of the Ocean of Meanings of the True Scripture of Southern Florescence*, Scroll Fifty-Three, concludes.
#1 *Omissions and Errors* cites the Jiangnan Ancient Repository edition, where *heaven* (天) is written as *hu* (乎), extending the character.

*Collected Explications of the Ocean of Meanings of the True Scripture of Southern Florescence*, Scroll Fifty-Four, by Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin.

**Autumn Floods, Part Four**

The *kui* pitied the *xian*, the *xian* pitied the snake, the snake pitied the wind, the wind pitied the eye, and the eye pitied the heart.

The *kui* said to the *xian*: "I stride with a single foot, and none is my equal. Now you command ten thousand feet—how is this possible?"

The *xian* replied: "Not so. Have you not seen one who spits? When he sprays, the large droplets are like pearls, the small like mist, and those that fall in profusion cannot be numbered. Now I move by my heavenly mechanism, yet I know not how it is so."

The *xian* said to the snake: "I walk with many feet, yet I do not match you who have none. Why is this?"

The snake said: "How can the movement of the heavenly mechanism be altered? What need have I for feet?"

The snake said to the wind: "I move by flexing my spine and ribs, and thus I have some semblance of motion. Now you rise in a great rush from the Northern Sea and rush just as suddenly into the Southern Sea, yet you seem to have no substance at all. Why is this?"

The wind said: "Indeed. I rise in a great rush from the Northern Sea and enter the Southern Sea, yet if one points at me, I am overcome; if one treads upon me, I am overcome. Nevertheless, to snap great trees and topple mighty halls—only I can do this. Thus, I achieve great victory through the accumulation of many small triumphs. To achieve such great victory—only the sage can do this."

**Guo’s Commentary:**
When things come to life, they do not know life and yet live. Life moves, yet who knows how it moves? Thus, the foot does not know how it walks, the eye does not know how it sees, and the heart does not know how it knows. Yet all attain their ends effortlessly! The rhythm of swiftness and slowness, the mirror of clarity and insight—some succeed, some fail, but none of this is of my doing. Yet some desire to claim possession of their bodies and boast of their abilities, thereby resisting the heavenly mechanism and harming the divine vessel. The perfected person knows that the heavenly mechanism cannot be altered, so they cast aside cleverness and foresight, acting without contrivance and allowing things to move of themselves. Thus, there is no movement that is not free and unbound. They follow the heavenly mechanism without contention, and so the small does not overcome. Riding the myriad things, guiding the uncarved block, allowing each talent to find its place and each thing to act of itself—then all under heaven are free and unbound. This is how the sage achieves great victory.

**Lü’s Commentary:**
The *kui*, with its single foot, pities the *xian* for its many feet; the *xian*, with its many feet, pities the snake for its lack of feet; the snake, moving by flexing its spine and ribs, pities the wind for its great rush from the Northern Sea to the Southern Sea. From this, we may infer how the eye, bound to this sight and that, pities the heart, which sees nothing yet reaches everywhere. The *kui* finds it easy to pity the *xian*’s difficulty with many feet; the *xian* finds it easy to pity the snake’s difficulty with no feet. Yet the movement of the heavenly mechanism is such that none knows how it is so—how then can difficulty or ease lie in the presence or absence of feet? From this, we know that the wind, the eye, and the heart all arise from spontaneity. How could the River Lord’s petty calculations of high and low, few and many compare with this? The wind achieves great victory through the small not overcoming, yet the eye and the heart, which employ their spirit far beyond the wind, cannot attain this. What is called "seeing without seeing, knowing without knowing" is the great victory that governs the myriad things. Is this true knowledge? No!

**Yi Du’s Commentary:**
The *kui*, with one foot, is precarious; the *xian*, with ten thousand feet, is secure; the snake, with no feet, is swift; the wind, without form, moves and transforms. The eye is bound to forms and appearances, while the heart enters the realm of sensory contact. To pity many feet with one foot is to pity the many with the few. To pity swift movement with slow is to pity the many with the nonexistent. The snake, burdened by its form, pities the wind’s ability to move and transform. The wind, lacking sight, pities the eye’s ability to see. The eye, enslaved by things, pities the heart’s centrality and effortless action. To walk with a halting step is as precarious as the spray of spittle—who could expect it to be like pearls or mist? All arise from the spontaneity of the heavenly mechanism. Thus, the many feet move slowly, the footless move swiftly, and those who walk securely without feet—all are but the heavenly mechanism at work. The wind rises from the Northern Sea and enters the Southern Sea, emerging from yin and returning to yang. Though it cannot overcome when pointed at or trodden upon, it can snap trees and topple halls—this is its victory. It is like the sage’s learning, which reaches the level of the wind and cannot be surpassed. From the *kui*’s pity for its single foot to the wind, this is the end of the matter. For only when there is heart and eye does pity arise. The eye gazes outward, the heart stirs within, and so one longs for this or that without end. But when there is no heart and no eye, as the wind is to things, then there is no pity. Who but the sage can attain this?

**Xiang Dao’s Commentary:**
When feet are of use, one foot cannot match the many, so the *kui* pities the *xian*. When feet are a burden, many feet cannot match the absence of feet, so the *xian* pities the snake. The snake, though it has form, sees the formless as insufficient and so pities the wind. The wind, though it rushes boundlessly, finds direction constraining and so pities the eye. The eye’s function is merely to see, while the heart governs all. Thus, it pities the heart.

**Bi Xu’s Commentary:**
Some things overcome the many with the few, the existent with the nonexistent—all is the work of the heavenly mechanism and the timing of fate. No force can alter it, and no principle can fully fathom it. Does this not describe the mutual pity of the *kui*, *xian*, snake, and wind? Nothing sees like the eye, nothing knows like the heart. The eye sees but does not discriminate—it conceals its clarity. The heart knows but does not speak—it veils its wisdom. This is how the small does not overcome and becomes great victory.

**Yong Zhai’s Commentary:**
From one foot to no feet, all move by the spontaneity of the heavenly mechanism—this is marvelous writing. The passage then compares the *xian*’s many feet to human spittle, and in the end returns to the wind, leaving the heart and eye unspoken. This is the marvel of marvels in the art of transformation.

Building upon the notion of the small not overcoming yet becoming great victory, then which of the myriad things could ever stand beyond the workings of creation? After the River Spirit and the Ocean Spirit concluded their dialogue, Master Nanhua further expounded the preceding idea, saying: the *kui*, *xian*, and snake, with their varying numbers of feet—few, many, or none—pity one another in their forms. The heart and eye, with their inner and outer labors and leisures, pity one another in their functions. All these are but the deluded sentiments of things! Only the wind possesses form yet does not hinder its pointing and flowing; it is formless yet achieves great victory. In its function, it moves and transforms the myriad things; in its non-function, it whirls into the sea like tumbleweed. For the breath of creation merely inhales and exhales, returning to creation itself—this illustrates how the sage bends and stretches with the world, embodying both form and function, excelling in both action and withdrawal, and ultimately never losing the Dao. People see its smallness as no match and belittle it, yet when it accumulates into great victory, it is not merely about uprooting trees or tearing off roofs—how could it have any intention to conquer things? Moved by the heavenly mechanism, it is simply so of itself. Compared to the River Spirit and the Ocean Spirit debating nobility and baseness, fewness and abundance, greatness and smallness, essence and coarseness, it is like beings of different kinds pitying one another with deluded sentiments, unaware that every thing possesses the principle of spontaneity, leaving no room for love or hatred between them. The fewness or abundance of physical forms, the slowness or swiftness of movement and stillness—each abides in its own nature, and none falls short of the Dao. This is why the sage’s way of dwelling in the world is never inappropriate.

Some may question why the later passage on the mutual pity of the minute and deluded ends with the wind, leaving the themes of the eye’s pity and the heart’s pity unaddressed. The doubt is resolved by noting that only with eyes and a heart can there be pity—this interpretation is sound. Confucius traveled to Kuang, where men of Song (or Wei) besieged him several times, yet he continued playing the zither and singing without pause. Zilu entered and asked, “Why is the Master so joyful?” Confucius replied, “Come, let me tell you. I have long avoided adversity, yet it has not been averted—this is fate. I have long sought success, yet it has not been attained—this is timing. In the eras of Yao and Shun, there were no destitute people, not because of wisdom’s gain; in the eras of Jie and Zhou, there were no successful people, not because of wisdom’s loss—such is the way of circumstances. The fisherman who travels by water without avoiding dragons displays the courage of his trade; the hunter who travels by land without avoiding rhinoceroses and tigers displays the courage of his trade; the hero who faces crossed blades and regards death as life displays the courage of his trade. But to know that adversity is a matter of fate, that success is a matter of timing, and to face great peril without fear—this is the courage of the sage. Rest easy, for my fate is constrained.”

Shortly after, the armored soldiers advanced and said, “We mistook you for Yang Hu, so we surrounded you. Now that we know you are not, we beg to withdraw.” Guo Xiang’s commentary: To clarify the inevitability of timing and fate, he used the example of seeking to avoid adversity. Circumstances unfold as they do—there is no need to trouble the heart over success or failure. The fisherman’s, hunter’s, and hero’s courage each has its place, but the sage is at ease in all. Knowing that fate is not self-determined, he does not exert his heart; abiding in fate, he is carefree in all circumstances. Lü Huiqing’s commentary: Confucius’s fear in Kuang, his composure between life and death without dread, and the eventual withdrawal of the Kuang people demonstrate that those who cannot relinquish knowledge and habit and worry over life and death not only gain nothing but only burden their hearts. Yan Du’s commentary: Success and failure lie with oneself; timing and fate lie with Heaven. Failing to attain success, one adapts; unable to avoid adversity, one endures. It is like the saying, “Wealth without arrogance, poverty without resentment.” The ancients never let success or failure burden them; each abided in their time. Avoiding dragons, rhinoceroses, and tigers, or facing blades—these are the minor braveries of one-sidedness. But facing great peril without fear is the great courage of the sage. One who embodies all three, like Mencius’s courage in righteousness, may be compared to this. Confucius told Zilu to rest easy, for his fate was governed by the Creator—what could the men of Kuang do to him? Soon after, the armored soldiers withdrew, proving that one who attains the Dao transcends life and death—Confucius had mastered this.

Bi Xu’s commentary: When Confucius traveled to Kuang and was besieged by the men of Song (or Wei), it was as if all things pointed and flowed to overcome him. Yet when they realized their mistake and withdrew, this was the great victory. Yong Zhai’s commentary: This passage speaks of timing and fate as natural, not subject to human effort—how could one who knows the Dao fear? The comparison of the fisherman, hunter, and hero to the sage is also fitting. “Rest easy,” and now there is no need to speak further.

This chapter clarifies that life and death are a matter of fate, and success and failure are a matter of timing. Thus, the noble person does not stand beneath a crumbling wall, nor does he seek life at the expense of benevolence. Facing great peril without fear, knowing that fate is constrained, he fulfills his human duties in ordinary times and accepts Heaven’s decree in such moments. For one who inwardly possesses the most noble and abundant, external success or failure, profit or harm cannot move his heart. The eventual withdrawal of the armored soldiers, realizing their mistake, demonstrates the principle that humans cannot overcome Heaven and that the weak can restrain the strong. Without the sage’s penetrating insight into principle and self-knowing clarity, how could this be achieved?

Lu Deming’s *Pronunciations and Meanings* records Sima Biao’s old commentary: “Song” should be “Wei.” Kuang was a town in Wei. Most modern editions mistakenly write “Song.”

Gongsun Long asked Wei Mou: “In my youth, I studied the Dao of the former kings; in my maturity, I understood the practice of benevolence and righteousness. I harmonized sameness and difference, separated hardness and whiteness, affirmed the un-affirmable, and validated the un-validatable...”

I had once exhausted the wisdom of all schools and silenced the eloquence of every debater—I believed myself to be utterly enlightened. Yet now, hearing Zhuangzi’s words, I am overwhelmed and bewildered. Is it that my reasoning falls short? Or that my understanding cannot match his? My beak is sealed shut; I dare ask for his method."

Prince Mou leaned against his desk, sighed deeply, looked up to the sky, and laughed: "Have you never heard of the frog in the broken well? It boasted to the sea turtle, saying: ‘How joyful I am! I leap and dance upon the well’s railing, rest in the chinks of its crumbling walls. When I plunge into the water, it supports my armpits and props up my chin; when I tread in the mud, it buries my feet and ankles. Looking around at the shrimps, crabs, and tadpoles, none can compare to me. Moreover, to command the waters of this single ravine and revel in the pleasures of this broken well—what more could one desire? Why not come in and see for yourself?’

The sea turtle had not yet placed its left foot inside when its right knee was already stuck. It retreated cautiously and told the frog of the sea: ‘A distance of a thousand *li* is insufficient to describe its vastness; a height of a thousand *ren* cannot measure its depth. In the time of Yu, floods lasted nine years out of ten, yet the sea’s waters did not increase; in the time of Tang, droughts lasted seven years out of eight, yet its shores did not recede. Neither the passage of time nor the measure of quantity alters it—this is the great joy of the Eastern Sea.’

Upon hearing this, the frog in the broken well was stunned, dismayed, and lost in self-doubt. Now, if one’s knowledge cannot grasp the bounds of right and wrong and yet still wishes to examine Zhuangzi’s words, it is like commanding a mosquito to carry a mountain or a centipede to ford a river—it will surely fail. And if one’s understanding cannot fathom the subtleties of his discourse yet seeks only momentary advantage, is this not the same as the frog in the broken well?

Moreover, he leaps through the Yellow Springs and ascends the Great Vast, unbound by south or north, dissolving into the four directions, sinking into the unfathomable. Unrestrained by east or west, he begins in profound obscurity and returns to the Great Thoroughfare. Yet you seek to measure him with narrow scrutiny and probe him with debate—this is truly like using a tube to observe the heavens or a awl to mark the earth. Is this not petty? Begone!

Have you not heard of the young men of Shouling who went to learn the walking style of Handan? Before mastering the state’s art, they lost even their original gait and could only crawl home. If you do not leave now, you will forget your former ways and lose your former learning."

Gongsun Long’s mouth gaped open, unable to close; his tongue rose, unable to descend. He fled in haste.

Thus, those who lose their footing in learning and practice crawl home in defeat; those who pursue knowledge at the expense of their true nature are utterly bereft of the Way.

Yuan Qi says: "Nine years of flood, seven years of drought—if true, humankind would perish!" Yet Zhuangzi speaks of ten years with nine floods and eight years with seven droughts, ascending to the heavens above or descending to the Yellow Springs below, so lofty and distant is his vision. *Shi* is synonymous with *shi* (release). *Jie* means to penetrate. To sink into the unfathomable is to enter deeply. To begin in profound obscurity is to stand before the limitless. To return to the Great Thoroughfare is to revert to the Ultimate Way.

To exhaust the Way with the clarity of petty scrutiny and probe it with verbal debate—is this not small-minded? The parable of losing one’s gait in Handan is especially apt! Gongsun Long, a master of disputation from Zhao, could reconcile sameness and difference, separate hardness and whiteness, confound the hundred schools, and exhaust the rivers of argument—yet upon hearing Zhuangzi’s words, he was struck dumb and lost all composure. Those who chase external learning while forgetting their original truth often meet such an end.

Thus, Wei Mou explained to the well-frog and the sea turtle that their perspectives differed, so they might understand the origin of right and wrong and where subtle discourse resides—only then could one ascend to the heavens or plumb the depths. To be *shi*-like in all four directions is to begin in profound obscurity and merge with the void. To return to the Great Thoroughfare is to become one with the Way.

Now, to attempt to fathom Zhuangzi’s Way with mere trivialities and argumentation is no different from the youths of Shouling who learned to walk in Handan—only to crawl home in the end. *Yuzi* means "young ones." Here ends *Fascicle Fifty-Four of the Ocean of Meanings in the Southern Florescence True Sutra*. *Fascicle Fifty-Five of the Ocean of Meanings in the Southern Florescence True Sutra* begins.

Master Chu Boxiu of Wulin’s *Exegesis on "Autumn Floods" (Fifth Chapter)*

Zhuangzi was angling in the Pu River when the King of Chu dispatched two grand ministers to approach him first, saying: "I wish to burden you with the affairs of the realm." Zhuangzi held his rod without turning, and said: "I have heard that in Chu there is a divine tortoise, dead now three thousand years, which the king wraps in silk and stores in a casket upon his ancestral altar. For this tortoise, would it prefer to die and leave its bones to be venerated, or to live and drag its tail through the mud?" The two ministers as one said: "It would prefer to live and drag its tail through the mud." Zhuangzi said: "Go then! I too shall drag my tail through the mud."

Guo Xiang’s commentary: To prefer living and dragging one’s tail through the mud is for each nature to find its own repose.
Lü Huiqing’s commentary: Zhuangzi, who knows nothing of death, speaks thus to rescue an age that pursues profit and forgets life. Only these two ministers’ understanding suffices for this.
Yidu’s commentary: Zhuangzi cites the divine tortoise to decline the King of Chu’s summons, for he does not wish to seek wealth and honor at the cost of his life.
Bixu’s commentary: Thus one knows that carriages and caps are external things, not inherent to one’s nature or destiny.
Yongzhai’s note: The analogy of dying to leave one’s bones or living to drag one’s tail is truly extraordinary. Zhuangzi’s refusal of the summons through the tortoise metaphor is profoundly apt, for worthy and talented men who resolve difficulties and plan harmony for the state are indeed indispensable—yet once their work is done and their merit complete, their lives may not be spared, just as the tortoise’s divinity serves man.
