After five or six months of stacking pellets—two without falling—the misses are few; three without falling, and only one in ten is lost; five without falling, and it is as if I pluck them. My stance is as rooted as a withered stump; my arm, as steady as a dead branch. Though heaven and earth are vast and the ten thousand things myriad, I know only the cicada’s wings. I do not waver, nor turn aside, nor let the ten thousand things distract me from the cicada’s wings—how could I not succeed?"

Confucius turned to his disciples and said: "When the will is undivided, it congeals into spirit." Is this not what the cicada-catching elder embodies?

Guo’s commentary: Stacking two pellets on the pole’s tip tests the steadiness of the hand—thus the misses are minimal. With three pellets unfallen, misses grow fewer still; with five unfallen, steadiness reaches its peak, and nothing is lost, for in abandoning all else, this is attained.

Lü’s commentary: To grasp the Dao of catching cicadas is to embody the guarding of pure qi—its undivided focus is no different.

Yi Du’s note: *Jun chang* refers to a bent waist. Catching cicadas as if gathering them, Confucius, struck by the man’s skill, suspected a Dao and questioned him. The reply: during the fifth and sixth months, when cicadas sing, stacking pellets precariously—even the most practiced can keep them from falling. This is the method of cicada-catching. *Zizhu* denotes the smallest measure, the beginning of numbers. "As if plucking them" marks the transition from unity to nothingness. "Withered stump" and "dead branch" describe his immobility. "Not letting the ten thousand things distract from the cicada’s wings—how could I not succeed?" Yet this is hardly innate! When the will is undivided, it congeals into spirit.

Bi Xu’s commentary: Cicadas can be used for brewing, hence their capture. Initially, one practices by stacking pellets on the pole’s tip to test the steadiness of the hand. With two stacks unfallen, the misses are minimal; with five unfallen, the body becomes like severed wood, the arm like a withered branch, and cicadas alight without hesitation—thus they are taken as if plucked. From this, we know that with singular focus and congealed spirit, the Dao is never unattainable—how much more so for catching cicada wings!

Yong Qi’s note: "Not wavering, not turning aside" means simply fixing the mind, focusing solely on the cicada without distraction. This analogy illustrates the guarding of pure qi, though in the world, such skill is treated as mere technique, unaware of the Dao embedded within.

"Congeals into spirit" (*ning yu shen*)—*ning* should be *yi* (doubt), as seen in the later "Refining" chapter.

Yan Yuan asked Confucius: "I once crossed the deep rapids of Shang, where the ferryman handled the boat as if by spirit. I asked him: 'Can boat-handling be learned?' He said: 'It can. Those skilled in swimming often master it. As for divers, they have never seen a boat yet handle it effortlessly.' I questioned him further, but he would not explain. May I ask what this means?"

Confucius said: "Those skilled in swimming often master it because they forget the water. As for divers who have never seen a boat yet handle it effortlessly—they see the depths as hills, the capsizing of a boat as a cart’s retreat. Though a thousand overturnings and reversals lie before them, none enter their dwelling—where could they not find leisure?

"One who stakes tiles gambles with skill; one who stakes hooks hesitates; one who stakes gold is confounded. The skill is the same, yet where there is pride, the external is weighted. All who weight the external are clumsy within."

Guo’s commentary: Though things have their nature, practice is required to master them. Through practice, nature is perfected, appearing as if innate. Seeing depths as hills, they view a boat’s capsizing in the abyss as a cart’s retreat on a slope. Though overturnings and reversals abound, they do not trouble the heart, for their nature is at ease, and all encounters are met with leisure. The heavier the stake, the more the mind clings—those who wish to nurture life and preserve the inner must be without pride or weight.

Lü’s commentary: Observing the boatman and the gold-staking examples, one who preserves form and restores essence must abandon the world and relinquish life to the point of spirit without retreat—only then can this be achieved.

Yi Du’s note: This parable of attaining life speaks of following nature and acting with sincerity, the heart unburdened by attachments—wherever one goes, self-possession abounds. The skilled swimmer, following nature to handle a boat, is not yet perfected; the diver, however, has never seen a boat yet handles it effortlessly. Though overturnings and reversals lie before them, none enter their breast—where could they not find leisure?

"Staking" refers to gambling with objects in archery. A hook is more valuable than a tile, gold more valuable than a hook. With nothing prized, skill remains; with something prized, the mind is thrown into chaos.

Bi Xu’s commentary: Handling a boat as if by spirit, the skilled swimmer fears no drowning. The diver, submerged in water, does not wait for a boat but handles it effortlessly—those who forget water still rely on boats; those who have never seen a boat forget both. Anxiety and rest do not enter the breast, for the inner is abundant and at ease. This illustrates how, with a cheap vessel like a tile, one’s aim is precise; with a valuable hook or gold, one’s aim falters. Thus, lightening the water allows one to handle a boat; weighting the prize makes the mind clumsy. This is the principle of nature.

Yong Zhai’s note: The skilled diver sees water as level ground and thus, without learning, can handle a boat. "Staking" refers to gambling with objects in archery. The archer’s skill is fundamentally the same, yet where there is attachment, what is prized lies without, and the inner is deluded.

Delusion turns even the skilled clumsy at times!

Tian Kaizhi visited Duke Wei of Zhou. The Duke said: "I have heard that Zhu Shen is a student of the Dao. You have traveled with Zhu Shen—what have you learned from him?"

Tian Kaizhi replied: "Kaizhi holds but a broom and dustpan to attend at the gate—what could I have learned from the Master!"

The Duke said: "Do not decline, Master Tian. I wish to hear it."

Kaizhi said: "I heard the Master say: 'One who nurtures life well is like a shepherd—he watches those lagging behind and whips them.'"

The Duke asked: "What does this mean?"

Tian Kaizhi said: "In Lu there was a man named Shan Bao who lived in the cliffs and drank from streams. He did not compete with others for profit. At seventy, his complexion was still that of a child. Yet misfortune struck when he encountered a starving tiger, which killed and devoured him.

There was also a man named Zhang Yi who frequented the gates of the high and mighty, running wherever he was called. At forty, he died of internal heat.

Bao nurtured his inner self, but the tiger consumed his outer; Yi nurtured his outer self, but illness attacked his inner. Both failed to whip those lagging behind.

Confucius said: 'Do not enter and hide; do not exit and expose; stand like dry wood in the center.' If one attains these three, one’s name will surely reach its peak.

Those who fear the roads—where ten travelers are killed by one—warn their fathers, sons, and brothers. They must gather a large escort before daring to venture out. How wise they are!

Yet what people truly fear lies only on their mats and in their meals. They do not know that the real danger comes from excess.

Guo’s note: The student of the Dao seeks harmony within. Clinging to one method to the point of excess falls short of the harmony of universal adaptation. 'Whipping the laggards' means correcting what is lacking.

To hide is already internal, yet to enter further is excessive entry. To expose is already external, yet to exit further is excessive exit. Like withered wood, empty of intent yet perfectly balanced—this is how one attains the highest name and true fulfillment.

On the road, one in ten is killed, and people greatly fear it. Yet the harms of sensual desire lead straight to death, and none avoid them. How grave the excess!

Lü’s note: Shan Bao embodied the one whose form perishes while life remains; Zhang Yi, the one whose possessions overflow while his form is neglected. Bao entered and hid; Yi exited and exposed. Both acted with intent. To stand like dry wood is to be without intent; the center is not what lags behind.

Yi Du’s note: A good shepherd watches those lagging behind and whips them, guiding them to follow the principle without loss. Shan Bao and Zhang Yi both failed to whip the laggards.

To enter and hide is to enter further; to exit and expose is to exit further. To stand like dry wood in the center is to be without intent regarding entry or exit. Attain this reality, and one’s name will surely reach its peak.

The danger of one in ten killed on the road is a peril of human society, easily seen and avoided. The perils of yin and yang in the space of mats and meals are subtle and hard to discern, so people do not guard against them.

As Laozi said: 'They rush to the place of death.'

Bi Xu’s note: Nurturing life is like herding sheep—those who take shortcuts fall behind and must be whipped. Shan Bao nurtured his inner self but neglected his outer; Zhang Yi cultivated his outer self but neglected his inner. Both failed to whip the laggards.

To enter and hide means to retreat into seclusion, dull to worldly affairs. To exit and expose means to chase after worldly trends, forgetting self-cultivation. To stand like dry wood in the center is to be dull and unadaptable. Free from these three attachments, one attains the eternal name and reaches the ultimate.

The dangers of the road are obvious and easy to guard against; the subtle harms of mats and meals are hard to maintain. Thus, the beauty of goodness has long been a hidden peril, and the world remains unaware.

Yong Zhai’s note: The hairpin and broom are tools for sweeping and cleaning. Herding sheep should follow nature, yet whipping the laggards means following the heavenly principle while also fulfilling human effort. Shan Bao and Zhang Yi both failed in human effort and could not wholly entrust themselves to heaven.

This passage is most intimate to the scholar’s own station. Extend this principle, and one understands what comes before and after—it speaks to the intent of heaven’s Dao and humanity’s Dao.

'Do not enter and hide' means not to be fixated on stillness; 'do not exit and expose' means not to be bound to activity. To stand like dry wood in the center is to be without intent regarding movement or stillness.

Master these three phrases, and one may be called a perfected person!

The fear of the road illustrates the danger of mats and meals—it is the axe that hews at life’s root, a warning to curb desire.

The invocator of the ancestral temple, clad in dark robes, approached the pen and said to the pig: 'Why do you hate death? I will fatten you for three months, fast for ten days, purify for three, spread white reeds, and place your shoulder and rump upon the carved platter. Would you accept this?'

Planning for the pig, he said: 'Better to eat chaff and be left in the pen.' Planning for himself, he said: 'If living brings the honor of carriages and caps, and dying brings rest upon the ancestral altar amid the ancestral temple, I would accept it.'

Planning for the pig, he rejects it; planning for himself, he accepts it. What makes the pig different?

Guo’s note: Desire leads to the loss of the self—principle and constant are the same, whether for man or beast.

Lü’s note: Planning for the pig, he rejects it; planning for himself, he accepts it. Is it that he loves himself less than the pig? It is the world that burdens him! Only by abandoning the world and forgetting life can one be free of burdens.

Yi Du’s note: Planning for the tortoise, it would rather drag its tail in the mud than leave its bones to be venerated. Planning for the pig, it would rather eat chaff in the pen than be placed upon the carved platter. This means that to dwell in wealth and honor against the principle of life is worse than to follow the principle of life and delight in poverty and lowliness."

Zhuangzi compares himself to the tortoise and the worldly to the pig—his subtle meaning is thus revealed.

Bixu’s note: When an oxhide is flayed to make a drum to marshal the three armies, for the ox’s sake it would be better to bear the yoke. When the white fox’s pelt becomes the Son of Heaven’s robe and adorns the ancestral hall, for the fox’s sake it would be better to roam the marshes. This is why the pen-raised pig does not wish to be placed upon the carved platter—it is the purport of attaining life and attaining destiny.

Yongzhai’s note: *Xuanduan* is a cap. *Teng* means to feed with fodder. *Tun* is the same as *zhuan* (pig). *Xun* is the peach. A curved vessel that can gather things is called a *julou*, like a dustpan or wicker basket. In the *Zuozhuan* (Duke Xuan, second year): "The chef stewed the bear’s paw improperly, killed him, and placed him in a basket." This is the same meaning. One may possess the nobility of carriages and crowns in life, yet end by dying in form, placing oneself upon the chopping block, within the dustpan or wicker basket—would one truly be content? Planning for the pig is one thing, yet planning for oneself is another—why is this so?

The four chapters above share a similar purport. When Jun Chang pursues the cicada, his focus remains undivided—this also elucidates the guarding of pure *qi* in the previous chapter. The diver who steers the boat as if by spirit embodies the meaning of "entering the spirit through mastery of principle." The shepherd who drives the sheep with his whip demonstrates the rule of nurturing life. The invocator who speaks for the pig warns against the delusion of carriages and crowns. All these serve to shatter the worldly man’s confusion and return him to the sublime purport of attaining life. The meaning of the classic is clear and plain—no further gloss is needed.

Plucking the hairpin—its upper part sliced like a rush’s tip—Li’s old annotation reads *ba* (to grasp), while *Yongzhai Oral Exegesis* equates the root *ji* (技) with *zhi* (枝, branch). "Plucking the hairpin" thus refers to a broom. Most commentaries pass over this without discussion. Master Wuyin Fan states: *Ba* (拔) should be read as *fu* (拂, to brush), and *fu-jing* (拂警) are tools held by servants. The meaning is coherent, though the phonetic gloss remains unclear. Examining the character’s form and reasoning through its principle, I find that *ji* (技) should be *fu* (帗). A minor scribal error in transmission occurred. The *Jian Rhymes* notes: *chen* (忱) is pronounced *fu* (拂) and shares the same sense as *ai* (愛)—a full-feathered duster, also held by attendants.

As for *tun xun* (豚循), Lu’s *Pronunciation and Meaning* states the character should be *zhuan ji* (篆輯), referring to the painted hearse used to carry coffins. *Ju* (聚) should be *mo* (茉), pronounced *cai guan*. *Chang* (偿) should be *lou* (篓), pronounced *li jiu*, denoting burial in a *mo*-coated, wicker-bound coffin. Yet the transmitted text of the classic retains these characters as they stand. Further examination of the *Liji*’s "Tan Gong" chapter reveals: "The Son of Heaven’s hearse is coated with *mo* and painted with dragon patterns, using *ning* (柠) [as adornment]." It also states: "A *lou* (篓) is set up," where *lou* is synonymous with *liu ju* (柳菆)—a gathering of wood to reinforce the coffin before coating it. The dragon patterns refer to the carved dragon designs.

The classic’s purport thus deepens: those who pursue wealth and rank trade their lives for death, yet even a pig would refuse such an exchange—how could a human be inferior to a pig?

*Collected Subtleties of the Meaning of the Southern Florescence Classic*, Scroll Fifty-Eight, concludes.

#1 Yu Chui’s *Zhuangzi Pingyi*: "Ning" (凝) should be "yi" (疑).
#2 Zhao the Remonstrator’s edition reads "jian" (间) as "wen" (问).

*Collected Subtleties of the Meaning of the Southern Florescence Classic*, Scroll Fifty-Nine. By Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin.

**Chapter Two: Attaining Life**

Duke Huan was hunting in the marshes, with Guan Zhong driving his chariot, when he saw a ghost. The Duke grasped Guan Zhong’s hand and asked, “What did you see, Father Zhong?” Guan Zhong replied, “Your servant saw nothing.” The Duke returned, distraught, and took to his sickbed, refusing to emerge for days.

Among the Qi scholars was one named Huangzi Gaofang, who said, “The Duke has harmed himself—how could a ghost harm him? When the *qi* of anger and sorrow scatters and fails to return, it causes deficiency. If it rises but does not descend, it makes one prone to rage; if it descends but does not rise, it makes one prone to forgetfulness. If it neither rises nor descends but lodges in the center of the body, striking the heart, it causes illness.”

Duke Huan asked, “Then do ghosts exist?” Huangzi replied, “There are *shen* and *lü* in the depths, and *ao* with its topknot. In the cluttered soil within doorways, thunder dwells; in the northeast, *bei’e* and *xielong* leap; in the northwest, *yiyang* resides. In water there is *wangxiang*; in mounds, *xing*; in mountains, *kui*; in the wilds, *panghuang*; and in marshes, *weiyi*.”

The Duke asked, “What does *weiyi* look like?” Huangzi said, “*Weiyi* is as large as a wheel hub, as long as a chariot shaft, clad in purple robes with a crimson crown. As a creature, it loathes the sound of thunderous chariots and, upon hearing it, clutches its head and stands upright. Those who see it are destined for hegemony.”

Duke Huan laughed heartily and said, “This is what I saw!” He then straightened his robes and cap, sat with Huangzi, and before the day was out, his illness had vanished without his notice.

**Guo’s Commentary:** This chapter speaks of how distress burdens life when one fails to understand, while tranquility restores one’s nature when one grasps the principle.

**Lü’s Commentary:** It shows that anxiety and doubt allow ghosts no power to harm, yet one harms oneself; when doubt dissipates, illness departs of its own accord. Thus, those who preserve their Heaven-given nature and prevent external things from intruding are rightly beyond harm.

How did Huangzi Gaofang know the names and forms of ghosts? In ancient times, those among the people whose essence was undivided—men called *wu* and women called *xi*—could, by dwelling in the abodes of ghosts and spirits, discern their names and forms. Was there no transmission of this knowledge?

**Yi Zhu’s Note:** These names of ghosts were passed down by the ancients. Zhuangzi cited them, embedding deeper principles within. Those whose learning has not reached the Dao of Heaven cannot debate their existence or nonexistence. Confucius said, “If one cannot serve men, how can one serve ghosts?” He thus left the matter unaddressed.

What Duke Huan saw in the marshes, Huangzi Gaofang resolved by addressing his doubt. By describing *weiyi* and saying that those who see it attain hegemony, his words struck the Duke’s heart. His doubt dissolved, and his illness vanished unnoticed. When people today fall ill and consult divination, or seek cures through shamans, they recover by the same principle—though the ignorant remain unaware.

**Bixu’s Commentary:** Guan Zhong, free of intent, saw no ghost; Duke Huan, burdened by intent, saw a ghost and fell ill. When yang *qi* surges upward and yin congeals, it breeds rage; when yang *qi* sinks and yang hides, it breeds forgetfulness. If it neither rises nor falls but lodges in the body’s center, striking the heart, illness follows. When the Duke asked about the existence of ghosts, Huangzi answered by describing their forms, culminating in *weiyi*—precisely matching what the Duke had seen. Thus, whether desires are great or small, their fulfillment brings joy; whether doubts are vast or trivial, their resolution brings release. In the moment, the key lies in awakening. This is why the perfected cannot abandon words.

**Yongzhai’s Note:** *Tanyi* is a disease of reversed *qi*. *Shen* dwells in the mud of ditches. The Duke saw his vision in the marshes, so he asked only about *weiyi*. Initially suspecting a demon, he fell ill from fear; when told that seeing it foretold hegemony, he rejoiced, and his illness vanished. This differs from seeing a pig caked in mud or a cartload of ghosts. Yet since the Sage included such matters in the hexagrams’ judgments, such occurrences in the world are not strange.

Duke Huan’s illness arose from doubt and could not be cured by medicine. Huangzi dispelled delusion with delusion, achieving a cure without drugs. Thus, the existence of ghosts depends on the mind’s arising and ceasing, while the mind’s likes and dislikes reveal human delusion. When delusion departs, likes and dislikes align with truth; when the original mind is clear, arising and ceasing no longer depend on externals. Those who chase delusion and lose their true nature are like those who see ghosts and fall ill. Who, then, knows the best way to heal? Huangzi’s words—“The Duke harms himself; how could a ghost harm him?”—are the finest remedy. This resembles how playing with tiles banishes heartache, or how the removal of a bow’s shadow cures a suspicious illness.

If one can purify the mind, wash away perceptions, and merge with inner emptiness—leaving no dust, untroubled by the myriad phenomena—how could ghosts appear? How could illness enter?

Though the recorded ghost names seem fantastical, the *Confucian Family Sayings* also mentions *kui* and *wangxiang*. The *Zuozhuan* speaks of “new ghosts being great, old ghosts small,” and the *Records of the Grand Historian* recounts the Marquis of Dili presenting a jade disk. Thus, ghosts are not nonexistent. But if yin and yang each remain in their proper place, neither harming the other, it is enough. The Classic states, “When the world follows the Dao, its ghosts lack numinosity.”

**Jiyuzi trained fighting cocks for the king.** After ten days, the king asked, “Are the cocks ready?” Jiyuzi replied, “Not yet. They are still vain and rely on their *qi*.”

After another ten days, the king asked again. Jiyuzi said, “Not yet. They still react to echoes and shadows.”

After another ten days, the king asked again. Jiyuzi said, “Not yet. They still glare fiercely and bristle with *qi*.”

After another ten days, the king asked again. Jiyuzi said, “Almost. Though other cocks may crow, they show no change. They appear like wooden cocks, their virtue complete. No other cock dares respond—they turn and flee.”

**Guo’s Commentary:** This chapter speaks of nurturing to perfection, which leaves one unmatched externally—how much more so for self-perfection?

**Lü’s Commentary:** If one’s nurtured state resembles the wooden cock—unmoved by external stimuli—then none can rival them.

**Yidu’s Annotation:** This uses the training of cocks as a metaphor for nurturing life, wherein cultivation proceeds by degrees. "Vain and reliant on *qi*" describes emptiness without substance, self-aggrandizing. "Reacting to echoes and shadows" speaks to swift responsiveness. "Glaring fiercely and bristling with *qi*" seeks an opponent while asserting one’s own superiority. "Though other cocks crow, they show no change" means facing a challenger without response, forgetting victory and defeat. When they "appear like wooden cocks" and no other cock dares respond, one knows that with virtue complete, not only is the self without intent, but it also prevents others from forming intent—this is the pinnacle of nurturing.

**Bixu’s Annotation:** "Vain and reliant on *qi*" denotes haughty boasting. "Reacting to echoes and shadows" refers to ostentatious posturing. "Glaring fiercely and bristling with *qi*" displays a contentious demeanor. "Though crowing, showing no change" means dust no longer dazzles. When they "appear like wooden cocks" and no other cock dares respond, the heart is ashen and the form withered—nothing contends with them.

**Yongzhai’s Note:** Responding to sounds or moving at shadows means the heart is still swayed by external things. "Glaring fiercely and bristling with *qi*" describes spirit and *qi* flourishing while the form remains unmoved. The first phrase, "vain and reliant," places *qi* externally; "glaring fiercely and bristling" places *qi* internally. When they "appear like wooden cocks," spirit and *qi* are both complete. This speaks of the art of guarding *qi*, using the cock as a metaphor. "Vain and reliant on *qi*" exposes *qi* to seek an opponent. "Reacting to echoes and shadows" pursues externals while neglecting the internal. "Glaring fiercely and bristling with *qi*" fills the interior and manifests outwardly, intending to overpower. "Appearing like wooden cocks" means inner harmony and outer transformation, transcending things to stand alone. No other cock dares respond—those who see them turn and flee. This illustrates the effect of nurturing *qi* to perfect spirit: when spirit is whole, awe is manifest. If one who studies the Dao reaches a state where their form resembles withered wood, *qi* and spirit need no nurturing to become whole. Even ghosts and spirits revere them—how much more their peers? This is how the ancients avoided contention yet excelled in victory.

**Note on the Text:** "Are the cocks ready?" is ungrammatical. According to the *Liezi*, the original reads, "Can the cocks fight yet?"—Zhuangzi’s phrasing is abbreviated.

**Confucius observed at Lüliang,** where the waterfall plunged thirty *ren*, its rapids foaming forty *li*, a torrent where eels, dragons, fish, and turtles could not swim. He saw a man swimming there and assumed he was in distress, seeking death. He sent his disciples along the current to rescue him. After several hundred paces, the man emerged, hair unbound, singing as he strolled beneath the embankment. Confucius followed and questioned him: "I took you for a ghost, but now I see you are a man. May I ask if you have a method for treading water?"

The man replied, "No, I have no method. I began with what was innate, grew with my nature, and fulfilled my destiny. I enter with the swirling current and emerge with the surging flow, following the water’s Dao without imposing my will. This is how I tread it."

Confucius asked, "What do you mean by beginning with what was innate, growing with nature, and fulfilling destiny?"

The man said, "I was born on the hills and am at ease on the hills—this is what is innate. I grew up in water and am at ease in water—this is nature. I do not know why I am so, yet I am so—this is destiny."

**Guo’s Commentary:** "Grinding and swirling inward" describes the swirling current; "revolving and surging outward" describes the surging flow. When one possesses a singular ability and applies it without restraint, nothing in the world is difficult. Using this effortless mastery to traverse the Dao of ceaseless generation—where could one not go?

**Lü’s Commentary:** Following the principles of nature and destiny, entering with the swirling current and emerging with the surging flow, one follows the water’s Dao without imposing will—thus one can tread it. As for places where even eels and dragons cannot swim, aligning one’s virtue to harmonize with the utmost reaches of things, naturally nothing one treads is unsuitable. Being born on the hills and at ease there is what is innate—this is not a matter of nature but of human effort. Growing up in water and at ease there is nature—this is one’s singular ability. Without such nature, even if one practices, one cannot achieve what others cannot.

**Yidu’s Annotation:** The man at Lüliang treads water with a Dao yet without imposing will—he follows principle. Thus, he enters with the swirling current and emerges with the surging flow without drowning. "Beginning with what is innate" means having a foundation; "growing with nature" means having something natural; "fulfilling destiny" means not knowing the cause or reason, yet it is not natural either. Hence, he is at ease on the hills and in water without knowing why.

**Bixu’s Annotation:** "Swirling" is like a millstone’s inward rotation. "Surging" is like a gushing spring. Imposing one’s will against the water prevents the completion of nature and destiny. Born on the hills and at ease there, one does not lose what is innate. Growing up in water and entering without peril stems from sharing the same fundamental nature. Swimming in the torrent without knowing why is the fulfillment of heavenly destiny. Understanding the essence of life is like swimming at Lüliang—it comes from habit and completion.

**Fuzhai’s Note:** This passage shares the same meaning as the earlier one on steering a boat. "What is innate" refers to the original state. *Mencius* says, "Those who speak of nature refer to what is innate"—meaning the natural principles of nature and destiny. "Following the water’s Dao without imposing will" expresses compliance without resistance. Being at ease on the hills or in water means following one’s nature without knowing why. The terms "nature" and "destiny" are initially indistinct—this is merely a matter of phrasing. The man at Lüliang’s treading of water and singing lies in following the water’s Dao without imposing will, so the water cannot harm him. If one navigates the world by following human Dao without imposing will, others will not harm them either.

Extending this principle to all interactions with things—where could one not attain wholeness? Beginning with what is innate, one relies on practice to achieve mastery; growing through nature, long habit becomes spontaneity; fulfilling destiny, one merges with water and forgets how it is so. This is called preserving wholeness through Heaven.

This chapter aligns with the idea of "not encountering things"—engaging with the world without harming it. Could these words serve as the standard for navigating life?

**Note on "并" (bìng):** The character formerly had no alternate pronunciation; it should be read identically to "傍" (bàng), in the falling tone.

When Zi Qing carved wood into a *lian*, upon completion, those who saw it marveled as if it were the work of ghosts or spirits. The Lord of Lu saw it and asked, "What technique did you employ?" He replied, "I am but a craftsman—what technique could I possess? Though if I must speak of it, there is one thing: when I prepare to craft the *lian*, I never dare to deplete my *qi*; I must fast to still my mind. After three days of fasting, I no longer harbor thoughts of rewards, rank, or emoluments. After five days, I no longer dwell on praise or blame, skill or clumsiness. After seven days, I suddenly forget I possess four limbs and a physical form. At that moment, the court and its affairs vanish; my skill becomes whole, and external distractions dissolve. Only then do I enter the mountain forests to observe the natural patterns of trees. When the form is perfectly embodied, only then do I begin carving. Otherwise, I desist. Thus, I unite Heaven with Heaven—the reason the vessel seems divine lies here!"

**Guo’s Commentary:** Regarding the court as nonexistent, all desires for favor vanish. He selects wood from the village, never departing from its natural state. Exhausting the marvels of the material, it appears as if crafted by ghosts or spirits.

**Lü’s Commentary:** The reason the vessel seems divine is just this. If external distractions remain unresolved while one seeks to wander among the creations of things, perfection cannot be attained.

**Yi Du’s Commentary:** The craftsman’s name was Qing. The *lian* is an instrument for halting music, also called *yuxiang*, shaped like a crouching tiger with twenty-seven serrated teeth on its back. "Never depleting *qi*" means emptying the mind to stillness. "Not harboring thoughts of rewards, rank, or emoluments" means forgetting gain.

Free from concerns of praise or blame, skill or clumsiness—this is forgetting reputation. Forgetting one’s own limbs and form, the spirit remains whole and merges with Heaven. Thus one regards the court as nonexistent, and the disturbances of external affairs dissolve. Only then does one enter the mountain forests, observing which trees’ forms align with the furnace’s needs. Then, and only then, does one apply the hand—without forcing, extending one’s own Heaven to meet the Heaven of the material. This is why the vessel seems divine.

**Bi Xu’s Commentary:** To labor the mind depletes *qi*; to be without desire is stillness. A heart unburdened by rewards, rank, or emoluments rejects external affairs. Free from concerns of praise or blame, skill or clumsiness, inner thoughts cease. Forgetting one’s form is to forget both inner and outer. Only then does one enter the mountain forests, selecting wood in its natural state and matching its natural craftsmanship—so wondrous it seems the work of ghosts or spirits, and even the Lord of Lu suspected it bore protective charms.

**Yongzhai’s Commentary:** The *ju* is the frame for bells and drums, akin to *gouli*, a wooden beast-shaped stand for suspending them. Free from concerns of rank, praise, or blame, forgetting one’s limbs—this means guarding the pure *qi*, keeping external things at bay. One observes the material’s innate nature and form, as if already shaped, then takes and uses it, aligning one’s own nature with the material’s. Never depleting *qi*, the spirit remains whole. Cultivating fasting of the mind and stillness is the Way to nourish spirit and *qi*, hence its manifestation in use. With skill concentrated and external distractions dissolved, one observes which wood’s nature aligns with the *ju*’s form, then applies the hand—expending little effort yet achieving great results. This is why the vessel seems divine. Yet the marvel of Heaven meeting Heaven cannot be fully expressed in words; only those who exhaust the spirit and know transformation may partake in it. If one remains unmoved by rewards, rank, praise, or blame, then in all actions, how could one not achieve the divine?

Dongye Ji demonstrated his charioteering before Duke Zhuang, advancing and retreating in perfect alignment, turning left and right as if guided by compass and rule. The Duke believed even the finest patterns could not surpass it and ordered him to perform a hundred intricate maneuvers before returning. Yan He encountered him and entered to say, “Ji’s horses are about to fail.” The Duke remained silent and did not respond. Soon after, the horses indeed faltered and returned. The Duke asked, “How did you know?” He replied, “Their strength was exhausted, yet you still demanded more—hence I knew they would fail.”

The craftsman’s chisel turns as if bound by compass and rule, his fingers transforming with the material without mental calculation. Thus his spirit-terrace remains unified and unobstructed. Forgetting the feet, the shoes fit perfectly; forgetting the waist, the belt fits perfectly; knowing forgets right and wrong, the mind is at ease; neither inwardly changing nor outwardly following, all things align. Beginning with ease and never straying from it—this is the ease of forgetting ease.

**Guo’s Commentary:** The horses’ strength was exhausted, yet more was demanded—hence their failure. This shows that even the most perfect must not be overreached. Though the craftsman’s skill is great, it still follows compass and rule—this speaks of working with the material’s natural ease. When all parts of the body are at ease, one forgets the self entirely. Right and wrong arise from unease; when one is content with what comes, there is no need for change or compliance. Thus, even those who know ease have not yet attained true ease.

**Lü’s Commentary:** Though Ji’s charioteering was flawless, it could not avoid failure. After the horses’ strength was spent, to persist in action is to strive where life has nothing left to give, where knowledge has no recourse—such effort yields no wisdom. The craftsman’s hand turns, ever more aligned with compass and rule, meaning his fingers’ movement refines the rule’s precision. The more refined, the more his work aligns without trace, as if the material transforms naturally, without waiting for the mind’s deliberation to match square and circle. Only thus does the spirit-terrace remain unified and unobstructed. As for forgetting the feet, the waist, the mind, and right and wrong—never straying from ease—is this not proof of acting without mental calculation?

**Yi Du’s Commentary:** Ji’s charioteering aligned with compass and rule, and Duke Zhuang believed even the most intricate patterns could not surpass it. He ordered Ji to perform a hundred intricate turns before returning. The horses’ strength was already exhausted, yet more was demanded—hence it was clear they would fail. This illustrates the principle of life’s nature: one must follow what is perfectly fitting and not overreach. The craftsman’s hand moves swiftly with compass and rule, guided by the hand while the heart responds—never lingering. Thus the spirit-terrace remains empty and unified, unshackled by profit or desire.

When the feet are forgotten, every shoe fits perfectly; when the waist is forgotten, every belt sits comfortably; when right and wrong are forgotten, the heart finds ease in all things. With no inner inclination to change and no outer compulsion to follow, one encounters affairs, observes their convergence, and acts according to ritual—thus every convergence becomes fitting. This is the ease of forgetting ease.

**Bixu’s Commentary:** Charioteering aligned with compass and rule is like weaving patterned brocade, guiding the horses to turn in hooked arcs, a hundred departures and returns all resuming their original course. Han Ying said: "Shun was skilled in employing people, Zaofu in employing horses. He did not exhaust his people, so none became idle; he did not exhaust his horses, so none became worn out." A horse’s stumbling and defeat arise from overdriving; a people’s exhaustion of wisdom stems from oppressive governance. Thus one who understands fate does not strive for what knowledge cannot remedy. The craftsman’s response to things is unobstructed, his nature unadulterated—his fingers transform with the object. With no mental hesitation, his spirit-terrace remains unified and unbound.

Forgetting the feet and waist is but a minor matter; when the heart forgets right and wrong, even the root is forgotten—how much more the branches? Inner and outer lie within oneself; all encounters become thus. Naturally at ease and constantly at ease, this is the ease of no-ease. The subtlety of the craftsman’s hammer is the same.

**Yongqi’s Note:** The skill of charioteering resembles recognizing patterns in weaving—hence it is said, "patterns do not exceed." "A hundred hooks" refers to a hundred turns in the hunt. Though the horses’ strength is spent, driving them relentlessly ensures failure. Even with skill, overuse leads to collapse—how can one overtax the spirit? The craftsman’s hammer spins the wheel as if covering it, naturally conforming to compass and rule, like Wu Daozi painting the halo of a divine image in a single stroke. "Fingers transforming with the object" is like the saying on calligraphy: "The hand knows not the brush, the brush knows not the hand; hand and brush both forgotten, the mind does not linger." This is what is meant by "sensory awareness ceases while the spirit moves"—thus the spirit-terrace remains pure and unconfined.

"Ease" means peace; "convergence" is like attainment—attaining the Dao and reaching ease. The inner realm becomes pure and unchanging; though engaging with things, one no longer knows what one is doing. Beginning with ease and never straying from it, over time even ease is forgotten. The *Book of Songs* says: "Holding the reins like weaving, the two flanks move like dance." This illustrates the meaning of "patterns do not exceed." The weaver gathers threads here to form patterns there—just as the skilled charioteer holds the reins above while the horses harmonize below. "A hundred hooks" refers to circularity. Driving without cease ensures failure; demanding more when strength is spent harms not only the horse but also exhausts the driver. The Duke kept his counsel, unwilling to dampen Ji’s resolve. Soon the outcome proved his foresight, yet it came too late to avert danger. Those who hear loyal advice but cannot act lose as much. The craftsman’s wheel spins within compass and rule—among the explanations, Master Lü’s is most apt, particularly his discussion of the word "cover." Yongzhai labored over the word "cover" before arriving at precision; combining the strengths of both yields perfection.

The passage’s intent is simply this: one who attains life’s Dao understands the principles of things, and things naturally align with him—not by striving to conform, but through profound skill. Roaming the world, he is never ill at ease—this is the ease of forgetting ease. If one can live in the world without clashing with things, there is no place that is not ease.

There was a man named Sun Xiu who came knocking at Bian Qingzi’s door, lamenting: "In my village, I am not called unrefined; in peril, I am not called cowardly. Yet when tilling the fields, I meet with bad years; when serving a lord, I meet with troubled times. Shunned by my village, banished by the district—what offense have I committed against Heaven?"

"Do you resent encountering this fate?" Master Bian replied: "Have you alone not heard of the perfect person’s way of conduct? They forget their liver and gall, leave behind their ears and eyes, wander in boundless vagueness beyond the dust and grime, roam freely in the work of non-action—this is called acting without reliance, growing without domination. Now you adorn knowledge to startle the foolish, cultivate the self to expose filth, shining brightly as if carrying the sun and moon in your stride. You have preserved your bodily form intact, kept all nine orifices complete, and avoided midway affliction with deafness, blindness, lameness, or disability to be counted among the living—this is already fortune enough. Why then do you have leisure to resent Heaven? Be gone!"

Sunzi departed. Master Bian entered, sat, and someone asked a question. He looked up to the sky and sighed. A disciple inquired: "Master, why do you sigh?" Master Bian said: "Just now, Xiu came, and I spoke to him of the perfect person’s virtue. I fear he was startled and thus fell into confusion." The disciple said: "Not so. Was what Sunzi said correct?"

"Was what the Master said incorrect? It is not that it could not confuse what is correct. Was what Sunzi said incorrect? Was what the Master said correct? He was already confused when he came—how can he be blamed?"

Master Bian said: "Not so. Once there was a crow that alighted in the outskirts of Lu. The Lord of Lu delighted in it, prepared a grand feast to honor it, and performed the *Nine Shao* to entertain it. The crow then grew sorrowful and anxious, its vision blurred, and it dared not eat or drink. This is called nourishing the crow with one’s own nourishment. As for nourishing the crow with the crow’s own nourishment, one should let it nest in deep forests, float upon rivers and lakes, and feed on whatever it encounters—then it would be at ease on level ground.

Now, Xiu is a man of simple sincerity and limited understanding. When I spoke to him of the perfect person’s virtue, it was like burdening a mole with chariots and horses or delighting a quail with bells and drums. How could he not be startled?

Guo’s Commentary: Whatever is not of true nature is but dust and grime. All self-initiated endeavors are the work of non-action; following one’s inclination without reliance, acting without domination, letting things grow of themselves without governing them.

The nourishment of self and the nourishment of crow each have their proper use, both attaining the harmony of nature and destiny.

Lü’s Commentary: The essence of this chapter lies in preserving life, achieving spiritual perfection and the return of essence, becoming one with Heaven. What Sun Xiu practices is the opposite. Upon hearing these words, he could not but feel sorrow and alarm, his vision blurred, and dared not partake—hence the concluding analogy of the sea crow.

Yi Du’s Commentary: Master Bian Qingzi was Sun Xiu’s teacher. Xiu once said: ‘In my village, no one calls me unrefined; in times of peril, no one calls me cowardly. Yet when I till the fields, I do not encounter a bountiful year; when I serve a lord, I do not meet a well-governed age. In my village, I am shunned by others; in my district, I am driven away. What crime have I committed against Heaven to receive such a fate?’

His teacher replied: ‘Have you alone not heard of the conduct of the perfect person? When one forgets the liver and gall, the five viscera all become empty...’"

To abandon the ears and eyes is to prevent the six dusts from entering. Thus one wanders beyond the dust, carefree and without action. The conduct of the true ruler arises from non-action, hence it acts without reliance; the enduring governance of the true master arises from non-governance, hence it endures without domination. Now you cultivate the body and adorn knowledge, seeking to distinguish yourself in the world—no wonder you suffer harm. To preserve your form without premature death is already fortunate compared to others; how can you find leisure to resent Heaven or blame others?

Fearing that Sun Xiu might not understand and be alarmed by these words, the master then offered the analogy of the sea crow, saying that those who nurture life each follow the natural suitability of their lot to reach fulfillment.

Bixu’s Commentary: Sun Xiu claims his conduct is refined and his resolve courageous, yet his undertakings meet no success—this is because he does not understand Heaven’s decree and vainly indulges in sorrow and lament. The conduct of the perfect person seeks no recognition from others; it forgets the liver and gall, let alone joy and anger. It abandons the ears and eyes, let alone sights and sounds. Cultivating courage, being shunned or driven away—these are all dust and grime. To act while forgetting oneself is to be free of all affairs. Now Sun Xiu acts with reliance, seeks to dominate while desiring longevity, and craves recognition through self-aggrandizement. Even if he narrowly escapes misfortune, he is but a man of intact form. For Sun Xiu strives after what cannot be achieved in nurturing life, so Master Bian answers with what cannot be altered by knowledge. This is like the great sound and perfect tone that must confound the vulgar minds of alleyways and markets—how could he not be alarmed?

Yongzhai says: *Bin* (宾) should be read as *bin* (摈), meaning "to cast aside." To proclaim one’s purity and startle the foolish is to set oneself apart. *Kuǎnqǐ* (款启) refers to small apertures, a metaphor for his limited vision. The teachings are too lofty—how could he not be startled? This is a rebuke of the shallow understanding of contemporary scholars who do not grasp the great Dao. To feed with ease is to let one eat naturally. The analogy of the sea crow has been discussed in previous chapters.

To delight in Heaven’s decree and understand fate is to be free of sorrow; to fathom principle and exhaust one’s nature is to have no doubts. What Sun Xiu describes diverges greatly from the teachings of Heaven’s decree and the nature of principle. Thus Master Bian instructs him that the conduct of the perfect person—by forgetting the liver and gall, emptying the inner self, and abandoning the ears and eyes, stilling the outer self—then wanders beyond the dust and grime. All worldly affairs and traces of action are dust and grime; to depart from these is to make every movement, whether standing, sitting, or lying down, an endeavor of non-action—what is called "transcending the worldly while within the world." What is there to rely upon? What governance is there to dominate?

Now you adorn knowledge and cultivate the body, shining like the sun and moon, only to attract the calamities of the world. To preserve your form without premature death is already fortunate—how can you find time to resent Heaven? This is to sharply awaken his delusion and guide him back to understanding. The analogy of the sea bird is clear in its meaning.

This chapter begins by discussing life, which all people value. Some over-nurture it and harm life; fate lies with Heaven and cannot be defied, yet some destroy it through their own actions. If one comprehends these two truths, one can preserve life and be at peace with fate—this is the way of deep roots and firm foundations, of longevity and enduring vision. Thus, whatever cannot be achieved in nurturing life, whatever Heaven’s decree cannot alter, one distances oneself from, knowing it is not one’s proper duty. Yet one possesses a pure and complete Heaven that must not be departed from even for a moment.

Consider the drunkard’s view of a carriage or the giant’s regard for a railing—what room is there for concern? The examples of catching cicadas and steering a boat illustrate how accumulated practice leads to mastery; herding sheep and fearing dangerous paths show how the whip follows to warn of peril. The discussion of competition illustrates how those who covet rank are no better than those who see ghosts, while those who cannot perceive delusion are easily confused. The subsequent analogies all serve to expound the principle of life—truly earnest and incisive!

The nourishment of life has its fixed allotment; it is not gained by seeking nor lost by not seeking. The breath of life is difficult to sustain without anxiety; it cannot be escaped by luck or evaded by wisdom. One must cultivate human affairs to accord with Heaven’s principle, seeking only to be without remorse. Longevity or premature death, fortune or misfortune—these are not to be eagerly pursued.

Whether one retreats to the mountains and valleys for pure cultivation or serves in the court with great undertakings, whether one nurtures life within or governs others without, it is all to beautify human relations and promote education, ultimately converging in the principle of the Dao and virtue. Yet how few truly know life is to be valued and can be vigilant even in the midst of feasting and repose!

Only when one appears like a wooden chicken when observed, and when driving does not exhaust one’s strength, has one grasped the principle of life and approached the conduct of the perfect person. The conclusion, with the sea crow of the Lu suburbs hearing bells and drums and growing sorrowful, shows that when external nurturance is lost, the inner nature is harmed. If one knows how to nurture, one knows how to preserve. The key lies in understanding one’s own life, extending it to benefit the lives of others, and harmonizing with things. To forget harmony is to find no disharmony.

*End of the Fifty-Ninth Scroll of the* Southern Florescence True Scripture: An Ocean of Annotations on the Profound Meanings.
*Beginning of the Sixtieth Scroll of the* Southern Florescence True Scripture: An Ocean of Annotations on the Profound Meanings.

The Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin on "The Mountain Trees" (Chapter One)

When Master Zhuang journeyed through the mountains, he saw a great tree with luxuriant branches and leaves. A woodcutter stood beside it but did not fell it. Asking the reason, he was told: "It is of no use." Master Zhuang said: "This tree, by being useless, has attained its full span of years."

Emerging from the mountains, the Master lodged at the home of an old friend. Delighted, his friend ordered a servant to kill a goose and cook it. The servant asked: "One can caw, the other cannot— which should we kill?" The host replied: "Kill the one that cannot caw."

The next day, a disciple asked Master Zhuang: "Yesterday, the tree in the mountains, by being useless, attained its full span of years; today, the master’s goose, by being useless, was killed. Where will you position yourself?" Master Zhuang laughed and said: "I will position myself between usefulness and uselessness."

Yet between usefulness and uselessness is but an approximation, not the true Way, and thus one remains entangled in burdens. If, however, one rides the Dao and virtue, floating freely, it is otherwise. Without praise or blame, now a dragon, now a serpent, one transforms with the times, never clinging to a single form. Rising and falling, taking harmony as one’s measure, one floats upon the ancestor of the ten thousand things. Treating things as things yet not being treated as a thing by them—how then could one be burdened?

This is the method of Shennong and the Yellow Emperor. As for the nature of the ten thousand things and the transmission of human relations, it is not so. Union leads to separation, completion to destruction, integrity to humiliation, honor to criticism, action to loss, worthiness to schemes, and worthlessness to deceit. How can one be certain of anything?

Alas! Disciples, take heed: it is only in the realm of Dao and virtue.

Guo’s Annotation: Though one might position oneself here, as it still entails burdens, one ultimately does not remain. As for those who ride the Dao and virtue, floating freely—Master Zhuang also dwells there, yet without fixation. Thus, he does not adhere to one path but transforms with the times, for only by moving with change can one remain perpetually unobstructed.

Lü’s Annotation: The world’s sages and worthies are often unaccommodated by their age, their burden lying precisely in their usefulness. Thus, Master Zhuang repeatedly warns against the entanglements of usefulness. Yet how many fools and incompetents have been killed for their inability to caw? Can uselessness alone guarantee escape? The tree in the mountains and the master’s horse—both err equally. Therefore, one must choose a position between usefulness and uselessness, yet even this resembles the Dao without being the Dao. For the essence of the Dao does not reside in either extreme, nor in the mean between them. Thus, even between usefulness and uselessness, one is not free from burdens. But if one rides the Dao and virtue, floating freely, then there is neither praise nor blame, neither honor nor disgrace. Now a dragon, now a serpent, one cannot be confined to worthiness or folly. All waxing and waning, rising and sinking, one transforms with the times, harmonizing without discord. How could this depend on being useful or useless? One simply floats upon the ancestor of the ten thousand things. The ancestor of the ten thousand things is like the father of all fathers. In this way, one treats things as things yet is not treated as a thing by them—how then could one be burdened?

As for the nature of the ten thousand things and the transmission of human relations: union inevitably leads to separation, completion to destruction, prosperity to humiliation, honor to criticism. Thus, how can one hope to escape burdens by positioning oneself between usefulness and uselessness? To be free from burdens, is it not only in the realm of Dao and virtue?

Yi Du’s Annotation: The principles of the world unfold like a crossbow’s trigger—one may ride them but not control them. The seasons of the world pass like an arrow—one may follow them but not grasp them.

Thus, the tree of yesterday survived by being useless, while the timber of today perishes by being useless. Therefore, the sage follows the times and rides the principles, flowing with things without stagnating in them, transforming with the world without being bound by it. Now a dragon, now a serpent—its changes are unfathomable, beyond praise or blame. Moving with the times, taking harmony as its measure, it drifts in the ancestor of the ten thousand things, treating things as things yet not being treated as a thing by them, responding to endless transformations. This is the "principle valued by the former kings."

As for the nature of the ten thousand things and the transmission of human relations, one cannot escape separation and union, completion and destruction. How can certainty be attained? To avoid this, is it not only in the realm of Dao and virtue?

Bixu’s Annotation: The timber that no longer exists has lost its pattern; the great root of the tree retains its substance. The perfected person conceals their substance and blends their pattern, thus moving through the world without bias. Dao and virtue are ever-renewing, drifting without trace. Free from praise or blame, one can gather all things like a closed sack. Like the dragon and serpent, one can appear or vanish. Transforming with the times, one adapts to the world’s needs. Without rigid action, one can rise or fall, taking harmony as the measure. In movement, one follows principle; drifting in the ancestor of things, one does not chase after ends. Thus, worldly burdens cannot touch them—this is the Way of the Great Ancients.

As for the nature of things: the worthy scheme like usable timber, while the unworthy deceive like dull blades. The realm of Dao and virtue lies in non-insistence and tracelessness.

Yongzhai says: Usefulness and uselessness still leave traces, inevitably leading to burdens. Only when good and evil are both extinguished, beyond all naming, can one fully preserve their nature. Riding Dao and virtue is to follow nature. "Now a dragon, now a serpent" illustrates adaptability to the times. Without intent, there is no praise or blame. Rigid action stems from intent. "Rising and falling" refers to the fading of traces. Taking harmony with nature as the measure, one may rise or fall as fitting. The "ancestor" is the origin.

The nature of the ten thousand things is private desire; the transmission of human relations is habit. The following lines exhaustively depict the human condition: one’s conduct in the world is not self-determined. How can one insist on certainty? They lament the impermanence of human affairs and the peril of hidden dangers, thus exhorting their disciples to recognize this. Only by following nature can one avoid harm.

Those who become sages and worthies do so through learning; those who study sages and worthies often follow paths that lead to corruption.

Only by forgetting the path in the heart can one be free from corruption.

The tree that is deemed useless survives, while the whetstone that is deemed useless perishes—this is a visible path. Yet whether one lives or dies, how can it depend solely on being useful or useless? It also hinges on what one encounters! Thus, the true person, dwelling between usefulness and uselessness, still finds it insufficient to avoid entanglement and seeks to transcend it—only the nature of what one encounters remains unknown.

Success or failure depends on one’s endowments; what one encounters depends on fate. Some say endowments belong to man while fate belongs to Heaven, dividing them into two distinct paths. Yet endowments also arise from Heaven and are cultivated by man; fate is preserved by man yet tied to Heaven. What one encounters is the trace of Heaven and man’s mutual influence, where good and ill manifest. Thus, the question of usefulness or uselessness is the concern of the worthy. To transcend these three and be free from entanglement is to enter the realm of the sage.

Only by roaming in the origin of the ten thousand things, treating each thing as a thing yet not being ensnared by things, can one escape the constraints of endowments and the bonds of fate. Therefore, the sage does not prize endowments and rarely speaks of fate.

The character *xiàng* (乡) formerly had no other pronunciation; here it is proposed to read it in the departing tone, identical to *xiàng* (向).

Shi Nan Yiliao met with the Lord of Lu, who wore a troubled expression. Master Shi Nan asked, “My lord, why do you appear so troubled?”

The Lord of Lu replied, “I have studied the Dao of the former kings and cultivated the legacy of my predecessors. I reverence the spirits, honor the worthy, and personally practice these virtues without the slightest lapse. Yet I have not escaped misfortune—this is why I am troubled.”

Master Shi Nan said, “My lord, your method for avoiding misfortune is too shallow! The sleek fox and the patterned leopard dwell in the mountains and forests, crouch in caves and cliffs—this is stillness. They move by night and rest by day—this is vigilance. Though hungry and thirsty, pressed by hardship, they still wander the rivers and lakes in search of food—this is resolve. Yet they cannot escape the perils of nets, snares, and traps. What crime have they committed?”

The disaster lies in their hides. Is not the state of Lu alone your hide? I wish for you to shed your form and cast off your hide, cleanse your heart and relinquish desire, then wander in the wilds where none dwell. In the southlands there is a city called the Land of Establishing Virtue. Its people are simple and unadorned, with little selfishness and few desires. They know how to work but not how to hoard, they give without seeking recompense. They know not where duty leads, nor where ritual directs. Wild and unconstrained in their actions, they tread the great square of the Dao. Their lives are joyful, their deaths may be buried. I wish for you to abandon your state, discard custom, and walk in mutual support with the Way.

The Lord said, “That Way is distant and perilous, with rivers and mountains in between. I have no boat or carriage—what am I to do?”

Master Shi Nan replied, “Be without rigid form, without lingering attachment—let this be your carriage.”

The Lord said, “That Way is secluded and remote, with no people. With whom shall I be neighbor? I have no provisions, no food—how can I reach it?”

Master Shi Nan replied, “Lessen your expenditures, diminish your desires—though you have no provisions, you will yet have enough. Cross the river and float upon the sea. Gaze upon it and you will not see its shores; the farther you go, the less you will know its bounds. Those who see you off will all turn back from the shore, and you will be far from here! Thus, he who possesses others is burdened; he who is seen as possessing by others is troubled. Therefore, Yao neither possessed others nor was seen as possessing by them. I wish to rid you of your burdens, remove your troubles, and wander alone with the Way in the boundless land.

When a double-hulled boat crosses the river, and an empty boat comes drifting to strike it, even one with a biased temper will not grow angry. But if there is a person aboard, one will shout to make way or draw near.”

When one calls out and is not heard, calls again and is not heard, then upon the third call, foul words must follow. Before, one did not grow angry, but now one does; before, the boat was empty, but now it is full. If one can empty oneself and wander through the world, who could harm them?

Guo’s commentary: To possess a body and pride oneself on one’s state—though one may harbor a thousand anxieties, revere worthies, and uphold conduct, one’s worries only deepen. Thus, let one be without a body, forget the state, and entrust oneself to natural transformation, sending them to Nanyue to distance them from Lu. If each follows their own step and every person treads their own path, then the ten thousand directions are attained—is this not vast? To "leave the state and abandon customs" means to sweep clean the heart; the lord merely speaks as if truly sending them to Nanyue. "Posture rigid" refers to stumbling obstacles; "lingering abode" refers to stagnant attachment. When form levels with things and the heart transforms with them, one lodges in things to bear oneself. If the lord can reduce expenditures and lessen desires, there will be nothing he lacks. Crossing the river and floating upon the sea without seeing its shores is a metaphor for cutting off passions and desires to a great distance. If the lord has no desires, each will return to guard their own place. "From here, you will be far" means to transcend and stand alone above the myriad things. "He who possesses others" means to hold them as one’s private possession. "He who is seen as possessing by others" means to be employed by them. To hold all under heaven and entrust it to the hundred officials is not to possess others; to rely on the people and employ things without being enslaved by them is not to be seen as possessing by others. If one wishes to be utterly free of attachment to the state, then though the world changes, one’s emptiness of self to avoid harm remains the same.

Lü’s commentary: To take the state of Lu as one’s skin is the source of distress, for one cannot forget the state. If the form is not discarded, the state becomes a burden; restraining the form is how one sheds the skin. If the heart is not pure, desires become its stain; washing the heart is how one removes desires. To depart from the human and enter the celestial is to wander in the wilds where none dwell, to establish the state of virtue, and thus to establish the Way. Its people are simple and desire little, not because they lack culture. Acting without storing, things arrive and supply their needs, giving without seeking repayment, being benevolent without considering it a favor. Not knowing where duty leads, they do not value comings and goings. Not knowing where ritual tends, they do not observe its forms. Wandering recklessly and treading the great path, they find joy in life and rest in death, for beginning and end do not depart from them. If one establishes a state as a state in this way, the reason one cannot wander is merely that the state and customs entangle them. Abandoning the state and forsaking customs, walking alongside the Way, one arrives without effort. The Way is near and level, yet people regard it as distant and perilous because their posture is rigid and unyielding, their abode lingering and unmoving. If one makes no rigid posture and no lingering abode their chariot, and minimal expenditure and few desires their provisions, what hindrance could prevent arrival? Not seeing its shores, wandering in boundlessness—those who see one off turn back from the shore, for those constrained by emptiness and fearful of its depths dare not proceed. From here, the lord stands alone without peer, and none can follow. If one wanders thus, one neither possesses others nor is seen as possessing by them. Yao’s being Yao was only like this.

The Great Vastness and the State of Established Virtue are what the previous chapter called the ancestor of the myriad things and the homeland of the Way and virtue. Next, it discusses the empty boat striking the vessel without provoking anger: those who ride upon the Way and virtue and float through the world are likewise in this state.

Yi Du’s commentary: Nanyue is a bright land; the State of Established Virtue is the realm of the sage. Being simple and desiring little is good for nurturing the heart. Acting without storing, giving without seeking repayment—this is great transformation. Not knowing where duty leads is true duty; not knowing where ritual tends is perfect ritual. These three are inwardly attained, so one wanders recklessly, treading the great path, at ease in life and at ease in death. To hollow out the form and discard the heart, to wander in the wilds where none dwell, is to make one’s spirit and virtue enter and unite with heaven. To leave the state and abandon customs, walking alongside the Way in the State of Established Virtue, is to make the Way manifest and unite with humanity. The Lord of Lu truly spoke of sending them to Nanyue, worrying that the Way was distant and perilous, not knowing that the State of Established Virtue is reached only by preserving the spirit and forgetting the form, without movement. The Lord of Lu also feared the Way was distant and without provisions, all because he could not forget things and took words and circumstances literally. Shi Nanzi wished him to seek within his own nature, to reduce expenditures to conserve his spirit, to lessen desires to nurture his heart, so that even without provisions, he would be self-sufficient. The river is a metaphor for virtue; the sea, for the Way. Not seeing its shores is to turn away from circumstances; not knowing its bounds is to adapt to change. Thus, those who see one off all turn back from circumstances, for those who reach the Way surpass what the mediocre can attain.

The noble possess others; the favored are seen as possessing by others. Yao did not possess others, so he could treat nobility as entrusted; he was not seen as possessing by others, so he could treat favor as beneath him. Thus, he was without burden and without trouble. This is why the Lord of Lu was to shed his burdens, forget his troubles, and wander with the Way in the land of Great Vastness. The empty boat is a metaphor for being without mind, so it strikes things without anger; if there is a person aboard, there is a mind attached to things, and things constrain them. If one can be without mind in dealing with things, who could harm them?

Bi Xu’s commentary: Severing the form removes the cultured skin; cleansing the heart eliminates cravings. Having thus governed oneself, one wanders in the wilds where none dwell, abandoning this esteem for worthies and taking up that establishment of virtue—this is the State of Established Virtue. Being foolish, they have little selfishness; being simple, they have few desires. Knowing where duty leads, they store; knowing where ritual tends, they repay. Without recklessness, how could one wander beyond the world? Without reckless action, how could one tread the great path? Being at ease in life and at rest in death, beginning and end do not depart from them.

Life may be joyful, death may be buried—beginning and end abide without parting.

May you, my lord, cast off its residual threads and walk alongside the subtle and wondrous. Yet you fear having no boat or carriage, unable to attain suspended liberation; you further fear the Way is distant and without provisions, the climbing vines not yet severed. With few expenditures and scant desires, one is self-sufficient without provisions—dwelling like the quail, eating like the grub. Crossing rivers and floating on seas, gazing without seeing shores, the dust of the kitchen finds no purchase. Turning back from the shore speaks of those whose strength is small and do not advance. From this point, my lord, you are far indeed—sight and hearing cannot reach you.

Yao was not some other person; he forgot the Fen River. Not seeing others as others, he went about his days unaware. I forget others, and thus have no burdens; others forget me, and thus have no sorrows. Therefore, I wander alone with the Dao in the State of Great Vastness. The State of Great Vastness refers to creation itself.

The empty boat striking another boat illustrates encountering things without mind. Before, one was not angered—there was no other person. Now, one is angered—seeing others as others. If one is not angered by an empty boat, it is clear that things do no harm to an empty self.

Yongzhai said: "To be burdened by one’s own skin speaks of how having a name in the world can summon disaster." Earlier, it spoke of the wilds where none dwell—this is the beginning of no-thing. Here, it again speaks of the State of Established Virtue. Considering this passage, those today who venerate the Pure Land trace their source to this. In the Warring States period, the southern lands of Yue were not yet connected, and the Central Plains used this to illustrate a point—originally without other meaning. Tilling the land for one’s own food without private hoarding, without the names of ritual and duty, thus having nowhere to go, nowhere to tend, acting recklessly from the heart—all accords with the great Dao. With the heart of one who admires the Dao, they encourage one another to reach this land.

Without form, one does not possess the body; without lingering, one does not possess the state. Thus, one may proceed. Crossing rivers and floating on seas, reaching where there is no end—this is merely the phrase "wandering without end." Those who see you off all turn back from the shore. From this point, my lord, you are far indeed. This speaks of those who study the Dao: once awakened, what once aided their awakening—like those who see you off—when the boat reaches the sea, the shore has already turned back. It is like seeing swordplay and becoming skilled in calligraphy: at first, the sword aids understanding, but once understood, the sword becomes the one who sees you off. Reading books is also a means of seeing one off.

The State of Great Vastness is the wilds where none dwell, the State of Established Virtue. The empty boat striking another without anger—this is the finest metaphor. Foxes and leopards, though they hide in seclusion, still cannot escape calamity—it is their skin that brings disaster. Now, the lord of Lu’s position is no different from the cultured skin that invites misfortune. If one can truly restrain the form, the outer skin will naturally fall away; if one cleanses the heart, inner desires will naturally be eliminated. Rising above and far from the俗, one wanders in the wilds where none dwell. Fearing the lord of Lu might find this too vague and groundless, it further sets forth the State of Established Virtue to entice him.

To act without knowing how to store is to be content with what is present. To give without seeking repayment is to bestow without expecting gratitude. How then could one know where duty and ritual tend? Thus, one acts freely without departing from the great Dao. "May be joyful, may be buried" speaks of being at ease in life and at rest in death. Abandoning the state and forsaking the俗 severs one’s entanglements. Walking alongside the Dao, one returns to non-action. Such a one may reach the State of Established Virtue.

The lord of Lu has not yet awakened and further worries that the Way is distant and without boat or carriage. It is told to him: if only you do not exalt yourself as a lord, do not cling to this state’s position, this itself is your carriage—then you may proceed. He also fears the remote and secluded place has no neighbors, no provisions to reach it. Thus, all who cling to things and are mired in being fear falling into emptiness, their breath ever like this. It is further told to him: with few expenditures and scant desires, one is self-sufficient without provisions. May you, my lord, float upon the sea of the Dao and virtue without shores or end.

Those who see you off are like titles, positions, and desires—those who have long followed and become familiar. Once you abandon them and wander without end, those who once followed now gaze at the shore and cannot advance, thus growing ever more distant from you. To see others as others, to perceive others as others—all cannot escape sorrow and burden. Only by being like Yao, vast and nameless, can one avoid such entanglements. May you, my lord, cast off burdens and eliminate sorrows, wandering alone with the Dao in the State of Great Vastness.

"Vastness" is none other than nothingness. From the wilds where none dwell, one reaches the State of Established Virtue. In Great Vastness, even virtue is forgotten—this is the "land of nothing whatsoever" spoken of in the *Free and Easy Wandering*. The empty boat striking another has been fully explained earlier.

There is no need to suddenly depart from one’s dwelling to avoid entanglements. The old interpretation took "居" as part of the previous phrase, and many commentaries followed. Here, it is determined that "离" concludes the phrase, with "居" belonging to the following text.

*Collected Explications of the Ocean of Meanings of the True Scripture of the Southern Florescence*, Scroll Sixty, concludes.
*Collected Explications of the Ocean of Meanings of the True Scripture of the Southern Florescence*, Scroll Sixty-One.

The Daoist of Wulin, Chu Boxiu, on *"The Mountain Trees"* (Chapter Two)

When Beigong She levied taxes for Duke Ling of Wei to cast a bell, he erected an altar beyond the outer gate of the capital. In three months, the upper and lower chimes were suspended.

Prince Qingji saw this and asked, "What technique have you employed?"

She replied, "In the space of unity, I dared not impose any artifice."

I have heard that once carving and polishing are done, one returns to simplicity. Pity the unknowing; doubt lingers in their hesitation. Gathered in boundless obscurity, they send off the departing and welcome the arriving. Let those who come not be barred; let those who go not be detained. Follow their forcefulness; adapt to their crookedness; rely on their self-exhaustion. Thus, morning and evening, taxes are levied without the slightest harm—how much more so for those on the great thoroughfare!

**Guo’s Commentary:**
Trembling, he guarded unity, daring not to falsely impose anything to complicate matters. He restored their original nature, allowing them to remain in pure simplicity. Without aim, without delight, he let them come and go freely. Yielding to the multitude, unbound by attachment, he acted as they could not but act. Thus, no harm was done; serene and ungrasping, he employed the world’s self-will—this is the path of great passage. Therefore, though he planned and labored, the work was completed without haste.

**Lü’s Commentary:**
If any extraneous artifice were interposed, it would no longer be the One. Carving and polishing return to simplicity—discarding ornament to pursue substance. *Tong*, unknowing, unaware of who or what. *Tang*, hesitant and doubtful, not daring to rush. Sending off the departing and welcoming the arriving, neither barring nor detaining; forcefulness unchecked, crookedness unobstructed, all arising from their inevitability. Thus, morning and evening, taxes were levied without the slightest harm, for he imposed nothing in the space of unity. How much more does this apply to the great thoroughfares of the world’s principles? This is how Pao Ding moved his blade through the spaces and found room to spare.

**Yi Du’s Commentary:**
The bell is hollow within and responsive—an analogy for the human heart. Levying taxes to cast bells is likened to nurturing the spirit to cultivate the mind. Only after consecrating the altar and offering the bell may it be used, just as the substance of the mind must be perfected before its function can be realized. Three months mark the minor completion of Heaven’s Way. The suspension of upper and lower bells fulfills both substance and function.

When Prince Qing Ji questioned the interposition of extraneous artifice, the answer was to embrace the One as function, daring no imposition. *Fu pu* ("returning to simplicity") is an analogy for recovering one’s nature. *Wu shi dai yi* ("unknowing, hesitant, doubtful")—what thought, what deliberation? Neither barring nor detaining what comes and goes, each follows its own course. Yielding to the forceful is softness to hardness; following the crooked is not forcing compliance. Allowing things to reach their natural end ensures they do not reach exhaustion. Thus, taxes were levied without the slightest harm, for all remains within the bounds of inherent nature—unharmed and self-sufficient.

**Bi Xu’s Commentary:**
