Though I speak, it is as if I have not spoken.

Bi Xu’s commentary: "Withered wood, detached from things"—this describes storing essence and treasuring spirit. "Departing from others, standing alone"—this describes losing companionship and entering solitude. Wandering at the origin of things, one never strays from their source. To feign understanding is to weary the heart; to seek words is to stammer the mouth. Detaching the heart and forgetting speech—this is the closest one may come.

The solemn qi of yin descends below; the blazing qi of yang ascends above. The two forces intermingle in harmony, and the myriad things undergo wondrous transformation. Though it seems there is a guiding principle, its form is unseen. Waxing and waning follow their measures; darkness and light follow their constancy. Though it seems there is creation, its workings are unseen. Life sprouts from the indistinct; death returns to the obscure. Without beginning, none know its start; without end, none know its finish. If not for this Dao, what could serve as its master?

Confucius again inquired about the Dao of forgetting speech. To study the Dao is not to seek attainment but to grasp the supreme beauty and joy of one’s nature. Regarding death and life, it is like beasts changing marshes or fish changing waters—a fleeting, minor transformation. Why should one grieve? The world unites the myriad things as one. Viewed from what they share, one’s own limbs are but stench and decay; death and life are but waking and dreaming—how much more so for other things? Thus, holding the reins or donning court robes is like changing waters or marshes—this is what is meant by "externally transformed yet internally unchanged." What is precious lies within oneself, never departing from the self. Its joy is boundless—how could there be rest?

Like water flowing smoothly, embracing and benefiting all, what need is there for contrivance? The perfected person’s virtue and deeds spread far—what need is there for cultivation? It is like the height of heaven, the depth of earth, the brightness of sun and moon—what need is there for effort? Thus, the Master compared himself to discarding a mussel shell and removing a cover, recognizing the great wholeness of heaven and earth.

Yongzhai said: "Standing alone" speaks of transcending the world’s bounds. The origin of things is no-thing. Yin and yang arise from heaven and earth—these four lines describe the Dao as nothing but the alternation of yin and yang. Their interaction creates harmony, for solitary yin cannot generate, nor can solitary yang. It seems there is something governing this, yet its form is unseen. Waxing and waning, darkness and light—daily there is activity, yet its workings are unseen. Beginning and end without origin—all describe the Creator. Supreme beauty and joy praise the Dao’s wonder.

Though fish and beasts change waters and marshes, they do not lose their waters and grasses. Likewise, humans share this world—how could they be different? Knowing that all emerge from heaven and share the same nature, not even death and life can disturb, much less fortune or misfortune. Servants come and go, discarded like mud—this is because I am noble and they are base. If one knows the Dao’s preciousness truly lies within oneself, external changes cannot deprive one of supreme beauty and joy. The boundless transformations of the world—how could they burden the heart? Only the foolish and vulgar fail to understand; only those who unite with the Dao grasp this.

"Ultimate words" refer to the preceding text. Even Laozi could not depart from speech to cultivate the heart—who could escape this? The reply likens it to rivers and seas: their waters flow ceaselessly because their nature is effortless and spontaneous. The perfected person’s virtue, like heaven and earth, sun and moon, is also spontaneous—what need is there for effort?

The origin of things is nameless, the beginning of heaven and earth—this is the Supreme Ultimate. The solemn emerges from heaven; the blazing emerges from earth—this is the Supreme Ultimate moving to generate yang, reaching its limit and becoming still, stillness generating yin, stillness reaching its limit and moving again, endlessly cycling. It seems there is something governing this, yet its form is unseen—this is what is meant by "above, knowing the Creator is no-thing; below, knowing things create themselves." Understanding the origin of things, one knows the origin of oneself, and even the origin of heaven and earth—it is no different. Attaining this supreme beauty and wandering in supreme joy—this is the ultimate of the human Dao.

The life and death of things have sprouting and return; the life and death of humans need not be deeply examined. Minor transformations refer to life and death; the great constancy is indestructible. The indestructible is the root of the single spirit: at rest, it is called nature, containing emptiness as abundance; in motion, it is called the heart, entering the dusty world as insufficiency.

He who grasps this principle traverses change and penetrates constancy—such clarity is called illumination. His presence is like the moon reflected in water; his transformation is like the wind moving through the void. Why trouble over the ease of crossing rivers or marshes? The world is shared by the myriad things—are not the four limbs and hundred parts of the body likewise not mine alone? Knowing that the lowly may be discarded while the body’s nobility endures, how can gain or loss, fortune or misfortune disturb one’s clarity?

Water’s clarity is its natural nature, just as the virtue of the perfected person requires no cultivation, yet things naturally gravitate toward it. Heaven’s duty is to cover, earth’s duty is to bear, and the sage’s duty is to teach transformation—this is what constitutes great wholeness.

The essence of this chapter lies in the sprouting of life and the return of death, yet the ancient sages seldom spoke of it directly, wishing instead for people to turn inward and seek it themselves. When one fills the true and perceives the real, one is no longer swayed by life and death. Moreover, all people dwell between life and death—whether wise or foolish, none can escape it. In life, they strive for abundant nurture; in death, they prepare elaborate burials—this is everywhere the case, yet none know where the sprouting leads or the return goes. To know where it returns, one must first investigate where it sprouts. At first hearing, these words may seem vague, offering no foothold for effort, but through diligent study and mutual illumination of the classics, insight arises.

The *Nanhua* [Zhuangzi] once said: "Examine its beginning—originally there was no birth, not merely no birth but also no form, no qi, mingling in the boundless. Then it transformed and had qi; qi transformed and had form; form transformed and had life; life transformed and turned to death—this is how they follow one another like the four seasons." It also said: "He who is good at nurturing life is thus good at nurturing death."

The secret the ancient sages left unspoken, the perfected person has already explained in detail—people simply do not seek it! This Dao can be apprehended by the heart but cannot be exhausted in words. It is like the Chan school’s inquiry into the state before one’s parents were born or after the dispersal of wind and fire: though one may enter through a teacher’s guidance, ultimately one must awaken on one’s own. As the saying goes, "Once explained, it misses the mark." Scholars, take heed!

---

Zhuangzi visited Duke Ai of Lu. The Duke said, "Lu has many Confucians but few who follow your teachings, Master."

Zhuangzi replied, "Lu has few Confucians."

The Duke said, "The entire state of Lu wears Confucian robes—how can you say there are few?"

Zhuangzi said, "I have heard that Confucians wear round caps to know the seasons of heaven, square shoes to know the forms of earth, and wear pendants with tassels to decide matters as they arise. Those who possess the Way may not wear its robes, and those who wear its robes may not know the Way."

The Duke insisted this was not so and asked, "Why not issue a decree throughout the state that those who lack this Way yet wear its robes shall be put to death?"

Thereupon, Duke Ai issued the decree for five days, and no one in Lu dared wear Confucian robes—except for one man who stood at the palace gate in full Confucian attire. The Duke summoned him and questioned him on state affairs; his answers were inexhaustible, shifting through a thousand turns without faltering.

Zhuangzi said, "With all of Lu, there is only one Confucian—can this be called many?"

---

Guo Xiang’s commentary: "He whose virtue is full within does not adorn himself without."
Lü Huiqing’s commentary: "Zhuangzi repeatedly used Confucius to question Laozi’s disciples to show that so-called sagely wisdom does not exhaust the ultimate Dao. Without this discussion, scholars would have no way to know the true reverence for Confucius."
Yidu’s commentary: "Yangzi said, 'One who unites heaven, earth, and humanity is a Confucian—this is the true Confucian.' Inner possession of the Way is substance; outer robes are ornament. Lacking either, one is no Confucian. Only the sage embodies form and thus can be worthy of the robes. Those who have not attained sagehood yet wear Confucian attire are vulgar Confucians. With all of Lu wearing Confucian robes, there was but one true Confucian—this is the utmost reverence for Confucius."
Bixu’s commentary: "One Kui was enough to assist a king; why would the flourishing of Confucian teaching require three thousand? A sheep in tiger’s skin will surely confuse others. Yet one of profound virtue may appear foolish—how could there be no one who recognizes this?"
Yongzhai’s commentary: "This passage further illustrates that many wear Confucian robes yet know nothing of the Way."

The *Nanhua* [Zhuangzi], with its transcendent and extraordinary talent, lived in a turbid age where no one was worthy of conversation, leaving no outlet for its marvels. Thus, it discoursed on emperors and kings, discussed Confucius and Laozi, and evaluated Yang Zhu, Mo Di, Jie, and Robber Zhi without omission. In scrutinizing the reality of words and deeds and discerning the subtleties of the heart, it was as bright as a mirror illuminating the finest autumn hairs. Some say its discussions often criticize Confucius, but this is merely observing its words without probing its intent. This chapter concludes by noting that with all of Lu wearing Confucian robes, there was but one true Confucian—I say no one revered Confucius more than the *Nanhua*. Consider Su Shi’s *Record of the Zhuangzi Shrine*—it may serve to confirm that my words are not baseless.

---

Baili Xi did not let rank or salary enter his heart, so when he fed cattle, the cattle grew fat, enabling Duke Mu of Qin to forget his lowly status and entrust him with governance. The Lord of Yu did not let life and death enter his heart, so he could move others. When the Lord of Song was about to commission paintings, all the scribes arrived, bowed, and stood in attendance; half remained outside, licking their brushes and grinding ink. One scribe arrived late, walking unhurriedly, bowed without standing, and went to his lodging. The Lord sent someone to observe him and found him sitting with his robe undone, legs sprawled. The Lord said, "This is the true painter!"

Guo Xiang’s commentary: "He who is inwardly self-possessed is complete in external affairs, thus his spirit is at ease and his intent settled."
Lü Huiqing’s commentary: "From the small example of Baili Xi’s governance to the great example of the Lord of Yu’s ability to move others—those who let external things enter their hearts and yet achieve such things have never existed. Undressing and sprawling—this is the mark of a true master painter."
Yidu’s commentary: "Rank and salary are small matters; life and death are great affairs..."

He who can disregard rank and salary has not yet disregarded life and death; he who can disregard life and death can disregard all things. One who is inwardly self-important will be outwardly solemn; one who is inwardly sufficient will be outwardly at ease. Inward self-importance scatters the spirit, creating the suspicion of rejection when seeking advancement; outward ease settles the spirit, allowing action to carry the intent of non-action. The Lord of Yu selected a painter and found the true one—this was by means of the Dao.

Bixu’s commentary: "One who waits for destiny while herding cattle will be observed by others for his conduct; one who serves his parents while forgetting his own life will be examined by the multitude for his filial piety. Those hasty for others’ use have not yet attained mastery; those who are serene and self-possessed will surely refine their art. If even coarse advancement is thus, how much more the subtleties of principle?"

Yongzhai’s commentary: "When he herded cattle, how could he have had the mind to seek rank and salary? Precisely because he did not seek them, he was employed. To move others is to transform them through resonance. The painter, without intent to seek recognition, undressed and sprawled—this is how the Lord of Yu knew he was a true painter. Without concern for rank and salary, he herded cattle, and so Duke Mu entrusted him with governance and achieved order; without pride in skill or clumsiness, he sprawled, and so the Lord of Yu knew his painting was true. When the heart is empty, things adhere to it—this is because one who is inwardly sufficient is outwardly at ease. Those who pursue talent and skill in the world today are anxious lest others not recognize them, while those who employ talent value only outward adornment—no wonder their attainments lack refinement."

*Note on textual variant*: "Herding cattle made the cattle fat" should read "herding cattle made *him* flourish," meaning that Baili Xi, though in a lowly position, delighted in the Dao while plowing and forgot poverty, so that his four limbs were full and joyful—this does not refer to the cattle growing fat.

*End of* The Southern Florescence True Scripture: Sea of Meanings Compiled and Elucidated, Scroll Sixty-Four
*The Southern Florescence True Scripture: Sea of Meanings Compiled and Elucidated, Scroll Sixty-Five*

The Daoist of Wulin, Chu Boxiu, on "Tian Zifang" III

King Wen observed in Zang and saw an old man fishing, yet his fishing was no fishing—he did not hold his rod as one who fishes, but fished as one always does. King Wen wished to raise him and entrust him with governance, but feared his great ministers and elders would not be at ease. He wished to leave the matter and release him, yet could not bear the thought of the common people being without heaven’s grace.

Thereupon, at dawn, he gathered his ministers and said: "Formerly, I dreamed of a worthy man, dark of complexion with a prominent brow, riding a piebald horse with one red hoof, who proclaimed: ‘Entrust governance to the old man of Zang, and the people may yet find relief!’" The ministers, startled, said: "This was the former lord, our king." King Wen said: "Then let us divine it." The ministers replied: "The command of the former lord—Your Majesty should have no doubt. What need is there for divination?"

Thus they welcomed the old man of Zang and entrusted him with governance. He altered no statutes, issued no partial decrees. After three years, King Wen surveyed the state and found that the knights had abandoned their posts and scattered, the high officials had failed to cultivate virtue, and the grain measures dared not enter the four borders. When knights abandon their posts and scatter, it is because they esteem uniformity; when high officials fail to cultivate virtue, it is because they share the same tasks; when grain measures dare not enter the four borders, it is because the feudal lords harbor no divided loyalties.

King Wen then made him Grand Preceptor, faced north, and asked: "Can this be extended to the realm?" The old man of Zang, silent and unresponsive, declined with vague words, issued orders by morning and fled by night, never to be heard of again.

Yan Yuan asked Confucius: "Was King Wen still not sufficient? Why then did he rely on a dream?" Confucius said: "Hush! Say no more. King Wen fulfilled it—what need is there for criticism? He merely followed the moment’s exigency."

Guo's Annotation: He merely passed the years, seeking nothing in the end, untroubled by gain or loss—his fishing was but a pretense. "Esteeming uniformity" means blending one’s radiance with the dust. "Purifying oneself to completion" sets one apart from the common tasks. When all under Heaven trust, they align in measures, weights, and balances. The achiever is not the self, so when the work is done, the person must withdraw; when affairs are settled, the name must depart. Only with name gone and self retired can one extend to all under Heaven. King Wen entrusted all to his ministers without claiming authority himself—this was fulfillment. "The moment" refers to the sentiment of the hundred clans, the instant between awakening and unawareness; following it and acting upon it aligns with their great disposition.

Lü's Annotation: Knowing Zang the Elder was fit to govern, King Wen grasped this in the space between his fishing and not-fishing. Attributing it to a dream, expecting divination yet not divining—above, he feared the unease of great ministers and elders; below, he feared the people would be left without Heaven. After employing him for three years and observing the state, the results matched his words: if words could become dreams, they were not untrustworthy; if he wished to divine but did not, it was not irreverent—he simply followed the moment. No changes were made to the canonical laws; the Six Canons and Eight Statutes received from the Son of Heaven became the Way of the state. No partial decrees were issued, so they could be made public to the feudal lords before being enacted—this was how they extended to all under Heaven. "Uprooting the planted" destroys the factions one has cultivated; "grain measures" are not the fine measures of the former kings.

Yi Du’s Annotation: This passage is an allegory of King Wen employing the Grand Duke. Before obtaining the Grand Duke, King Wen could not bear the people being left without Heaven; entrusting the search to a dream was the sagely way of following human sentiment. Upon receiving him in governance, the great constant laws remained unchanged, and improper decrees were not issued. After three years, all under Heaven esteemed uniformity, so the knights’ integrity collapsed and their ranks scattered. "Planted" refers to the uprightness of trees—the conduct of knights. When uniformity was esteemed, their conduct became useless and collapsed, their bonds had no application and scattered. With uniformity, all under Heaven had no divergent tasks, so high officials did not cultivate virtue, and grain measures dared not enter the four borders. With such accomplishment, King Wen faced north to serve him, yet the Grand Duke remained silent and unresponsive, declined with vague words, issued orders by morning and fled by night, never to be heard of again. King Wen’s elevation of the Grand Duke was not because he could not act alone to respond to Heaven’s will, but because he did not wish to differ from the multitude—thus he entrusted the dream to follow the people’s sentiment in that fleeting moment.

Bi Xu’s Annotation: "His fishing and not-fishing" refers to the straight hook; he feigned fishing to await the time, making concealment in fishing his constant practice. King Wen presented the dream and consulted his ministers, who said, "What doubt or divination is needed regarding the former lord’s command?" They then welcomed him and entrusted him with governance. "Knights’ integrity collapsed and ranks scattered" means that when the state was well-ordered, loyal ministers withdrew and the fortified walls were abandoned. "High officials did not cultivate virtue" means the people were pure and governance was simple. "Grain measures dared not enter the borders" means the times were harmonious and the years abundant. "Esteeming uniformity" meant ruler and ministers were of one heart; "sharing tasks" meant the four classes were settled in their occupations. Yan Yuan still doubted the dream’s reality, but the answer was that the granting and withholding of power lay in that fleeting moment—King Wen had fulfilled it, so why criticize further?

Liu Chao’s Annotation: The Three Dynasties followed the straight Way. Knowing Zang the Elder possessed the Way, entrusting him with governance would have sufficed—why resort to a dream to convince the ministers? One who knows the Way must comprehend principle and understand expediency. The Way is Heaven—self-trust is sufficient. Expediency is human—how can it be abandoned? Confucius and King Wen fulfilled it, but Yan Yuan had yet to attain it. Thus, Gao Zong’s dream was of a similar kind; Gao Zong was one who followed the straight Way. His spirit reached the four directions and flowed with Heaven and Earth; the verification of utmost sincerity at the juncture of Heaven and humanity is like shadow and echo. His dream of obtaining a good minister is not to be doubted. Zhuangzi’s allegory of King Wen was to clarify that expediency must examine the past to verify the present—thus he feigned a dream to convince others. Scholars who extrapolate from Zang the Elder’s discourse to interpret the Grand Duke’s tradition miss the mark.

Yong Zhai’s Annotation: "Constant fishing" means the fishing rod was always in hand yet without intent to fish—thus it is said he did not hold his fishing as one who fishes. "Integrity collapsed and ranks scattered" means he did not establish cliques. "Not cultivating virtue" means not claiming credit. "Sharing tasks" means working with the multitude without setting himself apart. Foreign grain measures, varying in size, dared not enter the borders—none among the feudal lords harbored divided loyalties, and all knew where to return. "Morning orders" refers to his flight upon hearing King Wen’s question about extending to all under Heaven. "Never to be heard of again" speaks for itself.

The ancient text attributes this to *fufu*—the first *fu* read as "great," as in the First Emperor’s inscription on Mount Tai: "The Censor *fufu*," where the meaning is identical.

"Collapsed ranks" (*huaizhi*) has been variously explained. Sima’s annotation states: "lines of formation." "Scattered multitude" (*sanqun*) means he did not gather followers.

Another interpretation holds that *zhi* refers to border outposts where lodges were built to receive remonstrating scholars, as the *Chengshu* notes: "the lodges for remonstrating scholars." Master Fan of Wu Yin Range says *zhi* denotes border markers—wooden stakes planted as boundaries, akin to the willows of frontier passes or the barriers of frontier posts. "Collapsed ranks and scattered multitude" thus imply the dismantling of garrisons, the disbanding of troops, and the merging of neighboring domains into one—this is the custom of "elevating unity."

Further evidence appears in Sima Zichang’s *Letter from Yue Yi to the King of Yan*: "The border stakes of Jiqiu were transplanted to the bamboo groves of the Wen River." Xu Guang’s commentary explains that the boundaries of Yan were shifted to the bamboo fields by the Wen River in Qi, where *zhi* served as the demarcating objects. By this account, Fan’s interpretation is well-founded; other explanations are recorded in the various commentaries.

Lie Yukou shot arrows for Bohun Wuren, drawing the bow to full draw. He placed a cup of water on his elbow and loosed the arrow—each shaft vanished in turn, and as one arrow flew, the next found its place.

At that moment, he was like a wooden figurine. Bohun Wuren said: "This is the shooting of archery, not the archery of non-shooting. Have you ever climbed a high mountain with me, trodden perilous rocks, and stood at the edge of a hundred-fathom abyss—could you shoot then?" Thereupon, Wuren ascended the high mountain, stepped onto the treacherous rocks, and stood at the brink of the sheer chasm. He walked backward to the edge, with two-thirds of his feet hanging over the void, then beckoned Lie Yukou forward. Lie Yukou prostrated himself on the ground, sweat streaming down to his heels.

Bohun Wuren said: "The perfected person soars above the azure heavens, plunges into the Yellow Springs below, roams the eight directions, yet his spirit and qi remain unaltered. Now you tremble with the intent to fix your gaze—this is perilous for your inner state!"

Guo’s commentary: *Ying guan* means the arrowhead is drawn to full tension. The left hand resists like a boulder, the right hand clings like a branch; the right hand releases the shot while the left remains unaware—thus the cup of water could rest on his elbow. The first arrow had not yet reached its mark when the next was already placed on the bowstring, demonstrating the marvel of his swiftness.

*Xiang ren* refers to the ultimate stillness. When virtue fills the inner self, spirit manifests outwardly; no matter how distant, deep, or obscure, all becomes luminous. Thus, he discerns the pivot of danger and security, abiding in tranquil self-possession. One who cannot perceive this ultimate division knows fear, and with fear, much is lost—how could this apply only to archery?

Lü’s commentary: *Yin zhi ying guan* signifies the utmost fullness of the draw. The elbow holding the cup of water exemplifies perfect steadiness. The first arrow had just been loosed when the next vanished, and as the first vanished, the following arrow was already nocked. *Vanished* describes the arrow’s departure, while *nocked* refers to the arrow now on the string—both terms describe the seamless, unbroken succession.

*Xiang ren* denotes the absence of divided awareness. This is the archery of shooting, whereas the archery of non-shooting is the preservation of pure qi, beyond the realm of skill, cunning, or boldness. Thus, one may ascend mountains or stand at the abyss without disturbance, and every shot finds its mark. Extending this principle, roaming the eight directions without altering one’s spirit and qi is only natural.

Yi Du’s annotation: Lie Yukou’s archery relied on precise awareness, enabling the arrow to vanish and the next to be nocked in turn. This is mastery within shooting, not the mastery of the Dao. Yet when observing Bohun Wuren’s ascent to the mountain’s edge, his backward steps to the brink, and Lie Yukou’s sweat dripping to his heels, even this reveals the coarse limits of sagely wisdom. As for roaming the eight directions with unchanging spirit and qi, none but the sage can achieve it—hence the warning: "This is perilous for your inner state."

The archery of shooting operates within the bounds of physical strength; the archery of non-shooting transcends even the notion of strength. Bi Xu’s commentary: Examining archery technique, the left hand resists like a boulder, the right hand clings like a branch—thus the cup of water could rest on the elbow. The bowstring loosed, the arrow flew, and the previous arrow vanished, as if the nock had split to admit it. Before the first arrow reached its target, the cup was already resting on the elbow again, illustrating the marvel of his swiftness. *Xiang ren* means unmoving.

The archery of shooting still adheres to technique. But to shoot while standing at the mountain’s edge or the abyss’s brink is to forget not only technique but even one’s form—thus one may roam the eight directions with unchanging spirit and qi.

Yongzhai observed: As one arrow was loosed, another already rested on the string. The arrow that had just left the bow vanished, and the next was already nocked. This seamless succession, shot after shot, is the archery of shooting. But when Bohun Wuren stood at the mountain’s edge, walked backward to the brink, and remained unshaken—this is the archery of non-shooting, the preservation of pure qi, the unchanging roaming of the eight directions.

This passage clarifies that those who exhaust their spirit in refined skill will soon reach their limits, while those who master skill through the Dao remain unshaken. To loose arrows in seamless succession, like a wooden figurine, is to perfect the art of archery. Yet when standing at the mountain’s edge or the abyss’s brink, one trembles and cannot stand—how then could one shoot? This is why Bohun Wuren demonstrated the archery of non-shooting, embedding the Dao within skill—not to make it the ultimate aim, but as a step toward roaming the eight directions. Those who cultivate the Way of nurturing spirit, let them observe this.

Some may wonder: Why does Lie Yukou, in writing his book, so humbly diminish himself? It is to exalt his teacher, and in exalting his teacher, to exalt the Dao. This is far beyond those who merely draw the bow of Hou Yi.

Master Fan of Wuyin, in his lecture following Lü’s commentary, corrected a minor oversight in Guo’s annotation, explaining that *fang shi* (方矢) carries the sense of *fang zhou* (方舟)—"side by side." It refers to the arrows already nocked on the string, not to placing the cup of water on the elbow. His interpretation is sound.

---

Jianwu asked Sunshu Ao: "You have served three times as prime minister without pride, and three times been dismissed without sorrow. At first, I doubted you, but now I see your nostrils flare with ease—how do you cultivate your mind?"

Sunshu Ao replied: "How do I surpass others? I accept what comes without refusal and let go of what departs without hindrance. I regard gain and loss as no concern of mine, and thus remain free of sorrow. How do I surpass others? Moreover, I do not know whether it lies with them or with me. If it lies with them, it is nothing to me; if it lies with me, it is nothing to them. I am still deliberating, still looking around—how could I have leisure to consider whether others esteem or despise me?"

Confucius heard of this and said: "The true persons of old could not be swayed by the clever, ensnared by the beautiful, robbed by thieves, or befriended by Fuxi or the Yellow Emperor. Life and death are great matters, yet they remained unchanged—how much less would rank and emolument affect them! Such persons thread their spirit through the great mountains without obstruction, plunge into the deepest springs without getting wet, dwell in lowly and humble places without weariness. Their fullness fills heaven and earth, and though they give to others, they themselves abound all the more."

The Guo commentary states: Vast and unbound, in profound unity with all things, what lies with them is not theirs alone to lose, nor what lies with me mine alone to keep. To hesitate and look around is to embrace the "no can do, no cannot do." Fuxi and the Yellow Emperor are but titles of merit, not the merit itself—thus their names are unworthy to befriend such persons. Those who would carve their flesh for the world lose both self and other. Let each person find their own fulfillment; to enable another’s fulfillment is to give without diminishing oneself. Their spirit and clarity fill heaven and earth, so wherever they dwell is fitting; wherever is fitting, they do not harm themselves for things but abide in the realm of self-possession.

The Lü commentary notes: With a serene ease between the brows, their breath descends to the heels, deep and subtle. Knowing that gain and loss are not theirs to claim, they accept fate and rest in it. Unaware whether it lies with them or with others, they forget through the Dao. To hesitate and look around is to be too occupied with self-examination to have leisure for others’ esteem or disdain. The true persons of old could not be swayed by eloquence, ensnared by beauty, plundered by thieves, or befriended by Fuxi or the Yellow Emperor—this is because they discerned the unborrowed and did not shift with things. Such persons thread their spirit through mountains and plunge into abysses, fill heaven and earth, and give to others while abounding all the more. This speaks to the inexhaustibility of the Dao.

The *Yidu* commentary observes: This echoes the *Analects* account of Lingyin Ziwen, illustrated through Jianwu. "Serene ease" describes the subtle movement of qi. When high rank comes, one accepts it; when it departs, one lets it go. Gain and loss are not one’s own—what cause for joy or sorrow? Forgetting self and other, returning to great unity, success and failure dissolve of themselves. Even heaven cannot bestow or strip away honor—how much less can people? The true person befriends transformation, so the wise cannot sway them with words, the beautiful cannot seduce them, thieves cannot rob them, and Fuxi or the Yellow Emperor cannot befriend them. Only thus can they thread through mountains without obstruction, plunge into abysses without getting wet, dwell in hardship without losing their flourishing, fill heaven and earth, and give to others while abounding all the more.

The *Bixu* commentary states: "Serene ease between the brows" describes a radiant, joyful countenance. I have no claim to superiority, and thus no pride—hence no sorrow. Moreover, life is but an illusion, an inn is but a transient lodging; the coming and going of high rank differ little from gnats flitting past the eyes. Thus, hesitating without advancing, one preserves the spirit in the realm of Dao and virtue; gazing in all directions, one rides the qi into the treasure of the mysterious. How could the esteem or disdain of others concern them? The true persons of old were unadorned and thus hard to sway, genuine and thus uncorrupted, desireless and thus beyond thieves, without craving and thus unyielding. Know this: where the heart is unobstructed, life and death cannot alter it; where form is unburdened, rank and emolument cannot entangle it. Such persons’ spirit has no fixed place, so it pierces the hardest without trace; their qi has no form, so it sinks into the softest without wetting. Hidden within the boundless, filling the limitless, they extend their power to things—things are satisfied, yet they themselves overflow.

The *Yongzhai* commentary says: "Serene ease between the brows" reflects breath dwelling within, nurturing the self. If the honor of the ministerial post belonged to the minister, it would have no bearing on me; if my own worth belonged to me, it would have no bearing on the minister. Thus it is said: "If it lies with them, it is nothing to me; if it lies with me, it is nothing to them." To hesitate and look around is to gaze loftily and wander in thought between heaven and earth—how could one know what others call honor or disgrace? The wise cannot be swayed, for words cannot exhaust them. The beautiful cannot seduce, for beauty cannot corrupt. Thieves cannot rob, for force cannot bend. Fuxi and the Yellow Emperor cannot befriend, for they withdrew from the world and held it lightly. "Obstruction" means hindrance. "Lowly and humble" means poverty and low status. The Dao resides within yet fills heaven and earth; extending it to transform others, its use is inexhaustible. At ease in the center, the breath between the brows is serene, deep yet subtly moving. Knowing that rank and emolument come unbidden and depart unstoppable, one sees gain and loss as not one’s own and wears no look of sorrow—this is how they surpass others. Is it with creation or with me? If with me, then creation is nothing; if with creation, then I am nothing. Forgetting both self and other—what cause for sorrow? To hesitate and look around is to be self-possessed, with no leisure for others’ esteem or disdain. Their joy lies within, and they view three rises and three falls in office as motes of dust passing before them. This speaks of those who accept fate and forget honor and disgrace, who scorn profit and forget rank and emolument. Thus Confucius likened them to the true persons of old. The true person remains unchanged by life and death, for their vast qi fills heaven and earth; extending it to benefit others, its use is boundless.

The *Nanhua* parable of Jianwu and Shu’ao serves as a measure for serving or withdrawing, yet inwardly, joy and harm are neither gained nor lost. Such a one is fit to discuss the Dao. The King of Chu sat with an ordinary lord. After a while, the king’s attendants said the ordinary lord had died three times. The lord said: "The death of the ordinary is not enough to lose what I possess." If the ordinary’s death does not lose what I possess, then the Chu’s existence is not enough to preserve existence. From this perspective, the ordinary never truly died, and Chu never truly existed.

The Guo commentary explains: The ordinary lord had three signs of death. "Not enough to lose what I possess" means abandoning the ordinary. To abandon it is not to see death as death, so existence is not enough to be called existence. Only vast and unassuming is the constant presence—existence and nonexistence lie in where the heart is placed. In truth, the world has no existence or nonexistence.

The Lü commentary states: In the world, what is constantly present, neither dying nor being born, is the true existence.

To preserve the constant presence is to truly preserve existence. How can the cases of Fan and Chu suffice to represent existence and nonexistence?

Yi Du’s annotation: The state’s existence is the existence of things; my existence is the existence of destiny. As for destiny, though the state perish, what is inherently mine does not perish. Those bound to things, though the state endure, have already lost what they possess. The King of Chu coveted another’s state, and his attendants warned, “Fan exhibits three signs of ruin,” desiring to claim that state. The Lord of Fan, unbound to his state, thus declared, “The death of Fan is not enough to lose what I possess.” Since Fan’s death does not lose what I possess, then Chu’s existence is not enough to preserve existence—mocking the King of Chu, whose so-called existence is already lost, and whose state’s survival is of no benefit. From this perspective, Fan never truly died, and Chu never truly existed. Viewed through the Dao, there is no existence or nonexistence.

Bixu’s annotation: The King of Chu harbored ambitions to annex neighboring lands, so his attendants sought to sway him with words. Fan’s three signs of ruin were: disrespect for the elderly, disregard for the worthy, and neglect of the people. “Fan’s death is not enough to lose what I possess” means not taking the loss of one’s state as a disaster. “Chu’s existence is not enough to preserve existence” means that though the state endures, one’s life is already forfeit. Thus, existence and nonexistence lie in the Dao, not in the state.

Yongzhai’s commentary: This echoes the idea that the amputee retains dignity in his remaining foot—meaning the Dao within oneself is independent of whether one possesses a state or not. Fan is not defined by ruin, nor Chu by existence; thus, worldly gains and losses are but external things. Yet the crux lies in the phrase “Chu’s existence is not enough to preserve existence.” The loser need not regret, nor the gainer boast—these words carry profound meaning. The Lord of Fan, unburdened by the state’s demise, preserved his own existence, knowing the self outweighs the state. The King of Chu, prideful in his state’s survival, had already lost what truly mattered, valuing the state above himself. If the self outweighs the state, the state’s ruin brings no harm; if the state outweighs the self, the state’s survival avails nothing. Thus, the noble person preserves virtue and power, not rank or territory—how much less the petty gains and losses beneath them?

This discourse begins with Zifang’s master, whose appearance belied his celestial nature, his hidden virtue too radiant to be named—sufficient to awaken the Marquis Wen to the falsity of his learning. The state of Wei’s entanglements were thus skillfully illuminated by the master’s virtue, a single word awakening the ruler. Why lament one’s own failure to stand or the Dao’s failure to spread? When Confucius met Wenbo Xuezi, the Dao was present in a glance—enlightenment need not lie in tedious instruction. Yan Hui, transcendent and untethered, seemed to lag behind, yet the great transformation works in subtle shifts—why not seek it in the fleeting moment? Laozi wandered at the origin of things, and Confucius recognized his detachment, possessing a singular vision. Such encounters plumb the profound—would further questions not be superfluous? Yet without seizing the moment to expound the principle, how could later learners benefit? Thus, the text delves into the mysteries of yin-yang harmony and the generation of things, tracing their sprouts to their ultimate return, so all may grasp the greatness of heaven and earth and forget the petty changes of form.

When Duke Ai claimed Lu teemed with Confucians, he judged by robes and caps; Zhuangzi examined their conduct and found them wanting. Yet when he proclaimed Confucius alone endured in the state, it revealed the indestructibility of the true Dao and the ease with which false learning fades. How could such discernment be deceived? King Wen elevated Zang the Elder; once governance was complete, he vanished by night. Those who govern with intent prioritize worthy ministers; those who respond without attachment do not cling to achievement. The way of ruler and minister reaches its pinnacle here—setting a standard for all ages.

As when Bohun observed Liezi’s archery or Shu Ao thrice resigned without distress—these are discussions of those who have mastered destiny, transcending the human to merge with heaven, moving freely through the eight directions, untouched by life and death. Only when learning the Dao reaches this point does it attain perfection. Otherwise, one is merely outwardly compliant while inwardly imperiled.

Concluding with the parable of the King of Chu and the Lord of Fan’s survival or ruin, it clarifies the distinction between self and externals—truly understanding what is weighty. *The Ocean of Meanings in the True Scripture of Southern Florescence*, Scroll Sixty-Five, ends. *The Ocean of Meanings in the True Scripture of Southern Florescence*, Scroll Sixty-Six.

The Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin, in his study of *Knowing the Northward Journey*:

*Knowing the Northward Journey* unfolds upon the Dark Waters, ascending the Hidden Well Mound, where it chanced upon Yuanwei Wei. Knowing addressed Yuanwei Wei, saying: "I would ask you this: What thoughts, what reflections lead to knowing the Dao? What dwelling, what practice brings repose in the Dao? What following, what path secures attainment of the Dao?" Three questions, yet Yuanwei Wei made no reply—not that he refused to answer, but that he knew not how to answer.

Knowing, receiving no response, returned south of the White Waters, ascended Fox Terrace, and there beheld the madman Qu. Knowing posed the same questions to the madman Qu. Qu replied: "Ah! I know the answers and shall tell you." Yet midway through speaking, he forgot what he meant to say.

Knowing, still unanswered, returned to the Imperial Palace and questioned the Yellow Emperor. The Yellow Emperor said: "Without thought, without reflection—only then does one know the Dao. Without dwelling, without practice—only then does one find repose in the Dao. Without following, without path—only then does one attain the Dao."

Knowing asked the Yellow Emperor: "You and I know this, yet they do not—who is correct?" The Yellow Emperor replied: "Yuanwei Wei is truly right; the madman Qu approaches it. You and I remain far from it. For those who know do not speak; those who speak do not know. Thus the sage enacts the teaching without words. The Dao cannot be summoned; virtue cannot be reached. Benevolence may be enacted, righteousness may be diminished, and ritual is but mutual pretense. Hence it is said: Lose the Dao, and virtue follows; lose virtue, and benevolence follows; lose benevolence, and righteousness follows; lose righteousness, and ritual follows. Ritual is the flower of the Dao and the beginning of chaos. Thus it is said: The practitioner of the Dao daily diminishes, diminishing further and further until reaching non-action—non-action that does not act. Now that one has become a thing, to return to the root is no easy task! Yet how simple it is for the great person! The living are companions of the dead; the dead are the beginning of the living—who knows their order? Human life is the gathering of qi; when gathered, there is life; when scattered, there is death. If death and life are companions, what cause have I for distress? Thus the myriad things are one. What they deem wondrous is divine and marvelous; what they despise is foul and rotten. Yet the foul and rotten transform into the divine and marvelous, and the divine and marvelous revert to the foul and rotten. Thus it is said: The world is pervaded by a single qi. Therefore the sage values unity."

Knowing said to the Yellow Emperor: "I questioned Yuanwei Wei, and he did not respond to me—not that he refused to respond, but that he did not know how. I questioned the madman Qu, who began to tell me but did not, not that he refused, but that midway he forgot. Now I ask you, and you know—why then are you not near?"

The Yellow Emperor replied: "He is truly right because he does not know. This one approaches it because he forgets. You and I remain far because we know."

When the madman Qu heard this, he deemed the Yellow Emperor one who knew speech.

Guo’s commentary: Allowing things to proceed of themselves—this is the teaching without words. The Dao resides in spontaneity, not in governance through speech. Not losing virtue is called virtue, yet even in naming virtue, one does not reach it. Ritual has fixed forms, from which arise artificiality and imitation. Thus the practitioner of the Dao willingly sheds its flowers and falsity. When ornament departs, simplicity is complete—though one acts, it is as if one does not act. Things lose their proper place, hence there is becoming a thing. To return to the root is no easy task! Only the great person embodies transformation, and transforming things is no difficulty. One who knows the way of transformation does not regard life and death as distinct. Each becomes the beginning of the other—who knows which is death and which is life? All gather and scatter—why should I rest? Each deems what it cherishes divine and marvelous, and what it detests foul and rotten. Yet what they cherish, I may despise; what I cherish, they may detest. Thus all share in the divine and marvelous, all share in the foul and rotten—how do death and life, self and other, differ? Taking not-knowing as true knowing, and knowing as not near, reveals that spontaneity is not attained through speech or knowledge. Thus the standard of non-speech is first raised, and clarity is later entrusted to the Yellow Emperor—so the obscurity of spontaneity may be glimpsed."

Lü’s commentary: *Knowing the Northward Journey* returns to the root, seeking what is shared and plumbing the depths of the mysterious. Hidden, it is not entangled; in the well, it is not obscured. Non-action entails no affairs; non-speaking entails no words. Not answering speech is the way of non-action. Returning south of the White Waters, one hastens toward clarity, seeking it on Fox Terrace or in some unfilled place. Madness knows no direction; Qu cannot extend. The Yellow Emperor’s palace is where the mind resides. The Dao cannot be known through knowledge—Yuanwei Wei’s not-knowing is true knowing. The madman Qu, desiring to speak yet forgetting, is not ignorant—thus he approaches it. You and I know, and thus remain far. The Dao has no direction, so it cannot be summoned; summoning it would beckon it to come. Virtue is within, so it cannot be reached; reaching would be a movement from here to there. Virtue is non-action, yet benevolence may be enacted; benevolence is partiality, yet righteousness may be diminished. Ritual is enacted but meets no response—flailing arms yet clinging to it—this is mere pretense, the beginning of chaos. Thus the practitioner of the Dao daily diminishes, diminishing until reaching non-action—non-action that does not act. Then benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music have no choice but to vanish. When non-action does not act, what of benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music are not the Dao? Now that one has become a thing, possessing knowledge, to return to the root is difficult indeed! Yet for the great person, radiant and unobscured by things, returning to the root amid the teeming is an easy matter. Life and death, beginning and end—no origin, no order. Qi gathers to form life; qi scatters to bring death."

The knowledge that qi’s gathering and scattering are but transient—what rest does this leave? Thus the myriad things are one. What one deems wondrous is called divine and marvelous; what one detests is called foul and rotten—yet these two transform into each other and nothing more. From this we know that all under Heaven is a single qi, which is why the sage values oneness.

*Dú* annotates: North and water both belong to the realm of knowing. The hidden and obscure alternate with the manifest, illustrating the interplay of yin and yang. "Non-action, non-utterance"—this is the Dao. Three questions met with no answer, that one might find it within the realm of non-speech. To wish to speak yet forget what one wished to say—this is the unattainable spoken. Turning back to the Imperial Palace to inquire, the Yellow Emperor, using the metaphor of the central Dao, answered with "no thought, no adornment, no following"—this is how one knows the Dao, rests in the Dao, and attains the Dao.

Knowledge cannot yet forget speech, so one says, "You and I know it," while that "non-action, non-utterance" and the madman Kuang’s ignorance—who is right? The Yellow Emperor could embody the Dao of non-action while engaging in action, thus taking "no answer" as truth. To wish to answer yet forget how is to resemble it, for speech ultimately does not approach the Dao. He further cited Laozi’s words to convey the meaning that the knowing do not speak.

"Non-action, non-utterance"—this is true knowing. The Dao of the profound and distant cannot be reached; the ever-renewing virtue cannot be attained. Benevolence can be enacted, yet the highest benevolence acts without deeming it right. Righteousness can be diminished, yet the highest righteousness acts while considering it right. Ritual is mere pretense, which is why it appears after virtue, the Dao, benevolence, and righteousness—this is the thinning of loyalty and trust and the beginning of chaos.

Daily diminishing what is known can lead to the Dao; daily diminishing still involves action. Diminish further and further until reaching non-action—then the myriad dharmas are all empty, adapting only to change. Now that one has become a thing, to return to the root and revert to the origin—is this not difficult? Only for the great person is it easy!

Death is the beginning of life, thus knowing life is the end of death. The *Book of Changes* says: "Essence and qi become things—this is qi’s gathering. The advancing hun-soul becomes transformation—this is qi’s scattering." If death and life are one, why lament their transience?

The divine and marvelous are what people favor; the foul and rotten are what they detest. Yet all arise from a single qi, endlessly revolving. The sage values oneness to illuminate the natural Dao, which cannot be attained through speech or knowledge but only by merging with the principle of non-speech.

*Bìxū* annotates: Knowing roams above the Dark Waters, wishing to conceal knowledge in profound silence. Yet knowing does not remain silent forever—where there is concealment, there is also emergence. Knowing has no rest, so it knocks on the gates of the obscure to seek tranquility. "Non-action, non-utterance" with "no answer" as the answer—how profound its meaning!

White Waters: one turns toward the light. The Imperial Palace: the numinous abode. The Yellow Emperor: the true sovereign. Withdrawing sight and reversing hearing, all existents are empty. To regard knowledge as right and ignorance as wrong is to compound error. The teaching of non-speech is the wondrous existence.

Yet even truth and true knowing are obstacles to the Dao, especially difficult to remove. The great Dao has no form to be reached; the highest virtue has no virtue to be attained. Benevolence embraces all, but its flaw is partiality and enactment. Righteousness governs judgment, but its flaw is usurpation and diminishment. Ritual exalts dignity, but its flaw is artifice and the rise of pretense. All stem from the loss of knowing, leading to chaos. One must first diminish knowledge, then diminish non-knowledge to reach non-knowing. After non-diminishing comes non-action, and after non-action comes non-non-action.

In non-action, there is no self—who but the great person achieves this? Only by forgetting life can death not bind; only by forgetting death can one return to life’s origin. To know its order is to recognize its beginning. Where there is gathering, there is scattering. Seeing life and death as a single thread, where is there no leisure?

The divine and marvelous are nature; the foul and rotten are form. All things deem the preservation of nature as beauty and its decay as evil. Nature transforms into form, and form returns to nature—all within a single qi. Attain oneness, and the myriad affairs are complete. Who would not value it?

The utility of having and not-having lies in their mutual necessity—coarse and subtle depend on each other. Thus, first presenting "non-action, non-utterance" with no answer illustrates the subtlety of the ultimate principle. Next, the madman Kuang’s wish to speak yet forgetting shows the meeting of speech and silence. Finally, the Yellow Emperor’s knowing uses words to expound the Dao, for knowledge is coarse, while transcending speech is subtle.

*Yōngzhāi* says: The opening passage divides into three sections—truth, semblance, and distance—with the main idea being that the knowing do not speak, and the speaking do not know. It continues that the Dao cannot be reached through words, nor virtue through traces. Benevolence, righteousness, and ritual all leave traces, thus encircling the Dao, with ritual being the worst offender!

Discarding the body and silencing the senses—this is the daily diminishing of the Dao. Diminish further and further until forgetting one’s former self, reaching non-action, and following the natural principle of Heaven—nothing remains to be done. Seeking the Dao while still clinging to things makes one no different from them, and returning to the root becomes difficult. "Returning to the root" means reverting to the origin of things, which only the great person achieves with ease through non-action.

Life is the companion of death; death is the beginning of life—like the blooming of flowers and trees, an inexhaustible principle. Thus, what lives is as if already dead. *Yíchuān* says: The rest of re-entering is not the rest of what has already emerged—this is the meaning. Life and death come and go—who knows their guiding principle is qi? If one knows life and death are but a single principle, why lament their transience or oneness?

The myriad things share one principle of life and death, yet people divide them into likes and dislikes, beauty and ugliness.

Just as flowers and plants in full bloom are deemed wondrous, yet when they wither, they become foul and rotten—unaware that fallen leaves nourish the roots, and new life begins anew from this very decay, so foulness and rottenness transform back into the wondrous. From ancient times to the present, there is only this single qi. The sage understands this, and thus does not distinguish between life and death, fortune and misfortune.

"One" means no distinction. *Chu Shi’s* *Guǎnjiàn* states: Knowing the northward journey to the dark waters is a metaphor for the learned scholar’s desire to return to the root. The hidden well on the hill signifies one who has not fully concealed themselves, whose knowledge still seeks to instruct others. Non-action means no longer speaking of knowledge, hence questions go unanswered. Returning south of the White Waters, one seeks it again in brightness. When the fox’s gate is closed, the mind of doubt is already empty. The "madly bent" refers to those deemed mad yet preserved in wholeness. Desiring to speak yet forgetting the light, one finds speech unattainable. Returning to the Emperor’s palace, one seeks within. The master of the Yellow Chamber, when questioned, cannot but respond, and thus reveals that knowing the Dao, abiding in the Dao, and attaining the Dao lie solely in non-thought, non-dwelling, and non-following. "Truly so" means grasping its reality; "resembling it" is secondary. If one does not draw near, one drifts far from the Dao!

Such is the contrast in understanding words—no wonder the Master, in dealing with others, listens to their words but observes their conduct. The teaching without words is led by personal example, requiring no reliance on speech. The Dao descends to become virtue, benevolence, righteousness, and ritual—just as humans are born with knowledge, knowledge leads to ability, ability leads to servitude, and servitude makes one an object of objects, making it difficult to return to the root. Only the great person can master things, and thus finds it easy.

Life and death are but the gathering and scattering of a single qi. The wondrous and the foul transform into one another—this is merely how people label what they find beautiful or ugly. The sage values unity, for in unity all is undivided; how then can one distinguish between the wondrous and the foul? Only those who understand life and death as companions can speak of this.

The passage beginning "The Yellow Emperor said..." reiterates earlier text and requires no further explanation.

Heaven and Earth possess great beauty yet do not speak; the four seasons have clear patterns yet do not debate; the myriad things have inherent principles yet do not explain. The sage traces the beauty of Heaven and Earth and comprehends the principles of the myriad things. Thus, the perfected person practices non-action, and the great sage does not act—this is called observing Heaven and Earth.

Now, that numinous clarity and utmost refinement, together with the hundred transformations—whether things live or die, are square or round—none know their root. Yet all things have existed since antiquity, self-subsistent. The Six Directions are vast, yet remain within it; the tip of an autumn hair is small, yet depends on it to form its body. All under Heaven rise and fall, never constant throughout life. Yin and yang, the four seasons, move in their cycles, each in its proper order. Vast and indistinct, as if absent yet present; flowing and formless, yet spirit-like—nurturing the myriad things without their awareness. This is called the root, by which one may observe Heaven.

*Guo’s* commentary: The perfected person practices non-action, relying solely on natural compliance. Observing their form and appearance, adapting to what is fitting, they differ not from Heaven and Earth. Thus, the hundred transformations transform themselves, and the numinous clarity remains undisturbed; the dead die of themselves, the living live of themselves; the round are round of themselves, the square are square of themselves. There is no maker of their root, hence none know it. Since antiquity, they have existed of themselves—how could they depend on being made?

To consider the Six Directions as within the boundless is narrow. Though the tip of an autumn hair is small, without the boundless, it would have no place to contain its essence. The four seasons move in their cycles—do they depend on being made? If it were manifestly present, it would be absent; if it were held in tangible form, it would lack spirit. To nurture things without grasping their root in inherent nature is to not know how they are nurtured.

*Lü’s* commentary: Heaven and Earth practice non-action yet lack nothing, for they possess great beauty. The four seasons alternate, beginning and ending without confusion, for they have clear patterns. Though the myriad things are many, the Dao is not absent from them, for they have inherent principles. Beauty fills their midst, patterns can be emulated, and principles—wherever one goes—all return to the Dao alone.

The sage traces beauty and comprehends principles, knowing that what is not done arises naturally—this is called observing Heaven and Earth. Now, that numinous clarity and utmost refinement, together with the hundred transformations—viewed from the perspective of things, they live or die, are square or round—how can one know their root? Yet though all things are vast and indistinct, none are not "that." Since antiquity, they have existed of themselves, and "that" has never departed. Yin and yang, the four seasons, each in their proper order—who else but "that" brings this about? As if absent yet present, formless yet spirit-like, it cannot be sought in the realm of being or non-being. The myriad things are thus interwoven, yet none know why—this is called the root.

*Yi Du’s* commentary: Great beauty is yin and yang. Clear patterns are generation and transformation. Inherent principles are nature and destiny. The sage roots themselves in the beauty of Heaven and Earth’s yin and yang and comprehends the principles of the myriad things’ nature and destiny. Inwardly, they become a perfected person and practice non-action; outwardly, though they act as a sage, their actions arise from non-doing. Observing the convergence of Heaven and Earth, they enact their rites and ceremonies alone.

Numinous clarity is the utmost refinement of Heaven and Earth. The hundred transformations transform themselves, and the numinous clarity does not interfere. Thus, whether things live or die, are square or round, none know their root. Vast and indistinct, all things have existed since antiquity, enduring from the distant past without aging. The Six Directions do not depart from this Dao, and even the tip of an autumn hair depends on this Dao to form. All under Heaven rise and fall by this alone. The Dao is ever-renewing, never constant, and thus yin and yang, the four seasons, follow it to attain their proper order. As if absent yet present, formless yet spirit-like, things are nurtured by it without awareness—this is called the root, the mystery that fashions the myriad things.

Extending this insight, one may contemplate the Way of Heaven.

The great beauty blankets and sustains all; its luminous laws govern life and death, completing principles and distinguishing categories. Words distort beauty, debates corrupt laws, and explanations disorder principles. Only the primal non-action silently accords with the four seasons, harmonizing with Heaven and Earth, endlessly transforming without limit—this may be called the essence of clarity.

All things are self-so, thus none know their root. Standing alone and unchanging, neither Heaven nor Earth could contain them without numinous clarity, nor could the tip of an autumn hair be formed without utmost refinement. The sage models the movements of Heaven and Earth, and things receive their blessings without awareness—this is called the root.

The great beauty is that spoken of in the *Yijing*: "With great beauty, benefit all under Heaven." The luminous laws are the fixed patterns of cold and heat’s alternation. The completion of principles refers to the causes of small and large, long and short—how could these be expressed! Primal non-action is all self-so. That by which the sage accords with the self-so is attained from Heaven and Earth alone. Numinous clarity and utmost refinement speak of the wondrous principle. The life and death, square and round of things are all wrought by numinous clarity and utmost refinement—who could exhaust their root and limit?

Vast and indistinct, the transformations of things are without pause, yet creation endures. As Su Dongpo said: "That which passes is like this, yet it has never gone"—none but the truly perceptive can speak thus. Rising and falling, coming and going. "Without constancy" means ever-renewing. "Indistinct" means invisible. "Abundant" speaks of the vitality of life. "As if absent yet present"—death is but a companion of life. "Formless yet spirit-like"—it does not rely on form to stand. This passage from the *Nanhua* establishes its own discourse, continuing the earlier theme of primal non-action.

The first three phrases echo: "What does Heaven say? The four seasons proceed, the hundred things are born." The sage embodies Heaven and Earth to nurture the myriad things—how could this be mere inert non-action, like a wooden puppet? For non-action emerges from the primal, and action is rooted in non-action, just as the movements of celestial timing and the fertility of earthly advantage do not transgress the self-so.

Uniting the numinous clarity and utmost refinement of Heaven and Earth with the hundred transformations of things, their flourishing and withering, their forms and appearances, are all manifestly visible—yet none know what brings them about. This is called the root. "Vast and indistinct, the myriad things"—this is the meaning of the teeming multitude. "Existing since antiquity"—the Way does not change. Thus, it pervades the Six Directions in its vastness, enters the tip of an autumn hair in its subtlety, moves with things in their currents while ever-renewing, and yin and yang together revolve in proper order.

"As if absent yet present"—dimly, something is there. "Formless yet spirit-like"—obscurely, clarity is seen. All things are born and nurtured by this, yet do not know it as their root. What is called the root—how could it be sought elsewhere? Turn inward to one’s own body and find that by which one is given life. Knowing the root and guarding it without departure—this is called returning to the root. Returning to the root is called stillness; stillness is called recovering the mandate. Only at this stage in the study of the Way may one advance further. Taking yet another step into the profound, it is said: "One may contemplate the Way of Heaven."

Now, the version collated by Liu Deyi, the Illuminated Scatterer of Chen Bixu, aligns with this. Comparing it with the preceding text, it is superior in meaning.

*End of Southern Florescence True Scripture: Sea of Meanings Compiled and Elucidated, Scroll Sixty-Six*
*Beginning of Southern Florescence True Scripture: Sea of Meanings Compiled and Elucidated, Scroll Sixty-Seven*

The Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin annotates *Knowing the Northern Journey*, Second Chapter:

Nie Que asked the Way of Bei Yi. Bei Yi said: "Correct your form, unify your gaze, and the harmony of Heaven will arrive. Gather in your knowledge, unify your measures, and spirit will come to dwell. Virtue will become your beauty, the Way will become your dwelling. You will gaze with the clarity of a newborn calf, without seeking its cause."

Before his words were finished, Nie Que fell asleep. Bei Yi rejoiced greatly, departed singing, and said:
"Form like withered bones, heart like dead ashes—truly, this is its genuine knowing, not clinging to the past to sustain itself.
Vague and obscure, without mind and beyond consultation—what manner of man is this?"

Guo’s commentary: "Not clinging to the past to sustain itself—this is moving with change. Without mind and beyond consultation—this is solitary transformation."
Lü’s commentary: "Correct the form, and one sits in fullness. Unify the gaze, and there is no delusion. Thus, deviant qi retreats, and the harmonious and balanced returns. Gather in knowledge, and one returns to the root; unify measures, and one does not stray. Spirit comes to dwell, and one guards the form without departure. Virtue becomes beautiful, filling and returning to the beginning. The Way returns, resting and gathering in emptiness. Like a newborn calf, one does not know where it goes. Before the words were finished, Nie Que feigned sleep, yet heard them as if riding a chariot. Bei Yi departed singing, delighted by how easily he had settled into this state. Form withered and heart ashen—this is the utmost stillness. Truly, this is its genuine knowing, for it is without knowing. Not clinging to the past to sustain itself—this is the remnant of its arising. The latter three phrases describe the depth of his attainment, yet I know not who he is."

Yi Zhu’s commentary: "Correct the form, and one does not stray; unify the gaze, and one does not wander. Thus, harmony and principle emerge. Gather in knowledge to relinquish knowledge; unify measures to forget measures. Thus, the heart is empty, and spirit comes to unite. Only through utmost harmony does virtue become your beauty; only through utmost emptiness does the Way become your dwelling. Gazing with the clarity of a newborn calf—this speaks of the wholeness of spirit. Without seeking its cause—this is daily renewal. Before the words were finished, Nie Que feigned sleep. Bei Yi, rejoicing in his attainment of the Way, departed singing. Truly, this is its genuine knowing, not clinging to the past to sustain itself—this is moving with transformation. Vague and obscure, without mind—this is being a person of transformation."

Bi Xu’s commentary: "When the body is not deviant and the eyes do not wander, the harmonious and balanced gathers. Withdrawing awareness and simplifying measures, auspiciousness abides. Then, all beauties follow, and purity remains. The gaze is clear and illuminating, not floating outward. The Way is near at hand. Thus, the ear hears what can be spoken, and spirit enters the wondrous gate. Immediate comprehension arises, and stillness is like sleep. Form like withered bones, heart like dead ashes—this is correcting the form and unifying the gaze. Truly, this is its genuine knowing, not clinging to the past to sustain itself—this is gathering in knowledge and unifying measures. Vague and obscure, virtue becomes beautiful and mindless, beyond consultation—thus the Way dwells. These all praise Nie Que’s virtuous bearing, and the wondrous subtlety of his feigned sleep, which words cannot fully express."

Yongzhai said: "Correcting the form and unifying the gaze—this is forgetting one’s body, ears, and eyes. Gathering in knowledge and unifying measures—this is relinquishing thought, deliberation, and consciousness. Thus, original qi is preserved, and spirit comes to dwell. Virtue becomes beautiful—this means it suffices to nourish the body. The Way dwells—this is dwelling in the vast dwelling of all under Heaven. Gazing with clarity—this is the appearance of knowing without knowing, looking directly. A newborn calf looks without mind, as does an infant. Without seeking its cause—this means not knowing why it looks as it does. Before the words were finished, he slept—speech and meaning were in accord, leaving no room for words. Truly seeing the reality of this principle, things do not enter the heart. Vague and obscure—this is the appearance of indistinctness. Since he is without mind, there is nothing I can say—what manner of man is this? This is profound praise. A good teacher establishes principles with simplicity; a good student receives transformation swiftly. Correcting the form and unifying the gaze—this is regulating the external. Gathering in knowledge and unifying measures—this is ordering the internal. This can be called simplicity of principle. Before the words were finished, he fell asleep—this is swift transformation indeed. The phrase 'gazing with the clarity of a newborn calf' best depicts the beauty of virtue, the dwelling of the Way, the absence of mind and action, and the state of pure harmony, utterly forgetting things. Observing this, one can know the method of entering the Way. Bei Yi’s departing song shares the same meaning as Zigong’s praise of the old man of Hanyin. When people rest, their minds are in the repository of schemes and the master of knowledge. Now, without mind and beyond consultation, he sighs in admiration of his pure virtue, saying there is no one like this in the world."

Shun asked Cheng: "Can the Way be obtained and possessed?"
Cheng said: "Your body is not your possession—how can you possess the Way?"
Shun said: "If my body is not mine, then whose is it?"
Cheng said: "It is the entrusted form of Heaven and Earth. Life is not your possession—it is the entrusted harmony of Heaven and Earth. Nature and destiny are not your possession—it is the entrusted compliance of Heaven and Earth. Children and grandchildren are not your possession—it is the entrusted shedding of Heaven and Earth. Thus, in walking, one does not know where one is going; in dwelling, one does not know what one is holding; in eating, one does not know the taste. It is the strong yang qi of Heaven and Earth—how can it be obtained and possessed?"

Guo’s commentary: "The body is not yours—how much less the Way! If the body were yours, then beauty, ugliness, life, and death would be determined by you. Now, qi gathers and you are born—you cannot forbid it; qi scatters and you die—you cannot stop it. Clearly, it is entrusted and self-completing, not yours. As for children and grandchildren, they are also qi entrusted and self-completing, like the shedding of a cicada. Thus, in walking, dwelling, and eating, all come within the natural. Strong yang—this is like movement. Those who understand this Way can perhaps relinquish the body and forget life."

Lü’s commentary: "Observing the things of the world, nothing is more one’s own than one’s body, yet even the entrusted form of Heaven and Earth cannot be possessed."

What clings closest to the existence of your body is none other than life, yet the entrusted harmony of Heaven and Earth—you cannot grasp its completion. What underlies your life is none other than nature and destiny, yet the entrusted compliance of Heaven and Earth—you cannot defy its rectitude.

Observe your body: if you know its root and origin, then in walking, where do you direct yourself? In dwelling, what do you hold to? In eating, what do you savor? All these are the workings of Heaven and Earth’s vigorous yang qi. Then how can you claim possession of the Way?

Du’s commentary: *Cheng* was a man of the Dao in ancient times. The body is the vessel that carries the Way, yet the body is subject to the bestowal and deprivation of Creation—thus it is not yours, but the entrusted form of Heaven and Earth. If even the body cannot be your own, how much less the Way! Not only the body, but life and nature-and-destiny are also not yours—they are the entrusted harmony and compliance of Heaven and Earth. As for children and grandchildren, they too are but its entrusted shedding. Knowing that none of these are yours, you should entrust them to the natural—thus in walking, dwelling, and eating, all proceed from the natural, and you know not how.

The vigorous yang qi of Heaven and Earth—humans receive it and are born, and by it they die. How can you claim possession of it?

Bi Xu’s commentary: The Way cannot be grasped by sight, hearing, or touch—how then can it be possessed? The body is but a lump that exists of itself—how can it be yours? The answer lies in the notion of "solitary transformation": it is entrusted and follows of itself. The body is not yours—it exists by following the form of Heaven and Earth. Life is not yours—it exists by following the harmony of Heaven and Earth. Nature-and-destiny is not yours—it exists by following the compliance of Heaven and Earth. Children and grandchildren are not yours—they exist by following the shedding of Heaven and Earth. Thus in walking, dwelling, and eating, all are stirred and set in motion by the primal qi—what part of it is yours?

Yong Zhai’s commentary: *Wei* means "to gather." The four great elements temporarily unite—this is called *entrusted form*. Yin and yang achieve harmony and things are born—this is called *entrusted harmony*. Nature-and-destiny reside within me, yet they are the principle of Creation—this is called *entrusted compliance*. Generations succeed one another like the molting of a cicada—this is called *entrusted shedding*. *Strong yang* is the qi of life. Human walking, dwelling, and eating are all set in motion by this qi, and are not one’s own. The *Sutra of Perfect Enlightenment* says: "Where now does this illusory body abide?"—this is the meaning. "Not knowing what to hold to" refers to primordial attachment.

*Cheng* may refer to Shun’s teacher, though few explanations are detailed. Upon further examination, Bi Xu’s *Pronunciation and Meaning* notes: "In ancient times, the emperor had four assistants: left and right counselors, a front *yi* and a rear *cheng*—these were official titles. This explanation is likely correct." The Way is originally formless and manifests through things. The body is not mine—it is numinous through spirit.

Heaven and Earth entrust form—what is formed must decay. That which is called "I" is but a temporary lodging. So too with life and nature: thus may one know that descendants are but *entrusted shedding*. Therefore, in one’s walking, dwelling, and eating, all should be left to nature.

The harmonious qi of Heaven and Earth flows and nurtures the myriad things. This flourishes while that withers; this dies while that lives—all is the operation and transformation of the Dao to its ultimate limit, and the reception of destiny by things is without end. How can you alone possess it?

For it is clear that the creative transformation of Heaven and Earth is without partiality. Only by breaking through the delusion of worldly people who cling to possession of their bodies and cherish their children and grandchildren can one enter the Dao. This is the crucial secret by which *Nanhua* [Zhuangzi] truly liberates people from their bonds.

Confucius asked Lao Dan: "Today I have leisure. May I inquire about the supreme Dao?"
Lao Dan replied: "Purify your mind through fasting, empty your heart through detachment, cleanse your spirit through stillness, and discard your knowledge. The Dao is profoundly difficult to speak of! I shall tell you its rough outline.

The luminous arises from the obscure; order arises from formlessness; spirit arises from the Dao; form arises from essence. The myriad things generate one another through form—thus creatures with nine orifices are born from the womb, and those with eight from eggs. Their coming is without origin, their going without limit; without gate, without chamber, they radiate boundlessly in all four directions.

Those who attain this have strong limbs, penetrating thoughts, keen ears and sharp eyes. Their minds do not labor, and their responses to things are without constraint. Heaven cannot but be high, Earth cannot but be vast, the sun and moon cannot but move, and the myriad things cannot but flourish—this is the Dao!

Moreover, broad learning does not necessarily bring knowledge, nor eloquence wisdom. The sage has already settled this. As for that which, when covered, is not diminished, and when uncovered, is not increased—this is what the sage preserves.
