Deep as the sea, lofty in its ceaseless return to the beginning, it measures and sustains the myriad things without exhaustion. Then the Dao of the noble person—is it external to these? The myriad things all draw from it without depletion—this is the Dao!

There exists a being within the Central Kingdom, neither yin nor yang, dwelling between Heaven and Earth. For now, it is human, but it will return to its origin. Viewed from its root, life is but the temporary clustering of things. Though there are long and short lives, how great is the difference? It is but a momentary affair. How can it suffice to distinguish between Yao and Jie?

The fruits and ferns have their principles; human relationships, though complex, follow their own order. The sage encounters them without resistance and passes beyond without attachment. To harmonize and respond is virtue; to coincide and respond is the Dao. From this arise the rise of emperors and the founding of kings.

Human life between Heaven and Earth is like a white colt passing a gap—sudden and fleeting. Suddenly it surges forth, and none does not emerge; gently it fades away, and none does not return. Having transformed and been born, it transforms again and dies. Living things mourn it, and humankind grieves for it. Loosening its heavenly constraints, casting off its celestial endowments, in a tangle of confusion, the hun and po depart, and the body follows—thus the great return!

The formless taking form, form returning to the formless—this is what all people know, yet it is not what those who are about to attain the Dao pursue. This is what the multitude discusses in common. Those who attain it do not discuss it; those who discuss it do not attain it. Clear insight is of no value; disputation is not as good as silence. The Dao cannot be heard; hearing is not as good as blocking the senses—this is called *great attainment*."

Guo Xiang’s commentary states: "The obscure, the formless, and the Dao all clarify that it arises alone and borrows nothing. Form, then, is but essence refined to the coarsest." Though the myriad things generate one another through form, all is natural. Thus creatures born from wombs or eggs cannot produce different species—this makes clear that spirit and qi cannot be forced.

Those who follow the nature of spontaneity and wander the path without bounds cast their forms into Heaven and Earth and lodge their spirits beyond things. Thus, without gate, without chamber, they radiate boundlessly in all four directions, roaming the six directions and moving in step with transformation.

If one encounters this Dao in life, then one’s heavenly nature is whole and one’s spirit settled. Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things cannot but be as they are. Therefore, the sage cuts off wisdom and entrusts all to nature, allowing each to preserve its proper place and act without limit.

Those who move with transformation use things without being enslaved by them. The Dao’s abundance lies in not seeking abundance, yet things naturally attain it—this is to say, without effort, it is truly worthy of being called the Dao. Without partial names, freely and naturally, one passes through all and is at peace, understanding that effort and fame are nothing. Those who return to the origin do not chase after ends.

Alas! Things are but the gathering of qi. Death and life are not so different—how much less so long and short lives! Things have no inherent principle; one should simply follow them. Human relationships involve the changes of knowledge and wisdom, and thus are difficult. Yet their knowledge and wisdom follow their own order; one should follow what one encounters, even if it means exceeding what is fitting.

*Harmonizing* and *coinciding* mean blending and uniting. The rise of emperors and kings is no more than this. The fleeting passage of the colt through the gap is not worth lamenting. Having been born, one dies—both are transformations. One does not mourn the death of things, nor grieve the death of humankind. Loosening skills and casting off order—this is to be uniquely free. In the misty transformations, there is no need to exert the mind.

The formless takes form, and form is completed; to pursue it is not to attain it. To be silent and block the senses is to truly gain it.

Lü Huiqing’s commentary states: "Spirit in relation to the Dao is still but the luminous. The ultimate of the supreme Dao is the obscure. When things achieve their principle of life, there is order; when their essence is most true, there is formlessness." The myriad things generate one another through form; their coming and going are without escape, and they radiate boundlessly in all four directions.

If one attains this, one rests in the depths of the myriad things. The body is strong, thoughts penetrating, and one’s use is without constraint. The completion of Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things—none is not this.

The erudite is not wisdom, nor is eloquence intelligence—these the sage has already rejected. What seems gain is not gain, and what seems loss is not loss—these the sage preserves. Profound and towering, none know its bounds. There is movement and measure, yet these lie not within the Dao. The myriad things draw sustenance, yet not from without. Seeking the Dao thus, one finds where it resides.

Neither yin nor yang, it follows only the Dao. To be merely human is to be the same as others; to return to the origin is to be one with Heaven. Ugliness and beauty, life and death—all are equal; what distinction is there between Yao and Jie? The principle of melons and beans is shared by the myriad things. The order of human relations is the sequence of the Great Dao: neither violating nor adhering, neither abandoning nor grasping—this is the meaning.

Harmonizing and responding, virtue thus achieves its partial completion; coinciding and responding, the Dao neither examines nor laments. The rise of emperors and kings stems from nothing more than this Dao. Human life passes like a colt through a gap—none can halt it. Things grieve and people mourn, for they do not understand that there has never been birth, never been death. Release skill, and tension and relaxation are unbound; discard rank, and expansion and contraction are unimpeded. The hun and po depart, and the body follows. Speech does not transcend the great smelting of the formless form. The formed from the formless—this all know, yet it is not the goal they pursue. When attained, it is embodied; when unattained, it is merely discussed.

To clearly perceive the Dao is to encounter nothing, thus eloquence is inferior to silence. To truly hear the Dao is to hear nothing, thus hearing is inferior to blocking. Speaking without words, listening without hearing—this is called the great attainment.

*Yi Du’s Commentary*: With an obscure will, one achieves luminous merit; with the formless Dao, one establishes ordered affairs. Unifying is called essence; the unfathomable is called spirit. The myriad things generate one another through form, yet what enables their generation is this so-called essence. Thus, creatures born from wombs or eggs each fulfill their nature and destiny, and the subtlety of supreme essence arises naturally—coming without coming, going without going. Without gate, without chamber, it radiates boundlessly in all four directions. Those who know this Dao unify their four limbs and senses with true principle, so their use of the mind is effortless, and their response to things is unconstrained. The movements, generation, and transformation of Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things likewise proceed from this.

As for those who take erudition and eloquence as wisdom, the sage has already discarded them. What is neither diminished nor augmented by gain or loss is what the sage preserves—moving with transformation without end, supplying the needs of things without lack. Things draw from it without exhaustion—all these are the functions of the Dao. Within the central realm is the sage. Neither yin nor yang, it is unfathomable. To be merely human is to encounter this form by chance, not by intent; thus, returning to the origin, one observes the transformations of things. Life is but a temporary gathering of qi—laughter and ugliness alike. All things, from melons to beans, possess the principle of nature and destiny; the hierarchy of human relations is no different. Harmonizing and responding is the virtue of Heaven; coinciding and responding is the way of man. The rise of emperors and kings stems from this, yet these are but traces of worldly response, not the sage’s wondrous use.

People dwell in the world but a fleeting moment. Birth and death alternate like day and night, yet those who follow circumstances and obscure principle grieve—bound by attachment, like a bow in its skill, a book in its binding. Only the uniquely liberated can cast these off. In the tumult of life, the hun and po do not linger; death is humanity’s return. The formless takes form—this is coming into life. The formed becomes formless—this is departing in death. This is what all people share, yet it is not the goal they pursue. It refers to the principle of life and death, which even the common people can speak of; those who attain the ultimate do not discuss it, for discussion precludes attainment. Thus, eloquence is inferior to silence, and hearing is inferior to blocking. This is to attain what cannot be attained—the great attainment.

*Bixu’s Commentary*: Yang emerges from yin, being from non-being—its principle shines clearly. Spirit is the subtle remnant of the profound; form and substance are the earthly residue of harmonious qi. Thus, the mingling of kinds is distinct, and creatures born from wombs or eggs are not alike. Its coming is unknown—who calls it continuation? Its going is unfathomable—who calls it an end? Emerging, it pervades all—where is the gate? Entering, it fills all—where is the chamber? Without lack, without excess, it pervades boundlessly. Those who encounter this profound and subtle Dao become one with Heaven, respond to things without limit, and Heaven cannot but be exalted. The four phrases all refer to the Dao; the *Hunyuan* says, "Attaining the One is this."

To seek the Dao with knowledge is to hear little; to seek it with haste is to speak haltingly.

To abandon knowledge and wisdom is what the ancients prized. What neither increase nor decrease can touch—how profound and towering it stands! That which measures and sustains the myriad things without omission first attends to its root, not relying on anything external. Thus, when things turn to it for sustenance, they never lack, for this clarifies the unchanging subtlety of the Dao—neither augmented nor diminished.

To be merely human is to embody the Dao’s countenance and Heaven’s form. To return to one’s origin is to enter the vast solitude of the One. Hah! How coarse—all that congeals into living things will, in time, scatter back into nothingness. To compare lifespans, to dispute right and wrong—these are but delusions of the heart-mind.

Even plants, devoid of feeling, still embody the principle of yin and yang. Human nature does not alter; none transgress the sequence of before and after. The sage responds when affairs arise, then forgets them once they pass. Those who would initiate undertakings invariably take harmony as virtue and resonance as the Way.

In this fleeting world, life slips away in the turn of an arm. Only the serene and still transcend all going and coming; only the unchanging transcend death and life.

To unravel skills and cast off ranks—this is the meaning of shedding growths and dissolving stagnation. In the midst of flourishing and winding transformations, one lingers between the desire to transform and its unfulfillment. When the hun and po fail to guard, the hundred bones dissolve and scatter, and the spirit returns to its true abode.

The formless takes form; the unchanging transforms all transformations. The formed remains unformed; the transformer of things does not transform. The coarse belongs to form, known to all; those who attain the Dao forget both coarse and subtle.

In speech, one merely utters its dregs, never touching the essence—thus, hearing stops at the ear, and one mistakes not-gaining for gaining. Master Yongzhai said: With order, the myriad things can be distinguished. The formless is creation. Spirit and essence reside within humans. The myriad things arise through form, and both humans and creatures exist within it. Though humans are nobler than other beings, their arising is the same.

The gate and chamber of the formless cannot be sought—how then can one know its going and coming? If one seeks afar and glimpses this Dao, the body finds peace, thoughts become clear, and responses to things are without contrivance. From heaven and earth to the myriad things—these four phrases describe penetrating above and below, yet none of this is the Dao.

People boast of their erudition as ability, unaware that what enables their wisdom is the Creator. Thus, the sage severs ties with creation, neither taking increase as increase nor decrease as decrease. What is preserved lies within me; external things cannot add to it. Ending returns to beginning, responding to things without exhaustion—yet one remains bound by intention and description. When things pass and draw from it without depletion, then there is no mind and no striving.

Neither yin nor yang, it cannot be named by things. Though one bears human form, if the heart advances toward things from the outset, one merely lodges a form between heaven and earth. The origin is the beginning of things. Hah! How coarse—when qi does not flow smoothly. Viewing the formed from its primordial origin, it is but a burden.

Within a hundred years, compared to heaven and earth, it is but a spark. Even the smallest fruit or fern has its season of growth and its kind of sprouting—this is the principle of nature. Human relationships involve the restraint of superiors and inferiors, the oppression of the strong over the weak, yet all dwell together in the world, arrayed side by side. To not oppose is to follow; to not guard is to transform. Harmony and resonance are the natural course of virtue and the Dao.

The rise of emperors and kings does not exceed this principle. Birth and death—what departs extends, what arrives contracts—this is what the *Yi* calls "exhausting the spirit and knowing transformation." Things arise from the formless and, in death, return to the formless. The principle is the same, yet humans grieve for themselves—this is because they are shrouded and unclear, as if bound in a net. To awaken is to unravel the net and cast off the shroud.

Flourishing and winding describe its transformations. The great return is the reversion to the true abode. The formless form is the unseen; the formed formlessness contains the unseen within. What Buddhists call the *dharmakāya*, which abides eternally and does not perish—this is known to all, yet none can depart from form to attain it. Those who seek the ultimate must go beyond such matters.

To reach the ultimate is beyond discourse; to discourse is not to reach it—this speaks of a yet higher level. To see and encounter is called "value," but this is a trace-bound seeing. The Dao cannot be sought through form or path, thus it is without value. Therefore, disputation is inferior to silence, and hearing is inferior to obstruction.

Brightness arises from darkness; form ultimately arises from essence. This reveals that all under heaven arises from the formless. The myriad things arise through form—this is the meaning of "one gives birth to two, two gives birth to three." Coming and going have no gate, yet all is open and vast—there is no gate. Thoughts and considerations circulate, yet ears and eyes are keen—there is no use.

Heaven, earth, and the myriad things arise from this—how great is the Dao’s function! People merely take petty erudition as wisdom and seek to align with the great Dao, yet the sage has already rejected it. Thus, the opening of this chapter first commands the abandonment of knowledge and thought, then reveals that one must reach a state where worldly gains and losses cannot affect it. Profound and towering, it begins and ends the myriad things, measures all without omission, and carves and polishes forms without artifice.

Things pass and draw from it without depletion, for it is inexhaustible and meets all demands. Is this not the Dao?

Within the Middle Kingdom there is one who is neither yin nor yang, whose words transcend life and death, unbound by their constraints. Merely existing as a human, possessing human form yet devoid of human passions—this is called returning to the origin, roaming in the primordial state of things.

Human life is but the coagulation of a single qi, though longevity and brevity differ in degree, all is but a fleeting moment—how then can one distinguish the right and wrong of Yao and Jie? Observe how even the lowly fruit and fern, though small, flourish in their kinds, each following its own order. The hierarchy of human relations, from noble to base, high to low, is likewise so.

Thus, the sage meets things and follows their nature without resistance; when they pass, they are forgotten, leaving no trace in the heart. Whether called harmony or accord, these are but wondrous responses to things, never departing from the bounds of Dao and virtue—this is what gives rise to emperors and kings, what the people rely upon.

The emergence and recession of things follow their constant principle, yet世 people cannot escape sorrow. They remain entangled in the artifices of nature; if one illuminates this with principle, the entanglement dissolves of itself. When the spirit departs, the body follows—this is the great return, what cause is there for grief?

The formless takes form and emerges into life; form returns to the formless and enters into death. This is not some abstruse matter approaching in obscurity, but a truth universally acknowledged. Yet when principle reaches its apex, words are forgotten; where words suffice, principle has not yet been attained. Thus, eloquence is inferior to silence, hearing is inferior to obstruction. In obstruction and silence lies the great attainment, and from this, the loss in eloquence and hearing becomes evident.

Measuring and sustaining the myriad things without exhaustion, the azure void illumines and disperses all. The manuscript of Liu Deyi reads "without omission," which carries greater meaning.

*End of the sixty-seventh chapter of the* Nan Hua Zhen Jing Yi Hai Mu Che Chun
*Beginning of the sixty-eighth scroll of the* Nan Hua Zhen Jing Yi Hai Zuan Wei

The Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin comments on *Knowing Northward Travels*, Third Chapter

Dongguo Zi asked Zhuangzi, "Where does the so-called Dao reside?"
Zhuangzi replied, "There is nowhere it does not reside."
Dongguo Zi said, "You must specify before it can be accepted."
Zhuangzi said, "It resides in the ant."
Dongguo Zi asked, "Why so lowly?"
Zhuangzi said, "It resides in the millet stalk."
Dongguo Zi asked, "Why even lower?"
Zhuangzi said, "It resides in the roof tile."
Dongguo Zi asked, "Why still lower?"
Zhuangzi said, "It resides in excrement and urine."
Dongguo Zi did not respond.

Zhuangzi said, "Your question fundamentally fails to reach the essence. When the swine inspector asked the market supervisor about treading on pigs to assess their fatness, the more he trod upon the harder-to-fatten parts, the better he understood the key to the pig’s fatness. Now, you ask where the Dao resides, yet with each increasingly base example, you clarify that the Dao does not flee from things. If you insist that the Dao must escape from things, then the Dao is not all-encompassing. If one wanders within the realm of ‘what is,’ one cannot achieve universal completion.

When we join in discussion and agree that the Dao is nowhere absent, we can then roam boundlessly with an open mind, all without deliberate action. Serene and still! Vast and clear! Harmonious and at ease! My will is empty, and I go nowhere without knowing where I arrive. Departing and returning, I know not where I rest; I have come and gone without knowing where it ends. Wandering in the boundless expanse, great knowledge enters yet knows not where it reaches its limit.

That which gives things their thingness has no boundary with things, yet things have boundaries—this is what we call the boundary of things. The boundaryless boundary is the boundary of the unbounded. We speak of fullness and emptiness, growth and decline, yet that which brings about fullness and emptiness is not itself fullness or emptiness; that which brings about growth and decline is not itself growth or decline; that which brings about root and branch is not itself root or branch; that which brings about accumulation and dispersal is not itself accumulation or dispersal."

Guo Xiang’s commentary: "To point to its form and substance, saying there is nowhere the Dao does not reside, yet still asking this, is to fail to reach the essence. The market supervisor’s method of treading on pigs to know their fatness lies in treading more upon the harder-to-fatten parts to grasp the essentials of the pig’s fatness. Now, asking where the Dao resides and descending to increasingly base examples makes clear that the Dao does not flee from things. If one insists that the Dao must escape from things, then the Dao is not all-encompassing. If one wanders within the realm of ‘what is,’ one cannot achieve universal completion.

When we join in discussion and agree that the Dao is nowhere absent, we can then roam boundlessly with an open mind—this is all without deliberate action. Empty and serene, the will is empty, and thus there is nowhere it does not go; hence, one knows not where it arrives. If there is going, then principle has not yet stirred while the will has already been startled. Yet going and coming do not depend on knowledge; it is not that there is no going and coming. Going and coming are the natural constant principle—how could they have an end?

‘Boundless expanse’ refers to vast emptiness. Great knowledge wanders in the vast emptiness, following the course of transformations without restraint, hence knowing no limit. That which gives things their thingness is no-thing, while things are themselves things—thus they are obscure! Things have boundaries, so they do not obscure one another; this is the true boundary. The boundaryless means that though there is the name of ‘giving things their thingness,’ it merely clarifies that things are themselves things. Yet that which gives things their thingness is ultimately no-thing—where then is its boundary? Having clarified that which gives things their thingness is no-thing, and that things cannot be themselves by themselves, then who is the doer? All is suddenly and naturally so.

Lü Huiqing’s commentary: "The ant has knowledge yet is most minute; the millet stalk has no knowledge yet has life; the roof tile has no life yet has form; excrement and urine have form yet are foul and decayed. If the Dao can be in such things, then it is clear the Dao is nowhere absent. To expect the Dao to reside in these four is to grasp its essence; to deem them increasingly base and question further is to fail to reach the essence. The method of treading on pigs—each descent reveals more—so if one expects the Dao to descend further, is this not increasingly far from its essence? Yet to insist that the Dao must escape from things is not the way to understand that the Dao is nowhere absent.

Though the four examples differ, none fully embodies the Dao’s essence, just as words may be all-encompassing yet their meaning is one. Wandering in the Palace of Nothing-What-Is and finding agreement, how could these four not be the Dao? Though the myriad things arise together, if we join in non-action, then in serenity, vastness, harmony, and ease, all return to their root, empty and still.

If my will does not chase after things, then I go nowhere without knowing where I arrive; departing and returning, I know not where I rest; coming and going, I know not where it ends—this is the Dao’s never having had things, and things’ never having been the Dao! Thus, wandering in the boundless expanse, great knowledge enters yet knows not where it reaches its limit. From this, we know that which gives things their thingness has no boundary with things; great and small cannot be distinguished.

Things with boundaries are what we call the boundary of things—they are not that which gives things their thingness. The boundaryless boundary is the boundary of the unbounded, like the formless form and the form that is formless. Fullness and emptiness are things; that which brings about fullness and emptiness is the Dao. The same applies to growth and decline, root and branch, accumulation and dispersal. Then who brings about the millet stalk, the ant, the roof tile, excrement and urine? Who is it?"

Du’s commentary: "The more noble and exalted, the farther from the Dao; the baser and lower, the closer to the Dao. The world often overlooks the lowly and base, not realizing that seeking the Dao is closest here. This aligns with the Chan saying that ‘the Buddha is at the head of the dung heap.’

The market supervisor’s method of treading on pigs to know their fatness lies in treading more upon the harder-to-fatten parts to grasp the essentials. Now, asking where the Dao resides and descending to increasingly base examples makes clear that the Dao does not flee from things. If one insists that the Dao must escape from base things, then the Dao is not all-encompassing.

The supreme Dao disperses and resides in things, becoming principle; great words disperse and reside in people, becoming teaching. All-encompassing, it is not lacking; universal, it is not partial; complete, it is without bias. This illustrates that the Dao is nowhere absent. Though the three names differ, their reality is one."

Still and serene, this describes its essence aligning with the heart;
Vast and clear, this describes the heart aligning with qi;
Harmonized and spaced, this describes qi aligning with spirit;
Void my will, and spirit aligns with emptiness.

Thus, it goes forth without awareness, and what should arrive arrives of itself;
Coming and going without knowing where it halts, it halts of itself;
I traverse to and fro without knowing its end—this is the principle of spontaneity.

Therefore, wandering in the boundless expanse of the empty wilds, great knowledge enters therein yet knows no limit—this is the power to master all things. One who masters all things becomes one with things, without boundary.

Boundary is the shore’s edge. Where things have boundaries, that is called the boundary of things. As the Śākya says: "The anterior and posterior boundaries"—this is the boundary of what has no boundary. The master of all things achieves this, so though there is boundary, it is as if there were none. The bounded belongs to things; the unbound resides in the self. Having clarified that the master of all things has no boundary, and that things cannot master themselves, then who is the agent? All occurs suddenly and of itself.

Fullness and emptiness, decline and decay, root and branch, accumulation and dispersal—all these lie in that; what have I to do with them? With an empty heart, one merely observes the transformations of yin and yang.

Master Bixu notes: "It fundamentally fails to grasp the essence." The question posed misses its fundamental source, hence the analogy of the market supervisor treading on pigs—if there is flesh beneath the wrist, one knows the pig is fat above. The body of the Dao is empty and boundless; where is it not present? Since it does not flee from things, neither do things flee from it. The Dao makes no distinction between purity and filth; words, too, transcend the coarse and the refined. Thus, it pervades the Great Clarity and extends to all things, universally nurturing them—like the subtle traces of Fuxi and Shennong, which elude definition, merging into oneness.

Roaming the palace of "nothing whatsoever," if there were something, it would not be all-encompassing. Discussing unity, if there were an end, it would not be universal. Acting together without contrivance, if there were contrivance, it would not be complete.

Stillness, vastness, harmony, and spacing—these are the daily practices of the Daoist, merely emptying the will. Unaware of where it reaches, it is all-encompassing; unaware of where it halts, it is universal; unaware of its end, it is complete. Wandering in boundless expanse without knowing its limit—this transcends knowledge and thought.

The body of the Dao has no boundary; in transforming things, it too has no boundary. Boundaries exist in things, not in the Dao. The unbound is without boundary, thus it can contain all boundaries. If it had boundaries, it could not contain the boundless.

The Dao has names of fullness and emptiness, yet lacks their reality; things have processes of decline and decay, yet lack their principle. The Dao’s transformations have root and branch, yet its body transcends root and branch; things have forms of accumulation and dispersal, yet their nature transcends accumulation and dispersal. From this, we know that Dao and things never flee from one another, and their wondrous function is nowhere absent.

Master Fu Zhai says: "Essence is the root. Your question does not reach the root, hence my words descend further. If you cling to fixed notions, the ultimate principles of things will all elude you." The three terms—all-encompassing, universal, complete—illustrate that things have no coarse or fine; their principle is one.

The palace of "nothing whatsoever" reveals the will’s freedom from fixed notions. Discussing unity, if there were coarse and fine, how could there be no end? Stillness, clarity, harmony, and spacing all describe the wondrousness of non-action. To investigate this to the point of emptiness and oneness is to fulfill my aspiration—hence, "void my will." *Yi* here is read as *already*.

Having no going forth, how could there be an arrival? Though there is coming and going, there is no halting. I traverse to and fro yet know not its end, only seeing it wander into the realm of great knowledge without limit.

Great knowledge is the Dao’s oneness with things, transforming together—what does not become a thing is able to master all things. Not transformed with things, there are boundaries and limits—this is the boundary of things. Reaching the limitless is to be unbound by the boundaries of things. Attaining the unbound is to grasp the boundary of the unbound. The fullness and emptiness, flourishing and decay, root and branch, gathering and dispersal of things all seem to proceed without end—this is the boundary of the unbound, the unbound of boundaries.

The Dao in the world is like water in the earth, its body and nature pervading and universal. Here, the Dao is said to reside in tiles and mortises, pointing to its lowest manifestations. Extending by analogy, one knows it pervades all places—what thing does not possess this Dao? Yet human capacities differ, and perceptions vary. The sage sees the Dao and not things; the common person sees things and not the Dao. It is the obstruction of things, not the Dao’s presence or absence.

Your question is crude and fails to grasp the Dao’s true essence, falling short even of the pig-treader who knows the essentials of fatness. If you claim the Dao flees from base things, it cannot be all-encompassing, universal, or complete. Merging these three and roaming the realm of "nothing whatsoever," how could there be any limit?

The states of stillness, clarity, harmony, and spacing ultimately return to quiescence. My will goes forth without knowing its destination—like spirit wandering the eight directions, where intent arrives instantly—even to the point of not knowing where it halts, not knowing its end, all describing the inexhaustible function of this Dao.

The master of all things is the Dao. To be without boundary with things is to give life to the myriad beings. Yet things have boundaries—their own limits—this is what is called boundary. How could the Dao have boundaries? The boundary of the unbound is the Dao dispersing into things. The unbound of boundaries is things returning whole to the Dao.

The Dao disperses into things, and transformation follows naturally, like a source flowing into streams.

Whole things return to the Dao, yet the return is difficult—like streams flowing back to the source, compelled by necessity. If one awakens to the fact that what fills and empties is not truly filling and emptying, that what accumulates and disperses is not truly accumulating and dispersing, then how can one know the extremity of necessity without returning to the natural?

Kehé Gān and Shennong studied together under Old Dragon Ji. Shennong, secluded in his humble abode, shut his door and slept through the day. At noon, Kehé Gān pushed open the door and entered, saying: "Old Dragon is dead!" Shennong, leaning on his staff, rose abruptly, then cast it aside with a burst of laughter, saying: "Heaven knew my perversity and arrogance, so it cast me aside and let him die. Alas, Master! You died for the wild words I provoked!" Qin Gang, hearing this, remarked: "Those who embody the Dao are the ones upon whom the noble of the world depend. Yet even one who has grasped but a ten-thousandth part of a hair’s tip of the Dao still knew to conceal his wild words and die—how much more so for those who truly embody it!"

To see without form, to hear without sound—such is called the obscure and dark. This is how one speaks of the Dao, yet it is not the Dao. Then Tai Qing asked Yuan Qiong: "Do you know the Dao?" Yuan Qiong replied: "I do not know." He then asked Yuan Wei. Yuan Wei said: "I know the Dao." Tai Qing asked: "Does your knowledge of the Dao have a pattern?" Yuan Wei replied: "It does." "What is its pattern?" Yuan Wei said: "I know the Dao can be noble, can be base, can be gathered, can be dispersed—this is the pattern by which I know it." Tai Qing then asked Yuan Shi: "If so, then between Yuan Qiong’s not-knowing and Yuan Wei’s knowing, which is right and which is wrong?" Yuan Shi said: "Not-knowing is profound; knowing is shallow. Not-knowing is internal; knowing is external."

Thereupon Tai Qing sighed and said: "Is not-knowing then knowing? Is knowing then not-knowing? Who knows the knowing of not-knowing?" Yuan Shi said: "The Dao cannot be heard—what is heard is not it. The Dao cannot be seen—what is seen is not it. The Dao cannot be spoken—what is spoken is not it. Do you understand that the shaper of forms is itself formless? The Dao should not be named."

Yuan Shi continued: "One who answers when asked about the Dao does not know it. Even the one who asks does not hear the Dao. The Dao is without question, and questions yield no answer. To question without questioning is to exhaust inquiry; to answer without answering is to lack inner attainment. Responding to exhausted inquiry with inner emptiness—such a one neither observes the cosmos outwardly nor knows the Great Beginning inwardly. Thus, he does not pass beyond Kunlun nor wander the Great Void."

Guo’s commentary: He awoke to the fact that death is not worth alarm, so he cast aside his staff and laughed. From Jianwu downward, all took the ultimate words as madness and did not believe them. Those who embody the Dao are the lords of humanity, yet the Dao cannot be attained through words—it lies in self-realization. Even the obscure and dark are not the Dao; the clarity of the Dao is beyond naming. True attainment does not come from knowing but from obscurity. Only by dwelling in the realm of no-hearing and no-seeing does one reach it. Form shapes itself, yet the shaper of forms is ultimately nothing. To name the Dao is to name nothing, for names cannot capture it.

Not-knowing leads to questioning; without response, inquiry yields nothing, so in the end, nothing is heard. Without question, without answer—this is the abandonment of learning and teaching, the return to the natural. Yet to press with questions is to demand the empty, to impose the unreal upon what is truly without substance. As for those who roam the vastness of heaven and earth, traversing the distant void to enter the obscure and dark—they do not respond, and that is all.

Lü’s commentary: Those who embody the Dao are the ones upon whom the noble of the world depend, for sagehood and kingship alike are tied to it. Yet even one who has grasped but a ten-thousandth part of a hair’s tip of the Dao—whose essence is so refined it cannot be divided, what is called "attaining the One"—still knew to conceal his wild words and die. How much more so for one who embodies the Dao, where the myriad transformations have never begun to have an end? Old Dragon Ji concealed his wild words and died precisely because the Dao, as a thing, cannot be reached by sight or hearing. What people discuss as the obscure and dark is not the Dao, for the Dao cannot be discussed through words. Tai Qing, hearing that discussing the Dao is not the Dao, sought answers from Yuan Qiong, yet Yuan Qiong did not know. Yuan Wei was not originally Yuan Wei; he knew that what was not sufficient to be called "knowing" was not knowing, and thus he knew it. Otherwise, all would be the same mystery.

To know that the Dao can be noble or base, gathered or dispersed, is still bound by patterns. Yuan Shi, however, reached the very origin of the beginning, and thus knew that not-knowing is profound while knowing is shallow; not-knowing is internal while knowing is external. Tai Qing sighed in the middle, saying: "Not-knowing is knowing—Yuan Qiong is right. Knowing is not-knowing—Yuan Wei is right. Who knows the knowing of not-knowing? Only Yuan Shi." The Dao cannot be heard, seen, or spoken. What is heard, seen, or spoken—who is that? Only after form arises does name come. To know the shaper of forms is to know the formless—this is why the Dao should not be named. Thus, what is heard is not hearing, what is seen is not seeing, what is spoken is not speaking.

To answer when asked is not to know the Dao. Even the one who asks has not heard the Dao. The Dao is without question, for the questioner cannot attain it. To answer without answering is to lack response, for the responder cannot attain it. All is as if nothing had ever begun. To question without questioning is to exhaust inquiry, yet one does not know that it is exhausted and so questions in vain. To answer without answering is to lack inner attainment, for one has not grasped the absence of things within. To meet exhausted inquiry with inner emptiness is to neither observe the cosmos outwardly nor know the Great Beginning inwardly—thus, one is not bound by time or place.

Beyond Kunlun’s bounds, beyond the Great Void’s expanse—only then does one know the height of form, and that heaven, earth, and the ten thousand things are contained within it.

*Dúzhù* notes: To embody the Dao is to become one with it, not merely to study or comprehend it. Without form, without sound—this is called "level" and "subtle."

When people discuss it, they call it "obscure obscurity." Yet to speak of the Dao in such terms is still not the Dao. What can be valued or debased, gathered or dispersed—these are the Dao’s manifestations. What cannot be valued or debased, gathered or dispersed—this is the Dao’s essence. To speak not, to know not, is to perceive its root; thus it is said, "Who knows the knowledge of the unknowing?"

The Dao is without sound, without color, without name—thus it cannot be seen, heard, or spoken. Yet where sounds, colors, and names exist, knowing that forms are formless reveals that the Dao should not be named. Therefore, the questioner is fundamentally mistaken, and the responder is likewise not correct. One who asks about the Dao has not yet known it—how much less one who answers? Exhausted inquiry met with inner emptiness is better than questioning and responding. To answer with non-answering, to respond to non-questioning—is this not the work of the spirit? Thus, outwardly not observing the vastness of the cosmos, inwardly not knowing the subtlety of the Great Beginning, not passing beyond Kunlun is to transcend earth, not roaming the Great Void is to depart from heaven—who but the supremely spiritual can attain this?

*Bìxū* notes: All under heaven’s noble ones are bound to it, for the Dao is the teacher of a hundred kings. Now, if even the minutest detail of the Dao is known to be hidden, how much more its fullness! The profound and obscure lie beyond the reach of ears and eyes. To discuss the Dao in such terms is still not the Dao; thus, when Taiqing asked about non-exhaustion, non-exhaustion replied with "not knowing." To know is to be limited. Again, he asked about non-action, and non-action replied that to know it is to be noble when attaining the Dao, base when losing it; to hold it is restraint, to release it is dispersion—these are the Dao’s manifestations. Not knowing is profound and internal—this is the nameless constant Dao, the subtlety of principle. Knowing is shallow and external—this is the named "Dao that can be spoken," the entanglement of affairs. To engage in discourse when questioned is to stray into description—how can one know the subtle? Thus, one who asks about the Dao has not heard it; to have heard is not to ask. Non-questioning and non-answering are like the waters of the Zī and Miǎn—easy to discuss, yet their sweet and bitter tastes are hard to convey. To question without knowing is non-questioning; to question non-questioning is to be confounded by principle. To answer without knowing is non-answering; to answer non-answering is to lack inner attainment. To illuminate with inner emptiness, to respond to confounded questioning, is like debating the scattering of years with the blind or discussing tones with the deaf—how can one know the vastness of the cosmos, the solitude of the Great Beginning, the loftiness of Kunlun, the remoteness of the Great Void?

*Yōngzhāi* says: One who embodies the Dao becomes the source to which all under heaven’s noble ones return. Now, if even Shennong, who had not yet perceived the Dao, knew to conceal the wild words of Old Dragon upon his death, how much more one who embodies the Dao and is one with Old Dragon? "Wild" here means "great," for the Dao resides in non-speech; to conceal one’s words is thus to preserve the Dao. The Dao is without form or sound, beyond seeing or hearing. To discuss it with others, calling it "obscure obscurity," is still not the Dao—this is the meaning of "the speaker does not know." Form and sound exist; obscurity does not. To know existence as non-existence is not as good as making both existence and non-existence non-existent. Thus, Shennong’s words still do not reach the Dao. Nobility and baseness, union and dispersion—these are the Dao’s measurable aspects. The "knowledge of the unknowing" is the subtlety beyond naming. That forms are formless is to say that non-thingness can thing all things. The Dao should not be named, nor should it be opposed. To name the Dao is to set name and Dao in opposition, departing from their original truth. The Dao is fundamentally non-questioning; to question and answer is to depart from it, and the questioner’s inquiry is likewise not the Dao. "Exhausted inquiry" means one’s understanding is limited to questioning, clinging to words in pursuit of knowledge. "Inner emptiness" means the heart has not attained the Dao; if it had, one would not respond. This chapter clarifies that the Dao is so vast it cannot be exhausted by question and answer. Sages and worthies, in this regard, remain silent to the end. Humans dwell among the ten thousand things, no more than a hair’s tip within them. To embody the Dao is likewise so. Thus, when Old Dragon died, Shennong arose to deceive—what *Taotang Diao* calls "embodying the Dao" refers precisely to Old Dragon, hidden yet manifest. The world takes what lies beyond seeing and hearing as the obscurity of the Dao, but this is not to know the Dao. They see the Dao’s nothingness but have not yet attained the nothingness of nothingness.

Qin Qing asked about the boundless, but the boundless cannot be known. He then asked about non-action, and non-action is merely the reckoning of knowing the Dao. Next, he asked about the beginningless, and the beginningless definitively distinguishes the depth and shallowness, the inner and outer of knowing and not knowing—this echoes the Yellow Emperor’s words at the chapter’s outset: "Not knowing is true; forgetting comes next; knowing is farthest from it." Thereupon, Tai Qing, centered yet deluded, claimed to know the knowledge of not-knowing, asserting that one need not seek knowledge to naturally accord with the Dao. The beginningless then awakened to the fact that the Dao cannot be grasped through hearing or seeing, through words or forms.

That which takes form from the formless—just as the living arise from life—means the Dao cannot be named. Thus, both questioner and respondent have yet to hear the Dao; if they had heard it, they would not ask, nor would they respond. To question where the Dao admits no question is to exhaust the Dao through questioning. To respond where there is no response is to lack inner grounding—how then could one know that which is greatest, earliest, highest, and most vast?

"Centered yet deluded" (*zhong er qi*)—the explanation does not cohere, and the meaning should instead be *yin* (印), as in the *Book of Songs*: "Gazing up at the vast sky" (*zhan yin hao tian*), where *yin* is interchangeable with *yang* (仰), a scribal error. *The Ocean of Meanings in the True Scripture of Southern Florescence*, Scroll Sixty-Eight, concludes. *The Ocean of Meanings in the True Scripture of Southern Florescence*, Scroll Sixty-Nine.

The Wulin Daoist Chu Boxiu’s *Knowing the Northern Journey*, Chapter Four

Guangyao asked Wu You, “Master, do you *have*? Or do you *have not*?” Guangyao could not frame his question, so he observed Wu You’s appearance—profoundly empty, utterly void. All day he looked but saw nothing, listened but heard nothing, grasped but held nothing.

Guangyao said, “This is perfection! Who could attain such a state? I can *have nothing*, yet I cannot *have no-having*. And if one *is* Wu You, how could one reach this?”

Guo’s commentary: This expresses the meaning of cutting off learning. When one severs it through the Dao, then the learner returns to the root. Thus, the best learning is precisely non-learning.

Lü’s commentary: Guangyao is the radiance of the great expanse, shining and illuminating. Wu You is without illumination. This is why Guangyao cannot discern whether he *has* or *has not*, and why his question remains unanswered. Profoundly empty, utterly void—beyond sight, hearing, or touch—this is what it means to be Wu You. Only because he *has nothing* is he Guangyao; because he cannot *have no-having*, he has not yet become Wu You. When one *is* Wu You, there is nowhere to reach—how could one attain this?

Yi Du’s commentary: Guangyao is the name for luminous knowing. Wu You is one who embodies the Dao. To embody the Dao is to be beyond seeking through sound, form, or name. Yet these three merge into one—its essence is nowhere absent, nowhere distinct. Thus, Guangyao marvels, “Who could attain this?”—meaning it admits no further addition.

Bixu’s commentary: Guangyao symbolizes inner illumination. Wu You symbolizes the wondrous root. Inner illumination embodies the wondrous root. If one says it *has*, it is profoundly empty; if one says it *has not*, it *has nothing* yet cannot *have no-having*. To discuss *non-being* while debating *being* is to multiply endlessly; to sever *being* and cut off *non-being*—how then could one awaken to the wondrous? Subtle indeed! Guangyao’s question is the great purport of *Knowing the Northern Journey*.

Yongzhai’s note: “You can *have nothing*, yet you cannot *have no-having*”—this saying is most wondrous. “Cannot *have no-having*” means I still dwell within the word *nothing*, am possessed by the word *nothing*—how could one reach profound emptiness? The *Sutra of Perfect Enlightenment* says: “To speak of *non-enlightenment* is likewise so.” *Non-enlightenment* may be called wondrous, yet it is still deemed incomplete—its meaning is the same as here.

The old smith of Great Ma, though eighty years old, never missed a hair’s breadth in hammering hooks. Great Ma said, “Is it skill? Or is it the Dao?” The smith replied, “Your servant has his *guard*.”

The servant, at twenty years of age, delighted in forging hooks, seeing nothing else in the world—nothing but hooks did he observe. What he employed was but the semblance of non-employment, thereby perpetually securing its use. How much more so for that which employs nothing at all! What thing does not draw sustenance from it?

Guo’s annotation: In grasping the weight of hammer and hook, he discerned the subtlest discrepancy in hair’s breadth. When all is held in primordial embrace, things come forth and all respond.

Lü’s annotation: Non-employment and employment are one—only the Dao is thus.

Yi Du’s annotation: Great Ma was the Grand Marshal of Chu, who had a craftsman skilled in forging silver belt-hooks. Though aged, his art remained precise, so the Marshal suspected him of either skill or the Dao. His reply—“not the Dao”—meant that with inner steadfastness, external things could not disturb him. From youth he had loved this craft, seeing nothing else, observing nothing but the belt-hook. This was the source of his mastery. For when the mind is fixed here, it is not fixed there; thus this grows ever more refined. What is employed borrows from what is not employed, thereby perpetually securing its use. That which employs nothing is the Dao. What thing does not draw sustenance from it? Skill lies in the precision of knowing—if even this precision is thus, how much more the precision of the Dao?

Bixu’s annotation: The Dao resides in steadfastness alone. Without observation or guard, all is without use. Whatever is employed here is not employed there—what is employed borrows from what is not employed. Borrowing non-employment as employment, one perpetually secures its use. He who governs the myriad things employs nothing, thus his use draws sustenance.

Yongzhai says: “Observing nothing but the hook” is what was earlier called “knowing only the cicada’s wing.” Employment is skill; non-employment is the Dao’s spontaneity. That which employs nothing is the Dao’s acting without acting. I employ the marvel of non-employment in skill, thereby perpetually securing its use—how much more the Dao’s non-acting and not non-acting! What in the world does not depend on it?

Guangyao’s analogy speaks of one learning the Dao, whose mind’s blossoms first awaken to illumination—without fixed patterns, it diminishes to non-acting. Naturally, he cannot ask questions, for he abides in soundless emptiness, where seeing and hearing grasp nothing. Guangyao, just awakened, marvels at the Dao’s perfection: “What cultivation brings one to this?” Like the River Earl gazing at the Sea Lord, he stands in awe.

“You can *have nothing*” means knowing all dharmas are empty, thus this Dao alone is clear. Yet one still sits within *nothing*, not yet reaching the realm of double mystery. Now that you have attained *non-having*, how did you come to this? Deeply he admires what he cannot attain.

In forging hooks, one sees nothing else, employs nothing—this is what the world calls “non-employment in use.” Observing nothing but the hook is the precision of one’s own employment—this is what is called “having nothing in use.” As for non-employment, is this not the very meaning of *nothingness*?

All things under heaven are born of *having*; *having* is born of *nothingness*. *Having* and *nothingness* reveal each other, so what thing does not draw sustenance from them? *Nothingness* as a thing is soundless, empty, most difficult to describe—yet the Dao’s marvelous establishment, its most divine operation, truly depends on this. Worldly people cling to *having*, not knowing that it arises from *nothingness* and returns to *nothingness*. Thus the perfected often establish teachings to shatter worldly attachments, revealing the beginning and end of the myriad things. If one truly stills the mind to seek it, forgets to grasp it, all existence becomes empty, and the One Reality alone appears—then one knows that “employing the semblance of non-employment to perpetually secure its use” is no empty word. When it comes to *non-having*, all texts concur, but upon careful examination of the scriptural intent, it should be *nothingness*—the preceding text clarifies this.

Ran Qiu asked Confucius: “Can one know what existed before heaven and earth?”
Confucius said: “One can. The past is like the present.”
Ran Qiu, having asked amiss, withdrew. The next day he returned and said: “Yesterday I asked whether one could know what existed before heaven and earth. You said, ‘One can. The past is like the present.’ Yesterday I was clear, but today I am confused. May I ask what this means?”
Confucius said: “Yesterday’s clarity was received by the spirit; today’s confusion comes from seeking it with what is not spirit. There is no past, no present, no beginning, no end. Can there be grandchildren before there are children?”
Ran Qiu did not respond.
Confucius said: “Enough! No answer is fitting. One does not use life to give birth to death, nor death to give birth to life. Do life and death depend on each other? All share the same body. Is there something that existed before heaven and earth? That which gives rise to things is not a thing. Things cannot emerge before things—yet there are things. There are things, yet *nothingness* remains. The sage’s love for others never ceases, for he takes this as his model.”

Guo’s annotation: Confucius speaks of heaven and earth as ever-abiding, even before their existence. With an empty mind awaiting destiny, the spirit receives it. To seek through thought only leads to greater confusion. Not only can *nothingness* not transform into *having*, but *having* also cannot transform into *nothingness*. Thus *having* as a thing, though it undergoes a thousand changes and ten thousand transformations, cannot become *nothingness* even once. Therefore, from ancient times before existence, it has always abided. “Children and grandchildren” means generation after generation without end. The dead are simply transformed by death, not given death by the living; the living are simply transformed by life. Life and death do not depend on each other—they transform independently, each forming its own body. Who, then, existed before things? If I say yin and yang existed before things, yin and yang are themselves things—who, then, existed before yin and yang? If I say nature existed before things, nature is simply the self-so of things. If I say the supreme Dao existed before things, the Dao is the ultimate *nothingness*—if it is already *nothingness*, what could exist before it? Who, then, existed before things?

Yet there remains something—*nothingness* already being so—this reveals the self-so of things, not that anything causes them to be so. The sage who loves others without end likewise draws from this self-so, thus their kindness flows through a hundred generations without ceasing.

**Lü’s Annotation:** Who named Heaven and Earth? To know how Heaven and Earth are named is to know how they came to be; to know how they came to be is to recognize that before Heaven and Earth existed, it was already as it is now. The spirit first receives this—not through thought, but by attainment. And yet it seeks for the unspiritual; this is why it is unspiritual.

From ancient to modern, from beginning to end, all things arise in mutual dependence—without dependence, all would be *nothingness*. If one grasps this, then one knows what is meant by "before Heaven and Earth existed." If what existed before Heaven and Earth can be known, then one may also know that before descendants existed, there were already descendants. To demand a response is to wish that one not seek with a mind already fixed. For the mind conceives of life and only then can it conceive of death; the mind conceives of death and only then can it conceive of life—this is the error of seeking with a mind already fixed.

Do life and death depend on each other? The body’s essence is without dependence. Where there is dependence or lack of dependence, each has its own unity. To know that life and death form a single body—how then could there be something that existed before Heaven and Earth? That which existed before Heaven and Earth would itself be a thing that gives rise to things. But that which gives rise to things is not a thing—thus no thing can emerge before things. What is called "the undifferentiated thing that existed before Heaven and Earth" is merely the existence of a thing; the existence of a thing is already *nothingness*. It speaks of that which never yet had a thing.

The sage’s love for others, which never ends, likewise draws from this. This is how Qian’s *power* governs Heaven, and how the noble person embodies it to lead others.

**Yi Du’s Annotation:** Can what existed before Heaven and Earth truly be known? By inferring from what exists after Heaven and Earth, it can be known. *Xunzi* says: "The Way of the hundred kings is present in the later kings; a thousand years ago is like today." Thus Confucius replied to Ran Qiu: "The ancient is like the present." At first, Ran Qiu asked with an empty mind—emptiness gives rise to spirit, so he was enlightened. Later, upon hearing the words, he failed to comprehend, for his mind was obstructed by something, and the unspiritual took residence, so he became confused. Confucius again taught him that there is no ancient or modern, no beginning or end—speaking in terms of spirit. Before descendants exist, one should not hastily claim to possess them. Originally, there was no death—death arises from life; originally, there was no life—life arises from death. Life and death each have their own unity and do not depend on each other.

The Great Simplicity is before qi is seen. It is neither form nor qi, and thus it can give rise to things. That which gives rise to things is not a thing. If one takes it to be a thing, though it emerges before things, it cannot precede things—just as the existence of a thing cannot precede itself. The existence of a thing is already without limit; the sage’s approach to things, though not imposing love upon them, ensures that love never ends—this is drawn from the same principle.

**Bixu’s Annotation:** To ask about what existed before Heaven and Earth is to clarify what preceded things. The answer—"the ancient is like the present"—is to observe the self through the self. "Enlightened" refers to youthful intelligence; "confused" refers to midlife dullness. The spirit first receives this by concentrating qi and harmonizing softness, preserving the uncarved simplicity of the Dao. It also seeks for the unspiritual, desiring to refine the coarse through beauty. If the old were like the young, there would be no ancient or modern; if life were like death, there would be no beginning or end. Having a child leads to having a grandchild—this is the principle of mutual arising. It clarifies that the existence of ancient and modern disperses, and that deliberate action without accumulation cannot depart from creation. One does not bring about death through the existence of life, nor does one bring about life through the existence of death. It is clear that the living live by themselves, the dead die by themselves—death does not arise from life, nor does life arise from death. This speaks of their original lack of dependence. Each has its own unity, for there is no separate Way.

Heaven and Earth are the greatest of independent transformations. If there were something that preceded them, it would be things preceding themselves—not something that existed before Heaven and Earth. Yet things and Heaven and Earth each have their own unity. Though all are things, each thing arises on its own; the earlier thing is not the later thing, just as children and grandchildren are each distinct. Thus each thing has its own Supreme Ultimate. To say that things come after is to say that later things precede earlier ones—just as the existence of a thing is already without limit. The sage treats the people as straw dogs, yet the people’s love for the sage never ends—this is because the sage does not precede things.

**Yong Qi’s Annotation:** Spirit is the awareness within me; the unspiritual is when the numinous awareness is clouded by qi. Formerly enlightened, the empty and numinous awareness was present, so it could receive; now confused, the empty and numinous awareness is absent, so it seeks again. "No ancient or modern, no beginning or end" speaks of the principle of creation—endless arising, like people having descendants, which is known without waiting for them to exist.

"Not responding" means not speaking further. As soon as there is the word "life," there is the word "death"—this is to create death only after life exists. As soon as there is the word "death," there is the word "life"—the meaning is the same. Life and death depend on each other, yet they are one body. "Body" here means principle. That which gives rise to things is not a thing. What is not a thing emerges before Heaven and Earth and cannot be named as a thing. Once named as a thing, it cannot be said to exist before Heaven and Earth. This is to be a thing, hence it is said that no thing can emerge before things. "Just as there is a thing"—this is one phrase. Once there is a thing, then things arise without limit.

The sage’s love for others is visible in its effects. That it endures without ceasing is because what is drawn from is the existence of a thing, yet it does not recognize that what gives rise to things is not a thing.

Ran Qiu’s question came with the force of a thunderclap splitting mountains, yet the Master answered it with such ease that Ran Qiu lost his footing and withdrew. From this, the measure of the sage and the worthy may be known. Though Ran Qiu had ascended the Master’s hall, his learning remained bound to the ways of the world, so that what he had seen and heard did not extend beyond the realm of the senses. How could he have known beforehand what existed before Heaven and Earth? No wonder he asked in astonishment.

The human body models itself on Heaven and Earth. What existed before Heaven and Earth is none other than the original nature of this body. To know the original nature of this body is to know what existed before Heaven and Earth; to know what existed before Heaven and Earth is merely to extend backward from what has come after. The sage holds fast to the ancient to steer the present, and thus can surely extend the present to illuminate the ancient—how could his knowledge be limited to a mere hundred generations?

Heaven and Earth are but tiny things within the vastness of space, the greatest of all things with form. Form arises from the formless, and in the end must return to dissolution. Yet humans, with their fleeting lives and limited vision, cannot witness this—like summer insects that know nothing of ice. The spirit first receives it, knowing the spirit as spirit. Yet it also seeks for those who are not spirit, not knowing that within what is not spirit, the spirit abides.

In the past, you were bright and clear, using knowledge to seek what is called spirit—this is the spirit first receiving it. Now, you are dim and obscure, having heard the Way and forgotten your knowledge—this is the spirit abiding within what is not spirit. Why must you seek further? Let him turn his gaze inward to the source of the mind, attaining what was originally attained, neither bright nor dim. Beyond ancient and present, life and death cannot bind him. Not clinging to life as life, not using death to fix life—this is called "transformation alone," which depends on nothing, just as the previous breath is not the present breath, and the former flame is not the later flame.

Returning to the question: Is there something that existed before Heaven and Earth? It means only the Dao dwells before Heaven and Earth; no thing existed before Heaven and Earth. That which gives rise to things is not a thing. The Dao generates Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things, and cannot be named as a thing. Once a thing emerges, it enters the realm of form and instruments, and can no longer be said to exist before things. It is because there are things that from one arise ten thousand, a profusion of forms constantly before our eyes. Few can stand firm and independent, untroubled by them. Thus, the endlessness of human and things arises from the endlessness of creation. The sage’s boundless love extends to all things, yet even this cannot prevent the scattering of simplicity into fragmentation. The governance of the great antiquity, uncontrived, cannot be restored. To return to the uncontrived governance of great antiquity, must one not seek what existed before one’s own Heaven?

The character *you* in the classic text is doubtful; it should likely be *by*. Yan Yuan asked Confucius: "I have heard you say, 'Do not send off, do not welcome.' May I ask about its wandering?" Confucius replied: "The people of old transformed externally but remained untransformed internally. The people of today transform internally but remain untransformed externally. Those who transform with things are one with those who do not transform. At peace with transformation and non-transformation, at peace with mingling with them, they must be without excess.

The parks of Xiwei, the gardens of the Yellow Emperor, the halls of Youyu, the chambers of Tang and Wu—these were where the noble ones of old, such as the masters of the Ru and Mo schools, clashed with their differing views. How much more so with the people of today! The sage dwells among things without harming them. Not harming things, things cannot harm him. Only one who is without harm can accompany others in sending off and welcoming.

Mountain forests! The wilds!"

Let me rejoice in this with boundless delight! Yet before the joy is complete, sorrow follows in its wake. When joy and sorrow come, I cannot resist them; when they depart, I cannot detain them. Alas! The people of this world are but travelers lodging in the realm of things. They know what they encounter but not what they do not; they know what they can do but not what they cannot. To be without knowledge and without ability—this is what no one can avoid. Yet to strive to avoid what no one can avoid—how tragic indeed!

The ultimate words transcend words; the ultimate actions transcend actions. To equalize what knowledge knows is but superficial. Guo’s commentary: Align the mind with form, and form transforms of itself. To use the mind to command form is to remain untransformed externally. To be ever without a fixed mind is to be one with the unchanging; being one with the unchanging, one can then transform with things. Whether transforming or not, all is entrusted to spontaneity—without a fixed mind, one allows things to transform of themselves, neither sending off nor welcoming, neither following nor resisting, but simply resting where they come to rest. Only by being without a fixed mind and entrusting all to transformation can one wander where the sages of old wandered. The sage is harmony. The masters of the Ru and Mo schools, whom the world finds hardest to harmonize—even one without a fixed mind can harmonize them, let alone those who approach this state!

Dwelling among things without harming them is the utmost compliance, which lies within me alone. Without a fixed mind, one attains the utmost compliance; with the utmost compliance, one can be without sending off or welcoming, and thus rise above them. Mountains and forests, wilds and marshes—these are no better than my own state, and so I delight in them without cause. Delighting without cause, one may also grieve without cause. Thus, what brings joy is not truly joy, and what brings sorrow is not truly sorrow.

The people of this world cannot sit in forgetfulness and find contentment within themselves, but instead lodge their joy and sorrow in external things, like travelers in a wayside inn. They know what they encounter but not what they do not; they know what they can do but not what they cannot. What they cannot do, they cannot force themselves to do—it is the same with ability. From this, we see that control does not lie with us; all is self-attainment. To attain through knowledge is to rely on learning, and thus remains shallow.

Lü’s commentary: The people of old transformed externally but remained untransformed internally; thus, they moved with things while preserving what could not be forgotten. The people of today transform internally, their minds conforming to things, yet remain untransformed externally, clinging to past norms without acknowledging their origins. Those who transform with things are one with those who do not. How can there be transformation or non-transformation? To have both transformation and non-transformation is not the way of non-transformation. How can one mingle with things if their actions are like a galloping horse that cannot be reined in? To be without excess is to neither send off nor welcome, but simply respond without concealment.

The parks of Xiwei, the gardens of the Yellow Emperor, the halls of Youyu, the chambers of Tang and Wu—these speak of an age of decline, where those who wandered grew fewer, and their dwellings grew narrower. The noble ones, such as the masters of the Ru and Mo schools, still clashed with their differing views. How much more so with the people of today! The sage dwells among things without harming them, allowing right and wrong to unfold in parallel, resting in the harmony of heaven. How could things harm him? Thus, though he accompanies others in sending off and welcoming, he alone wanders beyond such distinctions.

The people of this world are enslaved by external things, and so joy and sorrow find their way in. They abandon mountains and forests, the wilds and marshes, yet before my joy is complete, sorrow follows, and the two alternate without cease. Their coming cannot be resisted; their going cannot be stopped. Thus, the body is but a lodging for things, like a traveler in an inn. They know what they encounter but not what they do not; when they encounter, they coincide with things; when they do not, they part from them. They know what they can do but not what they cannot; when they can, they are enslaved by things; when they cannot, they enslave things. To be without knowledge and without ability is what no one can avoid—it is an inherent part of being. Yet to strive to avoid what no one can avoid is to lose one’s nature profoundly. How tragic!

The ultimate words transcend words; the ultimate actions transcend actions. To equalize what knowledge knows in order to avoid what no one can avoid—even if one knows this, it remains shallow.

Yi Du’s commentary: Those who transform externally but not internally allow their form to follow things while preserving inner constancy. Those who transform internally but not externally allow their minds to follow things while their form remains unchanged. Those who transform with things allow their form to change while their mind does not—thus, they are one with the unchanging. Whether things transform or not, one entrusts them to spontaneity, harmonizing with them without resistance, allowing each to fulfill its nature without excess or deficiency.

Parks are for hunting; gardens are for cultivation, narrower than parks. Halls are narrower than gardens; chambers are narrower than halls. This speaks of the constriction of human nature and destiny as the world declines, unable to return to simplicity, forcing its vast dwelling into narrowness, shaped by the times.

Are the sages truly superior or inferior? The teachings of the Ru and Mo schools, with their mutual exclusions, are the hardest to harmonize. Yet even one without a fixed mind can harmonize them—how much more so for those who approach this state! The sage dwells among things without harming them, and thus things cannot harm him. The rhinoceros does not aim its horn; the tiger does not bare its claws. This is the person of complete virtue, who alone can accompany others in sending off and welcoming—such "sending off and welcoming" is merely keeping company with others.

The nature of people is to delight in the new and weary of the old. Yet in all the world, nothing remains new without becoming old. To meet weariness with ever-changing things—how could the world not be without joy? The joy of the wealthy and powerful lies in power and profit; the joy of the reclusive lies in mountains and forests. Yet both rely on external things for their joy. Where is there anything new that does not become old, or old that does not bring weariness? When weariness comes, sorrow follows. Joy and sorrow lodge in the body like travelers in an inn.

Only those who study and attain the Dao do not dwell in wealth and power yet possess the means to govern and command; they do not hide in mountains and forests yet are sufficient to witness the transformations of the myriad things.

The presence of this power is inexhaustible, and its transformations emerge without end—what is enjoyed as new never becomes old, so how could there be weariness or sorrow? *Bixu’s Commentary*: Pursuing things is called "external transformation"; preserving the true is called "internal non-transformation." Indulging the nature is called "internal transformation"; clinging to victory is called "external non-transformation." Those who transform with things follow the same transformation as things; those who remain unchanging were never transformed to begin with. Transformation and non-transformation are simply matters of following nature—this is not merely passive compliance but also effortless simplicity.

The perfectly pure who engage with the world are like the sage who wanders, rests, and dwells in parks, gardens, palaces, and chambers—what need have they for "meeting" or "welcoming"? Even the noble scholars of Confucianism and Mohism cannot remain free of the heart’s divisions to distinguish right and wrong—how much less can those beneath them? To dwell among things without harming them is to be one with the dust and light. Things, too, cannot harm; self and other are free of the heart’s divisions. Only those who are free of what harms can engage with others in meeting and welcoming. Yet to remain free of the heart’s divisions without meeting or welcoming is easy; to meet and welcome without being swayed by things is difficult.

Mountains and forests are indifferent to people, yet many delight in them—stillness aligns with their nature. When change arrives, sorrow arises from emotion. All people in the world are led by sorrow and joy, so when they encounter [fate], misfortune abounds; when they do not, blessings remain whole. The capable are enslaved; the incapable enslave others. Thus the sage values non-knowledge and non-ability, while worldly people force knowledge and ability, harming things and themselves—this is the great affliction. If one could discard false words and false knowledge to enter that which is "not-knowing yet knowing," one would attain profound and far-reaching insight.

*Yong Qi* says: Responding to things without being burdened by them is "external transformation"; responding to things without disturbing the heart is "internal non-transformation." Engaging in conflict is "internal transformation"; being blunted by things is "external non-transformation." With my internal non-transformation externally responding to things, what passes is transformed without meeting or welcoming—then transformation is not known, and non-transformation is not known. The "one who does not transform" is the heart free of the heart—how could there be any strife? To be blunted is to be worn down. Why must one grind against things and insist on overcoming them?

Shen Nong, the Yellow Emperor, Yao, Shun, Tang, Wu, and the masters of Confucianism and Mohism did not fully grasp the Way of internal non-transformation, so they arrived at mutual contention over right and wrong—*man* refers to the clashing of the five flavors. Parks, gardens, palaces, and chambers are their habitual nests. Not harming things is to transform with them; transforming with things allows one to meet and welcome others.

When people wander in mountains and forests, their hearts must delight; delight gives rise to emotion, and emotion brings sorrow—*The Record of the Orchid Pavilion* employs this meaning precisely. Delighting in things and sorrowing in things, coming and going at their behest, all without freedom—then this heart of mine is but an inn for sorrow and joy!

"Encounter" means what is visible; "non-encounter" means what is invisible. What is visible is human; what is invisible is Heaven. Ability is what one can do; inability is what Heaven does. All people in the world have what they do not know and cannot do. Only because they know the human but not Heaven do they seek to avoid what cannot be avoided—is this not lamentable? Thus, the highest words are wordless, the highest actions are actionless. Not knowing what cannot be known, yet taking what can be known as knowledge—how shallow is their vision!

The externally transformed are yielding and harmonious in their brilliance; the internally untransformed are resolute in establishing virtue. The internally transformed have hearts that shift with things; the externally untransformed are rigid and defy convention. People in the world do not transform what should be transformed but transform what should not be transformed—this is how ancient and modern, pure and decadent, are distinguished, and how the noble and the petty are divided.

The sage governs the world with earthen simplicity, transforming with things; governs the self with truth, remaining unchanging. If one can truly govern the self, then extending this to the world is but a trivial matter. When there is no distinction between internal and external, transformation and non-transformation converge in transformation. Thus, one peacefully follows along without any missteps.

Parks, gardens, palaces, and chambers are where the sage finds ease—later generations who wander there grow fewer, calling their dwellings cramped. Even the masters of Confucianism and Mohism could not avoid contention over right and wrong, clashing and harming one another—how much less can people today dwell among things without harm and meet others without being led? It is no wonder they abandon the joy of parks, gardens, palaces, and communal living to seek the solitary goodness of mountains, forests, and rustic fields.

The principle of all things is that movement at its extreme must return to stillness; the nature of people is that joy at its extreme must turn to sorrow. Those wearied by the bustle of markets long for the clarity of mountains and forests; those who delight in mountains and forests do not grasp the principle of inevitable weariness. As emotions subtly shift, they move in tandem with transformation, unaware that this body is but an inn for sorrow and joy.
