*The Outer Things* says: "The great forests and mountains are good for people, yet even the spiritual cannot endure them"—this is the same meaning. "Encounter" refers to things appearing before one; "non-encounter" means things are absent and separate from people. "Visible" is as if unseen. "Ability" refers to proper action; "inability" is like the foolish who guard simplicity, abandon learning, and act without contrivance.

People invariably take the coming and going of things as sorrow and joy, not realizing that their own bodies are but temporary lodgings! How much more are the encounters and abilities they meet—must they not also be temporary lodgings of the self? Only non-knowledge is true knowledge; only non-ability is true ability—these are what people inherently possess yet cannot avoid. Now, abandoning what is inherent and instead pursuing excessive knowledge and ability, exhausting the mind and body, toiling endlessly to the point of ruin—this is what the true person laments.

People cannot be entirely without words or actions, but if the heart remains free amid words and actions, the burdens of words and actions naturally fall away—this is the highest speech and action.

If one takes the knowledge bounded by limits as the true object of knowledge, such shallowness strays far from the Dao.

The noble person—here referring to the ancients (as clarified below)—establishes this discourse on *zhi* (knowledge), for *zhi* arises from action and speech. In the "Northern Wander," one turns toward the root, bearing the intent to return to the source. The "Mysterious Water," most wondrous yet retaining the power to moisten all things, serves as a metaphor for those who hold the Dao in mind. *Wuwei* (non-action) and *wuyu* (non-speech) merge with the Dao. Thus, when asked thrice yet unable to answer, this "not-knowing" is true knowledge. Though the Yellow Emperor’s replies grow ever clearer, how do they bring one closer to the Dao?

Therefore, the sage sheds form and abandons knowledge, casts off the body and dulls the senses. Through *wuwei*, the myriad things attain completion; without speech, the world transforms. Knowing the Dao cannot be possessed, nor the self claimed as private, one sees that all things arise from the *wu* (non-being), for the cosmos is but a single *qi*. The wondrous and the foul interchange, yin and yang, beauty and ugliness arise of themselves—bursting forth, seeping in—shared by all. To transform with things yet remain unchanged is the sage’s singular attainment.

Embracing life and death as transformation, casting off the thatch and the fine robe alike, one dwells within change yet yields to it, neither resisting nor clinging to change, forgetting change even as it unfolds—how could one not rest in it? The deeper the descent, the more evident the Dao, even in the humblest clay vessel. Employing the artificial yet not relying on it, one excels in hammering and forging.

To know the era before heaven and earth from this present moment is to abide without departure. Without seeking or resisting, one harmonizes inner and outer transformation, engaging with things without harm. Thus, one who attains stillness not through circumstances is never truly still; one who finds joy not through external things is never truly joyful. Beyond the reach of transformation’s sway, untouched by burdens, a single day may span a century, a century shrink to a day—how then can we know that today’s dwelling is not the cosmos within a gourd?

Gazing calmly upon the world’s people, who take transient lodgings as their own, one sees how they often ruin their lives and harm their nature through encounters and abilities—no different from aloeswood or sandalwood cast into the furnace, their fragrance rising from the chimney while their forms turn to ash. Far better to remain untouched by encounters or abilities, preserving one’s true nature.

The Highest Sage said: "The teaching without words, the benefit of *wuwei*—few in the world attain these." Thus, the *Nanhua* concludes its outer chapters with the supreme speech that transcends speech, the supreme action that transcends action.

*End of South China Sea of the Nanhua True Scripture’s Subtle Compilation, Scroll Sixty-Nine*
*(Note: In the Tang manuscript, the character *zhe* 者 lacks the *wu* 物 below it.)*

*South China Sea of the Nanhua True Scripture’s Subtle Compilation, Scroll Seventy*
*By the Daoist of Wulin, Chu Boxiu*

**Miscellaneous Chapters: Gengsang Chu, Part One**

Among the disciples of Lao Dan was one named Gengsang Chu, who had partially grasped the Master’s Dao. He took up residence in the northern mountains of Weilei, where those among his ministers who flaunted their knowledge departed, and those among his concubines who paraded their benevolence kept their distance. Only the ungainly and the self-content remained to dwell with him and serve as his attendants. After three years, Weilei flourished abundantly.

The people of Weilei said to one another: “When Master Gengsang first arrived, we were struck by his difference. Now, when we reckon our accounts, they fall short, but when we tally the year’s harvest, there is surplus. Might he not be a sage? Why do we not together offer him sacrifices as our lord, worship him as our earth-god, and honor him as our grain-spirit?”

When Gengsang Chu heard this, he turned to face south with a troubled countenance. His disciples found this strange.

Gengsang Chu said: “Disciples, why do you find me strange? When spring’s qi stirs, the hundred grasses sprout; when autumn arrives in due season, the myriad treasures ripen. Is it because spring and autumn possess some special power that this comes to pass? The Dao of Heaven has simply run its course. I have heard that the perfected person dwells like a corpse in a humble chamber, yet the people, wild and untamed, flock to him without knowing where they go. Now, the petty folk of Weilei secretly wish to honor me with ritual vessels in the manner reserved for worthies—am I to be their measuring ladle? This is why I cannot set aside the words of old Lao Dan.”

**Guo Xiang’s Commentary:**
*Huaran* (flaunting) refers to embellished knowledge; *qieran* (parading) to ostentatious benevolence. *Yongzhong* (ungainly) denotes simplicity; *yangzhang* (self-content) denotes self-possession. At first, the people marveled at his rejection of knowledge and embrace of foolishness, but in the end, they awakened to the fact that one who moves in harmony with the four seasons is far from seeking merit. Spring and autumn’s processes of generation and fruition all follow the natural Dao, and thus he does not act. The perfected person dwells like a corpse, and the people go to him of their own accord—not through any exercise of knowledge. Thus, he does not wish to serve as a measuring ladle for others. As the *Laozi* says: “When his task is accomplished and his work done, the people all say, ‘We have done it ourselves.’” Now the people of Weilei act contrary to this, which is why he was troubled.

**Lü Huiqing’s Commentary:**
The Dao of old Lao Dan rejects benevolence, discards knowledge, and does not exalt worthies—not to enlighten the people by making them foolish. Thus, those among his ministers and concubines who possessed benevolence and knowledge all departed or kept their distance; only the ungainly and the self-content remained. *Huaran* and *qieran* refer to minor displays of benevolence and knowledge. *Yongzhong* means dull-witted; *yangzhang* means rigidly constrained. These are not the sort who rely on knowledge or benevolence. The people of Weilei were transformed by Chu’s Dao, no longer employing knowledge but instead devoting their energies to clothing and food—hence the great abundance. Chu’s conduct was enough to renew the people’s eyes and ears, so they were struck by his difference. His Dao achieved success without effort, which is why their reckonings fell short while the year’s harvest yielded surplus. Sacrificing as a lord, worshipping as an earth-god, and honoring as a grain-spirit are all tasks reserved for rulers and ancestral spirits—this expresses the people’s desire to exalt him. Spring and autumn are the work of Heaven, yet the myriad things remain unaware. The sage dwells like a corpse, and the people do not know where they go. Now, the petty folk of Weilei wish to honor him with ritual vessels in the manner reserved for worthies—this is what is meant by being unable to keep people from clinging to him. How could I not refuse to serve as others’ measuring ladle?

**Lin Yidu’s Commentary:**
Things receive their mandate from Heaven and are thus employed by Heaven; the people receive their mandate from their ruler and are thus employed by their ruler; disciples receive their mandate from their teacher and are thus employed by their teacher. Heaven employs things to generate them and gives them rest in death; the ruler employs the people in affairs and gives them rest with wealth; the teacher employs disciples in learning and gives them rest with the Dao. All who receive a mandate are unavoidably employed. Thus, Chu studied under Lao Dan and is called his “servant.” This is not a private favor to Chu; rather, Chu alone grasped the Master’s Dao because he was able to fulfill the reality of his inherent nature. Weilei is the Feather Mountain mentioned in the *Yu Gong*, as recorded in the *Dongling Jing*. His ministers and concubines all selected simple and unadorned people, casting aside those who flaunted knowledge or paraded benevolence. Those who were of no use as material for governance dwelled with him, while those who were not fit for office served him. After three years, there was great abundance, and the people all marveled at him. He did not seek merit, which is why their reckonings fell short; his distant effects bore fruit, which is why the year’s harvest yielded surplus. The people, transformed by his virtue, wished to establish him as their lord. Facing south to receive sacrifices as an earth-god or grain-spirit aligns with the *Laozi*’s idea that one can entrust the world to such a person. When spring arrives, things are born; when autumn arrives, things mature—this is the natural Dao at work, yet people remain unaware. To dwell like a corpse is to be still; an “enclosed chamber” is to be humble. Yet the people, wild and untamed, joyfully flock to him of their own accord—not through any exercise of knowledge. Now, the petty folk of Weilei wish to treat me with ritual vessels in the manner reserved for worthies—this is to treat me as a ladle. A ladle is a small utensil, convenient for common use, but this would violate the teachings of old Lao Dan, which is why he was troubled.

**Chen Jingyuan’s Commentary (Bi Xu):**
“Partially grasped the Master’s Dao” means his understanding of principle was most profound. Thus, he rejected intelligence, strategy, benevolence, and righteousness, associating only with the ungainly and unrefined, the self-content and self-possessed. At first, the people were startled by his abandonment of knowledge and embrace of foolishness, but later they rejoiced in the flourishing of their customs. As his Dao matured and his virtue grew, the people wished to sacrifice to him as their lord. His troubled countenance showed lingering unease with such traces. Spring and autumn follow the natural Dao, unfolding without speech—what merit is there in this for me? Thus, he dwelt in stillness and seclusion, and the people did not know where to find him. How could he consent to serve as others’ measuring ladle? To be honored with ritual vessels would be to fail to understand his teacher’s words and deliberately violate them.

**Liu Yao’s Commentary:**
The *Laozi* says: “When his task is accomplished and his work done, the people all say, ‘We have done it ourselves.’” Yet the people of Weilei wished to sacrifice to Gengsang Chu as their lord—this suggests Chu’s grasp of the Dao was still incomplete. It is also said: “If one possesses its reality but others confer a name upon him and he does not accept it, he will instead receive misfortune.” Now, hearing of their desire to face him as their lord, he was troubled—this suggests Chu’s compliance with things was still incomplete.

Moreover, it is said that Yao was not a man of men, nor did he appear as one among men—yet he endures a thousand generations after, and this is but his trace. Thus, Gengsang Chu’s Dao reaches the height of *non-doing*, yet has not attained the state of *non-non-doing*.

**Lin’s *Yanzhai Oral Exegesis*:**
"Encumbered and burdened" is like "limbs askew." "Unfettered" means free and untrammeled, distinct from others. "Yearly accounts show surplus" signifies long-term benefit. "To sacrifice to the altars of soil and grain" expresses reverence in worship. "Dancing at the tip of the brush" describes such phrasing. "Not at ease" conveys displeasure. "How could this be the result of *non-doing*?"—it means Heaven indeed effects this, for the Dao of Heaven moves of itself, a natural metaphor for the absence of intent. "Not knowing whither to go" speaks of forgetting the world. "Ladle"—a small vessel, and since I am shallow and easily perceived, others come to know me. The Buddhists say: "I cultivate *non-force*, yet ghosts and spirits see through it." "Not at ease with the words of Lao Dan" arises from fear of betraying his teacher’s instruction, hence his displeasure.

**Chu’s *Superficial Observations*:**
Gengsang—*Records of the Grand Historian* writes it as *Kangsang*, also rendered *Kangcang*, one of the various schools among the philosophers. The Tang dynasty canonized it as *The True Scripture of Dongling*. The text states: "Gengsangzi dwelled on the summit of Mount Yu." **He Yao’s Commentary:** Mount Yu lies in Xuzhou. Zhuangzi speaks of Weilei to describe his unrefined simplicity. "Distinctly" and "clearly" both denote manifest display. To practice benevolence and wisdom without concealment invites the resentment of the unbenevolent and unwise, bringing calamity and plunder. Better to dwell among the dull and blunt, where mutual *non-intent* prevails, customs are pure, and manners flourish—over time, the people delight in his transformation and wish to honor him. "Accounts fall short, yet yearly surplus remains" follows the principle of silk threads accumulating into cloth. Gengsang, fearing he was not truly known, dreaded the people’s allegiance as a burden to himself. Spring’s growth and autumn’s harvest—Heaven’s Dao moves of itself. In a sagely age, how would the people know the emperor’s power? Yet now they array me among the worthy—though I do not deem myself worthy, they still esteem me, as if setting up a ladle to invite arrows. Would I consent to this? Thus, Gengsang’s dwelling in Weilei was a concealment not yet thorough, unable to make others forget him entirely. How much better was Liezi’s residence in the Zheng gardens, where traces dissolved into undifferentiated oneness.

The disciple said: Not so. In a common ditch, great fish have no place to turn their bodies, and minnows constrain them. On a hillock of a few paces, great beasts have no place to conceal their forms, and foxes and badgers dominate. Moreover, honoring the worthy and entrusting the capable, rewarding goodness and bestowing benefit—this has been so since the time of Yao and Shun, how much more for the people of Weilei! Master, you should heed this.

Gengsangzi said: Come, little one!

The beast that fills a carriage, once armored and parted from the mountain, cannot escape the calamity of nets and snares; the fish that swallows a boat, once stranded and deprived of water, may be tormented even by ants. Thus, birds and beasts are never sated with height, and fish and turtles never sated with depth. For those who preserve their bodily form and life, to conceal themselves is but to be never sated with depth and remoteness.

Moreover, what are those two worth in praise? In their disputations, they are like those who recklessly bore through walls to plant mugwort and wormwood. Combing their hair strand by strand, measuring grains of rice to cook—how can such trifling acts suffice to save the age? When the worthy are promoted, the people contend with one another; when knowledge is employed, the people rob one another. These several things are not enough to enrich the people.

The people are most diligent in pursuit of profit: sons may murder fathers, ministers may murder rulers; in broad daylight they become thieves, and at midday they tunnel through walls. I tell you, the root of great disorder must arise from the time of Yao and Shun, and its branches will remain even a thousand generations hence. A thousand generations from now, there will surely be men who devour one another.

The beast leaves the mountain, the fish loses the water—this is to expose one’s name in the world and thereby invite harm to oneself. Yao and Shun, in their disputations, are like those who bore through walls to plant weeds, for they lack this principle. The people’s diligence in profit knows no bounds: when the worthy are promoted and knowledge is employed, contention and theft arise. The people, in their pursuit of profit, become so earnest that they spare nothing. This is because Yao and Shun left behind their traces, adorning falsehoods and spreading them to later ages, thus bringing about these ills.

Those who preserve their bodily form and life conceal themselves without ever tiring of depth and remoteness, like the dragon in the ninefold abyss, which only when submerged can manifest its numinous power. Yao and Shun, who succeeded to the throne and became rulers, achieved order and perfection through the practice of the seven virtues—yet how could they be faulted? Yet the *Nanhua* [Zhuangzi] upholds the Laoist teaching of abandoning benevolence and rejecting righteousness, always seeking to exalt the Dao and virtue while suppressing benevolence and righteousness, and thus must point to Yao and Shun as the origin. Its aim is to pluck out the root and dam the source, and it cannot but do so.

The governance of the sage causes the people to be without knowledge and without desire. Viewed through the traces of Yao and Shun, even the promotion of the worthy and the employment of knowledge inevitably lead to mutual contention and theft. When knowledge is made the means to desire, the people’s nature is led astray, and from this the source of disorder arises. The worthy and the wise, these several things, are not enough to enrich the people; they only cause superiors and inferiors to plunder one another, leading even to midday tunneling through walls without a second thought. All this is the fault of the ills left behind by the legacy of Yao and Shun.

That beasts devour one another is already detestable—how much worse when men devour one another? The shallow and narrow are the domain of eels and foxes, while the vast and deep belong to the flood-dragons and leviathans. Thus, when the Dao and virtue shine brightly, worldly customs cannot conceal them. Yet only those who are lofty, remote, deep, and recondite can remain untouched by profit and harm, while those who merely preserve their bodily form and life are not worthy of praise.

To distinguish the worthy from the foolish is to destroy simplicity; to comb hair strand by strand and measure grains of rice is to lose the undifferentiated whole. The sage does not promote the worthy or employ knowledge, thereby enriching the people and preventing usurpation and theft. Yet those who rely on knowledge seek only immediate success—how could they foresee the ruin of later days? The eel and the fox, though small, may rule the ditch and the hillock, for in every place, no matter how small, there is something to be revered. To be first in goodness and profit is to invite the pursuit of name, which in turn invites the pursuit of profit. When people possess worthiness and ability, others will inevitably honor and esteem them. Now, the humble folk of Weilei delight in honoring the able and esteeming the worthy—should you, Master, not heed them?

Yet when the beast leaves the mountain and the fish loses the water, this is to expose one’s name in the world and thereby invite harm to oneself. To take Yao and Shun as subjects of disputation is like boring through walls to plant weeds, for it lacks this principle. The people’s diligence in profit knows no bounds, and when they are without restraint, what will they not do? The disorder of Yao and Shun’s time arose from their leaving behind traces and adorning falsehoods, which spread to later ages and brought about these ills. The disciple’s claim that promoting the worthy and putting goodness first—Yao and Shun’s legacy—should be practiced in Weilei is not without reason. Yet the answer is that the perfected person conceals himself without ever tiring of depth and remoteness, like the dragon in the ninefold abyss, which only when submerged can manifest its numinous power.

Yao and Shun succeeded to the throne and became rulers, their achievements and governance complete, all carried out through the seven virtues—how could they be faulted? Yet the *Nanhua* [Zhuangzi] adheres to the Laoist teaching of abandoning benevolence and rejecting righteousness, always seeking to exalt the Dao and virtue while suppressing benevolence and righteousness, and thus must point to Yao and Shun as the origin. Its aim is to pluck out the root and dam the source, and it cannot but do so.

The reader must grasp the central intent and not be misled by peripheral words. Thus, though you cite them in debate, it is like planting mugwort to clear away weeds—combing through the strands only wearies yourself, and how can this benefit the world? Moreover, benevolence and wisdom, these several things, are what the world reveres, believing they can bring order. Yet if one does not govern them by the Dao, but merely follows their paths, one will see deceit and corruption flourish—how could it stop at mere mutual strife and theft? When customs grow shallow and thin, and all schemes are for profit, then the duties of minister and son become uneasy, the reverence for ruler and father is no longer feared, and rebellion against ethics and reason will know no bounds.

Gengsang Chu declined the well-wishers of Weilei, for he diagnosed the malady before its symptoms appeared and first secured the root. How could the world’s decay ever reach him?

Nanrong Qu straightened his robes and sat upright, saying: "One as old as I—where can I entrust my efforts to attain such words?"

Gengsangzi said: "Preserve your form, embrace your life, and let no anxious thoughts trouble you. If you do this, in three years you may attain these words."

Nanrong Qu said: "The eye and the form—I do not see them as different, yet the blind cannot see themselves. The ear and the form—I do not see them as different, yet the deaf cannot hear themselves. The heart and the form—I do not see them as different, yet the mad cannot grasp themselves. Forms and forms are alike, yet something may come between them—why do they seek each other yet fail to meet? Now you tell me: preserve your form, embrace your life, and let no anxious thoughts trouble you. I have striven to hear the Dao and let it reach my ears!"

Gengsangzi said: "My words are exhausted. The running bee cannot transform the wax moth; the Yue chicken cannot hatch the swan’s egg; only the Lu chicken can do so. Chickens and chickens—their virtue is not different, yet some can and some cannot, for their capacities are inherently great or small. My capacity is small and insufficient to transform you. Why not go south to see Laozi?"

Guo’s commentary: "Preserving the form" means guarding one’s allotted place and not grasping beyond life. Eye and eye, ear and ear, heart and heart—their forms are similar, yet their abilities differ, and one should not force imitation. Two forms open to each other yet fail to meet—something must come between them, for early exposure to separation makes transformation difficult.

Lü’s commentary: To abandon the virtue of Yao and Shun without acting—this is the ultimate accumulation. Then how can one entrust one’s efforts to attain such words? The answer is that when a person’s form is constantly preserved, the spirit can live—this is one. How could it be for the sake of things? Yet when ears and eyes are bound to sounds and sights, nose and mouth to scents and flavors, and the heart is enslaved by things, then the form is impaired and incomplete, life is sundered and unembraced, and thoughts ceaselessly trouble—thus one cannot be free of things. Only by preserving the form, embracing life, and letting no thoughts trouble you can the constant heart be attained! Where then is room for so-called sagely wisdom and benevolent righteousness?

The ears and eyes that do not distinguish sounds and sights, the heart that does not discern right and wrong—these are what the world calls deafness, blindness, and madness. For the Daoist, not seeing oneself is blindness, not hearing oneself is deafness, not grasping oneself is madness. Madness and sageliness lie only in whether one thinks or does not think. My form and that form both preserve the spirit, and the spirit has no sides—how could there be a barrier that does not open? That they seek each other yet fail to meet is only because something comes between them.

Though Qu claims not to have heard the Dao, what he knows already surpasses the common person; he has merely not yet matched Chu’s words to his heart.

Du’s commentary: Fearing that Gengsang’s Dao is hard to attain, Zhao asked how to entrust his efforts. The answer—preserve the form, embrace life—is what the *Laozi* calls "nurturing the soul and embracing the One." Nurturing the soul preserves the form; embracing the One preserves life. Concentrating the qi to achieve softness, letting no thoughts trouble you—this is how one may attain such words.

Zhao did not understand Gengsang’s intent, thinking that though the form is one, the ear, eye, and heart cannot substitute for each other. Judging by the deaf, blind, and mad, these three are distinct from the form. How could he know that the deaf, blind, and mad are precisely those whose forms are whole? My form and that form both open to external principles. Something comes between them, engaging and entangling. That they seek each other yet fail to meet is the work of the six thieves.

Qu, knowing he had not been transformed, said that Gengsang’s Dao had merely reached his ears. The running bee and Yue chicken illustrate his own small capacity, unable to transform the great—thus he sends him to see Laozi, which is what is meant by "greatness that transforms."

Bi Xu’s commentary: Zhao asked what effort could be entrusted to attain such words. The answer: abandoning worthiness preserves the form; forgetting knowledge embraces life. After a thousand days of cultivation, these words will be fulfilled.

One who holds yet does not cling—thus the mad find no self-possession. The six apertures contend, and so things interpose. What reaches the ear is but superficial perception; only spiritual awakening penetrates the heart. How can a cow’s hoof-print contain the transformation of Kun into Peng? How can a bee’s hive nurture the fledglings of Peng and Que? Such is the inherent principle. This is why Gengsang declined Zhao’s inquiry, wishing to conceal his mad words to preserve himself, and deferred to the ultimate principle in Lao Dan.

*Yanzhai’s Oral Exegesis*:
Man’s heart and senses are all open, yet the mad cannot attain self-possession, just as the deaf and blind perceive nothing. My form and others’ forms are fundamentally open and unobstructed, yet now they are interposed by desires, and the heart seeking the heart fails to find it. The Master taught me to cease restless thoughts and strive to hear the Dao, that I might perhaps attain understanding. The metaphors of the running bee and Yue chicken carry the same meaning as before. Zhao, hearing that the perfected man conceals himself in profound obscurity, asked what effort could be entrusted to fulfill such words. Gengsang instructed him to preserve his form without harm, embrace life without separation, extinguish mental activity and sever thoughts. After a thousand days of cultivation, it might be achieved. What was previously called honoring worthiness and prizing goodness is all laborious thought that harms the form and severs life’s root. Zhao had yet to awaken, still lost in the doubt at his core, thinking: the eye and form are originally one, yet the blind cannot see themselves; the ear and heart relate to form likewise. The deaf cannot hear themselves, the mad cannot attain themselves—just as Lian Shu said: “Is it only the physical frame that has deafness and blindness? Knowledge, too, has them.” Now Zhao’s affliction was not physical deafness or blindness, but precisely the deafness and blindness of knowledge, which is why Gengsang’s transformation was so costly.

When forms open, that is awakening. My form and that form both open to respond to things, fundamentally unobstructed; but when things enter and become the master, what was called “I” becomes the guest. Seeking yet failing to find is like the saying of Confucius’ disciples: “The Master’s words on nature and the Way of Heaven cannot be heard.” Seeking and finding is like when you know me, and I know the fish. Now, though heeding the Master’s teaching and striving to hear, Zhao has yet to awaken in his heart. At this point, Gengsang could do no more, so he sent him to seek swift transformation from one who embodied the Dao, that no perplexity might remain unresolved. Here one sees Gengsang’s virtue: he did not reproach others for being hard to transform, nor measure his own inadequacy. Thus he expanded the joy of his teacher’s gate, guiding disciples toward completion.

*Collected Subtleties of the Meaning of the Southern Florescence Scripture*, Scroll Seventy, concludes
*Collected Subtleties of the Meaning of the Southern Florescence Scripture*, Scroll Seventy-One

The Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin comments on the miscellaneous chapter *"Gengsang Chu"* (Second) from the *Nanhua Scripture*:

Nanrong Chu, carrying provisions, traveled seven days and seven nights to reach the abode of Laozi. Laozi said: “Have you come from the land of Chu?” Nanrong Chu replied: “Indeed.” Laozi said: “Why have you brought so many people with you?” Nanrong Chu, startled, looked behind him. Laozi said: “Do you not understand what I mean?” Nanrong Chu bowed his head in shame, then looked up and sighed, saying: “Now I have forgotten my answer, and so lost my question.”

Laozi said: “What do you mean?” Nanrong Chu replied: “Is it not so? If I am called foolish, I am deemed dull. If I am called wise, it only brings sorrow to my body. Without benevolence, I harm others; with benevolence, I bring sorrow upon myself. Without righteousness, I injure others; with righteousness, I bring sorrow upon myself. How can I escape this? These three dilemmas are my afflictions. I wish to ask you about them through Chu.”

Laozi said: “Earlier, I saw the question in your brows and eyes and thus understood you. Now you speak, and I believe you. Yet you stand there rigidly, as if you had lost your parents, raising a pole to seek them in the sea. You are a lost man—bewildered, adrift! You wish to return to your nature and original state, yet have no way in. How pitiable!”

*(Guo Xiang’s commentary: Laozi asked, ‘Why have you brought so many people with you?’ because he arrived burdened by these three dilemmas. Lü Huiqing’s commentary: Zhao sought the Dao, but his heart could not settle on one thing, and with these three dilemmas, it was as if he had brought a crowd with him. When one opposes the world with the Dao, the heart cannot conceal itself—this is how Laozi discerned him in the space between his brows and eyes. The Dao is what gives birth to all things; only by settling into oneness can one attain it. Now Zhao, with his scattered and inconsistent mind, seeks it in the boundless void—like a child who has lost his parents, raising a pole to search for them in the sea. How confused he is! To wish to return to one’s nature and original state yet have no way in—this is what the perfected one pities.)*

*(Yi Du’s commentary: “Provisions” refers to the vessel carrying his food. Seven days and seven nights signifies his fervent longing for the Dao, ceaseless day and night. Laozi knew he had come from Chu, burdened by these three dilemmas, so he asked why he had brought so many people with him. Overwhelmed, Nanrong Chu could not distinguish host from guest, and so he laid out the three dilemmas in succession, seeking resolution. This reveals his confusion about the roots of benevolence, wisdom, and righteousness. Laozi told him: ‘Earlier, I saw your brows and eyes and understood you; now you speak, and I believe you.’ Scholars of the world judge people by their words and appearance—this is the same principle, though those whose learning is incomplete cannot avoid delusion. Zhao has lost the true Dao, like a child who has lost his parents and tries to measure the sea with a pole—it cannot be done. ‘You are a lost man’ means he has lost the way of being human.)*

*(Bi Xu’s commentary: ‘Why have you brought so many people with you?’ refers to his shifting expressions and scattered mind. Startled, he looked behind him, his countenance betraying doubt and distress. What I meant was neither words nor appearance, so he was shocked into forgetting his answer and ashamed into losing his question. ‘Foolish’ describes a heart as dull as cinnabar. Benevolence, wisdom, and righteousness—all three bring suffering to self and others. Since the Dao is present in the very act of seeing, how much more so in words? The sea is not where parents are hidden; a pole is not a tool for probing the depths. Having lost his root and original return, he is at a loss, bewildered. To wish to return to one’s nature and original state yet have no way in—this is why he is pitiable.)*

*(The *Yanzhai Oral Teachings*: At first, he stood alone, yet Laozi said he had come with a crowd—what the Chan school calls ‘the mind within you is already in turmoil.’ ‘Foolish’ is like being benighted. The three dilemmas of benevolence, wisdom, and righteousness mean that neither having nor lacking a heart suffices—he is trapped in doubt, unresolved. ‘Rigidly’ describes a shallow, narrow demeanor. Raising a pole to seek the sea is to seek the boundless in the bounded. A ‘lost man’ is one who has lost his original heart and cannot find the natural Dao. The question ‘Why have you brought so many people with you?’ cuts deeply to the truth—this is where the exchange between Chu and Laozi becomes most earnest. If one lacks true inner vision, hearing this would surely provoke doubt. The patriarchs of the Chan school often use such methods. Overwhelmed by the first question, he forgot his answer and lost his footing, so Laozi followed with a second. When his fear and shame subsided, he laid out the three dilemmas, hoping to escape worldly entanglements. Laozi told him: ‘Are you like a child who has lost his parents, raising a pole to search for them in the sea?’ Your true nature is your closest kin—if you cannot preserve it but instead lose it, then seek it through benevolence and righteousness in the boundless affairs of the world, the more you seek, the farther you stray. Though your body remains, it is no different from being lost. ‘Bewildered’ describes having no return. To wish to return to one’s nature and original state yet have no way in is like being lost while trying to find the way back. The sage does not abandon him, so he pities and guides him. If one can transcend the three dilemmas and be free of entanglements, this is the way to return to one’s nature and original state. ‘Foolish’ is hard to reconcile; Bi Xu notes that an ancient southern manuscript reads ‘stubbornly foolish,’ likening it to a tree stump.)*

Nanrong Chu asked to enter and rest. He summoned what he loved and cast aside what he despised. After ten days of sorrow, he again sought Laozi.

Laozi said: "You have cleansed yourself—yet why this lingering heaviness? Still, within you there remains a subtle trace of aversion. That which is captured externally cannot be grasped with excessive restraint, for it will turn inward to strike; that which is guarded internally cannot be bound with entanglement, for it will turn outward to strike. If even one who protects both inner and outer cannot be sustained by the Dao and virtue, how much less one who abandons the Dao and acts recklessly?"

Nanrong Chu said: "When a villager falls ill, his neighbors inquire after him. If the sick man can describe his illness, then though he suffers, he is not truly ill. Now, when I hear of the Great Dao, it is as if I take medicine only to worsen my condition. I wish only to hear the classic of preserving life."

Laozi said: "The classic of preserving life—can you embrace the One? Can you not lose it? Can you know good and ill fortune without divination? Can you halt? Can you cease? Can you relinquish others and seek within yourself? Can you be unconstrained? Can you be unobstructed? Can you be like a child?

A child wails all day yet does not strain his throat—such is perfect harmony. He clutches all day yet his hand does not cramp—such is the sharing of his power. He gazes all day yet his eyes do not strain—his attention is not fixed on externals. He walks without knowing where he goes, dwells without knowing what he does, moves with things like a wave following the current. This is the classic of preserving life."

Guo’s commentary: To preserve form and embrace life, nothing surpasses forgetting the mind’s extensions and relinquishing the ears and eyes. If sounds and sights entangle externally, the mind’s defenses become obstructed within; if desires and aversions lash within, the ears and eyes become blocked without. Only when there is neither gain nor loss can there be true penetration. If even partial attachment is untenable, how much more so for inner and outer capture? When the ears and eyes are dazzled externally and the mind’s extensions flow unchecked within, even if one grasps tightly and binds fast, one cannot halt it.

Embracing the One without separation, one’s nature returns to its innate state. What is fitting brings fortune; excess brings misfortune—no divination is needed. *Halt* means stopping at one’s allotted portion. *Cease* means not pursuing past attachments. Relinquishing others to seek within means preserving oneself without imitating them. Without stagnation or rigidity, without the constraints of infancy, one allows the voice to emerge naturally, ungoverned by joy or anger; the hand to grasp spontaneously, not through possessiveness; the eyes to see freely, not bound to form. Trusting the feet to walk of themselves, the body to act of itself, even when riding the waves of things, one remains in accord with them.

Lü’s commentary: Knowing that likes and dislikes disturb the mind, one wishes to cleanse and return to emptiness and stillness—this is the summoning of what is loved and the casting aside of what is despised. Yet one still cannot put it into practice, hence one’s sorrow. A heavy, oppressive *qi* fills one, and a subtle leakage persists.

*Attachment* refers to things that cling stubbornly and are hard to remove. Now, if one resents the ears and eyes being ensnared by sounds and sights and seeks to control them externally, this is excessive grasping. Better to lock inwardly: if the mind does not go forth, externals will not be captured. As the *Daodejing* says: "Block the openings, shut the gates." If the mind’s defenses are captured by affairs and one seeks to halt them one by one, this is entangled grasping. Better to lock outwardly: if things do not enter, internals will not be captured. As the *Daodejing* says: "Open the gates, untie the tangles."

Thus, in perfect stillness and non-action, the myriad things cannot disturb the mind. Otherwise, even one with the Dao and virtue cannot sustain it—how much less one who merely imitates and acts? What is called "hearing the Dao" is knowing that things have never truly arisen and thus having nothing to do.

You know your own illness, but this is insufficient to withstand the medicine of the Great Dao. You wish only to hear the classic of preserving life. Preserving life takes non-action as its classic. The One is that from which the Dao itself arises, where auspiciousness abides—what need is there for divination? All these are able to halt deliberation and seek within oneself.

Unfettered and unobstructed, one becomes like a child. If his wailing arose from sorrow or anger rather than harmony, could his throat not become hoarse? To the point of grasping without knowing he grasps, seeing without knowing he sees—his actions and stillness arise from no-mind, moving with things like a wave following the current. This is the classic of preserving life.

Yi Du’s commentary: The mind’s retention of likes and dislikes is why one grieves. Washing away aversion is already cleansing. Yet the lingering heaviness and subtle leakage still manifest externally.

*Attachment* is like fettering; *striking* means closing off. The ears and eyes in relation to sounds and sights are external attachments—one must not let them become excessive grasping, drawing them inward to be closed off. The body and mind in relation to sensory contacts are internal capture—one must not let them become entangled grasping, casting them outward to be closed off.

For what enters from without, if there is a master within, it will not enter. For what emerges from within, if there is rectitude without, it will not be repelled. It is like a family with an unfilial son causing trouble outside: seize and confine him within. If he causes trouble within, seize and restrain him without. The harm of cravings to the body is like the harm of an unfilial son to the family—prevention and restraint cannot be neglected.

Zhao cites the villager’s illness as a metaphor for himself. One who is ill yet can describe his illness is not truly ill—just as *Liezi* says, "One who seeks life does not live." Zhao wishes to hear the Great Dao but has not found the method; it is like taking medicine that worsens the illness. He wishes only to hear the constant Dao of preserving life.

The answer is to embrace the One without losing it, then one need not divine to know fortune and misfortune, and can halt when seeing danger. *Cease* means to end entirely. Content with oneself and not dependent on externals, one is unconstrained and unobstructed, not losing the mind of a newborn. Concentrating *qi* to achieve softness, one’s constant virtue never departs. Thus one may enter flocks of birds and beasts without causing chaos, encounter tigers and rhinoceroses without harm. His wailing, grasping, and seeing all arise from no-mind, to the point of trusting the feet to walk of themselves, the body to act of itself, moving with the waves of things without departing from the Dao.

The *Bixu Commentary* states: One who can recognize their own illness is not yet truly ill; one who grows more confused upon hearing the Dao is difficult to awaken. Thus the great Way is hard to glimpse, and one wishes only to hear the lesser vehicle.

To "embrace the One without losing it" is to concentrate the mind while concealing its illumination. To "know fortune and misfortune" is to let sincerity and clarity halt danger. "Cease" means to no longer be enslaved, to seek within oneself and thus trust oneself. "Unconstrained and unobstructed" means to be free from all entanglements. Can one be like a newborn child? To preserve one’s uncarved simplicity.

The newborn’s pure virtue remains unspoiled, so their cries are whole, their grasp single-minded, their gaze unclinging, their spirit settled. They act without fear, flow with the current without being drowned—all this is the warp and weft of preserving life.

From *Fuqi Kouyi*: To summon what is good is to seek what is right; to dispel what is evil is to depart from what is wrong. Not forgetting likes and dislikes is the source of one’s own sorrow.

"Shu" (熟) means "shu" (孰), referring to long practice. "Yuyu" (郁郁) describes a mind not yet settled, so its agitation is visible. "Huo" (获) means to bind things with leather; "ta" (挞) is the bolt of a door—both metaphors for restraint. When responding to things externally, one seeks to restrain oneself, but the methods are too numerous to grasp. Turning inward, one seeks "inner restraint"; when the heart-mind is agitated, one seeks to restrain it, but the entanglements are too tangled to grasp. Turning outward again, one seeks "outer restraint." This shows that those who fail to grasp the essentials of the Dao find no foothold either within or without. If one cannot even uphold the virtue within their own body, how can they follow the principles of naturalness?

Such is the depth of foolish confusion: desiring to hear the great Dao yet unaware of where one’s own affliction lies, growing only more bewildered despite receiving instruction—like taking medicine that worsens the illness. Thus one no longer dares to seek the great Dao and wishes only to hear the warp and weft of preserving life.

"Embracing the One" means preserving wholeness of truth; "without losing it" means that what is received from Heaven is never lost.

Divination by milfoil and tortoise cannot foreknow fortune and misfortune; only utmost sincerity can foresee what is to come. "To halt" means to settle; "to cease" means to attain great rest. "Turn to oneself" means seeking within rather than pursuing externals. The infant cries without its voice growing hoarse, for it harbors no intent to disrupt its harmony. The newborn curls and cannot stretch, yet the young child’s prolonged grasp causes no obstruction. "Sharing in this virtue" means partaking of the same nature—all people are thus. One whose gaze does not waver looks without the mind’s interference. Unaware of where one dwells or what one does, yet moving with things in the same current—this may serve as the constant Way of preserving life.

"Pray enter and take lodging" expresses the wish to remain and receive instruction at the master’s gate. To summon what is good and dispel what is evil is to remain entangled in the passions of good and evil, yet unaware whether what one loves is truly good or what one hates is truly not good. "Self-reproach" (one version reads "cease reproach," another "reproach and cease," but neither yields clear sense; upon careful examination of the text’s meaning, it aligns with the *Book of Documents*’ "self-blame and self-correction"). To withdraw for ten days is to reflect; to reproach and correct is to move forward. If one’s learning has been lax and the vision of the Dao remains unclear, even upon encountering a sage teacher, swift transformation is difficult. Yet to wash the heart and regain clarity may be called having resolve and the ability to renew oneself.

Laozi said to you: "Who has cleansed you?" How flourishing! How boldly you advance, filling your countenance. Yet within, there lingers a subtle residue, outwardly manifest—some unremoved impurity remains. This further urges you to ascend one step higher and fulfill your resolve for self-renewal.

"Inner entanglement" refers to the solidification of the six roots; "outer restraint" refers to the defilement of the six dusts. "Restraint" implies sealing and guarding boundaries with strictness. Most interpretations read *tà* as "seize," but another plausible reading follows the complex form *miù*, breaking the sentence differently—both have their logic. Inner and outer entanglements are common afflictions of humankind. If one has a master within, and upholds it well, then emotions do not flow outward and one’s nature may be restored; the heart is not disturbed, and the Dao may be advanced.

If one remains unenlightened, it is like a villager who knows they are ill yet cannot cure themselves—how can they proceed to the great Dao? They wish only to hear the warp and weft of preserving life. To "embrace the One" is to keep the heart undivided; to "not seek attainment" is to ensure no loss. Divination cannot foreknow fortune and misfortune; when filth is removed, the heart’s brilliance shines forth. Knowing the utmost, one can halt; attaining forgetfulness, one can cease.

"Turning to oneself" means inner sufficiency, not relying on external things. "Can you be like a child?" This earnest analogy urges all to seek within and return to their original Heavenly nature. The infant’s wailing, grasping, and gaze differ from those of adults because within, it is filled with harmonious qi and harbors no intent toward externals—how could the warp and weft of preserving life surpass this?

Nanrong Qu said: "Then is this the virtue of the perfected person?"
He replied: "It is not."

This is what is called "melting like ice and thawing like frost." The perfected person shares sustenance with the earth and rejoices with Heaven, neither clashing with others over profit or harm, nor consorting in strangeness, nor scheming together, nor busying themselves with affairs. They come and go in serene stillness. This is called the *Classic of Preserving Life*.

He said: "Then is this perfection?"
He replied: "It is not. I have already told you: *Can you be like a child?* The child moves without knowing what it does, walks without knowing where it goes. Its body is like the branch of a withered tree, its heart like dead ashes. In this state, misfortune does not arrive, nor does fortune come. When misfortune and fortune are as if they never existed, how could human calamities arise?"

Guo's commentary: If one could reform oneself and apply these words, one might claim to possess the virtue of the perfected person. Yet "melting like ice and thawing like frost" makes clear that this is not so of itself. The perfected person is without intent, harmonizing with all things, never clashing over profit or harm. To think that merely hearing these words could lead to perfection—this is answered by saying it is not so. Hearing the perfect words may serve as a classic, but how can it be perfection itself? Thus, the learner does not attain perfection, and the perfected do not learn.

Misfortune and fortune arise from gain and loss; human calamities stem from love and aversion. Now, with the body like withered wood and the heart like dead ashes—utterly devoid of emotion—how could anxiety over gain and loss arise?

Lü's commentary: The human heart, when still, is like water. Yet knowledge congeals like ice, preventing emptiness. Knowing the *Classic of Preserving Life* is like ice melting and frost thawing. The perfected person’s heart remains ever like water, so their virtue does not require cultivation, and things cannot separate from them. They share sustenance and joy without clashing over profit or harm. Not consorting in strangeness, they remain unmarred by worldly peculiarities. Not scheming, they remain unaligned with worldly conventions. Free from entanglement and attachment, how could they be bound by "embracing the One" or "ensuring no loss"? Their serene coming and going is the constant of preserving life, yet this is not perfection itself. What is called perfection lies only in what is unknown—the child’s unknowing of where it goes or what it does, like withered wood and dead ashes.

Misfortune and fortune are governed by Heaven, Earth, and spirits, tied to the existence of body and heart. If one’s body is withered and heart ashen, how could they be burdened?

Du’s commentary: Nanrong Qu, hearing the *Classic of Preserving Life*, believed this to be the ultimate virtue of the perfected person. "Melting like ice and thawing like frost" is a metaphor for the obscuration of desires; hearing the teaching brings release. The perfected person’s benevolence suffices to dwell in the earth, so they accept its sustenance without discrimination; their wisdom suffices to serve Heaven, so they receive its joy without refusal. Not opposing others with the self, not yielding the self to things, profit and harm cannot sway their heart. Not pursuing strangeness to exalt the extraordinary, they preserve their constant virtue. Not scheming with cunning, they abide in simplicity. Not busying themselves with affairs, they remain steadfast in stillness. Coming and going without burden—this is the virtue of the perfected person.

Nanrong Qu asked again: "Then is this perfection?"
Laozi reiterated his earlier words: If one could be like a child, with a body like withered wood and a heart like dead ashes, how could misfortune or fortune reach them?

Bi Xu’s commentary: Taking this as the virtue of the perfected person is like seeing a bow and seeking roasted meat. Thus, medicine cures illness, and teachings resolve confusion—neither is the ultimate perfection. The perfected person cultivates virtue to harmonize yin and yang; common people exhaust their strength in farming. Sharing sustenance nurtures the body; sharing joy harmonizes nature. People and things flourish. With a sincere heart free from clashing, profit and harm are both forgotten. Abiding in constancy without strangeness, free from entanglement, they roam at ease—this is the *Classic of Preserving Life*. When principle is fully realized, words are forgotten.

Those who seek the ultimate must first return to purity and simplicity. Purity and simplicity are like an infant—the swiftest path to the Dao. To regard teachings as perfection is like chewing dregs in search of fine wine.

Yanzhai’s oral teachings: Nanrong Qu inquired about the *Classic of Preserving Life*, seeking what is secondary. Hearing Laozi’s lofty and wondrous words, he asked again about the virtue of the perfected person. Laozi replied, "It is not," fearing he would fixate on this, and thus showed him the meaning of "melting like ice and thawing like frost"—liberation and spontaneous awakening. Sharing sustenance with the earth is to be one with others; rejoicing with Heaven is to be one with Heaven.

The *Classic of Preserving Life* lies in not clashing with things to contrive strangeness, nor scheming to measure the bounds of every affair. The preceding speaks of the perfected person—here it is called the *Classic of Preserving Life*. The *Classic of Preserving Life* is precisely the affair of the perfected person. From this, one sees that the words "It is not" are not an assertion of fact.

Nanrong Qu asked again, "Then is this perfection?" Laozi replied, "Not yet." There should have been another topic of discourse, but instead he once more raised the earlier text—this was to avoid exhausting his words and allow for spontaneous awakening.

The *Liezi* records: A minister of Chen named Danlu remarked, "In my state there is one Kangkangzi who has attained the Dao of Laozi." The Lord of Lu sent his highest minister with lavish gifts to summon him. Thus, one knows that the Dao of Gengsangzi and Laozi are not different. Their promotion of benevolence and love for all things, their skill in guiding and joy in nurturing—only fearing that others might not attain it.

In this chapter, Gengsangzi speaks four times, and Nanrong Qu asks three times. When Qu went to see Laozi, Laozi spoke eight times. His earnest instruction, his unwillingness to abandon others to the realm of lost Dao—this is clearly evident.

The true nature is like water: empty, luminous, limpid, and clear—neither existent nor non-existent. When obscured and bound by the desires of things, it is like water freezing into ice. Water is utterly clear, yet when frozen, it is no longer clear; the spirit is utterly numinous, yet when congealed into form, it is no longer numinous. Hearing the Dao and awakening to principle, the ice melts and thaws—what harm is there to clarity and numinosity? It is only that people cease to seek within.

Sharing sustenance with the earth is to share in the common provision of plowing and tilling. Sharing sustenance with Heaven is to partake equally in the great harmony. If so, how could the gains and losses of people and things reach one? What use are strange conduct and scheming plans? How could one’s comings and goings fail to be fitting, or the *Classic of Life* fail to be preserved?

To study the Dao and reach this point is already to have arrived, yet he still says, "Not yet." To contradict the interpretation of perfection, he again cites the words of a child—this is the teacher’s artifice, shifting the disciple’s perspective. Clearly, it is a matter of two hands passing on the teaching, requiring the disciple’s own effort to bear it. For human nature is originally supple, but daily contact with things allows external qi to intrude, clashing and grinding—all become one’s adversaries.

If one can truly concentrate the qi and govern it with softness, returning to purity and simplicity, flawless as an infant—then what misfortune or fortune could reach one? The questioning and answering reach this point, where words are exhausted and principle is fully expounded—no further effort can be applied.

Alas! Qu’s capacity to carry the Dao was weak, and he ultimately failed to grasp even a single phrase. What a pity!

*End of Chapter Seventy-One of the* Subtle Compilation of the Meaning of the *Zhenjing* of the Southern Florescence*
*Chapter Seventy-Two of the* Subtle Compilation of the Meaning of the *Zhenjing* of the Southern Florescence*

The Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin’s *Miscellaneous Chapters: "Gengsang Chu" the Third*

When the dwelling of the spirit is profoundly settled, radiance issues forth as celestial illumination. This celestial illumination is such that others perceive the person as truly human. Those who cultivate themselves thereby attain constancy; those who attain constancy are forsaken by others yet aided by Heaven. Those forsaken by others are called Heaven’s people; those aided by Heaven are called Heaven’s sons.

The learner studies what cannot be studied; the practitioner practices what cannot be practiced; the debater debates what cannot be debated. To know when to halt before what cannot be known—this is perfection. Should one deviate from this, the celestial balance will undo it.

Guo’s commentary: When virtue is settled in profound tranquility, what issues forth is celestial illumination, not human brilliance. Thus, others perceive the person as human, and things perceive things as things—each sees itself and not the other, and so remains settled in tranquility. When one cultivates humanity, one attains self-mastery and thus abides in constancy. Abiding in constancy, one returns to dwell in the self’s dwelling and naturally receives aid. Emerging, one is Heaven’s son; remaining, one is Heaven’s people—both are attained through profound tranquility, not through effort.

Thus, whatever one is capable of—though practiced, it is not effort; though rehearsed, it is not study; though spoken, it is not debate. What cannot be known cannot be forcibly known, and so one halts at this perfection. Though one may intend to act, action leads to failure, for in the end, principle cannot be violated.

Lü’s commentary: The body is humanity’s dwelling. When it is neither obstructed nor disordered, celestial illumination issues forth. Celestial illumination is unknowing and unperceiving, yet luminously penetrating. Others see the person but do not recognize their celestial nature—this is one whose appearance is human but whose essence is celestial. Those who cultivate themselves thereby attain constancy, for the Way must reach Heaven before it can endure.

To "forsake others" means to withdraw from the crowd; to "receive Heaven’s aid" means to perfect one’s celestial nature alone. Heaven’s people are not subject to human dominion; Heaven’s sons are so called because they continue Heaven’s generation. All things under Heaven can be known through knowledge, and thus what can be studied is studied, what can be practiced is practiced, and what can be debated is debated. Only the Dao cannot be known through knowledge, and thus what cannot be studied is studied—as the classic says, "to study what is not studied." What cannot be practiced is the Way that is not a Way; what cannot be debated is the debate that is wordless. Should one reverse this and engage in effort, one will merely be undone.

Du’s commentary: The dwelling is the abode of qi. When yin and yang harmonize, there is tranquility. When the dwelling is settled in tranquility, the primordial qi arises within, and natural illumination shines without. Those who perceive it perceive the human Way; those who do not perceive it perceive the celestial Way. The world does not see the Way by which the perfected one unites with Heaven, but only their traces among others. Those who emulate and cultivate this attain constancy. With constancy, one endures and becomes a person of perfected nature. Having fully realized the human Way, though others may forsake them, Heaven aids them. Those forsaken by others are not the people of others but Heaven’s people; those aided by Heaven are not the sons of others but Heaven’s sons.

There are those who dwell in humble alleys, unknown to others, who follow Heaven in their comings and goings—these are Heaven’s people. There are those who occupy the halls of state, aided by Heaven, who revere and serve Heaven—these are Heaven’s sons. Today’s learners forcibly study what cannot be studied and thus harm their nature; they forcibly practice what cannot be practiced and thus harm their virtue; they forcibly debate what cannot be debated and thus violate principle. All this exceeds the bounds of one’s inherent nature, and so one cannot attain perfection but instead undermines one’s natural endowment.

Bi Xu’s commentary: When the numinous dwelling is greatly at peace, wisdom’s light shines within, and the celestial court gleams without. If I call an ox an ox, others call it an ox; if I call a horse a horse, others call it a horse—each thing names itself, and celestial illumination is not deluded. Those who cultivate great peace harmonize their light without altering their nature, never differing from the ordinary. In accord with things, they are forsaken by others yet honored by Heaven’s sons and aided by Heaven—these are those of constant virtue.

Worldly study studies what cannot be studied; true study studies what can be studied—this is the principle that "the world’s difficult tasks must begin with the easy." Worldly practice practices what cannot be practiced; true practice practices what can be practiced—this is the saying that "the sage’s words are easy, yet none in the world can practice them." Worldly debate debates what cannot be debated; true debate debates what can be debated—this is the saying that "the good do not debate; those who debate are not good." To know when to halt before what cannot be known and thereby attain perfection is like a boatman who stops at the shallows—should he seek to speed and sink, he would be imperiled. How could this not be failure? To return to one’s nature—what else could it be?

*Yanzhai’s Oral Exegesis*: Here, Master Zhuang broadly expounds the ultimate principle.

The cosmos is like the breast—when vast and settled, the light of Heaven emerges, which is sincerity manifesting as clarity. Once the light of Heaven shines forth, others see only the person, yet one is already aligned with Heaven. Cultivating the truth to this point is called "awakening," which is the enduring sincerity of utmost integrity. Thus, Heaven aids such a one, and people turn toward them.

The "Heavenly People" are no ordinary folk. The "Son of Heaven" is one whom Heaven cherishes as a child. In learning, conduct, and discourse—these three—people always flee from what they cannot learn, cannot practice, or cannot debate, for these are the natural Way. When one’s knowledge reaches its limit in what cannot be known and halts there, this is the pinnacle of attainment. To turn from this path is to invite the Creator’s ruin.

The body is the dwelling of spirit; when spirit is at peace, the dwelling is vast and settled—like a lord whose tranquility brings harmony to the household, or a ruler whose non-action brings serenity to the state. When vast and settled, movement, stillness, sitting, and all external states are naturally stable, not through rigid control or forced restraint, as if tethering a horse to halt it.

The light of Heaven is the inner radiance of one’s own numinous clarity, outwardly manifesting like a measureless weight of gold—others see one as merely human, yet in truth, one walks with Heaven. To cultivate this is to embody the constant virtue; with constant virtue, one’s merit aligns with Heaven’s movement. Outwardly appearing simple, the world overlooks and abandons them, yet Heaven loves and aids them, for their heart accords with Heavenly virtue.

The "Heavenly People" transcend human virtue, shining without dazzling. The "Son of Heaven" embodies Heaven’s principle and establishes the ultimate standard, extending virtue to others—this is what is meant by "dwelling above as the Son of Heaven, the virtue of emperors and kings; dwelling below as the Unmanifest Sage, the Way of the plain and unadorned kings."

All these are what the noble person should learn and practice, yet most people busy themselves with learning what others can do, losing their own innate abilities. Only those who attain the Way learn what others cannot learn—learning the unlearnable; practice what others cannot practice—non-action that pervades all; debate what others cannot debate—the debate of silence.

Truly attaining this is to know what others cannot know, reaching the utmost of knowledge. To abandon this and seek progress on the Way is to disrupt the natural balance, like clay on a potter’s wheel—how can one hope to perfect one’s virtue, let alone emit the light of Heaven and receive Heaven’s aid?

This is now difficult to explain; it seems it should be "accord with Heaven’s balance," as the ancient text uses *jūn* (balance), interchangeable with *gōu* (potter’s wheel).

Preparing things to sustain form, concealing the unforeseen to nurture the heart, reverence within extending outward—if, following this, myriad evils arise, they are from Heaven, not from people, and cannot disturb one’s completion. They cannot enter the numinous terrace, for the numinous terrace has its support, yet one does not know what supports it, nor can it be grasped.

If one does not see the sincerity within that gives rise to action, every action will be misplaced. If karma enters and does not depart, each change will be a loss. Doing evil in the open, people can punish it; doing evil in the hidden, ghosts can punish it. Only one who is clear about people and clear about ghosts can walk alone.

Those who act within the contract move beyond names; those who act outside the contract pursue extravagant expenditures. Moving beyond names, even the mediocre possess radiance; pursuing extravagance, one is but a merchant—others see them as towering, yet they are merely hulking.

One who exhausts things is entered by things; one who contends with things cannot even contain themselves—how can they contain others? One who cannot contain others has no kinship; one with no kinship is forsaken by all.

No weapon is sharper than the will—even the *móuzōu* blade is inferior. No enemy is greater than yin and yang, from which there is no escape between Heaven and Earth. It is not yin and yang that harm one, but the heart that employs them.

Guo’s commentary: Following what is self-sufficient, conforming to the completion of form. The heart generates itself—it does not emerge from calculation. Principle naturally extends outward—it is not reverence within neglecting externals. Heavenly principle has its own cycles of exhaustion and passage; calamity arises from human action. Accepting it as fate, its completion remains undisturbed. The numinous terrace is clear and unobstructed—anxieties and rest cannot enter.

"Having support" means not being moved by externals, yet in truth, it is not support. If one knows what supports it and tries to grasp it, one loses it. If action does not arise from one’s own sincerity, how can it be fitting? If affairs lie outside one’s proper role, this is the cause of loss.

If one feels no shame in hidden or visible actions, one can walk alone without fear. Moving within one’s proper role, conduct is not bound by names. Pursuing extravagance to benefit others is to diminish oneself for things.

One who acts beyond names inherently possesses this radiance and employs it. One who pursues extravagance, though it is not originally theirs, borrows it to trade. Others see them as stable, yet they deem themselves secure.

"Exhausting" means beginning and ending. "Contending" refers to acting outside the contract and being hulking. If one cannot even contain oneself, then even the self is not one’s own—how can there be kinship? Thus, one is forsaken by all.

The aspirations one clings to congeal fire and freeze ice—thus the weapon of the will is sharper than swords and halberds. When the heart commands qi, yin and yang clash and knot within the five viscera—can one escape this? Wherever one is, yin and yang abide; thus there is no escape.

Master Lü’s commentary: All things and I form one body—this means that when the primordial departs, things do not follow, for one is complete in oneself. "Guiding the form" means that wherever one goes, things follow; when things come, the heart responds—not born of calculation. From this reverence arises, and through it one reaches others. There is no reliance on externals; reverence straightens the inner self. If, despite this, myriad evils arrive, it is Heaven’s doing. Since they arise not from action but from ruin, they cannot disturb completion. When the numinous terrace remains unmoved, there is something that holds and is held. None know its direction, for it is held by non-holding. Knowing this, one attains the sincerity that issues forth and invariably strikes the mark. Otherwise, reckless action brings misfortune—how can it be fitting?

When karma enters from without yet finds no master within, it will not depart. "Not departing" means its swift removal; each time one errs further, vulgar learning seeks to restore the original state, yet one remains a deluded person. The contract exists to master and possess things. Acting upon what resides within oneself is within the contract—sincerity in solitary action. Acting upon what does not reside within oneself is outside the contract, for one’s sincerity is not unified in hidden and visible realms.

Those who act beyond names follow the Dao, thus they are trustworthy without expectation. Those who act outside the contract must first prove trustworthy, first expend effort to give—only the mediocre possess radiance, which returns to its brightness when unused. Merchants merely trade; others see their insufficiency yet they strut in self-importance. If one perceives that things have never truly existed, one exhausts things yet remains without self. Without self, things enter yet are not cherished—this is called "knowing the constant and embracing all." Otherwise, one merely accompanies things.

If the self cannot contain itself, "your fragment of body will be rejected by qi, your single joint will be unsupported by earth"—how then can you contain others? One who cannot contain others has no kinship; without kinship, all people are estranged. The weapon of the will wounds the heart; weapons of war wound only the body. Bandits can be fled and evaded, but the bandits of yin and yang cannot be escaped within heaven and earth. Only the perfected person weakens the will and does not insist—thus they have no weapon. Concealed in non-yin, non-yang, and without heart, the myriad things cannot steal from them.

*Dú* commentary: All things are complete within me; the principles of nature and destiny are fully possessed. Retreating to concealment without calculation, when things come, one merely responds. Reverence and righteousness are established, and virtue is not solitary. If, despite this, myriad evils arrive, it is the preservation of Heaven’s mandate, not human action. The learning of the perfected person has reached the mandate; even affairs that are detestable cannot disturb their settled heart. The numinous terrace holds something, desiring its preservation. If one does not know the way of holding it yet clings to it with intent, it cannot be held.

Virtue can perfect the self; extending it to things is not misplaced. If one is insincere and acts recklessly, karma enters and does not depart—thus what was once gained becomes loss. To do evil openly is to deceive others; to do evil in secret is to deceive spirits. With shame in the heart, how dare one walk alone? Remaining within the contract is not overstepping one’s role. Relying on externals is how one acts beyond names. Going beyond the contract is to delight in others. Chasing things without end is how one aspires to extravagance. Acting beyond names, one is replete and radiance shines forth. Those who pursue extravagance seek through reputation, accept from others, and fear not being accepted—seeing their fondness for strutting, their foundation is precarious. Yet they remain arrogantly self-satisfied, unaware of change. Knowing change, things enter. Those who merely accompany things do not depend on them. If the self does not even dare contain itself, how can it contain others?

The perfected person has no kinship; one without kinship fulfills the human Dao—how could the Heavenly Dao not be fulfilled? People know the cruelty of weapons, yet do not know the harm of the heart is far greater. Weapon harm can be avoided; heart harm goes everywhere unchecked. Excessive joy congeals ice; excessive anger scorches fire—all are commanded by the heart. Only one without heart cannot be invaded by yin and yang or harmed by the five phases.

Master Bìxū’s commentary: The nature of the worthy and foolish cannot be altered—this is "completeness in oneself." The propriety of advance and retreat has gradations—this is "guiding the form." The intent of closing the sack without care gives rise to the heart that responds to things. Within, one is reverent and solemn; without, one is not insulted. When misfortune arrives without cause, it is Heaven’s mandate; when blame is incurred through attachment, it is human affairs. Abiding in stillness without worry, the numinous terrace is unobstructed, and one’s nature remains unharmed. Having something to hold, true nature is preserved; not knowing what holds it, there is no master. What cannot be held is led by one’s settled heart.

Without sincerity, all actions are reckless; the Dao and karma are difficult to enter, leading to further loss. Acting within the contract is to proceed without deviation, thus one is self-illuminating. Acting outside the contract, aspiring to extravagance, one becomes a peddler. Others see their precarious strutting yet they deem themselves secure. Those who exhaust things are within the contract, growing ever more with others. Those outside the contract merely preserve themselves. Without kinship, one is isolated and unattached. The aspiration to extravagance is more poisonous than blades; the reckless heart is a greater bandit than yin and yang. Thus the malevolent qi of excess cannot be escaped.

*Yuànzhāi’s Oral Teachings*: All things are complete within me. One follows the natural arising of life and retreats to concealment in the realm of non-thought.

The heart’s response to things arises in accordance with the times—what the Buddhists call "wherever one goes, the mind arises there." Reverence abides within, naturally extending outward. When matters arise that do not conform to one’s intent, it is truly Heaven’s doing—how could they disturb the perfectly formed virtue within my breast?

*To hold* means to have something as one’s master, yet without knowing what that master is. *What cannot be held* refers to being fixated on holding fast, which remains untransformed. The phrase with three instances of *hold* is exceedingly subtle. When one lacks sincerity and acts recklessly, missing the mark upon acting, one becomes entangled in the consequences. Though one may recognize the error, one cannot let go—this is the shame of transgression and the fault of wrongdoing. With every attempt at correction, further deviations appear. The karma of untrained conduct—what people now call the karma of established actions—brings human condemnation and ghostly retribution, from which there is no escape.

Knowing the awe-inspiring nature of the unseen and the manifest, one should be vigilant in solitude, thus able to walk alone. *Within the contract* means not overstepping one’s allotted portion, so others cannot name it. *Outside the contract* means seeking what lies in others. The aspirations one sets are merely resources for expenditure, aiming at self-benefit. Only the mediocre possess brilliance—fullness that radiates enduring light. To abandon oneself and seek externally, with the mind set on profit, is the mentality of merchants. Others see their precarious strutting, deeming them towering and venerable, unaware that they are submerged in desire, pursuing it to the point of exhaustion.

Moreover, those who chase things, grasping at whatever they can, rushing toward disaster without remorse—such people cannot even accommodate themselves among others, let alone kin. To be estranged is to sever the bonds of humaneness. Any attachment of the heart can wound oneself, more poisonous than blades. The harm of yin and yang is like that of bandits. When the heart is at peace, it cannot cause harm.

If one knows that the myriad transformations arise within the body, the greatest of all things, one can accord with the principles of life. *To conceal* means to delve deeply. *To generate the mind* means to respond to things. By deeply entering the realm of non-thought, things come and one responds—responding without a mind, reverence abiding within and naturally extending outward. This is self-cultivation and the transformation of things. Even if calamities of recklessness arise, one accepts them without allowing them to disturb one’s perfected nature.

The *spirit terrace* is an analogy for the heart’s emptiness, spaciousness, and luminosity. When external things arrive, they are received without lingering; if they accumulate within, they become extreme and the spirit loses its efficacy. *To hold* means to govern it. Knowing it cannot be held, one holds it by not holding. Without sincerity, there is no inner reverence; acting inappropriately means failing to extend outward—both are errors.

*Karma* refers to worldly, intentional actions. Not inclining toward good necessarily inclines toward evil. Those who do good are few, while those who do evil are many—thus none escape the condemnation of humans and ghosts, for cause and effect intertwine endlessly. Viewed through the Dao, both good and evil karma are illusory—how much more so evil? Yet those who do evil are always uneasy, their dreams restless, and at the threshold of life and death, how could they not be terrified? It is not that ghosts and spirits seek vengeance; the heart itself does this.

To do good with the mind set on seeking blessings is to allow deluded thoughts to sprout, losing one’s true nature, and becoming susceptible to external temptations.
