Thus, if either good or evil karma lingers in the heart without separation, the more one acts, the more one loses—how then can one know the way to uphold the spirit terrace?

Only those who comprehend the conditions of the hidden and the manifest can walk alone between Heaven and Earth, moving without shame. Those who focus inwardly value substance, thus acting without fame and establishing virtue as if in secret. Those who focus outwardly value splendor, thus aspiring to utility and parading their abilities. Only by returning brilliance to clarity can one endure.

Merchants seek to sell, unlike those who deeply conceal as if empty. This describes inconstant people who prioritize externals over internals. Others see their restless striving and deem them grand and imposing. *Those who exhaust things* means fully realizing the nature of things. *To enter* means to return. If one clashes with things, self and other stand in opposition—how can one who cannot accommodate oneself accommodate others? For one of great virtue, what cannot be accommodated? If I lack virtue, others will reject me equally. Inability to accommodate others leads to isolation, with everyone else beyond oneself. Divergent aspirations breed conflict, no less than the banditry of yin and yang. Tracing its source, the heart is the thief.

How great is the heart! It is the source of good and evil, the pivot of fortune and misfortune. If one fails to grasp the essentials of holding it, desires will shake it, leading to insincerity and misaction. Condemnation by humans and retribution by ghosts become inescapable. Though Heaven and Earth are vast, a single fragment of the body will have no place to reside! Thus the noble person is cautious in what arises.

*Hidden and manifest*—the old pronunciation is *xián* (闲), but considering the meaning of "manifest" above, this should be *hé* (合), a missing stroke in transmission.

*End of Scroll Seventy-Two of the* Nan Hua Zhen Jing Yi Hai Zuan Wei*.*
*#1 According to the* Que Wu*, Zhang Junfang’s edition includes "others see their person, things see their things" after "others see their precarious strutting." The Guo commentary also does so.*

*Scroll Seventy-Three of the* Nan Hua Zhen Jing Yi Hai Zuan Wei*.*

The Daoist of Wulin, Chu Boxiu’s *Miscellaneous Chapters: "Gengsang Chu" (Chapter Four)*

The Dao is all-pervading—its division is #1, its completion is its destruction. What is detestable about division? Its division is for the sake of completeness. What is detestable about completeness? Its having a means to completeness.

Thus, to emerge and not return is to reveal one’s ghost; to emerge and obtain is called "obtaining death." To be extinguished yet possess substance—this is one with the ghost. By using the formed to model the formless, one attains stability.

Emerging without root, entering without aperture. Possessing substance yet without location, having length yet without root or tip, having an emergence yet without aperture—this is possessing substance.

Possessing substance yet without location is *yu* (space). Having length yet without root or tip is *zhou* (time). There is life, there is death, there is emergence, there is entry. Emerging and entering without visible form—this is called the Gate of Heaven. The Gate of Heaven is Non-Being. The myriad things emerge from Non-Being. Being cannot use Being to create Being; it must emerge from Non-Being, and Non-Being is the absence of Non-Being. The sage conceals himself therein.

**Guo’s Commentary:**
Completion and destruction have no fixed division, yet the Dao pervades all. Not abiding by one’s division and seeking completeness—this is why division is detestable. One’s original division is incomplete yet seeks completeness—this is why completeness is detestable. Not returning to guard within one’s division, one’s death will not be long in coming. Not emerging yet fundamentally obtaining—this is obtaining life. Extinguishing one’s nature, though possessing life, how is it different from a ghost? If the formed can be vast and without attachment, then life is preserved and form is stabilized.

Emerging spontaneously, it has no root; dying spontaneously, it has no basis. To say that what emerges has substance is merely that its emergence has no root or aperture. Space has the four directions and above and below, yet the four directions and above and below have no bounds. Time has the length of past and present, yet the length of past and present has no limit.

Life and death, emergence and entry—all occur suddenly of themselves, without cause, and thus their form is unseen. The Gate of Heaven is the collective name for the myriad things, akin to the "Gate of the Myriad Mysteries." Things have gathering and scattering, concealment and revelation, hence the names of emergence and entry, yet ultimately there is no emergence or entry—where then is the gate? If Non-Being is the gate, then it is the Gate of Non-Being.

Before Being existed, what was it that gave rise to it? It must have arisen from Being—how could Being itself create Being? This clarifies that Being cannot create Being but arises of itself. It is not that Non-Being can create Being—if Non-Being could create Being, what would Non-Being be? If there is one instance of Being, then Non-Being is already lost. If Non-Being is truly Non-Being, then Being spontaneously arises—this is the illumination! Thus, the sage allows things to live of themselves and does not force life.

**Lü’s Commentary:**
All things possess the Dao, thus without completion or destruction, their division is precisely what enables pervasiveness, and their completion is precisely what enables destruction. What is detestable about division? It is because completeness arises from division. What is detestable about completeness? It is because division arises from completeness. If division exists for the sake of completeness, then completeness stands in opposition to division, and division differs from pervasiveness. If there is a means to completeness, it is not spontaneous completeness, and completion differs from destruction. This is how the Dao becomes dispersed.

Only by dividing without awareness of completeness, and by being complete without awareness of the means to completeness, can one go anywhere without obstruction. The Dao transcends life and death. Emerging and possessing life must return to what was never born—then life is preserved. Emerging and not returning, though alive, reveals one’s ghost. Emerging and obtaining life is due to deliberate action—obtaining death is fitting. Extinguished yet possessing substance, one cannot return to the original thing. Emerging and not returning—how is this different from emerging and obtaining? Thus, their ghostly nature is one and the same.

Only by using the formed to model the formless can one attain stability. Stability means not being disturbed by life and death. Things that emerge must have a root; emerging from the Dao, they have never had a root. Things that enter must have an aperture; entering the Dao, they have never had an aperture. Things that possess substance must have a location, yet what emerges without a root possesses substance without location. Things that have length must have a root or tip, yet what enters without an aperture has length without root or tip.

Thus, the text should read: "What emerges without a root has length; what enters without an aperture has substance"—then the meaning is complete. Space has the four directions and above and below, thus possessing substance. If I take what is above me as "above," then what is above my "above" takes my "above" as "below," and this applies to what is below and the four directions as well—how can there be a fixed location? Time encompasses past and present, thus possessing length. If the present takes the past as past, and the future takes the present as past, how can there be a root or tip?

Realizing this, one is not constrained by space and time; the six directions and four limits are nowhere absent. Though there is life and death, emergence and entry, their form is unseen—this is called the Gate of Heaven. The Gate of Heaven is Non-Being. Being cannot create Being; it must emerge from Non-Being. The things of the world are born from Being, and Being is born from Non-Being—this is so. What is called Non-Being is not Non-Being, yet all Non-Being is negated—this is the true Non-Being. The sage conceals himself therein, roaming where things cannot pursue yet all are preserved.

**Yi Du’s Commentary:**
The Dao emerges from Heaven; division originates from nature. Division entails completion and destruction, but the Dao pervades them. People do not abide by their division yet seek completeness—this is why division is detestable. If division is incomplete yet seeks completeness, this is why completeness is detestable. If one is greatly complete yet makes no demands, what is there to detest?

Things emerge from the Dao and do not return—they reveal their ghost. If they can return, they do not depart from the spirit. Emerging and obtaining is called death; the spirit has no death. Extinguished yet possessing substance, one is the same as a ghost.

Only that which has form yet bears no burden remains constant—when it mirrors the formless, it attains stability.

Things burst forth of themselves, revealing no origin; they vanish of themselves, disclosing no aperture. Emergence is called life; vanishing is called death. To possess substance is nature. To abide nowhere is to cling to no realm. That which endures is the Dao. The root is swift, the end and beginning one. Where there is emergence, there is substantive nature; substantive nature is fundamentally empty—thus it is called the aperture of Non-Being.

All that possesses form and vessel cannot escape the midst of the cosmos, yet their death and life, emergence and vanishing remain unseen—this is called the Gate of Heaven. The Gate of Heaven is where spirit comes and goes, now closing, now opening; the myriad things emerge and vanish here, yet in essence, nothing exists. What exists must arise from Non-Being, but Non-Being itself is not a nothingness—this is the ultimate! The sage conceals himself therein, so nothing can harm him.

**Bi Xu’s Commentary:**
The Great Dao is all-pervading, embracing both Being and Non-Being, yet each thing has its allotted portion—one cannot prescribe a single remedy for all. As fish thrive in water while ants drown in it, the inherent portion is already fixed, the natural endowment of things. Thus, though completeness is detestable, one cannot escape the karma of prior causes—hence it is said, "it possesses the means to be complete." If the true is dissipated and does not return, yin qi comes to dwell there—thus its ghost appears. To open the mouth and manage affairs is called "emerging and obtaining." If what is lost is equated with loss, this is called "obtaining death." Once the celestial light is extinguished, though substantive nature remains, it becomes one with the dark and obscure.

Those who cultivate the Dao take emptiness as their body and Non-Being as their mind—how could this not be stability? Creation has no root; the Great Void has no aperture. Though rootless and apertureless, principle possesses substance—yet where it resides remains unknown. The wondrous root knows no premature end; this is called "enduring," yet no beginning or end is visible. Observing its solitary transformation, one sees that though apertureless, it possesses substance. The four directions and above and below are boundless, and its substance is likewise boundless; past and future are infinite, and its substance is likewise infinite. Though names exist for life, death, emergence, and vanishing, no paths lead to them—thus it is called the Gate of Heaven. The Creator is no-thing; all forms are self-created, and the Gate of Heaven, too, does not exist.

For Being cannot generate things—what is generated lies in Non-Being. Movement cannot transform forms—what is transformed lies in stillness. Both Being and Non-Being inevitably involve entanglement, so one lodges in the principle of utmost Non-Being and wondrous Being, merging them into a single Non-Being. The sage conceals himself therein, in unity with creation.

**Yongzhai’s Note:**
The world divides completion and destruction into two, but from the perspective of the Dao, they are one—this is to penetrate their division. When the heart divides self and other, it inevitably seeks completeness in self-interest. All that exists returns to Non-Being, yet those who seek completeness in self-interest merely pursue Being—thus those who embody the Dao detest this. Responding to things and returning is to obtain and become spirit; pursuing things without returning is to sink into the realm of ghosts.

To be without affirmation or negation toward things is to keep this heart ever alive. Clinging to affirmation and negation without transformation is to render this heart dead. "Emerging and obtaining affirmation" means being enslaved by externals and acquiring self-righteous views—this is a heart near death, from which yang cannot be revived. Being and Non-Being are the substantive principle between Heaven and Earth; if one extinguishes them with a private heart and clings to Being as real, that person is no different from a ghost. Only by using form to image the formless can one see principle as stable.

As the Buddhists say: "Simply empty all that exists; do not substantiate what does not." Things must have a beginning, yet it cannot be known; things must have an end, yet the place of their vanishing is unseen. Though substantive principle exists, it cannot be sought in any direction; past and present are thus, without visible beginning or end. The cosmos is used to illustrate the Dao’s vastness and constancy. The life, death, emergence, and vanishing of things all have their source, yet no visible form—this is the wonder of creation. The Gate of Heaven is creation’s spontaneity; because things emerge and vanish here, it is called a gate. All emerges from Non-Being, yet this Non-Being is itself a singular Non-Being. The sage’s heart conceals itself in Non-Being—this is also the meaning of "concealing in secrecy."

The Dao originates from the One; the true body is undifferentiated, yet it pervades and generates the myriad things—its body is thus divided. Yet the completion of the myriad things is the Dao’s destruction. Thus, one detests division because, though the qi of the Dao is fully present in the myriad things’ distinctions, the sage fears that as things proliferate, the Dao becomes ever more fragmented, the uncarved block scattered and difficult to restore. One detests completeness because people cannot forget things to unite with the Dao; the more they amass the means of life, the more they neglect the Way of preserving life. There are those whose forms are not nourished despite excess.

The Dao’s pervasiveness through the myriad things is like water’s pervasiveness through the hundred rivers. The Dao has no intention to pervade things, yet things cannot but receive the Dao; water has no intention to pervade rivers, yet rivers cannot but accept water. Only when the Dao pervades things does the power of generation and completion become manifest; only when rivers accept water does the work of transport and bearing come to fruition. Thus, in its division, how could division be detestable? In its completeness, how could completeness be detestable? This aligns with the *Qi Wu Lun*: "Its division is its completion; its completion is its destruction. The myriad things are neither completed nor destroyed, returning to unity in the Dao."

"Emerging without returning" means forgetting the Dao and pursuing things, seeing one’s movement toward the realm of death—"this" refers to this Dao. To be "born and obtain this Dao" is to enter death through the Dao as well. "Obtaining death" means reaching one’s destined death, akin to "nurturing life to nurture death." The world destroys its true nature, mistaking things for reality; though the form remains, it is no different from death—this is what is called a "walking corpse." Only by using form to image the formless can body and mind both be emptied—how could things then move them?

Emergence is not without origin, yet none know where it sprouts;
Return is not without aperture, yet none know where it returns.
Truly able to empty both body and mind, one becomes vacant yet numinous, still yet luminous—
things arise and are surely reflected, not a hair’s breadth deceived.
How much more so for one’s own sprouting and returning?

"Substance" refers to true nature.
"Eternity" refers to the source from which nature arises.
True nature manifests everywhere without fixed location:
in the eye, it is called seeing; in the ear, hearing.
The source from which nature arises governs form and division, its beginning and end unknown—
it endures from high antiquity yet does not age.

That which emerges without origin has eternity—
it speaks of birth yet none can fathom its root, merely flowing with transformation.
That which enters without aperture has substance—
it speaks of death yet none can perceive its gate, merely an undimmed singular truth.

Master Lü’s supplementary lines are most apt:
If one takes spacelessness as the cosmos, then wherever one dwells is at peace;
If one takes rootlessness as the cosmos, then wherever one goes is attained.
How could the cosmos fail to contain the myriad beings?
How could the myriad beings vie with the cosmos?

All things’ birth, death, emergence, and return must have that which governs and sustains them,
yet its form is unseen—this is called the Gate of Heaven.
Forced to name it a "gate" by the passage of things, in truth it has no existence.
To cling to its non-existence is still not free from existence;
only by transcending both existence and non-existence does one reach the subtlety of true emptiness,
wherein the ten thousand things and principles reside.
The sage conceals himself in non-existence, thus can possess all things without exception.

*Biao* means "tip" or "end."

The ancients’ knowledge reached its utmost!
Where did it reach? Some held that there had never yet

The theory of "shifting right and wrong" begins with the advent of life, thus taking life as its root. Life emerges from consciousness, thus taking consciousness as its teacher. Through mutual reinforcement, right and wrong proliferate. Once right and wrong shift, outcomes acquire names and realities, and one thereby takes oneself as correct. In its extreme, this leads to treating one’s own rightness as personal integrity and clinging to it—even to the point of dying for it—without realizing that what one calls the self never yet possessed any fixed substance. Success and failure, poverty and prosperity, are not of the self, yet people falsely divide themselves into categories of wise and foolish, honored and disgraced. This is the harm of today’s "shifting right and wrong"—like the warbler and the turtledove sharing the same nest, how could they know of the greatness of the celestial pond?

*Dubi Zhu* annotates: "Never yet possessed any fixed substance" refers to the time before the Great Beginning; "possessing substance" refers to the time after the Great Beginning. The Great Beginning is the origin of qi. Qi contains yin and yang, hence beings have birth and death. Beings arise from existence, and existence arises from the primordial. To know that life is the loss of the primordial is to know that death is the return to the root. Yet birth and death are already divided. After the advent of beings, life begins from primordial existence; once there is life, death soon follows. Primordial existence is like the head, life like the body, death like the corpse—though these three have sequence, they belong to one body, just as the Zhao, Jing, and other four clans originally shared one surname, yet scattered until they became many. *Zang* means "black darkness." To treat *zang* as an excrescence of life and disperse it is called "shifting right and wrong." What is spoken of here is unknowable. To claim knowledge and speak of it is to shift right and wrong further.

The *la* sacrifice is the great offering. *Pìgāi* refers to the ox’s viscera. When conducting the full ritual, one may not distribute the offerings; once completed, distribution is permitted. If distribution is forbidden, then to distribute is deemed wrong; if distribution is permitted, then to distribute is deemed right—thus the mutability of rightness. This is like deeming feasting and libations proper within the ancestral temple, yet deeming repose and stillness proper when retiring to the privy. Humans are bound to life, thus clinging to their own rightness. If one could relinquish life, where would rightness reside? With life comes knowledge, and through it one rides upon rightness. Yet both right and wrong are delusions clung to as if they were name and reality, taking the self as substance—substance being fixed and immutable. Thus the self becomes the arbiter of right and wrong, demanding others honor one’s principles, even to the point of repaying with death. Such is to judge wisdom and folly by acceptance or rejection, honor and disgrace by success or failure. This is the world’s shifting of rightness—how does it differ from the oriole and turtledove both deeming thistles and mugworts right?

The *Bixu* commentary states: Before the advent of beings, all was profound and ineffable; only those who act with silent devotion may inwardly realize it. Next comes the advent of beings, referring to the embryo. The perfected person treats life as loss and death as return, thus acknowledging life and death. Though life and death differ, both emerge from the singular source of primordial *qi*, just as the Zhao, Jing, and Qu clans, though bearing different surnames, all trace to the single lineage of the Duke of Chu. *Zhuódài* refers to splendid robes and caps; *Jiǎshì* to eminent clans and lofty ranks; *zhuófēng* to abundant domains and prosperous counties. Though these affairs differ, they do not depart from the capital of Chu—just as *qi* gathers into *zang* to form life, then soon scatters in death. Unaware of heaven and earth’s subtle transformations, one clings to right and wrong, deeming life right and scattering wrong, or deeming primordial *qi* right and silent gathering wrong. Right and wrong have no fixed master, thus no definitive words can be spoken; it falls to the learner to discern and analyze.

The analogy is this: the coarse and foul viscera may be scattered, yet the great sacrifice with its complete offerings may not. The principle of life, death, *zang*, and scattering is the same. The ancestral temple and the privy further illustrate the mutability of rightness. Life is the root of right and wrong, knowledge their teacher—thus riding upon them leads to endless confusion. Taking name and reality as fixed, one clings to them as personal principles, even unto death without regard. Each simply deems their own rightness right—how does this differ from the cicada and turtledove sharing the same narrow view?

The *Yongzhai Oral Teachings* state: In the beginning of primordial beings, life and death, beginning and end, were undivided. Next came the names of life and death. To treat life as loss is to lodge temporarily within the realm of form; to treat death as return is to go back to one’s true dwelling. Once life and death exist, beings arise, and thus division begins. Above lies the realm without beings, the inception of the Great Ultimate. Next comes the advent of beings, when yin and yang divide. Following that comes life, and with it the self—though even with the self, life and death are treated as one. Though these three have sequence, none depart from the Dao, like the royal clan dividing into three, their surname remaining one. The Zhao and Jing clans became eminent through office, the Jia clan through enfeoffment. *Zhuódài* refers to holding office. Though Zhao, Jing, and Jia are not one clan, all belong to the royal house of Chu. The above speaks of the three differing yet sharing one royal lineage, then beneath the character "four" adds "not" to conclude—linking above and below, severing yet not severing, a marvel of composition.

*Zang* is the soot at the bottom of a cauldron, also a flaw or affliction. To say that no *qi* congeals to form a person is also a flaw in *qi*. This aligns with the notion that life is an ugly, belching thing. Humans share this *qi*, yet forcibly divide and claim their own rightness. "That of which one cannot speak" refers to each person having their own rightness, yet what is deemed right remains unsettled—thus unknowable.

The completeness of the *la* sacrifice’s *pìgāi* offerings, the wholeness of the sacrificial animal—during the ritual, the animal’s body is arranged upon the stands, called "scattering." Though the sacrificial animal is one and may not be scattered, this illustrates how human rightness shifts and remains unsettled. The five viscera are represented by the hundred leaves, the hundred limbs by the toes—a literary device. Just as within a single chamber there is the sleeping quarters, the ancestral shrine, and the place of repose, each different yet part of one room, so too does the mutability of rightness remain undetermined. Observing the *la* sacrifice and the chamber, one sees that all so-called rightness is mutable and unsettled—hence the term "shifting rightness."

To examine substance as human is to be bound to form; to return to the state before the advent of beings is not easy. All beings are illusions—when the mind abides, they abide; when the mind vanishes, they vanish. If my mind does not stir, standing solitary and serene, one may call it the state before the advent of beings. Should one attain this, then even life and death become mere lodgings—this the ancients who attained the Dao could achieve. Next comes the advent of beings and the division of life and death, yet those who treat life as loss and death as return differ from ordinary people adrift in the flow of life and death. Beyond this lies the state without division into life and death: head, body, and corpse—though these three differ, all emerge from the Dao, like the royal clan of Chu being one yet bearing the distinct surnames Zhao, Qu, and Jing. This refers to the proliferation of noble kinsmen and the diversity of enfeoffment systems, an analogy for the growth of knowledge and the expansion of desires.

*Piao* is the soot clinging to the cauldron’s bottom, seeming to have form yet not, arising from form. Humans lodge in form and have life—this too is like *zang*. Soon scattered, the so-called self shifts elsewhere, its existence or nonexistence undefinable. Thus, speaking of it is like the *la* sacrifice’s *pìgāi* offerings: the complete sacrificial animal may not be scattered, yet once the ritual ends, the portions may be distributed. In the ancestral temple, one stands in solemn reverence; in the privy, one cannot avoid a degree of irreverence. Life is the root of right and wrong, knowledge their guide—thus riding upon them leads to endless confusion. Taking name and reality as fixed, one clings to them as personal principles, even unto death without regard. Each simply deems their own rightness right—how does this differ from the cicada and turtledove sharing the same narrow view?

These are all transferable truths. The scriptural text once spoke of "transferring truth" in five characters, whose detailed meaning should precede the phrase "those things unknowable"—this is confirmed by Guo’s commentary. Humans deem themselves right because they possess life; with life comes knowledge, and knowledge serves as its guide. These two ride upon one another without cease. If one clings to them as name and reality, taking them as one’s personal essence, they become unchangeable—unable to shatter the illusory dust and recognize emptiness as real. Thus, treating name and reality as personal principles, even to the point of death in recompense, all stems from insisting on one’s own rightness, leading to this flaw. The world follows these habits without awakening to their error, no different from the cicada and turtledove sharing the same narrow flight between elm and sapanwood, unaware of the roc’s journey of ninety thousand miles.

*End of the Seventy-Third Scroll of the* **Ocean of Meanings in the Southern Florescence True Scripture: Compiled Essentials** *#1 In the Gaoshan Temple edition, the phrase "its division" is followed by the characters "its completion."*

*Seventy-Fourth Scroll of the* **Ocean of Meanings in the Southern Florescence True Scripture: Compiled Essentials**
*By Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin*

**Miscellaneous Chapters: Gengsang Chu, Fifth**

When you tread upon a stranger’s foot in the marketplace, you apologize with an excuse of carelessness; if it is your elder brother, you merely smooth your feathers; if it is your closest kin, you let it pass. Thus it is said: the highest ritual does not treat others as others; the highest righteousness does not regard things as things; the highest wisdom does not scheme; the highest benevolence has no partiality; the highest trust dispenses with gold.

Dispel the turbulence of the will, untie the delusions of the heart, cast off the burdens of virtue, and clear the blockages of the Way. Wealth, honor, eminence, prestige, fame, and profit—these six are the turbulence of the will. Appearance, movement, countenance, principle, qi, and intent—these six are the delusions of the heart. Aversion, desire, joy, anger, sorrow, and delight—these six are the burdens of virtue. Rejection, acceptance, taking, giving, knowledge, and ability—these six are the blockages of the Way. When these four sets of six are not stirred within the breast, one is upright; when upright, one is still; when still, one is luminous; when luminous, one is empty; when empty, one acts without acting and yet nothing is left undone.

The Way is the reverence of virtue; life is the radiance of virtue; nature is the substance of life. When nature moves, it is called action; when action is contrived, it is called error. Knowledge is contact; knowledge is planning; what knowledge does not know is like a sidelong glance.

To move only when unavoidable is called virtue; to move without self-exclusion is called governance. Names may be opposed, but realities are in accord.

**Guo’s Commentary:**
When treading upon a stranger, one claims a slip to apologize. With an elder brother, one bows in deference. With the closest kin, one says nothing—this shows plain forgiveness. "Not treating others as others" means seeing others as oneself. Without mutual apologies, this is the perfection of ritual. Righteousness means each attains its proper place, so all things are oneself. Wisdom that relies on scheming is not natural; it is like the five constants, which do not seek mutual closeness yet all arrive as one. Gold and jade are but petty tokens of trust; great trust transcends them. Movement arising from nature is called action—this is true action, not contrived. The eye does not know sight yet sees; the heart does not know knowing yet knows. This is the natural. To move only when unavoidable is not forced movement, so there is no error. To move by imitating others is disorder. With the names of self and other, there is opposition; when each attains its reality, there is accord.

**Lü’s Commentary:**
If a stranger draws a bow to shoot me, I speak of it with laughter, for there is no kindness between us, and I do not expect kindness. Thus, treading on a foot requires an apology of carelessness. If a brother draws a bow to shoot me, I speak of it with tears, for there is kindness between us, and I expect kindness. Thus, even treading on a foot does not seem unloving—one merely smooths one’s feathers. With the closest kin, no apology is needed, for kindness is complete, and smoothing is unnecessary. From this, we see that the perfection of ritual, righteousness, wisdom, and knowledge does not depend on externals. To know the meaning of ritual without following vulgar rites is to practice the ritual of not treating others as others. To act appropriately without seeking to suit things is the righteousness of not regarding things as things. To respond as things arise without prior scheming is the wisdom of not scheming. To treat the people as straw dogs and make the world forget distinctions is the benevolence of no partiality. To be trustworthy without relying on gold is the trust that dispenses with gold. If one attains the Way, these five perfections are all attained.

The will is where the heart goes; the heart is the harmony of virtue; virtue is the Way within me. Thus, dispelling the will precedes untying the heart; casting off burdens precedes clearing blockages. To cultivate the will, value weakness. To make wealth and honor one’s will is not weakness but perversity—it must be dispelled. To value the heart, value emptiness. To make appearance and movement the heart is not emptiness but delusion—it must be untied. Virtue’s perfection is to return to the origin; thus, desires and aversions are burdens of virtue—one must cast them off. The Way’s attainment is to penetrate the One; thus, rejection and acceptance are blockages of the Way—one must clear them. When all these burdens are not stirred within the breast, the Way gathers.

Without reverence, there is no Way, so the Way is the reverence of virtue. Without life, virtue cannot be seen, so life is the radiance of virtue. Nature is the substance of life. When nature moves, there is action; when action is contrived, there is error. Life does not inherently know action, so knowledge is contact, not innate with life. Knowledge used after planning is called scheming. What knowledge does not know is the self-knowing of knowledge, like the unglanced-at that enables the glance. Thus, to move only when unavoidable is nature’s action, not contrived error—this is called the Way. To move without self-exclusion is to unite with things—how can movement cause disorder? If one can be thus, then though the world’s self and other, right and wrong may seem opposed in name, in reality they are never discordant, for the Way excludes nothing.

**Yi Du’s Commentary:**
With kin bound by heaven, one does not mind disrespect; with others, one would. Thus, treading on a stranger requires an apology of carelessness; with a brother, one smooths one’s feathers; with a parent, one says nothing. From this, we see that words and apologies are not truly real. The highest ritual is like heaven, so it does not treat others as others. The highest righteousness forgets the self, so it does not regard things as things. The highest wisdom unites with things, so it does not scheme. The highest benevolence loves broadly, so it has no partiality. The highest trust is unwavering, so it dispenses with gold. Turbulence does not penetrate, so it must be dispelled. Delusion does not free, so it must be untied. Burdens obscure, so they must be cast off. Blockages are not empty, so they must be cleared. When these four sets of six are not stirred within, one is upright in the One. Upright, one is still; still, one is luminous; luminous, one is empty and unobstructed. How wondrous!

The Way that can be spoken of is the reverence of virtue. The life that can give life is the radiance of virtue. What is mandated within me is nature, the substance of life. When nature moves, all action is natural; contrivance is error, the cause of loss.

To engage with things and plan affairs through knowledge inevitably involves the use of knowing, yet even the wise have what they do not know, just as the sidelong-glancing have what they do not see. The spirit, however, knows all and sees all without exception. Nature arises from stillness; compelled by necessity, it responds to things—this is its movement. In movement, it does not lose correctness, allowing all things to attain their own fulfillment. How could there be disorder? Though compelled to move, it appears contrary, yet when all things attain their own fulfillment, it is truly in accord. *Bixu’s Commentary*: When one has caused harm or error to others, if the relationship is distant, one cannot avoid offering apologies; if close, one simply forgives. In the highest ritual, forgetting the self brings order; the presence of others brings chaos. In the highest righteousness, holding fast to integrity preserves the self, but attachment to things causes loss. In the highest wisdom, clarity arises without thought; excessive scheming leads to confusion. In the highest benevolence, all things are as straw dogs, and closeness or distance are the same. In the highest trust, one never breaks a promise—how could gold or jade be needed as surety? Wealth and honor cannot disturb one whose will is unobstructed. Demeanor and movement cannot entangle one whose heart is empty. Desires and aversions cannot bind one whose virtue is profound. Advancement and retreat cannot rigidly obstruct one whose Dao is luminous. When no affairs disturb the numinous inner chamber, one is utterly clear and spiritually luminous, gazing afar into the vast desert of the world. How could the exhaustion of deliberate action drown one? Those who rely on what is described struggle to accompany the formless. The withered and desiccated are cursed to compare with the flourishing and radiant. Without nature, there would be no being; from what could being arise? How upright is its essence! Seeing, hearing, eating, and resting—all are acts of nature. Yet these acts are not true action, for they are the loss of the Dao. Thus, one does not engage or discourse—what need is there for knowledge? The wise, in what they commonly know, know indeed; but in what they do not know, they are utterly at a loss—like one who squints and cannot see straight. Moved only when pressed, in movement one attains. The real, when used to govern the self, what does it not govern? Inner and outer, self and things, are like east and west—opposite yet unable to do without one another. *Yongzhai’s “Righteousness”*: The highest ritual, righteousness, wisdom, and benevolence do not depend on external things.

Here the metaphor of "heel and foot" gathers its meaning in the following four-six rhythm, which must not sway within the breast—this is where one begins to practice. *Qin* (reverence) is the solemnity of holding fast. *Sheng* (life) is the manifestation of virtue. That nature resides within me is the original substance of my being. When nature acts, and action drifts into falsity, then it is lost. Responding to things, planning, and deliberating—all are the knowing within nature. Yet those who claim knowledge of what they do not know are like infants squinting without seeing. All movement and action, when done only out of necessity, may be called virtue—this is the forgetting of the self. Within this forgetting of the self, there is nothing that is not the self. This is the form within the formless, the formless within form. When things cannot disturb it, it is called governance; when it is necessity, when nothing is not the self—these names seem contradictory yet are never truly at odds. This is another way of speaking.

To distinguish respect and awe by nearness or distance is but the ritual of the vulgar world, mere pretense. Constant reverence lies in one’s elder brother; momentary respect lies in a village acquaintance. With one’s closest kin, love and respect abide without need for explanation. Even if one stumbles in heel or foot, no question remains—thus the highest ritual, righteousness, wisdom, and benevolence do not depend on external things or actions but attain their perfection spontaneously. This arises from the natural principle of heaven, allowing no deliberation, and those who practice it follow the same track.

As for dissolving the will and freeing the mind, removing burdens and clearing obstructions—this belongs to human effort and is a step lower. The four-six rhythm must not sway within, revealing the essentials of entering the Way. From rectitude comes stillness, enabling response to the world’s movement. From clarity comes emptiness, enabling the world’s fullness to be contained. Thus, what was earlier called the highest ritual and righteousness is seamless and converges with the Dao.

Virtue is what things revere; the Dao, in turn, is what virtue reveres—its loftiness is thus known. Life is the radiance of virtue; righteousness should be the radiance of virtue’s life. If one lacks virtue, how can there be life? That things are given life is called virtue. Nature is the substance of life; that form and spirit each preserve their proper pattern is called nature. When nature moves, it is called action; thus, to know non-action is to know that nature has never truly moved. When action becomes falsity, it is called loss; thus, to know action is to know that it has never been truly real.

The world’s men of knowledge engage with things, plotting and scheming, fearing only that their engagement is too narrow and their knowledge too shallow. They exhaust their bodies and spirits yet fail to realize that what they do not know is precisely what they claim to know—like one who squints and sees nothing, yet boasts of seeing all. Thus, in responding to things and handling affairs, one must act only out of necessity, then it arises from nature’s spontaneity and is without loss. This is the opposite of worldly names yet in truth accords with them. As *Laozi* says: "True words seem contradictory." This is how those with the Way differ from the vulgar and can engage with things without harm.

Yi was skilled at hitting the smallest target yet clumsy at making others praise him. The sage is skilled at heaven yet clumsy at man. Only the *quanren* (whole person) can be skilled at heaven and yet stubborn with man. Only the insect can be an insect; only the insect can be heaven. Does the *quanren* hate heaven? Does he hate man’s heaven? How much more his own heaven or man’s! When a sparrow comes before Yi, Yi must catch it—such is his power. But if the world is made his cage, the sparrow has nowhere to flee. Thus, Tang used a kitchen servant to cage Yi Yin, and Duke Mu of Qin used five sheepskins to cage Baili Xi. Thus, there is nothing that cannot be caged by what it loves.

The hunchbacked adorn themselves with elaborate patterns, yet this is not for praise. The convict laborer climbs high without fear, having abandoned life and death. To return to speech without offering and forget others—this is to forget others and thereby become one with heaven and man. Thus, one who is revered feels no joy, and one who is insulted feels no anger—only one in harmony with heaven’s accord is so. Anger that arises from non-anger is anger born of non-anger; action that arises from non-action is action born of non-action. To desire stillness, calm the qi; to desire spirit, follow the heart—this is action. To desire rightness, abide in necessity; necessity is the way of the sage.

Guo’s commentary: Skill in hitting the mark leads to praise—this is the constant principle. Following nature is heaven; acting with intention is man. To be skilled at heaven is to be clumsy with man. The *quanren* is the sage. That the insect can be an insect is to be able to be heaven—this is to be utterly without knowledge yet follow it, which is called skill at heaven. Power compels things, and things must follow; all things in the world have their loves, and each attains what it loves—where then can they flee? Adornment enhances appearance, but the amputee’s form is already maimed, so he no longer cares for beauty or ugliness and discards it. The convict laborer has no attachment to life, so he does not fear death. To return to speech without offering and forget others is to be ignorant of what others value, devoid of human sentiment, and thus naturally one with heaven and man. If even the mutilated convict laborer can be in harmony with heaven’s accord, how much more the natural accord of heaven? Anger arising from non-anger, action arising from non-action—this is the idea that the non-existent gives rise to the existent, and the existent cannot become non-existent.

To calm the qi is to be still; to fulfill principle and follow the heart is to be spirit. To perfect action by abiding in necessity is to act rightly in all things. The sage takes this as the Way—how could he seek non-action beyond the indistinct? Lü’s commentary: The scriptures speak of heaven-men, spirit-men, perfect men, and sages—here there is also the *quanren*. The sage flees transformation, skilled at heaven yet clumsy with man. The *quanren* surpasses even this, skilled at heaven yet stubborn with man.

Crawling and pecking, flocking and herding—such are the abilities of creatures. Unaware of why they do what they do, yet doing it, is the creatures’ accord with heaven. What the *quanren* detests is the heaven of men. The heaven of men knows what it does not know; the heaven of heaven forgets even what it does not know. If one detests even what one does not know, how much more would one detest measuring heaven and man with human judgment?

When a sparrow strays into Yi’s snare, it is caught by his might; those that do not stray are not caught by his might. If one takes all under heaven as a cage, then the myriad things are all ensnared and have nowhere to escape—how much more a mere sparrow? Only one who delves deeply and profoundly enough to penetrate the minds of all under heaven can take all under heaven as a cage. Thus, even figures like Yi Yin and Baili Xi could not escape, for they were caged by what they loved.

The crippled man, though scorned and praised by others, can still alter his adornments and refuse to follow convention. The convict laborer, though facing life and death, can still climb heights without fear—how much more one who can forget others? It is fitting that he neither flatters nor repays. Through repeated practice, one may still be unable to forget what others cannot help but feel ashamed of, yet forgetting others is but the means to becoming a heaven-man. Clearly, the heaven-man is not merely one who forgets others; forgetting others is but the path to it. This is the same as the knowledge of heaven—fitting that he respects without delight and is insulted without anger.

Anger often arises from non-anger, action often arises from non-action. In non-anger and non-action, there has never yet been anything, yet from them all things arise. Qi is emptiness awaiting things; when man cannot calm it but instead agitates it, it does not become still. If one can truly calm the qi, there is nothing that does not become still. The heart in man is spirit; when man cannot follow it but instead disturbs it, it does not become spirit. If one can truly follow the heart, there is nothing that does not become spirit.

To act rightly is to be true to oneself. Hesitating to undertake affairs, as if crossing a river in winter—all this is the meaning of necessity. *Yi Du Zhu*: To gain men through might yields little; to gain men through the heart yields much. To take them by archery is might; to cage them by what they love is virtue. Yi Yin loved to season the cauldron, so he carried the cauldron to offer himself to Tang, and Tang caged him as a cook. Baili Xi loved the five-colored sheep pelt, so Duke Mu of Qin caged him with five-colored sheep pelts. Thus, each won their hearts and put them to use.

The crippled man, a petty person, adorns his exterior; the petty man has already forgotten his form and bones, scorning praise and blame without weariness. When practice reaches completion and one no longer repays one’s teacher, one has forgotten the way of man, and from forgetting the way of man, one takes oneself to have entered the realm of heaven. Man cannot escape the obstruction of partiality; if one has not forgotten the self, there is always something that binds. Respected, he delights; insulted, he angers. Only one in harmony with heaven’s accord feels joy or anger not from respect or insult but in accord with the order or chaos of all under heaven. King Wu’s anger brought peace to all under heaven—this anger arose from non-anger.

Since anger arises from non-anger, action likewise arises from non-action. Thus, one does not agitate the qi but keeps one’s nature still; one does not oppose the heart but keeps one’s spirit whole. Desiring that all affairs be right, one acts from necessity—this is the sage’s way of responding to things. *Bixu Zhu*: One skilled at the mean is clumsy at concealing praise; one wondrous in naturalness is distant from human artifice. When the traces of heaven-men and men alike vanish, this is the *quanren*.

Creatures often name themselves by their abilities, while flying and running without substitution is called the ability of heaven. The *quanren* detests heaven, not using the mind to follow the Dao; detests the heaven of men, not using man to aid heaven—how much less would he care for men’s praise of skill or blame of clumsiness! A bird mistakenly enters Yi’s snare, just as a scholar inevitably enters the cage of the state. Yi gains birds through might, and Yi’s might kills the birds; the state gains scholars and prospers, while the state’s prosperity wearies the scholars. Gain and loss follow the principle of nature. Yi Yin and Baili Xi could not be without desires or forget their loves, so they were caged by Tang and Duke Mu. If the heart has no loves, how could it be caged?

Those who adorn their appearance delight in praise; those who value life fear death. One who repeatedly practices and cherishes without repayment has forgotten human affairs. When practice becomes second nature, and one takes it as natural, it is like the crippled man scorning praise and blame, or the convict laborer disregarding life and death. When humiliated, what room is there for joy or anger? One whose nature is in harmony with heaven’s accord is the same. If anger does not arise, it festers and grows; when it arises, it vanishes without a trace. If action does not act, it frustrates the desire to act; when it acts, it becomes vast and non-active. This is because the original nature is without anger and without action.

Calming the qi and stilling perception—what is there to be angry about? Following the heart and settling the spirit—what is there to act upon? When movement arises from necessity, it accords with affairs—this is the sage’s Dao. *Yanzhai Kouyi*: Yi cannot prevent men from praising themselves, just as the sage cannot escape the world’s renown. One who can fully embody heaven’s Dao and yet conceal his traces among men—this is the person of complete virtue.

Creatures’ flying, running, calling, and leaping each follow their nature—these are the abilities of creatures and the abilities of heaven. The *quanren* does not name himself by heaven, detesting heaven as disliking to bear its name. If even one who distinguishes between heaven and man in himself detests it, how much more would I distinguish between heaven and man? Yi was skilled at archery, so men feared him; if one takes all under heaven as a cage, the sparrow need not wait to be shot. Yi Yin and Baili Xi were also caged by what they loved; if they had no loves, they would have transcended things—who could cage them?

The hunchbacked man removes his ornate adornments, for his heart has already cast aside praise and blame.

The men of *xumi*, *chengdan*, and *chong*—who care not for their bodies—ascend heights without fear, for when the heart holds no attachment, there is nothing to cling to. This is like the *Yi*’s "reversal of the Dao." *Wei* means "to practice"; *kui* means "to give to others." This Dao resides within oneself—it is not merchandise to be sold. To know it for oneself is to forget others; to forget others is to enter into heaven.

In the *Xu Wugui* chapter, "I must sell it," yet they still treat it as constant—from this one may understand the meaning of "not giving." To be in harmony with the harmony of heaven is to become one with the Creator. Anger arises not from anger; to act in the world yet hold no concern is to be "non-active yet nothing is not done." The shift in phrasing below—"only when compelled does one act"—speaks of responding to things without intent.

If Yi were not skilled at archery, how could men praise him? If the sage were not skilled at governance, how could the people turn to him? Yet when things turn to one, one becomes burdened; where there is skill, there is clumsiness—this is an inevitable principle. To be skilled in heaven and clumsy in man is still acceptable; but to be skilled in man and clumsy in heaven is to be wholly entangled in human desire—what then can be done? Thus, to be skilled in heaven and stubborn in man is to be complete and free from the cares of the hidden and the manifest.

At dawn, the damp transforms; in due time, creatures fly and crawl—these are the abilities of creatures. The crow’s kindness, the magpie’s friendship, the spider’s web, the spider’s pellet—these are the abilities of heaven. That man can possess both the abilities of man and of heaven may likewise be inferred.

The complete person detests "heaven"—detests man’s division of himself to become heaven, not the natural heaven itself. How much less would he divide himself into heaven and man? He must conceal man within heaven, blending them into one—this is how he attains complete virtue and escapes the burdens of the world.

A single sparrow comes to Yi, and Yi seizes it by force. To seize things by force is not as abundant as seizing them without intent. If one takes all under heaven as a cage, what is gained is not merely a sparrow. Only when there is something loved can one be caged; with utter indifference and no desire, how can one be caged?

The hunchback does not wish for adornment; the convict does not fear death—both are remnants of punishment, despised by others, yet they have no intent to preserve life, no choice but to endure. But when this endures long enough, the heart holds no shame or fear, forgetting what others cannot forget, and thus entering into the natural. This speaks of dwelling in stillness long enough to become at ease and transformed. How much more so for one who is rooted in the natural and possesses the abilities of both heaven and man? Their transcendence of the dust and solitary awakening—who can measure it?

Trivial external respects and insults—how could they disturb a vast and unshaken heart? To be in harmony with the harmony of heaven is to possess the ability of man to become heaven. When anger arises without anger, what passes is transformed. When action arises from non-action, affairs are accomplished without record. The sage is not without joy or anger, nor without action; yet things do not arise from trifles, so his responses are not for private gain but move with the moment. With single-mindedness, he nurtures his *qi* to ride the opportunities of things—angry where anger is due, acting where action is due—taking the hearts of the people as his own heart. In encouraging good and punishing evil, it is as if he neither angers nor acts.

When *qi* is level and still, the heart is compliant and the spirit at peace. He responds only when moved, acts only when pressed—how could there be anything amiss? The classic text’s "not giving" is hard to explain; one version reads "not ashamed," which I follow here.

Gengsang Chu, compared to Laozi, embodied the whole in miniature, yet what he had not yet attained still stood out distinctly. Dwelling in Weilěi, the people praised his virtue—this is the common way of sages and worthies in benefiting things. But when the hearts of the multitude rejoice and wish to exalt him, the advance of love and benefit becomes conspicuous, and when things interact, emotions arise. Thus, Nanrong’s perception was still like that of Weilěi.

Gengsang feared his virtue was insufficient to transform, so he sent him to see his teacher, intending to shift his heart and awaken him. This was like passing the baton to another, ensuring trust without doubt, so that the profound words could enter. Thus, upon entering the gate, there was a single rebuke, a shout—no questions, no answers—both were lost. Like letting go at a cliff’s edge, where the root of life is severed—how rare is such an encounter!

Alas, Nanrong could not directly accept it but instead rambled and digressed, expounding at length. Laozi diagnosed the source of his illness and sharply admonished him. Nanrong withdrew, gathered himself, washed and reappeared—one might say he was good at receiving teaching and able to renew himself. Thus, in their next encounter, Laozi seized the moment to point directly, completely removing his clinging to cleverness, and gradually applied the medicine.

Zhao Zikui’s capacity for the Dao was shallow; he only wished to hear the classic of preserving life. Yet the Dao’s methods of filling and broadening lie within man’s ears. Laozi taught him to embrace the One, to seek himself, to return to infancy, and to follow things. The classic of preserving life is revealed here. When questioning reaches its limit, it returns to "Can you be like a child?"—words have their source, affairs have their lord.

Next, he discusses the vastness of the universe, issuing from the light of heaven, and the numinous terrace, which holds nothing. This means the chamber is empty and whiteness arises—one must not eagerly seek with a heart of intention and action. The explanations of "external and internal contracts," the metaphors of "overstepping and usurping"—these further teach scholars to know weight and add selection.

There is no birth or death; in sequence and priority, all are of one body. The ancestral temple and the privy, the exalted and the lowly—each has its proper place. This is to awaken to the truth that the root of life has no existence, and to break the delusion of shifting identities.

As for the uncle’s esteem, the rich man’s desires, the evil man’s ambitions, and the confused man’s heart—one knows that the will must be unified and the heart must be empty. Whatever involves the burdens of things and obstructs emptiness and clarity must be abandoned and kept far away—this is how one preserves one’s heaven and returns to the Dao.

The offerings at the winter sacrifice are complete yet may be scattered and are not constant. Yi was skilled at hitting the mark yet clumsy at concealing his reputation—these all dissolve the common views of clinging, expand the transformative power of the mysterious, blend the skill and clumsiness of heaven and man, and transcend the distinctions of things, self, right, and wrong. Forgetting praise and blame, respect and insult, one arrives at "not acting" and "not angering."

When still, one nurtures the balanced qi and preserves its vastness by not disturbing it; when spiritually attuned, one follows the heart’s love of harmony and aversion to deceit. Thus, one dwells in serene solitude with the divine luminaries, stabilized in unity and responding without fixed direction.

This is the profound transmission of heart-mind that Old Lão bestowed upon Gēng-Sāng, just as there were truths between Yánzi and the Master that could not be voiced. *Nán-Huá* revived the lost learning a hundred years later, and Mèng’s school, upon hearing it, knew its truth—practice to the utmost, and success is one. Therefore, it is held forth as the model for all under heaven.

*—End of Scroll Seventy-Four of the* Nán-Huá True Scripture: An Ocean of Meanings, Compiled with Subtleties*
*—Scroll Seventy-Five of the* Nán-Huá True Scripture: An Ocean of Meanings, Compiled with Subtleties*

**Xú Wúguǐ, the First**

Xú Wúguǐ, through Nǚ Shāng, gained audience with Lord Wǔ of Wèi. The lord greeted him, saying, “Master, you are worn out! Have you wearied yourself in the mountains and forests, and so now deign to see me?”

Xú Wúguǐ replied, “It is I who have wearied you—what weariness have you for me? If you indulge your desires and prolong your likes and dislikes, the natural sentiments of your life will sicken. If you suppress your desires and learn your likes and dislikes, your ears and eyes will sicken. I weary you—what weariness have you for me?”

Lord Wǔ, startled, made no reply.

After a moment, Xú Wúguǐ said, “Let me tell you: I read dogs. Those of low quality stop when full—this is the virtue of a wildcat. Those of middling quality seem to gaze at the sun. Those of high quality seem to have forgotten their oneness. In reading dogs, I am not as skilled as reading horses. In reading horses, the straight meet the plumb line, the curved meet the hook, the square meet the carpenter’s square, the round meet the compass—these are state horses, yet they do not compare to the horses of all under heaven. The horses of all under heaven have fully developed their material; they seem anxious, seem lost, seem to have forgotten their oneness. Such as these surpass all bounds, leaving dust behind, and none know where they go.”

Lord Wǔ was greatly pleased and laughed.

When Xú Wúguǐ departed, Nǚ Shāng asked, “Master, how did you alone delight our lord? When I delight our lord, I expound horizontally with the *Odes*, *Documents*, *Rites*, and *Music*, or follow vertically with the *Golden Tablets* and *Six Canons*. Those who serve him and achieve great merit are beyond counting, yet our lord never so much as parts his lips. How did you delight our lord so that he was pleased like this?”

Xú Wúguǐ said, “I simply told him about reading dogs and horses.”

Nǚ Shāng said, “Is that all?”

Xú Wúguǐ replied, “Have you not heard of the exiles of Yuè? After a few days away from their state, they rejoice at seeing those they know. After a month away, they rejoice at seeing those they once saw in their state. After a year, they rejoice even at seeing those who resemble people. Is it not that the longer one is parted from others, the deeper the longing for them? Those who flee into emptiness, though their paths be strewn with blossoms and lined with pillars, tread the void, and when they hear the sound of human footsteps in the hall, they rejoice—how much more so when brothers and kin drink and feast at their side? For how long has no true person’s words feasted at our lord’s side?”

Guō’s commentary: The ears and eyes, in their likes and dislikes, find nothing within or without—hence, they are sick. “Startled, he made no reply” means he was displeased with the words. Yet what is there to yield in the words of a true person? Only things have likes that can be indulged. Expounding horizontally and vertically, the lord never parted his lips—this is like delighting in cranes with bells and drums, hence the sorrow. Hearing about reading dogs and horses and rejoicing is like one who leaves their state and sees those they know, each longing for what their nature loves. When one attains what they love, there is no longing; without longing, one forgets the cause of their joy. The words of a true person attain our lord’s nature—first attaining it, he rejoices; attaining it long, he forgets.

Lǚ’s commentary: Wúguǐ forgot Lord Wǔ’s power and admonished his illness; Lord Wǔ, because Wúguǐ did not humble himself, was startled and made no reply. Wúguǐ used the analogy of reading dogs and horses to express his lack of demands. Dogs of low quality stop when full, like people who, when hungry, are useful and have demands. Those of middling quality seem to gaze at the sun, like those who look high and far yet cannot forget themselves. Forgetting oneness means forgetting oneself can be known. Horses that meet the compass, square, hook, and plumb line are state horses, comparable to state scholars who roam within the bounds. The horses of all under heaven have fully developed their material, untrained yet natural—they seem anxious, as if none share their joy; seem lost, as if none match them. Seeming to have forgotten their oneness is to forget the self entirely, not merely to lose it. Surpassing all bounds, leaving dust behind, none know their whereabouts—how much more so for the scholars of all under heaven who roam beyond bounds and cannot be known? The meaning is: if even the high quality of dogs and the horses of all under heaven are like this, how could I know your power and humble myself before you? How could you not read me?

Lord Wǔ grasped his meaning, hence his great delight. Speech is the means by which the Dao is met.

Words not aligned with the Dao, though drawn from the *Odes*, *Documents*, *Rites*, or *Music*, cannot move the heart; words aligned with the Dao, though merely about judging dogs or horses, suffice to bring delight.

When one loses the true nature of life and indulges in human artifice, it is like leaving one’s homeland and kin to wander in distant lands—akin to fleeing into the void, forever restless among weasels and martens. What is called "true" is the inherent nature of one’s being, like the familiar bonds of homeland and kin. Is there anyone so madly deluded as to hear the voice of a true person and not rejoice?

**Yi Du’s Annotation:**
Wu Gui was a recluse of Wei. Nü Shang was a chief minister of Wei. Wu Hou was the son of Wen Hou. Wu Hou, pitying Wu Gui for the toils of mountain and forest life, expressed his concern upon meeting him. Wu Gui replied: though dwelling in mountains and forests, I have never known toil. Now, my lord, when your desires overflow, the true nature of life suffers; when you suppress desires, the faculties of ear and eye suffer—these two afflictions cannot be escaped. Thus, I weary you, not you me. Wu Hou made no reply, resisting in his heart.

Wu Gui, knowing he could not speak of great matters, instead used the art of judging dogs and horses—appealing to his lord’s predilections—to strike the mark.

**On the Qualities of Dogs:**
The lowly quality: sated with food yet devoid of ability.
The middling quality: aspirations lofty and far-reaching.
The highest quality: as if having forgotten their oneness.

"Oneness" is the essence of all numbers; to forget even this is profound—how much more so for the coarse. Next, the judging of horses: "meeting the line," "hooked," "compassed," "square"—all are methods of training. The horses of all under heaven possess fully formed material, so one does not speak of "square" or "round," "curved" or "straight." Their gaze seems anxious, as if troubled; their bearing seems lost, as if unmatched. These may still be discerned by form. But when they forget their oneness, they surpass all bounds, leave dust behind, and none know their whereabouts.

**On Persuasion:**
That which goes against the grain is "contrary"; that which follows is "compliant." Wu Hou favored martial arts and despised culture, so Nü Shang called the *Six Classics* "contrary" and military strategy "compliant," seeking to align with his lord’s inclinations. He further cited the example of an exile from Yue: at first, after leaving his homeland for days, he rejoiced at seeing acquaintances; after a month, he rejoiced at seeing those he had seen before; after a year, long parted from his countrymen, his longing deepened—even seeing one who merely resembled a fellow villager brought joy. How much more so for one who flees calamity into the emptiness of the wild, where weeds choke the paths of weasels and martens, and all traces of human presence vanish? At such a time, even hearing the sound of footsteps—let alone the voices of brothers and kin laughing at one’s side—would bring boundless joy. Wu Hou’s heart had long cherished dogs and horses, so hearing of one skilled in judging them brought delight, though he had yet to witness the truth of it. Thus, having long been deprived of worthy words and voices in his presence, he rejoiced even at this humble art.

**Bi Xu’s Annotation:**
"When desires overflow, the true nature of life suffers; when desires are suppressed, the faculties of ear and eye suffer"—this is what was earlier called "inner and outer loss." "As if lost" and "as if forgotten" both denote a lack of self-possession. To forget one’s oneness is not as severe as to lose it entirely.

For the discussion here borrows dogs and horses merely as a starting point—how could these be considered the ultimate aim? Its true purpose is to reverse the inclinations of Wu Hou, first drawing him in through coarse matters before guiding him toward the subtle and profound.

**Wu Chou’s Annotation:**
The "ghostless" refers to the spirit-like person, who seizes the moment and rides the momentum without allowing the heart to intervene. Thus, the speaker’s words, though silent, convey deeper meaning: following the return of the Dao without opposing its principles, accommodating another’s preferences without clashing with their nature. Even Wu Hou’s harsh and violent temper yields to joy and laughter, for the analogy is rooted in the Way.

**Yongzhai’s Oral Exegesis:**
"Raccoon virtue" describes a nature like that of a raccoon, the basest of dogs. "Gazing at the sun" means fixing one’s stare upward without blinking. "The One" is the nature of life—though alive, it seems dead, like the wooden rooster, the highest grade of horse. "Complying with the compass, square, hook, and plumb line" signifies that each part conforms to the rule, without rigidly seeking exactness. "Village of completion" refers to natural, heaven-born perfection. "As if anxious, as if lost" conveys a state of absentmindedness. "Losing the One" is the same as "forgetting the One." Thus, "transcending the dust and leaving no trace" describes a destination beyond knowing—all these are borrowed metaphors.

*The Six Bow-Cases* refers to *Tai Gong’s Art of War*. "Golden tablets" is akin to saying "stored in a golden casket." "Service with merit" means that one’s actions yield tangible results. The analogy of "flowing into exile from the state" requires no explanation. "Voice and swallowing" refers to the sounds within the throat.

Chu Shi’s Humble Insights:
Dogs and horses are common livestock, their abilities no more than guarding against thieves or serving as mounts—even if one selects them with the keenest eye and discerns their true nature, this hardly amounts to an extraordinary skill. Yet when Marquis Wu heard of it, he was greatly pleased. Why? The more adept the persuader, the more he must seize upon his listener’s preferences to ensnare him, making his words easier to accept—just as a king fond of warfare is swayed by military analogies.

Ponder the phrase “village of completion” applied to the world’s horses: one can imagine the bearing of a steed that transcends the dust and leaves no trace. Even the arts of Bo Le and Jiu Fang Gao would here find nothing left to appraise. To say “losing the One” may still be describable; but to speak of “forgetting the One” is to capture a state so elusive it defies depiction—unlike the state of a fine state-bred horse, which can be likened to compass, square, hook, and plumb line.

The “One” is the first sprouting of things. “As if lost, as if forgotten” suggests a realm between presence and absence, where form and substance cannot be pinned down. Only by awakening to the Dao can one win Marquis Wu’s heart, and the effect is swifter than that of the *Odes*, the *Documents*, or the *Six Bow-Cases*.

The later analogy of exile—longing for one’s homeland—implies that those who have lost their nature will inevitably seek to recover it. If someone seizes the moment to rouse them, how different is this from hearing the sound of footsteps in a vast, empty land? “For so long now…” expresses regret that no one has offered profound words and subtle truths to move Marquis Wu’s heart, so that he delights in hearing about the physiognomy of dogs and horses. Were a worthy minister to draw near and gradually transform him with the whispered teachings of virtue, I know his innate goodness would return like water flowing back to the abyss—vast and unstoppable. Thus, the gentleman does not reject any who would purify their hearts and turn toward goodness.

Some may doubt that Xu Wugui was a worthy man: upon meeting Marquis Wu, he suddenly spoke of dogs and horses, seemingly without purpose. But Marquis Wu was habitually arrogant, so loyal ministers could not approach, and the words of true men went unheard. Xu Wugui sought an audience intending to correct him, yet the Marquis treated him as an ordinary scholar. Thus, he expounded: “I can discern the strengths and weaknesses of dogs and horses and decide which to keep or discard—how could you, my lord, fail to recognize the worth of men and treat them with due respect?” This was the unspoken meaning behind his words.

When Xu Wugui met Marquis Wu, the Marquis said: “Master, you dwell in the mountains and forests, eating taro and chestnuts, weary of onions and leeks, yet you deign to visit this lonely one—how long it has been! Are you now old? Do you crave the taste of wine and meat? Or does this lonely one possess some blessing for the altars of soil and grain?”

Xu Wugui replied: “Xu Wugui was born poor and lowly; I have never dared to partake of your lordship’s wine and meat. I come to labor on your behalf.”

The Marquis said: “What do you mean? How do you labor for this lonely one?”

He replied: “I labor your spirit and your form.”

Marquis Wu said: “What does that mean?”

Xu Wugui said: “The nurturing of Heaven and Earth is one. Standing high does not make one tall; dwelling low does not make one short. Yet you alone, as lord of ten thousand chariots, exhaust the people of your state to indulge your ears, eyes, nose, and mouth. The spirit does not permit this. The spirit loves harmony and detests deceit. Deceit is a sickness—thus, I labor to cure it. It is you, my lord, who suffer from this sickness. Why?”

Marquis Wu said: “I have long wished to meet you, Master. I desire to love the people, practice righteousness, and lay down arms—is this possible?”

Xu Wugui said: “It is not. Loving the people is the beginning of harming them. Practicing righteousness and laying down arms is the root of raising arms. If you proceed thus, you will surely fail. All completed beauty is a dangerous tool. Though you act with benevolence and righteousness, you verge on hypocrisy! Form inevitably gives rise to form; completion inevitably invites attack; change inevitably leads to external conflict. Do not parade splendid battle formations between the watchtowers; do not station swift cavalry in the ancestral temples; do not harbor rebellion within success; do not seek to outwit others; do not seek to outmaneuver others; do not seek to overcome others through warfare. Those who kill the people, seize their lands, and nourish their own selfishness and spirit through war—how can one say which side is good? Where does victory lie? If you cannot stop, my lord, cultivate sincerity within your heart to respond to the feelings of Heaven and Earth, and do not obstruct it. The people are already dead and free—what use will you have for laying down arms?”

Guo’s Commentary:
Heaven and Earth nurture all equally, not favoring the ruler, yet you indulge without limit. To exhaust the people to indulge your ears, eyes, nose, and mouth is to violate the balance of Heaven and Earth. The spirit does not permit itself; it is the things that grant it. To share with things is harmony; to permit oneself is deceit. The path of “loving the people” is what the people esteem, but loving oneself is hypocrisy. Hypocrisy spreads names and sparks competition; fathers and sons, rulers and ministers, will harbor doubts and deceive one another—how can one then lay down arms? Only by acting through non-action can this be achieved. Beauty completed in the past gives rise to hypocrisy later; the people will follow with hypocrisy. Benevolence and righteousness have form, hence hypocrisy. Form must be crafted, thus it is conspicuous. “Change” means losing what is constant. “Crane formations” are battle arrays. “Watchtowers” are high towers. Infantry are called “foot soldiers.” One should not lay down arms for the sake of righteousness, nor should one amass troops or race horses. To harbor rebellion within success is to lose it.

To preserve its uncarved simplicity is to keep it level, for simplicity has its own capacity. To follow genuine knowledge as knowledge, each with its own excellence, is to keep it balanced. Responding to things through the Dao, things submit without claim to victory. Not knowing what constitutes goodness, even conquest is no true victory for oneself. If one cannot yet cease, then nothing surpasses cultivating one’s own sincerity. Let weapons remain unstationed, yet this is not disarmament.

Lu’s commentary: To govern the state with knowledge is the state’s bane; to govern the state without knowledge is the state’s blessing. Thus, loving the people is indeed the beginning of harming them, and disarmament is indeed the root of creating weapons—for it is done through knowledge, not the Dao. When all under heaven know beauty as beauty, ugliness is already present; thus, achieving beauty is inherently an instrument of ugliness. As an instrument, it has already strayed far from the Dao. Even with the benevolence of loving the people or the righteousness of disarmament, it is but hypocrisy. The form of loving the people inherently invites attack, becoming the beginning of harming them; the form of disarmament inherently leads to external war, becoming the root of creating weapons. Only without form is there nothing to create.

When crane formations are arrayed upon watchtowers, they are admired and observed. When foot soldiers and warhorses are paraded upon drill grounds, they are played with and observed. This is not using them out of necessity. If one nearly attains success yet does not follow the principle of heaven, then rebellion is concealed within that attainment. To overcome others with cunning schemes is to rely on knowledge rather than the Dao. To overcome others through war is to rely on military strength rather than virtue. Killing people and seizing land to nourish one’s private desires and one’s spirit—self-interest is self-approval, while the spirit detests and afflicts it. To call conquering others through war “good” is to not know where true goodness lies in overcoming evil.

If a ruler must act out of necessity, let him cultivate sincerity to respond to the feelings of heaven and earth, and all things will respond—how then could the people’s deaths not be averted?

Du’s commentary: Heaven and earth are the greatest of formed things, yet what they nourish is the One. The One is the origin; the *Book of Changes* speaks of the origin of Qian and the origin of Kun, which even heaven and earth revere—how much more should humans? The Dao of heaven and earth takes levelness as correctness; ascending high or dwelling low, what distinction is there in short or long? Now, if a ruler occupies the heights to exalt himself, oppresses the people to nourish himself, suffers external attacks from traitors, and loses his inner spirit, the spirit does not approve—this is why he is afflicted and cannot but toil.

Marquis Wu again asked about loving the people and disarmament. When the path of loving the people becomes conspicuous, the people compete to regard love as benevolence—this is the beginning of harm. Acting for righteousness makes names prominent, and prominent names spark competition; thus, it is called the root of creating weapons.
