These are all actions of deliberate doing, hence perilous and unachievable. When simplicity scatters, it becomes instruments; instruments, once formed, have beauty and ugliness. Now, even if one wishes to practice benevolence and righteousness, all are unavoidably hypocritical. Form is what things take. This is creating form; once formed, there is merit, and merit inevitably invites attack. Change means losing one’s constant guard, and profit and desire wage war externally.

Crane formations are the image of deploying troops. Watchtowers are places to observe troops. Drill grounds are where troops train. Success for oneself is rebellion against others—this is concealing rebellion within attainment. Cunning arises from the sprouting of scheming within; though it may overcome others, it does not benefit oneself. Plotting stems from doubt and fear, unsettled. War is killing people to seek victory—all these harm what one nourishes and should not be done. Using this to nourish one’s private desires cannot fulfill them; using this to nourish one’s spirit cannot preserve it.

Though victory in war may be achieved, it is not the Way of true victory. Only by cultivating sincerity to align with Heaven and Earth and refraining from contention can the people avoid premature death and injury—why then insist on righteousness to lay down arms?

Bi Xu’s commentary: Marquis Wu long indulged in desires and forgot his root, so Wu Gui spoke bluntly of exhausting his lord’s form and spirit. Heaven and Earth nurture humanity as one; ruler and people are originally undivided. Now, however, the deficient are depleted to serve the excess—this is contrary to principle. The spirit of humanity and the spirit of Heaven share the same ultimate impartiality. To claim it as one’s private possession is what is called treachery. The people follow the ruler’s transformation; if the ruler ails, the people suffer—hence the admonition.

Marquis Wu then asked about the essentials of righteousness and laying down arms. As fish in a dried-up stream long for moisture, so people in hardship and want yearn for benevolence and righteousness. The answer: love, when esteemed, leads to inequality and much harm; righteousness, when established, invites conflict and loss—all are undone by those who enact them, bringing peril and little success. The Dao is lost, then benevolence arises; virtue is lost, then righteousness arises. When benevolence and righteousness are exalted, the people’s nature is altered, and falsity is born.

As for crane formations, watchtowers, and drill grounds—these are not the foundations of lasting peace and are not worthy of esteem. Following Heaven’s principle averts loss and death; indulging in martial affairs breeds ambition for conquest. Excessive cunning leads to early exhaustion; extreme warfare invites dynastic collapse. Responding to Heaven is impartial; claiming sagacity for oneself is private. How could the spirit tolerate the private? Heaven’s Dao aids the good—victory’s fruit lies herein.

*Yanzhai’s Oral Teachings*: Heaven and Earth give life to all things without distinction of high or low, noble or base. To nourish the form with external things while the heart remains unfulfilled is to deny the spirit’s self-possession. Harmony means unity with things. Treachery is self-interest. Our spirit is originally one with the myriad things; when emotions and desires obscure it with self-interest, this is what it abhors—then illness arises. If the ruler suffers this unawares, I must admonish him.

Intentional love for the people harms them; intentional disarmament provokes conflict. The completion of good and evil follows set paths—hence the term "vessel." To act with a mind of contrivance in pursuit of tangible achievements is to "create form." Once formed, it becomes fixed. A mind clinging to fixation without transformation invites contention, resentment, and desire, injuring the inner self. To be disturbed and disordered by external things is "external warfare."

Crane formations are names of military arrays; watchtowers are names of official towers; drill grounds are places of sacrifice. If the human heart were in harmony with things, even within a single chamber, one would see no ranks of infantry and cavalry arrayed before them—how could it become a realm of strife? Human nature deems gain as compliance and loss as opposition; without gain, there is no loss—hence "concealing rebellion within attainment." This phrase is well placed below.

Cunning refers to the sprouting of scheming within. Knowledge and strategy arise from this cunning; warfare, in turn, arises from knowledge and strategy. Seeking victory to gratify one’s private senses is like winning—yet within the breast, things contend and disturb. Though victorious, the spirit is wearied—hence "where lies the goodness in such victory?"

"Refrain from contention" means: simply cultivate one’s original sincerity to align with the natural reality of Heaven and Earth, meeting things without conflict. Without striving, one achieves true victory, and the people’s deaths are already averted—why seek disarmament? Wu Gui met Marquis Wu again not to scheme for personal advancement but to correct his errors and deliver the people from calamity.

Marquis Wu, however, spoke of tiring of scallions and leeks while craving wine and meat—how greatly he exalted himself and belittled others! Wu Gui, unbowed by power, directly said, "You exhaust your spirit and form," not merely scorning him but pitying him. Yet Marquis Wu remained oblivious, so steeped in daily sensual pleasures that he neglected the care of his form and spirit—thus his bewilderment at the admonition.

Wu Gui then expounded on Heaven and Earth’s nurturing as one, to humble his self-exalting heart. The key lay in the phrase: "The spirit loves harmony and abhors treachery." The spirit is one’s true self. Yet Marquis Wu’s inquiry about righteousness and disarmament arose from losing righteousness and then seeking it, from exhausting warfare and then desiring disarmament—suddenly reversing his nature. Was this genuine?

Grace and harm arise from the same principle. Only by entrusting oneself to authenticity can one be preserved. All things completed and deemed beautiful are vessels of harm. This refers to tangible achievements. Loving the people and laying down arms are the most conspicuous of these paths. When I act with this heart, others respond in kind—this is "creating form." Once formed, it inevitably invites attack. Movement brings encounters with things—this is "external warfare." How much more so when arraying troops, parading cavalry, and flaunting might to the world, coveting the world’s submission? Gains achieved contrary to principle all conceal rebellion. Heaven aids the compliant—how can the rebellious endure?

Victory through cunning fills the world with schemes; victory through strategy expands calculations and deepens harm to things. Victory through war kills people, annexes lands, and burns cities and states—no harm is greater! All stem from accumulated violence, yet the vast net of Heaven cannot be escaped, and one perishes with it. Thus, one must be vigilant from the slightest beginnings.

Now, wielding the power of rulership, you indulge boundless desires to nourish your private self. Compared to nurturing your spirit, which is the better path? Where lies the goodness in such victory? Let Marquis Wu reflect on this himself. If you have not yet understood the Way of nurturing the spirit, simply cultivate your inherent sincerity to align with Heaven and Earth without contention. This is following Heaven and Earth’s nurturing, recognizing their unity with yourself. Then ruler and people will rejoice in harmony, the utmost accord flowing silently. Things will be free of blight, and people free of premature death—why then cling to the petty pursuit of disarmament?

The Daoist master of Wulin, Chu Boxiu, on *Xu Wugui* (Chapter Two)

When the Yellow Emperor was to visit Grand Chen at Mount Juci, Fangming drove his chariot, Changyu rode as his attendant, Zhangruo and Weipeng led the horses, while Kunhun and Guji followed in the rear carriage. Arriving at the wilds of Xiangcheng, the Seven Sages all lost their way and had nowhere to ask for directions. They happened upon a young boy herding horses and inquired of him, saying: "Do you know Mount Juci?" The boy replied: "I do." "Do you know where Grand Chen resides?" "I do." The Yellow Emperor said: "How extraordinary, this young boy! Not only does he know Mount Juci, but he also knows where Grand Chen dwells. Pray, may I ask how to govern the world?" The boy said: "Governing the world is no different from this—what more is there to be done? From my youth, I roamed freely within the Six Directions. Then I fell ill with dizziness, and an elder taught me, saying: 'Ride the sun’s chariot and wander the wilds of Xiangcheng.' Now that my illness has slightly improved, I am about to roam beyond the Six Directions once more. Governing the world is just like this—what more is there to be done?"

The Yellow Emperor said: "Governing the world is truly not your concern. Nevertheless, I beg to ask how to govern the world." The boy declined to answer. The Yellow Emperor pressed him again. The boy said: "What difference is there between governing the world and herding horses? Simply remove what harms the horses—that is all."

The Yellow Emperor bowed twice, touching his head to the ground, and called him "Heavenly Master" before withdrawing.

*(Annotations from commentators preserved in parallel structure:)*
Guo’s note: "Sage" is but a name; names arise and things become confused. Even if one seeks Grand Hiddenness, how can it be attained? Let each follow its own nature, and there will be no affairs—only then can one govern the world. "Riding the sun’s chariot" means to go forth with activity and return with rest. In governing the world, nothing surpasses letting things follow their own course—why should one interfere? Thus, I practice non-action, and the people transform themselves. Affairs arise from the people’s actions, and now the people attain self-mastery. There must be a Dao to this. Horses are harmed by excess—follow Heaven, and by removing excess, Grand Hiddenness will arrive.

Lü’s note: "Hiddenness" means loftiness. Nothing is greater or higher than the Dao. Covering and sheltering the myriad things—this is the meaning of Mount Juci. Desiring to see Grand Hiddenness, the Seven Sages went together, yet all became lost in the wilds of Xiangcheng, finding no path to ask the way. It is like the Seven Apertures being drilled into Chaos, causing its death. Those who seek the great Dao while clinging to sagely knowledge will surely reach the heights only to become lost and never awaken. The horse’s celestial position is noon, the southern fire of the heart. The boy is one without knowledge, yet in herding horses, he should know Mount Juci and where Grand Hiddenness resides. The human heart contains spirit, and spirit has no fixed direction. To wander without leaving the Six Directions—this is not due to dizziness. To cure it, nothing surpasses ascending with clarity, riding the sun’s chariot to wander Xiangcheng. Though the illness has slightly improved, he still rides the sun’s chariot. If he ceased riding it to wander beyond the Six Directions, would he still have rest? Governing the world is like nurturing the heart—what else is there to do but remove what harms it? Following the heart’s inclinations as one’s teacher—who lacks a teacher? Once one knows it lies within, this is why he was called "Heavenly Master" and withdrew.

Yi Du’s note: Grand Hiddenness is a bold name for the Dao. Mount Juci is a metaphor for thorny, hard-to-reach places. Fang Ming and Zhi Jie are all fabricated names, each grasping a partial aspect—the scattering of the Dao. Xiangcheng County belongs to Ruzhou, south of Mount Juci. "Herding horses" means to follow the nature of things and guide them. The boy is one without knowledge or attachments. This is a parable about the Yellow Emperor’s six ministers, who relied on seeking the Dao to reach its abode. Xiangcheng is a metaphor for the Middle Way; the "wilds" mean no fixed destination. The horse-herding boy could point out the Seven Sages’ delusion, so the Yellow Emperor marveled at him. The mountain is not yet separate from its place; its existence is not apart from its being—this is the coarse aspect of the Dao, which can be taught and learned. As for the Dao’s subtlety, only by cutting off learning and forgetting words can it be attained. The sage’s governance of the world arises from non-affairs, and action arises from non-action—what more is there to do? "Roaming within the Six Directions" refers to past involvement in worldly affairs. Engaging with the world cannot be without rest, hence the dizziness of head and eyes. "Riding the sun’s chariot" means following the sun’s renewal and transformation. The wilds of Xiangcheng are near Mount Juci and far from the dust, so the illness slightly improved. "Again roaming beyond the Six Directions" expresses the intent to transcend the realm of things.

Zhuangzi likely means that those who study the Dao must first reach the Dao’s abode, hence "where Grand Hiddenness resides." Yet one cannot avoid emerging to engage with the world and partake in its rest, hence "roaming within the Six Directions and suffering dizziness." "Again roaming beyond the Six Directions" means entering the Heavenly Dao and practicing non-action—what more is there to do? The Yellow Emperor pressed him repeatedly, so the boy told him of herding horses: removing what harms the horses is the sage’s use of punishment to pacify the world.

Bi Xu’s note: The Yellow Emperor achieved merit but did not cling to it, so he sought the Dao in seclusion and encountered the horse-herding boy. The boy’s analogy of herding horses to governing the state is profound! The horse’s true nature is to graze on grass and drink water, self-sufficient; the people’s true nature is to plow for food and weave for clothing, self-sufficient—nothing more is needed. "Riding the sun’s chariot" means following the Dao of daily renewal, adapting to change without stagnation. The second question went unanswered, demonstrating the teaching of wordless instruction. Today’s horse-herders do not know that whipping harms them; those who nurture the people are blind to how laws and decrees breed deceit. They claim horses are hard to tame and people hard to govern—both are mistaken.

Liu Li’s note: The wonder of non-thought and non-action is uniquely sensed by the utmost spirit. In responding to the world, one cannot but share in the people’s troubles. Thus, it is said: "From my youth, I roamed freely within the Six Directions. Then I fell ill with dizziness." The way to share in the people’s rest is no other than following the bright laws of yin and yang, going forth with activity and returning with rest, without violating principle. Thus, it is said: "Ride the sun’s chariot and wander the wilds of Xiangcheng." In this way, the people’s troubles are removed—this is the time to achieve merit and withdraw. Returning to the Dao, one is not burdened by things, hence "now that my illness has slightly improved, I am about to roam beyond the Six Directions once more." For those who have not yet attained the highest in governing the world, nothing surpasses removing what harms their nature—this is the foundation of nurturing nature. Removing what harms the horses is the essence of herding horses. This is the coarse aspect that can be transmitted in words, so the boy could not decline to answer.

Wu Chou’s note: Mount Juci means fullness and concealment, a metaphor for the Dao’s wholeness. Dwelling on this mountain, one is great and unmatched, lofty and unsurpassed—hence "Grand Hiddenness." Xiangcheng is a land without people, a metaphor for the Dao’s path.

Viewed through the traces of the Yellow Emperor, he still seemed not yet profoundly merged with the Dao, yet his desire to meet the Seven Sages was precisely how the fullness of the Dao is revealed. Arriving at Xiangcheng and finding no one to ask the way—this is because the Dao’s wholeness originally resides within oneself. Why then seek Mount Juci in the distance, or suppose that the Grand Hiddenness could be seen by the Seven Sages? Only the horse-herding boy could know it. Herding horses by removing what harms them is a metaphor for preserving the true nature of life without artificially prolonging it—this is Mount Juci, the abode of the Grand Hiddenness.

*Yanzhai Oral Exegesis*: The names of the Six Ministers are all allegories. "Chariot of the Sun" means journeying together with the sun, as in "daily renewal." Within the Six Directions, one has not yet departed from things, hence the affliction of dimmed vision. To depart from this affliction and roam in spontaneity is to be beyond the Six Directions. Governing the world is likewise: one must not be burdened by things within the realm of existence. The horse-herder who follows their nature without harming it has fully realized the Way of herding. The "Celestial Master" is so called because he embodies the harmony of heaven and humanity and can serve as one’s teacher. The Yellow Emperor’s meeting with the Grand Hiddenness on Mount Juci is like Yao’s encounter with the Four Masters on Mount Gushe—it is a communion of spirit and qi, not something to be sought through form. The Yellow Emperor’s reliance on the Six Ministers signifies that as long as the six senses remain unextinguished, one still takes knowledge and perception as the means to sagehood. Though he sought the Grand Hiddenness, he inevitably became lost midway. The Grand Hiddenness, undifferentiated and complete, symbolizes the essence of the Dao. Mount Juci, fully concealing, symbolizes the Dao’s function. The wilds of Xiangcheng still retain the vestiges of the mundane world, unlike the boundless vastness of Dongting, for one has not yet attained emptiness, openness, and unbounded expansiveness. Not only do those who rely on such a place to seek the Dao find themselves at a loss, but even a ruler of singular clarity may become bewildered and directionless. Yet he still knew to ask the way of the horse-herding boy—this was at least somewhat commendable. The horse-herding boy is a metaphor for the spirit that guards the heart, akin to the Chan parable of herding the ox. But what is being herded? And who is the herder? Wisdom that can return the six senses to their source is no different from the skillful herder who removes what harms the horses. Governing the world is the same: its fundamental difficulty is no greater than this, just as governing the people is like herding sheep.

"Dimmed vision" refers to green-tinged eyes. The range of one’s sight does not extend beyond the Six Directions, confined by form and vessels and unable to illuminate all without exception—this is the affliction. The teaching that removes this affliction means being able to ride the light of heaven and ascend, so that roaming the wilds of Xiangcheng holds no confusion. Now that the illness has slightly improved and one roams beyond the Six Directions, one is no longer bound by form and vessels yet still recognizes the distinction between within and beyond the Six Directions—hence it is said to be only slightly improved. The boy merely took spontaneity as his teacher and could do this, so the Yellow Emperor called him "Celestial Master" and withdrew. This chapter uses allegory to illustrate the difficulty of learning the Dao, for many draw boundaries midway. One must consult the lord of the heart and take it as the guiding force, riding the light of heaven to ascend and roaming freely beyond form and vessels. Then Mount Juci can be reached without asking the way.

The scholar who delights in no change of thought is not content; the rhetorician who lacks the order of discourse is not content; the scrutinizer who has no censure to administer is not content—all are confined by things. The world-summoning scholar rises in court; the middling scholar delights in office; the sinewy scholar prides himself on overcoming difficulties; the brave scholar thrives in peril; the martial scholar rejoices in war; the withered scholar clings to reputation; the legalist scholar expands governance; the ritualist scholar reveres demeanor; the benevolent scholar values relationships. The farmer who has no weeding to do is not diligent; the merchant who has no marketplace is not diligent. The commoner who has morning and evening tasks is encouraged; the artisan who has mastery of tools is emboldened. The avaricious worry when wealth does not accumulate; the vainglorious grieve when power does not stand out. Those who delight in the fluctuations of circumstances, when they encounter the right moment, cannot remain inactive. All these follow the turning of the seasons and do not transcend change. They exhaust their physical and spiritual nature, channeling it into the myriad things, never returning throughout their lives—how lamentable!

Guo’s commentary: Unable to find fulfillment within and delighting in things without, they are thus confined. Each is confined by what they delight in, so that the myriad things come unbidden, not by force. The differences among scholars are such that those who encounter them must not lightly change their methods. When their dispositions align, their affairs align, hence their mutual affinity. When their endeavors achieve their aims, they are encouraged. When their tasks lack skill, they grow indolent. When things accord with their desires, they delight. Power and influence arise from changing circumstances. All these scholars have their moments of use, and when the moment comes, they cannot restrain themselves. If they do not encounter the right moment, even if they wish to act on their own, how can they? Thus, nobility and baseness have no constant ability, each has its limit, like the four seasons which cannot be altered. When things accord with their time and follow their proper order, each has its use. Therefore, following the seasons brings order to the times; altering one’s nature means not being confined by things. To be confined by things yet not be confined—what else but destruction could result? Not adhering to the abilities of a single school but pursuing the myriad directions to seize the advantages of the moment—hence there are those who crawl back in defeat, which is why it is lamentable.

Lü’s commentary: There is no one who does not have a place of supreme joy; to attain it and roam there is to be greatly confined. Yet these scholars only delight in the biases of their own natures, thus they are confined by things and cannot confine things. From the world-summoning scholar to those who delight in the fluctuations of circumstances, though their inclinations differ, when they encounter the right moment and are put to use, they cannot remain inactive—this is uniformly due to not knowing where the true lord resides. Acting when the moment calls for it is not the nature of life. The moment has past and present, just as the year has cold and heat. Now, having encountered one moment, they cling to it and do not let go, unable to remain inactive—all these follow the turning of the seasons, knowing cold but not heat, heat but not cold, taking what they encounter as constant and not transcending change.

No one lacks a true lord within, yet they exhaust their physical nature, chasing after things without knowing how to return—this is what the perfected ones lament. Those who know delight in deploying their talents; disputatious scholars love to gallop their words; meticulous scholars strive to exhaust others’ explanations—all three are enslaved by things, hence called "confined."

The Dao can summon the world’s people to admiration; affairs can align with the common folk to bring them joy. Strength of sinew, military might, and courage all speak of their ability to defend the state against peril. Reclusion, seclusion, mountains and forests, legalists enforcing laws and debating punishments, ritual teachings that transform the people, benevolence and righteousness that benefit things—farmers take clearing wastelands as their vocation, merchants take marketplaces as their vocation. The common folk have no leisure day; from dawn to dusk, all have their work. The hundred craftsmen, with their mastery of tools and machines, see their skills grow robust with age.

The avaricious strive to amass much; without accumulation, they grieve. The vainglorious strive for power and influence; without preeminence, they sorrow. Those who delight in circumstances love action. Action takes change as its master, and taking change as joy, the moments they encounter differ—thus they cannot remain inactive. All these myriad affairs are bound by things, each obscured by one corner, none attuned to the great thoroughfare.

The year governs the four seasons; the *Yi* governs the myriad things. The sage is one with Heaven, thus able to govern the year without being governed by the year, to govern things through the *Yi* without being governed by the *Yi*. Those of partial understanding invert this: governed by the year, they are like the disparate qi of the four seasons; governed by the *Yi*, they are like the diverse forms of the myriad things.

*Bi Xu* notes: Dismissing calculations and concerns leaves the knowing scholar at an impasse; abandoning alliances and coalitions leaves the disputatious scholar in distress; exalting simplicity leaves the meticulous scholar idle. Those who cultivate inner nurturance and take no joy in external pursuits cannot be enslaved by things.

Scholars who summon the world esteem worthies to invigorate the court. Scholars who align with the common folk follow principle to glorify their offices. When times call for quelling peril, the brave boast and brag. When fine weapons and armor appear, they distance themselves from plows and hoes. Recluses do not serve kings and lords, dwelling in fame alone. When laws and decrees flourish, the indolent are spurred to action. When rites and ceremonies abound, pretense and affectation arise. Those who cultivate benevolence and righteousness take social connections as fulfillment.

If scholars do not study, farmers do not accumulate, craftsmen lack skill, merchants lack goods, and the common folk lose their livelihoods, it is due to their own indolence. The avaricious value wealth over their own bodies; the vainglorious prize power above their own lives. Taking joy in wielding power to manipulate things and delighting in change and movement, they are like the ears, eyes, and nose—each has its moment of use, yet none can restrain itself.

When talents and knowledge each fulfill their roles, undertakings succeed; when the four seasons lose their order, the year’s work is undone. Those who do not harmonize with the year are all led astray by things—their hearts transform, their forms follow, and this is called "not returning." Truly, it is lamentable.

*Yanzhai Oral Teachings*: Thoughts shift a hundred times; speeches proceed with order; in probing inquiries, they vie over fractions and hairs. Each of the three takes joy in their own abilities; a single day without them brings no pleasure—all are confined by things.

Those who summon the world dazzle with fame, desiring to rise and establish themselves in the court. The common folk are ordinary people, thus they take rank and salary as glory. Those of sinew and strength take pride in aiding in peril. The brave rejoice when calamity arises. Recluses and hermits fix their minds on reputation. The legalist school seeks to govern affairs. Those who respect appearances maintain dignified bearing. The socially ambitious value connections. "Clearing wastelands" refers to farming; "marketplaces" to commerce. "Harmony" means joy. "Dawn-to-dusk work" means daily accumulation of profit. Artisans take pride in their skills as they mature. "Power" means having something to rely on; "things" means having something amassed. Petty men cling to the powerful and influential, often following their lead, seeking fulfillment through action. When the moment calls for use, they cannot remain inactive.

When, within a single year, the hundred things grow and mature, all follow their proper sequence. What changes and transforms is not freely chosen by things. "Not governed by the *Yi*" means things do not change of their own accord. To exhaust body and mind, drowning in things without returning—how lamentable it is!

This chapter begins abruptly; it is suspected that preceding text is missing and cannot be recovered. It critiques the joys of the knowing, disputatious, and meticulous scholars, which are precisely what Dao cultivators lament—how diametrically opposed they are! Each is confined by their own abilities and cannot attain freedom.

"Summoning the world" means commending the worthy and honoring the excellent to attract the world’s scholars, thus invigorating the court. "Aligning with the common folk" means guiding the people, hence they are honored with offices and ranks. The subsequent discussion of scholars, farmers, commoners, and the hundred craftsmen—though their inclinations differ, each clings to one bias, taking fulfillment in usefulness while forgetting their toil and suffering, unaware of the peril of losing their nature. Yet they cannot adapt; each use has its limit, and when limits are reached, deceit and harm arise.

When in a position of disuse, they constantly yearn for usefulness, scheming over how to implement and arrange things—vain thoughts never cease for a moment. When the moment calls for use, their ambitions swell with satisfaction, and they have no leisure for inaction as they enact laws and flaunt their abilities. How can they be expected to remain inactive?

The avaricious grieve without accumulation; the vainglorious sorrow without preeminence—this does not depart from the earlier meaning. All these rest in what they should not rest in. It is like the governance of spring, autumn, winter, and summer over warmth, chill, cold, and heat—though they harmonize with the year, each attains its bias and cannot interchange with things. Cold commands cannot be applied in summer; heat commands cannot be applied in winter. "Not governed by the *Yi*" means not being altered by things. The text weaves its phrases intricately. Only the perfected one’s heart is one with the great void, and their body embodies the qi of the four seasons—thus they can transform things without being transformed by things.

The seventy-sixth scroll of *The Ocean of Meanings in the True Scripture of Southern Florescence* concludes.
The seventy-seventh scroll of *The Ocean of Meanings in the True Scripture of Southern Florescence* begins.
Recorded by the Daoist of Wulin, Chu Boxiu.

**Xu Wugui, Third Chapter**

Zhuangzi said: "If an archer hits the mark without aiming beforehand, is this called good archery? If so, then all under heaven could be Yi—would that be acceptable?"
Huizi said: "It would."

Zhuangzi said: "If there is no shared rightness under heaven, and each affirms only what they themselves affirm, then all under heaven could be Yao—would that be acceptable?"
Huizi said: "It would."

Zhuangzi said: "In that case, the Confucians, Mohists, Yangists, and Bingists—together with you, that makes five. Which of them is truly right? Or is it someone like Lu Ju? His disciple said, *'I have grasped the Master’s Way! I can boil a cauldron in winter and make ice in summer!'* Lu Ju replied: *'This is merely summoning yang with yang and yin with yin—it is not what I call the Way. Let me show you my Way.'* Thereupon, he tuned two zithers, placing one in the hall and one in the chamber. When he plucked the *gong* note, the *gong* string resonated; when he plucked the *jiao* note, the *jiao* string resonated—their tones and measures were in harmony. But if he altered the tuning of one string so that it no longer corresponded to the five notes, and then plucked it, all twenty-five strings would vibrate. Though no different in sound, the ruler of tones had already emerged. Is this what you mean?"

Huizi said: "Now, the Confucians, Mohists, Yangists, and Bingists all contend with me in debate, refuting one another with words and overpowering one another with voices. Yet none has ever proven me wrong—what do you make of this?"

Zhuangzi said: "A man of Qi who sent his son to Song had a fate that was not whole; when he sought a fine bell, he bound it with ropes; when he sought a Tang servant, he never left his domain—such are those who leave things behind! The man of Chu who lodged his arrow in a target at night, in a time when no one was present, and thus won the favor of the boatman’s state—though he never left the cliff, he was sufficient to incur resentment. Guo’s commentary: *'Hitting the mark by accident is not good archery.'* If one takes hitting by mistake as good archery, then all under heaven could be called Yi—would that be acceptable? Clearly not. If those who hit by mistake are all Yi, then those who privately affirm themselves could also be called Yao. If all are Yao, then why do the five schools still refute one another? It is like Lu Ju and his disciple, both summoning yang with yang, yet arrogantly claiming to be right. Or when one alters the tuning of a single string and the five notes change with it: without sound, there is nothing to set them in motion; with sound, only the same resonates with the same. Now, if altering one string causes all twenty-five to change, it is merely adjusting tension and slack—Lu Ju boasted of this to his disciple, yet it is only mutual resonance, not a unique skill. The five schools each cling to their own views and affirm what they affirm, no different from the others, yet none can surpass the rest. *'None has ever proven me wrong'*—they each affirm themselves."

Hui Shi wished to take this as the ultimate truth. Zhuangzi then cited the case of a man from Qi who sent his son to a foreign land, instructing the gatekeeper to guard him, yet upon departure, he could not ensure his son’s safety. This man of Qi was unkind, yet he too considered himself right in doing so. Conversely, he would bind and protect a precious bell, fearing it might break or be damaged. He lost his son and could not search far, abandoning his own kind, yet he never once deemed himself wrong. Zhuangzi further recounted the tale of a man from Chu who lodged with a gatekeeper, both dwelling as guests yet unable to ascend high ground on their own. In the dead of night, the man boarded another’s boat, and before leaving the shore, he had already joined the boatman’s domain. The conduct of these two men—from Qi and Chu—was thus, yet they never considered themselves in error. How then do the five scholars differ from them in their self-affirmation?

Lu’s commentary: If all under heaven were archers like Yi, it would surely be untenable. Hui Shi, recognizing Zhuangzi’s words as directed at him, deemed them acceptable. To hit the mark is to be like Yi; to fail to meet prior expectations is to be like Yao—yet Yao need not be universally affirmed. This is what is meant by taking opposition as truth and victory as renown. Nevertheless, if the five scholars are not all correct, then the claim that all are Yao collapses. Otherwise, it is no different from Lu Ju tuning his zither, merely summoning resonance through sound. Shi claimed superiority over the other four, yet in truth, he differed not at all. Shi believed himself no different from the four, yet he still engaged in debate. *"None has ever proven me wrong"*—what then? These words sought to uphold the claim that all are Yao. Zhuangzi moved him with subtle speech.

The bond between father and child is a natural principle, yet the man of Qi abandoned his son in Song, entrusting him to a gatekeeper without concern for his safety—this illustrates Shi’s disregard for the essence of life while failing to cherish it. His pursuit of bells and cauldrons, binding them for fear of damage, and his search for a lost child only within his own domain, are like Shi’s attachment to external things—debate, reputation, and fame—treasuring them and fearing their harm, yet losing what is bestowed by heaven and failing to seek it as something precious. The man of Chu who lodged with the gatekeeper is like Shi, who lost the true dwelling of his nature and, amid the obscurity of right and wrong, contended with others for victory, achieving nothing but discord with the world—this is not what is called wisdom.

Yi Du’s commentary: If hitting the mark by chance is deemed good archery, then all under heaven are Yi. If private affirmation is taken as public truth, then all under heaven are Yao. Zhuangzi deemed this unacceptable, while Hui Shi found it acceptable. Zhuangzi asked: If this were true, then among the Confucians, Mohists, Yangists, Gongsun Long, and yourself, who is correct? Lu Ju’s disciple could, in winter, gather a thousand-year-old ash around wood and produce fire in an instant to heat a cauldron; in summer, he could store water in a clay jar, boil it in hot water, place it in a well, and turn it to ice—claiming this as mastery of Lu Ju’s Way. Lu Ju said this was merely resonance through similarity, not what he called the Way. Thus, he tuned a zither, placing one in the hall and another in the chamber, so that the *gong* and *jue* notes resonated. When he altered a single string in the hall, all five notes in the chamber lost their harmony. The strings moved, yet when plucked, they no longer responded to the old tones. This shows that sound summons sound, with no difference, and only the ruler of sound can command it. Lu Ju boasted of this to his disciple, yet it was merely mutual resonance, not a unique skill. The five scholars each clung to their own views, no different from Lu Ju’s boasting to his disciple, yet none could surpass the others. Hui Shi said that the other four were now debating with him, *"None has ever proven me wrong,"* and thus wished to take this as truth. Zhuangzi then recounted the man of Qi who abandoned his son in Song, instructing the gatekeeper to guard him, yet could not ensure his safety—this man’s lack of kindness was also self-affirmed. He bound bells for fear of damage yet did not search beyond his domain for his lost child, valuing external things over his own kind and never deeming himself wrong. Hui Shi’s self-affirmation was no different. Long ago, a man of Chu lodged with a gatekeeper (a criminal assigned to guard the gate). In the dead of night, he boarded another’s boat, and before leaving the shore, he had already joined the boatman’s domain, forgetting his debt of gratitude and incurring resentment—his conduct was thus, yet he did not consider himself in error, no different from Hui Shi and his followers.

Bixu’s commentary: An archer who hits the mark by mistake is not skilled. One who affirms himself is not impartial.

The Five Masters took their mutual victories as divergent Ways, while Lu Ju measured superiority and inferiority to distinguish their arts, unaware that a greater unity underlay their differences. When the zither in the hall is tuned, its pitches align; yet when the *guan* and *jue* strings are altered, their sounds diverge. Thus, stillness is the master of the five notes, and silence the origin of all distinctions. Yet Hui Shi regarded his own eloquence as supreme, so Zhuangzi cited the man of Qi who slighted his son to pursue a lost heirloom, prizing external goods while betraying the Way in his quest for victory—never recognizing his own error. To lodge with a gatekeeper and then trample his trust is to dwell in lowly traces; to act in the dead of night is to contend in darkness; to remain bound to the shore is to be fettered by limits; and to provoke resentment is to invite blame.

*The Yan Zhai Oral Exegesis* states: The first phrase refers to the target. If one abandons the target and shoots at random, then all who hit the mark become archers like Yi—implying that without a fixed standard of rightness, each man clings to his own view, and all become sages like Yao. Since the Five Masters’ teachings differ, which one is truly correct? In winter, one cannot cook a cauldron without fire; in summer, one cannot make ice with water—such things are indeed difficult. Yet at the winter solstice, yang begins to grow; at the summer solstice, yin begins to grow. Summon yang with yang, and winter loses its cold; summon yin with yin, and summer loses its heat. Though this defies the seasons, there is a principle by which it may be done. This is not what I call the Way—it merely shows their arts are not yet refined. Let each place a zither in the hall: strike one, and the other resonates; *guan* answers *guan*, *jue* answers *jue*—this is easily explained by their shared sound. But if only one string is tuned, and no single note is fixed among the five, then striking *guan* or *zhi* will suffice. Hence it is called "without a standard." Strike one string here, and all twenty-five strings there vibrate—this is far more difficult than *guan* answering *guan* or *jue* answering *jue*. Reasoning thus, the five notes all take sound as their ruler, for none departs from the voice of the strings. Thus, they are not fundamentally different from sound. How is this unlike summoning yin with yin or yang with yang? Lu Ju, claiming superiority, merely affirmed his own rightness—none grasped the true standard.

*Fu* means to resist; *zhen*, to submit. *Zhi* (蹢) is pronounced like *zhi* (掷), meaning to halt. The man of Qi, unable to employ his son in a worthy role, set him to guard the gate, yet still deemed himself correct. When he sought a small bell, he took pains to protect it, loving the object but not his child—another instance of self-affirmation, like searching for a lost son only within his own village. This is delusion. The man of Chu, lame in one foot, served as a gatekeeper—this is a separate statement, unrelated to the earlier *zhi*. "A remnant kind" suggests a rough resemblance. These three cases loosely parallel the Five Masters, much as the earlier analogy did. The transition here, before concluding the theme of resentment, is a masterful stroke in composition. The core of this chapter is to mock Hui Shi’s self-righteousness. Since Hui Shi loved debate, Zhuangzi crafted these cryptic words to confound him, much like Dongfang Shuo’s exchanges with his attendants. The argument that "all are Yi, all are Yao" was Zhuangzi’s way of restraining Hui Shi’s flaw, seeking to cure his self-affirmation. Thus, he cited Lu Ju’s contest with his disciples over superiority and inferiority. "Summon yang with yang, yin with yin" is simply like responding to like with like. But when one string is retuned here, and all the other strings there change, they no longer resonate because their sounds differ. The five notes are all sound, yet each has its governing tone—this is the ruler of sound. Only a keen listener can discern it. Thus, striking *guan* makes *guan* vibrate, striking *jue* makes *jue* vibrate—this is mere correspondence by kind, nothing extraordinary. The Five Masters each affirmed their own partial view, lacking impartiality, just as *guan* is confined to *guan* and *jue* to *jue*, unable to communicate. Hui Shi still failed to grasp this, believing his ability to surpass the other four proved he had never been wrong—thus, his rightness was true. Zhuangzi then cited the man of Qi who valued bells over his son, betraying principle yet clinging to self-righteousness, and the man of Chu who lodged with a gatekeeper and fought him, unaware of his own error—this was the third turn of the argument. Here we see Zhuangzi’s deep affection for Hui Shi, as later passages will reveal.

Sound is like wood; tone is like the beams, rafters, and purlins of a house. The ruler of tone is like the master craftsman’s hand, which shapes the beams and rafters—none can do without it. When Zhuangzi passed Hui Shi’s grave while attending a funeral, he turned to his followers and said: A man of Ying smeared his nose with a speck of white clay no thicker than a fly’s wing and had Carpenter Shi shave it off. Carpenter Shi swung his axe with such force that it whistled like the wind, yet he sliced away the clay without harming the man’s nose, who stood unflinching. When the Lord of Song heard of this, he summoned Carpenter Shi and said: "Try it for me." The carpenter replied: "Your servant once could do this, but my material has been dead for a long time." Since the Master’s death, I have had no material to work with, no one to speak with.

Guo Xiang’s commentary: Without the unmoving material, the partner who forgets words, even the most skillful carving would be useless.
Lü Huiqing’s commentary: Only because of this did Zhuangzi repeatedly engage him and deeply regret his failure to reach enlightenment.
Yi Du’s commentary: There were Hui Shi’s questions, and then Zhuangzi’s answers. With Hui Shi gone, Zhuangzi lamented the loss of one to converse with, hence his allusion to Carpenter Shi.

The man of Ying smeared his nose with white clay and had Carpenter Shi swing his axe to shave it off—this required the man of Ying’s unflinching stillness to achieve its wonder. When the Lord of Song wished to see it, Carpenter Shi said: "Your servant once could do this, but my material has been dead for a long time." The material refers to the man of Ying, who was already dead and could not be replicated.

Zhuangzi himself said that his loss of Hui Shi was like Carpenter Shi’s loss of the man of Ying, hence his lament: "I have no material to work upon, none with whom to speak"—this echoes Bo Ya’s breaking of his strings. Bi Xu’s commentary: There are those whose forms are withered wood, but few who stand before the blade without fear. There are those who wield the axe to display their skill, but rare are those who, facing the nose, swing freely. Thus we know that encounters of mutual perception and responses of wordless understanding are not common in this world!

*Yanqi’s Oral Exegesis*: "Swinging the axe to create a wind" speaks of its swiftness. To remove all the clay without harming the nose—this is difficult enough for the carver, but even more difficult for the one standing. The "material" is the ground for skill. Only with Hui Shi’s disputations could I exhaust my arguments. Now that Hui Shi is dead, there is none with whom I may speak!

Zhuangzi embraced the Dao with lofty firmness, beyond the reach of worldly custom to fathom its depth and vastness. Thus, the beginnings of discourse had no means to arise—only Hui Shi could engage with him in timely discussion, allowing him to expound his boundless, unbounded ideas and fully express the marvels within his breast. In this lay the conveyance of the Dao and the resonance of literature. After Hui Shi’s death, Zhuangzi passed by his grave and recalled him, turning to his followers to voice his grief. We may know then that Carpenter Shi’s axe was sharp indeed, yet without the man of Ying’s ability to stand firm, his craft would have had no place to apply. "Your servant’s material has been dead for a long time"—thus, though the axe swung without error, how rare was he who could forget his form and submit to the carving! Zhuangzi’s loss of Hui Shi was the same.

The phrase "I have no material to work upon" is difficult to explicate. Examining the text’s meaning closely: earlier it says, "Your servant’s material has been dead for a long time," and again, "one must have the material"—only a dead man who does not fear or flinch may be carved. Now that Hui Shi is gone, though this "material" remains, there is none to respond to it, as if there were no material at all. It means there is no kindred spirit in the world to spur mutual inspiration. "None with whom to speak"—this reveals the depth of his sorrow for his departed friend.

During Hui Shi’s lifetime, he often made critical remarks, and Master Nanhua (Zhuangzi) would exhaust his loyalty and effort to correct him. Though he could not escape the reputation for contentious eloquence, what they pursued were pure discussions and refined debates, avoiding the deceitful and cunning ways of their time—this was also the power of noble friendship. Thus, even after Hui Shi’s passing, Master Nanhua still gave him thought.

"Listening and carving it"—according to Guo Xiang’s commentary, it says "closing his eyes and letting his hands move freely." In Chen Bixu’s *Zhaojiangnan Li-shi Shuku* edition, these four characters are part of the main text, later mistakenly attributed to Guo’s commentary. These four characters do not resemble commentary, hence the correction.

*Collected Subtleties of the Meaning of the True Classic of Master Nanhua*, Scroll Seventy-Seven—Concluded
*Collected Subtleties of the Meaning of the True Classic of Master Nanhua*, Scroll Seventy-Eight

The Daoist of Wulin, Chu Boxiu, on *Xu Wugui*, Chapter Four

When Guan Zhong fell ill, Duke Huan asked him, "The illness of our Uncle has grown severe. If it should worsen to the point of crisis, to whom may I entrust the state?"

Guan Zhong replied, "Whom does Your Lordship wish to appoint?"

The Duke said, "Bao Shuya."

Guan Zhong said, "That will not do. Though he is a man of integrity and a fine scholar, he does not associate with those inferior to himself. Moreover, once he hears of another’s fault, he never forgets it. If he were to govern the state, above he would constrain his lord, and below he would alienate the people. It would not be long before he offended Your Lordship."

The Duke said, "Then who is suitable?"

Guan Zhong replied, "If there is no alternative, then Yin Peng will do. His character is such that above he forgets his rank, and below he does not rebel. He feels shame at not equaling the Yellow Emperor and pities those who do not equal himself. To share virtue with others is called sageliness; to share wealth with others is called worthiness. To govern others with worthiness brings no success; to humble oneself with worthiness brings success without fail. In the state, there are things he does not hear; in his household, there are things he does not see. If there is no alternative, then Yin Peng will do."

Guo’s commentary: "Above he forgets his rank, and below he does not rebel"—this means he is lofty yet not overbearing. He pities those who do not equal himself, thus he discards no one. If he were to hear and see everything, affairs would center upon him, leaving subordinates nowhere to turn. Though he does not entirely let go, he is merely adequate.

Lü’s commentary: "Tolerance becomes impartiality; impartiality becomes kingship; kingship becomes Heaven; Heaven becomes the Dao. These five are what he embodies. Thus, impartiality enables one to be impartial, and kingship enables one to be a king. The titles of king and duke derive from this. Can Yin Peng’s virtue be called tolerance that becomes impartiality?"

Yi Duzhu’s annotation: "Duke Huan’s hegemony was due to Guan Zhong’s efforts. When Guan Zhong’s illness grew critical, the Duke asked whom he might entrust with the state. Guan Zhong in turn asked whom the Duke wished to appoint. The Duke named Bao Shuya, Guan Zhong’s friend. Guan Zhong said it would not do, for though Bao Shuya’s integrity made him a fine scholar, he was not capable of great achievement. By not associating with those inferior to himself, he would lose the people’s hearts and lack support. By remembering others’ faults, he would incur widespread resentment. If he were to govern the state, above he would constrain his lord, and below he would alienate the people, so that he would soon offend the ruler. When the Duke asked who was suitable, Guan Zhong said that if there were no alternative, Yin Peng would do. ‘Above he forgets’ means he forgets his position; ‘below he does not rebel’ means he remains within bounds. Feeling shame at not equaling the Yellow Emperor, his Dao grows ever loftier. Pitying those who do not equal himself, his virtue grows ever broader. The Way of the ruler is to share virtue with others; the Way of the minister is to share wealth with others. In terms of transformation, this is called sageliness; in terms of conduct, this is called worthiness. To govern others with worthiness is to govern without proper method; to humble oneself with worthiness is to humble oneself so that others are drawn to him. ‘There are things he does not hear; there are things he does not see’—this means he can turn his hearing inward and reflect, so that there is nothing he does not hear and nothing he does not see."

Bixu’s commentary: "Bao Shuya could not endure hardship or tolerate impurity to bring salvation to the world. He sought to make all things equal to his own integrity, thus he would constrain his lord; by not associating with others, he would alienate the people. Yin Peng’s character was neither obsequious nor arrogant. He revered the Dao and pitied the people. The sage does not claim virtue for himself; the worthy does not hoard wealth. By humbling himself with worthiness, how could he fail to succeed? Thus, the great should humble themselves. ‘In the state, there are things he does not hear; in his household, there are things he does not see’—this means he forgets the world entirely. Was Bao Shuya’s recommendation of Guan Zhong impartial? And was Guan Zhong’s recommendation of Yin Peng anything but impartial?"

*Yanzhai Oral Teachings*: "'Does not associate' means he does not frequent them. 'Constrain' means to bind them. 'Alienate' means to force them with ritual and righteousness. 'Above he forgets' means he forgets his position. 'Below he does not rebel' means he keeps his distance and makes no demands of his superiors. 'To share virtue with others' is like saying 'virtue descends, and the common people cherish it.' 'To share wealth with others' means not being selfish. 'To govern others with worthiness' means to flaunt one’s reputation and be self-important. 'There are things he does not hear; there are things he does not see' means he is not overly scrutinizing. This passage does not appear in other texts but only in the *Liezi*, where it is also a parable.

"Bao Shuya was Guan Zhong’s worthy friend. When the Duke asked whom to entrust with the state, Guan Zhong should have recommended Bao Shuya, yet he first inquired whom the Duke wished to appoint. When the Duke named Bao Shuya, Guan Zhong, knowing his friend’s virtue but recognizing that his talent was insufficient to handle complex affairs, feared he would adhere rigidly to principle without flexibility, constrain the ruler, and alienate the people. Thus, he decisively declared him unsuitable. He did not recommend him out of personal favor, lest he be given a task beyond his capacity and offend the ruler. 'If there is no alternative, then Yin Peng will do' means he is merely adequate. 'Above he forgets and below he does not rebel'—in the *Liezi*, this reads 'below he does not rebel.' Zhang Zhan’s commentary states: 'Being above and forgetting himself, he does not worry about those below leaving him.' This suffices to prove that the *Zhuangzi* text is corrupt. The ancient character 畔 is interchangeable with 叛. Judging by this discussion of Yin Peng’s virtue, it seems inappropriate to speak of rebellion. If interpreted as 'boundary,' it does not make sense. The *Liezi* reading of 'below he does not rebel' is correct.

'In the state, there are things he does not hear; in his household, there are things he does not see'—this means his governance is lenient and forgiving. He does not flaunt his intelligence to impose harsh scrutiny. By humbling himself, he wins the people’s allegiance. Knowing he could be entrusted with the state, Guan Zhong preferred that he govern with understanding rather than enact laws that harm the people. Better to be magnanimous and win the people’s support, maintaining peace without incident. This was Guan Zhong’s ability to recognize and employ talent, which enabled him to achieve hegemony for Qi. Loyal to his lord and caring toward his friend, in terms of righteousness, this was truly a case of mutual benefit.

"'Can it not be said'—in the *Liezi*, this reads 'one need not avoid saying,' which is more appropriate.

King Wu of Wu was floating on the river and ascended Mount Ju. The troop of monkeys, seeing him, fled in alarm and hid in the dense thickets. One monkey, however, lingered, swinging and leaping, displaying its skill before the king."

The king loosed his arrow, swift and unbroken. The monkey, nimble and quick, seized and caught the shaft. The king commanded his attendants to hasten and shoot it, and the monkey was seized and died. Turning to his friend Yan Buyi, the king said: "This monkey, boasting of its skill and relying on its agility, dared to mock me—thus it met this end! Take heed! Alas! Never let your demeanor make you arrogant toward others!"

Yan Buyi returned home and studied under Dong Wu to uproot his prideful bearing. He abandoned pleasure and declined honors, and after three years, the people of the state praised him.

Guo’s commentary: *Min* means swift; *gei*, to nock an arrow. Though the arrow flew fast, the monkey could still seize it. The people of the state praised him for forgetting cunning and shedding pride, returning to unadorned simplicity.

Lü’s commentary: One who is arrogant in demeanor harbors arrogance in the heart, which manifests in countenance. To uproot pride is to discard such a heart—this is what is meant by the six aspects of bearing, movement, expression, principle, speech, and qi, all of which are distortions of the heart.

Yi’s annotation: The monkey, priding itself on its skill and relying on the convenience of the mountain forests to mock others, brought about its own death. Thus the king warned Buyi not to be arrogant in demeanor. Buyi accepted the lesson, returned home, and studied under a man of the Dao, uprooting his haughty pride to embrace simplicity. For this, the people of the state praised his virtue.

Bixu’s commentary: Those who cower and hide in seclusion avoid misfortune, while those who act recklessly and linger invite disaster. Thus the monkey, relying solely on its cunning, could not escape the many arrows. Even a creature of the mountains and forests, lacking understanding, dares to mock humans and meets swift death—how much more so for humans, the most intelligent of beings, who would dare to treat their own kind with arrogance and disdain? Buyi returned and uprooted his prideful bearing, and the people praised him. How easily he awakened!

*Yanzhai Oral Teachings*: *Min gei* describes the speed of the arrow’s flight, yet the monkey could still seize it with equal swiftness. The *xiangzhe* were the king’s attendants. When they all shot at once, the monkey, though nimble, could not match their strength and was seized and killed. This serves as a warning to those who boast of their abilities. Monkey and man are different species; the monkey, dwelling as king among the deep mountains and dense forests, feared even the sound of humans—how much more their presence? Yet when it saw the King of Wu, it displayed its skill, swinging and grooming itself—this was the omen of its swift death, and so it could not escape. Though it could seize the arrows in flight, it was truly swift and nimble. The king, marveling at its excessive cunning, ordered his attendants to hasten and shoot it, so that none of its shots missed their mark. How could it avoid being struck? Its death clinging to the tree was only fitting. From this, the king realized how swiftly arrogance brings disaster and how standing apart invites ruin in an instant. Thus he warned his friend never to be arrogant in demeanor. Buyi returned and uprooted his pride, abandoning honors—was this not courage in embracing goodness? Yet it took three years before the people praised him, for virtue lies in unflagging perseverance, and success comes only after a thousand days. But for evil, a single morning is enough to bring ruin—how could one not take heed?

Nanbo Zijing leaned on his armrest and sat, gazing upward and sighing. Yan Chengzi entered and said: "Master, you are the most extraordinary of beings. Can your form truly be made like withered bones, your heart like dead ashes?"

He replied: "Once I dwelled in a mountain cave. At that time, when the lord of the fields and crops caught sight of me, the people of the state of Qi thrice congratulated him. I must have been the first to know—thus he knew; I must have offered it—thus he prepared."

If I did not possess it, how could they have known? If I did not offer it, how could they have prepared? Alas! I grieve for those who lose themselves, and I grieve again for those who grieve for others, and I grieve yet again for those who grieve over the grief of others—thus does the distance grow with each passing day.

Guo’s commentary: The state of Qi thrice offered congratulations because they took honor in having seen Zicha. Zitai knew that his actions were insufficient to save others and only enough to lose himself, so he grieved without grieving—thus his grief gradually faded. His heart became still, his form withered—this is how the distance grew with each passing day.

Lü’s commentary: When the lord of the fields and crops caught sight of him, the people of Qi thrice congratulated him. He had already offered himself first, so they knew; he had already displayed himself, so they prepared. His heart was not yet fully inward but had already advanced outward—this is how he became known to others. The Way of Heaven has never yet possessed anything. If there remains even the slightest knowing intent within the heart, this is self-loss—loss meaning the forfeiture of one’s original heart. Zicha grieved for those who lost themselves in this way, wishing for their return. Yet to know their loss and grieve for it is still loss, not return. I grieve again for those who grieve for others—then both the grieving and the grieved remain ignorant of their own state. This is why the distance grows with each passing day, unburdened by things, so that his form does not wither, his heart does not turn to ashes—could it be otherwise?

Yi Du’s commentary: "The most extraordinary of beings" refers to one with surpassing talent who can forget his body and heart to this degree. Yet even Zicha considered this insufficient. Once I dwelled in the mountains, and when the lord of the state caught sight of me, the people thrice offered congratulations. How did I come to be thus regarded by others? Had I not first made my name known, how could they have known and prepared? There is no greater sorrow than the death of the heart. People all lose their innate goodness, so I grieve for them. Yet my grief is itself grievous! To cast off burdens in this way is still not the ultimate. I grieve again for those who grieve for others—thus shedding burdens layer by layer, the entanglements of the world grow ever more distant.

Bixu’s commentary: When Liezi lived in the gardens of Zheng, he remained obscure; when he went to Qi, he received emoluments. Those who cling to fame are like the sun hidden behind clouds—its light flickers forth only intermittently. Thus he constantly "sold" his name. Virtue arises from the inquiries of men like Chao and Xu, so later generations of recluses who dwell in mountain caves borrow the loftiness of their seclusion as a shortcut to officialdom—true reclusion has vanished. To grieve for those who lose themselves is to lament their pursuit of fame. To grieve for those who grieve for others is to recognize that the fault lies within oneself. To grieve for those who grieve over the grief of others is to awaken to the error of intentionality. Only then does one’s understanding of principle and affairs grow more distant with each day, merging at last with the great harmony of the Qi River!

*Yanzhai’s Oral Teachings* states: First he spoke of "offering"—since I left traces visible to others, they could know me. This is why it is self-loss. To grieve for those who lose themselves without realizing one’s own grief is yet more grievous. In the mountain cave, my former dwelling, I spoke only of grieving for the grief of others—this is how the Way grew ever more distant, until today my form is withered, my heart like dead ashes. This is the same as the opening of *The Equality of Things and Opinions*, where Nan Guo Zicha is questioned by Yan Cheng upon his entry. "Leaning on the armrest" describes the moment of utmost stillness. "Gazing upward and sighing"—his mechanism had already stirred, so he seized the opportunity to question him. "The most extraordinary of beings" refers to the most spiritually refined. Yet now he is withered like this—Zitai recalled past events in response to the lord of the fields. When the lord of Qi heard of Zicha’s worthiness and visited him in the mountains, the state thrice offered congratulations, for his attainment of worthiness could bring order. If I possess it, they know; if I display it, they prepare—this means he could not conceal himself and thus attracted fame. With fame comes entanglement; with heavy responsibility comes peril—what is this if not self-loss? This is truly grievous. My grief for those who lose themselves is near and easily seen. My grief for those who grieve for others grows deeper, turning inward to self-grief. My grief for those who grieve over the grief of others surrenders to the inevitable, grieving without grieving and letting the heavenly pipes sound of themselves. Only then do the world’s cares grow ever more distant, allowing his form to wither and his heart to turn to ashes. Truly, to conceal one’s talent in reclusion has ever been difficult—only the dragon that slips free of the world’s net, the wild goose that soars beyond the clouds, can preserve this to the end.

*Southern Florescence: The True Classic of the Vast Ocean of Meanings*, Scroll Seventy-Eight, concludes.
*Southern Florescence: The True Classic of the Vast Ocean of Meanings*, Scroll Seventy-Nine. Learned by the Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin.

**Chapter Five: Xu Wugui**

When Confucius journeyed to Chu, the King of Chu feasted him. Sun Shu’ao stood holding the goblet, while Shi Nanyilaio received the wine and made libation, saying: “Ah, the men of old!”—and with these words, he fell silent.

Confucius said: “I have heard of the speech that speaks not, yet have never spoken it. Here, now, I shall speak it.”

Shi Nanyilaio juggled his balls, and the feud between the two families dissolved. Sun Shu’ao slept sweetly, holding his feather fan, while the men of Ying laid down their weapons. Yet I, Qiu, would fain have a beak three feet long!

That is called the Way that is not the Way; this is called the eloquence that speaks not. Thus virtue gathers in the unity of the Dao, and speech rests in the knowing that knows not—perfect indeed!

The unity of the Dao cannot be matched by virtue; what knowing cannot know, eloquence cannot express. To bear names like those of the Confucians and Mohists is perilous.

Thus the sea refuses no tributary stream—such is its boundless greatness. The sage embraces heaven and earth, bestowing blessings upon the world, yet none know his name. Therefore, in life he holds no rank, in death he leaves no legacy; his substance does not accumulate, his fame does not stand. This is called the Great Man.

A dog is not good because it barks well; a man is not worthy because he speaks well—how much less so for greatness!

To be great is not enough to be called great—how much less so for virtue! The greatest completeness is none other than heaven and earth; yet what do they seek? And so they are complete.

He who knows this completeness seeks nothing, loses nothing, discards nothing, and does not exchange his self for things. Turning inward, he is inexhaustible; following the ancient, he does not wear away. Such is the sincerity of the Great Man.

*(Guo’s Commentary: The sage speaks no words; what he speaks are the words of the common people, hence “the speech that speaks not.” If one takes speech as non-speech, then though words issue from the mouth, they are as though never spoken. Now, to speak of the unspeakable here—Shi Nanyilaio and Sun Shu’ao settled lawsuits with silence, remaining serene while conflicts dissolved of themselves. If what is spoken is not one’s own, then though one speaks all one’s life, it is as though one has never spoken. Thus, to have a beak three feet long is not enough to be called long-tongued; for ordinary men, to close the mouth is not yet to be speechless. The former refers to the two disciples; the latter, to Confucius. The Dao’s capacity is without limit, yet its great return lies in nothing more than self-attainment—hence its unity. Speech stops at its proper place—what could be more perfect? Each attains for himself, not by sameness. Yet the Dao is one. Knowing what lies beyond one’s proper place, eloquence cannot express it. The Confucians and Mohists sought to make the same what cannot be made the same, to express what cannot be expressed—hence their peril. The sea receives all things without refusal, thus achieving its greatness. The sage, all-embracing and impartial, possesses yet does not possess. Titles and honors name achievements, but if the achievement is not one’s own, though honored, it is not one’s own. When all things are sufficient in themselves, substance does not accumulate; when merit is not self-made, fame does not stand. To claim possession is to be small. Worthiness arises from nature, not from speech. The greater something is, the less it can be attained by effort—only by spontaneity is it attained. Heaven and earth are complete of themselves, not by seeking. He who knows their self-completeness does not abandon himself to seek things—hence he seeks nothing, loses nothing, discards nothing. Returning to guard his own principle, he is naturally at ease; following his constant nature, he naturally arrives. It is not by polishing but by non-doing that he attains—hence it is called sincerity.)*

*(Lü’s Commentary: The three men were not contemporaries; this is a parable. The so-called “speech that speaks not” does not mean having no beak. If one acts as the two disciples did, then though one has a beak three feet long, it is as though one has not spoken. What the two disciples did is called the Way that is not the Way. Confucius’ non-speaking is called the eloquence that speaks not—how could the world know this! What virtue cannot match, what eloquence cannot express, is truly without name. To rest in namelessness is where good fortune abides; otherwise, though one’s name resemble that of the Confucians or Mohists, one cannot escape reckless action—perilous indeed! The Dao in the world is like the hundred rivers to the sea: it receives them without refusal. The sage’s all-embracing bestowal of blessings is likewise. None know his name. Without rank, without legacy—this is how the sage is nameless, and thus great. To take good speech as worthiness is already impossible—how much more so for greatness! Could it lie in speech? Thus, what knowing cannot know, eloquence cannot express—yet there is the eloquence that speaks not. The sage does not strive to be great; to strive is not enough to be great—how much less so for virtue! The unity of the Dao cannot be matched by virtue—hence there is the Way that is not the Way. What makes the world complete is its self-completeness, without seeking. All men have what they call completeness—it is nothing but sincerity. Sincere, he seeks nothing; seeking nothing, he loses nothing, discards nothing, for he is sufficient in himself and does not exchange himself for things. The Great Man knows that in himself the ten thousand things are complete; thus, turning inward, he is inexhaustible. Enduring since high antiquity, he does not decay—hence following him does not wear away. Sincerity is to hit the mark without effort, to attain without thought, to accomplish without action.)*

*(Yi Du’s Commentary: In ancient times, one always made libation before drinking, showing reverence for what is honored. Sun Shu’ao and Shi Nanyilaio, attending the feast, received the wine and made libation, wishing Confucius to speak and teach them—hence they said, “The men of old all spoke at such gatherings.” Confucius had long wished to speak not, so he said, “I have heard of the speech that speaks not.” Never having spoken it, here he would speak it—intending to show that his words arose from non-speaking. When Bai Gong Sheng of Chu plotted rebellion and killed the Prime Minister Zixi, both sides sent envoys to summon Shi Nanyilaio. He was juggling his balls in play and paid no heed to the two envoys. Neither side could secure him, and both withdrew their troops.)*

Sun Shu’ao, at leisure and at ease, reclined in high repose, wielding his feather fan in contentment, so that enemy states dared not invade, and conflicts were resolved a thousand *li* away. Confucius cited these two men—who by non-action quelled crises—to illustrate the meaning of non-speaking. This speech arises from non-speaking; though one had a beak three feet long, it would not impair the power of non-speaking. That which is without speech and without action is called the Way that is not the Way—it is the constant Way. This speech that arises from non-speaking is called the disputation that is not disputation—it is the great disputation.

To unite all virtues and return to the Dao: the Dao can unify them, but virtue cannot. That which lies beyond the reach of knowledge can be grasped in silence, but not in argument. Those who vie for supremacy through virtue or vie for superiority through speech—those whose names align with the Ru or Mohists—cannot guard their lives with caution and secrecy, and thus calamity befalls them.

The sea’s greatness lies in its capacity to receive all things without refusal. The sage’s sageliness lies in embracing heaven and earth without knowing whose they are, ennobled by none yet ever natural. A *yi* of gold is established by merit, but once the merit is achieved, it is not claimed—then there is no *yi*. In life, one holds no rank, so no substance is amassed. In death, no *yi* remains, so no name is established. This is what is called the Great Person.

A dog skilled in guarding does not suffer reproach for not barking; a scholar skilled in conduct does not suffer reproach for not speaking. Speech is insufficient to achieve greatness—how much less so virtue? This is Confucius’ intent in wishing to speak not.

To be fully equipped is to be sufficient for use; to seek is to be insufficient. Heaven and earth have no intent toward the myriad things, yet the myriad things naturally fill the space between them—this is what is called great completeness. To prepare out of desire is but a lesser completeness.

To know great completeness, one must know non-seeking. With non-seeking, there is no loss; with no loss, there is no abandonment. Only then does one not exchange oneself for things. To return to oneself is to follow the ancients, never transgressing sincerity.

*(Bi Xu’s Commentary: "Juggling nine balls" refers to spinning spheres in the palm as a playful diversion. The *Guiguzi* speaks of the "nine-turning method of fierce beasts," meaning that sagely wisdom is inexhaustible, like the ceaseless turning of spheres, akin to the boundless ferocity of beasts. Thus, Shi Nanyilaio regarded the affairs of the world as spheres turning in his palm, sleeping sweetly in lofty seclusion, wielding his feather fan to command. Could such men as these be concerned with speech? In silence, they comprehended all—what harm was there in a long beak? Words arise and breath is born; what use are three seals? Thus, there is the Way that is not the Way, the disputation that is not disputation.

That which the Dao unifies is the very Way that is not the Way. To know what lies beyond knowing is the very disputation that is not disputation. Therefore, even those as eloquent as the Ru or Mohists only invite disaster. The sea’s depth and vastness come from its capacity to contain; the sage’s all-embracing nature leaves him nameless. In life, he does not display virtue; in death, he leaves no lingering reputation. Because no substance is amassed, no name is established—this is what is called the Great Person.

Talent is complete when it is not confined to a single vessel. The value of a person lies in attaining the Dao, not in eloquence. To accommodate all things is called greatness; to broadly aid is called virtue. Those who preserve greatness should be humble; those who possess virtue should be unassuming. Like heaven and earth, which cover and bear all without intent, they discard the key to the myriad things, nurturing and fostering, bringing to completion both the animate and inanimate. Only through selflessness and non-seeking is great completeness achieved.

To hide gold in the mountains and not mine it, to sink pearls in the abyss and not dive for them, to let the people return to simplicity and not abandon them—this is not to be swayed by things. Returning to the root without limit, following the ancients without erasure—the sincerity of the Great Person harmonizes with heaven and earth.

*(Juanzhai’s Commentary: "Juggling balls" is a playful act. Holding a feather fan and sleeping contentedly expresses the intent of non-action. The Master said these two men both practiced the action of non-action—what need was there for his words? "Would that I had a beak three feet long" means he wished he did not have such a long beak. That which the Dao unifies is the natural. Virtue is what one attains within oneself. What arises from human effort cannot align with the natural Dao—here, "virtue" differs from its use elsewhere in this text. Those whose names resemble the Ru or Mohists do not embody the disputation that is not disputation. "Not knowing whose they are" means there is nothing by which to name them. "No substance is amassed" means that goodness is not attributed to oneself.

The worthy do not regard eloquence as ability—how much less so the Great Person? The name of greatness is insufficient to make one great—how much less so the virtue of the natural, which defies all naming? Great completeness is great perfection. Only through non-seeking is there no loss and no abandonment. Not exchanging oneself for things means valuing oneself above things, which lies in returning to oneself. To follow the ancient Way is to act without effort.

Juggling spheres in the palm, turning endlessly, the mechanism of application lies within the square inch—this metaphor illustrates that the myriad changes of worldly affairs are all within human control. The enlightened observe them as mere play. Xiong Nanyilaio was a man of wisdom and courage from Chu. Sima Zitai said that if he were obtained, he could match five hundred men—thus his talent was evident. Dwelling in seclusion south of the market, he found contentment in this, regarding the affairs of the world as nothing worth pursuing. When Bai Gong Sheng plotted rebellion and coveted his assistance, how little he knew him! It was fitting that he juggled his spheres and paid no heed. Though this was but a playful act, it prevented Bai Gong’s rebellion and spared Zixi from disaster—resolving the crisis for both sides.

Sun Shu’ao, who thrice took office and thrice resigned without joy or resentment, was a man whose measure could not easily be taken.
