In deep sleep and unhurried repose, wielding his feather fan in leisurely discourse, he could make enemy states lay down their arms and retreat—this is what military strategy calls "subduing the enemy without battle." This is the Way that is not the Way, the disputation that is not disputation, which cannot be described even with a mouth. The Master wished for a beak three feet long only to discuss such matters—not that he literally had a beak of that length.

That which the Dao unifies is the ancestor of the myriad things, to which virtue naturally returns. To know what lies beyond knowing is the truth of the Dao, which cannot be conveyed in words. Thus, virtue cannot unify, and disputation cannot encompass it.)*

Though the Confucians and Mohists were renowned for their eloquence, even they had no ground for debate here.

The sage possesses a boundless capacity, bestowing grace upon all under heaven without claiming credit, and thus no titles or posthumous honors are established—both name and reality are forgotten. This is how one attains the great completeness of heaven and earth, which does not depend on words or deeds. Being complete, one seeks nothing from things; seeking nothing, one does not lose the Way; not losing the Way, one discards nothing of others. One dwells in the present while perpetually following the ancient, penetrating things without losing oneself, ever returning to sincerity as the foundation. When sincerity is present, true conduct manifests in things—how could transformation not follow?

Great completeness indeed—so vast is its scope. "Seeking nothing" should be repeated below, linking to the following text. Some versions read "不摩" as "不磨," which is more fitting.

Master Qi had eight sons. Lining them up before him, he summoned Jiufang Tan and said, "Examine my sons for me and tell me which is most auspicious." Jiufang Tan replied, "Kun is the most auspicious." Master Cai was startled with joy: "In what way?" He answered, "Kun will share the ruler’s table for the rest of his life." Master Jing wept bitterly and left, saying, "Why must my son come to such an extreme!" Jiufang Tan said, "To share the ruler’s table brings blessings to three clans—how much more to his parents! Now that you’ve heard this and weep, you are rejecting fortune. Your son is auspicious, but you are not."

Master Mo exclaimed, "Tan, how could you possibly know that Kun is auspicious? His fate is merely to be sated with meat and wine, filling his nose and mouth—how could you know its origin? I have never herded sheep, yet lambs are born in my inner chamber; I have never hunted quail, yet they hatch in my hearth. If you find this strange, why? Those with whom I wander are those who wander in heaven and earth. With them, I roam in joy beneath the sky and feast upon the earth. I do not involve myself in their affairs, nor in their schemes, nor in their anomalies. With them, I ride the sincerity of heaven and earth without clashing with things; I drift along with them, never aligning with worldly conventions. Yet now, such vulgar rewards befall us! Wherever there are strange omens, there must be strange conduct. Alas! This is not the fault of my son or me—it is heaven’s doing!" And so he wept.

Not long after, Kun was sent to Yan, where bandits seized him on the road. Keeping him whole would make escape too easy, so they severed his foot and sold him in Qi. There, he ended up on the street of Qu Gong, where he lived out his days eating meat.

Guo’s commentary: What seems strange arises from the unexpected. My wanderings have no fixed purpose; I simply follow wherever heaven and earth lead. Following the constant and acting naturally, one remains detached and self-so—this is non-action. Flowing without preference, one benefits things, and things repay accordingly. But I do not seek merit—why should I receive recompense? Without strange conduct, strange omens arise—thus we know it is heaven’s decree. If it comes from doing, then ceasing to act would stop it. But if it comes without action, there is nothing to be done—hence the tears.

Later, when Kun was sent to Yan, bandits captured him. Fearing he might escape if left whole, they cut off his foot to sell him more easily.

Lü’s commentary: This passage shows that Jiufang Tan’s divination was inferior to Master Cai’s understanding through the Way. Master Cai’s wandering with his sons in heaven and earth followed the principles of the perfected in preserving life. Yet strange omens appeared—knowing they were heaven’s gift, not earned by any action.

Yi Du’s commentary: The southwest corner of a room is called the *ao*, corresponding to the *wei* earthly branch, associated with sheep. The southeast corner is called the *tu*, corresponding to the *chen* branch, associated with quail. Sheep are obtained through herding, quail through hunting—these are human affairs. Yet lambs born in *wei* and quail in *chen* are the workings of heaven. Without engaging in such human affairs, why would strange meat and wine appear? This speaks to the principles of yin-yang and destiny, which humans cannot evade.

I wander with Kun in heaven and earth. What we encounter in heaven, we enjoy without refusal; what we encounter on earth, we consume without refusal. I do not involve myself in affairs—this is the Way. I do not engage in schemes—this is principle. I do not concern myself with anomalies—this is the constant. Thus, I ride the sincerity of heaven and earth without clashing with things. Worldly conventions are not my concern. Yet now, there is the omen of sharing the ruler’s table—this is merely the world’s reward for his form. Where there are extraordinary omens, there must be extraordinary conduct. But neither my son nor I have such conduct—this omen is heaven’s gift.

All things that reach extremes are attributed to heaven by the sage. What heaven decrees is simply to be accepted. Qu Gong was a wealthy merchant.

Bi Xu’s commentary: Reaching such an extreme, one meets fortune with fear. The father is deemed inauspicious—he rejects blessings. Meat and wine enter the nose and mouth, speaking to external abundance. Not knowing their origin speaks to receiving emolument without merit—like never herding or hunting, yet sheep and quail suddenly appearing in the house, which is indeed strange. Wandering in heaven and earth is harmony with nature. Roaming in joy beneath the sky is delighting in custom. Feasting upon the earth is savoring its bounty. Not acting is preserving the center; not scheming is following one’s nature; not finding anomalies strange is adhering to the constant. Riding the sincerity of heaven and earth is embodying the Way. Not clashing with things is following principle. Not aligning with worldly conventions is non-action. True merit leaves no trace, yet worldly affairs bring recompense. Without strange conduct, one nears heaven’s decree—though fate is fixed and inescapable, one cannot help but feel fear. Thus, he wept.

Jiufang Tan relied on his divination, while Master Cai alone saw through the Way. Therefore, cultivation and effort cannot avoid calamity—all is destiny.

Wu Chou’s Annotation: Jiufang Tan exhausted his divination by relying on finite calculations, his knowledge bounded by limits. Thus, in his physiognomy, he recognized only the auspiciousness of lifelong feasting alongside the lord of the state, yet failed to foresee the misfortune of mutilation that would maim his life—no greater inauspiciousness exists. Therefore, Master Cai’s shedding of tears was indeed a portent.

From *Yanzhai’s Oral Exegesis*: Never having herded nor tilled, yet sheep and quails appeared in his chamber—this strange occurrence serves as a metaphor: if neither I nor you seek anything from the world, how could there be a matter of feasting alongside the lord of the state? I follow heaven and delight in it; I adapt to earth and nourish myself by it. Without affairs, without schemes, not engaging in anomalies yet aligning wholly with nature, I dare not respond to matters nor discern what is fitting or unfitting. While I rejoice in non-action, what they describe is thus: there remains this unpaid debt of worldly custom—truly a strange portent. If you do not invite such things, they will surely come with strange conduct. The alley of Qu Gong is but a gate facing the street, a place of leisure.

Jiufang Tan discerned men through his art, while Ziyuan divined affairs through principle. The physiognomer knew the auspiciousness of feasting on meat yet overlooked the mutilation; the principle-based diviner feared blessings beyond fate yet rested in the constant. This pertains to fixed destiny, which human effort cannot alter. How can one know that art does not penetrate principle, or that principle does not encompass art? What then is the distinction between auspiciousness and inauspiciousness? Observe the old man at the frontier whose horse, or the deer in the plantain grove—what indeed are their gains and losses? He who knows destiny merely listens.

Now Master Cai, though he never herded nor tilled, suddenly found sheep and quails born in his chamber—how could this not be strange, and how could he not wonder at their origin? Moreover, you and I follow the Way of delighting in heaven, savor the bounty of earth, do not engage in cunning schemes, and ride the sincerity of heaven and earth. Thus, we do not clash with things, forget the fitting in affairs, and entrust ourselves wholly to the Way of nature. Yet to speak of feasting alongside the lord of the state is a worldly desire, not our aspiration. Without strange conduct, yet encountering this strange portent—is this not heaven’s decree? If one knows it is heaven’s decree, why then weep?

Yet the perfected one illuminates the subtleties of principle, contemplates the vicissitudes of affairs, and knows that the greatest blessings arise from the depths of misfortune—nothing arrives without cause. Thus, he cannot help but weep. Before long, the mechanisms of fortune and misfortune, their mutual dependence, would unfold below.

The physiognomer predicted feasting alongside the lord of the state, yet later he ate in the alley of Qu Gong. *Pronunciation and Meaning Annotation*: Qu Gong was a wealthy household in Qi, serving as the street’s overseer. Comparing this to the earlier prediction of mutilation, the art of physiognomy was not entirely verified, unlike principle-based divination, which adheres to the Way without seeking fortune.

*Collected Subtleties of the Southern Florescence’s True Scripture*, Scroll Seventy-Nine Concludes
*Collected Subtleties of the Southern Florescence’s True Scripture*, Scroll Eighty

The Wulin Daoist Chu Boxiu’s Study of *Xu Wugui*, Chapter Six

Nie Que encountered Xu You and asked, “Where are you going?”
“I am fleeing from Yao.”
“What do you mean?”
“Yao, with his boundless benevolence—he will surely become a laughingstock to the world. Future generations may well devour one another. The people are not difficult to gather: love them, and they draw near; benefit them, and they come; praise them, and they are encouraged; bring them what they detest, and they scatter. Love and benefit arise from benevolence and righteousness, yet those who discard benevolence and righteousness are few, while those who profit from them are many. The practice of benevolence and righteousness is neither sincere nor genuine—it is but a tool for the rapacious and predatory. Thus, when one man’s judgment governs the benefit of all under heaven, it is like a single glance. Yao knew that worthy men could benefit the world, yet he did not see how they could harm it—only those beyond the pale of worthiness understand this.”

There are those who are *warmly self-satisfied*, those who are *moist and dependent*, and those who are *coiled and burdened*.

The *warmly self-satisfied* learn the words of a single master, then glow with private delight, believing themselves complete, unaware that nothing has truly begun. These are the *warmly self-satisfied*.

The *moist and dependent* are like lice on a pig: they choose sparse bristles, imagining them a vast palace or grand park, nestling between hooves and hocks, teats and thighs, believing themselves in a secure and advantageous abode. They do not know that one morning, the butcher will roll up his sleeves, spread straw, and light the fire—leaving them scorched along with the pig. These advance and retreat within their narrow bounds—such are the *moist and dependent*.

The *coiled and burdened* is Shun. Mutton does not long for ants, yet ants long for mutton—because mutton is rank. Shun had a rank nature, and the people delighted in him. Thus, with three migrations, he founded cities, and by the time he reached Deng’s ruins, a hundred thousand households had gathered. Yao, hearing of Shun’s worthiness, raised him from the barren soil, saying, “I hope to receive his beneficent influence.” Shun was raised from the barren soil, his years advanced, his hearing and sight declined, yet he could not retire—such is the *coiled and burdened*.

Therefore, the spirit-person detests the thronging of the masses, for where the masses gather, there is no harmony, and where there is no harmony, no benefit arises. Thus, one must have no extreme attachments, no extreme estrangements, embracing virtue and kindling harmony to follow the world—this is the true person.

Discard knowledge like the ant, find strategy like the fish, abandon intention like the sheep. With the eye, see the eye; with the ear, hear the ear; with the heart, return to the heart. Those who do so are as level as a carpenter’s line, their transformations following the natural course.

Guo’s Annotation: Benevolence is the root of contention. Once benevolence and righteousness are practiced, pretense will arise to serve them. Their traces become visible, and the rapacious will borrow these tools to achieve their ends. If benevolence and righteousness each arose from genuine feeling, then judgment would not rest with a single man. *Tui* means to sever. The myriad things take myriad forms, yet to sever them with a single measure is to wound them. Only by standing beyond worthiness can one avoid pretense.

Intent exhausts form, and teaching exhausts intent—how could they know my solitary transformation in the mysterious and obscure realm? Those who lack the talent to comprehend change and transcend the world, contenting themselves with momentary gain, are but lice on a pig.

The sage’s form does not differ from that of ordinary people, so while the use of ears and eyes may decline, the spirit remains whole. If one is immature in youth and declines in old age, can the sage’s sagacity and wisdom endure but a morning? The masses come of their own accord, not because they are sought. Clearly, Shun’s acquisition of the world arose from necessity, not from seeking advantage. For the people, it was a blessing; for Shun, it was bodily toil.

Ants, fish, and sheep—none can be without their ears, eyes, hearts, or intentions. Thus, they cannot abandon the carpenter’s line to find their own level, nor sever their traces to achieve mysterious union.

Lü’s Annotation: The affairs of Shun and Yu—I understand them now. They are but tools for the rapacious. To call them benevolence and righteousness is still to be bound by knowledge, and knowledge separates one from the realm of form, which is not universally affirmed. When one man’s judgment governs the benefit of all under heaven, it is like a single severing—it does not assist the natural course of things, bending to complete them without omission. This is the root of great disorder, arising between Yao and Shun, its branches lingering a thousand generations hence.

Taking warmth as right, one does not know the world has ultimate sufficiency; taking beauty as right, one does not know the world has ultimate beauty. Thus, those who learn the words of a single master, believing themselves complete while unaware that nothing has truly begun—these are named accordingly.

*Ru* means not to depart; *xu* means to depend. Content in lowliness and filth, unaware of disaster—thus they are named after lice on a pig. Coiling and grasping, not concealing their rankness, causing the world to long for and flock to them—thus they are named after Shun.

From learning the words of a single master, unaware that nothing has truly begun, one becomes *moist and dependent* in benefit and *coiled and burdened* in harm. If Shun’s advancement is spoken of in terms of the world, what does it add to me? It is enough to weary the body—hence the term *coiled and burdened*.

Though the masses come and gather, even as with Yao and Shun, the spirit-person detests it. Not aligning with them, they bring no benefit. This is why the true person has no extreme attachments or estrangements, embracing virtue and kindling harmony to follow the world.

The world delights and gathers, and Shun delights and follows. Shun saw the world as a worn-out sandal, yet what made him Shun saw Shun as dust, chaff, and husks—what else but the spirit and the true?

The ant, with its knowledge, is meddlesome; the fish, with its depth, preserves its life; the sheep, with its intention, is fierce. With the eye, see the eye, and the seer is attained. With the ear, hear the ear, and the hearer is attained. With the heart, return to the heart, and the knower is attained. Discard knowledge and intention, and conceal oneself in the profound and boundless, attaining the seer, the hearer, and the knower—then there is nowhere one does not find levelness, mending things naturally and without effort.

This is the Way to restore one’s true nature.

*Dú’s Annotation:* The law began with Fuxi, and governance was perfected under Yao. Yao was the origin from which the traces of the Seven Sages arose. By loving kinship, the people gather. By harmonizing with benefit, the people come. By exalting with praise, the people are encouraged. Imposing what they do not desire, the people scatter. Thus, in the world, those who abandon transformative righteousness are few, while those who profit from benevolence and righteousness are many—pursuing names and following traces, they depart from nature and enter artifice. Seeking to practice benevolence and righteousness without sincerity, the world’s rapacious, like beasts, will borrow these tools as means for burrowing and lodging. When all under heaven steal the name of benevolence and righteousness to plunder the world, there will inevitably come a time when men devour one another.

Moreover, for one man to wield the authority of benevolence and righteousness, decreeing and regulating for the benefit of all under heaven, is like glancing briefly and wishing to level the four seas—intending to benefit them, yet unwittingly harming all under heaven. The worthy, those renowned for benevolence and righteousness, are known only externally by those who deem themselves worthy, aligning with the *Laozi*’s principle of "not esteeming the worthy."

"Warmth" is self-comfort. "Beauty" is self-admiration. "Moist" is to be nourished. "Dependent" is to await. "Alley" is self-constriction. "Crouched" is self-restraint. These terms mock the vulgar scholars of the time, who, learning the words of a single master, cling to stale traces and obscure the sagely Way, delighting in their own warmth and beauty, unaware that the Dao resides in the beginning before things arose.

The *kui*’s form resembles a hoof, the curve of the body. Between the teats and thighs, warmth abides. Lice rely on the pig’s existence, finding safety and profit in moisture and dependence, unaware that when the butcher arrives, they will burn together with the pig. This illustrates that those in the world who cannot transcend their circumstances and remain dependent will not escape calamity. Thus, whether advancing or retreating within bounds, unless one possesses the talent to transcend the age and idly enjoy fleeting gains, all are "moist and dependent."

Shun received his mandate from Heaven; his truth lay within and did not manifest. His mere leftover earth and straightness sufficed to win the people’s admiration. Thrice he moved to evade Yao’s son, and the people followed of their own accord. "Barren soil" is land without grass or trees. Shun toiled for all under heaven without rest—this is what is meant by "crouched and restrained."

These three—warmth, moisture, and crouching—are not the true Dao. Thus, the spirit-like person detests the multitude’s arrival, and even when they come, does not privately favor them. Without partiality or estrangement, embracing virtue and kindling harmony to follow the world—this is what is meant by "true."

The ant’s knowledge is petty, the fish’s calculations deep, the sheep’s intentions fierce. The sage discards petty knowledge, attains deep calculation, and abandons fierce intention. With the eye, see the eye, that the seer may be attained. With the ear, hear the ear, that the hearer may be attained. With the heart, return to the heart, that the knower may be attained. In this way, one’s levelness is as a plumb line, and one’s transformations follow in order—yet this still does not sever traces to stand alone.

*Bìxū’s Annotation:* "Warm and soft, beautiful and fine" is self-delight. "Moist" is nourishment; "dependent" is a moment’s idleness. "Crouched" is a constrained, unyielding appearance. This metaphor rebukes shallow scholars, stubborn and self-satisfied, unaware that the great house of the Dao takes the exhaustion of principle and the fulfillment of nature as the state before things ever arose. To idle in comfort while moist is to "advance within bounds"; to meet disaster without awaiting a moment is to "retreat within bounds." Even one like Elai, who followed Zhou and was executed with him, what difference is there from the pig and its lice?

The sage treats all things as straw dogs, without attachment or reliance. Yet the people’s allegiance is like ants drawn to a rank scent—wherever he goes, a market forms in a year, a town in two, a city in three. Dengxu was the name of a settlement. "Barren soil" is land without grass or trees. Yao raised Shun to succeed him, hoping all under heaven would receive his grace. Shun, his work complete and years advanced, could not rest—this was the result of the rank scent of benevolence and righteousness. When merit is achieved, the multitude arrives and praises him; prolonged praise leads to estrangement, and eventually fear and scorn, which bring no benefit.

Only by being without partiality or estrangement and transcending worthiness can the people not flock in admiration—this is to "abandon knowledge like the ant." To forget one another in rivers and lakes is to "attain the fish’s calculation." Serene and without action, joyfully transforming through virtue, the people know their ruler yet do not gather like ants drawn to a scent—this is to "abandon intention like the sheep." Withdrawing sight and reversing hearing, extinguishing the heart, following inclination to achieve levelness, naturally aligning with the plumb line, responding to things and adapting to change without failing to follow principle.

*Yuànzhāi’s Oral Teachings:* "Warm and beautiful" describes shallow vision and self-satisfaction, mocking scholars who do not grasp the wonder of "never yet having had things." "Moist and dependent" refers to those fixated on fame and profit. The *kui*’s hoof and curved flank are where lice dwell, believing themselves secure, unaware of their unreliability. "Bounds" is a metaphor for confining the heart to wealth and honor. "Alley and crouched" describe a self-tormenting appearance, as when cultivators of virtue take pride in their names, and people flock to them, only to find it burdensome, never resting their whole lives. This is used to satirize rulers of action.

Embracing virtue and kindling harmony, nurturing one’s power without display.

The ant, though most minute, cannot be utterly devoid of knowledge; the sheep, though most foolish, cannot be utterly devoid of intention. The true person, however, is without knowledge and without intention. As fish are content in water, so too does the true person act with calculation. Water is a metaphor for the Creator, the fish for the self; the true person’s heart, ears, and eyes are the same as others’, yet they employ them without heart—thus the eye sees for the eye, the ear hears for the ear, the heart returns to the heart.

The plumb line is the natural level; change is to follow it, to comply with its movement. Nie Que and Xu You both valued their authenticity in governing themselves, never regarding the world as their concern. Observing their discourse, one sees they were not inept at governance—like a chef who knows the bounds of his wine vessels and cutting boards. Wandering within or beyond the world, there is only a distinction of toil and ease.

Now, benevolence and righteousness are the foremost of the Five Constants and cannot be lightly disparaged. Yet later generations, in practicing them imperfectly, often mistake the trace for the tread, losing their authenticity. Once they depart from nature and follow emotion, benevolence and righteousness no longer arise from effortless action; self-interest lingers within, inevitably leading to pretense. Seeming yet not being, this truly harms the Way. Thus, the teachings of Laozi and Zhuangzi, which return to purity and restore the root, reject them. Yet as for the utmost benevolence and great righteousness—those that encompass heaven and nurture all things, establishing the human standard in accord with the Dao and virtue—what rejection could there be?

As for Yao, who was deemed shallow, Xu You feared being ridiculed by the world. For he discerned the shadow and knew the form, seeking to flee and avoid future calamity. Generally, governing the world should be through non-action, allowing self-transformation. If one diligently seeks to benefit and aid, strength may fail, and pretense will follow. Once pretense arises, harm proliferates. Those above should take the hearts of the common people as their own; though they may not practice benevolence and righteousness, they will unwittingly align with them. Otherwise, it is like lending the tools of silk and nets to one who values fowl—such harm to creatures only grows worse. Thus, when a single ruler’s decisions seek to benefit the world, it is like glimpsing for a moment and claiming to comprehend the conditions of all things under heaven. They know only the advantage of exalting the worthy, not the harm it brings to later generations. Only those who stand beyond worthiness can see this, transcending by a head’s height to perceive the truth.

Later, Shu cited "warm and beautiful," "crouched and coiled," and "moist and dependent" to substantiate the earlier meaning, elaborating in great detail, with all explanations thoroughly expounded.

The spirit-person abhors the multitude’s arrival. The next two lines speak of the people’s allegiance to Yao, and Yao’s elevation of Shun, which pleased the hearts of all—all natural principles, not comparisons for profit. Thus, without partiality or estrangement, they followed virtue to accord with the world. This is the true person’s verification of responding to the world with their remaining threads.

The three phrases about ants, fish, and sheep were spoken in regard to Shun’s usurpation, with remarkably apt wording. First the ant, then the sheep, and lastly the fish. Not swayed by the scent of mutton, the ant abandons knowledge. Not moved by usurpation to impress others, the sheep abandons intention. In this way, superiors and inferiors each rest in their place, without longing for the traces of sageliness or exalting worthiness. Like fish content in the depths, forgetting one another in rivers and lakes—is this not a sound strategy?

Only then can one see with the eye without being dazzled by color, hear with the ear without being confused by sound, and return the heart to the heart without being enslaved by knowledge. Thus, the eyes of the world may be unified, the ears harmonized, and the hearts fully realized. Their level is like the plumb line, a model for the world; their response to affairs and changes follows the natural principle, without private interest in things, without harming the nature of things. What worry could there be that the world will not transform itself, that one must govern it with intention?

The multitude takes fame and profit as its bounds; the many lice take the pig’s body as their bounds. Advancing and retreating are like success and failure.

*End of Volume Eighty of the* Nan Hua Zhen Jing Yi Hai Zuan Wei
*Beginning of Volume Eighty-One of the* Nan Hua Zhen Jing Yi Hai Zuan Wei

The Daoist of Wulin, Chu Boxiu’s Study
*Chapter Seven: Xu Wugui*

The true person of antiquity treated it with Heaven, not allowing the human to intrude upon Heaven.

The true person of antiquity: when they attained it, they lived; when they lost it, they died. When they attained it, they died; when they lost it, they lived. Medicines—such as *ge* (plantain), *jiegeng* (balloon flower), *jiyong* (wild ginger), and *shiling* (pig’s ear)—in their time become sovereign remedies. How can they all be enumerated!

Goujian, with three thousand armored soldiers, took refuge on Mount Kuaiji. Only Minister Zhong knew how a state on the verge of ruin could be preserved, yet he did not know why his own person would come to grief.

Thus it is said: the owl’s eyes have their proper use; the crane’s sinews have their proper measure. To sever them is sorrow.

Thus it is said: when the wind passes over the river, it diminishes it; when the sun passes over the river, it diminishes it. If only the wind and sun were to guard the river together, the river would still consider itself untouched, for it relies on its source and flows onward.

Thus, water guards the earth with precision; a shadow guards a person with precision; things guard things with precision.

Therefore, the eye’s reliance on clarity is perilous; the ear’s reliance on acuity is perilous; the heart’s pursuit of its objects is perilous. All abilities stored in the treasury are perilous; once peril is established, it cannot be amended.

Disaster’s growth is ever-concentrated; its reversal is a gradual achievement; its fruition awaits time. Yet people regard it as their own treasure—is this not lamentable?

Thus, the ruin of states and the slaughter of peoples never cease, for none inquire into the cause.

*Guo’s Commentary:*
Abiding in affairs and awaiting affairs, affairs are thereby attained. Seeking non-affair through affair only deepens disorder.

Life and death, gain and loss—each follows where one abides. In life, it is gain; in death, some deem it loss. Thus, what is needed is without baseness; what is untimely is without value. Each suits the use of its time; if none is deemed impossible, then there are times of loss and times of sorrow.

All that has form naturally burdens itself; only that which lies beyond form may be ground yet remain unscathed. Like wind and sun passing over the river, though the river is truly diminished, it does not perceive it, for it relies on its source and flows onward.

Without intention, one halts at the proper measure—this is precision. With intention, there is no limit—thus peril. Therefore, the value lies in non-ability, in following natural spontaneity. If one cannot forget knowledge, disaster grows manifold. Returning to guard one’s nature, then achievement is unmade yet complete.

Seeking speed precludes fruition.

"One’s treasure" refers to knowledge and ability. Thus, the disasters of ruin and slaughter all arise from one’s own errors. Not knowing to inquire into the source of disaster in the heart, and instead cultivating the heart to avert disaster.

*Lü’s Commentary:*
Treating it with Heaven, one responds without action. Not allowing the human to intrude upon Heaven, though one acts, it is as if one has not acted.

The true person knows neither life nor death. At times, attaining it means life; losing it means death—this is for those who take life lightly. At times, attaining it means death; losing it means life—this is for those who abhor death.

Like medicines, some are sweet, some are poisonous; at times they serve as sovereign, but not always—the rest are mere ministers and assistants. To regard life as gain and death as loss is the medicine for those who take life lightly. To regard life as loss and death as return is the medicine for those who abhor death. Prescribing according to the illness, their transformations cannot all be enumerated.

Minister Zhong knew how a ruined Yue could be preserved, yet he did not know why his own person would come to grief—like the crow’s eye, which sees at night but not by day, its use cannot be shifted. The crane’s sinews can be long but not short; their measure cannot be severed. Severing them binds one to form, not knowing the source.

Wind and sun passing over the river do diminish it, yet the river deems itself untouched, for it relies on its source and does not run dry. One who penetrates the Dao adapts to all things, yet has a source.

Water, in relation to earth, reaches every crevice of insect burrows and ant nests; a shadow, in relation to a person, follows sitting, rising, walking, and stopping—these are without emotion yet guard with precision.

The ear’s hearing, the eye’s seeing, the heart’s thinking—none ever depart for an instant. Thus, things guard things with precision, yet their acuity, clarity, and intent are not like water and shadow, which are without emotion. Therefore, they cannot but be perilous.

All abilities stored in the treasury bring harm. The treasury refers to the five viscera; peril means becoming complacent in what is unsafe. If it cannot be amended, disaster grows concentrated.

Only because delusion is not of a single day does its reversal require gradual achievement; its fruition awaits time. The superior person thus reduces and reduces again, for peril cannot be allowed to take form.

Yet the world regards it as their own treasure—is this not lamentable?

*Yi Du’s Commentary:*
Treating the human with Heaven is sincerity manifesting as clarity. Allowing the human to intrude upon Heaven is clarity manifesting as sincerity. Without gain or loss, without life or death—this is what is called the profound.

*Dong* (aconite), *wuhui* (monkshood), *jiyong* (wild ginger), and *ai* (mugwort) are the basest of medicines, yet in their time they can cure illness, alternating as sovereign and minister. Gain and loss, poverty and success—there is no difference in this. The world falsely esteems the noble and despises the base, not knowing that use and disuse depend solely on timing.

Once, King Goujian of Yue took refuge with his troops on Mount Kuaiji. Minister Zhong knew how a ruined state could be preserved, yet he did not know his own person would perish—like the gull’s eye, which is dim by day and bright by night, or the crane’s sinews, which can be long but not short, each suiting the advantage of its time. To sever their proper use is sorrow for what is pursued, for one cannot escape partiality.

Yin and yang possess qi; the myriad things possess form. Qi is subtle; form is coarse. Qi grinds against form, and form must be diminished. Wind and sun are the qi of yin and yang; river water is that which has form. Wind and sun passing over the river must diminish it, yet though they guard it together, the river feels no disturbance, for it relies on its source. This illustrates how one abides amid yin and yang, daily diminished yet relying on fate to endure.

Water to earth, shadow to form, thing to thing—all guard one another without intent; thus their guarding is precise. Yet though precise, they cannot escape the subtle shifts of creation’s workings. Yesterday’s thing is already transformed today, yet the deluded remain unaware of this.

Ears, eyes, and heart in their pursuit—none can avoid peril. All abilities, when drawn from the storehouse of the viscera, become enslaved to what they serve. Once peril has fully formed, to seek swift correction is already too late; thus calamity grows ever more severe. If one returns to the root and restores one’s nature, all proceeds smoothly and bears fruit. To see one’s affairs come to fruition requires patient waiting. Yet世人 regard manifold skills as their treasure—this is what the perfected ones lament. They contend over cities and lands, slaughtering innocent people, unaware of the origins of the disasters they bring.

*Bi Xu’s annotation:* To await others with Heaven, letting things follow their nature. Not to impose human artifice upon Heaven, for falsity cannot match truth.

To gain it is life, to lose it is death—this is shared with all things. To gain it is death, to lose it is life—this sets one apart from all things. The myriad things flourish when they meet their time, wither when they miss it. The true person flourishes not when meeting their time, nor withers when missing it—like the herbs *dong*, *geng*, *yong*, and *ling*, though humble things, yet when a skilled physician employs them in treatment, they become sovereign. This illustrates how the true person governs the world, ever in accord with the times.

One who can preserve a state cannot save their own person—like a physician who treats others’ illnesses yet cannot cure their own. The gull’s eye and crane’s sinews, each suited or unsuited to its time, illustrate how one may possess talent and knowledge yet still not escape calamity. Wind blows and sun bakes, river water dwindles and cries out; slander runs deep and flattery enters, loyal ministers lose power—what one relies upon most heavily is not lightly disturbed.

Water parted from earth scatters; shadow parted from person vanishes; thing parted from thing empties; person parted from the Dao perishes. Only those who guard with utmost care approach wholeness!

Eyes in pursuit: Li Zhu. Ears in pursuit: Shi Kuang. Heart in pursuit: Zeng and Shi. None have avoided peril! Weighing merits and faults, the fruits of good and evil—these are not yet visible before one’s eyes. Yet世人 cling to merit as their treasure, and disaster follows on their heels—such was the case with Minister Zhong.

*Yanzhai’s Oral Exegesis:* Not to impose intent upon the principles of nature is called "not imposing human artifice upon Heaven." Life and death, gain and loss—all are left to nature. To call life "gain" is acceptable, to call death "gain" is also acceptable; to call life "loss" is acceptable, to call death "loss" is also acceptable. Like a physician using herbs, the sovereign becomes the ruler, the rest become ministers; though the herbs are the same, their use varies in weight. So too with people in the world: meeting their time, they are noble; missing it, they are base—yet in oneself, there is no duality.

Minister Zhong, in avenging Yue against Wu, could seek survival amid ruin—this was wisdom! Yet he did not know to turn back and thus brought about his own death. The gull’s eye and crane’s sinews are again cited, along with the metaphor of wind and sun both able to diminish water, yet the river never feels disturbance, for its source is long. Thus, though things may diminish oneself, one feels no disturbance.

These five phrases form a single idea: water and earth intermingle, form and shadow depend on one another, things guard things—this is the principle of nature. The pursuit of things by eyes and heart is not natural. All knowledge issuing from the chest’s storehouse, taken as ability, leads to peril.

*Ji* means "to reach." *Fan* means "to overturn." The heart set on scheming for merit must lead to ruin. Those who plan with patient endurance remain steadfast and unchanging. All this harms the person, yet世人 regard it as their treasure. From ancient times to the present, the ruin of states and slaughter of people have never ceased—this is because they do not question its origins.

To await others with Heaven is self-evident in meaning: to take Heaven’s principles as primary, and let human affairs follow. To impose human artifice upon Heaven is to take human affairs as primary, and thus violate Heaven’s principles.

The phrase "the true person of ancient times" should be "thus," as the previous text contains a redundant repetition. To gain this Dao and live, to lose it and die—this is the constant principle. Yet to gain this Dao and die, to lose it and live—this arises from the vicissitudes of human affairs. Like the short-lived Yan and long-lived Peng, or the herbs *wuhui* and *shiling*, applied according to the condition: when sovereign, they rule; when assisting, they serve. Appropriate to their time, they have no fixed role.

Zhong’s skill in statecraft was matched by his clumsiness in preserving his own person—like the gull’s eye and crane’s sinews, each suited to its time. To force what one cannot do is sorrow. Again, the metaphor of wind and sun passing over the river, which cannot avoid diminution, yet remains undisturbed by relying on its source. Then how can one avoid the disturbance of gain and loss, advantage and harm? To remedy this, the Dao is the source. For all things that come, if one does not admit them into the numinous storehouse, one’s source remains strong. The rise and fall of events are no more than mosquitoes passing before one—what disturbance could there be?

Water’s guarding of earth is a principle of mutual support, yet truly without intent. Shadow’s guarding of form arises from what it issues from and cannot be without. Things guarding things each generate their own intent; though their guarding is precise, they mutually generate and overcome, now flourishing, now flowing—like what is described in the *Outer Things* chapter—thus they cannot avoid peril. How much more so when ears, eyes, and heart pursue things as ability! Once peril has formed, correction comes too late—such calamity is indeed long-lasting.

To return to the root, one must focus on correcting faults, waiting patiently for gradual success. Yet世人 take keen senses and clever minds as their treasure—this is what the true person pities. The ruin of states and slaughter of people are the greatest of disasters, yet their beginnings lie in the pursuit of things by ears, eyes, and heart. The key is to check their source!

Thus the foot’s treading upon the earth is but slight, yet though slight, it relies on what it does not tread to achieve its full reach. Human knowledge is scant, yet though scant, it relies on what it does not know to grasp what Heaven calls it to know.

To know the Great Oneness, to know the Great Yin, to know the Great Eye, to know the Great Balance, to know the Great Square, to know the Great Faith, to know the Great Stillness—this is perfection.

The Great Oneness unites it; the Great Yin dissolves it; the Great Eye sees it; the Great Balance levels it; the Great Square embodies it; the Great Faith verifies it; the Great Stillness sustains it.

In exhausting what Heaven possesses, follow what illuminates; in obscurity, hold to the pivot; in beginning, there is the other.

Thus its dissolution resembles non-dissolution; its knowing resembles non-knowing—only through non-knowing does knowing arise.

In questioning it, one cannot be bound by limits, yet cannot be without limits. What is tangled yet real, ancient and modern yet unchanging and unalterable—can this not be called the great raising and sifting?

Why then remain perplexed? To resolve perplexity with non-perplexity and return to non-perplexity is to attain the greatest non-perplexity.

The Great Oneness is the Dao. Employing what lies within its bounds, the myriad affairs encounter no obstruction. Using the self-manifestation of the myriad things is the Great Eye. Following their inherent nature, allowing each to attain its own, is the Great Balance. Embodying them so each attains its proper place—thus the ten thousand directions all find their due—this is the Great Square. What is ordained by destiny, allowing no transgression, is the Great Faith. When the true is unshaken, it naturally settles; sustaining it with the Great Stillness is to sustain nothing at all.

No thing is without its spontaneity; following it brings clarity, without contrivance. The utmost principle has its limit—only by obscuring it does one grasp its pivot. What begins with the other is the other; thus I am deluded and do not act. Dissolving the other by relinquishing it, the other dissolves itself. Dissolution without effort resembles non-dissolution. Using the other’s knowing resembles non-knowing. When I do not know, the other’s knowing operates of itself; when the other’s knowing operates of itself, nothing in the world fails to know. Responding to things obscurely and without fixed form, each according to its portion—the myriad things, though tangled and disparate, each possesses its own reality, none replaceable by another. To crush and raise them has its great limit.

If one questions their great essence, things have their ultimate bounds; thus the principle of forgetting the self and entrusting things may be known—why then remain perplexed in this way? Since perplexity cannot be resolved, to esteem the greatest non-perplexity is the height of folly. The sage follows and entrusts it, hence the sovereign kings differ in their accounts, adapting their names to the age.

The foot treads but little; relying on what it does not tread, it achieves its full reach—this is what is meant by knowing non-use and only then speaking of use. Human knowledge is scant; relying on what it does not know, it grasps what Heaven calls it to know—thus the Great Oneness, Great Yin, and so on to the Great Stillness may all be known.

Those who practice the Way take the Great Oneness as their master, and nothing is not penetrated. Entering the gate of profound obscurity, reaching the source of utmost yin, one also attains the source of utmost yang. Things bear yin and embrace yang, thus they are bound and cannot be dissolved—because they do not know the source of utmost yin.

The eye’s vision is limited; not seeing with the eye, there is nothing unseen. To level the one is not yet to balance; harmonizing with right and wrong, allowing both to proceed, is to level with the Great Balance. Without south or north, without east or west—embodying the Great Square. Its essence is most true, within it lies faith—verified by the Great Faith. Marshes burn yet are not hot; rivers freeze yet are not cold; thunder splits mountains, winds shake seas, yet one is not startled—sustained by the Great Stillness.

Exhausting what Heaven possesses is to halt at what knowledge does not know. Following what illuminates, though one does not know, there is nothing unknown. In obscurity, holding to the pivot, neither this nor that finds its counterpart. Beginning with the other, one responds to the other. This is indeed inexhaustible.

Its dissolution resembles non-dissolution, for originally there was no bond—thus only after non-dissolution does dissolution occur. Its knowing resembles non-knowing, for originally there was no knowing—thus only after non-knowing does knowing arise. This is how the utmost person wanders among the vulgar, appearing foolish and clumsy.

To question with or without limits is still to be bound. Limits mean seeking from one’s own edge. Yet one cannot seek between being and non-being. What is tangled cannot be bound; what is slippery cannot be grasped—like nothing yet real, past and present unchanging and unalterable. Can one not call this the great raising and sifting?

To raise is to bring forth the hidden; to sift is to examine the real. If the other does not question this, I cannot inform it with this. Only by seeing that there has never been a thing can one be without perplexity. Resolving the perplexity of there being things while still preserving the state of there never having been a thing is still perplexity. Only by dissolving it and returning to non-perplexity does one approach the greatest non-perplexity.

The Great Oneness is Heaven; the Great Yin is Earth. The Great Eye is Heaven seeing all; the Great Balance is Earth bearing all. The Great Square gives birth to the myriad things and fully provides for them. The Great Faith responds to the myriad things without expectation. The Great Stillness stabilizes the myriad things without movement.

Knowledge begins with knowing and ends with nourishing it through non-knowing—what is known attains such subtlety, hence it is called perfection. When bound by calculation, value lies in unifying it. Yin governs coagulation; value lies in dissolving it.

The Great Eye has no intention to see, yet each thing comes and is beheld. The Great Balance has no intention to comply with things, yet each thing arrives and is harmonized. The Great Square is嫌于 lacking form, thus it takes ease as its form. The Great Faith is嫌于 unexamined, thus it is verified through the Dao. It concludes with the Creator, merely sustaining it.

The principles of the myriad things under Heaven each have their own Heaven. Observing them by following principle, there is illumination; observing them from obscurity, there is a pivot. With a beginning, there is an "other"; without a beginning, there are no things, no "other," and no self. Dissolution resembles non-dissolution; knowledge resembles non-knowledge. In all discussions that reach their ultimate, one doubts through non-knowledge and only then knows—this is perfection.

Questions with limits are incisive inquiries. Questions without limits are diffuse inquiries. Incisive inquiries may exhaust principle but cannot fully realize nature; diffuse inquiries may broaden knowledge but cannot return to simplicity—thus, neither is sufficient.

Slippery words often lack substance yet may contain truth. Past and present alternate, yet principle itself does not change. One who fully grasps principle is said to be "unfailing." As stated above, can this not be called a grand elucidation and critical discussion?

If a matter is impossible, then desist—why perplex oneself by pursuing it? When one’s own perplexity is resolved through non-perplexity, though the other may return to non-perplexity, the one who resolves perplexity remains greatly perplexed—this is Zhuangzi’s intent in dismissing words.

Master Bixu’s annotation: Earth is vast, yet what people tread upon is merely enough to hold their feet. It is by relying on the untrodden that one’s movement becomes boundless. The Dao is supremely subtle, yet what people know is only what can be spoken. It is by relying on the realm beyond words that one’s realization becomes inexhaustible. Thus, the perfected person takes non-use and non-speech as Heaven’s true calling.

The Great Oneness is wondrous existence; those who know it become expansively penetrating. The Great Yin is profound stillness; those who know it become effortlessly liberated. The Great Eye is Heaven’s radiance, clearly illuminating all. The Great Balance is level unity, harmoniously complying. The Great Square is undifferentiated, embodying all forms and functions. The Great Faith is sincerity, verifying all without exception. The Great Stillness is ultimate quiescence, sustaining all to manifest the above wondrous functions.

These seven terms all possess Heaven’s natural principles. Following principle brings clarity; in stillness, it operates spontaneously. Beginning is the Dao; what opposes the Dao is the "other." Effortlessly liberated, one resembles non-liberation. Naturally knowing, one resembles non-knowing. Only by knowing non-knowledge does one truly know—clarity deepens with illumination.

The Dao cannot be limited, yet seeking it cannot be without bounds. Myriad forms differ, but principle is one. Slipperiness is disparity. Past and present are not two; life and death naturally diverge. Principle cannot be diminished; life and death naturally possess it. Herein lies great elucidation and critical discussion—why not inquire into this Dao?

Knowing the Dao, one is no longer perplexed by this principle. Profound perplexity persists lifelong, unshaken by the foolish or the wise, like the crane’s classic that cannot be severed or the hare’s classic that cannot be extended. Endowment and reception of qi have their reasons; only those who silently accompany creation know this. To rely on worldly learning to return to non-perplexity is the act of a greatly perplexed person, vainly revering the state of great non-perplexity.

From *Yanzhai’s Oral Teachings*: The ground people tread upon is little; what they do not tread upon is vast. This illustrates that what people know is minimal, while what they do not know is Heaven. Not relying on what is known but on what is unknown, one can know Heaven.

The Great Oneness is the movement of creation. The Great Yin is ultimate stillness. The Great Eye is what sees. The Great Balance refers to distribution. The Great Square shares its body with the Great Void. The Great Faith is the principle of truth. The Great Stillness is what sustains the myriad things.

The beginning of no-thing must have something to initiate it. As the *Qiwulun* states: "Without that, there is no self"—this "that" refers to creation. Terms like Heaven, illumination, pivot, and "other" may be known and understood, yet they also resemble non-understanding and non-knowledge. Not daring to assume they can be known is to take non-knowledge as knowledge—this is true knowledge.

To inquire is to ask about the principle of creation; whether with or without limits, neither is sufficient. Slipperiness is rotation, speaking of creation as elusive. Though seemingly without thing, it is truly existent. Past and present share this creation, its use inexhaustible. Should this matter not be grandly elucidated and critically discussed? Yet people do not inquire into this principle—why doubt it? With this non-perplexing understanding, one resolves the world’s perplexities and returns to the realm of non-perplexity, approaching great non-perplexity!

It is merely the two words "non-perplexity" that inspire these lines, concluding the essay in a singularly marvelous way. The ground one treads upon is not as vast as what is untrodden; the matters one knows are not as numerous as what is unknown. Not relying on what is trodden or known but taking non-use as use—only then can one know Heaven!

The Dao of Heaven is unfathomable, admitting no conjecture. Thus, there is no place to apply knowledge in questioning it. To halt at what is unknown is true knowledge. The key lies in daily diminishing desires; when human desires are exhausted, Heaven’s principle appears.

From the Great Oneness and Great Yin to the Great Faith, all are known only after knowing Heaven. The Great Oneness unifies them: the Dao pervades all principles, penetrating the generation of the myriad things. They receive yang to form shapes and encounter yin to dissolve and transform, born from non-being and returning to non-being.

The Great Eye sees what others do not see. The Great Balance complies with things, allowing them to level themselves. The Great Square takes formlessness as its form. The Great Faith verifies without expectation. It concludes with the Great Stillness, sustaining it to respond to the world’s movements—ever non-acting.

To exhaust the heavenly principles is to reach the utmost of things’ naturalness; to follow illumination is to comply with principle and attain clarity of itself.

Within obscurity lies the pivot—silent yet ever in motion, originating from that other, harmonious yet never leading. Through non-dissolution, one dissolves the world’s entanglements; through non-knowing, one knows the secrets of the heavenly Dao.

What need is there to question or examine whether it has bounds or none? Thus, though it may seem like the babbling of a witless fool, true principle resides within—unchanging through ancient and modern times, each fulfilling its proper role. Can this not be called a great "raising and drawing forth"?

As the *Han History* states: "To raise and draw forth the past and present"—*raising* means to lift, *drawing forth* means to extend. Lifting and extending, one sets forth its purport.

Why do people not inquire into this, instead relying on their delusive, expansive "knowledge," blind to their own heavenly nature? How then can they comprehend what is meant by the primal power of Qian? This is because the mind’s heaven lacks illumination, and delusion obstructs it.

Thus, through non-delusion, one dissolves delusion, returning to non-delusion—this is the ultimate great non-delusion. Delusion is the falsity of wayward emotions; non-delusion is the truth of one’s original nature. If one still knows to revere and esteem this original truth—one’s natural self—then it is not yet the great non-delusion. If one truly attains the state of non-delusion, what delusion remains to be esteemed? What delusion remains to be dissolved?

A ruler of the Dao does not lord his state and position over others. A scholar of the Dao must uphold integrity and righteousness to correct his lord.

Though Lord Wu was fierce and difficult to sway, lacking the persuasive power of a ghostly counselor, he first spoke of fine steeds to open his mind, showing that even a ruler must have discerning eyes for his ministers. Thus, he began in opposition but ended in accord, gradually remedying his tyranny. The people acknowledged their own faults, and the innate goodness of human nature could not be wholly extinguished—like one exiled from his homeland who rejoices at the sight of a familiar face. Upon their reunion, he then offered blunt, unpalatable advice to awaken him to his errors.

Loving harmony and detesting treachery, he fulfilled the essentials of self-cultivation. Cultivating sincerity to resonate with Heaven and Earth, he exhausted the Way of governing a state. To have heard such words was a blessing for the altars of soil and grain—what need was there to act righteously for the people’s benefit or to lay down arms in pursuit of order?

When the Yellow Emperor beheld the Great Spirit, even the Seven Sages were confounded. This illustrates that when the six senses are benighted, the lord of the mind cannot shine alone—like asking the way of a horse-herding boy, one is not far from returning. Thus, the perfected take refuge in parables. If a wise ruler wishes to perceive the great Dao, he must cut off sagacity and discard knowledge, seeking it in the spirit that guards the mind while removing what harms the self. Then the Great Spirit will come of itself without being sought.

How could one like Lord Wu, who wearied his people to indulge his senses, ever attain the numinous and only then seek righteousness and disarmament?

Only when later rulers’ virtue was not pure and their pursuits not singular did the various scholars diverge in their aims, concealing their natures and turning toward the myriad things, no longer hoping to return to the root—thus drifting ever farther from the Dao.

Take the Confucians, Mohists, Yangists, Bingists, and Huians—each clung to one partial view, believing the Dao was exhausted therein. Yet in the thrust and parry of their discourse, they too contributed to revealing the Dao’s wonders—like the man of Ying whose severed foot inspired the master carpenter’s skill.

It is also like having the talent of Xi Peng, which then enables the elevation of Guan Zhong, never allowing personal affection for Bao Shu to alter the choice.

The monkey’s arrogance hastened its demise; people’s admiration for the monkey’s appearance brought it renown—this serves to warn the world against pride and insolence. How could it compare to those who still their hearts and wither their forms, ever receding from worldly entanglements? Those who juggle pellets and wield feathers are difficult to free.

Jiu Fang discerned the essence without mentioning the missing leg; Xu You, fearing Yao’s seven offers, fled and departed—both perceived the subtle and knew the manifest, gaining advantage by disregarding worldly honor.

Dong, Geng, and Yongling became emperors in their time, illustrating how people shift their standards. The wind and sun, the river’s waters—each vies to sway the other, illustrating how transformation alters people.

Things that cling to things are indeed fixed, yet in the end cannot escape change; once changed, they are imperiled. Only one who knows contentment and relies on non-action, whose mind depends on non-knowing, exhausts their own heaven to illumine the heaven of things. Unconfused themselves, they dissolve the world’s confusion.

*Collected Subtleties of the Meaning of the Southern Florescence True Scripture*, Scroll Eighty-One, Concludes
*Collected Subtleties of the Meaning of the Southern Florescence True Scripture*, Scroll Eighty-Two

The Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin, *On Zeyang* (First Chapter)

When Zeyang traveled to Chu, Yi Jie spoke of him to the king, but the king did not summon him, and Yi Jie returned. Pengyang then asked Wang Guo, “Why did you not recommend me to the king?” Wang Guo replied, “I am not the equal of Gong Yuxiu.” Pengyang asked, “What does Gong Yuxiu do?” He answered, “In winter, he retreats alone to the river; in summer, he rests in the mountain thickets. If someone passes by and asks, he says, ‘This is my dwelling.’ Yi Jie could not do this—how could I presume to do so? And I am not the equal of Yi Jie. Yi Jie is a man without virtue but with cunning; he does not approve of himself, yet he uses this to mystify his connections, plunging headlong into the realm of wealth and honor. He does not assist others with virtue but assists in their dissipation. The frozen borrow garments in spring; the sweltering turn back to winter’s cool breeze.

The King of Chu is a man of imposing form and stern demeanor. In matters of punishment, he is as unforgiving as a tiger. If not for a flatterer’s deceptive virtue, who could sway him? Thus, the sage—when impoverished—makes his household forget their poverty; when prosperous, he makes kings and lords forget their ranks and titles, transforming their arrogance into humility. Toward things, he delights in harmony; toward people, he rejoices in the Dao’s communion while preserving himself. Thus, without speaking, he imparts harmony to others; standing beside them, he transforms them. In the proper relations of father and son, they return to their places, each inquiring of the other’s conduct. His influence on the human heart is as distant as this. Therefore, it is said: ‘Await Gong Yuxiu.’”

Guo’s Commentary:
Wang Guo cited Gong Yuxiu’s character to restrain Pengyang’s eagerness for advancement. He was not like Yi Jie, who coveted wealth and honor, forging connections and exhausting his knowledge of forms and names to curry favor with superiors. Yet when one exhausts oneself thus, virtue thins and reputation fades. Though he followed the seasons’ gifts, he could not meet Pengyang’s urgent needs. The sage, serene and desireless, finds joy in what he encounters, not valuing extravagance. Thus, his household does not know the bitterness of poverty. He轻爵禄而重道德,超然坐忘,不觉荣之在身,故使王公失其所以为高. He does not torment himself with things, communing with others without losing himself. When each attains their own fulfillment, harmony is drunk—what need is there for words? Turning to the wind, they yield, and fathers and sons each return to their proper places. His virtue aligns with heaven and earth, thus remaining still and undivided. He wished Pengyang to abandon the King of Chu and follow Yuxiu, using the wind of tranquility to calm the king’s restless heart.

Lü’s Commentary:
Gong Yuxiu, so free of desires, was right to be trusted by the king. The spirit is the common ground of human hearts, which can be entered through emptiness. Yi Jie claimed he could not enter it, yet his connections were already mired in the realm of wealth and honor. “Assisting in dissipation” means his virtue did not endure but daily waned. The frozen borrow spring’s garments in winter; the sweltering seek winter’s breeze in summer—this speaks of seeking in vain. The King of Chu was harsh and violent; without a flatterer’s deceptive virtue, none could sway him. To ask me to speak for you is beyond my ability. Only a flatterer can disrupt a ruler’s integrity; only true virtue can disrupt his depravity. The flatterer is Yi Jie; the true virtue is Yuxiu. I delight and forget poverty, so my household forgets it too. When the Dao is honored and virtue esteemed, ranks and titles are not enough to elevate one, so kings and lords are transformed from arrogance to humility. “Imparting harmony” means his virtue suffices to nourish the human heart—no words are needed. “Standing beside them, he transforms them” means no power is needed. Fathers and sons return to their places, preserving human relations. “Each inquiring of the other’s conduct” leaves no room for regret. When the human heart is so distant, its entanglements are untied. Gong Yuxiu’s character being as it is, speaking of him to the king would surely be believed. Thus, it is said: “Await Gong Yuxiu.”

Yi Du’s Commentary:
Pengyang of Lu, styled Zeyang. Yi Jie was a man of Chu. Wang Guo was a Chu minister. Gong Yuxiu was a recluse. Yi Jie lacked innate virtue but had worldly knowledge; he could not approve of himself through the spiritual Dao, plunging headlong into the realm of wealth and honor. This was enough to dissipate your virtue, not to assist you. Like the frozen borrowing spring’s garments or the sweltering awaiting winter’s breeze, seeking Wang Guo’s help was not urgent. Moreover, the King of Chu’s character was as fierce as a tiger; if not swayed by flattery, he must be transformed by true virtue. The sage, though poor, is joyful, so his household forgets their poverty. When prosperous, he does not regard ranks and titles as exalted, making kings and lords transform their arrogance into humility. Toward things, he is without opposition, delighting in harmony. Toward people, he rejoices in the Dao’s communion while preserving himself. Without speaking, others drink his harmony. Standing beside them, he transforms their goodness, making each father and son return to their proper places. Abiding in unity without action, the Dao naturally extends to others, thus distancing itself from worldly customs. It is better to abandon the King of Chu and follow Yuxiu.

Bi Xu’s Commentary:
Zeyang sought an audience with the king for the sake of profit and rank. Wang Guo cited the recluse to restrain his competitive ambition. “Without virtue but with knowledge” means valuing ornament over substance. “Not approving of himself” refers to using this to deceive, solidifying connections through cunning and drowning in desires. Aiding the frozen and sweltering is human effort; awaiting spring and winter is heaven’s timing. Wang Guo followed heaven’s timing and did not comply with human effort, thus correcting Zeyang’s error. When Lao Lai’s wife wove baskets and Bo Huan’s wife hired herself out to pound grain, their households forgot poverty. When Marquis Wen of Wei honored Duan Ganmu and Emperor Guangwu of Han befriended Yan Ziling, they forgot ranks and titles, transforming arrogance into humility. Delighting in harmony with things, he moved with the world without being sullied.

To delight in harmony with things is to blend one’s light without dazzling. The teaching without words is warm as spring, anchored in the nameless uncarved block, allowing people to transform themselves. When virtue’s transformation follows its natural order, people rest content in their places. The Way is simple and effortless, requiring no action, yet those who hasten forward exhaust themselves in pursuit of office, their hearts far removed from those of the Dao-attuned.

*The Yanzhai Oral Exegesis* states: The spirit is one’s natural endowment. To be infatuated with wealth and rank, unaware of the spirit’s naturalness, is to fail to approve of oneself. This is the path of mutual self-diminishment, hence it is called dissipation. One who is cold and receives clothing becomes warm as spring; one who is sweltering and receives a breeze becomes cool as winter. In human interactions, one must use one’s surplus to relieve another’s lack. Pengyang’s fondness for advancement revealed his deficiency; to instruct him in retreat was like offering water to one holding heat or clothing to one in cold—it would bring benefit. “Flatterers rectify virtue” means that only true petty men can humble themselves to serve others. When lords and nobles forget their ranks to honor scholars, they transform arrogance into humility. To take joy in investigating principle, to harmonize with things without contention, to preserve one’s authenticity, and to awaken without words—this is like offering the purest harmony to drink, standing side by side while others transform, dissolving their intentions.

“That one”—as in the *Book of Songs*: “That man”—implies that if he were to return and dwell at home, then superiors and inferiors, elders and juniors, would each find their proper place. Wherever he applied his inquiries, no effort would be required, for harmony would prevail whether at home or in the village. How distant was Yue Xiu’s virtue from Pengyang’s! *Master Chu’s Superficial Observations* notes: Wang Guo spoke of Yijie’s fondness for advancement, his inability to emulate Gong Yuexiu’s conduct, yet both were beloved and esteemed by the King of Chu. Now, Zeyang, with advancement in his heart, sought Yijie’s recommendation. Yijie was weak in virtue but strong in cunning; he did not recognize that the inner spirit is what should be honored, instead becoming externally infatuated with wealth and rank. Without virtue to aid him, he could only consume and diminish. It was like borrowing spring’s warmth to relieve cold—how could it suffice? Or reversing winter’s wind to relieve heat—how could it help? To act contrary to what is fitting and reasonable is to seek without benefit.

The spirit delights in harmony and detests deceit. Human nature is fundamentally good, with no inherent impossibility. As for the spirit, one who attains it within and trusts it firmly can then approve of oneself. Yet Yijie’s esteem for competition was such that he failed to approve of his own spirit. Moreover, the King of Chu was stern and harsh; only flatterers or those of upright virtue could sway him. The paths of conduct, whether good or evil, do not extend beyond these two. Why not abandon evil and pursue good, following Yuexiu’s example? Then, perhaps, one might endure.

Thus, from the sage downward, Shu Yuexiu’s virtue suffices to transform others, all proceeding from non-action. As for offering harmony to drink without words, standing side by side while others transform—only the sage can achieve this. The sage comprehends the subtle and the manifest, encompassing all as one, yet remains unaware of how this is so—it is simply his nature. Returning to the root and moving in accord with heaven, he takes heaven as his teacher. Others then follow and name him as such.

To be anxious in knowledge and to act without respite—how can this endure? If it must cease, what then? One who is born beautiful is given a mirror by others; if not told, he does not know his beauty surpasses others. Whether he knows or does not know, hears or does not hear, his delight remains unceasing, and others’ admiration for him knows no end—this is his nature. The sage’s love for others is such that others bestow a name upon him; if not told, they do not know of his love. Whether he knows or does not know, hears or does not hear, his love for others remains unceasing, and others’ contentment in him knows no end—this, too, is his nature.

*Guo’s Commentary* states: Profoundly penetrating and without limit, all is illuminated, yet one remains unaware of how this is so—what is it if not nature? That which sways sways of itself; that which acts acts of itself. None fail to return to their mandate and take their natural endowment as their teacher—this is not a pursuit of fame to exalt one’s conduct. Following nature in movement, one’s traces are naturally lofty, so others cannot diminish one’s name. To act through knowledge is to be followed by ceaseless anxiety and exhaustion. The mirror is impartial, so others admire it. Yet does the mirror know it is a mirror? It is simply born to reflect; others call it a mirror. If people did not inform one another, none would know their beauty surpasses others. It is like the sage: others bestow a name upon him. His delight arises from being without attachment, regardless of whether one knows or does not know, hears or does not hear. He reflects what comes before him, hence his delight is unceasing. If reflection depended on hearing and knowing, it would sometimes cease. What one’s nature dislikes, how can it endure long? The sage is without love, like a mirror’s function, aiding others—thus others bestow a name upon him. If people did not inform one another, none would know of his love for others. Vast and unconstrained, treating the hundred clans as straw dogs, yet his Way accords with loving others—hence his love is unceasing. If love arose from hearing and knowing, it would sometimes wane; only what nature loves can endure.

*Lü’s Commentary* states: The human heart is entangled in affairs, unaware of what is called “the one body.” Only the sage can comprehend it. Thus, inwardly he does not see himself, outwardly he does not see things—things and self are one. What he embodies is inherently all-encompassing, yet he remains unaware of how this is so—it is confined to his nature and not externally obtained. Returning to the mandate is to return to the root. Swaying and acting are the flourishing of the ten thousand things. Though still and returning to the mandate, this does not prevent swaying and acting. Thus, though he speaks all day, he has not spoken; though he acts all day, he has not acted. All is simply to take heaven as his teacher. Heaven knows what one does not know—how could I claim to know myself as a sage? Others merely follow and name me as such.

To be without knowledge is to be without care. The multitude fret over knowledge, yet their conduct races like a gallop—how soon it comes to a halt! How then may one attain this state?

Those born with beauty are shown a mirror and told of it, and only then do they know their beauty surpasses others. Whether they know or do not know, hear or do not hear, their joy remains unceasing. Others’ admiration for them also never ends, for it arises from their nature.

The sage’s love for others is such that only when others name and tell him of it does he know he loves them. Whether he knows or does not know, hears or does not hear, his love for others never ceases. Others find rest in it, and this too never ends, for it arises from his nature—unaffected by whether he knows or does not know, hears or does not hear.

*Yidu’s Commentary:*
The sage, freed from all bonds, penetrates the great Dao, merging into a single whole without inner or outer. He does not know why it is so, yet it is so—this is his nature. Returning to the mandate is stillness; swaying is activity. Both take heaven as their teacher.

The sage does not seek a name; the world bestows it upon him. To fret over the obscurity of knowledge is to delight in employing it. Yet knowledge reaches its limit, and so one’s conduct soon halts. How then may one attain the Dao?

A mirror is without feeling toward others; people love it for distinguishing beauty from ugliness. Whether they know or do not know, hear or do not hear, their delight in it never ends. If the mirror possessed knowledge and perception like human preferences, its reflection would not endure, nor would people’s admiration for it. The mirror’s appeal lies in its lack of feeling; people’s fondness for it arises from their nature, and so it never ends.

A mirror reflects but does not speak; without being told, one would not know its reflection surpasses others. The sage’s love for others is likewise without feeling, and without being named, others would not know his love. If his love depended on hearing and knowing, it would cease in time. Yet people’s comfort in the sage’s kindness never ends—this too is nature.

*Bixu’s Commentary:*
To untangle entanglements is not to be ensnared by things. All-embracing unity leaves nothing outside the self. To know why it is so is to distance oneself from nature. Though stillness and motion differ, both follow nature as their teacher. The sage has no name; people, moved by his transformation, name him as such.

With a life of finite span, to fret over boundless knowledge is to say: “There is never enough time.” Yet when one wishes to stop but cannot proceed further, what is to be done? When one has a beautiful countenance, others show it in a mirror so they may know its beauty surpasses others. Whether they know or do not know, hear or do not hear, their delight in it never ends. And others’ admiration for beauty never ceases—this too is nature. The sage’s love for others never ends, and others’ comfort in it never ends—this too is nature.

*Yanzhai’s Oral Teachings:*
“Entanglement” refers to the ceaseless interplay of yin and yang, the unending cycle of cause and effect. The sage grasps the principle of yin-yang transformation, exhausts the subtleties of coarse and fine, and follows nature without knowing why. Whether in action or stillness, all returns to the mandate of heaven, with nature as its guide.

To fret over knowledge is to be burdened by private concerns, endlessly calculating. How much can truly be accomplished? Thus it is said: “One’s conduct soon halts.” If I intend to act but am constrained by fate, what is to be done? Hence it is said: “How soon it comes to a stop.” Here, “time” means fate. The root of all cessation lies in knowledge. If one knew what one does not know, there would be no care.

Beauty arises from ugliness; without being shown ugliness, one would not know beauty. The distinction between beauty and ugliness gives rise to care. Thus, whether one knows or does not know, hears or does not hear, delight in beauty never ends. If I forget beauty and ugliness and remain unmoved by things, others’ fondness for me will also never end. This is the principle of nature.

“Entanglement” refers to worldly burdens that bind one, preventing freedom—all stemming from the opposition of self and things. Only the sage can penetrate this with the Dao, exhausting the principles of things and returning to unity, yet not knowing why. This is because he meets them with his nature, not with the mind of self and other. What difference is there?

Thus, in moments of stillness, there is activity; in activity, one does not depart from the Dao of returning to the mandate. Motion and stillness are mutually rooted. This reveals that yin and yang have no principle of exhaustion—all take nature as their teacher, not arising from deliberate intent or self-directed purpose.

When one reaches the realm of great transformation, people name him as such. The sage does not make himself a sage; this is the meaning of “great virtue must attain its name.” The world frets over insufficient knowledge, and their conduct soon halts. To seek fame through knowledge and race without rest—what is to be done?

The analogy is this: people know beauty through a mirror, but without being told, they would not know. The mirror’s reflection is unceasing, and people’s delight in it is also unceasing.
