The sage’s love for others is the same—people name it as such. Thus, his love and others’ comfort in it never end, all arising from the spontaneity of nature, each resting in what is fitting.

*End of the Eighty-Second Scroll of the* Nan Hua Zhen Jing Yi Hai Zuan Wei
*Beginning of the Eighty-Third Scroll of the* Nan Hua Zhen Jing Yi Hai Zuan Wei

The Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin on "Ze Yang," the Second Chapter

Gazing upon one’s former state and former capital, one feels unbounded joy. Even if hills and woods have grown dense, entering them, one still recognizes nine parts in ten—how much more so when seeing what one has seen and hearing what one has heard! This is like a towering terrace suspended above a throng of questions.

Ran Xiangshi grasped the center of the ring and followed completion, moving with things without end or beginning, without measure or time. One who daily transforms with things is the one who does not transform—why cling to this? To model oneself on Heaven yet fail to do so, to be swept along with things—how can one make this one’s affair?

The sage never begins with Heaven, never begins with man, never begins with a beginning, never begins with things. He moves with the world without ceasing, his conduct complete yet not stagnant—how does he achieve such harmony?

Tang entrusted governance to his officials, the Gatekeeper Deng Dan and others, following their guidance without constraint, attaining the spontaneity of completion. He oversaw their names; in those names lay the excess of law, achieving a dual vision.

Confucius, in exhausting thought, served as their guide. The Lord of Rong Cheng said: "Remove days, and there are no years; remove inner and outer, and there is no space."

Guo’s commentary: To recover what was old still brings joy—how much more to recover one’s nature? To see what one has seen and hear what one has heard still brings joy—how much more to embody its essence and employ its nature! What the multitude practices, though perilous, they perform with ease—how much more so the sage, who knows no peril?

Ran Xiangshi, an ancient sage-king, dwelled in emptiness and followed things, allowing them to complete themselves. With things, he had no end or beginning, suddenly moving together with them, daily transforming with them—thus he was ever without self yet ever unchanging. Why not try to harmonize what one does?

Only by having no teacher can one truly model oneself on Heaven. Yet even modeling on Heaven does not escape being swept along—how can this suffice as an affair? Modeling on Heaven still falls short of what is needed—how much more so if one does not model at all? One must reach the point where Heaven and things are utterly absent before achieving dark union.

Thus, Tang entrusted matters to his hundred officials without interference, allowing them to gather naturally, not confining them, and to disperse naturally, not dissolving them. The ranks of the Master of Chariots and the like could follow the self-completion of things, and Tang attained this—thus his name was lent to the achievements of things, not resting in himself.

Names and laws are traces of what has passed, not the fitting measure. Thus, one who is effortlessly without intent entrusts governance to the many officials, and his name and traces appear in them. Confucius said: "What thought, what worry has the world? Thought is already exhausted." If even the slightest thought remains, how can one attain stillness and motionlessness, responding endlessly to assist the spontaneity of the myriad things?

Now, the reason years exist and days are preserved is because of life and death. If there were no life and death, the reckoning of years and days would vanish.

Lü’s commentary: Gazing upon one’s former state brings joy—this is human nature. Even if hills and woods have grown dense, one still feels joy—this is merely not forgetting one’s roots. How much more so when what one sees and hears has endured with Heaven and Earth, making one’s state and capital ancient indeed! To see and hear it all as if from a towering terrace suspended above a throng of questions—nothing escapes one’s view. How boundless is this joy!

"Throng of questions" refers to places without people. The "center of the ring" is ceaseless movement without beginning or end, following completion without action—thus there is no beginning or end, no measure of time. "Measure" refers to calculation. One who transforms with things is the one who does not transform—why not abandon this? If one’s conduct is always without measure and yet comes to a halt, to seek to model on Heaven yet fail is to be swept along with things—this is all one’s affair.

The sage never begins with Heaven, man, beginning, or things. He moves together without ceasing, complete yet not stagnant—this is what is meant by "returning to the mandate and stirring to action," the true way to model on Heaven, and thus he achieves harmony.

Tang attained the Master of Chariots, who governs regulation; the Gatekeeper, who rectifies entry; and Deng Dan, who perfects the cultivation of constancy. The one who governs regulation is the heart; the one who rectifies entry is the Dao. Constancy is the enduring nature of the Dao. All these model themselves on Heaven.

Only by following the teacher without being confined by things and attaining spontaneity of completion can one oversee their names. In those names lies the excess of law, achieving a dual vision. With spontaneity of completion, the names of the Master of Chariots and others follow the completion of one’s heart—these are not names of those who act with intent. Their essence is the Dao; their excess is the law. Seeing the origin of names, one knows the origin of laws—this is the dual vision. Though one has vision, not knowing that the world never begins with thought and worry is still not exhaustive—thus Confucius exhausted thought.

"Serving as their guide" does not mean Confucius guided Tang. With spontaneity of completion, what Ran Xiangshi attained shows that the names of the Master of Chariots and others are allegories. "Remove days, and there are no years"—then one does not know time. "Remove inner and outer, and there is no space"—then one does not know the cosmos. Only one who exhausts thought can attain this.

Yi Du’s commentary: Human nature pursues things, becoming lost and not returning—like one who has left the capital for a long time, gazing upon it brings unbounded joy. Entering the capital, recognizing nine parts in ten, one’s delight is still evident—how much more so when seeing what one has seen and hearing what one has heard! One’s true nature is like hills and woods. Entering them is like returning to the root. Recognizing nine parts in ten is not yet fully returning; seeing what one has seen and hearing what one has heard is the return complete. The joy of seeing one’s nature is like the joy of seeing one’s former capital.

Even a lofty, perilous terrace, when one is accustomed to climbing it, feels as if at ease—how much more so one who attains true nature! Ran Xiangshi, a sage-king of the Three Sovereigns and above, grasped the principle of true emptiness, ceaselessly moving and following the myriad things to complete the Dao. Without beginning or end, without measure of time, he transformed with things. One who transforms with things is the one who does not transform; one who does not transform is able to transform all transformations.

Those in the world who act—why do they not align their actions and return to spontaneity, so that true nature may be attained? Yet those who set their minds on following Heaven cannot attain it—how much less those who are swept along with things and do not return? Before there was Heaven or man, Heaven and man existed of themselves; before there was a beginning or things, the beginning of things arose from the self. Moving through the world, one bends and stretches without ceasing; in fulfilling all conduct, one maintains humility without excess, merging with principle as if it were inevitable—how could it be otherwise?

*Si Yu* was an official title of the gatekeeper. *Deng Da* was a system of regulations, meaning that one who ascends the *Deng Da* Way may serve as a teacher to others. The sage follows teachers but is not confined by them, simply allowing things to be natural—this is like becoming an infant with one who is an infant. Tang obtained these three men as his tutors, following them without constraint, complying with them to complete his Way. Tang then reversed the roles to oversee their titles, and those three men left no traces in the world!

Here, the laws of Ying and Fa were both manifested in Tang. Though Tang was a sage who fulfilled the human Way, the laws of his time were not yet complete. By the time of Confucius, the world’s transformations were fully realized, so he exhausted his thoughts to establish complete laws—thus becoming Tang’s tutor in turn.

*Bi Xu’s Commentary*: A man weakened by mourning gazes toward his homeland and hears its familiar sounds; though the woods and houses are overgrown and ruined, nine parts in ten lost, he still feels joy—how much more so one who sees without losing sight, hears without losing hearing, and abides in wondrous, serene being! The loftiness and clarity of the Great Dao conceal nothing, like erecting a towering terrace in a scenic place or hanging bells and drums in the open wilds, startling people’s ears and eyes to awaken them.

*Zhong Jian* (read as *jian*), meaning the open wilds. The center of the ring is empty, so it can revolve with things. Because it adapts to what arises, it cannot be fixed by any beginning, end, or measure of time. One who attains the Way of the ring’s center merges with things without boundary. Though transformations shift daily, the original source remains serene—what room is there for concern over transformation or its absence? Because it never grasps, it also never abandons; to follow Heaven without intent is truly to follow Heaven. If one is weary and buried in the dust, what then?

One who would follow Heaven must forget human affairs; one who is swept along must forget the wondrous source. Before there was Heaven, human affairs were not abandoned; before there were things, the wondrous source suffered no loss. Merging with things without betraying the real, treading all conduct without drowning in the dust—if one borrows falsity in entanglement, how can this be so? In ancient times, Tang’s worthy ministers *Si Zhu* and *Lin Yu* served as his tutors, so he followed them without constraint. Constraint is the extreme of reliance, which is why the gatekeeper *Deng Da* achieved the merit of following things to their spontaneous completion and presided over their names.

The names of laws are hard to forget in governance—how much more so when the proper name and the beneficial law are both clearly manifested? Moreover, when all officials oversee their duties, each exhausts their thoughts to assist, and in exhausting thoughts, there are no thoughts left—thus they may serve as tutors. Without days, there are no years; without beginning or end, there is no constraint. Without inner or outer, life and death follow what arises. This is the Way of penetrating entanglement and encompassing the whole as one.

*Yuan Qi Kou Yi*: One who returns to his homeland after long travel must feel a deep sense of relief. Entering it, the grass and trees intertwine, and though nine parts in ten are lost compared to the past, he still feels relief—how much more so when seeking the Dao and suddenly awakening, seeing what he has always seen, hearing what he has always heard! These are all things originally possessed—how could one not rejoice?

The terrace is the highest place. *Xuan* means to display music. *Zhong* means many. *Jian* is read in the falling tone, like the sound of *sheng* and *yue* playing together. Standing in the highest place, hearing the interwoven music, one can stir the ears and eyes of the world—how much more so when the sage, with the principle of emptiness and spontaneity, delights in the myriad things! How lofty is his self-abiding!

The center of the ring is a metaphor for supreme emptiness, without beginning or end, like the One. *Ji Shi* means past and present. *Ji* refers to the changes of time. "Daily transforming with things" means renewing with things each day, yet what I attain is the one that does not transform. Why do people not abandon old habits and return to the supreme Dao? Taking spontaneity as the law, without the name of "law of spontaneity," is nothing more than complying with things. If one has intent in acting, what can be done?

Man acts, but Heaven does not act. Not only are there no traces of action, but even the non-acting is absent—thus it is said, "There was never a beginning of Heaven, never a beginning of man." Things are traces. The beginning of no-things is the absence of traces. Not only is there no trace of things, but even the absence of traces is absent—thus it is said, "There was never a beginning, never a beginning of things."

Moving through the world, one is the same as others, with no affairs abandoned or neglected; all conduct is fully equipped, without attachment to any one thing. *Xu* is like *lao xu* in the *Qi Wu Lun*, meaning to be mired and drowned. Merging with the Dao, one does not seek to align—seeking alignment, one cannot attain it!

In ancient times, Tang took Yi Yin as his teacher but was not confined by him, attaining the principle of the completion of the myriad things and following it. He abided in non-action, allowing Yin to preside over names. Tang was non-active and nameless, while Yin was active and named. This name existed in the world as surplus law. *Liang Jian* ("two manifestations") means that body and name were divided, failing to attain their blended oneness.

Yi Yin’s role was not extraordinary in itself. Confucius admired him and exhausted his thoughts to assist the world, also desiring to do as Yi Yin had done—this remark is a subtle criticism. *Rong Cheng Shi*, an ancient sage, combined three hundred and sixty days to make a year, but when counting days one by one, they are called days, not years—this is like Laozi’s saying about counting carts without a cart.

External names arise from the internal; without the internal, there is no external.

To illustrate the principle of naturalness: Man’s true nature is originally whole, but over time, its inner integrity wanes as external perceptions and knowledge lead it astray. Gradually, the inner self drifts as far as one who leaves the old capital for a distant land, adrift in a foreign land. Yet when an enlightened teacher awakens him, how could he not gaze toward his homeland with longing? Even if nine-tenths of the timber in a ruined mound has rotted away, he would still rejoice in its remnants—how much more when he sees what he once saw and hears what he once heard? These arise from the original state of his nature, like standing atop a high tower amidst a crowd, seeing all without obstruction.

In ancient times, Ran Xiangshi attained the Dao of emptiness and penetration. In his governance, he followed things to their completion, his nature harmonizing with them. Without beginning or end, he forgot the greatness of transformation. Without the passage of moments, he forgot the smallness of transformation. Great and small, long and short—all merged into one. What attachment could there be to the present moment? One who daily transforms with things finds the former flame is not the latter. One who does not transform remains the same self today as before—when has it ever departed?

To seek the Way of naturalness while deliberately pursuing things is to depart from naturalness. How could such affairs ever succeed? The sage forgets Heaven and forgets man, and thus can act as Heaven and act as man. He forgets beginnings and forgets things, and thus can initiate and can respond to things. Moving in step with the world without decline, he follows things as they are, without loss. His actions are complete yet never excessive, encompassing all things without overreaching. His movements accord with the Dao—how could this be otherwise?

Tang, having three ministers as his tutors, learned from their teaching of non-action, unconfined by the techniques of governance. The governance of worthy ministers serves to restrain the world and nurture the people, and their way of exalting the ruler and securing peace lies solely in the Dao—skills and abilities play no part. This again depends on the ruler’s acceptance or rejection, where the pivot of order and chaos, fortune and misfortune, becomes apparent.

Tang attained the Dao of following things and allowing them to reach completion, entrusting his ministers with the names of governance. Though the achievement was accomplished by the three, the name was attributed to Tang. Such names are merely surplus law, not Tang’s true essence. The "two manifestations" refer to ruler and minister mutually supporting one another to perfect the Way of governance. Their traces became manifest in the world, so later Confucius exhausted his thoughts to perfect the methods of ordering the world. Though he did not live in Tang’s time, he too served as a tutor. As astronomers accumulate days to form a year, and emperors accumulate knowledge to become sages, Tang could not have perfected his Way of governance without the three ministers as tutors. Without Tang and the three ministers laying the foundation, Confucius could not have achieved it alone—just as inner and outer cannot exist without each other.

When the Dao is perfected and virtue complete, its beneficence flows boundlessly. In the vast harmony of all things, the people forget the ruler’s power, and sagely wisdom transforms with them—this is the meaning of "counting days without a year." Where then is the division between inner and outer?

The scriptural passage’s difficulty in interpretation likely lies in the character *he* (合), which should be read in connection with the preceding text.

Wei Ying made a covenant with Lord Mou of Tian, but Lord Mou of Tian betrayed it. Wei Ying, enraged, was about to send an assassin, when Xishou, hearing of it, found it shameful and said: "You are a lord of ten thousand chariots, yet you would resort to the vengeance of a commoner! I, Yan, request two hundred thousand armored troops to attack him for you, capturing his people, seizing his cattle and horses, and causing his lord’s back to break out in boils from inner heat. Then we will take his state. When Ji flees, we will strike his back and break his spine."

Ji Zi, hearing of this, found it shameful and said: "To build a city wall of ten *ren* in height—once the wall of ten *ren* is completed, it is then torn down—this is the toil that convict laborers lament. Now, for seven years, no war has arisen; this is the foundation of the Three Dynasties. Yan is a disturber of order; he must not be heeded."

Hua Zi, hearing of it, deemed it disgraceful and said: "Those who speak well of attacking Qi are disturbers of order. Those who speak well of not attacking Qi are also disturbers of order. Those who say that both attacking and not attacking are the words of disturbers of order are themselves disturbers of order."

The lord said: "Then what should be done?"
He replied: "My lord, seek only the Way."

Huizi, hearing of this, went to see Dai Jinren. Dai Jinren said: "There is a creature called the snail—do you know of it?"
The lord said: "Yes."
Dai Jinren continued: "On the left horn of the snail is a state called Chushi, and on the right horn is a state called Manshi. At times, they contend over territory and wage war, leaving tens of thousands of corpses strewn upon the field. The pursuit of the routed army lasts fifteen days before they return."
The lord said: "Alas! Are these empty words?"
Dai Jinren replied: "I beg to make them real for you."

The lord asked: "Do you suppose the four directions and the realms above and below have limits?"
He replied: "They are without limit."
Dai Jinren said: "To know that the mind roams in the boundless, yet to return and dwell in the lands of common access—does it not seem as if they exist or do not exist?"
The lord said: "So it is."
Dai Jinren continued: "Within the lands of common access lies Wei; within Wei lies Liang; within Liang lies the king. Does the king differ from the Manshi?"
The lord said: "There is no difference."

The guest departed, and the lord sat in silent abstraction, as if something had been lost.

Huizi entered and was received. The lord said: "This guest is a great man—even a sage cannot compare to him."
Huizi replied: "When one blows through a pipe, there is a resonant sound; when one blows across the hilt of a sword, there is but a faint whisper. Yao and Shun are those whom men praise, yet to speak of Yao and Shun before Dai Jinren is like that faint whisper."

*(Guo's annotation: The snail is most minute, yet bears two horns. If one truly knows that what is contested is as trifling as this, then there would be no contention in the world. The lands of common access refer to what lies within the four seas. Though one takes the four seas as vast, when measured against the boundless, they seem as if they exist or do not exist. The king and the Manshi are both finite things; being finite, whether great or small, they cannot be reckoned against the boundless. Even heaven and earth, though they dwell within the boundless, are as nothing—how much more so Wei within the lands of common access, Liang within Wei, and the king within Liang? What is there to contend over? The lord sat in silent abstraction, grieving that what was contested was so trifling. The sound of blowing through a pipe is audible; the sound of blowing across a sword’s hilt is scarcely heard.)*

*(Lü's annotation: No fault is greater than desire. Those who speak well of attacking Qi see profit as desirable and are thus disturbers of order. Those who speak well of not attacking see goodness as desirable and are likewise disturbers of order. Those who say that both attacking and not attacking are the words of disturbers of order are themselves not free from partial views and are thus disturbers of order. Only by seeking the Way does one avoid clinging to one-sided views, and thus the source of disorder is stilled. If one’s mind roams in the boundless, then the lands of common access in the four directions and the realms above and below—whether Wei or Liang—are all but projections of one’s own mind. Not only is there no difference between the king and the Chushi and Manshi, but even the lands of common access, Wei, Liang, Chushi, and Manshi are without distinction. Knowing this, then nothing is greater than the tip of an autumn hair, and Mount Tai is small. The king realized that the source of contention arises from what does not truly exist, and so he sat in silent abstraction, as if something had been lost. The divine man, the sage, and the great man are not inherently superior or inferior—it is only the perspective from which they are spoken that differs. Blowing through a pipe produces a sound because it has a receptacle; blowing across a sword’s hilt produces no sound because it has no receptacle.)*

*(Yi Du’s annotation: Dai Jinren was a man of Liang who embraced the Way. The lands of common access refer to where boats and carriages travel. The analogy of the snail’s horns and the Chushi and Manshi is a critique of the warlike rulers of the time. The lord of Wei took it as empty words, but when applied to human affairs, its truth became evident. Does the mind’s intent in the four directions and the realms above and below have limits? To know that the mind roams in the boundless yet returns to dwell in the lands of common access—this is to speak of dwelling in a finite place. Within the lands of common access lies Wei; within Wei lies Liang; within Liang lies the king. The closer one draws, the smaller it becomes, until the king’s own person is no different from the Chushi and Manshi on the snail’s horns. From this perspective, all things in the world with form are never without encumbrance—how much more so when it comes to contending over states and territory? The sound of blowing through a pipe is loud; the sound of blowing across a sword’s hilt is faint. To speak of Yao and Shun before Dai Jinren is scarcely heard.)*

*(Bi Xu’s annotation: When the king’s armies march, they do so with clear purpose and righteous conduct. If they were to make plunder their aim, provoking resentment and rebellion that uproots a state, such a thing has never been heard of. Now, to raise arms over a petty grievance and invade a neighboring state is surely the act of a disturber of order. Jizi’s counsel against attacking would indulge the arrogance of neighboring states and is likewise a disturbance. Huazi’s claim that both views are those of disturbers of order was meant to elevate men of the Way and urge remonstrance. What is called ‘seeking the Way’ is simply to cultivate virtue and refrain from contention. Huizi sought an audience with Jinren and presented this analogy to dispel the lord’s misgivings. The snail’s horns illustrate how minute the matter is—contention between two states does not extend beyond a single shell. Fifteen days represent the cycle of qi, for the qi of joy and anger returns and repeats. Heaven and earth are lodged in the great void like a pebble in Mount Tai; the lands of common access are lodged in the cosmos like a grain of millet in a granary. Wei dwells within the lands of common access like the tip of a hair on a horse’s body—how much more so Liang within Wei, and the king within Liang? Are they not like the Chushi and Manshi on the snail’s horns? Now, the contention between Qi and Wei—does it differ from the war between the Chushi and Manshi? The great man transcends the six directions and follows nature; the sage dwells within the world and upholds its laws. Blowing through a pipe produces a resonant sound; blowing across a sword’s hilt passes by with a whisper. This is like the governance of Yao and Shun, which men praise—yet when measured by the Way, it is scarcely heard. How much less so the invasion of states and the plunder of their people?)*

*(Yongzhai’s annotation: For seven years, no war arose—this was the great achievement of the lord of Wei. Xishou’s counsel to use force was like tearing down a city already built, bringing suffering to the laborers. Huazi’s words, with their focus on ‘attacking,’ still harbored partiality. Thus, all three were disturbers of order. Only by knowing the Way does one cease to speak of war. The analogy of the snail’s horns is initially empty, but the explanation below makes it real. The boundless refers to the great void. The lands of common access refer to the central states. Viewed from the great void, the central states are most minute; viewed from the central states, Wei is small; viewed from Wei, Liang is smaller still; and within Liang, the king’s person is ever more minute. Seen from the great void, the king’s person is no different from the Chushi and Manshi on the snail’s horns. Sitting in silent abstraction, as if something had been lost, he realized that what was contested was not worth contending over. Blowing through a pipe produces sound because it has an opening; blowing across a sword’s hilt produces no sound—before a man of the Way, to speak of benevolence and righteousness is to have no place for words.)*

The Xishou was a military officer’s title; at the time, Gongsun Yan held this post and sought to deploy troops to attack Qi, plundering the people and exhausting the state, relying on strength and belittling the enemy—truly a man of disorder. Jizi claimed that long abstention from war was the foundation of the king’s rule, his aim being to pacify the people and stabilize the state—how could he be called a man of disorder? Yet Huazi wished to advance his later argument, so he first unsettled the mind of the King of Wei, awaiting his urgent inquiry before revealing the marvel. The phrase “seek the unity of its Way” refers to the earlier words of the Xishou as not being the Way. Jizi wished to halt the war but lacked the Way; to say both were wrong was to have no means of resolving the matter, and thus both were inevitably men of disorder. Huizi requested an audience with Dai Jinren, for this was seeking the Way rightly. The two states on the snail’s horns illustrate how trivial was the dispute between Qi and Wei—this is detailed in the various commentaries and need not be repeated here. Blowing through a pipe produces sound, an analogy for the common people’s praise of Yao and Shun. To speak of Yao and Shun before a man of the Way is like blowing across a sword’s hilt—no sound emerges. To discuss the invasion of a state before Huazi is likewise so.

*The Southern Florescence True Classic: Sea of Meanings, Gathered Subtleties, Scroll Eighty-Three Concludes*
*The Southern Florescence True Classic: Sea of Meanings, Gathered Subtleties, Scroll Eighty-Four*

The Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin on "Ze Yang, Third Chapter"

When Confucius traveled to Chu, he lodged at the wine-seller’s house on Ant Mound. There, a neighbor—a husband and wife with their servants—ascended to the roof’s ridge. Zilu asked, “What are these angular figures doing?” Confucius replied, “They are the servants of a sage, burying themselves among the people, concealing themselves at the margins. Their reputation fades, yet their aspiration knows no bounds. Though their mouths speak, their hearts never truly speak. They go along with the world yet disdain to accompany it in their hearts. These are men submerged on dry land—is this not Yiliao of Shinan?”

Zilu requested to summon them. Confucius said, “Enough! He knows I am aware of him, knows I am bound for Chu, and takes me for one who will surely persuade the King of Chu to summon him. He would then regard me as a flatterer. If that were so, he would feel shame even to hear a flatterer’s words—how much more to meet him in person? What use would it be to seek him out?”

Zilu went to look, but their house was empty.

Guo’s commentary: “Burying themselves among the people” means living as one with them. “Concealing themselves at the margins” means neither advancing into glory nor retreating into withered obscurity. “Their reputation fades” means they diminish their fame. “Their aspiration knows no bounds” means they plan for long life. What they say are worldly words, yet their hearts differ from the world. They are recluses among men, like those submerged where no water flows. “Aware” means “clear.” “What use would it be to seek him out?” means it is better to leave him and follow his aspiration. “Their house was empty” means he had indeed fled.

Lü’s commentary: The couple ascended to the roof’s ridge upon Confucius’s arrival, showing they would not engage with him and were preparing to withdraw to higher ground. “Servants of a sage” means those who possess sagely virtue yet serve. “Burying themselves among the people” means they perform no visible deeds. “Concealing themselves at the margins” means they do not dwell in the central and upright virtue. “Their reputation fades yet their aspiration knows no bounds” means they withdraw and hide in secrecy, roaming beyond the world’s bounds. “Though their mouths speak, their hearts never truly speak” means they wish to remain silent yet cannot. “They go along with the world yet disdain to accompany it” means they are about to flee the world. To wander among men with sagely virtue yet remain unknown is like being submerged on dry land. From Confucius’s perspective of advancement, busying himself with the world’s affairs seems like flattery. Yet if all were like Yiliao, who among the common people would be saved? The Way of the sage would fall to the ground and be lost.

Formerly, Weisheng Mu once called Confucius a flatterer, to which Confucius replied that he dared not be. Now, regarding Yiliao, he calls himself a flatterer to show that what he values lies here, while his busyness is not by choice.

Yi Du’s commentary: Ant Mound is a place name. The wine-seller’s family ascended to the roof’s ridge to watch. “Angular” describes their multitude. “Burying themselves among the people” means living as one with them. “Concealing themselves at the margins” means they do not appear at the border. “Their reputation fades” means they diminish their fame. “Their aspiration knows no bounds” means their aspiration is set upon the Way. They have no intention to speak but merely respond to things; their hearts differ from the world, though outwardly they are the same as others. The sage’s hiddenness in heaven is like being submerged on dry land, akin to those who conceal themselves in the marketplace. Zhuangzi uses Confucius and Yiliao in a parable to critique the accounts of sages. “Their house was empty” means he was nowhere to be found. Here, one sees how the Master rests as one with the people, while Yiliao departs from men to enter the realm of heaven.

Bi Xu’s commentary: “Ascended to the roof’s ridge” means they climbed the roof beams to observe Confucius. Performing the tasks of a servant, they served the sage—like Gengsang Chu attending Lao Dan, burying themselves among the people, or Liezi living in the Zheng gardens, unknown to all. “Concealing themselves at the margins” is like Chang Ju and Jie Ni plowing in obscurity at the field’s edge.

Thus, when sounds fade, the will flows free; when words emerge, the heart forgets—scorning to dwell with the world, submerged on dry land as if sunk beneath the waves. Confucius gauged that Yiliao would not appear before him, just as Yan Xi felt shame at being seen by Xu You. "Why do you still remain here?"—meaning, how could you linger in such a place?

*Yanzhai Oral Exegesis*:
"Ridge" refers to the roof beam. "Servant" means disciple. "Bury" means to conceal. "Margin" means neighbor. "Conceal" means to dwell beside others without being known. "Sounds fade" means to flee from fame. "Submerged on dry land" is a metaphor for hiding in the marketplace. "Notices" means to recognize. "Flattery" means excessive speech. "Why do you still remain?" means to depart without lingering.

In ancient times, customs were simple and honest; people lived from birth to death without visiting one another, each content in their allotted place, inwardly sufficient and seeking nothing from without. Now, the Master hurries about on his missions, wishing to transform the world with benevolence and righteousness, bending and twisting rites and music—losing the serenity and joy of his nature. Those gentlemen of hidden virtue and concealed brilliance rightly flee to the heights, fearing only that their departure is not swift enough. Yet the sage loves others without cease, regardless of his own success or failure, ever holding the salvation of all under heaven in his heart. He cannot be spoken of in the same breath as those who, submerged on dry land, cultivate only their own goodness.

The Master knew that though they served the sage as attendants, they had not yet ascended to the inner sanctum—these were men who fled fame to follow their will, like the market-south hermit Xiong Yiliao. The sage’s knowledge of others was so precise that when Zilu wished to summon them, the Master knew they would not come. "Their house was empty"—just as the *Analects* says: he sent Zilu back to see them, but by the time he arrived, they had already gone. Here, one sees all the more clearly the Master’s foresight, while those who submerge themselves on dry land to cultivate only their own goodness reveal the narrowness of their way of life. Each follows their own inclinations and preferences, nothing more.

The border warden of Changwu asked Zilao: "In governing, do not be reckless; in ordering the people, do not be careless. Once, when I planted grain, I plowed recklessly, and the harvest repaid me in kind; I weeded carelessly, and the harvest repaid me in kind. The next year, I changed my methods, plowing deeply and tending the soil thoroughly—my grain flourished and multiplied, and I had my fill for the whole year."

When Zhuangzi heard this, he said: "Nowadays, those who cultivate their bodies and order their minds often resemble what the border warden described. They flee from heaven, depart from their nature, extinguish their emotions, and lose their spirit, all to follow the crowd. Thus, those who treat their nature recklessly—desires and aversions sprout like weeds, choking the shoots of our form, then grasping at our nature. They burst forth in indiscriminate eruptions, giving rise to abscesses, scabies, paralysis, and internal heat that scorches the marrow."

Guo’s commentary:
"Reckless and careless" means acting lightly and neglecting details, not fulfilling one’s proper role. To fulfill one’s role completely is the perfection of non-action. Fleeing, departing, extinguishing, and losing—all stem from following the crowd. If each were taken to its extreme, where would there be any rest? Weeds harm millet and sorghum; desires and aversions injure the true nature. When the form is overgrown, the spirit and qi are harmed, and desires and aversions lead the nature astray, never reaching what is fitting. This is the repayment for recklessness.

Lü’s commentary:
To practice the Dao is to diminish daily until one reaches non-action—this is how one cultivates the body and orders the mind. Yet to flee from heaven, depart from one’s nature, extinguish the spirit, and lose the emotions, following the crowd without knowing when to stop—this is the height of recklessness! When things are stable, they are easy to maintain; when signs have not yet appeared, they are easy to plan for. Within, desires and aversions sprout like reeds; without, they grow like rushes. They prop up our form and grasp at our nature—heavenly principle is extinguished! At such a time, can one hope to order them? From "bursting forth in indiscriminate eruptions" onward, all describe how desires and aversions become calamities, seizing what is true.

Yidu’s commentary:
In governing the people, to act recklessly and carelessly is to be negligent and achieve nothing. The border warden drew the same lesson from his own farming. The next year, he changed his methods, plowing deeply and tending the soil thoroughly—his grain flourished, and he had his fill for the whole year. The more effort he put in, the greater the reward. Cultivating the body and ordering the mind is no different. To flee from heaven is to escape one’s natural state; thus, one departs from their nature, extinguishes their emotions, and loses their spirit to follow the crowd—this is to move toward death. Weeds, when they first sprout, support the growth of the shoots. But when they grow rampant, they harm the seedlings. When the passions of desire and aversion first stir, the form also grows and flourishes. But when they blaze unchecked, they harm the nature. Therefore, one must restrain them at the first sprouting; otherwise, they will grasp at our nature. When the nature is lost and desires blaze, essence and qi leak and erupt without restraint, giving rise to abscesses, scabies, paralysis, and the disease of internal heat scorching the marrow—only ending when the spirit departs and the form decays. This is the repayment for recklessly cultivating the nature. "Scorching the marrow" refers to the disease of turbid qi.

*Yanzhai Oral Exegesis*:
The border warden used farming to illustrate governance; Zhuangzi then used it to illustrate learning—Su Shi’s *Discourse on Farming* follows this model. "Changed methods" means altering one’s farming techniques. The nature of likes and dislikes is like weeds—this is the meaning of "thatching the heart." When the nature is obstructed, desires grow daily, like weeds sprouting and filling the body, until the whole person is consumed by human desires. When human desires prop up the form, one loses the principle of naturalness, uprooting the true nature and extinguishing heavenly principle. When the nature is lost, the qi also falls ill. Some suffer from bursting forth, others from leaking eruptions—without restraint, any contact breeds disease. This passage warns that indulging desires will surely destroy the body.

"Changed methods" was formerly read with a falling tone, referring to farming techniques. Sima read it as a level tone, meaning to change one’s farming methods so they no longer matched others’. Another interpretation: to change the farming methods of the state of Qi.

Bi Xu cited the *Shuowen*: "When grain and wheat put forth ears, if the tops are level, it is called *qi*."

Examining the meaning of the classic in detail, the falling tone is correct, aligning with "allotment" to denote limits and measures. Those who act recklessly do not fully observe the proper measures of plowing and weeding, so their harvests are likewise reckless. Now, changing the grain to flourish yet neglecting nourishment—this serves as a fitting metaphor for cultivating the body and ordering the mind. The human mind and heavenly nature do not transgress the bounds of naturalness; only by fleeing from naturalness does one depart from true nature, leading to the extinction of emotions and the dissipation of spirit without awareness, all drowned in the ways of the multitude.

The harm of desires and aversions to nature is no different from the harm of reeds to seedlings. "Reeds" here refer to the initial growth of *ren* reeds, which at first support the seedlings in equal growth but ultimately overgrow and harm them. Desires and aversions uproot nature and lose the true, causing the body to burst or leak, turning every encounter into illness, inevitably leading to gradual exhaustion. This is the retribution for reckless cultivation of the body. How can one not take heed?

Xiang Ju studied under Lao Cong, saying, "I wish to travel the world." Lao Cong replied, "Enough! The world is as it is." He asked again. Lao Cong said, "Where will you begin?" He replied, "I will begin in Qi." Arriving in Qi, he saw a condemned man and pushed through the crowd to reach him, removing his court robe to cover the man. Wailing to heaven, he cried, "You! You! The world has great calamities, and you alone have encountered them first. They say: Do not steal! Do not kill! Yet honor and disgrace arise, and only then do people see what ails them; wealth and goods accumulate, and only then do they see what they contend over. Now, by establishing what ails people and amassing what they contend over, exhausting their bodies without respite, how can one avoid reaching this point?

The rulers of old held that gains belonged to the people and losses to themselves; that uprightness belonged to the people and crookedness to themselves. Thus, if even one person lost their proper form, they would withdraw and take responsibility. Now, it is not so: they conceal their actions to fool the ignorant, magnify difficulties to blame the fearful, impose heavy burdens to punish the incapable, and distance their reach to evade punishment. When the people know their strength is exhausted, they resort to deceit to continue, and with deceit emerging daily, how can scholars and commoners not also resort to deceit?

When strength is insufficient, they feign; when knowledge is lacking, they deceive; when wealth is wanting, they steal. To whom can the blame for theft and robbery be assigned? Guo’s commentary: "Great calamities" refer to the matters below. Once great calamities exist, even if one warns against them, how can they be avoided? Each seeks their own gain, so honor and disgrace vanish; with gains and losses in disarray, honor and disgrace arise, and boasting and strife follow. Racing between boasting and strife—what is this if not illness? If one takes contentment as wealth, what would there be to contend over?

When superiors have preferences, inferiors cannot rest in their proper places. If the ruler makes no mistakes, the people naturally attain their due; if the ruler does not act crookedly, the people naturally become upright. Why do the forms and natures of things become lost? It is all because the ruler disturbs them, leading to such decay. Returning to nature is concealment; employing nature is manifestation. When things are made manifest, all recognize them; when things are made easy, all dare to act. When burdens are lightened, all can bear them; when strength is matched to capacity, all can reach. When the people know their strength is exhausted, they resort to deceit to avoid punishment. As rulers daily produce deceit, where can scholars find truth?

Lü’s commentary: Ju was once a man of rank. Removing his court robe to cover the condemned man expressed his compassion. This act made clear that he had once committed such a crime, so he did not shy from reproach. When those above cannot forget honor and disgrace, the people see what ails them; when they cannot轻 wealth and goods, the people see what they contend over. Now, by establishing what ails people and making them ill, amassing what they contend over and making them contend, how can one expect them not to steal, kill, or incur death?

Tang and Wu held that when the myriad regions bore guilt, it lay with the One Man; that gains belonged to the people and losses to themselves. Yi Yin said that if even one man was not reaped, it was his own fault; if even one person lost their proper form, he would withdraw and take responsibility. Now, the ignorant are not enlightened, the fearful are not blamed, the incapable are not punished, and the distant are not reached—how different this is from the former kings who pardoned the ignorant, measured human strength, and pitied the incapable!

When the people know their strength is exhausted, they have no choice but to resort to deceit. When superiors produce much deceit, how can inferiors avoid deceit? Yan Du’s commentary: The great Dao scatters daily, and fraud and deceit arise daily; the people suffer disasters from this beginning. What crime have you committed to encounter this first? Is it not because you did not steal?

Have you not committed murder? What follows concerns the great disasters—honor and disgrace, wealth and property, the impoverishment and ruin of the people, and the like.

In high antiquity, men did not contend over honor and disgrace, so they knew not what ailed them; they did not hoard wealth and property, so they knew not what to fight over. Today’s rulers stand atop honor and disgrace, dwell amid wealth and property—thus summoning the very ailments of the people and gathering the roots of their strife. They further burden them with heavy exactions to the point of exhaustion, and ceaseless corvée leaves them no respite. Even if they wished not to die, it would be impossible. To take success as belonging to the people and failure as one’s own responsibility—this was the way of the ancient rulers who cherished the people and turned inward to examine themselves. But now it is not so. The following four lines point to the governance of the present rulers.

They conceal things for their own ends and deem the unknowing as foolish—this pattern may be discerned in what follows. All these measures run counter to human nature and are devised in defiance of it. When the people know their inner strength is exhausted and can no longer endure, they resort to deceit. Those above cannot return to the root but fuss over trifles—how can they hope to remedy or halt this?

**Bi Xu’s Commentary:**
Viewing a household through the lens of the household, viewing a state through the lens of the state—then the world remains the same. When Duke Qi saw a condemned man executed and covered him with his court robes to weep over him, this was the ancient ritual. He grieved that the failure of virtuous governance had brought things to this pass. For when honor and disgrace are established and wealth and property amassed, the calamity of executions is already set, and the strife of banditry and plunder overflows. Can one hope to escape great disaster?

Laozi said: “To bear the state’s misfortune is to be king of the world.” But now they have turned against the ancient Way! They conceal the canonical laws to keep the common people ignorant, devise inconvenient measures and punish those who resist, impose onerous burdens and penalize the mediocre, enforce relentless schedules and execute the slow and weak. When the people’s strength and wisdom are exhausted, they think only of deceiving their lord and misleading their superiors. Since those above have lost their authenticity, the people follow their transformation.

If one wishes the stream to run clear, one must purify the source!

**Yanzhai’s Oral Teachings:**
“Have you not...?”—is it not because you have committed theft or murder? Honor and disgrace are matters of reputation; wealth and property are matters of profit—these are the ailments that bring harm and exhaustion. When those above crave reputation, these harms arise. When a state is fond of amassing wealth, strife follows.

The lines on “losing the upright and gaining the crooked” and “if the hundred clans have faults, it lies with me alone” mean that if even one thing loses its proper form, one withdraws and takes responsibility—as if, when a single commoner is not bathed in grace, one had cast him into a ditch oneself. They hide their possessions and say nothing, yet deem the unknowing as foolish. They impose tasks too difficult to bear and punish those who dare not undertake them. They assign heavy burdens without measuring human strength, set distant journeys without calculating human capacity. When they demand what exceeds human strength, the people must respond with deceit; when they demand what exceeds human understanding, the people must respond with fraud. When exactions are insatiable, the people must resort to theft to meet them.

Thus, those above compel them to deceit, fraud, and theft—yet whom can one blame? When Xiang Ju sought to travel the world, the Master sang of climbing the mast and drifting to sea. When Duke Qi saw a condemned man executed on the road, the governance of the states of his time could be known. Covering the body with court robes and weeping—this was the utmost in compassion and sorrow.

In the world, cold, hunger, sickness, hardship, imprisonment, bereavement, and grief are all called disasters, yet none is more grievous to life and nature than execution. Why have you alone been the first to suffer this? Have you not committed theft? Have you not committed murder?

How has it come to such an extremity! Could it not be that the pursuit of honor and disgrace, wealth and property, has invited illness and provoked strife, leading to this? To establish what people resent and gather what they contend over—this has been the case for so long; how can disaster be avoided?

These words carry an implied critique of contemporary governance. In ancient times, those who ruled the world held compassion in their hearts, fearing even a single person might lose their proper place. Thus, their governance was perfected, and their transformative influence harmonious. Today, however, it is not so—here, the text directly points to the failures of present rule.

Those who speak incur no blame; those who hear should take it as a warning. The conclusion, asking whom one can blame, also conveys a sense of lamentation and insufficiency. May those in positions of authority turn inward and examine themselves! If they truly can moderate their own desires, eliminate suffering, and end strife, the people will be transformed by their virtue, and punishments will fall into disuse—would this not be perfect in every way?

[Note: *"One form should correspond to one thing"*—a scribal error, as noted in Yongzhai’s commentary.]

*Zhuangzi: The Ocean of Meanings, Annotated and Elucidated*, Scroll 84
*Zhuangzi: The Ocean of Meanings, Annotated and Elucidated*, Scroll 85

The Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin on *"Then Yang"* (Chapter Four)

Master Ju of Swift Virtue was sixty years of age and had undergone sixty transformations. Never did he begin with what was deemed "right" only to end by condemning it as "wrong"—yet how could he know that what he now called "right" was not the "wrong" of his fifty-ninth year?

All things possess life, yet none perceive their root; all emerge, yet none perceive their gate. People all honor the knowledge their knowing can grasp, but none know to rely on the knowing that lies beyond their knowledge—can this not be called the greatest of doubts?

Alas! Alas! There is no escape from this.

Is this what is meant by "so it is," or is it so?

Guo’s commentary:
*"Transformation"* means following the world without being bound to self or other. Flowing with things in harmony, it accords with the changes of their nature. These changes have no fixed limit; without root or gate, they arise suddenly and naturally—thus none can perceive them. Only those who transcend birth and emergence can glimpse their gate and fathom their root. What I do not know, other things may know. To employ the knowledge of things is to be without ignorance; to rely solely on my own knowledge is to know little indeed. If one does not depend on things for knowledge but instead exalts one’s own, then things will not conform—what is this if not the greatest doubt? Unable to use that which lies beyond oneself, one finds no place to lodge the self. Those who claim to be "right" are not so in the eyes of the world.

Lü’s commentary:
Master Ju, at sixty, had undergone sixty transformations, never failing to begin with what he deemed "right" only to end by condemning it as "wrong"—just like Confucius. Yet if knowing does not halt at what lies beyond its grasp, then what is called "right" remains unsettled. How, then, can one be certain that what is now deemed "right" was not the "wrong" of fifty-nine? Since the root of things’ birth and the gate of their emergence are unseen, what lies beyond knowledge is precisely the source from which the myriad things arise. Yet people all honor the knowledge they possess, while fearing the void of what they do not know, refusing to rely upon it. They turn back at the edge of the cliff—how great is their doubt! Alas! Alas! There is no escape, for such a one can never reach the ultimate, and the world cannot contain them. Even if what is now said seems "right," how can one be sure it is truly so? Let words be forgotten to grasp its truth.

**Du Zhu’s Annotation:**
From youth to old age, the new and old replace one another, yet one dwells within the transformations of creation without perceiving its passage. Boyi could follow the daily renewal of change, yet never did he not begin with what was "right" only to end with what was "wrong"—how could he know that what is now called "right" was not the "wrong" of fifty-nine years past? The root of things’ birth is the root of Heaven and Earth; the gate of their emergence is the Gate of the Mysterious Female. Both originate from the Valley Spirit, their source is one. What knowledge grasps is the work of the wise; what lies beyond knowledge is the work of the sage. To honor wisdom alone and not honor sagacity—can this not be called great doubt? Alas! Alas! Words are not as good as stilling the mind that grasps and contains. The myriad things within creation follow a principle from which there is no escape. What I deem "right," another may deem "wrong"—this is how disputes arise. Each abiding in what they deem "right" is fitting.

**Bi Xu’s Annotation:**
Transformations never cease—cross arms, and it is already lost. Those in the world who seek "right" do not seek the Dao/Way, but seek companions for themselves. Those who reject "wrong" do not reject crookedness, but reject what offends their hearts. What aligns with me may not truly be "right"; what offends my heart may not truly be "wrong"—hence the lament of beginning with "right" and ending with "wrong." Fifty-nine was once deemed "right," but if one now awakens to its "wrong," one knows the past was not truly "right." To know that what is "right" is not truly "right"—only one who deems nothing "right" encounters no "wrong." Thus, ultimate "right" holds no "wrong," and ultimate "wrong" holds no "right." The void and the indistinct are the root of the supreme Dao/Way; the bland and the still are the gate of the manifold mysteries. This is whence the myriad things emerge. What humans know arises from what they do not know; it is through not-knowing that they come to know. Those who fail to understand this—can this not be called great doubt? Worldly affairs entangle, renewing their changes daily. Between knowing and not-knowing, nothing is better than stillness. What is known pertains to human affairs; what is unknown pertains to Heaven’s principle. Human affairs involve action, and "right" and "wrong" cannot escape; Heaven’s principle involves non-action—how could it escape? If one deems what they know to be "right," many will deem it "wrong." Is what is said truly so? Words may not be "right."

**Yanqi’s Oral Exegesis:**
At sixty, one has undergone sixty transformations, each year’s understanding surpassing the last. Yet how can one be certain that what is "right" at sixty is truly "right"? All things that are born have a root; all that emerge have a gate—yet people do not see this, for it lies beyond their knowledge. Ordinary people know what they know and do not know what they do not know, yet deem this the ultimate—this is great delusion. "No escape" means it is so of itself, naturally. The knowledge of not-knowing pervades past and present, penetrates above and below—where is this principle absent? How could one escape it? *Yu hu* are both expressions of doubt. What changes visibly is called "transformation"; what changes invisibly is called "transmutation." At sixty, having lived sixty years in the world, one’s form, countenance, knowledge, and ability to comprehend affairs are subtly altered by creation, changing without awareness—never not beginning with "right" and ending with "wrong." Only upon reaching the age of harmonious hearing, after long experience, can "right" and "wrong" be settled and the principles of things clarified—yet one still does not know whether what is now called "right" was not the "wrong" of fifty-nine years past. This speaks of the endless transformations of things, the endless changes of affairs, and the endless shifts of the human heart. These three intermingle and transmute, forming past and present, revealing gains and losses. When affairs are resolved and principles settled, "right" and "wrong" become clear—yet one still does not know how future generations will judge them. People accumulate experiences to form an era; affairs accumulate changes to form transformations. Like mosquitoes and gnats, like wild horses passing before one’s eyes—countless, yet one’s innermost, true, and constant nature never alters. One who knows this will not be moved by life and death. The birth, death, emergence, and entry of things have roots and gates, yet people do not see them. They all honor what they know, deeming it their own ability, yet do not rely on what they do not know to attain true knowledge. If one truly knows what they do not know, the roots and gates of the myriad things become visible! Their birth, death, emergence, and entry follow constant principles. Whether they transform or not, one transforms with them—what confusion could there be? What humans know and can do is but a ten-thousandth part of what they do not know and cannot do. Even sages cannot exhaust it—how could knowledge and ability escape the transformations of things? Nevertheless, what I now deem "right" may not truly be so. All sages’ discussions of transformation include words of caution, unwilling to fix their meaning—this is the subtlety that cannot be definitively explained, the very essence of transformation.

Confucius asked the Grand Historian Da Qiang, Bo Changqian, and Xi Wei: "Duke Ling of Wei indulged in wine and revelry, neglecting state affairs; he hunted and fowled, ignoring the affairs of the feudal lords. What made him 'Ling' (Illustrious)?" Da Qiang replied: "It was because of this."

Bo Changqian said: "Duke Ling had three wives, with whom he bathed in promiscuous abandon. When the historian Qi presented himself in attendance, the Duke clasped gifts in hand and supported him with reverent care. Though his negligence was so extreme, his deference to the worthy was so solemn—this is what made him 'Ling.'"

Xi Wei said: "When Duke Ling died, divination for burial at the ancestral tomb proved inauspicious, while divination at Shaqiu proved auspicious. Digging several *ren* deep, they found a stone outer coffin. Washing and inspecting it, they saw an inscription that read: *'Do not rely on your son—Duke Ling will seize and bury him here.'* That Duke Ling would be called 'Ling' was fated long ago! How could these two men comprehend it?"

Guo’s commentary: *Ling* is the posthumous title for the unprincipled. Bathing with women was a breach of ritual; yet when Qi was deemed worthy and offered service, the Duke clasped gifts and supported him, preventing the full observance of propriety—this is what is meant by solemn reverence for the worthy. The *bi* were items for the attendant’s service. By honoring the worthy, he sought to compensate for his private impropriety. *Ling* has two meanings—it may also be called good, which is why Confucius inquired about it. The inscription said: *"You speak of Ji Zhe, saying he is unreliable—Duke Ling will seize your place."* All things are predetermined by fate, so future events may be known. Thus, what one must do cannot be left undone, and what one cannot do cannot be forced. Yet fools believe their actions are self-determined—how deluded! They merely recognize what has already occurred, unaware that even these outcomes arise from nature.

Lü’s commentary: Da Qiang and Bo Changqian judged by human standards, while Xi Wei judged by Heaven’s decree. Judging by Heaven, though the title was *Ling*, it was truly not something within human power to determine.

Yi Du’s commentary: These three were all Grand Historians, which is why Confucius questioned them. Duke Ling indulged in wine and revelry—this was dissipation; he hunted and fowled—this was neglect. Yet why was he granted *Ling* as his title? Da Qiang said, *"It was because of this,"* meaning *Ling* is the posthumous title for the unprincipled, a title that follows the law of names without diminishing its bearer.

Bo Changqian said: "The Duke bathed with his three wives, and when Historian Shan presented himself in attendance, the Duke had him grasp the ceremonial silk and support him as he emerged—this was his way of honoring the worthy, and thus his posthumous title was *Ling*."

Xi Wei said: "When the Duke died, divination was performed at Longshaqiu, where an inscribed outer coffin was unearthed, reading: *'Not relying on his son, Duke Ling seized and buried it.'* This spoke of the unalterable principle of Heaven: the land originally belonged to the Duke’s father, yet it was his son who obtained it—thus the Duke’s *Ling* title was destined long ago. How could those two [Da Qiang and Bo Changqian] comprehend this?"

Bixu’s commentary: "In the system of posthumous titles, *Ling* denotes one who was disordered yet unharmed, or whose virtue was luminous and numinous. His *Ling* was predestined, the title naturally aligning with the unseen decree. How could worldly sentiment fathom the principles of the transcendent and the hidden?"

*Yanzhai Oral Teachings*: "Given the Duke of Wei’s conduct, why was his title *Ling*? It was insufficient to match his wickedness. *Fengyu* (presenting in attendance) is akin to what we now call a summons. *Bo* means to grasp while assisting in an audience. *Bi* refers to the ceremonial silk—the Duke had others support him, demonstrating propriety."

At Shaqiu, where the ancients buried their dead, the stone outer coffin bore the name of *Ling* Gong long before his birth—thus his title was fixed in life, and what power had man over it? Not relying on his descendants means posterity cannot be entrusted; this land was destined for *Ling* Gong. The *Ling* posthumous title may signify either good or evil, which is why the Master questioned the three men.

Daji replied that precisely because of his conduct, his title was *Ling*—thus *Ling* clearly denoted a ruler without the Way. Bo Changqian said the Duke bathed with his three wives, an act of utmost impropriety, yet when a worthy minister presented tribute and assisted him in audience, attendants supported him with ceremonial silk as he emerged. The *bi* refers to the robes and goods offered by the attendant. Amidst the blazing fires of human desire, a single thread of Heavenly principle remained unobliterated—thus to call him *Ling* was nearly justifiable in good terms.

Xiwei said the Duke divined his burial site and found an inscribed stone coffin bearing the name *Ling* Gong in radiant clarity, its numinous resonance spanning a thousand years. His *Ling* title was thus long predestined, and how could those two comprehend it? The principle is the same as with the coffin of Chufu. The finest burial grounds of the Lord of Teng were all foreordained—how could his posthumous title be mere chance! Yet one must still fulfill human effort to accord with Heavenly principle; the beauty or ugliness of the title depends on one’s conduct in life, and thus one must be vigilant. The system of posthumous titles began with the Duke of Zhou, using a single character to express praise or censure—how solemn indeed!

Those who failed to cultivate a good name were called *Ling*; among the rulers of antiquity who met unvirtuous ends, some bore the title *Ling*, like King Li. Yet from the perspective of the enlightened, good and evil are both forgotten, past and present are equally without trace, and without rank or title, one flows in harmony with transformation, leaving no room for others to judge merit or fault—is this not the perfection of undifferentiated wholeness?

The three men each gave one answer: the first spoke of his lack of the Way, the second of his respect for worthies, and the third of the fixity of Heavenly principle. Judging by their words, there are differences in quality, yet ultimately none escape the fixity of Heavenly principle.

Shaozhi asked Taigong Diao: "What is meant by *qiuli* (village and hamlet) speech?"

Taigong Diao replied: "*Qiuli* refers to the customs formed by combining ten clans and a hundred names. It unites the disparate into sameness and disperses the same into difference. Now, if you point to the hundred parts of a horse and cannot obtain the horse, yet the horse stands before you—it is by assembling its hundred parts that you call it a horse. Thus, hills accumulate the lowly to become high, rivers gather waters to become vast, and great men unite all to become public-spirited. Therefore, what enters from without has a master but is not clung to; what issues from within has a norm but is not resisted.

The four seasons have distinct *qi*, yet Heaven does not bestow them, and so the year is complete. The five officials have distinct duties, yet the ruler does not favor them, and so the state is well-governed. The great men of culture and martial prowess do not bestow virtue, and so their power is complete. The myriad things have distinct principles, yet the Dao does not favor them, and so it is without name. Without name, it is without action; without action, yet nothing is left undone.

Times have beginnings and ends; the world undergoes transformations. Fortune and misfortune flow ceaselessly—what seems adverse may be fitting elsewhere; what is correct in one case may err in another. Compared to a great marsh, all materials find their measure; viewed from a great mountain, trees and stones share the same ground. This is what is meant by *qiuli* speech."

Shaozhi said: "Then is this sufficient to be called the Dao?"

Taigong Diao replied: "No. Now, the number of things is not limited to ten thousand, yet we call them the 'myriad things' because we name and refer to them by their greatest number. Thus, Heaven and Earth are the greatest of forms; yin and yang are the greatest of *qi*; the Dao is their commonality. To name and refer to them by their greatness is permissible, but once named, how can it be compared! If we use this analogy, it is like comparing dogs and horses—it falls far short.

Guo’s commentary: The great man is impartial toward the world, and so the world’s customs become one. What enters from without is the transformation wrought by the great man; what issues from within is the nature of the people and things. When nature is correct, the people do not act contrary to their hearts; when transformation is perfectly impartial, the ruler has nothing to cling to. Thus, he can unite villages and hamlets, unify the world, harmonize the myriad things, and level all differences.

Distinct *qi* exist naturally, and so they endure; if they were originally nonexistent and bestowed by Heaven, they would sometimes cease. Distinct duties arise from innate talents, and so they are entrusted accordingly—not privately granted by favor. Even culture and martial prowess are not bestowed by the great man; if they were granted, they might sometimes be lacking. How could this apply only to culture and martial prowess? All natures are like this.

Names are limited by reality, and so there is non-action; realities each act on their own, and so nothing is left undone. Times and eras change, and the mindless follow them. What is perverse here may be fitting there; what is correct here may err there. Each is true to its application and cannot be separated. Compared to the great marsh and great mountain, nothing is discarded—this is uniting the disparate into sameness.

To speak of *qiuli* is to encompass the world. Countable things are not limited to ten thousand—how much less can the uncountable be called sufficient for the Dao! The Dao pervades things without partiality; to forcibly name it 'Dao' is what is meant by 'the Dao that can be spoken.' Once named, how can it be compared? The distinctions of names fall far short. Thus, to call it the Dao is still insufficient; it must lie in the realm of namelessness and wordlessness to be truly attained."

Lü’s commentary: Combining names into *qiuli* unites the different into sameness; dispersing *qiuli* into names turns sameness into difference. It is not like the speech of a single household, where differences cannot be united and sameness cannot be dispersed. The hundred parts are all the horse, yet pointing to them does not yield the horse—only by assembling the hundred parts do you call it a horse. This is like the great man who does not regard his greatness in its entirety; then even what is called great cannot be obtained. The comparison to hills and rivers shows the utmost of greatness.

Thus, from the perspective of things, the myriad things are all complete within me. What enters from without has a master within and is not clung to; it embraces the myriad without excluding anything."

From my perspective, when I observe all things flowing away in their myriad forms, what emerges from within has its proper alignment and does not resist; it circulates without exclusion. Heaven, in relation to the four seasons, does not bestow them as gifts based on their inherent nature—were it otherwise, its works would be incomplete and the year would not reach fulfillment. The ruler, in relation to the five offices, does not claim their functions as his own by withholding them from the many—were it otherwise, his wisdom would be incomplete and the state would not be governed. King Wen and the Duke of Zhou possessed distinct talents; the myriad things follow distinct principles. Yet their way of neither bestowing nor claiming as private is no different from this.

Without partiality, there is no self; without self, nothing can be named. Without name, there is no action; without action, there is nothing that is not done. The changes of the times do not cease; fortune and misfortune have no constancy. What is adverse may yet be fitting; what is good may yet become ominous. The dispositions of things each pursue their own ends, their faces varied and not uniform. What is upright may yet be askew; what is correct may yet appear strange. Since the principles of things are so unequal, the Dao levels them through impartiality, never allowing the mind to incline toward conformity among them. This is like the great marsh where all the hundred forests are complete, or the great mountain where wood and stone are undivided—this is what is meant by the speech of *qiuli*.

The Dao is but a forced name; to call it the Dao is not sufficient. All things are boundless, and the myriad cannot exhaust their number—yet we speak of the myriad because it is the largest number we can name. Heaven and earth are vast in form; yin and yang are vast in *qi*. The Dao levels them through impartiality, and thus it is neither form nor *qi*, and so has no name. That the name is insufficient to exhaust the Dao yet we name it the Dao is also because we use the greatest term to describe it. Originally nameless, yet we impose a name upon it—then it has already come into being, and how can it compare to what is nameless? To take what is called the Dao as the Dao itself is like mistaking a dog for a horse.

*Yidu’s Commentary*: Ten households make a *qiu*; twenty households make a *li*. *Qiuli* combines ten surnames and a hundred clans into shared customs, yet it does not know to unite all under heaven as the public good. To unite difference into sameness and disperse sameness into difference is to distance oneself further from the Dao and set things further at odds. Pointing to the hundred parts of a horse does not yield the horse; assembling the hundred parts and calling it a horse is to disperse sameness into difference and unite difference into sameness. Hills accumulate from the lowly; rivers converge from streams—this illustrates how the great person unites all under heaven as the public good. Only through impartiality can what enters from without find its master within and not be clung to; not clinging, it can flow freely. What emerges from within finds its proper alignment without and does not resist; not resisting, it can circulate. Thus, without partiality, all under heaven is one; without bestowal, the myriad things reach fulfillment. The *qi* of the four seasons differ, yet heaven does not bestow them, so the year is complete. The duties of the five offices differ, yet the ruler does not claim them as private, so the state is governed. Even in the distinct tasks of King Wen and the Duke of Zhou or the distinct principles of the myriad things, the ruler’s Dao is without partiality—thus virtue is complete and nameless, and without bestowal, things fulfill themselves. Receiving the beneficence of the marsh without gratitude, without partiality one is naturally upright, and achievements are accomplished without recompense.

The great Dao is without partiality toward things, thus it is nameless and without action; without action, things each act on their own, and there is nothing that is not done. The world changes with the times; fortune and misfortune lie in wait for one another. What is adverse may yet be fitting, for faces and directions differ. What is upright may yet be askew, for each clings to their own view. This is like the great marsh where different villages serve the same use, or the great mountain where different plants share the same altar—uniting difference into sameness without departing from form and number, this is what is called the speech of *qiuli*. Heaven and earth, yin and yang are the greatest in form and *qi*; the Dao levels them through impartiality, and all are named for their greatness. Yet if this is already so, how can the small and large, noble and base compare to it?

*Bixu’s Commentary*: In the *Rites of Zhou*, four wells make a settlement, four settlements make a *qiu*, five households make a *bu*, and five *bu* make a *li*. Combining the differences of ten surnames and a hundred names into the customs of a single *qiu* or *li*, or dispersing the customs of a single *qiu* or *li* into the differences of ten surnames and a hundred names, is like separating the hundred parts of a horse—head, tail, eyes, ears—and then combining them to call it a horse. This is the meaning of Gongsun Long’s "separating hardness and whiteness" and "uniting sameness and difference." Mountains accumulate from many stones; rivers converge from a hundred streams. The great person unites commanderies and states into the public good—divided, Chu and Yue are distinct; united, their customs become one, no different from the combining and dispersing of *qiuli*. What enters from without finds its master within, so affairs do not stagnate. What emerges from within aligns with principle without deviation, so principle extends far. The *qi* of heat and cold differ, yet heaven entrusts them without bestowal, so the year’s work is complete. The duties of the offices differ, yet the ruler delegates without claiming them as private, so all under heaven is governed. The villages of King Wen and the Duke of Zhou differ, yet the great person entrusts them without bestowal, so virtue and enterprise are complete. The principles of plants and animals differ, yet the Dao gives rise to them without partiality, so it is nameless. Things name themselves; the Dao does not force names upon them. Things act on their own; the Dao does not force action upon them. The Dao does nothing, and thus can do everything. The alternation of winter and spring, the rise and fall of emperors and kings—what is misfortune or calamity here may be fortune or fitting there. This is like the great marsh where all materials, great and small, meet the standard, or the great mountain where wood and stone, refined and coarse, gather on the same altar—this is what is meant by the speech of *qiuli*.

The great Dao is boundless; things are also inexhaustible. Now, to name it based on the largest number and call it the myriad—if things were limited to the myriad, then the Dao would also have a limit, and how could it be worthy of being called "prior to the Lord on High"? The great Dao unites form and *qi* through impartiality, and by forced naming is called "great" and designated the Dao. Yet once it is called the great Dao, it has already come into being—how can it compare to what has never yet emerged from its source?

*Yuanzhai’s Oral Teachings*: Gathering wells makes a *qiu*; gathering *qiu* makes a *li*. Within a *li*, ten surnames and a hundred names—though people and things differ, their customs are the same. This is the metaphor of uniting difference into sameness.

Within a *qiu* or *li*, speech is the shared discourse of that *li*. Uniting differences to form sameness, the myriad things share one principle. Dispersing sameness to form differences, each of the myriad things has its own principle. Combining a hundred parts to make a horse—no single part bears the name "horse," yet assembling those hundred parts is called a horse. Uniting to form impartiality is to unite the differences of the myriad things into sameness.

There is a master yet no attachment; attachment contradicts spontaneity.
