Rectitude is the principle of the myriad things emerging from the heart—when this principle does not oppose things, there is no sameness or difference. Without conferring favor or claiming merit, the myriad things with their distinct principles are united by the great Dao into impartiality, thus defying all naming.

"Flowing abundantly" describes its ceaseless movement. "Mutual dependence" is its lack of constancy—what seems adverse may in fact be fitting. Like the old man who lost his horse, people cling to their own pursuits as faces differ from one another. What is deemed correct may become rigid, and rigidity may lead to loss.

For example, the timber of great mountains and marshes—trees and stones—all meet the measure and serve a use, uniting differences into sameness. Counting things by number gives the myriad; summing forms and *qi* yields Heaven and Earth, Yin and Yang. The Dao governs them with impartiality, all spoken of in terms of their greatness. Yet even with the name "Dao," how can this compare to that which has never yet emerged from its source?

Within every *qiu* and *li*, there are those revered for age and virtue. Examining the sentiments of the multitude to establish discourse—this is like the monthly critiques of the Han or the local sayings of each *li*, recording customs and affairs. Such is the speech of *qiu* and *li*, uniting differences into sameness. Though all emerge from the same *qiu* and *li*, disparities arise in youth and age, worthiness and foolishness, wealth and poverty, gain and loss—sameness giving rise to difference.

The vastness of the world begins with *qiu* and *li*; the greatness of the Dao pervades all affairs. Dispersing sameness to form difference is like the hundred parts of a horse. Uniting differences to form sameness is to assemble those hundred parts and call it a horse. In speech, there is union and separation; in profound insight, all returns to undifferentiated oneness. The principle reaches its ultimate, beyond the capacity of words.

Mountains accumulate from the lowly; rivers converge from waters. The great person unites with impartiality—this principle is no different. One who can aptly unite *qiu* and *li* may likewise unite the sentiments of all under Heaven. It lies solely in the word "impartiality." As the *Dao Classic* states: "Impartiality becomes king; the king is what all under Heaven turn toward—how could one refuse?"

What enters from without is learning; the noble person’s learning centers on the Dao, and centering on the Dao, nothing is impassable. What emerges from within is thought; the noble person’s thought is rectified by principle, and rectified by principle, nothing opposes it. Like the four seasons with their distinct *qi* forming a year, or the five offices with their distinct duties forming governance, all culminate in the completeness of the great person’s virtue, illuminating the Dao’s impartiality—how could it be named?

Nameless, it is non-action; through non-action, nothing is left undone—this is the inevitable course of principle. Yet times shift and circumstances alternate between concealment and revelation. What seems adverse may be fitting, and what is deemed correct may err—all due to clinging to one’s own sentiments, which leads to divergent paths.

For instance, the hundred villages of a great marsh, united for the use of a master craftsman—difference becomes sameness. The trees and stones of a great mountain, dispersed for the use of all under Heaven—sameness becomes difference. If one profoundly unites with principle and returns to the Dao, what need is there for debate over sameness and difference?

The name "Dao" does not exhaust the Dao; numbering things as the myriad does not exhaust things. Each is spoken of in terms of its greatness. The greatest of forms is governed by Heaven and Earth; the greatest of *qi* is governed by Yin and Yang. The Dao, in turn, governs Heaven and Earth, Yin and Yang—how could its greatness be measured? Yet once the name "Dao" exists, it cannot compare to the nameless. Thus, the Dao of the perfected person operates without name, and all under Heaven cannot name it.

This chapter resembles the *Discourse on Equalizing Things* in its discussion of being and non-being, life and death, yet here it pertains more to the Way of governance, further unfolding the theme of *qiu* and *li* discourse in a still more extraordinary manner. The intent behind establishing names is to embody impartiality and harmonize all under Heaven—this is what those of limited understanding should inquire about.

*Collected Explications of the Ocean of Meanings of the True Scripture of Nanhua*, Scroll Eighty-Five, concludes.

**Collected Explications of the Ocean of Meanings of the True Scripture of Nanhua, Scroll Eighty-Six**

**Chapter Five: "Ze Yang"**

Shaozhi said: Within the four directions, encompassing the six conjunctions, whence do the myriad things arise?

Taigong Diao replied: Yin and Yang illuminate, cover, and govern one another; the four seasons alternate, engender, and destroy. Desire and aversion, departure and approach—thus do they bridge and arise. Male and female unite in their customary pairing. Safety and danger transform into one another; fortune and misfortune beget each other; urgency and delay grind together; gathering and scattering thus take form. These are the names and realities that may be recorded, the essences that may be inscribed.

Following the sequence of their ordering, bridging and revolving in mutual employment—when exhausted, they return; when ended, they begin anew. This is what things inherently possess, what words exhaust, what knowledge attains—nothing more than the limits of things. Those who perceive the Dao do not follow what has been abandoned, nor trace what has arisen. Here discussion comes to rest.

Shaozhi said: Jizhen’s doctrine of "non-action" and Jiezi’s doctrine of "contingent agency"—which of these two teachings accords with reality? Which is partial to its own principle?

Taigong Diao replied: The crowing of roosters and the barking of dogs are what people know. Yet even one of great wisdom cannot, in words, exhaust how they transform of themselves, nor can they fathom what they will do next. Dissecting this to its utmost, its subtlety reaches the unparalleled; its vastness, the immeasurable. Whether contingent agency or non-action, one remains bound to things and thus errs in the end. Contingent agency is substantive; non-action is empty. Having name and reality, it resides in things. Without name or reality, it dwells in the emptiness of things. What can be spoken or conceived—speaking of it only increases its remoteness. What has not yet arisen cannot be hindered; what has already perished cannot be obstructed. Life and death are not distant, yet their principle cannot be seen. Contingent agency and non-action are but borrowed terms for doubt.

I observe their root—its going is without end. I seek their end—its coming is without cease. Without end, without cease, words fail, yet they share the same principle as things. Contingent agency and non-action are the root of words, the beginning and end of things. The Dao cannot be possessed; what is possessed cannot be without it. The name "Dao" is but a borrowed term for its operation. Contingent agency and non-action are but one corner of things—how do they suffice for the great square?

When words suffice, speaking all day exhausts the Dao. When words do not suffice, speaking all day exhausts only things. The ultimate of Dao and things—speech and silence cannot bear it. Neither speech nor silence—discussion reaches its limit.

**Guo’s Annotation:**
To ask whence things arise, some say the Dao generates them. Yet all this is self-so, without anything that generates. All such affairs—advancing and retreating, pursuing and abandoning—arise from the mutual illumination of Yin and Yang, the alternation of the four seasons. Beyond this, they rest in spontaneity. Their mutual ordering and employment are what things inherently possess, not what the non-existent can produce. Beyond things, nothing further exists; thus, knowledge does not surpass the limits of things. Abandonment and arising cannot be traced. Following this, discussion comes to rest.

Some say the Dao is non-action; others say the Dao is contingent agency. Contingent agency implies the power to employ things. Yet things are spontaneous, not what agency can produce. By this reasoning, Jizhen’s words are correct. The utmost subtlety and vastness are self-so, not produced by action. Things mutually employing one another are also self-so; thus, non-action is not contrary to things. All things, in their manifoldness, pass by through non-action. Reality acts of itself, without any agent. "Residing" refers to where things are. Where things are, their reality is utterly empty. One attains it only by seeking beyond words and intentions.

Suddenly, they arise of themselves—I cannot forbid it. Suddenly, they perish of themselves—I cannot oppose it. Near as it is in one’s own body, one still does not see its self-so and yet would grieve over it. These two doctrines are what the world doubts. The principle of things is inexhaustible; thus, knowledge and words are without end. Only then do they share the same principle as things. Constantly non-active, yet spontaneous.

The Dao cannot itself possess; what is possessed is spontaneous. Things proceed by it, hence the borrowed name "Dao." Grasping one corner suffices to know the rest. Seeking the Dao beyond words and intentions is sufficient; failing to forget words and retain intention is insufficient. The ultimate of Dao and things is constantly self-so through non-action, not residing in speech or silence. Its self-so is beyond the discussion of speech and silence.

**Lü’s Annotation:**
Shaozi, having heard the Dao spoken of as existent, finds it incomparable to the Dao and thus doubts its non-existence. He asks whence the myriad things arise—this is what is meant by "being established in emptiness." The sun and moon come and go, rise and fall, wax and wane—illuminating, covering, and harmonizing one another. Cold and heat, contraction and expansion, mutual generation and destruction—alternating, engendering, and destroying. Things born between Heaven and Earth move with Yin and Yang and the four seasons. Thus, desire and aversion, departure and approach ride upon them to proceed; male and female unite in their customary pairing, movement and stillness following constant patterns. Hence, there are matters of safety and danger, fortune and misfortune, gathering and scattering—these names and realities may be recorded, these essences may be inscribed, and they are not beyond inquiry.

The sequence of before and after is called order, mutually ordered yet never disordered. "Bridging" means riding upon them to proceed; "revolving" means relying upon them to cross. Mutually employing, yet never fixed. When exhausted, they return; when ended, they begin anew—this is Yin and Yang, the four seasons. This is what things inherently possess, not the non-existence of the Dao. Words and knowledge reach their limit here—this is whence the myriad things arise, not that they arise from what generates them.

Having name, it is the mother of the myriad things—so it is. As for those who perceive the Dao, they have never been without things, hence they do not follow what has been abandoned; they have never possessed things, hence they do not trace what has arisen. Serene and nameless, they emerge beyond the six conjunctions—how could words and knowledge reach them? Jizhen’s non-action follows what has been abandoned.

Jiezi posits "or-employing," tracing to their origins. The crowing of roosters and barking of dogs—these are their transformations, what they have already become; the causes of their crowing and barking, what they will become. When essence reaches its utmost without comparison, there is no interior; when vastness cannot be encompassed, there is no exterior. Between "or-employing" and "non-action," where indeed do they lie? This is why one remains entangled with things: by not cleaving to reality, one cleaves instead to emptiness. Taking named reality as the dwelling of things, one fails to see that it has never truly existed; taking nameless reality as the emptiness of things, one fails to see that it has never truly been absent. Thus, the more one speaks, the more distant one becomes.

Life and death cannot be refused or halted—they transcend speech and thought, though near at hand, they cannot be perceived. "Or-employing" and "non-action" are but borrowed doubts, not the true principle. Proceeding without end, one meets no beginning; coming without cease, one follows no end. This is the principle of things, not their form. "Or-employing" and "non-action" can be spoken and conceived, yet they remain bound to things from beginning to end—how then can one perceive the ceaseless and boundless? The Dao cannot be possessed, for it is without possession; possession cannot be without, for it arises from non-being, not from my own negation.

Thus, the Dao is but a provisional name—how can a name be the Dao? "Non-action" and "or-employing" are but partial aspects of things—how can they align with the great Dao? To speak and exhaust the Dao is rare speech, natural speech. To speak and exhaust things is excessive speech, leading to exhaustion. Viewed from things, the Dao is not a thing; viewed from the Dao, no thing is not the Dao. The ultimate of Dao and things cannot be borne by speech or silence.

One who speaks all their life without having spoken does not truly speak; one who remains silent all their life without having failed to speak does not truly remain silent. Only when discourse reaches this point does it attain its limit.

*Dubi’s Annotation:*
Yin and Yang illuminate each other as sun and moon, unite as heaven and earth, and govern as wind and rain. The four seasons succeed one another as cold and heat, give rise as spring and summer, and destroy as autumn and winter. From the existence of Yin and Yang, the four seasons, desires and aversions, and male and female arise bridges, safety and danger, fortune and misfortune—all proceed from them. As for their mutual regulation, employment, and the cycles of exhaustion and return, beginning and end—these are what things inherently possess, the utmost that words and knowledge can reach regarding things.

Those who perceive the Dao see beyond form and qi—how could they linger over things or trace the causes of their rise and fall? This is where such discourse ends.

"Non-action" is spontaneity, of heaven; "or-employing" is being made so, of man. Harmonizing all under heaven transcends partiality. The crowing of roosters and barking of dogs are known to all, yet the causes of their crowing and barking, and what they will become, even the wisest cannot fathom through speech or thought. Extending this to the utmost vast or minute, none escapes the workings of things beyond human power.

"Non-action" knows heaven but not man; "or-employing" knows man but not heaven. Clinging to one aspect of things is always an error. The names of emptiness and fullness, being and non-being arise mutually, and the more one speaks or conceives, the more distant one becomes—better to seek beyond speech and thought.

A person’s life and death follow their nature and destiny—who can forbid or halt them? This principle is not distant; it lies within us, like the cycles of the four seasons, unseen. Thus, the theories of "or-employing" and "non-action" seem borrowed doubts, not the ultimate of nature and destiny. Observing the root of returning life, its going is without end; the end of emerging life, its coming is without cease.

To speak of the Dao’s non-being is to share the principle of things; to speak of its being is to share their beginning and end. Neither being nor non-being, beyond forced names—thus, "or-employing" and "non-action" are but partial aspects of things, not the great square, let alone the formless Dao.

He whose speech suffices harbors no doubts within, thus exhausts the Dao; he whose speech does not suffice is the opposite. Better than either is neither speech nor silence, where Dao and things both attain.

*Bixu’s Annotation:*
A lesser knower asked about the arising of the myriad things in the world. Taigong explained the principles of Yin and Yang, the four seasons’ illumination, governance, generation, and destruction, the people’s desires and aversions, the pairing of male and female in birds and beasts. "Bridge-arising" describes loftiness and vigor. Affairs differ in safety and danger, fortune and misfortune, urgency and leisure, gathering and dispersal, yet they transform, give rise, interact, and complete one another in endless variation. Externally, they have names to record; internally, they possess subtleties to note. From heaven and earth to the myriad things, all follow order in mutual regulation and employment. When things are exhausted, they return; when affairs begin, they end.

Zen speech exhausts knowledge, reaching only the coarse limits of things, unable to glimpse the fence of the Dao. Only those who perceive the Dao do not follow the rise and fall of things but let them flourish—while I, gathering and containing, preserve life alone.

Again, he asked about the Dao’s "non-action"—how does it relate to affairs? And the Dao’s "or-employing"—how does it accord with the nature of things? Which is partial, which correct?

The answer: the crowing of roosters and barking of dogs are known to all, yet none know why they crow or bark. If it is "non-action," why do they suddenly crow at dawn or bark at dusk? If it is "or-employing," why do other things not do so? Who knows the principle of silent self-transformation? Who discerns the conditions of what will become? Only by setting aside "non-action" can one examine the conditions of "or-employing"; only by entrusting "or-employing" can one scrutinize the principle of "non-action." Extending this, even the utmost vast or minute cannot escape things, nor avoid entanglement.

Losing the flute of things are names and realities; when names and realities are lost, what remains of things? Only the wondrous Dao’s ultimate principle transcends thought and discussion: when qi comes, life arises; when qi scatters, death follows. Just born, one dies again; just dead, one swiftly lives—this can be called near indeed!

Yet its principle cannot be beheld—it lies solely in obscure enlightenment. "Or-employing" benefits others; "non-action" preserves the self. The enlightened meet its source at every turn; the deluded remain bound by doubt. It is but a borrowed path one treads.

I observe the Dao’s root and branch: empty, vast, and elusive, neither to be pursued nor welcomed. Discussing its boundlessness and ceaselessness differs not from that of flora and fauna. The world takes "useful action" and "non-action" as the foundation of its teachings, yet once teachings take form, they cannot transcend things. Thus, they partake in the dual principles of beginning and end, being and non-being—all proceeding by virtue of the wondrous root.

Ji Zhen’s "non-being" and Jie Zi’s "being" are but partial views, ridiculed by those of profound understanding. When being and non-being are threaded as one, and affairs and principles are both illuminated, words suffice. When words suffice, the Dao is without omission. When being and non-being are clung to in bias, and affairs and principles are set forth in opposition, words fall short. When words fall short, nothing escapes entanglement.

The Dao’s extremity cannot be silenced by silence; things’ extremity cannot be spoken by speech. Only by departing from speech’s speech and forsaking silence’s silence can one obscurely grasp the mechanism of wordless union, beholding with the eye the ultimate subtleties of the myriad wonders.

*Yanzhai Oral Exegesis*:
"Zhao" is like "responding."
"Gai" is like "uniting."
"Xiang zhi" means mutual waxing and waning.
Spring’s birth and autumn’s decay follow the seasons’ passage, giving rise to desires and aversions, departures and approaches, safety and peril, fortune and misfortune—all variations within the same. "Qiao" means arched and rising. "Pian" means division. From desires and aversions onward, their names and realities are subtle yet each visible and recordable.

The mutual principle of sequential change is the mutual lifting of yin and yang, arched and rising in motion, waxing and waning in turn—hence it is said that poverty and prosperity, beginning and end, are the inevitable patterns of things. The utmost of knowledge extends no further. Only those who know the Dao attribute all that rises and falls to spontaneity.

Thus, discourse reaches its limit here. "No agency" means all events are coincidental; "or agency" implies there is a governing force. The crowing of roosters and barking of dogs illustrate how human understanding differs. Even one of great wisdom cannot exhaust the meaning of what arises or what is to come. If one attempts to analyze this principle by distinguishing great and small speech, it cannot be fully exhausted. All are burdened by things, ultimately deemed as error—asserting that some entity governs them is substantive, while claiming there is no governing force is insubstantial. If substantive, then names become burdens; if insubstantial, both names and realities dissolve. Yet even this "insubstantial" remains bound to things. To speak of "being" or "non-being" is already far removed from the Dao.

That which has not yet arisen cannot be forced into non-arising; when death is due, how can it be obstructed? This principle lies near at hand yet remains unseen. Whether one posits "agency" or "no agency," worldly doubts arise from this very assumption. Observing from the primal state before movement, one sees the endless procession of the past; observing at the moment of cessation after movement, one sees the ceaseless arrival of the future. Only by dissolving all directions can one merge with the myriad things as a single body. "Agency" or "no agency"—both remain entangled with things, bound to them from beginning to end, never escaping "being." How then can one attain "non-being"?

Viewed in true reality, even the term "Dao" is but a provisional name. These two doctrines, clinging to one extreme, how can they accord with the great Dao? With true insight, speaking all day does no harm; without true insight, even abundant speech remains mere semblance. The Dao is essence; things are coarse. To seek its ultimate, neither speech nor silence suffices. Within the realm beyond speech and silence lies the most profound discourse. This aligns with what the Buddhists describe: "As I press my finger, the ocean seal radiates light; as you raise a thought, worldly dust stirs first."

Heaven has yin and yang, the four seasons; humans have desires and aversions, departures and approaches; things have male and female, division and union. "Arched rising" emerges from emptiness. "Common existence" arises through function. Events may have no cause or a cause, all emerging from the interplay of heaven, humans, and the myriad things, rooted in the remnants of the Dao. Safety and peril, gathering and dispersal—these eight arise from what precedes, their traces growing coarser. Through careful enumeration and observation, nothing is left unrecorded. Following the sequence of principles, the duties of ruler and minister, father and child become clear; relying on the empty movement of function, the mechanisms of reversal and return, beginning and end, are revealed. Thus, the extent of knowledge reaches its limit in things. This is the discourse of governing the world, the affairs within the realm.

As for those beyond the realm who perceive the Dao, they do not follow the rise and fall of things, nor trace their origins. Having forgotten both beginning and end, the middle also ceases to exist—where then is room for conjecture? In their time, Ji Zhen and Jie Zi held these two doctrines, each clinging to one side, like Yang Zhu’s egoism and Mo Di’s universal love. Because they did not accord with the Dao, they were derided as the crowing of roosters and barking of dogs. People recognize the sounds but not their cause—how then can I claim to understand the self-transformation in the doctrines of these two?

Analyzing this principle, whether in the minutest or vastest, "agency" or "no agency," all remain bound to things, never free from ceasing. "Agency" has a cause and is thus substantive; "no agency," though insubstantial, has a name and is thus substantive. To be bound is not to attain complete non-being. Those who once spoke of the Dao invariably departed from four phrases: being, non-being, neither being nor non-being, both being and non-being. To depart from these is the Dao, just as combining east, west, south, and north reveals the center.

Consider the coming and going of the four seasons, the racing of the sun and stars. Heaven moves vigorously without ceasing; the sea inhales and exhales with constancy. Is this "no agency"? Or "agency"? Then is there one who acts? One who commands? The crowing and barking are driven by wind and qi; life and death are driven by the great earth. The four seasons, sun and stars, heaven and sea—all have a true master governing them, yet it acts through non-action, commands through non-command. Human life and death, departures and arrivals cannot be obstructed. This principle lies near at hand yet remains unseen, its meaning the same. Observing its root, the past is endless; observing its end, the future is boundless. One sees that all are subject to creation’s service, from ancient times to the present without cease—not only I, but how can it be fully expressed? All share this principle with things.

If one clings to "agency" or "no agency," then the origin of speech and names arises, bound to things without end. The Dao cannot be possessed; to possess it is to obstruct and stagnate, how then can one reach the wondrous subtlety of emptiness? The Dao resides within the inquiry of being and non-being yet is not attached to either. It borrows being and non-being to act, and there is nowhere it is not the Dao. As for Ji Zhen and Jie Zi, each pursued a partial truth—how could they grasp the great expanse? Speech that suffices attains the essence of the Dao; speech that does not suffice attains only its coarse aspect. Though speech is one, it divides into Dao and things. If one exhausts the emptiness of things, it is the Dao—neither speech nor silence can contain it. Only by transcending beyond speech and silence does one reach the ultimate discourse of the Dao.

Master Chu’s general discussion: This chapter begins with the debates of Ze Yang and Wang Guo, praising Shan Fan’s hidden virtue in stabilizing the marketplace’s competitive winds. Herein lies the insight of the perfected person, skillfully unraveling the entanglements of things, guiding them toward tranquility and harmony. This is called "nourishing people with harmony and transforming them." Its benefits to the Way of governance are manifold! Because he loved the people without cease, the people loved and settled under him without cease. This is using the Dao to aid things, emerging from the truth of nature and emotion—how could the people not be transformed?

The worldly often lose themselves in pursuit of things, drifting ever farther from their original home. When they gaze toward it with longing, how joyful they would be if, before all traces vanish, they could still seek its return—restoring what they once saw, hearing what they once heard! How delightful their reception would be!

Governing the self is like governing a state. When the heart-king is upright, the five officials are well-ordered; when the state’s ruler is upright, his ministers and aides are worthy. This benefits not only the present but also fosters transformation for future generations—just as Tang, having three ministers to guide him, was followed by the Master who carried on his legacy. Is this not like the four seasons completing the year’s work, or the debate between the man of Hedong and the man beyond the heavens?

Later, when Qi and Wei broke their alliance and raised arms, the text invokes the metaphors of *Chu* and *Man* to mock the bellicose rulers of the time, exposing the narrowness of their habits and the futility of their conflicts. Confucius left the Ant Mound, criticizing the suspicion that clings to visible traces. The border guard spoke of planting grain, warning that desire and aversion are the roots of calamity. All these illustrate the essentials of engaging the world and ordering the self. When Boju lamented the condemned man, he took failure as his own, rectifying himself to rectify others. *Huanhuan* followed the transformations of the year, relying on knowing what it did not know—this is using the knowledge of things.

Here again is discussed the method of governing the people and transforming things. Duke Ling’s posthumous title was "Ling" because his burial was determined before the fact; thus, all his actions were unavoidable. The Creator has its fixed reckoning, merely entrusted to human hands! As for the words of villages—gathering and dispersing, sameness and difference—just as a horse is not called a horse by its hundred parts but by its standing form, the great person unifies all into the public good. Though the myriad things differ, the Dao is complete within them, like the hundred villages of a great marsh or the trees and stones of a mountain: some emerge together yet serve different uses, some arise differently yet share a common end. All remain within the transformations of form and qi, yet the ultimate principle is fully realized.

The conclusion takes Jizhen and Jiezi’s discussions of emptiness and fullness as mere attachments, entanglements that do no more than follow the cycle of things. Thus, one must transcend beyond speech and silence, where the heart fuses and the mind attains understanding. There lies the ultimate discourse on the Dao and things—then one knows that what can be spoken or named is not the true constant, and that the Dao cannot be contained by either speech or silence.

*End of the Eighty-Sixth Scroll of the* Southern Florescence True Scripture: An Ocean of Subtleties Compiled
*Beginning of the Eighty-Seventh Scroll of the* Southern Florescence True Scripture: An Ocean of Subtleties Compiled

The Daoist of Wulin, Chu Boxiu, on *"External Things"* (First Chapter)

External things cannot be relied upon—thus, Longfeng was executed, Bigan slain, Jizi feigned madness, Elai died, and Jie and Zhou perished. No ruler fails to desire loyalty from his ministers, yet loyalty does not necessarily earn trust. Hence, Wu Yun was cast into the river, Chang Hong died in Shu, and his blood, preserved for three years, turned to jade. No parent fails to desire filial piety from their children, yet filial piety does not necessarily bring love. Thus, Xiaoji grieved and Zeng Shen sorrowed.

When wood rubs against wood, it ignites; when metal is held to fire, it melts. If yin and yang clash in their movements, heaven and earth are thrown into great turmoil—then there are thunder and lightning, fire within water, even the burning of the great locust tree. When one is deeply entangled in dual perils with no escape, the cicada’s wings fail to form. If the heart is suspended between heaven and earth, weighed down by distress and stagnation, with profit and harm grinding against one another, the fire of life burns fiercely. The multitude scorch their harmony, and the moon, though constant, cannot overcome the fire. Thus, with a sigh, the Dao is exhausted.

**Guo’s Annotation:**
Good and evil alike cannot be relied upon. Blood turning to jade is the utmost sincerity, yet loyalty does not necessarily earn trust, nor filial piety love. Therefore, the perfected person responds to things without a fixed heart, adapting only to change. Heaven and earth in great turmoil—this is what is meant by "clashing movements." If one cannot forget form, they will be ensnared by joy and sorrow wherever they turn, with no right or wrong. The heavier one’s self-regard, the more difficult their position. Without knowing what to hold fast to, the heart cannot be settled. *"Suspended"* refers to one who sits in lofty meditation. *"Weighed down"* means lacking clarity and ease. *"Fire of life"* refers to inner heat. Abandoning profit preserves harmony; if profit and harm linger in the heart, that harmony is scorched. Great and dim, one is burdened by many cares; small and bright, one knows their limits. Only by sighing without self-regard, forgetting form and attaining spontaneity, is the Dao fully realized.

**Lü’s Annotation:**
All that is not the essence of life and destiny is an external thing—thus, it cannot be relied upon. Longfeng and Bigan took benevolence as something to cling to, while Elai, Jie, and Zhou took the lack of benevolence as something to cling to—both met their ends in good and evil alike. If one does not draw near to form and name, what reliance is there? External things are not only unreliable in others but also in oneself. No ruler or parent fails to desire loyalty and filial piety from ministers and children, yet loyalty does not necessarily earn trust, nor filial piety love. The desire for ministers and children’s loyalty and filial piety lies within oneself. If the Dao has not yet reached the point of sighing and exhaustion, even what one desires within oneself remains an external thing that cannot be relied upon—how much less in others? Wu Yun, Chang Hong, and the rest clung to what lay in others, thus meeting death, grief, and sorrow. Blood turning to jade shows the utmost loyalty, yet it still could not be relied upon by those who desired loyalty—is this not lamentable?

When wood rubs against wood, fire arises—those of the same kind cannot avoid harming one another. When metal is held to fire, it melts—those of different kinds cannot avoid harming one another. From *"yin and yang clashing in their movements"* onward, it speaks of great calamity, inescapable between heaven and earth. Then there is quaking into thunder, bursting into light, harm arising from the different, or injury from the same, even to the point of the fire of life scorching harmony, and the moon being insufficient to overcome it. Alas! With a body, how can one be without care? Entangled in what is the same or different, one is doubly ensnared. The cicada’s wings fail to form, and its desires go unfulfilled. If the heart is suspended between heaven and earth, weighed down by distress and stagnation, it is like when yin and yang clash and heaven and earth are thrown into turmoil, or when profit and harm grind against one another and the fire of life burns fiercely—like when there is thunder and lightning, water and fire burning the locust tree. Even the moon’s clear and bright nature cannot overcome the fire scorching harmony. All this arises from having a heart. Sighing, then, is to let the heart go until it reaches the heartless—here, the Dao is exhausted.

**Yi Du’s Annotation:**
Within oneself, there is righteousness; in things, there is destiny. Righteousness has a path to cultivate, but destiny has no principle that can be relied upon. External things cannot be relied upon—this is spoken in terms of destiny. The loyalty and filial piety of ministers and children lie within oneself; seeking recognition for loyalty and filial piety from ruler and parent lies in things. Though external things cannot be relied upon, what lies within oneself must still be fulfilled with loyalty and filial piety. Those like Longfeng and Xiaoji, though unrecognized by ruler and parent, are examples. Not only were they not trusted or loved, but they ultimately met execution, grief, and sorrow. This unreliability is what the noble person cultivates in what lies within themselves, awaiting what lies in heaven.

When wood rubs against wood, fire is born; when fire is held to metal, the metal melts. Fire does not refrain from burning what it gives rise to, nor does metal lose its nature when scattered and released. The sage harmonizes yin and yang to govern heaven and earth. When yin and yang are in accord, heaven and earth are open, and wind and rain come in their time. Only when they are thrown into turmoil and blocked do thunder and lightning strike, and water and fire burn the locust tree. Water is meant to extinguish fire, yet it gives rise to fire that burns the locust—this is like today’s lightning. When the sage reaches destiny, they are not constrained by yin and yang, free from joy and sorrow in their midst. The common person clings to external things, so the five phases become thieves to them, yin and yang become bandits, and they are ensnared by joy and sorrow without escape. The cicada, in doubt and confusion, cannot accomplish its task. When things go as desired, there is comfort; when they go awry, there is distress. When encountering circumstances, one sinks; when touching things, one stagnates. Profit and harm clash in the breast, grinding and striking to produce inner heat—this is the fire of life scorching one’s harmony and nature, leaving it incomplete.

The moon is heaven’s yin; fire is man’s yang. Human desire blazes while heavenly principle wanes—this is what is meant by *"the moon cannot overcome the fire."* The discord of yin and yang and the five phases is summoned by human desire. Only by sighing and forgetting form beyond profit and harm is the Dao fully realized.

The *Bi Xu* Annotation states: The Dao abides within, while affairs involve the external—even what lies in oneself cannot be certain, let alone external things. If one takes benevolence and righteousness as certain, then Boyi and Shuqi would not have starved to death. If one takes wisdom as certain, then Bigan would not have had his heart carved out. If one takes loyalty as certain, then Wu Yun and Chang Hong would not have been executed. Here, the loyal and worthy, the sycophantic and fortunate, both fall into the same trap and cannot escape.

"Azure" is the color of sorrow; the heart governs blood, and loyal ministers, grieving for their state, transform their blood into azure. Wu Yun and Chang Hong knew to serve their lord with utmost loyalty but did not foresee that a rebellious ruler would bring disaster. Xiaoji and Zeng Shen knew to serve their parents with utmost filial piety but did not anticipate that parental suspicion would lead to sorrow. None of them understood the principle that external things cannot be certain.

E Lai obeyed Zhou and, joining in wickedness, could not avoid calamity—like wood grinding against wood. Long Feng defied Zhou, and though good and evil differ in nature, he still met execution—like metal and fire locked in conflict. When yin and yang move in disorder, heaven and earth are greatly shaken; when loyalty and filial piety are punished, the state collapses.

Loyalty and filial piety are what ministers and children ought to fulfill. Yet if, by misfortune, one encounters a benighted ruler or stubborn father—perverse in principle and violent in nature—it is like fire in water burning the great locust tree. As the *Huainanzi* says: "An old locust tree gives birth to fire." If one is loyal and remonstrates, sorrow befalls the minister; if one flatters and deceives, sorrow befalls the ruler.

All fell into the calamity of forced action, thus their sorrows multiplied and their aspirations could not be realized. Their hearts longed to rise high and shine between heaven and earth, yet the ways of the world were choked and obstructed, drowning them in stagnation, leaving no place to extend their efforts.

Loyalty and flattery clashed, grievances and resentments flared daily, and human harmony was consumed and cast aside. The sincerity of loyalty and filial piety is like the moon; the nature of violence and tyranny is like fire. The moon is inherently no match for it. Only those who are serene, unattached, and perfectly compliant fulfill the Way of loyalty and filial piety to its utmost.

As the *Yanzhai Oral Teachings* states: In the time of Jie and Zhou, the worthy and the unworthy alike suffered disaster—nothing was certain. When Chang Hong was exiled and returned to Shu, he disemboweled himself and died. The people of Shu stored his blood in a casket, and after three years, it transformed into green jade. When Emperor Yuan of Jin withheld grain supplies and executed his minister, the minister’s blood spurted upward to the rafters. When the Northern Qi emperor, known for his bright moon-like wisdom, killed Hulü Guang, his blood pooled on the ground and would not fade—all of these are of the same kind. Both Xiaoji and Zeng Shen suffered harm for their filial piety—nothing was certain.

Wood, by nature, has no fire, yet when rubbed together, it ignites. Metal, by nature, is extremely hard, yet when exposed to fire, it melts. All speak of the uncertainty of outcomes. The character *xian* (弦) means "different." During great thunderstorms, trees may be struck and burned—all such events arise from the disorder of yin and yang. "Two entrapments" refer to the human Way and the workings of yin and yang.

"Falling into ruin" describes a state of constant dread, the heart suspended as if bound, self-tormented by entanglement, drowned in stagnation. Advantage and harm wage war within, internal heat ignites, and the harmonious qi in the chest is scorched and dispersed. Human nature is originally like the moon, but when scorched by the smoke of worldly desires, its lunar essence cannot prevail.

"Serene and unattached" describes a state of effortless compliance. The Way is exhausted only when the principles of heaven are utterly extinguished. As Master Chu’s *Superficial Observations* notes: When external concerns weigh heavily, inner essence becomes light. What one gains, one loses. All worldly concerns—fame and defamation, success and failure, gain and loss—are not inherent to one’s nature and destiny; they are external things. Yet the common world mistakes them for truth, pursues them without return, and even destroys itself without awakening. Why? Because the prevailing winds of the world esteem nothing but profit and fame, and with them come slander, praise, honor, and disgrace.

Those of insight know that profit is filth and disdain to pursue it. Instead, they aspire to fame to elevate themselves. No fame is more esteemed than loyalty and filial piety, for they can guide ruler and parent to flawlessness and contribute to the state’s governance and the flourishing of teaching. If the customs of high antiquity were still pure, with rulers as carefree as branches and people as untamed as wild deer, how could there be acts of defying the ruler’s countenance or opposing his wrath? How could there be the threats of blades, saws, cauldrons, and boiling pots?

For a minister, misfortune lies in encountering a violent ruler who defies principle and monopolizes killing—this is a time when yin and yang are disordered and thunderbolts strike at random, and only then does loyalty manifest. For a child, misfortune lies in encountering a cruel father, driven to exile and hardship—this is a time when fire burns in water and scorches the locust tree, and only then does filial piety become known.

The locust tree’s color is a pure yellow, symbolizing the harmony within nature. Wood, as a thing, when wrung yields water, when drilled yields fire—it contains the nature of both yin and yang. Fire in water is yang encroaching upon yin’s domain. When it burns the locust tree, it is excessive and overbearing—how can harmony not be harmed?

The human body is born of yin and yang and stands upon balanced harmony. Yet when assailed by external things, qi stirs within, joy and anger surge, yin and yang contend, harmony diminishes daily, and pathogenic influences invade. How long can a rootless tree endure? "Two entrapments" refer to serving one’s ruler and honoring one’s parents externally, and cultivating oneself and nurturing life internally—neither escapes sorrow and exhaustion.

The heart is anxious and pressed, aspirations unfulfilled, as if suspended between heaven and earth with no means of escape. The character *wei* (慰) is difficult to interpret; it may be borrowed from *yu* (郁), and its sound and meaning are fairly clear. It describes being oppressed by thoughts and mired in desires, weighed down by attachment to things. Thus, advantage and harm wage war, internal fire attacks, and the harmonious qi is scorched and extinguished, giving rise to sorrow.

The qi of yin and yang moves through the great void without form; its mechanisms of expansion and contraction respond to human joy and anger. Alas, humans are most intelligent—how can they not cherish and guard themselves? Another analogy compares the moon’s brightness: though great, it wanes more than it waxes, for it follows the principles of heaven. Fire’s brightness, though small, burns ever more fiercely, for it arises from human action.

Heaven’s Way abhors fullness, and its waning is easily restored. Human endeavor favors flourishing, yet its flourishing easily declines. The moon cannot overcome fire—this is an analogy for human desires flourishing and the principles of heaven being extinguished. The moon waxes and wanes according to constant measure; when it wanes and then waxes again, what brightness is lost?

When fire blazes, it scorches the plains and lights up the sky, yet when its fuel is exhausted, only ashes and dust remain. There are ministers and children who fulfill the Way yet suffer hardship—this is how the fame of loyalty and filial piety is established, while the violent hasten their own destruction. Thus, though the body may not prevail against the force of violence, in principle it prevails, just as the moon’s form may not prevail against fire, yet its brightness does.

Alas, the fulfillment of loyalty and filial piety’s fame is the misfortune of ministers and children. As the *Dao De Jing* says: When the six relations are not in harmony, there are filial and compassionate children; when the state is in chaos, there are loyal ministers. How, then, should one conduct oneself? By being serene and unattached, and exhausting the Way.

To be serene and unattached and to exhaust the Way is to forget oneself and be transformed by things. Once self and things are forgotten, how can there be sorrow from internal fire scorching harmony? When Zhuang Zhou was poor, he went to borrow grain from the Marquis of the River. The marquis said, "Very well. I will soon receive the taxes from my fief and will lend you three hundred pieces of gold—will that do?" Zhuang Zhou flushed with anger and said, "On my way here yesterday, I heard someone calling out from the middle of the road. I turned and saw a crucian carp in the rut of a cart wheel..."

When the crucian carp was asked, "What are you doing here?" it replied, "I am a wave-minister of the Eastern Sea. Might you have a斗 or a升 of water to keep me alive?" Zhuang Zhou said, "Very well. I am about to journey south to visit the kings of Wu and Yue, and I shall divert the waters of the Western River to welcome you—will that do?" The crucian carp flushed with anger and said, "I have lost my accustomed element, and I have nowhere to dwell. All I need is a斗 or a升 of water to stay alive, yet you speak of this! You might as well seek me now in the dried-fish market!"

Master Ren made a great hook and a thick black line, baited it with fifty steers, squatted on Mount Kuaiji, and cast his rod into the Eastern Sea. Day after day he fished, yet after a full year he caught nothing. Then a great fish took the bait, dragging the hook down in a sudden plunge, thrashing its fins and raising its tail. White waves rose like mountains, the sea waters churned, and the sound shook gods and spirits, startling all within a thousand *li*. Master Ren caught the fish, butchered it, and dried it into jerky. From Zhihe in the west to Cangwu in the north, there was none who did not feast on it.

Yet later generations—those of shallow talent who recite petty sayings—were all astonished and spread the tale. Those who brandish their rods in the shallows, rush to irrigate the marshes, or cling to worn-out doctrines may find it hard to catch great fish. Those who embellish trivial words to seek petty office are far from true attainment. Thus, they have never heard of Master Ren’s way, and they are far from governing the age.

Guo’s commentary: When Zhuangzi sought grain, his words were reasonable, without petty calculation. If they were not, what use would greatness be? The chapter on Master Ren shows that aspirations differ, and the proper way to govern the age varies accordingly.

Lü’s commentary: When Zhuangzi sought grain, he made clear that those who nurture life seek only to sustain themselves and do not strive for excess. When Master Ren fished, he showed that those who govern the age aim for great accomplishment and do not expect immediate results.

Yi Du’s commentary: To relieve another’s urgency, one must act in time. The Marquis of the River’s promise to lend Zhuangzi gold from his fief came too late. Thus, the crucian carp in the rut serves as a metaphor: the marquis did not grasp Zhuangzi’s urgency, just as Zhuangzi did not grasp the fish’s. The lord of Ren’s state made a great hook and thick line, showing his intent to undertake great deeds. The bait was a barren cow. When the great fish took it, its thrashing startled all within a thousand *li*—this shows that those with far-reaching aspirations may achieve late, but their impact shakes the world. When Master Ren caught the fish, there was none from Zhihe to Cangwu who did not feast on it, illustrating that great achievements benefit all under heaven. Later generations’ astonishment and retelling show that those with far-reaching aspirations, when they succeed in the world, leave their names to posterity—like Yi Yin and the Grand Duke. Minnows and petty officials are not where greatness is sought.

The *Bixu Annotation* states: "Constant companionship" refers to those who are close. Fish and water are always intimate, but now they are parted, so there is no place of rest. When a man is cold, clothing is needed; when hungry, food is needed. To channel the river’s waters to welcome the stranded fish—is this not too late? Offering a thousand gold to a tiger is not as good as a single shoulder of meat. When Lord Ren cast his great hook and thick line and caught the great fish after a year’s time, those in the world who lightly assess others and mockingly discuss affairs heard of this custom. Startled by the strange thing, they told one another—this is a metaphor that shallow learners cannot be entrusted with discussing the great enterprises of governing the age.

The "rod" (as in *ganlei*, pronounced in level tone) refers to the heavy rod of thorn bamboo, and the "line" to the silk thread. "County" (pronounced in level tone) means high, referring to lofty fame and reputation. *Yanqi’s Oral Exegesis* states: "Fief gold" is the tax revenue from a feudal estate. "Wave minister" is like a water official. "Constant companionship" means those who are always together. "Light talent" means to assess and measure. "Mocking discourse" is like groundless talk. "Lei" is a small cord. The proclamations of "county" (pronounced in departing tone) are like reward notices. To adorn trivial words to seek favor from superiors, hoping to match the standards they set—how much can one truly gain?

The character "custom" belongs to the next sentence, meaning "the scholars of the vulgar world." The *Marquis of Jianhe* in the *Garden of Stories* is written as the *Marquis of Wei Wen*; "call" (pronounced in departing tone) should be the character "xu" (also in departing tone), meaning "to deceive." "Fen" refers to the *ji* fish. "Wave minister" in the old annotation means "a minister tossed by waves." The kings of Wu and Yue are rather difficult to explain; most interpretations omit them. Only *Bixu* states: Wu and Yue are lands of water and fruit, and their kings are like rivers and seas, lords of all valleys. In Zhang Junfang’s collated edition, the character "you" is followed by "shuo" (pronounced in departing tone), but his argument is still unclear. After examining the meaning and textual variants, the general idea is roughly grasped. The character "king" was originally a "tu" (土) with an erroneous stroke added at the top—this explanation is quite concise.

The general meaning of this passage is that a person abiding in the Dao is like a fish in water and cannot be separated even for a moment. If one loses the Dao in oneself and seeks it externally, it is like hoping for the fief gold of the Marquis of Jianhe—how can this address the urgency of the present? The great hook and thick line are metaphors for wielding great means, and thus one’s gains are abundant. "Lei" should be written as "lei" (缧), meaning fishing line. The character "custom" under "wind" is redundant, resulting from a scribal error. This means that one who upholds the Dao for a long time and sees its effects cannot be demanded for immediate results. Yet when cultivation is complete and its implementation is seen, its blessings extend to the myriad things—how could it be limited to merely the regions from the Huai River to the north of Cangwu? The four characters "fen yu xia fen ran zuo se" (纷鱼下忿然作色) are a repeated scribal error.

"County" (in level tone) is better explained as referring to lofty fame and reputation.

*Collected Subtleties of the Meaning of the Southern Florescence True Scripture*, Scroll Eighty-Seven, concludes.
*Collected Subtleties of the Meaning of the Southern Florescence True Scripture*, Scroll Eighty-Eight.

The Daoist of Wulin, Chu Boxiu, on "External Things" (Chapter Two)

The Confucians use the *Odes* and *Rites* to rob graves. A great Confucian proclaims to his followers: "The east is stirring—how goes the matter?" A lesser Confucian replies: "The shroud has not yet been loosened, but there is a pearl in the mouth." The *Odes* indeed contain this verse: "The green, green wheat grows on the hillside mound. If one did not give in life, why hold a pearl in death?" Grasping the hair, twisting the skull, the Confucian uses a metal mallet to strike the jaw, carefully prying apart the cheeks—without harming the pearl in the mouth.

Guo’s commentary: The *Odes* and *Rites* are the transmitted teachings of the former kings. If the person is unworthy, the Way cannot be practiced in vain. Thus, Confucians may employ them for deceit, proving that traces alone cannot be relied upon.

Lü’s commentary: Petty Confucians draw upon the words of the former kings to further their own injustice—how is this different?

Yi Du’s commentary: The age of the former kings is long past. Confucians exploit their traces to commit robbery, even to the point of grave-robbing. Yet they cite lost poems to mock the deceased, using both to justify taking the pearl from the mouth. The traces of benevolence and righteousness are vast, so Tian Dan used them to usurp a state. The traces of the *Odes* and *Books* are small, so Confucians use them to rob graves. From the traces of the *Odes* and *Rites* expanding to benevolence and righteousness, or from the mind of grave-robbing expanding to state-usurpation—one cannot but be vigilant.

Bixu’s commentary: The *Odes* guide the will; the *Rites* guide affairs. Both transmit teachings to support the Way of governance. The noble man upholds the *Odes* and *Rites* to cultivate himself; the petty man recites the *Odes* and *Rites* to commit theft. Noble men are few, petty men many—thus the traces of the sages benefit the world little and harm it much. Thieves do not dig up the graves of Boyi and Shuqi but must open the tombs of Jie and Zhou—there is a reason for this. Hence, "excessive hoarding invites great loss" is the profound warning of Laozi.

*Yanzhai Oral Teachings*: This metaphor refers to the wandering persuaders of the time, who borrowed the words of sages to embellish their deceit. "Proclaiming from above to below" is called *lu*. The *lu* transmitter is the great Confucian who speaks first to inform those below.

The verdant wheat in two lines eulogizes the grave-field,
The next two lines satirize the wealthy—an ancient lost poem.
Touching his temples and descending,
It teaches to take the pearl from the mouth without harm.

The *Odes* and *Rites* serve the world
To rectify the Way of governance and stem its excesses,
Proceeding alongside the law,
Enabling people to rise and establish themselves.
Sages do not appear in every age,
Thus their foresight runs deep,
Striving to wholly reform the world’s ills.
Emerging from ritual, one must enter the law;
Where ritual is fulfilled, the law may be abolished.
The sage’s heart is fundamentally empty—
Yet how can the decadent customs of a declining age
Exploit their traces for deceit?
To the point of robbing graves without remorse—
This harms not only the living,
But even the dead cannot rest in their graves!
How can one fully recount the poison of its spread?
And yet they still cite the *Odes* to admonish—
This is doing what ought not be done,
Using what ought not be used.

Zhuangzi’s lament for the world was earnest,
Yet he could effect no change,
So he resorted to oblique metaphors to convey his meaning.
As for Lu’s reputation for many Ru,
When one examines the reality, only one was truly a Ru—
Thus this chapter is not spoken in vain.
It aims to condemn their hearts and correct their teachings,
To make them do what the *Odes* and *Rites* demand,
Fulfilling all that Ru conduct should fulfill.
It further serves as a warning against lavish burials,
Reviving the simple and honest customs of later ages.
Raising the net’s headrope, all its meshes align—
How could this not greatly benefit the Way of governance?

When Lao Lai’s disciple went out to gather firewood,
He encountered Confucius and returned to report:
“There is someone over there—
Tall above, hastening below,
His eyes like one scheming for all under heaven,
Yet I know not whose son he is.”
Lao Lai said: “That is Qiu.”
He summoned him to come.
Confucius arrived.
Lao Lai said: “Qiu, cast off your bodily pride and your cultivated wisdom—
Only then can you be a noble man!”
Confucius bowed and withdrew,
His expression altered as he asked:
“May I inquire about the path of my work?”
Lao Lai said: “To be unable to bear the world’s wounds,
Yet rush toward the calamities of ten thousand generations—
Is this not stubbornly clinging to what is precious?
Or has your strategy fallen short?
Kindness that startles with false delight
Becomes a lifelong disgrace—
This is merely the conduct of the mediocre,
Drawn together by fame, bound by concealment.
Rather than praising Yao and condemning Jie,
It is better to forget both and seal off what you praise.
To turn back is not without harm;
To act is not without wrong.
The sage hesitates to initiate affairs,
Yet each endeavor succeeds.
Alas!
Why must you persist in your pride?”

Guo’s Commentary:
It is merely the superior hastening the inferior. Yet afterward, the branches tower over the root. Gazing at him, one sees a puppet-like figure, as though managing another’s affairs—this is to say, he can cast off form and abandon knowledge, and thus be deemed a noble man. Bowing and withdrawing, he receives his words. The question is posed to make Lao Lai clarify the impossibility of following such a path. If one acts for a single generation, then the paths of ten thousand generations become blocked. If one simply allows things to take their course, the people’s nature will not be impoverished but will all possess their own, and there will be no matter beyond one’s strategy. To bestow kindness that startles with delight—without kindness, there is disgrace; yet kindness cannot be prolonged, so a single act of kindness brings lifelong shame. To speak of following such a path is to say one must not recklessly bestow kindness. "Concealment" refers to binding one’s traces. To follow is to preserve wholeness; to be still is to attain correctness. Affairs do not stray from their root, and thus his endeavors always succeed. Pride cannot be borne, so he abandons it and does not claim it as his own.

Lü’s Commentary:
Laozi and Confucius were originally without conflict, yet those who study Confucius in later ages cling to his traces and fail to grasp his heart; thus Zhuangzi offers this discourse. From "the superior hastening the inferior" to "whose disciple is this?"—these describe those who seek the sage by his appearance. "Pride in one’s person" refers to the demeanor of one who practices and exalts himself. "Knowledge" is not the abundant virtue of one who seems foolish. Great chaos arose between Yao and Shun, yet now, unable to bear the wounds of a single generation, one acts to save it—this is to rush toward the calamities of ten thousand generations. Is the enterprise of abundance inherently impoverished? Or has one’s strategy fallen short? Neither is the case. Kindness is not great wisdom, yet to take delight in it as though rushing toward joy brings lifelong disgrace—one would still refrain from such acts. As for those who draw one another by fame and bind one another by concealment, these are merely the conduct of the mediocre. How much less should a noble man who embodies the Dao act thus? Even they cannot utterly cast aside sagely knowledge, forget both good and evil, and yet still rush toward the calamities of ten thousand generations. The Dao does nothing that is not action, yet to turn back is to invite harm; to act is to invite wrong. How can there be anything worthy of praise? To hesitate like one crossing a river in winter, to be cautious as though fearing one’s four neighbors—this is what is meant by "hesitating." Why must one bear it and claim it, believing that without pride it cannot be attained?

Yi Du’s Commentary:
"Branches towering" describes a back slightly bent, leaning forward. "Behind the ears" is the mark of a noble person. To gaze as though managing the four seas is to say one’s vision is broad and selfless. "Pride in one’s person and display of knowledge" means one has not yet been able to leave no trace in the world. "May the path of my work be followed?" refers to following the traces of the Dao. As for benevolence, righteousness, sageliness, and wisdom—these are what the sage, unable to bear the suffering of a single generation, enacts to save his time. Yet later ages rely on these remnants, turning them into harm. To govern the world by sagely traces is to cause people to be oppressed and humiliated, leading to obstinacy and poverty, forgetting the principle of simplicity and failing to attain the true Dao. To bestow kindness that startles with delight—without kindness, there is disgrace. The mediocre are of a nature that can rise or fall; if they follow traces, they ascend—why must one bestow kindness? Kindness is what petty men cherish, so the noble man does not adopt it. "Drawing one another" refers to chasing fame; "binding one another" refers to delighting in concealment. Chasing fame is to align with the people’s calamities; delighting in concealment is to fulfill one’s own desires—both are partial and thus belong to the mediocre. To forget both and seal off what one praises is to have neither affirmation nor denial. Human nature, when turned against, is harmed; when followed, is preserved. When moved, it strays; when still, it is correct. To hesitate is not to rush, and thus one follows the principles of nature and destiny, always succeeding. To seek speed is not to reach one’s goal. Confucius bore the Dao and acted in his time, yet in the end displayed pride, so Lao Lai admonished him with these words.

Bi Xu’s Commentary:
"Pride in one’s person" refers to his desire to expose filth; "display of knowledge" refers to his intent to startle the foolish—thus he is instructed to abandon both. The wounds of a single generation are a matter of fate; to endure them is to escape temporarily. The calamities of ten thousand generations are a matter of traces; to act with arrogance and alarm is to fail to save them. He further inquired of Confucius: having traveled and suffered hardship, did he uphold the Dao so firmly that he ended in poverty? Or did his strategies and undertakings fall short? To take delight in kindness and startle others is what the sage finds shameful. The nature of the mediocre is easily led: in times of order, they draw one another toward fame; in times of chaos, they bind one another in retreat. Confucius, in his confusion and actions, praised Yao and condemned Jie—if sagely traces were obliterated, what would there be to praise or blame? To follow the world is not to oppose it, and thus one preserves oneself; to be still in contemplation is not to be disturbed, and thus one attains correctness. The sage acts with ease in the Dao, and his achievements naturally succeed; even when they do, he does not claim them—how much less when they do not? To forget words is to be without encumbrance; to bear records is to pride oneself on fame.

Yan Zhai’s Oral Teachings:
"Branches" means slight; it describes a back slightly curved. To gaze as though managing the four seas is to look upon the world with concern. "Pride in one’s person" refers to the demeanor of one who exalts himself in conduct; "knowledge" refers to thought and deliberation. "Startle" is akin to arrogance. Given this, you are right to be impoverished. To draw one another by fame and bind one another in schemes of concealment—these are the acts of mediocre men. To forget both Yao and Jie is to be without praise or blame. To turn back is to go against the principles of nature; to act without stillness is to invite nothing but wrong and perversion. The sage acts only when unavoidable, and thus always succeeds. How can you bear pride and take it as your own? Lao Lai’s disciple described the Master’s appearance in three phrases, with the last seeming to capture the heart of the sage. Without eyes that transcend the dust, one could not easily speak of this—it resembles the words of the gatekeeper Qiu Zhang describing Master Wen. Yet his teacher already understood him; the hearts of sages and worthies commune with the divine in this way. "Pride in one’s person" means to make one’s whole body a display of boasting; "demeanor" refers to an air of arrogance; "knowledge" refers to excessive scheming.

All these are sufficient to invite calamity, hence the need to abandon them. *Jing* (驚), here written as *wu* (骛), signifies distress—unable to bear the suffering of the age, one acts with benevolence and righteousness to rescue it. Later generations, clinging to traces, fall into corruption, racing onward without cease.

Yet was he truly so resolute in poverty as to hold the world in light regard? Or did he lack the foresight to consider this? Why then did his eagerness to bestow kindness manifest so visibly, impossible to conceal?

This is a rebuke of the Master’s restless travels and embassies, which exhausted his body and spirit—nothing but reckless haste. A lifetime of disgrace! Such are the tracks of the common folk. Where there are tracks, men vie for fame; where there is retreat, they bind themselves in seclusion. Praise for Yao and blame for Jie arise from this. If both were forgotten, how could Yao and Jie be distinguished?

*Fan* (反) means to return to what was said before. Those who cannot forget both praise and blame harbor love and hatred within, harming both themselves and others. *Dong* (动) means lacking inner constancy. Those who delight in praise and resent blame follow the whims of things, their conduct straying into perversion.

Thus the sage waits for the right moment to act, proceeding slowly to undertake affairs, and so always succeeds. How could one bear to take pride in one’s abilities, yet ultimately fail to escape self-importance?

The Master and Lao Lai—one emerged to serve Yao, the other withdrew like Xu You—were but parables in the *Nanhua*, meant to warn a world that, not knowing the times, forces action to seek renown. This is no true censure.

The Lord of Song dreamed in the dead of night of a man with disheveled hair peering through the side gate, who said: *"I come from Zailu’s deep, sent by the Clear River as an envoy to the River Lord. The fisherman Yu Ju caught me."* The Lord awoke and had the dream interpreted. *"This is a divine turtle!"* he was told.

The Lord asked: *"Is there a fisherman named Yu Ju?"*
His attendants replied: *"There is."*
The Lord said: *"Summon Yu Ju to court."*

The next day, Yu Ju appeared.
The Lord asked: *"What did you catch?"*
Yu Ju answered: *"My net snared a white turtle, five feet in circumference."*
The Lord said: *"Present your turtle."*

When the turtle arrived, the Lord wavered—first wanting to kill it, then to spare it. Doubtful, he consulted the oracle, which said: *"Slaying the turtle for divination will bring good fortune."* So they split the turtle open, drilling seventy-two holes without a single miscast.

Confucius said: *"The divine turtle could appear in the Lord’s dream but could not escape Yu Ju’s net. Though it knew how to divine seventy-two times without error, it could not avoid the disaster of having its entrails torn out. Thus, even knowledge has its limits, and the divine has its blind spots. Though one may possess supreme wisdom, ten thousand schemers may still outmaneuver it."*

The fish fears not the net but the pelican.
Abandon petty knowledge, and great wisdom will become clear; abandon contrived goodness, and true goodness will arise of itself.
An infant, though born without a stern teacher, can speak—by dwelling among those who can speak.

Guo’s Annotation: The insufficiency of the divine is thus—only by abiding in stillness within one’s capacity, without scheming beyond, can one remain whole. To employ one’s own wisdom while relying on the schemes of many is like a net without intent, thus catching fish.
Petty knowledge is self-serving; great wisdom entrusts itself to things. Abandon contrived goodness, and there will be nothing to covet; with nothing to covet, one will not grow arrogant but will be good of itself.
To float freely without practice and yet possess ability is not to strain toward learning from others.

Lü’s Annotation: Though the turtle possesses knowledge, it cannot escape harm; though it has divinity, it cannot evade the net—this is what it means to be constrained, to have limits.
Thus, those who follow the Dao sever sageliness and discard knowledge. Even with supreme wisdom, ten thousand schemers may outmaneuver it; the few cannot overcome the many, for their nature is thus.

The fish fears not the net but the pelican—because the pelican has intent, while the net has none.
Therefore, abandon petty knowledge, and great wisdom will become clear; abandon contrived goodness, and true goodness will arise. Then how can a ruler rely on knowledge to govern?
An infant, though without a stern teacher, can speak—if one dwells among the people with cunning, can one prevent them from knowing?

Yi Du’s Annotation: To discern the fortune and misfortune of others is the turtle’s knowledge. To be disemboweled yet retain its numen is the turtle’s divinity. Yet it could not escape Yu Ju’s net nor avoid the Lord’s calamity—thus, knowledge has its limits, and the divine has its blind spots.
The sage gathers the goodness of all people and unites the wisdom of the world, thus becoming supremely wise.
Only by being without intent toward things can one attain them—thus, the fish fears not the net but the pelican.

Abandon petty knowledge, and wisdom will encompass all things; abandon petty goodness, and goodness will flow from one’s nature.
An infant, without a teacher, can speak—gradually influenced without awareness, how could this be sought through knowledge?

Bi Xu’s Annotation: The turtle’s seventy-two divinations and the numbers eight and nine—hence Guan Ziming’s *Yi Zhuan* takes seventy-two as the measure of the calendar. The toad repels weapons yet cannot escape the slaughter of midsummer; the rooster crows at dawn yet cannot flee the cauldron’s fate. What is numinous in one regard must be dull in another—this is what it means for knowledge to have limits and the divine to have blind spots.
The multitude’s schemes multiply with knowledge; the fish fears what has intent.
To abandon the knowledge of others and cultivate one’s own clarity; to forsake goodness that strays from the Dao and preserve the goodness of self-wholeness—this is to draw near the Dao.

An infant’s simplicity gradually scatters by dwelling among those who can speak. Once it can speak, it distinguishes right and wrong, and profit and harm arise.

*Yanzhai Oral Teachings*: "Amen," the crooked and narrow gate. To name it as knowledge is to invite its exhaustion.
Even one with supreme wisdom—how can they overcome the schemes of ten thousand?

The pelican harms fish with intent—no net compares. I have intent, and so do others; if one can relinquish petty knowledge and entrust all to spontaneity, then great knowledge becomes luminous. Abandon the impulse to name one’s goodness, and goodness will return of itself.

The stone (同 *shuo*, "vast")—a vast teacher can instruct others, yet an infant speaks without instruction: both are metaphors for spontaneity. *Zailu* is the name of a deep pool, the dwelling of the divine turtle. When it serves as the emissary of the Clear River to the River Lord, it is enslaved by knowledge, descending from purity into turbidity—thus it cannot escape exhaustion. Yet it may still appear in dreams to the Primordial Sovereign, for its numinous spirit is not extinguished.

The turtle is a yin creature with a carapace, its white color corresponding to yang; its shell spans five feet, aligning with the Five Phases. When divination by killing the turtle yields auspicious omens, it reveals that its signs are not for private gain—though it brings no benefit to itself, it manifests numinosity for others. Seventy-two drillings leave no crack unread: its substance is exquisite, perfectly attuned to celestial patterns. Yet when it enters the net, it cannot escape; when its entrails are carved out, it cannot avoid its fate. Its spirit and knowledge have their limits—none of these can be relied upon.

Had it not served as the Clear River’s emissary but dragged its tail through the mud, preserving the knowledge of non-knowledge and the spirit of non-spirit, this would be the acme of wisdom and numinosity. Then what fear would it have of nets and snares?

This passage resembles the *Records of the Grand Historian: Treatise on Turtles and Divination*, though there the fisherman is named Yu Ju, the same figure here. Thus, even one of supreme wisdom must guard against the schemes of the multitude, which may prevail, and dare not rely entirely on their own power. The schemes of the many are no different from the pelican’s predation of fish—not like a net, which is mindless and can be evaded.

To avoid calamity, one must discard one’s own dim and petty knowledge and adopt the collective counsel as wisdom. Then great clarity will pervade all things, and by forsaking one’s own goodness, the world’s goodness will return to them. Like an infant dwelling among those who can speak, in time they transform together, unaware of how or why it comes to pass.

*Collected Explications of the Ocean of Meanings in the True Scripture of the Southern Florescence*, Scrolls 88–89

The Daoist of Wulin, Chu Boxiu, *Outer Things* (Chapter Three)

Hui Zi said to Zhuangzi: "Your words are useless."
Zhuangzi replied: "Only when one knows the useless can one speak of the useful. The earth is neither narrow nor small, yet what man uses of it is only enough to stand upon. If, however, one were to dig beneath one’s feet to the Yellow Springs, would that space still be of use?"
Hui Zi said: "It would be useless."
Zhuangzi said: "Thus the usefulness of the useless is made clear."

Zhuangzi said: "Can one who is capable of wandering choose not to wander? Can one who is incapable of wandering force themselves to wander? The will that drifts with the current, the conduct that cuts off all ties—alas, are these not beyond the capacity of one of supreme wisdom and profound virtue? To fall and not return, to rush like fire and not look back—though they may serve as ruler and minister to one another, it is but a matter of time. When the age changes, they will have no means to hold one another in contempt. Thus the perfected person does not drift with the current.

Those who revere the ancient and despise the present are but followers of the scholars. Moreover, if one views the present age through the lens of the men of Xi Wei’s time, who could remain unmoved by its waves? Only the perfected person can wander through the world without becoming eccentric, adapting to others without losing themselves. They teach without instructing, and respond to others’ intentions without being bound by them."

Guo’s commentary: "The sage responds from within, acting in accord with the moment; their words arise externally, flowing with the circumstances. When circumstances flow smoothly, affairs are unobstructed; when the external is clear, the internal is put to use—such is the principle of mutual necessity. What one’s nature can do, one cannot but do; what one’s nature cannot do, one cannot force. Only when nothing restrains it do all things attain their due, though they know not how they attain it. Without virtue of the utmost depth, none can uphold their will and conduct or trust in their extraordinary abilities.

What people love, they do not shun, be it right or wrong; life and death alike are embraced, and when the age changes, none can hold another in contempt—this is the great equality. Only by meeting each moment and following it can one move with transformation. Yet scholars revere the ancient and despise the present, losing sight of the source and allowing things to each preserve their own self."

Lü’s commentary: "Worldly sentiment deems those with knowledge and ability as useful, and those without as useless, not realizing that the useless is the very source of the useful. From the perspective of the Dao, what the world calls knowledge and ability—how small is their use compared to the space one’s feet occupy upon the earth! As *Liezi* says: 'The supreme wanderer knows not where they go; the supreme observer knows not what they see. Every thing wanders, every thing observes. This is what I call wandering, what I call observing.' Zhuangzi’s wandering is no different.

For one who has attained the Dao, there is nothing that is not the Dao—thus every thing wanders, every thing observes. Even if they wished not to wander, they could not. But one who has not attained the Dao, though they may wish to wander, cannot. The will that drifts and flees follows custom and becomes base; the conduct that cuts off all ties withdraws from the world and becomes lofty. Neither is the task of one of supreme wisdom and profound virtue, for both are obscured by partiality. To the point of falling and not returning, rushing like fire and not looking back—though they may serve as ruler and minister for a time, it is but a matter of circumstance. When the age changes, none can hold another in contempt, for their deviation from the Dao is the same.
