One of supreme wisdom and profound virtue does not become base through drifting nor lofty through cutting ties, but simply follows the Dao. Thus the perfected person does not drift with the current, leaving no trace. If one reveres the ancient and despises the present, viewing the present age through the degeneracy of Xi Wei’s time, how can their heart remain calm and unwavering? Only the perfected person can wander through the world without eccentric conduct, externally adapting to others while inwardly not losing themselves. They respond to others and teach them, yet it is not instruction; they grasp others’ intentions and follow them, yet do not become bound to them.

What they teach is what the other already possesses, not something foreign imposed upon them. If one cannot comprehend the intentions of all under heaven, then 'this' and 'that' arise. But if one grasps their intentions and follows them, where is the 'other'? This is the wandering of the perfected person."

Yi Du’s commentary: "The use of the useful is as a vessel; the use of the useless is as the Dao. Vessels have limits, and their use is small. The Dao is boundless, and its use is great. Zhuangzi’s discourse on the Dao is vast and expansive, so Hui Zi doubted its usefulness. He was told that only by knowing the useless could one speak of the useful. It is like walking upon the earth, though it is vast, what one uses is only enough for one’s feet. Beyond that, one fears sinking and dares not proceed—thus the usefulness of the useless is made clear. The *Free and Easy Wandering* chapter’s discussion of the great gourds and great trees shares this meaning.

To wander is to move or rest as one pleases, at ease. All people possess this ease by nature; whether one can or cannot depends on learning or not learning. Through learning, one returns to the root and can wander. Though one may not strive for external appearances, there is nothing that is not at ease—this is the ability to wander. Without learning, one is obscured by things; though one may strive daily for external appearances, they cannot be at ease.

To drift is to chase after things without returning; to flee is to shrink back without advancing. To cut off is to act decisively; to erase one’s traces is to obliterate one’s path—all are fixated on one side. If one takes this as wisdom, there will be things one does not know; if one takes this as virtue, there will be things one cannot bear. Thus the spirit falls and does not recover, the heart races like fire and does not look back. Though they may serve as ruler and minister for a time, it is merely coincidence—what is noble or base? The perfected person simply follows where they go, meeting each moment and adapting to it, without lingering. If one views the present age from the time before the Three Sovereigns, who would not be swept up in its waves? Only the perfected person wanders with the world, acting from their natural disposition, thus able to adapt to things without losing themselves.

They teach when others come to them, yet never make a study of it; they follow others’ intentions and respond, yet do not take them as 'other.'"

The *Inner Chapters* states: "If they become infants, then join them as an infant—this is right." Master Bixu annotates: People regard the space beyond their leaping bounds as useless ground, yet if one were to dig downward to the Yellow Springs, leaving only room for one’s feet, they could not take even a single dignified step. It is like planting crops—only with ample open space can they flourish. Thus the usefulness of the seemingly useless becomes clear.

For one who roams and studies the Dao, it is the nature of their being—how could they be made not to roam? For one who cannot roam and study the Dao, it is also the nature of their being—how could they be forced to roam? The world does not know its own measure, recklessly pursuing drifting, fleeing, and escaping. Those who act with resolute distinction, striving for lofty heights through sheer will, all fail to follow the path of supreme wisdom and profound virtue.

"Falling and collapsing" refers to abandoning study and neglecting one’s work. "Racing like fire" describes those who toil in study yet gain no progress, each chasing their own pursuits without looking back, merely taking turns as ruler and minister in their time. What distinction of noble or base is there? Only the perfected person acts with principle in their comings and goings, following their own aspirations.

Yet scholars value the distant and disregard the near—this flaw has persisted for ages. Viewing the present age from the time of the ancient sages, who is not swept up in its waves, losing their true nature? The perfected person moves with the world’s rise and fall, responding outwardly to things while inwardly preserving their authenticity. What others teach need not be learned as worldly ways, yet one may follow their intent without treating them as separate. This is how one remains whole in the world—this is called "roaming."

*The Oral Teachings of Yanzhai* states: "Dian" means to dig. If beyond the space for one’s feet lies only a deep abyss, one cannot walk—hence the usefulness of the useless, the joy of the roamer. Some can, some cannot—this illustrates those who attain and those who do not. "Drifting and fleeing" means chasing after things. "Resolute distinction" means setting oneself apart. The person of supreme wisdom and profound virtue cultivates naturalness and acts without contrivance.

"Falling and collapsing" means sinking into delusion. Worldly affairs race like fire in pursuit of profit and fame—these are all those who cannot turn back. Though there may be distinctions of ruler and minister, noble and base in their time, what remains after their bodies perish? Only the perfected person acts without attachment to the world, seeing past and present as one. Scholars revere antiquity and despise the present, unaware of the world’s changes. Viewing today from the vantage of high antiquity, all appear as those swept up in waves, losing their nature.

To roam the world without eccentricity is not to judge by past or present. To follow others without losing oneself is to blend outwardly with the world while inwardly preserving something. What others teach, they deem correct—I need not learn it, yet I follow their intent without division between self and other. This is the meaning of "equalizing things" in the *Qi Wu Lun*.

"Roaming" means wandering freely in the realm of the useless, fulfilling the great use of preserving oneself. Only those who attain the Dao can do this. Those who can do so cannot but roam; those who cannot should not be forced. Most of the world drifts and flees in pursuit of things, while others adopt resolute, lofty conduct, rigid and unyielding, seeing the world as a trap or snare. Some even drown themselves with stones or burn to death clinging to trees—how can they hope for carefree roaming? Thus, none of these follow the path of supreme wisdom and profound virtue. Most stumble and race after fame and profit to console their hearts.

Though distinctions of ruler and minister may exist for a time, if circumstances change, there is no basis for noble or base. Only the Dao is honored throughout the world; those who defy it cannot gain esteem. Thus, the perfected person lets things flow without obstruction, roaming together with the single qi of heaven and earth. Past and present follow a constant principle—if I can transform things, I may turn the present into antiquity. Why value the ear and disparage the eye, falsely distinguishing noble and base?

Moreover, viewing the present age from high antiquity, who is not swept up in its waves? Forgetting past and present, roaming the world without eccentric conduct, following others without losing oneself—taking the hearts of the many as one’s own heart, one’s own heart is fulfilled. This is called "turning the present into antiquity"—what noble or base is there? When Confucius told Ran Qiu that the past is like the present, this was his meaning.

Thus, when people come to learn, one teaches according to their nature, not forcing what they cannot do. One follows their intent without treating them as separate. In this way, past and present, self and others roam together as one. Though separated by ten thousand years, ten thousand miles, or ten thousand people, it is no different from gathering in the same hall or sharing the same seat at Master Zhuang’s gate, delighting in the Dao of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi.

This describes how the perfected person engages with the world: not only can they roam freely in the Dao, but they can also roam together with all things. Thus they unify the hundred kings under one Dao, harmonizing ten thousand generations into purity.

Eyes that penetrate are called clarity; ears that penetrate are called acuity; noses that penetrate are called sensitivity; mouths that penetrate are called sweetness; minds that penetrate are called wisdom; wisdom that penetrates is called virtue. The Dao does not desire obstruction—obstruction leads to choking, and if choking persists without cease, it causes damage, from which many harms arise.

Living things rely on breath, and if it is not smooth, it is not heaven’s fault. Heaven pierces them day and night without ceasing, yet people block their own openings. The womb has its layered chambers, and the mind has its celestial roaming. If a room has no empty space, mother and daughter-in-law will quarrel; if the mind has no celestial roaming, the six senses will clash.

The great forests and mountains are good for people, yet even the spirit cannot prevail. Virtue overflows into fame, fame overflows into excess, schemes rely on knowledge, knowledge arises from contention, rigidity grows from clinging, official duties are settled by the needs of the many, and when spring rains come in season, plants and trees flourish vigorously. Weeding and hoeing begin then, and more than half of the plants and trees that should be cultivated are lost without knowing why.

Guo Xiang annotates: When what should flow is blocked, principles cannot be released and trample one another.

All rooted beings possess no knowledge, nor do they rely on breath. *Yin* means "proper." Breath does not arise from knowledge; only through knowledge does one lose propriety, and losing propriety leads to obstruction. Thus, knowledge relies on breath, but breath does not rely on knowledge. Yet when knowledge is employed by desire, it is called "human"—not the tally of inevitability.

The heavenly principle operates in constant motion; when emotions do not interfere and one follows heaven, the apertures open. *Lang* means "spacious." *You* means "unfettered." *Boqi* refers to quarrels. *Rang* means "conflict." The natural principle finds passage through things. When fame is lofty, profit runs deep—thus those who cultivate virtue exceed what is proper. To suppress violence is to make fame surpass virtue. Urgency then compels the weighing of schemes. When all is at peace, knowledge serves no use. *Chai* means "blockage." Official duties are established because the many have disparate needs.

The arising of all things has its cause; affairs emerge from principle, so one remains unaware. Lü’s annotation: If the human ear, eye, nose, and mouth are not obstructed by sounds, colors, scents, and flavors, they become keen, bright, fragrant, and sweet. If knowledge and virtue are obstructed, they choke and fail to flow. When obstruction grows severe, they trample one another, and gain and loss wage war in the breast—how long before they lead to ruin? This is how the afflictions of yin and yang arise and the myriad harms are born.

All sentient beings live when breath abides and die when breath departs. The ebb and flow of breath follow the cycles of *zi* and *wu*, moving left and right with yin and yang, ceaselessly communing with primordial *qi*—this is heaven’s piercing and opening. Day and night are balanced, never diminishing, yet people obstruct their apertures with sounds, colors, scents, and flavors, preventing their flow—hence their decline and failure to remain proper.

If one can be tranquil, empty, and desireless, true *qi* will follow; if the body is aligned and perception unified, heavenly harmony will arrive. Thus, the womb has layered chambers, firmly encircling life’s purity, so that no filth may invade; the mind has celestial roaming, free and unburdened, so that no affairs may disturb it. A room must have empty space to distinguish hierarchy—otherwise, mother and daughter-in-law will bicker and quarrel. The mind must have celestial roaming to rise above the dust—otherwise, the six apertures will clash and conflict. The six apertures are the ear, eye, nose, mouth, mind, and knowledge.

If one truly understands celestial roaming, though dwelling in the human world, no thing can disturb the heart, and the spirit is sufficient to prevail. Why praise great forests and mountains as good? Supreme virtue does not act as virtue, thus it has no fame. When fame exists, virtue overflows and becomes excess, and fame itself overflows—then schemes must rely on persuasion, knowledge must emerge from contention, and blockage must arise from clinging. This is how affairs are settled by the needs of the many. Sounds, colors, scents, and flavors block the exterior, while thoughts, worries, knowledge, and schemes block the interior, preventing mutual flow.

The cultivation of the Daoist’s mind governs it before disorder arises—better than waiting for plants and trees to flourish wildly before weeding and hoeing. Du’s annotation: *Che* means "unobstructed and unburdened." When all six are unobstructed, there is nothing one cannot hear clearly, nothing one cannot taste sweetly, nothing one cannot know. Entering nowhere without self-possession—this is called returning to the root. Thus, one can inwardly see and reverse-hear, seeking within the ear, eye, nose, mouth, mind, and knowledge. Only then are the six roots liberated, free from the dust of the world—this is how one enters the Dao.

If the six are obstructed, they are blocked by things, trampling one another and harming all beings. All sentient beings rely on breath as their master. Breath—the coming and going of vital *qi*—originates in the heart and manifests through the nose. Earlier, the six were valued for their unobstructedness, and breath is their master. When human likes and dislikes miss the mark, it is because things obstruct them—this is not heaven’s fault.

The natural principle pierces and flows through all things, day and night without ceasing, never diminishing. Yet people, through the six senses, obstruct their own apertures. The womb has layered chambers to contain the five viscera and circulate *qi* and fluids. Celestial roaming is the mind’s emptiness and freedom, where the Dao arises within. A room, where mother and daughter-in-law dwell together, if not empty, leads to competition over hierarchy. The mind, assailed by myriad desires, if not empty, leads to conflict among the six apertures—this is how life is harmed.

If the mind is empty, life and death, shock and fear cannot enter; there is nowhere one does not find ease. Great forests and mountains are where the spirit resides, thus they are good for people. People know the goodness of mountains and forests but do not know the spirit that governs them. The spirit’s dwelling in mountains and forests is like the natural principle’s dwelling in the mind.

Virtue is the self-possession of one’s nature. When fame arises, virtue overflows; when virtue overflows, people no longer value virtue but fame. Contending for fame leads to violence. *Shuo* means "urgency in speech." *Zheng* is the tool of conflict. Schemes seek speed, thus they arise from persuasion. Knowledge seeks victory, thus it arises from contention. *Chai* refers to inner blockage by desires, thus it arises from clinging—none of these are natural. The many have disparate needs, and official duties align with them, thus affairs are settled decisively.

In the season of spring rains, grasses and trees surge forth from the earth, and if they fail to break through, they grow in fury. Then farmers begin to sharpen their tools, and more than half of what is planted ends up inverted. All things, when planted upside down, have no principle of life—yet in spring, even those inverted will grow. This is the work of creation, and none know why it is so. All this speaks of following the principle of naturalness.

The *Bixu Annotation* states: If one can withdraw the gaze and turn the hearing inward, draw in the breath and rinse the fluids, empty the center to conceal its function, then the six affairs will all be penetrated, and subtlety will reach its utmost without addition. Otherwise, there will be obstruction and turmoil, disorder between above and below, and all manner of illnesses will arise.

All sentient beings possessing awareness depend on breath to live. When the six senses are obstructed and the breath weakens, it is caused by the calamity of desires and aversions—this is not the fault of Heaven. The primordial qi flows through the apertures and cavities of all things and humanity, ascending and descending day and night without end. Yet when it is blocked by cravings, the empty cavities become stagnant—where then can the spirit find its abode?

Within the body lie the cinnabar field, the Three Offices, the golden hall and jade chamber, and the womb with its layered chambers. In the heart is an aperture called the Heavenly Palace, where the spirit roams and rests. If the chamber is cramped, mother and daughter-in-law turn against each other; if the heart is obstructed, desires and aversions multiply in chaos.

Thus, lush forests are the beauty of hills and mountains, but when the forest is felled, the vital atmosphere is diminished. Extraordinary talent is the beauty of the scholar, but when talent is overtaxed, the spirit is depleted. Those who boast of fame damage their virtue; those with violent ambitions harm their reputation. Planning values deep stillness—if one is hasty in deliberation, one becomes shallow and crude. Wisdom should be concealed; if it emerges through contention, it competes with things.

If one can stand firm like a stockade, unshaken and self-preserving, one avoids being harmed by external things. Official duties, when aligned with the needs of the many, are decisive in public matters, but in private, they lead to self-sacrifice. When virtue takes form, fame and knowledge become manifest, and violent contention arises; when spring rains fall, grasses and trees grow, and hoes and plows are set to work.

The multitude, in going against the Dao to seek life, are like grasses and trees that turn their roots upward yet wish to flourish. The *Yanqi Oral Teachings* state: When one attains the principle of naturalness and achieves great penetration, then what the ears and eyes perceive becomes true clarity, what the nose and mouth savor becomes true sweetness, what the heart knows becomes true knowledge, and virtue becomes true virtue.

*Geng* means "obstruction." *Zhen* refers to footprints that people see. When the Dao is obstructed, one becomes burdened by form and traces, and manifold harms arise.

Breath is life—what is called "nature" is this life, which all people possess. Only after receiving this nature of life does one gain awareness. The means by which one is aware depends on this breath. If it reaches a point where it does not accord with principle, how could Heaven have cut it off? The principle of Heaven within the human body manifests day and night, yet people block their heart’s apertures with worldly desires.

The *bao* is the membrane. The spaciousness is governed by the heart, the lord. To follow Heaven’s principle with ease is called "Heavenly wandering." If the chamber is narrow, mother and daughter-in-law quarrel—this illustrates how, when the heart is obstructed, the six senses contend.

Great hills and mountains are seen as good by people because, in ordinary times, their ears and eyes are narrow and cannot preserve the spirit of naturalness to overcome worldly desires. Seeking fame and profit causes one’s inherent nature to overflow; violent and hasty temperaments cause one’s reputation to overflow as well—both lead to the loss of name.

*Shuo* is like a drawn bowstring, implying urgency. Urgency leads to reliance on cunning schemes; contention leads to the emergence of such schemes. Stubborn clinging gives rise to the frustration of obstruction and discontent.

Those who seek to align with the needs of the many fall into the flaw of obstinate incomprehension—this speaks of the foolish child who wishes to settle official matters, yet official matters cannot be settled. When spring rains come and grasses and trees grow in fury, people sharpen their farming tools to uproot them. Do they do this with the intent to harm the grasses and trees? No—it is for the sake of cultivation, and they cannot do otherwise. That which grows grows of itself; that which is uprooted is uprooted of itself. When grasses and trees are removed, what is planted grows in their place—this is its completion, its destruction. Its destruction is its completion.

From this perspective, gain and loss, life and death—all should be left to naturalness. From the overflow of virtue downward, all are flaws of the accommodating heart. If one can be without such accommodation, then one attains Heavenly wandering.

The ears, eyes, nose, mouth, and heart—if they can be unobstructed and free from entanglement, it is because knowledge is penetrated by virtue. If virtue does not flow through them, all five become obstructed, the apertures and cavities are blocked, worldly desires surge and trample, and harm multiplies.

The breath that animates living things serves to circulate the qi throughout the body, harmonize with the balance of Heaven and Earth, and ascend and descend to nourish flourishing. It should endure without decline, growing stronger with age—this is the very doctrine upheld by those who cultivate life. Yet if one fails to nurture its source and instead engages in activities that obstruct it, this is not the way of flowing with the primordial qi of Heaven and Earth.

The primordial qi penetrates all things without ceasing. Where there is decay and decline, it is because people have reversed the six senses to block their own apertures. Sentient beings rely on breath, while plants rely on roots—both depend on the qi they receive as the basis of their lives.

The *bao* refers to the cavity. *Chonglang* means that this body arises from emptiness, and within it are the hollows of the five viscera through which qi and fluids flow. *Heavenly wandering* means that when the heart is empty, there is nowhere it cannot go with ease. If the chamber is not empty, superiors and inferiors clash in strife; if the heart is not empty, desires and aversions vie for dominance.

My chamber and my heart both have their master—how could external things disturb or agitate them? The great forests and towering mountains delight people because, having long seen only cramped and mean sights, they suddenly behold a vast and luminous expanse, and the heart must rejoice. Yet this is the spirit failing to overcome things and instead being overcome by them. The mountains, forests, and riverbanks may bring me joy that is not yet complete when sorrow follows—such is the subtle, ceaseless transformation of the great Dao, an inevitable principle.

Only the perfected person finds joy without relying on external things, and thus does not grieve with change, for they turn things by their own power. If things delight people, is it truly delight? If people take pleasure in things, is it truly pleasure? For when there is longing without, there is deficiency within; when one values that, one devalues this.

Fame is a public vessel and cannot be taken in excess, so the pursuit of fame is a loss of virtue. To possess fame and then flaunt it is yet another failure of fame. Both are losses—if one hastily seeks a remedy, one sees that contention arises from striving, and this is the proof of how manifold harms are born. Even those who can preserve themselves err in being blocked and unyielding, clinging to private interests.

In official affairs, the duty lies in what is fitting for all. "Fitting for all" means that the preceding six—seeing, hearing, smelling, tasting, and thinking—are all impartial and shared with the world. Otherwise, desires and cravings arise like grasses in spring rain, growing wildly and unstoppably. Thus begins the sharpening of farming tools—if governance is not applied early, though weeds are pulled, they sprout again with the rain, for the season makes it so, and none perceive it.

Human life depends on breath, and if one allows it to decline without vigor, are there no ways to support, protect, and replenish it? The key lies in knowing the proper time. This is another subtle revelation of the *Nanhua* on the secrets of nurturing life—scholars should ponder it deeply.

*(Annotations in original: "颤" same as "膻"; "珍" same as "碾.")*

Here ends *Nanhua zhenjing yihai zuanwei*, Scroll Eighty-Nine.
*Nanhua zhenjing yihai zuanwei*, Scroll Ninety begins.

Master Chu Boxiu of Wulin, *External Things* (Chapter Four)

Stillness may remedy illness; slander may ease old age; tranquility may halt haste. Yet though this be so, such are the tasks of the toiling—never the concern of the untroubled, who have never encountered them nor inquired after them.

What startles the world is not what the spirit-person inquires after; what startles the age is not what the sage inquires after; what startles the state is not what the noble person inquires after; what aligns with the times is not what the petty person inquires after.

In Yanmen, when a man’s kin died, he was ennobled as a court master for his virtuous mourning, and half his kinsmen perished from emulating his grief. Yao offered the world to Xu You, who fled from it. Tang offered it to Wu Guang, who raged against him. When Ji Tuo heard of this, he led his disciples to crouch by the Kuang River, and the feudal lords came to mourn. Three years later, Shentu Di threw himself into the river.

The fish-trap exists for the fish—once the fish is caught, the trap is forgotten. The snare exists for the hare—once the hare is caught, the snare is forgotten. Words exist for meaning—once the meaning is grasped, the words are forgotten. Where shall I find one who has forgotten words, that I may speak with them?

Guo’s commentary: To remedy illness, ease old age, or halt haste is not to be without illness, old age, or haste. Yet even such efforts remain labor, and thus the untroubled transcend and disregard them. The spirit-person resides within; the sage acts without. Each has their own path of advance and retreat, each their own rank of high and low. To revere filial piety for reward is far from the truth—this is the excess of esteem. Its waves disturb the nature, even driving men to drown in rivers, losing the intent of the two sages and reducing all to silence.

Lü’s commentary: Stillness to halt haste—these were among the arts of the ancients. Yet motion precedes stillness, flourishing precedes pruning, blazing precedes extinction, turmoil precedes tranquility. Such teachings are for the toiling, to ease their labor. The untroubled have never moved—why would they need stillness? They have never flourished—why would they need pruning? They have never blazed—why would they need extinction? They have never been in turmoil—why would they need tranquility? This is why they do not inquire. Only the virtuous attain untroubled ease, which the spirit and the sage both embody. Confucius and Laozi were born in the same Zhou era; Zhuangzi and Mencius both traveled in Liang—yet their words never touched, for their Ways differed and did not conspire together. The spirit-person and the sage differ in their traces; the noble person and the worthy differ in their talents; the noble and the petty are divided by righteousness and profit. The court master’s exhortation led his kinsmen to grieve unto death; Xu You’s flight led his followers to drown in rivers. Such is the harm of clinging to traces. Zhuangzi feared later generations would grasp his words but miss their intent, so he cited these two cases and concluded with the metaphor of the trap and snare, urging scholars to forget words and seek meaning.

Yi Du’s commentary: Here, *jing* (静) is likely a scribal error for *mo* (默).

Ziwei refers to trimming and leveling the beard and temples to erase the signs of age; the term may also be written as "shearing and erasing." Stillness and silence may remedy illness, yet this is not true freedom from illness. Resting in old age and halting haste are both products of human effort, not of nature—such are the tasks of the toiling, and thus the carefree have never inquired after them. *Xie* means "to drive" or "to govern." The sage is but the remnant thread of the spirit-person. Those who achieve merit for the world are the worthy. The virtue and work of the sage yield the effect of ordering the world. The noble person is the worthy’s refuge in name, possessing the affairs of governing the state. The petty person is the opposite of the noble. Thus, none of these have ever transgressed to inquire further.

Yanmen was a gate of the Song capital; in that place, there was one who mourned his parent’s death with such exemplary grief that the Lord of Song, admiring his filial piety, ennobled him as a court master. The villagers, emulating him, forced wails and feigned devastation, until half perished from self-destruction. Such is the harm of clinging to traces. Though the sage possesses the path to ordering the world, it fundamentally arises from non-action—through non-action, nothing is left undone.

Xu You and Wu Guang were ancients who practiced non-action, fleeing from Yao and Tang. They saw that these rulers had not yet attained the state of "nothing left undone," while Ji Ta and Shentu Di were even more extreme. The metaphor of the trap and snare requires no further explanation.

Bixu’s commentary: Stillness may remedy illness, yet it cannot fully restore the spirit. Shearing and erasing the signs of age cannot return one to infancy. Rather than halting haste, it is better to extinguish the heart-mind. The *Zhen Gao* states that pressing the corners of the eyes with the hands at times, so as to see light clearly, is the way to examine the spirit of the eyes; prolonged practice allows one to perceive the hundred spirits. The portents of aging appear in the *zi* of the eyes; smoothing wrinkles and creases can bathe the visage of age. Nevertheless, these are the tasks of the toiling, and thus the carefree transcendently disregard them. The sage, however, possesses a name.

The spirit-person leaves no trace. The worthy person esteems conduct and righteousness, which are but the surplus affairs of the sage. The noble person values following principle, which is but the dust and grime of the worthy. The petty person engages in careless deeds, which are but the superfluous growths of the noble.

The men of Yanmen’s faction mourned to excess, forcing tears that harmed their nature, for they clung to externals and lost their true selves, bound deeply by the lure of stipends. Ji Ta and Shentu Di crouched in caves and threw themselves into rivers, dissipating their true nature—all through deliberate conduct and the excess of love for fame. Once fish and hare are caught, the trap and snare may be forgotten; once the marvel of the Dao is realized, words and teachings instantly align.

Even the fisherman and hunter do not falsely adorn their hasty bargains—how much less should the seeker of subtleties craftily engage in discourse? The *Yanqi Kouyi* states: If the heart-mind can rest in stillness, then past losses may be repaired and made whole. Cutting away worldly desires allows one to roam freely to old age. Calming body and heart-mind can halt haste and urgency. These all speak of loss followed by recovery, illness followed by cure—hence the tasks of the toiling. For those at ease, whose hearts are fundamentally still, such matters need not be raised. These are not the concerns of the carefree, for *suo* here is akin to *hai* (startling). The sage governs the world through benevolence and righteousness—this is startling. The worthy startles the age with abundant virtue. The noble startles the state with reputation. The petty person busily seeks to conform for a time, yet even a slight elevation beyond this leaves such matters behind.

In Yanmen, one who excelled at mourning received a title; the villagers admired him, and half died from excessive grief—this illustrates the burden of love for fame. Xu You and Wu Guang gained renown through reclusion. Ji Ta, admiring them, squatted by the Xiang River (his crouching carried a sense of disdain, as if expecting the feudal lords to yield their states to him—already laughable). Three years later, Shentu Di, coveting the fame of reclusion, threw himself into the river and died—this exemplifies the extreme of love for fame. Having said all this, the text concludes with the metaphor of the trap and snare, mirroring the style of the previous section, where words suffice or do not suffice.

Remedying illness, erasing signs of age, halting haste—all involve labor and loss followed by efforts at recovery, not the affairs of the carefree, and thus are passed over without concern. The spirit-person’s relation to the sage, the sage’s to the worthy, the worthy’s to the noble—all are thus. If one seeks to conform to the times, one drifts far from the noble.

All this views the small from the vantage of the great, whose virtue and capacity encompass them without further inquiry, ultimately allowing self-transformation. Thus, one may ascend step by step. Therefore, whatever lies outside, the sage treats with non-insistence, and only then engages the world without harm. Though the sages of the Three Teachings established different teachings, their words never disparaged one another, aiming only to open the human heart and provide resources for governance, converging in goodness and no further.

*Hai* is the same as *hai* (startling). The *Dechong Fu* speaks of "startling the world"; Cui’s edition writes *hai*, which may be referenced. The men of Yanmen’s faction, admiring one who mourned well, forgot death. Xu You fled Yao; Shentu Di, admiring him, threw himself into the river—all took traces for the real, losing their own true selves, no different from pointing to the trap and snare to seek fish and hare. How deluded they were!

Thus, Zhuangzi thought of those who forget words and spoke to them, so that words forgotten, meaning might be grasped. This section begins by weighing the relative importance of inner and outer, clarifying the closeness of self and other. What lies outside is bound to things, and thus cannot be insisted upon. What lies within proceeds from the self; seek it, and it is attained. Yet most people strive for externals, and when they fail to obtain them, resentment and blame arise. Thus, the text establishes words to dispel their delusion.

Even the good deeds of loyalty and filial piety, which establish the self, cannot ensure the ruler’s or parents’ recognition, for they seek the inner through the outer—how much less can one seek the outer through the outer? From this, we know that within life and destiny, there is nothing that is not the Dao; realize it, and it is complete. Outside life and destiny, there is nothing that is not things; insisting on them leads to loss. Only through effortless non-action, silently aligning with the Dao, can one escape the twin pitfalls.

Zhuangzi’s metaphor of lending grain and the fish with outstretched fins speaks of bestowing things in due time. The Lord of Ren’s angling, scorning petty schemes, clarifies that the Dao must be preserved. Great scholars, citing the *Odes* and practicing the *Rites*, may yet rob graves for pearls. Their initial studies were not necessarily improper, but swayed by worldly desires, they transgress prohibitions and harm transformation without compunction—less admirable than the unlearned, who at least retain scruples and rest content in their allotted place.

All this traces the fault to those above who govern the people with sagely wisdom, for over time, the cunning among the people steal this wisdom for themselves. The text then introduces a parable with Lao Lai and Confucius, forgetting both praise and blame, so that worldly clamor naturally ceases—this embodies the idea that through my non-action, the people transform themselves. The white tortoise could foresee dreams but could not escape the net, for spirit does not make itself spirit without recognizing the spirit that is not spirit—this metaphor shows that relying on knowledge to escape trouble is not as good as forgetting knowledge and being without trouble.

Next, it states that only when one knows the useless can one speak of the useful, with meanings mutually illuminating. It discusses the "ability to wander," meaning to wander the heart-mind in blandness, wandering inwardly. The preceding passages are parables; here, it states, "Zhuangzi says," directly addressing the text’s central aim: to enable scholars to transcend the burdens of external things and advance into the realm of emptiness and penetration, where spirit fuses and intent is at ease, going wherever it will—then the Dao is near.

As worldly habits decline, people often wander where they should not, wandering into reckless haste, overturning and falling without regard. Even if a sage were to reappear, what could be done? Some delight in wandering, yet merely take rivers and seas as leisure, mountains and forests as goodness, and dissipate their lives—these wander the world in seclusion, yet cannot escape striving for externals.

Continuing with instruction, it teaches that when the body values the six penetrations, the Dao does not become obstructed; when knowledge relies on rest, one should value emptiness. When the chamber is empty, brightness arises, and there is nowhere one does not wander in the Heavenly roaming. Thus, the toilers’ pursuits are of no concern to the at ease—just as the noble and the sage differ in degree.

As for Yanmen, who gained rank through slander, or Shentu, who fled Tang and drowned in the river, both arose from prizing lofty and exceptional conduct, while below, they established purity and cultivation. Their original intent was to sharpen the world and revive teaching, yet they did not realize they harmed life and corrupted custom. Thus, they are raised as mirrors for later generations.

Now, to observe conduct through words is also an external thing, yet without pointing, one cannot see the moon. Therefore, the noble man does not weary of earnest speech, while the learner must skillfully seek its essence.

*South China True Scripture: Sea of Meanings, Compiled Subtleties*, Scroll Ninety Concludes

*South China True Scripture: Sea of Meanings, Compiled Subtleties*, Scroll Ninety-One

**Parables, First**

"Parables make up nineteen parts; weighty words, seventeen; *sha* words emerge daily, harmonizing with Heaven’s boundary.

Parables in nineteen parts borrow external discussions. A father does not act as matchmaker for his son. If a father recommends him, it is not as effective as if someone other than his father does. It is not my fault—it is others’ fault. If it aligns with oneself, one responds; if it does not align, one resists. What aligns with oneself is deemed right; what differs is deemed wrong.

Weighty words in seventy parts serve to conclude speech—these are the words of the venerable. Though one may be older, without warp and weft, beginning and end to mark their seniority, they are not truly senior. A person without means to surpass others lacks the human Way; one without the human Way is called a worn-out person.

*Sha* words emerge daily, harmonizing with Heaven’s boundary, flowing and extending to exhaust the year. Without speech, all is equal; equality with speech is not equal, and speech with equality is not equal—thus, it is said, ‘no speech.’ Speaking without speaking, one speaks all one’s life yet never speaks; remaining silent all one’s life, one never fails to speak.

There is that by which it is permissible, and that by which it is not; there is that by which it is so, and that by which it is not. How is it so? It is so in being so. How is it not so? It is not so in not being so. How is it permissible? It is permissible in being permissible. How is it not permissible? It is not permissible in not being permissible. Things inherently have that by which they are so; things inherently have that by which they are permissible. Nothing is not so; nothing is not permissible.

Without *sha* words emerging daily, harmonizing with Heaven’s boundary, who could attain longevity? All things are seeds, succeeding one another in different forms, beginning and end like a ring. None grasp their order—this is called Heaven’s equality. Heaven’s equality is Heaven’s boundary."

Guo’s commentary: Entrusting it to others, ten words are believed nine times. What the world values, ten words are believed seven times. *Sha*: when full, it tips; when empty, it tilts—it is not held by constancy. How much more with words, which follow things and change with them. "Emerging daily" means daily renewal; daily renewal exhausts the natural allotment, and when allotment is exhausted, harmony is achieved.

Words issuing from oneself are often not accepted by custom, so one borrows external ears—figures like Jianwu and Lianshu serve this purpose. A father’s praise of his son is often not believed; even when believed, it is suspected due to common bias. Thus, one borrows external discussion. Even if one is trusted, those harboring habitual doubt still do not accept it. Entrusting it to others, they believe—such is the burden in people’s hearing.

Alignment and opposition, mutual reproach—three differences in agreement, two differences in dispute. One must take rightness from the undisputed, for though all differ, one alone trusts what they deem right. What is this if not borrowing externally?

Weighty words, because of their venerability, are commonly valued by custom. Without borrowing externally, seven in ten would be believed. Though one precedes others in age, without the rest—warp and weft, beginning and end—to serve others, they are not truly senior. They are merely worn-out people, yet all believe them—this is how custom clings to the old and habitual.

Now, the natural has its allotment, and thus right and wrong have no fixed ground, flowing endlessly without determination. Remaining open and unattached, following as it comes—this is how each exhausts their Heaven-appointed years. Entrusting it to things and employing their words, then this and that, right and wrong, naturally equalize. If one establishes words to equalize them, then I and things are no longer equal.

Speaking what others speak, yet I ultimately do not speak—thus, one never speaks, yet never fails to speak. Their inclinations differ, with what is permissible and not, yet things each naturally have their own permissibility. Speaking broadly, nothing is impermissible in the end.

Only words that follow things and accord with their natural allotment can avoid premature decline. Though transformations succeed one another, their qi remains one. Today is the beginning; yesterday, the end—such is the principle itself, and none grasp its order. Is equality arbitrary? It is all the natural allotment!

Lü’s commentary: In nineteen parables, eleven are not parables; in seventeen weighty words, thirteen are not weighty. *Sha* words emerging daily, harmonizing with Heaven’s boundary—whether parable or not, weighty or not, all are *sha* words.

What are the nineteen parables? The Dao is near in our hearts, yet if we discuss it with our hearts, others doubt and do not believe. Just as a father does not act as matchmaker for his son, one must borrow external discussion. It is not that I do not wish to speak directly—people cannot be spoken to directly, so I speak for this reason.

What are the seventeen weighty words? If it aligns with oneself, one responds and deems it right; if it differs, one resists and deems it wrong. What I speak to others, I wish for their response, not their resistance. Thus, I follow what their hearts value—the words of the venerable—and speak of what I value as if it were my own words. All citations of antiquity in this book are instances of valuing the venerable. What they have heard precedes me—not because of age."

If one possesses the warp and woof, root and branch sufficient to surpass others, people will follow. Without means to surpass others, one is but a long-standing person—how can such be deemed weighty?

Words that emerge as if never having been spoken are like the sun rising—merely halting at dawn. The *zhi*-vessel, when poured from, yields in due time, for it is hollow within and holds no accumulation. The "Heavenly Boundary" is the utmost of non-action, where the sage finds repose. Harmonizing with right and wrong, resting in the "Heavenly Balance," then all emergence and withdrawal, speech and silence, are nothing but the "Heavenly Balance." Following its unfolding, extending it by principle, one exhausts the years. Only by being without self and without speech can all be made equal; with speech, there is self and other—how can equality be achieved? Thus, equality and speech, speech and equality, have never been equal. Though silence may be equal, it remains unequal to speech; this is not yet the great equality. Only when speech is without speech does the great equality arise—this is *zhi*-speech.

Thus, one may speak all one’s life yet never have spoken; one may remain silent all one’s life yet never have ceased speaking. What is called "acceptable" and "unacceptable," "so" and "not so," all have their origins. If there are inherent affirmations and acceptances, then there are no inherent negations or rejections—this can be known. The seeds of the myriad things emerge without ever differing in origin. Knowing their sameness is to know their beginning and end as a circle—this is the "Heavenly Balance." The "Heavenly Balance" harmonizes right and wrong within it, equalizing the myriad things, the utmost of non-action—hence it is called the "Heavenly Boundary."

**Dú’s Annotation:**
*Yu-yen* (parables) are names devised for speech.
*Chong-yen* (weighty words) are what the world venerates.
*Zhi-yen* (goblet words) resemble Laozi’s saying: "Good words are without flaw or riddle."

When the *zhi*-vessel is full, it tilts; when empty, it rights itself—this illustrates how good speech adapts to the moment, emerging like the sun without exhaustion, thus harmonizing with nature’s allotment. To have ten words and be believed nine times, or seven times, is constrained by yin-yang numerology and cannot be inexhaustible. Words from oneself are often disbelieved by the vulgar, so a father does not act as matchmaker for his son but borrows external discussion—this is *yu-yen*. *Chong-yen* involves attributing words to figures like Confucius or Yan Hui; though the words originate from oneself, if they can be revered, they become the words of the venerable. Without warp and woof, root and branch, even the venerable are not weighty.

Learning that attains the Dao enables one to surpass others; otherwise, one is but a stale person. The sage’s words respond to things appropriately, flowing without lingering—hence they are said to "rise like the sun." Only by harmonizing with the "Heavenly Boundary" can one unfold endlessly through the years. *Zhi*-speech emerges from non-speech; in non-speech, the myriad principles naturally align, but with speech, they do not. Zhuangzi’s *zhi*-speech arises after equality is achieved, yet equality and speech, speech and equality, remain unequal. Nothing compares to non-speech—though in non-speech, one never ceases speaking. Did Confucius, wishing to be without words, ever truly cease speaking? Words emerging from non-speech, though spoken all day, respond to things—what intent lies in speech? Though silent all day, one may still engage the world—how can this not be speech? This is the meaning of Zhuangzi’s *zhi*-speech.

What is acceptable has its origin; what is unacceptable has none. What is "so" has its origin; what is "not so" has none. The following text embodies these origins of affirmation, negation, right and wrong, self and other—acceptability and unacceptability, "so" and "not so"—to equalize self and other, unify right and wrong. Affirming what is affirmed, accepting what is acceptable, inherently so, allows the myriad things to each suffice within their nature and destiny. Affirmation and acceptance lie in things, not in oneself.

Without *zhi*-speech rising like the sun, harmonizing with the "Heavenly Boundary," who could endure long? "Seed" is the beginning of things’ arising. The myriad forms and changes are inexhaustible, succeeding one another in beginning and end like a circle without end. None grasp its order—this is what is meant by principle. The "Heavenly Balance" is beyond human effort. "Heavenly Balance" speaks of its levelness; "Heavenly Boundary" speaks of its origin—both are metaphors for the natural.

**Bìxū’s Annotation:**
Nine out of ten parables are believed; three out of ten weighty words are disbelieved—this is the world’s view. The *zhi*-vessel, full, tilts; empty, it rights itself; centered, it is upright. The sun, rising, slants; past noon, it declines; at midday, it is bright. *Zhi*-speech takes its uprightness; the sun’s rising takes its center. The noble one’s words emerge centered and bright, harmonizing with the utmost of principle.

Borrowed words are often trusted. A father’s praise of his son is hard to craft skillfully. The world does not examine right and wrong but deems what aligns with itself as good. Weight is given to the venerable; if age precedes but virtue does not, it is not precedence—merely a stale person. *Zhi*-speech rises like the sun, centered and bright, harmonizing with the utmost of principle, flowing with unobstructed words—thus one exhausts one’s years without regret.

"Non-speech" means silence, by which parables, weighty words, and *zhi*-speech are all made equal. For in non-speech, principle naturally aligns. Parables, weighty words, and *zhi*-speech are unequal by themselves. Thus, equality and speech are unequal—speech belongs to speech, equality to equality, akin to the idea of one and speech as two. "Speech without speech" means speech without attachment. The halting of speech is centered—how could it be attached? Without the attachments of right and wrong, love and aversion, there are no words of right and wrong, love and aversion—thus one may speak all one’s life yet never have spoken. If one seals one’s lips and binds one’s sack, yet centeredness never leaves the heart, then one may remain silent all day yet never cease speaking.

What is acceptable or unacceptable, "so" or "not so," all have their origins. What is "so" and acceptable arises from the Dao; what is "not so" and unacceptable does not.

For what is inherently "so" and acceptable, there is nothing that is not "so" or unacceptable. Thus, I once more cite the *zhi*-speech that endures, summarizing the preceding discussion.

The myriad things, though of different kinds, succeed one another by principle. The formed transforms into the formless; the formless generates the formed. The sentient intermingles with the insentient; the insentient shifts into the sentient. Their beginning shows no head; their end reveals no tail. Cyclical and unfathomable, this is called the "Heavenly Equality." Naturally balanced and level, it takes their utmost distinctions alone.

**Liu’s Commentary:** Water in a vessel is like speech within virtue—if not full, it does not flow.

What comes from without may be augmented yet not increased; what issues from within, though abundant, is never diminished. Thus, *zhi*-speech emerges daily.

Things have their boundaries and traces, yet the natural trace of beginning and end is like a ring. Thus, it is said: "Harmonized by Heaven’s trace." Like creeping vines or flowing water, this illustrates the thread of the natural. The Dao is whole, and things are unharmed—thus one may live out one’s years.

To speak all one’s life yet never have spoken, or to remain silent all one’s life yet never cease speaking—then the *Six Classics* are not fragmented, nor is the *Laozi* overly concise. If one uses parables to dissect human unity, or repeated words to dissect human trust, both are purposeful speech—the dregs of speech. Thus, *zhi*-speech is the root of all speech!

**Yanzhai’s Oral Exegesis:** A vessel holds wine; drinking it, one finds flavor. "Emerging daily" means that in every matter, this speech exists, harmonizing all hearts by Heavenly principle. A father acting as his son’s matchmaker—people would not believe it, so he relies on others’ prior words to quell disputes. Borrowing authority from elders, listeners dare not object, for the ancient sage-kings were all elders.

"Warps and woofs" refer to knowing constancy and change, beginning and end. "A full cycle of years" means a lifespan of a hundred. One who studies yet shows no attainment is unfit to lead others—such a person is but an old, useless relic. "Creeping and flowing" means attaining fulfillment through the years, thus passing one’s days and months.

To take wordless speech as speech is to return to the One Principle. But to express the One in words, or to discuss the One through words, is to allow the heart-mind to become uneven and divided. Only wordlessness is even—speech without intent is true speech. Thus, one may speak all one’s life yet never have spoken. In the midst of silence, one awakens others to principle—this is not true silence.

What people call acceptable or unacceptable, "so" or "not so," each has its own justification. How could I alone affirm or deny them? I simply follow what is inherently "so" and acceptable in affirming and accepting it. For what is inherently "so" and acceptable, there is nothing that is not "so" or unacceptable. The *Qi Wu* chapter discusses this in great detail.

If not for natural speech harmonizing all mouths, how could it remain unscathed through the ages? The seeds of the myriad things emerge from creation, succeeding one another between Heaven and Earth in their wondrous patterns, unfathomable in their principles. "Heavenly Equality" means the commonality of Heavenly principle.

The meanings of parables and repeated words have been clarified in various commentaries. The theory of "ten parts, nine or seven" is superior—those who speak from their own minds are few. This refers to worldly people who lack inner constancy, swaying with others’ judgments. Thus, one adapts one’s words to the moment, guiding others to trust and cultivate goodness. Such is the urgency of caring for the world and loving the people!

Interpretations of "vessel-speech" vary. A vessel holding water is like speech carrying the Dao. The Dao is not something speech can exhaust, just as water is not something a vessel can measure. To say the Dao does not belong to speech, or water does not belong to the vessel, is incorrect. Thus, its words emerge endlessly without exhaustion, and people listen without tiring—unlike parables or repeated words, which have their omissions and selections. For one who harmonizes by natural distinctions can unite all hearts under Heaven. With no intent of my own, what room is there for debates over sameness, difference, right, or wrong?

The saying "a father does not act as his son’s matchmaker" fully captures the essence of parables. I rely on others’ prior words because they would otherwise be hard to believe. Their sameness and difference lie in words, yet the response appears in deeds. This is not as good as wordless wholeness, where no one differs from me. Yet wordless wholeness is not as good as speech without intent, which transforms things without resistance.

Repeated words also come from prior speech. "Warps and woofs" discuss talent; "roots and branches" clarify learning. This further serves to admonish and encourage scholars. *Zhi*-speech is inexhaustible yet harmonizes by natural distinctions, flowing freely and creatively to live out one’s years—what worldly burdens could reach it? At this point, it is sufficient.

Later, it sweeps aside the edges, saying: In the principles of all things under Heaven, silence brings equality, uniting with the Dao. Equality and speech are like nonbeing and being, coarse and subtle—different principles. How can they be equal? Only by transcending being and nonbeing, merging coarse and subtle, does great equality arise. Thus, it is said: "wordless." This should be understood as the word "speech" in the following text.

This further clarifies the wonder of never having spoken and never having ceased speaking—spirit-like and transformative, not stagnating in the advance of speech or silence, yet all under Heaven follow like shadows. For speech that is acceptable or "so" arises from what is inherently so and acceptable—thus there is nothing that is not "so" or unacceptable. This is why *zhi*-speech encompasses parables and repeated words without omission. Thus, its words fill the world without fault.

The final chapter of this classic states: *Zhi*-speech is "creeping and flowing," repeated words are "real," and parables are "expansive." From this, we know that the words of this classic, vast and profound, endlessly transforming, do not exceed these three categories. Yet to leave no traces is easy; to act without treading is hard. To be silent is easy; to speak without flaw or obscurity is hard.

The *Nanhua* establishes these three modes of speech precisely to avoid flaws and reproach. To use speech to avoid flaws and reproach is akin to forgetting speech and thus being free of them. "Forgetting" means having yet not having—it is not the one-sided insistence on silence. To push the discussion of "forgetting speech" to its limit approaches what the Master desired in "having no speech."

All things in the world emerge from the same mechanism, yet their endowed forms differ, succeeding one another endlessly. Likewise, speech arises from the same heart, yet arguments vary, and debates are boundless. The sage therefore does not initiate but responds, speaking in accord with others—not his own words—thus like a ring without end, its limits cannot be fathomed. For my part, I harmonize with right and wrong and rest within the bounds of nature’s allotment. This, too, is the intent behind "dispensing with speech."

Zhuangzi said to Huizi: "Confucius, at sixty years of age, underwent sixty transformations. What he initially affirmed, he later denied. Who knows whether what he now calls right is not what he deemed wrong at fifty-nine?" Huizi replied: "Confucius diligently applied his will and exhausted his knowledge." Zhuangzi said: "Confucius has renounced such efforts, yet he has never spoken of it. Confucius said: 'One receives one’s endowment from the Great Root and revives the spirit to live. Singing in accord with the pitch, speaking in accord with the law, profit and righteousness are set before one, yet likes and dislikes, right and wrong merely conform to what people say. If one could make people submit in their hearts and dare not stand in opposition, thereby settling the world’s settlements—ah, ah! How could I ever attain such a state!'"

Guo’s Annotation: As the years pass, one transforms with them, moving in tandem with the age. When the times change, so too do the sentiments of the world. Yet those who ride things to roam in the mind—how are they different from the common crowd? Change never ceases, and thus nothing remains constant. To say that Confucius first applied his will and clung to knowledge before realizing he could not master self-transformation—this only shows how far Huizi falls short of the sage’s far-reaching resonance. Confucius renounced change as something self-so, not something achieved by knowledge or effort. Thus, he followed the times, responded to things, and never forced words. Had he enslaved himself to his rustic knowledge without returning to the root of spirit, life would have perished. "Singing" arises from the pitch; "speaking" emerges from the law. Both pitch and law are what the multitude creates, and the sage merely employs them. Thus, he never errs, yet he has never spoken of it, never acted upon it. "I have no words of my own—likes and dislikes, right and wrong, the display of righteousness and profit—these merely follow what people say. The mouth expresses the heart; if one uses the mouths of others, one uses their hearts as well. If I align with the hearts of others, who would dare stand in opposition? Letting the world settle itself, I settle it—what more is there to do? Riding along with it, nothing is beyond reach."

Lü’s Annotation: The tradition holds that at sixty, Confucius’s ear was attuned, and at seventy, he followed his heart. Following the heart, whatever the mind conceives is free of right and wrong; whatever the mouth utters is free of profit and harm. Before the Way reaches the point of following the heart, one cannot escape transformation. Transformation necessarily begins with affirmation and ends with denial—how can one be certain that what is called right at sixty is not what was deemed wrong at fifty-nine? Huizi did not understand that this was where Confucius was like others. As for where he was one with Heaven, from ancient times to the present, there has never been transformation that was truly considered the result of applying one’s will or clinging to knowledge. "Renounced" means to cast it away entirely. To receive the power to live is called virtue—this is what is meant by "receiving one’s endowment from the Great Root and reviving the spirit to live." Before birth, there is no qi, no form—how could there be what is called spirit? With birth comes qi and form, and thus the spirit is revived. "Singing in accord with the pitch" requires no effort to tune the sound. "Speaking in accord with the law" requires no effort to explain principles. Yet when righteousness and profit are set before one, and one then follows with likes and dislikes, right and wrong—this merely conforms to what people say. Because what one relies upon is not yet settled, it is not a matter of non-action and self-transformation. If one could make people submit in their hearts and dare not stand in opposition, thereby settling the world’s settlements—this would be enabling self-transformation, not merely conforming to what people say. "How could I ever attain such a state!"—this is his renunciation, of which he has never spoken.

Yu Du’s Annotation: At sixty, Confucius’s ear was attuned, and thus he was free of right and wrong. Huizi, not understanding this, thought it was achieved by applying one’s will and clinging to knowledge. "Renounced" is like the alternation of yin and yang. Never having spoken of it—the Great Root and the transformations of creation: all human endowments are received from creation. If one can return to the root and revive the spirit, the principle of life is attained. If one is enslaved to external things, the root is lost, the spirit perishes—how can life be preserved? Pitch arises from the qi of yin and yang; law follows the virtue of Heaven and Earth. The sage harmonizes with the qi of yin and yang, thus singing in accord with the pitch; he aligns with the virtue of Heaven and Earth, thus speaking in accord with the law. Now, when righteousness and profit are set before one, giving rise to likes and dislikes, right and wrong from one’s private views—this merely conforms to what people say, not to their hearts. To make people’s hearts submit, one must follow and yield to them, dare not stand in opposition, and let the world settle itself—this is what it means to be attuned. "Ah, ah!" expresses the desire for non-action. If I do nothing, they will settle themselves—thus, "How could I ever attain such a state!"

Bi Xu’s Annotation: As the years advance, virtue and nature grow ever clearer—this aligns with the chapter on Lian Boyu, though the meaning differs. To gradually awaken, first affirming and later denying, is to remain unable to forget oneself. But Confucius moved with transformation without stagnation, making others forget themselves—this is difficult. Initially affirming what is right, responding to things as they change; ultimately denying it, returning to the correct Way. What was not right before and what is not wrong now—this is diminishing yet ever increasing. Applying one’s will leads to fewer transformations; clinging to knowledge leads to greater self-importance. Confucius long renounced the world’s entanglements and never burdened himself with words. Those who receive their endowment from the Great Dao—even sagehood is not something to rely upon. Those who revive their spirit-nature to be born—follow change and yield to transformation. Thus, his voice harmonized with the mean, his words became cultural teachings. Righteousness and profit were set forth in the records—how could this merely conform to what people say? It extended to making others submit in their hearts, follow in reverence, and adhere to ancient principles—who would dare stand in opposition? Holding to this and yielding to the world, one can settle the world’s settlements. "I cannot attain such a state"—Confucius’s humble words.

*Yongzhai Oral Teachings*: Applying the mind and serving through knowledge and perception refers to broad learning. Confucius renounced the pursuit of broad learning to advance in the Way, though he never spoke of it to others. "Endowment" is like nature; "root" is the beginning. What the Creator bestows is the nature of awareness. Returning to the original nature of awareness, one can then fulfill the Way of human life. "Singing" is speech; "pitch" is law. When righteousness and profit are set before one, and one has likes and dislikes, right and wrong, then one can conform to what people say, but not to their hearts. Only by setting aside righteousness, profit, right, and wrong can one make people’s hearts submit. Without anyone daring to stand in opposition, one can then settle the world’s settled principles. Zhuangzi, having praised the Master’s heart, turned to Huizi and sighed: "Ah, ah! How could I ever attain such a state!"—this is reverence for the Master’s utmost attainment. Human life transforms with the years—this is unavoidable for the worthy and the foolish alike.

Within, thoughts and reflections daily accumulate; without, form and appearance daily alter. Gains and losses, advantages and harms assail one another; right and wrong, success and failure shift and change. All that arises and vanishes like illusions, dust, bubbles, and shadows before one—these are transformations. The Master reached sixty years and underwent sixty transformations, so that the Way of life renewed itself daily without stagnation. How could the old linger in his dwelling?

Though transformation is shared by all, the capacity to receive it differs from person to person. As the *Book of the Yellow Emperor* states: "The cosmos lies within the palm, the myriad transformations arise from the body." How true! Sixty years mark one full cycle of heaven and earth’s branches and stems, the midpoint of human life’s longest span. With long experience, right and wrong may seem settled—yet one still cannot know whether what is deemed right today was not wrong at fifty-nine. Tracing its source, the obstacle lies in the persistence of the self. If one has not yet attained selflessness, one cannot be certain that what follows sixty is truly right. Thus, even the Master Yu sighed over his fifty-nine errors.

"Diligent aspiration" refers to the accumulation of learning; "submitting to knowledge" refers to the application of ability. The Master had long since relinquished what he had learned and what he could do, silently advancing in this Way without others’ awareness.

All receive their talents and nature from the Creator; only by restoring one’s innate spirit can the Way of life endure. To this must be added the fullness of learning and the cultivation of virtue and achievement. "Singing accords with pitch, speech accords with law"—just as sound becomes pitch, the body becomes measure. All these arise from the spirit, and the human Way may then be called complete.

Yet when righteousness and profit stand before one, and one takes one’s own likes and dislikes as right and wrong, one merely silences others’ mouths. Most scholars of the world are thus—only the Master could make others submit in heart, daring not to follow blindly, without hidden resistance, as Master Fan’s punctuation makes clear. "Establishing the settled principles of the world" speaks to the swiftness of his transformation.

"Ah, ah! How could I ever attain such a state!"—these are Zhuangzi’s words of admiration for the Master. *The Ocean of Meanings in the Southern Florescence True Scripture*, Scroll Ninety-One, ends here. #1 The characters "自有" should be reversed to "有自."

*The Ocean of Meanings in the Southern Florescence True Scripture*, Scroll Ninety-Two. By the Daoist of Wulin, Chu Boxiu.

**Parable the Second**

When Master Zeng took office a second time, his heart had undergone transformation. He said: "When I first served to provide for my parents, a stipend of three *fu* brought me joy; later, though I received three thousand *zhong*, my parents were gone, and my heart grieved." His disciples asked Confucius: "Can one such as Shen be said to be free of entanglement in blame?" Confucius replied: "He is already entangled. How could one free of entanglement feel sorrow?"

To him, three *fu* or three thousand *zhong* were like watching sparrows, gnats, and flies pass before him. Guo’s commentary: *Xuan* means "to bind." Shen served for the sake of his parents, free from the fault of being bound to emolument. Emolument is for nurturing; nurturing is for contentment, not for the means themselves. If one is unbound, then whether noble or base, the mind remains even, tranquil, and at ease, fulfilling the proper way of serving with devotion. To one unbound, honor and emolument are but gnats, flies, or sparrows passing before him—how could sorrow or joy arise therein?

Lü’s commentary: Abiding in timeliness and accordance, sorrow and joy cannot enter—this the ancients called the "Celestial Unbinding." Thus, one free of entanglement cannot feel sorrow. Life and death are great matters, yet sorrow and joy cannot enter; then three *fu* or three thousand *zhong* are like watching sparrows, gnats, and flies pass by—clearly, their magnitude or quantity is not worth comparing.

Yi Du’s commentary: Master Zeng served out of poverty. When his stipend first reached his parents, though it was but three *fu*, his heart rejoiced; later, when he received three thousand *zhong*, his parents were gone, and his heart grieved. This is why his heart underwent transformation twice. His disciples, seeing that Master Zeng loved his parents and was not burdened by emolument, asked Confucius about it. Confucius said that Shen’s filial piety was love, but he had not forgotten his parents, so sorrow and joy remained in his breast—how could he be free of entanglement? Only one unbound can be free of sorrow, thus regarding *zhong* and *fu* as so light. This is to say Master Zeng had not yet attained such a state.

Bi Xu’s commentary: Joy and sorrow mark the two transformations. Filial devotion does not depend on poverty or wealth; attendance and nurture are not a matter of abundance or meagerness. Yet Master Zeng spoke thus—his heart still harbored the entanglement of the common man. However, Shen was called perfectly filial, and if he were truly free of the fault of being bound to emolument, how could sorrow arise? If he regarded *zhong* and *fu* as gnats and flies, then his entanglement could be dissolved.

*The Oral Teachings of Yan Zhai*: The disciples asked whether Master Zeng’s words revealed the fault of entanglement, suspecting that his two transformations—joy and sorrow—betrayed such a bind. Confucius replied that this very sorrow and joy were the entanglement. If one were unbound, external things passing before him would be no more than gnats and flies—how could they evoke sorrow or joy?

The ancients, when their learning was sufficient, took office to benefit the people; emolument was but a substitute for tilling the soil, meant only to support one’s parents and raise one’s family. How different from the officials of later ages, who beyond their salaries extort and accumulate, indulging their ears, eyes, mouths, and bodies, yet never once visit their parents’ halls to inquire after them! Master Zeng rejoiced at three *fu* when his parents were alive, and grieved at three thousand *zhong* when they were gone—his sorrow and joy were bound to their presence or absence, not to the abundance or meagerness of emolument. Yet his heart was not immune to transformation, which is why his disciples questioned him.

The Master said that Shen, caught between these two, could not be free of entanglement: the presence or absence of his parents inevitably bound him, but the abundance or meagerness of emolument should not have lingered in his heart. If one were truly unbound, how could sorrow arise? To him, *zhong* and *fu* would be but gnats and flies. Master Zeng’s filial conduct is renowned through the ages, yet his office and emolument of three thousand *zhong* are unrecorded. This parable in the *Nanhua* also reflects the intent to hold the worthy to account, urging people to value filial conduct over office and emolument, to accept whether parents are provided for or not, whether emolument reaches them or not, as a matter of fate—then where is the entanglement?

Yan Chengzi You said to Shu Guo Zijing: "Since I heard your words, after one year I became rustic; after two, compliant; after three, penetrating; after four, in harmony with things; after five, things came to me; after six, spirits entered; after seven, Heaven was accomplished; after eight, I knew not death, knew not life; after nine, I attained the Great Mystery. Life is action; death is admonition. I urge you: take heed of death."

There is that from which the self arises; life and yang emerge from it. There is that from which nothing arises. How then can this be so? Whither does it find its fitting place? Whither does it find none? Heaven has its celestial reckonings, earth has its human settlements—where should I seek them? None knows its end; how then could there be no fate? None knows its beginning; how then could there be fate? When there is that by which things respond, how could there be no spirits? When there is nothing by which things respond, how could there be spirits?

Guo’s annotation: "Rustic" means beyond external gains. "Compliant" means not acting on one’s own. "Penetrating" means understanding others. "In harmony with things" means that what comes with me is self-attainment. "Spirits enter" means transcending the bodily form. "Heaven is accomplished" means non-action. "Knowing not death, knowing not life" means all encounters are fitting. "The Great Mystery" means good and evil are the same. Thus, there is nowhere one does not merge into obscurity. This speaks of long study and hearing the Dao, knowing the spontaneity of Heaven’s piping; one will suddenly forget oneself, and impurities will daily recede until they are gone entirely.

Life with action loses its life. From action comes death; from prizing one’s life comes action. Now, what urges you is that death arises from prizing the self. The yang of life, once it severs all pursuit and action, suddenly stands alone—yet not from any cause. And yet it is indeed so. Thus, there is no fitting place and no unfitting place, and only then are all places fitting, all fitting in their attainment.

Heaven and earth are already self-sufficient; principle must complete itself, not through knowledge—how then could it not be fate? Not knowing why it is so yet finding it so is called fate. It seems as though there were intent, so fate’s name is discarded to clarify its spontaneity, and only then is the principle of fate complete. Principle has responses as though there were numinous spirits, yet principle responds of itself, not through any cause—thus, though there is response, there is no spirit.

Lü’s annotation: The Dao was never a thing; once it has become a thing and one desires to return to non-thing, then attaining emptiness and preserving stillness is not the work of a single morning. "Rustic" means forgetting benevolence and righteousness, guests and ritual music. "Compliant" means the heart’s non-resistance. "Penetrating" means the heart’s thoroughness with things, so that in every thing one roams, in every thing one observes. "Things come" means the Dao gathers to one. "Spirits enter" means spirits and gods come to dwell. "Heaven is accomplished" (six versions all lack this phrase). "Knowing not death, knowing not life" means knowing to stop at what one does not know. "The Great Mystery" means spirit. Speaking of the mystery of the myriad things, only then can one embody spirit.

Life without action knows neither life nor death. Life with action brings death. Urging one toward impartiality and away from self-interest, one comes to know no death. Life with action is the source of death, so the sage puts the self aside and thereby preserves it. By being without self-interest, one perfects one’s self-interest—this is how one urges you. Tracing beginnings and ends, one knows the discourse on life and death. Beginning and end are like a ring: there is only life’s yang—how could there be any source? Taking action as the self is also speaking of the nature of things.

How then can this be so? Thus, one who embodies the Dao and exhausts the spirit knows neither death nor life—how could there be a fitting or unfitting place? To seek it in celestial reckonings and human settlements is never to find common ground. How much less should one seek it in questions of fortune and misfortune, human affairs! To deem it no fate? Yet in the end, there seems to be constraint. To deem it fate? Yet its beginning cannot be found. To deem it no spirits? Yet there is that by which things respond. To deem it spirits? Yet there is nothing by which things respond. Thus, one stops at what one does not know and admits no concerns—this is attainment.

Yi Du’s annotation: "Rustic" means unadorned. "Compliant" means non-resistance. "Penetrating" means no obstruction. "Things" means forgetting the self. "Things come" means they do not depart. "Spirits enter" means returning to numinosity. "Heaven is accomplished" means uniting virtue with Heaven. "Knowing not death, knowing not life" is sageliness. "The Great Mystery" is spirit. In reaching spirit, one attains the ultimate!

This is the sequence by which learners enter the Dao. Human life with action burdens its life, and thus death arises from prizing one’s life. Therefore, the purpose of urging you toward action is that death arises from prizing the self. As for fate, it is the great commonality of things.
