Impartial and without self-interest, one knows no death. Life is yang, death is yin. Knowing life and death as one with yin and yang, there is no self. Truly knowing this principle, life is not worth delight, death is not worth sorrow—then where is there fitting or unfitting?

Celestial reckonings are Heaven’s images; human settlements are Earth’s vessels. Humans dwell between the two, and the Dao of Heaven and Earth is sought in the self alone. Fate is the Dao of Heaven; spirits are the Dao of humans. Beginning and end speak of the Heavenly Dao; response speaks of the human Dao. When Heaven and human communicate, the principles of yin and yang, life and fate are complete. Placing it between being and non-being and doubting it—this is profound understanding of the Dao.

Bi Xu’s annotation: "Rustic" means the initial heart’s simplicity. "Compliant" means not resisting others’ feelings. "Penetrating" means thoroughness with principle, no obstruction. "Things" means unity in undifferentiated wholeness. "Things come" means the multitude returns to one’s virtue. "Spirits enter" means profound attainment of the obscure. "Heaven is accomplished" means non-action and spontaneity. "Knowing not death, knowing not life" means being and non-being are one. The "Great Mystery" at nine years means the number exhausts pure yang, and spiritual transformation is unfathomable.

Life with action moves toward the place of death. Because of prizing the self, one urges impartiality. Those who turn from impartiality toward self-interest die from self-interest—how could their death be without cause? Life is the qi of strong yang, without any source. Can you truly reach the Great Mystery? The Great Mystery is without impartiality or self-interest, without life or death, without fitting or unfitting place—it may be called the ultimate! In Heaven, images are formed, and celestial reckonings may be calculated.

On earth, forms take shape, and human reckoning may discern them. Only I am without mind—who can fathom this? Some affairs have a beginning but no end, others an end but no beginning—all are as Heaven’s mandate ordains.

"Correspondence" refers to the nine verifications of prior Dao-cultivation. "Spirits" denote numinous echoes—some responsive, some not—depending on the depth of practice and the swiftness of spiritual communion. Though Dao-cultivation follows a sequence, its essence lies in solitary transformation. As for its duration, nine years may be the measure, yet enlightenment may strike in a single dawn or dusk.

*Yanzhai’s Oral Exegesis*:
"Wild" means returning to simplicity.
"Following" means aligning with others without losing oneself.
"Permeation" means thorough illumination.
"Things" are like withered wood or dead ashes.
"Coming" denotes that within stillness, something indestructible remains.
"Spiritual entry" means embracing the transformations of creation within one’s breast.
"Heaven-accomplished" means merging with Heaven as one.
"Not knowing life and death" means being at ease in every circumstance.
"The Great Mystery" is the utmost profundity.
From one to nine, these are but stages—this matter cannot be measured in years.

People take life as having a beginning, clinging to self-interest. Thus, they are exhorted with the principle of impartiality, that they may know no thing in the world is deathless. If one speaks of death, it must have a source. Yet if one seeks the origin of life, it has no source—if there is no birth at the outset, how can there be death? Yang is the inception of movement. Speaking thus of life and death, who can say whether it is truly so?

"Fitting or unfitting" is like saying "so or not so." Observing to the utmost, one finds that "so or not so" cannot be fixed. Can celestial reckonings and human discernment fully exhaust the principles of Heaven and Earth? The myriad affairs and transformations of the world are wrought by the Creator—how can one say there is no mandate? Yet in the primordial vastness, originally nothing existed—how can one say there is a mandate? Cold and heat, dawn and dusk arrive in season, qi responds in time—how can one say there are no spirits? Humility does not always bring fortune, benevolence does not always bring longevity—how can one say there are spirits? This speaks to the unknowability of the Creator.

Human life withers with convention, losing itself day by day. Those who cultivate the Dao reduce and reduce again, seeking to return to their origin. "Wild" means gradually reverting to simplicity. "Following" means aligning with others without losing oneself. "Permeation" means penetrating principle. "Things" means forgetting the self. "Coming" means others are drawn to one. "Spiritual entry" means entering the realm of the indistinct. "Heaven-accomplished" means harmonizing with spontaneity. "Not knowing life and death" means neither going nor coming. The "Great Mystery" at nine years means the number reaches the subtlest, and spiritual transformation is unfathomable.

Only by taking non-action as one’s foundation can one ascend to this realm. Yet the world is mired in action, hastening toward the place of death. They are exhorted to impartiality because death arises from self-interest. The *Bixu Zhaozhang* edition, collated by Zhang Junfang, ends the sentence with "self-interest," which refers to prizing and pampering one’s life excessively. What one seeks to benefit oneself instead brings the greatest harm. Thus, one is urged to abandon it and return to the impartial Way.

Death follows from taking life as existent. Life itself begins from nothingness. If one originates from nothingness and is without self-interest, then there is also no death—Heaven cannot kill, Earth cannot bury. Can you truly be thus? From this, one knows that those who do not take life as existent are wiser than those who prize life—how then can one speak of fitting or unfitting?

Heaven has its reckonings, by which fortune and misfortune may be deduced. Earth has its human discernment, by which order and chaos may be examined. What need have I to seek elsewhere? Since the division of the Two Modes, myriad things have been born for thousands upon thousands of years without end—if not for mandate, how could this be? Yet things are transformed without known beginning—from what could mandate arise?

Celestial reckonings and human discernment show correspondences of fortune and misfortune—how can there be no spirits? Yet Heaven’s Way sometimes defies certainty, and human affairs sometimes lack constancy—thus, one may doubt the existence of spirits. This speaks to the subtlety of creation, so difficult to perceive that its very elusiveness defines it. One can only fulfill one’s duty and await its unfolding. Thus, the highest learning turns one inward to examine oneself.

The beginning and end of Heaven and Earth, the concealment and revelation of the numinous within oneself—exhausting one’s nature to reach destiny, illuminating spirits to attain the divine—all lie in diligent practice and heartfelt realization. What need is there to wait nine years?

The multitude of shadowy companions asked the shadow: "Before, you bowed; now, you raise your head. Before, your hair was bound; now, it is loose. Before, you sat; now, you stand. Before, you walked; now, you stop. Why?" The shadow replied: "Such trifles—why ask? I act, yet know not why. I am like the cicada’s molted husk, the snake’s sloughed skin—resembling yet not the same. Fire and sunlight are my gathering; darkness and night are my replacement."

Do I depend on something to exist thus? How much more so for those that depend on something! When it comes, I come with it; when it goes, I go with it; when it is strong and bright, I am strong and bright with it. What question can there be of the strong and bright?

As Guo’s commentary states: movement is spontaneous, with nothing to question. It is spontaneous, thus one knows not why. The husk resembles the cicada, the slough resembles the snake, the shadow resembles the form yet is not the form—pushing this to its limit, what we now call the dependent ultimately reaches the non-dependent, and the principle of solitary transformation becomes manifest. It is merely vigorous, spontaneous movement, following and accompanying to and fro. Without intention, it cannot be questioned.

As Lü’s commentary states: The shadowy companions arise from the shadow, and the faint yin beyond the shadow is not singular—hence "trifling." The shadow’s bowing and raising, walking and stopping, follow the person alone—how could it know why? The form’s having a shadow is like the cicada’s husk or the snake’s slough, yet it is not the husk or slough. The shadow gathers and appears with fire and sunlight, and is replaced and concealed by darkness and night. This is what the shadow depends on to be a shadow, yet being without sentiment, how could it know of dependence? What the shadow depends on—fire, sunlight, darkness, and night—cannot be called dependent; how much less so for that which depends on something! What depends on something is that from which the shadow arises—namely, the form. Knowing the shadowy companions are non-dependent, we know the shadow is non-dependent; knowing the shadow is non-dependent, we know that from which the shadow arises is also non-dependent—thus it is not burdened by the form! When it comes and goes, I come and go with it; when it is strong and bright, I am strong and bright with it—none of this is me. What question can there be?

As Du’s commentary states: "Trifling" refers to the multitude of shadowy companions. "Why ask?" means there is no need to ask. All things created by the Maker depend on something yet know not why.

The carapace resembles the cicada, the slough resembles the snake, the shadow resembles the form—yet they are not the cicada, the snake, or the form. Fire and sunlight cast light, where shadows gather; darkness and night hold no light, where shadows hide. This is what I depend upon—how much more so for the form, which itself depends on something? It means dependence on the workings of creation. When the form comes, I come with it; when the form goes, I go with it; when the form is strong and bright, I am strong and bright with it—all this arises from spontaneous transformation. What question could there be?

Bi Xu’s *Annotation of the Single Lamp* states: One lamp, one shadow; ten lamps, ten shadows. As lamps and shadows multiply, faint shades grow numerous. Does their rising and falling arise from the form’s command, or do shadows arise naturally? Their movement and stillness, their presence and absence—none can know their cause. Shadows and faint shades have form yet no obstruction; cicada carapaces and snake sloughed skins have substance yet no nature. Before shedding, only the snake and cicada exist; once shed, the carapace and skin remain of themselves. Thus the shadow and the form do not depend on each other—how much less do the cicada and snake regard their sloughed remains! The world says the form gives birth to the shadow, the shadow gives birth to faint shades. Yet when the shadow arises, it gathers in sunlight and fire, and is replaced by darkness and night—what does it owe to the form? When the form stands in light, the shadow appears, seeming dependent; when it dwells in darkness, the shadow vanishes, seeming independent. Though its coming and going, its movement, arise from the other, its response without intent lies within oneself. Where is there room for inquiry?

*Yanzhai’s Oral Teachings* states: *Sousou* sounds like *xiao*, a state of being half-hidden, half-revealed. *Shao* means "roughly" or "generally." It speaks of what you possess, yet you do not know its origin.

The cicada has transformed, yet its shell remains; the snake has transformed, yet its slough remains. This analogy—comparing the moving form to the cicada or snake, and the shadow to the shell or slough—only *seems* apt, but is not. When an object meets sunlight or fire, its shadow gathers; when night falls, the shadow is replaced. That "other" (referring to the form and shadow as if they were distinct) claims to be independent—how could it be what I depend upon? Yet the form’s movement, too, has its dependencies. How much more so for those that rely on what is conditional?

The form moves only when stirred by the *qi* of strong yang, and I follow along. But what constitutes strong yang lies beyond the form’s knowing—why then do you ask me? This passage aligns with the *Qi Wu Lun*, though it adds the theory of sunlight, fire, and strong yang.

All things under heaven with form must cast shadows—this is universally known. Yet beyond the shadow lies the faint shade called *wangliang*, which most fail to perceive. For the shadow, being dim, clings ambiguously to its source, its obscurity giving rise to shifting, overlapping shades—hence the term "multitudes of *wangliang*." The *wangliang*’s relation to form is like the seven emotions’ relation to the heart: when the heart is not governed, the seven emotions run rampant, turning to assail it; when the shadow is unclear, the *wangliang* proliferate, turning to interrogate it. Yet what the shadow depends upon—can the *wangliang* comprehend it? What the heart obscures—can the seven emotions grasp it?

This discourse on the mutual arising of natural principles resembles the interplay of dependence and conditionality, where things may exist or vanish. Neither dependent nor independent, it serves as a metaphor for the origin of form and the inception of thought. The insight is exquisitely subtle, unarticulated by past sages.

The shadow arises from the form, yet without sunlight or fire, it cannot be seen—seeming interdependent. Though sunlight and fire are luminous, without form there would be no shadow—this is the principle of *duhua* (self-transformation). The shadow clings to the form, never parting in movement or stillness, as close as one’s own body. Its activity and quiescence, its presence and absence, must have a master. Yet people go about their days unaware, so the *wangliang*’s questioning is hardly surprising!

The *Qi Wu Lun* states: *"As if there were a true master, yet no trace of it can be found."* This precisely clarifies the point. The so-called "true master" is the lord of *duhua*, upon which the ten thousand things and forms rely for generation and movement, and from which the interplay of dependence and conditionality arises. If one can turn inward to seek it, then amid the vague and indistinct, clarity and harmony emerge. The principle of *duhua* becomes evident, and the doubts of *wangliang* dissolve.

"Strong yang" refers to the *qi* of creation that humans receive, enabling the body to move and manipulate external things. Its gathering brings existence; its dispersal brings dissolution—it is but a temporary lodging. If one knows the lord of *duhua*, then the true self endures, and the gathering and scattering of that *qi* need not be questioned. How much less the faint shades beyond the shadow?

When Yang Ziju was traveling south to Pei, and Lao Dan was journeying west to Qin, they met by chance at Liang. Midway, Laozi looked up to the sky and sighed: "At first, I thought you could be taught, but now I see you cannot." Yang Ziju made no reply. Upon reaching their lodging, he presented water for washing, a towel, and a comb, removed his shoes outside the door, and advanced on his knees, saying: "Earlier, your disciple wished to ask you a question, but you were walking and did not respond, so I dared not speak. Now that you have stopped, I beg to ask where I have erred."

Laozi said: "Your haughty and overbearing demeanor—who would wish to dwell with you? The purest white appears sullied; the greatest virtue seems insufficient."

Yang Ziju’s expression changed abruptly, and he said: "I humbly receive your instruction."

On his previous journey, the innkeeper had welcomed him, the master of the house had laid out the mat, his wife had held the towel and comb, the guests had yielded their seats, and the cook had stepped away from the hearth. On his return, the innkeeper vied with him for a seat.

Guo Xiang’s commentary: *"Sui sui xu xu"* describes an overbearing manner. People will shrink from difficulty and distance themselves; when one exalts oneself, others defer—hence the cook stepped aside.

Lu Huiqing’s commentary: His *sui xu* self-importance prompted the innkeeper’s obsequious welcome. Laozi sighed at Ziju’s ostentatious display, which led to shoes crowding the doorway. Bo Hun’s departure from Yu Kou followed the same principle.

Yi Du’s commentary: Ziju was Yang Zhu’s courtesy name. His washing, combing, and kneeling demonstrated his self-purification and humility. *"Sui sui xu xu"* revealed his arrogance outwardly. "Who would dwell with you?" admonished him that the sage knows purity yet guards obscurity—thus the purest white seems sullied, and the fullest virtue seems insufficient. Ziju heard this and awakened.

On his earlier journey, the innkeeper had welcomed him with ceremony, the host had laid out the mat, his wife had held the towel and comb, the guests had yielded their seats, and the cook had stepped away from the hearth—all out of respect for his outward display. Upon hearing the Dao and shedding his pretensions, on his return the innkeeper vied with him for a seat. Without displaying superiority, how could others know to revere him?

Bi Xu’s commentary: *"Sui xu"* describes a haughty bearing. On his first journey, his pomp and ceremony inspired awe. On his return, he appeared no different from the common folk, making others forget his distinction.

*Yanzhai* states: *"Sui xu"* denotes self-importance, the failure to forget self and others. It is as if one were dwelling with others. "The master of the house" refers to the innkeeper. "Yang" means "to cook." Yielding seats and hearths expressed respect; vying for a seat showed that his distinction was no longer recognized. Having been enlightened by Lao Dan, he withdrew into obscurity, and others treated him as ordinary.

*"Sui xu"*—self-importance—who would wish to dwell with you? One whose conduct is pure will be slandered, so they conceal their brilliance as if sullied. One whose virtue is abundant will be diminished, so they nurture it as if insufficient. This is the way to preserve oneself. Now you do the opposite—how could you be taught? Ziju heard this and was dismayed; his expression changed, revealing his remorse. Thus, on his earlier journey, the innkeeper had welcomed him, the master of the house had laid out the mat, his wife had held the towel and comb—everyone in the household had shown him respect.

Leaving one’s seat and avoiding the hearth—such conduct astonished all who witnessed it. Yet upon his return, the inn’s guests vied for a place beside him, for his pretenses had fallen away and his true nature remained, causing others to forget the crude displays of outward respect. This is why the ancients could enter a herd of beasts without disturbing them or join a flock of birds without disrupting their flight.

This chapter takes its title from a parable, embodying the spirit of the Old Immortal of Nanhua, who crossed water without wetting his feet. Though his words were many, he feared later generations might cling to traces and fall into error, so with each step he swept away his own advances. His parables and reiterations were but expedients, borrowed from external discourse out of necessity.

The *zhiyan*—like water held in a vessel—is restrained yet never lost, and when it flows forth, it does so without weariness. Differences and judgments each have their place; speech arising from wordlessness is no different from silence. Whether affirmed or accepted depends on the inclinations of the world—how could one know whether it is inherently so or merely deemed so? Thus, only in wordlessness can all be made equal.

Alas, in an age of declining Dao and fading virtue, none trust themselves, and those unable to fulfill their aspirations in their own time still hope to leave teachings for the future. Yet they fear there will be nothing to guide later generations, so they embed their message in what is esteemed to gain trust. By leading others through parables to seek the truth, and through subtle allusions to ascend to the profound, their success is one and the same.

As for the Master’s teachings, they evolved with the times—what was right at the outset may not be so at the end. If even the truths of one’s own life cannot remain constant, how can one expect to be unquestionably believed by later ages? When Zengzi took office twice and changed twice, his heart was not free from attachment, and joy and sorrow manifested in him, whether his motives were for his parents or for his stipend.

But one who hears the words and awakens—like Ziyou, who in a single year became as unrefined as the wilds—reaches the great mystery: the heart grows ever emptier, and the Dao ever more present. The parables, reiterations, and *zhiyan* all reside in the realm of transformative influence.

Next, the discussion turns to the presence or absence of fate and spirits, and the interdependence of form and shadow, all to illuminate the ineffable wonders of creation. If one fully embodies what creation bestows and does not resist its course, then the heaven and earth within oneself become as unfathomable as the most wondrous of things.

The conclusion—with "Sui xu" in his arrogance, who would wish to dwell with him? Yet upon hearing the teaching and returning, the inn’s guests vied for a place beside him—shows that enlightenment comes in an instant, with but a few words heard by the ear and grasped by the heart. Who could say that those who bear the Dao will leave no one for later generations to forget the fish-trap once the fish is caught?

I have read Su Dongpo’s *Record of the Zhuangzi Shrine*, in which he argues that the end of the "Parables" chapter should connect to the beginning of "Lie Yukou," and that the four chapters "Yielding the Throne," "Robber Zhi," "Discourse on Swords," and "The Old Fisherman" should be removed. While the two chapters might share a coherent meaning, the exclusion of four seems excessive. His objection likely stems from "Yielding the Throne" being overly detailed and repetitive, "Robber Zhi" slandering Confucius too harshly, "Discourse on Swords" resembling the rhetoric of the School of Diplomacy, and "The Old Fisherman" bordering on defamation of the Sage. Thus, these were not favored by Master Su.

Yet in the *Record*, he also states that Zhuangzi’s words may not align with his intent, outwardly rejecting while subtly aiding—thus revealing his understanding of Zhuangzi’s original purpose in using words to remedy the age’s ills. Why, then, take offense at their roughness?

Upon examination, the four chapters—"Yielding the Throne" and the others—seem somewhat distinct from the inner and outer sections, though their essential message does not stray from the fundamental principle. The difference lies in the coarseness or refinement of their expression, and the variations in emphasis. Perhaps they were later additions by disciples who failed to capture the purity of the original, hence their placement at the end of the miscellaneous sections. Yet their meaning can still be grasped, and there is no harm in it.

Leaving one’s seat and avoiding the hearth are outward displays of self-importance, prompting others to show respect. But upon hearing the Dao and shedding such pretenses, the inn’s guests vied for a place beside him, no longer displaying deference. Without showing others how to advance, they knew not how to respect him.

The *Bixu Commentary* notes: "Sui xu" refers to an arrogant demeanor. On his earlier journey, his bearing was imposing, inspiring awe in others. Upon his return, he appeared no different from the common folk, causing others to forget his presence.

The *Yanzhai* states: "Sui xu" denotes self-importance, where the distinction between self and others is not forgotten. It is as if one were merely dwelling among people.

The master of the house refers to the innkeeper. *Yang* means to cook. Avoiding the inn and the hearth were signs of respect. Vying for a seat showed that his distinction was no longer recognized. Having been enlightened by Lao Dan, he withdrew into obscurity, and others treated him as ordinary.

"Sui xu"—self-importance—who would wish to dwell with you? One whose conduct is pure will be slandered, so they conceal their brilliance as if sullied. One whose virtue is abundant will be diminished, so they nurture it as if insufficient. This is the way to preserve oneself. Now you do the opposite—how could you be taught? Ziju heard this and was dismayed; his expression changed, revealing his remorse. Thus, on his earlier journey, the innkeeper had welcomed him, the master of the house had laid out the mat, his wife had held the towel and comb—everyone in the household had shown him respect.

Leaving one’s seat and avoiding the hearth—such conduct astonished all who witnessed it. Yet upon his return, the inn’s guests vied for a place beside him, for his pretenses had fallen away and his true nature remained, causing others to forget the crude displays of outward respect. This is why the ancients could enter a herd of beasts without disturbing them or join a flock of birds without disrupting their flight.

This chapter takes its title from a parable, embodying the spirit of the Old Immortal of Nanhua, who crossed water without wetting his feet.

Such being so and permissible, it is but the acceptance or rejection of worldly sentiments. How can one know whether it is inherently so or inherently permissible? Thus, only in silence can all be made equal.

Alas, in an age of declining Dao and fading virtue, none trust themselves, and unable to fulfill their aspirations in their own time, they yet hope to leave teachings for posterity. Fearing there would be no means to bind the understanding of later generations, they embed their message in what is esteemed to gain credence. By guiding others through allegory to fathom the truth, and through subtle allusions to ascend to the sublime, their achievement is one and the same.

As for the Master’s progression—adapting with the times, beginning with what is right and ending with what is not—even the rightness of one’s own era cannot endure, how much less can one expect unchanging belief from later ages? Even Master Zeng, who twice entered and twice left office, could not free his heart from attachment, and joy and sorrow manifested therein, whether for family or for stipend.

Yet those who hear the words and awaken—like Ziyou, who in a single year became rustic and attained the great mystery—find their hearts growing ever more empty as the Dao gathers within. The allegories, reiterations, and impromptu words all reside in the realm of transformative influence.

Next, the discourse on fate and the presence or absence of spirits, on form and shadow and their interdependence, all illuminate the ineffable subtleties of creation. If one can fully embody what creation bestows, without obstruction or distortion, then the unfathomable numen within one’s own body is no different from that of heaven and earth.

The conclusion—with its sighs of pride and aloofness, asking who could dwell with such a one—ends with the parable of hearing the teaching and turning back, where those who once vied for seats now forget their pretenses. In the space of a few words, the ear listens and the heart awakens. Who would claim that those who bear the Dao for later generations would fail to grasp the fish while forgetting the trap?

I once read Su Shi’s *Record of the Zhuangzi Shrine*, in which he argued that the end of the "Allegories" chapter should connect to the beginning of "Lie Yukou," and that the four chapters "Yielding the Throne," "Robber Zhi," "Discourse on Swords," and "The Old Fisherman" should be excised. While the two chapters might share a coherent meaning, the rejection of the four seems excessive. His objections likely stemmed from the following: "Yielding the Throne" is overly detailed and repetitive in its arguments; "Robber Zhi" slanders Confucius to excess; "Discourse on Swords" resembles the rhetoric of the Strategists; and "The Old Fisherman" nearly amounts to slander of the Sage. Thus, these were not favored by Master Su.

Yet in the same *Record*, he also wrote that Zhuangzi’s words are true in substance though not in style, outwardly repelling yet inwardly aiding—thus revealing his insight into Zhuangzi’s fundamental intent in using words to remedy the ills of the age. Why then take offense at their roughness?

Upon examination, these four chapters—"Yielding the Throne" and the others—differ somewhat from the Inner and Outer Sections, as if in dialogue. Yet their essential message does not stray from the great foundation. The distinction lies in the varying degrees of refinement and emphasis in their expression; some may have been supplements by disciples, lacking the purity of the original, hence their placement at the end of the Miscellaneous Sections. Their meaning can be grasped intuitively without need for further debate to forestall later doubts.

*South China Immortal’s Scripture: The Sea of Meanings, Admiring the Subtle*, Chapter Ninety-Two, concludes.
*South China Immortal’s Scripture: The Sea of Meanings, Compiled and Subtle*, Scroll Ninety-Three.

The *Wulin* Daoist Chu Boxiu’s Study:
*Yielding the Throne, Chapter One*

Yao yielded the realm to Xu You, but Xu You declined. He then yielded it to Zizhou Zhi Fu, who replied: “That you would make me Son of Heaven is acceptable. Nevertheless, I presently suffer from a hidden sorrow, and am occupied with its cure—thus I have no leisure to govern the realm. The realm is the weightiest of burdens, yet one must not allow it to harm one’s life—how much less should other things do so! Only he who takes no account of the realm may be entrusted with it.”

Shun yielded the realm to Zizhou Zhi Bo, who said: “I presently suffer from a hidden sorrow, and am occupied with its cure—thus I have no leisure to govern the realm.” The realm is a vessel of great magnitude, yet one must not exchange life for it—this is how those who embody the Way differ from the common world.

Shun yielded the realm to Shan Juan, who replied: “I stand amid the cosmos: in winter I wear furs and pelts, in summer garments of fine hemp. In spring I till and sow, my form sufficient for labor; in autumn I gather the harvest, my body sufficient for rest.”

With the sun’s rise, I labor; with its setting, I rest—roaming free between heaven and earth, my heart content. Why should I take the realm for myself? Alas, you do not know me at all!

Thereupon he departed and entered the deep mountains, where none knew his whereabouts.

Shun yielded the realm to his friend, the farmer of Stone Gate, who said: “How earnest is the lord’s conduct! A man who preserves his strength!” Yet he deemed Shun’s virtue still incomplete. Thus, husband carrying on his back, wife bearing on her head, they led their child into the sea and never returned.

Lord Guju of Deng dwelt in Deng when the Di tribes attacked. He offered them furs and silks, but they would not accept; he offered them dogs and horses, but they would not accept; he offered them pearls and jades, but they would not accept—for what the Di sought was land.

Lord Guju said: “To dwell with a man’s elder brother and kill his younger brother, to dwell with a man’s father and kill his son—this I cannot bear. All of you, do your best to remain! What difference is there between serving me and serving the Di?” He then took up his staff and departed. The people followed in such numbers that they formed a state beneath Mount Qi.

Lord Guju may indeed be called one who honored life. Those who honor life, though noble and wealthy, do not allow their nurture to harm their bodies; though poor and lowly, they do not allow profit to burden their forms. Yet men of this age who occupy high office and exalted rank all fear losing them, and at the sight of gain lightly forfeit their lives—how deluded they are!

The people of Yue murdered their ruler for three generations. Prince Sou, distressed by this, fled into the cinnabar caves. When Yue was left without a ruler, they sought Prince Sou but could not find him, so they pursued him to the cinnabar caves. Prince Sou refused to emerge, so the people of Yue smoked him out with mugwort and bore him forth in a jade carriage. Prince Sou grasped the carriage strap to mount, then looked up to heaven and cried: “Rulership! Rulership! Can you truly not spare me?”

Prince Sou did not despise being ruler—he despised the troubles that come with rulership. Such a man may indeed be called one who did not allow the realm to harm his life. This is why the people of Yue desired him as their ruler.

Guo’s commentary is brief and does not elaborate. Lü’s commentary: In the late years of the Three Dynasties, fathers and sons, brothers and kin contended for the realm, each bringing ruin upon the other—so it is said, “The knight endangers his body and lightly risks his life to seek favor.” This is why the *Yielding the Realm* chapter was composed.

Xu You, Zhi Fu, and their like all refused to exchange their lives for the realm. Yang Xiong believed that the weight of Yao’s abdication to Shun was not taken lightly by such men. Does this not mean that the worthy must be tested through experience before the realm is entrusted to them? Yet they fail to understand that what enabled Yao to obtain Shun was not such testing—for testing is common to all men, and merely exposes one to the world. Had Xu You not shunned Yao’s offer, how could one know he would not have proven equal to Shun?

Du’s commentary: Sorrow concealed in the heart is called “hidden sorrow.” Zhi Fu did not allow the realm to harm his life; Zhi Bo did not exchange his life for the realm. Though they differed from the common world, they were not yet free of intent.

Shan Juan illustrated the depth of his embrace of the Way; the farmer of Stone Gate was skilled in closure and revered the root. Shan Juan’s words sought self-preservation for his own sake, while the farmer pointed to the lord’s conduct—deeming his virtue incomplete, neither was yet able to be without preference.

Lord Xuan of Deng fled the Di, unwilling to harm the people for the sake of land—he may indeed be called one who honored life. Yet to have a body is to require nurture; to have life is to bear burdens. The wealthy and noble delight in nurture, but excess nurture harms the body; the poor and lowly are pressed by profit, and excess profit burdens the form. Only by avoiding these two extremes can one honor life.

Prince Sou fled the throne—he may indeed be called one who did not allow the realm to harm his life. Though not entangled by external things, his love for the people and himself remained, so he was still bound, unable to be without striving. These are but traces of the sage, not his true essence.

The true essence of the sage is to forget life yet have life perfectly preserved, to forget nurture yet have nurture fully realized. Though entrusted with the realm and the state, he simply accords with the moment—what harm could there be?

Bi Xu’s commentary: He who sets the realm aside is untouched by the world’s harms. He who values his life is unmoved by other things. Only with a heart vast and empty can one entrust oneself to the four seas. The great virtue of heaven and earth is life itself—what the perfected man treasures. Who would trade it for the realm? Clad in coarse robes, nourished by simple gruel, who would make external things their concern and lose their natural purity?

Thus, the unyielding will not bend to others; only the deeply virtuous can truly honor what is beneath them.

The steadfast integrity that preserves one’s strength establishes great merit; the unrestrained and unrepentant provoke reproach and contempt. The earth provides sustenance to nurture all things; what nurtures things in turn nurtures the people. Now, to contend over the very things that sustain life and thereby harm the people they nourish—this the sage cannot bear to do.

The weight of wealth and rank lies in their power to injure the body through excess nurture; the lightness of poverty and lowliness lies in their tendency to destroy the body through the pursuit of profit. Thus, to rule as a lord yet let governance falter is not so good as retiring into reclusion to preserve oneself whole.

*Juanzhai’s note:* The "hidden sorrow" of illness is like a concealed malady. He who takes no thought for the realm may be entrusted with it, possessing it yet not clinging to it.

*Juanjuan* (pronounced *quan*), an appearance of self-exertion. *Baoli*, to labor strenuously. The two passages on Yao and Shun lack concluding remarks, their meaning being the same as before. "Used for nurture" refers to the land; "what is nurtured" refers to the common people. Those who honor life hold the body in high regard and external things in low esteem—this is a rebuke to those of the time who feared loss. Only he who has no desire to rule may be entrusted with the state, which is why the people of Yue sought Prince Sou to be their lord.

*Chu’s Observations:* Heaven produces sages to continue the transmission of the Dao, clarify human relationships, assist heaven and earth, and nourish the myriad things. Whether the lord’s position exists or not is of no consequence to them. Yet as the pivot of governance and the destination of litigation, there are times when it cannot be refused—it is but a temporary entrustment. Though seated in the dignity of ten thousand chariots and the wealth of the four seas, they dwell in earthen-floored thatched huts, wear coarse garments, and eat simple fare, unaware of the weight of their power or the extremity of their station. Since they did not seek it with their hearts, they do not regard it as glory, and thus their refusals and relinquishments are as effortless as removing a shoe.

Nothing in the world is greater than the realm, yet to yield it is to have nothing left to contend for. What measure can fathom what lies within such a heart? Even when offered the realm and refusing it, how could this be the act of one without inner resolve? The virtue of Yao, Shun, and the Great King does not require praise; the lofty integrity of the various masters could only be fully revealed by Zhuangzi. Examining their words of refusal, the general intent is nothing more than esteeming life and devaluing external things, prizing the inner and despising the outer, delighting in the sage’s Way and loathing the burdens of lordship. Moreover, if the ancients disdained to accept the realm when offered, how could they stoop to the deceit, force, perversity, and overreaching of later ages?

*The "hidden sorrow" of illness:* According to the *Lüshi Chunqiu*, this passage is cited with Gao You’s commentary: "Hidden" means concealed. The *Book of Songs* says, "As if there were a concealed sorrow"—this refers to one so preoccupied with putting one’s own affairs in order that there is no leisure to govern the realm, which is what sets them apart from the common.

The Great King fled the Di tribes, unwilling to harm the people; Prince Sou of Yue fled the people, fearing harm to himself. Fearing harm to the people is to love oneself; fearing harm to oneself is to love the people. This is why the people of Yue wished to make him their lord—his virtue was manifest, and he did not flee like ants drawn to honey. As for the highest virtue, which does not act as virtue, the people cannot name it—it cannot be gained or harmed, transcending even this level. Though the *Nanhua* does not fully articulate this, its intent lies herein, as can be seen in the later chapters’ essential purport.

Han and Wei contended over encroached territory. Master Zihua met Marquis Zhaoxi, who wore a troubled expression. Master Zihua said: "Suppose the world inscribed a contract before you, its words reading: 'Grasp it with your left hand, and your right hand will be severed; grasp it with your right hand, and your left hand will be severed. Yet whoever grasps it shall possess the realm.' Would you grasp it?"

Marquis Zhaoxi said: "I would not."

Master Zihua said: "Excellent! From this we see that both arms are weightier than the realm, and the body is weightier still than both arms. How much lighter is Han than the realm, and how much lighter still is the territory now in dispute! Yet you grieve, harming your life and body over what you cannot obtain!"

Marquis Zhaoxi said: "Well said! Many have instructed me, but never have I heard such words. Master Zihua truly understands the weight of things."

*Guo’s commentary* omits discussion of this. *Lü’s commentary:* If Marquis Zhaoxi could heed Master Zihua’s words and regard his dispute as trivial, he would rank next to those who do not exchange their lives for the realm.

*Yi Zhu’s note:* "Severed" means cut off and rendered useless. Could one disregard one’s arms to seize the contract and gain the realm? The marquis said he would not, from which we know that both arms are weightier than the realm, and the body is weightier still than the arms. Compared to the realm, Han is already light, and the disputed land is lighter still than Han. Yet he grieves, harming his life and body over what he cannot obtain—abandoning what is most weighty to contend for what is most trivial. Is this not delusion?

*Bixu’s note:* Which is dearer, fame or the self? Which is greater, the self or wealth? Why trouble oneself over abandoned borderlands?

*The *Honglie* explains:* To slaughter warhorses in pursuit of foxes, to grasp two turtles while losing a sacred tortoise, to sever one’s right arm for a single hair, to break a fine sword in competition with a small blade—these are truly those who do not know the weight of things!

*Juanzhai’s note:* The contract is like an agreement. To grasp it is to gain the realm, yet one who cherishes life would not do so. How much lighter is Han compared to the realm! Yet to grieve over not obtaining it, even to the point of harming one’s life and body, is weightier than losing an arm!

The Marquis of Han contended with Wei over a small strip of encroached borderland, wearing his distress plainly. He could be said to value what is light and slight what is heavy. Though Wei’s ministers remonstrated, none were heeded. Master Hua entered and admonished him with reason: to grasp the contract with the left hand would sever the right; to grasp it with the right would sever the left—one cannot avoid both gain and harm. It lies with the individual to weigh their lightness and heaviness and choose accordingly.

The Marquis understood that an arm is weightier than the realm, and the body weightier still than an arm, yet he did not perceive that Han was lighter than the realm, and the contested encroached land lighter still than Han. Once the lightness is clearly discerned, the weight becomes self-evident.

The Marquis, upon hearing the admonition, swiftly awakened and grasped the natural order of light and heavy. Alas! The Marquis of Han was indeed worthy! And Master Hua, too, was wise!

The Lord of Lu had heard that Yan He was a man who had attained the Way, so he sent an envoy bearing gifts to precede his visit. Yan He dwelt in a humble abode, wearing coarse cloth and tending cattle himself. When the envoy from Lu arrived, Yan He received him in person. The envoy asked, "Is this the home of Yan He?" He replied, "This is indeed my home." The envoy presented the gifts, but Yan He said, "I fear a mishearing may bring blame upon the envoy; it would be better to verify." The envoy returned, confirmed the matter, and came again to seek him, but Yan He could not be found.

Such was Yan He—one who truly despised wealth and honor. Thus it is said: The true essence of the Way is for cultivating the self; its remnants may be used to govern the state; its dregs may be employed to order the world. From this perspective, the achievements of emperors and kings are but the leftover affairs of sages, not the means to preserve the body and nurture life.

Yet today, the gentlemen of the俗世 often endanger their bodies and forsake their lives in pursuit of external things—how lamentable! Whenever the sage acts, he must examine both his purpose and his means. Consider this: if a man were to use the pearl of Marquis Sui to shoot a sparrow soaring a thousand *ren* high, the world would surely mock him. Why? Because what he employs is weighty, while what he seeks is light. How much more so is life itself, which far surpasses the pearl of Marquis Sui in value!

The *Guo Commentary* omits this, and the *Lü Commentary* does not elaborate further.

**Yi Du’s Annotation:**
Yan He dwelled in poverty yet attained enlightenment; he truly despised wealth and honor, which is why Zhuangzi esteemed him. Those who grasp the true essence of the Dao cannot be spoken of in terms of life and death—thus, one may hear the Dao in the morning and die by evening. Yet when one cherishes and values the body for the sake of the world, this becomes the path of the sage. The remnants of silk threads, the basest of earth and grass—trifling and unworthy of mention—are what the sage employs for the world’s advancement, merely a temporary lodging for the world’s affairs. Thus, they are called "leftover matters." The *so*-of-its-purpose and the *so*-of-its-means: when one acts, one must examine its rightness before responding. The parable of the Marquis of Sui’s pearl shooting a sparrow illustrates how worldly men exchange life for wealth and honor, forsaking the weighty for the light.

**Bixu’s Annotation:**
"Remnants of threads" and "worthless as dirt" describe how the farther one strays from the self, the coarser one becomes. The sage in cultivating the self empties the heart and weakens the will. The emperor and king in establishing merit wield tools and tread paths. To view merit-making alongside self-cultivation is but a leftover of the self. Yan He knew that the *so*-of-its-purpose was not yet right, nor the *so*-of-its-means necessarily so—thus, he refused the gifts. There are scholars who savor the bitterness of herbs yet scorn wealth and honor, whose bodies may bend but whose Dao cannot, who value themselves as the pearl of Marquis Sui and regard rank and emolument as lightly as swallows and sparrows.

**Yuanzhai’s Remarks:**
"Remnants of threads" and "worthless as dirt" for governing the state and the world are the discourse of sages and worthies. Zhuangzi’s words distinguish thus, yet people claim he divides things into two separate realms of refinement and coarseness. His intent is simply that those who know the Dao are not burdened by external things, possessing the world yet not clinging to it—only then can they fully realize governance through non-action. However, his words are overly emphatic, though his heart is not truly so. "Remnants of threads" and "worthless as dirt" arise only from leftover matters, like dust and chaff. Modern scholars of the *Pan* school have truly taken this as two separate realms, often citing the language of "remnants" and "dirt" in application. Thus, Master Zhu [Xi] vigorously corrected this. The parable of the pearl shooting the sparrow is most apt. Yan He’s heart truly despised wealth and honor, surpassing worldly views by ten thousandfold. Yet it is regrettable that he did not express his sincerity in words, thus failing to convince the envoy, slightly marring his pure virtue. The envoy, having arrived at his home and met the man yet unable to earnestly secure him, accepted his refusal and withdrew—was this not overly simplistic? Difficulty in advancement and ease in retreat are the constant way of the gentleman. The longer the nurturing, the deeper the roots—of Yan He, there is little room for further discussion. Yet the Lord of Lu ardently sought worthies, how rarely does one encounter such a man? Having fortunately met him, to lose him by a turn of the arm, unable to share in great governance and ascend to peace—this truly stemmed from the envoy’s failure to persuade, hence the admonition. Moreover, no worldly achievement surpasses that of emperors and kings, yet even this is deemed a leftover matter. Then what of the true essence of the sage—how could it be fathomed by the common stream? The *so*-of-its-purpose and the *so*-of-its-means are what the *Analects* calls the *whereby* and the *wherein*.

In modern editions, the character *zhe* (者) is often mistakenly added, and *xin* (心) is inserted where *zhi* (治) should be *chi* (持). In "all the sage’s actions," the character *sheng* (圣) is redundant. In "the weight of the Marquis of Sui," *hou* (侯) should be *zhu* (珠). This entire chapter appears in the *Master Lü’s Spring and Autumn Annals*, proving that Lü Buwei’s distance from Zhuangzi was not great—he must have grasped the truth.

When Master Liezi was poor, his countenance bore the hue of hunger. A guest spoke of this to Zi Yang of Zheng: "Lie Yukou is a man of the Dao, a vessel of utmost worth. Dwelling in your state yet impoverished—does this not suggest you do not esteem scholars?" Zi Yang of Zheng immediately ordered an official to send him grain. When Master Liezi saw the envoy, he bowed twice and declined. The envoy departed, and Master Liezi entered his home. His wife, gazing at him, struck her breast and said: "I have heard that the wife and children of a man of the Dao all enjoy ease and happiness. Now you bear the look of hunger. The lord, passing by, sent you food, yet you refused it—is this not fate?" Master Liezi smiled and said to her: "The lord does not know me himself. He sent me grain on another’s word, and if he were to punish me, it would also be on another’s word. This is why I did not accept it." In the end, the people indeed rose in rebellion and killed Zi Yang.

**Guo’s Commentary** omits this.
**Lü’s Commentary** does not elaborate further.

**Yidu’s Annotation:** When a scholar is known for his upright conduct, and others seek him out after verifying his true worth, then what they have carefully examined aligns precisely with what is known of him—thus he bears no shame. Zi Yang, as Prime Minister of Zheng, had never met Master Liezi, yet suddenly, on another’s word, he sent him grain. To know him by another’s word is to condemn him by another’s word—this is why he refused it.

**Bixu’s Annotation:** Would a scholar who willingly sinks into obscurity, content with anonymity, ever bend his will to accept undeserved emolument? How could he, swayed by the sentiments of wife and children, hesitate within the snares of disaster?

**Yuanzhai’s Note:** Zi Yang sent grain to Master Liezi on another’s word—he was no true knower of men. If praise could be trusted, so too could slander. As Prime Minister of Zheng, he held the power to weigh the worth of all within the state—could he remain ignorant of a worthy man dwelling in reclusion? To hear of his virtue and send him grain was to meet worth and show respect. Yet Master Liezi thought: if he sends me grain on another’s word, how can I be sure he will not punish me on another’s word? Thus he declined, refusing to accept. This is how the noble man perceives the subtle and knows the manifest, sees the past and foresees the future. His wife, striking her breast, spoke from the vulgar view of the world—who would say the wife and children of a man of the Dao would think thus? The actions of the perfected man are beyond even his wife and children’s full understanding, let alone others. Such words reveal how difficult it is to know a man who wears coarse cloth yet holds jade within. To know him and then govern with the Dao—only then can one fully employ talent and put it to use. As *The Fisherman* says: "Without intimacy, one cannot gain true trust."

King Zhao of Chu lost his state, and the butcher Shuo fled with him. When the king regained his kingdom, he sought to reward those who had followed him, including the butcher Shuo. Shuo said: "When Your Majesty lost the state, I lost my butcher’s trade. Now that Your Majesty has regained the state, I have regained my butcher’s trade. My rank and emolument are restored—what reward is there to give?" The king said: "Compel him to accept." Shuo replied: "When Your Majesty lost the state, it was not my fault, so I dared not submit to punishment. Now that Your Majesty has regained the state, it is not my merit, so I dare not accept reward." The king said: "Let me see him." Shuo said: "By the laws of Chu, only those who have rendered great service through heavy reward may be granted an audience. I know my wisdom is insufficient to preserve the state, and my courage insufficient to die in battle against invaders. When the Wu army entered Ying, I feared disaster and fled the enemy—I did not follow Your Majesty by design. Now, if Your Majesty wishes to set aside the law and break precedent to see me, this is not what I have heard of under heaven." The king said to Marshal Zi Jing: "The butcher Shuo dwells in lowly circumstances yet expounds lofty principles. You shall extend to him the rank of the Three Standards." Shuo said: "The rank of the Three Standards—I know it is nobler than my butcher’s stall. The emolument of ten thousand *zhong*—I know it is richer than my butcher’s profit. Yet how could I covet rank and emolument and cause my lord to bear the name of reckless bestowal? I dare not accept. I wish only to return to my butcher’s stall." Thus he refused.

**Guo’s Annotation:** His righteousness made further explanation unnecessary.

**Yidu’s Annotation:** In the time of Master Zhuang, many people disregarded fate and righteousness, seeking wealth and nobility by chance. Thus he cited the case of the butcher Shuo to admonish them. Though he dwelt in a butcher’s stall, his sense of duty was so steadfast—truly, he could inspire and refine the shallow customs of the age. The Three Standards refer to the rank of the Three Dukes. I know it is wealth and nobility, yet if not obtained by rightful means, I will not take it. Here, in the butcher Shuo, we see this principle. **Bixu’s Annotation:** Those who recite the *Odes* and *Documents* to dispel ignorance, or dwell in butcher’s and wine-seller’s shops yet uphold righteousness—what age has lacked such men? Those who seize power and claim it as their own merit, or trade influence for heavy reward—upon hearing this, should they not feel shame?

**Yuanzhai’s Note:** When the king regained his state, Shuo regained his butcher’s trade—each returned to his proper place. The Three Standards refer to the carriages and robes of the Three Dukes, each distinguished by its own banner. King Zhao rewarded Shuo to demonstrate that in restoring the state, he extended grace. Shuo declined the reward, abiding by righteousness and not overstepping his bounds. When the king lost his state, he could not submit to punishment; when the king regained his state, he dared not accept reward—this was fitting. In an age where many claim reward without merit, one who declines emolument on the grounds of fate is a rare sight. The king commanded an audience to honor his conduct and wish to know the man. Shuo deemed it improper to break precedent for a meeting and thus firmly declined. He would not allow his lord to bear the name of reckless bestowal—his integrity was thus. Such conduct is difficult even for scholar-gentlemen, yet the butcher Shuo performed it with ease. If all the ministers and people of the state were transformed by Shuo’s virtue and emulated him, what worry would there be that the ways of the world would not flourish in mutual ascent?

Yuan Xian lived in Lu in a hut with walls barely enclosing him, thatched with growing grass. The door of woven reeds was incomplete, its hinge made of mulberry wood.

And his two chambers had jars for windows, sealed with coarse cloth; the roof leaked above and the floor was damp below, yet he sat upright and plucked his zither. Zilu rode a grand steed, his robe lined with fine white silk, his carriage too wide for the alley, and came to visit Yuan Xian. Yuan Xian answered the door wearing a hat of birch bark, hempen sandals trailing, and leaning on a staff of wild thorn. Zilu said, "Alas! Master, what ails you?" Yuan Xian replied, "I have heard that to lack wealth is called poverty, but to study and fail to practice is called affliction. I am poor, not afflicted." Zilu stepped back, his face flushed with shame. Yuan Xian smiled and said: "To act in pursuit of worldly favor, to befriend for mutual advantage, to study for others’ approval, to teach for personal gain—such are the corruptions of benevolence and righteousness, the trappings of carriages and fine horses. I cannot bring myself to do them."

When Master Zeng lived in Wei, his padded robe had no outer layer, his complexion was swollen and pallid, his hands and feet calloused. For three days he did not light a fire, for ten years he did not make new clothes. When he straightened his cap, its ties snapped; when he grasped his staff, his elbow showed; when he pulled on his shoes, the seams burst. Yet he dragged his hempen robe and sang the *Odes of Shang*, his voice filling heaven and earth as if ringing from metal and stone. No Son of Heaven could make him a minister, no feudal lord could befriend him. Thus, he who nurtures his will forgets his form; he who nurtures his form forgets profit; he who attains the Way forgets his mind.

Confucius said to Yan Hui, "Hui, come! Your family is poor and your station low—why not enter office?" Yan Hui replied, "I do not wish to." "I have fifty *mu* of fields outside the city walls, enough to provide gruel; ten *mu* within the walls, enough for silk and hemp. Playing the zither amuses me, and what I have learned of your Way is enough to bring me joy. I do not wish to enter office." Confucius’s expression changed, and he said solemnly, "Excellent, Hui’s intent! I have heard that he who knows contentment is not burdened by profit, he who is truly self-possessed is not afraid of loss, and he whose conduct is cultivated within does not chafe at lacking rank. I have recited this for a long time, but only now, in you, do I see it realized. This is my gain."

The above three passages share a single thread of meaning. Guo and Lü did not elaborate on them. Yi Zhu alone commented: Yuan Xian was poor yet without resentment; Master Zeng was poor yet able to console himself; Yan Hui was poor yet took joy in the Way. He who nurtures his will forgets his form—this was Yuan Xian. He who nurtures his form forgets profit—this was Master Zeng. He who attains the Way forgets his mind—this was Yan Hui.

Bi Xu noted: When Zilu served as minister in Wei, he arrived at Yuan Xian’s humble abode with a team of four horses and a retinue of carriages, and sighed at his "affliction." Yuan Xian replied that he was poor, not afflicted, and Zilu was shamed by his own misplaced words. To chase after worldly trends, to seek fame and position, to curry favor and form cliques, to study without self-cultivation, to teach for material gain—these are the corruptions of benevolence and the ostentation of fine carriages. How could one who studies the Way bear to do such things? Yuan Xian studied the Way and practiced it, upholding righteousness without bending. Master Zeng nurtured his will and thus did not seek office; he forgot profit and thus had few companions. He forgot his mind and thus merged with the Way. "He who knows contentment is not disgraced; he who knows when to stop is not endangered." He who is not disgraced has cultivated conduct within; he who is not endangered does not chafe at lacking rank. This is what Confucius recited, and now, in Yan Hui, he saw it embodied.

Juan Zhai remarked: The two chambers both had jars for windows, so he used cloth to block the wind and rain. His hat was made of birch bark. His trailing sandals dragged as he walked. To embellish wickedness with benevolence and righteousness is called *te*. His padded robe was quilted; "no outer layer" means the outer fabric was worn through, revealing the padding. "Swollen and pallid" describes a bloated, unhealthy appearance. The *Odes of Shang* refers to the songs he sang. "As if ringing from metal and stone" describes their rhythmic resonance. He who attains the Way forgets his mind—without mind, he draws near to the Way. To study the Way is enough to bring joy; the Cheng brothers often taught others to seek Yan Hui’s joy, not to pass over it lightly. "I have recited this for a long time" means he had heard the words before but now saw them in a person. Yuan Xian, though living in a wattle hut with a thatched door, sat plucking his zither as if in a grand hall, for benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music never left him. Zilu, though honored as a minister, was a withered branch in a time of decaying virtue; that he deigned to visit showed he had not forgotten their friendship. Yet to ask, "What ails you?" revealed how little he understood. Though he had studied under a sage, his perception was thus. Yuan Xian carefully distinguished poverty from affliction to enlighten him. From "to act in pursuit of worldly favor" to "the trappings of carriages and fine horses" describes the great affliction of scholars—Zilu, though steeped in luxury, did not recognize his own malady. Only Yuan Xian’s sharp admonition served as a true friend’s reproof. Master Zeng’s swollen complexion, calloused hands and feet, snapped cap ties, exposed elbows, and burst shoes revealed his poverty. Yet nurturing his will, he forgot his form; singing as if from metal and stone, his vast integrity filled heaven and earth. Even a ruler of ten thousand chariots could not befriend him, much less make him a minister. Yan Hui, content with poverty and joyful in the Way, did not chafe at lacking rank. Following the Master’s steps and grasping his heart, he did nothing, yet found joy in a gourd dipper—how could those who wear crimson sashes and hold golden seals compare? These three were all Confucius’s finest disciples, who received the Sage’s teachings directly. Their attainments differed in refinement, so their joys differed in depth. Zilu, who roamed the states as an envoy, held high office, and amassed wealth to dazzle the world, found joy far removed from the other two. Thus Zhuangzi cited them as a warning.

The Lord of Zhongshan, Gongzi Mou, said to Zhanzi, "My body dwells by rivers and seas, yet my heart lingers at the palace gates—what is to be done?" Zhanzi replied, "Value life. If you value life, profit will seem light." The Lord of Zhongshan said, "Though I know this, I cannot overcome myself." Zhanzi said, "If you cannot overcome yourself, then yield. What harm is there in that? But if you cannot overcome yourself and yet force yourself not to yield, this is called double injury."

The doubly injured man belongs to no long-lived kind. Wei Mou, a prince of a ten-thousand-chariot state, found it harder to dwell in caves and grottoes than a commoner would; though he had not yet attained the Way, he may be said to have grasped its intent. Guo and Lü passed over him without discussion.

Dubious Annotation: Prince Mou of Wei was enfeoffed at Zhongshan. Zhanzi was a worthy man of Wei. The prince’s noble heart was most difficult to overcome, so though his body dwelt by rivers and seas, his heart lingered at the palace gates. He confessed his inability to forget wealth and honor—how could he let them go? The answer came: value life, and profit will seem light; when profit is light, thoughts of the palace gates will fade. Though Mou knew life should be valued and things made light, his heart could not overcome itself, and thus he harbored private attachments. Zhanzi told him: if you cannot overcome your attachments, then yield—will the spirit find fault in that? The spirit is born of emptiness, but Mou’s heart was not yet empty, so he could not overcome himself. To force himself not to yield was to bruise his passions and doubly injure his nature, placing him among those without longevity.

To say that Mou, a prince of a ten-thousand-chariot state, could suddenly retire to caves and grottoes and live as a commoner would be truly difficult; yet having grasped the intent, he might yet be expected to attain it. The *Bixu Annotation* states: Though Prince Mou had once savored the blandness of the Way, he could not overcome the allure of sweet bait. To follow his inclinations is to nourish life; to resist the spirit is to invite harm. Having lost the joy of nurturing form and added the sorrow of resisting the spirit, what is this if not double injury?

Wei Mou admired the fame of noble reclusion but fell short of its substance. His intent was easily aroused, his resolve hard to maintain; yet compared to those who blindly chase wealth and honor, he was surely a step ahead. *Yuanzhai* says: Know that my life may be valued, and external things will grow light. If principle cannot yet prevail, then yield for now and do not force restraint. Forced restraint harms the spirit, and the spirit abhors it. This is no way to nurture oneself—it excludes one from the long-lived kind. He may be said to have grasped the intent and to be striving to practice it.

The *xiangwei* and *guanque* were the gates of a lord’s palace. The *Huainanzi* writes it as *chouque*, with the same pronunciation and gloss. Xu Shen’s annotation: the two watchtowers of the Son of Heaven.

“Cannot overcome oneself, then yield” means to follow one’s nature and passions without forced restraint. Some connect it to the spirit, meaning to follow where the heart-spirit inclines. Yet those who study the Way should diminish passions and eliminate desires, aspiring to purity and emptiness. To say instead that one should follow one’s nature and passions, allowing the spirit to harmonize and the mind to flow freely, is to find no fault in failing to overcome oneself. And to say that forced restraint without yielding is double injury is to advocate indulging passions and pleasures as the Way, akin to what *Liezi* records of Guan Yifu’s teaching: the Way of nurturing life is to give free rein and not restrain.

Tracing the original intent: Prince Mou was born into wealth and honor, so to retire to caves and grottoes was truly difficult. If he over-restrained his passions, he risked injuring his nature, so he was gently guided to advance step by step—this, too, is a path to success. Zhuangzi took this as an exhortation to those of wealth and honor who study the Way, that they might not turn back at the precipice. Guan Yifu, by contrast, made strengthening the state and its armies his concern, so his teachings were partial and incomparable to Mou’s.

Zhanzi’s words cannot serve as a model for those who study the Way—like a skilled physician treating illness, he tailored his prescription to the patient, aiming only to cure. *The Ocean of Meanings in the True Classic of Zhuangzi*, Scroll Ninety-Three, ends here. *The Ocean of Meanings in the True Classic of Zhuangzi*, Scroll Ninety-Four.

The Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin on *"Yielding the Throne"* (Second Chapter)

When Confucius was stranded between Chen and Cai, he went seven days without cooked food, his vegetable broth ungrained, his complexion utterly spent—yet he still plucked the zither and sang within his chamber. Yan Hui picked wild greens, while Zilu and Zigong conferred, saying: "The Master was twice exiled from Lu, his name erased in Wei, his tree felled in Song, impoverished in Shang and Zhou, besieged in Chen and Cai. Whoever slays him incurs no guilt; whoever tramples him faces no prohibition. Yet he never ceases his zither and song—can a noble man be so shameless?"

Yan Hui had no reply. He entered and told Confucius, who pushed aside his zither and sighed deeply: "You and Ci are petty men. Summon them—I shall speak to them." Zilu and Zigong entered. Zilu said: "This can truly be called destitution!" Confucius replied: "What words are these! The noble man who attains the Dao is called *attained*; one who is cut off from the Dao is called *destitute*. Now I embrace the Dao of benevolence and righteousness, yet suffer the calamities of a disordered age—how can this be called destitution? Thus, when I look within and am not cut off from the Dao, when I face peril and do not lose my virtue, when the cold arrives and frost and snow descend, I know the flourishing of the pine and cypress. The straits of Chen and Cai—are they not a blessing for me?"

Confucius then calmly returned to his zither and strummed, while Zilu, elated, took up his shield and danced. Zigong said: "I did not know the height of Heaven or the depth of Earth. The ancients who attained the Dao found joy in destitution and joy in success—what they rejoiced in was not destitution or success, but the presence of virtue and power. Then destitution and success became as regular as the cycles of cold and heat, wind and rain. Thus Xu You delighted in Yingyang, and Gong Bo found contentment on Mount Qiu."

Guo Xiang’s commentary omits this. Lü’s annotation: From Yan He and Yu Kou to Confucius, none recklessly accepted the titles, emoluments, or gifts of others, enduring poverty, lowliness, cold, and hunger without altering their joy. Next was Prince Mou, who, though not yet attaining the Dao, possessed its intent. Worldly men, steeped in human artifice, hear of the ways of Xu You and Shan Juan and dismiss them as madness, refusing belief. Thus, none among the sages and worthies failed to delight in the Dao, forgetting their lives. If even forgetting life—so difficult—was undertaken, then surely not harming one’s life for the sake of the world or the state was easily understood.

Yi Zhu’s commentary: The Master’s Dao filled the space between Heaven and Earth. How could success or failure burden him? When he was trapped in Chen and Cai, cut off from all above and below, going seven days without cooked food, the Master did not take it as cause for sorrow but continued his zither and song. At that time, only Yan Hui truly understood him. Zilu and Zigong could not escape the charge of shamelessness, so he summoned the two and spoke of success and failure lying in the Dao, not in external things. "Now I embrace the Dao of benevolence and righteousness—how can this be called destitution?" This was facing peril without losing his virtue. Virtue and power reside within; without peril, they cannot be seen—just as only in bitter cold does one know the pine and cypress. Thus the Master considered it a blessing. He then returned to his zither and strummed, and the two disciples, enlightened, took up shields and danced. "I did not know the height of Heaven or the depth of Earth" expresses the ineffable vastness of the Master’s Dao. From this, one knows that the ancients who attained the Dao found joy in both success and failure, for what they rejoiced in was not success or failure.

Bi Xu’s commentary: "This can truly be called destitution" shows that they judged progress by success or failure in time, not knowing the root of the Dao. The pine and cypress flourish when frost and snow arrive; the sage remains unshaken amid peril. Using the examples of Duke Huan, Duke Wen, and the King of Yue to illuminate the straits of Chen and Cai, the truth is that the Dao is made manifest through events. "The height of Heaven and the depth of Earth" alludes to the greatness of Confucius’ Dao. Virtue and power are like metal and stone—once tuned, they cannot be altered. Success and failure are like the zither and lute—when a melody ends, the tuning changes. Thus, success and failure lie with man, like wind and rain, cold and heat—constant principles of Heaven. Xu You declined Yao’s throne and withered in Yingyang; Gong Bo declined office and found his will on Mount Qiu; Confucius, undaunted by the straits of Cai and Chen, stood firm between the two states.

Juan Zhai’s notes: *Bu san* means "without grains of rice." *Jie* means "to trample and humiliate." "The cold arrives, the pine and cypress flourish" refers to their late-withering nature. Through the straits of Chen and Cai, the sage’s unyielding integrity in destitution was revealed, serving as a model for later generations—hence it is called a blessing. *Xiaoran* suggests the sound of a carefree, unburdened manner. *Heran* describes a joyful, leaping appearance. Zigong’s words express his sudden awakening. "Shang and Zhou" refer to the Zhou capital, which included the old lands and people of Shang. What Zilu and Zigong spoke of were the Master’s outward circumstances; Yanzi understood the Master’s heart, thus transcending words. When success and failure lie in the Dao, worldly gains and losses cannot add or detract. Not being cut off from the Dao means not losing one’s virtue—then what peril could sway him? Only in bitter cold does one know the pine and cypress; only in peril is the sage revealed—this is why it is called a blessing. The Master returned to his zither and song, at peace with fate and unshaken in his joy. Zilu took up his shield and danced with fervor, awakened to the principle and heartened, unaware of his own exuberant movements. Zigong’s words praise the boundless greatness of the Master’s Dao. "Virtue and power" here should be understood as "attainment," as seen in the preceding text. Xu You and Gong Bo delighted in their own joy because they had attained this Dao. Mount Qiu is a mountain name.

Bi Xu’s *Southern Ancient Manuscript* reads: "The flourishing of the pine and cypress" is followed by three examples: Duke Huan attained it, Duke Wen of Ju attained it, and the Kings of Wu and Yue attained it at Kuaiji. Hence his commentary. The character *zhi* ("will") appears after "Gong Bo attained," and "impoverished in Shang and Zhou"—the character *Shang* is problematic, and various interpretations omit it without discussion. Only Yongzhai addresses it.

Shun offered the world to his friend Beiren Wuze, who said: "How strange is the Lord’s conduct! Dwelling in the furrows and fields, he should have been content with this alone—yet now he seeks to smear me with his disgraceful deeds. I am ashamed to see him." Thereupon he cast himself into the Qingling Abyss.

When Tang was about to attack Jie, he consulted Bian Sui, who said: "This is not my affair." Tang asked: "Who, then, is suitable?" Bian Sui replied: "I do not know." Tang then consulted Wu Guang, who said: "This is not my affair." Tang asked: "Who, then, is suitable?" Wu Guang replied: "I do not know." Tang said: "What of Yi Yin?" Wu Guang answered: "He is strong and enduring of disgrace—I know nothing beyond this." Tang then plotted with Yi Yin to attack Jie, defeated him, and offered the world to Bian Sui. Bian Sui declined, saying: "When the Lord plotted against Jie, he consulted me—he must have taken me for a villain. Now that he has defeated Jie and offers me the world, he must take me for a greedy man. I was born in a chaotic age, and a man without the Way has twice come to smear me with disgraceful deeds. I cannot bear to hear such things again." He then cast himself into the Chou River and died.

Tang next offered the world to Wu Guang, saying: "The wise plan it, the martial execute it, and the benevolent dwell in it—this is the Way of antiquity. Why do you not take your place?" Wu Guang declined, saying: "To depose a ruler is not righteous; to kill the people is not benevolent; to let others face danger while I enjoy the profit is not upright. I have heard that one does not accept emoluments from unrighteousness, nor tread the soil of a world without the Way—how much less accept its honors? I cannot bear to see this any longer." He then carried a stone and drowned himself in the Lu River.

Guo’s commentary: "A scholar may kill himself to fulfill benevolence, but he does not seek life at the cost of benevolence. Their aspirations were lofty and remote, their noble winds transcended the world—compared to those who drown themselves in profit and power, they were as different as heaven and earth. The old saying claims that men like Bian Sui and Wu Guang regarded the world as beyond the six directions, beyond what others could comprehend. This is mistaken. Those who treat the world lightly cannot hold anything in esteem; if they hold nothing in esteem, they have no cause for death. To regard the world as beyond the six directions is fitting only for Yao, Shun, Yu, and Tang. Detached and unentangled, drifting with the multitude, indifferent to gain or loss—why would they cast themselves away? These two men may be admired for their devotion to fame and their longing for loftiness, but they cannot be said to have placed the world outside themselves."

Lu’s commentary appears in a later chapter.

Yi Du’s commentary: "Shun and Tang followed the same Way. Shun obtained it by compliance, Tang by opposition. Compliance follows heaven to reach man; opposition reverses the Way to enter virtue. Shun’s offer to Beiren Wuze reveals the depth of his return to the mandate. Tang’s conquest of the world and his offers to Bian Sui and Wu Guang show that he had no personal desire for the world—the reason for his attack was for the people, not for himself. The matter of Yi Yin assisting Tang in attacking Jie is fully recorded in the *Book*, but Tang’s offer of the world has never been attested. Zhuangzi created this account to convey the idea of abdication."

Bi Xu’s commentary: "Men of purity regard honor as disgrace. Beiren Wuze, for instance, could stand alongside Zhong Wu as an equal or befriend Ziling without his resolve being shaken by external things. As for Bian Sui and Wu Guang, they refused to serve a chaotic age and fled—why go so far as to drown themselves? Their actions were a rebuke to later generations."

Juanzhai’s commentary: "Shun’s offer to his friend has no other attestation—it is also a parable. *Strong and enduring* means capable of action; *enduring of disgrace* means tolerating defilement. Bian Sui and Wu Guang were ancient recluses; their circumstances cannot be verified. Shun and Wuze were friends, and Shun must have known he was capable of bearing the responsibility, hence his offer of the world. When Wuze refused, Shun should have either abandoned the idea or fled—why cast himself into the Qingling Abyss? The text implies that Shun’s dwelling in the furrows and his visits to Yao’s court were disgraceful—thus his resolve is evident. How could Shun not understand the aspirations of one so far beneath him?

Tang, in his eagerness to attack Jie, was a man of action, while Bian Sui and Wu Guang were men of non-action. For Tang to consult them was like heading north when intending to go south. Only after obtaining Yi Yin did he succeed in defeating Jie. Upon returning, he offered the world to Bian Sui, who not only refused but, ashamed of being defiled, cast himself into the Chou River. When Tang offered it to Wu Guang, Wu Guang enumerated his violations of righteousness, benevolence, and integrity, ultimately refusing his emoluments, refusing to tread his soil, and drowning himself with a stone. These three men were all of lofty integrity, unyielding and steadfast. Since ancient times, death has been no cause for regret—thus the *Nanhua* presents their example to rouse a degenerate age.

Upon reflection, the meaning of this chapter is this: though Shun’s abdication is not recorded elsewhere, his virtue in yielding and being yielded to is perfect and flawless, beyond reproach.
