As for Tang’s abdication, it may not have been his true intention, and he could not escape the world’s censure. The accounts of Bian Sui and Wu Guang drowning in the Chou and Lu Rivers may represent the extreme of their avoidance—it is best to leave them unexamined.

In the rise of the Zhou, there were two scholars in Guzhu named Boyi and Shuqi. They said to each other: 'We have heard there is a man in the west who seems to possess the Way—let us go and observe him.' When they reached Qiyang, King Wu heard of them and sent Shu Dan to meet them. He made an alliance, saying: 'I will grant you wealth two ranks above others and an official position of the first order.' He slaughtered an animal and buried it in the earth as a pledge. The two men looked at each other and laughed: 'Ah! How strange!'"

"This is not what I call the Way. In ancient times, when Shennong ruled the world, his seasonal sacrifices were performed with utmost reverence yet without prayers for blessings. In his dealings with others, he was wholly loyal and trustworthy, governing without seeking anything in return. He delighted in sharing governance with others, taking joy in their governance as his own. He did not complete himself through others’ failures, nor exalt himself through others’ lowliness, nor profit from the times he encountered. Now, the Zhou, seeing the disorder of the Yin, hastily seized power. They schemed above and bribed below, relied on military force to maintain authority, slaughtered animals and buried them to seal oaths as pledges of trust, paraded their conduct to please the masses, and resorted to killing and warfare to seize advantage—this is merely replacing one chaos with another.

I have heard that the scholars of old, when encountering an orderly age, did not shirk their duties, and when facing a disordered age, did not seek mere survival. Now, the world is in turmoil, and the virtue of the Zhou has declined. To align myself with the Zhou would only sully my conduct—it is better to avoid them and keep my actions pure." The two men journeyed north to Mount Shouyang and starved to death.

As for Boyi and Shuqi, when it came to wealth and rank, if they could be avoided, they would not rely on them. With lofty integrity and unyielding conduct, they took solitary joy in their aspirations, refusing to serve the world—such was the resolve of these two scholars.

Guo’s commentary: *The Analects* states that Boyi and Shuqi starved on Mount Shouyang without mentioning their deaths. Here, it speaks of their death to clarify that they upheld the Way to the end.

Lü’s commentary: Those like Wuze, Bian Sui, Wu Guang, Boyi, and Shuqi not only refused the world and its ranks and emoluments but also regarded hearing its words or living in its age as defilement. They chose drowning or starvation rather than compromise, making their joy in the Way and disregard for life all the more difficult—something the sentiments of the common world cannot fathom. These men were all sages and worthies, thus they were certainly enlightened regarding the meaning of life and death.

Some deaths are weightier than Mount Tai, others lighter than a goose feather. The abdications of Shun and Yu, in their later developments, led to the usurpations of Qi of Xia and Tang of Yin, and the deeds of King Wu of Zhou—these were but accumulated consequences. Yet to have heard the example of Wuze, Bian Sui, Wu Guang, Boyi, and Shuqi—how could this not be of great benefit to later ages and the world to come? Thus, death was not what they cherished.

Yet Han Fei claimed that Tang, fearing the world would deem him covetous, offered the throne to Wu Guang, and when he feared Guang would accept, sent someone to persuade him. Tang wished to shift the odium onto his son, whereupon Guang drowned himself in a river. Sima Qian likewise did not believe in the existence of Bian Sui and Wu Guang. Han Fei, who understood the necessity of sacrificing oneself, thus measured Tang and Guang by such standards.

Now, Xu You, Zhi Fu, and Zhi Bo would not exchange their lives for the world, inspiring later ages to value life and disdain profit. Wuze, Bian Sui, Wu Guang, Boyi, and Shuqi, however, abandoned life to sharpen the world’s resolve, inspiring later ages to forget life and esteem righteousness. In their benevolence, they were one and the same.

When Zhuangzi discussed the supreme Way, dismissing fame and profit, Boyi, Shuqi, Bian Sui, and Wu Guang were all criticized. Yet when he spoke of abdicating the throne, awakening the world to the folly of endangering oneself for external things, they were all esteemed. Those who understand this will grasp the meaning without needing words.

Yi Zhu’s commentary: Confucius and Mencius praised Boyi and Shuqi as sages, securing their reputation for posterity. What Zhuangzi recorded were the words of historians, his intent being to correct the world’s folly in sacrificing itself for external things—thus his words could not be without excess. The original purpose of this chapter was to inspire lofty and reclusive conduct, emboldening the timid and rousing the indolent, yet it was not without its flaws. The flaw of Boyi and Shuqi was that it allowed tyrannical rulers to vent their cruelty without anyone daring to resist.

For when one does not encounter the right time, regulating one’s conduct to correct the world may also produce such consequences. But if one acts in accord with the times and follows the natural course of things, then one leaves no trace and incurs no harm.

Bixu’s commentary: In an age of pristine simplicity, sacrifices to the gods were made without seeking blessings, and serving a lord was done without demanding emolument. One governed when called to govern, and administered when called to administer—following the desires of others. The rivers and seas become the kings of all valleys by virtue of their lowliness. Now, to complete oneself, exalt oneself, and seek profit for oneself—this is what the sage does not endorse.

In carrying on King Wen’s legacy, Boyi and Shuqi abandoned Guzhu to seek the one with the Way—how could they have been men who coveted rank and emolument? Gathering ferns on Western Mountain and nurturing their aspirations in the secluded forest—was this not their innate purity?

Yuanzhai’s notes: "Praying for blessings" means seeking fortune. "Without seeking" means without fame. "Sharing governance" means acting without self-interest. "Hastily" means hurriedly. "Bribing" refers to using emoluments to attract the world’s scholars. "Relying on military force" means resorting to perilous means.

To preserve power is to establish martial strength. To display conduct is to make one’s name illustrious. To align with the Zhou means to say, “I and the Zhou share this world”—yet this is the path to defilement. Not relying on it as a resource means the two men did not seek to exalt their integrity or harden their conduct into obstinacy. Had there been a principle by which wealth and rank could be accepted, they would have accepted them; only when it was contrary to righteousness did they act as they did.

When the world united, the Shang fell into chaos. The virtue of the Zhou declined—though the Zhou was then rising, their conduct was already thus, detestable for seizing the world through cunning and strategy. Boyi and Shuqi abandoned their lord’s throne to observe at Qiyang, admiring the transformative power of Zhou’s virtue, wishing to become the people of a sage and together delight in the transformation of non-action. King Wu sent Shu Dan to make a covenant with them and entice them with rank and emolument—how could this have been the aspiration of the two men! Thus, they invoked the age of Shennong to prove the error of the present: in those times, sacrifices did not seek blessings; the seasonal rites at the altar and the harvest festival were performed with utmost reverence to repay the spirits, without any covetous expectations. From this, the governance of the state through non-action can be known. To share in governance is to govern without self-interest; to share in order is to govern without causing disturbance. One does not destroy others to complete oneself, nor belittle others to exalt oneself, nor exploit the times for personal gain. Thus, one regards others as oneself, and all things attain their proper balance.

Now, seeing the disorder of the Yin, the Zhou hastened to cultivate governance, seizing the opportunity of their peril to plot against them. They used emoluments to attract the world’s scholars, preserved power, pleased the masses, and sought profit—no different from replacing one chaos with another. When the times unite and virtue declines, and one rises alongside such an age, fearing the defilement of one’s person, it is better to avoid it. Thus, they went north to Shouyang and willingly starved to death. Starvation is a calamity of the body; the loss of integrity is the cessation of the heart. If the calamity of the heart is extended, it leads to defying punishments and sacrificing righteousness, spreading poison without end. The calamity of the body ends with oneself, yet it is sufficient to stem the tide of decline and revive moral transformation. Thus, the people praise them to this day, and Confucius affirmed their benevolence. The two men sought benevolence and attained it, harboring no resentment.

Now, the world is united, and the virtue of the Zhou has declined. Chen Bixu’s *Ancient Text from the South of the Jiang* reads “the virtue of the Yin declined,” for it was the decline of Yin’s virtue that led the Zhou to destroy them. Master Guo said: The original intent of this chapter is to inspire a spirit of lofty retreat. Those touched by this spirit, even if they are men of reckless ambition who ride the celestial thoroughfare to enter the purple court, will still sigh with emotion midway. How much more so for ordinary men! Thus, the followers of Boyi and Xu You are worthy to stand alongside Hou Ji and Xie, or to face Yi Yin and Lü Shang. Those who dwell in mountains and valleys yet magnify the world—though they may not all become sages’ assistants, are they not still loftier than those mired in dust and grime? Their deeds may be difficult to emulate, yet their influence is less prone to corruption, and thus they are to be esteemed.

Where lies the flaw in Boyi and Xu You? The flaw of Xu You is that it leads people to feign modesty in order to advance, even to the point of choking on water. The flaw of Boyi is that it allows tyrannical rulers to unleash their poison without anyone daring to resist. The flaw of Yi Yin and Lü Shang is that it emboldens reckless heroes of the world to dare to usurp and rebel. Only the sage leaves no trace, and thus has no flaw. If Yi Yin and Lü Shang are considered the traces of the sage, then Boyi and Shuqi are also the sage’s legacy. If Boyi and Shuqi are not the sage’s legacy, then the deeds of Yi Yin and King Wu are also not sagely. The sage follows the natural course of things, thus leaving no trace. Therefore, what is called sagely is that I originally have no advancement, so things attain their traces. Once traces are attained and the name “sage” is forcibly applied, then the sage is but the name of having no trace.

Lu Deming said: Some claim that *Yielding the Throne* places great emphasis on preserving life. Yet why did Bian Sui and Wu Guang throw themselves into the water? The rise of Zhuangzi lies in returning to the root; returning to the root begins with relinquishing glory. Thus, he clarifies the lofty spirit of yielding the throne and sets forth the untrammeled aspirations of defying the world: not descending to sharpen the customs, not enriching oneself to seek life. Though there are words about valuing life, they ultimately return to the intent of abandoning glory, thereby deeply exposing the flaws of worldly affairs. Those of a lesser rank—men who wear coarse cloth and sip congee—preserve the Dao in their loftiness, transcend the world in their freedom, and would rather cast themselves into the clear and cold waters than bow to the burdens of the world.

Liu Gai said: In matters of necessity, there is nothing one does not reject; in matters where one could refrain yet does not, there is nothing one does not take. Rejecting all is akin to restraint; taking all is akin to recklessness. The sage attains the middle way and engages with them, thus both are to be discarded. If one does not attain the middle way and engages with them, then both fall within the realm of judgment. Recklessness and restraint are indeed the flaws of the middle way. Yet later generations of reckless men do not merely advance—they even covet life, love profit, and plunge into the abyss of desire. Those of restraint do not merely refrain from certain acts—they even wash their ears and throw themselves into the abyss to detest the names of Yao and Shun. This is the flaw of recklessness and restraint. Zhuangzi speaks of yielding as a name, situated between giving and receiving, where one should not lose the proper measure. The king is the greatest in the realm; if one can yield the throne, what matter is there that cannot be yielded? Thus, the sage, out of necessity, governs the world, as seen in the case of Wangzi Sou. When the sage is utterly without external things, who would trouble themselves with the world’s affairs? When one is utterly without self within, the world naturally turns to them—how could they refuse? In this way, Yao and Shun’s abdication, Tang and Wu’s conquest, Yi Yin’s service to Tang, and Boyi’s avoidance of Zhou—whether treading the gates of Yao or dwelling in the fields—all share the same principle.

Chu Shi’s general discussion: This chapter records the lofty integrity of those who yielded the throne, from Yao, Shun, Xu You, and Shan Juan to Wangzi Sou. All valued the Dao and honored life, not allowing wealth and rank to burden their hearts, viewing the world as a worn-out shoe.

The disciples Zihua, Yan He, Zeng, Yan, and Gongzi Mou—these men preserved their true nature and upheld simplicity, never allowing profit or rank to sway their resolve, regarding wealth and honor as drifting clouds. Among them, Wei Mou compared himself to the sages and worthies and found himself lacking, yet as a prince of the state, to relinquish the exalted position of kingship and retreat into the seclusion of mountain caves was truly no easy feat. Thus, the far-reaching influence of his noble example awakened in those who held states and thrones the reverence for the Dao and the honoring of life. The teachings of purity and non-action were thereby established, and the legacy of the mysterious sage and the unadorned king was thereby made manifest.

Those in the world who forget themselves and sacrifice to external things, when faced with even the slightest gain or loss, will contend over the merest trifle. Yet to yield the throne while still in possession of it—this may be called the greatest deed under heaven! Those who embrace the Dao and hold fast to virtue, becoming the refuge of others, may not desire a state and instead withdraw into the mountains and seas—such cases exist. Why then did men like Wu Ze and Sui Guang hastily drown themselves, losing their irreplaceable lives? It is because scholars who cannot follow the middle way and instead stand rigidly apart cannot avoid excess. Those who demand too much of themselves pursue their aims without satisfaction, inevitably leading to usurpation; those who yield too much flee without refuge, inevitably leading to self-destruction. This not only demonstrates their refusal to accept but also reveals the extremity of their refusal, exposing it to later generations—an excess of admiration for fame.

Only the sage embodies the mean without excess, yielding or accepting as is fitting, withdrawing or appearing as circumstances allow, moving with ease along the middle way—such were the deeds of Yao and Shun. Boyi and Shuqi yielded their state and fled to Mount Shouyang, where they ate ferns and ultimately perished. They were not like those who deliberately feign loftiness to win fame in later ages; rather, the world had declined in virtue and could not tolerate their coexistence. Their aspiration was to transcend the mundane and rise above, preserving the Dao alone—even death was of no concern! As for those who yield while already rulers, their deeds are conspicuous. Those who avoid rule before ascending the throne—this is their withdrawal and concealment. The resolve to retreat and yield is fundamentally the same; only the timing differs.

*The Ninety-Fourth Scroll of the* Nan Hua Zhen Jing Yi Hai Zuan Wei *is complete.*
*The Ninety-Fifth Scroll of the* Nan Hua Zhen Jing Yi Hai Zuan Wei *begins.*

The Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin studied the *First Chapter on Robber Zhi*.

Confucius was a friend of Liuxia Ji, whose younger brother was Robber Zhi. Leading a band of nine thousand followers, Zhi rampaged across the world, plundering the feudal lords, breaking into homes and prying open doors, driving off people’s cattle and horses, seizing their wives and daughters. Greedy and heedless of kinship, he disregarded parents and brothers, offering no sacrifices to his ancestors. Wherever he passed, great states fortified their cities, small states took refuge in their strongholds, and the common people suffered grievously.

Confucius said to Liuxia Ji: “As a father, one must instruct one’s son; as an elder brother, one must teach one’s younger brother. If a father cannot instruct his son, or an elder brother cannot teach his younger brother, then the bond of father and son, elder and younger brother, is worthless. Now, sir, you are a man of talent in this age, yet your brother is Robber Zhi, a scourge to the world, and you cannot teach him. I am secretly ashamed for you. Allow me to go and persuade him on your behalf.”

Liuxia Ji replied: “You say that as a father one must instruct one’s son, and as an elder brother one must teach one’s younger brother. But if a son does not heed his father’s commands, or a younger brother does not accept his elder brother’s teachings, what can even your eloquence accomplish? Moreover, Zhi’s nature is such that his mind surges like a spring, his intentions gust like the wind. His strength suffices to repel enemies, his eloquence suffices to gloss over wrongs. He is pleased when his heart is followed, enraged when it is opposed, and easily provoked by words. You must not go.”

Confucius would not listen. Yan Hui drove the carriage, and Zigong stood to the right as they went to see Robber Zhi. Zhi was then resting his troops on the southern slope of Mount Tai, mincing human livers to spread upon his mat. Confucius descended from the carriage and stepped forward. Addressing the herald, he said: “I, Kong Qiu of Lu, have heard of the general’s lofty virtue and respectfully bow twice to the herald.” The herald went in to announce him.

When Robber Zhi heard this, he flew into a great rage. His eyes blazed like stars, and his hair bristled beneath his cap. He said: “Is this not that cunning and deceitful man Kong Qiu of Lu? Tell him this: You fabricate words and concoct phrases, falsely invoking Kings Wen and Wu. You wear a cap of branching wood and gird yourself with the flanks of dead oxen. With your glib tongue and deceptive speech, you eat without plowing, clothe yourself without weaving, and flap your lips to stir up right and wrong, deluding the rulers of the world and leading the scholars of the age to abandon their roots. You falsely preach filial piety and brotherly respect, all to seek the luck of enfeoffment and wealth. Your crimes are grave indeed! Flee at once, or I shall add your liver to today’s feast!”

Confucius sent word again: “I, Qiu, am fortunate to be known to Ji and wish to gaze upon the hem of your robe.” The herald relayed this message, and Robber Zhi said: “Let him come forward.” Confucius hastened forward. Robber Zhi, hand on sword and eyes glaring, roared like a nursing tiger: “Come closer, Qiu! If your words please me, you shall live; if they oppose me, you shall die.”

Confucius said: “I have heard that there are three virtues in the world. To be born and grow tall, surpassingly handsome, so that all who see you—young and old, noble and base—are delighted: this is the highest virtue. To comprehend the workings of heaven and earth, to distinguish all things: this is the middle virtue. To be brave, resolute, and daring, to gather followers and lead troops: this is the lowest virtue. Anyone possessing even one of these virtues is fit to face south and style himself a lord. Now, General, you possess all three. Your body stands eight feet and two inches tall, your face and eyes radiant, your lips like bright cinnabar, your teeth like aligned shells, your voice attuned to the *Huangzhong* pitch. Yet you are called Robber Zhi. I am secretly ashamed for you—why not take a nobler name?

If you are willing to heed me, I shall go south to Wu and Yue, north to Qi and Lu, east to Song and Wei, and west to Jin and Chu, to have a great city of several hundred *li* built for you, with a settlement of hundreds of thousands of households. I shall honor you as a feudal lord, renewing the world with you, disbanding your troops and resting your soldiers, gathering and nurturing your brothers, and together offering sacrifices to your ancestors. This is the conduct of a sage and a man of talent, and the wish of all under heaven.”

Robber Zhi said: “Those who can be swayed by profit or admonished by words are but the foolish and base common folk. As for being tall and handsome, so that all who see you are delighted—this is the legacy of my parents. Even if you do not praise me, do I not know it myself? Moreover, I have heard that those who flatter to one’s face also slander behind one’s back. Now you offer me a great city and a multitude of people, seeking to lure me with profit and treat me like the common herd. How can this last? Of all great cities, none is greater than the world itself. Yao and Shun possessed the world, yet their descendants had not even a place to plant an awl! Tang and Wu became Sons of Heaven, yet their lines were later extinguished! Was this not because the profit was too great?

Furthermore, I have heard that in ancient times, beasts were many and people few. The people all dwelt in nests to avoid them, gathering acorns by day and perching in trees by night. They were called the people of the Nest-Builder. In ancient times, people did not know clothing. In summer, they piled up firewood; in winter, they burned it to warm themselves. They were called the people who knew how to live. In the age of Shennong, they lay at ease and rose carefree. People knew their mothers but not their fathers, and lived among the deer. They plowed to eat and wove to clothe themselves, harboring no thought of harming one another. This was the height of perfect virtue. Yet even the Yellow Emperor could not sustain this virtue. He fought Chiyou on the fields of Zhuolu, and blood flowed for a hundred *li*. Yao and Shun arose and established a host of ministers. Tang exiled his lord, and King Wu attacked Zhou. From then on, the strong oppressed the weak, and the many bullied the few. From Tang and Wu onward, all have been men of disorder.

Now you cultivate the Way of Wen and Wu, wielding the world’s eloquence to instruct later ages. You wear fine robes with narrow sashes, uttering artful words and feigning conduct to delude the rulers of the world, all to seek wealth and honor. There is no greater robber than you!”

"Why does the world not call you 'Robber Qiu' and instead call me 'Robber Zhi'? You beguiled Zilu with honeyed words, making him remove his warrior’s cap, lay aside his long sword, and accept your teachings. The world all says, 'Confucius can quell violence and forbid wrongdoing.' Yet in the end, Zilu sought to kill the lord of Wei, and the affair failed—his corpse hung upon the eastern gate of Wei. This proves your teaching was insufficient.

"Do you claim to be a man of talent, a sage? Yet you were twice driven from Lu, your traces erased in Wei, impoverished in Qi, besieged in Chen and Cai, and found no refuge under heaven. Above, you could not secure your own person; below, you could not fulfill the Way of a son. Is this truly worthy of esteem?

"The one the world exalts above all is the Yellow Emperor. Yet even he could not preserve perfect virtue, fighting on the fields of Zhuolu until blood flowed for a hundred *li*. Yao was unfilial, Shun was undutiful, Yu was crippled by partiality, Tang exiled his lord, King Wu attacked Zhou, and King Wen was imprisoned at Youli. These six men are those the world reveres. Yet if one examines them closely, all were deluded by profit, violently distorting their true nature. Their conduct is deeply shameful!

"The world’s so-called worthy men—Bo Yi, Shu Qi, who renounced the lord of Guzhu and starved to death on Mount Shouyang, their flesh left unburied; Bao Jiao, who adorned his conduct to condemn the age, embracing a tree in death; Shentu Di, who remonstrated in vain, carried a stone into the river, and was devoured by fish and turtles; Jie Zitui, the paragon of loyalty, who cut flesh from his thigh to feed Duke Wen, only to be betrayed—enraged, he departed and burned to death in the forest. Weisheng, who arranged to meet a woman beneath a bridge, and when she did not come, the waters rose, yet he would not leave, holding fast to the pillar until he drowned. These six men, so zealous in their conduct, differ not from stray dogs, wandering swine, or beggars clutching gourds. All pursued fame and scorned death, heedless of nurturing their lives and preserving their destinies.

"The world’s so-called loyal ministers—none surpass Prince Bigan and Wu Zixu. Zixu was drowned in the river, Bigan had his heart carved out. These two are called loyal ministers, yet in the end, they became the world’s laughingstock. From the highest perspective, even Zixu and Bigan are not worthy of esteem.

"As for what you, Qiu, have said to persuade me: if you spoke to me of ghostly matters, I would not understand. But if you speak of human affairs, they do not exceed these examples—all are things I have heard and known.

"Now let me tell you of human nature: the eyes desire to see beauty, the ears to hear music, the mouth to savor fine flavors, and the will and qi seek fulfillment. The longest-lived reach a hundred years, the average eighty, the shortest sixty. Subtract illness, grief, death, and cares, and in a month, how many moments are there when one opens their mouth to laugh? No more than four or five at most.

"Heaven and earth are without end, but human death comes at its appointed time. Clutching this finite vessel and entrusting it to the boundless, it vanishes in an instant—no different from a swift steed galloping past a crack. Those who cannot delight their will and nurture their lives are not masters of the Dao.

"All that you, Qiu, have said, I reject. Hurry, leave and return home. Speak no more of it. Your Way is frantic and erratic, a web of deceit, cunning, and falsity. It cannot preserve the true. What is there to discuss?"

Confucius hastened away, exited the gate, mounted his carriage, and three times dropped the reins. His complexion was ashen, his head bowed against the crossbar, unable to catch his breath. Returning to the outskirts of Lu’s eastern gate, he encountered Liuxia Ji.

Liuxia Ji said, "Lately, you have been absent for several days, and your carriage and horses bear signs of travel. Might you have gone to see Robber Zhi?"

Confucius looked to the heavens and sighed, "Indeed."

Liuxia Ji asked, "Did Robber Zhi perhaps oppose your intentions as before?"

Confucius replied, "I thought myself free of illness, yet I cauterized myself. I rushed to stroke a tiger’s head and braid its whiskers—how nearly I did not escape its jaws!"

Chen Bixu’s Annotation:
The common folk of the world, who treat life lightly and court death—how do they differ from dogs and swine amid the rushing pebbles, resentful and fleeing in desperation? Like a gourd adrift in the current, they all sacrifice their innate, nurtured lives for the sake of posthumous fame. Those who chase externals grieve that their names will not be praised after death, willingly perishing without turning back. Those who turn inward pursue the joys of the present as enlightenment, flowing with the course of things without adornment. Moreover, the enduring vastness of heaven and earth, the radiant brilliance of sun and moon, are boundless and infinite. Yet now, within the fleeting span of a life, the brief breath of an instant, one entrusts oneself to their midst—yet cannot freely delight the heart and spirit, instead tormenting body and mind to scheme for posthumous fame. Thus, one loses the pristine Way of antiquity. Even in Robber Zhi’s ferocity and stubbornness, the themes he discussed were such that even Confucius could not refute them.

*Yanzhai Oral Exegesis*:
"Gushing spring" is a metaphor for the supremacy of qi. "Whirlwind" signifies lightness and elevation. "Yulun withered" describes calloused hands and feet. "Pebbles" and "swine in the torrent" illustrate how one throws oneself into slaughter like dogs and pigs. "Li" means attachment, indicating clinging to fame. "Not contemplating the root" means losing one’s original, true nature. "Ji" is synonymous with "drawing water." "Qi" means "none." *Chu’s Limited Insights*: A father cannot instruct his son, an elder brother cannot teach his younger brother—this is the misfortune of human relationships. Rampaging across the world, plundering and violent without satiety—this is the misfortune of the people. The Master sought to transform the world through virtue, power, benevolence, and righteousness, yet all followed like shadows and echoes, save for Robber Zhi, who alone could not be swayed—and instead, the Master suffered humiliation at his hands. This is the misfortune of the sage. Yet the Master is like the sun and moon: though momentarily entangled with malevolent eclipses or obscured by drifting sands, how could this ever harm his enduring purpose? For without contrasting the extremes of good and evil to sharpen the argument, or employing vivid imagery to articulate his meaning, his words would fail to fully convey his intent. This is why the sage and the madman are intertwined. The Master first presented the Three Virtues, admonishing him with the lowest, akin to persuading King Wen of Zhao with the Three Swords. Examining Robber Zhi’s words, though born of stubborn disputation, they nonetheless contain their own logic, which cannot be entirely dismissed merely because of the speaker. Yet he observed only the surface and did not grasp the heart, hence the discord in their discourse. This chapter’s language is bold and its spirit unbound, like a surging torrent that cannot be dammed, making it difficult to pin down with commentary. Thus, Master Guo, in his notes on these three chapters, briefly outlines the general meaning, allowing the essence to emerge naturally. Readers must not let the words obscure the intent.

"Shuhu" should be read as "shu" (pivot), pronounced like "ku gou." "Crown of branch-wood" refers to a hat made from the bark of young trees. "Tattered robes" are garments with wide sleeves, like the robes of recluses. "Displaying the corpse is called 'li.'" "Liu" means "boiling." "Li ming" should be "li ming" (profit and fame).

Zizhang asked Mang Goude, "Why do you not act?"
Mang Goude replied, "Without action, there is no trust; without trust, no responsibility; without responsibility, no profit. Thus, one observes fame and calculates profit, and righteousness is deemed true. If one abandons fame and profit and returns to the heart, then the scholar’s conduct cannot be neglected for even a day!"
Mang Goude said, "The shameless grow rich, the deceitful gain prominence. The greatest fame and profit lie in shamelessness and deceit. Thus, one observes fame and calculates profit, and trust is deemed true. If profit is sought, one returns to the heart, and the scholar’s conduct embraces the celestial."
Zizhang said, "In ancient times, Jie and Zhou were exalted as Sons of Heaven, possessing all under heaven. If today you told Zang Ju, ‘Your conduct is like Jie and Zhou,’ he would flush with anger and harbor resentment—such is the disdain of petty men. Confucius and Mo Di were impoverished commoners, yet if today you told a prime minister, ‘Your conduct is like Confucius and Mo Di,’ he would change his expression and deem it insufficient—such is the true esteem of the scholar. Thus, being the Son of Heaven does not necessarily confer nobility, nor does being a poor commoner necessarily confer baseness. The distinction between noble and base lies in the beauty or ugliness of one’s conduct."
Mang Goude said, "Petty thieves are imprisoned, while great thieves become lords. At the gates of lords, righteous scholars reside. In the past, Duke Huan of Qi killed his brother and took his sister-in-law, yet Guan Zhong served as his minister. Tian Chengzi murdered his lord and usurped the state, yet Confucius accepted his gifts. In theory, they are despised; in practice, they are deferred to. Is this not a contradiction in word and deed, clashing within the heart? Is it not perverse?"
Thus, the *Book* says: "Who is evil? Who is good? The successful are heads, the unsuccessful are tails."
Zizhang said, "If you do not act, then kinship and affection lack order, noble and base lack righteousness, elder and younger lack sequence. How can the Five Constants and Six Positions be distinguished?"
Mang Goude replied, "Yao killed his eldest son, Shun exiled his younger brother—where is the order in kinship? Tang exiled Jie, King Wu attacked Zhou—where is the righteousness in noble and base? King Ji was the rightful heir, yet the Duke of Zhou killed his brother—where is the sequence in elder and younger? The Confucians’ hypocritical words, the Mohists’ doctrine of universal love—how can the Five Constants and Six Positions be distinguished? Moreover, you rectify for fame, I rectify for profit. The reality of fame and profit does not accord with principle, nor does it reflect the Way. Daily, I debate with you before Wu Yue, saying: ‘The petty man dies for wealth, the gentleman dies for fame.’ Though their emotions change and their natures differ in what they pursue, when it comes to abandoning what they do for what they do not, they are the same. Thus, it is said: Do not be a petty man, turn back and die for the celestial. Do not be a gentleman, follow the principle of heaven. Whether crooked or straight, observe and align with the celestial limit. Face the four directions, ebb and flow with the times. Whether right or wrong, grasp the round mechanism, stand alone in intent, and wander with the Way. Without turning to act, without completing righteousness, you will lose what you seek."

Do not rush toward wealth, do not die for success—you will abandon heaven thereby.

Bi Gan had his heart carved out, Wu Zixu had his eyes gouged—these were the calamities of loyalty. Zhi Gong testified against his father, Weisheng drowned holding the bridge—these were the perils of trust. Master Bao stood until he withered, Master Shen did not defend himself—these were the harms of integrity. Confucius did not see his mother, Kuangzi did not see his father—these were the failures of righteousness. These are what the ancients transmitted and later generations discuss, believing that the scholar must align his words with his conduct, and thus bear his misfortunes and suffer his afflictions.

Guo’s Commentary: This chapter says that when conduct is exalted, conduct becomes forced; when scholars are valued, scholars become false. Thus, one must despise conduct and belittle scholars to preserve one’s inner truth—only then will conduct be lofty and scholars esteemed.

Lü’s Commentary: Good and evil stand opposed, so Confucius could not transform Robber Zhi. Fame and profit stand opposed, so Zizhang could not persuade the Greedy One. The Greedy One is the one who debated with Wu Yue. Zizhang studied to seek office, so he knew of fame; the Greedy One knew of profit, while Wu Yue embodied the Dao and was trustworthy. To do evil for profit—this the world calls the petty man. To do good for fame—this the world calls the gentleman. This is speaking in terms of the human Dao. In terms of the celestial Dao, the world’s gentlemen are heaven’s petty men. If one follows heaven and accords with its principle, then gentleman and petty man cannot be distinguished. Crooked or straight, observe the celestial mean—then there is no crooked or straight. Face the four directions, ebb and flow with the times—then though centered, do not cling to center as center. This is how the Dao pervades the six directions and opens the four gates, nowhere absent!

Right and wrong are equally boundless. Grasp the round mechanism and respond to all without fail; stand alone in intent and wander with the Way. Then, hesitating to act, you will succeed in every endeavor. All such things are how one reaches heaven. Without turning to act, you will abandon heaven—this is one’s own heaven, not letting human affairs nullify heaven’s decree.

Loyalty, trust, integrity, righteousness—these the world calls fame and goodness, yet all incur misfortune. The world knows only that profit and evil are burdens, but does not realize that fame and goodness are also not the Dao. Thus Wu Yue’s discourse repeatedly returns to this.

Yi Du’s Commentary: Zizhang walked like Yu and hurried like Shun, inviting suspicion of following in their tracks. Zhuangzi, criticizing the nearness of sages, used this to establish his argument. Full yet striving for gain—his pursuit of fame is evident. Conduct is the visible manifestation of virtue. When one has conduct and people trust it, profit follows. Fame and profit arise from trust and conduct; trust and conduct, in turn, arise from righteousness. Zizhang’s discourse centered on righteousness, so when he observed fame and calculated profit, righteousness was genuine. If one abandons fame and profit and returns to the root to observe, then the scholar’s conduct cannot be absent for a single day.

For conduct: conduct oneself with shame, and one’s words are valued for their restraint. The shameless call wealth “gain,” the overly trusting call display “prominence”—this is using many words to seek others’ trust, not possessing trust within oneself. Without shame, one seizes wealth at any cost; with excessive trust, one adorns words to seek advancement. This discourse says that acting for conduct is worse than acting for words. If one abandons fame and profit and returns to the heart, then the scholar’s conduct merely embraces heaven without knowing humanity.

The world’s restless pursuers of fame and profit constantly let human affairs obliterate heaven, so their words are thus. Zizhang said Jie and Zhou had no conduct, so petty men were ashamed to emulate them; Kong and Mo had conduct, so even the noble deferred. The distinction between noble and base lies not in power’s rise or fall, but in conduct’s beauty or ugliness.

The Greedy One further argued that petty thieves steal wealth and are controlled by others; great thieves steal states, become lords, and none can control them—they even steal their sagacity, wisdom, and the seven virtues. Formerly, Duke Huan and Tian Heng were great thieves, yet Guan Zhong served them. Confucius accepted their gifts—judging by words, he belittled their thievery; judging by conduct, he accepted gifts as a minister. Is this not a contradiction in his heart? He also cited the lost *Book*, implying that it is not conduct’s beauty or ugliness that matters, but success as the measure—then regicide and usurpation are not necessarily unprofitable.

Zizhang further said that without conduct, noble and base, close and distant lose order—how can there be norms for ruler and minister, father and son? The Greedy One cited sages and worthies who violated norms and lost order as proof. Moreover, acting for fame or profit both violate the Dao—abandoning the root to chase the branch is the same. “Do not be a petty man” to “you will abandon heaven”—Wu Yue thus explained the earlier meaning and admonished them. “Turning to act, completing righteousness” speaks of the error of pursuing fame. “Rushing toward wealth, dying for success” speaks of the error of pursuing profit. Only without pursuit, in accord with nature, is perfection.

Bi Gan and those below—these ancient men of loyalty, trust, integrity, and righteousness who invited disaster—serve as warnings. Bi Xu’s Commentary: The scholar in the world first cultivates trust and conduct, then service follows; when service is clear, emolument follows; when emolument is clear, office is prominent and righteousness manifest. If one abandons fame and profit and reflects inward, then for even a moment one cannot forsake conduct and righteousness.

*Xin* (trust) sounds like *shen* (extension), as below—worldly scholars endure disgrace to extend themselves, seeking abundant profit and fame, clamoring unceasingly for coarse clothes and meager food. If one abandons fame and profit and reflects inward, not relying on cultivation and adornment but embracing and guarding heaven’s mandate to await it—Jie and Zhou had position but no conduct, so petty men were ashamed to join them. Kong and Mo had no position but had conduct, so ministers and lords revered them, valuing virtue over position.

Confucians are slippery and unfit to emulate; Mohists self-righteously prepare for the world’s crises—how can they distinguish the Dao of ruler and minister, father and son, husband and wife?

Those who now claim the title of scholar are neither drowned in fame nor buried in profit—yet both remain contrary to principle, still unable to cast off their bonds. In the past, those of us below you and I shared no binding words. What we did was follow our own nature; what we did not do was contrived. Things are not done for profit—one simply returns to one’s natural state; they are not done for fame—one merely follows heaven’s principle. If one merely assists your natural endowment, then questions of right and wrong are discarded and no longer debated. With every glance unobstructed and every action grounded, holding fast to your judgments without being swayed by others’ approval or disapproval—this is called the "round mechanism." When the mind is not entangled with things, one stands alone and wanders with the Dao.

If conduct is facile, one chases after circumstances; if righteousness is achieved, one loses authenticity and forfeits one’s purpose. Zizhang took this as the practice of conduct and righteousness—yet those who hasten toward wealth invite disaster, and those who seek completion often fail and abandon heaven’s mandate. If one attains by chance, it is through shamelessness that one extends oneself further. Yuanzhai said: Zizhang believed that to seek fame and profit, one must cultivate righteousness as the proper path. But if one abandons fame and profit, the heart rebels, finding no joy in itself—thus one must pursue them, and nothing but the practice of righteousness will suffice. Those who place excessive trust do so by speaking trustworthy words to seek glory and prominence. "Attaining by chance" refers to those who now seek fame and profit through deceit alone. Yet if one abandons fame and profit and returns to the heart, one must still attain them—indulging the heart’s desires as if preserving one’s natural innocence without artifice. The true nature of words and actions clashes within, for they do not align. Success and failure, beginning and end—when one gains favor, one becomes a righteous follower; when one loses it, one becomes a usurper. This shows that the practice of transforming righteousness is all pretense, not natural truth.

The Five Constants, the Six Positions, and the Three Bonds—you may take the names of benevolence and righteousness as attainment, but I act only for profit, without borrowing the pretense of such names. For fame and profit are not true principles. "No binding words" is a metaphor for nature: if one can follow nature, then there are no distinctions of gentleman or petty man, right or wrong—all is seen as the ultimate principle of nature. The four directions correspond to the four seasons, and all movement and stillness are but a single qi. Grasping the round mechanism, one is free from right and wrong; trusting the mind to act alone, one moves with ease along the central Way.

To turn one’s conduct is to turn from the Dao. To "achieve righteousness" is to succeed through righteousness. "None" is interchangeable with "do not."

Should one insist that words be strictly followed to align with loyalty, trustworthiness, integrity, and righteousness, calamity and harm will surely befall—this means that feigning virtue to seek profit and success is no better than acting without pretense, for it distorts Mencius’ distinction between the Heavenly nobility and the human nobility. Conduct is the outward manifestation of righteousness, while trust and profit serve as its validation. Righteousness arises from within, and when conduct is revealed externally, trust and profit follow from without; thus, examining fame and profit reveals the truth of righteousness. If one does not speak of fame and profit but instead turns inward to the heart, then the scholar’s practice of righteousness cannot be abandoned even for a day. For the scholar’s duty is to act with righteousness, and whether fame or profit come or not is of no concern—this is the argument of Zizhang.

Seeking trust through excessive speech is the path to wealth and prominence, and the shameless regard this as right. Yet if one disregards fame and profit and turns inward to the heart, then the one who acts does so holding fast to their Heavenly nature, untouched by worldly concerns—this is the argument of the unprincipled. Zizhang was a disciple of Confucius, while the unprincipled were those who corrupted the Way; thus, their views naturally opposed each other.

As for the loftiest discourse—those who hoard wealth yet feel shame at being compared to Jie and Zhou, or ministers who dare not equal Confucius and Mozi—such conduct is truly noble. Yet when petty thieves are imprisoned while great thieves become lords, profit becomes a delight. This further cites the ancient sages to show that each had their biases and could not avoid flaws. The arguments of these two were not aligned, so the unprincipled once debated Zizhang on the principle of "no binding words."

The petty man pursues wealth to the end of the chapter, where the discourse on "no binding words" concludes: both men were bound to their partialities and thus did not accord with the Dao. Better to forget good and evil entirely, to be bound to nothing, and to follow nature—then there is no division between gentleman and petty man, and each attains the correctness of their nature. What room is there for distinctions of right and wrong, inner and outer, or judgments of truth and falsehood?

This is the state of solitary completion, unburdened by external things, thus wandering with the Dao without ever losing it. But if one alters their natural conduct to seek the name of righteousness, or chases wealth and profit in hopes of success, they abandon and extinguish their Heavenly principle, drowning in external things. The examples from Bi Gan’s heart-cutting onward illustrate how those who cling to partialities cannot avoid disaster, yet scholars still take their words as correct, emulate their conduct, and suffer calamity and ruin without awakening.

How lamentable!

*The Southern Florescence: An Exegesis on the Ocean of Meanings of the True Classic, Scroll Ninety-Five, Concluded*

*The Southern Florescence: An Exegesis on the Ocean of Meanings of the True Classic, Scroll Ninety-Six*

**Robber Zhi, Part Two**

Wu of No Feet asked Zhi of Knowing Harmony: "Among men, none ultimately fail to pursue fame and profit. Those who grow wealthy draw others to them; those who draw others humble themselves before them; those who humble themselves before them esteem them. To see the esteemed and the humbled—this is the Way of long life, bodily ease, and joyful intent. Yet you alone show no such intent. Is your knowledge insufficient? Or do you know but lack the strength to act? Or do you deliberately reject the upright and cling to error?"

Zhi of Knowing Harmony replied: "Consider those whom this man deems his contemporaries, born in the same age and dwelling in the same village—he regards them as transcendent beings who surpass the common world. Yet they lack any steadfast principle, merely surveying the times of past and present, the distinctions of right and wrong, and conforming to custom. They cast aside what is most weighty, abandon what is most honorable, all for the sake of what they do. How far this is from the Way of long life, bodily ease, and joyful intent!

Grievous pain and serene joy are not reflected in the body; trembling fear and trembling delight are not reflected in the heart. They know how to act but not *why* they act—thus, though they be honored as Son of Heaven and possess all under Heaven, they cannot escape suffering."

Wu of No Feet said: "Wealth brings every advantage to man. It exhausts beauty and exhausts power, reaching what even the perfected cannot attain, what the worthy cannot match. It wields the courage and strength of others to augment its might, employs the wisdom and schemes of others to sharpen its discernment, and appropriates the virtue of others to adorn its goodness. Though it does not rule a state, it commands reverence like a lord or father.

Moreover, the allure of sounds and sights, flavors and power—these delight the heart without need of learning, and the body finds ease in them without need of imitation. Desires and aversions, attractions and avoidances—these require no teacher, for they are man’s very nature. Though all under Heaven may condemn me, who can renounce them?"

Zhi of Knowing Harmony replied: "The actions of the wise move in accord with the people and do not transgress their measure. Thus, contentment brings no contention, and having no ulterior purpose, they seek nothing. Those who lack contentment seek and contend in all directions yet do not deem themselves greedy; those who have surplus relinquish it, even casting aside all under Heaven, yet do not deem themselves modest. The true nature of modesty and greed lies not in external compulsion but in returning to one’s inner measure.

Though one wields the power of the Son of Heaven, one does not use nobility to lord over others; though one possesses all under Heaven, one does not use wealth to toy with others. Calculating the harm, considering the consequences, one sees that these bring injury to one’s nature—thus one declines and does not accept, not to seek fame or reputation.

Yao and Shun ruled as emperors and brought harmony, yet they did not act out of benevolence toward all under Heaven but to avoid allowing beauty to harm life. Shan Juan and Xu You were offered the throne yet refused it, not out of empty deference but to avoid allowing affairs to harm themselves. All these pursued what benefited them and declined what harmed them. Though all under Heaven called them worthy, they did not act to cultivate fame or reputation."

Wu of No Feet said: "If one must cling to reputation, endure bodily hardship, and deny sweetness to preserve life, one is no different from a chronically ill man who drags himself along a long slope, never dying."

Zhi of Knowing Harmony replied: "Equilibrium brings blessing, while excess brings harm—this is true of all things, but wealth is the most extreme case. Now, the rich man’s ears are filled with the sounds of bells, drums, pipes, and flutes; his mouth savors the tastes of fine meats and sweet wines, stirring his intent and causing him to neglect his affairs—this may be called chaos. He drowns in arrogance, as if bearing a heavy burden while climbing—this may be called suffering. Greedy for wealth, he exhausts himself; greedy for power, he depletes himself. At rest, he drowns; in comfort, he swells—this may be called sickness. Seeking wealth and profit, he fills his ears like a wall yet does not know to avoid harm, pressing forward without cease—this may be called disgrace. Wealth accumulates yet goes unused; he clings to it without release, his heart filled with sorrow and resentment, seeking ever more without end—this may be called anxiety. Within, he fears the treachery of flatterers; without, he dreads the harm of bandits and thieves. Within, he surrounds himself with high towers and moats; without, he dares not walk alone—this may be called fear.

These six are the greatest harms under Heaven, yet men neglect and fail to examine them. When calamity strikes, they exhaust their nature and squander their wealth, seeking in vain to return to a single day of carefree ease. Thus, when they look for fame, they find it not; when they seek profit, they gain it not. They strain their intent and exhaust their bodies in pursuit of this—is this not delusion?"

**Guo’s Annotation:** This chapter speaks of how those who know contentment are ever content.
**Lü’s Annotation:** Wu of No Feet takes wealth as the means to see others humbled and esteemed, deeming it the Way of bodily ease and joyful intent. Zhi of Knowing Harmony, however, holds that the wealthy, though born in the same age and dwelling in the same village, are readily humbled and esteemed by the world—this shows their lack of inner principle. They conform to custom, casting aside what is most weighty and most honorable, mistaking worldly pursuits for the Way. How far this is from bodily ease and joyful intent!

Grievous pain and serene joy are not reflected in the body; trembling fear and trembling delight are not reflected in the heart—thus they know how to act but not *why* they act. This is like using the Marquis of Sui’s pearl to shoot a sparrow at a thousand *ren*’s height. Though one may be most noble and most wealthy, one cannot escape suffering—how much less those who are content with wealth?

Wu of No Feet takes wealth as the natural inclination of man, asking who can renounce it. Zhi of Knowing Harmony holds that those who do not know contentment cannot yield even an inch, thus contending in all directions yet not deeming themselves greedy. Those who know contentment do not take all under Heaven as their own, thus casting it aside yet not deeming themselves modest. The true nature of modesty and greed lies in returning to one’s inner measure.

*Measure* refers to the varying capacities of vessels, implying that human nature is not uniform—this cannot be so. "Drowning in arrogance" speaks of relying on abundant resources, their *qi* swelling with pride. "In comfort, he swells" means that when the body is sleek and well-nourished, one relies on it and neglects self-preservation. The text exhaustively describes the harms of wealth, showing how it ultimately leads to this: when one looks for fame, it is not seen; when one seeks profit, it is not gained.

Those who twist their intentions and sever their bodies in contention—this is what was earlier called "acting for the sake of harmony yet not knowing why one acts." Confucius could not transform Robber Zhi, and Zizhang could not subdue the covetous; the covetous took what was right from Wu Yue, while Wu Zu was humbled by One Who Knows Harmony. Thus, it is clear that neither good nor evil, fame nor profit, can overcome one another—only virtue and the Dao can prevail.

*Dubious Annotation*: Those without enough to eat yet unaware of their portion say that no one does not desire to rise in fame and pursue profit. When people covet another’s wealth, they submit to and serve them; being thus submitted to, one may nourish their own nobility, and their heart rejoices. Why then do you have no such intention? Is your wisdom insufficient to attain this, or your strength unable to act? Or do you persist in right principle yet still harbor the mind of one who abandons it to seek sustenance?

One Who Knows Harmony responds: Those who now love profit and desire wealth, lacking inner constancy, do not even enjoy their own riches and honor but merely take pride in sharing the same life and village with the wealthy. They consider this surpassing the world and transcending custom—yet in truth, they are transformed along with the world. Thus, they abandon life, the weightiest of all, and cast aside the Dao, the most exalted, believing that what others do is beyond their capacity, unable to entrust themselves to Heaven’s spontaneous action. Are they not far indeed from the Dao?

Human nature is stirred by things, moved by what the body does not inherently possess and the heart does not inherently hold. Those who act for the sake of acting love action; the reason for acting lies in non-action, where nothing is left undone. Only because people do not understand non-action do they, though dwelling in the utmost wealth and honor, still fail to escape exhaustion.

Wu Zu further says: Wealth’s power over others exhausts all beauty under Heaven and reaches the limits of all influence—even sages and worthies cannot match it, nor can virtue and the Dao overcome it. The brave enhance its might, the wise sharpen its discernment; it borrows others’ virtue to appear worthy, and though without rank, it commands reverence like a lord or father. Such are the affairs of the wealthy.

As for sounds and sights, flavors and pleasures, power and influence—these are what all people desire, needing no learning to know them, for they are the nature manifest in emotion. Who under Heaven can refuse them?

One Who Knows Harmony again says: The wise act for the sake of the people, not deviating from their measure. This measure is the law of the heart. Thus, being content, they contend for nothing; acting without contrivance, they seek nothing. Those who are now discontent seek in all directions and contend to obtain, yet do not deem themselves greedy or excessive. Therefore, though they gain all under Heaven, they may decline it without deeming themselves modest. The names of greed and modesty, though seen outwardly, arise inwardly; reflecting within, one knows this well.

Not using nobility to domineer over others ensures long retention of nobility; not using wealth to toy with others ensures long retention of wealth. Perceiving this in its subtlety, calculating gains and losses, fearing harm to one’s nature, one declines and does not accept—not to seek fame and reputation, yet the world naturally ascribes fame and reputation to them. Yao and Shun’s yielding to Xu You and Shan Juan’s refusal of office were both cases of avoiding harm and declining profit, not seeking fame, yet fame arose nonetheless.

Wu Zu says of One Who Knows Harmony’s aspirations: Clinging to fame and reputation, tormenting the body and rejecting pleasure—how is this different from a long illness, enduring suffering without dying?

One Who Knows Harmony says: Among all things under Heaven, equilibrium is fortune, excess is misfortune—and wealth is the most extreme! Now the wealthy are deluded by external desires, neglecting their fundamental tasks, obstructed by unruly *qi*, like one bearing a heavy load while climbing high. Can this not be called suffering? Coveting wealth and power to comfort the heart and exhaust the mind, when at rest they drown in desire; when the body is sleek, they rely on it and act recklessly. If they seek and do not obtain, illness arises. Amassing wealth like a wall, clinging without release, disgrace will come! The ancients accumulated wealth and stored grain to prepare for famine, disease, and calamity in their villages, using it to aid others and perfect virtue. Now the wealthy hoard without use, endlessly seeking more, their worries accumulating within, their thoughts unceasing; guarding and protecting without, they prepare for everything. Wealth is the greatest harm under Heaven! All neglect to consider the threat of thieves and bandits, who will seek to take everything—by then, the nature of life is already exhausted. Having depleted their accumulated wealth, they may even long to return to a single day of poverty, carefree and unburdened—but this cannot be obtained!

Yet they still entangle their intentions with deep thoughts and sever their bodies to fend off calamity. Is this not delusion?

*Blue Void Annotation*: This chapter further explains the previous two. Those who seek fame desire nobility; those who pursue profit desire wealth. These are the paths to ease—who lacks such intentions? Some are dull-witted and unaware; others know but lack the strength to act. Persisting in right principle without forgetting, they say they entrust themselves to fate and do not take—what then do they have to do with wealth and honor? The worldly take pride in sharing the same era and village with the wealthy, considering it surpassing others. But those with inner constancy are not swayed by things; those who comprehend past and present are not moved by affairs.

Nothing is weightier than the self; nothing is weightier than life. Yet now, conforming to custom and being transformed by the world, they abandon what is weightiest and cast aside what is most exalted, believing in what others do and unable to entrust themselves to Heaven’s spontaneous action. How far are they from the way of peace for the body and joy for the mind?

In poverty and lowliness, they are fearful and anxious; in wealth and honor, they are indulgent and complacent—this is obscuring the root and prizing the traces. Those who act for the sake of acting pursue fame and profit, unaware of what wealth and honor truly are. Abandoning their own spontaneous action to seek what is pursued, they know they cannot escape it.

The ants in a mound gather around stench; the scholar who covers his face in shame refuses food offered with contempt. Fish forget one another in rivers and lakes; people forget one another in the arts of the Dao—what need is there for reliance or coercion?

The unrestrained delight in sounds and sights; the arrogant and extravagant find comfort in power and influence—this is human nature. Who does not desire it? Acting for the sake of the people is not for oneself. Not deviating from their measure means reducing selfishness and curbing desire.

"Contending in all directions" refers to waging war across the four quarters.

Their aspiration lies in pacifying the people, not in coveting treasures and goods—thus they are not greedy. Yet when their merit is accomplished and their name established, they abdicate their position with propriety, not considering themselves paragons of integrity.

Prince Sou fled into the cinnabar caves; Yan He fed oxen to decline an official summons—did they seek fame and reputation? Shun offered the world to Shan Juan, but Shan Juan, tending his fields, paid no heed—did he seek fame and reputation?

Those obsessed with gluttony regard tranquility as sickness and solitude as cowardice, unaware that ease is fortune and excess is harm. Wealth invites swift disaster, more ruinous than other things, yet the world remains blind to this.

When men of tranquility and solitude observe bells, drums, fine wine, and rich feasts, they see the ruin of the Dao and its practices. When they observe surfeit and luxury, they see the stirring of hardship and suffering. When they observe those who seek comfort in power and influence, they see them drowning in bodily afflictions. When they observe those who snatch gold without hesitation, they see them suffering worse than execution and disgrace.

Yet the hoarding never ceases, and anxiety and fear never dissipate. Once disaster strikes and their lives collapse, they only wish their accumulated wealth would swiftly vanish. At such a time, their true nature is exhausted, their wealth depleted. They long to release hawks and hounds on the hunting grounds, to hear the cranes cry at Huating—how could such things ever be regained?

*Yunzhai notes: "This refers to the wealthy and powerful."*
They possess no lofty, unattainable conduct; their hearts lack constancy, and they lose their true nature, swayed by common customs. It is nothing more than observing the inclinations of past and present to seek personal gain.

What is most weighty and revered—heavenly principle—they abandon and forsake, solely pursuing what they call the quest for wealth and honor. How can this be the way to peace of body and joy of mind?

What they do is human effort; why they do it is heavenly principle. To abandon heavenly principle and not follow it, even the Son of Heaven cannot escape calamity—how much less those beneath him?

The wealthy and powerful exhaust all that is beautiful and excellent, wielding all their power and influence. Even the most realized persons and worthies cannot match them. They employ others, rely on others—all speak of their power to command things, as the common saying goes: "Wealth can reach the gods."

Though the world may deem me wrong, how can I evade it? This is the speech of those who set themselves above others.

The wise act with the shared endowment of heaven in the people as their guiding principle, never daring to transgress the laws and measures. When their virtue suffices for themselves, they have nothing to contend over. Their actions do not depend on others, and their pursuits involve no entanglement.

The four quarters are the four directions. The essence of integrity and responsibility does not lie in external pursuits but in seeking heavenly principle and the laws, reflecting upon them. Turning inward to consider, they do not let a fine reputation harm themselves. Though they possess the world, they do not cling to it; though worthy fame returns to them, they feel no shame. They do not seek to establish fame and reputation—this is how Yao, Shun, and Xu You are all spoken of with approval.

*Wu Zu says:* If one must seek fame and not wealth, they merely torment their body. Though their body remains, it is as if afflicted with a lingering, undying illness.

The lines *"Ease is fortune; excess is harm—wealth in its extremity"* are most profound.

*Xian* means to stuff one’s mouth full. *Hai ni* means to be ill at ease. *Feng qi* means anger that blocks the qi. *Wei* means satisfaction. *Qu jie* means to exhaust all effort.

Though they dwell in stillness, they are submerged in desires; their bodies grow plump and sleek, bearing the air of arrogance and surfeit. Their wealth piles up like a wall, clung to without release; sorrow and anxiety fill their chests. What they hoard within, they fear others will seize; what they deploy without, they fear bandits and thieves will plunder—truly, they are beset by worry and dread.

When disaster arrives, though they wish to preserve their lives and relinquish their wealth, they cannot achieve even a day’s peace like a poor man. Their nature is spent, their wealth exhausted. *Dan* means alone. *Liao yi jue ti* means their minds and bodies are bound.

*Wu Zu* delights in profit, so he speaks of the wealthy enjoying peace of body and joy of mind. If one attains wealth to live in the world and nurture life, nothing is not beneficial.

*Zhi He* pursues harmony in fame, so his actions never transgress measure. Content, he does not seek more; calculating gain and reflecting on return, he knows profit cannot be relied upon and that greed swiftly invites disaster. Thus he declines and does not accept—not to seek reputation, for reputation comes to him of its own accord.

*Wu Zu* further mocks those who cling to fame and torment their bodies, no different from living with a diseased gallbladder. *Zhi He* tells him that ease is fortune and excess is harm, expounding the ultimate discourse of the world. *Wu Zu* is thus convinced in his heart.

From here to the end of the chapter, it thoroughly describes the schemes and machinations of the wealthy, which cannot escape the discernment of the enlightened. Yet all is of no benefit to themselves, and in the end, they cannot avoid becoming mere hoarders for great thieves.

When disaster arrives, it is too late to realize their error. As Shi Chong sighed at the execution ground, "My slaves only coveted my wealth."

The *Nanhua* bewilders in this way; those who hear it should take it as a warning.

*Gai* is pronounced *gai*, meaning extraordinary. *Feng* is pronounced *ping*, meaning pent-up frustration. *Jiao* is the same as *jiao* (scorched). *Lou shu* refers to windows. *Liao rao qi yi* means deep contemplation. *Ci jue qi ti* means forgetting life.

*Liu Gai says:* If the world has no right and wrong, right and wrong arise from human sentiment. If the world has right and wrong, right and wrong dissolve in human nature. The virtue of right is auspicious; the virtue of wrong is inauspicious. The *Book of Changes* says: "Auspicious and inauspicious are the victory of correctness."

Those who cannot unite in correctness and forget distinctions, but instead entangle themselves in the realm of human effort, each valuing themselves and belittling others—who can settle this? Thus, though Confucius and Robber Zhi are divided, they call each other thieves.

Zhuangzi was not unaware of honoring Confucius and despising Robber Zhi. But because the world does not awaken to the principle of forgetting distinctions, they vie with knowledge and boast of ability. If one were to follow sentiment and honor them, right and wrong would become even more pronounced, and the true nature of life would grow ever more chaotic.

Thus, by borrowing what the world universally condemns to confound one’s self-righteous sentiments, even a sage cannot prevail in debate. Therefore, the chapter concludes by deeming Zizhang’s words inadequate and ending with the discourse on *zhihe* (knowing harmony).

Master Chu’s comprehensive commentary states: Robber Zhi’s arguments, though forceful in sophistry and self-aggrandizement, ultimately forced even the sagely and wise to concede—making him the most violent and wicked in the world. Some critics condemn the text for its irreverence toward the sacred, attributing it to later fabrications, but this reasoning is flawed. The benevolence of Confucius and the brutality of Robber Zhi are self-evident, requiring no debate. The purpose of such discourse is to illuminate the perfection of the Master’s sagely Dao and the vastness of his accommodating virtue. Yet how could Robber Zhi truly comprehend the source of the Master’s sageliness? Judging conduct by conduct, discerning hearts by hearts—his arguments, though seemingly sound, merely reflect his own limited understanding of the Master. Had Robber Zhi fully grasped the Master’s sageliness, he would no longer be Zhi. Thus, though the Master appeared subdued, his reputation grew ever more exalted; though Zhi exalted himself, his infamy only deepened. The world’s shared sense of right and wrong remains undiminished.

Expounding upon the words to unfold their meaning, the various interpretations are manifold, none surpassing another. Yet I discern an implicit subtlety often overlooked: readers routinely dismiss the text as irreverent, leaving its profound truth obscured for millennia. Thus, I offer this rectification. The original intent was to satirize the rulers and ministers of the time, who, clinging to wealth and power, wielded life and death arbitrarily, impervious to moral transformation. Even were Confucius to return, he would not escape their humiliation. Hence, the text compares them to Robber Zhi, with Confucius speaking in his own voice.

Next, it presents Zizhang’s question on *man gou de* (fulfillment through unprincipled gain). Those who seek fulfillment through such means receive answers no different from Zhi’s. All such arguments aim to prevail over others, blind to the loss of authenticity, the betrayal of principle, and the estrangement from the Dao.

Following this, Wu Zu asks about *zhihe* (knowing harmony), his ambition fixed on fame and profit, prioritizing bodily comfort and personal gratification—another adherent of unprincipled gain. *Zhihe* responds: the wealthy value their accumulations yet know how to distribute them, benefiting the multitude and sustaining all things. The poor depend on them for survival, spared the misery of displacement and starvation. In ancient times, Tao Zhugong excelled in managing wealth; once rich, he dispersed his fortune among his neighbors. Thrice he gave away his wealth, thrice he relocated, even avoiding the reputation of virtue. Today’s wealthy, however, drown in sensual pleasures and insatiable desires, amassing fortunes like towering walls while harboring constant fear. The greater their wealth, the deeper their harm—witness the ruin of Jingu and Gold Valley as cautionary tales. They fare worse than those who till the soil for self-sufficiency, who may nurture life to its full span unburdened.

All this serves as a piercing needle to the world’s deep-seated maladies, subtly revealing the sagely and wise teachings. If scholars could truly abandon superficial traces and delve into the intent behind the words, dissolving the selfishness of fame and profit to return to the great root of the Dao, the transformative power of non-action and tranquility would suffice to bring benevolence and longevity to the Eight Directions—far beyond mere personal well-being.

Herein lies the *Nanhua*’s mission to defend the Dao and propagate transformation, its compassion for the times and pity for the people no different from that of Confucius and Mencius.

*Collected Subtleties of the Meaning of the Nanhua True Scripture*, Scroll 96—concluded.
*Collected Subtleties of the Meaning of the Nanhua True Scripture*, Scroll 97.

The *First Discourse on the Sword* by Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin

In ancient times, King Wen of Zhao was fond of swords. Over three thousand swordsmen gathered as retainers at his gates, clashing before him day and night. Each year, more than a hundred perished or were wounded, yet his passion never waned. After three years, the state declined, and the feudal lords plotted against it. The Crown Prince Kui grew anxious and offered a reward to his attendants: "Whoever can persuade the king to abandon his obsession with swordsmen shall receive a thousand gold pieces." His attendants replied, "Zhuangzi is the one who can do this."

The prince then sent an emissary bearing a thousand gold pieces to present to Zhuangzi. Zhuangzi declined the gift and accompanied the messenger to an audience, asking, "What instruction does the prince have for me, that he offers me a thousand gold pieces?" The prince said, "I have heard that you are enlightened and sagely. I humbly present this thousand gold as a gift for your attendants. If you refuse it, how dare I speak further?" Zhuangzi replied, "I have heard that the prince seeks my aid to end the king’s fondness for swords. If I persuade the king in a manner contrary to his wishes, offending him and failing to align with the prince’s intent, I would face execution. How then could I make use of the gold? But if I persuade the king in a way that pleases him and aligns with the prince’s intent, what in the state of Zhao could I not obtain?"

The prince said, "Indeed. My father, the king, sees only swordsmen." Zhuangzi replied, "Very well. I am skilled in the sword." The prince said, "Yet the swordsmen my father favors all have unkempt hair, bristling sideburns, slouching caps, tassels of coarse silk, short-backed robes, glaring eyes, and speak in harsh tones—this is what delights him. If you appear before the king in scholar’s robes, the outcome will surely be adverse." Zhuangzi said, "Allow me to prepare a swordsman’s attire."

After three days, the attire was ready, and the prince accompanied him to see the king. The king stood with bared blade, awaiting him. Zhuangzi entered the palace gates without haste and did not bow upon seeing the king. The king asked, "What instruction do you bring, that the prince has sent you before me?" Zhuangzi replied, "I have heard that Your Majesty is fond of swords, so I have come to present my swordsmanship." The king asked, "What power does your sword possess to restrain others?" Zhuangzi said, "My sword cuts down one man every ten paces and leaves no obstacle in a thousand *li*." The king was greatly pleased and exclaimed, "You would be invincible in the world!"

Zhuangzi said, "The way of the sword is to present emptiness, offer advantage, strike after the opponent moves, and arrive before they do. I wish to demonstrate this." The king said, "Rest now in your lodging. I shall issue a command to arrange a contest and summon you." The king then assembled swordsmen for seven days, during which over sixty were killed or wounded. Five or six were selected, and they stood bearing their swords at the foot of the hall. The king summoned Zhuangzi and said, "Today, let us test the swordsmen in a trial of skill." Zhuangzi replied, "I have long awaited this." The king asked, "What length of weapon do you wield?" Zhuangzi said, "Any length will suffice for me. However, I possess three swords, and I shall use whichever Your Majesty prefers. Allow me to describe them before demonstrating."

The king said, "I wish to hear of the three swords." Zhuangzi replied, "There is the Sword of the Son of Heaven, the Sword of the Feudal Lords, and the Sword of the Commoner."

The king asked, "What is the Sword of the Son of Heaven like?"
Zhuangzi said, "The Sword of the Son of Heaven has its blade forged from Yanxi and Shicheng, its edges from Qi and Mount Tai, its spine from Jin and Wei, its guard from Zhou and Song, and its grip from Han and Wei. It is encircled by the Four Barbarians and enveloped by the Four Seasons, bound by the Bohai Sea and girdled by Mount Chang."

Its regulation follows the Five Phases, its discourse balances punishment and virtue; its opening aligns with yin and yang, its grasp corresponds to spring and summer, its movement to autumn and winter. Pointed, it has nothing before it; raised, it has nothing above it; pressed, it has nothing below it; wielded, it has nothing beside it. Above, it cleaves the floating clouds; below, it severs the earth’s foundations. When this sword is once employed, it rectifies the feudal lords, and all under heaven submits. This is the Sword of the Son of Heaven.

King Wen, dazed, lost himself in thought, then asked, "What is the Sword of the Feudal Lords like?"
Zhuangzi said, "The Sword of the Feudal Lords has its blade forged from the wise and brave, its edges from the pure and incorrupt, its spine from the worthy and good, its guard from the loyal and sagely, and its grip from the heroic and outstanding. Pointed, it likewise has nothing before it; raised, it likewise has nothing above it; pressed, it likewise has nothing below it; wielded, it likewise has nothing beside it. Above, it models the round heavens to follow the Three Luminaries; below, it models the square earth to follow the Four Seasons; within, it comprehends the people’s will to pacify the four quarters. When this sword is once employed, it strikes like the thunder’s shock—within the four borders, none fail to submit in reverence. This is the Sword of the Feudal Lords."

The king asked, "What is the Sword of the Commoner like?"
