Zhuangzi said, "The Sword of the Commoner: unkempt hair, disheveled topknot, dangling cap-strings, short-backed robes, glaring eyes, and quarrelsome speech. They clash before one another, above severing necks and throats, below piercing livers and lungs. This Sword of the Commoner differs not from fighting cocks—once their lives are spent, it serves no purpose in the affairs of state. Now Your Majesty holds the position of the Son of Heaven yet delights in the sword of the commoner; I humbly deem this unworthy of you."

The king then led him up to the hall. The royal chef presented the meal, and the king circled it thrice. Zhuangzi said, "May Your Majesty sit composed and settle your qi. The matter of the swords has been presented in full."

Thereupon, King Wen did not leave his palace for three months, and the swordsmen all submitted, dying in their places.

Guo’s commentary is silent. Lü’s commentary: "Zhuangzi’s conduct was such that he wished to drag his tail in the mud rather than become a sacrificial victim in the grand ancestral temple, awakening the world to the folly of risking life for mere things. Yet his discourse on swords remains unheard of—likely he borrowed this to illustrate that the Dao’s application knows no bounds. If one can halt a ruler’s harmful preferences and secure a state’s peril, the blessings bestowed are no small matter! Thus, those who embody the Dao act when the time is right."

Accepting their service while declining their gifts, the enlightened ruler makes clear that the noble person cannot be won by wealth. Adopting their attire and employing their rites, one aligns with their affairs—only then may words find entry.

The Son of Heaven’s sword is forged with all under heaven, demonstrating that the divine instrument of the realm cannot be wielded arbitrarily. By revealing its emptiness, enticing with advantage, following with action, and preceding with arrival, one grasps the Way of employing this divine instrument—achieving what cannot be achieved.

To know the root and branch, the light and heavy, and the methods by which it is regulated and applied, is to wield it such that all under heaven submits. From Yan and Han, Qi and Dai, to the Bohai and Mount Da, the Son of Heaven’s sword encompasses all under heaven. From the five phases, punishments, and virtues to the severing of earth’s bounds, it signifies the divine as timeless and boundless.

Only the spirit-like person may wield this divine instrument, thus correcting the feudal lords and bringing all under heaven to submission—this was the proven efficacy of Tang, Yu, and the Three Dynasties. Such was Zhuangzi’s purpose in discoursing on swords. Upon hearing this, King Wen felt a disorienting loss, realizing his own preference was not for the true sword.

The feudal lords’ sword is forged with a single state, thus when speaking of knights, one speaks of the people’s hopes. Courage and wisdom lead, forming the blade’s edge. Purity and integrity follow, forming the guard. Worthiness leans upon it as the spine. Loyalty and sagacity root it as the tang. Eminence is what one grasps and enacts, forming the hilt. In governing a state, observing whether these—edge, guard, tang, and hilt—are harmonized reveals the weapon’s efficacy and the state’s stability or peril.

Though the realm and a single state differ in scale, their employment relies on the movement of spirit, which is one and the same. As for the commoner’s sword, it directly addresses the king’s misguided preference to correct his error. That the swordsmen all submitted and died in their places demonstrates how to overcome rigidity and strength—nothing more.

Yi Du’s commentary: What people deeply cherish, external things cannot wrest away. How much more so for one who stands above others, wielding power with an arrogant heart, whose words cannot penetrate and whose nature cannot be transformed? Thus, when King Wen of Zhao favored swords, Zhuangzi presented himself as a swordsman, seizing upon his preference to embed deeper meaning. Expounding the Way of heaven and humanity, he delineated the affairs of the Son of Heaven, feudal lords, and commoners to move him. In doing so, he succeeded in curbing King Wen’s obsession with swords.

The Son of Heaven’s sword must take neighboring states and the perils of mountains and seas as its edge, guard, tang, and hilt, encircling and binding them. Its regulation is based on the five phases, punishments, and virtues; its application follows yin and yang and the four seasons. Thus, it meets no resistance, moves without obstruction, cleaves the floating clouds above, and severs the earth’s bounds below. Who but the most divine under heaven could achieve this?

In discussing the feudal lords’ sword, one relies on governance through people, employing courage, wisdom, purity, integrity, loyalty, sagacity, and eminence as edge, guard, tang, and hilt. Wielded thus, it strikes like thunder, leaving none unsubdued. As for the commoner’s sword, the answer lies in the king’s present preference—no different from a fighting cock, exhausting its qi and strength to die. This illustrates that petty techniques are insufficient for governing a state. This aligns with Mencius’ response to King Xuan of Qi’s fondness for courage.

Upon hearing these words, the king felt shame and remorse, circling his meal without daring to eat his fill. Thereupon, he did not leave his palace for three months, and the swordsmen all submitted, dying in their places—proof that he had heard Zhuangzi’s words and repented.

Bi Xu’s commentary: The one who wages war in the ancestral temple is an emperor; the one who transforms through spirit is a king. Temple warfare models itself on heaven and earth; spiritual transformation models itself on the four seasons. Thus, when governance is refined within the borders, distant lands admire its virtue; when victory is secured before battle, feudal lords submit to its might. To wield all under heaven as a sword—how could it be compared to mere Tai’e or Ganjiang?

King Wen of Zhao’s fondness for swords and disdain for officials aimed to advance the principle of divine martiality without killing. Of old, there was a treasured sword named Han Guang—"Containing Light." Invisible to the eye, unfelt to the touch, its shadow showed no curve, its sound no clarity. Housed in the ancestral temple, it awed the four barbarians; employed in enemy lands, a single child wielding it could repel three armies.

Yet when revealed as emptiness within, opened to external vastness, moved without form, and unleashed without action, it advanced and retreated with the dance of phoenixes and the flourish of dragons. What need was there for measuring length, comparing speed, striking waists and necks, or endlessly severing and slaying? For arms are inauspicious instruments, used by the sage only when unavoidable.

The sword is the courage of a single man, akin to a fighting cock—once its life is spent, what use is it to a state of ten thousand chariots?

Liu Chao’s commentary: In the nature of all things under heaven, none do not despise the different and revere the same, discard the small and admire the great, even to the point of pursuing harm for the sake of profit—this is often the case. If something does not align with oneself, even if beneficial, it is not followed; if no benefit is perceived, even if great, it is not admired.

Zhuangzi’s discourse on the Way, including this passage on the words of persuaders and rhetoricians, embeds profound principles in subtle expressions, necessarily conveyed through language. Human nature exalts itself and devalues others, justifies itself and condemns others. To seek unity among those with differing kindling would even humble Confucius before the violence of a bandit. Yet by aligning with what is shared, Zhuangzi’s single utterance severed King Wen of Zhao’s lifelong obsession—such is the principle.

As for the disheveled topknots, drooping caps, flowing beards, short robes, glaring eyes, and contentious speech—these were King Wen’s preferences, not Zhuangzi’s true nature.

Now, should one alter one’s usual disposition and change one’s customary attire, the listener will revere what is said. To discourse first on the Son of Heaven, then on the feudal lords, and last on the common folk is to evoke admiration for what is grand. Grandeur commands the realm; next, it wins the homage of the four borders; at the lowest, it severs necks—thus does one approach what is profitable. The nature of affairs does not extend beyond this. The sage harmonizes and responds, nurturing things as they are, so that even the multitude of monkeys submit to the morning-four-evening-three stratagem—how could this lack its own principle?

Yet to bend oneself without ever straightening another is to make Zhuangzi’s discourse on the sword seem like mere compliance. Moreover, the Robber Zhi and the Fisherman are not his true concerns. The general purport of his words is mutual attack, though the underlying principle is subtle indeed. If one traces the surface to seek meaning, how can one grasp the speaker’s intent?

Yanjuan notes: *Drooping cap* means not raising the cap high, like the headscarf of a stalwart knight. *Flowing beard* signifies coarseness. *Short robe* means it does not drape fully. *Contentious speech* refers to verbal disputation. To display emptiness and open with profit is to advance; to strike from behind or arrive first is to attack with concealed force. *Dun* means to sever, as when swords clash and cut. *Xin* is the sword’s edge; *jia* is its hilt. The four seasons, five phases, sun, moon, yin, and yang all follow the natural workings of creation. Above, they float like clouds; below, they sever the earth’s foundations—such is the vastness of their application. Thrice circling the land of one’s sustenance without daring to sit, one feels shame and cannot rest. Once the king was moved and abandoned this frivolous pursuit, the swordsmen all withdrew and perished in their dwellings.

Master Chu’s general discussion states: The *Nanhua* establishes its words to clarify the Dao, soaring above the nine heavens and delving into the nine earths, opening and closing creation, unfathomable even to spirits and gods. Yet when it draws on things as metaphors, it does not stray from the discourse of the human world, while profound subtleties lie concealed within, sufficient to awaken hearts and remedy the ills of the age. The *Discourse on the Sword* is a piece of mighty rhetoric with a subtle purpose, its resonance enduring for millennia—how could it be mere idle sound?

The *Han History* records that the Sima family of Zhao gained renown through their transmission of swordsmanship, so the art of the sword has flourished since ancient times. Thus did the Master of Painted Bamboo seize upon it to express the marvels within his breast. Some, clinging to superficial resemblance, mistake it for the rhetoric of itinerant persuaders, thereby missing the essence of the classic and confusing luminous pearls with fish eyes.

Boshi, in his humble estimation, has examined the intent behind the *Nanhua*’s words and offers this explanation: The state of Zhao is a metaphor for the individual; King Wen’s fondness for the sword is an allegory for the heart ensnared by desire. The crown prince’s grief is like a glimmer of awareness that cannot restrain the heart’s failings. Seeking Zhuangzi to curb the king’s obsession is akin to overcoming it through reason. The three swords presented illustrate the varying degrees of principle, and the discerning eye will perceive their distinctions.

"One man in ten paces"—none can withstand its edge. "A thousand *li* without pause"—its use is swift and decisive. This resembles one who preserves the wholeness of spirit. The Son of Heaven relies on neighboring states for defense, feudal lords on worthy scholars for support, and commoners on the courage of the individual. For the King of Zhao, in his exalted position, to favor the sword of the commoner is to obscure the supreme nobility of virtue and pursue the basest of desires. To have swordsmen clash before him day and night—how can one ensure it does not become like the fable of the cock that harmed the state? Such degradation is extreme.

To remedy this failing and restore his original nature, nothing but the highest principle will suffice. When principle prevails and desire dissipates, what remains is the true nature, and the poisoned blade is transformed into a sacred vessel—then the heart has no further use. This is to recover what was lost, though not without difficulty, and is called acting through effort, yet the success is the same.

The three swords of the Son of Heaven, the feudal lords, and the commoners represent the varying depths of nature, the heights of aspiration, and the degrees of accomplishment. The ancient rulers who governed the realm with divine martial prowess yet without killing all wielded this sword, employing its spirit—how could mere Tai’e or Ganjiang compare?

Thus, the King of Zhao circled his table without tending to his nourishment, for ritual and propriety delighted his heart, and even fine meats seemed insufficient. Once the king sat calmly and composed his breath, the matter of the sword was resolved—this shows how the heart is harmed by movement and the nature is attained through stillness. To recover one’s nature is to return to one’s original truth, which is also to attain nothing at all.

When the King of Zhao did not leave his palace for three months, he was able to preserve stillness, cultivate emptiness, and maintain his nature unchanged. The swordsmen all perished where they stood, for this is a metaphor for the immediate death of the heart. When the craftsman departs, the harmony of the craft ceases; looking back, even the so-called sacred vessel is transformed along with it—what distinction then remains between Son of Heaven and commoner?

To accede to the crown prince’s request and decline his gifts is akin to Lu Zhonglian’s preservation of Handan without accepting a thousand gold—both are acts of righteousness. In the end, he curbed the King of Zhao’s frivolous obsession and stabilized his state, embedding the principles of governance within while not abandoning them.

The *Nanhua* grieves for those in the world who are mired in desire, losing their nature without realizing it, and thus composes this discourse to show that restoring one’s nature depends on inner mastery, guarding against desire like a double-edged sword. The moment the heart stirs, one must overcome it with reason, rather than waiting for swordsmen to clash at the gates day and night before seeking a skilled persuader to intervene.

This is the Dao concealed within a craft, expounded through words to resolve doubts. Yet those who seek correspondence in external forms risk obscuring the grand principles for ages, even confining the profoundest teachings to the pen of the pedant—how lamentable! Through exhaustive inquiry, one may awaken, return to the source, and perhaps align with the original intent of the text.

Zixuan, in his study of this classic, grasped its essence. His mighty prose and profound arguments vie with it, yet for this chapter alone he appended not a single word, allowing readers to delve deeply and attain understanding on their own.

Lest some should harbor doubts on this point, it is necessary to clarify.

*End of Scroll Ninety-Seven of the* Nan Hua Zhen Jing Yi Hai Zuan Wei
*Scroll Ninety-Eight of the* Nan Hua Zhen Jing Yi Hai Zuan Wei
*Compiled by the Daoist Priest Chu Boxiu of Wulin*

**The Fisherman, First Chapter**

Confucius wandered through the dark-canopied forest and rested, seated upon the Apricot Altar. His disciples were reciting the *Book of Documents*, while Confucius accompanied them with zither song, the melody not yet half-finished. A fisherman descended from his boat and approached, his temples and brows snowy white, hair unbound, sleeves of elm-cloth fluttering. He strode up from the marshland, halted at the shore, his left hand resting on his knee, his right supporting his chin, listening.

When the song ended, he beckoned to Zigong and Zilu, who both stepped forward. The stranger pointed at Confucius and asked, “What is that man doing?”

Zilu replied, “He is a gentleman of Lu.”

The stranger inquired about his lineage.

“His lineage is the Kong clan.”

“And what does the Kong clan govern?”

Zilu did not answer, but Zigong replied, “The Kong clan cultivates loyalty and trust in nature, practices benevolence and righteousness in conduct, refines ritual and music, and selects proper human relations. Above, they serve the rulers of the age with devotion; below, they transform the common people. They aim to benefit all under Heaven—this is what the Kong clan governs.”

The stranger asked further, “Is he a lord with lands?”

“No,” Zigong said.

“Is he an advisor to kings and lords?”
“No, he is not.”

The stranger laughed and turned away, saying as he walked, “Benevolent, yes, but I fear he will not preserve himself. His heart toils and his form labors, endangering his true nature. Alas, how far removed he is from the Dao!”

Zigong returned and reported to Confucius. Confucius pushed aside his zither and rose, saying, “Could he be a sage?” He went in search of the man and found him by the marsh, just as he was using a staff to pull his boat. The stranger turned, saw Confucius, and stood facing him. Confucius retreated, bowed twice, and stepped forward.

The stranger asked, “What do you seek?”

Confucius replied, “A short while ago, Master left with words unfinished. I, Qiu, am unworthy and did not grasp their meaning. I humbly awaited in your wake, hoping to hear even the sound of your cough or spit to complete my understanding.”

The stranger said, “Ah! How earnest is your love of learning!”

Confucius said, “From my youth I have cultivated learning, and now I am sixty-nine years old. Yet I have never heard the ultimate teaching—how could I not empty my heart?”

The stranger said, “Like attracts like, and sound responds to sound—this is the principle of Heaven. Let me set aside what I possess and expound what you possess. What you possess pertains to human affairs. When the Son of Heaven, the feudal lords, the great officers, and the common people each rectify themselves, governance is at its finest. When these four abandon their stations, no disorder could be greater. When offices fulfill their duties and each person attends to their affairs, none will overstep. Thus:
- Fields lie fallow, homes stand exposed, clothing and food are insufficient, taxes are unpaid, wives and concubines are at odds, and elders and juniors lack order—these are the worries of the common people.
- Incompetence, official duties left undone, conduct that is not pure, subordinates who are negligent, achievements unrecognized, and ranks and emoluments unsustained—these are the worries of the great officers.
- The court lacks loyal ministers, the state is benighted and disordered, craftsmen lack skill, tribute is unworthy, seasonal rites fall behind, and the Son of Heaven is disobeyed—these are the worries of the feudal lords.
- Yin and yang are not in harmony, harming the myriad things; feudal lords are violent and disorderly, harming the people; ritual and music lack moderation, resources are exhausted, human relations are unordered, and the hundred clans are licentious—these are the worries of the Son of Heaven’s ministers.

Now you, above, have no authority of lord or minister, and below, no office of great officer, yet you presumptuously refine ritual and music, select proper human relations, and seek to transform the common people. Is this not excessively meddlesome?

Moreover, people have eight flaws, and affairs have four perils—these must not go unexamined.

To take up what is not your affair is called *overreaching*;
To advance where none heeds you is called *obsequiousness*;
To guide speech by another’s wishes is called *flattery*;
To speak without discerning right or wrong is called *sycophancy*;
To delight in speaking ill of others is called *slander*;
To sever friendships and estrange kin is called *treachery*;
To praise falsely and deceive, leading others to ruin, is called *depravity*;
To fail to distinguish good from bad, to please both sides, and to stealthily seize what you desire is called *perfidy*.

These eight flaws bring chaos to others and harm to oneself. The noble person does not befriend such a one, nor does the enlightened ruler employ them.

The four perils are these:
To love managing great affairs, altering and changing the constant, all for the sake of hanging one’s name on achievements, is called *presumptuousness*;
To monopolize knowledge, arrogate affairs, and act without restraint is called *greed*;
To see one’s faults yet not change, and to heed admonitions with greater obstinacy, is called *obduracy*;
To approve only what accords with oneself, and to reject even what is good if it does not, is called *arrogance*.

These are the four perils. Only when you have cast off the eight flaws and do not practice the four perils can you begin to be taught.”

Confucius sighed deeply and said, “I, Qiu, was twice driven from Lu, my footprints erased in Wei, my tree felled in Song, and I was besieged in Chen and Cai. I do not know what I have done wrong to incur these four slanders.”

The stranger said, “How difficult it is for you to awaken!”

There was a man who loathed his shadow and detested his footprints, so he ran to flee them. The more he lifted his feet, the more prints appeared; the faster he ran, the more his shadow clung to him. Believing himself still too slow, he ran without cease until his strength gave out and he died. He did not know that by standing in the shade he could rest his shadow, and by remaining still he could still his traces—how foolish he was!

You scrutinize the space between benevolence and righteousness, examine the boundary between sameness and difference, observe the changes of movement and stillness, adjust the measure of giving and receiving, order the passions of liking and disliking, and harmonize the rhythms of joy and anger—yet you are perilously close to not escaping [such folly]! If you diligently cultivate yourself, guard your true nature, and return things to others, you will have no encumbrances. Now, if you do not cultivate yourself but seek [perfection] in others, is this not misplaced?

Confucius, looking solemn, said, “May I ask what is meant by *the true*?”
The stranger replied, “The true is the utmost of essence and sincerity. Without essence and sincerity, one cannot move others. Thus, forced weeping, though sorrowful, is not mournful; forced anger, though stern, is not awe-inspiring; forced affection, though smiling, is not harmonious. True sorrow is mournful without sound; true anger is awe-inspiring before it erupts; true affection is harmonious before it smiles. When the true resides within, the spirit moves without—this is why the true is prized.

Applied to human affairs, it manifests thus: in serving parents, one is naturally filial; in serving a lord, one is loyal and steadfast; in drinking wine, one is joyful; in mourning, one is grieved. Loyalty and steadfastness take merit as their essence; drinking wine takes joy as its essence; mourning takes sorrow as its essence; serving parents takes comfort as its essence. When merit is perfected, none of its bounds are missed. In serving parents with comfort, one does not debate the means; in drinking wine with joy, one does not select the vessels; in mourning with sorrow, one does not question the rites.

Rites are what the common world practices; the true is what one receives from Heaven, naturally and unalterably. Thus, the sage models Heaven and values the true, not constrained by custom. The foolish do the opposite: they cannot model Heaven but fret over others, do not prize the true, and drift along, shaped by custom—how pitiable! You were early steeped in human artifice and late to hear the great Dao!”

Confucius said, “Today I have met you as if by Heaven’s favor. You do not disdain to liken me to a servant, yet you teach me in person. May I ask where you dwell? I wish to follow and complete my study of the great Dao.”

The stranger said, “I have heard: those who can be led may be guided to the subtle Dao; those who cannot be led do not understand the Dao—beware of leading them, lest you incur blame. Strive on!” He then poled his boat away, vanishing among the green reeds.

Yan Yuan turned the carriage, and Zilu handed Confucius the reins, but Confucius did not look back. He waited until the water’s ripples stilled and the sound of the pole was no longer heard before daring to board. Zilu, standing beside the carriage, asked, “I have served you for a long time, yet never have I seen you meet someone with such reverence. Even rulers of ten thousand chariots or lords of a thousand chariots, when they meet you, do not fail to accord you equal courtesy—yet you still bear a haughty demeanor. Now, this old fisherman, leaning on his pole and standing upright, and you bending at the waist, bowing repeatedly in response—was this not excessive? The disciples all find your conduct strange. How did the fisherman deserve this?”

Confucius leaned on the crossbar and sighed, “How difficult it is to transform you, You! You have been steeped in ritual and righteousness for so long, yet your crude and vulgar heart remains. Come closer, I will tell you. To meet an elder without respect is a breach of ritual; to meet a worthy without reverence is a lack of benevolence. If he were not a perfected person, he could not humble himself before others. If one does not humble oneself with precision, one cannot attain the true—and thus one harms oneself. Alas, the lack of benevolence in others is no greater misfortune, yet you alone cling to it!

Moreover, the Dao is the path by which the myriad things proceed. Those who lose it die; those who attain it live. In affairs, to go against it is to fail; to follow it is to succeed. Thus, wherever the Dao resides, the sage reveres it. This old fisherman possesses the Dao—how could I not revere him?”

Zhuangzi employed allegory not to condemn Confucius’ teachings, but to show that from the Son of Heaven to the common people, each has its proper order. His critique of flaws and maladies strikes precisely at the heart of affairs. Yet when Confucius said that at sixty-nine he had gained nothing, was it not because he had not yet attained the freedom of following the heart? For once one follows the heart, then donning benevolence and righteousness, practicing loyalty and trust, adorning ritual and music, and selecting human relationships—all means by which the world is governed—are no longer genuine. It is like mistaking the finger for the moon; the finger is not the moon.

Did Confucius, upon reaching this realization, have nothing left to do? Even receiving instruction from the Fisherman could not be uttered aloud, hence the words: *“I depart from you! I depart from you!”*—both to be forgotten in wordless silence.

**Bi Xu’s Annotation:** When the four classes of people adhere to their proper vocations, they are not swayed by worldly profit. Affairs respond to what they encounter, thus they abound in sufficiency and know no sorrow. Those of small ambition harbor no grand designs; those who lose control of their methods fail to establish merit and cannot preserve their emoluments. Schemes that miss the mark, words that lack sincerity, excessive labor leading to shoddy work, exorbitant demands resulting in poor tribute—these violate the Dao and breed resentment. Thus, delays invite disaster, changes to what is fitting disrupt harmony, alterations to constants harm things, deep anger sparks violence, extreme indignation provokes plunder, excessive ritual and music lead to licentiousness, and heavy taxes bring destitution. Yet if one reflects and cultivates these, flaws and maladies may be avoided!

To travel through the various states and wish to avoid slander is like racing through dust hoping one’s robes remain unstained, or braving rain wishing one’s headscarf stays dry. Let things return to things, let people return to people. Cultivate the self and preserve the true—neither self nor other will be burdened.

The true is the nature of spontaneity, inwardly arising from sincerity and outwardly resonating with Heaven and humanity. In its application to human principles, loyalty, filial piety, sorrow, and joy each finds its proper place. The beauty of accomplishment leaves no trace. Ritual is the teaching of the world; the true is the nature of Heaven. The foolish are anxious about others and swayed by custom, thus they fall short of the Dao.

The Fisherman’s Way is uncontrived and uncalculating, serene and desireless, yet all excellences follow from it—this is why Confucius returned to revere him.

**Liu Chao’s Annotation:** What aligns with oneself is deemed right, hence the King of Zhao regarded Zhuangzi as worthy. What differs from oneself is deemed wrong, hence Robber Zhi reviled Confucius as a thief. Without alignment or opposition, only where the Dao resides will I offer my utmost respect and speak fully—this is why the *Fisherman* chapter was composed and why Confucius was chosen for the allegory.

The spontaneity of Heaven and human principles are far apart, yet their roots and branches, their beginnings and ends, have never been mutually abolished. When the true is accumulated within, the spirit moves without, while the functions of penal codes, names, rituals, and laws are but its outer manifestations. Confucius clarified the cessation of anxiety and its causes, aligning with the people to benefit those in the world who guard the true. Moreover, governance values cherishing the self. As Laozi once said: *“Only one who cherishes the self as the world can be entrusted with the world.”* Thus, the art of benefiting the world inherently includes governing by non-governance. This is what Confucius embraced.

As for Chang Ju and Jie Ni, who preserved their purity while disrupting human relationships, Confucius never failed to decline and avoid them. From this, we know the intent behind the allegory has its proper place.

**Juan Zhai’s Annotation:** After the Spring and Autumn period, the order of court visits was lost. Praise became deceitful and false, lauding what ought not be lauded. Evil was condemned in those who did not deserve condemnation.

To adapt one’s countenance to another’s preferences is called "facial accommodation," wherein neither good nor evil is distinguished—all is done to please. To accommodate both sides is called "dual accommodation."

The Eight Blemishes and Four Afflictions are the great sighs of humanity; only by shedding these can one speak of the Dao. The Fisherman remarked that all the Master’s deeds were done for others, which is why he could not escape worldly slander. If one cultivates the self and guards the true, with no opposition between self and other, then nothing will encumber one. Now, if one does not seek within but busily strives for others, is this not externalizing the self?

Without utmost sincerity, one cannot move others—this is the meaning of "sincerity even moving spirits." The six lines on forced weeping, forced laughter, forced affection, and their genuine counterparts are most incisive. What is true within moves the spirit without.

Rites are embellishments of externals, the doings of worldly custom. The true is the principle of Heaven’s mandate and natural spontaneity. Those who do not know the nobility of Heaven’s nobility take worldly emoluments as their reward, willingly transformed by vulgar currents, and thus appear perpetually dissatisfied.

Those who do not refine themselves cannot attain the true—this is further instruction for scholars. The Fisherman was a man of the Dao, and I revere his Way, which is why I honor him.

**Chu’s Narrow View:** Some say the Fisherman was Fan Li in his five-lake skiff or the one Qu Yuan encountered by the marsh. Yet I believe one need not fixate on his identity. Rather, he represents those who conceal their virtue and hide their brilliance, dwelling in lakes and seas—like Jiang Taigong, Yan Ziling, Zhang Zhihe, or Lu Guimeng. Among them are those who concealed even their names; how could all be exhaustively traced?

"Black curtains" refers to dense forests dark as draperies, hence the name. In the *Nanhua*, the Fisherman’s dialogue with Confucius and the Madman of Chu’s song passing by Confucius share the same intent. Confucius was earnest in his care for others, so his worldly traces became conspicuous, allowing people to speculate about him. Thus, the Fisherman admonished him to shed blemishes, distance himself from harm, cultivate the self, guard the true, and return things to others.

Fame, too, is a thing. The Creator is sparing with it, and excess invites envy. The true is the noble treasure within; no external thing can compare. If one does not value the true, the inner self lacks a foundation, and one drifts, readily transformed by custom—no wonder.

The metaphors of fearing one’s shadow and hating one’s tracks, along with the two analogies of forced weeping and forced anger, are most precise. The passage on serving parents with kindness and filial piety offers great benefit to the art of governance, showing that the Fisherman was not merely one who perfected himself but acted with timely restraint.

Upon hearing these words, Confucius awakened, wishing to abandon his learning and ultimately receive the teaching. Those who govern the world through action, upon hearing the benefits of non-action, cannot but revere it. The Fisherman poled his boat away, demonstrating that having transformed others, he left no lingering trace. Only after the water’s waves stilled and the sound of his oar vanished did Confucius dare to board—having heard the ultimate words, his heart was joyfully and sincerely convinced. Though the man had departed, reverence remained.

All the Fisherman’s words clarify that the world’s understanding of Confucius extended only so far as his worldly advancement. Only the *Nanhua* grasped the Master’s heart, pointing to his traces yet criticizing them—thus the true could be silently apprehended.

Many fault this *Classic* for disparaging Confucius. I say that the *Nanhua* alone grasped the subtlety of how to honor him. Words that seem contrary are in fact upright—this is precisely the meaning.

*Collected Subtleties of the Ocean of Meanings in the True Classic of Nanhua*, Scroll 98, concludes.

**#1** The *Omissions and Errors* cites Zhang Junfang’s edition, where the character *è* (恶, "evil") appears as *dé* (德, "virtue").
**#2** The character *bā* (八, "eight") is a scribal error for *rén* (人, "person").

*Collected Subtleties of the Ocean of Meanings in the True Classic of Nanhua*, Scroll 99.
By Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin.

Lie Yukou, Chapter One

Lie Yukou was traveling to Qi when he turned back midway and encountered Bohun Maoren. Bohun Maoren asked: "Why have you returned?"

Liezi replied: "I was startled."

"By what?"

"I once took meals at ten millet-porridge stalls, and five of them served me first."

Bohun Maoren said: "If that is so, why were you startled?"

Liezi answered: "When inner sincerity is not dissolved, the body’s demeanor radiates brilliance, which externally overawes others’ hearts, causing them to slight the noble and the aged and to disregard their own concerns. Those porridge-sellers merely traffic in food and broth. Though my surplus was slight, the profit they sought was meager, and their leverage was light—yet even they acted thus. How much more so a lord of ten thousand chariots! He would exhaust himself for the state and expend his knowledge on affairs, then entrust me with tasks and demand results from me. That is why I was startled."

Bohun Maoren said: "Excellent observation! Now that you have settled yourself, others will safeguard you."

Shortly after, Liezi went to visit, and the sandals outside the door filled the entrance. Bohun Maoren stood facing north, leaning heavily on his staff and pressing it against his chin. After standing for a while, he departed without a word. The attendant informed Liezi, who grabbed his sandals and ran barefoot to the gate, saying: "Master, since you have come, will you not prescribe a remedy?"

Bohun Maoren replied: "Enough! I had already told you that others would safeguard you—and indeed, they have."

You cannot make others safeguard you, nor can you prevent them from safeguarding you—why then this pretense of surprise and delight in standing out? If you must provoke a response, you disturb your fundamental nature, and all for nothing. None of those who accompany you will tell you this: their petty words are all poison to men. Unawakened, uncomprehending—how could they discern the truth?

The cunning toil and the wise fret, while the incapable seek nothing. They eat and wander freely, drifting like an untethered boat, empty and roaming. (Guo’s note: "Jiang" refers to the households that sell broth. "First to offer gifts" speaks of their reverence for you. If one’s inner self is unresolved, one will outwardly feign dignity. Their every movement is calculated to create an imposing presence, yet this only overawes others while their inner substance remains insufficient to command true respect. If authority arose from inner substance, it would deepen others’ reverence for the aged. But when one moves others with superficial beauty, the trouble of disorder arises. The broth-seller’s influence is slight and their profit meager—they need seek nothing from others. If one does not neglect their own form, they will be safeguarded wherever they go. "Safeguarded" means to be gathered and protected. If one acts with impartiality and transforms through natural influence, there will be no provocation, no seeking; without provocation or seeking, there will be no mutual safeguarding. To bestow favors before others act is to offer kindness not rooted in them—this pretense of standing out is the very cause of provocation. If provocation is inevitable, it will disturb one’s fundamental nature. Petty cleverness infiltrates others through trivial words. Only the sage is truly without ability. From this point downward, even to the insects, none forget their own abilities to rely on the multitude. (Lü’s note: The sage wears coarse cloth while holding jade within, preserving their form and life. Their concealment of self is never too deep or remote. If inner sincerity is unresolved, one cannot forget the heart. When sincerity manifests in form, it creates a radiance that can be scrutinized, revealing that this is not the way to conceal oneself. Eating at ten broth-stalls, half of them offering gifts first—this is using externals to overawe others’ hearts, making them slight the noble and aged while prizing oneself, thus inviting chaos and self-inflicted harm. "Ji" is interchangeable with "ji." Only by responding after being provoked, embracing one’s nature and holding fast to spirit while navigating the world, can one prevent others from safeguarding them. Standing out reveals one’s hidden motives; pretense of delight disturbs one’s fundamental nature. This is the great peril of nurturing the heart and preserving spirit. Thus, those who do not warn you but speak petty words are the ones to be scrutinized—such is the need that steams and matures into completion.

The learner daily accumulates; thus, they eat without seeking fullness and dwell without seeking comfort. The Daoist daily diminishes, shedding knowledge and cunning to return to incapability. Thus, they drift like an untethered boat, empty and roaming. (Yi Du’s note: Unable to achieve inner liberation, one manifests externals to create radiance. "Die" implies close scrutiny. Unable to inwardly conceal their virtue, they rely on external displays to impress, causing others to chase appearances and slight the noble and aged. "Man" describes the fragmented and chaotic state of things—when virtue has not reached profound liberation, and the heart of scrutiny manifests outwardly, chaos arises from it. Even the broth-seller, with meager profit and slight influence, still competes to flock to you—how much more so a lord of ten thousand chariots, who exhausts himself for the state and expends his knowledge on affairs, seeking worthy assistance and demanding results? This is why you were startled. "Excellent observation!"—this is not merely seeing others but also reflecting inwardly.)

When paying respects to one’s elders, one removes their shoes before ascending the hall. Shoes fill the doorway outside—this shows many seek to return to you, truly making you one whom others rely upon. "Dispensing medicine" refers to offering good words to teach others, like medicine curing illness. Though Liezi could fully realize his nature, he had not yet reached the realm of destiny, nor could he abandon form and erase boundaries—thus, others still relied upon him. It was not that Liezi made them rely on him, but that he could not prevent others from doing so. As the scripture says, "It is difficult to make the world entirely forget me"—this is precisely the case.

When both self and things are forgotten, one responds when things stir. Yet if you display extraordinary traces to provoke their approach, you will inevitably invite their influence. This will disturb your fundamental nature, allowing external things to enter and mingle with you. Those who follow you will offer no true counsel but instead deceive you with flattery—this is human poison. If you cannot awaken from your delusion, how can you discern rightly? *Shu* means "to know." To know one another is to become familiar. The clever and knowing cannot escape worry and toil. Without cleverness or knowledge, one remains incapable yet eats their fill and roams freely, drifting like an untethered boat.

The *Bixu Annotation* states: When inner sincerity remains unresolved and the heart is not empty, the scrutiny of form creates radiance—this is the affair of demeanor. By outwardly overawing others’ hearts, one makes them revere one’s brilliance. They slight the noble and aged while honoring me, fearing the chaos that may arise. Though the profit is meager, they treat me thus—how much more so a lord of ten thousand chariots? If the ruler values worthiness, the burden of responsibility will not be light—this is why you were startled.

Shoes fill the doorway outside—people truly rely upon and attach themselves to you. Offering earnest instruction is like a physician dispensing medicine. Where traces exist, people will rely upon you; without intent, none will know you. Liezi could preserve his virtue but had not yet made it free and unbound. Responding to things with delight and displaying traces of distinction disturbs your fundamental nature—how can this be endured? Those who follow you are all beneath you; no loyal warnings are heeded, only cunning and poison. Who can clearly perceive this and admonish you?

Moreover, people come to rely on you not to seek non-action but to learn cleverness and knowledge—only the sage understands this. Thus, with an empty heart and no attachments, entrusting all to the multitude, one remains free from toil and worry, eating their fill and roaming at will.

*Juanji* says: When sincerity accumulates within but has not yet transformed, the movements of form and appearance create radiance—this is why others respect you. Zhaozhou said: "This old monk’s cultivation lacks power; he has been seen through by ghosts and spirits"—this is the meaning. The noble and aged are those whom people should respect, yet now they slight them and honor me instead. *Ji* means "to gather," for the more one’s traces are exposed, the less one can escape the troubles of the age. If even a broth-seller treats me with such reverence, how much more a ruler? The ruler exhausts himself in labor and depletes his knowledge, inevitably seeking my service to achieve success—this is the very gathering of troubles. People will turn to you and rely upon you as their teacher—this sense of "reliance" already carries insufficiency. Observe how others’ perceptions are but a fleeting glimpse, yet yours are a step higher.

In ancient times, when sitting on mats, one would remove their shoes before entering. If eager to welcome a guest, one might not have time to put on shoes and would rush out carrying them. If you cannot prevent others from relying on you, this is the difficulty of making them forget you. Why do you do this? What has brought you to this point?

The people are so moved, delighted, and overjoyed that you cannot conceal yourself—your eccentricities manifest outwardly, and this will disturb your fundamental nature, to no benefit. Moreover, none of your friends admonish or correct you, so you will remain unaware for life, and who will ever question your conduct?

The clever exhaust themselves with labor, the wise inevitably suffer, but only those who embody the Dao and act naturally, without employing their abilities, may eat their fill and wander carefree. This passage culminates in the word "emptiness"—truly a marvelous stroke.

This entire chapter appears in the *Liezi*. There are only three or four differing characters between the versions. *Nanhua* adds the lines beginning with "the clever" to summarize the preceding meaning, making it even more brilliant, like Guo Ziyi taking command of Li Guangbi’s army.

According to the *Liezi*, Lie Yukou lived in the gardens of Zheng for forty years without being recognized. Thus, the five broth-sellers’ prior offerings must have occurred before his time in Zheng. Yet to be startled by a broth-seller’s gift reveals a subtle scrutiny of others and self-examination. When shoes fill the doorway, it shows one cannot conceal their presence. If people vie to flock to and rely upon you, why employ this path of delighting and astonishing others?

All who seek to move others must first unsettle their fundamental nature; only then can they be transformed—what more is there to say? If I remain without intent, even spirits cannot fathom me, let alone people. Yet none of your friends warn you, and you, indulging in clever flattery, remain oblivious—how have you grown so accustomed to this?

In ancient texts, *shú* (熟) and *shú* (孰) were interchangeable. Those who vie to apply cleverness and knowledge labor and worry, with none content to rest in inability—this "inability" is akin to "non-action." Through non-action, one seeks no more than a full belly and carefree wandering, drifting like an untethered boat—nothing more than emptiness.

The *Bixu* edition of the *Liezi* reads "without excess gain." The man of Zheng, Huan, groaned in the land of Qiu. After three years, Huan became a Confucian. His influence extended like a river moistening nine *li*, benefiting three clans, and he taught his younger brother Mo. When Confucians and Mohists debated, their father sided with Mo. After ten years, Huan took his own life. In a dream, his father said: "It was I who made your son a Mohist." When Hu once examined his mulberry, it had become the fruit of the catalpa.

The Creator’s retribution does not punish the person but the person’s Heaven. It was Heaven that made him so. People, believing themselves exceptional, despise their kin. The well-drinkers of Qi quarreled over it. Thus, it is said: "In this age, all are like Huan."

From this, those with virtue do not know, let alone those with the Dao. The ancients called this "fleeing from Heaven’s form." The sage finds peace in what is naturally peaceful and does not seek peace in what is not; the multitude seeks peace in what is not peaceful and does not find peace in what is. Guo’s commentary: Mo was Huan’s younger brother. Huan, resenting his father’s aid to his brother, was so moved that he took his own life. In death, he appeared in a dream, saying he had become a Confucian and transformed his brother into a Mohist. Yet his brother, though influenced by him, did not regard him as a worthy teacher, leading to his resentment even in death. Such was the depth of his sincerity that he became the fruit of the catalpa.

The passage beginning with "the Creator" is Zhuangzi’s own words. The power of accumulated habit is the retribution—it repays one’s nature, not one’s actions. Thus, the work of study and practice perfects one’s nature; it is not for the sake of action. Each has their own nature, so each is made to cultivate accordingly. Huan prided himself on his Confucianism, believing in his accumulated learning, unaware of its naturalness.

Those who possess merit and despise others do not spare even their kin; those who act without self-interest treat high and low without losing proper order. Digging a well draws forth the spring; chanting and singing open the nature. Without a spring, there is nothing to dig; without nature, there is nothing to chant. The world forgets the naturalness of springs and nature, fixating only on the superficial work of digging and chanting, taking pride in possession—is this not delusion?

Observe Huan’s folly in taking learning as his path. His father allowed him to follow his own way, knowing there was nothing to be done. To claim natural ability as one’s own merit is to flee from Heaven—thus punishment befalls them. The sage neither clings to nor rejects peace, following the hearts of the people in what they find peaceful. Their divergence is what makes them part of the multitude.

Lü’s commentary: Huan became a Confucian and made his brother a Mohist, leading to their debates. Their father sided with Mo, and Huan took his own life—all the result of their own actions. Yet Huan’s Confucianism and Mo’s Mohism were their Heaven-given natures. Judging by their actions, father and sons, brothers, Confucians and Mohists were not of one body or occupation. Judging by their Heaven-given natures, they were one and the same. What the father dreamed was Huan’s Heaven—Huan’s Heaven was also his brother’s Heaven, yet Huan did not recognize himself. It was Heaven that made his brother a Mohist.

What is received from nature cannot be learned—it is merely Heaven. If his brother became a Mohist, and Huan believed his own Heaven was superior, he forgot the bonds of father, son, and brother. To study Confucianism and become a Confucian, or to study Mohism and become a Mohist, like Huan becoming the fruit of the catalpa—all are the Creator’s retribution, Heaven’s doing. Yet people do not understand what makes them aid others; they believe themselves exceptional, even despising their kin, as Huan did—how tragic!

This is no different from the people of Qi fighting over a well they claimed as their own. Those in the world who do not know their Heaven and despise others while exalting themselves are all like Huan. The root of such loss of nature lies in possessing knowledge. Those with virtue preserve their Heaven through not-knowing—how much more so those with the Dao?

Those with knowledge flee from Heaven; fleeing from Heaven and doubling back on true nature cannot escape reversion—thus the ancients called this "the punishment of fleeing Heaven." The sage finds peace in what is naturally peaceful, while the multitude finds peace in what is not. What is peaceful is Heaven; what is not peaceful is man.

*Dú’s Annotation*: "Groans and recitations"—the sounds of chanting.
*Qiú’s Land*—a place name.

For Confucians to achieve renown, they must master the unity of Heaven, Earth, and man before resting. Those who chant for three years to attain it grasp only the coarse. Even in that era, a thorough Confucian like Huan was hard to find—yet Zheng employed him. "River’s moisture" is a metaphor for far-reaching beneficence. "Three clans" refers to father, mother, and wife.

Huan became a Confucian, his brother a Mohist—each expanded what was innate in their nature, debating right and wrong through their respective arts. Their father sided with Di, and Huan took his own life, later appearing in a dream to his father, saying, "I taught your son to be a Mohist—it was I!" Di could not submit to him, and their father aided Di—this is why I died in resentment. My true nature has already transformed into the fruit of the catalpa and cypress.

"Good" refers to the goodness of innate conscience and ability. Knowledge, ability, and the heart all arise from true nature—this is called "good." Catalpa and cypress are firm, enduring, and slow to wither. Thus, the nature of a Confucian cannot be altered. Each person has their own Heaven, and scholars expand what is desirable within them.

What the Creator bestows, man cannot forcibly reject; what the Creator does not bestow, man cannot forcibly acquire. This is the division between Huan and Di, Confucianism and Mohism—even the reverence of a father or the affection of an elder brother cannot alter it. For each has their own Heaven, which makes them as they are.

When people despise their kin because their views differ from others, it stems from the bias of their learning. Though this is man’s doing, Heaven remains present in it. The well-fighters of Qi grappled over water, drawing it without knowing its source—just as Confucians of that time clung to the branches, debating right and wrong. Without studying to the point of understanding destiny, one cannot grasp the root.

Those with virtue can feign ignorance as knowledge without self-conceit—how much more so those with the Dao? "Heaven’s punishment" refers to destiny’s natural course, which cannot be escaped. Yet Huan sought to flee it.

*Zhuangzi* rejects the notion that what is peaceful is benevolent and what is not is not—these are all human ways. As for the Way of Heaven, there is neither peace nor its absence; it simply follows principle and responds to the times.

*Bìxū’s Annotation*: Huan killed himself in accumulated resentment; his father’s dream arose from deluded thoughts. The catalpa and cypress atop his grave bore fruit—speaking of his unyielding constancy, sealing this cold-enduring essence as proof.

Li and Kuang’s natures were inherently wise, so the Creator repaid them with wisdom. What one’s nature inherently possesses is repaid in kind—Huan did not himself become a Confucian nor teach his brother to be a Mohist. Scholars contend over teachings and debate, no different from well-drinkers grappling—all driven by the will to prevail. Only those with virtue do not seek recognition—how much more so those with the Dao?

"The punishment of fleeing Heaven" means scorning Heaven’s principles and bringing punishment upon oneself. The sage accepts the long legs of the crane without lengthening the short legs of the hare; the multitude does the opposite, so Heaven’s principles and human affairs clash.

*Yuànzhāi* says: The river moistens nine *li*, its beneficence vast—using its surplus, he had his brother study Mohism. Their studies differed, their arguments diverged. Their father loved Di and aided him; Huan resented his father and killed himself, then appeared in a dream, saying, "The resources I provided for your son to become a Mohist were my surplus beneficence. Now our contention has led to death—why not look at the pines and cypresses atop my grave, already bearing fruit?" This spoke of how long he had been dead.

"Good" is *làng*, pronounced like "lang," meaning a grave. *Zhuangzi* thus concludes: Huan claimed he could make his brother a Mohist, not knowing the Creator repays man according to a principle of retribution—not by man’s abilities, but by what man receives from Heaven. His brother studied Mohism and became a Mohist—this was the Creator responding to his Heaven, not Huan’s human effort in providing resources. "That which made him so"—the first "that" refers to the Creator, the second to his brother.

"Man" here refers to Huan. The well-drinkers of Qi grappled over water, claiming it as their own—Huan’s views were no different. Those with virtue regard the Creator as unknowable—how much more so those who have attained the Dao?

"Fleeing" means abandoning one’s Heavenly principles. "Punishment" means offending the Creator. Each person has an innate nature, bestowed by Heaven and unalterable. Huan’s Confucianism and Di’s Mohism were both inherent in their natures, merely cultivated through learning.

Confucians follow Yao and Shun; Mohists follow the Great Yu—both studied under sages. Confucians uphold the Mean; Mohists drift into universal love, where excess is as flawed as deficiency, so the sagely school does not accept them. At that time, both Confucianism and Mohism led to honor and prominence. Huan boasted of being a Confucian while making his brother a Mohist, taking pride in this.

The two teachings pursued different aims, leading to debate. Their father, unable to judge them impartially, sided with Di. As Huan, he should have yielded and gradually enlightened them—Heavenly nature has no principle of irrevocable loss. Why rush to resent his father and take his own life? The harm was great!

His lingering resentment manifested in a dream to his father: "Why not look at my grave? My spirit has already transformed into the fruit of the catalpa and cypress." "Fruit" here means essence—speaking of his unchanging constancy, his true nature still preserved.

*Zhuangzi* thus concludes: The Creator’s repayment to man is not for the person but for the person’s Heaven. "Repayment" means return. "Heaven" refers to nature. Huan transformed into another being, no longer retaining his form, yet he appeared in a dream to explain himself—his nature had not perished.

That passage serves to bind the preceding text, declaring that human form is not enduring, yet nature must have its return—what is held in a single thought cannot be extinguished. Huan died in resentment, yet his nature did not perish but transformed into wood of unyielding constancy. If one nurtures life according to principle, fulfills their years, leaves no entanglements, and follows transformation to return to the origin—how then shall their true nature find its home?

The tale of the man of Zheng becoming catalpa and cypress seems strange, yet when measured against Kuafu’s birth of Deng Forest, it may well be so. For whether sentient or insentient, the transformations of life have no limit—all arise within the mutations of form and vessel. Man dwells amid these yet remains unaware, thus changing along with them. But if one knows there is that which is formless and unchanging, then one is not subject to the transformations of things but can transform things instead.

All men are, in the end, like Huan—hence the rebuke of the world’s scholars for their shallowness, whose vision is thus confined. How can they hope to penetrate the Three Powers and govern the myriad things? The virtuous act through unknowing. Huan’s loss of the Way came from knowing and making distinctions. To be utterly without knowledge of how—this is to preserve one’s Heaven.

The "punishment of fleeing Heaven" has no single interpretation. Examining what brings ease and what brings unease in the text below serves as evidence. Some divide it into a separate chapter, disrupting the coherence of the classic’s meaning. Huan fled the principle of nature, turning his back on the Heaven of father, son, and brother—this is to be ill at ease where one should be at ease. His resentment drove him to seek punishment, finding ease where one should find none.

*Nanhua* concludes Huan’s case with the phrase "punishment of fleeing Heaven," offering a warning to later generations who defy Heavenly principle and, through stubborn self-will, bring ruin upon themselves.

*Collected Subtleties of the Ocean of Meanings in the True Classic of Nanhua*, Scroll Ninety-Nine, ends here. ¹ According to Cheng’s commentary, the character *wu* (無) should precede *duo* (多).

*Collected Subtleties of the Ocean of Meanings in the True Classic of Nanhua*, Scroll One Hundred
By Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin

**“Mastering Adversity” – Zhuangzi said:**
To know the Dao is easy; to refrain from speaking of it is hard. Knowing yet not speaking—this is how one aligns with Heaven. Knowing and speaking—this is how one aligns with man. The ancients aligned with Heaven and not with man.

**Zhu’s Commentary:**
Learning to "slay dragons" from Master Disjointed Limb, one may exhaust a thousand gold pieces from a household, yet after three years of mastery, find no use for such skill.

The sage treats the inevitable as if it were not, and so remains free of conflict. The common people treat the uncertain as if it were certain, and so abound in conflict. Yielding to conflict, they act with desire. Conflict, when relied upon, brings ruin.

The petty man’s knowledge clings to bribes and letters, squandering spirit on trivial pursuits, yet aspires to guide all things and embody the Great Unity in emptiness. Such a one is deluded by the cosmos, burdened in form, unaware of the Great Beginning. The perfected person, however, returns spirit to the Beginningless and delights in the realm of Nothing-Whatsoever. Like water flowing without form, it issues forth into the Great Purity.

Alas! Your knowledge dwells in the tip of a hair, yet you know not the Great Peace!

**Guo’s Annotation:**
Though knowledge embraces heaven and earth, it never opens speech to lure others, responding only to what is fitting. Affairs lie in aptness, not in prizing distant achievement. Though principle may be certain, to treat it as if it were not—this is perfect compliance. How could conflict arise? Though principle may be uncertain, to insist upon it breeds discord, for each clings to their own view. When things follow their nature, they are sufficient; when sufficient, they seek nothing. If compelled to act, one who takes tranquility as paramount does not perish.

Bribes for favors, letters for inquiries—these are the pursuits of petty knowledge. Obsessed with trifles, one gains little, yet seeks to guide all things, traversing emptiness and venturing afar. Ambition outstrips spirit, form becomes a burden, and one loses the Way in confusion. Thus the perfected person, serene and non-active, follows the course of Heaven. Knowledge that grasps only the small must rest in the Great Peace to attain perfection.

**Lü’s Annotation:**
The distinction between aligning with Heaven and aligning with man—this "non-action" is why even the mad and the cowering seem akin, while knowledge never draws near the Yellow Emperor.

The dragon, as a creature, resembles the transformations of sagely wisdom. To "slay" it is to cast it aside. Exhausting a thousand gold pieces empties one’s possessions. With no use for such skill, one also has no need to cast it aside—this is the wholeness of Heaven.

No conflict is more bitter than that of the will; even the finest swords are inferior. The sage’s talent establishes what is established and enacts what is enacted—this may be certain, yet he never insists upon it, leaving it to Heaven. Thus, treating the inevitable as if it were not, he is not wounded by frustration, and so remains free of conflict. The common people do the opposite, and so abound in conflict. Acting in accord with conflict, they seek and rely upon it—only to perish.

The petty man’s knowledge does not stray from inquiries and gifts, exhausting spirit in shallow pursuits. Yet he aspires to guide all things, to embody the Great Unity in emptiness—tasks beyond his capacity. This is why he is deluded by the cosmos, burdened in form, unaware of the Great Beginning, unable to achieve the Great Unity in emptiness.

Only the sage returns spirit to the Beginningless and delights in the realm of Nothing-Whatsoever. In movement, like water flowing without form, issuing into the Great Purity, he alone can guide all things and embody the Great Unity in emptiness.

The heart as a thing—none knows its abode, yet it is vast. But when its knowledge clings to bribes and letters, it dwells in the tip of a hair and knows not the Great Peace. How lamentable!

**Yi Du’s Annotation:**
The sage does not speak by intent but responds to things when unavoidable. The hearts of Confucius and Mencius were one, yet their words differed—this is why. Yangzi took delight in speech even when silence was fitting. His intent did not differ from Confucius and Mencius; the gap between them lay only in speaking or not speaking. Thus it is said: To know the Dao is easy; to refrain from speaking of it is hard.

When the Dao prevails over things, one can remain silent. This is how speech and silence distinguish Heaven and man, though in truth they are never separate. Worldly people are consumed by desire, so this is used to correct them.

"Slaying dragons" is the most refined skill of scholars, yet it has no practical use. This speaks of Zhuangzi’s learning—probing principle to the utmost, exhausting nature to reach destiny—yet never pursuing useless endeavors. Thus one must be cautious in method.

"Yielding" is destiny. "Insisting" is righteousness. The sage, though righteousness may present an inevitable course, handles it with yielding, for he recognizes destiny—thus he remains free of conflict. The common people, though righteousness offers no inevitable course, act with insistence, ignorant of destiny—thus they abound in conflict.

*Mencius* says: "Words need not be trusted; actions need not be resolute"—this is treating the inevitable as if it were not. The *Analects* says: "Words must be trusted; actions must be resolute"—how stubbornly petty! This is treating the uncertain as if it were certain.

Conflict does not lie outside; it is the battle of joy and anger within the breast. Yet joy and anger cannot be avoided. Yielding to them, one may gain what is sought; relying upon them, one perishes. They must be moderated.

The use of *baozhi* (fragrant grass) in sacrificial rites, the employment of *gandu* (bamboo slips) and writing tablets to convey sincerity—these are but the doings of common folk, who exhaust their spirit in trivialities. They neither aid the world nor guide beings, nor do they seek union with the Great Oneness or the Way of formless emptiness. Such men are deluded by the cosmos, their forms burdened, unaware of the Great Beginning.

The Great Oneness is the origin of number; the Great Beginning, the origin of *qi*. In formless emptiness, we speak of the Great Oneness; in burdened form, we speak of the Great Beginning. Emptiness cannot be without number, while burdened form suffers from its lack of emptiness—thus it is.

The Beginningless is that which precedes all beginnings, the realm of "nothing whatsoever," the Great Void. Water, stored in the body as the kidneys, governs essence. The common people expend their spirit on affairs and objects, their minds racing in the realm of desires. The perfected man stores his spirit in the Beginningless, delighting in the land of "nothing whatsoever."

The water of the common people flows through form and thus is easily exhausted. The water of the perfected man flows through the formless and is therefore inexhaustible, issuing forth into the Great Purity, reaching everywhere. Yet the petty man knows not the Way of Great Tranquility—how lamentable!

*Bixu’s Commentary*: When the heart holds right and wrong yet remains silent, that is Heaven. When the heart feels compassion and gives it voice, that is man. If Heaven and not man, then inner illumination abides—who can be deceived?

Those whose ambitions sprawl aimlessly pursue learning vast and hollow. Those whose skills are strange and forced gain only fragmentation. The dragon is a creature of transformation: when gathered, it forms a body; when scattered, it becomes a pattern. It cannot be fixed in sight—how then could it be slain? Such claims are but grand words.

Yet when skill is perfected and its artistry finds no use, there lies profound meaning: external things cannot be relied upon. Thus the perfected man remains detached, allowing them to unfold, avoiding resentment and conflict. To insist on mastery is to invite disaster—gouged eyes, spilled blood—can one not be cautious?

*Gengsangzi* said: Before resentment arises, it is already a weapon—how could its harm be limited to blades and arrows? To waste one’s spirit on trivial pursuits, gaining little while losing much—this is to be deluded by the cosmos, unaware of the Great Beginning, like one who sees the tip of an autumn hair yet fails to behold Mount Tai.

To tune strings and pipes yet hear not the thunder—such is the way of the world. To return the spirit to the Beginningless is to conceal one’s brilliance. To delight in the land of "nothing whatsoever" is to embrace emptiness and vastness. Thus one knows action in boundless space and applies it in stillness. Yet you cling to the outermost branches and lose the great root—how tragic!

*Yuanzhai* says: Do not speak of difficulty, for the true difficulty lies in forgetting speech. To know the Way and forget speech is to leave the human realm, to walk with Heaven.

To spend one’s family fortune learning to slay dragons, only to find no use for the skill—*Zhuangzi* likens this to his own Way, vast yet without application. The sage treats the inevitable as if it were not, thus knowing what he does not know. The common people treat the uncertain as if it were certain, hence their many conflicts.

War is the greatest of conflicts. If one follows the impulse to contend, then all actions in the world become quests for adversaries, and in striving for dominance, one loses oneself. Letters and inquiries—trivial matters—how can they aid the world or guide all beings to unite with the origin of the Great Oneness and the subtlety of formlessness? Thus one is deluded by the cosmos, burdened by form, unaware of the natural principle of the Great Beginning. The perfected man returns his spirit to the origin of nothingness and abides in non-action.

"Delighting in sleep" is a metaphor for peaceful abiding. Water flows—people see its form but do not know it arises from the formless. When it issues forth and departs, it returns to the Great Purity of emptiness. The common people, unaware of the beginning and end of things, are like water.

To know the tip of a hair is to see only the small. Great Tranquility is the principle of non-action and naturalness, encompassing all. To know the Way and speak of it is the affair of knowledge. To know the Way and forget speech is the affair of the sage, who is one with Heaven.

The wise who speak of the Way may still broaden instruction and teach others, which is not a grave error. But those of shallow learning, puffed with hearsay and self-satisfaction, though they may not speak, their very demeanor betrays their words—how could they grasp the ancient ones’ union with Heaven’s subtlety?

As for "slaying the dragon," most interpretations disparage the theme, misaligning with the text’s intent. Only Lü’s commentary captures its essence. *Bixu* calls it "useless fame," which also misses the mark. Here, I propose renaming it "Forgetting the Subtle Chapter," and offer my humble insight:

One who studies to seek the Way is like one who enters the sea to find a dragon. Yet few see dragons, and fewer still can slay them. This illustrates the difficulty of attaining the Way—and how much harder it is to forget it once attained.

Beginning with the search for the dragon and glimpsing it, one knows the body’s infinite transformations. Culminating in slaying the dragon, one realizes the Way’s formless, supreme spirit. The dragon is not found in stillness but sought in the indistinct and boundless. Slaying is not done with blades but transcends attachment to flesh and glory.

To exhaust spirit and subtlety—how could the dance of *Sanglin* capture it? To spend a thousand gold coins from one’s household is to empty all possessions. After a thousand days of mastery, the skill finds no use—then, with a single encounter, all is resolved, and both dragon and slayer are forgotten.

The Chan school says: "In Dragon Tooth Mountain, at the sight of the dragon, the heart rests." This is the first stage of practice. I venture that the four lines on "slaying the dragon" are extraordinarily concise, their meaning running parallel to the "Butcher Ding" chapter. That chapter ends with skill still in use; this one transcends both form and function, thus reaching perfection.

The sage treats the inevitable as if it were not—what exists is also as if it did not.

The multitude treats the non-inevitable as inevitable, forcing what is nonexistent into existence. The "soldiers" refer to the cravings and desires warring within—whether they exist or not depends on the person alone. Those who follow these "soldiers" act on their desires and seek fulfillment, unaware that reliance on them leads to ruin. Petty knowledge engages in trivial pursuits, exhausting the spirit—this too is self-sabotage. How can one hope to embrace a will that seeks to guide all things under heaven, to fathom the Great Unity and manifest the emptiness of the world? The Great Unity is the origin of all numbers, from which the myriad things depart from nothingness into being, passing form to form in ceaseless generation and transformation.

The multitude is deluded by the cosmos, for they are shackled by present forms and forget the primordial nothingness of the Great Beginning. The perfected person, however, returns the spirit to the beginningless—this is the realm of the Great Beginning’s nothingness, the land of *what has never been*. Water, foremost among the Five Phases, is visible yet cannot be grasped, possessing form yet also formless. When it descends, it flows and nourishes the myriad things; when its qi ascends, it disperses into the Great Purity. Moving with yin, it accomplishes the work of creation—all lies within this.

Yet the worldly exhaust their intellect on trifles, unaware of the Great Tranquility, the Way that moves in harmony with heaven’s ceaseless turning. Great Tranquility is the unaroused true nature, the unmanifest heart. When things stir a response, it is like the Heavenly One generating water, dispersing into the Great Purity. The Song envoy Cao Shang, sent by the King of Song to Qin, departed with but a few chariots;

The king was pleased and granted him a hundred additional chariots. Upon returning to Song, he sought out Zhuangzi and said: "To dwell in narrow, impoverished lanes, struggling to weave sandals, with a withered neck and sallow face—this is where I fall short. Yet to awaken the lord of ten thousand chariots and secure a following of a hundred chariots—this is where I excel."

Zhuangzi replied: "When the King of Qin fell ill, he summoned physicians. Those who lanced boils and drained abscesses received one chariot; those who licked his hemorrhoids received five chariots. The baser the treatment, the greater the reward. Did you, perchance, treat his hemorrhoids? Why else would you have received so many chariots? Begone!"

Guo’s annotation: Only by stooping low does one achieve great merit; great merit brings rich rewards. Thus, those who embrace lofty detachment forsake worldly glory.
Lü’s annotation: All who debase themselves to seek favor are but lickers of hemorrhoids.
Yidu’s annotation: Cao Shang flaunted his chariots, while Zhuangzi likened him to a hemorrhoid-licker—utter contempt.
Bixu’s annotation: The baser the cure, the greater the reward; thus, those who hold to the Dao forsake glory, while those who chase profit forget disgrace.
Yongzhai’s note: *Zuò* refers to a type of abscess. The baser the physician’s work, the richer the reward—such filth and shame are not worth prizing.
Cao Shang boasted of his chariots, while Master Nan Hua (Zhuangzi) exalted himself through the Dao. Chariots bring fleeting ostentation and everlasting stench; the Dao brings eternal honor and undying fragrance. Can one not be cautious in what one pursues?

Duke Ai of Lu asked Yan He: "I rely on Confucius as the pillar of my state—will it not flourish?"
Yan He replied: "Dangerous indeed! Confucius is crumbling!"

Those who adorn feathers with paint, engage in florid rhetoric, take mere branches as their essence, and harden their natures to govern the people—such men neither know nor trust, yet their doctrines are received by the heart and wielded by the spirit. How can they suffice to lead the people? Are they fit for you, Duke Ai? Or for me? To err in this would be pardonable. Now, to cause the people to abandon substance for false learning is no way to govern them. Considering posterity, it would be better to desist. Such governance is difficult indeed.

What is imposed upon others yet never forgotten is not the spontaneous bounty of Heaven. Merchants are held in contempt; even when ranked among the honored, the spirit disregards them. External punishments are meted out by metal and wood; internal punishments arise from movement and transgression. When petty men incur external punishments, metal and wood interrogate them; when they incur internal punishments, yin and yang consume them. Only the true person can escape both inner and outer punishments.

Guo’s annotation: The perfected person finds peace in the people’s tranquility. To rely on a single pillar is to leave a legacy for ten thousand generations. Yet to vie in adorning oneself with benevolence and righteousness, to embellish one’s plumage with carvings, is to endanger the common folk—even the perfected person can find no peace in this. Such embellishment is not true spontaneity; it will lead later generations to pursue emptiness, their intentions and inclinations running wild. Later rulers, admiring Confucius’ distant path, harden their natures and feign virtue to govern, while those above and below imitate one another unawares. If such men are set above the people, later generations will not merely conform in outward form but will receive and employ their doctrines with heart and spirit, no longer finding their own nature within. Those people—you, Duke Ai—each have their own proper way. To imitate one another is to lose authenticity. This is the present-day proof: to model oneself after another is no way to nurture oneself. It is simply impermissible.

This is a consideration for posterity, not a judgment on the present. To govern is to foster falsity, which is why the sage does not govern. To disseminate and recognize such doctrines is to treat the myriad things as straw dogs. Merchants are held in contempt—how much more so scholars and gentlemen? Though one may be compelled to rank them in affairs, their inability to forget themselves causes the spirit to spurn them. Such is the great truth of the common people!

Metal refers to blades, saws, axes, and halberds; wood refers to cudgels, fetters, and stocks. When one is still and proper, there is no punishment, inner or outer. Those who do not follow the bright and open path are called petty men. When one moves beyond measure, one’s nature and qi are harmed within, while metal and wood interrogate without. Unless one is a true person, none can halt this process.

Lü’s annotation: The *Book of Changes* takes *zhen* as the pillar of affairs. All movement under Heaven is rectified by the One. Only by forgetting the heart can one attain the One; attaining the One is how one becomes a pillar. Those who govern the world and its states—if they do not understand this but merely rely on sagely wisdom for governance, the harm will inevitably reach the state described here.

The Dao models itself on the natural, just as the swan’s whiteness comes not from daily washing but from its innate nature.
