When sagely wisdom becomes a burden, it is like painting feathers—feathers are the natural essence of Heaven, while painting is the artifice of man. Pursuing florid rhetoric to magnify the small or confuse names and realities, acting contrary to nature—all such efforts are forced. To suppress one’s nature in governing the people, yet remain unaware of their distrust, is to fail to forget the heart and instead be enslaved by it, to fail to embody the spirit and instead be ruled by it. This is how one becomes a servant of the people—how could such a one be fit to lead them?

The reason the Dao cannot be shared with others is that its core lacks a master and thus remains unrectified. Can Confucius truly set you right, or must you cultivate yourself? Only by cutting off learning and nurturing the heart can one attain the One. To rely solely on the sage as a pillar is a mistake—it is not the way to true rectitude. To abandon true learning for falsity is no way to govern the people. If one claims to act like clouds drifting and rain falling, why not simply forget all effort?

Merchants are not ranked with scholars—this is ancient ritual. Yet the ritual of ranking by occupation is a human convention, for the spiritual does not rank itself; this is the nature of man. To value righteousness and disdain profit is the true expression of human nature. Those who pursue profit and forget righteousness have lost their original heart. Metal and wood punish the body; movement and excess punish the heart. Stillness and non-action are the heart’s rectitude; all movement is deviation. To act and yet seek propriety is to proceed from necessity—otherwise, all is excess.

Yang Xiong said that by day, men’s faults are few; by night, their faults are many. "Night" here means the same as "petty." Those who practice the Dao without attaining its radiance and greatness, yet still incur inner and outer punishment, remain petty men. Only the true person acts in stillness, proceeding from necessity—how could inner and outer punishments ever burden them?

Yi Du’s annotation: Duke Ai knew only the coarse aspects of Confucius, so he wished to employ him as a pillar. All affairs return to rectitude as all branches grow from the trunk. Yet Yan He said that if Confucius were to govern a state, not only would he fail to bring order, but he would endanger it. He would merely adorn his plumage, amplify its colors, and indulge in florid rhetoric, neglecting substance. Taking branches for fingers, he would lose his original nature. Desiring to suppress and control, he would govern the people with falsity, unaware of their distrust. If later rulers followed his example, they would take his traces to heart, let his spirit rule them, and fail to transcend form to follow their nature and destiny—how could they be fit to lead the people?

Moreover, the people and Duke Ai each have their own nature and destiny—how could they imitate you? If you wish to imitate him, that is not the way to nurture yourself. To speak of employing Confucius as a pillar is acceptable as a misstatement, but not as a correct one. To abandon true learning for falsity is no way to govern the people, for fear that later generations would chase his traces and perpetuate error. Better to let things follow their nature.

"Distribution" is like the flow of a spring—its use has weight, and when given to others, it is not forgotten; this is human distribution. Heavenly distribution gives without the giver seeing the thing, and the receiver remains unaware of the favor. Human distribution gives with the expectation of repayment. Even merchants are not ranked with scholars, though ranked by occupation, for the spiritual does not rank itself. Affairs and the Dao are distinct!

Metal and wood harm the four limbs; movement and excess harm the five viscera. Petty men, being benighted, cannot escape inner and outer punishment. Beginning with the ebb and flow of yin and yang, if one cannot return, metal and wood will reach them. Only the true person can avoid this!

The *Bixu Annotation* states: Painting feathers for adornment, embellishing with florid and branching rhetoric, and governing the people with deliberate artifice—thus do customs become rife with falsity. Taking up affairs wearies the mind; controlling things exhausts the spirit. One will sicken oneself—how then can one govern the people?

"Yu" (與) and "yi" (颐) are both pronounced like the "yu" in *dangyu* (party faction); I follow the pronunciation of *tuiyu* (推與, to bestow). "Bi" (彼) refers to Confucius. "Ru er" (汝爾) denotes the multitude. It speaks of Confucius’ virtue being worthy of the people’s allegiance, yet if one carelessly applies his methods of nurturing the masses, one cannot know whether they will succeed or fail. Abandoning substance for false learning, one governs in such a way that the people are expected not to forget one’s virtue—this is not due to lack of intention. Even peddlers and hawkers may not expect repayment, let alone scholars and gentlemen!

Bestowing favors and expecting repayment is what worldly sentiment praises; bestowing without favor and receiving without repayment is what the principles of the Dao esteem. Demanding repayment for favors gives rise to harm through punishment. External punishments come from metal and wood; internal punishments arise from movement and excess. Whether manifest or hidden, none can escape them. Thus, those who enact laws find their hearts torn between ice and fire; those who violate decrees face the axe and halberd in the outer world. When superiors and inferiors alike lose their harmony, how can one hope for order and governance?

*Yuanzhai* says: "Zhenggan" (贞干) means worthy assistants, steadfast and capable of managing affairs. Having painted with colors, one further adorns with feathers—this speaks of excessive literary embellishment. Taking "branches" (支) as the aim, one forgets the root. Suppressing one’s nature through forced rectitude and governing from above, one displays what is unreal without even realizing it.

What is received by the heart becomes fixed therein, and thus the spirit and consciousness take it as their sovereign. How can one who is thus governed suffice to lead the people? *"Yi"* means "to benefit"; *"yi"* (颐) means "to nourish." If you regard another as worthy and nourish them, it will bring no benefit to you—it may mislead you, but it will not improve your lot. Better to desist.

The people may be governed without governing; to govern with intent is to make governance difficult. To administer policies without forgetting them is to govern with intent—like a merchant who, when taken for a scholar, is deemed unworthy of equal standing. Even if circumstances bring them together, the spirit finds no joy in it. Such are men of contrivance; thus, those who embody the Dao disdain to associate with them.

*"Xun"* means interrogation; *"shi"* (食) is akin to the *shi* in "eclipse," denoting affliction. The transgressions and faults of the human body are no different from punishments and executions. Only the Perfected escape this.

Duke Ai sought Confucius as his assistant, hoping for a cure to his ailing state—like one who, being ill, seeks a physician. The more urgent the plea, the greater the expectation; thus, he questioned Yan He to confirm his resolve. He then enumerated the flaws of contemporary worthies, showing that exalting them brought no benefit but only fostered hypocrisy and deceit, making the people harder to govern.

Confucius, the most prominent of the worthies of his time, serves here as an example. Adorning with feathers and embellishing with colors—this metaphor speaks of engaging in florid rhetoric, fragmented and divorced from the root, forcing one’s nature to display what is false, unaware that the people, seeing through it, respond with deceit.

When things arrive, the heart receives them; when the heart receives things, the spirit governs them. With no inner emptiness and outer turmoil, one is no different from the common folk—how can such a one lead them?

He further asked: Does Confucius truly benefit you? Can you nourish your people yourself? *"Wu"* (误) should be *"wu"* (悟), "to awaken." You ought to reflect and awaken to this truth. All that has been said above leads people away from genuine learning toward falsity—it is no way to set an example for the world. Better not to act at all.

The people are difficult to govern because their knowledge is excessive, yet this stems from those above who incite it. Such conduct is like that of merchants, unworthy of being ranked with scholars. Even if, for a time, they are accorded equal standing—such as in village festivals or communal feasts—the spirit still disdains their company, for their aspirations differ. Herein lies the division between the worthy and the unworthy.

Those petty men who study falsity cannot escape the punishments of inner and outer realms. *"Xiaoren"* (宵人) refers to those who grope in darkness without insight, who, though in broad daylight, remain as if in endless night. *"Movement"* refers to the first deviation of the heart’s intent; *"excess"* manifests in action. Once excess takes form, it cannot be concealed—thus, metal and wood interrogate it, and yin and yang afflict it. *"Shi"* (食) means "to invade." The Perfected, embodying purity and non-action, how could inner or outer punishments reach them?

*End of the One Hundredth Scroll of the* Southern Florescence Scripture: An Ocean of Subtle Meanings
*Beginning of the One Hundred and First Scroll of the* Southern Florescence Scripture: An Ocean of Subtle Meanings

Master Chu Boxiu of Wulin, on *Liezi* Chapter Three:

Confucius said: "The human heart is more treacherous than mountains and rivers, harder to fathom than Heaven. Heaven at least has its seasons—spring, autumn, winter, summer—and its fixed times of dawn and dusk. But man conceals his true nature beneath a thick façade and deep emotions. Thus, some appear meek yet grow arrogant; some seem mature yet act unworthy; some appear compliant yet prove insightful; some seem resolute yet prove weak; some seem relaxed yet prove fierce. Those who rush toward righteousness as if parched will flee from it as if burned.

Therefore, the noble person tests them from afar to observe their loyalty, up close to observe their reverence, under pressure to observe their competence, with sudden questions to observe their wisdom, with urgent deadlines to observe their trustworthiness, with entrusted wealth to observe their benevolence, with warnings of danger to observe their integrity, with intoxication to observe their restraint, and in mixed company to observe their demeanor. When all nine tests are complete, the unworthy are revealed."

Guo’s commentary: "More treacherous than mountains and rivers... flee from it as if burned" describes how human nature and appearance can contradict each other. Though difficult to discern, they are not without traces. The noble are easy to recognize, while the unworthy are hard to discern. Yet by observing their conduct, examining their comforts, and searching through proper channels, they too can be known.

Lü’s commentary: "Meek" implies little self-assertion, hence its opposite is arrogance. "Mature" contrasts with "unworthy." "Compliant yet hasty" contrasts with "insightful"—for the insightful are upright and fond of righteousness, unlike the merely compliant. "Resolute" and "weak," "relaxed" and "fierce" are all opposites, so one cannot rely on a single approach in assessment.

Yi Du’s commentary: The treachery of mountains and rivers is visible, but the treachery of the human heart is formless. Heaven’s movements follow fixed cycles, but the human heart’s changes are unpredictable. Even the treachery of mountains and rivers and the transformations of Heaven are hard to grasp—how much more so the human heart! "Thick façade and deep emotions" speak to its unfathomable nature. From "appear meek yet grow arrogant" to "seem relaxed yet prove fierce," human nature and appearance contradict each other, yet they are not without traces—only difficult to discern. Zhuangzi’s nine tests observe the heart through outward signs, revealing whether one is noble or petty.

Bixu’s commentary: This speaks of how the treachery of mountains and rivers is visible, while the treachery of the human heart is hard to measure. Some have stern appearances yet arrogant natures; some appear mature yet act unworthy; some seem compliant yet prove distant; some seem resolute yet prove weak; some seem relaxed yet prove fierce. With such contradictions between inner and outer, one cannot rely on a single approach. Thus, the noble employ the nine tests: the loyal remain steadfast even when sent far away; the reverent do not slacken when near; the competent do not falter under pressure; the wise adapt without confusion; the trustworthy keep their word without wavering; the benevolent do not deceive when handling wealth; the principled do not falter in danger; the restrained do not lose control when drunk; the pure remain unstained in mixed company. If one judges character merely by superficial impressions rather than concrete actions, one cannot fully grasp the true nature of the noble and the petty.

Yunzhai’s commentary: Some appear meek yet seek personal gain; some conceal their strengths behind an unworthy guise; some are compliant or hasty yet understand reason; some seem resolute yet prove weak; some seem relaxed yet prove fierce. This shows how unpredictable people can be. "As if parched" describes their eagerness; "as if burned" describes their swift retreat. Through the nine tests, the worthy and unworthy become clear. This passage’s reasoning is sound—by attributing it to Confucius, we see that Zhuangzi was not disrespectful toward him.

Heaven has its cycles of cold and heat, clear and rainy weather, which can be predicted by calculations. Earth has its mountains, rivers, valleys, and ravines, which can be crossed by bridges and boats. But the human heart, in its small compass, holds changes and treacheries beyond measure or remedy. Why is this? The human heart’s grasp or loss of principle, its comings and goings, are untimely—this is what makes it so hard to know or see. Yet when it clings to something, its form becomes visible. By observing appearances and scrutinizing words, one can grasp six or seven parts of it. But if one cloaks it in depth and thickness, one cannot avoid testing it.

Those whose hearts are upright manifest uprightness in all their actions; those whose hearts are crooked manifest crookedness in all their actions. Though they may cunningly disguise themselves, there is always something they cannot conceal—this is how the noble and the petty are distinguished. The key lies with those in authority: if they wish to remain within bounds, approachable and close to the people, then the hearts of the world will be as one, and its customs as harmonious as a single family. What need is there to fear the difficulty of knowing them, or to worry about the difficulty of transforming them?

From "appear meek" to "as if burned" describes the contradictions between inner and outer. From "test them from afar" to "in mixed company" examines the steadfastness of their principles. While the nine tests can reveal the worthy and unworthy, they are laborious. It is better to remain empty in the face of events and calmly observe their eyes and movements—as if seeing their very lungs and liver. If one further speaks and gains their trust, how can they escape judgment?

When Zheng Kaofu received his first appointment, he bowed; at his second, he stooped; at his third, he bent low, walking along the wall. Who would dare to transgress! But take the likes of that man: at his first appointment, he strutted like Lü Ju; at his second, he danced atop his carriage; at his third, he called his elders by name. Who could compare to Tang or Xu! The greatest harm lies in virtue with intent, and intent with eyes—once it has eyes, it turns inward, and turning inward, it fails.

There are five grave vices, with "inner virtue" as the foremost. What is "inner virtue"? It is when one prides oneself on one’s goodness and derides what one does not do.

Poverty has eight extremes; success has three certainties; the body has six repositories. Handsome beards, tall stature, robust build, striking beauty, and courage—though one may surpass others in all eight, they may still lead to ruin.

The Green Follower, the Prostrate Wanderer, and the Timid Inferior—those who embody all three attain mastery. Wisdom that extends outward invites trouble; bold action breeds resentment; benevolence and righteousness bring reproach.

Those who grasp the essence of life are marveled at; those who grasp knowledge are diminished; those who grasp the great mandate follow it; those who grasp the petty mandate encounter it.

*(Guo’s Annotation: "Tang" refers to Yao. "Xu" refers to Xu You. It speaks of how that man and Kaofu could not compare to the deeds of Tang and Xu.)*

Virtue with intent is not true virtue. True virtue arises spontaneously, unknowing of its own attainment. To act with the heart’s inclination as virtue is still acceptable; but to constrain the heart within the space between brows and lashes is already gross pretense. If one then seeks to probe hidden depths and make profundity one’s pursuit, both heart and endeavor will fail.

To assert oneself as right and others as wrong invites attacks from many quarters—thus becoming the foremost calamity. If within there is no self-satisfied sentiment, and one freely affirms whatever the myriad things affirm, each affirmation unerring, then all under heaven will yearn to serve them.

"Poverty" refers to being exhausted by servitude. The world is never impoverished by its shortcomings but is constantly ensnared by its strengths.

The Green Follower walks leaning on things; the Prostrate Wanderer cannot bow to take up tasks; the Timid Inferior is weak and fearful.

These three, being unfit for practical service, are instead employed as assistants—thus they must attain understanding.

One who is outwardly unconstrained will, by boundlessness, harm their inner self; timid yet composed, they merely preserve their person. As for benevolence and righteousness, all under heaven expect their love, yet love cannot be all-encompassing—hence many reproaches arise.

*Kuiran*: vast and untroubled. *Xiao*: released and dispersed. The *sui* (follower) merges indistinctly with transformation. The *da* (understanding one) awakens only by abiding at the nodal point.

Lu’s commentary: From Zheng Kaofu to the refined harmony of Tang and Xu, one sees how vessel and capacity vary—those who "know not, perceive not" yet follow Heaven’s pattern, while those who defame it become rebels. Virtue possesses a heart, and the heart possesses an eye; knowledge is complete, yet it corrupts the pattern—no greater thief exists than this. "Inward vision" is precisely what is called a thief.

When the five senses stir, lost and unable to return, none is not calamitous. The central virtue is foremost: if virtue has a heart, then it has a self; if it has a self, it asserts itself as right and others as wrong—thus it harbors self-satisfaction and sucks at what it does not do.

If all eight surpass others, one becomes self-satisfied—hence impoverished. If the three fall short of others, one strives—hence attains understanding. Mencius’ discussion of solitary ministers and disinherited sons, their vigilance and careful consideration of rightness, is of the same vein.

When wisdom and intelligence extend outward, things arrive. Courageous action breeds resentment; benevolence and righteousness invite reproach—this clarifies that what the vulgar world deems fine is not truly fine, and what it deems foul is not truly foul. The essential point lies in the strong-willed who possess resolve, leaving their form behind.

One who, in life, attains understanding is what is called "Heaven-born"—they know nothing of "knowing," existing merely as *kuiran*. One who, in knowledge, attains understanding knows that what they know arises from non-knowing yet cannot return to non-knowing—merely *xiao*. Fate is what the Creator enacts; we and the Creator are human—thus one who understands the great mandate follows it without departure. Knowing that poverty and success lie with Heaven, not with oneself, one who understands the minor mandate encounters it without refusal.

*Yi du* notes: A single-command officer, a double-command grandee, a triple-command minister. *Yanlou* to "following the wall"—all describe the dignity of yielding and deferring, where rank increases and deference deepens. "Unruly" means to insult. *Lüju*: the bearing of an erect waist. "Dancing atop the carriage" is the height of frivolity. "Summoning one’s uncles" is the extreme of right-handed arrogance. Yao and Xu yielded the world, yet those who could not do so—how could they match Tang and Xu? This speaks of the noble who, upon receiving mandate, grow ever more reverent, and the petty who, upon receiving mandate, grow ever more insolent.

Virtue with a heart is lower virtue; higher virtue has no heart. A heart with an eye is a moving heart; a still heart has no eye. Virtue with a heart steals the Dao; a heart with an eye steals virtue. When Dao and virtue are lost, human artifice arises; when artifice arises, inward vision follows. Thoughts and schemes, bustling and restless, corrupt one’s true nature.

The "calamitous virtues" are the eye, ear, nose, tongue, and heart. The heart is the central virtue; when it moves, the four follow. If within there is self-satisfaction, and others do not conform to one’s preferences, one reviles them—this is the heart’s theft.

The eight that surpass others inevitably become enslaved by others—hence impoverished. The three that fall short of others yet preserve their person—hence attain understanding. Humans possess eight extremes and three necessities, just as the body has six repositories—this is the natural principle.

When wisdom and intelligence extend outward, they harm the inner self. Courageous action, driven by nature, invites resentment. Insistence on righteousness leads others to expect love and heap reproach. One who understands the essence of life is greatly awakened and unbound. One who understands the essence of fate is one with the divine. One who understands knowledge is *xiao*. *Xiao* is small; the Dao is great—hence it seems un-*xiao*.

One who understands the great mandate forgets life and death, free of encumbrance, delighting in Heaven. One who understands the minor mandate accepts poverty and wealth, longevity and early death as they come, at peace. Bi Xu notes: *Wenzi* says, "The Dao with knowledge is chaotic; virtue with a heart is perilous; a heart with an eye is dazzled." "Having a heart" means amplifying love and rightness. "Having an eye" means chasing after appearances. "Inward vision" means discerning, distinguishing, rejecting, and selecting. The "calamitous virtues" are the eye, ear, nose, tongue, and heart. The heart governs within; self-satisfied and self-righteous, it reviles those who differ—this is called inward vision, and inward vision is corruption.

All who excel at overcoming things will, in time, become impoverished. Those who fear falling short of others will, in time, attain understanding. This is the principle of rise and fall. Wisdom and intelligence turned outward harm the inner self; courageous action invites resentment; benevolence and righteousness, unyielding, are misapplied—none preserve the person.

Thus, one who understands the essence of life is greatly awakened and unbound. One who understands knowledge is *xiao*, resembling foolishness. One who understands the great mandate follows life and death. One who understands the minor mandate accepts encounters with equanimity—how can poverty or success burden them?

Juan Zhai says: The lines on virtue having a heart are most intimate to the learner’s condition. Chan schools call this the "leaking mind" or the "second thought." To practice virtue while knowing it as virtue is to have a heart. Within this heart, there is the intent to calculate and scheme—this opens an eye. With this eye-opened heart, one turns inward, and the myriad distinctions no longer recognize the undifferentiated whole.

The "calamitous virtues" refer to the heart, ears, eyes, and nose. "Having self-satisfaction" means priding oneself on ability while reviling others’ inability—this heart is unfit for learning the Dao. *Yuanjue* says: "Do not disdain long practice, nor belittle the beginner." This is the same idea.

The "eight extremes" mean that relying on anything will lead to impoverishment. The "three necessities" mean that contented insufficiency may yet attain understanding. *Yuanxun*: compliant and yielding. *Yanxia*: the bearing of rising and falling. "The body has six repositories" means the six abodes of accumulation within the human form.

Wisdom, courage, benevolence and righteousness, attaining life, attaining knowledge, and attaining destiny—these are the six. "Encountering" still harbors the heart of gain and loss, of entrusting to fate; "following" means to let it be without reservation. The six repositories are later drawn out into two concluding phrases through the character *ming* (destiny)—this is the structure of the text.

Zheng Kaofu, the tenth-generation ancestor of Confucius, was a grandee of Song. This passage still echoes the dialogue between Duke Ai and Yan He regarding the remnants of Wei’s governance. It speaks of how the sage and the worthy conduct themselves in the world, never allowing prosperity or adversity to burden their hearts. "Thrice commanded and creeping along walls"—this is fear of success. "Thrice commanded and named among the elders"—this is arrogance in success. Both remain ensnared by the shocks of favor and disgrace; how could they ever align with the lofty aspirations of Yao, Tang, or Xu You? Yao’s yellow-roofed carriage was not of his own desire; Xu You’s refusal to overstep his role—though their paths differed, their hearts were one. Thus, this is used to conclude the preceding chapter’s meaning.

Later, it discusses the folly of worldly self-regard, unaware that prosperity and adversity arise from destiny. To practice virtue with a calculating heart gives rise to distinctions, and thus one’s kindness cannot be vast. To labor the mind with fixed views leads to excessive deliberation and inner restlessness. Kindness that is not vast harms virtue; inner restlessness harms the heart. These are the greatest corruptions.

"Inward vision" means to ponder one’s desires, to scheme and arrange as if before one’s eyes, to plan for certain success—only for ruin to follow. The Buddhists speak of five kinds of eyes: only the heavenly eye and the fleshly eye reside in the face; the wisdom eye, the Dharma eye, and the Buddha eye all reside in the heart. Their heart-eye is manifest, the effect of cultivated virtue; this heart-eye is a warning, the root of moral failure. If one does not guard against failure, how can one ever attain success? The teachings of the two schools stand as outer and inner to each other.

Are there five calamitous virtues? They are seeing, hearing, speaking, bearing, and thinking—all that do not proceed from rectitude. The heart governs within and leads the head; when one prides oneself as peerless and reviles others, this is the beginning of moral failure. With the four calamities following, what evil would one not commit? If one can return to the central virtue from within, the path back is not far; turning misfortune into fortune lies in human effort alone.

The "eight extremes" and "three necessities" are also marvelous, embodying the principle of mutual generation and cyclical recurrence—just as the organs and viscera within the human body respond to the waxing and waning of yin and yang without self-awareness.

Wisdom is meant to cultivate virtue, yet when applied externally and entangled in affairs, it stirs courage and breeds resentment. Benevolence and righteousness are meant to extend kindness, yet broad relief is difficult; thus, one’s aid is incomplete and invites blame. One who attains life is serene and at ease; one who attains knowledge forgets knowledge entirely. The great destiny is followed and entrusted; the small destiny is accepted as it comes. This is why the worthy and the noble find joy in both adversity and prosperity, leaving worldly troubles far behind.

*Yu yi* is difficult to interpret; it should mean "you." *Xiao* is pronounced *xiao* and shares the same meaning.

*Southern Florescence Scripture: Ocean of Meanings and Subtleties*, Scroll One Hundred One—concluded
*Southern Florescence Scripture: Ocean of Meanings and Subtleties*, Scroll One Hundred Two

The Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin on *Liezi*, Chapter Four

A man who had an audience with the King of Song was granted ten chariots. With these ten chariots, he grew arrogant and sought to belittle Master Zhuang.

Master Zhuang said: "By the river lived a poor family who made their living weaving reeds. Their son dived into the depths and obtained a pearl worth a thousand gold pieces. His father said to him, 'Fetch a stone and smash it!' For a pearl of such value must lie beneath the chin of the black dragon in the ninefold abyss. That you could obtain it means you must have encountered the dragon while it slept. Had the black dragon awakened, what trace of you would remain?

Now, the depths of the state of Song are not merely a ninefold abyss, and the King of Song is not merely a black dragon. That you could obtain those chariots means you must have encountered him while he slept. Had the King of Song awakened, you would have been ground to powder!"

Another man was sent to extend an invitation to Master Zhuang. Zhuang responded to the envoy, saying: "Have you not seen the sacrificial ox? It is clothed in embroidered robes and fed with fine grass and beans. Yet when it is led into the grand ancestral temple, though it might wish to be a lone calf again, could it ever be so?"

Guo's commentary: "Those who seek wealth and rank must align with the people’s expectations. If one clings to strange doctrines, rides the celestial thoroughfare, and seeks to sway the ruler’s heart, a wise sovereign will not accept it. Thus, if there is praise, there must be trial. Only when the people are not opposed and the multitude’s hopes are met can one be raised to office—this is how the Three Dynasties followed the straight path."

Those who cherish life fear the sacrificial knife and decline invitations; the skull, hearing of life, knits its brows in disdain. The sentiments of life and death differ, each appropriate in its own way.

Lü's commentary: "Those in the world who risk danger, seeking favor and fame without awakening, are all like the pearl-diver. This is what the perfected ones find perilous and lament. Yet they use such gains to boast before others—is this not absurd? Master Zhuang entered a state beyond death and life, once declaring death as joyous as a king facing south. Thus, the sacrificial ox of the grand temple holds no terror for him. Yet the common folk endanger body and life in pursuit of profit, which is why his conduct is so restrained."

Yi Du's commentary: "Weaving reeds for food is the basest of trades. Yet when the son dived and obtained a pearl worth a thousand gold pieces, it was because he encountered the black dragon while it slept. Had the dragon awakened, what would have become of him? Now, how is your obtaining the King of Song’s chariots any different? He also cited the sacrificial ox in response to the envoy, refusing to let wealth and rank burden his life."

Bixu's commentary: "Gaining a pearl while weaving reeds—how is this different from a quail hatching where no field was tilled? That one chanced upon the dragon’s sleep was already perilous. To boast of ten chariots while forgetting the disaster of being ground to powder, or to decline an invitation while yearning for the life of a lone calf—such is the difference between the wise and the foolish."

Yuanzhai's note: "*Jiao xi* means to be haughty and treat others as children. *Wei xiao* refers to weaving reeds into mats. Obtaining the pearl while the dragon slept illustrates how those who seek wealth and rank tread a perilous path. If their ruler awakens, the calamity will not be light—what trace of them would remain? To be left with nothing but scraps."

The passage on the sacrificial ox in the ancestral temple shares the same meaning as the tortoise dragging its tail through the mud. *Wei xiao* is also written as *wei xiao* (reed mats), referring to gathering firewood for sustenance—Bixu’s edition follows this reading. When the boy dived into the abyss and playfully retrieved the pearl, it was unexpected, so he did not recognize its wonder. Nor did he heed whether the black dragon slept or woke. But when his father wished to test the pearl by striking it with a stone, he acted with intent. Moreover, he warned that if the black dragon awoke, they would be ground to powder. Having narrowly escaped death once, how could he dare descend into the abyss again? This analogy illustrates that seizing what others desire invites grave misfortune. Even if one obtains it by chance without intent, such luck cannot be repeated. "*What trace would remain?*"—some suspect the character *wei* (trace) omits *qu* (body), but this is even less plausible. These four words are a stroke of genius; Yongzhai’s interpretation is apt.

The metaphor of the sacrificial ox requires no further explanation.

When Zhuangzi was near death, his disciples wished to bury him with lavish rites. Zhuangzi said: "I take heaven and earth as my coffin and outer coffin, the sun and moon as my paired jades, the stars as my pearls and jades, and the myriad things as my funeral gifts. Are my burial rites not already complete? What more could be added?" His disciples said: "We fear that crows and kites will devour you." Zhuangzi replied: "Above, I would be eaten by crows and kites; below, by ants and mole crickets. To snatch from one to give to the other—how partial is that! To seek balance through imbalance is to fail to achieve true balance; to seek verification through unverified means is to fail to achieve true verification. The enlightened are but tools of the numinous; the numinous verifies all. That the enlightened cannot surpass the numinous has long been so. Yet fools rely on their limited vision to impose upon others—such efforts are external, is it not lamentable?"

Guo’s commentary: To impose one’s own notion of balance upon the myriad things is inferior to allowing them to find balance on their own. To force a response based on one’s own perceptions rather than letting things respond naturally will inevitably fail. Those who act upon their limited vision are themselves enslaved—how can they command others? Only by following the numinous can one attain perfect harmony, thus responding effortlessly to all things. The reach of enlightenment extends no further than form and appearance; perfect harmony transcends distance, depth, and obscurity, allowing each thing to find its own fulfillment. Action arises from without, but its efficacy resides in things. If one clings to one’s own views and insists on being right, even the desire to influence others will result in external exertion.

Lü’s commentary: To embody the unity and sameness of heaven, earth, and the myriad things is to live fully equipped to sustain one’s form; in death, to use them as funeral gifts is no empty claim. To spare oneself from being eaten by crows, kites, ants, or mole crickets is to fall into partiality of giving and taking. Only without intent is there no giving or taking. To balance through balance is to achieve perfect balance; to verify through verification is to achieve perfect verification. But with intent, there is inevitably selection and rejection, losing one’s constant mind—this is the height of unverified and unbalanced. To seek balance is to fail to achieve true balance; to seek verification is to fail to achieve true verification. Like water, it is stillness that brings balance, which the great craftsman emulates. Only because it is balanced can it balance all; only because it is verified can it verify all. Those who today know how to give and take rely merely on enlightenment; those who do not know rely on the numinous. The enlightened are but tools of the numinous, while the numinous verifies all—this is why enlightenment cannot surpass the numinous. Yet fools, unaware of the numinous, rely solely on their own perceptions to impose upon others, expending effort externally. How can they return to the essence of life and destiny?

Yi Du’s commentary: The former kings established burial rites with coffins, outer coffins, clothing, and gold to conceal the body, fulfilling the devotion of a child—though they knew the spirit returns to heaven, the essence to earth, and the form transforms like a cicada’s molting into something else. As children, they could not bear otherwise, so the former kings accommodated human sentiment with ritual and decorum. Zhuangzi was not ignorant of the ancients’ intent in establishing rites, but in his time, ritual excesses led to competitive extravagance in burials, going beyond mere filial devotion. Thus, he spoke loftily to correct this, urging a return to fundamental simplicity. Taking heaven and earth as his coffin and outer coffin demonstrated his alignment with the Dao. All that falls under the Dao—all that has form and appearance—was at his command. Thus, the myriad things were at his disposal, yet he sought nothing. The perfected person’s self-conduct was thus; in dealing with others, the rites of the former kings remained. Whether the body is left above or below ground, it will inevitably be devoured by other beings. To snatch from one to give to another is still partiality. The sage preserves the spirit, not the form, for this reason. What seeks balance through imbalance fails to achieve balance; what seeks verification through unverified means fails to achieve verification. To balance the world through non-balance is to let the world balance itself, not through intent; to verify the world through non-verification is to let the world verify itself, not through intent. Where there is balance, there is imbalance; balance arises from imbalance, thus eliminating imbalance. Where there is verification, there is non-verification; verification arises from non-verification, thus eliminating non-verification. Only balance and verification are governed by the numinous, while the enlightened serve as its tools. The numinous is the Way of Heaven; enlightenment is the way of man. Thus, enlightenment cannot surpass the numinous. The world’s fools, relying on their own perceptions, use enlightenment to impose upon others, extinguishing their nature and expending effort externally while neglecting the internal—is this not lamentable?

Bixu’s commentary: The wealthy adorn coffins with jade disks, pearls, and jades, but to use the sun, moon, and stars as such—is this not already complete? To let crows, kites, ants, and mole crickets achieve balance is to avoid partiality; to snatch from one to give to another is imbalance. To impose one’s own views to balance the myriad things—how can they ever find balance?

To impose partial views upon the myriad movements—how can the myriad movements ever respond? Discernment creates distinction, and those who discern are thus enslaved; the numinous, however, is darkly boundless and empty, responding to all things without exception. Discernment has its limits, while the boundless knows no end—this is why enlightenment cannot surpass the numinous. Yet the world’s fools, relying on their own perceptions, pry into the hidden affairs of others, seize them as their own, expend effort externally without knowing to return inward—how the perfected sigh in lament!

Yuzhai’s commentary: This chapter satirizes the excesses of lavish burials in its time. To snatch from crows and kites to give to ants and mole crickets is partiality in perception. The principles of the myriad things are inherently balanced; if I impose an unbalanced mind to balance them, then what was balanced becomes unbalanced! The principles of things can be verified one by one; if I use an unverifiable mind to verify them, then what was verifiable becomes unverifiable. Originally, nothing compelled this, yet one assumes something compels it—this is to mistake the absence of intent for intent. The self-imposed burdens of the enlightened are ever thus. As for the numinous, it simply allows things to respond of themselves. "Enlightenment cannot surpass the numinous" means that intent cannot surpass non-action. Yet fools, relying on their private views to impose upon others, seek merit externally—how lamentable!

In ancient times, burials followed the natural contours of mountains, neither mounded nor marked with trees, neither exposing stench above nor reaching springs below, seeking only to conceal the form. Thus, the simplicity of coffins and shrouds, the austerity of funerary objects, may be known. Later generations, habituated to extravagance, adorned themselves in life with jade disks, pearls, and precious stones—already excessive—then used them to decorate coffins. The profusion of funerary objects, the grandeur of tombs and tunnels, need not be elaborated. This stems from those who, clinging to status and wealth, indulge in life’s luxuries, making it impossible to skimp on funerary rites. Surveying the lavish burials of antiquity—such as Tiger Hill or Mount Li—one finds they were deemed secure for ten thousand years, yet ultimately served only as treasure troves for great thieves.

Now, the disciples of Nanhua wish to bury their master with lavish rites—this too is a natural expression of human sentiment. Yet they still follow vulgar custom, hence the sigh: "I take heaven and earth as my coffin and bier!" How penetrating these words—unheard of in ancient times! The ideas of Yang Wangsun’s naked burial and Liu Bolun’s carrying of a spade both arise from this. Once the form is entrusted to the earth, how can crows, kites, ants, or mole crickets be avoided? In life, we originate from nothingness, yet externally, fleas and lice thrive, while internally, decay and dissolution transform us—all arising from our own existence. In death, like the cicada’s husk or the snake’s slough, we cast off the form and depart. The numinous, however, goes everywhere without exception—why then fear crows, kites, ants, or mole crickets?

Enlightenment refers to what is visible in form, yet it must rely on what is invisible within to govern it—moving when it wills to move, halting when it wills to halt. Within it lies constancy, which is what is meant by verification. Imbalance resides in form, for form differs in wealth and poverty, longevity and early death. Yet the numinous within humans is one. Observing things through the numinous, there is no imbalance; observing through form, imbalance arises. Verification is to strike and receive a response, to be moved and achieve resonance. If one views things with distrust, things will not trust in return.

Form inherently lacks verification; it takes verification from the numinous, seeking externally what lies within—thus, the internal is weighty, the external light. If one seeks verification from the external within the internal, then verification becomes non-verification, and balance becomes imbalance. The enlightened are made to serve, their actions limited; the numinous verifies, its tranquil essence boundless. Thus, it is said that enlightenment cannot surpass the numinous.

The Perfected One establishes this discourse not only to correct the excesses of lavish burials in his time but also to teach later scholars that what matters lies within, not without; what must be cultivated is the numinous, not the form. The source of balance and verification lies within, for the numinous and enlightenment temporarily depend on one another. If one can achieve this, one becomes one with heaven and earth. The argument that the sun, moon, and stars suffice as coffin ornaments, rendering pearls and jade excessive, is thus made.

The two Perfected Ones, Nanhua and Chongxu, appeared in their time to propagate the teaching, elevating the world to tranquility. Their enduring instructions have bestowed blessings across the ages. The two classics elucidate one another’s purport, and their excellence cannot be ranked. Yet this text begins with Liezi riding the wind, still dependent on something, while later passages cite it inconsistently. Some argue that with Zhuangzi’s talent, he could have galloped freely, forging his own marvels—why then follow Chongxu’s path?

I have examined the reasoning: all who possess virtue must express it in words, for words guide conduct. Those whose conduct aligns yet whose words differ do not exist. The ultimate in profound discourse is timeless, whether expressed directly or obliquely, through straightforward or paradoxical speech—all serve to illuminate the Dao. Nanhua delights in the excellence of former worthies, adopting entire passages to convey his own meaning in sixteen instances. The *Minghai* chapter of *Liezi* is quite brief, while *Zhuangzi* elaborates it in detail. Thus, in each chapter’s conclusion, one sees the indigo surpassing the plant, its brilliance redoubled. *Zhuangzi* is enriched by *Liezi*, while *Liezi* is further illuminated by *Zhuangzi*.

Earlier, the passage on riding the wind was seen as dependent on external means, judged by its traces; later, the subtlety of its words is grasped through the mind’s resonance. The final chapter is titled "Yu kou," clarifying that the citations are not concealed and that the ultimate purport aligns. Yet within this chapter, *Liezi*’s original text is scant—could this mark the beginning of Guo Xiang’s edits?

The matter of fermenting wine warns against deviating to impress others. Soon after, sandals filled the doorway, yet it could not prevent people from harboring reservations. Next, the dispute between Huan and Zhai, who died in fury and transformed into intertwined catalpa trees, fleeing naturalness to meet execution—this was the Creator’s retribution for violating their heavenly nature. To know the Dao is to be silent, like the heavens in their ceaseless motion...

To know and yet speak of it is to grasp but its shallow mechanism. Thus, one who masters the art of dragon-slaying finds no use for his skill, for mere skill cannot suffice to slay dragons. Those who lick ulcers to gain carriages receive more the more they lick—without excess, there is no way to honor their servility. All this serves to warn disciples and silence the ills of the age.

As for relying on steadfast pillars to prop up a state, it is better to cease such efforts. Realizing the punishment for overreaching action, the heart must grow more cautious. The nine signs are applied, yet the unworthy still attain them. Three summonses arrive, and reverence or disdain become clear. The eight directions and three necessities are not constant. A single pearl atop nine peaks is barely grasped.

This further illustrates the manifold ways of engaging the world and responding to things, as well as the calamities invited by chasing fame and pursuing profit. If one can take what has form and trace it back to that which has never yet become a thing, then the burdens of the human realm may be avoided. Forsaking the sacrificial ox to become a lone calf depends on whether one wholeheartedly believes and strives to practice.

The chapter concludes with the death of *Zhuangzi*, showing that illusory forms are not worth clinging to, for all things must come to an end. His disciples, fearing the crows and kites would feast on him, still viewed him through worldly eyes. Only the perfected person forgets form and follows transformation, free from partiality in giving or taking. Embracing spirit and employing clarity, they reveal the unerring nature of balanced signs—this is how they depart from the human and enter the celestial, ascending to the Dao in its fullness!

*Collected Subtleties of the Meaning of the Southern Florescence True Classic*, Scroll One Hundred Two—Concluded
*Collected Subtleties of the Meaning of the Southern Florescence True Classic*, Scroll One Hundred Three

The Daoist of Wulin, Chu Boxiu, studied the foremost Way in the world. Many have governed through methods and safeguards, all believing their achievements cannot be surpassed.

Where, then, does the ancient Way of safeguarding truly lie? It is said: nowhere it is not present. How does the numinous descend? How does clarity emerge? The sage is born, the king is accomplished—all originate from the One. Not departing from the Source is called the Heavenly Person; not departing from essence is called the Spirit Person; not departing from the real is called the Perfected Person.

Taking Heaven as the Source, virtue as the root, and the Dao as the gate, foretelling transformations—this is the sage. Taking benevolence as kindness, righteousness as principle, ritual as conduct, and music as harmony, suffused with compassion—this is the noble person. Taking law as distinction, name as outward form, integrity as verification, and examination as balance—its numbers being one, two, three, four—all officials rank accordingly. Taking affairs as constant, clothing and food as primary, multiplying and storing, caring for the aged, weak, orphaned, and widowed—all have means of sustenance: such is the governance of the people.

Were the ancients not complete? They matched the divine luminaries, harmonized with Heaven and Earth, nurtured the myriad things, brought harmony to the world, bestowed blessings upon the hundred clans, and illuminated the fundamental principles, linking them to secondary measures. The six connections and four openings, the great and the small, the refined and the coarse—its movement is nowhere absent.

Where its illumination lies in numerical measures, many remnants remain in old laws and transmitted histories. Where it lies in the *Odes*, *Documents*, *Rites*, and *Music*, scholars of Zou and Lu, and girdled masters, can often elucidate them: the *Odes* to guide the will, the *Documents* to guide affairs, the *Rites* to guide conduct, the *Music* to guide harmony, the *Changes* to guide yin and yang, and the *Spring and Autumn* to guide names and distinctions.

Its principles, dispersed throughout the world and established in the Central States, are sometimes praised and expounded by the hundred schools. When the world was in great disorder, worthies and sages were obscured, the Dao and virtue were not unified, and the world often grasped one insight to esteem itself. Like the ears, eyes, nose, and mouth, each has its clarity but cannot communicate with the others—just as the hundred schools and various arts each have their strengths and occasional uses.

Yet they are not comprehensive or broad, being partial scholars. They judge the beauty of Heaven and Earth, analyze the principles of the myriad things, and examine the completeness of the ancients, but few can fully embrace the beauty of Heaven and Earth or match the countenance of the divine luminaries. Thus, the Way of inner sageliness and outer kingship became obscured and unmanifest, and the people of the world each followed their desires to create their own methods. Alas! The hundred schools departed and did not return—they must not have been in accord!

Later scholars, unfortunately, did not see the purity of Heaven and Earth or the great essence of the ancients, and the arts of the Dao were torn asunder throughout the world.

Guo’s commentary: If one acts through having, then it is true action; if it is true action, there is no falsity—what more could be added? The divine luminaries descend and emerge only after being moved by affairs. If things each return to their root and embrace the One, without adornment on the outside, this is how sages and kings are born and accomplished.

The four names—Heavenly Person, Spirit Person, Perfected Person, and sage—are one in essence, differing only in how they are expressed. The seven principles of benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music are but the coarse edges of these four names, upheld by worthies and noble persons. The numerical measures of names, laws, integrity, and examination govern the people’s principles, which sages and worthies do not oppose.

The ancients, as in the four names above, illuminated the fundamental principles, so the secondary did not depart from them. Nowhere absent, they were thus complete. Though the numerical measures that can be illuminated are many, they are already external and coarse. One can only clarify their transmission—how could they be used to welcome the Way?

The *Six Classics* are dispersed throughout the world, all being the paths of sages and worthies, yet they are not often praised. Using them for advancement without unity, the world cannot avoid disorder, so illuminating the paths of sages and worthies is no easy task. The hundred schools, with their forced interpretations, each believe in their partial views and cannot embrace the whole.

The sage unifies the great sentiments of the hundred clans and establishes systems accordingly. The hundred clans entrust their sentiments to what is unified and forget their likes and dislikes, thus attaining tranquility with their generation. In chaos, they revert to it: people indulge their immediate preferences, families use their own codes, states have different policies, and households have distinct customs. Their strengths differ and cannot be constantly employed. Not sufficient to bear full responsibility, each uses but one partial aspect, thus dissecting the principles of the myriad things, obscuring the Way of the sage-kings, and making it rare to encounter a complete person.

The great essence of the ancients was to return to the root and embrace the One—this is the purity of Heaven and Earth. As the arts of the Dao declined, each promoted their own methods: some took things as primary, causing things to depart from their nature to follow their superiors, and the true conditions of life and destiny were lost.

Lü’s commentary: The hundred schools of the world all believe their methods and arts, when applied through action, cannot be surpassed. Since their methods differ, where, then, does the ancient art of the Dao lie? It is said: nowhere it is not present, but one cannot grasp its entirety. Without grasping its entirety, how can the divine luminaries descend and emerge? When the numinous descends, it is where the sage is born; when clarity emerges, it is where the king is accomplished. The One is the master of the divine luminaries.

The so-called Heavenly Person, Spirit Person, Perfected Person, sage, and noble person share the same great essence, differing only in how they are expressed. Speaking of the Dao, one first clarifies Heaven, for Heaven is what is revered. Thus, not departing from the Source is called the Heavenly Person. Essence enters the numinous; without reality, one does not attain it. The sage fully embodies the utmost of Heaven and spirit, thus unifying the Dao and virtue to foretell transformations—this is the numinous descending to become the sage. When it is seen in benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music, suffused with compassion, it is called the noble person—this is clarity emerging to become the king.

From the sage upward, they are one with Heaven; from the sage downward, they are one with humanity. By law they are divided, yet it may not be transgressed; by name they are distinguished, yet it may not be confused; by conduct they are tested, yet it may not be deceived; by verification they are ordered, yet it may not be deluded. In all these, there is a numerical principle at work: those with greater numbers hold higher positions and wield greater influence, while those with fewer occupy lower ranks and govern lesser affairs. The ranks of the hundred officials are determined by this alone.

Above, it is where the sage is born; below, it is where the king is accomplished. None is left unprepared, and thus they can match the divine luminaries, purify Heaven and Earth, nurture the myriad things, and harmonize all under Heaven. Clarifying the fundamental numbers without doubt, linking the peripheral measures without loss—this Way is not confined by the Six Directions, and its movement is present everywhere. Such was the great essence of the arts of the Dao in antiquity.

As for that which is called the numinous, it cannot be reckoned by numbers nor measured by degrees; it cannot be transmitted through written words. What is manifest in numbers and measures is the domain of officials, who enact its laws, and of state historians, who record its traces. As for what lies in the *Odes*, *Documents*, *Rites*, and *Music*, the scholars of Zou and Lu are largely able to clarify it. Refining the *Odes* unifies the Way and perfects the will; guiding with the *Spring and Autumn* directs names and duties—all are manifestations of the ancient arts of the Dao, clear and present in numbers and measures. The former kings applied these numbers to governance, dispersing them throughout the world, and the various schools of their time spoke of the Dao, yet none strayed beyond the bounds of the ancient arts.

When all under Heaven is well-ordered, the sage’s wisdom shines, and the Dao and virtue are one. Scholars perceive its wholeness and are not obscured by strange methods or heterodox arts. But when the world falls into chaos, each grasps but a single aspect, examining it to indulge their own preferences. Though each may have its strengths, none is comprehensive or all-encompassing—they are but partial scholars.

Heaven and Earth possess great beauty, yet it is divided; the myriad things have their inherent principles, yet they are dissected. Examining them through the completeness of the ancients, the hundred schools rarely embody the beauty of Heaven and Earth or match the countenance of the divine luminaries. Thus, the Way of the sage-kings, though integral, is no longer illuminated. Each pursues what they desire, and the arts of the Dao are torn asunder across the world.

**Duyi’s Note:** The arts of the Dao are present everywhere; the arts of methods have their place. The essence of the Dao is omnipresent, and its function is never absent. Some call it the numinous, some call it clarity; some call it the sage, some call it the king. It descends or emerges, is born or accomplished—does it truly have a fixed locus? The numinous is the repository of clarity; clarity is the manifestation of the numinous. The sage is the legacy of the king; the king is the transformation of the sage. Roaming in the One, harmoniously fused and unified, without gaps—like the four seasons, each distinct yet together accomplishing the year’s work.

Whether called Heavenly Person, Spirit Person, Perfected Person, sage, or noble person, the hundred officials—though their roots and branches, essence and coarse forms differ—all do not depart from the One alone. That which emerges and has form is the root, born yet not coarse; that which is refined is essence. The true is the utmost of essence and sincerity, uniting with Heaven’s power and penetrating the Dao. These four—sage, king, and so on—are neither identical nor distinct, entering and exiting through different paths. When the sage emerges to become the noble person, the Dao and virtue disperse to become transformative righteousness; rites and music further disperse to become laws, names, conduct, and verification, equipping the hundred officials—these are but the remnants of the noble person.

The sage disperses the Dao to extend its use, hence there are laws; disperses the same to establish distinctions, hence there are divisions. The hundred officials grasp the laws but do not reach the Dao; they speak of divisions but do not attain its function. Names are the guests of reality; outward signs are the exterior of the inner. The hundred officials fulfill names but do not exhaust reality; they fulfill outward signs but do not reach the inner. What they grasp is conduct, verified in externals; what they verify is wisdom, decisively manifesting in outcomes. Their numbers—one, two, three, four—are the implements of names and laws.

Vessels have sizes, knowledge has scopes, and thus the hundred officials are ranked accordingly. Taking affairs as the norm and clothing and food as the priority, they nurture the people. Through transformation, the people multiply; through governance, they accumulate wealth. The old, weak, orphaned, and widowed are provided for; the divine luminaries and Heaven and Earth are matched. Then they nurture the myriad things, allowing them to follow their natures, and harmonize all under Heaven, so that it responds in season and its blessings flow to the hundred clans.

The fundamental numbers speak of essence; the peripheral measures speak of the coarse. Clarity linked to these—this is how the Dao is complete and present everywhere. What is subtle and lies in nature and destiny may be transmitted through the mind’s method; what cannot be transmitted may be possessed within oneself. What history cannot record, yet is clear and within numbers and measures, the *Odes* and *Documents*—these are the domain of officials and scholar-officials who can clarify them. The *Six Classics* each have their guiding principles, yet all converge in governance.

The Lao-Zhuang school’s rejection of benevolence and righteousness sought to correct excess and return to uprightness. But overcorrection leads back to error. Thus, here the *Six Classics* of the sage alone are invoked to rectify the prior overcorrection. The *Six Classics* were divided, and the hundred schools each affirmed their own truths, causing the arts of the Dao to lose their clarity. Those who spoke of the Dao in their time could not embody it in their hearts, leading to the obscuring of the sagely and worthy. The Dao and virtue, though two, were not one. Each pursued their own desires, prizing their private insights as wisdom and their private preferences as benevolence. Thus, few could embody the beauty of Heaven and Earth or match the countenance of the divine luminaries. In the Way of inner sageliness and outer kingship, they surely did not succeed.

**Bixu’s Note:** The various methods of the world each form a school, seeking utility in the age—where then is the Dao? This speaks of the pure and refined having departed, leaving only the dregs. Yet the numinous descends and clarity emerges through the possession of the Dao; the sage is born and the king is accomplished—not by two separate paths. Taking the profound and obscure as their foundation, they are the Heavenly Person.

The pure and unadulterated is the spirit-person; the guardian of the true without falsity is the perfected-person. As for those who take the principle of spontaneity as their foundation, base themselves on the merit of non-virtue, traverse the path of emptiness and penetration, and evade the subtleties of the numinous—these are the sage-rulers of the age, who encompass the three ranks above. Next are the noblemen and the hundred officials who govern the world with benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music, their demeanor warmly kind and harmonious, their grace extending to the myriad things. They establish laws to define duties, confer titles to manifest character and conduct, observe conduct to verify talent and ability, and examine seniority to order promotions and demotions—all governed by arts and methods.

When the Dao is insufficient, laws are employed; when laws are insufficient, arts are employed; when arts are insufficient, discretion is employed; when discretion is insufficient, power is employed. When power is insufficient, one returns to discretion; discretion returns to arts, arts return to laws, and laws return to the Dao—where the Dao is, there is non-action and self-transformation. Arts are the sovereign’s secret instruments, not to be rashly glimpsed by subordinates; power is the sharp tool for controlling things, not to be rashly wielded by subordinates. If the sovereign possesses arts yet ministers glimpse them, they are not the profoundest arts; if the sovereign possesses power yet ministers act wrongly, it is not the weightiest power. The key lies first in rectifying names and duties, ensuring no encroachment or usurpation—only then can arts be applied and power monopolized.

The hundred officials rank themselves by office, yet this does not exceed the sequence of one, two, three, four. The categories of laws, names, conduct, and examinations are used to teach and nurture the myriad people, ensuring none lose their livelihood. In the age of great antiquity, there were no laws yet all was complete—not because laws were set up to complete it. When one matches the divine luminaries, ghosts emit no numinous echoes; when one harmonizes with Heaven and Earth, the four seasons remain constant; when one nurtures the myriad things, the harvests are ever abundant; when one harmonizes the world, people suffer no premature misfortune. Thus, benevolence extends to grasses and trees, and trust reaches even pigs and fish—all stems from illuminating the root principles and binding the branch measures.

The ruler practices non-action and is revered—this is the root principle, the Way of Heaven, the division of duties. The minister acts and is burdened—this is the branch measure, the Way of Earth, the source of scrutiny. The distinction between root and branch lies solely in careful discernment. This Dao is unimpeded, penetrating the six directions and opening the four quarters. From the tiniest hairs of Heaven and Earth to the spirits, forms, and vessels, in all their shifts and transformations, nothing enters into the realm of the unquestioned.

As for the principles found in yin-yang, pitch standards, the *Odes*, *Documents*, *Rites*, and *Music*, their methods spread throughout the world, and the hundred schools of learning occasionally invoke them. Yet when their simplicity scatters and the age’s Way collapses, each clings to their own preferences, unable to mutually employ one another. Thus, the Way of sage-kings dims, and people each pursue what they praise, drifting ever farther from the Dao. The fragmentation of the Dao and its arts is the misfortune of scholars.

**Luan Qi’s Note:** In the final chapter, Zhuangzi discusses the learning of past and present, much like the final chapter of the *Mencius*, which speaks of "hearing knowledge" and "seeing knowledge." From the beginning of the chapter to "the Dao and its arts will be torn asunder," this serves as the overarching preface. It then follows the various schools of thought, including his own work among them. The learning of Zou and Lu was misled by this general preface, revealing that even this elder, though his writings often contain contentious words, never failed to recognize the learning of the Confucian school as orthodox. People all regard their own learning as unsurpassable, each claiming their own rightness.

The ancient arts of the Dao share the same characters as "arts of transformation" and "arts of the mind." Where do they reside? Nowhere they are not present—this conveys the idea of being within the times. Though learning may differ, the Dao is present in all. How do the numinous descend and clarity emerge? The birth of sages and the accomplishment of kings—this is the principle of Heaven and Earth’s generation and completion, all originating from the One. The One refers to creation. "Foundation," "essence," and "truth" all align with the character "One," though the phrasing varies. From "taking Heaven as the foundation" to "taking the Dao as the gate," all express the meaning of non-action and spontaneity. Traced to their transformations, they originate from the One.

"Warmly kind and benevolent" describes their demeanor. Laws have distinctions; names have standards; their verifications and sequences each have their basis. "One, two, three, four" speaks to their meticulous clarity and completeness. Taking clothing and food as primary, teaching the people to focus on farming and sericulture, caring for the elderly, weak, orphaned, and widowed—these are the roots of enacting governance and extending benevolence. The four phrases beginning with "matching the divine luminaries" describe the vastness of its efficacy. Root and branch refer to essence and coarse detail. "Penetrating the six directions and opening the four quarters" means there is no application where it does not suffice.

The sequence of the *Six Classics* clearly refers to Confucius. When scattered into the hundred schools and myriad arts, the world grasps but one aspect and clings to it, boasting of their own discernment—like eyes and ears unable to communicate, leaving them incomplete before Heaven, Earth, and the divine luminaries. Inner sageliness is the substance; outer kingship is the function. When the Way of inner and outer is unclear, people each pursue their desires, creating their own arts, lost and unable to return. The phrase "the Dao and its arts will be torn asunder" concludes with great force.

This chapter begins by discussing the scholars of the time, each devoted to their own abilities, regarding their applications as unsurpassable, unaware of the wondrous principle of non-action and spontaneity—thus drifting far from the Dao. Where, then, do the ancient arts of the Dao truly reside? They are present everywhere. Later people, creating their own methods, interpose barriers, leading to differences between states and divergence among schools, flowing into the arts of the various schools.

The arts of the Dao serve to match the divine luminaries and enact governance, enrich customs and connect with the conditions of things, guiding the people without their awareness, leading to self-transformation. The sage-rulers of high antiquity, with hands folded and non-action, oversaw the flourishing of the people—this was the descent of the numinous and the emergence of clarity, responding to affairs as they arose, acting without acting. The birth of sages and the accomplishment of kings are the effects of the numinous in its transformations. From "not departing from the foundation" to "being called a sage" is how one completes Heaven—this is the work of the sage, wherein the divine resides.

From "taking benevolence as grace" to "being called a gentleman" is how one completes humanity—this is the work of the king, wherein the Way is manifested in governance. Thus, it is spoken of in terms of inner and outer.

Next are laws, names, numbers, and measures, as well as the *Odes*, *Documents*, *Rites*, and *Music*—all instruments of the former kings’ governance, which require the right people to implement them. The Way, when matched with the divine luminaries, can purify Heaven and Earth; virtue, when nurturing the myriad things, can harmonize the world.

The root-number is what is called the One. All beyond the One are but branches. The sage’s arising takes the One as its root; the king’s accomplishment relies on the Two to achieve completion. Root and branch depend on each other, and the Way of governance is thus complete.

The governance of the ancient sage-kings was meticulous, their concern for the people profound. They sought not merely to order their own time but to establish models for ten thousand generations. From the cultivation of the Way’s intent to the clarification of names and duties—all are the traces of the sage’s attainment of governance.

When applied to the world, their effects vary in depth, and their manifestations in affairs and governance differ in order and disorder. This arises from the obscurity of the sagely and worthy’s guidance, the divergence in the return to the Way and virtue. Scholars merely prize the withered straw dogs of the past, and governance fails to reach its potential, giving rise to portents and anomalies. Each grasps but a single aspect and mistakes it for the whole, no different from mistaking a hoofprint’s puddle for the Eastern Sea.

The great beauty of Heaven and Earth cannot be fully realized without the Way; the forms and appearances of the divine luminaries cannot be fittingly expressed without virtue. How could those who devise their own methods ever attain this?

The closing lines are impassioned in meaning, revealing that the *Nanhua*’s intent aligns with that of the Master—how timely its admonition! "Action must not be forced," and in the phrase below, *wei* (為) should alternate with *zi* (字). "Desire" here likely means "desire to act," as the context makes clear.

*Collected Subtleties of the Ocean of Meanings of the True Scripture of Nanhua*, Scroll One Hundred Three—End
*Collected Subtleties of the Ocean of Meanings of the True Scripture of Nanhua*, Scroll One Hundred Four

The Daoist of Wulin, Chu Boxiu, ranked second under heaven, neither vaunting himself before posterity nor indulging in the myriad things, nor dazzling through numerical measures, yet hewed to the marking-line to rectify himself and met the world’s urgent needs. Among the ancient arts of the Dao were those who held to such principles—Mo Di and Qin Guli, who heard of their ethos and rejoiced in it. Yet they carried it to excess, while Mozi himself adhered to its grand cycle.

They composed *Against Music*, calling it *Frugality*, forbidding song in life and mourning in death. Mozi’s universal love and mutual benefit led to strife, yet his Dao did not incite anger. He was fond of learning and broad in knowledge, neither differing from others nor aligning with the former kings. The Yellow Emperor had *Xianchi*, Yao had *Dazhang*, Shun had *Dashao*, Yu had *Daxia*, Tang had *Dahu*, King Wen had the music of the *Biyong*, and King Wu and the Duke of Zhou composed *Wu*. In ancient mourning rites, the noble and base had their proper forms, the high and low their distinctions: the Son of Heaven had seven layers of inner and outer coffins, the feudal lords five, great officers three, and scholars two. Yet Mozi alone forbade song in life and mourning in death, using only a paulownia coffin three inches thick without an outer casket, setting this as the model. Teaching others thus, he surely did not love them; practicing it himself, he surely did not love himself. This ultimately undermined Mozi’s Dao.

Though he sang yet not as song, wept yet not as weeping, rejoiced yet not as joy—was this truly fitting? His life was toilsome, his death meager, his Dao extreme. He made others anxious, made them sorrowful; his conduct was difficult to follow. I fear this cannot be the Dao of the sage, for it runs counter to the hearts of all under heaven. The world cannot bear it, and though Mozi alone could endure it, what could he do for the world? Estranged from all under heaven, he was far removed from the kingly way.

Mozi spoke of the Dao, saying: "In ancient times, Yu stemmed the floodwaters, dredged the rivers and streams to connect the four barbarians and the nine provinces. There were three hundred great rivers, three thousand tributaries, and countless smaller ones. Yu personally wielded the plowshare, gathering the nine kinds of earth to dam the waters. His shins were bare of flesh, his calves devoid of hair; he bathed in torrential rains, combed his hair in fierce winds, and established the myriad measures. Yu was a great sage, yet he toiled his body for the world to such an extent."

Thus, later Mohists wore coarse garments of felt and hemp, bound their feet in sandals, and labored day and night without rest, taking self-affliction as the ultimate principle. They said: "If one cannot do this, it is not the Dao of Yu, and one is unworthy to be a Mohist." The disciples of Xiangli Qin, the followers of Wu Hou, and the southern Mohists such as Ku Huo, Ji Chi, and Deng Lingzi’s group all recited the *Mo Jing*, yet their interpretations diverged and twisted, calling one another "heterodox Mohists." They debated the paradoxes of *jian bai* and *tong yi*, reviled one another with sophistry, and responded with forced analogies and unnatural arguments.

The Mohists revered their *juzi* as sages, all wishing to serve as their embodiment, hoping to become their successors—this practice has endured without end. Mo Di and Qin Guli’s intentions were sound, yet their conduct was misguided. They sought to compel later Mohists to advance by emulating Yu’s self-mortification—bare calves and hairless sinews. This is the height of disorder and the nadir of governance.

Nevertheless, Mozi was truly one who loved the world’s welfare, so much so that even if he withered away, he would not abandon his pursuit. What a man of talent he was!

**Guo’s Annotation:** Diligence and frugality lead to exhaustion, hence no radiance. Yet with resources in surplus, one is prepared for emergencies. Overzealous adherence to extremes, however, exceeds what the masses can bear. Scarcity breeds strife; when the people are made to toil frugally yet remain in surplus, conflict is deemed wrong. Not through anger, but through self-denial. Believing themselves right, they seek to make all things conform to their own way. The former kings indulged the diversity of their people, then harmonized them all, unaware of how they achieved this. They abolished ancient rites and music, deeming them extravagant and wasteful. All things should be loved by exerting effort and following nature’s inclinations; now, by taking frugality as the law and overdoing it, they claim to enrich the world—yet this is no true love. Mozi alone perfected his Dao while rejecting the Dao of virtue. Disregarding the natural dispositions of the myriad things, his Way was barren and devoid of nourishment, imposing sorrow and hardship, making it unfit for the sagely path. The sagely Way allows each person to find joy in their nature, and thus the world encounters no difficulty. Therefore, a true king must align with the world’s joy and progress alongside all things. Mozi merely saw Yu’s physical toil and failed to perceive the harmony of his nature, taking self-affliction as the ultimate principle. Clinging to his Dao out of season, this is what it means to be a Mohist. Yet even among the Mohists, factions arose. The *juzi* excelled in distinguishing right from wrong to perfect their conduct. All wished to become their leader, to uphold their teachings, intending to avoid extravagance and prepare for the world’s emergencies—this was their justification. But in overdoing it, they erred.

No disorder is greater than opposing the nature of things and harming their essence, hence this is the lowest form of governance. Their genuine admiration for sages and worthies was not misplaced, yet it cannot be taught to others. To seek such men in vain, to find no equal in the world, to persist in emaciation without surrender—this is what makes them truly devoted men of talent, not men of virtue.

**Lü’s Annotation:** The governance of the former kings reached its perfection in the grandeur of culture and institutions, yet they did not indulge in extravagance for posterity, nor wastefulness toward the myriad things, nor radiance in excessive regulations—this was not their constant way.
