Using the carpenter’s line to correct themselves, they prepared for the world’s emergencies; this was one aspect of the ancient arts of the Dao. The Dao embodies constancy while embracing all change, but Mozi saw only the need to prepare for emergencies and took it as the norm. This is what is meant by grasping one aspect and scrutinizing it to one’s own satisfaction—it cannot be shared with others. From his *Against Music* to his *Universal Love Without Distinction*, all were taken to extremes, reflecting his own excessive adherence. The former sages established moderation in rites and music, and proper forms for mourning and burial. Yet Mozi forbade singing in life and mourning in death, rejecting the former kings and abolishing ancient rites and music. His frugality and austerity were thus extreme—not only did he fail to love others, but he also failed to love himself.

Mozi’s original intent was universal love and mutual benefit, yet he did not consider whether people could endure the bitterness of his austerity. Few lost their way, so his Dao did not collapse. Joy and sorrow are inescapable for humanity; the former sages gave them form and measure. Mozi, however, forbade singing yet condemned singing, forbade weeping yet condemned weeping—was this truly in accord with human nature? To toil in life and be sparing in death imposes sorrow and grief. Though some aspects of the ancient arts of the Dao lay in this, Mozi took it too far—it cannot be called the sagely Way. Even if he could endure it, what of the world’s inability to bear it? He strayed far from the kingly Way.

In the past, Yu faced the great flood and labored to such an extent—this was a response to the world’s emergency. Mozi took it as the norm, which was wrong. The intent to toil and prepare for the world’s needs was commendable, but in overdoing it, he made his conduct unbearable for the world. This is not how to compel later scholars to advance through self-affliction. Frugality and diligence are indeed difficult to practice, yet Mozi excelled at them—truly a man who loved the world’s welfare, one who cannot be found even when sought. What a man of talent he was!

**Yi Du’s Annotation:** After the great Dao was lost, the various masters emerged in succession—men like Mo Di and Guli, Song Keng and Yin Wen—culminating in the likes of Hui Shi, who debated in thousands of words. Zhuangzi refuted and dismissed them, leaving them hollow. The Mohist teachings emphasized hardship, frugality, and austerity, condemning ease, pleasure, extravagance, and waste. Thus, they rejected radiant regulations and used the carpenter’s line to correct themselves, sufficiently preparing for the world’s emergencies while ensuring surplus resources. Mo Di’s followers, hearing of this, were delighted. Yet in fully embracing it, they went too far; in fully adhering to it, they were too rigid.

Forbidding singing in life, he wrote *Against Music*; taking frugality as the Way, he allowed no mourning in death. His Dao sought to ensure sufficiency for all and eliminate strife, so through self-denial, he did not grow angry. Fond of learning and seeking to make all things conform to himself, he thus rejected distinctions. To toil in life and be sparing in death, to abolish ancient rites and music, to reject the ways of the former kings—from the Yellow Emperor’s *Xianchi* to the Duke of Zhou’s *Wu*, he condemned their singing in life. From the ancient mourning rites to the double-layered garments of scholars, he condemned their mourning in death. Though his Dao had not yet collapsed, it was bound to fail. To forbid singing yet condemn singing, to forbid weeping yet condemn weeping—was this truly in accord with human nature? Who alone perfected Mohism while opposing the natural dispositions of the myriad things? His Way was vast and desolate, making it difficult for people to follow. He strayed far from the former kings.

The former kings shared the people’s breath, grounding their Way in human nature, not aiming for difficulty but desiring the world to be as they were.

Once, Yu tamed the floodwaters, dredging the Yangtze and the Yellow River. He wielded the plow and spade himself, enduring wind and rain, his body toiling for the world in such a manner. Later generations emulated him, taking self-affliction as the ultimate virtue. Yet Yu’s Way was not Mohism—only the corruption of its transmission gave rise to what we call Mohism.

Xiangli Qin, Denglingzi, and their followers all recited the *Mo Jing* yet diverged in their interpretations, splitting the same school into different factions. They debated to disparage one another, responded with sophistry, and regarded the most eloquent as sages, eager to become their successors in hopes of transmitting the teachings. Mozi’s frugality, preparedness, and restraint were sound, but his excess in self-affliction was not. In discourse on chaos, he stood above; in discourse on order, he fell below. Truly, he sought what the world desired, yet no likeness could be found. Mozi’s talent approached Yu’s, but his Way strayed far from Yu’s, and thus could not avoid corruption, reducing it to mere Mohism.

*Bixu’s Commentary*: The Mohist teaching rejects extravagance and ostentation, emphasizing diligence, frugality, and self-discipline to address the world’s crises. Yet its parsimony was excessive—what he could endure, the multitude could not follow. Rejecting music, restricting expenditures, mourning lightly in life and meagerly in death—this was truly contrary to human nature! Nevertheless, its universal love approached benevolence, its mutual benefit approached righteousness, its non-aggression approached wisdom, and its non-anger approached knowledge. Moreover, its love of learning and advocacy for unity set it apart from common customs. Where it diverged from the former kings, its condemnation of ancient rites and music was most severe.

From the *Xianchi* to the *Wu*, from layered coffins to elaborate mourning garments—these were the rites and music of antiquity. Mozi, however, forbade singing in life—how much more so silk and bamboo music? He forbade mourning in death—how much more so pearls and jade! To practice this oneself was unnatural; to teach it to others was too harsh, inevitably leading to the corruption of perverse and unprincipled deviations. Human singing, weeping, laughter, and joy arise from innate emotions—yet he rejected and abolished them all, making it unlike the world’s nature. Barren and desolate, it brought sorrow and grief, which the multitude could not bear, though Mozi alone could endure it. Since it did not accord with the world’s nature, it strayed far from the kingly Way.

Mozi revered Yu’s diligence and frugality, praising his achievement in flood control. "Nine times he dredged the world’s rivers," meaning he cleared the rivers of the Nine Provinces without obstruction. "His calves bore no flesh, his shins no hair"—all recorded in the *Book of Documents*—yet he did not reach the subtlety of the original Way. Later generations emulated him, taking self-affliction as the ultimate virtue, even to the point of cutting their flesh or severing their limbs to seek blessings. This was another corruption of Mohist learning. Xiangli Qin and his followers were those who led Mohism to ruin. They regarded the most eloquent and erudite as teachers, eventually falling into the corruption of empty debate and competitive argument. While their diligence, frugality, and preparedness were commendable, teaching others through suffering was not—how could order be expected when later generations emulated its chaos?

Yet their love of learning was earnest, unmatched in the world. Their determination in study and resolve in teaching rivaled Confucius—truly the finest of scholars! Only their conduct strayed from the true path of virtue and power.

*Juanzhai’s Note*: They did not teach later generations extravagance, hence their lack of adornment. They did not measure all things by rites, music, or standards, restraining themselves to correct the world, desiring that the world’s resources be sufficient. They argued that people’s struggles arose from insufficient clothing and food. Later Mohists, however, suppressed too severely. *Fei Le* ("Against Music") and *Jie Yong* ("Moderation in Use") are chapters in the *Mozi*. They condemned warfare as wrong and rejected anger as a Way. "Broadening without divergence" meant expanding their doctrine to advocate unity. Teaching people to love themselves yet failing in both respects—this was not in accord with human nature, hence "unlike."

Great simplicity—its practice was difficult. It went against the world’s heart, yet Mozi alone found peace in it. Since it did not align with human hearts, it could not bring kingly rule to the world. Mozi extolled the Way to the point of toiling the body for the world, thus emulating Yu’s achievements. "Nine" is read as *sijiu*, meaning "gathering laborers to work together." To call odd and even the same was forced sophistry. The *Juzi* were the great masters of Mohist learning. "Sought but not found" means no such person remained. Though they pushed themselves to the point of emaciation, they did not cease—truly heroic scholars!

They did not indulge in extravagance among the myriad things, nor did they seek brilliance in rites and ceremonies. Diligent, frugal, and disciplined, they prepared for the world’s crises—this was Yu’s conduct as seen in the world. Mo Di and Hua Li, hearing of it, were delighted, yet they carried it too far, making it arduous and difficult to practice, too rigid in discipline, leaving them barren and unnatural. They composed *Fei Le* and *Jie Yong* to teach the world: no singing in life, no mourning in death—these were the manifestations of their rejection of music and restriction of use. Universal love aimed at mutual benefit; non-aggression aimed at non-anger—these were not without virtue. Their love of learning and pursuit of breadth, their desire for unity, still betrayed a competitive

To apply the response to constancy is like binding and cauterizing oneself when ill—it only deepens the wound’s pain; what could be more foolish? The followers of Xiangli Qin, claiming to be a distinct branch of Mohism, vied to criticize and outdo one another, elevating those who perfected their craft as sages. The *Juzi*—akin to the Confucians’ "great scholars"—all aspired to succeed them, and this succession continues to this day. This reflects a division within Mohism: while Mo Di and Qin Guli carried forward the earlier tradition, their intent in teaching self-denial was misguided. They sowed chaos rather than order, and where they brought governance, it was but a lesser defense.

Yet Mozi’s true nature was unmatched in his love for the world, and though his teachings took root in his time, they were not the Dao of the sages. Still, he may be called a man of talent. Mencius, in refuting Yang Zhu and Mo Di as deviating from the sages’ Dao, used stern words and vehement opposition, as if they were mortal enemies—this reveals the urgency of defending the true Way. *Nanhua* (Zhuangzi) meticulously examined the deeds of the Mohists and their origins, exposing their flaws while acknowledging their strengths. This may be called impartial judgment tempered with forbearance. Though he did not explicitly address Yangism, his intent was clear.

Mohism traced its roots to Yu the Great, Yangism to Lao Dan—both emerged from the sages’ school, yet their learning was partial. Like Zengzi and Zisi, who studied under Confucius but erred by excess or deficiency, these were but offshoots of Yang and Mo. Thus, one must be prudent in learning. Unburdened by convention, unadorned by things, uncompromising with others, unyielding to the crowd, they wished for the world’s peace to preserve lives. In nurturing oneself and others, they sought only sufficiency and no more, thereby purifying the heart.

Among the ancient arts of the Dao, there were those who embodied this. Song Jian and Yin Wen, inspired by their example, crafted the *Huashan* cap as a symbol of their way. In engaging with the myriad things, they began by dispelling prejudices. They spoke of the heart’s capacity, calling it "the heart’s conduct." Through harmony, they sought concord; through regulation, they aimed to pacify the world, proposing to establish this as the guiding principle. To endure insult without shame, to rescue states from peril, to ban aggression and halt warfare—these were their means of saving the world from strife.

With this, they traversed the world, persuading rulers above and instructing the people below. Though the world did not embrace their teachings, they persisted relentlessly, hence the saying: "They were met with disdain yet forced their presence." Nevertheless, their concern for others was excessive, while their care for themselves was scant. They declared: "Five measures of rice are enough." The master feared hunger, yet the disciples, though starving, never forgot the world, laboring day and night without rest. They proclaimed: "We must survive!"—how could they not be hailed as saviors of the age? They said: "The noble person does not indulge in petty scrutiny nor lend themselves to things. What brings no benefit to the world is better left undone than forced."

Externally, they sought to ban aggression and halt warfare; internally, they advocated minimal desires. Their teachings, whether grand or subtle, refined or coarse, extended only this far. Guo Xiang’s commentary: *Zhi* means opposition. "Sufficiency and no more" meant no desire for excess. *Huashan*, level above and below, symbolized their conduct. To "dispel prejudices" was to prevent mutual transgressions. They strove to harmonize and reconcile through their Dao. The two masters proposed that such principles be established as the world’s foundation.

"To endure insult without shame" was their urgent means of preserving lives. "Rescuing from conflict and halting warfare" was their method of harmony. Though the world rejected them, they persisted relentlessly—this was the principle of harmony. "Met with disdain yet forcing their presence" was their way of enduring without shame. If they did not allow natural transformation but forced consolation, their efforts would be too burdensome. "Five measures of rice" made clear their minimal self-regard.

Song Jian and Yin Wen addressed the world as "masters" and called themselves "disciples." They labored day and night for the people, expecting reciprocity. "How could they not be hailed?"—this describes their lofty and expansive demeanor. "Not indulging in petty scrutiny" meant practicing forbearance. "Not lending themselves to things" meant exerting their own strength. What brought no benefit to the world was abandoned—this defined their role as saviors. Their conduct extended only this far, unable to traverse the vast and empty.

Lü Huiqing’s commentary: Unburdened by convention, unadorned by things, extending sincerity to others, enduring disgrace without contention, wishing for the world’s peace and sufficiency without seeking excess—if their hearts harbored discord, they cleansed it as impurity, thus purifying the heart. The world’s conflicts arise from mutual encroachment and harshness; to dispel prejudices is to end strife and desire peace. The heart of the Dao embraces all, leaving no room for contention.

The two masters spoke of its capacity and conducted themselves with humility to foster harmony, aiming to pacify the world—this was "the heart’s conduct." They wished to establish it as the foundation, revering and upholding it. From "enduring insult without shame" to "persisting relentlessly," this was their way of harmony. Though the ancient arts of the Dao included such teachings, their excessive concern for others and minimal care for themselves led Song and Yin to diverge. They declared: "We labor day and night to save the world, yet if people do not revere us as saviors and ignore us, how can we survive? We need not fear starvation." Their conduct extended only this far; beyond this, they knew nothing—meaning they had not grasped the Dao.

Yi Du’s commentary: To be free from worldly burdens, unadorned by things, at ease with others without harshness, yielding to the crowd without arrogance, wishing for the world’s peace and sufficiency—Song and Yin’s Dao differed slightly from Mo Di’s, hence they followed after him. Their legacy endured, and later generations, inspired by their example, crafted the *Huashan* cap as a symbol of their way.

To engage with the myriad things, one begins by distinguishing between the vast and the small, setting boundaries for each. Yet the Dao of the sage treats self and others as one body, making no such distinctions—vast and small share the same realm, with no need for confinement. What they accommodate is for progress; what they practice is not of their own heart. The two masters spoke of the heart’s capacity and called its actions the heart’s conduct. Their aspiration was the world’s peace, so they sought harmony through unity, regulating all within the seas. They proposed establishing a ruler, and all wished to serve as his proxy, their intentions aligned.

To endure insult without shame, to persist in clamor without ceasing—these were their own excesses. They flattered their lords above and instructed the people below, revealing an overabundance of concern for others. To endure insult without shame, yet be content with a mere five *sheng* of rice—this showed too little care for themselves. They schemed for pride, expanded their reach, and took saving the world as their task. Yet to excel in seven things without adaptability is insufficient to establish true principle. The two masters exceeded in transformation but fell short in principle. The noble person does not engage in harsh scrutiny; their words and efforts arise from their own strength.

If an act brings no benefit to the world, examining it is no better than abandoning it—yet they still sought to save the world. Externally, they advocated for the cessation of war; internally, they sought to diminish desires. Though their methods varied in refinement and scale, their conduct extended only this far. Bi Xu’s commentary: Without attachment, one is unburdened; in simplicity, one is unadorned; in directness, one is uncompromising; in yielding, one does not rely on force. Wishing the world peace and sufficiency without excess—clarifying this heart is all there is to it. The *Huashan* cap symbolizes the heart’s steadfast uprightness, governing with the evenness of a summit, distinguishing the worthy from the foolish, and taking leniency and law as the foundation of governance—yet their words and deeds never faltered.

When laws are lenient and harmonious, they align with the people’s hearts; the world praises them and joyfully elevates such a one as ruler. Enduring humiliation to halt strife, they made the people cease contention. Cessation of war, upholding kindness, the people embraced tranquility—with this, they persuaded the world, ensuring the people would follow and desire peace and life. This was their overabundance of concern for others. Austere and frugal, they endured hardship, offering but five *sheng* of rice daily, yet still deferring to their teachers, preferring their own hunger over forgetting the world—this was their too little care for themselves.

*"Must I surely live?"*—they said, *"I strive to save others, so Heaven must preserve me."* *"Scheming for pride?"*—they did not scheme for pride, nor did they seek the empty fame of saving the world for vainglory. Not engaging in harsh scrutiny, they focused on self-mastery. Without lending themselves to things, they led by force of action. They refrained from all that brought no benefit to the world, externally harmonizing and regulating human affairs without contention, internally restraining desires to temper their nature. Though matters differed in refinement, they merely removed what was unreasonable and acted accordingly—this was the ultimate principle of governance.

Juan Zhai’s notes: *"Adornment"* refers to self-indulgence; *"resentment"* is human nature. *"Distinguishing confinement"* means being at ease within one’s lot—*"distinction"* is following one’s portion, *"confinement"* is resting in contentment. *"Capacity"* refers to essence; *"conduct"* refers to function. They sought to unite people’s joy through harmony, to regulate all within the seas, proposing to establish a ruler. Persisting in clamor without ceasing, they wearied others with their ceaseless boasting. Daily, they had but five *sheng* of rice, shared among teacher and disciples—even the master went hungry, let alone the disciples! Enduring hunger and hardship, laboring day and night without rest—how could this be a path to long life? Yet they did so to correct those who feigned saving the world for personal gain.

*"Scheming for pride"*—they sought to rectify this, like Yu Rang, who said: *"I undertake this utmost difficulty to shame all those ministers who harbor disloyalty."* Their teaching also said: Do not engage in harsh scrutiny, abandon the distinction between self and others, act for oneself without relying on others’ strength. Knowing that assisting the world in futile matters is better left undone, they still acted where they saw fit. The essence of their teaching was to eliminate external strife from war and internal turmoil from desires—this was their limit.

Unburdened and unadorned, the heart is empty and preserves simplicity. Uncompromising and free from resentment, one cultivates sincerity and harmony. Transforming customs and engaging with things, they universally wished for safety. Without excessive personal enjoyment, they did not seek recklessly, for amassing too much invites harm—this is the way to lasting peace. Establishing this teaching in the world, clarifying the original heart without concealment, Song and Yin heard of it and rejoiced, following their Dao. The *Huashan* cap symbolized the uprightness and evenness of their conduct.

In engaging with things, they distinguished the good from the foolish, taking leniency toward the ignorant as their foundation—thus they never inclined toward evil, sufficiently enriching customs and advancing education. Yet their methods had flaws, falling short of the sage’s perfect and enduring governance. *"The heart’s capacity"* is like the bearing of hands or feet, referring to its demeanor in movement and stillness. *"The heart’s conduct"* refers to its arrangements and undertakings, manifesting the heart’s inherent goodness in action. Harmonizing all within the seas, without strife or anger, seeking universal peace and sufficiency—these words held kindness but lacked the intent of true governance.

Their wish to establish a ruler expressed the desire to follow his teachings. Enduring humiliation to halt strife, ceasing war, and stopping conflict—all embodied the principle of yielding and non-contention. Insistent and forceful, they demanded others heed their words. Offering but five *sheng* of rice, they showed too little care for themselves. Preferring their own hunger over forgetting the world, they showed too much concern for others. Laboring day and night to exhaustion, they sighed: *"I must surely live!"*—*"I toil to save others, so the Creator must preserve me."*

The ascetic mendicants of today, frugal with themselves yet meticulous in aiding others, somewhat resemble them—but lacking learning and insight, they fall far short. The phrase *"Scheming for pride?"* is difficult to interpret; among various explanations, Guo Xiang’s commentary comes closest. This is Zhuangzi’s sigh of lament.

Seeking arrogance is akin to plotting carelessness—speaking broadly and recklessly without regard for practical matters. These two sought to save the multitudes of the world through their own solitary strength, yet did not weigh the difficulty of such an endeavor. Not pursuing harsh scrutiny is called "excellent forbearance"; not borrowing external things to glorify oneself, and abandoning what brings no benefit to the world—this is called "excellent discernment."

In outward conduct, they forbade attack and ceased war, causing people to be self-sufficient and free from strife. In inward practice, they diminished shallow desires, disciplined themselves without reproach, and knew no respite. Though the principles of their affairs differed in scale and refinement, in essence, their conduct reached its utmost limit. Yet they could not ascend to the inner sanctum of the sages, and thus remained confined to Mohist teachings alone.

This passage critiques the flaws of the Mohists of that era, wherein the words hold primary and secondary meanings—these must be examined with care.

*The Meaning of the Southern Florescence Canon: Gathered Essence of the Ocean of Significance, Scroll One Hundred Four (concluded)*
*The Meaning of the Southern Florescence Canon: Gathered Essence of the Ocean of Significance, Scroll One Hundred Five*
*By the Daoist of Wulin, Chu Boxiu*
*Chapter Three: The World*

Those who act with impartiality yet form no factions, who are yielding yet free from self-interest, who decide without fixed allegiance, who follow things without duality, who neither dwell on deliberation nor rely on cunning, who make no distinctions among things and proceed with them as one—such was the Daoist art of antiquity. Peng Meng, Tian Pian, and Shen Dao heard its influence and delighted in it. They took the equalization of the myriad things as their foremost principle, saying: "Heaven can cover them but cannot bear them; Earth can bear them but cannot cover them; the Great Dao can embrace them but cannot discriminate among them. Knowing that the myriad things each have what they can and cannot do, they declared: 'Selection cannot be all-encompassing; instruction cannot reach all; only the Dao leaves nothing behind.'"

Thus, Shen Dao discarded knowledge and abandoned the self, drifting with inevitability. He let things flow and settle, taking this as the principle of the Dao. He said: "To know that one does not know is to approach the brink of harm after slight knowledge." Unburdened and unconstrained, he mocked the world’s esteem for worthies; unbound and untrammeled, he rejected the world’s great sages. Like a hammer striking or an axe severing, he turned with things as they shifted. Casting aside right and wrong, he sought only to avoid entanglement. He did not model himself on wisdom or foresight, nor did he distinguish before or after, standing aloof and self-contained. Pushed, he then moved; pulled, he then went—like a whirling gale, like a spinning feather, like a grinding stone in its groove. Whole yet without fault, in motion or still without error, he was never at fault. For what reason was this so?

The unknowing thing harbors no peril of self-assertion, no burden of knowing; its movement and stillness never depart from principle, and thus it lives out its days without praise. Hence it is said: "To be as the unknowing thing—this alone suffices; there is no need for worthies or sages." A clod of earth never loses the Way.

The heroic and eminent mocked him, saying: "The Way of Shendao is no path for the living, but only the principle of the dead—how strange it is!" Tian Pian was likewise. He studied under Peng Meng and received "no-teaching." Peng Meng’s master said: "The Daoists of old reached the point where none could affirm or deny them." Their influence was like the rush of wind—how could it be put into words? Yet they constantly opposed others and drew no crowds, and so could not escape being crushed like turtleshell.

What they called the Way was not the Way, and what they affirmed could not avoid being wrong. Peng Meng, Tian Pian, and Shendao did not know the Way. Nevertheless, they had once glimpsed something of it.

Guo’s commentary: Without fixed direction, each follows its own course—yet things attain their proper ends, and so become one. Only when all functions are employed does completeness arise; only when nature is entrusted does it reach fulfillment. *Lingtài* means "to listen and let go." It refers to the shallowness of knowing, which fails to entrust things to their spontaneity—thus slight knowledge is scorned, and harm draws near. To take on what one is not suited for is to take on the tasks of the multitude; if the multitude each does what it can, then there is no need to esteem worthies. To reject the world’s great sages is to destroy their traces so that things do not follow them.

Though the Legalists’ methods are subtle, they still rely on hammering and striking, and so cannot merge completely. Unable to discern right and wrong or distinguish before and after, they indulge their nature merely to avoid immediate harm. *Weiran* means "standing alone." To move or go only when pushed or pulled is what is meant by "following necessity." Rest arises from reputation, and reputation arises from self-assertion. Only the sage can cast aside knowledge and habit, following the principle of Heaven. Thus the foolish and the wise each occupy their proper place; the noble and the base each hold their rightful position; the worthy and the unworthy each follow their nature. To say there is no use for worthies or sages is why they are said not to know the Way. They wished to make people like clods of earth. Yet even ordinary things, in all their variety, cannot attain the Way—for the Way is not partial to any one thing.

Only by relinquishing knowledge and entrusting nature does the spirit become luminously clear—this is what makes one a worthy or a sage. Yet to say a clod never loses the Way is to liken a person to dirt—how could this not be death? This is why the heroic mocked them. Not yet having merged with the ultimate Way, they appeared strange and uncanny.

"Received no-teaching" refers to the Way of self-entrustment, where none can affirm or deny—what is called "equalizing the myriad things." *Wòrán* is the sound of wind blowing against something. Not conforming to popular expectations, though they established laws, they were crushed without leaving a trace. The Way is present everywhere, yet to say only a clod of earth never loses it is why they are said not to know. Nevertheless, they had once glimpsed something—though they did not reach it.

Lü’s commentary: Without partiality or self-interest, one is empty and without fixed direction, and so becomes one with things. Without regard or calculation, one moves with things. In the stillness of the ancient arts of the Way, these two heard the wind and were delighted; moved, they then grasped the causes of all under Heaven—yet these three did not know them.

Heaven is great, Earth is great, the Way is great—yet even they have what they cannot do. Thus we know that the myriad things have what they can and cannot do. Selection cannot be all-encompassing; teaching cannot reach all. Only by equalizing with the Way is nothing left out.

Thus Shendao cast aside knowledge and habit to follow necessity. *Ling* means "to clarify the turbid"; *tài* means "to remove disturbance." The ancients entered the Way through this, not taking it as the Way itself. These two took the Way to end here, not knowing that knowledge and self had never begun to exist.

When the myriad things arise together, this is how they return; in their profusion, this is how they revert to the root. None of this disturbs the heart. What Shendao took as the principle of the Way was merely "to know that one does not know"—yet to slight this knowledge is to invite harm. Only unknowing preserves wholeness.

Shendao knew only that knowing is not knowing, but did not know that not-knowing is true knowing. *Xǐkuǎ* means "unstable." "Unbound and untrammeled, rejecting the world’s worthies and sages"—this is what is meant by "casting aside knowledge and self." "Hammering, striking, severing"—the next three phrases describe *lingtài* in relation to things: refining and forging, crushing and breaking, turning and following. Thus they forgot knowledge, foresight, before and after, standing aloof alone. Moving or going only when pushed or pulled—like the whirling wind, the spinning feather. The groove of the grinding stone—its movement is not of itself.

"To be as the unknowing thing"—thus there is no peril of self-assertion or burden of knowing. Movement and stillness never depart from principle, and so there is no praise or fault. Shendao took this as the principle of the Way. "Only a clod never loses the Way"—this is the teaching of "cutting off the sage and casting aside knowledge," yet to cut off and cast aside is precisely what makes one a sage or worthy. How then is this different from the principle of the dead? This is why the heroic mocked him and he was deemed strange by the world.

Tian Pian studied under Peng Meng and received "no-teaching"—for if one relies on teaching, it does not reach. He spoke of the ancients reaching the point where none could affirm or deny them. Their influence was like the rush of wind—how could it be put into words? Yet it nearly approached the saying that "there has never been right or wrong, and the wise do not speak." But when one’s conduct opposes others and seeks to avoid drawing their gaze, one cannot escape being crushed.

The Way has never begun to exist as a thing, so to take emptiness and imperishability as its reality—why constantly oppose others and rely on hammering and crushing? What they called the Way was not the Way, and what they affirmed could not avoid being wrong, for they were mired in the realm of unknowing.

Though these three did not know the Way, they had once glimpsed something of it. Mo Di, Hua Li, Song Keng, and Yin Wen not only did not know the Way—they had never even glimpsed it.

The Dao originally arises from the truth of human nature and destiny, and its essence lies in governing the self. Yet Mo Di and Hua Li established conduct that departed from the world, even to the point of withholding love from others—thus losing their root and straying far from truth. Therefore, when discourses on the Dao spread and divided the world, those who first grasped it were followed by Song Keng and Yin Wen, who were said to know the Dao; Tian Pian and Shen Dao, who knew it and drew near; and others who progressed from the coarse to the refined.

*Dubi Zhu* notes: The safeguarding of the Dao lies herein. The three masters heard its influence and rejoiced, for their Way differed from that of Song and Yin. Thus, they took the equality of the myriad things as their starting point, unlike those who engage with things by first distinguishing boundaries.

Heaven can act as heaven but not as earth; earth can act as earth but not as heaven. The Dao operates between them, capable of embracing all yet unable to discriminate. From this, we know that the myriad things each have what they can and cannot do. Thus, when blended, they pervade all; when left to themselves, they reach their fullness; when embraced, they are complete; when distinguished, something is always left out.

Therefore, Shen Dao discarded knowledge and ceased disputation, abandoned the self and ceased engagement, following only what could not be avoided. He never sought to comprehend things through their stimuli nor to move them through the communication of words. Unfettered and self-abandoned, he was not burdened by things. Thus, even slight knowledge was deemed nearly injurious to principle. Seeking to forget it all, he took no responsibility, left no affairs, made no movements, and left no traces. The worthy have undertakings; the sagely have virtuous conduct. He laughed at and rejected these, holding none in esteem.

"Hammering and crushing" means breaking the form of what is to come. "Chopping and severing" means cutting away what has already decayed. Adapting to things with flexibility, setting aside right and wrong—thus one escapes entanglement.

Not following knowledge, without thought before or after, the mind like dead ashes, solitary and steadfast—never initiating yet always harmonizing, never moved yet always responding. Movement is like pushing a cart; advance is like dragging a tail, following only what cannot be avoided. Thus, like the wind returning, feathers spiraling, or a millstone’s groove, his power was whole, and his movement and stillness without fault. This was because he had no knowledge of things and no self regarding himself, so that no afflictions or burdens could reach him.

Fortune and misfortune arise from action; praise and blame emerge from assertion. The two masters roamed beyond fortune and misfortune, praise and blame, thus becoming like things without knowledge, taking the formless as not losing the Dao.

The Dao is what all things with form follow in common; power is what all beings with minds attain in common. Even in the tiniest shard of tile or stone, the Dao is present. Yet Shen Dao’s Dao was not the conduct of living people—hence it was deemed strange.

Tian Pian and Shen Dao studied together under Peng Meng and attained the unteachable Dao. Their influence was subtle and hidden, carrying an air of doubt; their true state could not be clearly expressed. They constantly opposed others and avoided drawing attention, for they had not yet equalized the myriad things.

The term "yuan-duan" describes a blunt, unpolished appearance without sharp edges. What they called the Dao sometimes strayed into non-Dao; what they deemed right sometimes fell into wrong. The three masters had indeed heard of the Dao but had not attained it.

*Laozi* once said to "reject sagacity and discard knowledge," yet Zhuangzi did not adopt Peng [Meng] and Shen [Dao] here—seemingly at odds. However, he likely used the two as allegories, stripping away their traces to show that their words were merely correctives for their time.

The *Bixu* commentary states: Factionalism precludes impartiality; self-interest obscures clarity. Without intent, the self does not dominate; governing by law leaves no room for doubt. Thus, one forgets knowledge and makes no choices, acting only by upholding the law.

Heaven and earth possess no complete achievements; sages possess no complete abilities. Since things have both possibilities and impossibilities, there must be governing principles. To abandon law and rely on selective instruction would leave affairs incomplete and principles unfulfilled.

The Dao encompasses all without omission, for it contains the law of spontaneity. The following four lines regarding Shen Dao mean that only thus can nothing be left out. "Leng-tai" means refining by law, sifting the coarse and fine of things to uphold the world’s principles. Though using law is not ideal, it is still better than having no law; without law, principles cannot stand, and chaos is unparalleled.

Shallow knowledge cannot avoid intent; with intent, one cannot be without bias. "Xike" mocks the absurdity of exalting worthiness without order. "Zongtuo" is reckless and unrestrained, not the sage’s boundless emptiness—these are the flaws of such a system!

"Chui-pai" means striking decisively; "yuan-duan" means severing limbs. Yet in application, they adapted to the nature of things, neither affirming nor denying, merely seeking to avoid disaster. Forgetting thought and knowledge, they rested securely, moving only after being pushed, acting like drifting wind or spinning feathers. Without the bias of knowledge, they became like things without awareness. Even if divine clarity descended, there would be nothing to apply—hence their withered, detached state drew universal astonishment.

The three masters all established teachings based on Mohist learning. Where there is teaching, there is right and wrong; yet they claimed nothing was right, nothing wrong, like a wind-vane producing sound without distinction—this was their attainment of the "unteachable."

Yet in opposing human nature, they could not avoid harsh judgments and severing punishments—this was not the kingly Dao. Their principles may have been sound, but their practice was not.

The three did not understand the Dao, yet they studied and gained renown in their time. Their teachings were simply not orthodox.

Yuan Qi said: "Qu-wu" refers to the principles and tendencies of the myriad things. "Not two" means oneness. Peng [Meng], Tian [Pian], and Shen [Dao]—the three masters—were recluses of Qi. Their doctrine held that heaven and earth are but two among the myriad things, and the foremost of these is the Dao of non-action. What heaven and earth can do is partial; the Great Dao encompasses all without distinction.

Things have both possibilities and impossibilities. Selection cannot be comprehensive; instruction cannot be exhaustive. Only by returning to the Dao is there nothing left to debate.

Abandoning knowledge and self is non-action. "Leng-tai" refines things without constraint. Their doctrine stated: If one divides by knowledge and ignorance, one is pressed by knowledge and harms oneself. "Tan-ke" means instability; "wu-ren" means not dwelling on affairs—hence they mocked the world’s exaltation of worthiness.

"Zongtuo" means unrestrained conduct, so they dismissed all sagely learning as wrong. "Chui-pai" and "yuan-duan" describe the absence of sharp edges, allowing them to adapt to things. Without right or wrong, they avoided worldly entanglements.

The metaphors of wind returning, feathers spinning, and the groove of a millstone all illustrate being without intent and adapting to things. Only without knowledge can one be free from self-bias and the burden of intent, moving and resting in accord with principle.

Not seeking knowledge from others, without reputation, they avoided blame—what need was there for the name of worthiness or sagacity? Merely being like a clod without awareness could preserve the Dao.

Such arguments resemble those of ascetics in the mountains and forests, so the heroic laughed at them as little better than the dead. These men studied in mutual accord, requiring no teaching to understand.

Their master’s words said: The ancients who practiced the Dao took the absence of right and wrong as their foundation, speaking like drifting wind without intent. Thus, how could they be discussed? Their views often opposed others, unable to gather like-minded followers, inevitably becoming one-sided doctrines. They sought only to avoid sharp edges.

"Yuan-duan" here is the same as "guan-duan" earlier. Though their words were bold, what they called the Dao was not the Dao. The three did not understand the Dao—yet from Zhuangzi’s grand perspective, they had all heard of it, merely failing to grasp its true essence.

To avoid factionalism is to be without self-interest. To order well without imposing one’s views allows the world’s things to converge as one. Without thought or planning, moving with things—this is why the three delighted in the wind of such a Dao, for their paths were the same.

Their teaching took the equalization of the myriad things as primary. Things are inherently unequal; the Dao equalizes them. Heaven and earth are the greatest of things, yet even they lack complete achievements—how much more so other things? The Dao encompasses all without distinction—this is how it equalizes.

The myriad things have both possibilities and impossibilities. Selection and instruction only increase inequality; uniting them through the Dao leaves nothing out. Thus, Shen Dao discarded knowledge and feigned stupidity, abandoned self and followed things, responding only when unavoidable—even his actions were non-actions.

Clarifying the source of the self, refining and sifting like "leng-tai," all things would follow. True knowledge arises from non-knowledge; merely diminishing knowledge still harms one’s nature—only by attaining non-knowledge is wholeness achieved.

"Xike" means not taking on affairs, so they mocked the world’s exaltation of worthiness as governance. "Zongtuo" means unrestrained conduct, so they dismissed all sagely learning as wrong. "Chui-pai" and "yuan-duan" describe the absence of sharp edges, allowing them to adapt to things. Without right or wrong, they avoided worldly entanglements—like wind returning, feathers spinning, or the groove of a millstone, all metaphors for being without intent and adapting to things.

Only without knowledge can one be free from self-bias and the burden of intent, moving and resting in accord with principle. Not seeking knowledge from others, without reputation, they avoided blame—what need was there for the name of worthiness or sagacity? Merely being like a clod without awareness could preserve the Dao.

The following passage aligns with the preceding text, and its meaning will be self-evident.

"Chui-pai" refers to flogging, and "yuan-duan" to the later term "yun-duan," meaning the execution of criminals—though they employed law and punishment, they adapted flexibly to circumstances, ensuring thorough fairness and alignment with principle. By harmonizing with the world’s conventional notions of right and wrong and penetrating to the essence of affairs, one may avoid calamity. "Gou mian" is a humble expression. Without relying on knowledge, one forgets considerations of past and future. Motionless as withered wood, they move only when pushed or pulled; their movement is like wind returning or feathers spinning, without intent in action and thus without error.

Things devoid of knowledge do not assert themselves or employ understanding; in movement and stillness, they are without intent and naturally accord with principle. With no reputation to seek, how can slander arise? Thus, they do not covet the name of sage or worthy, taking the state of a clod without awareness as the attainment of the Dao—unaware of the subtle workings of resonance and transformation, which is why the heroic mocked them as no different from the dead.

Tian studied under Peng, simply following the natural tendencies of things, learning to support them without distorting their essence—hence it is said he "attained without teaching." To study the Dao is to reach the point of transcending right and wrong, moving like wind passing a cliff, without intent to distinguish right from wrong—how could one then debate its reasons? Thus, they constantly opposed human sentiment, avoiding the world’s clamor for spectacle. "Clamor for spectacle" resembles the peril of building an observation tower.

Yet they could not entirely abandon law and punishment, for without them, governance would be difficult. What they called the Dao was not the true Dao, so though their words were often apt, they could not escape criticism. None of the three truly understood the Dao, yet their teachings once gained renown and cannot be entirely dismissed.

The *Nanhua*’s discussion of Peng, Tian, and Shen’s teachings surpasses those of Ku Huo and Yi Chi, placing them closer to Guan Yin and Lao Dan. They regarded the root as refined, things as coarse, accumulation as insufficiency, and dwelled in tranquility alone with the numinous. There were those in ancient Daoist arts who embodied this: Guan Yin and Lao Dan heard of their teachings and delighted in them.

They established their foundation in the constant alternation of non-being and being, governed by the Great Unity, manifesting gentleness, humility, and deference as their outward form, and emptiness and non-destruction of the myriad things as their essence. Guan Yin said: "Abide in non-possession, and things will naturally manifest. In movement, be like water; in stillness, like a mirror; in response, like an echo. Vast as if absent, silent as if pure. Those who harmonize lose; those who grasp fail. Never precede others, yet always follow them."

Lao Dan said: "Know the masculine, yet guard the feminine, becoming the world’s stream. Know the bright, yet guard the humble, becoming the world’s valley. All seek precedence, yet I alone take the rear, saying, 'I bear the world’s disgrace.' All seek fullness, yet I alone take emptiness. Without hoarding, I have abundance, overflowing with surplus. In conducting myself, I am unhurried and without waste. In non-action, I mock craftiness. All seek fortune, yet I alone seek preservation through humility, saying, 'I merely avoid blame.' Taking depth as my root and restraint as my guiding principle, I say: 'What is rigid will break; what is sharp will dull.' Always yielding to things, never carving away at others—this may be called the ultimate."

Ah, Guan Yin and Lao Dan! The vast and true perfected ones of antiquity!

Guo’s commentary: "Accumulation is insufficiency; entrusting to the world brings abundance. How can non-being establish anything? By founding it in the constant alternation of non-being and being, one clarifies that things establish themselves. Heaven and earth, the myriad things—each attains its own nature without borrowing from others. Is this not governing through the Great Unity? Things come and one responds, responding without retention, so merit departs with things. Without self-assertion, one entrusts to the myriad things, and their forms naturally manifest. In movement and stillness, be like water and mirror—this illustrates constant non-attachment. Vast and silent, the ever-whole knows not what it has gained. Each thing guards its own portion, remaining still and silent.

Without the masculine or the bright, one does not vie for superiority or self-display—is this not exceeding one’s portion and endangering one’s life? The ancients did not follow boundless knowledge, thus preserving their nature. With nature whole, they returned like streams and valleys, and the world joyfully deferred to them without tiring. The feminine, the humble, the rear, the low—these are what the world calls disgrace. Those who seek fullness know only being as benefit, unaware of non-being’s use; those who seek emptiness abide in tranquility to await the multitude of beings. Without hoarding, one entrusts things to their own keeping, thus never exhausting their abundance. Standing alone and self-sufficient—this is the meaning.

In conducting oneself, one acts according to what benefits the people, following the four seasons to bring things to completion. Always in accord with principle, thus without harm or waste. The crafty act and harm the natural unfolding of the sacred vessel; the non-active follow things’ spontaneous arising and completion, allowing each to act on its own. Even spiders can weave webs—every person has their own abilities, so why value forced labor? Yielding to the highest principle ensures constant preservation; without seeking, fortune is self-sufficient. Following things, one avoids blame. Principle is rooted in the primordial Great Ultimate—how can it be called shallow? Taking restraint as one’s guiding principle means moderating excess.

Utmost compliance renders metal and stone no longer hard; encountering opposition, even water and vapor lose their depth. Compliance preserves, opposition destroys—this is the true principle. Advancing with restless haste is sharpness; each guarding its portion naturally has abundance, not carving away at others, thus preserving its nature."

Lü’s commentary: "Taking the Dao as refined, one regards things as coarse; regarding things as coarse, one takes non-being as refined. The Dao has never begun with things, thus accumulation is insufficiency. To reach the ultimate of emptiness, one must arrive at non-accumulation and then stop, dwelling in tranquility alone with the numinous."

The Dao of antiquity, with its roots and branches, essence and coarse forms, pervades all without exception—this is what is meant by taking the root as essence, adapting to the times alone. The Dao is fundamentally without thing, yet when it manifests in time, there remains something not yet established. If one founds it upon the constant of "non-being and being," then things cannot contend with it.

One and speech make two; if there is something called "one," it is not the Great One. With the Great One, even "one" cannot be attained, thus the myriad things return to it without knowing their master. The Dao, being formless, does not contend, and so takes softness, weakness, humility, and lowliness as its outward signs. Observing its outward signs, the inner reality it embodies may be known. Things each return to their root, and the body naturally becomes empty and void. Taking emptiness and voidness as the means by which the myriad things are not destroyed is the true reality—distinct from those who hammer, carve, or sever, mistaking these for the Dao.

Master Guan Yin’s eleven sayings all speak of the achievement of having no abode in oneself so that things naturally manifest. As *Laozi* says: "Know the masculine, keep to the feminine; know the white, guard the disgraced." The feminine is still and does not initiate; disgrace recedes and returns to the root. Valleys channel without accumulation; hollows respond without hoarding—thus the source of rivers and seas arises. This is what is meant by founding upon the constant of "non-being and being" and taking the Great One as the master. Remaining behind to receive disgrace, taking softness, weakness, humility, and lowliness as outward signs—dwelling in emptiness without hoarding, thus not destroying the myriad things but allowing them to be used, this is how one comes to have abundance.

Not preceding others but following them, one moves slowly without expenditure—distinct from those who labor the body and exhaust the self, mistaking this for the Dao. Allowing things to be empty of themselves without destroying them is unlike inanimate objects devoid of awareness. Preserving the whole by bending avoids blame—this is what is called fortune. Taking depth as the root, one need not strive for hardness. Taking restraint as the guiding principle, one need not strive for sharpness. Utterly empty and utterly vast, it constantly accommodates things. Not carving away at others, taking the root as essence and dwelling in tranquility alone with the numinous—what is embodied is the true reality of the Dao, which may be called the ultimate. Thus, one sighs: "Ah, the vast and true person of antiquity!"

*Duduzhu*’s commentary: "Constantly without desire, observe its wonders—this is taking the root as essence. Constantly with desire, observe its manifestations—this is taking things as coarse. Taking accumulation as insufficiency, for accumulation leads to limits, while dispersion leads to boundlessness."

*Zhuangzi* once said: "Utter non-being supplies all demands, for it is the utmost non-being that meets the needs of all that is under heaven; it is the utmost emptiness that responds to all realities under heaven." Tranquil and without desire, one is thus distant from the myriad things; not departing from essence, one thus dwells with the numinous. "Non-being" is the non-being that opposes being; "constant non-being" is not the non-being of absence but the non-being that does not oppose being—what is called "constant being" likewise does not oppose non-being. Founding upon the constant of "non-being and being," one enters obscurity—how could one then distinguish wonders and manifestations within it?

"Constant non-being" and "constant being" both take the Great One as their宗. With the Great One, not even the "one" of all under heaven can precede it, thus one guards it with softness and weakness and acts with humility and lowliness. "Outward signs" refer to what is visible externally. While others all seek the substantial, I alone take the empty; thus, I regard emptiness and voidness as true reality. Moving slowly without expenditure, acting without contrivance or artifice—thus, I regard not destroying the myriad things as true reality. Preserving oneself through emptiness and voidness, engaging with things without destroying them, soft, weak, humble, and lowly—these are the practices of *Laozi*. Emptiness and voidness without destruction—these are the virtues of *Laozi*.

Having no abode in oneself, one can thus cause things also to have no abode, adapting to change with the times, transcending the six dusts, so that forms and things manifest without obstruction. Moving in accord with the Way, one is still like water and thus clear like a mirror. Vast and possessing form yet seeming absent, silent and soundless yet seeming pure—harmonious yet not blending, attaining yet not possessing, never preceding but always following others, harmonizing without initiating.

Valleys contain and excel at receiving; hollows are empty and excel at responding. Knowing the masculine, one guards the feminine; not preceding things. Knowing the white, one guards the disgraced, nourishing oneself with obscurity. Glory and profit are what people precede; disgrace and defilement are what people leave behind. Others all seek the substantial and accumulate, thus they are insufficient; I alone take emptiness and voidness without hoarding, thus I have abundance. Like a secluded mountain standing alone, one is never insufficient.

In conducting oneself, the more dull one is, the greater the benefit; outwardly enriched yet inwardly undiminished, following the natural course of things without carving or severing. People seek fortune by striving for it; I seek fortune by not seeking it—preserving the whole by bending, merely avoiding harm, this is what is called fortune. Depth is the root of the Dao; restraint is its guiding principle. Hardness invites destruction, so one guards it with softness. Sharpness invites blunting, so one nurtures it with emptiness. Profound in dealing with things is called magnanimity; profound in dealing with others is called not carving away at them. This is the Dao of Guan Yin and Lao Dan.

*Bixu*’s commentary: "The essence of the wondrous root may be attained through intention; the coarseness of things may be transmitted through words. Because of accumulation, there is insufficiency; nothing surpasses great emptiness in abundance. Dwelling alone with the numinous means not deceiving even in darkness. 'Constant non-being and being' is the function of the Dao; the Great One is the master of the self. Emptiness and voidness are the宗 of things."

The perfected person has no self, and the myriad things are all oneself—moving without intention, still yet able to illumine, responding and thus penetrating, without fixed emotions. Seeming absent yet not absent, seeming pure yet not turbid, harmonious yet not defiled, seeming to lose yet not losing the self, not preceding but following. In one’s person, knowing the masculine yet guarding the feminine, nurturing oneself with humility; knowing the white yet guarding the black, dwelling in obscurity yet clear. Receiving the world’s disgrace, one endures humiliation. Without hoarding, one has abundance; giving to others, one has even more. Restlessness depletes the spirit; cleverness makes one a servant to others. Merely avoiding blame—what more could fortune seek?

Deep roots never leave their宗; restraint as the guiding principle makes it easy to grasp.

Spaciousness toward all things brings boundless compassion; refraining from diminishing others yields vast relief. These are but the coarse manifestations of the perfected person’s engagement with the world—what Guan Yin and Lao Dan diligently practiced.

The *Yuzhai* says: to regard accumulation as insufficiency is to store wealth throughout the world. Take non-being as the宗, and the inception of the Great Ultimate as the master.

The *exterior* is how one responds to the world and engages with things, manifesting outwardly. In emptiness, all things are complete—just as Shili Le Xuan said: "Where not a single thing exists, all things are fully present." Without abode or partiality, the master reveals itself, taking form as things arise.

The movement of water, the stillness of a mirror, the resonance of a valley—all are without intention. *Seeming absent*: as if present yet not present. *Seeming pure*: pure yet without name. To harmonize by merging with things, to attain by attaining nothing.

Knowing the masculine yet guarding the feminine, concealing ability within inability. Knowing the white yet guarding the black, dwelling in obscurity yet not being obscure. The meaning of streams and valleys: low-lying yet able to contain all things.

Only by treating emptiness as substance can one have abundance without hoarding, remain unharmed in tranquility. Others regard cleverness as cleverness; I regard non-doing as cleverness. Others regard fortune as fortune; I regard avoiding blame as fortune.

Taking depth as the root speaks to its origin in the Great Unity’s inception. Taking restraint as the guiding principle speaks to simplicity as the method of preserving oneself. All things that are hard and sharp will suffer breakage and ruin. To measure oneself by accommodating others is to ensure that none can diminish or harm one’s life—this is the ultimate Way of the world!

The Way is the root of all living things, subtle and invisible; things are but the remnants of the Way, coarse and manifest. The world pursues accumulation to sustain itself, yet the more it accumulates, the more it lacks. The vast and boundless void is where spirit and clarity unite, encompassing and embracing all without destruction or completion—even if the world’s myriad things were fully possessed, how could they surpass the nothingness of emptiness?

When one is serene and desireless, the body harmonizes with the Great Void and dwells with spirit. Free from accumulation outside, abundant within the breast—this is what Guan Yin and Lao Dan excelled in. All things arise from non-being, yet human delusions cling to being. To thoroughly investigate constant non-being is difficult; to maintain non-being while engaging with being is even more so!

To establish oneself in the realm of constant non-being and being, one must take the Great Unity as the master. The Great Unity is the One before form, the origin before heaven and earth, the primordial nature of humanity. Abiding in this, one knows that things have never truly begun—thus, the exterior is revealed through gentleness, humility, and yielding.

The *exterior* refers to what is seen in conduct. Thus, one engages with things without opposing them, emptying oneself without destroying the myriad things. *Not destroying* means preserving without judgment. When the self is forgotten, things transform on their own—why wait to destroy them? When no thing fills the foreground, what is solid is emptied by me.

Within the self, without abode, things take form on their own—this is the same idea. The movement of water, the stillness of a mirror, the resonance of a valley—all illustrate the naturalness of non-intention. *Seeming absent*: cannot be grasped as existing. *Seeming pure*: cannot be disturbed.

Harmonizing by merging with things, losing by grasping—thus, not preceding but following, one remains unceasing throughout life. Knowing the masculine yet guarding the feminine is to see strength and think of softness. Knowing the white yet guarding the black is to dwell in brightness yet value obscurity. Streams and valleys illustrate the virtue of yielding, where all flows converge.

Receiving the world’s disgrace, possessing capacity—thus virtue becomes great. Without hoarding, one has abundance. Empty yet inexhaustible, moving yet ever-flowing. Thus, one stands serenely above the myriad things, with no thing intruding upon the heart, and no thing not belonging to oneself.

One’s conduct is never restless yet always self-sufficient. The heart delights in non-doing, not envying worldly cleverness. Others seek fortune beyond themselves; I alone regard preservation through humility as fortune. If one can merely avoid blame, what greater fortune could there be?

*Deep roots* refer to inner solidity. *Restraint as the guiding principle* refers to reducing entanglements—thus avoiding the breakage of hardness and the blunting of sharpness. Spaciousness that accommodates all things neither diminishes others nor enriches oneself—this is evident.

All these are the ultimate principles of how one establishes oneself and engages with things, the refined essence of the vast and perfected person.

As the *Daodejing* states: "Knowing the white yet guarding the black"—the phrasing differs slightly in the *Zhuangzi*. *Nanhua Zhenjing Yihai Zuanwei*, Scroll One Hundred Five Concludes. *Nanhua Zhenjing Yihai Zuanwei*, Scroll One Hundred Six.

The Daoist Chu Boxiu of Wulin, ranked fourth among the scholars under heaven, spoke thus:

Void and formless, ever-changing and impermanent—does it align with death? With life? With heaven and earth together? With the spirits’ departure? Vague and boundless, where does it go? Sudden and fleeting, where does it drift? All things are encompassed, yet none suffice as a return. Among the ancient arts of the Dao, there was one that resided herein, and Zhuang Zhou, hearing its wind, delighted in it.

With meandering and distant discourse, vast and unbounded words, and limitless, unbounded phrases, he indulged freely without constraint, never forcing his intent upon others. He regarded the world as turbid and murky, unfit for solemn speech. Thus, he employed *zhi*-words as ceaseless unfolding, *chong*-words as truth, and *yu*-words as expansiveness. Alone, he roamed with the spirit of heaven and earth, yet did not scorn the myriad things, nor dispute right and wrong, thereby dwelling harmoniously with the common world. Though his writings were ornate and resplendent, their continuity remained unbroken and unharmed; though his phrases were uneven, their strangeness and wonder were worth beholding.

His inner fullness could not be restrained. Above, he wandered with the Creator; below, he befriended those beyond life and death, beyond beginning and end. In its foundation, it was vast and expansive, profound and unrestrained; in its essence, it was harmonious and perfectly attuned, ascending to the utmost. Yet though it responded to transformations and untangled things, its principle was inexhaustible, its advent unchanging. Vague and obscure, it remained unfathomed.

Guo’s commentary: Formless and impermanent, it follows things. Death or life—it accords with transformation. Where does it go? Where does it drift? Without intent toward things. None suffice as return, thus it wholly abides in placelessness. With limitless, unbounded phrases, he indulged freely without constraint, not hastening to make his intent known. Burdened by form and name, solemn speech is deemed mad and untrustworthy, hence he did not employ it. His *zhi*-words and *yu*-words both conveyed the utmost principle, perfectly aligning with the nature and destiny of the myriad things. Without personal right or wrong, he allowed things to proceed in duality. Shaped by the multitude of things, he dwelt among the common world. Returning to mutual accord, it remained unharmed. Not merely responding to the affairs of the time, hence uneven. His inner fullness could not be restrained, for it possessed abundance.

Zhuangzi conveyed his intent with equanimity, whether speaking of himself or others. Examining his words, they are vast and boundless—like Yu’s grand declarations, what fault lies herein?

Lü’s commentary: Formless, hence unseen; impermanent, hence unfathomable. To deem it aligned with death is to say it never had life; to deem it aligned with life is to say it never had death. To deem it aligned with heaven and earth is to say it never had past or present; to deem it aligned with the spirits’ departure is to say it never had self or other. Thus, vague and boundless, it remains quiescent and unmoving. All things are encompassed, none are not entrusted to it. None suffice as return—is this not the work of the spirit alone?

With meandering and vast, unfathomable words, he indulged freely without rigidity, for all had their counterparts. Not forcing his intent upon others, even if his words lacked substance or coherence, they were not hindered from being trustworthy. Solemn speech, like legalistic words, follows only the Dao. *Zhi*-words illustrate the Dao’s endless daily use. *Chong*-words and *yu*-words adapt to the times. When people do not trust one’s words, one invokes the ancients for weight. When *chong*-words fail to convey, then *yu*-words follow.

What Zhuangzi embodied was to roam alone with the spirit of heaven and earth, without scorn for the myriad things—hence his words were likewise. Scorn (*aoni*) is like estrangement. Not disputing right and wrong, he thus mingled with the common world. Though his writings were magnificent and resplendent, their continuity remained unbroken and unharmed. *Lian* means without gaps; *fei* implies a fixed form, yet it cannot be sought or valued by the common world. *Chu gui* refers to the strangeness of his words, which the common world cannot deem base. Only because his inner fullness could not be restrained, above he wandered with the Creator, below he befriended those beyond life and death, beyond beginning and end—thus entering the realm of the spirit!

In its foundation, it was vast, taking heaven as its essence, harmonious and perfectly attuned, never departing from its source—hence it responded to transformations. Its principle was inexhaustible, untangling things. Its advent was unchanging, for form does not await shedding to be untangled. Vague and obscure, unfathomed—this is the unknowable nature of the spirit.

Yi Du’s commentary: The perfected person roams the mind in quiescence, harmonizes *qi* in emptiness. Though possessing form, it is as if formless; renewing the old, it remains impermanent. Heaven and earth are the body of the spirit; the spirit is the function of heaven and earth. The body is constant, while function governs change. Externalizing things to the point of transcending life and death, embodying the Dao to the point of following transformation. Though all things are encompassed, none lie beyond the Dao. Thus, the sages of old made their Dao the model for all ages, valued by the world—its essence lies in nothing not being encompassed, nothing not being pervaded.

Zhuangzi’s words aimed to correct the ills of his time. Knowing they could not avoid being meandering and vast, he placed himself after the other masters who had heard the wind, indulging freely in his speech without partiality, observing broadly without forcing his intent. The world was unfit for solemn speech, hence he followed with *zhi*-words, *chong*-words, and *yu*-words. Roaming with the spirit of heaven and earth, without scorn for the myriad things, his words aligned with principle and responded to things. Right and wrong are fundamentally nonexistent, hence no need to dispel them—sometimes, one dispels them through words. Only by blending right and wrong could he dwell in the world without fear. His words, though magnificent and unbroken, remained unharmed; his phrases, though uneven, were strange and wondrous to behold—all arising from inner fullness, manifesting outwardly, unable to be restrained. Wandering with the Creator, beyond life and death, beyond beginning and end—hence its foundation was vast.

Its fundamental harmony is attuned, its responses transform and resolve things—riding principle without exhaustion, following the times without deviation. Thus, it remains vast and obscure, its limits unknowable, without beginning or end yet never departing from its source.

The *Bixu* commentary states: Stillness and formlessness are the essence of the Dao. Transformation without constancy is its function. Life and death are the Dao’s transformations. Heaven and earth are the Dao’s constancy. Spirit and illumination are the Dao’s pathways. Vast and boundless, nowhere to return—such is the Dao’s subtlety. "Without price" means adhering to the proper measure. "Not with partial vision" means no bias. "Solemn speech" refers to upright and grand words.

The *Nanhua* writes with central correctness as its foundation, yet unfolds endlessly; with profound virtue as its substance, yet remains true and unfeigned; with allegory as its function, yet broadly imparts teaching. Roaming with the spirit of heaven and earth, without scorn for the myriad things, it accompanies heaven without obscuring humanity—thus dwelling in the human world. Magnificent and extraordinary, flowing in unbroken succession, uneven yet wondrous to behold, its Dao is full and replete, profound and boundless. Thus, it transforms effortlessly, vast and reaching the root, harmonizing the principles of things, ascending to the source of transformation.

If the Dao could be exhausted through discourse, how coarse would be the depths of its primal unity! If it could be fathomed by thought, how shallow would be the vast emptiness of creation! Thus, from ancient times, sages and worthies have arisen in succession, unable to cease.

*Yongzhai* says: From "stillness and formlessness" to "whither does it go?"—this clarifies that the utmost spirit moves in unison with creation, without pathways. Thus, the myriad things appear before it, yet none know where they return. Without bias, one does not see with partiality—what is seen is not confined to one end. "Solemn speech" is dignified and truthful language. Roaming with the spirit of heaven and earth means befriending the spontaneity of creation. "Without reproach" means no attachment. "Unbroken succession" means harmony and accord. "Without harm" means without satire. "Uneven" means rising and falling without fixed form. "Wondrous" means playful and humorous. All these reveal the intent behind the writing.

Fullness cannot be restrained—its principles pervade the text, a book indispensable to the world. "Ascending" means attaining the principles of heaven, thus responding to transformation and resolving the principles of things. "Without deviation" means not departing from the Dao. "Vast and obscure" describes the profundity of the text, yet what fills the author’s heart cannot be fully expressed in words.

This chapter, following the general preface, divides into five parts, placing itself last, succeeding Laozi, to show its learning has a source. The first three sections each bear the word "though," yet all judge the right and wrong of their learning—only Laozi is without it. Here, the word "though" appears again, indicating its learning is not without use in the world. Where the text shifts, the brushwork is most masterful.

Formless and unconstant—this speaks of the Dao as without fixed form yet spiritually transformative. Death and ultimate departure—this speaks of humans following transformation without limit. Vast and boundless, nowhere to return—this speaks of the forgetful wanderer for whom no path is not fitting. With absurd and far-reaching words, unrestrained yet not careless—like one who acts wildly yet treads the great way, not allowing others to see one’s rigidity, blending with the world without losing the Dao.

Because the world cannot be addressed with solemn and upright speech, *zhi*-words, *chong*-words, and *yu*-words are established to convey meaning. Roaming alone with the spirit of heaven and earth, one leaves the human realm to enter the celestial, roaming freely to the eight limits. Without scorn for the myriad things, without faulting others’ right and wrong, one dwells in the world with harmonious light, responding to things without obstruction. Though the words are magnificent, they follow the world without harm. Their phrases are uneven and irregular—what is called "absurd" and "wondrous to behold" is what is meant by "magnificent." Their fullness within is manifest without. Thus, roaming with the Creator, befriending the endless and beginningless, is to roam with the spirit of heaven and earth—its wonder cannot be described. Its foundation is vast and profound, as if rooted in depth, its harmony attuned. "Ascending" means taking heaven as its source. "Responding to transformation" refers to birth. "Resolving things" refers to death.

Humans dwell within creation, moved by its mechanisms—its principles cannot be exhaustively explained, its coming cannot be escaped. Vast and obscure without end—this is what makes it creation. If one can obscure the mind amidst the vast and obscure and grasp what moves transformation, then one may roam with the spirit of heaven and earth, unashamed of the endowment of human spirit.

This section of the *Nanhua* first discusses transformation; next, it obscures its own words and deeds; finally, it returns to transformation, showing that its ability to fathom the spirit and know transformation means all its horizontal and vertical discourse is nothing but the Dao.

Hui Shi was multifaceted; his writings filled five carts. His Dao was contradictory and fragmented, his words never hitting the mark. His *Intent of Surveying Things* states: "What is greatest without beyond is called the Great One; what is smallest without within is called the Small One. What has no thickness cannot be accumulated, yet it is vast as a thousand *li*. Heaven and earth are low; mountains and marshes are level. The sun is just at its zenith as it inclines; things are just born as they die. Great sameness differs from small sameness—this is called the small sameness and difference. The myriad things are entirely the same and entirely different—this is called the great sameness and difference. The southern region is both infinite and finite. Today I go to Yue, yet I arrived yesterday. Linked rings can be unlinked. I know the center of the world—it is north of Yan and south of Yue. Embracing all things with love, heaven and earth are one body."

Hui Shi regarded these as great truths. Observing the world and enlightening debaters, the debaters of the world delighted in them. "Eggs have hair."

"A rooster has three feet. Ying possesses all under heaven. A dog can be a sheep. A horse lays eggs. A toad has a tail. Fire is not hot. Mountains have mouths. Wheels do not touch the ground. Eyes do not see. Fingers do not reach. What is reached is not absolute. A tortoise is longer than a snake. A carpenter’s square is not square; a compass cannot draw a perfect circle. A chisel does not encircle its handle. The shadow of a flying bird never moves. The speed of an arrow’s flight has moments when it neither moves nor stops. A dog is not a hound. A yellow horse and a black ox make three. A white dog is black. A lone colt never had a mother. Take half of a one-foot staff each day, and it will never be exhausted for ten thousand generations.

Debaters used these to engage with Hui Shi, endlessly. Huan Tuan and Gongsun Long, followers of the debaters, adorned men’s minds and altered their intentions; they could win in verbal argument but could not convince the heart. Such was the confine of the debaters.

Hui Shi daily used his knowledge to contend with others in debate, uniquely crafting strange arguments with the world’s debaters. This was his root. Yet Hui Shi’s oral disputations, though he deemed himself the most worthy, were grand yet without method. There was in the southern region a recluse named Huang Liao who asked why heaven and earth did not collapse or sink, and the causes of wind, rain, thunder, and lightning. Hui Shi did not decline but responded, without deliberation, expounding on all things. He spoke without ceasing, profusely and endlessly, yet still deemed his words few, adding ever more strangeness."

Taking reversal of others as substance and seeking fame through victory over others—this is why he never harmonized with the crowd. Weak in virtue yet strong in things, his path was narrow and obstructed.
