Viewing Hui Shi’s abilities through the Dao of heaven and earth, his efforts were but the toil of a single mosquito or gnat—what use were they to the myriad things? To fulfill even one aspect would be preferable; to value the Dao more highly would be near the mark!

Yet Hui Shi could not find peace in this; he scattered himself among the ten thousand things without surfeit, and in the end gained renown for his eloquence. Alas for Hui Shi’s talent—so vast yet unharnessed, chasing the ten thousand things without return! It was like exhausting echoes with sound, or racing one’s shadow in competition—how lamentable!

Guo’s Annotation: Before I had read the *Zhuangzi*, I once heard debaters contend over the meaning of the "foot-long staff" and the "linked rings," all claiming these were Zhuangzi’s words, and thus took them for the school of disputation. Examining this chapter’s critique of the various masters, when it reaches this passage, it declares their Dao to be contradictory and their words off the mark—thus I realized how hearsay and wayward discourse harm truth. I also thought such talk lacked any system for governing the state, truly what one calls useless chatter. Yet for sons of the elite, equal in their leisurely diversions, when weary of canonical words, to be able to debate names and analyze principles, thereby expressing their qi and focusing their thoughts, and leaving this to later generations—if it keeps their natures from deviance, is this not still preferable to gambling and board games? Thus I preserve it without further comment, to bequeath to those fond of such matters.

Lü’s Annotation: The *Laozi* says: "Much speech leads to exhaustion," and again: "Sparse speech accords with nature"—thus those who speak do so only when unavoidable. Yet Hui Shi’s oral disputations deemed himself worthy, unaware of heaven and earth’s vast emptiness and his own excessive self-regard, unable to abide in the feminine. No wonder he took heaven and earth as grand, preserving the masculine yet lacking defense!

The sage takes wordlessness as speech, thereby embodying virtue. Now Hui Shi relied on eloquence, taking reversal of others as substance and victory over others as fame—thus he knew nothing of wordlessness. Enslaved by words, unable to overcome himself, he was weak in virtue; seeking fame through victory over others, he was strong in things. His path was obstructed, meaning it was not the Dao of the six penetrations and four unfoldings.

The Dao of heaven and earth is great because it is non-action. Hui Shi’s abilities could not escape self-regard. Viewed through the Dao of heaven and earth, though his debates were vast, they were but the toil of a single mosquito or gnat—what use were they to the myriad things? The One and the many are both the Dao. The One is the root, the many the branches. Though the One alone is insufficient to complete root and branches, compared to those who forget the root and chase the branches, one may still say it values the Dao more highly and is near the mark.

Hui Shi did not return to the root to find peace but scattered himself among the ten thousand things without surfeit, ultimately gaining renown for eloquence, chasing things without return. Without sound, echoes cease; in darkness, shadows vanish. Without self, none in the world contend with one. Though Hui Shi had talent, he did not emerge from this; he merely pursued the externals of speech, competing with things—how was this different from exhausting echoes with sound or racing one’s shadow? His loss of nature was profound! Thus I deeply lament and pity him.

**Yi Du’s Annotation:**
"External" implies there is something beyond—this is called "great." When something is so great that nothing lies beyond it, it is called the "Great One." "Internal" implies there is something within—this is called "small." When something is so small that nothing lies within it, it is called the "Small One."

Hui Shi’s disputations could unsettle men’s minds and alter their intentions. Sometimes he debated the world over numbers, as in "a chicken has three feet." Sometimes he debated names, as in "a dog is not a hound." Sometimes he debated forms, as in "a carpenter’s square is not square." Sometimes he debated colors, as in "a white dog is black." Sometimes he debated high and low, as in "heaven and earth are base." Sometimes he debated long and short, as in "a tortoise is longer than a snake." His arguments generally held that the myriad things possess no distinctions of high or low, long or short; no differences of form, name, square, or round; no divisions of green, yellow, black, or white. He took the equalization of all things as his foremost principle, claiming that the great Dao, once dispersed, gives rise to forms and names—all mere products of human bias, nothing more than artificial distinctions.

Relying on this, Hui Shi debated the world and ultimately gained fame for his eloquence. Yet when measured against the works of heaven and earth, his disputations were but the labor of a single mosquito or insect—something the ancients would not have done, nor what scholars would have praised. Thus, regarding Hui Shi, one does not say, "The guardians of the ancient Way reside in this." This is why Zhuangzi lamented his talent, which was ultimately spent in chasing things, losing his original truth.

**Bi Xu’s Annotation:**
The Great Void has no beyond and admits no duality; the tip of an autumn hair has no within and stands alone. What can be accumulated has thickness—how could it be limited to a thousand *li*? Viewed from the Great Void, heaven and earth are both base; seen from the azure expanse, mountains and marshes are all level.

In the time it takes to cross arms, the sun has already shifted from midday to slanting light. In the span of a bow and a rise, things are born and die in the same instant. Things possess appearances, images, sounds, and colors—this is their great sameness. Things gather by kind and separate by category—this is their minor difference. Yet all arise from the transformation of a single *qi*—this is their fundamental unity. The ten thousand forms differ in species—this is their ultimate diversity.

Once position is fixed, there is already limitation. Now arriving, then departing, the intent precedes the act. If form can be divided and spirit can depart, then even linked rings can be undone. His discourse expanded without regard for principle.

North of Yan and south of Yue each deems itself the center. The empty and the blended merge without interruption. Hui Shi used such arguments to display his grand vision to the world. Debaters delighted in them, echoing one another in unison.

An egg has no feathers, yet the fledgling that hatches from it does. A chicken has two feet, but counting "one, two" makes three. Ying was established as a capital and thus came to possess the world. "Dog" and "sheep" are merely names imposed by the ancients. To call an embryo an "egg" is but a regional expression. The people of Chu call a toad a "dingzi," and when it has a tail, it is in its tadpole stage. Fire-beasts of the sea and mountains do not find fire hot; a mountain’s protrusion is called a "mouth," just as one speaks of the "mouth of the Milky Way" or a "road’s end." The rut left by a wheel’s passage is called a "track"—the earth is not mentioned.

The eye cannot see itself; what sees is the spirit. Whatever one points to, one points to where it is not. If it were reached, the boundary would meet it, and there would be no separation. A tortoise is longer than a snake when comparing lifespans, not forms. A compass and square are the methods for making squares and circles, not the shapes themselves. Mortise and tenon are but temporary joins.

When principle is not mutually entailed, it is like the independent transformation of form and shadow. A flying bird moves, yet its shadow does not. An arrow is loosed and flies without cease; when it falls, it stops and does not move. A dog with a suspended hoof is called a "hound" by convention, but a dog is not a hound. A yellow ox and a black cow make three when combined and separated. Hard and white stones exemplify the unity of difference and sameness.

If a dog is white in body but blind in one eye, one calls it "blind" and not "white." If its hoof is crippled and its body white, one forgets the white and names it "lame." A colt has a mother and thus is not called "orphan." A square inch of land, used morning and night, can never be exhausted—this is the meaning of "the foot-long staff is inexhaustible."

His discourse concerned the Dao, not things, and he sought to astonish the world’s debaters. This was its foundation. Heaven moves with vigor; earth is vast and deep—this is their majesty. Hui Shi relied on his glib tongue, seeking to contend with them, yet he did not know to guard the feminine, to cultivate tranquility and nurture heavenly harmony. He merely preserved the masculine without defense.

He leaned on others, seeking to prop up his theories with the words of the ancients, unable to establish a school of his own. Thus, when asked about the workings of heaven, earth, wind, and thunder, Hui Shi spun out explanations—copious and strange—self-regarding and competitive, weak in virtue. His broad disputations prized the unusual, overpowering things.

Viewed by the Dao of heaven and earth, Hui Shi’s abilities were but those of a mosquito or insect—what account should be taken of them? The world values the Dao because its teachings are transmitted in books. Hui Shi’s writings, at best, suffice as the words of a single school. Yet his arguments—from "a chicken has three feet" onward—address no urgent need of the age. He did not know that great eloquence is like silence, yet he sifted husks and chaff, exhausting his spirit in vain. This is why the Master of Painted Bamboo sighed deeply in lament.

**Yan Zhai’s Oral Teachings:**
Followers like Mo Di, Song Xing, Peng Meng, and Shen Dao were still partial in their grasp of the Dao. Hui Shi, however, was devoted solely to disputation and thus does not rank among those who heard the Dao’s unfolding. He is mentioned separately at the end of the "Examining Things" chapter.

"Utmost greatness has no beyond"—this is the Great Void. "Utmost smallness has no within"—this is like the tip of an autumn hair. These eight words align with Zhuangzi’s teaching, but to call them the "Great One" and "Small One" invites contention. In truth, the One has no great or small. Within his arguments, distinctions arise between sameness and difference, difference and sameness.

"Without thickness" means utmost thinness. Accumulated, it becomes thick, and its greatness can extend a thousand *li*. When heavenly *qi* descends, it levels with the earth; when mountain *qi* connects with marshes, it levels with the marsh. When the sun is at its zenith, to glance sideways is to see it no longer centered.

When things first arise, their seeds are the deaths of former days. Things have small and great, forming small sameness and difference; combining the sameness and difference of the myriad things forms great sameness and difference. The great does not transcend the accumulation of the small, and the small, when combined, can become great—thus there is neither sameness nor difference.

The southern direction points to the boundless sea, yet calling it a "direction" implies it must have limits. Heaven tilts to the northwest, and the sea lies to its south, even more distant than the other three directions. "Now approaching what came before" means that though one has not yet reached the place, one first hears its name and later arrives.

Linked rings each form their own circle, inherently unconnected—this, too, is like untying. The north of Yan and the south of Yue are certainly not the center of the world, yet the people of each land take their own country’s center as the world’s center. Heaven and earth are but one thing among the myriad, like a single body.

The down on a hatchling may not yet be visible, yet a duck is a duck and a chicken is a chicken—their feathers differ, so the down already exists. A chicken has two feet by nature, but when something moves it, that makes three. The capital of Chu was Ying, yet its king was like one who possessed the world.

The names "dog" and "sheep" arise from people; had one initially called a dog a sheep, then today it would still be called a sheep. Though birth from wombs and eggs differs, their names also arise from people—one could just as well call a horse egg-born.

Tadpoles begin as *dingzi* and *xiamu*, first taking the form of polliwogs, thus having tails. "Cold water" and "hot fire" are also names given by people; yet there are fire-dwelling rats, so fire is not always hot.

In an empty valley, a person’s call echoes in response—is this not the mountain having a mouth? A wheel rolling on the ground becomes a wheel; when fixed to the ground, it cannot turn—yet one may say it does not roll upon the earth.

The eye sees, and then the finger can reach; where the eye cannot reach, the finger cannot see. Thus what reaches is neither the eye nor the finger alone, and they cannot be wholly separated.

If a tortoise were as long as a snake, it could not be called a tortoise; to call it a tortoise, its length must be only thus. Once called a carpenter’s square, it cannot also be called a square—so too with the compass.

The handle fits into the socket, yet the tenon’s rotation cannot be stopped by the mortise, for it is not confined by the encircling. The shadow follows the flying crow, yet one may say the crow flies but not that the shadow moves.

An arrow on the bowstring is at rest; when shot at the target, it is in motion. Between leaving the bow and reaching the target, there is a time of neither motion nor rest.

"Dog" and "hound" are one, yet to call it a dog is not to call it a hound. The ox and horse are two bodies; "yellow-black" is a color. To speak of two bodies together with a color makes three; to attach "yellow-black" to the bodies of ox and horse also makes three.

The names "black" and "white" do not arise from the beginning of things—thus one could just as well call white black. To name a foal "orphan" implies it has no mother, yet one also says it once had a mother.

A foot-long rod split in two may be used today and tomorrow, and for ten thousand generations it will not be exhausted. This is scholars extending his arguments, contending endlessly with Hui Shi in forced disputation.

Root and trunk—his fundamental capacity goes no further than this. Relying on eloquence to bolster himself, he equates his existence with heaven and earth, thinking himself mighty when in truth he lacks all learning.

A lone figure—one who stands apart, uniquely aloof. Heaven and earth, wind and thunder are all marvels of creation—how can words contain them? Hui Shi, refusing to yield, countered with narrow doctrines, taking opposition as ability and clashing with the world.

Within, he gains nothing, his virtue daily weakening; yet he exhausts himself in external disputation.

Oh, the profound obscurity!

Viewing Hui Shi’s abilities through the Dao of heaven and earth, he is but a mere gnat—what use is he? To be content with one’s private opinions alone may suffice; but to claim superiority over the noble Way is perilous indeed. Hui Shi never grasped the Dao, gaining fame only through disputation. He may be called talented, yet his reckless abandon, oblivious to reflection, is truly lamentable.

Echo arises from sound, sound being its root and echo its branch; to exhaust echo through sound is to ignore the root. So too with form racing its shadow.

Zhuangzi concludes his work with Hui Shi—though not among those who heard the Dao, his words remain extraordinary, preserved and not discarded. Writing books differs from composing essays, each having its own structure. Openings and closings are where intent resides, as in the *Spring and Autumn Annals*’ abrupt end with the capture of the qilin, or the *Doctrine of the Mean*’s “Heaven’s charge.” In this work, the *Inner Chapters*’ “Hundun’s seven apertures” follow the same pattern. Those who explain the classics in terms of literary technique may not fully grasp the principle; those profound in principle may overlook literary form. Thus, few achieve perfection. Only Master Aixuan, Lin Gong of Wenjie, excelled in both principle and literary refinement, elevating the interpretation of the *Six Classics* above all others through the ages. Alas, after Master Leshan, Chen Gong of Le Xuan, his learning was not transmitted, and now none remain who know it.

Master Aixuan of Putian, Vice Minister of Works, Lin Guangchao (style name Qianzhi), passed his teachings to Master Wangshan, Lin Gong (style name Xueke), who in turn transmitted them to Master Leshan, Chen Zao (style name Yuanjie), both of whose collected works circulated in the world. Master Zhuxi, Lin Gong of Yanzhai, was the direct heir of Le Xuan.

At the end of Lu Deming’s *Pronunciations and Meanings*, it is recorded: “Zixuan’s commentary, in its broad strokes, may be said to have grasped Zhuangzi’s intent.” Guo sighed at the decadent sophistry of his time; I, too, have late witnessed the vain discourse of the privileged. This is what is meant by “different eras, same customs”—how can one speak of it further?

Some ask: If Zhuangzi and Hui Shi shared the bond of Hao Liang’s covenant and the model of the Ying craftsman, why do their teachings diverge so sharply, their words missing the mark? Could their bond have been like the Ying craftsman’s, where praise and blame were as one, yet their mutual reproach so severe?

I say: One who seeks to exhaust the breadth of teaching and illuminate its words—how could they not refine their language and exhaust their analogies? Zhuangzi sounded his resonant tones in the *Seven Chapters*, presenting this text to the world. His profound words traversed the path of the mysterious, his arguments unfolded with eloquent subtlety. Though his discourse disdained vain debate, his teachings were never empty chants. Yet his writing is easy to read, its purport difficult to fathom. Those who approach it without comprehension risk misjudging its principles. To remedy this flaw in the text, he thus grandly displayed Hui Shi’s vast disputation.

Liu Gai’s general discussion states: The Dao’s body is vast, encompassing all without omission. Form and number begin with the One, the odd and even giving rise to one another. Beyond this, even the most skillful reckoning cannot calculate. The ancients followed the order of the great Dao, aligning with the principles of spirit and illumination, thus establishing the Way of inner sageliness and outer kingship. In matters of measurement and degree, complexity and constraint abound, yet the root and branches, the one that scatters into ten thousand, were never truly severed. Thus, they emerged and withdrew, stilled and stirred, shortened and lengthened, to correct the world’s crookedness and adapt to its uneven changes.

Moreover, Fu Xi had his methods, yet they were perfected under Yao; the Two Emperors had their governance, yet it was completed under the Zhou. They neither rushed ahead to favor the new nor lagged behind to cling to the old. This is what sages in high position could not fully encompass. Yi Yin bore his task; Bo Yi corrected it with purity, yet purity verged on narrowness. Liu Xia Hui harmonized it, neither opposing the world to uphold integrity nor following custom to seek fame. This is what sages in low position could not fully perfect.

The Dao reached its culmination with Confucius, emerging perhaps once in a thousand or a hundred years. The sages before Confucius adapted to their times out of necessity; the various masters after Confucius established their schools, each affirming their own rightness. By Zhuangzi’s time, the sages were long gone, and the Dao of virtue and righteousness had been torn apart by Yang Zhu and Mo Di; non-action and purity had fallen to Tian Pian and Peng Meng. Thus, Song Keng, Yin Wen, and their followers, hearing the wind, gave free rein to their ideas.

Zhuangzi sought to restore the Way of Confucius, though it was no longer Confucius’ era. He thus spoke loftily of the supreme Dao to correct the world’s baseness, advocated returning to simplicity to sever the world’s extravagance, and embraced emptiness and stillness to rescue the world’s turbidity. Deeming concise words insufficient to remedy its ills, he expounded at length without fixed doctrine; finding solemn speech inadequate to enlighten the vulgar, he indulged in the boundless and unfettered. He composed thirty-three chapters, concluding with “Preserving the Dao in the World.”

His words often exalted Lao Dan above Confucius, and in discussing the learning of the hundred schools, Confucius was not included. He placed Mo Di and Qin Guli’s followers first, then Lao Dan and Guan Yin, before modestly ranking his own learning, and concluded with Hui Shi’s multifarious doctrines. For when the Dao is not at the stage of grand culmination, even the most expansive true person remains partial. Lao Dan’s book grasped the root of Zhuangzi’s thought, thus harmonizing and ascending; Hui Shi’s book grasped only its branches, remaining confined to a single facet.

Alas! Did the books of the various masters not revere Confucius? Yet none understood the basis of that reverence like Zhuangzi. Scholars should seek understanding beyond words.

The *Nanhua Jing* divides its chapters into *Inner* and *Outer*, weaving together the great principles of the Dao, virtue, nature, destiny, ritual, music, punishment, and governance.

The Way of inner sageliness and outer kingship is present herein. Yet its discourse stands lofty and transcendent, distinct from all other masters. Though its ascent proves arduous, leaving it deemed eccentric and extravagant, its depths resound like thunder, its brilliance gleams like moonlight—never to be extinguished.

The *Miscellaneous Chapters* encompass all worldly affairs, employing oblique metaphors and winding analogies, leaving nothing unrecorded. Though Guo Xiang later pruned and restored its fragments, the core of its matters remains largely unchanged. The final chapter, however, critiques all the Daoist arts under heaven as inevitably entangled in deliberate action, their tendencies often skewed—none enduring without flaw. At first reading, it may seem tangled and disordered, its guiding purpose elusive. Yet upon closer examination, its divisions are sharply defined and reasoned: first, the Confucian path; second, the Mohist teachings; third, the art of governance; fourth, the discourse on law; fifth, the praise of Laozi; sixth, the critique of Zhuangzi. Thus, it surveys the arts and defenses of the Way across all ages! It then turns to self-critique, clarifying that its learning derives from Lao Dan.

Given the abundance of its discourse, it fears scholars may mistake words for meaning. Thus, it concludes with an appraisal of Hui Shi, extolling his eloquence while refuting his errors, guiding later generations in their choices. When I first read this scripture in full, upon reaching the section on Hui Shi’s multifarious doctrines, I found no foothold, no boundary—much like the *Liezi*’s account of Gongsun Long deceiving the King of Wei. Such passages defy thought or speech, lingering in the mind for years.

In the *Chunyou* year of *bingwu*, I was fortunate to encounter Master Fan of Wu Yin from Western Shu, who sojourned in the capital. For nearly two years, I attended his lectures, and as we neared the final chapters, I whispered to my fellow students: "This scripture holds many perplexities, but this is its final barrier. I wonder how the master will elucidate it—surely in a manner beyond ordinary perception."

When the scripture’s text was recited, all listened with rapt attention. The master then inquired: "What do you make of this discourse?" The assembly, acknowledging their dullness, begged him to dispel the clouds of confusion. The master replied: "This scripture itself states: *Vast, shifting, strange, and wondrous—all are united in the Dao; let them exist without discussion.*" The students were startled and entreated further instruction. After a long silence, the master asked: "Do you still not understand? This is not a saying of the *Nanhua*; it is precisely the kind of erroneous and misguided speech the text refutes. Why trouble to explain it? From *the greatest having no bounds* to *heaven and earth as one body*—all are the words of Huizi. From *a chicken having three legs* to *ten thousand generations without exhaustion*—these are the matching phrases of his disputatious disciples, practiced in flattery and cunning, vying to outdo one another in strangeness, spouting words without restraint to this extreme. Some, failing to examine closely, mistake these for Zhuangzi’s own words, deepening their doubts and debates—all because they do not trace the source. Master Guo knew this but did not state it plainly, allowing readers to grasp it for themselves. There are those in the world who delight in the strange, bewitched by such bizarre words. They exhaust their minds and thoughts, conjuring strange interpretations to reconcile them, yet though they toil, what benefit is there?"

At this, the assembly’s minds cleared at once, as though a heavy cover had been lifted to reveal the sun and sky. I privately reflected: The sagely teachings handed down to enlighten later generations are as vast as the sea, to be drawn from according to each person’s capacity. The study of commentaries and annotations has its gradations; only by encountering a master’s heart-to-heart transmission can one avoid the confusion of many paths. Otherwise, one remains trapped in Huizi’s phrases, never attaining the *Nanhua*’s transcendent gate. Though one may master countless doctrines and fill five carts with books, one is no more than a debater. As the ancients said: *"To devote oneself to learning is not as good as devoting oneself to seeking a teacher."* How true! The master’s grace is boundless as the heavens. In compiling these explanations, I labored for seven years before completion. With reverence, I kindle incense and bow westward, performing the ninefold rites, as though the venerable Master Wu Yin stood before me, and the radiant spirit of the *Nanhua* Immortal looked down from above.

What I regret is that my fellow students, scattered north and south by upheaval, may have lost some of the master’s teachings I once heard, with no way to verify or correct them—only deep sighs remain. The master’s name was Yingyuan, his courtesy name Shanfu, a native of Shunqing in Shu. His learning encompassed both inner and outer realms, his understanding probed heaven and humanity. Serene and dignified, upright and proper, his every action accorded with ritual—just as the classics describe: *without speaking, he nourished others with harmony; standing beside others, he transformed them.* Esteemed elders of rivers and lakes knew him well; there is no need for further confusion. I briefly record here the circumstances of our master-disciple encounter at the end of this scroll, that later scholars may know the source of this tradition.

Respectfully inscribed in the spring of the *gengwu* year of *Xianchun* by the student Chu Boxiu of Wulin.
*End of Scroll One Hundred and Six of the* Nanhua True Scripture: An Ocean of Meanings, Compiled and Elucidated.
